headline: Not Telling
abstract: If I talk about a novel I’m working on, I believe that my characters will be angry, and will no longer confide in me about their embarrassing, troubled lives.
lead_paragraph: The desire to write my first novel was a desire for privacy. I was writing short stories, and had said out loud more than once that I would never write a novel, maybe because I knew publishers preferred novels, and I was telling anyone who happened to care that I wouldn’t write to please publishers. But the thought of a novel had always been alluring as well — alluring and daunting.

lead_paragraph: THE injury wasn’t new, and neither was the insult. Rebecca, a combat veteran of two tours of duty, had been waiting at the V.A. hospital for close to an hour when the office manager asked if she was there to pick up her husband.

headline: Beware the April Fools’ Jokes Coming From Madison Avenue
keywords: ['Hoaxes and Pranks', "APRIL FOOL'S DAY", 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Social Media']
abstract: April 1 is a day for pranksters, and businesses and chambers of commerce are vying for top attention.
lead_paragraph: SOCIAL media like Facebook and Twitter have been given credit for reviving interest in watching television live so comments about unbelievable catches, undeserved awards, unexpected plot twists and unfashionable dresses can be shared in real time with family and friends. Those social platforms also seem to be having a stimulative effect on the interest along Madison Avenue in April Fools’ jokes.

headline: Sanctions or Not, Russian Sway in London May Be Bluster
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: Many worry that London, a global financial center, might suffer collateral damage if there are more penalties imposed on Russia over its actions in Crimea. But the data suggests otherwise.
lead_paragraph: Russian listings on the London Stock Exchange; Russians buying multimillion-dollar homes in Chelsea, on streets called Billionaires’ Row; Russian children in Britain’s most exclusive schools, while their parents shop at Harrods and Asprey; Russians running soccer clubs and newspapers and cellars that sell some of the world’s most expensive wines.

headline: Judge Won’t Block Rules on Abortion Drug in Arizona
abstract: The rules, which were approved by the Arizona Legislature in 2012 and will take effect on Tuesday, restrict the use of medication to induce abortions during the early stages of pregnancy.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Tucson has refused to block some of the strictest rules in the nation on the use of abortion drugs.

headline: The Employer’s Creed
abstract: The hiring process deeply affects the kind of people we have in our society. A little healthy bias in decision-making might cultivate deeper, fuller human beings.
lead_paragraph: Dear Employers,

headline: Competition Intensifies in Vietnam’s Aviation Sector
abstract: The private VietJet Air is making a strong push just as Vietnam Airlines, the state flag carrier, plans a long-awaited initial public offering.
lead_paragraph: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam — Chien Anh, a restaurant manager here, used to fly on either Vietnam Airlines, the state-owned flag carrier, or the budget airline it mostly owns, Jetstar Pacific. But after the private VietJet Air started flights in 2011, Mr. Anh’s loyalty began to shift.

headline: In Gary, Ind., a ‘Gateway’ Has Become ‘the Eyesore’
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Buildings (Structures)', 'Abandonment (Property)', 'Demolition']
abstract: The Sheraton Hotel stands brooding next door to Gary’s City Hall, where Mayor Karen Freeman-Wilson, is determined to finally tear it down, floor by floor, as if reversing time.
lead_paragraph: GARY, Ind. — If one building could tell the story of this city’s hope and heartbreak, it would be the Sheraton Hotel.

headline: 3 Toyota Plants in Ontario Set to Vote in a Union Drive, as the Company Resists
abstract: The vote could create Toyota’s only unionized shop in the United States and Canada.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Workers at three Toyota assembly plants in Ontario will vote next week on whether to join Canada’s largest union, an effort that could create the carmaker’s only unionized shop in the country and the United States.

headline: The Pitinos Gather for a Garden Reunion
abstract: Minnesota Coach Richard Pitino, the son of Louisville’s Rick Pitino, will lead the Gophers in the N.I.T. semifinal Tuesday against Florida State at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The childhood memories came flooding back as Richard Pitino, the son of Louisville Coach Rick Pitino and a coach himself at Minnesota, told a story in his office last week. Pitino closely resembles his father, with the trademark piercing eyes and sweptback hair, and speaks with the cadence and confident manner of someone who has lived in New York all his life.

headline: Japanese Rush to Buy Before Rise in Sales Tax
keywords: ['Consumer Behavior', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Sales and Excise Taxes', 'Deflation (Economics)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'E-Commerce']
abstract: The first sales tax jump since 1997 has Japan’s businesses, politicians and consumers worried.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — March was a boom month for Askul, but the online retailer is far from happy. Shoppers racing to beat an impending increase in Japan’s national sales tax swamped Askul’s systems, snapping up toilet paper, instant rice and other essentials that will be more expensive when the rate goes up to 8 percent on Tuesday, from 5 percent.

headline: Leading the Country on Pre-K
abstract: The agreement to finance prekindergarten for all children is a major victory for New York City.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio has every right to call the agreement between Gov. Andrew Cuomo and legislative leaders in Albany to finance a vast expansion of prekindergarten in New York City a major victory — for him politically and for tens of thousands of children who will be put on a path to a better future.

headline: Landslide’s Debris Hampers a Search for Remains
abstract: Some areas are still so watery that heavy equipment cannot enter, and no roads exist from most of the work areas so that material can be trucked out.
lead_paragraph: DARRINGTON, Wash. — The debris field left after the landslide above the community of Oso stopped its roaring downward path has drawn awe-struck comparisons to the moon, in its gray starkness apparently devoid of life, and to the volcanic landscape after Mount St. Helens erupted in 1980 near Portland, Ore.

headline: Cobalts Were Seen as Lemons From Start, State Data Shows
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Owners of the Chevrolet car complained about power steering failures, locks opening and closing and doors jamming shut long before the car became known for having a deadly ignition defect.
lead_paragraph: Long before the Chevrolet Cobalt became known for having a deadly ignition defect, it was already seen as a lemon. Owners complained about power steering failures, locks inexplicably opening and closing, doors jamming shut in the rain — even windows falling out.

headline: Fault Runs Deep in Ultrafast Trading
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Books and Literature', 'Financial Brokers', 'High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A new book points out problems with high-frequency trading, but the fault lies with the markets themselves.
lead_paragraph: “The United States stock market, the most iconic market in global capitalism, is rigged.”

headline: Scrutiny for Wall Street’s Warp Speed
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Financial Brokers', 'High-Frequency and Flash Trading']
abstract: Critics argue that Michael Lewis’s new book on high-speed trading broke no new ground. But few wanted to miss out on the conversation.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street traders are used to waking up before dawn. But on Monday, they didn’t rush to read the overnight news from Asia — it was the latest from Michael Lewis.

headline: Winner of the Wager
abstract: Andrew Reynolds returns on April 1. You have been warned.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle has an element in it that I, personally, find quite fun and amazing from a construction standpoint. Your mileage may vary, of course, but it seems to me that you’d have to be quite a cynic not to love a grid where two different answers fit equally well in the same square. You may be reminded of another puzzle that is the Platonic Ideal of this technique, which is the 1996 BOB DOLE/CLINTON wonder that hedged its bets by allowing either side as the winner of the presidential election.

headline: Climate Signals, Growing Louder
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Methane', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Editorials']
abstract: Recent reports issuing grim warnings about the consequences of a warming planet should cause deniers of climate change to cease their attacks.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps now the deniers will cease their attacks on the science of climate change, and the American public will, at last, fully accept that global warming is a danger now and an even graver threat to future generations.

headline: A Step Toward Justice in College Sports?
abstract: A players’ union would help. But several lawsuits could bring about even bigger changes.
lead_paragraph: If you were going to hold up a school as being exemplary in the way it puts athletics in, as they say, “the proper perspective,” Northwestern University would certainly be one you’d point to. For instance, although it lacks the kind of winning tradition — at least in the big-time sports — that other schools in the Big Ten can boast of, it proudly points to the 97 percent graduation rate of its athletes.

headline: Climate Study Puts Diplomatic Pressure on Obama
keywords: ['Third World and Developing Countries', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: With no chance that Congress will agree to a huge increase in so-called climate aid, a new study on the effects of climate change creates a diplomatic challenge for President Obama.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A sweeping new study on the effects of climate change — which the report says is already disrupting the lives and livelihoods of the poorest people across the planet — creates a diplomatic challenge for President Obama, who hopes to make action on both climate change and economic inequality hallmarks of his legacy.

headline: An 8th Grader, a Gun and a Bus Rider in the Way
abstract: The death of an innocent bystander has left the city wondering how what the police said was a petty turf war between “crews” of children could breed such random, deadly violence.
lead_paragraph: Kahton Anderson had all the status symbols a 14-year-old in his world could want: Air Jordans and Reeboks, sometimes a new pair every month. Name-brand sports clothes. A new PlayStation 4.

headline: Riding the Triangle to the Pinnacle at Stanford
abstract: The Cardinal’s women’s coach, Tara VanDerveer, has had such success with the triangle offense that the men’s coach, Johnny Dawkins, has also become an enthusiastic practitioner.
lead_paragraph: STANFORD, Calif. — One of the mysteries surrounding the Knicks’ hiring of Phil Jackson as president is whether he will hire a coach who will deploy the triangle offense. Though it is the system his teams in Chicago and Los Angeles used to win 11 championships, it exists only in bits and pieces in the N.B.A.

headline: Singapore’s O.C.B.C. Reaches Deal for Hong Kong Bank
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — One of Singapore’s oldest banks said Tuesday it would pay nearly $5 billion for one of the last major family-owned banking groups in Hong Kong.

headline: After N.C.A.A. Snub, Larry Brown and S.M.U. Look Forward, Not Back
abstract: Coach Larry Brown convinced his team that success in the National Invitation Tournament would be important to the program’s future.
lead_paragraph: The band played, the cheerleaders cheered, and more than 1,000 fans joined the Hall of Fame coach Larry Brown and his players at Moody Coliseum on March 16 in anticipation of celebrating Southern Methodist’s first berth in the N.C.A.A. tournament since 1993.

headline: Officials Urge Calm as Protests Take a Turn in Albuquerque
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Attacks on Police', 'Police', 'Veterans']
abstract: In the face of the public’s weakened confidence in Albuquerque’s police after a string of shootings and clashes with protesters, officials called for calm.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — After demonstrations over a string of fatal shootings by the police became so heated over the weekend that officers in riot gear lobbed tear gas at an unruly crowd, the governor of New Mexico and Albuquerque city officials urged calm on Monday and reassured a jittery public that investigations of the shootings were underway.

headline: Gas Pipes From East Harlem Blast to Undergo Further Tests
abstract: Parts of several pipes will be tested at a laboratory in Washington as part of the investigation into the deadly gas explosion that destroyed two buildings in East Harlem last month.
lead_paragraph: Parts of several pipes — some installed more than a century apart — will be tested at a laboratory in Washington as part of the investigation into the deadly gas explosion in East Harlem last month.

headline: For the Mets, a 90-Victory Goal, if Not a 90-Victory Team
abstract: Opening day and optimism go well together, so there was no better time for Sandy Alderson, the Mets’ general manager, to deliver a rallying cry: “This team is now about being successful.”
lead_paragraph: The Mets really want to contend this season. They want their fans to believe it, and they want their players to believe it. Opening day and optimism go well together, so there was no better time for Sandy Alderson, the general manager, to deliver a rallying cry: “This team is now about being successful.”

headline: Photos: A Damp Spin Through Brooklyn
abstract: Professional road racers, track specialists, bike messengers and urban cyclists competed in the Red Hook Criterium in Brooklyn, N.Y., last Saturday.
lead_paragraph: If you looked up through the heavy rain Saturday in the Red Hook neighborhood of Brooklyn, you could just make out the silhouettes of its industrial landscape: warehouses, dock cranes, factory chimneys, even the barely discernible Statue of Liberty. If you looked left or right between umbrellas, you could see beards, tattoos, cow bells and colorful caps with inadequate brims. If you looked down, you could see drops of blood in some rain puddles. And if you blinked, well, you would have missed the point: ridiculously fast, brakeless, fixed-gear bike racing.

headline: Behind Barbed Wire, Shakespeare Inspires a Cast of Young Syrians
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Children and Childhood', 'Theater']
abstract: Syrian children at a refugee camp in Jordan performed Shakespeare’s “King Lear,” a tragedy that briefly took their minds off their own miseries.
lead_paragraph: ZAATARI REFUGEE CAMP, Jordan — On a rocky patch of earth in this sprawling city of tents and prefab trailers, the king, dressed in dirty jeans and a homemade cape, raised his wooden scepter and announced his intention to divide his kingdom. His elder daughters, wearing paper crowns and plastic jewelry, showered him with false praise, while the youngest spoke truthfully and lost her inheritance.

headline: Play Ball!
abstract: All the action from around the major leagues in a full slate of openers.
lead_paragraph: All the action from around the major leagues in a full slate of openers.

lead_paragraph: It will cost $1 million to even apply for a license.

headline: If You’re the Victim of a Tax Fraud, Tell the I.R.S.
abstract: Plus, tracking charges from Amazon.
lead_paragraph: Q. I got an aggressive telephone call from someone claiming to be from the Internal Revenue Service, saying I owed money. I was suspicious and hung up. If this is a fraud, is there a place to report it?

headline: Sabathia Is Sharper, Stronger and Ready to Lead Yanks
abstract: As the Yankees enter a new era, a reinvented C. C. Sabathia will be one key in their mission to return to the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Just as it was last season when he played for the Boston Red Sox, Jacoby Ellsbury will see the first pitch of the Yankees’ season Tuesday. Last year, Ellsbury saw a strike thrown by C. C. Sabathia.

headline: Man Who Shot at White House Gets 25 Years
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Firearms', 'White House Building (Washington, DC)', 'Terrorism']
abstract: A federal judge sentenced an Idaho man on Monday to 25 years in prison for firing a semiautomatic rifle at the White House in November 2011.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge sentenced an Idaho man on Monday to 25 years in prison for firing a semiautomatic rifle at the White House in November 2011. A federal grand jury indicted the man, Oscar Ramiro Ortega-Hernandez, on a charge of attempting to assassinate the president and on 16 firearms and assault charges. He pleaded guilty to reduced firearms and property damage charges related to terrorism. In a video recorded before the shooting, he called himself “the modern-day Jesus Christ” and expressed frustration with the government.

headline: Capitol Corruption Panel’s Demise Angers Watchdogs
keywords: ['State Legislatures', 'Law and Legislation', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Politics and Government', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said the investigative commission, which he formed last July, was no longer necessary because of reforms he had persuaded lawmakers to support.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — It was a quiet and sudden end to what had started as a high-profile battle against Statehouse corruption.

headline: Detroit’s Revised Debt Plan May Cut Pensions Deeper
abstract: The city of Detroit on Monday evening proposed new details, including potentially larger cuts to pensions for some retirees, for its plan for paying off portions of its debts.
lead_paragraph: The city of Detroit on Monday evening proposed new details, including potentially larger cuts to pensions for some retirees, for its plan for paying off portions of its debts and emerging this year from the nation’s largest municipal bankruptcy.

headline: Japan: Man Freed From Death Row Faces New Effort to Block a Retrial
abstract: Prosecutors filed an appeal on Monday to block a court from granting a retrial to a former boxer convicted of murder whose release last week after 48 years on death row exposed problems in Japan’s justice system.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors filed an appeal on Monday to block a court from granting a retrial to a former boxer convicted of murder whose release last week after 48 years on death row exposed problems in Japan’s justice system. Prosecutors in the central city of Shizuoka challenged the decision by a district court, which said the police might have fabricated some of the evidence used to convict the former boxer, Iwao Hakamada, now 78, of killing a family of four in 1966. While the appeal will not affect the court’s decision to release Mr. Hakamada, it is seen as a face-saving move by prosecutors to prevent further scrutiny of their reliance on forced confessions and possibly shoddy police work to obtain Mr. Hakamada’s conviction and possible others.

headline: Years After Obama Hailed Warming Ties With India, the Temperature Has Fallen
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: The once warm relationship between India and the United States has decidedly cooled, marked by disagreements over important diplomatic issues, like the crisis in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — When President Obama visited India in 2010, he called the warming relationship between it and the United States the “defining partnership of the 21st century.” Decades of disagreements, from Cold War ideological battles to squabbles over the United States’ close relationship with India’s archrival, Pakistan, would take a back seat to the many shared interests of two of the world’s largest and most diverse democracies.

headline: For a Ground Zero Developer Seeking Subsidies, More Is Never Enough
abstract: Billions of dollars in Liberty bonds, insurance money, developer fees: Year after year, Larry A. Silverstein has shaken the public tree and benefits have fallen to the ground.
lead_paragraph: The developer and philanthropist Larry A. Silverstein has cut a striking figure in New York City. He owns the H.M.S. Bounty-size yacht favored by his peers and has dominated the rebuilding of ground zero for a decade.

headline: Concussion Testing for Nationals’ Harper During Game
abstract: Bryce Harper was helped off the field in the second inning after colliding with Mets second baseman Eric Young Jr., but he said he passed his concussion tests and returned to finish the game.
lead_paragraph: In the second inning of the first game of a season, Washington’s Bryce Harper charged toward second base to break up a potential double play and, in a reward for his efforts, hit his head against the leg of the Mets’ second baseman, Eric Young Jr.

headline: With Connecticut Project Stalled, Renowned Decorator Falls Out of Favor
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Residents of Thompson, Conn., were excited when Mario Buatta bought a historic Gothic Revival home 22 years ago, but they say it is in worse shape now.
lead_paragraph: THOMPSON, Conn. — Mario Buatta has decked out aristocratic homes for America’s nouveau riche, freshened up dowdy landmarks in the nation’s capital and in just five years completed a top-to-bottom transformation of a California chateau, where 98 rooms awaited his attention.

headline: Erratic Knicks Linger Just Outside a Playoff Berth
abstract: The Knicks, despite inconsistent play, beat the Jazz on Monday and are in contention for the final postseason spot in the Eastern Conference in part because the Atlanta Hawks have lost 20 of 27 games.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — The Knicks are a team of extremes. They build big leads, then lose them. They win close games one night, then get blown out the next. Their addiction to variety was on full display on a five-game trip that concluded Monday night with a 92-83 victory over the Utah Jazz.

headline: Runaway Barge Irks Tappan Zee Officials
abstract: A barge separated from its mooring for the third time Sunday and, for the first time, the contractors building the replacement bridge were penalized for the safety lapse.
lead_paragraph: Propelled by high winds and muscular swells, a runaway barge carrying long tubelike steel piles rushed down the choppy Hudson River on Sunday afternoon, no tugboat steering the way.

headline: Linda Rodin’s Memory of Her Mother, in a Bottle
abstract: The multi-hyphenate ambassador of chic on her newest addition to the RODIN line: a recreation of the way her mother smelled.
lead_paragraph: This Mother’s Day, May 11, Linda Rodin will introduce Rodin Bis, the newest scent in her eponymous beauty line. It’s a re-creation of the way her mother smelled, as she explains here.

abstract: When these three design missteps are brought together, they can actually transform a room.
lead_paragraph: Three design no-nos — a sectional sofa, a swivel chair and a TV-dinner table — come together to make sloth awfully stylish.

headline: Lorenzo Semple Jr., Creator of TV’s ‘Batman,’ Dies at 91
abstract: It seemed as though ABC had a drama in mind, but Mr. Semple immediately saw the absurdity in the character of a wealthy bachelor who enjoyed dressing up as a bat to fight crime.
lead_paragraph: Lorenzo Semple Jr., a playwright and screenwriter who would probably be best known for his scripts for films like “Papillon” and “Pretty Poison” if he hadn’t put the Zap! and the Pow! in the original episodes of the arch, goofy 1960s television show “Batman,” died on Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 91.

headline: Ultraluxury Apartment Sales Drive Records in Manhattan Real Estate
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: The average price for an apartment passed $1.7 million in the first quarter as the average price per square foot reached $1,363, according to reports by major brokerages.
lead_paragraph: The Manhattan real estate market got off to a robust start in the first three months of the year, as signed contracts for ultraluxury apartments in new developments began to close, many with multimillion-dollar price tags, according to reports to be released by major brokerages on Tuesday.

headline: A Comedy’s Final Twists Lead to Love and Ratings
abstract: The denouement of “How I Met Your Mother” was very in much in keeping with the show’s patented balance of sentiment and sly self-awareness.
lead_paragraph: A thousand and one nights came to an end in less than 60 minutes. “How I Met Your Mother” closed down on Monday with an hourlong finale crammed with all the deflection, distraction and guile that made this CBS comedy the Scheherazade of prime time.

headline: Years After Revolt, Chinese Village Glumly Returns to Polls
abstract: Despite an uprising and democratic elections years ago, many voters said they had come to view their earlier electoral success as the beginning of the end of local self-governance.
lead_paragraph: WUKAN, China — After staging a very public revolt against official corruption and then voting in remarkably unfettered democratic elections, the people who live in this southern Chinese village returned to the polls on Monday amid torrential rains and growing fears that the Communist Party was taking back control of their local government.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 5:50 P.M. (Encore) PLEASANTVILLE (1998) Gary Ross wrote and directed this fantastical tale of two teenagers, David (Tobey Maguire) and Jennifer (Reese Witherspoon), above, who are transported from the 1990s into a 1950s television sitcom. Everything is perfectly swell, until David and Jennifer accidentally jump-start artistic and sexual awakenings in some of the show’s monochromatic inhabitants (Jeff Daniels, Joan Allen and William H. Macy, among others). Writing in The New York Times, Janet Maslin said “much of the interest here is in watching how the black-and-white scenes (filmed on color stock) begin to flower, often to the characters’ embarrassment.” She added that the film’s “unsung heroine is Jeannine Oppewall (‘L.A. Confidential’), the production designer who wittily turns the fantasy of Pleasantville into an actual place. Watch the sidewalks crack and the skirts grow less poufy as reality sets in.”

headline: Caring for the Dead: It’s the Thought That Counts
abstract: Chinese who cannot afford the time or expense to travel to attend to their relatives’ graves for the “tomb sweeping” festival can employ others to do it. For a fee, they’ll even cry on your behalf.
lead_paragraph: Too busy to care for your dead relatives? Can’t afford a train ticket home? Chinese who cannot go home and sweep family graves this weekend for the traditional “tomb sweeping” festival, known as Qingming (pronounced Chingming), can rent professional tomb sweepers from online companies.

headline: Puebla Keeps U.S. Players
abstract: The Mexican club Puebla said it would not release its two American defenders, DaMarcus Beasley and Michael Orozco, to join the United States national team for Wednesday’s exhibition game against Mexico in Glendale, Ariz.
lead_paragraph: The Mexican club Puebla said it would not release its two American defenders, DaMarcus Beasley and Michael Orozco, to join the United States national team for Wednesday’s exhibition game against Mexico in Glendale, Ariz. That is Puebla’s right, as the game does not fall on a FIFA international match date, but the decision did not sit well with United States Coach Jurgen Klinsmann.

headline: Tortorella and Vancouver Experience Frustrating Turnabout
abstract: The Rangers are on an upswing lately, but the Canucks, the team they swapped coaches with before this season and will face Tuesday, are in 10th place in the Western Conference.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER — When the Rangers visit the Vancouver Canucks on April 1, there should be no doubt which team has played the fool for most of 2014.

headline: Rural Health Care Blamed for Infant Deaths in Kolkata
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Hospitals', 'Infant Mortality', 'Medicine and Health', 'Rural Areas']
abstract: B.C. Roy Memorial Hospital officials say that because rural health centers are not equipped to handle critical cases, sick babies are often near death by the time they arrive at the hospital.

headline: An Evolving View of Animals
abstract: Tim Flach wants us to look at animals the way we look at people. Not so much to humanize them, but to get humans to consider how they relate to animals.
lead_paragraph: The portrait has a blunt simplicity. A chimpanzee sits with his back facing the camera. His gently lit body is nearly hairless from alopecia, and only a few strands of gray hair remain on his sandpapery scalp. A spotlight on his head reveals a reddish scar that has yet to fully heal.

headline: Hey, Robot: Which Cat Is Cuter?
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Robots and Robotics', 'United States Economy', 'Artificial Intelligence', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Crowdsourcing (Internet)']
abstract: Crowdworking platforms are advancing the speed at which robots can do anything — and everything — better than humans.
lead_paragraph: One recent morning, while contemplating writing this column, I scrolled through thousands and thousands of listings for mundane microgigs on Mechanical Turk, or Mturk, a decade-old platform created by Amazon. On Mturk, which advertises paid “human intelligence tasks,” I could review and correct transcriptions. I could tag images, perform a Google search, write a few sentences on a given topic, rate jokes or list items found on a receipt. For each, I would make a nickel or a quarter.

headline: 1889: Among the Clouds
abstract: 125 years ago, a correspondent of The New York Herald climbed all the way up the newly finished Eiffel Tower.
lead_paragraph: The completion of the Eiffel Tower, already announced in the HERALD, was yesterday officially commemorated by a little fête in the Champ de Mars. Towards two o’clock about a hundred and fifty persons responded to the invitation addressed to them by M. Eiffel by assembling at the foot of the tower, and afterwards toiling laboriously up the workmen’s staircase to the second platform. Among the number were several political notabilities, over a dozen Municipal Councillors and a group of ladies, undaunted by the difficulties and inconveniences of the ascent. The number of those who climbed was considerably decreased up to the third platform, and a veritable falling off took place ere the last little platform was reached, only eleven persons accompanying M. Eiffel to that elevated place.

headline: Japan Ends Decades-Long Ban on Export of Weapons

headline: 11 Detained After Protesting ‘Black Jail’ in China

abstract: Eleven people, including four well-known lawyers representing families of Falun Gong adherents and other people held in one of China’s notorious “black jails,” have been detained in the northern province of Heilongjiang, the police say.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:47 a.m. | Eleven people, including four well-known human rights lawyers who were protesting against a “black jail” in Heilongjiang Province have been sentenced to administrative detention for “using cult activities to endanger society,” according to a notice issued Monday by the police in Jiansanjiang, a city near China’s northeastern border with Russia. The case highlights an ultra-sensitive issue — the existence and treatment of adherents of the Falun Gong, a banned religious group.

lead_paragraph: In his new book, “Flash Boys,” Michael Lewis describes how high-frequency trading works, highlighting a system on Wall Street that has allowed certain professional investors to pay hundreds of millions of dollars a year to locate their computer servers close to stock exchanges so they can make trades milliseconds ahead of everyone else. “There is only one problem with Mr. Lewis’s tale: He reserves blame for the wrong villains,” Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column.

headline: Permahawkery

headline: Chefs’ Fridges by the Numbers
abstract: In this year’s Food and Drink Issue, we pried our way into the refrigerators of 11 New York City chefs to learn what kitchen professionals keep in stock at home. Here’s an incomplete and unofficial tally of the more interesting items we noticed in the chefs’ fridges.
lead_paragraph: In this year’s Food and Drink Issue, we pried our way into the refrigerators of 11 New York City chefs to learn what kitchen professionals keep in stock at home. We were surprised to find a number of similarities among them, including a decidedly low supply of fresh food (with a few notable exceptions), and a high supply of indulgences like alcohol and sweets. Here’s an incomplete and unofficial tally of the more interesting items we noticed in the chefs’ fridges:

headline: Salonen Will Hear Lots of His Own Music in New Zurich Post

headline: If Ivy League Is the Endgame, I’m Not Sure I Want to Play
abstract: “Exmissions” is the opposite of “admissions,” and the other parents working to get their offspring into preschool in Manhattan all seemed to have the kind of clear long-term plans that make a school’s “top tier hit rate” matter. headline: Professor Says Cable Channel Suspended Her Interview Series With Modi
abstract: Until Tuesday, News X had billed its six-part series as an exclusive, revealing look at the Bharatiya Janata Party’s candidate for prime minister.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI – Until Tuesday, the Indian cable channel News X was breathlessly billing its six-part series featuring the Bharatiya Janata Party’s candidate for prime minister as “Narendra Modi’s first interview” before the elections, while its executives went on Twitter to hype the “new details” the controversial politician would reveal.

headline: Rolling Stones to Resume Tour
abstract: The European leg of the tour includes 14 shows in just over five weeks.
lead_paragraph: The Rolling Stones will resume their “14 on Fire” tour at the Telenor Arena in Oslo on May 26, the group announced on Monday. The Stones had canceled its concerts in Australia and New Zealand after the fashion designer L’Wren Scott, who was Mick Jagger’s girlfriend, was found dead in her New York apartment on March 17. The group said at the time that those concerts would be rescheduled, but the new dates have not yet been announced.

headline: Today in Small Business: Erosion
abstract: What small businesses can learn from Amazon Prime. Customer-service lessons from Four Seasons Hotels. And an Instagram meme called, “Baby Suiting.”
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Report Traces Port Authority’s Flaws to a Crumbling Business Model
keywords: ['Transit Systems', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Governors (US)', 'Bridges and Tunnels', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The bistate agency has increasingly yielded to governors’ requests to fund dubious projects, a review from New York University’s Rudin Center for Transportation Policy and Management says.
lead_paragraph: For years, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has been an easy target — a behemoth so politicized that its role in the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge last year is perhaps the scandal’s least surprising element.

headline: In Performance: John Douglas Thompson
abstract: John Douglas Thompson performs a scene from “Satchmo at the Waldorf,” Terry Teachout’s play about the life of the singer and trumpeter Louis Armstrong.
lead_paragraph: John Douglas Thompson performs a scene from “Satchmo at the Waldorf,” Terry Teachout’s play about the life of the singer and trumpeter Louis Armstrong.

headline: Before a Hearing on G.M. Defects, Document Points to an Inconsistency
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: An engineer’s approval of an ignition switch change in 2006 appeared to contradict a deposition he gave in a court case.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As a House subcommittee prepared to open a hearing on the Chevrolet Cobalt defects and why it took so long for General Motors to issue a recall, House investigators released a document Tuesday that showed a G.M. engineer approved a critical change to a faulty ignition switch that has been linked to 13 deaths.

headline: Chinese Ambition With a Hefty Price Tag
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: There are risks to Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation’s deal for the Wing Hang Bank, an economic slowdown in China and lending excesses in Hong Kong among them, notes Peter Thal Larsen of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: The Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation is paying a hefty price to expand in China. The Singaporean company is realizing a long-held ambition by acquiring the Wing Hang Bank of China. But the deal, at almost $5 billion, looks expensive at a time when growth on the mainland is slowing and the Federal Reserve’s tapering is threatening to push up deposit costs.

headline: Mortar and Bricks Divide a Charleston Community
keywords: ['Prisoners of War', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: A chimney built by German P.O.W.s now sits on land owned by a Jewish family with deep roots in Charleston.
lead_paragraph: A chimney built by German P.O.W.s now sits on land owned by a Jewish family with deep roots in Charleston.

headline: ‘How I Met Your Mother’ Gets Its Best Ratings for Finale
abstract: After nine years, the CBS comedy tried to wrap up its many loose ends Monday night. The audience of 12.9 million was the show’s largest.
lead_paragraph: CBS’s hit comedy “How I Met Your Mother” exited to what amounted to a standing ovation on Monday night — from viewers, if not critics — scoring the best ratings in the show’s nine-season history.

headline: Obama Claims Victory in Push for Insurance
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The announcement that 7.1 million people had signed up for plans under the Affordable Care Act came as the Obama administration braced for an escalated political battle ahead of the midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama declared victory Tuesday in the government’s aggressive push to enroll seven million people in private health insurance plans under the Affordable Care Act, even as his senior aides braced for an escalated political battle over the law ahead of the fall’s crucial midterm elections.

headline: New York Tax Credit to Encourage Theater Productions Upstate
abstract: A new tax credit passed by the legislature is intended to persuade Broadway producers to use upstate theaters as rehearsal halls and construction shops for shows going on national tour.
lead_paragraph: New York has passed a tax credit aimed at persuading Broadway producers and others to use upstate theaters as rehearsal halls and construction shops for shows going out on national tour. The 2014-15 state budget, passed by the legislature on Monday, includes a credit that would cover 25 percent of production-related costs for shows that prepare their road tours at theaters outside of the five boroughs. Theaters in upstate cities like Buffalo, Rochester, Elmira and elsewhere are most likely to be used, given their size and availability.

headline: Back Surgery Puts Woods Out of the Masters for the First Time Since 1994
abstract: Tiger Woods said on his website that he had surgery on Monday in Utah for a pinched nerve and would need time to rehabilitate.
lead_paragraph: Knee problems could not keep Tiger Woods out of the Masters. He placed second in 2008 in the fifth of six starts he made before having season-ending surgery.

headline: Red Hook Criterium
abstract: Amid rain and fog, more than 280 riders of all levels participated in the Red Hook Criterium in Brooklyn, N.Y., last Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Amid rain and fog, more than 280 riders of all levels participated in the Red Hook Criterium in Brooklyn, N.Y., last Saturday.

headline: Le Pen Reacts to Provisional Results
abstract: As talks of a government reshuffling grew, the leader of France’s National Front party, Marine Le Pen, spoke about the record win in local elections for her far-right party on March 30.
lead_paragraph: As talks of a government reshuffling grew, the leader of France’s National Front party, Marine Le Pen, spoke about the record win in local elections for her far-right party on March 30.

headline: A Reporter Clutches Life After a Loss That Hits Home
abstract: Habib Zahori on losing his friend Sardar Ahmed, a journalist who was killed along with his wife and two of their three children in a Taliban attack on a hotel in Kabul.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — I once asked my mother sarcastically why she and my dad had six children. She looked at me patiently and said, “Because we were not sure that all of you would survive.”

headline: Universal Music Group Breaks Up Its Island Def Jam Division
abstract: The reorganization displaces Barry Weiss, the former Sony executive who was brought in three years ago to run Universal’s East Coast operations.
lead_paragraph: Universal Music Group, the giant record company that sells almost 40 percent of the world’s music, made a series of structural changes on Tuesday, splitting up one of its major divisions and displacing Barry Weiss, the former Sony executive who was brought in three years ago to run the company’s East Coast operations.

headline: Spanish-Language ‘Vagina Monologues’ to Play at Westside Theater
abstract: The producers of a Mexico City production of Eve Ensler’s play will bring it to the Westside Theater in Manhattan, where the original ran for 1,381 performances.
lead_paragraph: Eve Ensler’s theatrical feminist empowerment manifesto, “The Vagina Monologues,” was a hot property for the Westside Theater, where it ran for 1,381 performances between 1999 and 2003. Now the show is returning to the Westside, but in a new form – as “Los Monólogos de la Vagina,” a Spanish version modeled on the production that has been running in Mexico City for the last 14 years. Performances begin on May 6.

headline: A Blazing Iditarod Trail
abstract: Alaska’s unseasonably warm winter created long stretches of snowless track and record finish times for the Iditarod Trail Invitational.
lead_paragraph: Alaska’s unseasonably warm winter created long stretches of snowless track and record finish times for the Iditarod Trail Invitational.

headline: Elbow Injury Threatens Parnell’s Season
abstract: The Mets said Parnell, who blew a save in the season opener on Monday, has a partial tear of the medial collateral ligament in his right elbow.
lead_paragraph: It had not been an easy spring for Mets closer Bobby Parnell. He was trying to regain his strength after having neck surgery last September, but his progress seemed slow. The Mets shrugged it off, but on Monday, when he blew a save in the first game of the season, his velocity was still too low. Afterward, he complained of tightness in his right forearm, and on Tuesday, he was examined at the Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan.

headline: Daniel Radcliffe: I’d Love to Do ‘Rosencrantz and Guildenstern’
abstract: Mr. Radcliffe will soon begin performances on Broadway in “The Cripple of Inishmaan,” but he spoke Monday about some other shows he’d like to do.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Radcliffe may be focused on starting performances April 12 in his next Broadway play, “The Cripple of Inishmaan,” but he also has other shows in mind that he would like to do in the future. During a TimesTalk event on Monday night, Mr. Radcliffe – a box office draw after playing the title character in the eight “Harry Potter” films – was asked about plays and musicals that he might like to do in the years ahead.

headline: Image of the Day: April 1
abstract: A man taking a bow before a bronze bull outside the Bombay Stock Exchange in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

headline: Victims’ Families on Cobalt Problems
abstract: Family members of those involved in crashes of the Chevrolet Cobalt spoke at a press conference in Washington ahead of a House hearing about General Motors on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Family members of those involved in crashes of the Chevrolet Cobalt spoke at a press conference in Washington ahead of a House hearing about General Motors on Tuesday.

headline: Rice University Picks Design Team for New Opera Theater
abstract: Rice University has picked a New York firm, Diller Scofidio + Renfro, to design a new opera theater on campus.
lead_paragraph: A new opera theater for Rice University’s music school in Houston will be designed by Diller Scofidio + Renfro, the university is to announce Wednesday.

headline: Times Minute | A Day of Israeli Diplomacy
abstract: On the Minute, how American students excel at problem solving and record times on this year’s Iditarod Trail Invitational.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Times Minute | Israeli Diplomacy
abstract: On the Minute, how American students excel at problem solving and record times on this year’s Iditarod Trail Invitational.
lead_paragraph: On the Minute, how American students excel at problem solving and record times on this year’s Iditarod Trail Invitational.

headline: In Performance: John Douglas Thompson of ‘Satchmo at the Waldorf’
abstract: The actor John Douglas Thompson in a scene from “Satchmo at the Waldorf,” a one-man show, written by Terry Teachout.
lead_paragraph: This week’s video features the actor John Douglas Thompson in a scene from “Satchmo at the Waldorf,” a one-man show, written by Terry Teachout, about the life of the jazz trumpeter and singer Louis Armstrong. In this scene Mr. Thompson plays both Armstrong and Joe Glaser, his manager of 40 years. The show, directed by Gordon Edelstein, is at the Westside Theater.

headline: Bookshelf | A Guide to New York’s Hidden Oases of Calm
abstract: A new guide, “Quiet New York,” seeks out the city’s most tranquil hideaways, both beloved and obscure.
lead_paragraph: Somewhere in Manhattan, a lone peacock struts past the quince and laurel in a churchyard garden; further uptown, a Beaux-Arts mansion opens its doors onto a massive, storied collection of Spanish art; in Brooklyn, hung-over yogis rise and unroll their mats under a ceiling draped in silk. These are the sorts of tranquil scenes toward which Siobhan Wall’s “Quiet New York” (Frances Lincoln, out today)— a slim, illustrated guide to the city’s “hidden corners and unexpected vistas” — steers both tourists and natives seeking solace and refuge in a city where both are hard to come by.

headline: Federal Funding for Maternal and Infant Visits Extended — Briefly
abstract: The Maternal, Infant and Early Childhood Home Visiting Programs enjoy bipartisan support. Locally run programs successfully reduce infant mortality and increase longer term family success. So Congress has extended the funding for the federal-state partnership — for six months.
lead_paragraph: It’s the quip that extends across class and culture: Babies don’t come with instruction manuals. But for parents of means, they can come with help in the form of visiting doulas or night nannies, and for parents with local family, help (or “help”) might be readily available. The universal is that every new parent needs a hand, and many families find it in what are formally known as Maternal, Infant and Early Childhood Home Visiting Programs.

headline: Highlights From House Hearing on G.M. Defects
abstract: Highlights from a House subcommittee hearing Tuesday investigating why it took General Motors and the nation’s auto regulatory agency nearly a decade to identify ignition problems in Chevrolet Cobalts and other cars.
lead_paragraph: As our colleagues Bill Vlasic and Matthew L. Wald report, Mary T. Barra, chief executive of General Motors, and David Friedman, the nation’s top auto safety regulator, faced a House panel Tuesday investigating why both the automaker and regulators failed to act for more than 10 years on an ignition defect that G.M. has now linked to 13 deaths.

headline: Families Urge G.M. to Get Defective Vehicles Off the Road
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: Relatives of accident victims asked the automaker to stop drivers from using vehicles with faulty ignition switches until they are repaired.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Relatives of accident victims who died in cars recalled by General Motors joined members of Congress in urging G.M. to tell people to stop driving vehicles with defective ignition switches until repairs are made.

headline: Upstairs, Downstairs, British All Around
abstract: At a Midtown hotel, the civilized Peacock and the publike Shakespeare beckon, fish and chips and all.
lead_paragraph: My dinner date had eaten in this room before. A Williams College graduate, she remembered its earlier incarnation as the school’s alumni club.

headline: Inventive Kitchen Mixes Chocolate and Chicken
abstract: The creators of Umami Burger are hoping to create yet another new taste at ChocoChicken in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The creators of Umami Burger, who boasted of producing a whole new taste and who went on to expand from a single Los Angeles restaurant to a national franchise, are hoping to do the same thing again, this time with chicken. And chocolate.

headline: Russia Tightens Pressure on Ukraine With Rise in Natural Gas Price
abstract: Gazprom, the Russian energy company, increased the price by 44 percent even as American and Russian diplomats worked toward a settlement over Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Even as American and Russian diplomats groped toward a settlement that would halt further Russian military intervention in Ukraine, Gazprom, the Russian energy company, stepped up the economic pressure on Tuesday by sharply raising the price it charges for natural gas.

headline: Inside the (Smaller) Bank Branch of the Future
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Technology that was once the stuff of James Bond movies and spy novels may soon turn up in local bank branches.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio – Inside the low-slung, nondescript beige building on the edge of an industrial parking lot here, JPMorgan Chase executives are conducting a vast experiment to construct bank branches of the future — complete with cash machines unlocked by palm and iris scanners instead of debit cards. They hope the new branches will fundamentally upend Americans’ relationship with banking.

headline: Steelhead Drive Is Gone After Mudslide, Along With Many Lives Lived on It
abstract: The Ruthvens, the Satterlees, the Spillers and the Halsteads, among many families now presumed dead after the landslide in Oso, Wash., defined their neighborhood with their lives.
lead_paragraph: OSO, Wash. — The words, recorded by the Snohomish County emergency response system in the frantic minutes after a giant wall of earth slid down the mountain here on the morning of March 22, were breathy and labored. “All the homes on Steelhead Drive are gone,” a man said with long pauses between his words.

headline: A Big Biden Deal
abstract: Carry on, but don’t keep calm: this is big.
lead_paragraph: Now that Obamacare has finished with an amazing surge in signups, apparently passing the 7 million mark for the exchanges, there have been two main responses. Republicans are in full-on denial — the books are cooked! Nobody has paid! It’s only because people have been forced to do it! Benghazi! Vince Foster! Meanwhile, progressives are full of caution. It’s just a start, we don’t know how well this will work in the longer run, too soon to celebrate.

headline: Essay: The Real Competition to Virtual Currency
abstract: Bitcoin and its peers have so far failed to gain wide acceptance because the current monetary system works very well and is itself adaptable.
lead_paragraph: BITCOIN enthusiasts may want to study a satirical etching, published in 1792, that is now in a collection at London’s National Portrait Gallery. In one half, titled “French Liberty,” an emaciated French revolutionary gnaws on raw onions. In the other, “British Slavery,” a corpulent Englishman feasts on a giant slab of meat. The etching’s message — that a revolution is a farce if it fails to provide the basics — hangs uneasily over the world of virtual currencies.

headline: Marijuana by the Washington Monument
abstract: The D.C. mayor signed a bill decriminalizing possession of marijuana up to one ounce.
lead_paragraph: You may soon be able to gaze at the Washington Monument with marijuana in your pocket, risking nothing more than a small fine.

headline: Anna Gunn and Billy Magnussen to Star in ‘Sex With Strangers’
abstract: The actors will star in Laura Eason’s new drama at Second Stage Theater.
lead_paragraph: The Emmy Award-winning actress Anna Gunn (“Breaking Bad”) and the Tony Award-nominated actor Billy Magnussen (“Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike”) will star this summer in Second Stage Theater’s production of Laura Eason’s drama, “Sex With Strangers,” the theater announced on Tuesday.

headline: Addressing Harassment on the Streets and Subways of New York City
abstract: City Room received nearly 200 responses to a request for stories of street harassment in New York City. Read a sampling, as well as a listing of events planned for “International Anti-Street Harassment Week.”
lead_paragraph: City Room asked readers in February to share their stories of street and subway harassment in New York City. We received almost 200 blog comments and emails.

headline: G.M. Hires Lawyer Specializing in Disaster Payouts
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Reparations']
abstract: Kenneth Feinberg, who oversaw compensation after 9/11 and the BP oil spill, will help in deliberations over whether to pay damages to victims of accidents in cars with faulty ignition switches.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As families of crash victims lined the back of the House hearing room, displaying photos of their lost loved ones, Mary T. Barra, the General Motors chief executive, told lawmakers that the company was considering paying damages to victims of accidents in the millions of cars recalled for defective ignition switches.

headline: Stupidity in Economic Discourse 2
abstract: Duh, I’m just a dumb Keynesian.
lead_paragraph: I’ve written before about the myth of the stupid progressive economist.Many conservative economists have a fixed idea in their heads — it’s more than just a presumption, because it seems completely impervious to evidence — that progressive economists are dumb guys who don’t understand basic economics. And because of this fixed idea, conservatives appear literally unable to read what my side writes; they criticize the dumb things they’re sure we must have said, without checking to see if that’s what we actually said.

headline: NATO to Firm Up Its Presence in Eastern Europe as It Halts Cooperation With Russia
abstract: The move by NATO codifies and expands on steps the alliance had already taken to protest Russia’s intervention in Crimea.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — NATO’s foreign ministers vowed on Tuesday to strengthen the alliance’s military presence on the territory of its Eastern European members because of Russia’s military intervention in Ukraine.

headline: Sharon Jones and Robert Cray to Play Blues Festival in Lower Manhattan
abstract: Sharon Jones and the Dap-Kings and the Robert Cray Band will perform at the Lowdown Hudson Blues Festival in Battery Park City in July.
lead_paragraph: Sharon Jones and the Dap-Kings and the Robert Cray Band are among the groups that will perform at the Lowdown Hudson Blues Festival, a pair of free outdoor concerts at Brookfield Place in Battery Park City on July 16 and 17. The festival, now in its fourth year, is presented by Arts Brookfield, a real estate concern that presents free arts programming at Brookfield Place, formerly the World Financial Center, and at several of its other properties.

headline: Goldman Explores Sale of Market-Making Unit
keywords: ['High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The investment bank is valuing the unit on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange at about $30 million after paying $6.5 billion for it in 2000.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs, a fixture on Wall Street for more than 100 years, has decided to part with a business at the symbolic heart of the industry: the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: The Gun Report: April 1, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: An article on the front page of today’s Times tells the story of Kahton Anderson, the 14-year-old who climbed aboard a bus in Brooklyn, N.Y., on March 20, armed with a silver .357 revolver he meant to fire at another teenager. Instead he hit 39-year-old Angel Rojas, who was on his way home between his two jobs, killing him. The story also offers a snapshot of gang life in New York City, where small slights between rival crews loom large both on the turf they inhabit and on the Internet.

headline: After Rough Winter, Auto Sales Jumped in March
abstract: Most of the market had significant growth after a harsh winter that kept consumers away from dealerships.
lead_paragraph: The auto market rebounded in March from a harsh winter that stunted steady sales gains in the United States. On Tuesday, automakers reported strong growth, exceeding analysts’ expectations and suggesting that in spite of sharp declines early in the year, some companies might meet quarterly targets.

headline: Let Us Introduce Ourselves
abstract: Ever wonder not just about what is in the news but how decisions about the news are made?
lead_paragraph: Ever wonder not just about what is in the news but how decisions about the news are made?

headline: On the Verge | Into the Light
abstract: The avant-garde industrial designer Philippe Malouin steps out of the shadow of his famous mentor, Tom Dixon.
lead_paragraph: The avant-garde designer Philippe Malouin steps out of his famous mentor’s shadow.

headline: European Finance Ministers Approve New Loans for Greece
abstract: Pointing to signs that Greece is emerging from its economic crisis, euro zone finance ministers approved the release of 8.3 billion euros in rescue loans.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Euro zone finance ministers, meeting in Athens under tight security on Tuesday, approved the release of 8.3 billion euros in rescue loans to Greece, pointing to signs that the country is emerging from its economic crisis.

headline: A Nudge on Digital Privacy Law From E.U. Official
abstract: The top data protection official said legislation to revamp the system, which has been in the works since 2010, should be passed this year.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The top data protection official for the European Union called Tuesday for member governments to restore public trust in the Internet by pressing ahead with an overhaul of the bloc’s electronic privacy laws by the end of this year.

headline: A Primer on Northwestern Players’ Quest to Unionize
abstract: Last week, a regional director of the National Labor Relations Board ruled that Northwestern football players could be considered employees. What comes next?
lead_paragraph: Two months ago, a group called the College Athletes Players Association submitted a petition to the National Labor Relations Board in Chicago seeking to have Northwestern’s football team recognized as a union.

headline: With Plane Still Missing, Legal Moves for Payouts Start
abstract: Although there is still no certainty that Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 has crashed, lawyers are pursuing families that might be granted multimillion-dollar settlements.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — For 10 days, Monica R. Kelly and her American law firm’s aviation lawyers have stalked the dim hallways of the Lido Hotel here to make their pitches to relatives of passengers aboard missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

headline: Online Reviews? Keep This in Mind
abstract: Many factors can skew the quality and quantity of crowd-sourced comments.
lead_paragraph: The size and racial makeup of a city, the price of a meal and even the weather can skew the quality and quantity of online restaurant reviews, according to the first large-scale academic study to analyze how outside factors affect crowd-sourced review sites.

headline: Owner of American Lawyer Said to Put Publisher Up for Sale
abstract: The owner of American Lawyer, one of the mainstay magazines for the legal industry, has put the magazine’s publisher up for sale, a person briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The owner of American Lawyer, one of the mainstay magazines for the legal industry, has put the magazine’s publisher up for sale, a person briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

headline: The Scuffin Takes the Cake
abstract: The scone-muffin hybrid is the readers’ choice among the new breed of Frankenpastries.
lead_paragraph: Last week, we reported on a surge of creativity in American bakeries inspired by the Cronut: a croissant-doughnut hybrid that has brought its creator, the New York pastry chef Dominique Ansel, fame and fortune. The race to invent the next celebrity Frankenpastry is afoot, and we asked you to pick among some front-runners — like the mallomac (part Mallomar, part macaron) and the pie milkshake (a miniature pie blended into a shake) — as the recipe you’d most like to make at home.

headline: A Bowl of Berries Left to Dry in the Sun
abstract: The short stories in Lydia Davis’s “Can’t and Won’t” range from one-liners to lists to letters.
lead_paragraph: Lydia Davis’s short stories are difficult to describe, but people like to try. A friend of mine likens them to mosquitoes. Some you swat away, he says. Others draw blood.

headline: On Coates v. Chait
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Teenage Pregnancy']
abstract: Thoughts on race, culture, agency and exhortation.
lead_paragraph: Over the last two weeks, New York Magazine’s Jonathan Chait and The Atlantic’s Ta-Nehisi Coates, two of the internet’s most admired liberal journalists, have engaged in an extended back-and-forth about the legitimacy of public critiques of cultural dysfunction in poor, inner-city African-American culture — and particularly the kind of critiques offered by President Obama, who often speaks exhortatively about personal and parental responsibility in addresses to black audiences. My impression (drawn from Twitter) is that many readers following the debate felt that Coates essentially won it with his most recent entry, a rich brief for the proposition that even (or especially?) coming from the lips of an African-American president, a disproportionate rhetorical focus on black pathology, black moral failure, and black dysfunction simply perpetuates modern American society’s habit of (to rewrite a famous Malcolm X line that Coates quotes) congratulating itself for pulling its knife partway out of black America’s back and then blaming the victim when he still has trouble walking.

headline: Zlatan Ibrahimovic, One of Soccer’s Brashest Stars, Reveals a Quieter Side
abstract: Ibrahimovic, who plays for Paris St.-Germain and has a reputation as soccer’s high-scoring bad boy, claims to be little more than a homebody.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For more than a decade, Zlatan Ibrahimovic has carried a reputation as soccer’s bad boy, not so much a 6-foot-5 striker but a highlight-making, coach-criticizing, teammate-punching lightning rod whose inflated scoring totals were matched in size only by his ego.

headline: G.M.’s Barra Apologizes
abstract: The chief executive of General Motors, Mary Barra, opened the hearing with an apology to the families of the victims involved in crashes of the company’s cars.
lead_paragraph: The chief executive of General Motors, Mary Barra, opened the hearing with an apology to the families of the victims involved in crashes of the company’s cars.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Afghanistan, China, Greece and Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Afghanistan, China, Greece and Ukraine.

headline: High-Frequency Trading Book Riles Tempers on CNBC
abstract: The new book by Michael Lewis has inflamed passions across Wall Street, stoking a debate over the business of high-frequency trading. On Tuesday, it also made for some explosive TV.
lead_paragraph: The new book by Michael Lewis has inflamed passions across Wall Street, stoking a debate over the business of high-frequency trading.

headline: Alvin Ailey to Bring New Work to Koch Theater
abstract: A world premiere from the choreographer Robert Moses is among the highlights of the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater’s two-week engagement at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: A world premiere from Robert Moses, the company premiere of Asadata Dafora’s 1932 solo “Awassa Astrige/Ostrich” and new productions by David Parsons and Hans van Manen are among the highlights of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater’s two-week engagement at Lincoln Center from June 11 to June 22.

headline: Checking In on the Members of Our Business Group
abstract: Introducing a new member and charting the progress of the others.
lead_paragraph: We started the She Owns It business group more than two years ago to offer a window into the real-life business challenges of owners who happen to be women. Since then, the group has met monthly to discuss topics such as hiring, health insurance, manufacturing, growing pains and customer service. Its composition has changed over the years as members have rotated in and out.

headline: Do The Right Thing: Making Ethical Decisions in Everyday Life
abstract: In this lesson, we explore ethical dilemmas that face normal people around the world, in all walks of life. Each example features individuals who followed the guidance of their own moral code, often risking personal injury or community censure to do so. We’ll ask students to examine the underlying characteristics of such episodes, and consider whether some acts are more deserving of support than others.
lead_paragraph: Overview | Something happens — a moment of injustice, a threat to the nation, a potentially criminal act. Why do some people speak out or take action, while others remain silent? And how can we encourage more people to recognize the moment when bravery is required?

headline: Running Late? Push Federal Tax Day Back to October
abstract: If you don’t have everything you need to file your taxes on time, you can file for an extension.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks remain before the April 15 deadline for filing your federal income tax return. But what if you don’t think you will be able to file your return on time?

headline: Artful Knives, a Guide for Beginner Chefs, an Icy Cocktail and More
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'Restaurants', 'Knives', 'Cocktails', 'Books and Literature', 'Tableware']
abstract: Recommendations for the week of April 1.
lead_paragraph: To Wield: An Artful Collection Forged by Hand

headline: Japan Center Questions Stem Cell Breakthrough
abstract: An investigation into the case said the study’s lead author had altered or misrepresented the illustrations in her research papers.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — A study once hailed as a breakthrough in creating stem cells contained fabricated and doctored images that cast doubt on its findings, a Japanese research institute concluded on Tuesday in a blistering investigation into a case that has become a major embarrassment for the country’s scientific community.

headline: Getting the Jump on Mosquitoes
keywords: ['Deet (Insect Repellent)', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Mosquitoes', 'Malaria', 'West Nile Virus', 'Dengue Fever', 'Lymphatic Filariasis']
abstract: Arm yourself with information about risks and prevention techniques to gain an advantage in the battle against bites.
lead_paragraph: Thwack! Bitten. Again.

headline: Lynda Carter’s Travel Tips, From Water to Walking
abstract: The actress and singer explains how she avoids fatigue on the road and how she packs “every cream I own” for her trips.
lead_paragraph: Although most people know Lynda Carter from her memorable role in the “Wonder Woman” television series, she has actually spent more time singing jazz than swinging a lasso of truth. She left Phoenix, her hometown, in the late 1960s, when she was still a teenager, to sing with different bands, touring from the Las Vegas Strip, in its ’70s heyday, to the Catskills and back again.

headline: Ridgefield, Conn.: Upscale Americana
abstract: A bedroom community where most of the housing stock consists of single-family homes, from colonials and Capes to equestrian farms and estates.
lead_paragraph: People moving to Fairfield County from other regions of the country often suffer sticker shock when they begin house-hunting. But that was not the case for Rebecca and Peter Cook, who relocated to Ridgefield from San Francisco two years ago for Mr. Cook’s job with IBM. Coming from one of the most expensive housing markets in the country, the Cooks weren’t intimidated by Ridgefield’s $600,000-plus median home price. Rather, they were entranced by the three-century-old town’s signature village center, with its broad, tree-lined Main Street, grand historic homes and charming downtown storefronts.

headline: Checks Are Expendable, but in Legal Tender We Trust
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Haunted by financial crises, people worldwide are looking to paper money, especially $100 bills, to hold its value, according to a report by the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: THE financial industry may be fixated on virtual currencies and credit card technologies, but don’t declare cash an endangered species just yet.

headline: The Cashless Society Meets the Loose-Change Economy
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mobile Applications', 'Mobile Commerce', 'Personal Finances', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: Online or mobile payment systems have yet to catch on in contexts where small, informal transactions are the norm.
lead_paragraph: MAJ. RON BUSROE of the Salvation Army has no doubt that people are carrying a lot less cash.

lead_paragraph: Mr. Lorber, 65, is the chairman of Douglas Elliman Real Estate, as well as the president and chief of both the Vector Group and its real estate investment subsidiary New Valley Realty, which is a majority owner of Douglas Elliman. He is also the executive chairman of the fast-food chain Nathan’s Famous.

lead_paragraph: SINCE the 1970s, paying with plastic has been pretty standard everywhere: Customers swiped their cards, signed receipts and took home their purchases.

headline: A Nostalgia Ride With a Driving Ensemble Behind the Wheel
abstract: The Amphion String Quartet focused on the early 20th century in a program on Sunday at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: At a single concert on Sunday at Alice Tully Hall, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center’s audience got what amounted to two recitals for the price of one. That was the good news.

headline: From Slave Ship Shackles to the Mountaintop
abstract: The National Civil Rights Museum in Memphis will reopen on Saturday after a $28 million reconstruction.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — The climax of the sweeping new exhibition at the National Civil Rights Museum here is almost painfully mundane. An open container of milk and a half-drunk cup of coffee sit on a table near a 1960s television topped by rabbit-ear antennas. A peach-colored bedspread is pulled back, and the remains of a catfish lunch are nearby. Pale yellow curtains are open to the balcony outside. We are looking at Room 306 of the Lorraine Motel.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 72
abstract: FIFA is continuing the installation of goal-line technology at the 12 World Cup stadiums in Brazil.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: The Critics’ Take: What You Should See, Hear, Visit Now
abstract: Our arts critics share some of their current cultural picks with Times Insiders.
lead_paragraph: You’re busy and looking for guidance. You want to know what The Times’s culture critics think you should see, hear or read this month. Here’s what they recommend.

headline: A Skype Founder and a Famous Smoothie Maker Swap Tales in London
abstract: As London’s technology scene rises, buoyed in part by the recent public offering by the maker of Candy Crush Saga, many in the British capital are trying to think of ways to avoid the kind of tensions that have arisen between the haves and have-nots in the San Francisco Bay Area.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On a wet British morning, small groups of entrepreneurs sat huddled around tables in a converted warehouse in East London, swapping advice and stories about their companies.

headline: Scribd Adds Lonely Planet Guides to Its Roster
abstract: Scribd, the e-book subscription service, will now include Lonely Planet guidebooks.
lead_paragraph: While travel trend reports continue to predict the death of the printed guidebook, Lonely Planet seems to have found a way to keep its popular printed guides very much alive, through a more digitally friendly, and lighter, interface.

headline: Cleveland’s Thriving Theater Hub Lures Residents
abstract: PlayhouseSquare, a vibrant performing arts complex, has helped double the population of the city’s core to 12,000.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — When a national tour of “Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat” played here last month, Vincent Wil Hawley walked from his apartment at Residences at Hanna, a new 102-unit conversion in a renovated office building annex, and was in his seat five minutes later.

headline: Letter Tells of U.S. Searches for Emails and Calls
abstract: The letter, from the director of national intelligence to a senator, underscored that such activity was not just theoretical.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — United States intelligence analysts have searched for Americans’ emails and phone calls within the repository of communications that the government collects without a warrant, according to a letter from James R. Clapper Jr., the director of national intelligence, to Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon.

headline: Delayed by Stubborn Winter, Spring’s Colors Are Ready to Burst
keywords: ['Gardens and Gardening', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Seasons and Months']
abstract: After the coldest March in the New York area since 1984, flowering species that would normally have bloomed in succession are expected to overlap in rare combinations.
lead_paragraph: When scattered snowflakes fell on the last day of March, New Yorkers might have been forgiven for thinking spring would never arrive. But with the weather predicted to warm up this week, plant experts say they may finally be in for a treat: a simultaneous burst of color, as flowering species that normally bloom in succession instead paint the landscape pink, yellow and white all at once.

headline: Dangerous Roads, Constant Crises: Adam Nossiter on Central Africa
abstract: Adam Nossiter, The Times’s bureau chief in West and Central Africa, spoke with us about covering 25-plus countries as his regular beat.
lead_paragraph: After covering the American South for two decades, Adam Nossiter became the West and Central Africa bureau chief for The Times in 2009. Since then, he has seen villages charred by fires set in the Central African Republic during a sectarian civil war. He has reported on France’s intervention in the war in Mali, the bloody end to the 2013 hostage crisis in Algeria and Nigeria’s continuing fight with the terrorist group Boko Haram. He has also portrayed the everyday lives of people whose countries are working to build the kind of governments that many outside the continent take for granted. His beat extends across at least 25 countries.

headline: Obama on Health Care Enrollment Numbers

headline: Laurie Colwin: A Confidante in the Kitchen

lead_paragraph: Emily Gould stood in an Upper West Side kitchen on a Saturday evening and gazed into a crumb-encrusted pan full of creamed spinach. “It kind of suffered on the subway a little bit,” she said.

headline: Wells Fargo Names New C.F.O.
abstract: Timothy J. Sloan, 53, is leaving the C.F.O. post to head Wells Fargo’s wholesale banking group, and John R. Shrewsberry, 48, currently head of Wells Fargo Securities,will become the new chief financial officer.
lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo reshuffled some its top executives on Tuesday, naming a new chief financial officer and a new head of wholesale banking.

headline: Nothing Up His Sleeve, Just a Knack for Deception
abstract: Vinny DePonto’s solo play “Charlatan” features sleight of hand card tricks, mind-reading and sideshow stunts.
lead_paragraph: On the night I attended “Charlatan,” a solid magic show decked out in theatrical finery, its star, Vinny DePonto, first appeared on a video screen before the sound went mute and the production ground to a halt. After a break, he ditched the opening and started again, this time live onstage. Embarrassing? Sure. Did the technical difficulties hurt the evening? Yes and no.
