lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – Meryl Streep, hard rocker?

headline: Old Forecast of Famine May Yet Come True
abstract: As crop yields fall and populations rise, the alarming vision of Thomas Malthus might be proved right by climate change — two centuries after he first expressed it.
lead_paragraph: Might Thomas Malthus be vindicated in the end?

headline: Not Giving an Inch in a Battle of Wits and Words
abstract: In his documentary “The Unknown Known,” Errol Morris goes mano a mano with the former defense secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld.
lead_paragraph: In 2003 the journalist Hart Seely published “Pieces of Intelligence: The Existential Poetry of Donald H. Rumsfeld,” a book that arranged some of the public pronouncements of that secretary of defense into spiky, evocative morsels of free verse. Mr. Rumsfeld may have been an accidental poet, but “The Unknown Known,” Errol Morris’s new documentary about him, nonetheless makes an implicit argument for his literary distinction. Not only does Mr. Rumsfeld revel in his status as the proud and prolific author — via his beloved Dictaphone — of memos known at the Pentagon as “snowflakes,” but he also shows himself to be a man fascinated by language and delighted by his ability to use it.

headline: Your Evening Briefing

lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: A Revolution in Money
abstract: Futurists predict a revolution in the tenets of finance in the coming decades, similar to the changes that have been sweeping the information and telecommunications industries.
lead_paragraph: Imagine it’s 2040.

headline: A Wild Ride Returns. Confused?
abstract: John Jesurun’s absurdist serial about a businessman’s efforts to bilk a wealthy family is back with a new episode after nine years.
lead_paragraph: It takes a wild, warped and sweeping literary imagination to join Jean-Paul Sartre, Condoleezza Rice, Britney Spears and Wassily Kandinsky in a single script. John Jesurun has one. Since 1982, he has written and directed “Chang in a Void Moon,” an absurdist serial about a businessman’s efforts to bilk a wealthy family. Last week, after a nine-year hiatus, the first of three new episodes debuted at Incubator Arts Project. (The next runs Friday through Sunday; the third runs April 11 to 13.)

headline: Tuneful Paul Simon Tribute Bridges Decades
abstract: Folkies, pop crooners, punks and soul singers could all latch onto something from the catalog of Paul Simon on Monday night at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Folkies, pop crooners, punks and soul singers could all latch onto something from the catalog of Paul Simon on Monday night at Carnegie Hall. “The Music of Paul Simon,” with about two dozen performers playing a song each, was the 10th annual all-star songwriter tribute at Carnegie Hall produced by Michael Dorf of City Winery. It’s a series of benefit concerts that has raised nearly a million dollars for music education. Among the performers was a duo of 13-year-old songwriters, Megan Doyle and Snow Guilfoyle, from one of the beneficiary institutions, the Church Street School for Music and Art, singing the contrapuntal “Scarborough Fair/Canticle.”

abstract: The family of Amir Hekmati, the former Marine imprisoned in Iran, released a letter from his ailing father’s doctor asking Iran to free Mr. Hekmati.
lead_paragraph: The doctor for the terminally ill father of Amir Hekmati, the 30-year-old former Marine imprisoned in Iran, has written to the Iranian judicial authorities asking them to release Mr. Hekmati on compassionate grounds so he can return home, according to a copy of the letter shared by the family on Tuesday.

headline: A French Artist’s Vision of Voguing
abstract: in a new show at Julie Meneret Contemporary Art, Frédéric Nauczyciel explores the state of the iconic dance genre through photography, video and performance.
lead_paragraph: Frédéric Nauczyciel can’t remember when he learned about voguing, the dance form characterized by the poses that emulate those in the pages of Vogue, or the first time he saw “Paris Is Burning,” the iconic 1990 documentary on New York’s ball dance culture that touched on the city’s vogue scene. “It’s like it’s always been there for me,” he says. But three years ago, contemporary voguers in two cities an ocean apart began to captivate Nauczyciel so much that they are now the subject of his first New York exhibition, “The Fire Flies (Baltimore / Paris),” which opens tomorrow at Julie Meneret Contemporary Art.

headline: Low Vitamin D Levels Linked to Disease in Two Big Studies
abstract: The new research, however, doesn’t show whether low levels are a cause of illness or are simply an indicator of overall health.
lead_paragraph: People with low vitamin D levels are more likely to die from cancer and heart disease and to suffer from other illnesses, scientists reported in two large studies published on Tuesday.

headline: An Enigma, Bound by Chaos, Staged by a Veteran Choreographer
abstract: The dancer Cori Kresge marked her 10th anniversary with the Wendy Osserman Dance Company with a new, hourlong Osserman piece at the Theater for the New City.
lead_paragraph: Any opportunity to see the dancer Cori Kresge is welcome. When she was a member of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company’s Repertory Understudy Group, her steely, sensuous strength and staggering facility made you question her status as an “understudy.” In works by the Cunningham alumni Rashaun Mitchell and Silas Riener, she has been just as incisive, if more animal, almost otherworldly, in what seems like her insatiable need to be dancing.

headline: Inhaled Insulin Clears Hurdle Toward F.D.A. Approval
keywords: ['Insulin', 'Medicine and Health', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Diabetes', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)']
abstract: The product, called Afrezza, would offer people with diabetes a treatment option that does not require injections, although its success in clinical trials has been modest at best.
lead_paragraph: A government advisory committee on Tuesday recommended approval of a form of insulin that is inhaled rather than injected. The endorsement could lead to a new option for millions of Americans with diabetes and vindication for the persistent billionaire who spent a large amount of his fortune to develop the product.

headline: The Profits and Losses of Fugitive Tracking
abstract: In “The Retrieval,” written and directed by Chris Eska, a black youngster working for Civil War bounty hunters helps them capture black fugitives.
lead_paragraph: A tough, tender little movie, “The Retrieval” tells a story of divided souls wandering a divided land. It takes place in 1864, the year before the Civil War ended, and opens in the dead of night. As cannons boom in the distance, a 13-year-old black boy, a seeming runaway, takes refuge in a barn guarded by a white woman with a long gun. Shortly after the boy settles in next to a few black fugitives — one silently hands him food — he slips out to alert his employers, white bounty hunters who quickly torch the barn and capture the fugitives, who fetch as much as $600 a head.

headline: Good Wine, Bad Companions and a Nude Stroll in an Olive Grove
abstract: “Dom Hemingway,” a violent British comedy, stars Jude Law as a recently released prisoner off to a French villa to get what’s coming to him — in a good way — from a gangland boss.
lead_paragraph: There is, perhaps, only so much to say about a movie that opens with a man delivering a soliloquy about his penis. When you first see the title character of “Dom Hemingway,” a violent British comedy about a gangster who talks the hard-boiled talk with verve and gutter lyricism, he’s speaking and staring into the camera. His arms are stretched out to the side, Christlike, and while the camera doesn’t show the full monty, the shot is wide enough for you to see that Jude Law has packed on a few pounds to play this flamboyant tough guy and hasn’t taken a Gillette to his chest.

abstract: A concert presented by the Austrian Cultural Forum’s Vienna Complex series focused on works by Ernst Krenek, who emigrated to America after his music was suppressed by the Nazis.
lead_paragraph: It has been up to the Austrian Cultural Forum the past few months to provide what the Vienna Philharmonic and Carnegie Hall’s Vienna: City of Dreams festival largely did not: a range of Austrian composers who were suppressed by the Nazis.

headline: Wearing Three Hats, All From One Seat
abstract: The violinist Joshua Bell led the Academy of St. Martin in the Fields from the concertmaster’s chair when the orchestra played a program featuring Beethoven’s “Eroica” Symphony.
lead_paragraph: The sight of a star soloist simultaneously conducting and performing a concerto has become fairly common. But the violinist Joshua Bell, who took over as music director of the Academy of St. Martin in the Fields nearly three years ago, reaches back to an 18th-century tradition in that he also leads performances from the concertmaster’s chair: He’s not just having his cake and eating it — he helps bake it, too.

headline: Aging Church Passes Digital Collection Plate
abstract: St. Francis at Ripa Roman Catholic Church in Rome has turned to the crowdfunding website Kickstarter to raise money for a renovation.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Not far from the banks of the Tiber River, the 800-year-old church of St. Francis at Ripa has never been one of Rome’s most famous destinations. A quietly glorious Baroque sanctuary, with a famous statue by Bernini tucked into a side chapel, it has often been overlooked by tourists and Roman Catholics in a city so rich with other splendors.

keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Web-Original Programming', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']

lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — An outbreak of the deadly Ebola virus in the West African nation of Guinea has reached the crowded capital, Conakry, prompting new fears about its spread, health officials said Tuesday.

headline: Venezuela: A Call for Peace

lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — THE recent protests in Venezuela have made international headlines. Much of the foreign media coverage has distorted the reality of my country and the facts surrounding the events.

headline: Final Four Games Get Local Accents, Sort Of
abstract: Turner and CBS scrambled to assemble announcing teams for Saturday’s Final Four teamcasts on TNT and truTV.
lead_paragraph: Turner and CBS Sports stretched a bit to find announcing teams for Saturday’s Final Four teamcasts — the university-specific productions on TNT and truTV that will be shown against the traditional versions of the games on TBS. Only one announcer chosen called a full season of the colleges’ games on radio. The rest are from local, regional or conference TV — and not all are directly associated with the Final Four teams.

headline: Dr. Lefebvre’s American Dream
abstract: The story of a French academic, his love for America and his plan for a post-Civil War gift to the country — in the shape of a giant statue.
lead_paragraph: On April 15, 1861, the day the Civil War was declared, citizens in the town of Paris, Mass., gathered with “the fervor of a crusade” to send off their volunteers. The community’s doctor, René Lefebvre, joined the crowd with his son and future son-in-law and most of his neighbors. Dr. Lefebvre’s wife and daughter, like the other women of the town, offered prayers and encouragement as they valiantly held back tears. The celebration of patriotism and liberty convinced Dr. Lefebvre that “this soil, opened and fructified by the Puritans, can bring forth naught but liberty.”

headline: Follow the Money
keywords: ['International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Do the debates about Ukraine tell us something new about today’s world?
lead_paragraph: If you follow the debates about Ukraine, you can see three trends: those who use the crisis for humor, those who use it to reinforce preconceived views and those trying to figure out if it’s telling us something new about today’s world.

headline: Mayor Signs Marijuana Law
abstract: Mayor Vincent C. Gray on Monday signed into law a bill decriminalizing possession of small amounts of marijuana.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Vincent C. Gray on Monday signed into law a bill decriminalizing possession of small amounts of marijuana. Congress has 60 days when at least one chamber is in session to review the law before it is enacted.

headline: The Aliens Have Landed
abstract: But there’s nothing (science) fictional about climate change.
lead_paragraph: In the ’30s, as Germany rearmed, we said, “Yeah, France can handle that.” Earlier this week, the Panzer Corps of climate change zoomed right around our Maginot line of denial, and we all became the retreating French.

headline: Arizona: Abortion Ruling Is Appealed
abstract: Opponents of tough new state rules governing abortion-inducing drugs appealed a federal judge’s decision allowing the rules to go into effect.
lead_paragraph: Opponents of tough new state rules governing abortion-inducing drugs appealed a federal judge’s decision allowing the rules to go into effect. Planned Parenthood Arizona and Tucson Women’s Center asked the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit on Tuesday to block the law, which requires doctors to follow protocols approved by the Food and Drug Administration in 2000. The original F.D.A. rules limited so-called medication abortions to the first seven weeks of pregnancy and called for high doses of one of the drugs. Most clinics now use methods backed by major medical groups as safer, using smaller doses through the first nine weeks of pregnancy. Opponents say the law makes medication abortion harder to get. On Monday, Judge David C. Bury of United States District Court denied the groups’ request for a temporary restraining order.

headline: New Effort Gives Tech Workers Additional Way to Donate to Charity
abstract: RaisedBy.Us, created by two New York tech executives, will give tech workers an opportunity to give a portion of their paycheck to a charity of their choice.
lead_paragraph: Very soon, the tech industry will be out of excuses when it comes to giving back to local philanthropies and causes.

keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Wages and Salaries', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Medicine and Health', 'Minimum Wage', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Medicare', 'Editorials']
abstract: A new feature with updates on issues and subjects we follow.
lead_paragraph: A new feature with updates on issues and subjects we follow.

headline: At Hearing, Caterpillar Defends Tax Practices
abstract: Members of a Senate panel accused Caterpillar of channeling its most profitable operations through a subsidiary in Switzerland.
lead_paragraph: Officials of Caterpillar sparred with members of a Senate panel on Tuesday, defending more than a decade’s worth of tax practices that put most of the company’s profits out of reach of United States tax authorities.

headline: A Billion-Dollar Bracelet Is the Key to a Disney Park
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mobile Applications', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: Disney is counting on its multifaceted reservation system to ease the way to visit Mickey Mouse and company.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Walt Disney World has spent more than a year rolling out a $1 billion system that changes how visitors do everything from enter their hotel rooms to ride Space Mountain. But a few weeks ago a front desk agent at one of Disney’s marquee hotels was still wrestling with the technology.

headline: Jury Convicts Second Man in 2011 Killing of a High School Basketball Star
abstract: Robert Cartagena, found guilty of murdering Tayshana Murphy during a feud between groups of youths in Harlem, faces 25 years to life in prison for intentional murder.
lead_paragraph: Had Tayshana Murphy lived, her parents would probably be watching her play college basketball this year. As one of the country’s top-rated point guards at Murry Bergtraum High School in Lower Manhattan, Ms. Murphy, 18, was being scouted by colleges like St. John’s and Miami University when she was gunned down in Harlem three years ago.

headline: Terror Suit Against Jordanian Bank Tests U.S. Diplomacy and Secrecy Laws
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Palestinians', 'Terrorism', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Relatives of Americans killed by terrorist attacks in Israel filed suit against Arab Bank and the case has provoked a split in the Obama administration that pits the State Department against the Treasury and Justice Departments.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2004, relatives of some American citizens killed or injured by terrorist attacks in Israel sought redress in an unusual way. They filed a multibillion-dollar lawsuit against Arab Bank, the largest financial institution in Jordan, accusing it of transferring funds to Hamas leaders and other terrorists responsible for the attacks.

headline: Apple and Samsung Reprise Patent Fight (With Google a Shadow Presence)
abstract: The lawsuit is Apple’s second big patent action against Samsung Electronics, and the proceedings took on an air of something of a reunion bringing together a vastly dysfunctional family.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — As lawyers for Apple and Samsung made their opening statements in their patent trial in a federal courthouse here, they could not even agree on what the fight was about.

headline: Authorities Kill Gang Leader, Mexico Says
abstract: Mexican authorities said they had killed another leader of the Knights Templar drug gang, adding to a string of successes against the organization that seemed to leave only one boss still at large.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The Mexican authorities said on Tuesday that they had killed another leader of the feared Knights Templar drug gang, adding to a string of successes against the organization that seemed to leave only one boss still at large: a former schoolteacher believed to be hiding in the hills of the Pacific state of Michoacán.

headline: Music Industry Pushes Unified Message on Compensation
keywords: ['Music', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Law and Legislation', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Royalties']
abstract: The National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences is trying to pull together different constituencies to work for a single, all-purpose bill for fair compensation.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to the music industry’s lobbying efforts in Washington, it is time for some harmony.

headline: Athletics Embrace the Sour Smell of Sweet Success
abstract: Oakland’s success in the last two seasons has come in their lovable ballpark, which is among the oldest in baseball but with none of the others’ charm.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — There was something in the air Monday night when the Oakland Athletics opened their season at home.

headline: Albany’s Perilous Oil Boom
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Explosions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Editorials', 'Railroads', 'Railroad Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Tank cars are accidents waiting to happen, and regulators at all levels should take steps to reduce the risks.
lead_paragraph: Daniel McCoy, who manages Albany County and its port on the Hudson River, decided last month, that he had to do something about the dangers presented by the rumbling oil tank cars carrying crude oil from North Dakota’s Bakken fields to Albany, from which it is then shipped to refineries in the Northeast.

headline: To Protect Foreigners, Afghanistan Shuts Down Their Hangouts
abstract: After a wave of violence in the Afghan capital, several restaurants and guesthouses popular with foreigners were ordered closed until after elections on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan government, battered by a series of pre-election attacks aimed at foreigners in Kabul, the capital, has come up with a novel way of protecting them: Close their hangouts.

headline: Bad Move on Jonathan Pollard
abstract: The release of the convicted spy by the United States would do nothing to advance progress on the core issues of an Israeli-Palestinian peace deal.
lead_paragraph: The emergence of the convicted spy Jonathan Pollard as a bargaining chip in Israeli-Palestinian peace negotiations is a lamentable sign of America’s desperation to keep both sides talking. Peace between Israelis and Palestinians can be achieved only if they want it for themselves, something that is very much in doubt right now.

headline: Unusual Events Force Exceptional Turnover in Charlotte Mayor’s Office
keywords: ['Mayors', 'Elections, Mayors', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Bribery and Kickbacks']
abstract: An uncommon sequence of events, including a corruption inquiry, has led Charlotte to the point where it will soon have its fourth mayor in less than a year.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — For much of this city’s recent history, there has been an unwritten tradition of regular turnover in the mayor’s office: With a single exception, none of Charlotte’s mayors since 1977 have held the post for more than four years.

headline: Mr. Ryan’s Faith-Based Budget
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicare', 'Editorials']
abstract: The budget resolution for 2015 will probably get full support from House Republicans, but voters should look closely at the details.
lead_paragraph: The Republican budget for 2015, released Tuesday by Representative Paul Ryan, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, will never come close to being law, so it doesn’t have to pretend to be serious. This is a document designed solely to be reduced to a few bullet points so House Republicans can have something to show their most antigovernment voters.

headline: Checking for a Concussion With the Clock Running
abstract: The Nationals’ Bryce Harper was in a collision at second base in the top of the second inning, and was back on the field in the bottom of the inning.
lead_paragraph: For all the lore about baseball having no clock, the Washington Nationals sure had to beat one on Monday when Bryce Harper sustained a possible concussion while sliding into second base.

headline: Holder, in New York City, Calls Terror Trials Safe
abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said that last week’s conviction of Sulaiman Abu Ghaith had “proven beyond any doubt” that terrorism trials can “safely occur” in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. made a high-profile visit to New York City on Tuesday, meeting with federal prosecutors who last week won the conviction of a former top adviser to Osama bin Laden and forcefully reiterating, at a news conference, his view that the case had “proven beyond any doubt” that terrorism trials can “safely occur” in the city.

headline: Police Confront Rising Number of Mentally Ill Suspects
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: In towns and cities across the United States, police officers find themselves playing dual roles as law enforcers and psychiatric social workers.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — James Boyd, a homeless man camping in the Sandia Foothills here, could hear the commands of the police officers who were trying to move him out.

headline: Bishops Follow Pope’s Example: Opulence Is Out
abstract: Backlash to a plan by Archbishop Wilton D. Gregory of Atlanta to build a large mansion is the latest in a series of lay uprisings since Pope Francis chose to live in a modest residence.
lead_paragraph: The archbishop of Atlanta had a plan to resolve the space crunch at his cathedral: He would move out of his residence so priests could move in, and then he would build himself a new house with donated money and land.

headline: An Accounting of the Victims
abstract: On Tuesday, officials released names of 22 of the 28 confirmed dead from last month’s landslide in Oso, Washington. At least 20 more are still missing.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, officials released names of 22 of the 28 confirmed dead from last month’s landslide in Oso, Washington. At least 20 more are still missing.

headline: Hawks in a Playoff Race That Isn’t Their Priority
abstract: Atlanta Coach Mike Budenholzer reiterated that the emphasis was on laying a foundation for long-term success rather than on the fleeting rush of playing into late April.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — For any N.B.A. devotee, much less someone associated with the league, the standings are required daily reading during the ticktock to the playoffs.

headline: Rowland, Ex-Connecticut Governor, Is Implicated in New Case
abstract: A couple pleaded guilty to campaign violations for having a nursing home and affiliated entities pay John G. Rowland $35,000 as a campaign consultant.
lead_paragraph: John G. Rowland, a three-term Republican governor of Connecticut who resigned in 2004 under a cloud of corruption charges, has been implicated in a new investigation of improper campaign financing, according to legal filings and statements made in court this week.

headline: Afghan Women See Hope in the Ballot Box
abstract: There’s finally a sense that women have become a significant part of Afghanistan’s political life, but many fear the gains could be reversed if extremists retake power or Western aid dwindles.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Mariam Wardak is one of those young Afghans with her feet in two worlds: At 28, she has spent much of her adult life in Afghanistan, but she grew up in the United States after her family fled there. She vividly remembers the culture shock of visits back to her family’s village in rural Wardak Province a decade ago.

headline: To Curtail Departures, SAC Pursues 2-Year Pacts
abstract: Steven A. Cohen is asking employees who remain with his family office to sign two-year contracts.
lead_paragraph: The billionaire investor Steven A. Cohen is putting pressure on his traders to try to keep his investment firm together, as the once-powerful hedge fund awaits a judge’s decision next week on its guilty plea to securities fraud charges.

headline: Out of This World
abstract: David Levinson Wilk gets out.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — I stared at my finished grid for quite a while before I understood what the theme was, yet there it was, staring back at me the entire time. Hands up if this one by David Levinson Wilk took you a while.

headline: Chicago Mayor Seeks Alterations to Repair Badly Underfunded Pension Plan
abstract: Rahm Emanuel wants to raise property taxes and require some city workers and retirees to contribute more for their retirement benefits to repair a pension system at risk of insolvency.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Contending with one of the most poorly funded pension systems among the nation’s major cities, Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s administration has begun an urgent push to require some city workers to pay more for their retirement benefits and to raise property taxes for Chicagoans.

headline: Nets’ Surge Earns Jason Kidd a Second Award
abstract: Kidd was named the Eastern Conference coach of the month for the second time this year, providing another indicator of how complete the Nets’ turnaround has been this season.
lead_paragraph: Jason Kidd on Tuesday was named the Eastern Conference coach of the month for the second time this year, providing another indicator of how complete the Nets’ turnaround has been this season.

headline: Global Warming and the Developing World
abstract: What should be done to address the effects of climate change in developing countries?

headline: Strong Start in Deal-Making
abstract: Led by announced acquisitions like Comcast’s $45 billion bid for Time Warner Cable, the dollar volume of mergers worldwide rose 35 percent in the first three months of the year, compared with the same period a year ago. It was the strongest start for deals since 2011.
lead_paragraph: Led by announced acquisitions like Comcast’s $45 billion bid for Time Warner Cable, the dollar volume of mergers worldwide rose 35 percent in the first three months of the year, compared with the same period a year ago. It was the strongest start for deals since 2011.

headline: For Hiroki Kuroda, Every Season Begins a New Chapter
abstract: Part of Yankee starter Kuroda’s daily preparation includes a detailed scouting report he compiles from scratch each season.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Hiroki Kuroda walked through the visiting clubhouse at Minute Maid Park on Monday, holding a white, three-ring binder under his arm. The contents of the book were largely empty before Kuroda’s first scheduled start in what could be his final season in the major leagues. But as the season progresses, he plans to fill it with the kind of information that has helped him along his road to becoming the stingiest Japanese-born starting pitcher in major league history.

headline: House Approves Funds for Ukraine
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: President Obama said he would sign the bill providing for loan guarantees and sanctions against Russia.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House of Representatives passed legislation on Tuesday that provides a $1 billion loan guarantee for Ukraine and imposes new sanctions on Russia for its annexation of Crimea.

headline: Man to Serve Three Months in Jail for His Affair With Student
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: Malik Taylor, 32, admitted in state Supreme Court in Manhattan that he had several sexual encounters over two months with a 16-year-old student at the school where he worked.
lead_paragraph: A former administrator at a Manhattan high school who admitted to having affairs with students will serve three months in jail after pleading guilty on Tuesday to one count of third-degree rape in a deal with prosecutors, the Manhattan district attorney’s office said.

headline: Half of New York’s Tech Workers Lack College Degrees, Report Says
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Vocational Training']
abstract: A commissioned report shows how important the technology sector has become to New York City’s economy.
lead_paragraph: The fast-growing technology industry in New York is often cited as a magnet for graduates of the nation’s top universities. But a new report to be discussed in a speech by a deputy mayor on Wednesday found that almost half of the technology jobs in the city are filled by people without college degrees.

abstract: With money secured from Albany for its top policy priority of prekindergarten classes, Mayor Bill de Blasio and his team are eager to begin a new phase with the public and the press.
lead_paragraph: The conversation flowed easily, becoming by turns serious and playful, with sober talk of budgets and taxes mixed in with banter about youthful dreams of baseball stardom, and the congeniality of Travis d’Arnaud, the Mets’ starting catcher.

headline: Is the American Middle Class Losing Out to China and India?
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: Listening in on the debate over wages and free trade.
lead_paragraph: President Obama may be right: Free trade is a winning strategy that will lower consumer costs and expand employment in exporting industries.

headline: Earthquake Hits Off Coast of North Chile
keywords: ['Earthquakes', 'Tidal Waves and Tsunamis', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'Coastal Areas']
abstract: A strong quake struck off Chile, forcing an evacuation along the country’s long coastline and putting the entire Pacific Coast of South America on tsunami alerts.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — An 8.2-magnitude earthquake struck off the coast of northern Chile on Tuesday night, forcing a massive evacuation along the country’s long coastline. At least five people were reported to have died.

headline: S.M.U. Holds Off Clemson to Advance to N.I.T. Final
abstract: Markus Kennedy played a key role for the Mustangs, with a game-high 21 points and some crucial scoring plays.
lead_paragraph: Southern Methodist Coach Larry Brown recently referred to his tenure as Knicks coach during the 2005-6 season as “humiliating.”

headline: Turkey: Police Break Up Protest Over Voting Irregularities
abstract: Television reports showed two antiriot vehicles moving along a street and firing water cannons at groups calling for a recount.
lead_paragraph: Police in Ankara on Tuesday used water cannons and stun grenades to disperse crowds protesting voting irregularities in one of the closest races in Sunday’s local elections, which brought a landslide victory nationwide for the Islamic-rooted governing party. Television reports showed two antiriot vehicles moving along a street and firing water cannons at groups calling for a recount. Mansur Yavas, the opposition mayoral candidate, filed an appeal at the Supreme Electoral Board for examination of irregularities in light of findings by more than 1,000 volunteers working to pin down fraud. Photographs of dozens of ballot box information forms posted on Twitter, which the government moved to shut down last month, showed discrepancies between handwritten vote counts for the opposition party and entries in the digital counting system. The Supreme Electoral Board said on Tuesday that the official count was a legal process and urged parties to remain calm.

headline: Small Area Open Near Fukushima
keywords: ['Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Radiation']
abstract: Japan reopened a small part of the 12-mile evacuation zone around the destroyed Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant, allowing residents to return to live in their homes for the first time since the accident three years ago.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan reopened a small part of the 12-mile evacuation zone around the destroyed Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant on Tuesday, allowing residents to return to live in their homes for the first time since the accident three years ago.

headline: Missing From Christie’s Proof-of-Innocence Claim: The Proof
abstract: As of Tuesday afternoon, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey was refusing to make public the interviews that, his lawyer asserts, “vindicate” the governor in the traffic-jam-as-punishment scheme run by his aides.
lead_paragraph: As of Tuesday afternoon, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey was refusing to make public the interviews that, his lawyer asserts, “vindicate” the governor in the traffic-jam-as-punishment scheme run by his aides.

headline: Yanks’ Rebuilt Lineup Is Quickly Picked Apart
abstract: After one inning Tuesday, it seemed that the Yankees $470 million off-season investment was for naught as they looked ragged and C. C. Sabathia struggled early in a 6-2 loss to the Astros.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The first indication that things were going wrong came early. After an off-season of binge spending by the front office and a winter spent healing old injuries, it was finally time for the 2014 Yankees to showcase their revamped lineup and their supposedly reinvented No. 1 pitcher, C. C. Sabathia, looking to make up for the worst season of his career.

headline: Last Clashes for Nets and Knicks
abstract: The teams are both still jockeying for the postseason and can affect each other’s position.
lead_paragraph: The Nets and Knicks have met twice this season, taking turns embarrassing each other. The Knicks had a blowout 113-83 victory on Dec. 5 at Barclays Center, and the Nets returned the favor on Jan. 20, pounding the Knicks, 103-80, the indignity made worse by the “Brooklyn” chants that broke out at Madison Square Garden as the game got out of hand.

headline: Two Dollar Bill Is Oddity, but Some Love the Tender
abstract: One billion are in circulation, but it has always lagged in popularity behind the $1 bill.
lead_paragraph: Move over, Bitcoin. There is another uncommon tender angling for a spotlight, or in this case, a comeback: the $2 bill.

headline: How Exercise Can Help You Live Longer
abstract: An encouraging new study finds that exercise may slash your risk of heart disease, regardless of your cholesterol numbers or waist size.
lead_paragraph: Having unhealthy cholesterol numbers, elevated blood pressure or an expanding waistline substantially increases your chances of developing heart disease. But an encouraging new study finds that exercise may slash that risk, even if your other risk factors stay high.

headline: Marc Platt, 100, Stage and Screen Dancer, Dies
abstract: Mr. Platt was a lively and versatile dancer who had standout roles onstage and in films, including in the original 1943 Broadway production of “Oklahoma!”
lead_paragraph: Marc Platt, a lively and versatile dancer who had standout roles onstage and in films, including in the original 1943 Broadway production of “Oklahoma!” and as one of the virile young woodsmen seeking spouses in the 1954 film musical “Seven Brides for Seven Brothers,” died on Saturday in San Rafael, Calif. He was 100.

headline: Once Stumbling, Nets Are Surging Into Playoffs
abstract: The Nets clinched their second consecutive playoff berth and extended their home winning streak to 14 games, setting a franchise record.
lead_paragraph: The Nets on Tuesday clinched their second consecutive playoff berth, beating the energetic but depleted Houston Rockets, 105-96, at Barclays Center. While securing a postseason ticket seemed to be a formality, it was a testament to how good the Nets have become these last three months.

headline: Irene Fernandez, Champion of the Oppressed in Malaysia, Dies at 67
keywords: ['Foreign Workers', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: Ms. Fernandez’s indefatigable advocacy for better treatment of foreign workers prompted her government to denounce her and human rights groups to shower her with awards.
lead_paragraph: Irene Fernandez, a champion of the oppressed in Malaysia whose indefatigable advocacy for better treatment of foreign migrant workers prompted her government to denounce her as a traitor and human rights groups to shower her with awards, died on March 25 in Serdang, Malaysia. She was 67.

abstract: Live results from the Democratic primary for Washington, D.C., mayor.
lead_paragraph: Live results from the Democratic primary for Washington, D.C., mayor.

headline: Jets Add Receiver Jacoby Ford
abstract: The Jets continued to revamp their receiving corps by signing Ford, a 5-foot-9-inch speedster who also returns punts and kickoffs.
lead_paragraph: The Jets continued to revamp their receiving corps by signing Jacoby Ford, a 5-foot-9-inch speedster who also returns punts and kickoffs. Ford, who has been hampered by injuries throughout his four-year career, caught 13 passes for 99 yards last season with the Raiders. He will be reunited with Sanjay Lal, his position coach in Oakland. Aside from Ford, the Jets have signed Eric Decker and released Santonio Holmes, and they are likely to select a receiver in the early rounds of the draft in May.

headline: D.C. Mayor Is Defeated in Upset at Primary
abstract: Muriel E. Bowser won a stunning upset on Tuesday in the Democratic primary for mayor in a race that turned on the integrity of the incumbent, Vincent C. Gray.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Muriel E. Bowser, whose activist father introduced her to signature-gathering and door-knocking as a girl, won a stunning upset on Tuesday in the Democratic primary for mayor in a race that turned on the integrity of the incumbent, Vincent C. Gray.

headline: Charles Keating, 90, Key Figure in ’80s Savings and Loan Crisis, Dies
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Savings and Loan Associations']
abstract: Mr. Keating was a businessman who later went to prison after fleecing thousands of depositors with help from a group of United States senators dubbed the Keating Five.
lead_paragraph: Charles H. Keating Jr., who went to prison and came to symbolize the $150 billion savings-and-loan crisis a generation ago after fleecing thousands of depositors with regulatory help from a group of United States senators known as the Keating Five, has died. He was 90.

headline: China’s Cofco to Buy Majority Stake in Noble Agriculture Unit
abstract: Cofco, a huge state-owned foodstuffs conglomerate, has agreed to pay $1.5 billion for a 51 percent stake in Noble Agri as part of a push to meet China’s demands for food security.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Cofco Corporation, a huge Chinese state-owned foodstuffs conglomerate, agreed on Wednesday to pay $1.5 billion for a majority stake in the Noble Group’s agriculture business.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9:05 A.M. (Starz Cinema) THE SECRET IN THEIR EYES (2010) A retired Argentine court investigator (Ricardo Darin, above) and a judge (Soledad Villamil) revisit a hauntingly brutal crime from decades earlier — and their former lives toiling alongside a boozy colleague (Guillermo Francella) — in this drama directed by Juan José Campanella. The film alternates between the present and the 1970s, when Argentina was embarking on a military dictatorship. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis called this Oscar winner for best foreign-language film “an attractive, messy drama riddled with violence and edged with comedy that comes with a hint of Grand Guignol, a suggestion of politics and three resonant, deeply appealing performances.”

headline: Jerry Roberts, 93, Code Breaker for Britain
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Cryptography, Codes and Ciphers', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: Mr. Roberts, a German linguist, was part of a top-secret team gathered to decipher messages between Hitler and his field commanders.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Roberts, the last surviving member of the British code-breaking team that cracked strategic ciphers between Hitler and his top generals, helping to hasten the end of World War II, died on March 25 in Hampshire, England. He was 93.

headline: Rangers Set Road Record With Win in Vancouver

lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — Benoit Pouliot scored the winning goal in the first period as the Rangers earned their franchise-record 25th road win, beating the Vancouver Canucks, 3-1, on Tuesday at Rogers Arena.

headline: Library of Congress Beefs Up Recordings Collection, but Watch Out for That Barber
abstract: The original cast recording of “Sweeney Todd” is one of 25 items being added to the National Recording Registry by the Library of Congress.
lead_paragraph: Sweeney Todd, the murderous barber who sent his victims to their Maker impeccably shaved, is being sent to his own just reward: a permanent place in the Library of Congress.

headline: Nest’s Thermostat Is Going Global
abstract: On Wednesday, Nest Labs announced that it had started selling its wireless thermostat in Britain, the first time the product has been sold directly outside North America.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Months after Google agreed to buy Nest Labs, the maker of Internet-connected home devices, for $3.2 billion, Nest is finally taking its thermostat global.

headline: Pivotal Offers a Big Data Bundle
abstract: The technologies of big data may be new, but the business strategies often look familiar. A prime example is the Wednesday announcement by Pivotal, a cloud and big data company. It is offering a bundle of products and simplified pricing, a tactic similar to Microsoft’s in the personal computer business.
lead_paragraph: The technologies that fly under the banner of “big data” may be new, but the business strategies have a familiar look.

headline: Tech Spending Recovers, but It’s Different
abstract: Technology spending is set to grow significantly in 2014, a major research firm said Wednesday. More interesting, however, is how it is growing. More Android devices will be sold this year than all Apple operating system phones, ever. Mobile data is turning into the phone companies’ main business. Companies are buying cloud software.
lead_paragraph: It isn’t what you spend, it’s how you spend it.

headline: Chinese Government Expands Freedom of Information
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Freedom of the Press', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'Newspapers']
abstract: The Chinese government has extended its freedom of information rules to cover “all public interest information,” including state-owned enterprises, universities and how public servants spend state money.
lead_paragraph: Amid concerns over increasing restrictions to freedom of information in the United States, the Chinese government appears to be moving in the opposite direction, issuing new, broader guidelines for “public information.”

headline: AIDS Patients in Andhra Pradesh Find Fear at State Hospitals
keywords: ['Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Blood', 'Discrimination', 'Doctors', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hospitals', 'Medicine and Health', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Tests (Medical)']
abstract: One expert on the disease estimated that the majority of those with AIDS or H.I.V. in the state avoid going to government hospitals because they anticipate being treated as pariahs.
lead_paragraph: WARANGAL, India — As M. Balakrishna, a 38-year-old AIDS patient, pushed his gaunt body out of bed with his skinny arms, his knees wobbled as his feet hit the floor. His apartment was covered with spare motorbike parts, relics of a time when he was still able to work as a mechanic.

headline: Death Sentence Is Upheld for Doctor’s Killer
abstract: A court has upheld a death sentence for a man who fatally stabbed a doctor and severely wounded another in the coastal city of Wenling last year. Attacks on medical staff are disturbingly common in China.
lead_paragraph: A court in China has upheld a death sentence for a man who fatally stabbed one doctor and severely wounded another in the coastal city of Wenling last year. Attacks on medical staff occur regularly in the country, a fact that has the government worried.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, April 2, 2014
abstract: Can you calculate the number of tickets sold each week for “The Lion King”?
lead_paragraph: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | With the Thrills Come Extreme Risks
abstract: How many injuries attributed to extreme sports occurred between 2000 and 2011?
lead_paragraph: In “With the Thrills Come Extreme Risks,” Jane Brody writes about the injuries caused each year by extreme sports.

headline: Finding Chris Hondros
abstract: Chris’s Hondros’s “Testament” captures the mind and eye of a photographer who was killed in war. But to those who knew him, it is a chance to continue conversations started long ago.
lead_paragraph: Whenever Chris Hondros returned to New York City after a long assignment, it was like a roving professor holding office hours. One meeting at Caffe Reggio in Greenwich Village would morph into drinks or dinner with out-of-towners visiting Brooklyn. Friends came and went, but the discussion was always rich and lively. That’s what I miss the most about him.

headline: What Makes a Good TV Show Finale?
abstract: Are you a “How I Met Your Mother” fan? What did you think of Monday night’s finale? What other television show finales have been memorable for you? Why? In general, what do you think a finale should — and shouldn’t — do?
lead_paragraph: Are you a “How I Met Your Mother” fan? What did you think of Monday night’s finale? What other television show finales have been memorable for you? Why?

headline: Applus Services Seeking to Raise $414 Million in I.P.O.
abstract: The Spanish testing and certification company’s public flotation will include a primary offering of new shares by the company and a secondary offering of existing shares by its current shareholders.
lead_paragraph: The Spanish testing and certification company Applus Services said on Wednesday that it planned to raise as much as 300 million euros, or about $414 million, in an initial public offering in Spain.

headline: After Protests, City Tries to Ease Fear of Chemical Plant
keywords: ['Chemicals', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Residents of city in Guangdong Province are worried about the health and environmental impacts of the proposed plant, staging the latest in a series of demonstrations against potential polluting industrial projects in China.
lead_paragraph: Government officials met with popular local bloggers in a town in China’s southeastern Guangdong Province that has been hit by days of protest over plans to build a petrochemical plant. The meeting, part of an effort to reduce residents’ concerns about the plant, comes a day after the vice mayor of Maoming city met with some protesters.

headline: As Lufthansa Pilots Walk Out, 900 Canceled Flights but Relative Calm
abstract: Advance planning by the airline seemed to be paying off in the first day of a strike, though some travelers were left scrambling.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Advance planning by Lufthansa, one of Europe’s busiest airlines, seemed to be paying off Wednesday, at the beginning of a three-day strike by pilots, despite the cancellation of about 900 flights worldwide.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: What you need to know to start your day: A push for the $10.10 minimum wage, the streaming wars begin anew, and watch out for measles and mumps.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: New York Today: Let Fountains Flow
abstract: What you need to know for Wednesday: turning on the water, clouds give way to sun, and New Yorkers who love two-dollar bills.
lead_paragraph: Good Wednesday morning to you.

headline: Postcolonial Resentments Loom Over Meeting of Europeans and Africans
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'International Relations']
abstract: At the gathering in Brussels, President Robert G. Mugabe of Zimbabwe had sought to marshal a boycott for a major summit meeting to protest European influence.
lead_paragraph: Scores of European and African leaders and officials gathered in Brussels on Wednesday for a major summit meeting overshadowed by bloodletting in the Central African Republic and lingering postcolonial resentments.

headline: Hope for Negotiations Stays Alive in Mideast
abstract: Even as the Palestinian leadership took formal steps on Wednesday to gain the benefits of statehood outside the negotiation process, the parties appeared ready to seek a formula for continuing the negotiations.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Palestinian leadership on Wednesday formally submitted applications to join 15 international conventions and treaties despite opposition from the United States and Israel, reflecting a deep crisis in Middle East peace talks. Yet all three parties appeared ready to seek a formula for continuing the negotiations.

headline: No More Ms. Nice Guy
abstract: I was confused about why the director was being so mean. Why didn’t he like me? Couldn’t he see I was trying my best?
lead_paragraph: ‘If an injury is to be done to a man, it should be so severe that his vengeance need not be feared.’ — Niccolo Machiavelli

headline: In Our Pages: April 3
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A boxing match disappoints in London in 1914; France watches TV for the first time in 1939.
lead_paragraph: 1914: Wells Easily Defeats Lurie

headline: Daily Report: Old Rivalry Aired Again in Patent Case Between Apple and Samsung
abstract: Apple’s suit against Samsung can be seen as a reprisal of an earlier lawsuit between the two companies, only this time with Google as a shadow third presence.
lead_paragraph: As lawyers for Apple and Samsung made their opening statements in their patent trial in a federal courthouse in San Jose, Calif., they could not even agree on what the fight was about, Brian X. Chen reports.

headline: Unit of Deutsche Börse Faces U.S. Criminal Inquiry
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'Money Laundering', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The German stock exchange said the unit was cooperating with an investigation by the office of Preet Bharara, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York.
lead_paragraph: Deutsche Börse, the German stock exchange, said on Wednesday that its Clearstream unit was the object of a criminal investigation into potential violations of United States money laundering laws and sanctions against Iran.

headline: Going to the Show
abstract: The April 2014 crossword puzzle post for Times Insider.
lead_paragraph: TIMES INSIDER — Welcome to the inaugural crossword puzzle post for Times Insider. If you are a subscriber to Times Premier, you’ll have monthly access to a special, handpicked selection of past New York Times crossword puzzles, so step up to the plate and take a swing at your April challenge. Then come back here and tell me how it felt to run those bases.

headline: A Gothic Night of Suspense
abstract: Red Bull Theater is presenting Charles Ludlam’s “The Mystery of Irma Vep: A Penny Dreadful” in a production directed by Everett Quinton.
lead_paragraph: How reassuring to know that in some corner of the globe, it will always be a dark and stormy night. And that’s not just because of different climate and time zones, but also because somewhere a production of Charles Ludlam’s “The Mystery of Irma Vep: A Penny Dreadful” is surely playing. Since its debut in 1984, this animated catalog of all things gothic has been performed in theaters of all stripes throughout the world, with two actors embodying a host of glamorously creepy characters in a plot that borrows from the Brontë sisters, Daphne du Maurier and Universal horror flicks.

headline: Student of History Is Making Some
abstract: Darby English joins MoMA as a consulting curator to help the museum chart “a black direction.”
lead_paragraph: Darby English is an uncommonly thoughtful art historian who says that interpreting a work of art is never straightforward. He specializes in African-American art history and deplores the tendency to reduce black art to a vehicle for ready-made arguments about injustice and social uplift. Lest he himself be flattened into a type — an African-American man whose tastes are defined by some presumed community — he requested, only half-jokingly, that this article not be accompanied by artwork by Jacob Lawrence, perhaps the most acclaimed black painter of the 20th century.

headline: Stemming Departures at SAC
abstract: SAC Capital Advisors is pressing traders to sign two-year contracts. | The next three decades may upend the basic tenets of finance. | Efforts are underway to make payment systems safer. | Goldman Sachs weighs sale of market-making unit.
lead_paragraph: Steven A. Cohen is putting pressure on his traders to try to keep his once-powerful hedge fund together as it awaits a judge’s decision next week on its guilty plea to securities fraud charges, Matthew Goldstein writes in DealBook. Mr. Cohen is aiming to curtail a slow but steady departure of top portfolio managers by pressing those who remain to sign two-year contracts that would bind them to him until the end of 2016.

headline: ECO 348, The Great Recession: Austerity, Part II (Debt)
abstract: Memories of spreadsheets past.
lead_paragraph: Link fixed

headline: If You Like Immersion, You’ll Love This Reality
keywords: ['Virtual Reality (Computers)', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Headphones and Headsets']
abstract: Jeremy Bailenson, who directs Stanford’s Virtual Human Interaction Lab, says virtual reality is the natural extension of every major technology being used today.
lead_paragraph: The news that Facebook paid $2 billion for a virtual reality start-up, Oculus VR, might strike you as a bit zany. Like flying cars and robotic maids, the idea of donning a pair of computerized glasses and slipping into a digital world feels like a snapshot from yesterday’s future.

headline: The Will To Believe
abstract: More sad austerity memories.
lead_paragraph: Just belatedly finished the slides for my 8:30 class (saw Lake Street Dive Monday night — awesomely good, but I don’t handle late nights too well). And what strikes me again, just as it did for my last class, is how thoroughly the austerity debate was a case of the will to believe overpowering any and all critical assessment of evidence.

headline: High-Frequency Trading Firm Virtu Is Said to Delay I.P.O.
abstract: Virtu Financial has decided to postpone its initial public offering by at least a week, a move that comes as high-frequency trading firms have been put in the spotlight by Michael Lewis’s new book, “Flash Boys.”
lead_paragraph: The high-frequency trading firm Virtu Financial has decided to postpone its initial public offering by at least a week, amid a storm of negative attention over its industry’s business model, two people briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

headline: Pollution and Dust in Britain Bring Health Warnings
abstract: Older people and those with health issues were urged to limit their activity on Wednesday as light winds were trapping pollution and possibly drawing dust from the Sahara.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A combination of air pollution and dust from the Sahara on Wednesday prompted British authorities to issue a smog alert and a health warning for the elderly and for people with heart or lung problems.

headline: French Leader Approves a Cabinet of Mixed Messages
abstract: With some of his appointments, President François Hollande appeared to be trying to satisfy leftist factions in his Socialist Party, but he seemed no closer to a coherent economic policy.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President François Hollande of France approved a new cabinet on Wednesday, putting some high-profile figures — including Ségolène Royal, his former partner — in key positions, but sending mixed messages about his plans for France’s troubled economy.

headline: When in India
abstract: Western Mumbai’s luxurious Bandra neighborhood is home to both Bollywood stars and high fashion.
lead_paragraph: On the outskirts of Mumbai, homegrown concept shops are starting their own suburban sprawl.

headline: How to Explain Bitcoin to Your Mom!
abstract: A guide to the system of virtual currency.
lead_paragraph: A guide to the system of virtual currency.

headline: After Sobs, Prayers and Illness in Court, Pistorius May Testify
abstract: If Oscar Pistorius testifies as expected in his murder trial in South Africa, his account may be the only thing that can save him from a conviction.
lead_paragraph: PRETORIA, South Africa — Listening to the prosecution lay out its case against him at his murder trial over the past month, Oscar Pistorius could not keep silent, or still. He sobbed, prayed, threw up, buried his face in his hands and covered his ears, a response to the graphic and upsetting evidence, and, perhaps, to the grim reality of his own changed circumstances.

headline: Chrysler Recalls Over 850,000 S.U.V.s
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The Jeep Grand Cherokees and Dodge Durangos have a brake booster that could be corroded and lose effectiveness because of water getting in and freezing.
lead_paragraph: Chrysler is recalling more than 850,000 sport utility vehicles because of a possible braking problem. The recall covers the 2011 to 2014 Jeep Grand Cherokee and Dodge Durango models, including about 644,000 in the United States.

headline: Bomber Kills Six at Interior Ministry Entrance in Kabul
abstract: The suicide attacker penetrated nearly to the heart of the security establishment days before the presidential election.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A suicide bomber killed six policemen after detonating his explosive vest at the entrance gates of the Interior Ministry headquarters on Wednesday, ministry officials said, penetrating nearly to the heart of the Afghan security establishment.

headline: What Is New York Missing?
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A Central Park jogger. overhearing a caller, couldn’t help wondering what New York didn’t have that the caller wished for.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Kerry on Stalled Mideast Peace Talks
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said it was “completely premature” to write off the Israeli-Palestinian peace process even as negotiations faltered.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry said it was “completely premature” to write off the Israeli-Palestinian peace process even as negotiations faltered.

headline: Modern Mermaids
abstract: The little mermaids in two new picture books make for a refreshing and amusing departure from their famous predecessor.
lead_paragraph: Not every little mermaid has to follow in the wake of Hans Christian Andersen’s beloved fairy tale. Two new mermaids with tales all their own swim to the surface in “The Mermaid and the Shoe,” written and illustrated by K.G. Campbell, and “The Mermaid’s Shoes,” written and illustrated by Sanne te Loo. These modern mermaids make for a refreshing and amusing departure from their famous predecessor.

headline: A Few Auto Industry April Fools’ Day Pranks
abstract: Every April 1, automakers and automotive publications crank out a few silly jokes and pranks in celebration of the world’s strangest celebration.
lead_paragraph: April Fools’ Day comes but once a year, and inevitably it catches some people unaware. The automotive industry always seems to generate some pranks, and although things were relatively quiet this year, a few high jinks came to light, including these:

headline: A Memorial Inscription’s Grim Origins
abstract: Questions have arisen about whether a quotation from a translation of Virgil’s “Aeneid” about two warriors’ deaths is appropriate for the National September 11 Memorial Museum.
lead_paragraph: Who are “you”?

headline: Scholarly Perspectives on Inscription at the 9/11 Memorial Museum
abstract: Three classicists share their thoughts about the appropriateness of a quotation used as an inscription on the repository of unidentified remains at the museum.
lead_paragraph: “No day shall erase you from the memory of time,” says the inscription on the repository of unidentified remains at the National September 11 Memorial Museum, which opens next month. The line — “nulla dies umquam memori vos eximet aevo” — is taken from Virgil’s “Aeneid,” in which “you” are not nameless, numberless, innocent citizens, but two bloodthirsty young Trojan soldiers. The Times asked a few classicists to share their thoughts about the appropriateness of this quotation. Here are three responses:

headline: Highlights from Senate Hearing on G.M. Defects
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Highlights from the Senate hearing in Washington, where Mary T. Barra, chief executive officer of General Motors, was questioned by lawmakers about ignition defects that led to a massive recall and are linked to 13 deaths.
lead_paragraph: Mary T. Barra, the chief executive of General Motors, faced tough questions during a Senate hearing Wednesday about the company’s failure to address safety issues, as our colleagues, Bill Vlasic and Matthew L. Wald report.

headline: Feeding Teenagers: The Days of Control Are Gone
abstract: I went from getting toddlers to sit still for a 15-minute dinner to texting teenagers to make sure they joined us at the table, and from encouraging them to try new foods to taming their newfound food freedom.
lead_paragraph: I had better control of my teenagers and their eating years ago. When my four children were younger, I was the woman in charge. I made the meals, packed the lunches and decided what snacks would be eaten after school. I manned the schedule and scheduled the meals. I closed the kitchen and opened it. I approved and refused food. I was the food manager.

headline: The Wealth Gap in America Is Growing, Too
abstract: It’s not just the income inequality between America’s very rich and everyone else that’s at issue. There is also a significant wealth gap as well.
lead_paragraph: It is, by now, well known that income inequality has increased in the United States. The top 10 percent of earners took more than half of the country’s overall income in 2012, the highest proportion recorded in a century of government record keeping.

headline: Responding to Quake, Chile Uses Lessons of Past
abstract: Compared with the reaction to a 2010 disaster, the response by Chilean officials to a magnitude-8.2 earthquake Tuesday revealed important shifts in emergency preparation.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — Soon after an 8.8-magnitude earthquake hit southern Chile in 2010 near the end of President Michelle Bachelet’s first term, officials failed to issue a tsunami warning before a massive wave killed a large number of the 525 people who died in the disaster. Looting then plagued hard-hit areas after Ms. Bachelet delayed allowing the military to move in.

headline: After Push by Obama, Minimum-Wage Action Is Moving to the States
abstract: The president’s visit to Michigan is part of an effort that has seen most of the action on worker pay move to the states.
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — The more President Obama talks about the need to raise the federal minimum wage, the less likely it appears that Republicans in Congress are inclined to do it.

headline: Will G.M. Compensate Victims?
abstract: The G.M. hearing yesterday was more theater than substance.
lead_paragraph: Congressional hearings are often more theater than substance. That was certainly true of a four-hour House hearing on Tuesday into why it took General Motors and a federal safety regulator more than a decade to identify a defect in 2.6 million cars that has been linked to at least 13 deaths.

headline: By Design | Renzo Piano Reflects
abstract: A structure that was created forty years ago still resonates with the Italian architect. Renzo Piano shares an anecdote on the B&B Italia building in Novedrate, Italy.
lead_paragraph: Forty years later, the architect remembers one of his most meaningful Italian commissions.

headline: Despite Slowdown in China, Rio Tinto Stays Committed to Mining Plans
keywords: ['Mines and Mining', 'Aluminum', 'Metals and Minerals', 'Steel and Iron']
abstract: The company’s chief executive, Sam Walsh, says a slowdown in the iron ore market is not the end to global growth for the mineral.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Rio Tinto, one of the world’s largest mining companies, has big plans for pulling even more iron ore from the earth.

headline: Supreme Court Strikes Down Overall Political Donation Cap
keywords: ['McCutcheon v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Campaign Finance', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: The decision let stand familiar base limits on contributions from individuals to candidates, but it said that overall limits for contributions to all federal candidates violated the First Amendment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday continued its abolition of limits on election spending, striking down a decades-old cap on the total amount any individual can contribute to federal candidates in a two-year election cycle.

headline: Finding Chris Hondros
abstract: Chris’s Hondros’s “Testament” captures the mind and eye of a photographer killed in war. But to those who knew him, it is a chance to continue conversations started long ago.
lead_paragraph: Chris’s Hondros’s “Testament” captures the mind and eye of a photographer killed in war. But to those who knew him, it is a chance to continue conversations started long ago.

headline: To Cement Berlin’s Start-Up Success, a Bridge to U.S.
abstract: While some wonder whether Berlin can capitalize on its reputation as a tech hub, Konstantin Guericke, a co-founder of LinkedIn, believes the German capital can secure a place as one of Europe’s leading tech centers.
lead_paragraph: Berlin boasts one of the fastest-growing start-up communities, as engineers and designers have flocked to the German capital in recent years, attracted by the underground music scene, cutting-edge art galleries, stylish bars and low rent.

headline: G.M. Chief Faces Ire of Senators in Hearing
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Setting the tone for Wednesday’s questioning of Mary T. Barra, the chief of General Motors, Senator Claire McCaskill said the company had a “culture of cover-up” that discouraged quick action to fix a defective part.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The questions came faster and harder at Mary T. Barra on Wednesday.

headline: Today in Small Business: It’s Never Too Late to Start Up
abstract: Small businesses created 72,000 jobs in March. Corporate April Fool’s pranks. And France has the world’s hottest economy?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: NATO Commander Says He Sees Potent Threat From Russia
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Gen. Philip M. Breedlove said Russia put “a very large, very well-equipped force” within striking distance of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — NATO’s top commander said on Wednesday that the 40,000 troops Russia has within striking distance of Ukraine are poised to attack on 12 hours’ notice and could accomplish their military objectives within three to five days.

headline: Malaysia Police Chief on Investigation
abstract: The inspector general of the Malaysian police, Khalid Abu Bakar, said that only the passengers on Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 had been cleared and not the crew.
lead_paragraph: The inspector general of the Malaysian police, Khalid Abu Bakar, said that only the passengers on Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 had been cleared and not the crew.

headline: Minneapolis Newspaper Gets a New Life, but I Remember the Old One
abstract: Glen Taylor owns many businesses, including the Minnesota Timberwolves of the N.B.A., and is now making a bid for The Star Tribune in Minneapolis.
lead_paragraph: By now it’s a familiar story: a once-mighty regional newspaper is brought low by punishing economics and a series of owners who could not change that math, and is now being scooped up by the local rich guy. In the instance of The Star Tribune in Minneapolis. Glen Taylor, who owns a vast array of businesses —including pro basketball’s Minnesota Timberwolves, an egg producer, a medical device company and a host of printing operations — is making a bid to add the dominant local paper in the Twin Cities to his holdings.

headline: Same As He Ever Was
abstract: Ryan, real and imagined.
lead_paragraph: Update: I forgot to mention that centrist infatuation with Ryan didn’t just involve ignoring the manifest dishonesty of his budget proposals; it was also a stunning misjudgment of character. Think about it: I don’t do up-close-and-personal, I mostly just do numbers, and I had him pegged as a con man right away; meanwhile, people who claim to be experts on judging the man saw a saint.

headline: Karen Joy Fowler Wins PEN/Faulkner Fiction Prize
abstract: Ms. Fowler won the $15,000 prize for her novel “We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves.”
lead_paragraph: Karen Joy Fowler, a novelist known for her science fiction and for stories set in the 19th century, is the winner of the 2014 PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction for “We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves” (G.P. Putnam’s Sons), a novel with a contemporary setting. The $15,000 prize, which was announced on Wednesday by the directors of the award, will be presented at a ceremony at the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington on May 10.

headline: Reaction to the Supreme Court’s Campaign Finance Decision
abstract: The Supreme Court decision struck down limits on federal campaign contributions. It only concerned those from individuals. Federal law continues to ban contributions by corporations and unions.
lead_paragraph: The Lede chronicled much of the reaction to the Supreme Court’s campaign finance decision on Wednesday that struck down limits on federal campaign contributions. As our colleague Adam Liptak reports, the ruling, issued near the start of a campaign season, will change and most likely increase the role money plays in American politics.

headline: Cairo University Is Rocked by Several Explosions
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Terrorism', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Elections', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Blasts in the Egyptian capital killed at least one police officer and wounded several others in the first major attack since the start of the presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Several explosive devices detonated near the campus of Cairo University on Wednesday, killing a senior police official and wounding several officers in the first major attack in the capital since the beginning of Egypt’s presidential campaign just days ago.

headline: In Crimea, Russia Showcases a Rebooted Army
abstract: A sleek new Russian vanguard is notable for mobility, equipment and behavior that differ sharply from the forces seen in action in recent years.
lead_paragraph: PEREVALNOYE, Crimea — The soldiers guarding the entrances to the surrounded Ukrainian military base here just south of the capital, Simferopol, had little in common with their predecessors from past Russian military actions.

headline: Seeking Even Faster Growth, an E-Commerce Company Stumbles
abstract: Jimmy Beans Wool, a successful, growing online yarn merchant, expanded and ran into trouble.
lead_paragraph: JIMMY BEANS WOOL is an online yarn and fabric retailer with a brick-and-mortar store in Reno, Nev. The company, which has 37 employees, was founded by a married couple who are former software engineers, Laura and Doug Zander, in 2002. After five years, sales were $1 million. They topped $7 million in 2013.

headline: How Can Jimmy Beans Wool Get Its Growth Back on Track?
abstract: The company implemented numerous growth strategies, but sales fell flat. The owners even stopped taking salaries,
lead_paragraph: We just published a case study about Jimmy Beans Wool, an online yarn and fabric retailer with a brick-and-mortar store in Reno, Nev. Founded in 2002 by Laura and Doug Zander, the company began as a small storefront yarn shop and developed a loyal following online through its creative use of social media, most notably YouTube videos. From 2007 to 2012, sales grew organically at an annual rate of as much as 50 percent. They topped $7 million in 2013.

headline: A New Hotel in the Versace Mansion
abstract: The Villa by Barton G. is the new hotel in the former Miami Beach home of Gianni Versace, the late Italian fashion designer.
lead_paragraph: The former Miami Beach home of the late Gianni Versace, the Italian clothing designer, is seeing its second incarnation as a luxury boutique hotel, this time under the ownership of another fashion mogul.

headline: House Hunting in ... Byron Bay, Australia
abstract: The luxury home market, which saw prices drop as much as 30 percent during the real estate crisis, now enjoys the highest sales volume in five years.
lead_paragraph: AN ECO-FRIENDLY MODERN HOME ON AUSTRALIA’S EAST COAST

headline: NYT Now: Kerry on Mideast Peace Talks
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry says it’s too early to draw conclusions about Israel-Palestinian talks after negotiations stalled.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry says it’s too early to draw conclusions about Israel-Palestinian talks after negotiations stalled.

headline: Security Camera Footage of Chilean Quake
abstract: Closed-circuit television cameras in a pharmacy in northern Chile captured the moment an earthquake struck.
lead_paragraph: Closed-circuit television cameras in a pharmacy in northern Chile captured the moment an earthquake struck.

headline: McCutcheon: Another Blow to Democracy
abstract: The Supreme Court’s 5-to-4 ruling striking down aggregate limits on political campaign contributions is no less destructive for being so widely predicted.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s 5-to-4 ruling on Wednesday striking down aggregate limits on political campaign contributions is no less destructive for being so widely predicted.

headline: Classical Playlist: Beethoven, the Bad Plus, Fred Astaire and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: BEETHOVEN: Piano Concertos No. 2 in B flat and No. 4 in GLeif Ove Andsnes, pianist and directorMahler Chamber Orchestra(Sony Classical)The superb Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes continues “The Beethoven Journey,” as he calls his thoughtful exploration of the composer’s works, with the second installment in his survey of the five piano concertos. This recording pairs the ebullient Second Concerto, which can often sound like an audacious extension of Haydn, with the noble, and mercurial, Fourth Concerto, in which Beethoven takes the genre into realms of the poetic and the mystical. In these elegant, vibrant performances, Mr. Andsnes intriguingly reveals the magisterial qualities of the earlier work and the classical directness of the later one. He does double-duty as pianist and conductor, drawing impressive playing from the remarkable Mahler Chamber Orchestra. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Tackling Mass Incarceration
abstract: A new program for young men in trouble with the law is the most ambitious pay-for-success experiment in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Nine years ago Molly Baldwin found herself in a curious position. Roca, the teenage pregnancy and violence prevention program she’d founded in her 20s, had a multimillion-dollar budget, a two-story building in downtown Chelsea, Mass., a portfolio of programs addressing everything from poverty to immigrant rights and a measure of fame for using Native American peacemaking circles to heal gang-impacted youth. The only problem was, those cathartic conversations weren’t translating to change.

headline: Death Toll Rises to 29 in Washington State Landslide
abstract: The Snohomish County Medical Examiner’s office said one additional victim had been found as searchers continued the grim task of looking through tangled muck.
lead_paragraph: The death toll rose to 29 on Wednesday in the landslide more than a week ago that buried a Washington community as searchers continued the grim task of looking through the tangled muck for more victims.

headline: With Fire TV, Amazon Seeks a Beachhead in the Living Room
abstract: The company’s new device, called Amazon Fire TV, will marry its video library with content from other providers.
