lead_paragraph: Amazon is a retailer that makes and sells entertainment. On Wednesday, it took a big step toward a future in which shopping and video are tightly linked, perhaps even inseparable.

headline: Bomb Blasts at Cairo University Caught on Camera
abstract: Egyptian journalists who rushed to the scene of a bombing at Cairo University captured two subsequent explosions on video.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Kareem Fahim reports, Egyptian journalists who rushed to the scene of a bombing near the campus of Cairo University on Wednesday captured two subsequent explosions on video.

headline: Jason Kidd’s Bad Rap, Now 20 Years Old
abstract: In 1994, as Jason Kidd was beginning his first N.B.A. season, he made a brief foray into rap music with “What the Kidd Didd,” a song that has, thankfully, been largely forgotten.
lead_paragraph: Through 20 years in professional basketball, Jason Kidd has earned a Rookie of the Year award, taken home two Olympic gold medals and won an N.B.A. title. His team, the Brooklyn Nets, is storming toward the playoffs, and Tuesday he was named the N.B.A.'s Eastern Conference coach of the month.

headline: A Pivotal Financial Crisis Case, Ending With a Whimper
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: In a settlement with Kenneth Lewis, the former Bank of America chief, regulators took a strong case and rendered it weak, writes Jesse Eisinger in The Trade column.
lead_paragraph: The regulatory cloud has lifted for Kenneth D. Lewis. Last week, the former head of Bank of America received a modest penalty, paid for by his former employer, and a temporary ban from an industry he is no longer a part of.

headline: Mozilla Chief Tries to Separate Views on Gay Marriage and Business
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Web Browsers']
abstract: The chief executive of Mozilla, Brendan Eich, defended his views on gay marriage Tuesday, saying he is able to keep his personal views separate from those of the company he is running.
lead_paragraph: Can a chief executive run an open-source software company while simultaneously holding views some say are antithetical to the ethos of the open-source community?

headline: Handler, Leucadia’s Chief, Takes Pay Cut in New Role
abstract: Richard B. Handler was one of the better paid chief executives on Wall Street when he ran the Jefferies Group. Now, after the Leucadia National Corporation acquired Jefferies, his compensation has fallen by more than 80 percent.
lead_paragraph: When he ran the Jefferies Group, Richard B. Handler was one of the better paid chief executives on Wall Street. Now, after the Leucadia National Corporation acquired Jefferies, his compensation has fallen by more than 80 percent.

headline: A Sweet, Springlike Confection of a Bag
abstract: Bottega Veneta’s compact cross-body bag in mint green is the transitional accessory du jour.
lead_paragraph: Spring has sprung. But April showers and freezing morning temperatures aren’t exactly sending New Yorkers forward in their warm-weather best. It might not be time yet for shift dresses and wraparound sandals, but a new everyday bag is a sure way to liven up this dreary start to the season. Bottega Veneta’s most recent confection of a cross-body bag may be compact in size, but it makes a powerful statement with its sugary mint-green shade and multitextured surface incorporating edgy snakeskin and the house’s signature woven leather. It complements drab winter wear for now, and will be a welcome addition to a lighter wardrobe come May.

headline: Photos of Survival in Congo
abstract: Ten photos that depict the struggle to survive amidst crushing violence in Congo.
lead_paragraph: Azayi Kabunga was an important man, a village chief and schoolteacher. I first met him in his village deep in Eastern Congo in 2009, in the North Kivu region. Within a year, Azayi Kabunga was in a camp for displaced Congolese in distant Goma, broken and ashamed that he was no longer able to support his family. He remains displaced today, unable to go home because of violent militias.

headline: Aldrich Art Museum Celebrates Anniversary With Six Exhibitions
abstract: The Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum, in Ridgefield, Conn., is celebrating its 50th anniversary this year with a free event on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: The Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum, in Ridgefield, Conn., is kicking off a yearlong celebration of its 50th anniversary with six exhibitions, including one, “Standing in the Shadows of Love,” that looks back at the museum’s first decade, with works by Robert Indiana, Robert Rauschenberg, Robert Smithson, Ree Morton and Robert Morris.

headline: A Final Image of Lincoln, Hastily Sketched at City Hall, Is to Go on Display
abstract: When Abraham Lincoln was lying in state, no photographers or illustrators were allowed, but one mourner managed to capture his likeness. The image will be shown in New York this week.
lead_paragraph: Starting at noon on Monday, April 24, 1865, through noon the next day, perhaps as many as 100,000 people trooped through City Hall. The line of mourners came through the basement doors, wended its way up the stairs through the Governors Room, where New Yorkers paid their final respects to the martyred President Abraham Lincoln, and snaked back down to City Hall Park.

headline: NYT Now: CCTV Shows Chilean Quake
abstract: Security cameras inside a pharmacy captured the moment a magnitude 8.2 earthquake struck off the coast of northern Chile.
lead_paragraph: Security cameras inside a pharmacy captured the moment a magnitude 8.2 earthquake struck off the coast of northern Chile.

headline: Walking the Talk
abstract: Caregiver support groups: Sometimes the best ideas are the simplest.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday mornings, Cyndi Mariner puts on her Nikes, grabs a hat, and heads for Shoreline Park in Mountain View, Calif. Joining a handful of other people caring for elderly parents, she walks for an hour along San Francisco Bay. The walkers watch the kayaks and sailboats on the water, notice the hummingbirds buzzing across the trail. And they talk about things like how not to scream when your loved one with dementia has asked you the same question five times in a row.

headline: In Singapore’s Center, but a World Away
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: The Green Corridor, a stretch of nearly hidden parkland opened in 2012, is an unlikely nature preserve in the urban heart of the city.
lead_paragraph: It’s not often that you can find yourself completely alone in densely developed Singapore, not a building or road in sight and the only sound the trilling of birds overhead.

headline: Recipes for Kids: Black Bean and Corn Quesadillas
abstract: It’s a Mexican grilled cheese sandwich, with tortillas instead of bread.
lead_paragraph: It’s a Mexican grilled cheese sandwich, with tortillas instead of bread.  We like whole-grain or corn tortillas better than white flour tortillas because  they have lots of flavor and more nutrients. (Corn tortillas are smaller, so if you use them here, use 2 per quesadilla, with the cheese  between them.)

headline: Browse Without Prying Eyes
abstract: Molly Wood explores services that allow you to search online without compromising your privacy.
lead_paragraph: Molly Wood explores services that allow you to search online without compromising your privacy.

headline: A Fashion Nod to ‘Venus’ in Portugal
abstract: A young Lisbon resident from the busy Bairro Alto neighborhood finds style inspiration from the Velvet Underground song “Venus in Furs.”
lead_paragraph: The Bairro Alto neighborhood in Lisbon is known as a noisy place. From outdoor cafes bustling with students to loud bars and fado houses, the historic Portuguese area is a hangout for young people. Rui Palma, who lives around the area, was walking to class wearing a vintage cobalt coat, a shirt with a printed interpretation of a painting by the Pre-Raphaelite Dante Gabriel Rossetti and Dr. Martens, which he bought in London because they reminded him of the lyrics “shiny, shiny, shiny boots of leather,” from the Velvet Underground song “Venus in Furs.”

headline: Sweeping Away a Search History
abstract: A person’s online search history contains a wealth of personal information. Here are some tips to stem the flow.
lead_paragraph: YOUR search history contains some of the most personal information you will ever reveal online: your health, mental state, interests, travel locations, fears and shopping habits.

headline: A Reading of “Self Help” by Katie Peterson
abstract: The American poet reads her ode to deep self-exploration.
lead_paragraph: The American poet reads her ode to deep self-exploration.

headline: Brothers of Invention
abstract: In Mike Judge’s wry study of start-up culture, “Silicon Valley,” the process of discovering the next big thing is authentically dull.
lead_paragraph: There is no epiphanic moment of invention in “Silicon Valley,” Mike Judge’s new HBO comedy series about the socially awkward, emerging center of the world. Remember the lightbulb-flash scene in “The Social Network,” “A Beautiful Mind” or any other pop-cultural depiction of high-functioning nerdery, the moment when, in a fit of mania and caffeine, our hero scribbles out some groundbreaking bit of math on a slab of glass? In “Silicon Valley,” as in Silicon Valley, the process of discovering the next big thing is much more authentically dull.

headline: Image of the Day: April 2
abstract: Saina Nehwal, an Indian badminton player, during the Yonex-Sunrise India Open 2014 tournament in New Delhi.

headline: Lashing Out in Verse
abstract: Yahya Hassan, an angry 18-year-old immigrant poet, is having his moment in Denmark and beyond.
lead_paragraph: LEIPZIG, Germany — Like many teenagers, Yahya Hassan does not lack for bravado. But his way of expressing it stands in stark contrast to that of most of his peers: At just 18, the Danish-Palestinian Mr. Hassan has emblazoned himself on Denmark’s consciousness with a poetry collection that appeared with a first print run of 800 last fall and has since sold more than 100,000 copies.

headline: A New Barcelona Boutique Hotel, Scented With Fresh-Baked Bread
keywords: ['Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Follow your nose to the lobby, where loaves and pastries are cooked up day and night by a beloved local bakery.
lead_paragraph: What’s the only thing better than a chic new hotel in Barcelona? A chic new hotel in Barcelona that serves — and smells like — freshly baked bread. Opening this week in the Gaudí-building-studded Eixample district, the Hotel Praktik Bakery would be an attraction for its airy interiors, by the designer Lazaro Rosa-Violán, alone: the 74 rooms feature subtle antique-industrial touches on a restful white palette. But it’s the vast lobby — with its outpost of the acclaimed local breadsmith Anna Bellsolá’s Baluard bakery churning out loaves and pastries morning, noon and night — that makes the place a must-book. And for an establishment devoted to the possibilities of dough, the hotel doesn’t require all that much of it: rates begin at less than 100 euros per night.

headline: Times Minute | G.M. Faces Congress
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Trucks and Trucking', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Engines', 'Defective Products', 'Bankruptcies']
abstract: On the Minute, Matt Wald on the investigation into General Motors’ faulty switch. Did G.M. withhold information and the next steps for Congress.
lead_paragraph: On the Minute, Matt Wald on the investigation into General Motors’ faulty switch. Did G.M. withhold information and the next steps for Congress.

headline: Senators Clear Path for Release of Detention Report on C.I.A.
abstract: Maine’s two senators announced their support for declassifying parts of a report on the C.I.A.’s interrogation methods, all but assuring that a Senate panel will approve the report and send it to President Obama for release.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two members of the Senate Intelligence Committee on Wednesday announced their support for declassifying parts of a long-delayed report on the C.I.A.’s defunct detention and interrogation program, all but assuring that the committee will approve the report and send it to President Obama for eventual release.

headline: Times Minute | G.M. Faces Congress
keywords: ['Bankruptcies', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Defective Products', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: On the Minute, Matt Wald on the investigation into General Motors’ faulty switch, and the next steps for Congress.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: N.H.L. Teams Pass the Hat, or Shovel, or Maybe a Belt
abstract: An N.H.L. tradition lives on in the objects players pass around to valuable players following a victory.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway Hat, Duffy’s Shovel, the Starter Jacket, the Haida Hat. They are the talismans of victory for N.H.L. players, odd objects of pride and fun. Most of all they are the emblems of teamwork and camaraderie, curios that help cement the bonds of a hockey club.

headline: Power Surge for Donors as Terrain Is Reshaped on Campaign Money
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Elections', 'Political Action Committees']
abstract: A Supreme Court decision eradicating a key campaign finance limit is expected to widen the world of high-dollar fund-raising now dominated by “super PACs” and big-spending political nonprofit groups.
lead_paragraph: Big donors, leaders of political parties and candidates with access to wealthy supporters will be the biggest beneficiaries of the Supreme Court decision issued on Wednesday, a ruling that could fundamentally reshape the political terrain in the 2014 elections and beyond.

headline: What Michael Lewis’s Book Has to Do With Your Money
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: For investors, the answer is not much, other than an entertaining distraction.
lead_paragraph: Do you consider yourself an investor or a trader?

headline: Wheelies: The Non-Detroit Electric Edition
abstract: Detroit Electric announces a move to the Netherlands; Ford says it will cut the work force at a Russian plant by 70.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Opera America Names Eight Grant Winners
abstract: Eight composers were chosen to receive grants in a new program to encourage more operas by women.
lead_paragraph: Late last year, Opera America set out to encourage women composers to write new operas, and offered incentives, by way of a two-year grant program, underwritten by the Virginia B. Toulmin Foundation. The organization announced the first group of recipients of its Opera Grants for Female Composers on Tuesday. Eight composers, and their proposed projects, were chosen from among 112 eligible applicants. Each will receive a $12,500 grant to help develop her opera.

headline: Polls Show Broad Support for Campaign Spending Caps
abstract: Over the years, polls have found steady support for limits on campaign donations, regardless of party identification, age or income levels.
lead_paragraph: Even as the Supreme Court moved on Wednesday to remove limits on campaign donations, the public remains broadly supportive of them, surveys show.

headline: Before and After the Supreme Court’s Ruling
abstract: How Wednesday’s decision in McCutcheon v. Federal Election Commission changes the total amount individual donors can contribute to federal candidates, national parties and political committees.
lead_paragraph: How Wednesday’s decision in McCutcheon v. Federal Election Commission changes the total amount individual donors can contribute to federal candidates, national parties and political committees.

headline: Despite Impressive Season, Rockets Do Not Look Like Contenders
abstract: Tuesday’s loss to the Nets raised questions about the Houston Rockets’ preparedness to make a deep run in the N.B.A. playoffs.
lead_paragraph: After losing to the Nets at Barclays Center on Tuesday night, the Houston Rockets (49-24) acted as if they had had enough of the N.B.A.’s grueling 82-game regular season. They played that way, too.

headline: Barry Diller Says Aereo’s Survival Depends on Justices’ Decision
abstract: The court is to hear arguments over the legality of the streaming service on April 22. Mr. Diller, an investor, says losing the case could stifle innovation.
lead_paragraph: With crucial Supreme Court arguments over the legality of Aereo scheduled for later this month, one of the streaming service’s major investors, Barry Diller, said on Wednesday that its viability as a business was riding on the decision.

headline: Commodity Chief Blythe Masters to Leave JPMorgan Chase
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Commodities', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The departure of the executive comes as the bank prepares to sell its physical commodities business to a Swiss trading firm for $3.5 billion.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:35 p.m. | A prominent executive is leaving JPMorgan Chase as her powerful trading operation has stopped performing up to expectations, underscoring that Chase, the nation’s largest bank, is not immune to the boom and bust cycles that periodically sweep through Wall Street.

headline: Confessore on Money Ruling
abstract: Nick Confessore, The Times’s campaign finance reporter, on what the Supreme Court’s action to strike down aggregate limits on federal campaign contributions means.
lead_paragraph: Nick Confessore, The Times’s campaign finance reporter, on what the Supreme Court’s action to strike down aggregate limits on federal campaign contributions means.

headline: Knoedler Forgery Lawsuit Names Art Historian as Defendant
abstract: In a new federal lawsuit, a customer of the former Knoedler & Company gallery accuses the company of selling him a $7 million forgery, not a painting by Mark Rothko, and he blames a prominent art historian for playing a role in the transaction.
lead_paragraph: A respected Swiss art historian and curator has been drawn into the legal tangle surrounding the sale of dozens of high-priced forgeries by the shuttered New York art gallery Knoedler & Company.

headline: Reasons for Virtu to Remain Private
abstract: Amid the hullabaloo about high-frequency, a delay to an initial public offering would help protect Virtu’s estimated valuation of more than $3.5 billion, writes Richard Beales of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: It’s a good thing Virtu Financial doesn’t really need to go public.

headline: Is That an R-330Zh Zhitel on the Road in Crimea?
abstract: Russia is reluctant to tout its new military acumen and upgraded hardware on display in Crimea, as photographed by a New York Times correspondent.
lead_paragraph: PEREVALNOYE, Crimea — As Russian troops and extralegal militias swiftly seized Crimea from Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin maintained a falsehood. The impressively equipped and disciplined conventional troops that enveloped Ukrainian military bases, he said, were not Russian.

headline: The West Village: Wish List Satisfied
abstract: Vicki Baum and Steven Roth wanted an apartment with a contemporary interior.
lead_paragraph: The M21 bus, which runs across Houston Street, is viewed with fondness by Vicki Baum and Steven Roth. Forty years ago, that’s where they met. Both residents of the West Village, they got on the bus at the same stop one day and recognized each other from the neighborhood.

headline: Lyft Raises $250 Million From Alibaba, Third Point and Others
abstract: Lyft, one of the big players in the nascent-but-booming ride-sharing industry, said on Wednesday that it had raised $250 million from a group that includes the Chinese e-commerce titan Alibaba Group and the investment firm Third Point.
lead_paragraph: Lyft, one of the big players in the nascent-but-booming ride-sharing industry, said on Wednesday that it had raised $250 million from a group that includes the Chinese e-commerce titan Alibaba Group and the investment firm Third Point.

headline: Giving a Debtor a Big Club Against Lenders
abstract: A federal district court’s view on a sale of a piece of a loan is problematic, writes Stephen J. Lubben in the In Debt column.
lead_paragraph: A federal district court’s opinion in Meridian Sunrise Village v. NB Distressed Debt Investment Fund Ltd. is one of the most important recent decisions for distressed debt investors and loan investors generally. It is also one you haven’t probably heard of. Indeed, but for a brief mention in one of Bill Rochelle’s invaluable columns on Bloomberg Law a few weeks back, I would have missed it myself.

headline: Meet Microsoft’s Cortana, a More Personal Siri
abstract: On Wednesday, Microsoft for the first time showed Cortana, a virtual assistant for its mobile operating system that is designed to be a more intelligent, personal version of Apple’s Siri assistant for the iPhone. Cortana is the most high-profile feature of Windows Phone 8.1, a soon-to-be-released update to Microsoft’s mobile phone operating system.
lead_paragraph: REDMOND, Wash. — When Microsoft was developing Cortana, a virtual assistant for its mobile operating system that was unveiled Wednesday, the company thought, naturally, about how it could improve on Siri, Apple’s sometimes bumbling assistant for the iPhone.

headline: By Design | One Man’s Trash
abstract: Two design companies in Palermo, Italy and Los Angeles, Calif., have transformed recycled lumber and castoffs into unique furniture.
lead_paragraph: Two creative teams on different continents prove that repurposed furniture doesn’t have to look like junk.

headline: Openings and Events for the Week of April 3
abstract: A new perfume for the season, as well as accessories and the Big Egg Hunt.
lead_paragraph: Openings and Events

headline: NATO and Russia on Suspension
abstract: NATO’s secretary general, Anders Fogh Rasmussen, and the Russian Foreign Ministry spokesman, Alexander Lukashevich, discussed the suspension of military cooperation between the alliance and Russia.
lead_paragraph: NATO’s secretary general, Anders Fogh Rasmussen, and the Russian Foreign Ministry spokesman, Alexander Lukashevich, discussed the suspension of military cooperation between the alliance and Russia.

headline: Budget Fun on the California Coast
abstract: From disc golf to drumming, the Frugal Traveler puts together a low-cost itinerary for a trip to Santa Cruz.
lead_paragraph: Most of the signs outside DJ’s Mini-Mart in Santa Cruz, Calif., were like those you might see on any convenience store in America: “Budweiser,” “ATM Inside,” the current Powerball jackpot amount. But another, more prominent one caught my attention: “Welcome Disc Golfers.”

headline: A Big Sur Bath by the Light of the Moon
abstract: At the Esalen Institute, an isolated spot on the California coast, the sound of the sea and bits of conversation form the soundtrack for a post-midnight soak in a spring-fed bath.
lead_paragraph: It was 12:45 a.m. when I pulled off Highway 1 in Big Sur and joined a half-dozen couples and small groups of friends waiting quietly in rental cars under a twinkling black horizon. Was that a shooting star? The breeze was redolent of redwoods and sea salt, and the surf sounded rhythmically below like the soft breath of children, already asleep.

headline: Deliveryman Fatally Shot on a Street Many Avoid
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Delivery Services', 'Robberies and Thefts']
abstract: Richard Salvia, 50, was killed on Tuesday outside a house on Grandview Avenue. Many restaurants refuse to deliver to that area because of past robberies.
lead_paragraph: For Richard Salvia, it was a new job: carting Chinese food around northern Staten Island in his Chevrolet Impala. For the restaurant he worked for, it was a relatively new spot for deliveries — a dead-end street of scattered homes that had, in the past, been deemed too dangerous for regular visits.

headline: Pondering How Tales Are Told
abstract: At the 38th annual Humana Festival of New American Plays, five full-length plays highlighted storytelling, be they fantastical, historical or ripped from the headlines.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Theater is fundamentally a storytelling medium, and at the 38th annual Humana Festival of New American Plays here, the manner in which tales are told — be they fantastical, historical or ripped from the headlines — became a recurring theme in the five full-length plays on offer. The finest of the bunch was Lucas Hnath’s “The Christians,” in which a debate over the meaning of that big book of stories known as the Bible causes a dangerous rift in a thriving evangelical church.

headline: Reaction to Cairo University Blasts
abstract: Two witnesses spoke out after explosions near Cairo University in what appeared to be a militant attack targeting security forces.
lead_paragraph: Two witnesses spoke out after explosions near Cairo University in what appeared to be a militant attack targeting security forces.

headline: 10 Tentacles, 12 Recipes
abstract: Squid made easy.
lead_paragraph: Squid made easy.

headline: Hank Lauricella, 83, Last of a Football Breed
abstract: Mr. Lauricella, known as Mr. Everything for his all-around play, was runner-up in 1951 for the Heisman Trophy while leading Tennessee to a national title, then became a Louisiana state legislator.
lead_paragraph: Hank Lauricella, the last of the great football single-wing tailbacks and all-around players, who was known as Mr. Everything at the University of Tennessee, died March 25 in Jefferson, La. A Louisiana legislator for 32 years, he was 83.

headline: Venture Capital’s Need for Secrecy Collides With Public’s Right to Know
abstract: A ruling by a California state court allows venture capital firms to control the amount of information they disclose. But is it the best solution? Probably not, says Jonathan Axelrad, a partner at Goodwin Procter.
lead_paragraph: California is home to some of the biggest venture capital firms and many of the young companies they invest in. So it is not surprising that the state has been a major battleground in efforts to strike a balance between the venture industry’s need for confidentiality and the public’s right to know about investments made by public agencies.

headline: Another Warning for the Northwest From Chile’s Earthquake Hot Zone
abstract: A powerful earthquake off the coast of Chile provides a fresh warning to the Pacific Northwest.
lead_paragraph: As disaster agencies tally scattered deaths and damage from the 8.2-magnitude earthquake (and thankfully modest tsunami) off the coast of northern Chile on Tuesday night, earthquake experts have been stressing two facts:

headline: 9 Novels Both Girls and Boys Can Love
abstract: Tired of “boy books” and “girl books?” Nine books (or series) that both the boys and girls in my family have enjoyed.
lead_paragraph: The Motherlode contributor Jessica Lahey appeared on the Today show discussing “closing the chapter on boy vs. girl books.” Smart topic — as a passionate reading child, I actually cared a whole lot about whether the protagonist of most books was a boy or a girl (for a rare few it didn’t matter at all), but my favorite books were the ones in which both sexes got equal playing time, either because gender didn’t matter in a particular storyline, or because the book or series followed multiple characters, both male and female.

headline: Abortion Providers in Texas Sue Over a Restrictive Rule That Could Close Clinics
abstract: The rule, which will take effect Sept. 1, requires that all clinics providing abortions at any stage of pregnancy meet the costly building standards of ambulatory surgery centers.
lead_paragraph: Health clinics offering abortions in Texas filed a federal lawsuit on Wednesday to block a new state rule that could shut down more than half of the state’s remaining providers this fall, forcing women seeking an abortion in southern and western Texas to drive several hundred miles each way or go out of state.

headline: Gannett Makes Deal With Weinstein to Develop Entertainment Material
abstract: Weinstein will receive a first look at Gannett journalism with the possibility of turning it into films, television and other forms of content.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Gannett joined the ranks of journalistically oriented media companies trying to make show business connections, announcing on Wednesday a deal that gives the Weinstein Company a first look at Gannett journalism with an eye toward developing movies, television shows or material for other types of media.

headline: The Gun Report: April 2, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Colorado, which suffered through the Columbine High School and Aurora movie theater massacres, passed a law in July limiting the size of ammunition magazines to 15 rounds and expanding background checks to both online and private firearm sales. But Second Amendment advocates are taking the state to court over it.

headline: Mental Health Groups Split on Bill to Overhaul Care
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: As Congress takes up a proposal by a Republican representative, Tim Murphy, advocates divide over its expansion of involuntary treatment programs.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers, patient advocates and the millions of Americans living with a psychiatric diagnosis agree that the nation’s mental health care system is broken, and on Thursday, Congress will hear testimony on the most ambitious overhaul plan in decades, a bill that has already stirred longstanding divisions in mental health circles.

headline: Disney Soundtrack Freezes Out Shakira
abstract: Shakira’s self-titled new album reached No. 2 with 84,000 copies sold, about half the sales of the soundtrack to Disney’s film “Frozen,” in its eighth week at No. 1.
lead_paragraph: The “Frozen” soundtrack is a hit. We already knew that. But now we know that it is a really, really big hit. Like, on the Adele-Taylor Swift scale.

headline: JPMorgan Executive May Trade Corporate Saddle for a Real One
abstract: In addition to running JPMorgan’s commodities business, Blythe Masters competes in horse shows occasionally and has enjoyed success recently in her equestrian pursuits.
lead_paragraph: Blythe Masters is looking forward to taking “some well-deserved time off” when she leaves her job as a top executive at JPMorgan Chase later this year, the bank said in an internal memo on Wednesday.

headline: The Perpetual Bubble Economy
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Lawrence Summers says that to keep the country’s economy growing, the government should run deficits — perhaps indefinitely, even during good economic times.
lead_paragraph: Want a thriving labor market? Blow a bubble.

headline: ‘I Believe in the Valor of Pallor’
abstract: The writer Jill Kargman talks about staying out of the sun and why she wants to look like Veronica, the comics character.
lead_paragraph: Daughter of Arie Kopelman, the former chairman of Chanel, and sister-in-law to Drew Barrymore, Jill Kargman, 39, is known for writing lighthearted novels including “The Ex-Mrs. Hedgefund” and “Arm Candy.” More recently, she released a collection of essays called “Sometimes I Feel Like a Nut” and is working on a scripted comedy for Bravo. A native of New York, she lives on the Upper East Side with her husband, Harry Kargman, and their three children, and approaches beauty with as much humor as she does her writing.

headline: App Smart: Converting Units
abstract: A suite of apps can help you easily convert pounds to dollars, meters to feet and even more obscure units of measurement.
lead_paragraph: A suite of apps can help you easily convert pounds to dollars, meters to feet and even more obscure units of measurement.

headline: A Singer Confidently Following Her Heart
abstract: Alexa Ray Joel, the daughter of Billy Joel and Christie Brinkley, is performing original songs, standards, rock classics and folk during a run at the Café Carlyle.
lead_paragraph: Alexa Ray Joel, the 28-year-old daughter of Billy Joel and Christie Brinkley, has her father’s eyes. Large, round, heavy lidded and soulful, they express a confidence and brash, forthright attitude that is also conveyed in singing whose rough timbre and piercing high notes at times bring to mind a soprano answer to Stevie Nicks. Her sound, though not beautiful, is many shaded and emotionally high pitched. She has no problems with intonation.

headline: FIFA Fines and Bans Barcelona From Transfer Market
abstract: Barcelona has been barred from acquiring new players until the summer of 2015. The club said it plans to appeal the FIFA penalties.
lead_paragraph: Barcelona has been banned from acquiring new players until the summer of 2015 by FIFA, which punished the Spanish club Wednesday for what it said were repeated violations of the rules for signing teenage players.

headline: Weights or Measures, Converted on the Fly
abstract: Apps are available to tackle the most common calculations and the most unusual.
lead_paragraph: DO you automatically know how many kilograms are in a pound? I do. It’s 0.45359237. I have to know this because I also write about tech outside the United States, and while feet and pounds are used to measure some things in America, almost every other country has adopted the metric system.

headline: Teaching About Climate Change With The New York Times
abstract: We updated an earlier collection on climate change with seven starting points for teaching and learning about the topic, along with a new list of links to much more, from Learning Network lesson plans to Times video, graphics, articles and photographs.
lead_paragraph: Updated: Nov., 2015

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 71
abstract: Nike this week introduced World Cup uniforms for the United States and England.
lead_paragraph: The fashion police cordoned off a section of the Internet Tuesday and gleefully took some pepper spray to the new away uniform the United States men’s and women’s national teams will be wearing on soccer fields around the world, including at the World Cup in Brazil. Definitely not an April Fools’ Day joke.

headline: Senate Questions Barra on G.M. Safety
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Senator Claire McCaskill of Missouri and Senator Dean Heller of Nevada questioned the chief executive of General Motors, Mary T. Barra, during a hearing on the company’s safety problems.
lead_paragraph: Senator Claire McCaskill of Missouri and Senator Dean Heller of Nevada questioned the chief executive of General Motors, Mary T. Barra, during a hearing on the company’s safety problems.

headline: Leaving Few Clues Behind
abstract: The search for Jay Ott, a missing Brooklyn designer.
lead_paragraph: The first sign that something was not right came when Jay Ott’s co-workers at the Dock Group began to gather at their Chelsea office on Monday morning last week.

headline: What You Get for ... $2,400,000
abstract: This week’s homes include a new-old house in New Orleans, a contemporary on a Minnesota lake and an old-timer in Nantucket.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS

headline: Plum Picks from Jean Paul Gaultier’s Archive Go Up for Sale at Matches
abstract: In anticipation of the designer’s retrospective opening in London, a trove of his vintage pieces are available to buy online.
lead_paragraph: Jean Paul Gaultier’s most iconic looks, from the cone bra to the corset, were canonized in an exhibition last fall at the Brooklyn Museum, “Jean Paul Gaultier: From the Sidewalk to the Catwalk.” Now, those who coveted the vintage pieces in the show can buy similar ones with the click of a mouse. The British online boutique Matches Fashion has partnered with Cameron Silver, the owner of the Decades vintage emporium in Los Angeles, to offer up a range of exclusive pieces from the Gaultier vault. The online sale, beginning today and lasting 10 days, features unworn items spanning 20 years that Silver culled from the archive of Gaultier’s parent company AEFFE; it coincides with the London debut of the same museum retrospective at the Barbican, which runs from April 9 to August 25.

headline: Where the Amazon Fire TV Fits Into the Living Room
abstract: The just announced device will stream Internet video to your television. But so will Internet-connected TVs and a host of competing devices. Can it stand out from the crowd?
lead_paragraph: Amazon on Wednesday announced its very own streaming media box, the Amazon Fire TV. It costs $99 and will stream Netflix, Amazon Instant (of course), Hulu Plus, Showtime Anytime, Crackle and Vimeo, and more to be named.

headline: The Rail Content Is On the Move
abstract: This blog’s regular features, including live race analysis and news and notes from Joe Drape, Melissa Hoppert and others, can now be found on the sports home page.
lead_paragraph: Thank you for visiting The Rail. This blog’s regular features, including live race analysis and news and notes from Joe Drape, Melissa Hoppert and others, can now be found on the sports home page. This change in presentation will provide readers with a single destination for all important and timely horse racing news.

headline: What to Take on the Ark? Songs, of Course
abstract: New York Festival of Song’s new-music offshoot, “NYFOS: Next” makes a passionate case for the art song as a can’t-live-without item on any civilized traveler’s packing list.
lead_paragraph: Laundry detergent. Light bulbs. Tulip bulbs. Warm underwear. Fish hooks for fish on a Friday. These were among the 92 items on Noah’s packing list as he prepared to set sail on his ark, according to “Ark Luggage,” a new song with music by David Lang and words by the filmmaker Peter Greenaway that had its American premiere on Tuesday evening at the National Opera Center in Manhattan.

headline: G.M. Secrecy on Crashes Adds to Families’ Pain
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Relatives of people killed in accidents involving recalled General Motors cars find it hard to get information partly because of how G.M. defines victims, and the technology of “black boxes.”
lead_paragraph: There is anger that General Motors did not come forward sooner with information about its faulty cars. There is grief that loved ones were lost in crashes that might have been preventable. And there is outrage that federal safety regulators did not intervene.

headline: Parting With DeSean Jackson, the Eagles Added a Kick
abstract: The Eagles sold the narrative of a young black player’s suspected gang affiliation to rationalize parting ways with their best receiver.
lead_paragraph: For six seasons the Philadelphia Eagles basked in the glow of their star receiver DeSean Jackson. Philadelphia tagged him as its franchise player two years ago, and in 2013 he rewarded the Eagles with a Pro Bowl season, catching 82 passes for 1,332 yards.

headline: Terminal Tossing and Turning
abstract: In “Sleep Donation,” by Karen Russell, a plague of insomnia threatens America.
lead_paragraph: The kernel of inspiration for Karen Russell’s new novella, “Sleep Donation,” appears to come from Gabriel García Márquez’s classic “One Hundred Years of Solitude,” which described a plague of insomnia that comes to the mythical Latin American town Macondo — a plague that makes the afflicted unable to sleep for days and causes such memory loss that objects, plants and animals need to be labeled. A sign hung around the neck of a cow reads: “This is the cow. She must be milked every morning.”

headline: Amazon Unveils Fire TV
abstract: Amazon’s vice president for Kindle, Peter Larsen, announced the set-top device as part of its plans to merge shopping and entertainment.
lead_paragraph: Amazon’s vice president for Kindle, Peter Larsen, announced the set-top device as part of its plans to merge shopping and entertainment.

headline: Where a Laugh Track Is Do-It-Yourself
abstract: Rhys Darby of “Flight of the Conchords” created “Short Poppies,” and plays the quirky New Zealanders who are its subject.
lead_paragraph: Certain television comedies seem more insecure than ever these days, appearing to amplify the laugh track or studio-audience giggles to deafening proportions to make sure viewers know that something funny just happened. So shows that let you make your own decisions about what’s worth a laugh are refreshing if for no other reason than that they demonstrate a certain respect for the audience.

headline: Bookshelf | Choice Bits
abstract: Diane Keaton shares her thoughts on beauty, and some of Hollywood’s leading actresses, in her forthcoming memoir.
lead_paragraph: Musings from Diane Keaton’s upcoming memoir, in which she confronts Hollywood’s (and perhaps her own) preoccupation with youth and beauty.

headline: The Jonathan Pollard Case, Explained
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Jonathan J. Pollard, a former Navy intelligence analyst convicted of spying for Israel, is the only person in U.S. history to receive a life sentence for spying for an American ally.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan J. Pollard, a former Navy intelligence analyst convicted of spying for Israel, is the only person in U.S. history to receive a life sentence for spying for an American ally.

headline: A Cruise Line Adds Women to the Dancer Pool
abstract: Crystal Cruises plans to add female hosts to its previously all-male lineup to dance with passengers on three coming trips.
lead_paragraph: Gender equality hits the high seas as Crystal Cruises will add women to the until-now all male host pool, dancers hired to cha-cha, waltz and jitterbug with solo or partnerless cruisers on three coming trans-Atlantic itineraries.

headline: Embracing Spring Fashion With Colors and Prints
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Handbags and Purses', 'Shoes and Boots']
abstract: Colorful skirts, pastel totes, sportswear-inspired mesh shirts, belts painted in natural hues and slip-ons that do the talking.
lead_paragraph: Congratulations, you’ve made it to the other side. It’s officially spring, and even if you haven’t completely thawed, the days are longer, the sun is out and it’s time to brighten (and lighten) up. Start by embracing color and print, and wear something with a dash of humor — say, a sweet pair of emoji slippers. This is the happy season.

headline: Program Looks to Give Bees a Leg (or Six) Up
abstract: In California’s Central Valley, researchers are trying to find assortments of bee-friendly plants that local farmers and ranchers can easily grow.
lead_paragraph: LOCKEFORD, Calif. — Helping America’s beleaguered bees could start with something as humble as planting a shrub.

headline: Tavi and the Taviettes
abstract: Young women have embraced Tavi Gevinson’s message of community and self-empowerment.
lead_paragraph: She counts among her friends the actress Emma Watson, the singer Lorde and the fashion designer Rachel Antonoff (“She has gravitas”), but the real impact of Tavi Gevinson, the 17-year-old fashion-prodigy-turned-publishing-mogul, can be seen most clearly in the young women who circle in her orbit.

headline: Her Mother’s Life as a Prequel
abstract: A luxe start was only that for Maggie Betts, a socialite turned filmmaker.
lead_paragraph: Maggie Betts grew up with money, thanks to her father, Roland W. Betts, the developer, owner of Chelsea Piers and close friend of George W. Bush. She has powerful friends, including famous filmmakers and flamboyant fashion designers. And she likes going out, with enough appearances on the party pages to fill a large photo album.

headline: For the Tech-Savvy With a Need for Speed, a Limited Choice of Towns With Fiber
abstract: The United States is 14th globally when it comes to offering fiber connectivity. Municipalities that offer it are often small or rural.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve ever drummed your fingers waiting for a web page to load or a file to download, you know that the latest apps and devices are only as good as your Internet connection. And yet, in the United States only 7.7 percent of broadband subscribers have optical fiber connections, the fastest and highest quality available.

headline: Look Out! That Song Is Going to Hit You Right in the Head!
abstract: The German band Kraftwerk equipped the audience with 3-D glasses and put new spins on some of its old songs in a concert at the United Palace Theater.
lead_paragraph: Kraftwerk, the German band whose music predicted pop’s electronic future back in the 1970s, hasn’t forgotten an old-fashioned precept: A concert is a physical, spatial event. Even as all sorts of experiences — arts, communication, commerce — migrate to two-dimensional computer screens, “An Evening With Kraftwerk: 3-D Concert” played up the sensations of a particular performance in a particular room. Kraftwerk’s current tour found an ideal setting on Tuesday night as the band started a two-night stand at the ornate United Palace Theater in Washington Heights.

headline: Showing Off More Than His Arm
abstract: The N.F.L. prospect Johnny Manziel arrives at his draft workout dressed to sell.
lead_paragraph: With Tim Tebow out of the N.F.L. and off to a career in broadcasting, the league is in need of a new fresh-faced, polarizing star.

headline: A Timeout for Art
abstract: The Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles held its annual gala and welcomed Philippe Vergne, its new director.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “I’m not here for the free drinks,” said the pop star Katy Perry, hoisting up her cocktail in a mock cheer. “I’m here for an art education. I want to stimulate my neural pathways.”

headline: Black Bear in Williamsburg
abstract: A beer and shot joint with a biker aesthetic and an older crowd.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, when Williamsburg reigned as the coolest neighborhood in the land, North Sixth Street and its cluster of Asian-fusion restaurants were already a stomping ground for tourists. Today, the strip is even more suburbanized, with an Urban Outfitters to come. It’s an odd habitat for Black Bear, a beer-and-a-shot joint that opened last fall and quickly became a congenial den for hibernation.

headline: No Charges for Officer in Hostage’s Death
keywords: ['Hostages', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Robberies and Thefts']
abstract: The Nassau County district attorney’s office said it had found no legal grounds to charge Nikolas Budimlic, who accidentally killed a student last May while confronting an armed hostage taker.
lead_paragraph: A Nassau County police officer who accidentally shot and killed a college student last May while confronting an armed hostage taker will not face criminal charges, the county’s district attorney said on Wednesday.

headline: A Muddy Tract Now, but by 2020, China’s Answer to Wall St.
abstract: A largely empty expanse in Shenzhen is the setting for a financial experiment that could have a huge impact on the world’s second-largest economy. But so far it is just a bold blueprint.
lead_paragraph: There isn’t much to see in Qianhai today except for a tract of muddy, mostly undeveloped land that has been reclaimed from the sea in the southern Chinese city of Shenzhen, near the border with Hong Kong.

headline: Parsing Microsoft’s Decision to Cut Windows Fees
abstract: Microsoft said it would no longer charge a fee to hardware makers that want to put Windows on devices with screens that are smaller than nine inches, for which it was estimated to be getting around $15 each in licensing revenue.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft’s new virtual assistant for its mobile operating system got the most attention at a company developer conference on Wednesday, but a decision by Microsoft to drop licensing fees on some Windows devices is the news from the event that will very likely have the most lasting consequences for the company.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Lebanon, Kenya, Afghanistan and Brazil.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Lebanon, Kenya, Afghanistan and Brazil.

headline: BlackBerry Breaks Up With T-Mobile
abstract: Weeks after a public spat between the two companies’ chief executives, Blackberry said that it would not allow T-Mobile US to sell Blackberry phones after April 25.
lead_paragraph: While BlackBerry’s dismal market share in the United States might suggest that it needs all the retailers it can get, the Canadian smartphone maker has now cut off one prominent American customer. Weeks after a public spat between the two companies’ chief executives, BlackBerry said that it would not allow T-Mobile US to sell BlackBerry phones after April 25.

headline: For Many Germans, Pilots’ Walkout Crosses a Line
abstract: A three-day work stoppage by Lufthansa pilots appears to be breaking the unwritten rules of German workplace relations.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — As with so many situations in Germany, there is an orderly way to do things and then there are ways that are not socially acceptable. That principle, it turns out, applies even to labor strikes.

headline: Normcore Street-Style
abstract: Joan Smalls and other street style examples of normcore.
lead_paragraph: Joan Smalls and other street style examples of normcore.

headline: Jeff Bezos, Please Call Your Office
abstract: Amazon’s founder and chief executive was not on hand for the public announcement of the company’s Fire TV, its biggest move in hardware since 2011. Where was he?
lead_paragraph: Amazon’s news conference on Wednesday solved one of the biggest riddles in technology — when would Amazon ever introduce one of the devices it has been endlessly rumored to be working on?

headline: The New Normal
abstract: The bumpy, somewhat ironic, not necessarily genuine road toward normcore fashion, or how hipster narcissism managed to take an ugly turn.
lead_paragraph: Normcore (noun) 1. A fashion movement, c. 2014, in which scruffy young urbanites swear off the tired street-style clichés of the last decade — skinny jeans, wallet chains, flannel shirts — in favor of a less-ironic (but still pretty ironic) embrace of bland, suburban anti-fashion attire. (See Jeans, mom. Sneakers, white.)

headline: Moving a Slab of Museum Wall, Artfully
abstract: With a friend identified as Tom, Yve Laris Cohen performed his piece “al Coda” at the Whitney Museum of American Art’s future site.
lead_paragraph: A handful of art-and-dance lovers dodged cranes on Friday afternoon while making their way to the West Village construction site of the future Whitney Museum of American Art to watch a performance piece as part of the Whitney Biennial. Hard hats were passed out; release forms were signed.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here are some of the things that had people talking today.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: She Can Remember Everything, Even Her Show’s Various Time Slots
abstract: A tweaked and rescheduled “Unforgettable” returns to CBS after it was canceled then resuscitated.
lead_paragraph: “Unforgettable” is a well-made cop show on CBS that could have easily been a distant memory by now. Instead, it begins the second half of its second season on Friday night, a case study in how to give more chances to a decent show that didn’t find its natural home immediately.

headline: Seen on the Street | Outside the Fall/Winter 2014 Kiev Women’s Shows
abstract: A glimpse at what the gals are wearing this season.
lead_paragraph: A glimpse at what the gals are wearing this season.

headline: The Many Classes of Google Stock
abstract: Starting Thursday, the GOOG stock symbol will represent a new class of nonvoting shares. And the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index will now reflect 501 stocks.
lead_paragraph: The price of Google shares is going to be cut in half on Thursday.

headline: Two Stolen Paintings Are Found in Italy
abstract: The Italian police recovered two paintings, including a still life by Gauguin worth millions of dollars, that had been missing since 1970.
lead_paragraph: In 1975, a factory worker at Fiat, the Italian carmaker, bought two colorful paintings for about $70 at an auction in Turin of objects left unclaimed by train passengers. For years, they hung on his kitchen wall. One was a still life with fruit and a small dog, the other showed a woman in white seated in a verdant garden.

headline: Carters Return to Capital, Onstage
abstract: Former President Jimmy Carter and his wife, Rosalynn, will attend the opening of “Camp David,” a play that recounts the 13 days that led to the peace treaty between Israel and Egypt.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jimmy Carter was never a creature of Washington, and so after he lost re-election in 1980 — “I was involuntarily retired,” he often says — he seldom looked back. But on Thursday night, Mr. Carter will return to the capital in the strange role of spectator to his often-maligned presidency.

headline: In Dallas, Echoes of an Olympiad
abstract: On Sunday night, the last day of the Spring North American Championships in Dallas, three major titles were decided.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — On Sunday night, the last day of the Spring North American Championships here, three major titles were decided.

headline: Peabody Awards Honor News Coverage, ‘Scandal’ and Foreign Dramas
abstract: There were 46 winners for achievement in electronic media, including documentaries, Netflix series and interviews with world leaders.
lead_paragraph: The annual Peabody Awards, more plentiful than ever, were announced on Wednesday with winners honored for everything from news coverage of typhoons in the Philippines to the guilty pleasure of the ABC drama “Scandal.”

headline: Paris St.-Germain Beats Chelsea but Loses Ibrahimovic
abstract: P.S.G. won at home, 3-1, in the Champions League quarterfinals but may be without its top scorer in the second leg.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The ball had barely settled in the back of the net, and José Mourinho, Chelsea’s unpredictable manager, was already on his way to the Paris St.-Germain bench. While the P.S.G. players and coaches celebrated Javier Pastore’s last-minute goal, Mourinho somewhat bizarrely walked around shaking hands with the ecstatic home side, too.

headline: Dean Wareham, Longtime New Yorker, on Why L.A. Is the Land of Milk and Honey
abstract: The indie-rock icon, who left Brooklyn for Hollywood shortly before releasing his new solo album last month, reflects on the joys of Mexican food, tennis and silent movies.
lead_paragraph: For as long as indie rock has been a genre, Dean Wareham has been a part of it. Galaxie 500, the band the New Zealand-born singer and guitarist formed with a pair of Harvard classmates in the late ’80s, informed a generation of shoegazers and remains a make-out-session staple today. Equally beloved is his ’90s dream-pop band Luna, through which he met his wife, the singer and bassist Britta Phillips. Together, they’ve spent the last decade or so writing and touring as Dean & Britta. They’ve also been regular collaborators of the director Noah Baumbach, scoring “The Squid and the Whale” and playing the co-hosts of an awkward dinner party in last year’s “Frances Ha.”

headline: State Actions on the Minimum Wage
abstract: President Obama’s proposal to increase the federal minimum wage to $10.10 from $7.25 is unlikely to pass through Congress, but several states have been tackling the issue on their own.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s proposal to increase the federal minimum wage to $10.10 from $7.25 is unlikely to pass through Congress, but several states have been tackling the issue on their own.

headline: Deals at Rizzoli, Modani, Pollack and Treillage
abstract: Discounts on fabrics, books and accessories.
lead_paragraph: During Pollack’s warehouse sale, through Monday, fabrics including sheers, velvets, silks and embroideries are up to 90 percent off (Peachy upholstery fabric in a color called Carrot Cake, originally $155 a yard, is $20 a yard); 629 Grove Street (16th Street), Jersey City; 212-627-7766, pollackassociates.com.

headline: Homes Worth Aspiring To
abstract: “The Urban House” features 25 pristine and glamorous interiors. Eat your heart out.
lead_paragraph: Ron Broadhurst’s new book “The Urban House” (Rizzoli, $45), is a sensory splash of 25 pristine dwellings in cities around the world. Nearly half are in New York and 11 were designed by women, including Andrée Putman, Annabelle Selldorf and Jeanne Gang. Richard Meier wrote the foreword and is represented by a floor-through white palace in the Sherry-Netherland.

headline: Cozy Up to the Campfire With Color and Ease
abstract: The Bison camping chair by Alite Designs has mid-century roots.
lead_paragraph: Tae Kim, the founder of Alite Designs, a San Francisco company specializing in stylish camping equipment, had the molded fiberglass chairs of Charles and Ray Eames in mind when he designed Bison ($200). Even the four colors of the new chair’s water-resistant removable sling seat (black, Tiburon blue, Presidio green and Jupiter orange) are out of the midcentury-modern playbook. But Bison is nothing if not evolutionary.

headline: If Cherry Trees Came with Gold Dust
abstract: Lindsey Adelman’s new Cherry Bomb light mixes natural beauty with high drama.
lead_paragraph: Lindsey Adelman’s Cherry Bomb lighting fixtures, to be introduced next week at the Nilufar Gallery in Milan, were inspired by cherry trees she admired in Japan. The lights, which resemble brass vines that creep up walls or across ceilings, are also named after the fireworks that are illegal in many states.

headline: Making a Scene, Onstage and Off
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Theater', 'Television', 'Design']
abstract: Eugene Lee, a set designer known for his work on the Jimmy Fallon show and numerous Broadway productions, has perfected the art of acquisition.
lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — For years, the crystal chandelier that Eugene Lee salvaged back in the 1980s, when the original Helen Hayes Theater in Times Square was being demolished, presided over Studio 8H at Rockefeller Center, adding a little elegance to the rarefied air around “Saturday Night Live” cast members like Eddie Murphy and Dennis Miller.

headline: Loving Trees, Even the Messy Ones
abstract: Enzo Enea, a Swiss landscape architect, on oranges, mangoes and other fruits of his career.
lead_paragraph: In 1993 Enzo Enea, a landscape architect, bought out his father’s garden ornament business in Switzerland. Today he has nearly 200 employees who have landscaped corporate headquarters, churchyards, rooftop gardens, vacation homes and condominium projects in Miami, where Mr. Enea, 49, has a satellite office. His next Florida project, the Oceana Bal Harbour condominium building, designed by the architect Bernardo Fort-Brescia, is on a 5.5-acre oceanfront site that sits across Collins Avenue from the Bal Harbour Marina and will be home to two giant outdoor Jeff Koons sculptures. (This interview was edited and condensed.)

headline: Should I Add Lighting to Closets?
keywords: ['Closets', 'Lighting', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: By all means, but also make sure what you illuminate is well organized and even enviable.
lead_paragraph: Q. My home has deep, dark closets. Should I add lighting to make them more of a selling feature?

headline: Ticking and Tocking in Playful Ceramics
keywords: ['Ceramics and Pottery', 'Typography', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Watches and Clocks']
abstract: New from Heath Ceramics: wall clocks with symbols based on vintage fonts.
lead_paragraph: Heath Ceramics is venturing into wall clocks in partnership with House Industries, a Delaware design firm best known for its vintage-inspired typefaces. Their clock called Stencil features numbers in a newly created font that Andy Cruz, a House Industries founder, said was inspired by “19th-century French stencils, Shaker tin stencils and your standard American G.I. stencil.” The Ornament clock has a pattern one might expect to see on a Nordic ski sweater.

headline: A Painter Stretches
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Art', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: Tom Levine more than tripled his live/work space when he moved from SoHo. He shares his new loft with two cats and a shrine to Jasper Johns.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to believe, but there was a time when being a starving artist in New York could have real estate advantages. Tom Levine is proof.

headline: Gathering Moss
abstract: It often pops up accidentally, but few know how to make it happen on purpose.
lead_paragraph: BREVARD, N.C. — Look up, Mossin’ Annie Martin told me, look up on the tin roof of the “bulimia treatment center.” Can you see the rust-green clump waiting to be rescued by a loving hand? That’s Entodon seductrix: what she, and no one else, refers to as “shiny, sexy moss.”

headline: Iraq Veteran at Fort Hood Kills 3 and Himself in Rampage
keywords: ['Fort Hood Shooting (2014)', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder']
abstract: The authorities said that the motive of the gunman, an Army specialist who was being treated for behavioral and mental health issues, remained unclear, but that the shooting did not appear to be related to terrorism.
lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex. — A soldier who was being evaluated for post-traumatic stress disorder opened fire at Fort Hood on Wednesday, killing three people and wounding 16 before killing himself, the authorities said. The shooting set off a huge police response and shut down the sprawling Army base, the same facility where a deadly rampage by an officer resulted in 13 deaths in 2009.

headline: Stone Furnishings: Petrified, in a Good Way
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Rock and Stone', 'Copper, Brass and Bronze', 'Tables']
abstract: Furniture and accessories made from minerals need not say “Flintstones.”
lead_paragraph: Gregory Buntain and Ian Collings, partners in the Brooklyn design firm Fort Standard, love materials with a sense of permanence and age: thick white oak, like the wood they use for the oversize legs on their Column tables, for instance, or the rough cast-bronze they chose for their chunky Sprue candelabra.

headline: NBC Sports Isn’t Paying Elliott to Be on the Bench
abstract: Josh Elliott, the former “Good Morning America” anchor hired Wednesday by NBC Sports, is a reasonable candidate to replace Bob Costas as the prime-time Olympic host when he decides to step aside.
lead_paragraph: Josh Elliott joined NBC Sports on Wednesday and compared himself to being “the last man on the bench of the Showtime Lakers with the best seat in the house.”

headline: Mets Fall as Their Pitching Concerns Grow
abstract: Young pitching is considered the team’s strength, but a spate of injuries has General Manager Sandy Alderson concerned.
lead_paragraph: The Mets are often asked what reasons they have to be optimistic. Lately, their unequivocal response has been starting pitching. It is their obvious strength, now and for the future. They consider Matt Harvey, Zack Wheeler, Noah Syndergaard and Rafael Montero precious assets. The Mets plan to be cautious with them, bring them along at the right pace and eventually ride them to relevance.

headline: An Illness, Inherited?
abstract: I spent many months, as a fetus, in a mental institution, listening to the world shuffling outside.
lead_paragraph: EDINBURGH — I spent many months, as a fetus, in a mental institution, listening to the world shuffling outside. I don’t know what meds were administered to me in that developing stage. I lived in the belly of a woman I would never know. But my relationship with something dubiously entitled mental health was already established.

headline: Lofty Newspaper Project Is Closed After Two Years
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Project Thunderdome, an ambitious effort to provide articles to 75 newsrooms owned by Digital First Media, will be shut down as the company looks to cut costs and focus on local news.
lead_paragraph: It started as a way to solve one of the thorniest problems in the newspaper industry — how to transition from the high margins yet declining circulation of print to the less profitable but fast-growing readership of the web.

headline: New Mexico: Albuquerque Seeks Police Monitoring
abstract: Mayor Richard J. Berry of Albuquerque asked the Justice Department on Wednesday to monitor the city’s police force, roiled by a rash of shootings resulting in 23 deaths and 14 injuries in four years.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Richard J. Berry of Albuquerque asked the Justice Department on Wednesday to monitor the city’s police force, roiled by a rash of shootings resulting in 23 deaths and 14 injuries in four years. In a news conference, Mr. Berry also announced plans to certify all of the department’s 426 field officers in crisis intervention so they can better handle calls involving people with mental illness, who made up the majority of the victims in the shootings, and implement an evaluation system for the officers. The changes depend on extra funding, as well as approval by the police union and the Justice Department, which has been investigating allegations of civil rights violations by the police for 16 months.

headline: Iran’s Choice for U.N. Post Fuels Tension With U.S.
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Visas', 'Hostages', 'United States International Relations', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Washington has yet to announce a decision on a visa for Hamid Aboutalebi, a diplomat with links to the group behind the 1979 hostage crisis in Tehran.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Six months after President Obama made a groundbreaking telephone call to his Iranian counterpart, Hassan Rouhani, the administration has made clear that expectations of a complete thaw in relations between Iran and the United States are premature.

headline: Ex-Contractor Sentenced for Leak to Fox News
abstract: A federal judge on Wednesday sentenced a former State Department contractor to 13 months in prison for leaking information about North Korea to a Fox News reporter.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Wednesday sentenced a former State Department contractor to 13 months in prison for leaking information about North Korea to a Fox News reporter. The former contractor, Stephen J. Kim, pleaded guilty in February in exchange for a deal that would limit his prison time to that duration. Mr. Kim is the sixth person to be convicted under the Obama administration after being accused of leaking information to the public, and two other cases remain open.

headline: Updates on the Fort Hood Shooting
abstract: Live updates about the shooting in Fort Hood, Texas, which has left as many as four people dead and several others injured.
lead_paragraph: As our colleagues Manny Fernandez and Ashley Southall report, four people were shot and killed, including the gunman, and 16 others were injured in a shooting at Fort Hood in Texas on Wednesday, stirring memories of a mass shooting at the same base almost five years ago. Authorities said the gunman died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound. The Lede followed media coverage of the event in the first hours after the news broke.

headline: E.P.A. Faulted for Failure to Report Risks
abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency failed to consistently disclose health risks, including possible cancer risks, to research study participants who were exposed to dangerous pollutants, an agency watchdog report has found.
lead_paragraph: The Environmental Protection Agency failed to consistently disclose health risks, including possible cancer risks, to research study participants who were exposed to dangerous pollutants, an agency watchdog report has found. An E.P.A. inspector general’s report released Wednesday said that when the agency exposed 81 people to soot and diesel exhaust emissions in studies in 2010 and 2011, the risks were not always consistently represented and did not include information on cancer risks associated with long-term exposure. The E.P.A. said risks associated with cancer in the study, which only briefly exposed participants to the pollutants, were so minimal that they were not included on consent forms obtained from the subjects.

headline: War and Unrest Provide for a Scarred Campaign Trail in Afghanistan

lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — There is much about Afghanistan’s presidential campaigns that Americans would probably find familiar. Chartered jets carry candidates to corners of the country where they would ordinarily never set foot, political operatives try to spin skeptical reporters, and rich men hand over bundles of cash to curry favor with their next potential president.

headline: The Court Follows the Money
keywords: ['McCutcheon v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Campaign Finance', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Editorials']
abstract: Five justices voted to eliminate sensible contribution limits to federal campaigns, giving those few people with the most money the loudest voice in politics.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Wednesday continued its crusade to knock down all barriers to the distorting power of money on American elections. In the court’s most significant campaign-finance ruling since Citizens United in 2010, five justices voted to eliminate sensible and long-established contribution limits to federal political campaigns. Listening to their reasoning, one could almost imagine that the case was simply about the freedom of speech in the context of elections.

keywords: ['Law of the Sea (UN Convention)', 'ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'International Relations', 'Editorials']
abstract: The legal case against Beijing is an appropriate way for the Philippines to resolve a major dispute peacefully.
lead_paragraph: Undaunted by China’s aggressive rhetoric and expansionist claims to nearly all of the South China Sea, the Philippines has filed a legal case against Beijing with an international arbitration tribunal in The Hague. This is an appropriate venue to resolve a major dispute peacefully and in accord with global norms. The strategy of the Philippines has implications for others with similar claims against China — Vietnam, Malaysia, Brunei and Taiwan — and thus deserves support from the international community.

headline: Medicare to Share Information on Pay for Physicians
abstract: Medicare said that it planned to make available detailed information on what it pays individual physicians as soon as next week, despite the long-term resistance by the American Medical Association.
lead_paragraph: Medicare said on Wednesday that it planned to make available to consumers and others detailed information on what it pays individual physicians as soon as next week, despite the long-term resistance by the American Medical Association and other groups. The information will include data on the $77 billion paid by Medicare in 2012 to more than 880,000 health care professionals for 6,000 types of services and procedures. Patient information will remain private. “Data like these can shine a light on how care is delivered in the Medicare program,” said Jonathan Blum, principal deputy administrator at the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, in a blog post. “They can help consumers compare the services provided and payments received by individual health care providers. Businesses and consumers alike can use these data to drive decision-making and reward quality, cost-effective care.” Medicare, the federal insurance program for the elderly, was prevented from releasing information on individual physicians until a ruling last year by a federal judge in Florida. In a statement issued by the A.M.A., the medical group raised concerns that Medicare’s broad release of the payment information could “mislead the public” and recommended that doctors be allowed to review and correct any information before it was made public.

headline: Facing the Skepticism in Adoption, in Qatar and in the U.S.
abstract: In Qatar, skepticism of adoption is such that, after an adopted girl died, her parents were accused of being intent on selling her organs. In the United States, doubts are less grisly but still apparent.
lead_paragraph: In the United States, when others voice their confusion about why parents adopt, it is simple enough to smile and ignore it. In other cultures, that gap in understanding may not be so easily handled. I read the story of Matthew and Grace Huang, the Los Angeles couple sentenced last week in Qatar to three years in prison after being found guilty of killing their 8-year-old adopted daughter, with familiar sorrow. In January 2013, the Huangs rushed their daughter, Gloria, to a hospital in Qatar, where they lived with their three African-born children. After her death, the couple was arrested and accused of withholding food and water from the girl for four days, which they deny.

headline: Bringing Big Money Out of the Shadows
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Political Action Committees', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'McCutcheon v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)']
abstract: If you hate Citizens United, you should like the court’s decision in McCutcheon.
lead_paragraph: Once again, a narrow majority of the Supreme Court has knocked down a campaign finance limit, and, once again, court watchers have gone ballistic. Yet for those who worry about the polarizing effect of money on politics, the McCutcheon decision gives us a little hope. A world in which individuals can give limited, disclosed amounts of money to an unlimited number of politicians is preferable to one in which large chunks are given only to “super PACs” and other unaccountable outside groups.

headline: A Student of the Game, on the Golf Course and Off
abstract: Karrie Webb, a seven-time winner of major tournaments, has an encyclopedic knowledge of golf’s history and used some of her Founders Cup purse to help finance a film on the L.P.G.A.’s founders.
lead_paragraph: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — The week of the Founders Cup in Arizona, Karrie Webb sat for an interview with filmmakers for a feature-length documentary on the 13 women who started the Ladies Professional Golf Association. The project intrigued Webb, a seven-time winner of major tournaments and a World Golf Hall of Fame member whose excellence in the game is surpassed only by her encyclopedic knowledge of its history.

headline: Greece: Immunity Lifted for Lawmakers
abstract: Greece’s Parliament on Wednesday voted to lift the immunity of another four of the Golden Dawn party’s lawmakers so they can face trial on charges of setting up a criminal organization.
lead_paragraph: As part of a widening effort to clamp down on the activities of Golden Dawn, a party widely condemned as neo-Nazi and violent, Greece’s Parliament on Wednesday voted to lift the immunity of another four of the party’s lawmakers so they can face trial on charges of setting up a criminal organization. Of the party’s 16 legislators, 13 now face prosecution. Meanwhile, in a potentially serious blow to the coalition of Prime Minister Antonis Samaras, a close aide to Mr. Samaras resigned after a video posted online appeared to show him accusing the prime minister of influencing an investigation into Golden Dawn in order to gain votes. In a note announcing his resignation on Wednesday, the aide, Panagiotis Baltakos, said he made the comments, which were secretly recorded, to “relieve pressure” on him by Golden Dawn. He said the party officials had accused him of conspiring against the party.

headline: Israel: Foreign Ministry Strike Ends
keywords: ['Strikes', 'Organized Labor', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Employees of the ministry on Wednesday announced the end of an unprecedented strike over pay and working conditions that had shut the offices and 103 missions abroad for over a week.
lead_paragraph: Employees of Israel’s Foreign Ministry on Wednesday announced the end of a general strike over pay and working conditions that had shut down the ministry’s offices and the country’s 103 missions abroad for more than a week. The labor dispute disrupted visits of Israeli officials abroad and visits of foreign dignitaries to Israel and left hundreds of Israelis who had passport problems stranded in foreign countries. It ended with the signing of a document of principles that will serve as the basis of an agreement pledging an improvement in conditions, including financial incentives for diplomats serving abroad in countries considered hardship postings.

headline: Japan Says It Will Abide by Whaling Ruling
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said Wednesday that he would comply with an international court order to halt Japanese whale hunts off Antarctica.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said on Wednesday that he would comply with an international court order to halt Japanese whale hunts off Antarctica. Separately, officials in the Agriculture and Fishing Ministry said Japan would cancel that annual hunt in the Southern Ocean this year, which had been conducted within a loophole in a moratorium on commercial whaling that allowed killing for research purposes. However, the ministry left open the possibility that it might restart the hunt in the future under a different legal reasoning. The international court’s ruling said that the scientific output from Japan’s whaling program “to date appears limited” and suggested that the hunt was continued because of politics and logistics, rather than science.
