headline: What’s on Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 6:15 P.M. (MoreMax) MUNICH (2005) Steven Spielberg ventures beyond this story’s historical impetus — the 1972 Olympics, at which 11 Israeli athletes and coaches were killed by members of a Palestinian group known as Black September — to create a philosophical thriller about its aftermath: Israel’s apparent campaign of vengeance, using five agents who crisscrossed Europe to hunt suspects for years. Eric Bana portrays the film’s moral center, a former Mossad agent sent on a mission to eliminate those responsible for the deaths. Daniel Craig, Ciaran Hinds, Hanns Zischler and Mathieu Kassovitz (above left with Mr. Zischler) play his team. Tony Kushner and Eric Roth wrote the screenplay, based on a book by George Jonas. “An unsparingly brutal look at two peoples all but drowning in a sea of their own blood, ‘Munich’ is by far the toughest film of the director’s career and the most anguished,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. But more than anything, she added, “ ‘Munich’ is a slammin’ entertainment filled with dazzling set pieces and geometric camerawork.”

headline: Mon Levinson, 88, Op Art Sculptor, Dies

headline: The Campaigns for Kabul
abstract: Peculiar alliances have exposed how the flawed political system undermines democracy.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Most politicians’ homes I have visited here are heavy on fake gilt and rococo furniture, but Ashraf Ghani, one of the leading candidates in Saturday’s presidential election, is known as a technocrat and a sophisticate. “It’s a beautiful house,” I said, looking around at the exquisite Nuristani carved chests and Persian miniature paintings that decorated his living room. “It is,” replied Naseem Sharifi, one of Mr. Ghani’s campaign managers, beaming. Then he frowned. “The other day, they collected three or four kilos of human flesh off the roof.”

headline: Political Cacophony Challenges Musicians
abstract: Gustavo Dudamel, a Venezuelan with the Los Angeles Philharmonic, and Valery Gergiev, a Russian with the Mariinsky Theater, are being asked to decry their government’s actions.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 12, the charismatic Venezuelan conductor Gustavo Dudamel led a youth orchestra in Caracas to celebrate the 39th anniversary of El Sistema, the government-supported program that has organized hundreds of thousands of children across Venezuela into instrumental ensembles, serving as a model of using music education for social uplift. As the performance was underway, a crackdown on peaceful demonstrations was being enforced in the streets. People were protesting the policies of President Nicolás Maduro’s government, along with the pervasive crime, crippling inflation and scarcities that plague Venezuela today.

headline: Research on Children and Math: Underestimated and Unchallenged
abstract: New research suggests that kindergarteners are capable of learning more advanced math concepts than are offered in most classrooms.
lead_paragraph: We hear a lot about how American students lag behind their international peers academically, especially in subjects like math. In the most recent Program for International Student Assessment, commonly known as PISA, students in the United States ranked 26th out of 34 countries in mathematics. On the surface, it would seem that we’re a nation of math dullards; simply no good at the subject. But a spate of new research suggests that we may be underestimating our students, especially the youngest ones, in terms of their ability to think about numbers.

headline: Brookstone Files for Bankruptcy and Plans to Sell Itself
abstract: The company hopes that a $147 million combination with Spencer Spirit Holdings will provide a path toward profitability. The company would continue to operate its stores, catalog and website under the Brookstone brand.
lead_paragraph: Brookstone, the struggling retailer known for its consumer gadgets, massage chairs and other home furnishings, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Thursday, with plans to sell itself to the owner of the Spencer’s retail chain for about $147 million.

headline: The Fifth Freedom
abstract: Fear and want are nothing compared with nasty words.
lead_paragraph: Never mind freedom of speech, freedom of religion, freedom from want, freedom from fear. What America’s embattled billionaires are demanding, as their birthright (and I mean that pretty much literally), is something much more important: freedom from criticism. Making a desperate stand in the maquis the Wall Street Journal, heroic, oppressed men like Tom Perkins and now Charles Koch have been telling it like it is: anyone who says anything negative about them is just like the Nazis, or maybe Stalin.

headline: Hand-Held Treatment for Overdoses Is Approved

Similar to an EpiPen used to stop allergic reactions to bee stings, the easy-to-use injector — small enough to tuck into a pocket or a medicine cabinet — can be used by the relatives or friends of people who have overdosed.

headline: This Time, Jim Jarmusch Is Kissing Vampires
abstract: “Only Lovers Left Alive,” a new film by Jim Jarmusch, features a bloodsucking couple whose love spans centuries and continents.
lead_paragraph: The filmmaker Jim Jarmusch is old school. He writes all his scripts out by hand and then dictates them to a typist. Ideas are jotted down in small, color-coordinated notebooks and, despite the presence of an iPad and iPhone in his life, he doesn’t have email. “I don’t have enough time as it is to read a book or make music, or see my friends,” he said. “People don’t believe me, too. They think I’m just saying that because I don’t want to give it to them. But no, I do not have email.”

headline: Today in Small Business: What to Pay Yourself
abstract: What you are doing wrong on Facebook. Crowdfunding’s next frontier. And what happens to your company’s online accounts when the one person with access dies?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: The Hospital-Dependent Patient
abstract: Some fragile survivors of intensive, expensive treatments are like a house of cards, their health collapsing under even a minor stress.
lead_paragraph: “He’s back?” my colleague asked, eyes widening as she passed the patient’s room. “He’s in the hospital again?”

headline: Co-Stars Again, but Hardly Strangers
abstract: Nick Offerman (of “Parks and Recreation”) and Megan Mullally (of “Will & Grace”) are married and performing in Sharr White’s drama “Annapurna” at the Acorn Theater.
lead_paragraph: It was love at first rehearsal, or so the story goes. In the spring of 2000, Megan Mullally, then at the start of her fame as the acerbic millionairess Karen Walker on the sitcom “Will & Grace,” was kicking off her hiatus from the TV season in an unlikely venue: a sawdust-floored warehouse near downtown Los Angeles, where the Evidence Room, a theater company, was opening a cavernous new space with an ambitious staging of Charles L. Mee’s “Berlin Circle.”

headline: D.I.Y. Accountability
abstract: The C.I.A. will get to censor a report on its own interrogation program.
lead_paragraph: Here is the story so far on the Central Intelligence Agency’s interrogation program: The C.I.A. illegally detained terrorism suspects, tortured and abused them at secret prisons, denied that it was happening and then destroyed videotaped evidence. It misled lawmakers about what happened, stonewalled Congressional inquiries, withheld the results of its own investigation from Congress, and interfered in various ways with a Senate probe — even breaking into Senate staffers’ computers and deleting files.

headline: New Jersey’s Largest Newspaper Announces Big Staff Cuts in Reorganization
abstract: The Newark newspaper is cutting 167 jobs, including 40 newsroom positions, as part of a plan by the owner to centralize print and digital operations.
lead_paragraph: The Star-Ledger of Newark, New Jersey’s biggest newspaper by print circulation and among the largest in the nation, announced on Thursday that it would cut 167 jobs, including 40 newsroom positions.

headline: The Second Issue of a Truly Great International Magazine
abstract: In “ZEITmagazin – The Berlin State of Mind,” which hits newsstands today, 260 pages offer up undeniably interesting subjects and contributors.
lead_paragraph: Read all about it! The second issue of ZEITmagazin – the Berlin State of Mind is out today. Culling a half-year’s worth of editorial highlights from ZEITmagazin — which comes out with Die Zeit, Germany’s biggest weekly newspaper — the semiannual journal of culture, politics and art has a print run of 10,000 and is available in just about any international city where you can get an Uber. With a 28-page spread of Instagram photos curated by Ai Weiwei and pictures of surreal Tuscan food taken by Juergen Teller, the Teutonic glossy clocks in at 260 pages. Michael Douglas talks post-cancer life and of an adolescent encounter with Liberace; François Hollande and Angela Merkel take to bed with a plate full of pretzels; and a cadre of stars including Boy George, Juliette Binoche and Stephen King recount their dreams. Photographic subjects run the gamut from Berlin teenagers to Brad Pitt to a Chinese burial ritual. Ja, bitte.

headline: Letters: Among the Bombed
abstract: Readers respond to a review of Richard Overy’s “The Bombers and the Bombed,” an interview with Philip Roth and more.
lead_paragraph: Among the Bombed

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Michael Lewis on Complexity and the Rigging of Wall Street
keywords: ['Financial Brokers', 'High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Michael Lewis, author of this week’s cover story, talks about uncovering the complexities in the stock market that led to the 2008 collapse of the U.S. financial system.
lead_paragraph: This week’s cover story is an adaptation from Michael Lewis’s new book, “Flash Boys: A Wall Street Revolt.” Lewis is the author of several books about financial markets, including “Boomerang” and “The Big Short.”

headline: A Vacant Chair for Blythe Masters
abstract: The JPMorgan executive’s exit from the bank could solve a longstanding search for a chairman of Glencore, the giant Swiss trading house, speculates Christopher Hughes of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Blythe Masters’s exit from JPMorgan Chase with the sale of its physical commodities business could solve Glencore’s longstanding search for a chairman.

headline: Elephants and Pajamas: It’s the Marxfest of Course
abstract: Marxfest, taking place throughout May in New York City, will offer screenings, talks a trip to the Bronx Zoo and many other events to celebrate the Marx Brothers.
lead_paragraph: An excuse for a festival devoted to the Marx Brothers should probably not be necessary. But a group of Marxophiles (“they were going to call themselves Marxists, but they thought better of it,” a spokesman said) have banded together to present Marxfest, an eclectic series of screenings, talks, concerts and events of other sorts (a trip to the Bronx Zoo to look at elephants, for example), to be presented from May 1 to 31 at sites all over New York City. And they have an occasion to commemorate: 2014 is apparently the centenary of the poker game at which the comedian Art Fisher coined the nicknames by which the brothers became known – Groucho, Harpo, Chico and, in those days, Gummo, who was soon replaced in the family act by Zeppo.

headline: An Artist on His First Exhibit: ‘Wow, George Bush Is a Painter’
abstract: George W. Bush and his wife, Laura, gave an interview to their daughter Jenna before he displays more than two dozen paintings of world leaders.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If George W. Bush, budding artist, has learned one lesson about his newfound passion, it is this: “Don’t paint your wife.”

headline: TV Fandom in Red, Bad and Blue
abstract: Culture, ideology and anti-heroes, from Archie Bunker to Don Draper.
lead_paragraph: In the latest New Yorker, Emily Nussbaum has a provocative piece linking the phenomenon she’s dubbed the “bad fan” — the kind of prestige-TV viewer inclined to justify every crime their favorite TV anti-hero commits, to explain that Walter White’s shrew of a wife just doesn’t appreciate him, to gripe that “The Sopranos” featured too many dreams and not enough whackings, etc. — to an earlier era of television controversy, and the famous case of Archie Bunker:

headline: Image of the Day: April 3
abstract: Medha Patkar, the Aam Aadmi Party candidate from Mumbai North-East constituency during an election campaign in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

headline: South Sudan Urgently Needs Help to Stave Off Famine, U.N. Warns
abstract: The country needs food, water, seeds and farming tools in order to plant crops, a United Nations official said, or it will face the worst starvation in Africa since the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — South Sudan needs $230 million in international aid in the next 60 days or it will face the worst starvation in Africa since the 1980s, when hundreds of thousands of people died in Ethiopia’s famine, the United Nations official coordinating humanitarian aid in South Sudan warned on Thursday.

headline: I Refuse to Be Busy
abstract: Most of the time, being “busy” is a choice, and it’s a choice I refuse to make.
lead_paragraph: I’m not busy.

headline: MF Global Customers to Be Paid Back in Full
abstract: More than two years after the collapse of the brokerage firm, James W. Giddens, the court-appointed trustee overseeing the return of customer money, announced that he was sending a final round of checks to make MF Global’s customers whole.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the collapse of MF Global, the search for $1 billion of the brokerage firm’s customer money evoked one ominous metaphor after another, including “uphill battle” and “magical mystery tour.”

headline: Jeremy Stein to Resign From Fed Board to Return to Harvard
abstract: Mr. Stein, who has been critical of the board’s stimulus campaign, will return to Harvard to preserve his tenured professorship.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jeremy C. Stein, a member of the Federal Reserve’s board who has raised concerns about its stimulus campaign, will resign at the end of May and return to his previous role at Harvard.

headline: Pimco’s Gross, Facing Skeptical Investors, Discusses His Dead Cat
abstract: William H. Gross, the founder of the giant asset manager Pimco, devoted considerable space in his investment outlook letter on Thursday to a eulogy for his cat of 14 years.
lead_paragraph: William H. Gross, the founder of the giant asset manager Pimco, is contending with skeptical investors and a choppy bond market, not to mention a stream of negative publicity after the resignation of his heir apparent.

headline: Industrial Revolution
abstract: Milan’s hidden neighborhood of Isola is thriving with artisans of all kinds, making a destination for food and bespoke crafts.
lead_paragraph: Tucked behind the city’s rail yards, the many charms of Milan’s burgeoning Isola neighborhood are little known, even to the most design-savvy locals.

headline: Britain Shows Support for Tougher Cigarette Laws
abstract: The government published a report calling for cigarettes to be sold in plain packaging as a way of dissuading young people from smoking.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British government took a step Thursday toward imposing a ban on branding for cigarette packs, indicating that it was likely to go ahead with sweeping new restrictions on the marketing of tobacco.

headline: The Gun Report: April 3, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in five years, there has been a mass shooting at the Fort Hood military base in Killeen, Tex. In 2009, in what some consider an act of terrorism, Nidal Malik Hasan, a U.S. Army Major and psychiatrist, opened fire, killing thirteen people and wounding thirty others. Yesterday, after a dispute with another soldier, Specialist Ivan Lopez, 34, a National Guardsman, opened fire in two locations, killing three people and wounding 16 others. When a soldier confronted him, he shot and killed himself.

headline: Money, Voting and the Meaning of First Sentences
abstract: Look at the start of the McCutcheon ruling. Compare it to the start of Shelby County, striking down a provision of the Voting Rights Act.
lead_paragraph: Amid all the recriminations and counter-recriminations that follow a very controversial Supreme Court ruling, it can help to step back and get a little perspective.

headline: A Sisterhood of the Snow in Alaska
abstract: Nine women head into the Chugach Mountains for a heli-skiing adventure, and a little camaraderie.
lead_paragraph: The loud, industrial buzz of the helicopter dulled down to a steady purr through my thick headphones. Wedged tightly between three seatmates in the back of the AStar, I was outwardly calm, but inwardly I was having an “Oh, my God, I can’t believe I’m actually doing this” moment. We were being shuttled to a remote spot among the seemingly endless peaks of the Chugach Mountains in southeast Alaska where, ultimately, nine of us, all women, would click into fat powder skis or strap into snowboards for descents we’d been dreaming about all winter. Ranging in age from early 30s to mid-40s, we had come together to Valdez for this ultimate bucket-list ski trip.

headline: Hotel Review: Refinery Hotel in Manhattan
abstract: This 11-month-old property, built in a former hat factory from the early 19th century, boasts a contemporary feel and a prime location.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: Restaurant Report: Xiao Bao Biscuit in Charleston, S.C.
abstract: In a spot where drivers used to fuel their cars, diners now fill up on the type of Asian food that’s hard to find around the city.
lead_paragraph: Though only two miles from tourist-trodden Charleston, with its colonnaded mansions and crab cakes, Xiao Bao Biscuit feels airdropped in from the bustling streets of Asia — perhaps with a stopover in Brooklyn.

headline: Will Durant’s Lost Final Book to Be Published
abstract: The manuscript of Will Durant’s final book was in in a box in his granddaughter’s attic.
lead_paragraph: Will and Ariel Durant’s 11-part series, “The Story of Civilization,” published between 1935 and 1975, sold millions of copies and turned the couple into household names (though Ariel was not credited as a coauthor until Volume 7).

headline: In the Keys, New Plans for an Old Bridge
keywords: ['Bridges and Tunnels', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: A restoration of the Old Seven Mile Bridge in the Florida Keys has the High Line in New York as an inspiration.
lead_paragraph: In the Florida Keys, the Old Seven Mile Bridge has been given new life in the form of a $77 million restoration program, approved in late March.

headline: Under Icy Surface of a Saturn Moon Lies a Sea of Water, Scientists Say
abstract: The finding of a body of water makes the moon, Enceladus, a promising candidate for harboring extraterrestrial life, even more than Mars.
lead_paragraph: Inside a moon of Saturn, beneath its icy veneer and above its rocky core, is a sea of water the size of Lake Superior, scientists announced on Thursday.

headline: Salsa, Flirting With Bok Choy
abstract: Possibly the only Mexican-Taiwanese restaurant in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, Lucky Luna has two cuisines that are neighborly but distinct.
lead_paragraph: Who seeks nuance in a side of rice and beans? Yet here it is at Lucky Luna, the rice faintly marine from an overnight soak and simmer in a broth of kombu and shiitake stems. The beans, too, are not the usual congealing muddle, but discrete drops of heirloom yellow-eyes, scented with coriander.

headline: Soldier’s Attack at Base Echoed Rampage in 2009
keywords: ['Fort Hood Shooting (2014)', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Security and Warning Systems']
abstract: The replay of a shooting at Fort Hood raised questions about what lessons Army officials had learned from 2009, when Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan went on a shooting spree, and how prepared they are to deal with threats from within.
lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex. — In the aftermath of a deadly rampage at Fort Hood here in November 2009 that left 13 people dead, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates announced a Pentagon review of the shooting to help ensure, he said, that “nothing like this ever happens again.”

headline: Turkey Lifts Twitter Ban After Court Calls It Illegal
abstract: The social media site was unblocked after a two-week ban, following a ruling from the country’s highest court that the ban violated freedom of expression.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The Turkish government unblocked Twitter on Thursday, a day after the country’s highest court ruled that the two-week ban on the social media site violated freedom of expression.

headline: Ruling’s Breadth Hints That More Campaign Finance Dominoes May Fall
keywords: ['McCutcheon v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: Experts in election law say there is no reason to think that the march toward deregulating election spending will stop with Wednesday’s ruling on overall donation limits.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The sweeping language and logic of Wednesday’s Supreme Court decision on campaign finance may imperil other legal restrictions on money in politics.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Under the Skin’
abstract: Jonathan Glazer narrates a sequence from his film.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Glazer narrates a sequence from his film.

headline: The Repercussions
abstract: Akhil Sharma’s new novel, “Family Life,” charts the lives of a boy and his parents as they struggle with grief and a recent move from India to America.
lead_paragraph: (This book was selected as one of The New York Times Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2014. For the rest of the list, click here.)

headline: Epic Fail
abstract: Two new books present failure — personal and professional — as a quintessential part of success.
lead_paragraph: Books about failure put both their authors and their readers in awkward positions. Writers are at pains to abase themselves somewhat, to show that they know the terrain by sacrificing some dignity without losing all credibility. Many readers, meanwhile, may be willing to ponder how they fail or why they fear it, but few will pick up a book for people who think of themselves as “failures.” Add to this the fact that all books fail to be everything their authors hoped and that almost all books fail to sell, and it becomes clear why books about failure remain few and far between.

headline: The Case Against Savings Accounts (but Not Savings)
abstract: Is a savings account a teaching tool, or a “black hole that swallows birthday checks”?
lead_paragraph: My 8-year-old daughter saves money in a jar in her bedroom. As her goals got bigger (and relatives started giving her money for birthdays and holidays), I wondered whether it was time for her to have an actual savings account at a real bank or credit union.

headline: U.N. and Syrians on Refugees in Lebanon
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Amid a flood of Syrian war refugees, Lebanon now has the highest concentration of refugees as a percentage of population in the world.
lead_paragraph: Amid a flood of Syrian war refugees, Lebanon now has the highest concentration of refugees as a percentage of population in the world.

headline: Jazz Festival to Honor Eric Dolphy
abstract: A two-day festival, Eric Dolphy: Freedom of Sound, will take place at Montclair State University in Montclair, N.J., on May 30 and 31.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years after his death, the multi-instrumentalist and composer Eric Dolphy, one of the most original improvisers and composers in the history of jazz, will have a major two-day festival in his honor. Eric Dolphy: Freedom of Sound will take place at Montclair State University in Montclair, N.J., on May 30 and 31; the festival was announced this week by Seed Artists, its producer.

headline: Lebanon Hosts Over a Million Who Fled Syria, U.N. Reports
abstract: United Nations officials call the influx a devastating milestone in the humanitarian crisis created by the Syrian civil war.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The number of registered Syrian war refugees who have flooded into Lebanon exceeded one million on Thursday, the United Nations said, describing it as a devastating milestone in a humanitarian crisis that has overwhelmed this small country and severely taxed the ability of the government and aid organizations.

headline: Amid Cheers, Union Bid Stirs Concern for Women
keywords: ['Title IX (Gender Discrimination Legislation)', 'College Athletics', 'Organized Labor', 'Athletics and Sports', 'Women and Girls', 'NCAA Basketball Championships (Women)', 'Basketball (College)', 'Football (College)', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Those involved in sports equality issues see benefit and risk for women’s sports in the changes that might ripple from the Northwestern football players’ quest to unionize.
lead_paragraph: Gary Blair, who coached Texas A&M to a national basketball title in 2011, was asked recently about how unionization of college athletes might affect women’s sports.

headline: New York City Can Block Religious Services in Public Schools, Appeals Court Says
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Religion and Belief', 'Religion-State Relations']
abstract: A federal panel said the city did not violate the right to free exercise of religion by barring religious groups from holding services in schools.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals panel ruled on Thursday that New York City can bar religious groups from holding services in school buildings, reversing a lower-court decision.

headline: Talk of Freeing a Spy for Israel Stirs Old Unease for U.S. Jews
abstract: More and more Jews say the time to free Jonathan J. Pollard is long past, but they are unsure whether he should be used as a chit in a diplomatic transaction with Israel.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Each year, just before Passover, Malcolm Hoenlein writes a letter to President Obama requesting that he grant clemency to Jonathan J. Pollard, the American sentenced to life in prison in 1987 for passing suitcases stuffed with classified documents to Israel.

headline: First Blush
abstract: A little shade of pink goes a long way in transforming otherwise industrial forms of design.
lead_paragraph: The edges of modern design are softening this season with delicate hues in the palest of pinks.

headline: Senate Panel Votes to Reveal Report on C.I.A. Interrogations
abstract: People who have read the report have said it details the C.I.A.’s brutal methods of interrogating terrorism suspects in the years after Sept. 11, 2001.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The public will soon get its first look at a voluminous report on the C.I.A.’s detention and interrogation practices during the George W. Bush administration, after the Senate Intelligence Committee voted on Thursday to declassify key sections of it.

headline: Bryan Cranston to Write Memoir of His ‘Breaking Bad’ Years
abstract: The actor said his book would “tell the stories of my life and reveal the secrets and lies that I lived with for six years shooting ‘Breaking Bad.’ ”
lead_paragraph: Bryan Cranston, the veteran actor and celebrated star of “Breaking Bad,” has agreed to write a memoir of his life and work, his publisher said on Thursday.

headline: Officials on Base Shooting
keywords: ['Fort Hood Shooting (2014)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The secretary of the Army, John M. McHugh, and the White House press secretary, Jay Carney, provided some detail about the soldier accused of killing three people at Fort Hood on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The secretary of the Army, John M. McHugh, and the White House press secretary, Jay Carney, provided some detail about the soldier accused of killing three people at Fort Hood on Wednesday.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘Under the Skin’
abstract: Jonathan Glazer narrates a sequence from his science fiction film.
lead_paragraph: In this video, the director Jonathan Glazer narrates a sequence from his film “Under the Skin,” about a predatory extraterrestrial played by Scarlett Johansson. In this sequence, that character walks down a street in Glasgow where she trips and falls. The sequence was shot with hidden cameras on a street in Glasgow, Scotland. A photo that was snapped during one of the takes eventually became a meme last fall. Here, Mr. Glazer discusses his ideas behind the scene and how it came together.

headline: Jack White Plans to Record and Produce a Single on Record Store Day
abstract: Mr. White will record and produce a 45-r.p.m. single for sale to fans at his label’s Nashville location on April 19.
lead_paragraph: Record Store Day – April 19, this year – has typically brought stacks of collectible rarities and limited-edition pressings, made available just for the day, usually on vinyl only, and only at physical record stores, an endangered species these days. Collectors snap these discs up, and so do speculators: it often seems as if most items find their way to eBay before the day is out.

headline: Celebrate Shakespeare on His 450th Birthday: Seven Ideas for Teaching and Learning
abstract: In honor of the Bard’s 450th birthday this month, and the surplus of Shakespeare in theaters as a result, we’ve revamped our main resource page and provided seven broad ideas that might serve as starting points in teaching his work.
lead_paragraph: Alan Cumming plays Lady Macbeth in a scene from a reimagining of Shakespeare’s tragedy “Macbeth.” Related Review

headline: Brooklyn Housing Court, Like Many City Renters, Can’t Find a New Home
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: With a 10-year lease about to expire, and after two years of searching, officials have yet to find a new space for the court that suits its frenetic operations.
lead_paragraph: Like much of New York, Brooklyn Housing Court is having housing issues.

headline: Parsing Big Ears
abstract: Ben Ratliff and Christopher R. Weingarten, a critic for Rolling Stone, discuss the free-form music festival in Knoxville, Tenn.
lead_paragraph: Ben Ratliff and Christopher R. Weingarten, a critic for Rolling Stone, discuss the free-form music festival in Knoxville, Tenn.

headline: Treasures and Trivia of the Romanov Era
abstract: Simple household objects and precious gold and bejeweled items from the Romanov period will be on exhibit this spring in New York museums.
lead_paragraph: JORDANVILLE, N.Y. — Artifacts as ordinary as coat hangers that were owned by czars and members of their inner circle, are re-emerging at museums, stores and auction houses. The greatest concentration will appear next month in a new museum at a Russian Orthodox monastery in this hamlet near Utica.

headline: Dicey Language in The Times, a View from Venezuela’s President and Coverage of Women’s Basketball
abstract: Following up on recent posts on a variety of subjects.
lead_paragraph: I’m following up here on a few subjects raised in earlier posts, on subjects as far afield as Venezuelan politics, women’s basketball and the use of profane and vulgar language in The Times.

headline: Anadarko Pays Billions in Settling Toxins Case
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Air Pollution', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: The oil company agreed to pay the United States government to restore thousands of sites polluted by toxins and compensate thousands of personal-injury claimants.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A giant Texas oil company, Anadarko Petroleum, has agreed to pay $5.1 billion for a vast environmental cleanup, a sum the Justice Department said was the largest it had ever won in such a case.

headline: On Car Safety, Congress Should Check the Mirror
abstract: Lawmakers beat up on the chief executive of General Motors, but didn’t acknowledge their own culpability.
lead_paragraph: At hearings in the House and Senate earlier this week, lawmakers went all out to show that they cared about auto safety by beating up on the chief executive of General Motors and, to a lesser extent, the head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. What they didn’t do was acknowledge their own culpability.

headline: Tech Start-Ups Are Targets of Ransom Cyberattacks
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Extortion and Blackmail', 'Start-ups']
abstract: Several web companies have recently been hit with attacks that can knock them offline using a flood of traffic unless they pay ransoms in Bitcoins.
lead_paragraph: Scott Heiferman and Gary Burns had less than four minutes to decide whether to pay up or go down.

headline: Mozilla’s Chief Felled by View on Gay Unions
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Under pressure from employees and the public for his support of a ban on gay marriage, Brendan Eich stepped down as chief executive of the company behind the Firefox browser.
lead_paragraph: Updated | In Silicon Valley, where personal quirks and even antisocial personalities are tolerated as long as you are building new products and making money, a socially conservative viewpoint may be one trait you have to keep to yourself.

headline: A Master of Texture Conjures the Sky and the Sea
abstract: The Spanish conductor Pablo Heras-Casado led the New York Philharmonic in a program of mid-20th-century masterworks by Britten, Bartók and Shostakovich.
lead_paragraph: “Look at him,” a man muttered behind me at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday evening when the Spanish conductor Pablo Heras-Casado walked out onstage for his debut appearance with the New York Philharmonic. “Another child.”

headline: Popcast: Parsing Big Ears
abstract: Ben Ratliff and Christopher R. Weingarten, a critic for Rolling Stone, discuss the free-form music festival in Knoxville, Tenn.
lead_paragraph: Big Ears, the extraordinary music festival in Knoxville, Tenn., had its third edition this past weekend.

headline: U.S. Ordered to Return Assets Held in Crackdown of Luxury Cars Exported to China
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A ruling by an Ohio judge was a blow to a federal investigation of the business of buying luxury cars for a quick resale in China at a high markup.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities were dealt a setback this week in their yearlong crackdown on a growing niche business of buying luxury cars in the United States for quick resale in China at markups of as much as triple the initial purchase price.

headline: A Musical Mr. Fixit for the Soul
abstract: “Bruce Springsteen’s High Hopes” on HBO is primarily a highly polished piece of promotion for his latest record and for his new American tour.
lead_paragraph: “It’s quite nonintellectual and nonverbal; it’s just — feeling.” That’s how Bruce Springsteen describes his songwriting process at the beginning of “Bruce Springsteen’s High Hopes” on Friday night on HBO. So then, of course, he spends the rest of the short film talking about it.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 70
abstract: Christian Benteke, a Belgium international, sustained an injury in training with his club team that will keep him out of the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: blood pressure, smoking bans and weight gain. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: blood pressure, smoking bans and weight gain. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Wisconsin, a Love Song
abstract: Nickolas Butler, author of “Shotgun Lovesongs,” discusses writing, Wisconsin winters and the stirring influence of Bon Iver.
lead_paragraph: Nickolas Butler, author of “Shotgun Lovesongs,” discusses writing, Wisconsin winters and the stirring influence of Bon Iver.

headline: A Vegetarian and Gluten-Free Guide to Paris
abstract: The city’s infamously meat- and bread-centric culture is changing — slightly, anyway — thanks to a few new health-conscious culinary destinations.
lead_paragraph: Vegetarians in France are odd ducks. Culinary deprivation is neither sexy nor patriotic here. Regional specialties like the pulpy oysters of Isigny, the velvety foie gras of Périgord, the textured andouillette sausage of Lyon and the black-and-white Coucou chickens of Rennes are meant to be savored, not censured. And although there is no European consensus on exactly what the word “vegetarian” means, less than 2 percent of the French identify themselves as such (compared with four times as many Britons and Germans). Rare is the French host who asks guests before they come to dinner if they have dietary preferences or restrictions. Explain that you’re a pescatarian, vegan or even gluten-free and you’re likely to be met with confusion, bewilderment and a pile of raw vegetables on your plate.

headline: Mets Find Woes Growing and Crowds Dwindling
abstract: Starting pitcher Zack Wheeler gave the Mets a chance, allowing three runs in six innings, but the bullpen allowed five more runs and the offense could not score after the first inning.
lead_paragraph: The Mets’ offense was anemic, their bullpen was tattered, and it was only the third game of the season. Their starting pitching would have to carry them, it seemed.

headline: Citibank Executive Drafted to Help Bank Regain Fed’s Confidence
abstract: Eugene McQuade, who last month had announced plans to retire as chief executive of Citibank, will lead the bank’s preparations for the stress test over the next year.
lead_paragraph: Citigroup has drafted one of its stalwarts, who was on the verge of retiring, to help the bank regain the confidence of the Federal Reserve.

headline: After 3 Decades, Letterman Says He Will Sign Off
abstract: David Letterman, the host of CBS’s “Late Show With David Letterman,” said he would retire when his contract ran out in 2015. Now the speculation begins on who will succeed him.
lead_paragraph: David Letterman, the longest-running host in the history of late-night television, will retire from his CBS show next year, the latest shake-up in a roiling talk-show lineup.

headline: A Hotel Suite With a Museum’s Touch
abstract: The Made in the USA Suite at the Park Hyatt in Washington features handcrafted items from the Phillips Collection’s Museum Shop.
lead_paragraph: Guests staying in the Made in the USA Suite at the Park Hyatt Washington will be surrounded by art and design inspired by the Phillips Collection’s newest exhibit, “Made in the USA: American Masters from the Phillips Collection, 1850-1970,” featuring American art, design and furnishings.

headline: Rebellion in South Sudan
abstract: South Sudan’s former vice president, Riek Machar, speaks about plans for his rebels to attack oil fields that supply revenue to the government of Salva Kiir.
lead_paragraph: South Sudan’s former vice president, Riek Machar, speaks about plans for his rebels to attack oil fields that supply revenue to the government of Salva Kiir.

headline: A Soulful Safari, Stalking the Spiritual
abstract: In “Cathedral of the Wild: An African Journey Home,” Boyd Varty writes about growing up on a South African game reserve and his spiritual quest.
lead_paragraph: Boyd Varty was not the kind of child who did his learning in the classroom. He was raised in Kruger National Park in South Africa, where his family has operated the Londolozi Game Reserve for more than 80 years. He still lives and works there.

headline: At Quiet Rebel Base, Plotting an Assault on South Sudan’s Oil Fields
abstract: A rebel leader with a satellite phone, a touch-screen tablet and a copy of “Why Nations Fail” ponders the next step in a young country’s civil war.
lead_paragraph: NASIR, South Sudan — There are only four bullets in the rifle that Liep Wiyual plans to use against government troops on the front lines in South Sudan.

headline: Reunion Tour
abstract: Lifelong bonds are tested in a small Midwestern town in this first novel.
lead_paragraph: Sometime after Charles Dickens and before Jonathan Franzen, the heart on the shirt sleeve seems to have gone out of style in the literary world, replaced by irony, satirical remove and a more subdued, presumably cleareyed, emotional palette. But once in a while, it’s nice to get your eyes wet and your heart beating rapidly to a nostalgic tune. Nickolas Butler’s “Shotgun Lovesongs” is a good old-­fashioned novel, a sure-footed and unabashedly sentimental first effort that deserves to be among the standouts in this year’s field of fiction debuts.

headline: Open Marriage Trying to Induce Same
abstract: “10 Rules for Sleeping Around,” about one couple who allow each other to fool around and another that doesn’t, combines nudity and jokes, but fails to be a sex comedy.
lead_paragraph: A sex comedy can sometimes get by, even if it is deficient in one of the two things that term promises. But a sex comedy that is short on both sex and comedy is unlikely to please anyone.

headline: Taking Time and Earning Trust
abstract: The shutter became a lot less heavy once Carolyn Van Hooten realized she had earned the confidence of her subjects.
lead_paragraph: The shutter became a lot less heavy once Carolyn Van Hooten realized she had earned the confidence of her subjects.

headline: Borrowing the Maximum
abstract: With rates low and home values up, a hefty mortgage is tempting. Buyers should consider maintenance costs, taxes and the stability of their income.
lead_paragraph: With property values rising in many markets, and the threat of higher interest rates on the horizon, some borrowers might think the best strategy is to buy the most home they could afford. After all, why not max out on a mortgage while values are headed upward and interest rates still relatively low.

headline: West Village Mansion in the Rough
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: A historic limestone-and-brick building in the West Village that served as an outpost for the New York Foundling, one of the city’s oldest charities.
lead_paragraph: A formidable limestone-and-brick building on a historic West Village corner that had been used as a Catholic elementary school, as a nursing school affiliated with St. Vincent’s Hospital, and most recently as a locus for child-abuse and protection services administered by the New York Foundling, one of the city’s oldest charities, is about to enter the market at $47.5 million.

headline: Improv Night At The Oligarchs’ Ball
abstract: A funny thing happened on the way to the New Gilded Age.
lead_paragraph: OK, it was pretty funny when Fix the Debt tried to make itself hip by hiring a flash mob to promote deficit scoldery. But this — which is either real or a very subtle spoof — is cosmically weird:

headline: Upper East Side Block of Genuine Interest
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: Change has come to a stretch of townhouses, although you may not notice if you bustle by.
lead_paragraph: So maybe you think you’re pretty good at “Where’s Waldo.” But can you spot the impostors on East 80th Street between Park and Lexington? Mostly it’s a block of demure 1920s high-style mansions and private houses unchanged since 1930.

headline: The Fashion World as a Good Neighbor
abstract: Some big names will host a fund-raiser next month at Highline Stages for the Meatpacking District Improvement Association.
lead_paragraph: Next month, some big names in fashion will host a fund-raiser at Highline Stages on West 14th Street for the Meatpacking District Improvement Association. Diane von Furstenberg and Andrew Rosen, the chief executive of Theory, are presiding over the event, along with the hotelier André Balazs.

headline: 36 Hours in Hood River, Ore.
abstract: Whether you’re into beer or biking, wine or water sports, you can indulge in this area on the Columbia River east of Portland.
lead_paragraph: Hood River’s multifaceted climate is a little like Sochi’s — only without palm trees. Popularized as a windsurfing destination in the 1980s, this waterfront town in the Columbia River Gorge is blessed with mild to balmy temperatures nine months of the year, while nearby Mount Hood never runs out of snow. The result is an outdoor adventurer’s playground, and the saying “the Gorge is my gym” has inspired a blog of the same name, featuring daily wind and snow reports. The ultimate workout is the hat trick — a sport on snow, water and earth in the same day. It could be ski, paddleboard and bike; or snowboard, windsurf/kiteboard and hike. Or perhaps Nordic ski, white-water kayak and rock climb. And don’t forget fly fishing for steelhead. Once you’re hooked, the hardest part is the decision.

headline: Steve Coogan on ‘Alan Partridge’
abstract: The actor discusses the character he has played for more than two decades.
lead_paragraph: The actor discusses the character he has played for more than two decades.

headline: Glimpses of the Past and a High-Tech Future
abstract: Walking around SoHo, you may find, between the boutiques, little oases of contemporary art and reservoirs of local history.
lead_paragraph: Walking around SoHo on a sunny weekend, when the shoppers are out, you may find it hard to remember that the neighborhood once belonged to artists. But between the boutiques are little oases of contemporary art and reservoirs of local history. Artists Space and the Drawing Center, two nonprofit sites, have been renovated and revitalized; Walter de Maria’s “New York Earth Room,” at 141 Wooster Street, and his “Broken Kilometer,” at 393 West Broadway, are still under Dia’s meticulous care. Best of all, last year’s transformation of Donald Judd’s home and studio at 101 Spring Street into a public museum has given us a time machine to the SoHo of the 1970s.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: These are some of the things that got people talking today.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Comedy Listings for April 4-10
abstract: A guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Afghanistan, Syria, Spain and Rwanda.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Afghanistan, Syria, Spain and Rwanda.

headline: Winning Style Points on the Street
abstract: “Flex Is Kings” documents a dancing style that incorporates elements of several street moves like vogueing.
lead_paragraph: “Flex Is Kings,” a documentary about a street dancing style — from East New York, Brooklyn — reminiscent of vogueing, break dancing, and miming, concentrates on two performers. One is Flizzo, who says in the film that his grandmother described these dancers as looking as if they were having strokes.

headline: Musical Tributes for Mexico’s Dead
abstract: In Iztapalapa, a violent Mexico City neighborhood, two musicians with a guitar and an accordion are hired to ease the strains of grief, celebrate the dead and remind mourners of more festive memories.
lead_paragraph: In Iztapalapa, a violent Mexico City neighborhood, two musicians with a guitar and an accordion are hired to ease the strains of grief, celebrate the dead and remind mourners of more festive memories.

headline: With Instruments and Odes, Comforting Mexican Mourners
abstract: The Wolves of the Sierra, musicians who play songs at funerals in Mexico City, are part of a tradition of hiring musicians to celebrate the dead.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The gravediggers tossed dirt onto the gray coffin, the dust adding tears to weepy eyes. A young man in a T-shirt poured out a little beer for his cousin, who died at just 27. Then came the surge of music.

headline: The Power Grid
abstract: Measured by seasons, home run totals stretch from one to 73. Here are some stories behind the numbers.
lead_paragraph: When Chris Davis hit 53 home runs in 2013, he filled one of the few blanks in the arc that stretches from 1 to 73. Only one home run number now remains untaken from 1 to 60; more gaps exist from 61 to 73. Here’s a closer look at all the numbers, and some stories behind them.

headline: Theater Listings for April 4-10
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Pointing Fingers Over Bulging Bellies
abstract: A three-part documentary, on BBC World News, offers a trip through the maze of marketing and lobbying that revolutionized the food industry beginning about a half-century ago.
lead_paragraph: Is there nothing for which Richard M. Nixon cannot be blamed?

headline: Courage, Loyalty, Honor, Kablooey
abstract: Producers describe “Captain America: The Winter Soldier,” a sequel in the comic-book-based franchise, as a blend of action film and political thriller.
lead_paragraph: It’s a bird, it’s a plane — oh, wait, it’s Captain America.

headline: Hard Times Take Their Toll on a Singapore Family
abstract: “Ilo Ilo,” Anthony Chen’s first feature film, focuses on a middle-class family in Singapore facing uncertainty in a 1997 financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: “Ilo Ilo,” Anthony Chen’s small, wonderful first feature film, is an acutely perceptive examination of middle-class life in Singapore during a 1997 financial crisis that sent tremors of panic through Asia’s developing countries. Its semi-autobiographical story focuses on a family of three, with a baby on the way, suddenly facing uncertainty.

headline: Chasing a Dream and an Unalloyed Ethos
abstract: Brooklyn is our 19th-century Paris or 18th-century Rome, with one of the largest concentrations of artists in the world.
lead_paragraph: ARRIVE in Brooklyn, and you’ve entered the belly of contemporary art. It’s our 19th-century Paris or 18th-century Rome, with one of the largest concentrations of artists in the world. Here, you’ll find both commercial galleries and nonprofit and artist-run spaces — and thousands upon thousands of places you can visit during open-studio weekends scattered throughout the year.

headline: A Much Darker Hitchhiker’s Guide
abstract: In “Under the Skin,” Scarlett Johansson is an extraterrestrial femme fatale picking up, and disposing of, unsuspecting men in Glasgow.
lead_paragraph: Scarlett Johansson as an extraterrestrial femme fatale cruising the streets of Glasgow in Jonathan Glazer’s cerebral sci-fi horror fantasy “Under the Skin” is an indelible personification of predatory allure. Wearing a dark wig and a fake-fur jacket, her character, an alien with a sinister agenda, is as fetishized an object of desire as Marlene Dietrich admired through the lens of Josef von Sternberg. You may also think of Ava Gardner, as perfect a female specimen as Hollywood ever produced, coldly working her wiles.

headline: Movie Listings for April 4-10
abstract: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select film series.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for April 4-10
abstract: A selected guide to performances of hip-hop, electronic dance music, dance-pop and more in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Jazz Listings for April 4-10
abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Opera & Classical Music Listings for April 4-10
abstract: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: An Island Idyll Turns Sinister
abstract: When honeymooners in the Caribbean wind up entangled in a violent underworld, the actress Gina Carano puts her mixed-martial-arts skills to use.
lead_paragraph: Free Gina Carano! This former mixed-martial artist has plummeted from the heights and all-star cast of “Haywire” — Steven Soderbergh’s delightful 2012 revenge thriller — and now, after a supporting role in “Fast & Furious 6,” appears trapped in B-film depths. Witness “In the Blood,” an action trifle from John Stockwell that offers Puerto Rico locations and brief appearances by vivid actors (Treat Williams, Stephen Lang) but squanders Ms. Carano.

headline: Pluralism, With Bug Zappers and Doll People
abstract: The Lower East Side of Manhattan is now home to more than 100 art galleries, reflecting a plurastic mix of styles and attitudes.
lead_paragraph: WHEN the New Museum announced plans in 2002 to move from SoHo to the Bowery, on the Lower East Side, it caused much head scratching in the New York art world. With only about a half-dozen galleries there — a decidedly not chic mix of small businesses and industry and tenement housing — it seemed a strange decision to venture so far off the scene’s usual map.

headline: Where Blue-Chip Brands Meet Brassy Outliers
abstract: Chelsea has some of the largest commercial art spaces in town, possibly in the world, but also a handful of small galleries that show some of the best work.
lead_paragraph: WITH upward of 200 galleries, Chelsea is still the largest and, cash-wise, the richest of the city’s art districts. It’s also a microcosm of the art industry, offering a range of current product, a ton of junk and some stimulating work. Apart from a few outlier galleries, its main boundaries have stayed consistent: 17th Street to 27th Street, 10th to 11th Avenues. Here, you’ll find some of the largest commercial art spaces in town, possibly on earth; multisite franchises (Gagosian, Matthew Marks, David Zwirner); and a handful of reliably ambitious small galleries, which show some of the best work. Art district, not art neighborhood, most accurately describes this area, though that’s changing. Apartment buildings are going up, along with the new Whitney Museum. And the High Line is bringing a fringe of green to dour streets. Painting is everywhere, but the most interesting work I saw was in sculpture, photography and video, with a continuing performance piece my attraction of choice.

headline: Dance Listings for April 4-10
abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Halle Berry as a Woman of Many Faces
abstract: Ms. Berry is an exotic dancer who has mysterious blackouts in the Geoffrey Sax film “Frankie & Alice.”
lead_paragraph: Multiple-personality roles are always difficult to sell to an audience because they have been parodied so often, a problem Halle Berry never quite banishes in “Frankie & Alice,” an earnest drama said to be based on a true story.

headline: Broadcast News: British Airhead Still Has a Platform
abstract: Directed by Declan Lowney, “Alan Partridge” is the first feature film about the title character, a vapid, self-absorbed broadcaster long played by the British actor Steve Coogan.
lead_paragraph: Can unpleasantness be its own kind of charm? The British comedian and actor Steve Coogan has built a career around the answer “well yes, sort of.” American audiences that know him for his uncharacteristically sweet turn in “Philomena” or his role as the miniature Roman soldier in “Night at the Museum” movies may have a distorted view of his talents. As a character named “Steve Coogan” (in “The Trip” and elsewhere), he has satirized the fragile vanity of the semicelebrity class. But his greatest creation may be a broadcaster named Alan Partridge, a man whose Wikipedia entry helpfully describes him as “an insecure, superficial and narcissistic ‘wally.’ ”

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for April 4-10
abstract: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: This Week’s Movies: April 4, 2014
abstract: The New York Times film critics on “The Unknown Known,” “Captain America: The Winter Soldier” and “Under the Skin.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics on “The Unknown Known,” “Captain America: The Winter Soldier” and “Under the Skin.”

headline: Upstairs and Behind Doors, Creative Passion
abstract: The Upper East Side of Manhattan’s gallery scene is largely hidden, inside tall office buildings and discreetly marked brownstones and townhouses.
lead_paragraph: THE Upper East Side gallery scene is one of the better-kept secrets in the New York art world, but this may be changing. Recently, the area has acquired some of the buzz that adheres to the Lower East Side, thanks to the volatile gods of New York real estate. With rents rising elsewhere, space along 57th Street and on or just off Madison Avenue, from the 60s to the low 80s, is newly attractive. Among the newcomers: On May 1, Blum & Poe, one of Los Angeles’s most prominent galleries, will inaugurate a duplex space at 19 East 66th Street with an exhibition of butterfly paintings by Mark Grotjahn.

headline: Spare Times for Children for April 4-10
abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: THE LITTLE ORCHESTRA SOCIETY

headline: Flórez Withdraws From 3 Performances at the Met
abstract: Juan Diego Flórez, the bel canto tenor, is withdrawing from the first three performances of Rossini’s “La Cenerentola” at the Metropolitan Opera later this month citing illness, the opera house announced on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Juan Diego Flórez, the bel canto tenor, is withdrawing from the first three performances of Rossini’s “La Cenerentola” at the Metropolitan Opera later this month citing illness, the opera house announced on Thursday.

headline: Bidding War for Mobile Carrier Tests France’s Free Market
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: Two billionaires are vying to acquire SFR in a battle that exemplifies France’s struggle to decide how much market competition it wants.
lead_paragraph: A $20 billion battle for control of a French mobile phone operator is testing the limits of President François Hollande’s willingness to let market economics work, while consumer advocates are concerned that the government’s favored solution will reduce competition.

headline: Spare Times for April 4-10
abstract: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Talks at 92nd Street Y (Tuesday through Thursday) Next week, the Y’s lineup reads like a Who’s Who of the cultural landscape.

headline: On This Magical Island, Women Rule
abstract: “Amaluna,” a Cirque du Soleil show directed by Diane Paulus, creates a fantasy world where female strength is out front.
lead_paragraph: Who among us, in a fit of desperation over losing his beloved to a giant lizard man, has not torn off his shirt and scaled a pole with the ease of a lemur — only to reach the top and find he has nowhere to go, but must hang there, devastated and batlike, to the moody vocalizing that surrounds him, as if in a dream?

headline: Delete the Expletives, or the Euphemisms?
abstract: Readers debate an Op-Ed writer’s assertion that the media should print offensive language when it’s essential to a news article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Boldly Go
abstract: Art critics for The New York Times survey five districts where the gallery scene is thriving.
lead_paragraph: ACCORDING to the thermometer as well as the calendar, it’s finally spring, a great time for that urban sport known as gallery-hopping. The options in New York City have never been richer — in some neighborhoods, taking in the galleries requires Olympic stamina.

headline: Canada’s Oil Sands
abstract: Greg Rickford, Canada’s minister of natural resources, responds to an Op-Ed article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Terror and Finance
abstract: A reader says the key is transparency.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Uncorking a Napa Vintage for a Toast to Adult Romance
abstract: The Encores! production of “The Most Happy Fella,” led by Shuler Hensley and Laura Benanti, is an unabashed hymn of hope to fresh starts and quickened feelings.
lead_paragraph: Say hello to springtime, New York. It’s been dragging its heels for too long. But at last it has finally and unmistakably arrived. And isn’t it bliss?

headline: Who Takes the Blame for Venezuela’s Crisis?
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Minimum Wage', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The Democratic Unity Platform, an umbrella opposition group, and Edward R. Royce, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, respond to an Op-Ed article by Venezuela’s president.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Nest Labs Stops Selling Its Smoke Detector
abstract: Citing concerns that its smoke and carbon monoxide detector might be unintentionally turned off, Nest Labs is halting sales of the product and disabling a feature that allows users to turn it off with a wave.
lead_paragraph: Nest Labs, the home automation company recently acquired by Google for $3.2 billion, said on Thursday that it was halting sales of its smoke and carbon monoxide detector over safety concerns.

headline: Seeking Eden, They Fled to Far Isle; Hell Followed
abstract: In the late 1920s and early ’30s, couples (and a threesome) moved to an uninhabited island in the Galápagos chain, a tale told in a new historical documentary.
lead_paragraph: “The Galapagos Affair: Satan Came to Eden” is a darkly amusing historical documentary about the fruitless search for paradise on Earth by vainglorious, world-weary dreamers who set themselves above, and apart from, the rest of humanity. The heart of the film — directed by Dayna Goldfine and Dan Geller (“Ballets Russes”), who wrote the screenplay with Celeste Schaefer Snyder — is a hybrid of juicy period soap opera and “Survivor.”

headline: With Hollywood Stars on the Agency Team, Clients Take the Call
abstract: The actor Liev Schreiber teamed up with Scott Carlson, an advertising veteran, to found an ad agency in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: HAVING a celebrity as one of its executives can help an advertising agency open doors with prospective clients, but the actor Liev Schreiber, who founded an agency with the industry veteran Scott Carlson, has not been having great luck with doors lately. Mr. Schreiber, who stars as a Hollywood fixer on “Ray Donovan,” was on the set of the Showtime series recently when he walked into a door and broke his nose.

headline: Sam’s Club Releases Survey on ‘Microbusinesses’
keywords: ['Small Business', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The Walmart division says the survey, done with Gallup, will be the first of a quarterly series on the nation’s smallest businesses.
lead_paragraph: Sam’s Club announced on Thursday that it had joined with Gallup to release quarterly surveys on the country’s smallest businesses, as it released the results of the first such survey.

headline: The Court’s Ruling on Political Spending
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'McCutcheon v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)']
abstract: Readers react to a Supreme Court decision striking down the existing cap on individual contributions.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Agreement on Interstate Repair Needs, but Not on How to Pay for Them
abstract: Lawmakers and some groups are pushing to lift the ban on Interstate tolls, but some businesses like FedEx and McDonald’s fear increased costs and a loss of customers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The debate over repairs to the nation’s federal highways could be simplified as this: Will improved Interstates force people into bypassing their Big Macs?

headline: After the Indulgence of Young Lust, the Going Gets Tougher (and Rougher)
abstract: “Nymphomaniac: Volume II,” the second half of Lars von Trier’s tale of an aging sex addict, examines the risky fallout of her obsession.
lead_paragraph: Lars von Trier’s latest movie, “Nymphomaniac,” is being released in two sections and two formats. As of Friday, both “volumes” can be seen in theaters or, for the lazy or easily embarrassed, on various on-demand platforms. The division is a little awkward, but it makes a certain thematic sense. “Volume I,” which was reviewed here two weeks ago, is (relatively speaking) the fun part.

headline: Golf Digest’s Cover Spurs Criticism From L.P.G.A. Pros
abstract: Golf Digest’s May issue features Paulina Gretzky, the daughter of the hockey great Wayne Gretzky, a decision that has frustrated some golfers on the L.P.G.A. Tour.
lead_paragraph: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — Juli Inkster made her 120th start in a major on Thursday at the Kraft Nabisco Championship. A seven-time major winner and a member of the World Golf Hall of Fame, Inkster is one of 11 women since 1969 to appear alone on the cover of Golf Digest. The list, which includes Marlene Hagge, Jane Blalock (twice) and Nancy Lopez, grew this week with the unveiling of the May issue, with Paulina Gretzky on the cover.

headline: Events in New Jersey for April 6-12, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: A Family Finds There’s Something Out There
abstract: A family has an adventure in “Alien Abduction,” a sci-fi film inspired by so-called sightings in the Brown Mountain area of North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: As on the nose as its title, Matty Beckerman’s “Alien Abduction” repackages ancient legend for modern audiences in a found-footage story of streamlined efficiency.

headline: Homes as Art, Destroyed in Detroit
abstract: For almost three decades, Tyree Guyton, an artist, has been turning mostly empty homes and lots near Heidelberg Street in Detroit into what he sees as an art installation.
lead_paragraph: For almost three decades, Tyree Guyton, an artist, has been turning mostly empty homes and lots near Heidelberg Street in Detroit into what he sees as an art installation.

headline: Fires in Detroit Destroy an Artist’s Canvas: Vacant Houses
abstract: A project to fight blight by covering empty houses with colorful dots and discarded dolls, stuffed animals and other items has been marred by what officials suspect is arson.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — A faint stream of smoke was still rising in the frigid air here the other morning, though all that remained of the building itself was a charred foundation, now framed in yellow police tape. Detroit’s seemingly endless stock of abandoned buildings has been a target for arson for all too long, but this house was different.

headline: Oh, C’mon, You Make Pale Blond Girls Feel Tan
abstract: In “Being Ginger,” a man searches for a woman who will like him for the carrot top he is.
lead_paragraph: For most of “Being Ginger,” its flame-haired maker and subject, Scott P. Harris, thinks he’s looking for a woman who will love him. What he’s really searching for, however, is a way to love himself.

headline: Start-Ups and Upstarts
abstract: Nerds have ruled television for a while, but their image is changing, as shows like HBO’s “Silicon Valley” and “Veep” make clear.
lead_paragraph: Something is up when an ad for Planters Peanuts archly features its mascot, Mr. Peanut, delivering a TED Talk-flavored motivational speech, complete with flashy graphics and spurious data points.

headline: China: U.S. to Shun Joint Naval Drills
abstract: The United States will not send a fleet to take part in naval exercises that China is hosting this month, military officials said Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The United States will not send a fleet to take part in naval exercises that China is hosting this month, military officials said Thursday. The decision to shun the Chinese exercises came after American defense officials learned that China did not invite Japan to join the exercises. An American Defense Department official said that the United States was unhappy that Japan had not been invited. Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel, who is in Hawaii for a meeting of Southeast Asian countries, is headed to Japan and China this weekend for talks with his counterparts in both countries. Military officials said that the issue of the deteriorating relations between the two Asian powers would undoubtedly come up.

headline: Flash Boys for the People
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Small investors may actually benefit from high-frequency trading.
lead_paragraph: THIS week’s publication of “Flash Boys,” by the journalist Michael Lewis, has turned a harsh spotlight on the world of high-frequency trading. Mr. Lewis has joined a chorus of critics who say that the booming field, in which computers buy and sell stocks at lightning speed to take advantage of minute changes in prices, has essentially rigged the market against small investors.

headline: The Heart, but Not the Feel, of a Diner
abstract: With an extensive menu, the Beehive serves American classics in a classy setting, with an emphasis on breakfast.
lead_paragraph: Like a diner, the Beehive in Armonk is open all day, every day, and the menu seems to run on forever. But the ambience of the restaurant, set on a dusty street a bit apart from downtown, helps lift it to a higher level.

headline: That Bend in the River Might be Manufactured
abstract: “Watermark” explores how water shapes us, and how we shape water, as the filmmakers travel across 10 countries.
lead_paragraph: A gargantuan wall of roiling, nicotine-brown water gives way to a parched riverbed where bleached branches decorate the baked earth like skulls. The images, captured in ultrahigh definition by Nicholas de Pencier, are primal and striking, presented initially without identification or narration. In a general sense, we know what we’re looking at, but the specifics remain stubbornly veiled.

headline: Richard Prince’s ‘Canal Zone’ to Be Shown at Gagosian
abstract: After a federal appeals court ruled largely in his favor in a copyright suit, the artist Richard Prince is ready again to show his 2008 series, “Canal Zone.”
lead_paragraph: It was less than a year ago that the contemporary art world — and the artist Richard Prince in particular — declared a victory for appropriation when the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit ruled that Mr. Prince’s use of photographs by Patrick Cariou in his own paintings and collages were permissible under fair use, because they had “a different character” from Mr. Cariou’s work.

headline: Joan Miller, Modern-Dance Champion, Dies at 77
abstract: Ms. Miller’s signature works included social commentary and wit, often about the African-American experience.
lead_paragraph: Joan Miller, a dancer, teacher and enduring presence in modern dance in New York since the 1970s, died on March 23 at her home in Manhattan. She was 77.

headline: An Argentine Makeover for a Former Pub
abstract: At a steakhouse that replaced a place known for its big burgers, the portions are still hearty.
lead_paragraph: Long before Huntington became Suffolk County’s unofficial restaurant capital, it was home to Canterbury Ales, which opened in 1976 and rapidly became the go-to place for big burgers, abundant portions and a rustic pub atmosphere. It closed last summer, and in February, Sur Argentinian Steakhouse opened in its place.

headline: Bush 41 Reunion Looks to Burnish His Legacy
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Allies and even former opponents of the elder George Bush will gather in Texas to mark the 25th anniversary of his presidency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The elder George Bush will not give a speech. He is done with all that, he tells friends. But he will mingle and reminisce and bask in the admiration of graying men and women who helped him govern at a time when, some thought, they had reached the end of history.

headline: Warden at Rikers Island Demoted After Inmate Dies in Overheated Cell
abstract: Acknowledging “systemic management problems” at the mental health unit, the Correction Department also disciplined a correction officer and the supervisor of mechanics.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s Correction Department, facing an outcry over the death of a mentally ill inmate in an overheated cell at Rikers Island, announced on Thursday that it was demoting the warden in charge of the mental health unit and punishing two other employees.

headline: A Village Stadium Is a Symbol of Power for Hungary’s Premier
abstract: Viktor Orban, the country’s prime minister, has been aggressive both politically and in the business world, and a new soccer stadium in his tiny hometown is testament to his rising ambitions.
lead_paragraph: FELCSUT, Hungary — Something strange is going on here among the humble Soviet-era cottages.

headline: Futzing and Flirting as Armageddon Unfolds
abstract: In “Goodbye World,” a violent breakdown in society prompts friends to reunite at the home of a couple who live off the grid.
lead_paragraph: If its premise didn’t involve the collapse of civilization, “Goodbye World” could be a pilot episode for a TV drama about attractive, self-absorbed professionals in their 30s. Prettily shot in Mendocino, Calif., Denis Hennelly’s glide of a movie coops up old friends in a secluded country house and watches them natter about love and money while the world burns.

headline: Overseer of Compliance at SAC Is Selected
abstract: If a judge approves, Bart M. Schwartz, a former federal prosecutor who has served as an independent monitor in a number of government investigations, will be Steven A. Cohen’s minder.
lead_paragraph: Bart M. Schwartz, a former federal prosecutor who has served as an independent monitor in a number of government investigations, will be Steven A. Cohen’s minder, if a federal judge approves.

headline: G.M. Turns to Experienced Crisis Experts
keywords: ['Public Relations and Publicity', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: The creation of the team of outside advisers stands in marked contrast to General Motors’ early approach to handling the recall crisis, when it looked primarily inward to set strategy.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — At the end of the second bruising day of testimony on General Motors’ ignition switch recall, Mary T. Barra was in no mood for more questions.

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: A Tavern With Organic Salmon and S’mores Pie
abstract: South End, which opened in September 2012, changes its creative menu often and pays attention to how its plates look.
lead_paragraph: I had held off visiting the South End restaurant in a small shopping complex in New Canaan because I feared that it was just a renaming of the previous, underwhelming occupant of the space.
