lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Europe Moves Ahead on Internet Rules
abstract: Internet service providers may soon be restricted from blocking services like Netflix. Washington could learn something from the development.
lead_paragraph: American government officials and corporate executives are fond of reminding the world that the United States created the Internet. But right now Europe is taking the lead in protecting what makes the Internet great: its openness.

headline: State Officials Cite Technology Problems on Health Insurance Sites
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Officials in five states said that their health insurance exchanges had been hobbled by problems like those that bedeviled the federal marketplace.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Officials from five states, on the defensive at a congressional hearing, said Thursday that their health insurance exchanges had been hobbled by technology problems like those that bedeviled the federal marketplace. But they said their states were recovering.

headline: Party All the Time
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Political Action Committees', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'McCutcheon v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)']
abstract: The Supreme Court’s McCutcheon decision strengthens democracy by enabling the parties to take back power from major donors.
lead_paragraph: Over the last several decades, the United States has adopted a series of campaign finance reform laws. If these laws were designed to reduce the power of money in politics, they have failed. Spending on political campaigns has exploded. Washington booms with masses of lobbyists and consultants.

headline: California Democrats Await Fallout After 3 Are Caught Up in Scandals
abstract: Charges of corruption leveled against three state senators brought a rare bit of bad news to a party that has come to thoroughly dominate politics in that state.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — One state senator was charged with conspiring to traffic in arms from the Philippines, and taking bribes from undercover F.B.I. agents including one who posed as a marijuana dealer. Another was accused of taking bribes from federal agents impersonating Hollywood film executives. And a third was convicted of perjury and voter fraud after lying about where he lived when he ran for office.

headline: An Oasis That Defies the Season
abstract: Via45, a rustic Italian restaurant in the center of a strip of high-end retail stores, offers a beach-house feel and the flavors of summer.
lead_paragraph: The word jumped off the menu, as unexpected and inviting as a bonfire in a blizzard: watermelon.

headline: Rube Goldberg Survives
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Why those seven million enrollments in Obamacare matter.
lead_paragraph: Holy seven million, Batman! The Affordable Care Act, a k a Obamacare, has made a stunning comeback from its shambolic start. As the March 31 deadline for 2014 coverage approached, there was a surge in applications at the “exchanges” — the special insurance marketplaces the law set up. And the original target of seven million signups, widely dismissed as unattainable, has been surpassed.

headline: Iraqi Envoy Calls on U.S. to Strengthen Relationship
abstract: The ambassador, Lukman Faily, said that the United States should be more generous in providing assistance but emphasized he did not advocate a resumed military presence.
lead_paragraph: Iraq’s ambassador to the United States gently chided his host on Thursday, asserting that American fatigue with war — a consequence of the prolonged conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan — had left his country’s security more vulnerable and was contributing to Mideast instability.

headline: Before Rematch, UConn and Florida Recall Lessons of a Thriller
abstract: On Thursday, two days before the teams’ Final Four matchup at AT&T Stadium, their game on Dec. 2 still echoed for both squads and both coaches.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — After Connecticut lost to Louisville by 33 points to finish the regular season, Huskies Coach Kevin Ollie gathered his team for film study. Instead of ruminating on the loss, though, Ollie showed footage from a December win.

headline: His Promise Would Not Be Denied
abstract: I spent an entire gestation not looking at Tom, hoping that he wouldn’t see me.
lead_paragraph: I remember the first time I told Tom I loved him. I waited until I knew he wouldn’t hear me and then whispered in the dark, “I love you.”

headline: In U.S. This Year, I.P.O.s Leave the Gate at Full Speed
abstract: The market for initial public offerings has reached levels not seen in the United States in years, with 64 companies raising $10.6 billion in the most active first quarter since 2000.
lead_paragraph: When the online food-ordering company Seamless was founded in late 1999, it was too young to take advantage of the era’s fever pitch for newly public start-ups.

headline: The End of ‘Television Without Pity’
abstract: A website that popularized the episode recap is shutting down, but TV obsessives will be relieved to know that its archives will live on.
lead_paragraph: For obsessive TV viewers looking to feed rather than check their addictions, there was nothing quite like “Television Without Pity,” a website that got its start in the late 1990s. It was first devoted to the show “Dawson’s Creek” and then broadened its scope to hundreds of other programs, helping to invent and popularize the “recap” as a genre of criticism while providing reliably snarky companionship to the couch-potato community.

headline: Events in Connecticut for April 6-12, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: The Sister Next Door
abstract: Questions about an uncomfortable nickname, and problems with gifts, invitations and live music.
lead_paragraph: I am one of very few white people living in a building whose residents are predominantly black. Several of my neighbors have become dear friends. And three of them have started calling me “sister.” I am not sure what this means or how to respond. I think of several of my neighbors as family, though not the immediate kind. But returning the favor, and calling them “brother” or “sister,” feels awkward. I think of these as religious terms, and I am not religious. What would you do?

headline: How to Squeeze the Political Parties
keywords: ['McCutcheon v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Campaign Finance', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: A six-figure check will buy unlimited access to powerful politicians.
lead_paragraph: Reince Priebus, the Republican Party chairman, was practically giddy on Wednesday imagining the riches he can squeeze from big private bank accounts as a result of the Supreme Court decision that knocked down yet another campaign finance limit. “We are grateful and we are excited,” he said, explaining that donors will now be able to “max out” in giving to more party committees, at far higher levels than previously allowed.

headline: Critics Say Zip Line Will Hurt, Not Help, Lake George Tourism
abstract: Ralph Macchio Sr. wants to erect a zip line in the Adirondacks, but opponents say his plan will detract from the scenic qualities to which tourists are drawn.
lead_paragraph: LAKE GEORGE, N.Y. — Just south of this town’s tourist-friendly strip, the owner of a Western-themed ranch has a vision for French Mountain: the country’s longest zip line, which would whisk riders 3,450 scenic feet from the mountain down to his property.

headline: Don’t Press the Up Button
abstract: “Lift” by the best-selling mystery writer Walter Mosley opens April 10 at the Crossroads Theater Company in New Brunswick.
lead_paragraph: With best-selling mysteries like “Devil in a Blue Dress” among his more than three dozen books, Walter Mosley is a master of crime fiction who knows how to put his characters into tight, scary situations. In “Lift,” his new drama of suspense that begins performances on April 10 at Crossroads Theater Company in New Brunswick, the writer traps two strangers within an urban nightmare: Inside a damaged elevator that is stuck high up in a burning skyscraper.

headline: A Track’s Shift to Dirt Adds to Horses’ Risks
abstract: Keeneland will soon replace its synthetic track with dirt, a surface that fatally broke down racehorses at a much greater rate from 2009 to 2013, according to the Jockey Club.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, the Jockey Club released statistics from its equine injury database showing that synthetic racetracks were far safer than dirt or turf, and that the one at Keeneland Race Course was one of the safest in the nation, with a fatality rate last year of 0.33 per 1,000 starts.

headline: Television Tests Tinseltown
abstract: Are movies, and the act of going to them, passé? If so, how could they be updated?

headline: Gunman Had ‘Clean Record,’ With No Violent Sign, Officials Say
keywords: ['Fort Hood Shooting (2014)', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Military officials said they had seen nothing to indicate that Specialist Ivan Antonio Lopez was previously violent or suicidal.
lead_paragraph: Specialist Ivan Antonio Lopez had seen a military psychiatrist as recently as last month. He was being treated for depression and anxiety, and had been prescribed Ambien to help him sleep. He had come back from a four-month deployment to Iraq in 2011 and told superiors he had suffered a traumatic head injury there. But military officials said he had never seen combat, and there was no record of any combat-related injury. He was being evaluated for possible post-traumatic stress disorder.

headline: Karzai Is Trying to Keep His Sway After Term Ends
abstract: As Afghanistan girds for its presidential election, an exercise that President Hamid Karzai has shaped at every stage, those hoping to see him retire quietly may be disappointed.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — American officials have ignored him, and Afghanistan’s presidential contenders have tried to persuade voters that they will be different from him. But those hoping to see President Hamid Karzai slip into a quiet retirement may be disappointed in the months to come.

headline: Resilient Venus Williams Falls at Family Circle
abstract: The 33-year-old may have been the oldest of the dozen American women at the Family Circle Cup, but she made it the furthest before being eliminated.
lead_paragraph: DANIEL ISLAND, S.C. — Despite being the oldest of the dozen American women entered in the Family Circle Cup this week, Venus Williams, 33, made it the furthest. She was the only one to reach the third round, where she lost Thursday to the 20-year-old Canadian Eugenie Bouchard, 7-6 (6), 2-6, 6-4.

headline: Stenographer, Fired Over Drinking Problem, Left Headaches for Appellate Courts
keywords: ['Secretaries, Stenographers and Typists', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Archives and Records', 'Supreme Courts (State)']
abstract: The incomplete records from State Supreme Court proceedings in Manhattan highlight a major pitfall in relying solely on stenographic reporters to safeguard the official record of trials.
lead_paragraph: A court reporter who was fired after developing a drinking problem has left behind an incomplete record of at least six trials and two dozen other proceedings, creating delays and legal hurdles for prosecutors and lawyers trying to argue appeals, court administration officials said.

headline: Energy-Saving Company Set for Public Offering
abstract: The company, Opower, hopes to raise more than $100 million through a stock sale that could leave it with a value close to $1 billion.
lead_paragraph: For decades, regulators, environmental advocates and utilities have struggled to persuade consumers to use less electricity.

headline: Among Fort Hood Victims, a Sergeant Is Killed, and a Major Is Wounded
keywords: ['Fort Hood Shooting (2014)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Army has not released a list of the victims of the shooting rampage at the base, pending notification of relatives, but the names have started to emerge.
lead_paragraph: The names of the victims of the shooting in Fort Hood began to come out on Thursday, released by relatives and by officials offering their condolences.

headline: Character, and Characters, of the Village
abstract: Mostly contemporary residents’ capsule essays on Greenwich Village; a chance to explore historic Hudson Valley houses; a look at a Central Park address.
lead_paragraph: Some New York neighborhoods generate more stories than others. Few have provided more grist for fiction and nonfiction than Greenwich Village and its habitués. Now comes a beguiling collection titled “Greenwich Village Stories” (Universe), edited by Judith Stonehill, co-owner of the much-missed New York Bound Bookshop.

headline: Israel: Airstrikes in Gaza Follow Militants’ Rocket Attacks
abstract: Israeli military aircraft carried out multiple airstrikes in the Gaza Strip early Friday, the Israeli military and Palestinian officials said, after militants fired four rockets into southern Israel late Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Israeli military aircraft carried out multiple airstrikes in the Gaza Strip early Friday, the Israeli military and Palestinian officials said, after militants fired four rockets into southern Israel late Thursday. The airstrikes hit open fields and training camps of Palestinian militant groups, including sites run by Hamas, the Islamic movement controlling Gaza. Two Palestinians, a man and a child, were injured in one of the airstrikes near their home in Gaza City, said Ashraf al-Qedra, a spokesman for Gaza’s Health Ministry. There were no reports of casualties from the Palestinian rocket attacks in southern Israel, according to the Israeli news media. Taher al-Nounou, an adviser to Ismail Haniya, Hamas’s prime minister in Gaza, accused Israel of escalating the confrontation to divert attention from the “failure” of negotiations.

headline: No Rest for the Weary
abstract: Starring Denzel Washington, “A Raisin in the Sun” at the Ethel Barrymore Theater is a disarmingly relaxed revival, brimming with empathy for its flawed characters.
lead_paragraph: The spark of rebellion, the kind that makes a man stand up and fight, has almost been extinguished in Walter Lee Younger.

headline: Sol Mates
abstract: An opinion on stacking and a collaboration by Martin Ashwood-Smith and Joe Krozel.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Ah, double quad stacks in a puzzle that I, myself, was divided on. How appropriate. Don’t panic, Martin Ashwood-Smith and Joe Krozel: I liked your puzzle for the most part, but I’m going to use it to make a point.

headline: Inquiry to Revisit Jameis Winston Case on Civil Rights Grounds
abstract: The federal Department of Education is investigating whether Florida State properly responded to a student’s sexual assault allegation against Winston, the 2013 Heisman Trophy winner.
lead_paragraph: The United States Department of Education is investigating whether Florida State properly responded to a student’s allegation that she had been sexually assaulted by the university’s star quarterback and Heisman Trophy winner, Jameis Winston.

headline: Visions of a Forgotten Utopian
abstract: Reasons to visit the Upper West Side include a rowhouse on 107th Street that exhibits works of Nicholas Roerich, artist and Renaissance man.
lead_paragraph: At London auction houses, the paintings of Nicholas Roerich are frequently the objects of bidding wars among Russian oligarchs. One fetched more than $12 million there last year. During his lifetime (1874-1947), Roerich, a St. Petersburg-born artist, had legions of admirers, including Einstein, Gandhi, and Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt. Yet his name draws a blank on the Upper West Side in what was once called the Bloomingdale District, where a limestone-trimmed rowhouse at 319 West 107th Street exhibits 200 or so of his vivid images and jagged mountain landscapes. The plaque marking the site is as weathered as a crooked tombstone.

headline: Texas: Posthumous Pardon Is Denied for Man Executed in 3 Deaths
keywords: ['Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Capital Punishment', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'ARSON']
abstract: The Board of Pardons and Paroles denied the request for Cameron Todd Willingham, who was executed in 2004 after being convicted of setting his house on fire and killing his three daughters.
lead_paragraph: The Texas Board of Pardons and Paroles denied a request for a posthumous pardon for Cameron Todd Willingham, a man executed in 2004 after being convicted of setting his house on fire and killing his three young daughters. Members of Mr. Willingham’s family and the Innocence Project in New York requested the pardon, noting that the arson science used to convict Mr. Willingham had long been questioned and presenting new evidence suggesting a secret deal between the prosecutor and a jailhouse informant. The board’s decision was unanimous. The letter from the board denying the request noted that the family could apply again after two years. Barry Scheck, the co-director of the Innocence Project, said the decision “illustrates that the clemency system is completely broken in Texas.”

headline: Many Pupils Say 2014 New York Reading Tests Are Easier, but Complaints Persist
keywords: ['Tests and Examinations', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: Passing rates plummeted when the state changed its tests to match Common Core curriculum standards, but this year students say they were better prepared to handle the material.
lead_paragraph: William Summitt and Simon Sanders said they were ready. Their fourth-grade class at the Children’s School, near Park Slope in Brooklyn, had prepared for the state reading tests by going over sample passages beforehand, including a challenging excerpt from “King Lear” in which the king asks his three daughters questions about their love for him.

headline: Phil Jackson Praises Knicks’ Energy, Saying They’re ‘Playing With Purpose’
abstract: Jackson, who has watched the Knicks win 12 of 15 games, acknowledged their inconsistency but said they looked strong down the stretch.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Phil Jackson has a new role as president of the Knicks, and there are times, he said, when he has to resist the urge to yell at the officials.

headline: Friends Without Words
abstract: Jaime Herrera, who has been deaf since he was a child, is a janitor at the main branch of the New York Public Library.
lead_paragraph: When new employees are hired onto the cleaning staff of the New York Public Library’s main branch at Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street, they are often trained by a 14-year veteran named Jaime Herrera.

headline: Shut Out in Shootouts, Devils Try to Salvage Season
abstract: The Devils face the Capitals on Friday, as both teams chase Columbus for the final playoff spot in the N.H.L.’s Eastern Conference.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Few stretches have better showcased the Devils’ uneven season than the past week. Yet while their playoff chances are slim, somehow the Devils are still lurking in the Eastern Conference postseason chase.

headline: In Sugar Land, a Bitter Pill for a Regional University
abstract: The University of Houston-Victoria, a small institution, is taking as an eviction notice a plan by the University of Houston System to convert a Sugar Land center into a branch campus of its flagship institution.
lead_paragraph: Just off Highway 59 in fast-growing Fort Bend County, Texas, two academic buildings make up a multi-institutional teaching center known as the University of Houston Sugar Land. Most of its university courses are offered by the University of Houston-Victoria, a small but ambitious institution more than 100 miles away.

headline: To Candidate With More Years, Age Isn’t Off Limits
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'Age, Chronological', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: John Ratcliffe, 48, has not made the age of Representative Ralph M. Hall, 90, a campaign issue in the Republican primary runoff, but Mr. Hall has not shied away from the topic.
lead_paragraph: John Ratcliffe has a lot to say about United States Representative Ralph M. Hall, the oldest member of Congress and Mr. Ratcliffe’s opponent in a May 27 Republican primary runoff. Mr. Ratcliffe accuses Mr. Hall, Republican of Rockwall, of having stayed in Washington too long and of having become a “less effective” legislator.

headline: Marian Gaborik Showing Creativity With Kings
abstract: A former Ranger, Gaborik has found confidence and chemistry on a line with Anze Kopitar and Justin Williams.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For the sprightly, dynamic wing Marian Gaborik, so many things can happen in an instant.

headline: Before Tanaka’s Debut, Plenty of Expectations but Little Apprehension
abstract: Masahiro Tanaka, who will make his major league debut on Friday, went 24-0 in Japan last year and then signed a seven-year, $155 million contract with the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Masahiro Tanaka and his interpreter flew to Toronto on Thursday, heading into what is expected to be a scene of great anticipation and excitement.

headline: Sandy Grossman, Maestro of N.F.L. on TV, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Grossman was an Emmy-winning director of football broadcasts who worked with John Madden and Pat Summerall and orchestrated live shows from a production truck.
lead_paragraph: Sandy Grossman, who aspired to be a broadcaster but instead became an Emmy-winning director of N.F.L. games — most prominently those called by John Madden and Pat Summerall — died on Wednesday at his home in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 78.

headline: U.S. Says It Tried to Build a Social Media Site in Cuba, but Failed
abstract: The Obama administration insists that the effort to create a Twitter-like network was intended to encourage political discussion, not to foment rebellion.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration acknowledged Thursday that it had attempted, and failed, to build a Twitter-like social media site in Cuba, but insisted that it was part of the Agency for International Development’s effort to encourage political discussions, not a covert program to overthrow the government.

headline: Carole King Sees ‘Beautiful: The Carole King Musical’ for the First Time
abstract: After months of wondering whether Carole King would ever come to see the Broadway musical based on her life and comprised of her music, the singer/songwriter surprised the cast and crew by attending Thursday evening’s performance of the show.
lead_paragraph: She finally showed up.

headline: Election Rookie Is Struck, First, by Texas’ Size
abstract: A Railroad Commission candidate also gets an education in jockeying for attention, and how an odd name can either hurt or help a campaign.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Ringing Bells in Old Paris
keywords: ['Movies', 'Video Releases (Entertainment)', 'Blu-Ray Disc', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The silent “Hunchback of Notre Dame,” now in a Blu-ray from Flicker Alley, offers Lon Chaney in one of his most memorable performances.
lead_paragraph: The “cult of grandiosity” was a term coined by the art historian Arnold Hauser to describe the prose style of Victor Hugo and the taste of his Second Empire readership. It might also be applied to “The Hunchback of Notre Dame,” Universal’s 1923 version of Hugo’s “Notre-Dame de Paris,” which, newly released by Flicker Alley on DVD and Blu-ray, was among the most unusual superproductions of its day.

headline: Outsourcing Security as Bangalore’s Police Force Shrinks

lead_paragraph: BANGALORE — During the day, Vir Bahadur, 30, guards the entry gate of a small residential building in downtown Bangalore, from 8 in the morning until 6 in the evening, seven days a week.

abstract: A residential building of 40 apartments partially collapsed Friday morning in Fenghua city, eastern China, with 15 apartments reduced to rubble, according to the local government.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:40 p.m. |

headline: Brooklyn Boxer Rises, but Her Feet Stay on the Ground
abstract: After years of struggle, Heather Hardy is a rising force in professional boxing and has become a source of pride in Gerritsen Beach, a tightknit neighborhood devastated by Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Brooklyn Tough
abstract: Heather Hardy, 5 feet 5 inches of determination, began boxing in 2010 and is on a roll, undefeated after nine professional fights..
lead_paragraph: Heather Hardy, 5 feet 5 inches of determination, began boxing in 2010 and is on a roll, undefeated after nine professional fights..

headline: New Infielder and Closer Help Yankees to First Win
abstract: Yangervis Solarte had a memorable debut, collecting three hits, scoring twice and making a nice defensive play to help the Yankees to a 4-2 victory against the Astros.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — In the hours before the Yankees took the field for their series finale against the Houston Astros, Yangervis Solarte took his lineup card from player to player, asking teammates to sign it as a memento of his first major league start. With all the high-profile players the Yankees brought in for the 2014 season, little attention was paid to Solarte, who was signed as a minor league free agent in January and was invited to spring training.

headline: Roger Fessaguet, a Wizard of Haute Cuisine in New York, Dies at 82
abstract: Mr. Fessaguet, a chef whose influence extended beyond La Caravelle in Manhattan, was known for attracting A-list celebrities and presidents with his approach to classic French cuisine.
lead_paragraph: Roger Fessaguet, who presided over the exalted kitchen of the elegant Manhattan restaurant La Caravelle in the 1960s and ’70s, when it attracted A-list celebrities with classic French cuisine and Parisian ambience, died on Wednesday in Damariscotta, Me. He was 82.

headline: Long Island College Hospital Names Choice for the Future
abstract: Brooklyn Health Partners, a minority-owned business, met the demands of community and union groups by promising to keep the hospital operating with full service.
lead_paragraph: Brooklyn Health Partners, an organization formed specifically to bid for Long Island College Hospital, was chosen Thursday to buy it for $250 million.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Starz) THE LONE RANGER (2013) Armie Hammer, in the title role, portrays an idealistic government lawyer in a fantastical 1869 Texas who acquires a black mask and a white horse on his way to exacting revenge against the bandits who ambushed him and his brother (James Badge Dale). Johnny Depp (above left, with Mr. Hammer) plays Tonto, his Comanche sidekick, who gives him the name “kemo sabe” and informs him that he is now a “spirit walker” and cannot be killed in battle. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that “this very long, very busy” Disney movie, directed by Gore Verbinski and produced with Jerry Bruckheimer, “will unite the generations in bafflement, stupefaction and occasional delight,” noting that it “tries to do for the post-Civil War frontier what the ‘Pirates of the Caribbean’ franchise did for the high seas in the Age of Sail, turning history (including the history of movies) into a hyperactive, multipurpose amusement machine.” And as in those “Pirates” films, “Mr. Depp’s blend of gravity and goofiness saves the day, or at least alleviates the tedium, on several occasions,” he added.

headline: Sensors Are Dispatched in Search for Missing Jet
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Accidents and Safety', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Ships from Britain and Australia were deployed with technology that can detect pings from Malaysia Flight 370’s flight data recorders.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — A crucial stage in the four-week search for the missing Malaysia Airlines plane began on Friday as two military ships — one from Australia and the other from Britain — directed their sensor technology beneath the surface of the water and began the underwater phase of the hunt, hoping to pick up signs of wreckage lying at the bottom of the Indian Ocean.

headline: New Leader for Bills
abstract: The Buffalo Bills, who have had only one owner in their existence, Ralph Wilson, were taken over Thursday by his wife, Mary, less than two weeks after his death at age 95.
lead_paragraph: The Buffalo Bills, who have had only one owner in their existence, Ralph Wilson, were taken over Thursday by his wife, Mary, less than two weeks after his death at age 95. Team officials are working on a plan to sell the club, which began playing in 1960 as part of the American Football League, because Wilson’s heirs do not want to continue owning the franchise.

headline: Bratton and Sharpton Discuss Profiling Issue
abstract: Police Commissioner William J. Bratton met with the Rev. Al Sharpton to talk about profiling by police in retail stores, which has resulted in several lawsuits by black shoppers.
lead_paragraph: Police Commissioner William J. Bratton and the Rev. Al Sharpton met behind closed doors for an hour on Thursday, discussing allegations of profiling by the police in retail stores.

headline: Dr. Philip W. Brickner Dies at 85; Made House Calls to the Vulnerable
abstract: Dr. Brickner preached the virtues of home care, but his biggest accomplishment was helping to develop ways to treat people who do not have homes.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Philip W. Brickner, a doctor who made house calls, and in doing so recast an old-fashioned medical practice as cutting-edge, cost-effective health care for the elderly and the vulnerable, died on March 24 at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 85.

headline: South Korea Tests Missile Able to Strike Most of North
abstract: The launching by South Korea comes after Pyongyang conducted a series of its own missile tests, raising tensions on the Korean Peninsula.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Amid rising military threats from North Korea, South Korea conducted its own recent missile test, successfully launching a newly developed ballistic missile capable of striking most of North Korea, the South Korean Ministry of National Defense announced on Friday.

headline: More Women on Company Boards Reduces Fraud, Study Finds
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Gender', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: A study of securities fraud cases in China has found they were less likely to occur in companies where more women were on the board, leading the authors to recommend more gender diversity on boards around the world.
lead_paragraph: Having more women on company boards reduces fraud, according to a new study from China, which says “the optimal percentage of women on boards is 50 percent”  — higher than the average anywhere in the world.

headline: Faithful Rush to Protect Church With a Cross Deemed Too Tall
abstract: Thousands of Christians gathered in eastern China at their newly built church to guard it from a forced demolition ordered by government officials.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of Christians gathered for a second day Friday outside a large, new church in eastern China to protect the building from armed police sent by the local government to demolish it.

headline: Taking Time and Earning Trust
abstract: The shutter became a lot less heavy once Carolyn Van Houten realized she had earned the confidence of her subjects.
lead_paragraph: Carolyn Van Houten is a senior at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and is interning at The Herald newspaper in Jasper, Ind. Previously she interned at The Chicago Tribune and The Tampa Bay Times. Ms. Van Houten, 23, was born and raised in North Carolina and grew up on a horse farm. She is attending the New York Portfolio Review sponsored by The New York Times and the City University of New York Graduate School of Journalism this weekend. Her conversation with James Estrin has been edited.

headline: Should the United States Care That It’s Not No. 1?
abstract: Do you think measures like the Social Progress Index have any validity? Do they say something accurate about quality of life in the United States and other nations?
lead_paragraph: The United States has the most powerful military and the biggest economy in the world. Our movies and music are consumed across the globe. But at least according to one measure, the Social Progress Index, we come in 16th.

headline: Love, Envy and a Glass of Water
abstract: Michael Volle’s performance is the highlight of a revival of Otto Schenk’s 1983 production of “Arabella.”
lead_paragraph: A sumptuous if sleepy run of Strauss’s “Mandryka” began at the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday evening. Oh, wait, the opera’s called “Arabella,” you say? I hadn’t noticed, so engrossed was I by the German baritone Michael Volle, who made his Met debut with an assured, intelligent performance as Mandryka, a Croatian landowner desperately in love with a coquettish Viennese girl.

headline: New York Today: Floating Your Boat
abstract: What you need to know for Friday: the city’s boat launches open, dismal weather turning nice for the weekend, and a late-night farewell.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this drizzly Friday.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: What you need to know to start your day: job numbers are due, anger at Obama selfie, and the Afghan election back story.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: U.S. to Reassess Status of Talks on Middle East
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said he was flying home to Washington to meet with President Obama to reassess the peace negotiations, and whether there is a path forward.
lead_paragraph: RABAT, Morocco — With Israel and the Palestinians falling into a familiar cycle of tit-for-tat retribution, and a peace agreement more elusive than ever, Secretary of State John Kerry conceded on Friday that this week had been a “reality check” for the peace process.

headline: Bye-Bye, Baby
abstract: Birthrates are falling around the world. And that’s O.K.
lead_paragraph: NEARLY half of all people now live in countries where women, on average, give birth to fewer than 2.1 babies — the number generally required to replace both parents — over their lifetimes. This is true in Melbourne and Moscow, São Paulo and Seoul, Tehran and Tokyo. It is not limited to the West, or to rich countries; it is happening in places as diverse as Armenia, Bhutan, El Salvador, Poland and Qatar.

headline: China’s Poisonous Waterways
abstract: Polluted rivers and soaring cancer rates are far from uncommon in rural China.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Over the past few years, trips back to my home village, Huaihua Di, on the Lanxi River in Hunan Province, have been clouded by news of deaths — deaths of people I knew well. Some were still young, only in their 30s or 40s. When I returned to the village early last year, two people had just died, and a few others were dying.

headline: Daily Report: Nest Halts Sales of Smoke Detectors
abstract: Citing concerns that its smoke and carbon monoxide detector might be unintentionally turned off, Nest Labs is halting sales of the product and disabling a feature that allows users to turn it off with a wave.
lead_paragraph: Nest Labs, the home automation company recently acquired by Google for $3.2 billion, said on Thursday that it was halting sales of its smoke and carbon monoxide detector over safety concerns, Nick Wingfield reports.

headline: Pakistani Taliban Extend Cease-Fire After Government Releases Prisoners
abstract: The group said the extension was meant to let the Pakistani government show its intent on carrying peace talks forward.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani Taliban announced on Friday that they were extending a cease-fire until Thursday, after the release of a group of prisoners by the Pakistani government, to facilitate a fledgling peace process.

headline: Following Orders in Rwanda
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Tutsi Tribe', 'Hutu Tribe']
abstract: Rwandans must learn that it is all right to question leaders, and mandatory not to cooperate with evil.
lead_paragraph: ADA, Ohio — I met my client Pierre in a southern Rwandan prison in 1998. “The authorities ordered us to kill Tutsis,” he explained. It was, he was sure, a defense that could lighten his sentence.

headline: Marquis de Sade Manuscript Returns to France
abstract: After decades of legal contortions and disputes over ownership, it has returned home and will be put on public display in September to mark the bicentenary of the Marquis de Sade’s death.
lead_paragraph: PARIS – “The 120 Days of Sodom,” by the Marquis de Sade, is one of the most perverse works of 18th-century literature. It is also considered a national cultural treasure of France.

headline: Protecting Hong Kong’s Autonomy
keywords: ['Elections', 'Freedom of the Press', 'United States International Relations', 'Editorials']
abstract: Britain needs to speak out against threats to press freedoms and open elections.
lead_paragraph: In 1997, when Britain returned Hong Kong to China, the United States stressed the need to ensure that the semiautonomous city would maintain a vigorous rule of law and a free market. “We will be watching it very closely,” Secretary of State Madeleine Albright said then. Some 17 years later, such vigilance is as important as ever given growing concerns about press freedoms as well as interference from China in Hong Kong’s internal affairs.

headline: Meda, a Swedish Drug Maker, Rejects Takeover Offer
abstract: The Swedish drug maker Meda said Friday that it rejected a takeover offer from the generic pharmaceutical company Mylan. A merger would have allowed Mylan to get tax benefits from being reincorporated abroad.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:58 a.m. | LONDON – The Swedish drug maker Meda said Friday that it rejected a takeover offer from the generic pharmaceutical company Mylan.

abstract: As Russia claimed the region of Crimea, editors in the Times newsroom discussed what to do about the datelines.
lead_paragraph: Philip B. Corbett, the associate managing editor for standards, oversees The Times’s manual of style and usage.

abstract: Steven Myers, who has covered the Kremlin for many years, wrote about the nuances of reporting on President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
lead_paragraph: Steven Lee Myers returned to Moscow last summer as acting bureau chief, having previously worked there from 2002 to 2007.

keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'News and News Media']

lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — For the two seasoned war correspondents, it was not an unusually risky trip. Getting out to see Afghanistan up close was what Anja Niedringhaus, a Pulitzer Prize-winning photographer for The Associated Press, and Kathy Gannon, a veteran reporter for the news agency, did best.

lead_paragraph: Updated, 2:56 p.m. |

headline: Euphemistic At The IMF
abstract: The World Economic Outlook needs subtitles.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the financial crisis struck, we’ve suffered grievously from the tyranny of respectable opinion. As I’ve often argued, the problem with our inadequate and often perverse response to mass unemployment isn’t that we lack a workable economic framework; basic IS-LMish macroeconomics has, in fact, provided quite good guidance.The problem, instead, has been that following economic logic has been deemed unserious. Serious people want balanced budgets and price stability, never mind what the textbooks say. This has among other things led to the peculiar result that respectable people grab on to academic papers that present dubious nonstandard results — expansionary austerity! A debt cliff at 90 percent! — while radicals like me are the ones citing Econ 101.

headline: A Big Rush for I.P.O.s
abstract: The market for initial public offerings has reached levels not seen in the United States in years. | Steven A. Cohen’s minder has been selected. | One of Citigroup’s stalwarts will lead the bank’s preparations for the Fed stress test over the next year. | The chief executive of Mozilla has resigned.
lead_paragraph: BIG RUSH FOR I.P.O.S  |  Since 1999, the stock market has waxed and waned, but the business of initial public offerings is bustling once again, Michael J. de la Merced writes in DealBook. GrubHub, an online food-ordering company, and IMS Health, a big provider of prescription data, are just two of the latest companies hoping to seize upon investor demand for new stock offerings. At the same time, they are hoping to avoid the stumbles that have plagued a few high-profile issuers in recent weeks, including King Digital Entertainment, the maker of Candy Crush Saga.

headline: Readers Object to Times’s Portrayal of Palestinian Role in Impasse
abstract: The foreign editor argued that coverage has been generally “comprehensive and fair.”
lead_paragraph: David L. Mandel of Sacramento was one of many readers who wrote to object to an article in Wednesday’s Times on the breakdown in peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians. Like many others, he found the headline misleading and the article itself lacking in context.

headline: Hiring Rises, but Number of Jobless Stays High
abstract: Better weather encouraged employers to begin hiring workers more aggressively in March, adding 192,000 to payrolls. The jobless rate remained flat 6.7 percent.
lead_paragraph: Employers are hiring at a more aggressive pace again after a winter cold snap, but the pace of job gains is only slowly making up for years of lost ground in the labor market.

headline: Moelis & Co. Seeks More Than $211 Million in I.P.O.
abstract: The firm said in a revised prospectus that it planned to price its stock sale at $26 to $29 a share. At the midpoint of that range, the advisory concern would be valued at about $1.4 billion.
lead_paragraph: Moelis & Company, the boutique investment bank, disclosed on Friday that it was seeking to raise more than $211 million in its coming initial public offering.

headline: Congress Member Defects, but Party Can’t Get Rid of Him
abstract: A Congress candidate who joined the opposition Bharatiya Janata Party did so after candidacy filing deadlines, so the party he abandoned cannot take him off the ticket and the party he joined cannot give him a fresh one.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Ramesh Tomar has the questionable distinction of being a parliamentary candidate who is an enthusiastic member of the Bharatiya Janata Party but whose name will appear on voting machines next to the open-palm symbol that belongs to its main rival, the Indian National Congress party.

headline: An Exclusive Education on the Making of Brioni’s Suits
abstract: The 69-year-old Italian clothier opens the doors to its tailoring and knitwear workshops in Italy.
lead_paragraph: Brioni opened its first shop in Rome in 1945. And today, despite the rise of casual sportswear and the brand’s acquisition by the Kering Group in 2011, the pre-eminent Italian men’s wear label continues on in the same tradition with which it began: creating everything in-house, without outsourcing a single step of production. “That something so traditional can still seem so relevant and contemporary, and entirely made in Italy, is truly rare in this business,” says the company’s creative director, Brendan Mullane. Case in point: several Brioni suits from the company’s archives will appear in London at the Victoria and Albert Museum, in the exhibition “The Glamour of Italian Fashion: 1945-2014,” which opens this Saturday.

headline: Amazon Channels a Cheaper Television Experience
abstract: To make its set-top box viable, Amazon will have to spend a lot of money. That’s something it’s never been afraid of doing.
lead_paragraph: After I wrote my article on Wednesday about Amazon’s new Fire TV set-top box, I received an email from a reader that summed up the retailer’s challenge — and opportunity.

headline: It’s Still Bad for the Long-Term Unemployed
abstract: The evidence remains that the so-so recovery is not enough to help the long-term jobless.
lead_paragraph: At first blush, it’s great news. The number of long-term unemployed Americans – meaning those out of a job for more than six months – has dropped to 3.7 million in March from a high of 6.8 million in April 2010. The ranks of the long-term jobless have plummeted by 837,000 over the past year alone, helping to drive down the unemployment rate.

headline: ‘Real Unemployment’ Rate Points in the Wrong Direction
abstract: The broader measure of unemployment, U6, still points to keeping easy money in place for quite some time.
lead_paragraph: The unemployment rate number people talk about and analyze every time the new jobs numbers come out — such as the 6.7 percent rate reported Friday morning — is not the “real” unemployment rate. And some policymakers are among them — which makes one line in particular in the report more interesting and important than usual.

headline: Most Details in Jobs Report Are Positive
abstract: The trend toward a rising labor force in 2014 suggests that America is finally getting back to work.
lead_paragraph: The unemployment rate was unchanged in March. But it was the best possible variety of unchanged.

headline: Teenagers in The Times | March 2014
abstract: The latest monthly collection of articles about young people published in The Times.
lead_paragraph: Every month we collect all the articles in The Times about young people and publish them in one handy place. We also offer a lesson plan for teaching with the collection.

headline: What They Said: Death Penalty Imposed in Mumbai Gang Rapes
abstract: The death sentences handed down to three men convicted of raping two women last year have drawn a range of reactions, from jubilation to skepticism.
lead_paragraph: A Mumbai court on Friday sentenced to death three men convicted of two separate instances of gang rape, invoking for the first time a section of the Indian Penal Code that allows the death penalty for repeat rapists even without the death of a victim.

headline: Still Needed: Millions of Jobs
abstract: A look at some of the categories of the unemployed and how they may fare.
lead_paragraph: Imagine for a moment that the federal government wanted to maximize employment – wanted to make sure as many people as possible had jobs.

headline: Obama Mourns Fort Hood Shooting Victims
abstract: President Obama, speaking at an East Room event, said the country mourned with the families who lost loved ones in the recent Fort Hood shooting.
lead_paragraph: President Obama, speaking at an East Room event, said the country mourned with the families who lost loved ones in the recent Fort Hood shooting.

headline: After Six Years, a Full (Private-Sector) Recovery
abstract: The number of private-sector jobs has risen to a record high.
lead_paragraph: Today’s job reports for March finds there were 116,087,000 private-sector jobs. That figure is 110,000 higher than the 115,977,000 employed in January 2008, the previous peak.

headline: Inside a Maine Prison
abstract: Joseph Ponte, New York’s newly appointed corrections commissioner who starts his new position on Monday, spent the last three years in Maine remaking the state’s corrections system.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Ponte, New York’s newly appointed corrections commissioner who starts his new position on Monday, spent the last three years in Maine remaking the state’s corrections system.

headline: An Ex-President, Brush in Hand, Captures His Fellow Leaders
abstract: The world’s most distinctive gallery of world leaders, the work of George W. Bush, who took up painting after he left office, opens in Dallas on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: A dour Vladimir V. Putin glares ever so frostily, full of menace, free of mirth, ready to annex any passer-by unwise enough to get too close.

headline: In South Carolina, Celebrating God’s Own Woolly Mammoth
abstract: A bill to underline an official state fossil ran into some trouble.
lead_paragraph: State legislatures have moved at their own slow-but-sure evolutionary pace in designating official state fossils, just as they adopt signature flowers and animals. For all the statehouse flirtation with creationism, 43 states have dared to proclaim official fossils — the Triceratops in South Dakota, the saber-toothed cat in California, the duck-billed dinosaur in Montana. It seemed appropriate that South Carolina would finally join the march forward with an extinct creature called the Columbian woolly mammoth, since it was the site of one of the earliest North American digs to uncover ancient mammoth tooth fossils, in 1725.A bill to underline the state’s pride in its ancient resident moved quickly with the House’s blessing. But then Senator Kevin Bryant proposed an amendment rooted in the Book of Genesis, imputing God as the creator of the woolly mammoth: “And God made the beast of the earth after his kind, the cattle after their kind, and everything that creepeth upon the earth after his kind: and God saw that it was good.” The senator stirred up a familiar debate between firm believers in evolution and those who insist it should be devalued and taught as a “pro and con” theory.

headline: GrubHub Soars in Market Debut; Other New Listings Rise, Too
abstract: Shares of GrubHub opened at $40 each in their market debut on Friday, rising nearly 54 percent above their I.P.O. price. IMS Health and Opower also enjoyed a pop in their first trades.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:39 p.m. | Over the last few days, GrubHub raised the price range for its initial public offering, increased the number of shares it planned to sell and, finally, priced its stock sale above expectations.

headline: Just Graduated, and Fumbling Through a First Job
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Youth', 'Personal Finances', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Workplace Environment', 'Careers and Professions']
abstract: Few people can look at their first few jobs without cringing — or at least smiling wryly — at the many missteps, but there are lessons there.
lead_paragraph: TARA GOODFELLOW shudders when she remembers how she acted at her first job out of college. She once chased a 50-year-old colleague up the stairs to get to their boss first to explain her side of a story. She impulsively quit her job over the phone.

headline: Queens Shops Get Financial Lift by Storing Cellphones for Students
abstract: The businesses charge a small fee, but still make money from teenagers who pick up their phones and then purchase goods.
lead_paragraph: New York City prohibits students from carrying cellphones in public schools, but many are reluctant to leave their phones behind. As a result, the rule has created a modest side business for shops near some schools that allow students to store their phones for a fee.

headline: ‘Jesus Christ Superstar’ to Return for Arena Tour
abstract: A new production touring North America this summer will include Ben Forster as Jesus, Brandon Boyd as Judas Iscariot and John Lydon as King Herod.
lead_paragraph: Hosanna hey or hosanna huh? “Jesus Christ Superstar,” Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice’s musical about the final days of Jesus, will soon rise again, this time as a arena show that will feature an eclectic roster of rock and pop artists and will tour North America starting in June.

headline: Equivalences
abstract: The just-likers of the right.
lead_paragraph: There are definitely times when it seems that our winner-take-all society is also a whiner-take-all society; it’s really amazing how quick billionaires are to portray themselves as victims because some people say nasty things about them. One remarkable aspect of this whining is that the nasty things aren’t really all that nasty. Saying that the Koch brothers are using their wealth to promote a political agenda that will make them even wealthier is a substantive claim, not character assassination; it’s not at all the same as, say, suggesting that Hillary Clinton is a murderer. Yet the Kochs and Perkinses act as if this kind of thing were utterly vile, an attack on their liberty.

headline: Today in Small Business: Gay Rights in the Workplace
abstract: The case against Yelp. Lessons from a fish restaurant. And how business owners can spend their cash.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Going Back to School, Without the Pressure
keywords: ['Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Personal Finances', 'Retirement', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Elderly']
abstract: Residences near or on college campuses offer courses and culture for older adults.
lead_paragraph: ARLENE AND LARRY DUNN, both music aficionados, had always been fans of two ensembles at the Oberlin College Conservatory of Music. So, the Dunns put the retirement community Kendal at Oberlin on the top of their list after they began looking for a new home. In addition to having a rich cultural life, the Dunns could audit Oberlin’s classes free and attend lectures. Last year, the Dunns sold their home in rural LaCrosse, Ind., and moved to the college community in neighboring Ohio.

headline: Bad-Girl Pop Idol Is All Heart
abstract: An emotional Miley Cyrus flaunted her body and her success at the Izod Center, but also sought solace after the death of her beloved dog, Floyd, this week.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Miley Cyrus moved through the paces of her “Bangerz” tour when it played the Izod Center here on Thursday night. She danced with furry animals and twerking showgirls. She grinned through drug references and curse words. She sang about feeling sexy; she sang about dumping a guy who cheated. She splayed her legs and grabbed her crotch. And she juggled visual and musical elements of hip-hop, pop and country, as if they were all the same to her, as they may well be. But few people expected the tears.

headline: At Moelis & Co., Founder Will Have 97% of Votes
abstract: The company acknowledged how reliant it was on Kenneth D. Moelis, but a corporate governance expert said a structure that allowed cashing out yet keeping control was like “having your cake and eating it, too.”
lead_paragraph: Updated, 2:15 p.m. | When Kenneth D. Moelis moved last month to take his investment bank public, it was clear that he would exert a considerable degree of control over the company he founded.

headline: The Joads Turn 75
abstract: This month marks the 75th anniversary of the publication of John Steinbeck’s “The Grapes of Wrath,” one of the most decorated novels ever written by an American.
lead_paragraph: This month marks the 75th anniversary of the publication of “The Grapes of Wrath,” John Steinbeck’s novel about the Joad family and its grueling relocation from Oklahoma to California. The book is one of the most decorated ever written by an American. It won the National Book Award and the Pulitzer Prize, played a significant role in earning Steinbeck a Nobel Prize in 1962, inspired songs by Woody Guthrie and Bruce Springsteen, and has weighed down the backpacks of millions of high school students over the years.

headline: Illuminations
abstract: Stories that investigate the strange, the mundane and the profound, with thoughts on Flaubert, housekeeping and roosters.
lead_paragraph: Some writers have the uncanny ability to slant your experiences. Read enough Lydia Davis and her stories start happening to you.

headline: More Good Obamacare News
abstract: Uninsurance is dropping fast.
lead_paragraph: Until just the other day, Obamacare was a total disaster; no way would it meet its first-year enrollment targets, or come anywhere close.

headline: Narrative Adventure
abstract: New books by Neil Swidey, Wil S. Hylton and Peter Stark.
lead_paragraph: TRAPPED UNDER THE SEA  One Engineering Marvel, Five Men, and a Disaster Ten Miles Into the Darkness  By Neil Swidey  Crown, $26.

headline: Bookshelf: Newfound Friends
abstract: New picture books include “Stella’s Starliner,” by Rosemary Wells, about a little fox and her shiny Airstream trailer.
lead_paragraph: New picture books include “Stella’s Starliner,” by Rosemary Wells, about a little fox and her shiny Airstream trailer.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘The Unknown Known,’ ‘Captain America: The Winter Soldier’ and ‘Under the Skin’
abstract: The New York Times film critics on “The Unknown Known,” “Captain America: The Winter Soldier” and “Under the Skin.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “The Unknown Known,” “Captain America: The Winter Soldier” and “Under the Skin.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Liar’s Luck
abstract: A crooked lawyer on the run plays the tables in Macau and Hong Kong.
lead_paragraph: Damn. Another writer I have to care about. After a certain age, it’s as irksome to add to the list of writers one reads as it is to add to one’s circle of friends. For most of his career, Lawrence Osborne gave the impression of being someone I could safely ignore. He wrote a novel in his youth that went the way of most first novels before carving out a career as a travel writer and wine connoisseur, but then in his 50s something jolted him into writing another novel, “The Forgiven,” about Westerners partying on the edge of the North African desert, which turned out to be dark, brilliant and about as ­ignorable as a ­switchblade.

headline: Suddenly That Summer
abstract: Linn Ullmann’s family novel is set in motion by a nanny’s murder.
lead_paragraph: Although a vicious crime serves as the grain of sand around which this pearl of a novel is formed, Linn Ullmann’s “The Cold Song” is not a crime story. Little concerned with villain, motives or detection of evidence, it doesn’t aim for a solution, for redemption or justice. And with a first chapter that begins, “Milla, or what was left of her, was found by Simen and two of his friends when they were digging for buried treasure in the woods,” it hardly seeks to maintain suspense about the identity or fate of the victim. Yet the novel — Ullmann’s fifth, translated from Norwegian by Barbara J. Haveland — is steeped in dread the way a fruitcake is steeped in rum: ­Every page, every line, seems to glisten with vapors of sumptuous, intoxicating unease.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Arabella’
abstract: The soprano Malin Bystrom sings “Mein Elemer!” from Act I of Arabella. Conducted by Philippe Auguin.
lead_paragraph: The soprano Malin Bystrom sings “Mein Elemer!” from Act I of Arabella. Conducted by Philippe Auguin.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: In “Thrive,” which is No. 1 on the hardcover nonfiction list, Arianna Huffington offers a technocratic version of the old work-life equation, swathed in New Age incense.
lead_paragraph: Triple Threat: It’s tempting to be cynical, I know, when you come across another book by a rich and powerful person avowing that power and riches are, like, totally overrated and happiness is all that matters. And when that rich and powerful person is Arianna Huffington — whose media empire, The Huffington Post, is famous among other things for encouraging writers to work without pay — well, cynicism becomes downright unavoidable. (At least her message is consistent: Why pay contributors if money corrupts?) Huffington’s new book, “Thrive,” enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 1, arguing that our obsession with wealth and status obscures the importance of mental well-being as the “third metric” of success. Basically, it’s a technocratic version of the old work-life equation, swathed in New Age incense: “Our breath,” Huffington declares early on, “also has a sacredness about it.” None of this means the book doesn’t make good points along the way, advising readers to sleep longer, take more walks and disengage every now and then from the digital world — including, presumably, from The Huffington Post. When Huffington appeared on “The Daily Show” recently, Jon Stewart seemed unsure what to make of her new persona. “I swear,” he said, “you’re like William Randolph Hearst and Martha Stewart and Oprah, all rolled together now. And I don’t know what the hell is going on.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE BLAZING WORLD,  by Siri Hustvedt. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) Hustvedt’s multifaceted novel is a portrait of a creative titan whose career and reputation have seemingly been blighted by the art establishment’s ingrained sexism.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: HERE AND NOW: Letters 2008-2011,  by Paul Auster and J. M. Coetzee. (Penguin, $16.) After meeting at a literary festival in 2008, the novelists Paul Auster and J. M. Coetzee began exchanging letters as a way to “strike sparks off each other.” Their collected correspondence, between Auster’s home in Brooklyn and Coetzee’s across the world in Australia, touches on family, travel, various books and films. But they also pose topics for discussion, from sports to philosophy to international politics.

headline: De Blasio Setting Up a Test: Prison Reformer vs. Rikers Island
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Solitary Confinement']
abstract: Joseph Ponte, the newly appointed correction commissioner, will be up against one of the country’s toughest city jails and one of the most powerful union leaders in the state.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Ponte, New York’s newly appointed correction commissioner, and his wife were visiting the city two weeks ago, and while she went apartment hunting, he had a few hours free. He dropped by Rikers Island to have a look at the jail block where a mentally ill inmate died this year, left unattended in a stiflingly hot cell.

headline: New Girl in Town
abstract: The plucky heroine of this middle-grade novel wants to stay put after yet another move, this one to a magical place.
lead_paragraph: As any young bookworm knows, the library shelves are crammed with beloved characters whose lives have been vastly improved — if not saved — by words. Consider Harriet the Spy, who made sense of the world in her green composition notebook long before journals earned their own verb; or Matilda Wormwood, who sailed away from the sinking ship of her family on a life raft made of stories. Even Wilbur found salvation through two words — Some Pig — woven into the web of a wise spider.

headline: Taking the Helm
abstract: A 13-year-old boy growing up on Narragansett Bay tries to save his family in this young adult novel.
lead_paragraph: “Swim That Rock,” an affable coming-of-age novel by Jay Primiano and John Rocco, is bookended by pencil drawings ostensibly made by Jake Cole, the book’s 14-year-old narrator. The opening spread (in fact drawn by Rocco, a noted children’s book illustrator) features maps of the story’s setting — Rhode Island’s Narragansett Bay and Upper Bay Tributaries. Their style and annotations call to mind Christopher Robin’s whimsical map inside the front cover of A. A. Milne’s “Winnie-the-Pooh.” In place of the “100 Aker Wood,” Jake gives us “100 Acre Cove”; instead of “Where the ­Woozle Wasn’t,” he marks the spot where he “caught 17 stripers with Captain.”

headline: Back From the Future
abstract: A teenager from a different time must defy the strict rules of her community to try to avert world disaster.
lead_paragraph: Ann Brashares’s newest young adult novel, “The Here and Now,” is a marked departure from her best-selling Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants series, which followed four best friends as they came of age. “The Here and Now” faces the challenge of taking similarly familiar, contemporary voices and recasting them in a fast-paced work of dystopian speculative fiction.

headline: Stories of Resistance and Escape
abstract: Three books look at the experiences of Jews in hiding during the Holocaust, and at the people who sheltered them.
lead_paragraph: My Jewish great-grandparents made the fortunate decision to leave Europe in the first decade of the 20th century, so my closest personal connection to the Holocaust was through my high school French teacher, Annette Berman. Annette was a 15-year-old Jewish schoolgirl living in Paris when World War II began. As restrictions and fear mounted during the German occupation, she and her family hid for weeks in her best friend’s apartment; then, using borrowed identity cards, they traveled to a remote village where Annette spent the next two years disguised as a Roman Catholic, delivering messages and explosives for the French Resistance on her bicycle. Reading the heart-­stopping journeys of the child survivors in “Hidden,” “Hidden Like Anne Frank” and “The Whispering Town” drove home to me that Annette’s incredible story is far from unique.

headline: Leftward Shift by Conservative Cleric Leaves Saudis Perplexed
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Salman al-Awda, who won fame for his hard-line views, speaks up for democracy and amplifies his voice with social media.
lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — When this country’s ultraconservative clerics make news, it is often for embarrassing reasons: unleashing fatwas against soap operas, for instance, or declaring Mickey Mouse to be a “soldier of Satan.”

headline: The Pursuit of Happiness
abstract: A historian considers the social meaning of fun as a form of resistance for ordinary people.
lead_paragraph: The key to this spirited and challenging book is in its subtitle: “joyous revolt.” The revolt depicted in “American Fun” derives from John Beckman’s somewhat narrow definition of what constitutes fun. For his purposes, it requires active, spontaneous and unscripted participation, not passive amusement or entertainment contrived by the vaudeville circuit’s B. F. Keith or by Walt Disney.

headline: Sticky Fingers
abstract: Donna Leon’s “By Its Cover” appears to have been inspired by a systematic sacking of thousands of rare books that came to light in 2012.
lead_paragraph: Whenever some fresh instance of blatant corruption or rank depravity comes to light in Italy (toxic waste in agricultural Campania, political scandal in Lombardia, a proposal to build an ugly skyscraper in Mestre), Commissario Guido Brunetti, the principled protagonist of Donna Leon’s uplifting Venetian mysteries, looks to his family and to the wise philosophers of ancient Rome to restore his faith in humanity. Leon tends to console herself by writing a new book. BY ITS COVER (Atlantic Monthly, $26), which finds the author in a fury over vandalism and theft in national libraries, museums and churches, appears to have been inspired by the looting of Naples’s Girolamini Library by its director, a systematic sacking of thousands of rare books that came to light in 2012. (“It would make a stone weep,” according to one of Brunetti’s colleagues.) Although the criminal damage done at the venerable Biblioteca Merula is on a far more modest scale, it’s no less heartbreaking to the library director, as well as to the commissario. It’s also a great mystery. How was the damage done when the only patrons of this obscure library are innocuous scholars like Joseph Nickerson, an American academic researching maritime and Mediterranean trade history, and an ex-priest affectionately known as Tertullian for his obsessive study of the writings of the Church Fathers? The melancholy tone of the storytelling suits the narrative, especially when the ex-priest is found savagely murdered.

headline: The Devil’s Woods
abstract: In this debut novel, a teenager contemplates ridding a logging town of a brute.
lead_paragraph: It’s tempting to say that “A Man Came Out of a Door in the Mountain,” the first novel by Adrianne Harun, is set in a “dead-end town” — indeed the book’s publicity copy employs the phrase. It’s useful shorthand, invoking a familiar image. The trouble with it is the fact that Harun, the author of a story collection, “The King of Limbo,” is not one bit interested in the familiar. Her nameless British Columbia logging outpost makes the dead-end town look benign and cozy, a cousin of the cul-de-sac.

headline: Never Hurts to Ask
abstract: Essays on pain, both physical and emotional, and how it affects our relationships with one another and with ourselves.
lead_paragraph: Regarding the pain of others requires more than just a pair of eyes. It necessitates an act of the imagination: a willingness to think or feel oneself into the interior of another’s experience, to cross between what Susan Sontag once designated as the kingdoms of the sick and of the well. This kind of empathetic border crossing can be both difficult and dangerous, the sort of journey of which one might say: “I get across quickly because I’m headed in the right direction, by which I mean the wrong direction. I’m going where no one wants to stay.”

headline: Balkan Son
abstract: A memoir of returning to Bosnia years after fleeing the war-ravaged land.
lead_paragraph: Between 1992 and 1995, a war savaged the country that was once known as Yugoslavia. Violence and destruction ripped through the fabric of the society, tearing apart families, eliminating villages and laying waste to the innocence of children.

headline: Small World
abstract: Lives on the Upper West Side are closely intertwined in this domestic novel.
lead_paragraph: The facade of a classic prewar New York City apartment building — the opening image of Tova Mirvis’s third novel, “Visible City” — presents a plain-spoken metaphor for human acquaintance. Meeting a stranger, you may walk past without interest or, intrigued by a glimpse of color or movement, strive to see more and deeper, beyond the mannerly surface. Unlike those riskier “rear window” views, streetfront views shed light primarily on the most predictable of daytime activities. Peer long enough, however, and you might witness something more private.

headline: As Strike Winds Down, Lufthansa Plans a Return to Nearly Normal Service
abstract: The airline said most flights would operate this weekend, after a three-day strike, although there was no sign the company and the pilots were closer to resolving their dispute.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Lufthansa said Friday that it expected to resume nearly normal flight operations on Saturday after the end of a three-day strike by pilots, but there was no sign that the two sides were any closer to resolving the dispute that had led to the work stoppage.

headline: Fashion Memo | True Colors
abstract: Bright shades break up the monotony of black and white in these accessories.
lead_paragraph: Childishly bright primary colors are making a play for most popular.

headline: A Doubter in the Holy Land
abstract: Would I hear the calling that my mother heard?
lead_paragraph: A friend and I were beginning that strange dance of making plans to make plans, when I mentioned that I’d be traveling to Jerusalem soon. “We should get together right away,” he joked, “before you come down with Messiah syndrome.” It was the kind of precision-targeted crack only an old friend can manage. I can’t remember whether I laughed or winced first.

headline: The Selfish Selfie
abstract: Exploiting Rob Ford; hogging the road.
lead_paragraph: It seems that Rob Ford, the mayor of Toronto, poses for photos with anyone who asks for one. I believe that many who pose with him are not supporters; they’re indulging in the opportunity to have a souvenir of themselves rubbing shoulders with his notoriety. Is it unethical to have your photograph taken with someone you fundamentally disapprove of for your own less-than-noble reasons? C.H., TORONTO

headline: Denis Leary on Ice
abstract: Even bovines need friends; Bravo-lebrities; the meaning of “buychology.”
lead_paragraph: Even bovines need friends; Bravo-lebrities; the meaning of “buychology.”

headline: Portraits of Reconciliation
keywords: ['Hutu Tribe', 'Tutsi Tribe', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: 20 years after the genocide in Rwanda, these perpetrators and survivors are standing for forgiveness.
lead_paragraph: 20 years after the genocide in Rwanda, these perpetrators and survivors are standing for forgiveness.

headline: Rob Lowe on the Problems With Being Pretty
abstract: The actor discusses aging into the good roles and cashing in on his scandalous legacy.
lead_paragraph: Your second memoir, “Love Life,” is out this month. Did you lose any friends over your first book? No, and honestly I didn’t expect to. If you’re telling a story, and somebody is going to come out badly, it better be you.

headline: The Pernicious Rise of Poptimism
abstract: In an effort to undo the errors of its past, music criticism has gone soft.
lead_paragraph: Not too long ago, I completed the annual music geek’s ritual of filling out my ballot for The Village Voice’s vaunted Pazz & Jop poll. During the past 40 years, The Voice has surveyed critics on their favorite albums and singles in an effort to create something approaching a consensus. In scrambling to put together a Top 10 list that I could live with, I poked through my iTunes playlists, looked at other critics’ 10-bests (it’s allowed!) and flipped through essays by everyone from The New Yorker’s Sasha Frere-Jones to the tastemakers at Pitchfork. My survey of 2013’s critical landscape only reinforced something I’ve suspected for some time now: Music criticism has gotten really weird.

headline: Reply All: The 3.23.14 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: THE SCIENTIFIC QUEST TO PROVE BISEXUALITY EXISTS

headline: Who Made That Black Box?
abstract: And let’s get one thing clear: It is actually orange.
lead_paragraph: Let’s get one thing clear: The “black box” isn’t black. It’s orange. Before airlines made that color standard for their flight recorders, some Boeings used a yellow sphere, and the British had a gizmo called the Red Egg. So why do they call it “black”? One explanation goes this way: In 1939, an aviation engineer named François Hussenot devised a means of capturing an aircraft’s history to a box of photographic film. Onboard sensors flashed into the box through calibrated mirrors and traced a running tab of flight parameters, including altitude, air speed and the position of the cockpit controls. Because the device worked like a camera, its insides had to be in total darkness; thus, perhaps, the “black"-ness of the box.

headline: Jindalcare and the G.O.P. Dilemma
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Law and Legislation', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Republican health care reform in the shadow of a more stable Obamacare
lead_paragraph: On Monday, I wrote that the apparent stabilization of Obamacare sharpens the political and policy challenge facing the law’s critics. Instead of the sort of easy unraveling that some Republicans had convinced themselves was in the offing, I argued (in a point made rather more forcefully by Ramesh Ponnuru) that it’s now much more likely that the only way the things conservatives dislike about Obamacare will ever change or go away is if conservatives actually unite around reforms or a replacement that sustains some of the current law’s coverage expansion (albeit on significantly different terms).

headline: Swiss Climber’s Feat Honored Despite Lack of Proof
abstract: Ueli Steck climbed the 26,545-foot Annapurna last year on his own. He has been awarded the Piolet d’Or, mountaineering’s highest honor.
lead_paragraph: CHAMONIX, France — After 20 hours of climbing alone, navigating an 8,000-foot ice wall and surviving an avalanche that nearly knocked him off the mountain, Ueli Steck of Switzerland reached the summit of the south face of Nepal’s 26,545-foot Annapurna last Oct. 9. Eight hours later, he walked into the base camp.

headline: Appealing to a College for More Financial Aid
abstract: Some strategies can help win more money for your child, but it depends on the institution.
lead_paragraph: The era of the financial aid appeal has arrived in full, and April is the month when much of the action happens.

headline: The Good News in the Jobs Report — Sort Of
abstract: In terms of jobs, we’re not just trying to get back to where we were before the bottom dropped out. We’re trying to get back to where we would have been.
lead_paragraph: We’ve recovered! The country now has more private sector jobs than it did before the recession, surpassing its previous peak. That was in January 2008, when there were 115,977,000 jobs, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics’ survey of businesses. Last month, the bureau announced Friday morning, there were 116,087,000. High fives all around.

headline: Blackstone to Buy Industrial Manufacturer for $5.4 Billion
abstract: The leveraged buyout, announced Friday afternoon,  is Blackstone’s biggest since 2007, when it bought Hilton Worldwide Holdings for $26 billion.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:14 p.m. |The Blackstone Group has agreed to acquire industrial manufacturer Gates Corporation for $5.4 billion.

headline: 3 in India Sentenced to Death for 2 Rapes
abstract: The three men were sentenced under the strict provisions of a new law in India that has caused unease even among some women’s advocates.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — Three men convicted of participating in the gang rape of a Mumbai photojournalist last year were sentenced to death on Friday under the strict provisions of a new rape law that has begun to cause unease among some women’s rights advocates.

headline: Back to the Jersey Shore
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Coastal Areas', 'Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Summer (Season)']
abstract: The forecast for summer at the Jersey Shore is busy. Properties are selling and winter-weary renters are making reservations.
lead_paragraph: With beaches replenished, boardwalks rebuilt and stores reopened, the Jersey Shore is gearing up for a summer busy enough to make last year’s anemic one a distant memory.

headline: Time to Reduce Repo Run Risk
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: Banks remain vulnerable to sudden runs because of their dependence on short-term borrowing, but Dodd-Frank contains many tools that regulators can use to reduce risk, contends Jennifer Taub in Another View.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Taub is an associate professor at Vermont Law School. Her book “Other People’s Houses” (Yale University Press) will be published in May.
