headline: Expanded Tacoma Art Museum to Open in November
abstract: The new 16,000 square-foot addition, called the Haub Family Galleries, will house approximately 300 Western American paintings.
lead_paragraph: The Tacoma Art Museum will unveil its new 16,000 square-foot addition to the public on Sunday, Nov. 16. The extension, called the Haub Family Galleries, will house approximately 300 Western American paintings donated by Erivan and Helga Haub in 2012. The collection includes depictions of cowboys and Native Americans, landscapes and historical themes by established artists including Frederic Remington and Georgia O’Keeffe, as well as contemporary Native American artists like William Acheff and Kevin Red Star. The expansion, design by Olson Kundig Architects, will include redone lobby, a sculpture hall and renovated outdoor plaza.

headline: Davis McCallum to Be Artistic Director of Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival
abstract: Mr. McCallum’s background includes a good deal of Shakespeare. He’ll take up his new position immediately.
lead_paragraph: The Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival, in Garrison, N.Y., has appointed the director Davis McCallum as its new artistic director, the company announced on Friday. He succeeds Terry O’Brien, who founded the festival in 1987, and who stepped down last fall, after the company’s 27th season. Mr. McCallum takes up his new position immediately, but is not directing at the festival this summer. A spokeswoman said that it was too soon to say when, and what, his first production for the company would be.

headline: Sure, Build It in My Backyard
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Nikolai Fedak, 23, runs New York Yimby, a website that both charts and cheers development.
lead_paragraph: In a city that is knee-deep in preservationists willing to do almost anything to keep new construction from erasing the past, it might seem surprising to find a young man who has made a career out of promoting the new. But Nikolai Fedak, the creator and mastermind of New York Yimby, a pro-development blog turned website, does not find this strange at all.

headline: Stones Schedule Return to Australia and New Zealand
abstract: The band will return in October and November, but specific dates have not yet been announced.
lead_paragraph: The Rolling Stones have made good on their promise to reschedule the seven shows in Australia and New Zealand that were canceled after the death of the fashion designer L’Wren Scott on March 17 – more or less. The group announced on its website on Thursday that it had rescheduled its Australia-New Zealand tour for October 25 through Nov. 22. But specific dates for the shows in Perth, Adelaide, Sydney, Melbourne, Macedon Ranges, Brisbane and Auckland have not yet been announced.

headline: Kerry on ‘Reality Check’ in Peace Talks
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said Washington was evaluating whether to continue its role in the Middle East peace talks, saying it is “reality check time.”
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry said Washington was evaluating whether to continue its role in the Middle East peace talks, saying it is “reality check time.”

headline: Times Minute | Final Four Preview
abstract: The sports editor Jason Stallman looks ahead to the final games of the 2014 N.C.A.A. tournament.
lead_paragraph: The sports editor Jason Stallman looks ahead to the final games of the 2014 N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Times Minute | Final Four Preview
abstract: The sports editor Jason Stallman looks ahead to the final games of the 2014 N.C.A.A. tournament.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Paris Marathon Kicks Off a Month of Foot Races
abstract: A look at some of the major marathon races that will be run over the next several weeks, starting with a big one this weekend in Paris.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The countdown to the World Cup finals in Brazil is getting harder to ignore, but other global sporting diversions are still there for the savoring before the sounds and sights of soccer overwhelm the landscape.

headline: With Little Snow, Little Work for a Mushing Company
abstract: The California drought has taken a large toll on Jim Ouimet and his mushing company, Mammoth Dog Teams, which thrives on snow.
lead_paragraph: The California drought has taken a large toll on Jim Ouimet and his mushing company, Mammoth Dog Teams, which thrives on snow.

headline: Photos: With Little Snow and Little Work, a Musher Worries
abstract: The California drought has taken a large toll on Jim Ouimet and his mushing company, Mammoth Dog Teams, which thrives on snow.
lead_paragraph: In the mountains of Mammoth Lakes, the California drought has taken a large toll on a local business that thrives on snow. The effects have left Jim Ouimet and his 35 dogs nearly out of work.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Akhil Sharma’s ‘Family Life’
abstract: This week, Akhil Sharma discusses his new novel, “Family Life”; Julie Bosman looks back at her four years on the publishing beat; Leslie Jamison talks about “The Empathy Exams”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Akhil Sharma discusses his new novel, “Family Life”; Julie Bosman looks back at her four years on the publishing beat; Leslie Jamison talks about “The Empathy Exams”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: How Do You Sell a New Stock Exchange? IEX Makes an Appeal to Mom and Pop
abstract: IEX, an innovative new stock exchange that hopes to level the playing field for all investors is trying to appeal to the everyman with a new online marketing campaign.
lead_paragraph: This week’s cover story recounts the origins of IEX, a new stock exchange that hopes to level the playing field among investors, let some disinfecting sunshine in on the shadowy world of high-frequency trading and spur Wall Street to follow its lead. But a non-engineering, non-algorithm-writing type might be forgiven for finding it hard to understand the technological and financial details of the story, even with Michael Lewis’s guidance. That’s a problem for a new operation like IEX: How do you get the public excited when your product consists, in part, of a shoe box full of fiber-optic cable that adds microseconds to trading times?

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Akhil Sharma’s ‘Family Life’
abstract: This week, Akhil Sharma and Leslie Jamison.
lead_paragraph: This week, Akhil Sharma and Leslie Jamison.

headline: The Vanishing
abstract: Michael Rockefeller disappeared in New Guinea in 1961. Did he drown, or was he eaten by Asmat tribesmen?
lead_paragraph: Few American mysteries have proved more durable than the disappearance of Michael Rockefeller. In March of 1961, less than a year after his graduation from Harvard, this 22-year-old heir to the Rockefeller fortune flew to Dutch New Guinea to work on a documentary film and to collect artifacts for the Museum of Primitive Art, a Manhattan institution endowed by his father, New York’s governor, Nelson Rockefeller. That November, the young man’s catamaran capsized off the southwest coast of the Asmat tribal area. After a monthlong search, he was declared lost at sea, probably drowned. But a more lurid explanation has persisted: Rockefeller managed to swim to shore, only to be murdered — and eaten — by headhunters.

headline: Barley and Herb Salad With Roasted Asparagus
abstract: This can be a main-dish salad or a side, enlivened with intensely delicious roasted asparagus.
lead_paragraph: When fat stalks of asparagus come into the markets, what better thing to do with them than roast or grill them? What’s more, the California chef and teacher John Ash, demonstrating a recipe at the recent “Healthy Kitchens, Healthy Lives” conference at the Culinary Institute of America in Napa Valley – an event that bridges health care, nutrition science and cooking – insists that not only does asparagus taste better when it’s not cooked in or near water, but also that it doesn’t cause that distinctive odor in urine many people experience after eating it. I can’t vouch for the latter claim, but asparagus is intensely delicious when you roast it And it’s a beautiful addition to this lemony mix of barley and herbs. For the herbs, I like to mix sweet (tarragon, chives) with bitter (parsley, marjoram, thyme).

headline: Bulgur and Chickpea Salad With Roasted Artichokes
abstract: Quartering and roasting the artichokes instead of steaming them whole intensifies flavor and cuts down on preparation time for this salad.
lead_paragraph: My initial idea here was to stuff the artichokes with the salad and steam them. But that took a lot of time, and diminished the flavor of the salad. So I trimmed and cut the artichokes into wedges, tossed them with olive oil and roasted them. The roasted artichokes tasted so wonderful that I’ll be inclined to cook them this way from now on. They are perfect served atop or on the side of this lemony grain, chickpea and herb salad.

headline: Rainbow Quinoa Salad With Mixed Nuts, Herbs and Dried Fruit
abstract: This salad is inspired by one demonstrated at the “Healthy Kitchen, Healthy Lives” conference in Napa Valley.
lead_paragraph: Dr. David Eisenberg of the Harvard School of Public Health and the Samueli Institute,a nonprofit research organization, demonstrated along with his daughter, Naomi, a whole-wheat couscous salad that is the inspiration for this one at the “Healthy Kitchens, Healthy Lives”medical education conference in Napa Valley this year. You can use a variety of dried fruits and nuts, as well as a mix of herbs. Chop the larger dried fruits small so that the pieces are uniform.

headline: The People’s Palaces at the Beach
keywords: ['Beaches', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Bathhouses built during the Depression, once grand structures that drew thousands of bathers a day in the New York area, may return to glory under ambitious revitalization plans.
lead_paragraph: On a raw spring day, John T. Krawchuk, the director of historic preservation for the city’s parks department, led a tour through the fenced-off pavilion at Orchard Beach, where cracks snaked up the walls and the marine-blue terra-cotta that graces the facade was chipped or missing.

headline: The Campaign Against Mozilla’s Brendan Eich
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: You know we’ve come a long way in a short time when a C.E.O. can be forced to resign for holding the view that gays and lesbians should not be allowed to marry.
lead_paragraph: You know we’ve come a long way in a short time when a chief executive of a prominent company can be forced to resign for holding the view that gays and lesbians should not be allowed to marry each other. As recently as 2010, a majority of Americans believed that the government should not recognize same-sex marriage, according to Gallup.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Under The Skin’
abstract: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “Under The Skin.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “Under The Skin.”

headline: Red and Basmati or Jasmine Rice With Peanuts, Asian Dressing and Baked Tofu
abstract: With a little advance preparation, this spicy salad can be made in 30 minutes.
lead_paragraph: You can cook the two kinds of rice together for this spicy Asian salad if you soak the red rice for an hour first. The antioxidant-rich pigment from the red rice will bleed into the white rice, turning it an attractive pale rusty color.

headline: Ukraine Releases Shooting Video
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Video released from the Ukrainian Interior Ministry purportedly shows police officers shooting at protesters in deadly February clashes.
lead_paragraph: Video released from the Ukrainian Interior Ministry purportedly shows police officers shooting at protesters in deadly February clashes.

headline: Movie Review: ‘The Unknown Known’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “The Unknown Known.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “The Unknown Known.”

headline: Middle Eastern Black Rice and Lentil Salad on a Bed of Spinach
abstract: The hues of this crunchy salad indicate that it’s an antioxidant-rich dish.
lead_paragraph: Black rice is inky, as black as squid ink, and glistens against a bed of spinach. The pigments provide anthocyanins, flavonoids that are high in antioxidants. I was inspired to cook the rice with lentils by a pilaf that I ate recently at the “Healthy Kitchens, Healthy Lives” conference at the Culinary Institute of America in Napa Valley. In addition to the familiar green or black lentils, I’ve thrown in uncooked split red lentils, which contribute their own soft salmon color and crunch; they are soaked for a few hours to soften them, and that’s all they need. Prepare the ingredients for the salad while the rice and lentils are cooking.

headline: Finding Ways to Market an E-Commerce Business
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Customer Relations', 'E-Commerce', 'Online Advertising', 'Small Business', 'Social Media']
abstract: Three owners discuss the very different tactics they have employed.
lead_paragraph: A reader, Laura Araujo, recently posted a comment in which she expressed some frustration with her efforts to market a small, e-commerce business. Ms. Araujo, 27, has a full-time job as a financial analyst but to earn extra money she opened a franchise business on the side in December. “I was looking for a franchise that I can do primarily evenings and weekends and operate by myself,” Ms. Araujo said.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Captain America’
abstract: The Times critic Manhola Dargis reviews “Captain America: The Winter Soldier.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manhola Dargis reviews “Captain America: The Winter Soldier.”

headline: Law Lifts Enrollment in Medicaid by Millions
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'States (US)']
abstract: The Obama administration said the increases were much greater in states that expanded Medicaid eligibility under the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Enrollment in Medicaid has increased by three million people, to a total of 62 million, largely because of the Affordable Care Act, the Obama administration said Friday.

headline: Image of the Day: April 4
abstract: India’s Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle, carrying a navigation satellite, blasted off from the spaceport in Sriharikota, Andhra Pradesh.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Akhil Sharma’s ‘Family Life’
abstract: Mr. Sharma discusses his new novel, and Leslie Jamison talks about her essay collection, “The Empathy Exams.”
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Sonali Deraniyagala reviews Akhil Sharma’s new novel, “Family Life.” Ms. Deraniyagala writes:

headline: Turning Up the Heat on Fruit
abstract: Not too sweet, not too fussy, fruit compotes are a way to take advantage of the apples, pears and citrus available before the arrival of stone-fruit and berry season.
lead_paragraph: Fruit compotes make great compromise desserts; they’re sweet, but not as sweet as sorbets, and like sorbets they don’t require flour, butter or pastry skills. I didn’t develop any kind of knack for pastry until I began collaborating with pastry chefs on their cookbooks, but for years I managed to round out my dinner parties with fruit-based desserts (though the children of my friend Clifford Wright used to roll their eyes when I brought dessert – “She doesn’t bring dessert, she brings fruit,” they’d say).

headline: Loeb Steps Up Pressure on Sotheby’s Board
abstract: The activist investor Daniel S. Loeb fired his latest salvo at Sotheby’s on Friday, calling on shareholders to overthrow the auction house’s “lackadaisical” board.
lead_paragraph: The activist investor Daniel S. Loeb fired his latest salvo at Sotheby’s on Friday, calling on shareholders to overthrow members of the auction house’s “lackadaisical” board.

headline: Clip: ‘Watermark’
abstract: A scene from the documentary directed by Jennifer Baichwal and Edward Burtynsky.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the documentary directed by Jennifer Baichwal and Edward Burtynsky.

headline: Michael Schumacher Is Said to Have ‘Moments of Consciousness’
abstract: Friday’s statement was a notable turn from the sparse bulletins from his caretakers since Schumacher, the Grand Prix driver, suffered severe brain injuries while skiing in December.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After more than three months in a coma, Michael Schumacher, the most successful Grand Prix driver in racing history, is showing “moments of consciousness and awakening” in the intensive care ward where he was taken after suffering brain injuries in a skiing accident in the French Alps on Dec. 29, his spokeswoman said in a statement Friday.

headline: Tea Party Aims at Incumbents, but Falls Short
keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: The Tea Party has nudged Republicans to the right in Congress, but falls short when it comes to recruiting good challengers to take out incumbents.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, ought to be a prime target for a Tea Party challenge. He helped write the Senate overhaul of immigration laws that provided for a pathway to citizenship for illegal immigrants, backed President Obama’s Supreme Court nominees and expressed a willingness to raise taxes as part of a larger deal to address the nation’s fiscal health — all perilous positions in a deeply conservative state.

headline: G.O.P. Incumbents on the Ballot
abstract: Eleven Republican senators are up for re-election this fall, and more than half of them face opposition in the primaries.
lead_paragraph: Eleven Republican senators are up for re-election this fall, and more than half of them face opposition in the primaries.

headline: In Spain, a Family Reunion, Centuries Later
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Genealogy', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Passover']
abstract: A search for roots in Spain reveals the habits of daily life, struggles with the Inquisition and a secret religious life.
lead_paragraph: At twilight, I roamed a honey-colored labyrinth of brick houses in Segovia’s medieval Jewish quarter, walking a cobblestone path in the footsteps of my distant ancestor from 16 generations ago.

headline: After Earthquakes, a Creative Rebirth in Christchurch
abstract: Imaginative projects and resilient residents are helping Christchurch, the largest city on New Zealand’s South Island, cope with devastation.
lead_paragraph: On the afternoon of Feb. 22, 2011, as the C1 Espresso cafe in Christchurch was in the midst of a busy lunch rush, the walls and tables suddenly began shaking, windows started popping out of their frames, and the lights flickered out. The region had been experiencing aftershocks from a large earthquake that had struck six months earlier, but this one was different. In a span of minutes, the entire city center was devastated, including the cafe, which was eventually demolished. Nearly 200 people across the city died.

headline: NYT Now: Kerry Calls for ‘Reality Check’
abstract: Amid growing frustration with the Israelis and Palestinians on the stalled peace talks, Secretary of State John Kerry said it was “reality check time.”
lead_paragraph: Amid growing frustration with the Israelis and Palestinians on the stalled peace talks, Secretary of State John Kerry said it was “reality check time.”

headline: Dispute Over Leave Agitated Ft. Hood Soldier Before Shooting
keywords: ['Fort Hood Shooting (2014)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Specialist Ivan Antonio Lopez, who shot almost 20 fellow soldiers, had been denied leave by his superiors, a law enforcement official said.
lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex. — The Army specialist at Fort Hood who killed three and wounded 16 of his fellow soldiers on Wednesday had an angry dispute over a leave request shortly before the shooting rampage, a law enforcement official said Friday.

headline: Microsoft Office for the iPad: It’s Delightfully Familiar
abstract: If you love Microsoft Office on your desktop, you’ll love the company’s new iPad version. If you hate Office, you’ll have one more place it.
lead_paragraph: The plan sounded simple: Get an iPad. Get a keyboard for the iPad. Get Office for iPad. Then, finally, review Office for iPad.

headline: 2 Giant European Cement Makers Are in Merger Talks
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Cement', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Lafarge, based in France, and Holcim of Switzerland said they were in advanced discussions to combine, but a merger of companies of their size is certain to attract antitrust concerns.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Holcim and Lafarge, two giant European cement makers, said Friday that they were in ‘‘advanced discussions’’ about a merger of equals that would create the industry’s leader, if the deal survives regulatory scrutiny.

headline: Audio Editing in iMovie
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Software', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: Plus, how to back up Windows Phone.
lead_paragraph: Q. In iMovie ’11 for the Mac, how do you lower or remove the original audio from a clip so that the selected background music is the only sound?

headline: The War Between Our States
abstract: Tony Schwartz, in his Life@Work column, writes of the many leaders who lack real self-awareness — a willingness to look at what motivates their behavior and a recognition of the impact they have on those they lead.
lead_paragraph: Who are you at your best?

headline: Talking Shoots and Leaves
abstract: At the Indoor Outdoor Gardener in Brooklyn, the backyard fills with plants each spring, and year-round the interior is packed with plants, seeds, fertilizer and more.
lead_paragraph: The Indoor Outdoor Gardener in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, has two types of repeat customers. Robin Green, 56, is in one category: a steady presence for 10 years who stops in just to say hello to the owner, Helena De Paola, and walks out with yet another plant. Then there is Brian Schnabel, who made his first visit on a recent Sunday morning but was so entranced he was back shopping later that afternoon, buying a small trellis on Ms. De Paola’s recommendation.

headline: Looking Glass Complications
abstract: The horror film “Oculus” features a sinister mirror.
lead_paragraph: Who the heck is manufacturing all these superpowered mirrors? There’s the one in “Snow White” that knows who is fairest of them all. There’s the one in “Beauty and the Beast” that has Google Earth-like abilities. The Harry Potter stories have both the Mirror of Erised, which shows the user his deepest desires, and the two-way mirror, a person-to-person communication device.

headline: A Bold Bid to Combat a Crisis in Legal Education
abstract: Brooklyn Law School said it would cut tuition and abandon what has become a widespread obsession with climbing the ladder of national law school rankings.
lead_paragraph: Brooklyn Law School is hardly alone in facing a crisis in legal education. Five law schools have closed in the last two years, more than at any other time in American history.

headline: One Word That Should Never Follow ‘I Love You’
abstract: Let’s be honest, when you add this word, the purpose of the statement is to communicate everything except “I love you.”
lead_paragraph: I don’t remember the exact day, or the exact reason, or even the exact words, but I know it started with “I love you, but …”

headline: The American Woodcock’s Love Song at 300 Feet
abstract: To woo its mate, the male American Woodcock issues a series of nasal sounds as he ascends in a spiral, then descends in arcs with a warbling that many naturalists have struggled to characterize.
lead_paragraph: The American woodcock is one of the Northeast’s most peculiar birds, with a humble, lovable beauty that has inspired myriad nicknames. Bogsucker, mudbat, Labrador twister and timberdoodle all describe a shy brown bird only 10 to 12 inches long. Incredibly well camouflaged, woodcocks are almost invisible by day, resting and feeding among the bristling, messy shrubs of old fields, meadows and young woodlands. But in early spring, as the sun’s fleeting warmth fades into the chill night, the bird performs one of nature’s most curious courtship displays.

headline: Peninsula Hotel Will Open in Paris
abstract: A Peninsula hotel scheduled to open in Paris this summer will be the brand’s first European property.
lead_paragraph: Peninsula Hotels, the Hong Kong-based luxury brand, enters Europe for the first time, with its 10th location scheduled to open in Paris this August.

headline: C.E.O. of The Times Co. to Publish a Book on Language
abstract: The book, “Enough Said,” will examine language in the digital age, drawing on lectures that the executive, Mark Thompson, gave at Oxford.
lead_paragraph: Mark Thompson, the president and chief executive of The New York Times Company, is writing his first book, an examination of language in the digital age, his publisher, St. Martin’s Press, said. The book, to be titled “Enough Said,” draws from a series of lectures at Oxford that Mr. Thompson delivered in 2012 as a visiting professor at the university.

headline: In L.A., a Group Show Explores the Art of the Obscured
abstract: At “Veils,” a 40-artist exhibition at the Underground Museum, talents both established and emerging are showing works about hidden meaning.
lead_paragraph: As its name suggests, “Veils” — a 40-artist group exhibition opening Saturday in the West Adams neighborhood of L.A. — offers interpretations of the physical act of concealment. But the show’s curators, Jhordan Dahl and Ariana Papademetropoulos, also made a point to stretch the concept, exploring ideas about public personas and the occult. The works on display range from Jeffrey Vallance’s 1992 series of clown makeup imprints on linen handkerchiefs to an eerie watercolor self-portrait by the artist (and occultist) Marjorie Cameron to “Long-Banged Angel,” an eight-foot-high Eric Yahnker drawing of Farrah Fawcett in her glory days, lustrous feathered hair completely obscuring her eyes.

headline: The Gun Report: April 4, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to National Rifle Association-backed legislation, the commanding officers of the Fort Hood shooter were barred from asking him about the privately owned handgun he used to carry out this week’s shooting, Media Matters reports.

headline: Investors Return to Anadarko After Record $5.1 Billion Settlement
abstract: The settlement, covering years of environmental claims, was at the low end of a court-defined range and ends a messy legal wrangle for Anadarko and its Kerr-McGee subsidiary, Kevin Allison of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Stock investors seem to have a firm grip on Anadarko Petroleum’s toxic waste settlement. The record $5.15 billion settlement on Thursday, covering years of environmental claims, was at the low end of a court-defined range, which had a midpoint of $9.8 billion. The 15 percent jump in the oil company’s market capitalization after the settlement was announced is mostly explained by those numbers. And it brings Anadarko’s 12-month stock performance nearly back in line with the Standard & Poor’s 500 Index after a bumpy ride.

headline: Three Soldiers Killed at Fort Hood Are Identified
keywords: ['Fort Hood Shooting (2014)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: One of the three soldiers shot and killed at Fort Hood died while barricading a door, preventing the gunman from opening fire inside a room packed with military personnel.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:04 p .m.When Specialist Ivan Antonio Lopez opened fire at Fort Hood late Wednesday afternoon, Sgt. First Class Danny Ferguson leaned up against a door to prevent the gunman from entering a room packed with military personnel.

headline: Why Mozilla’s Chief Had to Resign
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Brendan Eich’s resignation as Mozilla’s chief executive over his views on gay marriage was not an example of political correctness run amok. At an activist organization, his views were shattering Mozilla’s cherished sense of community.
lead_paragraph: What conclusions should we draw about Silicon Valley from what happened at Mozilla?

headline: Just the Facts, With Tweaks
abstract: The Art of the Real series at Lincoln Center looks at documentaries from years past that blurred lines between truth and fiction, observation and intervention.
lead_paragraph: “I think here there are two kinds of truths: dramatic truth and documentary reporting,” the trailblazing French filmmaker Jean Rouch once said in an interview. “But pure documentary is very rare, and maybe it’s inevitable that a film have some drama in it.” He was talking in 1977, giving context for films he’d made in the 1950s.

headline: Osteoporosis
abstract: This animation begins by showing a hip fracture due to osteoporosis. The bone then dissolves into a frontal section to compare the bony interior of a normal femur to that of an osteoporotic femur.
lead_paragraph: This animation begins by showing a hip fracture due to osteoporosis. The bone then dissolves into a frontal section to compare the bony interior of a normal femur to that of an osteoporotic femur.

headline: In a Tale of the Nation’s First Spy Ring, a Spotlight on Colonial New York
abstract: New York is largely overlooked in stories of the Revolutionary War, but a TV series, “Turn,” dramatizes the true tale of the Culper Ring, a band of friends who made up what is considered the nation’s first spy ring.
lead_paragraph: Before it was the wonder city of eight million stories, New York in the autumn of 1776 was just 25,000 strong. Under indomitable British occupation – indeed, New York was the colonial headquarters of the British military – it was at a hinge in its history.

headline: Struggling to Film in America’s Chokehold
abstract: The embargo on Cuba is blocking independent movie producers on the island from getting American investments, even by crowdfunding.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — In Hollywood terms, it was small change. But for Miguel Coyula, a Cuban filmmaker accustomed to working on a tiny budget, the $5,200 he raised on the crowdfunding site Indiegogo.com last year would have bought some lighting equipment, a Steadicam and a tripod, all crucial for his science-fiction feature, “Blue Heart.”

headline: After Playing, Parting Is Such Sweet Sorrow
abstract: My cello was useless and forgotten, yet it never occurred to me to get rid of it until a recent donation drive for public school music programs.
lead_paragraph: When people learn that I’m a music critic, they often ask what my instrument is. I’ve always answered, “I play the cello.” If I’m feeling expansive, I say I’m a cellist.

headline: Trading Flaming Skull for Inner Dad
abstract: Nicolas Cage stars with Tye Sheridan in David Gordon Green’s “Joe,” a character study marking a departure from Mr. Cage’s recent action pictures.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — After playing, among other characters, a one-eyed dad who drinks beer out of his enemy’s skull (“Drive Angry”) and a motorcyclist from hell who can make his head burst into flame (“Ghost Rider: Spirit of Vengeance”), Nicolas Cage had gotten a reputation as a guy whose love of action pictures had, over the last decade, pulled him away from what he does best, namely, act. Quirky comedies and thoughtful indies were set aside for films heavy on bloodletting and explosions. Critics, even longtime champions like Roger Ebert, yearned for the Nic of old.

headline: 50 Years of the Ford Mustang
abstract: It was love at first sight for Fred Glazier, who saw the Ford Mustang at the 1964 World’s Fair. Soon after, he bought his own, and he still drives it today.
lead_paragraph: It was love at first sight for Fred Glazier, who saw the Ford Mustang at the 1964 World’s Fair. Soon after, he bought his own, and he still drives it today.

headline: Chocolate Caramel Macarons
abstract: Melissa Clark takes the best parts of a French macaron and an American macaroon and creates a sweet sandwich cookie for Passover.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark takes the best parts of a French macaron and an American macaroon and creates a sweet sandwich cookie for Passover.

headline: Seeking College Application Essays About Money From This Year’s Seniors
abstract: Ron Lieber, the Your Money columnist for The New York Times, is looking for college application essays about money, work and social class from this year’s high school seniors.
lead_paragraph: Last year, I put out an open call for college application essays about money, work and social class and hoped that high school seniors would send them in. Several dozen young men and women did, and we featured the best of the essays in a Your Money column. I particularly enjoyed getting to know Lyle Li, now a New York University freshman, whom we featured in a video.

headline: A Pizza Party
abstract: For Yosuke Masuko, the goal of operating a pizza company in Vietnam is ‘‘delivering wow and happiness.’'
lead_paragraph: For Yosuke Masuko, the goal of operating a pizza company in Vietnam is ‘‘delivering wow and happiness.’'

headline: Books, and Compassion, From Birth
abstract: Some experts on early education say efforts focused on 4- and even 3-year-olds come too late.
lead_paragraph: Last year, when I was visiting a public school in Sunset Park in Brooklyn for teenagers with boundless difficulties, my host, a poet who teaches at various city schools, mentioned a student who had become pregnant. Hoping to start a library for the child soon to arrive, the poet told the young woman embarking on motherhood that she would like to give her some books — books of the kind her own grandchildren growing up in a very different Brooklyn had by the dozens. The offer was met skeptically. “I already have one,” the girl said.

headline: Closing the Seder With Something New
abstract: Chocolate macarons, matzo toffee and a citrus torte: three desserts perfect for Passover.
lead_paragraph: Here’s the secret to the best Passover desserts: stick to recipes that never relied on flour to begin with. Why make a chocolate cake with matzo flour when a flourless chocolate torte is going to be so much better anyway? This is why flourless tortes, candies and nut- or coconut-based cookies are the usual end to many a Seder.

headline: Wheelies: The Kia People Mover Edition
abstract: Kia will unveil an eight-passenger minivan at the New York auto show; the National Corvette Museum pulls the seventh car from its sinkhole.
lead_paragraph: ■ Kia announced Thursday that it would unveil an all-new eight-passenger vehicle at the New York auto show this month. Details were scant, but the new model would probably take the place of the Kia Sedona minivan, which was scheduled for replacement. (Kia)

headline: My Little Pony, 50 Years Later
abstract: The Ford Mustang was introduced 50 years ago, and some people who bought the pony cars in 1964 still own them.
lead_paragraph: When the Ford Mustang was introduced 50 years ago this month, it was first to break from the gate in a market class that would come to be known as pony cars.

headline: A Ford Mustang That’s Not a Mustang
abstract: In Germany, where a dump truck manufacturer claimed rights to the Mustang name, the original Mustang was badged as the T5.
lead_paragraph: If a dump truck can be a Mustang, can a Mustang be a T5? That conundrum can be answered in the positive, the result of a German manufacturer of trucks having copyrighted the Mustang name long before Ford’s pony car was released in the 1960s.

headline: Five Injured After Bus Smashes Into Upper Manhattan Building
abstract: The accident occurred around 7:30 a.m. Friday when a minivan struck the bus near the intersection of Broadway and 155th Street.
lead_paragraph: A New York City Transit bus collided with a minivan and then smashed into a building in Upper Manhattan on Friday morning, injuring five people, according to fire officials.

headline: Federal Panel Rejects Design for Eisenhower Memorial
abstract: The federal panel that oversees the design of the nation’s monuments on Thursday rejected the plans for a planned memorial to Dwight D. Eisenhower and asked for revisions.
lead_paragraph: In the latest setback for a memorial to Dwight D. Eisenhower planned for Washington’s National Mall, Frank Gehry’s current design was rejected and sent back for revisions on Thursday by the panel that oversees the nation’s monuments.

headline: Prosecutor on India Rape Case Sentencing
abstract: Ujjwal Nikam, the special prosecutor in a Mumbai gang rape case, spoke to the news media Friday after three men were sentenced to death.
lead_paragraph: Ujjwal Nikam, the special prosecutor in a Mumbai gang rape case, spoke to the news media Friday after three men were sentenced to death.

headline: When the Final Curtain Isn’t So Final
abstract: After 15 years, some original cast members — older, grayer — poignantly set sail again on the musical “Titanic.”
lead_paragraph: On a frigid February day in 1999, I gave my final performance as Radioman Harold Bride in the Broadway musical “Titanic.” I’d been offered a new role in a downtown play. It was harder than I ever imagined saying goodbye to the company; to the beloved duet I’d performed nightly with the ship’s stoker, played for most of the run by Brian d’Arcy James, who sang a message of love to his landlocked girl while I, a Marconi geek, waxed poetic over my telegraph. I stepped downstage for the last scene of the show, tears streaming, as we all waved farewell to the doomed ship and belted out the final notes of Maury Yeston’s luscious score: “Fortune’s winds sing God’s Speed to thee!” A few weeks later, after more than 800 performances, “Titanic” closed.

headline: Corporate Profits Grow and Wages Slide
abstract: As a proportion of the overall economy, corporate profits were at their highest since 1929, while wages and benefits were at their lowest for any year ever measured.
lead_paragraph: CORPORATE profits are at their highest level in at least 85 years. Employee compensation is at the lowest level in 65 years.

headline: Is That Jesus in Your Toast?
abstract: You may be experiencing “moral hunger.”
lead_paragraph: TAKE a close look at your breakfast. Is that Jesus staring out at you from your toast?

headline: Activists Seen as Possibly Circling Symantec
abstract: Symantec is close to hiring JPMorgan Chase to defend the enterprise technology company against activist investors, people briefed on the matter say.
lead_paragraph: Symantec is close to hiring JPMorgan Chase to defend the enterprise technology company against activist investors, people briefed on the matter said on Friday.

headline: Big Ticket | At $30 Million, It’s All About the Views
keywords: ['Luxury Goods and Services', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A five-bedroom apartment in the Time Warner Center with unencumbered park and river views was the most expensive sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A vista-infused apartment near the peak of the south tower at the Time Warner Center with unencumbered Central Park views to the east and Hudson River scenes to the west sold for $30 million after a brief bidding war and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Should I Swap My Rent-Stabilized Apartment?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Home Repairs and Improvements']
abstract: This week we address swapping apartments; selling a fixer upper; and the case of a nudist neighbor.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a new weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Ophira Eisenberg’s Walk-Up Cave
abstract: The host of the radio show “Ask Me Another” lives with her husband in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: There are certain people who simply don’t understand the concept of apartment buildings without elevators. It just so happens that some of those baffled individuals share a last name with Ophira Eisenberg.

headline: Syria Ships Out More Chemicals After a 2-Week Lapse
abstract: The delay raised questions about whether Syria can meet an extended deadline of April 27 to export its chemical weapons arsenal for destruction.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Syria has delivered a consignment of chemical weapons materials for export and destruction overseas for the first time in more than two weeks, a delay that revived concerns about the country’s readiness and ability to meet newly extended deadlines for completing the task this month.

headline: The Weight of Executives’ Personal Beliefs
abstract: Should executives be held to account for unpopular or even offensive views, or does such a stand repress free speech?

headline: Music Writer’s Opus, Now With Sound
abstract: Seven of the music historian and critic Peter Guralnick’s books are being reissued in “enhanced e-book” editions that include video, audio and new chapters.
lead_paragraph: As a college classics major, the music historian, writer and critic Peter Guralnick once submitted a paper comparing the Roman poet Catullus’s “Little Bird, Delight of My Girl” to Robert Johnson’s “Stones in My Passway.” “It was not well received,” he recalled recently, but it helped establish a template that has served Mr. Guralnick superbly in writing groundbreaking books on blues, country and soul music, and biographies of pop music figures like Elvis Presley and Sam Cooke.

headline: A Long Way From South Dakota
abstract: The South Dakota-raised noise-rocker’s obsession with science and technology courses through “The Future’s Void,” which is out on Tuesday on Matador Records.
lead_paragraph: On the cover of her new album, “The Future’s Void,” the South Dakota-raised noise-rocker EMA sports an Oculus Rift virtual reality headset, but the photograph was shot before that company’s recent $2 billion purchase by Facebook. And she wrote the song “Satellites,” which rages against government surveillance, months before the National Security Agency scandal broke.

headline: Q. and A. | Kelis Explains How She Got from ‘Milkshake’ to Her Own Cooking Show
abstract: The shape-shifting singer discusses the new album and how she became a Le Cordon Bleu-certified chef.
lead_paragraph: Kelis Rogers, who broke out in 2003 with her booty-popping come-on “Milkshake,” has a history of surprising her fans. The Harlem native’s 2006 album, “Kelis Was Here,” staged a rebellion against the pop sound that established her, forgoing the signature Neptunes production of her first three albums in favor of an eclectic sound with a wide-ranging cast of collaborators. She followed up four years later with yet another new direction, the boundary-pushing electro-dance riot “Flesh Tone.” If that wasn’t enough to prove her restlessness, somewhere in the middle she also attended culinary school, becoming a Le Cordon Bleu-certified chef; she even hosts her own Cooking Channel show, “Saucy & Sweet.”

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New, Starring Kelis and Alejandro Jodorowsky
abstract: Kelis and Alejandro Jodorowsky nosh on gold popcorn while considering a Frank Gehry building, a cultural crystal ball and glittery brogues.
lead_paragraph: Alejandro Jodorowsky, surrealist Chilean-born director and self-described “psychoshaman” whose new autobiographical film, “The Dance of Reality” — his first in 23 years — opens in May, takes on Kelis, Grammy-nominated pop star and Le Cordon Bleu-certified chef whose sixth album, “Food,” comes out later this month. She also has a line of sauces in the works.

headline: From Slavery and Shiloh to the Post-Bellum World
abstract: “Civil War: The Untold Story,” a five-part PBS documentary, goes west a bit and lingers after the South’s surrender to reflect on postwar challenges.
lead_paragraph: “Civil War: The Untold Story” delivers on the promise of its title only intermittently.

headline: NYT Now: India Rape Case Sentencing
abstract: The special prosecutor in a Mumbai rape case, Ujjwal Nikam, discussed the sentencing of three men.
lead_paragraph: The special prosecutor in a Mumbai rape case, Ujjwal Nikam, discussed the sentencing of three men.

headline: Turns From a Gospel Singer and a Jazz Saxophonist
abstract: Erica Campbell, a member of the gospel duo Mary Mary, releases a solo outing, “Help.”
lead_paragraph: Erica Campbell

headline: Review: 2015 Subaru WRX STI
abstract: Budget conscious automotive enthusiasts who worship at the altar of performance know the Subaru WRX STI is an answered prayer.
lead_paragraph: Budget conscious automotive enthusiasts who worship at the altar of performance know the Subaru WRX STI is an answered prayer.

headline: Weekend Reading: High-Frequency Reading
abstract: This week we take an ultrafast look at the financial headlines.
lead_paragraph: This week we take an ultrafast look at the financial headlines.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Running in Circles Solved!
keywords: ['Doctors', 'Medicine and Health', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists', 'Tests (Drug Use)']
abstract: Dr. Lisa Sanders reveals the diagnosis in a mysterious case of an agitated young man with uncontrollable manic behavior.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to solve the mystery of a 23-year-old man with episodes of aggressive, manic behavior that couldn’t be controlled. Nearly 1,000 readers wrote in with their take on this terrifying case. More than 300 of you got the right class of disease, and 21 of you nailed the precise form of the disorder. Amazing!

headline: Another High-Speed Trading Investigation
abstract: The list of federal and state agencies investigating the practice of high-frequency trading continues to grow, with Attorney General Eric H. Holder telling a House panel on Friday that the Justice Department had its own inquiry.
lead_paragraph: The list of federal and state agencies investigating the practice of high-frequency trading continues to grow.

headline: Iran’s Reformers Include More Than One Former Hostage-Taker
abstract: Hostage-takers who became leading reformers in Iran include the man who devised the plan to seize the United States Embassy in Tehran in 1979 and the woman who explained the group’s demands to foreign reporters.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Saturday, 2:44 p.m. | As my colleagues Somini Sengupta and Thomas Erdbrink reported, there has been discomfort and anger in Washington since Iran applied for a visa to let a veteran diplomat who played a part in the 1979 hostage crisis move to New York and serve as its ambassador to the United Nations.

headline: Kazuo Ishiguro Readies First Novel in 10 Years
abstract: Alfred A. Knopf will publish “The Buried Giant” in 2015.
lead_paragraph: Alfred A. Knopf will publish “The Buried Giant,” Kazuo Ishiguro’s seventh novel and his first in nearly a decade, in spring 2015. Mr. Ishiguro’s British publisher, Faber & Faber, announced the forthcoming novel in advance of the London Book Fair, which starts Tuesday.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
abstract: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: Buzz From Tokyo to Toronto Evokes Another Yankee Debut
abstract: Masahiro Tanaka, like Hideki Matsui 11 years earlier, made his major league debut in a road game against the Blue Jays, creating similar excitement among Japanese fans and news media members.
lead_paragraph: Across the Yankees universe on Friday night, all eyes were on Toronto, where the team’s prized off-season acquisition from Japan, pitcher Masahiro Tanaka, made his major league debut against the Blue Jays. Battalions of Japanese reporters were on hand to document the milestone, and baseball fans in Japan, coffee mugs in hand, woke up early on Saturday to watch the game live.

headline: Come Here, Look Back, Move Forward
abstract: On Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, Stephen Petronio Company begins its 30th anniversary season.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Stephen Petronio does not like to go backward. He says that moving in reverse — say, on a train — makes him feel mentally disturbed and physically ill. Nevertheless, there is a lot of backward in his life these days.

headline: Stripper With a Heart of Gold
abstract: Volkswagen seems to have put most of its effort into the engine of the 2014 Jetta. While the power plant is terrific, many elements of the car are less so.
lead_paragraph: TESTED 2014 Volkswagen Jetta SE

headline: Still a Wild Child After Reform School
abstract: The 2015 Subaru WRX is a significant leap forward from the previous model, with a better interior and a body style that flexes some muscle.
lead_paragraph: Let the other guys worry about self-steering cars, blind-spot beepers and onboard Wi-Fi connections.

headline: Subaru’s Blue Streak
abstract: The 2015 WRX and its track-ready STI version deliver unmitigated driving pleasure at a relatively affordable price.
lead_paragraph: The 2015 WRX and its track-ready STI version deliver unmitigated driving pleasure at a relatively affordable price.

headline: Keeping Tabs, Just in Case
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Photography', 'Archives and Records']
abstract: New York City’s Department of Records and Information Services released Friday thousands of newly digitized images, including ones collected in the ’30s and ’40s by the Bureau of Criminal Alien Investigation.
lead_paragraph: Most histories trace antiterrorism squads to the Haymarket bombing in Chicago in 1886, after which American police departments devoted a new zeal to gathering intelligence.

headline: A Peace Process in Which Process Has Come to Outweigh Peace
abstract: All three parties have vested interests in the Middle East peace process, leading analysts to say the current Kerry-led negotiations are inhibiting a final reckoning.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The crisis that engulfed the ailing Middle East peace process this week was much more about preserving the process than finding a path to peace.

headline: Fabric Art, Made From the Fighting
abstract: “Homefront & Battlefield: Quilts & Context in the Civil War” reminds us that textiles were also a big part of wartime culture (and, not incidentally, one in which women played a major role).
lead_paragraph: Building on last year’s touring exhibitions of Civil War art and photography, “Homefront & Battlefield: Quilts & Context in the Civil War” reminds us that textiles were also a big part of wartime culture (and, not incidentally, one in which women played a major role). Organized by the American Textile History Museum in Lowell, Mass., the show has just arrived at the New-York Historical Society. (It will travel to the Shelburne Museum in Vermont next fall and the Nebraska State Historical Society in the winter of 2015.)

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 69
abstract: The Arena da Amazonia in Manaus hosted its first event on Thursday night, but not without incident.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: How the Centuries Will Play Out
abstract: For music lovers, Thursday brings a clear choice between older and newer, both options tantalizing.
lead_paragraph: For music lovers, Thursday brings a clear choice between older and newer, both options tantalizing. Uptown, the repertory could hardly be more classic, as the eminent conductor Christoph von Dohnanyi leads the New York Philharmonic in Schumann’s stirring Symphony No. 2. But the main event may well end up being the performance of Brahms’s galvanic Piano Concerto No. 1, with the exhilarating British pianist Paul Lewis. (7:30 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, 212-875-5030, nyphil.org.)

headline: NYT Now: Perry on Fort Hood Shooting
abstract: Governor Rick Perry of Texas addressed the media about the deadly Fort Hood shooting on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Governor Rick Perry of Texas addressed the media about the deadly Fort Hood shooting on Wednesday.

headline: Tappers, Striking New Ground
abstract: The rhythm of tap expresses itself aurally when metal slaps and strikes the ground.
lead_paragraph: The rhythm of tap expresses itself aurally when metal slaps and strikes the ground. For many, this dance is still associated with Broadway-style showmanship or fluttering jazzlike improvisations. But tap today has a broader theatrical scope and emotional range. This week the pioneers of a new age of tap bring their vision to “Rhythm in Motion,” presented by the American Tap Dance Foundation and featuring some furiously inventive women, like Brenda Bufalino, Michelle Dorrance and Chloe Arnold, among other innovators. (Tuesday through Sunday, Theater at the 14th Street Y, 344 East 14th Street, Manhattan, 212-780-0800, atdf.org.)

headline: Festival Offers a Fuller Brubeck
abstract: Long before his death in 2012, the legacy of the jazz pianist Dave Brubeck was often reduced, in popular conversation, to his biggest album, “Time Out,” and its ageless hit, “Take Five.”
lead_paragraph: Long before his death in 2012, the legacy of the jazz pianist Dave Brubeck was often reduced, in popular conversation, to his biggest album, “Time Out,” and its ageless hit, “Take Five.” Jazz at Lincoln Center will offer a broader, richer portrait with its Dave Brubeck Festival, from Monday through next Sunday in the organization’s home, Frederick P. Rose Hall.

headline: Ruling Spurs Rush for Cash in Both Parties
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'McCutcheon v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Fund-raisers are focusing on a group of 500 to 700 donors in both parties who appear to have maxed out their contributions or come close to a cap struck down by the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the Democratic leader in the House, wasted little time on Thursday blasting the Supreme Court’s latest decision freeing donors to spend more money on campaigns. The founding fathers, Ms. Pelosi said at a news conference on Thursday morning, had fought for “a government of the many, not a government of the money.” Democrats, she said, will not “unilaterally disarm.”

headline: The Journey to Humanity
abstract: When the paleobiologist Neil Shubin looks at his fellow humans, he sees ghosts of animals past.
lead_paragraph: When the paleobiologist Neil Shubin looks at his fellow humans, he sees ghosts of animals past. The way we grip with our hands? We can thank our primate forefathers. Our ability to hear so many sounds? Distant ancestors the size of a shrew. And the further back we venture, the stranger things get. We don’t describe our skin as scaly for nothing.

headline: For Photography, the Biggest Show on Earth
abstract: The Scotiabank Contact Photography festival, opening May in Toronto, is the largest photography festival in the world.
lead_paragraph: Eighteen years ago four Toronto art dealers decided to whip up a little excitement around photography. Dismayed that the city had no museum devoted to the subject, and that curators at the big arts institutions seemed slow to embrace it as an art form, they issued an open invitation to museums, galleries, art centers and coffee houses to take part in a monthlong festival they called Contact ’97. To their surprise, 50 exhibitors responded. Stephen Bulger, the owner of the city’s only gallery showing photography year-round, predicted, “In five years, this will be an international event.”

headline: Friday Night Music: Figaro
abstract: Indie rock of the 18th century.
lead_paragraph: Yes, I know it’s only Friday afternoon. But my friend Emily Mann, artistic director at the McCarter Theater, has invited me to the opening of the first part of McCarter’s production of the Figaro plays, starting with dinner tonight. Strictly speaking I have the wrong play here — tonight’s play is The Barber of Seville — but I’m much more of a Mozart guy than a Rossini guy, so what the heck:

headline: Immigration Bill Splitting House G.O.P.
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner has tried to avoid an intraparty fight as midterm elections approach.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A push to give legal status to young undocumented immigrants who serve in the military is roiling the immigration debate in the House, dividing Republicans and reviving some movement toward substantive immigration legislation this year.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Fish With Morocco in Mind
abstract: The first step is to season the catch with chermoula, a mixture of herbs, spices and olive oil.
lead_paragraph: In Morocco, fish is fried, grilled or simmered, just as it is everywhere else, but there is this essential difference: The first step in nearly every Moroccan fish recipe requires the fish to be slathered, anointed or rubbed with a mixture of herbs, spices and olive oil.

headline: High Line Chief Does Her Relaxing Uptown
abstract: Jenny Gersten, the executive director of the group that runs the High Line park in Manhattan, spends her Sundays taking care of her dog, exercising and spending time with her family.
lead_paragraph: Jenny Gersten, 45, who became executive director in January of Friends of the High Line, which runs the elevated park in Manhattan, had been the artistic director of the Williamstown Theater Festival in Massachusetts. Theater runs in her family: her mother, Cora Cahan, is the president of the New 42nd Street, which revitalized theaters in the area, and her father, Bernard Gersten, recently retired as executive producer of Lincoln Center Theater. Ms. Gersten’s husband, Willie Reale, 56, writes musical theater with his brother Robert and is a supervising producer of “Blue Bloods,” the CBS police drama. They live in the West 80s with their sons, Augustus, 15, and Leonardo, 11, and their black Labrador retriever, Penny.

headline: Parting Glance: Anja Niedringhaus
abstract: Anja Niedringhaus, 48, an internationally known German photographer, was killed while on assignment in eastern Afghanistan on Friday. Some of her closest colleagues offered deeply personal accounts of her life and career.
lead_paragraph: Anja Niedringhaus, 48, an internationally known German photographer, was killed while on assignment in eastern Afghanistan on Friday. Some of her closest colleagues offered deeply personal accounts of her life and career.

abstract: Among the fans who will be celebrating the Mustang’s 50th birthday will be some owners who bought the car when it first went on sale.
lead_paragraph: Among the fans who will be celebrating the Mustang’s 50th birthday will be some owners who bought the car when it first went on sale.
