headline: Perry and Cruz on Base Shooting
abstract: Gov. Rick Perry and Senator Ted Cruz delivered remarks after meeting with military personnel wounded Wednesday in the shooting at Fort Hood in Texas.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Rick Perry and Senator Ted Cruz delivered remarks after meeting with military personnel wounded Wednesday in the shooting at Fort Hood in Texas.

headline: Inside Prison With Ponte
abstract: Joseph Ponte, New York’s newly appointed correction commissioner, has plans for reform. But Rikers will be a far bigger challenge than Maine’s jail system, where he instituted key changes.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Ponte, New York’s newly appointed correction commissioner, has plans for reform. But Rikers will be a far bigger challenge than Maine’s jail system, where he instituted key changes.

headline: Grandma’s Diamond Is Forever
abstract: Ian Ross’ paycheck as a freelance EMT wasn’t enough for bills and an engagement ring. So like many millennials, he turned to a family heirloom when he asked Madlyn Wendell to marry him.
lead_paragraph: Ian Ross’ paycheck as a freelance EMT wasn’t enough for bills and an engagement ring. So like many millennials, he turned to a family heirloom when he asked Madlyn Wendell to marry him.

headline: No Spring Thaw in the Job Market
abstract: The continuing sluggishness underscores that the recovery will not happen on its own.
lead_paragraph: One of the many good things about the arrival of spring is that politicians, economists and other policy makers can no longer blame the winter weather for the slow economy and the grinding pace of job growth.

headline: Weinstein Releases 2 French Films Without Fanfare
abstract: The Weinstein Company, no stranger to promotion, opted to open “The Players” and “On the Other Side of the Tracks” this weekend with no advance word.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As others roll out blockbusters, the movie mogul Harvey Weinstein is serving up seasonal fare that has become almost as rare as a good croque madame: French films.

headline: Ryan’s Plan: To Balance the Budget, Hurt the Poor
abstract: Sixty-nine percent of the cuts in the Ryan budget come from programs that benefit people with low or moderate incomes.
lead_paragraph: The House leadership is trying to muscle Paul Ryan’s 2015 budget plan through the Republican caucus, and the amount of effort required is revealing. The budget is full of breathtakingly unfair spending cuts, but many Republican House members don’t like it because they think it doesn’t go far enough.

headline: Brazilian Firm Magnifies Focus on Distressed Debt
abstract: Jive Investments Holding, which acquired some of Lehman Brothers’ Brazilian assets in 2010, is raising a new $100 million distressed-debt fund.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The investment firm Jive Investments Holding, which acquired some of Lehman Brothers’ Brazilian assets in 2010, is raising a new $100 million distressed-debt fund focused on nonperforming corporate loans, according to people briefed on the firm’s plans.

headline: Under a Shiny Shroud, Cloaked in Mystery
abstract: Luciana Achugar is bringing her “Otro Teatro,” which proposes growing a new body, to New York Live Arts.
lead_paragraph: “Otro Teatro,” the Spanish title of Luciana Achugar’s latest work, translates as “other theater” or “another theater,” with the possible connotation of an alternative one. The New York premiere on Wednesday took place in the conventional setting of the theater at New York Live Arts, but Ms. Achugar has some unconventional notions of what might transpire there for performers and audience. A handout suggests a project “to grow ourselves a new body,” “a utopian body,” “an anarchic body, “a body in pleasure.”

headline: Saying ‘Yes’ Before a Studio Audience
abstract: Two very different people find out that soul mates don’t come wrapped in perfection.
lead_paragraph: After exchanging emails and briefly talking on the phone, Sanjeev Sirpal knew it was time to meet a woman he had first encountered on Match.com.

headline: Weibo Seeks to Raise More Than $380 Million in I.P.O.
abstract: China’s Twitter-like microblogging services says that it hopes to price its sale of 20 million American depositary shares at $17 to $19 each.
lead_paragraph: If all goes according to plan, the biggest of China’s Twitter-like microblogging services will raise more than $380 million in its coming initial public offering.

headline: A Quick Take on an Unusual Book Review
abstract: We asked the culture department’s book editor, Rachel Saltz, a few questions about a recent review of a digital-only book.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, The Times published a rare review of a digital-only book. The book, “Sleep Donation,” by Karen Russell, was reviewed positively by Michiko Kakutani. In 2012, the book critic Dwight Garner reviewed 15 journalistic minibooks published for digital readers.

headline: David Letterman’s Legacy
abstract: Bill Carter, a media reporter for The Times, discusses David Letterman’s late-night legacy.
lead_paragraph: Bill Carter, a media reporter for The Times, discusses David Letterman’s late-night legacy.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Afghanistan, Kenya, South Africa and England.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Afghanistan, Kenya, South Africa and England.

headline: Lusty Warriors, Panting Anew
abstract: “Games of Thrones” begins its fourth season on Sunday with a teeming cast and the usual plotlines of power, lust, betrayal and revenge.
lead_paragraph: Television shows that deal routinely with death usually get it out of the way early: Someone dies at the beginning of the episode, and everyone else spends the rest of the hour talking about it. “Game of Thrones” turns that formula around. In the early weeks of this HBO hit’s fourth season, which begins on Sunday, people mostly talk for an hour — reminding us of who they are, which family they belong to, what castle they call home — until the episode ends with an operatic, in one case game-changing, killing.

headline: Understanding Particulars of G.M.’s Safety Recall
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Some questions and answers for drivers affected by G.M.’s recall of 2.6 million cars.
lead_paragraph: If you drive one of the 2.6 million General Motors cars recalled because of a faulty ignition switch, you’re probably eager for the part to be replaced. Dealerships say they are gearing up to schedule the work as soon as the necessary parts become available — which is expected to happen starting Monday, according to G.M. But it could take months to repair all the affected cars.

headline: Classical, as It Meets Club Scene
abstract: The Unsound Festival, which bypassed New York last year, is back, opening with a concert at Issue Project Room in Brooklyn on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: When the Unsound Festival, a highly regarded annual experimental-music series that started in Poland in 1993, first planted its flag in New York in 2010, it arrived with a vaguely precise mandate. “Advanced music,” Mat Schulz, the festival founder, put it in an interview in The New York Times that year: “a kind of approach to making music rather than strict definitions.” Accordingly, of-the-moment electronica jostled against outlier strains of classical music.

headline: TPG and Others Said to Agree to Invest in Airbnb
abstract: Investors have reached an agreement in principle to invest in Airbnb, valuing the site at about $10 billion, a person briefed on the matter said on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Updated April 5, 9:58 a.m. |

headline: Slain Photographer Had Covered Several War Zones
abstract: Some of the scenes captured by Anja Niedringhaus, a Pulitzer Prize-winning photographer who was killed by a police officer in Afghanistan on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Some of the scenes captured by Anja Niedringhaus, a Pulitzer Prize-winning photographer who was killed by a police officer in Afghanistan on Friday.

headline: Why That Sharp Wit Stood Out on Late Night
abstract: David Letterman’s retirement announcement and Chelsea Handler’s coming exit highlight the scarcity of caustic humor in the late-night talk landscape.
lead_paragraph: Life as we know it is over, and late-night television will never be the same.

headline: In Colorado, Cannabis Cup Time
keywords: ['Hashish', 'Law and Legislation', 'Marijuana', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Organizers of the fifth annual Cannabis Cup trade show in Denver are expecting the largest crowd in the event’s history.
lead_paragraph: With Colorado’s recent legalization of the recreational use of marijuana, ticket sales for Denver’s fifth annual Cannabis Cup this month are expected to double, according to event organizers.

headline: Vanderbilt Knockout Teams in Dallas
abstract: A look at the final of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams, the premier event at the Spring North American Championships.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — We are looking at the final of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams, the premier event at the Spring North American Championships here.

headline: Lupita’s Lancôme Gig, the Army’s Hair-Raiser and Christy Turlington’s Comeback
abstract: Plus, Marc by Marc’s social media moment, a powerful cosmetics campaign and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here are some of the things that got people talking today.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Affluent Wine Buyers in Asia Find Their Confidence
keywords: ['Wines', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: An adventurous and increasingly educated crowd is fueling a boom in fine wines in China and elsewhere in Asia, though prices have come down.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Six bottles of 1990 Romanée-Conti Burgundy sold to an Asian buyer at a Christie’s auction in Hong Kong last month for 980,000 Hong Kong dollars ($126,345). A case of wine from the Cros Parantoux vineyard in Burgundy, France, fetched $82,333 in a sale held by the American auction house Acker Merrall & Condit at a restaurant overlooking Hong Kong’s harbor.

headline: ‘With Grandma’s Ring, I Thee Wed’
abstract: For more young couples, the ideal engagement ring or wedding band is a family heirloom piece with personal meaning (and no price tag).
lead_paragraph: Nervous yet hopeful, Ian Ross knew what he wanted to ask, but he wasn’t sure just how to say it. He stared into her eyes, knowing that the whole proposal was riding on this moment.

headline: Hedge Fund Advertising Off to a Slow Start, Survey Finds
abstract: Only a fraction of hedge funds and private equity firms have even registered under a new statute that gives them the ability to broadly solicit capital.
lead_paragraph: Hedge funds have not exactly rushed to take advantage of their new ability to advertise.

headline: Stand Up, They’re Rocking the Boat, Like 1950 Again
abstract: A one-night-only performance of “Guys and Dolls” at Carnegie Hall on Thursday starred Nathan Lane, Patrick Wilson, Sierra Boggess and Megan Mullally.
lead_paragraph: For most people, the term fugue evokes a very sober, complex form of contrapuntal instrumental music. But then there is the “Fugue for Tinhorns,” the song that opens the classic 1950 musical “Guys and Dolls,” in which three small-time gamblers in New York argue over their picks to win a big horse race. Here was the great composer and lyricist Frank Loesser wresting the fugue form from classical music and turning it into a charming, clever, but no less musically ingenious opener for a show about some lovable denizens of the New York underworld, as vivid as ever in the brilliant book by Jo Swerling and Abe Burrows. And what better setting for that song, and Loesser’s inspired score, than Carnegie Hall, which on Thursday night hosted an exhilarating, one-time-only, ready-for-Broadway performance of “Guys and Dolls,” with Rob Fisher conducting the Orchestra of St. Luke’s, no less.

headline: A Petticoat as Spy Signal
abstract: Not all redcoats were alike, and neither were all patriots. Some were spies for the revolutionary cause, like the characters in “Turn,” new on AMC.
lead_paragraph: “Turn” could mean a lot of things. The Turn is what survivors on “The Walking Dead” call their zombie apocalypse. Repeated three times, it’s the title of a folk song, and it’s the first half of turncoat, as in traitor, or turndown, as in turndown service in a fancy hotel, or maybe just turnip, the root vegetable.

headline: So Far Away. No, She’s in Row K.
abstract: Carole King finally went to see “Beautiful: The Carole King Musical,” hiding in the Broadway theater audience in a dark wig and glasses.
lead_paragraph: It had become a confounding mystery of the Broadway season: Why hadn’t Carole King come to see the Carole King musical? Did it mean that she didn’t like the show and was trying to distance herself from it? Was she just a recluse holed up in Idaho who didn’t like crowds? Then why did she perform at the Grammys and make regular appearances on “Morning Joe”?

headline: What, Me Old?
abstract: Suddenly strangers seem to think I’m frail.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-five years ago, when the twin daughters of a childhood friend were 7 and I was 41, I told them that someday, when they were grown, I’d babysit for their children.

headline: Carlotta Gall on Fear and Hope in Afghanistan
abstract: Carlotta Gall, former Afghanistan correspondent for The Times, stopped by the paper’s New York offices on Friday to talk about the response to her book, the coming elections in Afghanistan and the long-term effects of covering a war zone.
lead_paragraph: In 2006, while reporting in Quetta, Pakistan, about the possible connection between Pakistan and the Taliban resurgence in Afghanistan, Carlotta Gall was attacked in her hotel room by four plainclothes agents of the I.S.I., Pakistan’s main intelligence service. Gall was punched twice in the face and temple, and her computer, notebooks and cellphone were seized.

headline: A Con Artist, a Librarian, Love and 76 Trombones
abstract: There’s trouble in River City, but also rhyme, rhythm and a lot of hope in “The Music Man,” Meredith Willson’s heartwarming 1957 musical.
lead_paragraph: Hope is a major theme of “The Music Man,” and the opening number of the show at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport raises hopes for a sterling production throughout. Meredith Willson’s heartwarming 1957 musical, which won the Tony Award for Best Musical over “West Side Story,” begins in a railway car filled with traveling salesmen who complain about a flimflam man in their trade named Harold Hill. Their fast-paced patter song, “Rock Island,” is set to the beat of their bouncy ride through the Iowa countryside. Tightly choreographed and precisely sung in this production, it is a delightful introduction to a clever musical that celebrates the joys of rhythm, rhyme and syncopation.

headline: Video: Nickolas Butler’s Wintry Place on Earth
abstract: Mr. Butler discusses writing his debut novel, frozen Wisconsin and the influence of Bon Iver.
lead_paragraph: EAU CLAIRE, Wis. — As Nickolas Butler explains it, he actually began “Shotgun Lovesongs,” his debut novel about the gravitational pull of a small Wisconsin town on a group of friends, in Iowa, with a fit of homesickness. He was in his first semester at the University of Iowa Writers’ Workshop, in a class with James Alan McPherson.

headline: Last Bohemian Turns Out the Lights
abstract: Clayton Patterson, an avant-garde artist, has been disillusioned by gentrification on the Lower East Side and is moving to Austria.
lead_paragraph: At the end of March, Clayton Patterson, the outlaw artist, was sitting in the window of his storefront home on Essex Street complaining about New York. It’s something Mr. Patterson does well. He is an accomplished ranter, whose disputes with the city are numerous and varied but tend to revolve around the ruination of the Lower East Side by luxury apartments, ugly corporate chain stores, overpriced parking meters, pretentious restaurants and college students who vomit on the street.

headline: Scrambling for a New Site
abstract: Couples search for new wedding venues after the Angel Orensanz Foundation for the Arts closes.
lead_paragraph: The moment Lisa Goldstein walked into the grand old former synagogue that is the Angel Orensanz Foundation for the Arts on the Lower East Side, she was in love. Ms. Goldstein, 33, said, “I always joked I picked the venue before the groom.” She and her fiancé, Keith Helman, 34, had booked the space for April 5, 2014. Invitations were sent. A Monique Lhuillier dress was picked out. Peter Callahan, the celebrity caterer, was booked.

headline: For Letterman’s Job, Dueling 10-Best Lists
abstract: It is now officially the most coveted job in television: successor to David Letterman. Let the maneuvering begin.
lead_paragraph: It is now officially the most coveted job in television: successor to David Letterman. Let the maneuvering begin.

headline: New York’s Police Department Has Been Watching
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: New York City’s Department of Records and Information Services released Friday thousands of newly digitized images, including ones collected in the ’30s and ’40s by the Bureau of Criminal Alien Investigation.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s Department of Records and Information Services released Friday thousands of newly digitized images, including ones collected in the ’30s and ’40s by the Bureau of Criminal Alien Investigation.

headline: The Few, the Brave: Men in Tights
abstract: Some men are finding their flair in wearing shorts over sports tights.
lead_paragraph: Given the winter’s crazy cold, it was hardly surprising to see men layering black sports tights under shorts for their workouts and outdoor runs — sensible, even. What was more of a shock was to see some of those men take the look out of the gym, incorporating it into their daily street wear.

headline: Parting Glance: Anja Niedringhaus
abstract: Anja Niedringhaus, 48, an internationally known German photographer, was killed while on assignment in eastern Afghanistan on Friday. Some of her closest colleagues offered deeply personal accounts of her life and career.
lead_paragraph: Anja Niedringhaus, a Pulitzer Prize-winning photographer for The Associated Press, was killed in Eastern Afghanistan today when an Afghan policeman approached her vehicle at a security checkpoint and opened fire with a Kalashnikov assault rifle. The German native was 48 years old.

headline: Who Are You on Facebook Now?
abstract: The social network customizes “gender” with 50 different choices, including non-binary, androgyne, gender questioning and neither.
lead_paragraph: On his driver’s license and passport, at his doctor’s office and insurance company, for online dating and social media, and on every application or document that requires checking a box for gender, 24-year-old Ryley Pogensky is a “male.” But to his friends on Facebook, he is now a “trans man.”

headline: Banking on My Future as a Father
keywords: ['Sperm', 'Infertility', 'In Vitro Fertilization', 'ARTIFICIAL INSEMINATION', 'Men and Boys', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Age, Chronological']
abstract: A spate of reports on potential fertility problems among older men sends the author on a mission to the sperm bank.
lead_paragraph: “When are you going to have one of these?” a friend asked a few months ago, referring to the 10-month-old crying baby in her arms.

headline: Apple and Samsung Fight Over Who Was the Follower
abstract: As a patent trial continued, Samsung’s lawyers showed internal Apple documents to paint a picture of Apple as a fading brand, concerned about its future after Samsung entered the handset market.
lead_paragraph: Last year, a member of Apple’s sales team prepared a research document expressing concern about the growth in sales of smartphones with larger screens, while sales in the segment of phones including the iPhone were slowing down.

headline: Corrosion Risk Prompts Ford Recall, and Spiders Clog Mazdas
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Spiders']
abstract: Exposure to road salt could result in a loss of steering in some Ford vehicles; spider webs may cause gas leaks in Mazda 6s.
lead_paragraph: Ford is recalling nearly 386,000 Escape sport utility vehicles from the 2001-4 model years because a corrosion problem could result in a loss of steering. The company is also recalling 49,000 vehicles from the 2013-14 model years because the seat backs are not strong enough, the automaker said in a news release on Friday.

headline: A Power Lunch, Times Two
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls', 'Work-Life Balance']
abstract: Julia Louis-Dreyfus and Nancy Pelosi compare notes on how they both scaled the heights of their male-dominated professions.
lead_paragraph: Talk about a high-concept lunch date: bring Nancy Pelosi, who from 2007 until 2011 was the first woman to serve as speaker of the House (she is now the minority leader), together with Julia Louis-Dreyfus, the actress who plays the vice president (and as-yet-unannounced presidential candidate) on the HBO comedy “Veep,” whose third season begins Sunday. Of course, Ms. Louis-Dreyfus has real-life rank, too, having won four Emmy Awards for her work on three television comedies: “Seinfeld” and “The New Adventures of Old Christine” as well as “Veep.”

headline: Master Drawings as Springboard for Invention
abstract: An exhibition at the Princeton University Art Museum includes more than 90 drawings.
lead_paragraph: It was only in the last century that drawing became a respectable, stand-alone medium. Before that, it was treated as an educational tool or as preparation for larger works. Drawings were often discarded and rarely signed, creating problems for curators and opportunities for enterprising forgers.

headline: Death of a Pied Piper
abstract: Frankie Knuckles, who died last week, once ruled the club floor.
lead_paragraph: Frankie Knuckles, the veteran club D.J. who died Monday at the age of 59 of complications from diabetes, may have ruled the underground club scene, but his death was mourned very publicly.

headline: The ‘No More Tears’ Formula for Yoga Wear
abstract: The workout clothes from Phat Buddha aim to reduce sobbing in the dressing room.
lead_paragraph: The moment of tears in the clothing-store dressing room has started at least a million diets. But for Alissa Benishai, a real estate developer, it started a business.

headline: It’s My Birthday. I’d Like That Shirt in Blue.
abstract: Gift registries, once the stuff of weddings, have branched out to other occasions.
lead_paragraph: When Jordan Weinstein turned 32, he did not send out invitations, host a party or even have a few friends over for cake. That all struck him as unnecessary and indulgent. What he did do, however, was register for gifts at REI, the sporting goods store, and then distribute the link to his mother, fiancée and brother to pass around.

headline: The Found Art of Thank-You Notes
abstract: Where messages in an inbox look little different from spam, a tidy square in a crammed mailbox commands attention.
lead_paragraph: When Jimmy Fallon sits down to write his weekly thank-you notes on “The Tonight Show,” he is both ribbing and breathing life into a custom many felt was headed the way of the dodo. “Thank you, cotton candy,” Mr. Fallon scribbles on a correspondence card, “for making my grandmother’s hair look delicious.” Thank you, “bowling, for giving me an excuse to drink with somebody else’s shoes on.”

headline: Under Cover: Taking On Wall Street
abstract: Brad Katsuyama, a former trader at the Royal Bank of Canada, is one of the main players in Michael Lewis’s story, “The Wolf Hunters of Wall Street,” and is featured on this week’s cover.
lead_paragraph: This week’s cover story tells how a small group of Royal Bank of Canada employees uncovered and then set out to counter the unfair advantages of high-frequency trading in the stock market. Brad Katsuyama, a former trader at the bank, is one of the main players in Michael Lewis’s story and is featured on this week’s cover.

headline: Nineties Nostalgia Propels Coogi Brand Resurgence
abstract: For an example of how ’90s nostalgia is propelling street wear and high-end fashion, consider vintage Coogi knitwear.
lead_paragraph: Ugly sweater party? Please. For another example of how ’90s nostalgia is propelling street wear and high-end fashion, consider Coogi knitwear, instantly recognizable for its rainbow of snarls and swirls.

headline: Starting Duda Pays Off as Mets Win Their First
abstract: Lucas Duda beat out Ike Davis for the starting job at first base, then hit two home runs as the Mets defeated the Reds.
lead_paragraph: In the midst of a miserable first week of the season, the Mets tried to eliminate at least one potential controversy by naming Lucas Duda as the starting first baseman on Friday. The protracted battle between Duda and Ike Davis threatened to be a distraction to a team fraught with bullpen, hitting and attendance issues.

headline: Sign of Spring on Pay: Real Wage Growth
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'United States Economy', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: Years after the recession, there are now signs that the labor market is tightening enough that more workers may get raises that significantly exceed inflation.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Dworkin, a Dallas builder, was surprised to find someone he didn’t recognize inside a half-finished house this winter where crews were about to texture the home’s drywall.

headline: The Dieting Supremacist. Hate Her.
abstract: After losing 20 pounds, an old nemesis sneers with disgust at people who are scarfing huge portions of calorie-rich foods.
lead_paragraph: I’ve lost almost 20 pounds in the last year — you still reading? — and I cannot tell you the contempt I feel when I see lesser beings stuffing their mouths with French fries and T-bone steak and pain au chocolat. Pain au chocolat is my favorite thing on earth. If I am ever sentenced to death for, say, kicking a teenage boy on Rollerblades in front of a truck, I will be requesting it as my last meal.

headline: Money Wins, Peace Loses
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Elections', 'McCutcheon v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Campaign Finance', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)']
abstract: A Supreme Court decision and a foundering Mideast peace process made this a week for cynics to shrug their shoulders.
lead_paragraph: This was a week for cynics to shrug their shoulders. In Washington, the conservative majority on the Supreme Court struck down aggregate limits on individual campaign contributions, arguing in effect that these denied the very rich their right to participate fully in the political process. And in the Middle East, John Kerry became the latest in a long line of secretaries of state to watch his or her “peace process” founder in the deep fog of Israeli-Palestinian recriminations and distrust.

headline: Airport Workers March on a Symbolic Day
abstract: Airport workers, elected officials and community leaders rallied for improved wages, benefits and a paid holiday.

headline: Iran: Border Guards Released by Pakistani Militants
abstract: Four of five Iranian border guards seized by Pakistani militants along the volatile Iran-Pakistan frontier two months ago have been released, Iran state media reported Friday.
lead_paragraph: Four of five Iranian border guards seized by Pakistani militants along the volatile Iran-Pakistan frontier two months ago have been released, Iran state media reported Friday. The captors claimed to have executed one of the border guards. Iran’s government-run Press TV website quoted Esmail Kosari, deputy chairman of a parliamentary committee on national security and foreign policy, as saying that the other four had been handed over to Iranian officials in Pakistan. It was not immediately clear why they had been released, and there was no confirmation from Pakistan’s government. The abductions on Feb. 6 caused deep strains in relations between Iran and Pakistan, and the Iranians had threatened to send troops into Pakistani territory to rescue the captives. The border area, in Sistan-Baluchistan Province in southeastern Iran, is a hotbed of Sunni militant resistance to Iran’s Shiite authorities. In October, Iran executed 16 Sunni insurgents in retaliation for an attack by armed men who crossed the border from Pakistan and killed 14 Iranian border guards near the city of Saravan.

headline: Bill Cunningham | At Face Value
abstract: The fact is, fashion is commerce. But it can also be wearable art.
lead_paragraph: The fact is, fashion is commerce. But it can also be wearable art.

headline: Judge Loath to Permit TV Testimony on Islamist
abstract: A prosecution witness in the coming trial of Mostafa Kamel Mostafa, a cleric accused of aiding Al Qaeda, is reluctant to come to New York from Britain.
lead_paragraph: The testimony of a key prosecution witness in the terrorism trial of a radical Islamic cleric has been thrown into doubt because a federal judge in Manhattan is balking at allowing him to testify from Britain via closed-circuit television.

headline: Bill Cunningham | At Face Value
abstract: The fact is, fashion is commerce. But sometimes it can be wearable art.
lead_paragraph: The fact is, fashion is commerce. But students (above) waiting to get into a show in Paris have yet to discover that it is not an art form, although some looks at the shows there resemble walking sculptures that perhaps should be shown at the Venice Biennale: Issey Miayke’s Tree Ring pleated dresses, Gareth Pugh, Rick Owens and Junya Watanabe. Comme des Garçons has completely abandoned wearable clothes for wearable sculptures. That label’s work resembles that of Chakaia Booker, an American artist. Around Paris, other examples of fashion as art include, bottom row, faces in color.

headline: Evening Hours | Bring On the Greenery
abstract: Protecting the oceans, animals and art.
lead_paragraph: Protecting the oceans, animals and art.

headline: Lingering Hope vs. Onset of Grief Over Lost Flight
abstract: Two sons of passengers on Flight 370 have chosen different ways to cope: One holds vigil with other passengers’ relatives, while the other is assuming the worst.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Steve Wang has not slept at his home in Beijing since Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 vanished with his mother on board. His days are a blur of rooms at the Lido Hotel: his suite on the 13th floor; the capacious ballroom, where Malaysian officials hold briefings; quiet corners where he has anguished meetings with other passengers’ relatives also living at the hotel. There are meals in between, though he said he no longer felt hunger.

headline: Police Believe Boy, 16, Killed Deliveryman
abstract: James Sanders, 16, is suspected of firing the shot that killed Richard Salvia on a desolate Staten Island street.
lead_paragraph: A 16-year-old and two older teenagers were arrested on Friday on murder charges in the fatal shooting of a deliveryman on a desolate street on the north shore of Staten Island, the police said.

headline: Before Joining a Board, Size Up the Job and the Mission
abstract: Giving back is something many people of means want to do. But not all boards are the same.
lead_paragraph: IN the last five years, Keith T. Banks, the president of U.S. Trust, a private wealth management division of Bank of America, has done what many of the firm’s wealthy clients do: He has joined nonprofit boards. He’s up to four. Yet the boards he sits on are not only different in mission, but also in size and expectations for trustees.

headline: Viewing Video Games From Another Level
abstract: “The Art of Video Games” is on view through May 18 at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers.
lead_paragraph: A benchmark for video games as cultural artifacts came in 2012 when the Museum of Modern Art in New York announced it had acquired 14 games for its collection. Depending on your perspective, the museum might be a little late in acknowledging the significance of video games — or early, compared with other art institutions. (The games were acquired by the museum’s department of architecture and design, putting them in the “design” category rather than alongside painting and sculpture.) Now, an ambitious survey of video games organized by the Smithsonian American Art Museum, and previously on view there, is at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers.

headline: A Resolution at Last for a Father’s Unsettling Legacy
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Synagogues', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Concentration Camps', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Ashes from Dachau were pressed from hand to hand with an admonition. Forgetting was impossible, but so was deciding what to do with them.
lead_paragraph: DOBSON, N.C. — Sometime in late 2012, feeling his mortality after two heart attacks, Joseph Corsbie realized that the moment had come to tell the story of the ashes. He had first heard it nearly 30 years earlier from his father, Walter. And only in the face of imminent death had Walter finally spoken, keeping his promise to never forget.

headline: Second Maker of Car Seats Cites Buckle Flaw in Recall
keywords: ['Child Car Seats', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: But Evenflo is refusing to recall rear-facing infant seats that use the same buckle.
lead_paragraph: The Evenflo Company is recalling almost 1.4 million child restraints because a balky buckle could make it hard to free the child in an emergency. But the manufacturer is refusing to recall rear-facing infant seats that use the same buckle, according to a report from Evenflo posted on Friday on the website of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: U.S. Eyes Afghan Vote, Seeking Amenable Ally
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Elections', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Obama administration officials will closely watch this weekend’s election in Afghanistan, hoping that a successor to President Hamid Karzai will allow international troops to remain on the ground.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has watched cautiously from the sidelines in the months leading up to Saturday’s elections in Afghanistan, focusing instead on new crises in the Middle East and Ukraine, and no longer on the country that was a foreign policy priority when President Obama first entered office.

headline: In Bid for Revote, Union Claims Tennessee Officials Frightened Workers
abstract: The United Automobile Workers has seized on leaked documents from Gov. Bill Haslam in its efforts to persuade the National Labor Relations Board to order a new unionization election at the Volkswagen plant in Chattanooga.
lead_paragraph: The United Automobile Workers has seized on leaked documents from Gov. Bill Haslam of Tennessee in its efforts to persuade the National Labor Relations Board to order a new unionization election at the Volkswagen plant in Chattanooga.

headline: Charter School Refugees
abstract: Some schools in New York City serve more special-needs students than others.
lead_paragraph: LAST week, the New York State Legislature struck a deal ensuring that charter schools in New York City would have access to space, either in already crowded public school buildings or in rented spaces largely paid for by the city. Over the next few years, charters are expected to serve an increasing proportion of city students — perhaps as much as 10 percent. Which brings up the question: Is there a point at which fostering charter schools undermines traditional public schools and the children they serve?

headline: Curtis Bill Pepper, Author, Reporter and Traveler, Is Dead at 96
abstract: Mr. Pepper, a prolific journalist and author, excelled at finding anecdotes that revealed greater truths about his subjects.
lead_paragraph: Curtis Bill Pepper, an author and reporter who roamed Europe and the Middle East for more than 40 years writing about politics, film, art, the Vatican, Leonardo da Vinci and more, died on Friday at his home in Todi, Italy. He was 96.

headline: Michael Lewis’s Crusade
keywords: ['High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: An imperfect tale of high-frequency trading provides a much needed spark.
lead_paragraph: There is always something just a little frustrating about reading a Michael Lewis book. On the one hand, Lewis’s core point — whether it is that left tackle has become the second most important position in football (“The Blind Side”), or that the stock market has become rigged by high-frequency traders, as his new book, “Flash Boys,” claims — is almost always dead-on. His ability to find compelling characters and tell a great story through their eyes is unparalleled. He can untangle complex subjects like few others. His prose sparkles.

headline: Personality and Change Inflamed Mozilla Crisis
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The issues troubling Mozilla, a highly unusual tech titan, run deeper than the firestorm that led to the departure of its chief, Brendan Eich, after only two weeks.
lead_paragraph: Mozilla is not your typical Silicon Valley company.

headline: All in the Family, Sort Of
abstract: More lessons from the campaign trail. When you’re making a photo album, people, no pics of strange pigs or point guards!
lead_paragraph: Here’s the latest life lesson from the campaign trail: If you are, say, making a home movie about how great your family is, try to remember to use pictures of your actual relatives, and not random attractive strangers.

headline: Grandstanding on Prisons in Texas
abstract: Gov. Rick Perry is bellowing about imaginary overreach from Washington and refusing to comply with the Prison Rape Elimination Act.
lead_paragraph: Rick Perry, the Republican governor of Texas, is gearing up for the 2016 presidential elections by bellowing about imaginary overreach from Washington and refusing to comply with the Prison Rape Elimination Act of 2003.

headline: Army Base Shooting Highlights Difficulty in Identifying At-Risk Soldiers
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Fort Hood Shooting (2014)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Firearms']
abstract: The recent Fort Hood shooting has shed light on the difficulties the military has had in identifying soldiers at high risk of violence and deciding whether to restrict their access to firearms.
lead_paragraph: The case of the Army specialist who opened fire with a .45-caliber Smith & Wesson handgun at Fort Hood on Wednesday is casting light on the difficulties the military has had in identifying soldiers at high risk of violence and deciding whether to restrict their access to firearms.

lead_paragraph: Heather Hardy, 5 feet 5 inches of determination, began boxing in 2010 and is on a roll, undefeated after nine professional fights..

keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Discrimination']
abstract: A federal judge in Cincinnati declared Friday that he would require Ohio to recognize same-sex marriages performed legally in other states.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Cincinnati declared Friday that he would require Ohio to recognize same-sex marriages performed legally in other states, the latest in a series of court decisions around the country overturning restrictive state marriage laws and amendments.

headline: Applications Fall and Admission Rate Rises as Cooper Union Charges Tuition
abstract: Once revered for being “free as air and water” and for its selective application process, Cooper Union in the East Village has increased tuition and accepted a higher percentage of students than in previous years.
lead_paragraph: The results are in for the first big test of Cooper Union’s new era — the era in which students actually pay to attend — and the university appears to have scored about 80 percent.

headline: Polarizing Wildcats Find Their Way Together
abstract: Andrew and Aaron Harrison have been praised for their talent and criticized for their demeanors, but they have found their footing recently with the Wildcats.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Tex. — On a cul-de-sac in a leafy residential subdivision in this booming oil town 30 miles west of Houston, Andrew and Aaron Harrison were raised to look out for each other, as perhaps only identical twins could.

abstract: The Army said that the soldiers killed in the Fort Hood rampage were highly decorated veterans who had served multiple tours of duty.
lead_paragraph: The Army on Friday identified the three people killed in a shooting rampage at Fort Hood as decorated soldiers who had served multiple tours of duty overseas.

headline: Grand Jury Questions Christie Aide in an Inquiry

lead_paragraph: The chief spokesman for Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey appeared before a grand jury in Newark on Friday to answer questions in the federal inquiry into the George Washington Bridge lane closing scandal.

headline: Hand-to-Hand Coordination
abstract: Saturday crunchiness with Ashton Anderson and James Mulhern.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I’ve never had a crossword puzzle make me think of the actor Keanu Reeves right off the bat, but that’s exactly what Ashton Anderson’s and James Mulhern’s grid did for me. The WHOA at 1 Across, made even more Keanu-y by the “Bill and Ted’s Excellent Adventure” clue “That’s crazy, dude!” got Mr. Reeves stuck in my head while I tackled the northwest corner.

headline: Saturday’s Highlights: From 4 to 2
abstract: Highlights from Saturday’s N.C.A.A. men’s tournament games.
lead_paragraph: If top-seeded Florida is to win its third national title in nine seasons, it must first topple No. 7 Connecticut, which dealt the Gators their last loss, on Dec. 2, before defeating either No. 2 Wisconsin, the only other team to beat the Gators this season, or No. 8 Kentucky, which has lost all three matchups with Florida this season.

headline: French Push U.N. to Seek War Crimes Case in Syria
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'International Relations']
abstract: The French have taken the first steps toward a Security Council referral of Syrians suspected of war crimes to the International Criminal Court.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — France has taken the first steps toward proposing a Security Council resolution that would refer Syria to the International Criminal Court for the prosecution of war crimes, diplomats said Friday, an action long sought by rights advocates.

headline: We Were Just Laughing: Days With Anja Niedringhaus and Kathy Gannon
abstract: A reporter who was recently with Anja Niedringhaus and Kathy Gannon of The Associated Press, longtime fellow chroniclers of events in Afghanistan, reflects on the attack on them and the changing environment in the country.
lead_paragraph: It is heartbreaking to call friends and colleagues in Kabul on a day like this. The connection from the United States is bad and I can barely catch their words. I was just there with them all earlier this week, laughing and swapping stories with two veteran journalists, Anja Niedringhaus and Kathy Gannon of The Associated Press, longtime fellow chroniclers of events in Afghanistan.

headline: Waiting for the Markets to Blink
keywords: ['Mutual Funds', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Interest Rates', 'United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Quantitative Easing']
abstract: Stocks are priced as if buyers see prosperity around the corner. But bond yields indicate pessimism. Successful investing for the rest of 2014 may hinge on knowing who’s right.
lead_paragraph: HEADING into the second quarter, investors seem to have little conviction about the direction of stock and bond markets. Both ended the first three months of 2014 barely changed, despite a big change in Federal Reserve policy.

headline: My Bitcoin Befuddlement
abstract: For this potential investor, a virtual currency might look more appealing if he could just fathom how it worked.
lead_paragraph: AM I the only person in the world who doesn’t have Bitcoin jangling in a cryptographic wallet? Sometimes it seems that way.

headline: Complaints Build as a Cathedral Project Begins Its Rise
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Building (Construction)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Officials at St. John the Divine say the church needs the money from the 430-apartment project, which neighborhood residents say is “monstrous.”
lead_paragraph: Laurie Frey heard jackhammers one morning this week and raced down the block to find demolition workers preparing to cut down the tall trees on the lot next to the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine. She realized what the power saws meant: A project to build a second apartment complex on the cathedral grounds was finally beginning.

headline: Seeking Silver Linings in Emerging Markets

lead_paragraph: IN a quarter in which most stock funds eked out small gains, emerging-market equity portfolios couldn’t even manage that much.

headline: When Bond Funds Think Outside the Box
abstract: Unconstrained bond funds can invest anywhere, but they can also be riskier than their traditional counterparts.
lead_paragraph: UNCONSTRAINED bond funds can own debt instruments of any type — long- or short-term, high- or low-quality, corporate or government or whatever, in any country and currency — to try to enhance returns. With interest rates near record lows and investors eager to bolster yields, enthusiasm for these portfolios, also known as nontraditional funds, seems boundless too.

headline: Technology That Transforms Life (and Mutual Funds’ Returns)

abstract: Cloud computing, personalized medicine, robotics and other tech innovations brought big returns for some mutual funds in the first quarter.

The managers of three mutual funds — Fidelity OTC Portfolio, Lord Abbett Micro Cap Growth and Driehaus Micro Cap Growth — have all focused on it, and their approach put them among the performance leaders in the first quarter.

headline: How E.T.F.s Have Gained Momentum
abstract: As a group, exchange-traded funds remain far smaller than mutual funds. But E.T.F. assets grew at a faster clip than those of mutual funds in the 12 months through February.
lead_paragraph: MUTUAL funds in the United States held $15.2 trillion in February. Exchange-traded funds were tiny by comparison, with only $1.7 trillion.

headline: Dreaming of a Maserati, but Staying the Course
keywords: ['Retirement', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Stocks and Bonds', '401(k), 403(b) and 457 Plans', 'Mutual Funds', 'Savings', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: When you reach 59 1/2, the magic age for penalty-free withdrawals from retirement accounts, it’s tempting (if not advisable) to go on a spending spree.
lead_paragraph: I GAINED access to a windfall the other day. And after fantasizing briefly about all the things I could buy, I’ve decided not to touch the money.

headline: New Global Aids Chief for U.S. Assumes Post
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome']
abstract: Dr. Deborah Birx, a former chief for global AIDS for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, was sworn in on Friday as the nation’s global AIDS coordinator.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Deborah Birx, a former chief for global AIDS for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, was sworn in on Friday as the nation’s global AIDS coordinator. The post puts Dr. Birx, a former Army colonel, in charge of the President’s Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief and American participation in the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria. A vast majority of all funds spent on global health come from those two organizations. Dr. Birx is the fourth to hold the post, which was created under the George W. Bush administration. It is in the State Department and carries ambassadorial rank. Dr. Eric Goosby, the last coordinator, resigned in November. His predecessor, Dr. Mark Dybul, is now executive director of the Global Fund, which is based in Geneva.

headline: Lawmakers Deserve More Pay, Congressman Says
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Representative James P. Moran says members of Congress cannot “live decently” in Washington on their $174,000 salary and deserve more money.
lead_paragraph: Representative James P. Moran says members of Congress cannot “live decently” in Washington on their $174,000 salary and deserve more money. Their pay has been frozen since 2010, and Mr. Moran, a Virginia Democrat who is not seeking re-election, told Roll Call that he would introduce a measure that would provide members with a per diem allowance. “The fact is that this is the board of directors for the largest economic entity in the world,” Mr. Moran said.

headline: Pro’s Example Keeps Connecticut’s Foul Shooting Sharp
abstract: During the N.C.A.A. men’s tournament the Huskies have made 88 percent of their free throws, with some help from a video of N.B.A. player Steve Nash.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Whether Connecticut has better 3-point shooters than Florida, or better rebounders or ball handlers, is up for debate. This much about their matchup Saturday night, though, is unassailable: The Huskies are the superior free-throw shooting team.

headline: Judge Dismisses Suit Against Administration Officials Over Drone Strikes
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Targeted Killings']
abstract: A federal judge ruled that courts should hesitate before holding a government official personally responsible for violating a citizen’s rights in the context of a wartime action.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Friday dismissed a lawsuit against top Obama administration officials that was filed by the parents of three United States citizens whom the government killed without trial in drone strikes, including Anwar al-Awlaki, a radical Muslim cleric.

headline: Creatures Great, Small and Imagined
abstract: The “James Prosek: Wondrous Strange” exhibition runs through June 8 in the McKernan Gallery at the New Britain Museum of American Art.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 700 pounds and 15 feet long, the blue marlin lay on the deck of a fishing boat off the coast of Cape Verde as James Prosek snapped photographs, made sketches and took measurements. Awe-struck and moved, he watched the giant fish’s colors fade from their living vibrancy to the muted tones of death.

headline: Mouse Infestation Closes Birthplace of the Cronut
keywords: ['Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Mice', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning']
abstract: A YouTube video showing a rodent in the Dominique Ansel Bakery led health officials to shut the shop temporarily.
lead_paragraph: New York City residents and tourists are apparently not alone in their love of Cronuts, those croissant-and-doughnut hybrids that have people lined up for blocks before dawn outside a SoHo bakery.

headline: Knicks Fall to Washington, and Drop Behind Atlanta
abstract: Needing to keep pace with Atlanta in the Eastern Conference playoff race, the Knicks dropped a home-court game against Washington by a point.
lead_paragraph: Carmelo Anthony was able to string together so many good days and nights for the Knicks that it almost came to be taken for granted. But when the Knicks desperately needed Anthony, facing a must-have game against the Washington Wizards with the schedule dwindling to a handful of dates, he struggled to play through an injury to his right shoulder and was ultimately unable to provide another big effort.

headline: Rocked at Start, Tanaka Finds Rhythm and Lifts Yankees to Win
abstract: After giving up a home run in the first inning, Masahiro Tanaka found his rhythm and helped the Yankees to a 7-3 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Three pitches into Masahiro Tanaka’s major league career, one thing was clear on Friday. As good as he may be, and as much faith as the Yankees had in him to commit $175 million for his services, Tanaka is not unhittable.

headline: Fewer Pupils Qualify for Gifted Programs
abstract: Some wonder who is being left out after the New York City Department of Education released data on Friday that shows a decrease in gifted enrollment.
lead_paragraph: The numbers of children qualifying for seats in gifted programs in New York City public schools declined this year, the Education Department said on Friday, though they were still far higher than when citywide admissions testing began a few years ago.

headline: As Critics Vent, Maple Leafs Take Deep Breaths
abstract: The Leafs have slid down the standings, and passionate fans in Toronto have little patience with a franchise that has not won a Stanley Cup since 1967.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The fading playoff hopes of the Toronto Maple Leafs rest with the backup goaltender James Reimer, who was vilified by some frustrated, overzealous fans two weeks ago in a series of nasty messages sent to his wife’s Twitter account.

headline: James Benkard Dies at 76; Defended Inmates in Death Penalty Cases
abstract: Mr. Benkard was a corporate lawyer who was honored for his work in cases involving the death penalty and prisoners with mental illness.
lead_paragraph: James W. B. Benkard, a prominent New York corporate lawyer who was honored for his extensive pro bono work in cases involving the death penalty and prisoners with mental illness, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 76.

headline: Rough Start Aside, an Elite Debut
abstract: The Yankees’ Masahiro Tanaka struck out eight and walked none. Only five pitchers since 1914 had been able to match or better those totals in their major league debuts.
lead_paragraph: Masahiro Tanaka’s adjustment period to Major League Baseball appeared to last about three innings.

headline: Corrections: April 5, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on April 5, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (HBO) MAN OF STEEL (2013) The director Zack Snyder traces the path of Clark Kent, portrayed by a ripped Henry Cavill, above, from boy to man — and superhero status — in this newfangled origin story. Russell Crowe and Ayelet Zurer play Jor-El and Lara Lor-Van, the birth parents of Clark, who was born Kal-El on the doomed planet Krypton; Diane Lane and Kevin Costner are Martha and Jonathan Kent, the Kansas couple who adopt him after he’s rocketed to Earth; Amy Adams is his romantic interest, Lois Lane; and Michael Shannon is General Zod, his alien foe. “At once frantically overblown and beautifully filigreed, ‘Man of Steel’ will turn on everyone it doesn’t turn off,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “If you wave away all the computer-generated smoke and see past the pulverized buildings, it’s possible to remain hooked on the resonant origin story that wends through ‘Man of Steel’ — that of the immigrant.” And while Mr. Snyder isn’t capable of mythmaking, she added, “in his sometimes poetic, sometimes crude way, he has given Superman a new lease on franchise life by affirming that this most American hero is also an alien yearning to breathe free.”

headline: 4 Killed After Car Plunges Into Creek, Police Say
abstract: Rescue divers pulled four victims from a creek in Astoria after the vehicle they were riding veered off the road.
lead_paragraph: Four people died on Friday night after the car they were riding in veered off a rain-slicked road, hit a curb and flipped into a creek off the East River, authorities said.

headline: Afghan Turnout Is High as Voters Defy the Taliban
keywords: ['Voting and Voters', 'United States International Relations', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Elections']
abstract: The election will mark the first time Afghans have changed their leader at the polls in modern history as Hamid Karzai’s dozen years in power end.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Defying a campaign of Taliban violence that unleashed 39 suicide bombers in the two months before Election Day, Afghan voters on Saturday turned out in such high numbers to choose a new president and provincial councils that polling hours were extended nationwide, in a triumph of determination over intimidation.

headline: U.S. Response to Crimea Worries Japan’s Leaders
abstract: The failure of the United States to take more forceful action to help Ukraine leaves Japan concerned about whether Washington would aid it in a conflict with China.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — When President Bill Clinton signed a 1994 agreement promising to “respect” the territorial integrity of Ukraine if it gave up its nuclear weapons, there was little thought then of how that obscure diplomatic pact — called the Budapest Memorandum — might affect the long-running defense partnership between the United States and Japan.

abstract: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is facing questions over its handling of the General Motors scandal involving defective ignition switches.

headline: Analytics: Taking Sides
abstract: Benoit Denizet-Lewis’s article on the science of bisexuality garnered more than 400 comments from readers. Here’s what they had to say.

headline: Ship Reports Getting Signal That Could Be Black Box of Missing Jet
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: Australian authorities said that they were investigating reports by ships in the search flotilla that underwater sensors had picked up signals that could be from the plane’s data and voice recorders.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Australian authorities coordinating the multinational search for the missing Malaysia Airlines plane in the southern Indian Ocean said Sunday that they were investigating three reports by ships in the search flotilla that underwater sensors had picked up signals that could be from the plane’s data and voice recorders.

keywords: ['Part-Time Employment', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Workplace Environment', 'Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Work-Life Balance']
abstract: A part-time department director would like to move up to full-time work. But despite taking on new responsibilities, she hasn’t been able to persuade management.
lead_paragraph: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: Paid for Playing Games
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Mobile Applications', 'Careers and Professions', 'Labor and Jobs']

headline: An Economic Gauge, Imperfect but Vital
keywords: ['Gross Domestic Product', 'Books and Literature', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A new book, “G.D.P.: A Brief but Affectionate History,” conveys a sophisticated understanding of the often-cited measure of the economy.
lead_paragraph: In “G.D.P.: A Brief but Affectionate History,” Diane Coyle, a British economist, conveys a sophisticated understanding of an economic standby, the quarterly measure of gross domestic product. A vital gauge of any nation’s prosperity, the G.D.P. has its strengths and its limitations, which are well explained in Dr. Coyle’s rich and engaging little book.

headline: Automation Alone Isn’t Killing Jobs
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Part-Time Employment', 'Unemployment', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The long-term unemployed are now burdened by complex interactions of technology, education and market demand.
lead_paragraph: Although the labor market report on Friday showed modest job growth, employment opportunities remain stubbornly low in the United States, giving new prominence to the old notion that automation throws people out of work.

headline: The Oracle of Omaha, Lately Looking a Bit Ordinary
abstract: Yes, Warren Buffett’s 49-year market record is stellar. Just don’t count the last five.
lead_paragraph: Warren Buffett is probably the most famous investor of his generation, and for good reason: His track record over the long term is a thing of beauty.

headline: Kim Bowers of CST Brands, on Managing Up vs. Managing Down
abstract: A chief executive says she prefers people who know how to manage down: “If I find someone whose team would walk across hot coals for them, that’s the person I want to work with.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Kim Bowers, chief executive of CST Brands, a gas-station and convenience-store retailer, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: I Had a Nice Time With You Tonight. On the App.
abstract: In a new app, a business model expands from connecting singles to keeping romantic partners together.
lead_paragraph: Last Sunday, I spent a lazy afternoon with my boyfriend. We chatted while I made brunch, discussed the books we were reading, laughed at some cat pictures and then settled down with dinner, before bidding each other good night.

headline: The Wallet as Ethics Enforcer
abstract: Take back executives’ bonuses? It’s not likely to happen at G.M., or at many other companies, under current rules.
lead_paragraph: There is a lot we don’t yet know about the disastrous decisions made by General Motors after it became aware of faulty ignition switches in its Chevrolet Cobalts more than 10 years ago.

headline: Space Chips for the Common Man
abstract: Satellites are quickly falling in price. In the latest turn, a Cornell student is putting into space 104 birds that he says are less than an inch and a half on a side, and cost about $30 each in parts.
lead_paragraph: Moore’s Law is taking over space.

headline: 2 Italian Priests and a Canadian Nun Are Abducted in Cameroon
abstract: The three were said to be taken by “unknown people” who broke open the doors of their residences in an area near the Nigerian border that is known for kidnappings.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Two Italian priests and a Canadian nun were abducted early Saturday from their mission in northern Cameroon, the Italian government and Vatican officials said.

headline: Journeyman on the PGA Tour Downsizes His Life and Upgrades His Game
abstract: Will MacKenzie credits much of his success this year — over $1.7 million in earnings — to putting his life in order, after making less than $50,000 golfing in 2012.
lead_paragraph: Last Sunday in San Antonio, as Will MacKenzie played into contention at the Texas Open, he tried to keep thoughts of the Masters out of his head. He was tied for second after a final-round 70, and then waited for the leader, Steven Bowditch, to finish.

headline: For Soprano, From ‘Butterfly’ to ‘Bohème,’ in a Flash
abstract: Kristine Opolais, who sang the title role in “Madama Butterfly” at the Metropolitan Opera Friday night, stepped in at the last minute Saturday afternoon as Mimi in “La Bohème.”
lead_paragraph: Last-minute cast changes at opera houses are always full of drama, but the one that took place in Saturday afternoon’s performance of Puccini’s “La Bohème” at the Metropolitan Opera promises to go down in the annals of day-of-the-performance substitutions.

headline: Vivendi Chooses to Sell Mobile Phone Unit to Altice, Ending Noisy Bidding War
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: The French media conglomerate Vivendi said it would sell SFR to Altice in a deal worth as much as 17 billion euros, or about $23.3 billion.
lead_paragraph: After a bidding war, the French media conglomerate Vivendi said Saturday that it would sell its mobile phone unit, SFR, to Altice in a deal worth as much as 17 billion euros, or about $23.3 billion.

headline: As Their Numbers Fall, College Basketball’s Black Coaches Face a Conundrum
abstract: In 2014, the percentage of African-American head coaches is at its lowest level since the 1995-96 season.
lead_paragraph: Sometime around 1989, a small group of black coaches and writers began a Final Four tradition. We would meet, at coffee houses, snack shops, dimly lit restaurants, and talk into the hours of the morning about issues affecting young black athletes.

headline: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 68
abstract: Both Gerd Müller and Miroslav Klose are tied as the over all career-leading goal-scorers for Germany with 68.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Despite Support in Party, Democratic Governors Resist Legalizing Marijuana
abstract: Despite a slight majority of support by Americans, some Democratic governors are leery about having their states become the next to legitimize marijuana.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — California voters strongly favor legalizing marijuana. The state Democratic Party adopted a platform last month urging California to follow Colorado and Washington in ending marijuana prohibition. The state’s lieutenant governor, Gavin Newsom, has called for legalizing the drug.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, April 6
abstract: Notable quotes from business articles that appeared in The New York Times last week.
lead_paragraph: “The recovery still feels like a recession to many Americans and it also looks that way in some economic statistics.”

headline: For Knicks, Mediocrity Is No Bar to Postseason
abstract: A late-season surge is likely to send the Knicks to the N.B.A. playoffs with a sub-.500 record as the No. 8 seed in the Eastern Conference.
lead_paragraph: Carmelo Anthony and his teammates represent the 68th Knicks team. Surprisingly, they still have a chance to become the 43rd to make the playoffs. Of those 43, they would be the seventh to have a losing record. And of those with losing records, they almost certainly would be the worst of the bunch.

headline: First Reviews Confirm Replay as a Strategy, Not a Cure-All
abstract: Of the first 20 calls reviewed on video replay, 12 held up, and a spent appeal cost the Giants in a close game.
lead_paragraph: The least shocking news of the first full week of the baseball season should be this: The new instant replay system did not reverse every missed call. That was not the intent.

headline: Family Connection Breaks Ground at Masters
abstract: Kevin Stadler and his father, Craig, who have drifted over the years, will be reunited at Augusta National this week, the first father and son to play the tournament in the same year.
lead_paragraph: For Craig Stadler and his firstborn, Kevin, golf is the multivitamin that renews their father-and-son relationship. Like countless others, the Stadlers will converge on a golf course this week from different states and different stages of their careers to play a few rounds and catch up on each other’s hectic lives.

headline: War Pain Yields to New Anxiety Inside Ft. Hood
keywords: ['Fort Hood Shooting (2014)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The number of soldiers at Fort Hood has fallen, and as the Army moves away from wartime footing, those who planned to make a career in the military face an uncertain path.
lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex. — Pastor Randall Wallace of the First Baptist Church of Killeen has watched thousands of troops head off to war and then come home to Fort Hood, the mammoth military base that shares this patch of Central Texas with an unpretentious jumble of pawn shops, fast food joints and vinyl-sided bungalows.

headline: In Women’s Final Four, Jousting Before the First Jump Ball
abstract: As they prepare for the N.C.A.A. women’s basketball semifinals, Notre Dame Coach Muffet McGraw and UConn’s Geno Auriemma each have a story to tell.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Not long after Muffet McGraw won her first and only national championship in 2001, she was cold-called by Paul Gullifor, a Notre Dame loyalist, women’s basketball aficionado, college professor and author.

headline: O Caddie! My Caddie!
abstract: Poets have reflected on golf’s highs and lows for centuries, using techniques that are central to the game itself.
lead_paragraph: Tempo, rhythm and timing.
