lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: For the Devils, Shootouts Become a No-Win Mind Game
abstract: If the Devils had won four of their 11 shootouts this season, they would have entered this next-to-last weekend of the regular season in a wild-card playoff spot.
lead_paragraph: The Devils have a case of the yips. Not your garden variety, as with a golfer losing his putting touch. This one runs through the whole team and has been going on all season.

headline: Encouraging Debut and Frustrating Loss for Yankees
abstract: Michael Pineda had a strong performance on the mound Saturday, but R. A. Dickey was better, and Toronto defeated the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The return of Michael Pineda after two years of rehabilitation was supposed to be the final sign that the Yankees had recovered their health and that the numerous injuries that plagued them in 2013 were a thing of the past.

headline: John Calipari’s Trip to the Final, Step by Agonizing Step
abstract: Despite a troublesome hip, Kentucky’s coach is focused on the task at hand — trying to win another championship.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — John Calipari descended five steps from the court at AT&T Stadium, passed a marching band, 14 rows of seats and a towering stanchion of stands before lurching into a tunnel. He banked right, shuffled down a long, curved corridor and then, only then, did he reach the door to the Kentucky Wildcats’ locker room.

headline: A Fairer Pay System?
abstract: Readers discuss the huge disparity in pay between top executives and most workers.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss the huge disparity in pay

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 6
abstract: The tragic shootings at Fort Hood will dominate the conversation on the Sunday shows — particularly the treatment of mental health problems in the military.
lead_paragraph: Fort Hood, Tex., suffered a devastating blow this week when Specialist Ivan Antonio Lopez opened fire at the Army base, killing three and wounding 16 of his fellow soldiers, then taking his own life. Five years ago, another soldier went on a similar shooting rampage at Fort Hood, killing 13 people. On Thursday, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel struggled to explain why new security measures had not been effective.

headline: Her First, and Last, Book
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Youth', 'Age, Chronological']
abstract: A young woman with a lesson for graduates about the meaning of life.
lead_paragraph: TWO years ago, Marina Keegan’s life brimmed with promise. She was graduating with high honors from Yale University, already a precocious writer about to take up a job at The New Yorker.

headline: The Trauma of Being the Also-Ran
abstract: While I struggled, another Brooke Williams was getting calls from Vogue on my phone.
lead_paragraph: IT was March 1997. I unlocked my apartment door, petted the dog and hit “play” on my answering machine.

headline: Hypocritical Tax Cuts
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Taxation']
abstract: Congress seems more than willing to incur debt to extend tax breaks.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, a strong bipartisan majority in the Senate Finance Committee voted to reinstate dozens of temporary tax breaks that had expired at the end of 2013. The package, mainly tax cuts for businesses, included sensible items like tax credits for the production of wind energy and other alternative fuels, and for research and development. It also included special-interest giveaways and some silly stuff like bigger write-offs for racehorses. But what’s particularly outrageous is that the bill calls for the government to borrow the entire $85 billion cost of the two-year reinstatement.

headline: The Trick of Life
abstract: The less I thought about myself, the more myself I became.
lead_paragraph: SEVEN years into writing a novel, I started to lose my mind. My thirty-seventh birthday had just come and gone, the end of 2008 was approaching, and I was constantly aware of how little I had managed to accomplish.

headline: Policing the Sport of Kings and Knaves
keywords: ['Doping (Sports)', 'Horsemanship and Equestrian Events', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Horse Racing', 'Editorials']
abstract: Horseracing is in urgent need of oversight from the United States Anti-Doping Agency.
lead_paragraph: The abuse and doping of thoroughbred horses has become so pervasive at racetracks that the Jockey Club, the sport’s most influential voice, is endorsing federal legislation to put the United States Anti-Doping Agency in charge of cleaning up the industry.

headline: Note to Republicans: Channel Jack Kemp
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Enterprise Zones', 'United States Economy', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: For success in 2016, the G.O.P. needs to convey a positive message.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, delivered a speech last month outlining proposals for economic growth, his sponsor was the Jack F. Kemp Foundation, a Beltway organization set up in memory of the Republican politician who died in 2009 and has recently been cited as a hero by some of the party’s most prominent figures.

headline: Sheldon: Iran’s Best Friend
abstract: How Sheldon Adelson and Iran are both trying to destroy Israel.
lead_paragraph: IT occurred to me the other day that the zealously pro-Israel billionaire Sheldon Adelson and Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, actually have one big thing in common. They are both trying to destroy Israel. Adelson is doing it by loving Israel to death and Khamenei by hating Israel to death. And now even Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey inadvertently got drawn into this craziness.

headline: Sanjit (Bunker) Roy
abstract: A social reformer in India with a weakness for Joan Baez and butterscotch ice cream.
lead_paragraph: Sanjit (Bunker) Roy is an Indian social reformer and founder of Barefoot College, an organization that trains the poor, particularly poor women, to become self-sufficient through education and training. He has trained grandmothers, from sub-Saharan Africa to the Himalayas, to be solar engineers so they can both literally and figuratively be the source of power in their remote villages.

headline: When Coziness With Sources Is a Conflict
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Public Editor (Times Column)']
abstract: Let’s take a look at three situations involving Times journalists and those they cover.
lead_paragraph: IN theory, most serious journalists can agree on this principle: It’s a bad idea to get too close to your sources. Cordiality, yes; coziness, no.

headline: Health Care Without End
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Americans will still be arguing about Obamacare in 2030.
lead_paragraph: SO you think it’s finished? So you think now that enrollment has hit seven million, now that the president has declared the debate over repeal “over,” now that Republican predictions of a swift Obamacare unraveling look a bit like Republican predictions of a Romney landslide, we’re going to stop arguing about health care, stop having the issue dominate the conversation, and turn at last to some other debate instead?

headline: As Vermont Goes, So Goes the Nation?
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Third-Party Moves (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Third-party persistence drove health care reform.
lead_paragraph: WHEN most liberals hear the words “third party,” they have nasty flashbacks to Ralph Nader’s spoiler campaign in 2000. The history buffs among them might think of the populist Greenback Party’s feckless protests against the gold standard in the 19th century or the five presidential campaigns of the Socialist Eugene V. Debs — the last of which, in 1920, he ran from prison.

headline: Bring Me My Dragons!
abstract: The power struggles in the nation’s capital seem pallid compared to those in the Seven Kingdoms.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — I’D been hoping to get the flu.

headline: The New Gay Orthodoxy
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Discrimination', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The ouster of Mozilla’s chief executive suggests a shrinking room for debate.
lead_paragraph: TO appreciate how rapidly the ground has shifted, go back just two short years, to April 2012. President Obama didn’t support marriage equality, not formally. Neither did Hillary Clinton. And few people were denouncing them as bigots whose positions rendered them too divisive, offensive and regressive to lead.

headline: A Rationalist’s Mystical Moment
keywords: ['Atheism', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Occult Sciences', 'Religion and Belief', 'Psychics and Psychic Phenomena']
abstract: Since I recognized no deities, I had to assume I’d had a breakdown.
lead_paragraph: MY atheism is hard-core, rooted in family tradition rather than adolescent rebellion. According to family legend, one of my 19th-century ancestors, a dirt-poor Irish-American woman in Montana, expressed her disgust with the church by vehemently refusing last rites when she lay dying in childbirth. From then on, we were atheists and rationalists, a stance I perpetuated by opting, initially, for a career in science.

headline: What Life in the Real World Costs
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Tuition', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Writing and Writers', 'Parenting', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Magical thinking wasn’t going to pay my tuition to college.
lead_paragraph: I APPLIED to college sitting on the carpeted stairway of our apartment, yelling down questions to my mother. “Mom, am I anything?”

headline: Capitalize Workers!
abstract: Let ordinary Americans benefit from market gains.
lead_paragraph: Raising the minimum wage has justifiably captured policy makers’ attention, but if the goal is to materially raise living standards for every American worker, we should also be calling for a minimum pension. Done right, this would not only create real wealth for the middle and working classes, it would use the power of financial markets to reduce wealth disparity instead of widening it.

headline: Like, Degrading the Language? No Way
keywords: ['English Language', 'Indecency, Obscenity and Profanity', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners']
abstract: Casual American speech is becoming more polite and more subtle.
lead_paragraph: IF there is one thing that unites Americans of all stripes, it is the belief that, whatever progress our country might be making, we are moving backward on language. Just look at the crusty discourse level of comments sections and the recreational choppiness of text messages and hit pop songs.

headline: One Afghan Woman’s Voice
abstract: Despite Taliban threats, Afghans turned out across the country Saturday to vote for a new president. Shukria Barakzai, one of the female members of the Afghan Parliament, prepared to vote.
lead_paragraph: Despite Taliban threats, Afghans turned out across the country Saturday to vote for a new president. Shukria Barakzai, one of the female members of the Afghan Parliament, prepared to vote.

headline: Yes He Can, on Immigration
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Deportation', 'Law and Legislation', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Editorials', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: It has been frustrating to watch President Obama’s promises on immigration reform fade to protestations of impotence and the blaming of others.
lead_paragraph: If President Obama means what he says about wanting an immigration system that reflects American values, helps the economy and taps the yearnings of millions of Americans-in-waiting, he is going to have to do something about it — soon and on his own. It has been frustrating to watch his yes-we-can promises on immigration reform fade to protestations of impotence and the blaming of others. All Mr. Obama has been saying lately is: No, in fact, we can’t, because Republicans and the law won’t let me.

headline: In Europe, Echoes of America as Concussions Spur Debate
abstract: With a push for change from lawmakers, players and doctors, and from discussions with the same experts who brought the issue to the fore in the United States, the topic is gaining momentum.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The debate over how to respond to the growing research linking brain trauma to injuries sustained in sports has spread to Europe, with many of the same dynamics seen in recent years as the issue gained momentum in the United States.

headline: Points for Product Placement: N.C.A.A. Cashes In, but Not the Players
abstract: Among the biggest complaints about the N.C.A.A. is that it has aggressively monetized nearly every aspect of its championships while it forbids players to negotiate paid endorsement deals.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The new champions of men’s college basketball, whoever they may be, will cut down a net here Monday night. And when they do, they will climb to the basket on a blue-and-yellow Werner ladder, and they will clip the cords with a pair of orange Fiskars scissors.

headline: Stanford Star Makes Campus Her Stage
abstract: Chiney Ogwumike is the heartbeat of the team as she and the Stanford Cardinal prepare for Sunday’s national semifinal against Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: STANFORD, Calif. — Chiney Ogwumike was not yet a year old, standing contentedly in a baby walker next to her father, who was eating pizza while they watched television. Except that Ogwumike was not watching television. She was watching the slice of pizza in her dad’s hand.

headline: Under Revised Quake Estimates, Dozens of Nuclear Reactors Face Costly Safety Analyses
abstract: Owners of reactors who say they cannot show that their facilities would withstand the most severe earthquake they might face, are required to undertake extensive structural reviews.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Owners of at least two dozen nuclear reactors across the United States, including the operator of Indian Point 2, in Buchanan, N.Y., have told the Nuclear Regulatory Commission that they cannot show that their reactors would withstand the most severe earthquake that revised estimates say they might face, according to industry experts.

headline: U.N. Leader Urges Action in Central African Republic
abstract: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, called on the Security Council to authorize a peacekeeping force of 12,000 to try to halt sectarian violence in the Central African Republic.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, arrived in the Central African Republic on Saturday in an effort to drum up world support for an effort to stanch the widening sectarian conflict there.

headline: If Tiger Woods Were Healthy, Oh, the Places He Could Go
abstract: Woods, recovering from back surgery, has won major tournaments at three of the four sites where this year’s events will be held.
lead_paragraph: When golfers win consistently or play well on a certain course, they like to say “it fits my eye,” meaning that the shape of the fairways and the nuances of the greens blend with their swings and their senses. And for Tiger Woods, stalled at 14 for six years in his passionate pursuit of Jack Nicklaus’s record 18 major victories, this was supposed to be the year when the stars were aligned for him to win another major or two, when the course for each of the four major tournaments fit his eye.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking: April 4, 2014
abstract: This week, Joe discusses the General Motors recall and high-frequency trading.
lead_paragraph: General Motors says it has connected 13 deaths and dozens of accidents to a defective ignition switch. The company, led by a new C.E.O., is now recalling millions of Chevy Cobalts, despite reports that the problem has stretched back more than a decade.

headline: Even Small Medical Advances Can Mean Big Jumps in Bills
abstract: Some high-tech treatments help patients better control chronic diseases like diabetes, but they also drive an enormous surge in costs, and experts say many of them offer dubious benefits.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — Catherine Hayley is saving up for an important purchase: an updated version of the tiny digital pump at her waist that delivers lifesaving insulin under her skin.

headline: Having Close to 50 Wins May Not Be Good Enough in West
abstract: Four teams in the N.B.A.’s Western Conference are chasing 50-win seasons, but there are only three playoff berths available as the regular season winds down.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Brandan Wright says he remembers how good the Golden State Warriors felt about themselves when he was a rookie in the 2007-8 season. They were the N.B.A.’s top-scoring team. They had won 48 games — the franchise’s best record in 14 seasons and a six-game improvement over the previous one, when they had upset the top-seeded Dallas Mavericks in the Western Conference playoffs.

headline: Voices Emerging Against a Union
abstract: Northwestern football Coach Pat Fitzgerald said he has urged players to vote no in a secret ballot union election scheduled for later this month.
lead_paragraph: EVANSTON, Ill. — Northwestern’s football coach, Pat Fitzgerald, has urged players to vote no in a secret ballot union election scheduled for later this month, he said Saturday.

headline: To Strike at Kochs, Democrats Revive Tactic That Hurt Romney
abstract: As they did successfully in 2012 against Mitt Romney, Democrats are painting the Koch brothers as indifferent to the struggles of ordinary people.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After months of wincing in the face of negative ads funded by the industrialists David and Charles Koch, Democrats believe they have finally found a way to fight back: attacking the brothers’ sprawling business conglomerate as callous and indifferent to the lives of ordinary people while pursuing profit and power.

headline: When Money Talks, Game Is Drowned Out at Big Stadiums
abstract: The N.C.A.A. has moved the Final Four to giant football stadiums to sell more tickets, but the intimate feel in which basketball thrives has been lost.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — When Steve Anderson arrived at AT&T Stadium on Saturday for the Final Four, he entered on the ground floor, then went up and up and up — and up again — to his seat in the upper tier.

headline: Few Answers After 4 Die When Car Plunges Into Creek in Queens; Driver Survives
abstract: The Police Department identified the victims as Darius Fletcher, 21; Jada Monique Butts, 19; Jaleel Furtado, 20; and Crystal Gravely, 19.
lead_paragraph: A car carrying five young friends returning from a birthday party plunged into a creek in Queens after the driver lost control on a rain-slicked road Friday night.

headline: Grand Slam by Davis Seals Mets’ Ninth-Inning Rally Over Reds
abstract: A replay challenge and a game-ending grand slam by pinch-hitter Ike Davis helped the Mets defeat the Reds in thrilling fashion.
lead_paragraph: After Lucas Duda, Ike Davis’s competition to be the Mets’ first baseman, earned the starting job Friday, Davis watched him hit two home runs that night to stake a firm hold on the position.

headline: Apathy and Fear of Taliban Combine to Keep Rural Voters Away From the Polls
abstract: In districts where the insurgency is strongest, the Taliban did not have to pick up rifles to disrupt the vote.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — While polling centers across Kabul and other Afghan cities were celebrating record turnouts on Saturday, Tahir Khan, a tribal leader in rural Nangarhar Province, experienced a very different Election Day.

headline: A Posthumous Triumph
abstract: Readers comment on my column about Marina Keegan, a young woman who reminded us to seek meaning in life, and not just money, partly because we never know when our time will run out.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column looks about the message–of seeking meaning and fulfillment in life–from a young woman who graduated from Yale two years ago, Marina Keegan. Marina’s first book will be published this coming week, and it’s a call to life life to the fullest, to be idealistic when you’re young and can be. It’s a spirit I see in a lot of young people, and I’m a big fan of this generation of young people. I think they have more idealism than many previous generations, but also more of a practical sense of how to actually get things done rather than engage in largely symbolic gestures–a very practical idealism, if you will. Marina embodied that. And I write of her in the past tense for reasons that become obvious in the column.

headline: Technology’s Man Problem
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Discrimination', 'Women and Girls', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: Crude apps, patronizing behavior. For some, “bro” culture offers one explanation for why there are so few women in tech.
lead_paragraph: Elissa Shevinsky can pinpoint the moment when she felt that she no longer belonged.

headline: Blast Near Falluja Kills 17 Iraq Troops
abstract: The soldiers, part of an army convoy patrolling Albu Hadeed, near Falluja, were attacked by gunmen from the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria militant group, security officials said.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — An explosion in a house west of Baghdad on Saturday killed 17 Iraqi soldiers who had sought cover during a clash with militants, officials said.

headline: At Times
abstract: A puzzle by Patrick Berry that I enjoyed, at times.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Sundays are the only day that The New York Times crossword puzzle runs with a title and, the title is there in part to punnily help us figure out what we’re in for when we solve. Today, the title of this puzzle by Patrick Berry is fairly literal.

headline: The Victims of Fort Hood
abstract: A gunman killed three people and wounded 16 others before killing himself at Fort Hood, the same sprawling Army base in Texas where in 2009 an officer went on a shooting rampage that left 13 people dead.
lead_paragraph: A gunman killed three people and wounded 16 others before killing himself at Fort Hood, the same sprawling Army base in Texas where in 2009 an officer went on a shooting rampage that left 13 people dead.

headline: Tasting Early Success, Only to Walk Away
abstract: Ilya Gurevich and Tal Shaked won the World Junior Chess Championships in the 1990s, but neither of them pursued chess careers as adults.
lead_paragraph: A victory at the World Junior Chess Championships can open the door to a life on the elite competitive circuit, as a list of past winners shows: Boris Spassky, Anatoly Karpov, Garry Kasparov, Viswanathan Anand, Levon Aronian.

headline: Afraid It Was Missing the Boat, a City Tries to Catch the Bus
abstract: Arlington, Tex., one of the largest American cities without public transportation, approved a commuter bus line last year, and supporters hope it will change attitudes there.
lead_paragraph: Arlington has long been among the largest American cities without public transportation. Since 1980, the city’s voters have rejected transit proposals three times, with opponents citing fears ranging from costs to worries about an increase in crime.

headline: Now in Driver’s Seat, Patrick Credits Grass Roots
abstract: Dan Patrick, the radio host and state senator, credits his success to popular support, but his front-runner status has been built on lessons learned navigating old-school politics.
lead_paragraph: Almost eight years ago, before he became a state senator, Dan Patrick was known around the Texas Capitol as the Houston talk radio host who had shouted down a powerful committee chairman in the middle of a legislative hearing.

headline: Civil Rights Sins, Curated by One of the Sinners
keywords: ['Museums', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Archives and Records']
abstract: Mississippi officials hope a publicly operated civil rights museum scheduled to open in 2017 will be a symbol that the state is reckoning with the ugliest parts of its history.
lead_paragraph: HATTIESBURG, Miss. — In the woods off Monroe Road, a truck is so rusted that it is melting into the earth. It was Vernon Dahmer’s truck, the one that he drove and that his family continued to use after his death, the circumstances of which can be inferred from the three penny-size holes in the back panel.

headline: A Military Town: Bonded to Fort Hood
keywords: ['Fort Hood Shooting (2014)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The town of Killeen, Tex., is adjacent to the Fort Hood military post. The town’s economy and culture are closely connected to the base.
lead_paragraph: The town of Killeen, Tex., is adjacent to the Fort Hood military post. The town’s economy and culture are closely connected to the base.

headline: Delays in Effort to Refocus C.I.A. From Drone War
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Targeted Killings', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: Despite avowals about the need to refocus the agency on its original missions of analysis, intelligence collecting and espionage, the paramilitary operations have proven hard to give up.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the skies above Yemen, the Pentagon’s armed drones have stopped flying, a result of the ban on American military drone strikes imposed by the government there after a number of botched operations in recent years killed Yemeni civilians. But the Central Intelligence Agency’s drone war in Yemen continues.

headline: Log Jams Create Problems for Searchers
abstract: Gov. Jay Inslee of Washington and Lt. Richard Burke of the Bellevue Fire Department discussed the search in Oso, Wash., and explained how log jams have delayed the effort.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Jay Inslee of Washington and Lt. Richard Burke of the Bellevue Fire Department discussed the search in Oso, Wash., and explained how log jams have delayed the effort.

headline: Finding Fellowship After Deadly Washington Mudslide
keywords: ['Landslides and Mudslides', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Logging Industry']
abstract: Scores of volunteers changed the nature of the response to the disaster, even as it changed them.
lead_paragraph: DARRINGTON, Wash. — The landslide on March 22 in the high slope above the community of Oso mowed down a forest. Trees great and small, splintered and tumbling, became part of the slide’s signature, in killing 30 people and leaving 13 others still missing.

headline: For Center, 20 Years of Creating Vegetables
abstract: At the Vegetable and Fruit Improvement Center at Texas A&M University, the goal is to breed produce that tastes better, has more nutrients and better tolerates weather.
lead_paragraph: In 1983, after more than 10 years of research, a Texas A&M University horticulturist named Leonard Pike created an onion that did not make people cry. This alone was revolutionary, but Dr. Pike also conferred another attribute upon his plant progeny: a single center.

headline: A Long Shot Nears Its Goal: UConn Topples Florida
abstract: Led by DeAndre Daniels (20 points), UConn beat Florida, the N.C.A.A. tournament’s top overall seed, for a second time this season and advanced to the championship game.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — During the singing of the national anthem Saturday, Connecticut’s players stood in silence, heads down, arms around one another, lost in their thoughts. They swayed from side to side, as if at a revival — their own. All wore the same white long-sleeve T-shirt. It read, “UConn Pride.”

headline: Sales-Tax Plan Would Redefine District Wealth
keywords: ['Sales and Excise Taxes', 'Education (K-12)', 'Shopping Centers and Malls']
abstract: Places with the wealthiest properties would no longer necessarily have the richest school districts. Those would be the ones with the most shopping.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Peter Matthiessen, Lyrical Writer and Naturalist, Is Dead at 86
abstract: Mr. Matthiessen’s nonfiction explored the remote endangered wilds of the world, and his fiction often placed his protagonists in the heart of them.
lead_paragraph: Peter Matthiessen, a roving author and naturalist whose impassioned nonfiction explored the remote endangered wilds of the world and whose prizewinning fiction often placed his mysterious protagonists in the heart of them, died on Saturday at his home in Sagaponack, N.Y. He was 86.

headline: As Town Mourns an Educator, It Celebrates a Close-Knit Community
abstract: Nearly the entire town of Darrington packed into the community center to pay their respects to Linda McPherson, who was among the first of the 30 victims of the landslide to be identified.
lead_paragraph: DARRINGTON, Wash. — The long procession of funerals for victims of the Oso landslide began here and in the neighboring town of Arlington on Saturday.

headline: A Change in Atmosphere in Central Syria
abstract: The boom of shelling no longer dominates the days and nights.
lead_paragraph: The boom of shelling no longer dominates the days and nights.

headline: Relative Calm in Parts of Syria Is Deceptive
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons']
abstract: Beneath a calm imposed by military force, siege and starvation, the stage appears set for an unstable period of prolonged conflict that could explode again in months or years.
lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria — The change of atmosphere here in the Syrian capital is unmistakable. The boom of shelling no longer dominates the days and nights. Tensions over security are draining from the city like air from a balloon. Checkpoints remain ubiquitous but sentries are relaxed, even jocular, teasing strangers, “Any bombs?”

headline: Citizenship-for-Cash Program in Malta Stirs Security Concerns in European Union
keywords: ['Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Passports', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: Opponents said the program, under which foreigners can pay to buy Maltese citizenship, could open the door to the West for criminals or terrorists.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A program in Malta that offers citizenship for cash is raising concern among officials who fear it could open a back door into Europe and the United States for swindlers, criminals or terrorists who can afford the price tag of up to $1.57 million.

headline: Election in Hungary Tests Nation’s Tilt to the Right
abstract: Prime Minister Viktor Orban and his coalition appear headed for victory Sunday, but the election will gauge the depth of voters’ support and their interest in pushing Hungary further right.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — While Europe was enmeshed in its years of euro crisis, Viktor Orban, Hungary’s popular but controversial prime minister, tilted his country’s politics rightward, to a chorus of foreign and domestic criticism but little censure from the European Union.

headline: With Upset at Wood Memorial, Wicked Strong Ensures Spot in Derby
abstract: Wicked Strong won by three and a half lengths, rewarding his backers with $20.40 for a $2 bet, and delivering a $590,000 first-place check to his owners, Centennial Farms.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, Jimmy Jerkens thought he had a horse that would take him to the Kentucky Derby, a colt by the name of Wicked Strong. This was the one that would make him forget about the last time he had circled the first Saturday of May at Churchill Downs — five years ago with a tender-footed runner named Quality Road.

headline: Lawyer Sees No Revenge in an Arrest in New Delhi
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Search and Seizure', 'Police']
abstract: The lawyer for a New York police officer arrested in India for having three rounds of ammunition said that there was no connection between the case and the arrest of an Indian diplomat in New York last year.
lead_paragraph: The lawyer for a New York police officer arrested in India last month for having rounds of ammunition in his luggage said Indian officials were following the law in detaining his client, and not retaliating for the arrest of an Indian diplomat in New York last year.

headline: Tending Their Wounds, Vowing to Fight On
abstract: Some veterans of Kiev’s Independence Square are healing abroad, physically and mentally, from the bloody protests that helped topple Ukraine’s president.
lead_paragraph: KOBLENZ, Germany — Shot twice at the bloody denouement of Ukraine’s revolution, Yuri Kravchuk spends his days in the most pristine of hospital wards, gazing out the window at this orderly German city, churning images of battle through his mind.

headline: Brazil Sends In Armed Forces to Assist in Policing Poor Area
abstract: The operation is a part of a five-year-old “pacification” policing program, which has established permanent police patrols in select slums in Rio de Janeiro ahead of this year’s World Cup tournament.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — About 2,700 members of Brazil’s security forces on Saturday occupied a slum complex that sits along two highways connecting Rio’s international airport to its main tourist zone.

headline: Richard Brick, Who Drew Films Back to New York, Dies at 68
abstract: Named New York City’s commissioner of film, theater and broadcasting in 1992, Mr. Brick worked to bring movie crews back to the city for films like “Last Action Hero,” “Carlito’s Way,” and “Six Degrees of Separation.”
lead_paragraph: Richard Brick, a filmmaker and teacher who as the film commissioner of New York City in the early 1990s helped repair the city’s strained relationship with Hollywood and bring film crews back from Toronto and other faux-New York locations, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 68.

headline: Barbara Gibbons, 79, Writer of ‘Slim Gourmet’ Cookbooks, Dies
abstract: Ms. Gibbons made low-calorie recipes like macaroni-and-cheese, pizza, pancakes, chocolate pudding cake and what she called “man-pleasing beef stew.”
lead_paragraph: Barbara Gibbons, the author of “The Slim Gourmet” syndicated column and cookbooks — and the original 208-pound customer for their low-calorie recipes — died on March 26 at her home in Dallas. She was 79.

headline: Jesus Lives, but Should He Live in My Front Yard?
abstract: As a young adult Christian whose political views are left of center, working in higher education where intellect is the only religion, I’m constantly negotiating how much of myself to share. My daughter has no such doubts.
lead_paragraph: As I drove home from church, I eyed the bright foam sign my 6-year-old daughter held. “Jesus is Alive” it read in kid scrawl. “We’re supposed to put them in our yards!” Noelle beamed, eyeing her creation proudly through pink-rimmed glasses.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 5, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: April 5, 2014

headline: With a Spirited Garnett Back, the Healthy Nets Edge the 76ers
abstract: In their victory over the 76ers on Saturday, the Nets had their entire roster available for the first time since Feb. 27.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Kevin Garnett’s coach and teammates were teasing him Saturday morning, calling him a rookie. It had been so long since Garnett, 37, had joined them on the court that he seemed like a new player on the Nets.

headline: Zuccarello Provides Spark, but Clinching Must Wait
abstract: Mats Zuccarello scored twice, but his line was on the ice for all three Senators goals in a loss at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: Mats Zuccarello’s performance encapsulated a lot of what went right and what went wrong for the Rangers in their 3-2 loss to the Ottawa Senators on Saturday at Madison Square Garden. He scored twice, but he was also on the ice for all of the Senators’ goals.

headline: With Late 3-Pointer, Kentucky Edges Wisconsin to Advance to Final
abstract: Aaron Harrison put up the shot that sent the Wildcats into the title game against Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Wisconsin Coach Bo Ryan had a player once who wanted to leave college early and go to the N.B.A. It was Devin Harris, in 2004, and he was a junior.

headline: Judith Orlando and John Tamagni
abstract: The couple retired from the New York office of Lazard Frères & Co., the financial advisory and asset management firm.
lead_paragraph: Judith Sapadin Orlando and John Searle Tamagni were married Saturday afternoon at the Heights Casino, a private squash, tennis and social club in Brooklyn. The ceremony was led by Arnold L. Lehman, a Universal Life minister and the director of the Brooklyn Museum, where the groom is the chairman of the board of trustees.

headline: Janna O’Shea and Michael Zagari
abstract: The couple work at the Walt Disney Company.
lead_paragraph: Janna Elizabeth O’Shea and Michael Richard Zagari are to be married Sunday at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in Manhattan. Carissa Templeton, a minister affiliated with Rose Ministries, is to perform a nondenominational ceremony.

headline: Aviva Berman and Ezra Billinkoff
abstract: The bride is a senior financial analyst at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital; the groom is the online campaigns director of Mayors Against Illegal Guns.
lead_paragraph: Aviva Jaclyn Berman, a daughter of Gita Guttman Berman and Steve Berman of Atlanta, is to be married Sunday to Ezra Lewin Billinkoff, a son of Dr. Sharon Lewin and Donald Billinkoff of New York. Rabbi Robert N. Levine is to officiate at Summerour Studio, an event space in Atlanta, where Rabbi Dr. Analia Bortz is to take part in the ceremony.

headline: Nancy Costello and Katherine Rodway
abstract: A retired insurance-claims adjuster and a director of a rocket-engine and spaceflight-development company are married in New York.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Jane Costello and Katherine Linda Rodway were married Saturday at St. Peter’s Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. John Magisano, a minister of the Metropolitan Community Church, officiated.

headline: Hilary Cloos and Jeffrey Feinsod
abstract: The bride is a farrier; the groom is a project manager for a computer services firm.
lead_paragraph: Hilary Robinson Cloos and Jeffrey Marc Feinsod were married Saturday evening at Helsinki Hudson, an event venue in Hudson, N.Y. Brian C. Fox, the bride’s brother-in-law, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Marjorie Galler and Steven Horn
abstract: The bride is a medical student and the groom is in law school.
lead_paragraph: Marjorie Fran Galler, a daughter of Roberta I. Galler and Marvin Galler of Boca Raton, Fla., is to be married Sunday to Steven Jared Horn, a son of Carol S. Horn and Lawrence A. Horn of Bethesda, Md. Rabbi James Ponet will officiate at the Four Seasons Hotel in Boston.

headline: Julia Balduzzi, Ryan May
abstract: A lawyer weds a software technology salesman.
lead_paragraph: Julia Alexandra Balduzzi and Ryan Patrick May were married Friday evening at the Henry Morrison Flagler Museum in Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Eddie Rodriguez, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated.

headline: Aliza Balog, Scott Goodside
abstract: The bride received a law degree from the University of Pennsylvania, and the groom graduated from Duke.
lead_paragraph: Aliza Jordana Balog and Scott Bradley Goodside were married Saturday evening at Tappan Hill Mansion in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi David E. Fass officiated.

headline: Samantha Beinhacker, Scott Anderson
abstract: The bride works for a nonprofit; the groom is a marketing director.
lead_paragraph: Samantha Langbaum Beinhacker and Scott Edward Anderson were married Saturday at the Green Building, an events space in Brooklyn. Lori Hanau, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Doreen Lee, Eric Kushins
abstract: The bride is an instructor of clinical medicine at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and an attending physician at Montefiore Medical Center, both in the Bronx; the groom is a business lecturer at Rutgers, where he is also studying for a dual Ph.D. in organizational management and sociology.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Doreen Formosan Lee and Eric Ross Kushins were married Saturday at the Eliza Thompson House, a historic inn in Savannah, Ga. Adam F. Kushins, the groom’s brother who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Richard Forde, David Foushée
abstract: A wedding at the couple’s home in California.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Richard James Forde and David Russell Foushée were married Saturday at the couple’s home in Yountville, Calif. Jan Chapman Lanterman, a friend of the couple and a deputy marriage commissioner in the County of Napa, Calif., officiated.

headline: Seraphim Reycraft, Henry Hoffman
abstract: The bride works at the Benchmark Education Company, an educational publisher in New Rochelle, N.Y.; the groom is a partner in SL Advisors, an investment advisory firm in Westfield, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Seraphim Yoo Reycraft, a daughter of Seraphim D. Reycraft and Thomas C. Reycraft of Pelham, N.Y., was married Saturday to Henry Maxwell Hoffman, a son of Erika V. Hoffman and Dr. Byron Jay Hoffman Jr. of Chapel Hill, N.C. The Rev. Michael Greco, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Pelham.

headline: Whitney White, Peter Van Steemburg
abstract: The bride and groom work in Los Angeles, she as a director of development for television and he as the vice president for acquisitions of a film distribution company.
lead_paragraph: Whitney Anne White and Peter Dixon Van Steemburg were married Saturday evening at the Parker, a hotel in Palm Springs, Calif. Margaret Grey Fairchild, a minister of the American Marriage Ministries, officiated at a nondenominational ceremony that was led by Rebecca Linder Blachly, a former divinity student.

headline: Mark Anderson, Keith Bucklew
abstract: Mr. Anderson and Mr. Bucklew are both involved in arts organizations in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Mark Chenoweth Anderson and Keith Elden Bucklew were married Thursday at the Cannon House Office Building in Washington. Susan C. Bucklew, a senior United States judge for the Middle District of Florida and the sister-in-law of Mr. Bucklew, officiated in the office of Representative Kathy Castor, Democrat of Florida.

headline: Jacqueline Waldman, Stephen Wax
abstract: The bride is to become a stock research associate at Bank of America Merrill Lynch; the groom is a senior manager with Deloitte.
lead_paragraph: Jacqueline Cheryl Waldman and Stephen Brian Wax were married Saturday evening at the New York Palace hotel in Manhattan. Cantor Neil Ben-Isvy officiated.

headline: Carly Lindauer, Cliff Hamilton
abstract: The bride works in communications for the College Board; the groom is a psychiatry fellow at the Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: Carly Heather Lindauer and Dr. Cliff Scott Hamilton were married Saturday evening at Millesime, a restaurant in New York. Rabbi William I. Kuhn officiated.

headline: Elizabeth Ford, Christopher Keaney
abstract: The bride works for NBCUniversal; the groom is a vice president at WebMD.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Scott Ford and Christopher Patrick Keaney were married Saturday at the Stonehouse Villa, an event space in Driftwood, Tex. Spike Gillespie, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Rachel Wasserman, Lonnie Greenberg
abstract: The bride and groom both work in media advertising.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Jana Wasserman and Lonnie Greenberg were married Saturday evening at the PGA National Resort and Spa in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. Cantor Bruce Benson officiated.

headline: A Match Made in Kickball
abstract: The bride and groom meet in a sports club league.
lead_paragraph: Emily Samantha Schneider, a daughter of Susan E. Greenberg and Evan B. Schneider of Manhattan, is to be married Sunday to William Alexander Scheer, a son of Carole A. Scheer and Alex W. Scheer of Bulls Head, Staten Island. Rabbi Janet Roberts is to officiate at Giando on the Water, a restaurant in Brooklyn.

headline: Inauguration Day, in More Than One Way
abstract: After being friends for years, the tone changes the night the president is sworn in.
lead_paragraph: Tiffany Melen Hall and John Brandon Rhea were married Saturday at the Chevy Chase United Methodist Church in Chevy Chase, Md. The Rev. Kirkland Reynolds, a Methodist minister and the church’s pastor, officiated. Bishop Gregory G. M. Ingram, who presides over the First Episcopal district of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, participated.

headline: Corrections: April 6, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on April 6, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Search Crews Detect Signals They Say May Be From Missing Malaysian Jet
abstract: The chief of the Australian team coordinating the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 said Monday that it had detected “transmissions consistent with” flight recorders, possibly from the missing jet.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — The chief of the Australian team coordinating the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 said Monday that an Australian vessel had detected “transmissions consistent with” flight data and cockpit voice recorders, possibly from the missing jet.

headline: ECO 348, The Great Recession: Inflation or Deflation?
abstract: Debasing the dollar and all that.
lead_paragraph: Slides here (pdf).

headline: Israel Warns Palestinians but Stays Open to Talks
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Israel would take “unilateral steps” in response to the Palestinians’ move last week to join international conventions.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu threatened Sunday that Israel would take its own “unilateral steps” in response to the Palestinians’ move last week to join international conventions and reiterated that a Palestinian state could be created “only through direct negotiations, not through empty statements and not by unilateral moves.”

headline: 1914: Sir Herbert Tree To Star in Bernard Shaw’s ‘Pygmalion’
abstract: In 1914, Bernard Shaw announced a new production of his “Pygmalion” play in a London theater, starring Sir Herbert Tree.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Mr. Bernard Shaw’s “Pygmalion,” to be produced by Sir Herbert Tree at His Majesty’s Theatre on Saturday, will be the feature of the week, which otherwise would be uneventful, especially as many managers are taking advantage of Holy Week to give their companies a rest.

headline: What’s On Sunday
abstract: Television listings for Sunday, April 6.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (HBO) SILICON VALLEY In this new comedy created by Mike Judge, a group of socially stunted programmers shares the home — or, as they call it, the incubator — of a dot-com billionaire who lets them live rent-free in exchange for a 10 percent stake in their ventures. The show’s mockery of “obscene wealth and the grandiosity that comes with giving back” is badly needed, Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. “A new cultural revolution is at hand, and many of its leaders are even more smug and self-righteous than the counterculture activists who, back in the 1960s, also thought they could change the world.” She added, “ ‘Silicon Valley’ isn’t making the world a better place, it is putting the real Silicon Valley in its place, one Tesla at a time.” Above, from left, Kumail Nanjiani, Martin Starr, Thomas Middleditch, Zach Woods and T. J. Miller star in the show. The season opener of “Game of Thrones” leads in at 9; “Veep” follows at 10:30.

headline: Concert Versions of Broadway Musicals Appear Beyond Theaters
abstract: Broadway musicals get a second life in cabaret settings.
lead_paragraph: Rosie O’Donnell sat in a booth at the Broadway supper club 54 Below, sipping red wine and getting teary as she watched members of the original cast of “Taboo,” the flop she produced on Broadway a decade ago, power through the score.

headline: Qatar Museums Authority Leader to Leave Post
abstract: After three years, Edward Dolman has decided to step down as the executive director and acting chief executive of the Qatar Museums Authority.
lead_paragraph: Edward Dolman is stepping down as the executive director and acting chief executive of the Qatar Museums Authority, a job he held for three years, the authority announced on Sunday. But he will remain a member of the authority’s international advisory board.

headline: Guarded Optimism After Breast Cancer Drug Shows Promising Results
abstract: Palbociclib, a drug being developed by Pfizer, sharply cut the risk that advanced cancer would worsen among patients taking part in a Phase 2 study, researchers said.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Researchers say that a new type of drug can help prevent advanced breast cancer from worsening, potentially providing an important new treatment option for women and a blockbuster product for Pfizer.

headline: The World’s Biggest Tetris Game
abstract: The Drexel University professor Frank Lee and his team hacked into the lighting system of a 29-story skyscraper in Philadelphia to play Tetris on the building’s facade.
lead_paragraph: The Drexel University professor Frank Lee and his team hacked into the lighting system of a 29-story skyscraper in Philadelphia to play Tetris on the building’s facade.

headline: Making a Game Larger Than Life
abstract: Frank Lee, a professor from Drexel University, and a group of colleagues recreated Tetris on a Philadelphia skyscraper to celebrate the cultural icon that laid the foundation for casual games like Candy Crush Saga.
lead_paragraph: After a 20-hour Tetris marathon on his Macintosh SE/30 desktop computer, Frank J. Lee drove across the Bay Bridge from Berkeley to San Francisco, his mind still stuck on the game. He was an undergraduate majoring in cognitive science, and the year was 1990.

headline: Apple’s Deep Pockets: What $159 Billion Could Do
abstract: The maker of iPads and iPhones has a problem that anyone would like to have: What to do with a vast amount of cash.
lead_paragraph: Big technology companies have a problem anyone would love to have: They are sitting on vast amounts of cash.

headline: New York’s Paid Sick Leave Law Quietly Takes Effect
keywords: ['Paid Time Off', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Law and Legislation', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: On April 1, without hoopla, the city quietly became the largest in the nation to ensure that the vast majority of workers wouldn’t lose pay or their jobs if they or their close relatives became sick.
lead_paragraph: Shiv Puri gathered his employees together after the lunchtime rush last week to deliver the big news: This year, the cook and kitchen staff at the Bombay Sandwich Company on West 27th Street will receive paid sick leave for the very first time.

headline: In Our Pages: April 7
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Fires ravage parts of Dakota in 1889; the Ottoman government lets women study abroad in 1914.
lead_paragraph: 1889: Fires on the Prairie

headline: In a Test of Wills With China, U.S. Sticks Up for Japan
abstract: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel is visiting China amid tit-for-tat maneuvering and territorial disputes between China and its East Asian neighbors.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — On his first trip to China as the secretary of defense, Chuck Hagel is finding himself in the middle of a spat that would not be out of place in “Mean Girls,” a movie about social cliques in high school.

headline: ‘Captain America: The Winter Soldier’ Has a Huge Opening
abstract: The film took in about $96.2 million at North American theaters over the weekend, a 48 percent increase over the three-day opening for its series predecessor in 2011.
lead_paragraph: The Marvel movie machine can even bring summer early. “Captain America: The Winter Soldier” broke industry records for an April opening by taking in about $96.2 million at North American theaters over the weekend, an astounding 48 percent increase over the three-day opening for its series predecessor in 2011. The movie has already taken in an additional $207 million overseas.

headline: Two Officers Critically Injured While Responding to Brooklyn Blaze
abstract: The police officers were hospitalized after being found unconscious near an elevator in an apartment building in Coney Island, the police said.
lead_paragraph: Two veteran police officers, partners out on patrol around lunchtime on Sunday, rushed to the 13th floor of a high-rise housing development in Coney Island, Brooklyn, after a report of a fire was called in.

headline: Oligarchy and Monetary Policy
abstract: Who benefits from inflation paranoia?
lead_paragraph: I’ve been thinking about how we talk about — or don’t talk about — the desirability of low inflation targets. As I noted the other day, the lates IMF World Economic Outlook makes a compelling case for raising the target above 2 percent — but avoids saying so explicitly, resorting to coded euphemisms. Meanwhile, inflation paranoia is very much a partisan thing. In my class notes for tomorrow I list the signatories of the economists’ letter warning about dollar “debasement” from quantitative easing; it’s obvious that everyone on the list is a highly committed Republican, and some people with the right ideological credentials are on board even though they have no relevant professional credentials. (William Kristol and Dan Senor, monetary experts?)

headline: UConn’s Center Adds Fitness to Her Ebullience
abstract: Stefanie Dolson, once an exhausted and ineffective freshman center, has been an ebullient bandleader in the Huskies’ parade toward a repeat championship.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — It was yet another Connecticut-Stanford game, and as usual, something weighty in women’s basketball rested on the outcome.

headline: Young, Rich and Ruling Radio, Country Walks a Broader Line
abstract: The genre’s audience has grown stronger, wider and younger, and media companies have invested heavily in artists and radio stations with increasingly mainstream appeal.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — On the radio, it has displaced Top 40 as America’s most popular musical format.

headline: Attuned to the Money
abstract: “Greed: A Musical for Our Times,” a revue by Michael Roberts, offers 19 songs about avaricious bankers and crooked chief executives.
lead_paragraph: Was Bernard L. Madoff ever tempted to sing about his pyramid scheme? Did Martha Stewart contemplate an insider-trading tap dance? Their efforts might have enlivened “Greed: A Musical for Our Times,” a revue by Michael Roberts at New World Stages.

headline: The Kentucky Derby Dartboard: Week 2
abstract: Ranking the top contenders for the Kentucky Derby on May 3 after another weekend of major prep races.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Churchill Downs adopted a points system to determine the field for the Kentucky Derby, replacing the use of graded-stakes earnings. Points are earned by the top four finishers in designated Derby prep races. The odds are from the Churchill Downs futures pool, and the records are starts-win-place-show. An article on Saturday’s Wood Memorial and Santa Anita Derby can be found here.

headline: Cement Makers Holcim and Lafarge Are Said to Agree on Merger Plan
abstract: Two European construction materials giants, Holcim and Lafarge, have agreed to merge, a person close to the discussions said on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: PARIS – The boards of Holcim and Lafarge, two of the world’s largest construction materials companies, have agreed to merge, a person close to the discussions said on Sunday.

headline: Jeb Bush Talks Approach If He Runs for President
abstract: Mr. Bush signaled that if he ran for president, his campaign would argue against ideological purity tests and challenge Republican orthodoxy on issues like immigration and education.
lead_paragraph: COLLEGE STATION, Tex. — With eyes increasingly on him, Jeb Bush signaled on Sunday the kind of campaign he would mount if he runs for president, one arguing against ideological purity tests while challenging party orthodoxy on issues like immigration and education.

headline: In His Return From Injury, Niese Feels Good, but Reds Feel Better
abstract: Jon Niese, who spent spring training rehabilitating from shoulder discomfort and from elbow inflammation, was sharp from the start, but Alfredo Simon outdueled him.
lead_paragraph: Jon Niese sat alone in a booth at a sports bar in Port St. Lucie, Fla., last Monday, ordered a turkey burger topped with a fried egg and watched the Mets’ season opener on television. He probably would have started that game if his spring training had not been derailed by shoulder discomfort and elbow inflammation.

headline: John
abstract: John
lead_paragraph: John

headline: Smith Tries but Cannot Carry the Knicks
abstract: J. R. Smith set a team record for 3-pointers and an N.B.A. record for 3-point attempts, but an ailing Carmelo Anthony disappeared from the offense, and the Knicks had no discernible defense.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Carmelo Anthony’s right arm, by his own description, felt dead by the second half Sunday afternoon. It was not an ideal situation for the Knicks, who were seeking to remain viable (or at least marginal) candidates for the postseason against the Miami Heat.

headline: French Film Goes Viral, but Not in France
abstract: An 11-minute French film released on YouTube that depicts the life of an ordinary man in a world run by women resonates outside France.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The main character is a harried parent just trying to slog through the routine of the day: dropping off the toddler at day care, picking up the mail, running errands.

headline: Unrest in Eastern Ukraine
abstract: In Donetsk and Lugansk, crowds bearing Russian flags clashed with the police and stormed government buildings on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: In Donetsk and Lugansk, crowds bearing Russian flags clashed with the police and stormed government buildings on Sunday.

headline: My So-Called Opinions
abstract: Why we millennials often struggle with our most basic convictions.
lead_paragraph: I.

headline: Telling Victim From Villain at Duke
abstract: The scandal that engulfed Duke lacrosse players and others in 2006 is detailed in “The Price of Silence.”
lead_paragraph: This again? We were blitzed with the Duke University lacrosse scandal in 2006. And, it seems, we’re still not done with it.

headline: Powerhouse Theater Summer Season
abstract: Among the highlights of the summer season for the Powerhouse Theater will be “In Your Arms.”
lead_paragraph: Among the highlights of the summer season for the Powerhouse Theater will be “In Your Arms,” a collection of wordless dance vignettes written by playwrights like Terrence McNally, Christopher Durang, Carrie Fisher, Douglas Carter Beane and Lynn Nottage, with music by Stephen Flaherty (“Ragtime”) and choreography by Christopher Gattelli (“Newsies”). Produced by New York Stage and Film and Vassar College, the season is also to include new plays by Richard Greenberg (“Take Me Out”) and John Patrick Shanley (“Doubt”) and is scheduled to begin on June 20 in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

headline: Museum Director to Be Commissioner of Cultural Affairs
abstract: Tom Finkelpearl will be the city’s point person on the arts, overseeing a $156 million budget.
lead_paragraph: Tom Finkelpearl, the president and executive director of the Queens Museum, is scheduled to be named the cultural affairs commissioner by Mayor Bill de Blasio on Monday, the mayor’s office confirmed, putting Mr. Finkelpearl in charge of a $156 million budget and making him the point person on the arts for a city widely considered the cultural capital of the world.

headline: An Unusual Family Legacy With Heavy Responsibility
abstract: In “Jinn,” Earth’s fate depends on a young car designer who discovers that he belongs to a line of warriors powerful enough to fight off supernatural creatures.
lead_paragraph: In Ajmal Zaheer Ahmad’s “Jinn,” the supernatural beings of the title have good and evil versions. But there’s good and evil, and there’s just plain bad. Most of the time, this incoherent thriller resembles an overheated trailer for itself: a glaringly rough assembly of ill-staged computer-generated action sequences and portentous moments.

headline: For UConn, as Well as the Huskies, a Golden Opportunity to Impress
keywords: ['Basketball (College)', 'NCAA Basketball Championships (Men)', 'NCAA Basketball Championships (Women)', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: For university presidents like Susan Herbst, the Final Four offers a rare opportunity for an extended bonding session with key supporters who are basking in the glow of big-time sports success.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Halfway through a private brunch Saturday, as Connecticut’s biggest donors finished their all-you-can-eat French toast and sausages, the university’s president, Susan Herbst, put down her glass and made her way to the center of the room.

headline: Good and Evil, Ritual and Nightmare, in Sight and Sound
abstract: “The Long Tone” included a performance by the duo Demdike Stare, with accompanying film by Michael England, at the First Unitarian Church in Brooklyn Friday.
lead_paragraph: “Concealed,” by the British electronic-music duo Demdike Stare and the filmmaker and animator Michael England, is an audiovisual project, no more or less aural than visual, about dread and dreams, what happens in the world when the conscious mind isn’t noticing.

headline: A Homely Nymph, Wooed by a God to Rouse His Wife’s Jealousy
abstract: A concert performance of Rameau’s “Platée” by the vocal and instrumental ensemble Les Arts Florissants brought the comic opera masterpiece to life even without the dancing.
lead_paragraph: The conductor William Christie appeared onstage at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night to apologize to the audience that had packed the place for a performance of Rameau’s comic opera masterpiece “Platée.” He explained that he was still recuperating from a recent surgical procedure and would not be able to conduct Les Arts Florissants, the vocal and instrumental ensemble he founded in France 35 years ago, a group that has set the standard for the performance of French Baroque opera. He also regretted, he said, that the audience would not be seeing the director Robert Carsen’s staged production, which had recently played to acclaim in Vienna and Paris. This would be just a concert performance, the “busker’s version,” Mr. Christie said.

headline: Proclaiming Joy, in Concert, on His 75th Birthday
abstract: The South African musician Hugh Masekela thanked Harry Belafonte and welcomed Paul Simon onstage at his Jazz at Lincoln Center concert at Rose Theater.
lead_paragraph: When Hugh Masekela celebrated his 75th birthday on Friday night, with a Jazz at Lincoln Center concert at Rose Theater, he recalled pivotal advice from Harry Belafonte, who was in the audience. In 1960, Mr. Masekela left the brutal apartheid of his birthplace, South Africa, to become a trumpeter in New York. He recalled that Mr. Belafonte, an early supporter, urged him to “put some of that stuff from your home into what you do.”

headline: Full-Throttle Emotions and Blind Faith
abstract: Anthony Minghella’s production of Puccini’s “Madama Butterfly” returned to the Metropolitan Opera with this season’s second cast.
lead_paragraph: The soprano Renata Scotto, a celebrated interpreter of the tragic teenage heroine of Puccini’s “Madama Butterfly,” found that being too emotionally invested in the character was problematic because “you suffer and you can’t sing.” The soprano Kristine Opolais said in a recent interview on Latinos Post that because she doesn’t hold back emotionally, she finds the role so psychologically taxing that she might have to limit future performances.

headline: The Faces of Power, From the Portraitist in Chief
abstract: The paintings by former President George W. Bush mostly confirm the version of Mr. Bush we are familiar with: a man who is seemingly open and charming but also closed and opaque.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Former President George W. Bush is something of a natural when it comes to making oil paintings, a decent amateur. Although he picked up a brush only in 2012, this naturalness emerged as a definite possibility barely a year later. That’s when images of two strange, seemingly introspective paintings by Mr. Bush went viral, hacked from the email of a Bush relative, very discreetly showing the former president bathing.

headline: Bolshoi’s ‘Giselle,’ Geared to Virtuosity and a Vocal Audience
abstract: The Bolshoi Ballet performed “Giselle,” in Vladimir Vasiliev’s 1997 production.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Of all the surviving 19th-century ballets, “Giselle,” with its narrative nexus of love and dance and death, is the one that can most be relied upon not to disappoint. Unlike other ballet classics from that era, it seldom loses narrative tension; its technical and acting challenges keep stimulating individual casts. And yet the Bolshoi Ballet performance I saw on Wednesday was the dullest account in my entire experience of this war horse (nearly 40 years). While the one on Thursday was considerably better, both were drearily routine affairs.

headline: The ‘Superpredator’ Scare
abstract: After a surge of teen violence in the early 1990s, some social scientists predicted the future was going to be a whole lot worse. Reality proved otherwise.
lead_paragraph: After a surge of teen violence in the early 1990s, some social scientists predicted the future was going to be a whole lot worse. Reality proved otherwise.

headline: A Couple of Couples
abstract: A couple of good things about Douglas Taillon’s debut puzzle.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — This is a Monday puzzle that goes above and beyond, in my opinion.

headline: When Youth Violence Spurred ‘Superpredator’ Fear
abstract: A funny thing happened on the way to the predicted apocalypse of youth violence: Instead of exploding, violent crimes perpetrated by children sharply declined.
lead_paragraph: As the police and prosecutors in Brooklyn tell it, Kahton Anderson boarded a bus on March 20, a .357 revolver at his side. For whatever reason — some gang grudge, apparently — he pulled out the gun and fired at his intended target. Only his aim was rotten. The bullet struck and killed a passenger who was minding his own business several rows ahead: Angel Rojas, a working stiff holding down two jobs to feed his family of four.

keywords: ['Pornography', 'Children and Childhood', 'Parenting', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: An advice columnist, an educator and the A.C.L.U. respond to a Sunday Review news analysis.

abstract: James S. Berkman, head of school at Boston University Academy, takes issue with a column by David Brooks.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Job Skills Gap
abstract: The National Skills Coalition argues that lack of skills plays a significant role in unemployment.
