abstract: A wheelchair user says the effort to increase the number of accessible taxis should be expanded to subways.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Election Time in Afghanistan
abstract: But the threat of disruption from the Taliban is always present.
lead_paragraph: But the threat of disruption from the Taliban is always present.

headline: Vox Takes Melding of Journalism and Technology to a New Level
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The new site, led by Ezra Klein, the founder of Wonkblog, features a next-generation content management tool that greatly enhances digital storytelling.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ask Ezra Klein what prompted him to leave a high-profile position at The Washington Post to start a new website, and the answer is a little wonkish, even for the founder of the newspaper’s Wonkblog, a mix of politics, economics and domestic policy that had become must reading in the Beltway.

headline: Neither Female Nor Male
abstract: An Australian court decision challenges the way we sort people.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — PRETTY much the No. 1 question you are asked when you’re pregnant is: “Girl or boy?” If you choose not to find out, but to be deliciously surprised at birth, as I did, then you will be asked to guess: “What do you feel it is?” I used to scrunch up my eyes and try hard to draw on what people told me was an age-old female intuition: Which genitals were sprouting in my round belly? I could never tell, though.

headline: Final Round at the Jacoby Open Swiss Teams
abstract: March 30 was the final day of the Spring Nationals here.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — March 30 was the final day of the Spring Nationals here. When the last round of the Jacoby Open Swiss Teams began that evening, Roy Welland of New York City, Sabine Auken and Christina Madsen from Denmark, and Josef Piekarek and Alex Smirnov from Germany were two victory points ahead of Martin Fleisher, Zia Mahmood and Chris Willenken of New York City; Steve Garner of Chicago; Chip Martel of Davis, Calif.; and Michael Rosenberg of Cupertino, Calif.

headline: Senate Set to Pass Bill Extending Jobless Aid
keywords: ['Unemployment', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Unemployment Insurance']
abstract: House Republicans from high-unemployment regions planned to send the House speaker a letter urging him to take up the Senate bill or something similar.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate is expected to easily approve legislation Monday restoring unemployment benefits to nearly three million people, throwing the bill to a divided House where Republicans favor starkly different approaches to the issue.

headline: Traveler Magazine Learns Luxury Service at Hotels
keywords: ['Magazines', 'Internships', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: A magazine executive created an internship program for his business staff at top Manhattan hotels to learn the art of luxury service, aiming to improve sales and marketing.
lead_paragraph: Like most of the staff at the opulent Carlyle Hotel in Manhattan, Bill Wackermann was busy. He attended an early morning meeting to prepare for the day’s guests. He inspected a room under renovation. He answered phones at the concierge desk.

headline: Turning 40, But Infused With Youth And Vigor
abstract: Athleticism and poise were evident in Ailey II’s anniversary performance at the Alvin Citigroup Theater.
lead_paragraph: As with so many dance companies, Ailey II, the junior ensemble of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, exhilarates and disappoints at the same time. The dancers are tremendous. The choreography, not so much.

headline: Look Up! All Signs Point to Art
abstract: This summer, images by dozens of American artists will be plastered on 50,000 outdoor displays from billboards to bus shelters in an initiative to create a vast outdoor art exhibition.
lead_paragraph: Can the likes of Jasper Johns, Edward Hopper and Cindy Sherman help jump-start the struggling billboard business?

headline: Margalit Fox Answers the Question: ‘Why That Life?’
abstract: Margalit Fox, obituary writer since 2004, on the art of the obit.
lead_paragraph: Margalit Fox has written more than 1,000 obituaries for The Times.

headline: India’s Next Prime Minister?
abstract: Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party could become India’s next prime minister. Here’s a look at his controversial past and his economic promises.
lead_paragraph: Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party could become India’s next prime minister. Here’s a look at his controversial past and his economic promises.

headline: Timeline of the Riots in Modi’s Gujarat
abstract: Explore key developments in the 2002 riots in Gujarat that shadowed Narendra Modi’s ascent to the prime minister’s office.
lead_paragraph: Explore key developments in the 2002 riots in Gujarat that shadowed Narendra Modi’s ascent to the prime minister’s office.

headline: Eight (No, Nine!) Problems With Big Data
abstract: It’s a valuable tool for analysis, but don’t believe all the hype.
lead_paragraph: BIG data is suddenly everywhere. Everyone seems to be collecting it, analyzing it, making money from it and celebrating (or fearing) its powers. Whether we’re talking about analyzing zillions of Google search queries to predict flu outbreaks, or zillions of phone records to detect signs of terrorist activity, or zillions of airline stats to find the best time to buy plane tickets, big data is on the case. By combining the power of modern computing with the plentiful data of the digital era, it promises to solve virtually any problem — crime, public health, the evolution of grammar, the perils of dating — just by crunching the numbers.

headline: Jeter, With His Final Home Opener Up Next, Climbs Career Hits List to No. 8
abstract: Derek Jeter had two hits to pass Paul Molitor and move into eighth place with 3,320 as the Yankees wrapped up their season-opening trip at 3-3.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — A year ago, when the Yankees opened their season in the Bronx against the Boston Red Sox, there was a noticeable void. It was felt during the pregame introductions when players like Kevin Youkilis and Travis Hafner were announced over the public-address system, but Derek Jeter was not.

headline: Discovery Blitz, Including a Daredevil and Oprah
abstract: With hundreds of new shows, specials and returning series, Discovery Communications needed more than two hours of star-stuffed spectacle to showcase next season’s lineup to advertisers.
lead_paragraph: WHAT began with a sales pitch, ended with Oprah Winfrey — and in between featured two hours and 20 minutes of attractions like reality television stars, Ron Howard, Roseanne Barr, a marching band and one of the Wallendas, the daredevil circus performers?

headline: Bronx Neighborhood Fights for Its Spot on the Map
abstract: Allerton in the north Bronx has for years been overlooked and mislabeled by city planners and Google, but now residents have set out to get their neighborhood its due.
lead_paragraph: Allerton residents know where they live. It is everyone else they have to worry about.

headline: The Capitalism of Catastrophe
keywords: ['Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Doomsday']
abstract: Vendors of calamity products met their clientele at the third annual National Preppers and Survivalists Expo, a trade show held over the weekend in Tulsa, Okla.
lead_paragraph: TULSA, Okla. — Disasters happen. It is a fact as certain as income taxes. And when a solar flare erupts or a flu pandemic hits, there is only one question that will matter: Are you, or are you not, prepared?

headline: Atlanta Archbishop Says He’ll Sell Mansion
abstract: Archbishop Wilton D. Gregory had apologized over the $2.2 million home he had built.
lead_paragraph: After an uproar over the cost of a $2.2 million residence, the archbishop of Atlanta said over the weekend that he would sell the mansion.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 67
abstract: The U.S. national team goalkeeper Tim Howard and Everton moved up to fifth place in England’s Premier League on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: BlackRock Elevates Executives in Succession Planning Move
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: BlackRock, the giant investment management firm, announced executive moves on Sunday aimed at grooming a number of potential successors to its founder and leader, Laurence D. Fink.
lead_paragraph: BlackRock, the giant investment management firm, announced a series of executive shifts on Sunday aimed at grooming a number of potential successors to its founder and leader, Laurence D. Fink.

headline: SAC Capital Plea and JPMorgan Earnings
abstract: A judge will consider the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors’ guilty plea to insider trading charges on Thursday, and JPMorgan will release its first-quarter earnings on Friday.
lead_paragraph: SAC CAPITAL FADES AWAY AS JUDGE CONSIDERS ITS PLEA

headline: Departing White House Counsel Held Powerful Sway
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Kathryn Ruemmler, the longest-serving White House counsel of President Obama’s administration, will step down in May, according to officials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama selected Kathryn Ruemmler to be White House counsel in June 2011, it was something of a surprise: As a younger, relatively obscure lawyer, and one with no personal ties to the president, she did not fit the mold of predecessors.

headline: State Visit of Ireland’s President to Britain, a First, Underlines Evolution of Relations
abstract: When Michael D. Higgins goes to Britain on Monday for a state visit, the first for an Irish president, the theme of reconciliation between two nations will be on display.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a sign of the warmth of relations between two countries with a troubled history, Ireland’s president, Michael D. Higgins, is to arrive here Monday for the first state visit to Britain by an Irish president.

headline: Questions for Comcast as It Looks to Grow
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Cable Television', 'Television', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: As the company prepares to defend its proposed merger with Time Warner Cable at a Senate hearing this week, some obvious questions require answers.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to say how rugged the questions will be when Comcast goes before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Wednesday to defend its proposed megamerger with Time Warner Cable.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Fashion District Robberies Turn Heads, and Some Can’t Help Smirking
keywords: ['Robberies and Thefts', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: A series of brazen smash-and-grab thefts at expensive shops in the Vendôme district has been cause for both alarm and satire.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Since the reign of France’s Sun King, the historic Place Vendôme has served as this city’s capital of luxury, home to high-end fashion boutiques and diamond shops, Coco Chanel’s mansion, and the palatial Hôtel Ritz Paris. Lately, though, this quarter snug in the heart of Paris has turned into the hub of a decidedly more low-rent form of plunder: smash-and-grab robberies.

headline: Toledo Blade Sues Over Detention of Journalists at Tank Plant
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'News and News Media', 'Photography']
abstract: The lawsuit claims that a reporter and a photographer were detained by military police officers outside a General Dynamics tank plant after taking photographs of it.
lead_paragraph: The Toledo Blade newspaper has filed a lawsuit against six government officials, including Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, claiming that two of its journalists were detained unlawfully while taking pictures outside a tank plant in Lima, Ohio.

headline: A Community Mourns Soldiers Killed in Fort Hood Rampage
keywords: ['Fort Hood Shooting (2014)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: At a church service in Killeen, Tex., soldiers were remembered, as policy makers elsewhere debated what changes might help prevent another mass shooting.
lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex. — Even before a gunman killed three soldiers last week at Fort Hood, the homily for Sunday’s noon Mass at St. Joseph Catholic Church here was always going to be about death, a consequence of the year’s liturgical calendar two weeks before Easter.

headline: Oligarchs and Money
abstract: Are class interests perpetuating high unemployment?
lead_paragraph: Econonerds eagerly await each new edition of the International Monetary Fund’s World Economic Outlook. Never mind the forecasts, what we’re waiting for are the analytical chapters, which are always interesting and even provocative. This latest report is no exception. In particular, Chapter 3 — although billed as an analysis of trends in real (inflation-adjusted) interest rates — in effect makes a compelling case for raising inflation targets above 2 percent, the current norm in advanced countries.

headline: Weil Hires Senior Goldman Bankruptcy Specialist for London Office
abstract: On Monday, Weil plans to announce that it has hired Andrew Wilkinson as the newest high-profile member of the firm’s vaunted corporate restructuring and bankruptcy practice, serving as a partner in the London office.
lead_paragraph: A month and a half ago, Barry Wolf sat down for dinner at Babbo in London’s upscale Mayfair district with two of his partners at the law firm Weil, Gotshal & Manges.

headline: Waiting, Fittingly, for a Catcher to Bloom
abstract: The Mets’ commitment to the young catcher Travis d’Arnaud, who continues to struggle at the plate, is one of the reasons this looks like another transition year for the team.
lead_paragraph: Six games into their season, the Mets have the fewest hits in the majors and the most strikeouts a game in the National League. They also just took two of three from the Cincinnati Reds — a playoff team last season — and came within an opening-day strike of a .500 homestand.

headline: A Rush to Overbuild Downtown
abstract: The developer of the World Trade Center site is seeking a better deal from the Port Authority to build the next tower. The agency should stick to its original plan.
lead_paragraph: The developer Larry Silverstein and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the World Trade Center site, feuded for years about how to rebuild the area after Sept. 11, 2001. Then, in 2010, they made a deal that gave Mr. Silverstein nearly $2 billion in financing and incentives to build two towers adjacent to the museum and memorial.

headline: Surgery Will Shelve Mets’ Parnell for Season
abstract: Bobby Parnell, who learned last week that he has a partially torn ulnar collateral ligament, will become the third Mets pitcher to have Tommy John surgery since last summer.
lead_paragraph: Closer Bobby Parnell will have Tommy John elbow surgery Tuesday, the Mets said after their 2-1 loss to Cincinnati on Sunday. Parnell, who learned last week that he had a partly torn ulnar collateral ligament, is expected to miss the rest of this season, and his availability for the start of the 2015 season could be in jeopardy.

headline: Expressway to Amazon in a Box
abstract: An entrant in the growing field of devices and services to stream media, the Fire TV is likable but falls short of some rivals, a reviewer says.
lead_paragraph: OSTENSIBLY, the new Amazon Fire TV is a streaming media set-top box — an Internet-connected device that lets you watch video from Amazon Instant Video, Netflix, Hulu, YouTube, Crackle or a few other outlets and play games with or without a controller, which is sold separately.

headline: Sun Pharmaceuticals of India to Buy Ranbaxy, a Smaller Rival
abstract: Sun Pharmaceutical Industries, the Indian drug maker, said on Sunday that it would pay about $4 billion in stock for Ranbaxy Laboratories, a smaller Indian rival.
lead_paragraph: Sun Pharmaceutical Industries, the Indian drug maker, said on Sunday that it would pay about $4 billion in stock for Ranbaxy Laboratories, a smaller Indian rival.

headline: Abusive and Frivolous Patent Suits
keywords: ['Inventions and Patents', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Editorials']
abstract: Businesses are increasingly using patents to sue for licensing fees, but Congress is on the case.
lead_paragraph: Abusive and frivolous lawsuits brought by holders of patents are costing the American economy billions of dollars. Fortunately, Congress is on the case. A large bipartisan majority in the House approved a bill last year that would reduce such litigation; the Senate, where a similar bill is being negotiated, may soon follow.

headline: Business Titans Too Rich to Bribe Seek to Ease Fears in East Ukraine
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: Kiev is hoping that naming wealthy businessmen to positions of power will help allay the fears of Russian speakers in the east of the country.
lead_paragraph: DNIPROPETROVSK, Ukraine — Two months ago, Hennadiy Korban, a millionaire businessman, fled to Israel to escape retribution for siding with opponents of Ukraine’s president, Viktor F. Yanukovych. After Mr. Yanukovych’s ouster, he flew home in triumph aboard a private plane to begin a new life — as a harried civil servant.

headline: U.S. Tries Candor to Assure China on Cyberattacks
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The U.S. held an unusual briefing for China on its cyberwarfare strategy in an effort to establish “an understanding of rules of the road.” So far, the Chinese have not reciprocated.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the months before Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel’s arrival in Beijing on Monday, the Obama administration quietly held an extraordinary briefing for the Chinese military leadership on a subject officials have rarely discussed in public: the Pentagon’s emerging doctrine for defending against cyberattacks against the United States — and for using its cybertechnology against adversaries, including the Chinese.

headline: Behavior Detection Isn’t Paying Off
abstract: The T.S.A.’s expensive program to identify high-risk passengers on the basis of mostly nonverbal signs is proving to be ineffective.
lead_paragraph: A multiyear experiment in behavior detection is only worsening the Transportation Security Administration’s reputation for wastefulness. Since 2007, the T.S.A. has trained officers to identify high-risk passengers on the basis of mostly nonverbal signs, like fidgeting or sweating, which may indicate stress or fear. The total price tag: nearly $1 billion.

headline: The Mentally Ill, Behind Bars
abstract: The New York City jail system must be redesigned to serve the growing number of inmates with mental illnesses.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio and his new correction commissioner, Joseph Ponte, have inherited a city jail system in which nearly 40 percent of the 12,000 inmates have mental illnesses — up from about a quarter just seven years ago. Yet despite the stark shift, the system has not been redesigned to serve the complex needs of inmates with mental illnesses.

headline: What It Means if the Death Penalty Is Dying
abstract: As executions become concentrated in fewer and fewer states and racial disparities continue, does the application of capital punishment make it unconstitutionally cruel and unusual?

headline: Even Missing Star, Irish Are Unstoppable
abstract: Notre Dame thrashed Maryland to remain unbeaten and reach the national championship game.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — That other undefeated women’s college basketball team, the one apparently without the luck of the Irish, nonetheless steamrollered its way to the national championship game on Sunday night.

headline: More Deportations Follow Minor Crimes, Records Show
abstract: Two-thirds of the nearly two million people deported since President Obama took office had committed only minor infractions or had no criminal record, a New York Times analysis has found.
lead_paragraph: With the Obama administration deporting illegal immigrants at a record pace, the president has said the government is going after “criminals, gang bangers, people who are hurting the community, not after students, not after folks who are here just because they’re trying to figure out how to feed their families.”

headline: Early Tallies Indicating Afghan Vote a Success
abstract: Election officials said the vote count indicated that about 60 percent of the 12 million eligible voters had cast ballots.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — After enduring months of Taliban attacks and days of security clampdowns, Afghans reveled Sunday in the apparent success of the weekend’s presidential election, as officials offered the first solid indications that the vote had far exceeded expectations.

headline: With a Holler, Homers Make N.C.A.A. Broadcasts Fun
abstract: Alternative broadcasts of N.C.A.A. tournament games feature hometown announcers with a brash but entertaining subjectivity.
lead_paragraph: Was that a devilish cackle from Rex Chapman when Aaron Harrison sank the 3-pointer that lifted Kentucky over Wisconsin on Saturday? Or was it the laugh of an announcer hired to be an unrepentant homer?

headline: France Curtails Role at Genocide Services After Rwanda Leader Casts Blame
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: French officials said they would not attend the commemoration of the 1994 massacres after President Paul Kagame of Rwanda accused France of “political preparation” in the killings.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Stung by critical remarks from Rwanda’s president that laid some of the blame for that country’s 1994 genocide at the door of France, the French government has scaled back its planned participation in the 20th anniversary commemoration of the massacres.

headline: Glaxo Starts Investigating Possible Iraq Misconduct
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: GlaxoSmithKline said it was investigating claims of improper conduct, including hiring government-paid physicians to promote its products in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: The British drugmaker GlaxoSmithKline said on Sunday that it was investigating claims of improper conduct related to its business in Iraq, less than a year after China accused Glaxo of engaging in a bribery scheme aimed at increasing drug sales there.

headline: Comptroller to Opt Out of Public Financing System
abstract: Thomas P. DiNapoli, New York State’s comptroller, says the system just enacted is a badly written, sloppy piece of legislation that was obviously rushed into effect.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Thomas P. DiNapoli, the state comptroller, is the first to admit that what he plans to do is hypocritical.

headline: Calipari Credits a Mysterious ‘Tweak’ With Turning Kentucky’s Season Around
abstract: Coach John Calipari said the Wildcats had lost their “mojo” until he made a secret adjustment.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Kentucky Coach John Calipari was sitting at home one night in early March when an idea popped in his mind.

headline: A Star Candidate’s Support for Secession Undercuts Quebec’s Governing Party
abstract: The desire by Pierre Karl Péladeau, a media mogul running in provincial elections, for Quebec to secede from Canada appears to have destroyed his party’s hopes for victory.
lead_paragraph: BUCKINGHAM, Quebec — With his media holdings and celebrity, Pierre Karl Péladeau is a combination of Rupert Murdoch and Silvio Berlusconi, so his decision to run as a candidate in Quebec’s legislative elections has drastically altered the campaign. But the commotion he has caused was not what his party, the Parti Québécois, had hoped for when it introduced Mr. Péladeau as its star candidate last month.

headline: Costa Rica Set for Lopsided Victory
abstract: The victory of Luis Guillermo Solís, a history professor, who sought to win one million votes in the presidential election, seemed likely on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — With his opponent in the race for president of Costa Rica on the sidelines, a history professor seemed poised to win a lopsided victory on Sunday.

headline: Toughened by Hardship, Day Is Relishing His Challenges
abstract: The incongruity between the austerity of his childhood in Australia and the affluence of his life in America is not lost on Jason Day, who is expected to contend for the Masters title this week.
lead_paragraph: BRADENTON, Fla. — The two-story grand foyer in the 5,462-square-foot home opened to a formal living room with toys strewn on its tile floor. The golfer Jason Day, bathed in sunlight streaming in from the French doors, was talking about rooting through a junkyard for his own toys, including his first club, as a child. He had to raise his voice at times to be heard above the thwacking sound made by his 22-month-old son, Dash, who was hitting a giant plastic golf ball across the room.

headline: Cities Advance Their Fight Against Rising Inequality
abstract: Cities across the country are considering proposals to tackle income inequality, but experts say localities have little control over the policy tools that could make the biggest impact.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — In January, Teresa Fuentes’s employer told her she could work no more than 30 hours a week preparing burgers and passing out food at the drive-through for about $9.50 an hour.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Political Advertising', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Account assignments, executive appointments and miscellaneous news from advertising agencies.
lead_paragraph: Accounts

headline: Surge of Violence Across Syria Kills Over Two Dozen
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: An explosion killed antigovernment fighters preparing a car bomb in the central city of Homs, and shells struck central areas of Damascus, the capital.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Violence flared across Syria on Sunday, as an explosion killed more than two dozen antigovernment fighters in the central city of Homs and shells struck areas of Damascus, the capital, killing at least two people. On Saturday, a man died after a riot broke out in the crowded Zaatari refugee camp in Jordan.

headline: Arts Prize to Betye Saar
abstract: The assemblage artist Betye Saar, above, will receive the 55th annual Edward MacDowell Medal for lifetime achievement in the arts.
lead_paragraph: The assemblage artist Betye Saar, above, will receive the 55th annual Edward MacDowell Medal for lifetime achievement in the arts, which is given by the MacDowell Colony, an artists’ retreat in New Hampshire. The honor is to be presented to Ms. Saar, 87, by the author Michael Chabon and others at a ceremony on Aug. 10 in Peterborough, N.H. In a statement, Mr. Chabon praised Ms. Saar’s work for building “scale models of a world that is intensely personal and yet instantly, inescapably recognizable as our own broken world.” Previous winners include Robert Frost, I. M. Pei, Georgia O’Keeffe and Stephen Sondheim.

headline: Plugging Away at Living, Come What May
abstract: In Will Eno’s “The Realistic Joneses,” two couples, both named Jones, get to know one another amid fear, loneliness and unspoken love in a small town near the mountains.
lead_paragraph: Plays as funny and moving, as wonderful and weird as “The Realistic Joneses,” by Will Eno, do not appear often on Broadway. Or ever, really. You’re as likely to see a tumbleweed lolloping across 42nd Street as you are to see something as daring as Mr. Eno’s meditation on the confounding business of being alive (or not) sprouting where only repurposed movies, plays by dead people and blaring musicals tend to thrive.

headline: Art Supplies From Heaven
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: An artist’s tribute to a creaky old store that could get you any kind of paper you wanted.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Ex-Chief of Kaplan Aims to Build a Rival Digital Learning Company
abstract: Jonathan Grayer, the chief of Weld North, has acquired two digital learning businesses that will help the company expand into school management and teaching English as a second language.
lead_paragraph: For 14 years, Jonathan N. Grayer helped build Kaplan from a small test preparation company into one of the giants of the education business and the crown jewel of what once was The Washington Post Company.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Recap: Slicing and Dicing ‘Two Swords’
abstract: The HBO series kicked off its fourth season on Sunday with new threats, new faces and the same old Lannister infighting.
lead_paragraph: Here be spoilers, and a roomful of tasty chickens.

headline: Credit Suisse Is Said to Be Facing Double-Barreled Inquiries
abstract: As Credit Suisse negotiates with the Justice Department over its liability for involvement in tax shelters, New York State has opened its own inquiry.
lead_paragraph: After years of false starts and stops, the Justice Department is nearing the end of an investigation into the role Credit Suisse played in hiding American wealth offshore. But at the same time, a new investigation is beginning, threatening to entangle the giant Swiss bank for even longer.

headline: ‘Reverse Auctions’ Draw Scrutiny
keywords: ['Government Contracts and Procurement', 'Auctions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'E-Commerce']
abstract: Supporters say FedBid and similar companies encourage competition, but critics say they prompt businesses to submit unrealistically low bids to shut out rivals.
lead_paragraph: It is like an eBay of Washington, a well-appointed and well-connected online marketplace for lucrative government contracts.

headline: The Two Underdogs Left Standing Hail From Different Schools of Thought
abstract: While Connecticut’s players persevered, Kentucky’s were likely one-and-done.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Ever since March Madness began, Connecticut and Kentucky have embraced the role of underdog, and with good reason: Few believed either team had what it took to reach the N.C.A.A. title game.

headline: Catholic Schools in U.S. Court China’s Youth, and Their Cash
abstract: More wealthy Chinese parents are sending their children to American parochial schools, where they pay a premium to receive an American education and religious instruction but do not have to convert.
lead_paragraph: WAYNE, N.J. — When she arrived at DePaul Catholic High School to join the class of 2014, Di Wang hardly lacked for international experience. The daughter of a Chinese petroleum executive from Shaanxi, she had attended an elite summer camp in Japan. She knew firsthand the pleasures of French cuisine. Her favorite movie was “The Godfather.”

headline: Facing His Torturer as Spain Confronts Its Past
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Torture', 'Spanish Civil War (1936-39)', 'Extradition']
abstract: José María Galante says he was tortured by an infamous enforcer of the Franco dictatorship in the 1970s. He is seeking to prosecute the man in an Argentine court.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — José María Galante was a leftist college student when he was handcuffed to the ceiling of a basement torture chamber, his body dangling in the air. A police inspector laughed and taunted him, striking martial arts poses before repeatedly kicking and beating his face and chest.

headline: Snowden to Receive Truth-Telling Prize
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Edward J. Snowden and the journalist Laura Poitras, who helped him disclose the documents on government surveillance, will receive a Ridenhour prize.
lead_paragraph: The Ridenhour prize for truth-telling will be given to Edward J. Snowden and Laura Poitras, the filmmaker and journalist who helped Mr. Snowden disclose his trove of documents on government surveillance.

headline: Gravity Hits Highflying Tech Stocks
keywords: ['Dow Jones Stock Average', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Nasdaq Composite Index', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index"]
abstract: A turnaround for highflying tech and biotech stocks like Tesla, NXP Semiconductor and Alexion signals a potential shift that the time to chase eye-popping growth may be over.
lead_paragraph: For much of the past year, Tesla Motors seemingly could do no wrong in investors’ eyes.

headline: Connecticut’s Shrink-Wrap Defender
abstract: The Huskies guard Ryan Boatright possesses a defensive philosophy that mirrors that of his coach, Kevin Ollie, and it has made life difficult on opposing point guards.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Ryan Boatright watched Aaron Harrison shoot Kentucky into the national championship game against his Connecticut Huskies, watched him make the same darn 3-pointer from the same darn spot on the court, with about as much time left as his game-winning shot last week against Michigan, and it bothered him. Not the shot, really, so much as Wisconsin’s defense on the play.

headline: Train Engineer in Fatal Derailment Is Said to Have Sleep Apnea
abstract: The Metro-North engineer at the controls during a derailment in the Bronx had an undiagnosed sleep disorder, a person with knowledge of the National Transportation Safety Board’s announcement said.
lead_paragraph: The National Transportation Safety Board will announce this week that the Metro-North Railroad engineer at the controls last year during a fatal derailment in the Bronx had an undiagnosed sleep disorder, according to a person with knowledge of the planned announcement.

headline: N.C.A.A. Planning to Address Benefits for Some of Its Players, Officials Say
abstract: The president, Mark Emmert, and organization officials said an overhaul would look to give the power conferences the autonomy to provide some things athletes in a unionization effort are seeking.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — For the last few months, football players at Northwestern have been pushing to be recognized as a union, which they hope will eventually force universities to further limit practice time and to provide them with benefits like better medical coverage.

headline: Corrections: April 7, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on April 7, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: Liberty Media, the investment company, said last week that it would sell most of its stake in Barnes & Noble, partly because the Nook tablet failed to meet long-term expectations. Meanwhile, Amazon’s Kindle is competing well with the iPad, and last week Amazon introduced Fire TV, a set-top box.
lead_paragraph: Liberty Media, the investment company, said last week that it would sell most of its stake in Barnes & Noble, partly because the Nook tablet failed to meet long-term expectations. Meanwhile, Amazon’s Kindle is competing well with the iPad, and last week Amazon introduced Fire TV, a set-top box.

headline: Queens Community Mourns 4 Friends Killed in Crash
abstract: The deaths of the young people, who were passengers in a car that plunged off a dead-end road and into a creek, seemed to touch everyone in a pocket of East Elmhurst.
lead_paragraph: As Nancy Leader left for church on Sunday morning, her eyes turned to the five candles along the front steps of her family’s home. One for her granddaughter, Jada. One for Darius. One for Jaleel. One for Crystal. And one for Andrew.

headline: Cost Among Hurdles Slowing New York City’s Plan to Phase Out Dirty Heating Oil
abstract: Three years into a four-year plan to end use of No. 6 heating oil, a heavy pollutant, in 10,000 city buildings, barely more than half have switched to cleaner oil.
lead_paragraph: Outside Alicia Barksdale’s living room, high above Upper Manhattan, the brick chimney atop the building next door belches black smoke all winter long, and even into the spring.

headline: Lucy Hood, Innovative TV Executive, Dies at 56
abstract: Ms. Hood, president and chief operating officer of the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences, was known for her efforts to expand the purview of television.
lead_paragraph: Lucy Hood, a television industry executive who made audience participation a staple in American living rooms when she introduced text voting to “American Idol,” the Fox megahit singing contest, died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. She was 56.

headline: Two Rivals. Zero Losses. One Trophy.
abstract: Connecticut (39-0) pulled away from Stanford to set up a championship game against Notre Dame (37-0). It will be the first N.C.A.A. women’s basketball final featuring two undefeated teams.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — It was widely expected that the semifinals of the women’s Final Four would serve as thin-crust appetizers for the deep-dish main course whipped up by undefeated Connecticut and Notre Dame in the championship game.

headline: India Election Digest: April 7
abstract: What you need to know about India’s elections on Monday: The northeastern states of Tripura and Assam are the first regions to vote, and the opposition Bharatiya Janata Party readies its manifesto.
lead_paragraph: As Indian voters head to the polls, India Ink will be compiling a daily digest of the top election-related news from local media.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 6, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: April 6, 2014

headline: The Hour of the Chronograph Watch
abstract: At last week’s watch fair in Basel, Switzerland, the stopwatch struck again — this time, in a bevy of throwback designs.
lead_paragraph: At last week’s Baselworld watch fair in Basel, Switzerland, the chronograph — an elaborate stopwatch of sorts, popular in aviation and sporting events — proved it’s here to stay. But unlike the crop we spotted at Geneva’s Salon International de la Haute Horlogerie (SIHH) watch fair earlier this year, this new set consistently favors a more classic aesthetic. With pared-down dials, uncomplicated indices and timeless rose gold or stainless-steel cases, these 10 vintage-inspired chronographs are functional for any racing event and handsome enough for more formal affairs.

headline: Colleges Increasing Spending on Sports Faster Than on Academics, Report Finds
abstract: A recent report found spending on sports is outpacing educational expenditures not only in Division I, the most competitive level, but in small institutions and community colleges.
lead_paragraph: Even as their spending on instruction, research and public service declined or stayed flat, most colleges and universities rapidly increased their spending on sports, according to a report being released Monday by the American Association of University Professors.

headline: Life With a Dog: You Meet People
abstract: The health benefits of owning a pet, particularly a dog, are well documented and wide-ranging, from cardiovascular to social.
lead_paragraph: As I approached four years as a widow, the loneliness of a one-person household began to drag me down. Acquiring a four-legged companion, rather than a two-legged one, appealed to me.

headline: Word of the Day | hoodwink
abstract: This word has appeared in four New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: hoodwink•\ˈhu̇d-ˌwiNk\• verb

headline: The Front-Runners of Wall Street
abstract: Major Wall Street institutions have enabled a practice that gives some investors an unfair edge, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Folbre is professor emerita of economics at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline: Arts Education Lacking in Low-Income Areas of New York City, Report Says
abstract: Classrooms in places like the South Bronx and central Brooklyn tend to have fewer state-certified arts teachers, according to a report by Scott M. Stringer, the city comptroller.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s comptroller plans to release a report on Monday quantifying what student advocates have long suspected: that many public schools in the city do not offer any kind of arts education, and that the lack of arts instruction disproportionately affects low-income neighborhoods.

headline: Photo Replay: March 31-April 6
abstract: Facing up to a challenge and coming to grips with the competition by relying on an extra measure of physicality.
lead_paragraph: Facing up to a challenge and coming to grips with the competition by relying on an extra measure of physicality.

headline: Kansas Legislature Passes Education Finance Bill
abstract: The measure directs more money to poorer districts, addressing a statewide disparity in school funding.
lead_paragraph: Facing a Kansas Supreme Court ruling that funding disparities between school districts violated the State Constitution, Kansas lawmakers agreed late Sunday to direct more money to poorer districts.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Westbrook Is Key as Thunder Face a Strong Conference Foe
abstract: Oklahoma City will need Russell Westbrook’s energy to stack up against Los Angeles, a top Western contender with an elite point guard.
lead_paragraph: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: Fire vs. Police: Charity Game Leads to Fight
abstract: The fire and police departments faced some heat at an unexpected location: a charity hockey game where the two teams traded blows.
lead_paragraph: Firefighters and police officers playing in a charity hockey game on Sunday wound up trading blows in a bench-clearing brawl that recalled the intense rivalry between their departments.

headline: Mickey Rooney, Master of Putting On a Show, Dies at 93
abstract: Mr. Rooney led a roller-coaster life: the world’s top box-office star at 19, a bankrupt has-been in his 40s and a comeback kid on Broadway as he neared 60.
lead_paragraph: Mickey Rooney, the exuberant entertainer who led a roller-coaster life — the world’s top box-office star at 19 as the irrepressible Andy Hardy, a bankrupt has-been in his 40s, a comeback kid on Broadway as he neared 60 — died on Sunday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 93.

headline: Thomas Polgar, C.I.A. Officer, Dies at 91; Helped Lead U.S. Evacuation of Saigon
abstract: Mr. Polgar, the C.I.A.’s Saigon station chief, urged Americans, in a final dispatch, to learn from their defeat in Vietnam.
lead_paragraph: Saigon was falling and the United States was fleeing, desperately evacuating the last of its embassy staff and C.I.A. officers in the final, chaotic hours of April 1975. With the airport under siege by the North Vietnamese, helicopters landed on rooftops to ferry away Americans and some South Vietnamese.

headline: What’s On Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13) IN PERFORMANCE AT THE WHITE HOUSE: WOMEN OF SOUL Tessanne Chin, Melissa Etheridge, Aretha Franklin, Ariana Grande, Patti LaBelle (above), Janelle Monáe and Jill Scott pay homage to the “foremothers” of music in this concert taped last month in the East Room and hosted by President Obama and his wife, Michelle. In “Brothers Hypnotic” (2014), presented by “Independent Lens” at 10, the director Reuben Atlas trails the Hypnotic Brass Ensemble, founded by the Chicago jazz trumpeter Kelan Phil Cohran. The ensemble grapples with Mr. Cohran’s ideals of black consciousness while performing on New York streets, at Lincoln Center and in recording studios. “The fearless streak displayed by the Hypnotic Brass Ensemble deserves its equivalent in a bolder movie technique,” Nicolas Rapold wrote in The New York Times. “But Mr. Atlas delivers a rousing finale with a shiver-inducing studio session involving father and sons that’s at once a glimpse at deeply felt family dynamics and a moving bridge across generations.”

headline: Sweeping Graves the Party Way
keywords: ['Cemeteries', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Superstitions', 'Text Messaging', 'Tombs and Tombstones']
abstract: This year, the state is exhorting people to include the veneration of Communist leaders and revolutionary heroes as part of the holiday that traditionally commemorates a family’s departed members.
lead_paragraph: “Qingming is here, filling our hearts with longing,” read the text message signed by the Ministry of Civil Affairs that popped up, unsolicited, on the mobile phones of many Chinese as the traditional Tomb Sweeping Festival got underway over the three-day weekend, which included a public holiday on Monday.

headline: Hunt for Malaysian Jet Tests Technical Limits
abstract: Formidable obstacles remain in finding and recovering whatever is left of the Boeing 777 that vanished a month ago with its 239 passengers and crew.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The metronomic pings that may signal the flight data recorders from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 emanate from stygian depths in the eastern Indian Ocean, 2.8 miles below the waves, where the water pressure is more than three tons per square inch. The bottom is a quarter-mile deeper than even the sandy plain near the Mid-Atlantic Ridge where the black boxes of Air France Flight 447 were found off the coast of Brazil nearly three years ago.

headline: Apologetic and Sobbing, Pistorius Testifies He Killed His Girlfriend by Mistake
abstract: Oscar Pistorius, the double-amputee track star who is accused of murdering Reeva Steenkamp, apologized to her family from the witness stand.
lead_paragraph: PRETORIA, South Africa — Tearful, tremulous, speaking so softly that he was nearly inaudible at times, the Paralympic athlete Oscar Pistorius took the stand in his murder trial on Monday, maintaining that he shot and killed his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp, last year because of a tragic mistake.

headline: Standoff in Taiwan Legislature Appears Close to Resolution
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Law and Legislation']

lead_paragraph: Demonstrators in Taiwan said Monday that they will end their occupation of the legislature on Thursday, more than three weeks after they took over the building to protest the government’s handling of a trade pact with China.

headline: The Big Data Challenge to Legacy Data Management Companies
abstract: The challenge of big data software tools to traditional data software companies is not that the new technology will be a direct replacement for the old. But big-data software like Hadoop is a formidable threat to the economics of incumbents. A look at Teradata, a leader in data warehouse software, and its announcements this week, shows the challenge and how an incumbent is responding.
lead_paragraph: Scott Gnau, president of Teradata Labs, seemed a little irritated by all the attention being showered on the big data marketplace. Big-data exuberance has surged with the recent news about how much money was raised by Cloudera, the frontrunner among start-ups distributing Hadoop, open-source software used for storing and parsing huge volumes of data. The total — mainly from Intel, but also venture capital firms — was $900 million, putting a value of $4.1 billion on the young company.

He is attending Yale University in the fall to pursue an M.F.A. in photography. His conversation with Alessandra Malito has been edited.

headline: Daily Report: Gravity Hits Highflying Tech Stocks

But at the same time, a new investigation is beginning, threatening to entangle the giant Swiss bank for even longer,” Ben Protess and Alexandra Stevenson write in DealBook.

headline: Channels of Oligarchic Influence: An Example
abstract: Wining, dining, and bad history.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been suggesting that inflation paranoia has a lot to do with the interests, or at any rate the perceived interests, of the 0.1 percent; the same goes for other policy arenas. But how does that influence work? Well, there are multiple channels. In some cases we have crude buying of influence through the promise of campaign contributions or the threat of backing someone else — hence the pilgrimage of GOP would-be presidents to Las Vegas to abase themselves before Sheldon Adelson. Some of it involves financing think tanks and media organizations. But an important channel, I believe, is personal: oligarchs quite literally wine and dine people who go along with their views and interests — and when billionaires are doing the wining and dining, well …

abstract: The comedian Dave Chappelle has extended his run at Radio City Music Hall to five shows.
lead_paragraph: After staying away from scheduled performances on New York stages for a decade, the comedian Dave Chappelle announced on March 27 that he would make his return at Radio City Music Hall on June 19. By the time tickets went on sale, on Friday, the run had been extended to four shows (though June 22), and on Monday, with only premium tickets remaining (“official platinum seats” for up to $495, compared with the standard top price of $96.30), a fifth show has been added — on June 18. If Mr. Chappelle’s comeback is a test of show business proverbs – “the audience is fickle and will forget you if you’re not out there” versus “absence makes the heart grow fonder” – the absence one appears to be winning.

abstract: Call it a selfie, of sorts: a British photographer gives caged birds their close-up.
lead_paragraph: What began as a simple idea — taking portraits of caged birds against blank, colored backdrops — has turned into something of an obsession for the British photographer Luke Stephenson, whose images are compiled in a new self-published book. To access his feathered finds, he tapped into a network of quirky avian fanciers — from a vicar with an affinity for lovebirds to a hipster with an unironic collection of rare breeds — venturing into their homes with his miniature, portable studio. Save for a few dust specks, his images of budgerigars, conures, siskins and, yes, canaries aren’t retouched. He simply chooses complementary backgrounds, letting each subject get comfortable before taking its picture. Stephenson discovered that birds are generally well-behaved subjects. “Humans, on the other hand,” he says, “are a lot less predictable.” “An Incomplete Dictionary of Show Birds”; incompletedictionary.com.

headline: High-Frequency Trading Falls in the Cracks of Criminal Law
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Insider Trading', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: High-frequency trading firms’ methods do not fit comfortably into any of the typical theories of securities fraud that have been used to pursue misconduct, Peter J. Henning writes in his White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: Words like “rigged” and “scam,” which have been used to describe how high-frequency trading firms make money in the markets, usually indicate something illegal has occurred. The attorney general, Eric H. Holder Jr., added to that perception when he confirmed at a congressional hearing on Friday that the Justice Department was investigating high-frequency trading “to determine whether it violates insider trading laws.”

headline: In a Nation of Muslims, Political Islam Is Struggling to Win Votes
abstract: With voters focusing on economic issues, polls suggest that Islamic-based parties will fare poorly in national legislative elections on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Last September, ultraconservative Islamic groups telegraphed their power, railing against an international beauty contest until the government ordered it to be staged entirely on the Hindu resort island of Bali. In 2012, radical Islamic groups known for their violent tactics and religious conservatives raised enough of a fuss that Lady Gaga canceled a concert here in the Indonesian capital. And hundreds of local governments in recent years have passed rules on morality and dress inspired by Shariah, or Islamic law, and instituted bans on alcohol.

headline: A ’64 Quake Still Reverberates

lead_paragraph: When a strong earthquake rocked northern Chile on April 1, scientists were quick with an explanation: It had occurred along a fault where stresses had been building as one of the earth’s crustal plates slowly dipped beneath another. A classic low-angle megathrust event, they called it.

headline: Raymond Pettibon’s Surf Paintings Ride Into Manhattan
abstract: A new show at Venus Over Manhattan displays the artist and cult illustrator’s ocean-themed works.
lead_paragraph: Just in time for the winter thaw, the uptown gallery Venus Over Manhattan has opened “Are Your Motives Pure?,” a show of surfer paintings by the artist and cult punk-rock illustrator Raymond Pettibon. The gallerist Adam Lindemann has painstakingly amassed more than 40 greatest hits — from small works embellished with the artist’s usual comic-book-style riffs to bold, monumental paintings — from a rarefied group of collectors all over the world. “Having a Pettibon surfing painting is like having a Richard Prince car hood,” Lindemann says. They’re a slick and sunny slice of American pop culture. But while Pettibon examines the trappings of surf culture in the paintings, the artist — who despite living in Venice Beach, Calif., has never ridden the waves himself — is also dealing with universal truths. These works are about the solitary surfer against the vast ocean, man against nature. “You get a sense that nature is going to swallow him up,” Lindemann notes. “You could see them as disaster paintings.”
