headline: Getting to Know Your Inner Fish
abstract:
When Neil Shubin unearthed Tiktaalik, a 375-million-year-old fish, he knew he had found an animal with more than just fins. Inside it lived the bony foundations of all vertebrates yet to walk the earth. He talks about the discovery, and the new PBS miniseries, starting April 9, that it spawned.
Subscribe to the Podcast »
lead_paragraph:
When Neil Shubin unearthed Tiktaalik, a 375-million-year-old fish, he knew he had found an animal with more than just fins. Inside it lived the bony foundations of all vertebrates yet to walk the earth. He talks about the discovery, and the new PBS miniseries, starting April 9, that it spawned.
Subscribe to the Podcast »

headline: Many Drug Prescriptions Go Unfilled
abstract: A Canadian study has found that almost one-third of patients never fill the prescriptions for the medicines they are told to take.
lead_paragraph: A Canadian study has found that almost one-third of patients never fill the prescriptions for the medicines they are told to take.

headline: Ted Hearne Awarded New Voices Residency for Composers
abstract: Mr. Hearne is known for sharp-edged political works like “The Katrina Ballads,” about the government response to Hurricane Katrina.
lead_paragraph: Ted Hearne, a singer and composer known for his topical, politically sharp-edged works – “The Katrina Ballads,” about the inadequacy of the government’s response in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, for example, and “Ripple,” based on documents made public by WikiLeaks – has been named the third annual New Voices composer by the San Francisco Symphony, the New World Symphony and the music publisher Boosey & Hawkes, which jointly administer the program.

headline: Debating Which Perks Best Motivate Employees. Free Lunch?
abstract: Hukkster has found ways to offer Twitter-style benefits on a smaller scale.
lead_paragraph: At the most recent She Owns It business group meeting, the owners talked about retaining and motivating employees. Katie Finnegan said she realized the importance of this task soon after her company, Hukkster, made its first hires. To get ideas, she and Hukkster’s co-owner, Erica Bell, spent an afternoon at the San Francisco office of Twitter, where one of Ms. Finnegan’s friends works.

headline: CSF oligoclonal banding  - series
CSF oligoclonal banding  - series
Unhappiness With Direction of U.S. Women’s Team Led to Coach’s Dismissal
abstract: Tom Sermanni had been in charge and unbeaten for more than a year, but he was fired in the wake of a string of disappointing results.
lead_paragraph: Tom Sermanni awoke Sunday morning as the coach of the United States women’s national team, preparing one of the best teams in the world for next year’s World Cup in Canada. By that night, the team had an impressive victory and a vacancy on its bench.

headline: Complete blood count - series
Complete blood count - series
Next for Brody’s Daughter: A Stage Role Opposite Cherry Jones
abstract: Morgan Saylor, who played Dana Brody on “Homeland,” will join the cast of “When We Were Young and Unafraid.”
lead_paragraph: These have been some difficult months for Dana Brody, the brooding, trouble-making young woman played by Morgan Saylor on the Showtime thriller “Homeland”: she spent some time in an in-patient at a mental facility; a very bad thing happened to her father, Sgt. Nicholas Brody, in the season finale; and then it was reported that her character would no longer be a regular on the series. But life goes on for Ms. Saylor and her acting career: she’ll be joining the cast of Manhattan Theater Company’s coming production of “When We Were Young and Unafraid,” the theater announced on Monday.

headline: Growth hormone stimulation test - series
Amid Bids for Deoleo, Spain’s Government Seeks to Protect Olive Oil Sector
keywords: ['Foreign Investments', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Olive Oil', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: At least three foreign bidders submitted offers last week for Deoleo, Spain’s biggest olive oil company, but the national government is warning any buyer against reducing focus on Spanish olive oil farming.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — A takeover battle for Deoleo, Spain’s biggest olive oil company, is testing the Spanish government’s willingness to allow foreign investors control over one of its main agricultural sectors.

headline: Ultrasound
abstract: This animation demonstrates how an ultrasound identifies the solid and hollow areas of structures within a fetus.
lead_paragraph: This animation demonstrates how an ultrasound identifies the solid and hollow areas of structures within a fetus.

headline: Robots Teach Robots to Beat Them at Pac-Man
abstract: Computer scientists at Washington State University have created robots that can train other robots to play games, and eventually to beat them.
lead_paragraph: Computer scientists at Washington State University have created robots that can teach other robots — in this case, to play the 1980s video-game sensation Pac-Man — and ultimately to outperform their teachers.

headline: The New Ceramicists
abstract: A group of young artists is redefining the formerly folksy medium with sleeker, more sophisticated forms.
lead_paragraph: A group of young artists is redefining the formerly folksy medium with sleeker, more sophisticated forms.

headline: Gas Exchange
abstract: This animation illustrates the passage of air and exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide within the lungs on both a gross and microscopic level.
lead_paragraph: This animation illustrates the passage of air and exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide within the lungs on both a gross and microscopic level.

headline: Rich Versus Middle-Class Donors
abstract: Newt Gingrich said that eliminating caps on contributions to individual candidates would “equalize the middle class and the rich.”
lead_paragraph: In a discussion on ABC’s “This Week” the other day about the Supreme Court decision eliminating aggregate limits on contributions that individuals can make to political campaigns, Newt Gingrich suggested that the court should take one more step and eliminate caps on contributions to individual candidates.

headline: Vidalia Onions: A Crop With an Image to Uphold
abstract: The vegetable, which began as an agricultural fluke, has grown to become a powerful example of what happens when marketing hype, politics and produce converge.
lead_paragraph: VIDALIA, Ga. — Like the rush to be the first to get bottles of Beaujolais nouveau to Paris or an Alaska Copper River king salmon to Seattle, the pressure to sell the first Vidalia onions of spring is intense. The identity of this town rests on the squat, sweet onion. This time of year, just before the first of the Vidalias are pulled from the sandy soil, the green tops farmers call quills cover nearly every field.

headline: Nerve Conduction
abstract: This animation provides a general overview of the nervous system and shows the process in which nerve impulses are transmitted.
lead_paragraph: This animation provides a general overview of the nervous system and shows the process in which nerve impulses are transmitted.

headline: Obama Announces Grants in Maryland
abstract: President Obama spoke at Bladensburg High School in Maryland, one of three schools in Washington’s Maryland suburbs that received a grant for implementing innovative education programs.
lead_paragraph: President Obama spoke at Bladensburg High School in Maryland, one of three schools in Washington’s Maryland suburbs that received a grant for implementing innovative education programs.

headline: Lasik eye surgery - series
Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 66
abstract: Jay Rodriguez, who was expected to challenge for a spot on England’s team, will miss the World Cup because of a knee injury.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Long a Survivor in Syria, a Dutch Priest Is Slain
abstract: The Rev. Frans van der Lugt, who had provided refuge to Muslim and Christian families alike in the war-ravaged Old City, was reportedly killed by a lone gunman.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Rev. Frans van der Lugt, a Dutch Jesuit priest who became a symbol of suffering and compassion in the war-ravaged Old City district of Homs, Syria, was shot to death Monday morning by a lone gunman, according to members of his order. The killing came amid growing disputes between Syrian insurgents blockaded in the Old City — those who want to accept an amnesty from the government in exchange for laying down their arms, and those who do not.

headline: Judge the ‘Rebel Heart’ Sailboat Parents, or Envy Them?
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Parenting', 'Sailboats and Sailing', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Are parents raising children in extreme circumstances, like on a sailboat crossing the Pacific Ocean, bringing children into their chosen way of life or selfishly exposing them to unnecessary risk?
lead_paragraph: My closest colleague here and I have had to agree to disagree on this one.

headline: Discounts for Starwood Suites in New York
abstract: The Starwood Hotels “Suite Week” program will offer travelers discounts on suites at its New York City hotels.
lead_paragraph: Starwood Hotels in the New York City area will hold the first “Suite Week” April 15 to 29, offering 30 percent off the best available rates in suites at all of its hotel brands.

headline: Annenberg Fund Awards Fellowships to Seven Young Artists
abstract: The Leonore Annenberg Fellowship Fund for the Performing and Visual Arts, a 10-year program that is now in its seventh year, will award fellowships to seven young artists from diverse backgrounds.
lead_paragraph: The Leonore Annenberg Fellowship Fund for the Performing and Visual Arts, a 10-year program that is now in its seventh year, will award fellowships to seven young artists from diverse backgrounds, including a violinist who grew up in rural Kentucky and has won several important classical music prizes, but also doubles as a bluegrass fiddler, and a dancer with American Ballet Theater who began his career path when, as a 14-year-old in Florida, he auditioned for a performing arts high school on a whim.

headline: Inside the Mind of a Child With Autism
abstract: Nudged by an author and former journalist, researchers want to study therapy incorporating animated characters as a way to achieve a deeper connection.
lead_paragraph: Therapists who specialize in autism often use a child’s own interests, toys or obsessions as a way to connect, and sometimes to reward effort and progress on social skills. The more eye contact a child makes, for example, the more play time he or she gets with those precious maps or stuffed animals.

headline: Answers to Tough Questions About Dying
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Elder Care', 'Hospice Care', 'Living Wills and Health Care Proxies']
abstract: A new online tool from the National Institute of Nursing Research explains end-of-life care.
lead_paragraph: Lots of people want to encourage you to have the Conversation with aging family members about their wishes at the end of life, and then to help you document those preferences in an advance directive.

headline: Egg Production
abstract: All of the immature egg cells (oocytes) a woman will ever produce are stored in the ovaries by the time she is born. The average age that girls begin to menstruate is 12 years old. Each menstrual cycle occurs approximately every 28 days. During each cycle, hormonal messages from the brain cause the ovaries to develop a single mature egg cell for potential fertilization, even as other hormones instruct the uterine lining to thicken in preparation for nourishing the fertilized egg cell.
lead_paragraph: All of the immature egg cells (oocytes) a woman will ever produce are stored in the ovaries by the time she is born. The average age that girls begin to menstruate is 12 years old. Each menstrual cycle occurs approximately every 28 days. During each cycle, hormonal messages from the brain cause the ovaries to develop a single mature egg cell for potential fertilization, even as other hormones instruct the uterine lining to thicken in preparation for nourishing the fertilized egg cell.

headline: Artistic Director Named for Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet
abstract: Alexandra Damiani was named the new artistic director of the New York-based Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet on Monday.
lead_paragraph: It has been almost a year since Benoit-Swan Pouffer left the position of artistic director of Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet, and rumors have swirled about potential candidates for the enviable task of running a well-funded, New York-based operation with an extensive repertory of work by big-name choreographers.

headline: Comcast Shares Are Down, but Time Warner Cable Deal Is Still Safe
abstract: Since Comcast announced its deal for Time Warner Cable, its shares have fallen about 10 percent, meaning Time Warner Cable investors are receiving about $140 a share instead of nearly $159.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, lawmakers on Capitol Hill will ask Comcast to defend its proposed takeover of Time Warner Cable, a deal that would merge the two largest cable operators in the country. The Senate Judiciary Committee is expected to ask Comcast executives tough questions about competition and scrutinize how much choice consumers have when it comes to high-speed Internet.

headline: Greta Gerwig Replaces Maggie Gyllenhaal in ‘The Village Bike’
abstract: Ms. Gerwig will portray a pregnant young wife in Penelope Skinner’s play.
lead_paragraph: Greta Gerwig has found time in her increasingly busy schedule for the stage: she’ll star as a pregnant, sexually adventurous young wife in Penelope Skinner’s “The Village Bike” for MCC Theater, the theater announced on Monday.

headline: Salamanders, Nature’s Climate-Protecting Vacuum Cleaners
abstract: Small and slippery, these amphibians live humble lives in the forest. But salamanders may play an outsize role in slowing climate change.
lead_paragraph: Small and slippery, these amphibians live humble lives in the forest. But salamanders may play an outsize role in slowing climate change.

headline: A Hungry Butterfly Is a Hurting Butterfly
abstract: Monarch butterflies quickly show the effects of going without food in their wings, which get smaller and paler.
lead_paragraph: Monarch butterflies that go without food may end up with smaller, paler wings, according to new research in the journal PLOS One. To study the effect of food on growth, researchers deprived monarch larvae of milkweed. They found that two days of food restriction had a small but clear effect on wing size and coloration.

headline: Salamander’s Hefty Role in the Forest
keywords: ['Salamanders', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Global Warming', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Trees and Shrubs']
abstract: Small but prolific predators, salamanders affect the ecosystem of a forest and collectively could help stave off climate disaster.
lead_paragraph: If someone asked you to name the top predator in North American forests, you might think of bears, or maybe great horned owls. But here’s another answer to think about: woodland salamanders.

headline: Before the Silk Road, the Grain Road
abstract: More than 5,000 years ago, nomadic shepherds in Central Asia used imported grain from China and elsewhere, perhaps in funeral rituals, a new study has found.
lead_paragraph: Nomadic shepherds in the high plains of Central Asia used grain imported from China and southwestern Asia more than 5,000 years ago, according to a new study — perhaps to sprinkle over bodies in funeral rituals.

headline: China’s Dominance in Cement Has Little Effect on European Suppliers
keywords: ['Cement', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Cement is heavy to transport and relatively inexpensive to produce, so China’s dominance in the industry has little bearing on global supplies or prices.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — In the cement industry, as with so much else in global commerce, China is a dominant force.

headline: Interest in a Property Grows With One Key Addition: An Architecture Prize
abstract: After the Japanese architect Shigeru Ban won the award, architecture’s highest honor, the clamor for a piece of the prize became palpable at his two projects in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: When he won the Pritzker Prize on March 24, the Japanese architect Shigeru Ban had a very busy day. As the 37th winner of architecture’s biggest prize — the profession’s Nobel — Mr. Ban made all the major papers, had appearances on CNN and NPR, and even sat down with Charlie Rose.

headline: Heroic Figures From the Bible, Writ Large and Sparely
abstract: The Manhattan School of Music’s Symphonic Chorus and Chamber Choir performed Stravinsky’s Mass and Honegger’s “King David” on Friday evening.
lead_paragraph: Stravinsky could be prickly and selfish, but he also had a generous streak. When the Swiss playwright René Morax, who was looking for a composer to provide incidental music for his “King David,” asked for his opinion of Arthur Honegger, Stravinsky gave a warm recommendation, and Morax and Honegger joined forces.

headline: Minimalist Leather Goods from a Harvard-Trained Architect
abstract: Otaat, a range of bags and accessories made in L.A., deftly balances form and function.
lead_paragraph: The accessories designer Albert Chu likes to cite his grandfather — a mathematician who proved the Gauss-Bonnet Theorem in 1944 in just a few well-edited pages — as a formative influence. “After all, why do something in a zillion steps when you can do it in a sentence?” he says. “It may be harder, but to me, the end result is so much more satisfying and beautiful.” The same principle applies to Otaat, Chu’s L.A.-based line of mostly unisex leather bags and wallets. A rigorous thought process — Chu is a Harvard-trained architect and approaches designing bags as he does buildings — results in shapes that are easy, elegant problem-solvers. A sac called the “Ninja Pouch” flips and flops into multiple configurations; rectangular bags have dual handles that allow for horizontal or vertical orientation; softly structured “box” bags function as either. There’s a whiff of playful humor to the designs, underscored by the fact that Chu also sells conical party hats, made with the same premium leather and high-end stitching as the bags. As for the line’s name? It’s an acronym for One Thing at a Time, but it’s hard not to want all of it at once.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: April 4-6, 2014
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge has blocked Florida from enforcing a new law that banned doctors from discussing gun ownership with their patients. U.S. District Judge Marcia Cooke said the legislation was so vague it violated physicians’ right to free speech.

headline: Colder Can Mean Older
abstract: A mouse study found that cooler mice were longer-lived, while a survey of humans found that body temperature decreased with age.
lead_paragraph: Q. Does a lower body temperature mean a longer life?

headline: Crossing Borders With Allure
abstract: In “Border Vanguards,” on Friday at Zankel Hall, the American Composers Orchestra featured works by Silvestre Revueltas, Marcos Balter and Gabriela Lena Frank.
lead_paragraph: Making new music approachable without pandering has long been of keen interest to the American Composers Orchestra, especially in the eight years that Derek Bermel has been involved — first as a composer in residence, and now as its artistic director. “Border Vanguards,” presented at Zankel Hall on Friday night, showed how this ensemble has become unusually adept at assembling menus of complementary courses, mixing the savory with the sweet in a manner palatable to almost anyone.

headline: The 16th Century’s Line of Fire
abstract: Mathematics would seem to be immune to ideology. But not always, as a look back at a controversy from the dawn of the modern era makes clear.
lead_paragraph: Bertrand Russell once wrote that mathematics had a “beauty cold and austere.” In this new book, the historian Amir Alexander shows that mathematics can also become entangled in ugliness hot and messy.

headline: For Space Projects, Zero Gravity
abstract: The Mars rover Opportunity, still operating after 10 years on the planet, and the Cassini spacecraft orbiting Saturn are among the NASA missions facing budget extinction.
lead_paragraph: Opportunity, NASA’s resilient rover, just keeps rolling across Mars even though it landed a decade ago. It has survived mechanical malfunctions, computer glitches, tricky sand traps, ferocious dust storms and long, frigid Martian winters.

headline: ‘If/Then’ Opens Well at the Box Office
abstract: The show earned a healthy $931,268 in its first full week of post-opening performances.
lead_paragraph: Idina Menzel’s fans are following her to “If/Then,” the Broadway musical which drew lackluster reviews but earned a healthy $931,268 at the box office in its first full week of post-opening performances.

headline: Puerto Rico Hires Bankruptcy Lawyers
abstract: The move by the Government Development Bank, which oversees all of the commonwealth’s debt deals, raises the specter that Puerto Rico is preparing to revamp its finances.
lead_paragraph: Puerto Rico’s fiscal agent has hired another well-known restructuring law firm, raising the specter that the financially troubled island is preparing to revamp its finances.

headline: Lawyers for a Guantánamo Detainee Cite Failing Health in Seeking His Release
keywords: ['Detainees', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Lawyers for a former British resident imprisoned at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, asked a judge to free him because of failing health — a new tactic in seeking a detainee’s release.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lawyers for the last former British resident imprisoned at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, asked a federal judge on Monday to order his release because he has post-traumatic stress disorder and other mental and physical ailments.

headline: Beaujolais, Freed From Clichés
abstract: Re-examining assumptions about Beaujolais.
lead_paragraph: Updated | May 5, 2014

headline: Derek Jeter’s Colleagues Figure Prominently in a Victory
abstract: Jeter, retiring at the end of this season, doubled for the Yankees, who announced after the game that closer David Robertson was headed to the disabled list.
lead_paragraph: As the ball flew off Derek Jeter’s bat and into the left-field corner, Brian Roberts and many of his teammates thought they were about to witness another signature Jeter moment. Here was his final home opener, and as the ball zoomed closer to the wall, it appeared Jeter would again put his indelible stamp on Yankee history, just as he had with his famous flip, his dive into the stands, his World Series home runs and his 3,000th hit.

headline: Smallpox and Murder Come to a Sweltering City
abstract: In “Frog Music,” based on a historical incident, a professional frog catcher comes to 19th-century San Francisco during a heat wave, befriends a prostitute and falls prey to an unsolved crime.
lead_paragraph: Emma Donoghue’s new novel is based on a very peculiar historical incident: a murder that took place in San Francisco in 1876 and was never conclusively solved. It does not speak well for Ms. Donoghue’s elaborately fictionalized narrative to say that her no-nonsense factual afterword is a more interesting telling of the story.

headline: Showtime Series Aims to Engage Sleepy Public on Global Warming With Celebrity Guides
abstract: A new Showtime series aims to reengage a somnolent public on the risks of human-caused global warming.
lead_paragraph: Early in 2011, two longtime 60 Minutes producers, David Gelber and Joel Bach, met with me to describe their ambitious plan to create a television series on global warming that, they hoped, would break through the enduring public apathy and haze of disinformation surrounding the subject. I wished them luck, while warning that the scale and complexity of the problem would make it hard to be both engaging and accurate.

headline: Bach Is on the Spring Syllabus
abstract: Juilliard415 returned to Alice Tully Hall to present Bach’s “St. John Passion.”
lead_paragraph: Juilliard415, the orchestra of the historical performance program at the Juilliard School, has been enjoying quite a spring. Last month, it collaborated with the Choir of Trinity Wall Street in a performance of Bach’s “St. Matthew Passion,” conducted by Gary Thor Wedow at Alice Tully Hall, that caught fire and magic.

headline: Bordeaux, Decanted
abstract: Sharing insights and reactions to the inaugural wine.
lead_paragraph: Bordeaux is not the kind of wine most people fall for instantly. It lacks the sweet come-on that can be so seductive initially, but soon grows tiring. Instead, it’s a little austere, a bit reticent, especially when it’s young. But with time, Bordeaux reveals its many wonderful attributes. It’s a wine you learn to love.

headline: The Unintended Consequences of Treating College Athletes Like Employees
abstract: Unionization may not be the best solution, but the colleges brought this on themselves.
lead_paragraph: The head of an institution with a vested interest in maintaining the current college sports business model is unhappy about recent attempts to change it. Who could have predicted such a thing?

headline: Asymmetric Stupidity
abstract: Does politics make us stupid? Some more than others.
lead_paragraph: Ezra Klein’s new venture Vox is up, and so far, so OK — some fairly interesting pieces, and nothing like Nate Silver’s lamentable decision to make a professional concern troll his chief writer on climate. I am troubled by Ezra’s big inauguratory think piece, but that’s because I think the piece raises a genuine intellectual puzzle.

headline: Website Collects Online Information for Road Trips
abstract: With the age of folding maps all but over, Roadtrippers.com is channeling the flood of online travel resources into a route planning site.
lead_paragraph: The days of doing battle with folding state maps while driving across the country are fading, but even the latest route-finding technology can be cumbersome. Travel websites, smartphone apps and GPS units are great, but their specificity can lead to a technology pileup as each is put to its particular use.

headline: Studios File New Lawsuit Against Megaupload and Its Founder
abstract: The suit asserts copyright infringement at the now-closed entertainment website.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood’s major film studios on Monday added a new civil lawsuit on copyright infringement to the legal challenges facing the owners of the now-closed entertainment website Megaupload.com.

headline: Reactions
abstract: Letters to the editor and online comments.
lead_paragraph: PSYCHOLOGY

headline: Email From Steve Jobs Hints at How Apple Ticks
abstract: A 2010 email written by Steven P. Jobs, which Samsung lawyers obtained as evidence to present to jurors, provides an outline that provides several tidbits about how Apple ticks.
lead_paragraph: .story-body-text strong { color: #444444; font-family: nyt-cheltenham, Georgia, serif;} .DC-note .DC-note-title { display: none !important; }

headline: Few Frills, but Free Wi-Fi
abstract: Business travelers are showing with their wallets that they can live without the extra amenities found at more expensive full-service hotels.
lead_paragraph: Forget the kale in the minibar and a turned-down bed. For many business travelers, a clean, affordable room without all the frills, and in the right location, will do just fine.

headline: Racking Up the Miles, But Still Chasing Elite Status
abstract: Disgruntled business travelers anticipate losing their elite status on Delta as the airline tightens its loyalty program. Other carriers may follow.
lead_paragraph: MICHAEL SOMMER and his friend Tom Mayo were on the ski slopes in Park City, Utah, on a sunny morning last Friday, passing a cellphone back and forth while they discussed with me how airline service for loyal fliers is going downhill fast.

headline: Panel Urges Low-Dose Aspirin to Reduce Pre-eclampsia Risk
abstract: The condition, which usually occurs in the second half pregnancy, is a leading complication for expectant mothers and their infants, affecting roughly 4 percent of pregnancies nationwide.
lead_paragraph: Pregnant women should take low-dose aspirin daily to reduce their chance of developing pre-eclampsia if they are at high risk for the life-threatening disorder, an influential government panel said on Monday.

headline: Gauging the Intelligence of Infants
abstract: A test developed 25 years ago has held up surprisingly well, but the widespread screening its developer advocated has not become a reality.

headline: A Transformed Theater in a Transformed Land
abstract: A visit to the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow after 30 years shows a historic house restored to pre-Soviet glory.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Thirty years ago, during my first trip to Russia, I bought a ticket for the Bolshoi Ballet. Though I paid an excessive amount by 1984 Soviet standards for a restricted-view seat all the way on the side of the sixth, uppermost ring, I didn’t care: I was in the Bolshoi Theater for the first time. It was the world premiere of Yuri Grigorovich’s new production of the three-act ballet “Raymonda” (1898). To see better, I switched to a slightly more central place. To steady myself, I sometimes placed my hand on the ceiling.

headline: Albums From Sohn, Oran Etkin and Pedro Luis Ferrer
abstract: New releases include the first full album by the producer and remixer Sohn, and the latest from the clarinetist and saxophonist Oran Etkin and the Cuban songwriter Pedro Luis Ferrer.
lead_paragraph: SOHN

headline: Look for Cancer, and Find It
abstract: Researchers say that mammography can “overdiagnose” breast cancer, meaning that some of the tiny cancers it finds would probably never progress, but tumors are treated anyway.
lead_paragraph: Mammography has become a fighting word in recent years, with some researchers questioning its value and others staunchly defending it.

headline: Highbridge Capital Hires a Trader in London
abstract: The hedge fund Highbridge Capital Management, which recently hired away two portfolio managers from Steven A. Cohen, has recruited a portfolio manager in London from Claren Road Asset Management, a division of the Carlyle Group.
lead_paragraph: The hedge fund Highbridge Capital Management, which recently hired away two portfolio managers from Steven A. Cohen,  has picked off a portfolio manager in London from Claren Road Asset Management, a division of the Carlyle Group.

headline: In Ethiopia, the Children Call Her ‘Grape’
abstract: Carmit Keddem, the deputy director of a center for health logistics at a public health consulting firm, often travels in Africa for her work.
lead_paragraph: I AM the deputy director of the Center for Health Logistics at John Snow Inc., a public health consulting firm. We work in dozens of countries, and manage logistics for the Agency for International Development’s health supply chain. Basically, that means we work with governments to make sure that health products are available across health care systems in each country.

headline: Fearing Punishment for Bad Genes
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Disability Insurance', 'Life Insurance', 'Long-Term Care Insurance']
abstract: Many people at risk of serious inherited diseases would like to know if they carry the genes, yet fear a positive result could be used against them.
lead_paragraph: About 700,000 Americans have had their DNA sequenced, in full or in part, and the number is rising rapidly as costs plummet — to $1,000 or less for a full genome, down from more than $1 million less than a decade ago.

headline: The Kills’ Alison Mosshart Reveals Her Artistic Side
abstract: The frontwoman of the acclaimed blues-punk duo explains how she created the work she’s exhibiting in a group show in New York.
lead_paragraph: Alison Mosshart has spent more than a decade pulling rock-star moves as the frontwoman for the blues-punk duo the Kills. But when she’s not onstage, she’s usually making art. Right now, the singer is exhibiting what she calls “an oddball mix of works on paper, canvas and fabric” from the last few years as part of “Push It,” a 21-person group show devoted to female artists, on view at ArtNowNY through April 26. It’s the first time Mosshart has ever shown her art in public, but she doesn’t plan on letting it be her last. She hopes to stage a solo show later this year in her hometown of Nashville, Tenn. — if she can steal enough time from recording the next Kills album in London, that is. Here, she reflects on her art-making and how it relates to her music.

headline: Early Stephen King Novels to Be Reissued in Special Editions
abstract: Six of Mr. King’s early novels, including “Carrie,” “The Shining” and “The Stand,” will be issued in limited numbers, with new art and introductions.
lead_paragraph: Six of Stephen King’s early novels, all originally published by Doubleday between 1974 and 1983, are being given the deluxe treatment by Cemetery Dance Publications, a publisher that specializes in horror and suspense, and has published lavish editions of several of Mr. King’s later books.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Rwanda and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Afghanistan, Bosnia, South Africa and Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Afghanistan, Bosnia, South Africa and Ukraine.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Settles Into Hit Status
abstract: The premiere Sunday night averaged 6.6 million viewers at 9 p.m., the largest audience for any show on HBO since the finale of “The Sopranos” in 2007.
lead_paragraph: It’s now official: HBO has its biggest hit since “The Sopranos.”

headline: San Diego Couple Rescued in Ocean Defend Decision to Sail Across Pacific
abstract: A California family rescued with an ill child from their stalled sailboat in the Pacific Ocean documented their sailing travels online.
lead_paragraph: A California couple, rescued from their 36-foot sailboat in the Pacific Ocean on Sunday after their infant daughter became ill, defended their decision to sail into open seas with two young children, as my colleague, Jennifer Medina reported.

headline: Germany Announces Deal on Art Looted by Nazis
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Art']
abstract: The German government reached an agreement with Cornelius Gurlitt, son of a Nazi-era art dealer, that could pave the way for the restitution of art taken from Jewish owners.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The German government on Monday announced an agreement with Cornelius Gurlitt, the son of a Nazi-era art dealer, that would pave the way for the possible restitution of art wrongfully taken from Jewish owners and held in his private collection for decades.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Hamilton Prevails in Bahrain Thriller
abstract: Lewis Hamilton battled Nico Rosberg in a head-to-head Formula One duel; Gene Haas to enter Formula One team.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 1:35 a.m.: Lewis Hamilton and Nico Rosberg, drivers for the Mercedes Formula One team, waged an often side-by-side duel at Sunday’s event in Bahrain. Hamilton held on for victory by a margin of one second.

headline: Sidestepping the Biopsy With New Tools to Spot Cancer
abstract: Blood tests are praised as less invasive than traditional procedures, but their usefulness is questioned.
lead_paragraph: For people with cancer or suspected cancer, the biopsy is a necessary evil — an uncomfortable and somewhat risky procedure to extract tissue for diagnosis or analysis.

headline: A Strad? Violinists Can’t Tell
abstract: In a blind test, more than half of the accomplished musicians chose newer instruments over older ones like the prized Stradivarius.
lead_paragraph: It’s a foregone conclusion in the violin world: The best violins were made 300 years ago by Italian masters like Stradivari and Guarneri del Gesù.

headline: The Road to Hell and Back Is Paved With Surprises
abstract: Performance spaces around Washington are the sites of a weeklong music festival celebrating the works and 75th birthday of the composer Louis Andriessen.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Dutch composer Louis Andriessen, whose 75th birthday is being celebrated with a weeklong festival at venues across the Washington area, has built a reputation for writing accessible music. And it is, with orchestration as colorful and bold as a Hawaiian shirt and with a knack for keeping listeners engaged through unexpected twists that might include a violinist singing, an electric guitar lurking near the woodwinds or a brass chorale morphing into a bebop band.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: UConn Beats Kentucky for Title
abstract: The Connecticut Huskies held off yet another comeback attempt by the Kentucky Wildcats to win the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball championship.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The Connecticut Huskies had seen this script before, but they decided on a different ending.

headline: What Fish Teach Us About Us
abstract: Neil H. Shubin, the paleontologist who helped discover a fossil hailed as a missing link between sea and land animals, talks about his television series, “Your Inner Fish,” and why he teaches anatomy classes.
lead_paragraph: To Neil H. Shubin’s long résumé — paleontologist, molecular biologist, dean and professor of anatomy at the University of Chicago School of Medicine, best-selling author — can now be added “television host.” Dr. Shubin, 53, who helped discover the 375-million-year-old fish called Tiktaalik, hailed as a missing link between sea and land animals, will preside over “Your Inner Fish,” a three-part series on evolution (based on his book of the same title) that makes its debut Wednesday on PBS.

headline: Masiello Will Keep Manhattan Job
abstract: Steve Masiello will be allowed to return as the coach of Manhattan, which he led to the N.C.A.A. tournament for the first time in a decade, after he finishes his bachelor’s degree.
lead_paragraph: The Manhattan men’s basketball coach, Steve Masiello, will be allowed to return after he finishes his bachelor’s degree, the university announced Monday.

headline: Army Releases Detailed Account of Base Rampage
keywords: ['Fort Hood Shooting (2014)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: In their first detailed timeline since the shooting last Wednesday, Army officials described how Specialist Ivan A. Lopez, 34, stayed on the move throughout the rampage, driving in his own vehicle to three buildings, shooting and killing a soldier in each.
lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex. — In a little more than eight minutes, Specialist Ivan. A. Lopez fired at least 35 rounds at his fellow troops at Fort Hood, unleashing panic and bloodshed over two blocks on foot and from inside his vehicle as he killed three unarmed soldiers and wounded 16 others while they were sitting at desks, driving in a car and standing outside buildings, an Army official said Monday.

abstract: Mr. Van Bramer, a Queens City Councilman, has positioned himself as an advocate for cultural organizations.
lead_paragraph: He played drums as a teenager for the St. Joseph’s Brigade, a Catholic fife, drum and bugle corps. He fondly recalls singing along to his mother’s 45s while he and his seven siblings cleaned their childhood home in Astoria, Queens. (“Top of the World,” by the Carpenters was a favorite.)

headline: Court Rejects Appeal by Imprisoned Leaders of Egyptian Revolt
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Hunger Strikes']
abstract: An appeals court upheld the prison sentences of three liberal leaders of the 2011 uprising as the families of other detainees released letters about their hunger strike.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The prison sentences of three liberal leaders of the 2011 uprising in Egypt were upheld by an appeals court on Monday as the families of two other detainees — an Egyptian journalist and an American citizen — released an exchange of letters about the hunger strike they were conducting.

abstract: A chance mention of an Ecuadorean town with no children and a handful of old residents set Santiago Arcos on a mission to document its dwindling life.
lead_paragraph: A chance mention of an Ecuadorean town with no children and a handful of old residents set Santiago Arcos on a mission to document its dwindling life.

headline: Trisha Brown Dance Attains Half of Fund-Raising Goal
abstract: Trisha Brown Dance Company, which is winding down, is expected to announce on Tuesday that it has raised $2.5 million toward keeping Ms. Brown’s work in the public eye.
lead_paragraph: As the Trisha Brown Dance Company nears the halfway point of a three-year farewell tour, it plans to announce on Tuesday that it has raised half of the $5 million that it is seeking to preserve Ms. Brown’s legacy through educational initiatives and occasional performances.

headline: A Troupe, Now 10, Has Its Routines
abstract: New Chamber Ballet performed three premieres during a program that was part of the company’s 10th-anniversary season.
lead_paragraph: The most unusual thing about New Chamber Ballet is its regularity, its systematic schedule of performances. What other company presents new work with such consistency, and under such consistent circumstances?

headline: After EMI Debacle, Guy Hands Finds Solace in Gardening
keywords: ['Gardens and Gardening', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: With the purchase and overhaul of the Garden Centre Group in Britain, Mr. Hands and his private equity firm, Terra Firma, are aiming to get back in the game.
lead_paragraph: Guy Hands tried to make money from the likes of Katy Perry and Coldplay when he bought the music giant EMI in 2007. But he has had much more success selling resin garden animals and bedroom slippers to retirees in garden centers across Britain.

headline: Rein In Shady Tax Preparers
keywords: ['Tax Preparers and Preparation', 'Income Tax', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Consumer Protection', 'ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS']
abstract: Unregulated scam artists cheat the poor of hard-earned refunds.
lead_paragraph: WHEN you hear the words “tax preparer,” you may imagine a calculator-clutching accountant, carefully scrutinizing receipts beneath a green eyeshade. But the reality is that in most states nearly anyone can be a tax preparer. There’s no test to pass or code of ethics to follow. Walk around a low-income community and you’ll notice that check cashers, payday lenders, pawnbrokers and even furniture retailers offer tax-preparation services.

headline: Billboard Names Tony Gervino as Editor
abstract: Mr. Gervino is a former executive editor of Hearst Magazines International, and has been an editor at various lifestyle and sports magazines.
lead_paragraph: Billboard, the music industry’s premier trade publication for more than a century, named Tony Gervino as its editor on Monday, the latest in a series of changes to remake the magazine in a more general-interest direction.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
abstract: The poll by The New York Times, NY1 and Siena College was conducted March 29 through April 3 with 1,190 adult residents throughout New York City.
lead_paragraph: A poll by The New York Times, NY1 and Siena College consisted of telephone interviews with 1,190 adult residents throughout New York City from March 29 to April 3.

headline: Are Court Stenographers Necessary?
abstract: After a New York court reporter left behind an incomplete record, some are asking whether it still makes sense to use stenographers in legal proceedings.

lead_paragraph: The New York Times, NY1 and Siena College asked New York City residents to assess Mayor Bill de Blasio and how he has been dealing with issues that range from education to unemployment.

abstract: A survey by The New York Times, NY1 and Siena College shows a gap between the mayor’s expectations and his day-to-day ability to make social progress.
lead_paragraph: Nearly half of New Yorkers approve of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s job performance so far in City Hall, and his high-profile effort to provide free prekindergarten has attracted wide support, according to a poll conducted by The New York Times, NY1 and Siena College.

headline: Full Results of The New York Times/NY1/Siena College Poll
abstract: Forty-nine percent of New Yorkers approved of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s job performance, according to the poll.
lead_paragraph: Forty-nine percent of New Yorkers approved of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s job performance, according to the poll.

abstract: The Yankees’ new catcher talked about his first home game with the team and being a part of Derek Jeter’s final opening day at Yankee Stadium.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees’ new catcher talked about his first home game with the team and being a part of Derek Jeter’s final opening day at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Country Music Awards Nod to Young and Old
abstract: The 49th annual Academy of Country Music Awards on Sunday night split the difference between young and old.
lead_paragraph: The 49th annual Academy of Country Music Awards on Sunday night split the difference between young and old: The show opened with a splashy, poppy performance by the Band Perry, and the 25-year-old Kacey Musgraves, left, won the album of the year award for “Same Trailer Different Park.” But some of the biggest shows of respect went to veterans like Merle Haggard, Garth Brooks and, especially, George Strait, who won for entertainer of the year, the top prize. The three-hour show, broadcast by CBS from two casinos in Las Vegas, also rewarded Miranda Lambert with single of the year, for “Mama’s Broken Heart,” and best female vocalist. Jason Aldean was male vocalist of the year; Florida Georgia Line took home best vocal duo; and the Band Perry was best vocal group. Jessi Alexander, Connie Harrington and Jimmy Yeary, the songwriters behind Lee Brice’s hit “I Drive Your Truck,” won song of the year, and Justin Moore was named new artist of the year.

headline: The Water Cooler Runs Dry
keywords: ['Television', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Movies', 'Culture (Arts)', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: With so much to watch and read and listen to, we have fewer cultural experiences in common.
lead_paragraph: If you’re closing in on 50 but want to feel much, much older, teach a college course. I’m doing that now, at 49, and hardly a class goes by when I don’t make an allusion that prompts my students to stare at me as if I just dropped in from the Paleozoic era.

headline: What Suffering Does
abstract: In a culture obsessed with happiness, we should remember that coming to terms with suffering is instructive to the soul.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few weeks, I’ve found myself in a bunch of conversations in which the unspoken assumption was that the main goal of life is to maximize happiness. That’s normal. When people plan for the future, they often talk about all the good times and good experiences they hope to have. We live in a culture awash in talk about happiness. In one three-month period last year, more than 1,000 books were released on Amazon on that subject.

headline: Equity Fund Buys Maker of Matzos
abstract: The Manischewitz Company is expected to announce its sale to Sankaty Advisors, part of Bain Capital, as it works to reach beyond its established Jewish customer base.
lead_paragraph: This year, Passover will be brought to you by private equity.

headline: Polio Spreads From Syria to Iraq, Causing Worries
keywords: ['Poliomyelitis', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Children and Childhood', 'Epidemics', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Although Iraq has only one confirmed case, the World Health Organization said dozens could be afflicted, primarily under-inoculated young children.
lead_paragraph: Syria’s polio outbreak has now officially spread to Iraq, the first neighbor of the war-ravaged country to be hit by the crippling virus despite an ambitious Middle East inoculation effort, and global health officials warned Monday that dozens of vulnerable Iraqi children could potentially be infected.

headline: Student Deaths, One After the Other, Unsettle a Close-Knit Campus
keywords: ['Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The deaths of three students this semester at George Washington University underscore the difficulties colleges face in recognizing and addressing mental health issues.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three deaths at a single dormitory this semester, two of them last week, have shaken the campus of George Washington University. The first death has been confirmed as a suicide. One last week is thought to have been a suicide, while the cause of the other is still unknown.

headline: Dangerous ‘Game’ for a Writer
abstract: Even though I was supposed to be dealing with blacks and Italians in Suffolk County, my mind was frozen in the vernacular landscape of “Game of Thrones.”
lead_paragraph: In “The Writing Life,” Annie Dillard points out that “[a writer] is careful of what he reads, for that is what he will write.” I’ve encountered versions of this adage — along with the more extreme, don’t read anything while writing, lest you contaminate your voice — from a variety of sources and have often wondered how it could possibly be true. After all, I’ve spent my share of time with Dostoyevsky and Camus and I’m still waiting. Such admonishment always struck me as one more of those superstitions writers cultivate for the sake of it, like never discussing a work in progress or stopping only when you know what happens next.

headline: Sweep of Heat by Nets Would Be Striking, if Not Substantive
abstract: A victory at Miami on Tuesday would make the Nets the first team to beat the Heat four times during a regular season since LeBron James joined the Heat.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — No team has beaten the Miami Heat four times during a single regular season since LeBron James arrived in 2010. The Nets have a chance to do just that on Tuesday night.

headline: Prisoner in Israel Is Linked to Talks
abstract: Marwan Barghouti, a popular political figure and a convicted murderer serving multiple life sentences in Israel, could be an impetus to continue negotiations.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — He is the single most popular Palestinian politician, and he is serving five consecutive life sentences plus 40 years in an Israeli prison for crimes including murder. He is an ardent supporter of both the two-state solution and what Palestinians call the resistance against Israeli occupation. He is considered the top contender to become the next Palestinian president, and perhaps the only figure who can reunite the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

headline: Operatic Drama Swells in Labor Talks at the Met
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Opera', 'Classical Music', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: Contract talks between the Metropolitan Opera and its 16 unions have gotten off to their most contentious start in decades.
lead_paragraph: Labor strife at the Metropolitan Opera has been known to reverberate from the opera house to the White House. President John F. Kennedy helped salvage the 1961 opera season by asking his labor secretary to intervene in negotiations. President Jimmy Carter sent telegrams urging management and labor to keep talking in 1980, but a long lockout still truncated the season.

headline: Ten Cents a Bag? That’s About Right
abstract: A bill introduced by the New York City Council to limit the use of plastic bags is a good start.
lead_paragraph: There’s something ridiculous about the life of a two-handled plastic shopping bag. The 20 minutes it spends cradling your groceries home is bracketed by two vast gulfs of time. First, thousands of years beneath the earth, in a natural-gas deposit, and then, after its conversion to a disposable polyethylene product, a second eternity as all-but-indestructible trash.

headline: As Kayla McBride Boldly Goes, Notre Dame Follows Suit
abstract: The UConn women’s team paralyzes everyone else with fear but has lost seven of its last nine meetings with Notre Dame.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — It was not her numbers in the box score, though they were impressive enough. It was the look on Kayla McBride’s face, adamant, fearless, that described how thoroughly Notre Dame dominated Maryland, 87-61, on Sunday in the semifinals of the women’s Final Four.

headline: Afghanistan’s Vote
keywords: ['Elections', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials']
abstract: The high turnout in the presidential election suggests a maturing political system in a war-torn country.
lead_paragraph: That an estimated 60 percent of 12 million eligible voters in Afghanistan faced down Taliban threats and cast ballots in Saturday’s presidential election is good news, suggesting civic resilience, a certain faith in democratic processes and a maturing political system in a war-torn country. It is a further sign that the time has come to end America’s combat role there after 13 years of conflict.

headline: As Obama Spotlights Gender Gap in Wages, His Own Payroll Draws Scrutiny
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Wages and Salaries', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A recent study, by the conservative American Enterprise Institute, showed that female White House staff members make on average 88 cents for every dollar a male staff member earns.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Tuesday will call attention to what he has said is an “embarrassment” in America: the fact that women make, on average, only 77 cents for every dollar that a man earns.

headline: A Familiar Script in Ukraine
abstract: The events taking place in eastern Ukraine are very similar to those that led up to Russia’s annexation of Crimea. Does the West have a response ready?
lead_paragraph: The events taking place in Donetsk and elsewhere in eastern Ukraine are very similar to those that led up to the Russian annexation of Crimea. In fact, the pro-Russian secessionists who seized the local administration building in Donetsk, the center of the industrial Donets Basin, are following the script laid down in Crimea to the letter. They have declared the region’s independence from Ukraine and called for a referendum by May 11 on joining Russia.

headline: NBC Expects to Strike Gold in a Late-Night Renaissance Led by Fallon
abstract: Executives suggested they would seek healthy increases in advertising rates when the upfront market for the 2014-15 season begins.
lead_paragraph: TOP executives of NBCUniversal took a victory lap of sorts on Monday, briefing a roomful of reporters on recent healthy ratings — practically round the clock — for their NBC television network and suggesting they would seek healthy increases in advertising rates when the upfront market for the 2014-15 season begins next month.

headline: G.M.’s Cobalt Crisis
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: How the company handles all the recalls and inquiries will show if anything has changed.
lead_paragraph: The Chevrolet Cobalt is in many ways the perfect representation of the bad, old days of General Motors, when quality didn’t much matter, market share was more important than profitability, and financial decisions came before design and even safety decisions.

headline: Officials on Unrest in Ukraine
abstract: On Monday, officials from the United States, Russia and Britain discussed the growing unrest and violence in the Ukrainian cities of Donetsk, Kharkiv and Luhansk.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, officials from the United States, Russia and Britain discussed the growing unrest and violence in the Ukrainian cities of Donetsk, Kharkiv and Luhansk.

headline: School Funding Deal in Kansas Complicates Governor’s Campaign for Re-election
abstract: Late additions to the bill included diminishing job protections for teachers, which would almost certainly become a thorny campaign issue for Gov. Sam Brownback should he sign the measure.
lead_paragraph: Kansas lawmakers agreed over the weekend to send more money to the state’s poor school districts, addressing a State Supreme Court ruling last month that school financing had to be equalized around the state.

headline: Mickey Rooney’s Quietest Role
abstract: His performance in “Bill,” about a real-life character who spent more than 40 years in a state institution, stands out in a singular career.
lead_paragraph: Forget Andy Hardy. Set aside, for the moment, the rest of his MGM highlight reel, the hoofing and crooning with Judy Garland, in his double-breasted suit with his pomaded hair swooped back, or in Western get-up or (yuck) blackface. Forget, too, the turbulent personal life of the problem gambler who “went through the ladies like a hot knife through fudge,” as Ava Gardner (Wife No. 1 of 8) put it.

headline: Pacers’ Reliable Lineup Shows Signs of Overuse
abstract: The Pacers’ top five players lead all N.B.A. starters in time spent on the court together this season, but that appears to be contributing to their mediocre performance as a unit lately.
lead_paragraph: Too much of a good thing can be bad, and the Indiana Pacers have found that their overused starting lineup is wearing down at the worst possible time.

headline: Pressing Obama’s Agenda, Maryland Lawmakers Raise Minimum Wage
abstract: The General Assembly’s vote was a victory for Gov. Martin O’Malley, who said on Monday that he would also sign a bill to decriminalize possession of small amounts of marijuana.
lead_paragraph: Maryland embraced President Obama’s call to raise the minimum wage to $10.10 an hour on Monday, the second state to do since Connecticut acted last month.

headline: Concession Offered, Taiwan Group to End Protest of China Trade Pact
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Activists, mostly students, who stormed Taiwan’s legislature to show resistance to a trade deal with China, agreed on Monday to leave the building later this week.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Yang Shih-wei admits he is an unlikely opponent of a trade deal with China. A 27-year-old Taiwanese banker who spent a year working at a trading company in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou, he has seen firsthand how quickly Taiwan’s giant neighbor is growing. And he says that if Taiwan wants to compete economically, it cannot shun China.

headline: Tech Firms May Find No-Poaching Pacts Costly
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Employees of technology companies have filed a class-action lawsuit that contends that illegal hiring practices among their companies has cost them billions in lost wages.
lead_paragraph: It is the talk of the Valley.

headline: John Pinette, 50, Stand-Up Comic and Actor, Dies
abstract: A former accountant turned comedian, Mr. Pinette, who was a guest on “The Tonight Show” and “The View,” often dealt in comedy rooted in his own life.
lead_paragraph: John Pinette, a stand-up comic whose Falstaffian figure provided him with no shortage of subject matter, died on Saturday in Pittsburgh. He was 50.

headline: Iran’s Choice for U.N. Post Denied Entry Into the U.S.
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Hostages', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Hamid Aboutalebi, who was to become Iran’s ambassador to the United Nations in July, was a member of the Muslim student group that took American hostages in 1979.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate voted unanimously on Monday night to bar Iran’s newly named ambassador to the United Nations from entering the United States, charging that he was involved in the hostage-taking at the United States Embassy in Tehran in 1979.

headline: Charlotte Names New Mayor Amid Scandal
abstract: The City Council chose Daniel G. Clodfelter, a state senator in his eighth term, to replace Patrick D. Cannon, a Democrat who resigned after he was arrested on public corruption charges.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — In a city left reeling after its mayor resigned in a federal corruption sting two weeks ago, the City Council on Monday chose a successor, Daniel G. Clodfelter, a state senator in his eighth term who is a former member of the Council.

headline: Hackers Lurking in Vents and Soda Machines
abstract: Companies are finding that their greatest cybersecurity threats can hide in third-party systems, like networked air-conditioning equipment.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — They came in through the Chinese takeout menu.

headline: Drivers in New Jersey to Lose Link as Pulaski Skyway Route Closes
abstract: The rickety bridge serves as a critical link for roughly 40,000 vehicles in and around Jersey City and Newark and for commuters to New York City. It is set to close Saturday for two years for repairs.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Here is the view of New Jersey transportation from an eight-acre tow yard on the edge of the city:

headline: U.S. Gas Tantalizes Europe, but It’s Not a Quick Fix
keywords: ['Natural Gas', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Liquefied natural gas from the United States may hold promise for Europe to reduce its reliance on Russia, but regulatory and market obstacles stand in the way.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — As congressional pressure builds on the Obama administration to quicken gas exports to Europe to reduce its dependence on Russia, it may be tempting to gaze upon a marshy, alligator-infested Louisiana inlet of the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Air National Guard on Baby Rescue
abstract: Maj. Mark Bomann, the flight doctor who treated a sick baby who was rescued from a family boat in the Pacific Ocean, said the 1-year-old girl was in stable condition.
lead_paragraph: Maj. Mark Bomann, the flight doctor who treated a sick baby who was rescued from a family boat in the Pacific Ocean, said the 1-year-old girl was in stable condition.

headline: Chuck Stone, a Fiery, Trusted Columnist in Philadelphia, Dies at 89
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Newspapers']
abstract: Mr. Stone was a passionate voice against racism, police brutality and political corruption, with credibility at both the statehouse and street levels.
lead_paragraph: Chuck Stone, whose columns for The Philadelphia Daily News denouncing racism, political corruption and police brutality inspired such trust that wanted criminals sometimes surrendered to him rather than to the police and the authorities called on him to mediate prison crises, died on Sunday in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 89.

headline: In Switch, Development Agency Welcomes Business and Technology to Poverty Fight
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Foreign Aid', 'Social Media']
abstract: Rajiv Shah, head of the United States Agency for International Development, has set off a fierce debate over the way the agency operates and the usefulness of traditional foreign aid.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Civic leaders recently broke ground on a lush cricket field here for the Nelson Mandela Children’s Hospital, a nearly $100 million state-of-the-art pediatric facility that is to provide care for youth throughout Southern Africa. Donations are pouring in, but not enough.

headline: 2 Tots, a Sailboat and a Storm Over Parenting
abstract: Charlotte and Eric Kaufman became the focus of a debate over parenting after they took their daughters — ages 1 and 3 — on a trip across the South Pacific that ended with a Navy rescue.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As her family began what was supposed to be a monthslong journey in a 36-foot sailboat from Mexico to New Zealand, Charlotte Kaufman wrote openly of her misgivings about taking her two daughters — ages 1 and 3 — to sail the South Pacific, with her husband as captain and herself as the crew.

headline: ‘Succeed and Proceed,’ to Instant Riches
abstract: In defending a one-and-done recruiting system, Kentucky Coach John Calipari has become the facilitator of not so much the big picture but of the big dream.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Throughout the course of an intriguing N.C.A.A. tournament, John Calipari spoke about the transformation that took his team of freshmen from midseason mediocrity to the N.C.A.A. championship game, where it lost to a veteran Connecticut team. But the most compelling change was how Calipari has transformed his pregame and postgame interview sessions into small revivals and prayer meetings, promoting and preaching the gospel of Kentucky basketball, defending and explaining a recruiting system praised and vilified as “one and done.”

headline: Wish for Change Animates Voters in India Election
abstract: Narendra Modi, a front-runner for prime minister who campaigned as a technocrat but rose as an ideologue, has won admirers among the disillusioned working and middle classes.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Over the last several years, as the yearning for a strong leader began to deepen and swell in the Indian electorate, one politician was systematically preparing himself to be the answer to that demand.

headline: Two World War II Veterans Honor 19 Soldiers Who Disappeared 70 Years Ago
keywords: ['Military Aircraft', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Missing Persons', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Veterans']
abstract: The soldiers vanished on training flights; a possible piece of the aircraft was found last year off Long Island.
lead_paragraph: EAST FARMINGDALE, N.Y. — On Monday morning, two World War II veterans held bouquets of roses and boarded an old warplane at Republic Airport here. Both men — Frank Kittle, 90, and Jack McMullen, 91 — narrowly escaped death while serving on such planes over Europe during the war.

headline: Dogs and Scoundrels, Well Dressed
abstract: The new production of “The Threepenny Opera,” at the Atlantic Theater Company, stars F. Murray Abraham, Laura Osnes, Michael Park and Mary Beth Peil.
lead_paragraph: An English bulldog plays a minor role in the new production of “The Threepenny Opera” that opened at the Atlantic Theater Company on Monday. Romeo is his name, and he acts very naughty in the tableau that opens the show, slobbering away at the leg of a streetwalker who’s passed out flat on the ground. Still, Romeo is as cute as can be and looks as if he wouldn’t have a mean bite, even if, say, you slapped a tiara on his head and asked him to do his best impression of Queen Victoria.

headline: That’s Enough!
abstract: We’ve had enough of Ian Livengood, haven’t we?
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — We started off the week with a terrific debut by Douglas Taillon, and we continue the fun with a really nice puzzle by Ian Livengood. This one was another one that felt like it was over too soon.

headline: Sharpton Is Linked to Spying on the Mafia
keywords: ['Organized Crime', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Informers']
abstract: Acting as an informant for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Mr. Sharpton used a briefcase to secretly record conversations during his interactions with Mafia figures in the 1980s, according to a recent report.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Al Sharpton was an F.B.I. informer who had extensive dealings with Mafia figures in New York in the 1980s and secretly recorded their conversations using a briefcase modified with hidden electronic equipment, a report said on Monday.

headline: At Google, Bid to Put Its Glasses to Work
abstract: The technology giant will give more assistance to Glass users at businesses, where the wearable device has already found some acceptance.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — At the 500 Club bar in the heart of the Mission district here, patrons are banned from wearing Google Glass. Two miles up the hill at the hospital at the University of California, San Francisco, a lung surgeon wears Glass to assist him as he operates.

headline: Conference’s Snub Haunts UConn
abstract: Left behind in realignment and now a member of a lightly regarded league, the Huskies’ basketball teams have proved the snub was probably a huge mistake.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Warde Manuel had a few minutes — but only a few — to say a few words. He had another rush to an airport to make, another plane to catch.

headline: Somalia: 2 U.N. Advisers Slain
abstract: A security guard in Somalia’s semiautonomous Puntland region shot to death two consultants working for the United Nations shortly after they had landed at the Galkayo airport on Monday, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A security guard in Somalia’s semiautonomous Puntland region shot to death two consultants working for the United Nations shortly after they had landed at the Galkayo airport on Monday, officials said. Nicholas Kay, the United Nations’ special representative for Somalia, said the two victims were advising the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime. One victim was British and the other was French, The Associated Press reported, citing British and French officials. The president of the Puntland region, Abdiweli Mohamed Ali, confirmed that the gunman was a security guard and said that he had been arrested, along with an accomplice, another guard. Mr. Ali said an investigation was underway.

headline: Sleep Disorder and Schedule Change Cited as Possible Factors in Train Derailment
abstract: A Metro-North employee involved in a fatal accident was found to have an undiagnosed sleep apnea condition.
lead_paragraph: For the last two and a half years, William Rockefeller worked nights. And on most of those nights, he was operating a Metro-North Railroad train along the Hudson line, the scheduled stops as familiar to him as the exit signs a driver sees day after day along a highway.

lead_paragraph: The Connecticut Huskies took on the Kentucky Wildcats in Monday’s N.C.A.A. championship game.

headline: Canada: Parti Québécois Seen Losing Power in the Province
abstract: An attempt to secure power in Quebec by calling a snap election turned against the separatist Parti Québécois on Monday. Based on early returns, four television networks forecast a victory for the Liberal Party.
lead_paragraph: An attempt to secure power in Quebec by calling a snap election turned against the separatist Parti Québécois on Monday. Based on early returns, four television networks forecast a victory for the Liberal Party. The results are likely to be viewed as a severe rebuke of the movement for Quebec independence. Before the election, the Parti Québécois played down the likelihood that it would seek a third referendum on separation if re-elected. For years, polls have shown that a firm majority of Quebeckers oppose leaving Canada. Yet the party’s attempt to avoid the issue, which was the basis of its founding, fell apart last month when its star candidate, Pierre Karl Péladeau, a media magnate, immediately vowed to make Quebec a nation in a rousing speech that concluded with a raised fist.

headline: Another Injury Shelves David Robertson
abstract: On Monday, the Yankees placed Robertson on the 15-day disabled list after he injured his groin in Toronto.
lead_paragraph: The last time David Robertson was named to replace Mariano Rivera was in 2012 after Rivera had sustained a season-ending knee injury. Robertson made only a handful of appearances before he suffered a strained oblique muscle, and the job of closer went instead to Rafael Soriano.

headline: UConn Defeats Kentucky for Men’s Title
abstract: A year after missing the tournament because of a poor graduation rate, Connecticut won the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball championship over Kentucky.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — All week, Shabazz Napier was asked about the Connecticut team of 2011, the team that began March as outsiders before rumbling through the N.C.A.A. tournament. He was a freshman on that team, as old as the five players in Kentucky blue joining him Monday for the opening tip-off in the national championship.

headline: Food Bank’s Tax Service Puts Money in the Hands of Those in Need
abstract: The Food Bank for New York City runs 68 sites that offer free tax preparation to those who qualify. Last year it helped filers claim $81.2 million in credits and refunds.
lead_paragraph: Single mothers and fathers, unemployed workers and retirees on lean budgets were all following the signs for the Food Bank for New York City to the basement of a senior center in the Bronx.

lead_paragraph: SPRING VALLEY, N.Y. — A principal leans across the table at a pizza parlor and, with whispered intensity, totals up the damage done to the East Ramapo Central School District in recent years.

headline: For Derek Jeter, Awkward Play and Trademark Cool
abstract: Despite an uneven game, the Yankees won on Monday against the Baltimore Orioles, with Jeter going 1 for 4 in his final home opener.
lead_paragraph: This was his day, the first at home of his 20th and final season, and there stood Derek Jeter, in the hallway outside the Yankees’ locker room, utterly helpless. Like a magician backstage, eager for his act but missing his magic wand, Jeter fiddled with the locks on his case of Louisville Sluggers. It would not open.

headline: Rookie Answers Yankees’ Needs, if Not Fans’ Chants
abstract: Yangervis Solarte, a career minor leaguer, has provided an unexpected boost to the Yankees’ lineup.
lead_paragraph: In the moments before the Yankees took the field during Monday’s home opener, the backup catcher Francisco Cervelli approached Yangervis Solarte in the dugout to remind him of the traditions at Yankee Stadium.

headline: A New Twist on the Iconic Maralunga Sofa
abstract: During Milan’s annual design week, Salone Internazionale del Mobile, Cassina introduces an update on its 40-year-old bestseller.
lead_paragraph: Cassina’s founder Cesare Cassina and the visionary furniture designer and architect Vico Magistretti crafted an enduring design legacy together, one to which even the most dedicated of couch potatoes are forever indebted. Legend has it that when Cassina first saw Magistretti’s prototype for the now-iconic 1974 Maralunga sofa, he disliked it so much that he punched it — hard. His frustration split the back of the model, which fell back over itself so that it resembled a headrest. This serendipitous series of events eventually resulted in the design for the Maralunga, the first upholstered sofa to incorporate movement — the back transforms into an actual headrest — for ultimate comfort. To mark the 40th anniversary of its bestseller, the company collaborated again with design visionaries to develop a new version of the sofa, this time tapping 20 students from the Swiss art and design school ECAL for the task. Just in time for Milan’s annual design week, Salone Internazionale del Mobile, the results are on view at the Cassina showroom in the city beginning tomorrow.

Once on the grounds of Augusta National Golf Club, many patrons purposefully made their way to the par-4 17th hole to ogle at or take photographs of a fairway that has healed beautifully, though a circular scar remains visible from the removal in February of a very large, distinctive beauty mark.

headline: Should the United States Stop Using the Death Penalty?
abstract: Do you think capital punishment is “cruel and unusual punishment” and therefore prohibited by the Constitution? Or, do you think the death penalty serves a purpose, like deterring crime, providing relief for victims’ families or imparting “real justice?”
lead_paragraph: Room for Debate recently asked if the death penalty is dying in the United States, and if that is a bad thing. After all, 18 states already outlaw capital punishment, with New Hampshire possibly becoming the 19th. Last year the United States executed 39 people, down from its post-1976 peak of 98 executions in 1999.

headline: The Case of Who v. Whom
abstract: We stumble regularly over who and whom, but this should not be an insurmountable problem. Mentally remove the attribution phrase and the grammar becomes painfully clear.
lead_paragraph: We stumble regularly over who and whom. And as I’ve noted before, our most common problem seems to be using the objective-case “whom” when “who” is needed. Most often this occurs when an attribution phrase separates the relative pronoun from the verb and misleads us.
