headline: After Slide, Rich Nations Now Lifting Growth, I.M.F. Reports
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Recession and Depression', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: The International Monetary Fund expects about 3 percent growth in the United States in 2014 after 1.9 percent growth in 2013.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The rich countries whose property bubbles and collapsing banks plunged the world into recession in 2009 are now helping to lead the still-halting recovery out of it.

headline: A Makeover at Universal Studios Hollywood Aims at Disney
abstract: After years of semi-neglect by previous owners, the California theme park is getting a $1.6 billion overhaul as Comcast tries to broaden its appeal.
lead_paragraph: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif. — Now Comcast is mouse hunting on both coasts.

headline: Comcast Gears Up to Persuade Regulators
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Cable Television', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Television']
abstract: The companies filed documents in support of the plan, which has faced opposition and will be the subject of a Senate hearing this week.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Comcast presented regulators on Tuesday with 650 pages of reasons to approve its takeover of Time Warner Cable, saying a merger of the two largest cable television companies would spur rather than inhibit competition by encouraging rivals to improve their cable and high-speed Internet service.

headline: Notes Found in Review of Police Work Could Exonerate 2 Convicted in Killing
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Police notes from a case inherited by Detective Louis Scarcella say that two witnesses named killers different from the men who were convicted in a 1985 case.
lead_paragraph: A review of homicide convictions stemming from the work of Louis Scarcella, a Brooklyn detective accused of framing suspects, has turned up a stash of old handwritten police notes that could exonerate two men convicted of a murder in 1985. One of the men served 21 years in prison; the other died behind bars.

headline: Charting Roseland in the 1990s
abstract: In the early 1990s the Roseland Ballroom, which closed Monday night, was one of the best places in New York to see bands from the newly minted alt-rock scene.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1990s the Roseland Ballroom, which closed Monday night after Lady Gaga’s final performance there, was one of the best places in New York to see bands from the newly minted alt-rock scene. Here the artist Andrew Kuo charts 23 shows he saw at Roseland from 1992 to 1995, when he was a high school music fan, including Nirvana, the Beastie Boys, Pavement and Hole.

headline: How Has Fiction Handled the Theme of Money?
abstract: Pankaj Mishra and Rivka Galchen discuss how fiction writers have approached the subject of money.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Pankaj Mishra and Rivka Galchen discuss how fiction writers have approached the subject of money.

keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Elections', 'Hinduism', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Amit Shah, the Bharatiya Janata Party’s general secretary, was caught on camera speaking of revenge to Hindus in an area in Uttar Pradesh that saw religious riots last autumn.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Amit Shah, the general secretary of India’s opposition Bharatiya Janata Party and widely seen as the lieutenant of Narendra Modi, the party’s prime ministerial candidate, spoke at a private meeting near Muzaffarnagar in the northern Indian state of Uttar Pradesh.

headline: A Little to the Imagination
abstract: How baring a little skin up top can soften an edgy look.
lead_paragraph: The season’s strategically worn bandeau tops and shoulder-baring dresses are a sharp and sexy complement to masculine dressing.

headline: Riverdale Just Won’t Be the Same: Archie Will Die
abstract: Archie Andrews, the star of “Archie” comics will meet his end in “Life With Archie,” a flash-forward series that depicts two futures: one with Betty and one with Veronica.
lead_paragraph: CNN broke the news today about the impending death of Archie Andrews, the happy-go-lucky redhead from Riverdale and star of various “Archie” comics. But the truth of his demise is complicated.

headline: Zuni Ask Europe to Return Sacred Art
abstract: The Zuni Native American tribe has been active in reclaiming ceremonial objects, and is now making a moral case to museums beyond the reach of federal law.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Octavius Seowtewa, an elder of the Native American Zuni tribe from New Mexico, was sitting in a Paris cafe late last month, scrolling through his iPhone pictures of Ahayuda, carved and decorated wooden poles that are considered sacred to the Zuni. They were taken at his recent meetings with representatives of major European museums, whom he is hoping he can persuade to return the artifacts.

headline: Measuring Motherhood, One Preschool Application at a Time
abstract: I felt proud of the way I’d navigated through the Manhattan preschool maze we’d chosen — until my friend Jamie one-upped me, as I thought she had a hundred times before.
lead_paragraph: At last I’d completed Zee’s preschool applications, and was feeling positive about my mothering. Which was a good thing, because we were meeting my dear friend Jamie, one of those moms who magically knew all the tricks.

headline: Choice to Oversee Cohen Fund Has Link to It
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Hedge Funds', 'Insider Trading']

headline: Private Equity’s New Kind of Club Deal
abstract: Blackstone is enlisting some of its fund investors to help buy the auto parts maker Gates for $5.4 billion. Returns from such so-called co-investing, though, could make it a passing fad, Jeffrey Goldfarb of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Trendy new buyout clubs may disappoint their eager would-be patrons. The Blackstone Group is enlisting some of its fund investors to help buy the auto parts maker Gates for $5.4 billion. Such collectives are increasingly displacing teams of private equity firms in bigger deals. Returns from so-called co-investing, though, could make it a passing fad.

headline: South Beach Meets Sioux Falls in D-League
abstract: The Sioux Falls Skyforce of the N.B.A. Development League and the Miami Heat have forged one of the more unusual and innovative partnerships in professional sports.
lead_paragraph: SIOUX FALLS, S.D. — Not long after he was released by the Oklahoma City Thunder in September, DeAndre Liggins learned that the N.B.A. Development League affiliate of the Miami Heat had acquired him. Liggins, a shooting guard, figured the team was in Florida. He was wrong.

headline: Rhode Island Settles Case on Jobs for the Disabled
keywords: ['Disabilities', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT', 'Abuse of the Disabled']
abstract: The Justice Department said the state had agreed to changes aimed at giving residents with developmental disabilities more opportunities to find well-paying and competitive jobs.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department on Tuesday announced a “landmark” agreement with the State of Rhode Island to free people with developmental disabilities from a decades-old system that kept them unjustly segregated in sheltered workshops and adult day programs, removed from the competitive workplace and the broader community.

lead_paragraph: The director Catherine Hardwicke, the actress Lake Bell and the director Ben Younger will be among the 33 jurists for this year’s Tribeca Film Festival, which runs from April 16 to 27, festival organizers announced Tuesday.

headline: In Mississippi, a Long-Time Republican Senator Isn’t Regressive Enough
abstract: If you care deeply about the distinctions between various types of Republicans, you might be aware that Thad Cochran is not particularly conservative.
lead_paragraph: If you care deeply about the distinctions between various types of Republicans – not a hobby I’d recommend for those without professional training – you might be aware that Thad Cochran of Mississippi is not a particularly conservative senator.

headline: For Car Thieves, the Older and Heavier the Ride, the Better
abstract: Automobile thefts, virtually eliminated in New York since the 1990s, have seen a recent rise, driven by a legislative quirk and the lure of scrapyard payouts for heavy vehicles.
lead_paragraph: Of all the crime declines in New York over the past two decades, the virtual eradication of car theft has been among the most complete: They are down 94 percent from the 1990s, when blaring multitune car alarms served as the city’s after-hours soundtrack.

headline: The Case of Brendan Eich
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The fate of a C.E.O. and the future of pluralism.
lead_paragraph: I’ve written a fair amount about pluralism lately, in the context of debates about what kind of accommodations might be made for religious institutions and communities in a public-policy landscape that’s likely to become increasingly hostile to some of their beliefs. That discussion offers an interesting background to the defenestration of Brendan Eich, briefly the CEO of Mozilla, for his past donation to the ballot initiative that (temporarily) re-established the conjugal/opposite-sex definition of marriage in California. I say “interesting” because while Eich’s ouster has been cited (by some liberals as well as conservatives) as a kind of left-wing escalation in the culture war, there are some ways in which his fate might be reasonably seen as less troubling, to principled pluralists and religious conservatives both, than some of the other cases and controversies currently in the news.

headline: Oscar Pistorius Breaks Down
abstract: The Paralympic athlete Oscar Pistorius broke down on the stand during his murder trial in Pretoria, South Africa.
lead_paragraph: The Paralympic athlete Oscar Pistorius broke down on the stand during his murder trial in Pretoria, South Africa.

headline: Twitter Gives a New Look to User Profiles
abstract: The social network, which is struggling with slowing growth, will automatically highlight a user’s most popular tweets and allow customers to change their profile pages to highlight a favorite photo and favorite tweet.
lead_paragraph: Twitter began the rollout Tuesday of a new look for its profile pages that is meant to highlight each user’s best tweets.

headline: ‘Taking a Taxi': Remembering Mickey Rooney on Broadway
abstract: The former music director of “Sugar Babies” on working with Mickey Rooney on the actor’s Broadway debut.
lead_paragraph: Glen Roven, the original musical director of “Sugar Babies,” shared this reminiscence of working with Mickey Rooney on Broadway in what became the actor’s late-in-life comeback triumph. Mr. Rooney died on Sunday at 93.

headline: Underwater Pings
abstract: The sounds from a Teledyne Benthos ELP-362A, a device similar to the pinger believed to be affixed to the black boxes aboard Flight 370, as recorded off headphones a diver searching for a device might use. The depth of the black box in icy ocean waters and other variables may affect the device’s actual sound.
lead_paragraph: The sounds from a Teledyne Benthos ELP-362A, a device similar to the pinger believed to be affixed to the black boxes aboard Flight 370, as recorded off headphones a diver searching for a device might use. The depth of the black box in icy ocean waters and other variables may affect the device’s actual sound.

headline: Samsung Edges HTC in New Android Phones
abstract: The Samsung Galaxy S5’s features, including a slightly better camera, make it the more logical choice over the elegantly simple HTC One (M8).
lead_paragraph: IN a rare bit of cosmic alignment, two Android phone stars drop into orbit at the same time this week.

headline: Congress Picks Local Legislator to Face Heavyweight Rivals in Varanasi
abstract: Ajay Rai, a member of the state assembly, will run for a parliamentary seat that is also being contested by Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party and Arvind Kejriwal of the Aam Aadmi Party.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Indian National Congress said Tuesday that it had nominated Ajay Rai, a legislator from the Varanasi constituency of Uttar Pradesh, to run against Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party and Arvind Kejriwal of the Aam Aadmi Party.

headline: Mideast Frustration, the Sequel
abstract: “Poof, that was the moment,” Secretary of State John Kerry said of Israel’s announcement that it planned to build 700 new apartments for settlers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For those who suspect that the Middle East peace process has become a diplomatic drama, playing on an endless loop, Secretary of State John Kerry’s testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Tuesday could serve as Exhibit A.

headline: Hospitals Safer Than Homes for Births
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Hospitals', 'Medicine and Health', 'Midwives', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: A new analysis suggests that giving birth in a hospital is considerably safer than having a baby at home or in a birth center.
lead_paragraph: A new analysis suggests that giving birth in a hospital is considerably safer than having a baby at home or in a birthing center.

abstract: A fistfight erupted in the Ukrainian Parliament as lawmakers debated unrest in the country’s east.
lead_paragraph: A fistfight erupted in the Ukrainian Parliament as lawmakers debated unrest in the country’s east.

headline: Pastor Is Convicted of Trying to Sell Counterfeit Art
abstract: A jury found Kevin Sutherland guilty of second-degree attempted grand larceny for trying to sell five counterfeit paintings to an undercover police officer.
lead_paragraph: A Florida pastor who dabbles in art dealing was convicted on Tuesday of trying to sell five fake Damien Hirst paintings to an undercover police officer.

headline: Cuba Social Media Project Was No Plot, Agency Says
abstract: The head of the United States aid agency told Congress that the program was not meant to destabilize the Cuban government, only to promote open communication.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Twitter-like social media site created and financed by the United States Agency for International Development for use in Cuba was an attempt to promote open communications among citizens on the island nation, not a covert attempt to overthrow the government, the agency’s top official told members of Congress during a hearing on Tuesday.

headline: Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam Names New Director
abstract: Beatrix Ruf, who as director of the Kunsthalle Zurich has drawn attention for the exhibitions there, will be the new director of the Stedelijk Museum.
lead_paragraph: The Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam, a mecca for modern and contemporary art fans, has named Beatrix Ruf to be its new director, The Art Newspaper reported Tuesday. Ms. Ruf has been director of the Kunsthalle Zurich for the last 13 years. She is succeeding Ann Goldstein, who announced her resignation in August after having led the institution since 2009.

headline: Ayad Akhtar Play Among Highlights of New York Theater Workshop Season
abstract: Mr. Akhtar’s play “The Invisible Hand,” about an American stockbroker who is kidnapped by militants, is the centerpiece of the company’s 2014-15 season.
lead_paragraph: The New York premiere of “The Invisible Hand,” a work by the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Ayad Akhtar, is the centerpiece of the New York Theater Workshop’s 2014-15 season, which the company announced on Tuesday.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Cost of a Bad Hire
abstract: Legal pot is becoming a workplace issue. Ten tricks for getting paid faster. Is affiliate marketing right for your business?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: A Bird Walks Into a Bar ...
abstract: An obscure tiki drink is a favorite of bartenders.
lead_paragraph: On the concise drinks menu for the downstairs bar at Celeste, a cocktail den that opened in Chicago in February, there’s a small section titled Classics. The four drinks under that heading are the manhattan (of course), the Negroni (natch), the Brown Derby (a little more arcane, but a classic) and the Jungle Bird.

headline: Image of the Day: April 8
abstract: A mahout riding atop an elephant in Jammu, Jammu and Kashmir, on the last day of the Hindu festival of Navratra.

headline: A Writerly Life, Beneath the Surface
abstract: “Updike,” Adam Begley’s biography of John Updike, finds that the celebrated novelist’s existence wasn’t as effortless and easy as he made it look.
lead_paragraph: His high school friends called him Uppie, as if he were a drug. He’d claim the back booth in Stephen’s Luncheonette, in Shillington, Pa., his hometown, and amuse everyone by blowing smoke rings and French inhaling. He was gawky and shy but almost sexy.

headline: Philip Roth to Be Honored With Yaddo Medal
abstract: The artists’ colony will present the Yaddo Artist Medal to Mr. Roth at a fund-raiser in New York City in May.
lead_paragraph: Yaddo, the artists’ colony in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., has chosen the Pulitzer Prize-winning author Philip Roth to be the first recipient of a new medal it is awarding artists.

headline: Dianne Feinstein Accused of ‘Deep Emotional Feeling’
abstract: Michael Hayden said the senator’s feelings had tainted a report on the C.I.A.’s abuse of prisoners.
lead_paragraph: If Michael Hayden, the former Director of the Central Intelligence Agency, wanted to say something ridiculous about a member of Congress, he succeeded. During an appearance on “Fox News Sunday,” where Republicans go to trash Democrats without fear of follow-up questions, he said that Senator Dianne Feinstein’s “deep emotional feeling” had tainted the Senate Intelligence Committee’s report on the C.I.A.’s abuse of prisoners after the 9/11 attacks.

headline: Maazel Withdraws From Two Carnegie Hall Concerts
abstract: Valery Gergiev and Fabio Luisi will conduct in place of Lorin Maazel, who withdrew from two concerts this weekend because of illness.
lead_paragraph: Lorin Maazel, who was to have led the Munich Philharmonic Orchestra on Friday and Saturday at Carnegie Hall, has withdrawn from the performances because of illness, the hall said. Valery Gergiev will conduct the Friday evening program, and Fabio Luisi will take over on Saturday. The programs Mr. Maazel, 84, was to conduct were both devoted fully to the works of Richard Strauss, and are unchanged.

headline: For Passover, Fried Artichokes
abstract: Crisp as a potato chip on the outside, but tender at the heart.
lead_paragraph: ROME — I have always loved artichokes fried in the Jewish style, or carciofi alla giudia, a traditional dish of the Roman Seder. So on a recent trip to Rome, I hunted for them. Every chef I queried had the same answer, delivered with the same slightly weary shrug: “You have to go to the ghetto for that.”

headline: Obama Signs Measures to Help Close Gender Gap in Pay
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: One measure, announced in a ceremony seemingly staged with an eye on the midterm elections, bars federal contractors from retaliating if employees discuss salaries.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Tuesday signed two executive measures intended to help close longstanding pay disparities between men and women as Democrats seek to capitalize on their gender-gap advantage at the ballot box in a midterm election year.

headline: Among Ukraine’s Jews, the Bigger Worry Is Putin, Not Pogroms
abstract: Despite assertions by Russia, many Ukrainian Jews say there has not been a resurgence of anti-Semitism since the revolution in February.
lead_paragraph: DNIPROPETROVSK, Ukraine — From his office atop the world’s biggest Jewish community center, Shmuel Kaminezki, the chief rabbi of this eastern Ukrainian city, has followed with dismay Russian claims that Ukraine is now in the hands of neo-Nazi extremists — and has struggled to calm his panicked 85-year-old mother in New York.

headline: Wheelies: The Car Tipping Edition
abstract: Hooligans tip Smart cars around San Francisco; some Toyota factories replace robots with people.

headline: Best, Brightest and Rejected: Elite Colleges Turn Away Up to 95%
abstract: Deluged by more applications than ever, the most selective colleges are rejecting legions of students they once would have accepted.
lead_paragraph: Enrollment at American colleges is sliding, but competition for spots at top universities is more cutthroat and anxiety-inducing than ever. In the just-completed admissions season, Stanford University accepted only 5 percent of applicants, a new low among the most prestigious schools, with the odds nearly as bad at its elite rivals.

headline: Imax Selling 20 Percent of Its China Business
abstract: After making an $80 million investment, China Media Capital and FountainVest Partners will help the unit, China Imax, complete a public offering.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — China Media Capital, a state-run entertainment investment fund that has already done business with Time Warner, DreamWorks Animation and 21st Century Fox, added Imax to its deal portfolio on Tuesday.

headline: The Stars Remain Aligned
abstract: Jean-Georges still shines among the striving competition.
lead_paragraph: Jean-Georges is still a four-star restaurant. That is all. Thank you for your time.

lead_paragraph: As investors nurse steep losses from  technology stocks, one hedge fund has decided to return money to investors and turn its focus to companies not listed on the stock market.

headline: A New Line | Talon’s Boho-Chic, West Coast-Inspired Jewelry Collection
abstract: Zosia Mamet is the face of a new range of jewelry from the Brooklyn brand known for its aromatic amulet necklaces.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn designer Emily Hirsch creates jewelry with a talismanic quality. She began her line Talon in 2009 with glass and metal amulet necklaces that contained vials of blended essential oils that reminded her of her California childhood. Now, she is expanding to a full range of pieces steeped in the feeling of 1970s West Coast Americana, including rings, earrings, cuff bracelets etched with detailed feather and flower motifs and a pendant necklace in opal, carnelian, onyx or Indian garnet, each stone set in recycled silver or gold.

headline: Inquiry Implicating Rowland, Ex-Connecticut Governor, Offers Look at a 2012 Race
abstract: The House campaign that led to a federal investigation that has put scrutiny on John G. Rowland included allegations of impropriety in both major parties.
lead_paragraph: Last week he was holding forth as usual on hot-button topics like Benghazi and big government, and bantering with on-air guests who addressed him by his former title, “Governor.”

headline: New Ferry Service Between Maine and Nova Scotia
abstract: The Nova Star, a cruise-ship-style ferry, will take passengers between Maine and Nova Scotia beginning May 15.
lead_paragraph: Beginning May 15, Nova Scotia-bound travelers have a new transit option from Maine: getting there by cruise-ship-style ferry.

headline: Three Legs Good, One Leg Bad
abstract: As we’ve been saying all along.
lead_paragraph: The good news for Obamacare just keeps coming in. Via Charles Gaba, the Rand Survey — which was the subject of a report in the LA Times, but which wasn’t publicly available — is now in. And it says that as of mid-March — that is, before the final enrollment surge — the Affordable Care Act had already produced a net gain of 9.3 million insured adults. Again, that’s a net gain; so much for claims that more people are losing insurance than gaining it.

lead_paragraph: With just one signature, it will be legal to openly carry firearms in Kansas, nullifying city and county gun regulations across the state.

abstract: The discreet doorway suggests a nightclub, but reveals a restaurant with an inventive American menu.

headline: Germany Moves Forward on Renewable Energy Plan
abstract: The government wants to slow the rapid expansion of solar and wind parks in an effort to hold down spiraling prices.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel’s government approved legislation on Tuesday revamping Germany’s sweeping plan to generate more than 40 percent of its energy needs through renewable resources by 2025 by slowing the rapid expansion of solar and wind parks in an effort to hold down spiraling prices.

headline: Man Wrongfully Convicted in 1989 Brooklyn Murder Is Set Free
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Jonathan Fleming, who was serving a sentence of 25 years to life, was released after new evidence, including a phone bill receipt, was uncovered in his case.
lead_paragraph: A timeworn phone bill from a Quality Inn in Orlando, Fla., turned out to be one of the most valuable pieces of paper Jonathan Fleming owns.

headline: Astier de Villatte’s Collaboration with a Countess
abstract: The French scents and accessories company joins forces with Setsuko Klossowska de Rola for a pair of ceramics collections.
lead_paragraph: Ivan Pericoli and Benoit Astier de Villatte of Astier de Villate, known for their scents and ceramic accessories, are presenting two new ceramics collections created in collaboration with the Countess Setsuko Klossowska de Rola, a painter and the widow of Balthus (and the subject of some of his most famous paintings). The first collection is inspired by the architecture of the Grand Châlet of Rossinière, the home Klossowska de Rola shared with Balthus beginning in the the ’70s and where she still lives today. The second includes playful ceramics modelled by the countess herself, including a candlestick tree and an incense burner in the form of a cat.

headline: Bomb on Train in Pakistan Kills 14
abstract: A rebel group claimed responsibility for a bomb blast aboard a train in Baluchistan Province, saying it was retaliation for a military operation.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A bomb ripped through a stationary train in western Pakistan on Tuesday, killing 14 passengers and wounding at least 40, half of them seriously, in a new escalation of the long-running conflict in Baluchistan Province.

headline: Trying to Make a Character Move as Easily as You Do
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Xbox One (Video Game System)']
abstract: Kinect Sports Rivals uses an upgraded sensor, bundled with Microsoft’s Xbox One console, to try to improve motion gaming.
lead_paragraph: Motion-controlled gaming has never worked as well as advertised.

headline: Family Disaster Preparedness
abstract: Any family who has weathered a severe storm knows it’s easier if you’re prepared. But I admit it—we’re not. No stockpile of water, no emergency plan. Are you?
lead_paragraph: Eighty percent of the population would not survive the first 100 days of the apocalypse, Bob Gaskin, who served in the Marines and is the founder of the Black Dog Survival School, told an assembled crowd at the Third Annual National Preppers and Surivalist Expo in Tulsa, Okla. “If you don’t know now what you’re going to do then,” he said, “you aren’t going to make it.”

headline: Captain and Design Faulted in East River Ferry Crash
abstract: The National Transportation Safety Board said the 2013 episode, which injured 80 people, occurred because the captain forgot he had switched control settings, which were unclear in the first place.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A ferry crash on the East River that injured 80 people last year was caused by captain’s error and a poor design on the ferry’s high-tech bridge, the National Transportation Safety Board said on Tuesday.

headline: Westerleigh, S.I., Built on Temperance
abstract: A two-square-mile neighborhood of Staten Island with origins in the temperance movement of the late 19th century.
lead_paragraph: Followers of the temperance movement late in the 19th century created a place called National Prohibition Park, where they could escape the stresses and bad influences of the city. The community, on Staten Island’s North Shore, is now known as Westerleigh.

headline: In San Francisco, Staying True to an Area’s Roots
abstract: The newly coined Mission Creek neighborhood, long home to manufacturing, is still a place where you can find products being made, from stationery to chocolate.
lead_paragraph: The newly coined Mission Creek neighborhood in San Francisco’s northeast Mission District has long been home to light industrial manufacturing. But lately Mission Creek has become a creative hub for local goods, and unlike in many fast-changing areas of the city, the new arrivals here have so far stayed true to the area’s roots: It’s a place where people make things.

headline: The Kentucky Derby as a ‘Rite of Passage’
abstract: Carl Myers, who owns a stake in a thoroughbred that competed in the Derby, talks about watching the race and visiting Kentucky horse country.
lead_paragraph: Native Dancer, the thoroughbred that won race after race in the 1950s, was unlike the stocky draft horses Carl Myers knew as a boy growing up in Amish country in Lancaster County, Pa. The colt was lean and elegant and, with its gray coat, stood out among the other thoroughbreds on his family’s black-and-white television set.

headline: Hotel Review: Hotel Santo Toribio in Cartagena, Colombia
abstract: Opened in November 2012, the three-story Santo Toribio offers boutique lodging inside the 16th-century walled part of the city.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: Restaurant Report: Burnt Ends in Singapore
abstract: This gourmet barbecue joint has been packed since it debuted last May.
lead_paragraph: New restaurants are a dime a dozen in Singapore, but novel concepts are still a rarity — which probably explains why Burnt Ends, a gourmet barbecue joint, has been packed since it debuted last May.

headline: Improving the User Experience of Automated Integration Testing
abstract: The New York Times Test Infrastructure Development team has been working on a reporting system with a new front end to present results for our functional test suites. We’ve decided to open source our projects as we continue to work on them.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Test Infrastructure Development team has been working on a reporting system with a new front end to present results for our functional test suites. We’ve decided to open source our projects as we continue to work on them.

headline: 30 Seconds With Jim Palmer
abstract: The Hall of Fame pitcher, now a television commentator for Orioles games, won 268 games in his 19-season major league career.
lead_paragraph: Jim Palmer, the Hall of Fame pitcher for the Baltimore Orioles, grew up a Yankees fan in New York. One of his fondest memories is of his father taking him to his first game at Yankee Stadium in 1954. The Indians were playing the Yankees. He was amazed at how the field glowed.

headline: Jeter’s No. 2 Is No. 1
abstract: At Monday’s home opener in the Bronx, Deter Jeter shirts were everywhere, welcoming back the Yankee captain as he begins his final season.
lead_paragraph: At Monday’s home opener in the Bronx, Deter Jeter shirts were everywhere, welcoming back the Yankee captain as he begins his final season.

headline: A Few Notes to Hear All
abstract: At the second concert of the Music for Contemplation series on Saturday in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, three musicians offered a 110-minute performance of “Peckinpah Trios.”
lead_paragraph: At the risk of hyperbole, it seemed likely that fewer notes were played during a 110-minute performance of “Peckinpah Trios,” a 2004 piece by the Dutch composer Antoine Beuger, on Saturday night, than might have been contained in a single ringtone on an audience member’s smartphone. No one present could make the comparison the hard way, thanks to the standard cautionary announcement.

headline: Those Fish Fins You Call Hands and Other Evolutionary Quirks
abstract: The paleontologist Neil Shubin hosts a three-part exploration of our evolutionary history in “Your Inner Fish,” which begins on Wednesday on PBS.
lead_paragraph: The club of scholars named Neil who are good writers and also telegenic is fairly small, with Neil deGrasse Tyson (see “Cosmos: A Spacetime Odyssey”) sometimes seeming to be its only member. But let’s not overlook Neil Shubin, a paleontologist who makes an appealing guide to our evolutionary history on “Your Inner Fish,” a three-part exploration, based on his books, that begins on Wednesday on PBS.

headline: Damien Hirst to Tell His Story
abstract: The British artist’s autobiography is to be published in fall 2015. He will write it with James Fox, who worked with Keith Richards on his memoir, “Life.”
lead_paragraph: The British artist Damien Hirst has signed a deal to publish his autobiography with Viking Penguin, the publisher announced on Tuesday. The autobiography, due out in Britain in fall 2015, will be written with James Fox, who worked with Keith Richards on his 2010 memoir, “Life.” The book is to be published in the United States by Penguin Press, also in fall 2015. (Viking Penguin and Penguin Press are imprints of Penguin Random House.)

headline: Oxygen Shifts Focus to Millennial Viewers
abstract: The channel announced plans to appeal more to a younger generation with series that reflect multiculturalism.
lead_paragraph: In another sign of the growing influence of the millennial generation on Madison Avenue, the Oxygen cable channel will be revamped to appeal to a modern young woman, offering several new series with a multicultural focus.

headline: Text to Text | Bangladesh Factory Safety and the Triangle Shirtwaist Fire
abstract: Can stronger laws and inspections make a difference in preventing disasters like the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire or the Rana Plaza factory collapse in Bangladesh? To answer this question, we selected two Times articles to compare.
lead_paragraph: Can disasters make life better for future generations?

headline: Scene City: A Spy Thriller in Heels
abstract: Vogue and Cinema Society host screening of BBC’s “Turks and Caicos.”
lead_paragraph: Vogue and Cinema Society host screening of BBC’s “Turks and Caicos.”

headline: How to Make Great Pizza Dough
abstract: Anthony Falco of Roberta’s in Bushwick, Brooklyn, shows Sam Sifton how to make restaurant-style pizza dough at home.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Falco of Roberta’s in Bushwick, Brooklyn, shows Sam Sifton how to make restaurant-style pizza dough at home.

headline: After ’09 Fraud, Afghanistan Reports a Cleaner Election
abstract: Citing international and Afghan election observers, the nation’s complaints commission said this weekend’s vote was much cleaner than the one in 2009.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan presidential election on Saturday appeared to be substantially cleaner than the widely discredited 2009 election, according to complaint figures released Tuesday by the authorities here.

headline: Underwater Search
abstract: Officials designated an underwater search area around the two locations where they have estimated the missing plane may have entered the water.
lead_paragraph: Officials designated an underwater search area around the two locations where they have estimated the missing plane may have entered the water.

headline: A Little Pizza Homework
abstract: People don’t often make dough from scratch. This should change that.
lead_paragraph: There is pizza dough in my refrigerator right now. I made it last night in about 20 minutes, 15 of which were spent reading a magazine while it rested. I’ll bake it tomorrow night under mozzarella, then put a small arugula salad on top, an homage to the Green and White pizza available at Roberta’s in Brooklyn.

headline: Obama Pushes Equal Pay for Women
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Lilly M. Ledbetter, left, watched as President Obama signed two executive measures aimed at increasing transparency about women’s pay.
lead_paragraph: Lilly M. Ledbetter, left, watched as President Obama signed two executive measures aimed at increasing transparency about women’s pay.

headline: Unearthing Lost Gems in Career of Lyricist
abstract: “Unsung Carolyn Leigh” features, among other works, songs written for an unproduced “Gatsby” musical from 1969.
lead_paragraph: A fantasy that tantalizes many music theater aficionados is the dream of unearthing a lost masterpiece from the trove of shows that flopped on Broadway or were never produced. Tastes change, after all, and work considered too avant-garde back in the day may suddenly be rediscovered and retrospectively deemed “ahead of its time.”

headline: T’s Toast to Salone
abstract: Our editor in chief, Deborah Needleman, and the Italian art curator Francesco Bonami hosted a range of design and fashion luminaries last night in Milan and introduced T’s spring design issue.
lead_paragraph: To kick off Salone Internazionale del Mobile and celebrate T’s spring design issue, which is out this weekend, some of the world’s best-known architects and designers gathered at the Villa Necchi Campiglio last night in Milan. Video art by Derrick Adams set the scene for the fete, where T’s editor in chief, Deborah Needleman, and the Italian art curator Francesco Bonami hosted a range of design and fashion luminaries: Tom Dixon, Francesco Vezzoli, Daniel Libeskind, Ambra Medda, Joseph Dirand, Laura Sartori Rimini, T’s Tom Delavan and the house of Missoni’s leading ladies, from Rosita and Margherita to Angela and Teresa.

headline: You Can’t Always Get What You Want
abstract: Numbers suggest that the difference between need-blind and need-aware admissions is fuzzy.
lead_paragraph: Numbers suggest that the difference between need-blind and need-aware admissions is fuzzy.

headline: Weakness in Infield Leaves Yankees Vulnerable
abstract: Starter Ivan Nova struggled, but an infield made up of aging veterans and inexperienced fill-ins provided little support for him.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees’ infield will undergo a drastic makeover after shortstop Derek Jeter retires at the end of the season. But even now, the four players who take the infield these days for the Yankees are hardly recognizable.

headline: Experts Find a Door Ajar in an Internet Security Method Thought Safe
abstract: The tiny padlock next to web addresses that promised to protect sensitive information is broken, a team of security researchers has discovered. Experts are examining how best to secure their users’ confidential data.
lead_paragraph: Updated | A flaw has been discovered in one of the Internet’s key security methods, potentially forcing a wide swath of websites to make changes to protect the security of consumers.

headline: Iran’s Choice of Envoy ‘Not Viable,’ U.S. Says
abstract: The Obama administration toughened its objection to Iran’s choice as its United Nations ambassador because of his role in the 1979-81 hostage crisis.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration intensified its objections on Tuesday to Iran’s nomination for United Nations ambassador, a former translator whose role in the 1979-81 Tehran hostage crisis has touched American political nerves, asserting that the choice was “not viable” in what seemed as close as possible to ruling it out.

headline: An Editorial Cartoon on Native American Mascots Comes to Life in Cleveland
abstract: A news photograph taken last week looks remarkably like an editorial cartoon drawn 12 years ago imagining just such an encounter between an offended Native American protester and a sports fan who claimed that his outfit was a way of honoring indigenous people.
lead_paragraph: Last week, a die-hard fan of the Cleveland Indians named Pedro Rodriguez expressed his love for the baseball club as he has each year for the past decade, by attending the first game of the new season dressed in homage to Chief Wahoo, the club’s Native American mascot, in a feathered headdress with his skin painted bright red.

headline: If the Devil Taps You, Pretend You Didn’t Feel It
abstract: The Yale in New York series presented “The Soldier’s Tale” at Zankel Hall, with every production team member and performer affiliated with the university.
lead_paragraph: When Stravinsky wrote “The Soldier’s Tale,” his 1918 dramatic work that combines spoken text with a seven-piece chamber ensemble, he had in mind the touring puppet shows and playing troupes he encountered in the Russia of his youth. Over the years, when “The Soldier’s Tale” has been presented as a staged drama or a ballet, it has often been updated or mythologized. It is probably best known as a concert work, without its spoken text.

headline: The Lives of Animals, Disabled and Otherwise
abstract: Three television programs this week about animals go beyond how cute they are to consider their disabilities, their intelligence and their interactions with humans.
lead_paragraph: Fans of the PBS series “Nature” are used to having their breath taken away by the photography, but they’re less accustomed to having their heartstrings tugged. Wednesday’s installment, “My Bionic Pet,” about animals with disabilities, goes for the emotions. It’s one of three programs this week that prove that television about nonhuman creatures can be more than mere pretty pictures or idiotic turtle wrangling.

headline: Youth Movements, Glittering if Not Yet Totally Polished
abstract: Ailey II, the junior ensemble of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, presented programs celebrating the company’s 40th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: Seeing back-to-back programs of the same company can reveal a lot about its dancers. Do they become more or less complex, the more you get to know them? Do you want to keep spending time with these people, or have you had enough?

headline: Embracing Ambiguity in Israel
abstract: Frederic Brenner looks at his complex identity through the lens of Israel’s ambiguities and contrasts.
lead_paragraph: Frederic Brenner looks at his complex identity through the lens of Israel’s ambiguities and contrasts.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 65
abstract: On Tuesday, FIFA unveiled the tracklist for “One Love, One Rhythm: The Official 2014 FIFA World Cup Album.”
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

keywords: ['Deferred Prosecution Agreements', 'Freedom of Information Act', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Students at the University of Virginia Law School have challenged the Justice Department to unseal settlements with big banks and corporations.
lead_paragraph: Some law school students send the Justice Department résumés and references. At the University of Virginia School of Law, one class is sending document requests and lawsuits.

abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Romania, Central Africa Republic and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Romania, Central Africa Republic and India.

headline: TripAdvisor Expands Environmental Rating Program
abstract: TripAdvisor has expanded its GreenLeaders program, which evaluates ecological and environmental friendliness, to include international properties.
lead_paragraph: International travelers looking for a certain amount of “green” in their accommodations can now turn to TripAdvisor for help.

headline: Target to Stock More Environmentally Friendly Products
keywords: ['Sustainable Living', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Organic Foods and Products']
abstract: According to the Organic Trade Association, the industry grew to $31.5 billion in sales in the United States in 2012 from $8.4 billion a decade earlier.
lead_paragraph: When Eric Ryan helped start Method Products in 2001, the market for environmentally friendly soaps and cleaning products, he recalled, was a “niche of a niche of a niche.”

headline: For Injured Bolshoi Director, a Time to Judge
abstract: Sergei Filin, the artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet who was wounded in an acid attack last year, talked about his recovery and his goals.
lead_paragraph: Sergei Filin, the artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet who was partly blinded last year in a brutal acid attack that stunned the dance world, paused for some eye drops then put on his brown-tinted wraparound sunglasses before making his way to the theater.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the day’s biggest stories.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: ARTnews Sold to Private Company
abstract: ARTnews, which had been owned by Milton and Judith Esterow since 1972, describes itself as the world’s oldest and most widely circulated art magazine.
lead_paragraph: Talked-about sales in the art world usually involve a painting or sculpture. On Tuesday, the big item in the shopping basket was ARTnews, which describes itself as the world’s oldest and most widely circulated art magazine. Milton Esterow and Judith Esterow, the owners of the magazine since 1972, said in a statement that they sold the 112-year-old publication to Skate Capital, a private asset management firm owned by a Russian, Sergey Skaterschikov.

headline: Kerry and McCain on Foreign Policy
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry and Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, exchanged harsh words over the Ukraine crisis and foreign policy on Russia at a Senate hearing.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry and Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, exchanged harsh words over the Ukraine crisis and foreign policy on Russia at a Senate hearing.

headline: The Art of Collaboration, in Action
abstract: The Lysander Piano Trio, which performed last week at Weill Recital Hall, is one of the few new distinguished groups of its kind in a field where string quartets flourish.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Concrete Sculpture at the SP-Arte fair in São Paulo
abstract: A number of hometown galleries trotted out work that reveled in its raw minimalism.
lead_paragraph: Last week, São Paulo played host to the 10th annual SP-Arte fair, held in the gargantuan Ciccillo Matarazzo pavilion in Ibirapuera Park, a sinuous structure of concrete, steel and glass designed by Oscar Niemeyer for the 1957 São Paulo Biennial. Perhaps the setting explains the preponderance of minimalist concrete sculpture trotted out by several hometown galleries at this year’s event, which closed on Sunday. At Galeria Jaqueline Martins, São Paulo-based Ana Mazzei’s “Et Nous, Nous Marchons Inconnus” (which translates to “And We, We Walk Unknown”) was a procession of gray geometric forms marching from wall to floor. David Batchelor, a Scotsman, placed a number of cement bricks on plinths at the booth of Galeria Leme, adorning them with shards of broken, colored glass. Meanwhile, at the upstart gallery Emma Thomas, a buffet of drinking glasses (water, Margarita, shot, Champagne) were spread across a table and filled to the brim with cement by the local artist Lucas Simões. Called “Bebado Samba” (or “Drunken Samba”), it’s a punning rejoinder to Brazil’s midcentury “Concrete” and “Neo-Concrete” art movements, which spiraled off into a plurality of aesthetics and “a scene impossible to read as a single movement,” according to the artist. “ The final view can be seen as a party where the drunken conversations happen.”

headline: Weather Channel Returns to DirecTV
abstract: As part of a deal to end a three-month dispute, the cable network agreed to reduce reality programming, while it received a small price increase.
lead_paragraph: The Weather Channel will return to DirecTV Wednesday after a nasty three-month dispute, with the cable network getting a small price increase but agreeing to substantial concessions, including an alteration of its daily national programming schedule to accommodate the demands of the satellite service.

headline: Legacy Evolving at a Presidential Library
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Nineteen Hundred Sixties', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: With a new stress on achievements in civil rights and the legislative foundations of the Great Society, the LBJ Presidential Library is promoting a new assessment of President Johnson.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — There are few conferences that could have lured President Obama and three former presidents — Jimmy Carter, Bill Clinton and George W. Bush — as the Civil Rights Summit is doing this week at the LBJ Presidential Library here. This three-day gathering to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Civil Rights Act, which began on Tuesday, includes Mr. Obama as the keynote speaker on Thursday morning, with the former presidents speaking successively each night. Mr. Carter was to speak Tuesday night; Mr. Bush will conclude the summit on Thursday.

headline: McClatchy to Sell Anchorage Daily News to Alaska Dispatch Publishing
abstract: The $34 million deal for the state’s largest newspaper is expected to close in May.
lead_paragraph: Business moguls continue to shake up the world of newspapers, this time to the far north.

headline: Investors’ Appetite for I.P.O.’s Seems to Ebb
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Private Equity', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Even as soaring stocks have fueled a surge in initial public offerings, there are signs that Wall Street is beginning to sour on fresh arrivals.
lead_paragraph: Companies are rushing to the public markets on Wall Street to sell their shares, and this week is expected to be the busiest for initial public offerings in more than seven years.

headline: Over 50 and Underappreciated
abstract: A new flood of beauty advice for women of a certain age.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, the cosmetics industry veteran Andrea Robinson was in her Park Avenue apartment, showing off a newly built home office with white walls and a monochrome animal print rug. The sparse aesthetic contrasted with the lush textiles of the living room, where a fire was roaring.

headline: In Women’s Game, It’s Not Just Basketball, It’s Family
abstract: With a majority of the sport’s student-athletes leaving campus with a degree, teams and rivalries cultivate relationships that are often lost in the one-and-done world of the men’s game.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Until Connecticut left no doubt in its superiority in an unprecedented championship showdown of unbeaten teams with Notre Dame on Tuesday night, the N.C.A.A. women’s tournament was almost a rumor compared with its all-consuming men’s counterpart.

headline: Official’s Remarks Attacking S.E.C.’s Timidness Cause Stir
abstract: James Kidney, a trial lawyer at the Securities and Exchange Commission, pointedly criticized colleagues for being “tentative and fearful.” His frank remarks, made during his retirement speech, are drawing attention.
lead_paragraph: A textbook retirement speech blends beloved anecdotes with tired clichés. James Kidney, a trial lawyer at the Securities and Exchange Commission who recently departed the agency, offered a different style: an airing of grievances.

headline: Powerful, Disruptive Shareholders
keywords: ['Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Corporations', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Chief executives are remaining silent but running scared.
lead_paragraph: THE season is starting for annual meetings, when shareholders have the chance to attend gatherings of companies in which they own stock to tell chief executives what’s on their mind.

headline: HBO Signs ‘Game of Thrones’ to Two More Seasons
abstract: The epic fantasy had its highest ratings on Sunday night for its season premiere. The network’s announcement carries the series through six seasons.
lead_paragraph: A day after receiving news that “Game of Thrones” had shattered its previous ratings records, HBO announced that it had ordered two more seasons of the program, a fantasy drama.

headline: Global Warming Scare Tactics
abstract: There is evidence that efforts to raise public concern about climate change by linking it to present-day natural disasters will backfire.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — IF you were looking for ways to increase public skepticism about global warming, you could hardly do better than the forthcoming nine-part series on climate change and natural disasters, starting this Sunday on Showtime. A trailer for “Years of Living Dangerously” is terrifying, replete with images of melting glaciers, raging wildfires and rampaging floods. “I don’t think scary is the right word,” intones one voice. “Dangerous, definitely.”

headline: Magazines Coordinate Their Content in Version of TV’s Crossover Episodes
abstract: HGTV Magazine and Food Network Magazine have teamed up for a party issue and to promote Pure Leaf Tea.
lead_paragraph: Crossover episodes of television series are a popular method to stimulate ratings, as viewers are encouraged to watch cast members from one show turn up on another. Crossovers date to the early days of the medium and there was one as recently as March 26, when cast members from two TV Land series, “Hot in Cleveland” and “The Soul Man,” exchanged appearances on each other’s programs.

abstract: Seventeen students were admitted after participating in an experiment that invited prospective freshmen to compose essays on scholarly topics instead of submitting traditional applications.
lead_paragraph: Helen Chen, a senior at a small public high school in San Francisco, is the kind of student who tries teachers’ patience.

headline: European Court Rejects Data Retention Rules, Citing Privacy
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Elections', 'E-Mail', 'Terrorism', 'Telephones and Telecommunications']
abstract: The ruling strikes down a law, enacted after 2006 terrorist attacks in London and Madrid, that required telecommunications companies to keep information about calls and emails.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — A top court on Tuesday struck down a European Union law, adopted in response to deadly terrorist attacks, that required telecommunications companies to retain information about calls and emails for up to two years.

headline: A Cappuccino for Public Safety
abstract: Infrastructure problems can lead to catastrophes, yet the cost of preventing them would amount to only a few dollars a day.
lead_paragraph: In New York, many things are referred to as jokes. The Van Wyck “Expressway,” for example, a coarsely paved road that has been under repair for as long as anyone can remember, is a joke. Compared with those of other world capitals, our mass transit system is a joke. And every now and then we’re reminded that underground is a bewildering mess of pipes, wires and fibers, the stuff that keeps the whole semi-anarchic mess running. That’s a joke, too, one that The Times called “a glaring example of America’s crumbling infrastructure.”

headline: Search for Malaysian Jet to Be Costliest in History
abstract: Many of the governments involved will face a difficult decision about whether to keep bearing the extraordinary expense.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — As the intensive hunt for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 entered its second month on Tuesday, the only certainty was that it would become the most expensive search and recovery effort in aviation history, with an international fleet of ships and planes scouring the Indian Ocean at a cost of millions of dollars a day.

headline: At Fort Hood, Wrestling With Label of Terrorism
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Fort Hood Shooting (2014)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Army officials have never called the first Fort Hood mass shooting, in November 2009, an act of terrorism.
lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex. — In the hours and days after a deadly shooting at Fort Hood last week, Army officials have not shied away from talking about terrorism — to contrast it with the 2009 attack and to ease fears about the motive behind the second mass shooting on the base in nearly five years.

headline: Playing Hockey With Putin
abstract: Is the West serious or not about facing off against Russia?
lead_paragraph: Shortly before the Sochi Olympics, Russian President Vladimir Putin played in an exhibition hockey game there. In retrospect, he was clearly warming up for his takeover of Crimea. Putin doesn’t strike me as a chess player, in geopolitical terms. He prefers hockey, without a referee, so elbowing, tripping and cross-checking are all permitted. Never go to a hockey game with Putin and expect to play by the rules of touch football. The struggle over Ukraine is a hockey game, with no referee. If we’re going to play — we, the Europeans and the pro-Western Ukrainians need to be serious. If we’re not, we need to tell the Ukrainians now: Cut the best deal with Putin that you can.

headline: Details of Sharpton’s Time as Informer Shed Light on a Life With Many Chapters
abstract: In the 30 years since his involvement with the F.B.I., the Rev. Al Sharpton has gone from being a belligerent street activist to being a cable-channel host and sometime political candidate.
lead_paragraph: It was the early 1980s, and the Rev. Al Sharpton was seeking a foothold in the music business. He called news conferences and said he would schedule demonstrations and boycotts if black promoters were not given a role in Michael Jackson’s “Thriller” tour.

headline: U.S. Fines General Motors $28,000 for Not Cooperating With Ignition Flaw Inquiry
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The automaker missed an April 3 deadline to answer questions from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration about why it did not recall cars until years after learning of safety problems.
lead_paragraph: Federal safety regulators fined General Motors $28,000 on Tuesday, saying it had not provided much of the information requested for an investigation into a recall of about 2.6 million cars with an ignition switch defect that G.M. has linked to 13 deaths.

headline: Keeping Track: Unemployment Insurance and a Financial Tax
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Editorials']
abstract: Updates on the issues we’re following.
lead_paragraph: Jobless Benefits, Withheld

headline: In Montana, Cutthroat Trout Are Hungry Trout
abstract: In Montana, the eagerness of westslope cutthroat trout, or cutts, to take a host of dry flies has earned them a soft spot in many anglers’ hearts.
lead_paragraph: WEST GLACIER, Mont. — When “A River Runs Through It” was released 21 years ago, moviegoers who had never seen a fly rod descended upon tackle shops. Once outfitted, they made a beeline to Montana for a chance to cast to oversize brown and rainbows like those Brad Pitt seemed to land on every other cast. Those anglers probably did not realize that like themselves, the browns and rainbows were relatively recent arrivals, shouldering into the historical domain of Montana’s state fish.

headline: Closing Ports to Stolen Fish
abstract: Congress should take the lead on enforcing a treaty adopted by the United Nations that cracks down on illegal fishing.
lead_paragraph: The oceans are vast and humans are small — as the monthlong hunt for a vanished Malaysian jetliner demonstrates. Think of the challenge, then, for law enforcement and fisheries managers in going after fleets of shady boats that engage in illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. These criminals ply the seas and sell their catches with impunity, making off with an estimated 11 million to 26 million metric tons of stolen fish each year, a worldwide haul worth about $10 billion to $23.5 billion. Many use banned gear like floating gillnets, miles long, that indiscriminately slaughter countless unwanted fish along with seabirds, marine mammals, turtles and other creatures.

headline: Illinois Moves to Ease Chicago Pension Woes
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'State Legislatures', 'Bankruptcies', 'Property Taxes', 'Government Employees']
abstract: The state legislature approved a plan put forth by Mayor Rahm Emanuel that would presumably include a property tax increase for Chicago residents.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The Illinois legislature on Tuesday approved a plan to start easing Chicago’s crippling pension problems by requiring some city workers to pay more for their retirement benefits and by granting smaller increases in those benefits.

headline: Gov. Cuomo Drops the Ball
abstract: The governor of New York seemed to be caught off-guard when Republican legislators in Albany killed a plan to provide public financing for college courses in state prisons.
lead_paragraph: Less than two months ago, Gov. Andrew Cuomo announced a plan to provide public financing for basic college-education programs in state prisons — a tried and true way to reduce recidivism at a fraction of the cost of keeping people behind bars.

headline: Number of Mothers in U.S. Who Stay at Home Rises
abstract: A study released by the Pew Research Center found that the number rose since 2000 after decades of decline, likely driven in part by economic factors and changing demographics.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Likely driven in part by economic factors and changing demographics, the number of stay-at-home mothers in the United States has risen since 2000 after decades of decline, a report released Tuesday by the Pew Research Center shows.

headline: After Rwanda’s Genocide
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'International Relations', 'Editorials']
abstract: Addressing the poisonous legacies of the 100-day massacre is the only way to avert future tragedy, and it is the best way to honor the 800,000 victims.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Rwanda commemorated the victims of a genocide unleashed 20 years ago by Hutu extremists in power then. More than 800,000 people, mostly Tutsi men, women and children, were systematically hunted down and brutally murdered over a period of just 100 days. The world stood by and let the blood bath happen.

keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Women and Girls', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Discrimination']

abstract: Thieves who target burls, protrusions on trees that are valued for their intricately patterned wood, are driven by a sluggish economy and costly methamphetamine habits, officials said.

There, a rare old-growth coast redwood had been brutally hacked about 15 times by poachers, a chain saw massacre that had exposed the tree’s deep red heartwood.

lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Ten years ago, no one knew or cared how high Phil Mickelson could jump. Back then, Mickelson was considered the world’s best known golfer without a major championship. How he would react to his first major victory mattered not at all because it might never happen.

Kagin, the son of one minister and father of another, who saw religiosity creeping into the public domain and fought against it in a dual role as head lawyer and jester-provocateur for one of the country’s most militant atheist organizations, died on March 28 at his home in Union, Ky. He was 73.

lead_paragraph: Talking toys have been around since Edison made a doll that recited nursery rhymes by means of a small hand-cranked phonograph. Now there are dolls that reply emotively to a child, by name.

lead_paragraph: A fight over an arts funding grant causes a kerfuffle the size of Kansas in “The Most Deserving,” a frisky but inconsequential new comedy by Catherine Trieschmann that opened at City Center on Tuesday night under the auspices of the Women’s Project Theater. Kansas is actually where the big set-to takes place, when a meeting of a county arts council turns testy, resulting in a series of events that leaves just about everyone’s feathers permanently ruffled.

headline: Red Herrings and Overlooked Clues in Plane Search
abstract: Missteps, false leads and bureaucratic delays have thwarted the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.
lead_paragraph: More than a month after the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, searchers pledged to scour the ocean for the plane’s black boxes. But as the batteries powering the data and voice recorders’ sonic beacons fade, so do the chances that the airliner’s wreckage and the 239 bodies of the passengers and crew on board will be found. Several missteps, red herrings and bureaucratic delays have thwarted the search.

headline: Updated Q. and A. on Malaysia Airlines Flight 370
abstract: Tracing the mysterious pings, and other points of interest.
lead_paragraph: The disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 has led to a multinational air and sea search across a vast area of the Indian Ocean. Recently, after weeks of debris sightings that turned out to be irrelevant, sounds have been heard that may be coming from the missing plane, but thus far there has been no confirmation. As the search narrows and the international inquiries into the disappearance continue, Matthew L. Wald, a correspondent for The New York Times, answers some basic questions.

headline: The Birth of the 13th Amendment
abstract: The strange story behind the struggle to put abolition in the Constitution.
lead_paragraph: The climax of Steven Spielberg’s film “Lincoln” — the passage of the 13th Amendment in the House of Representatives — vividly captures the culmination of a dramatic yearlong legislative battle that mixed skillful behind-the-scenes maneuverings with high-minded constitutional debate, internecine party politics, personal animosities and the polarizing dynamics of a presidential election. Approval in the House on Jan. 31, 1865, trailed the amendment’s passage in the Senate on April 8, 1864, by almost 10 months. Its adoption by 27 states the following December introduced the word “slavery” into the Constitution for the first time.

headline: Drexel Works to Build Up Philadelphia
abstract: The university has plans for technology, academic and retail space on campus and in the surrounding area, and it is considering development of a rail yard near 30th Street Station.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The northward view from John F. Kennedy Boulevard near 30th Street Station here features only a parking lot bordered by a sagging chain-link fence and overshadowed by the rusting trestles of an elevated freight railroad.

headline: Secret Service Employees Reassigned
abstract: The Secret Service has reassigned several employees in the wake of alcohol-related misbehavior in the Netherlands before President Obama arrived there for meetings last month.
lead_paragraph: The Secret Service has reassigned several employees in the wake of alcohol-related misbehavior in the Netherlands before President Obama arrived there for meetings last month, an agency spokesman said Tuesday. The spokesman, Ed Donovan, said the reassigned employees were part of the Special Operations Division, which provides emergency response should the president be attacked while traveling. The reassignments were first reported by The Washington Post. Mr. Donovan added, “Policies that would affect the entire work force are currently under review by leadership.” Three agents were sent home from the Netherlands for “disciplinary reasons” in connection with their drinking. One was found passed out in a hallway.

Roberts Jr. to claim on April 2 that “ingratiation and access . . . are not corruption.”

lead_paragraph: LONDON — He returned to Chelsea from Real Madrid last summer declaring himself to be no longer the Special One he had declared himself to be on arrival for his first spell as Chelsea’s manager in 2004.

headline: Muslim Shrine Stands as a Crossroads in Syria’s Unrest

lead_paragraph: SAYEDA ZEINAB, Syria — This cinder-block town near Damascus, once a hub of prayer and commerce open to the world, seems like a tightly guarded military zone.

headline: Government’s Abuses ‘Far Outweigh’ Syrian Rebels’, Rights Chief Says
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The comments by the United Nations human rights chief promoted the Syrian envoy to refer to her actions as “lunatic.”
lead_paragraph: The United Nations human rights chief said Tuesday that abuses by the Syrian government “far outweigh” the atrocities committed by opposition forces, prompting the Syrian envoy to refer to her actions as “lunatic.” The comments of the high commissioner for human rights, Navi Pillay, were likely to fortify French efforts to push the Security Council to refer Syria to the International Criminal Court. Her office, as well as a commission of inquiry, have repeatedly cited rights violations on both sides. “But you cannot compare the two,” she said. “Clearly the actions of the forces of the government far outweigh. The violations, killings, cruelty, persons in detention, disappearances far outweigh, so you cannot compare the situation. It’s the government that’s mostly responsible for the violations.” The Syrian envoy, Bashar al-Jaafari, denounced Ms. Pillay for bias and said she was “acting irresponsibly.”

headline: Russia: Court Upholds Registration Law
abstract: The Constitutional Court said Tuesday that it had upheld a law requiring nongovernmental organizations that engage in political activity and receive funds from abroad to register as foreign agents.
lead_paragraph: The Constitutional Court said Tuesday that it had upheld a law requiring nongovernmental organizations that engage in political activity and receive funds from abroad to register as foreign agents. In a decision on Sunday, the court reduced fines associated with the law. Critics of the law, which was passed in 2012 with support from President Vladimir V. Putin, have said it was being used to clamp down on civil society groups, like the election-monitoring organization Golos, that had been critical of the Kremlin. Thousands of organizations have been investigated under the law since its introduction and four have been fined, Russia’s prosecutor general said last year.

headline: Britain: A Moment of Contrition Compounds Problems for a Minister
abstract: Ordered to repay about $9,600, Culture Secretary Maria Miller had a moment of contrition last week in Parliament, where she made a formal apology after over-claiming her expenses.
lead_paragraph: Ordered to repay about $9,600, Culture Secretary Maria Miller had a moment of contrition last week in Parliament, where she made a formal apology after over-claiming her expenses. That it was just a moment — she spoke for 32 seconds — has prompted an avalanche of criticism and a mini-crisis for Prime Minister David Cameron. Five days later, Ms. Miller’s expenses still dominated British newspaper headlines on Tuesday while organizers of an online petition, calling on her to repay more money or quit.

headline: China: Suicide Victim Linked to Official
abstract: A senior police official linked to the disgraced Communist Party official Bo Xilai hanged himself in a hotel room last week, the state news media reported Monday.
lead_paragraph: A senior police official linked to the disgraced Communist Party official Bo Xilai hanged himself in a hotel room last week, the state news media reported Monday. The police official, Zhou Yu, whose body was discovered Friday, played a prominent role in the “strike black” campaign under Mr. Bo, the former Chongqing party chief. The campaign was portrayed as a crackdown on organized crime but also targeted lawyers and businesspeople considered to be enemies of Mr. Bo or his allies. Mr. Bo was removed from his post in 2012, convicted on corruption charges and sentenced to life in prison. It is unclear if Mr. Zhou’s suicide was related. The microblog of a district department in the Chongqing police force said Mr. Zhou had diabetes and had recently received a diagnosis of severe liver disease that led to depression.

headline: N.C.A.A. Women’s Title Game
abstract: Connecticut defeated Notre Dame in the first meeting of unbeatens in the women’s championship.
lead_paragraph: Connecticut defeated Notre Dame in the first meeting of unbeatens in the women’s championship.

headline: Venezuela: President and Leaders of the Opposition Agree to Hold Talks
abstract: President Nicolás Maduro and the leaders of a coalition of opposition political parties agreed on Tuesday to take part in talks that could help defuse tensions that have arisen during two months of anti-government protests.
lead_paragraph: President Nicolás Maduro and the leaders of a coalition of opposition political parties agreed on Tuesday to take part in talks that could help defuse tensions that have arisen during two months of anti-government protests. The agreement was brokered by a group of South American foreign ministers meeting in Caracas, Venezuela’s capital, and the talks will be carried out with the participation of the foreign ministers of Brazil, Colombia and Ecuador, along with a representative of the Vatican. It was not clear when the talks would begin, but an opposition leader said the first meeting would occur in public. Venezuela is marked by a bitter political division, and the agreement to talk is a promising shift, although there appears to be little willingness on either side to give ground.

headline: Cuba Project Defended at Senate Hearing
abstract: The administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, Dr. Rajiv Shah, defended his agency’s social media project in Cuba to Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont.
lead_paragraph: The administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, Dr. Rajiv Shah, defended his agency’s social media project in Cuba to Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont.

headline: At the Milan Furniture Fair, Two British Designers Reinvent Passé Materials
abstract: In a shared space, Max Lamb is showing his unique take on the speckled composite material known as terrazzo, alongside a furniture collection made of fiberglass from Faye Toogood.
lead_paragraph: At the Salone del Mobile in Milan this week, two of London’s biggest design talents have shacked up with each other to offer side-by-side takes on semi-outdated materials. Occupying one half of the gallery Project B, the furniture designer Max Lamb has lined an entire room — furniture included — in his new twist on terrazzo, the speckled composite material which will remind many Americans of airport flooring, but which for Lamb served as a reference to classic Italian vestibules. While the pattern is currently trending in design and fashion (see Carven’s recent terrazzo-print sweatshirts), Lamb says he’s been experimenting with it since 2011, after his frequent work with stone led him to visit an old-school terrazzo maker in Yorkshire, near where he grew up. He then “went a completely different route,” he says. His version — the first product in a new line of designer architectural surfaces called Dzek, launched by the former Phillips de Pury retail director Brent Dzekciorius — embeds chunks of marble in resin instead of cement, making the material much more durable. And unlike the terrazzo of yore, which was usually poured on-site, it’s pre-cast and sold by the square foot. “It has endless applications,” he says. “It can be used on walls, floors, ceilings. You can even C.N.C.-mill a bathtub out of it.”

headline: As Braves Honor Hank Aaron, Mets Rain on the Parade

He always seems at ease, which makes it appear all the more remarkable when he controls and suppresses an offense the way he did the Atlanta Braves on Tuesday night.

headline: Are You Programmed to Enjoy Exercise?
abstract: According to an eye-opening new genetics study of lab rats, the motivation to exercise — or not — may be at least partly inherited.
lead_paragraph: It’s possible that some of us are born not to run. According to an eye-opening new genetics study of lab rats, published in The Journal of Physiology, the motivation to exercise — or not — may be at least partly inherited.

headline: Study Finds Sicklier Enrollees in Earliest Stage of Health Law
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The review suggests that the first to sign up through the new insurance marketplaces were more likely to face serious health problems than those who get coverage through their employer.
lead_paragraph: People who signed up early for insurance through the new marketplaces were more likely to be prescribed drugs to treat pain, depression and H.I.V. and were less likely to need contraceptives, according to a new study that provides a much-anticipated look at the population that signed up for coverage under the new health care law.

headline: India Election Digest: April 9

lead_paragraph: What you need to know about India’s elections on Wednesday: Parts of Arunachal Pradesh, Manipur, Meghalaya and Nagaland go to the polls, while the vote in a fifth northeastern state, Mizoram, was postponed to Friday.
