headline: Sliver of Medicare Doctors Get Big Share of Payouts
abstract: Some doctors who take Medicare received millions of dollars each in a single year, according to newly released data that provides an unprecedented look at the practice of medicine in the United States.
lead_paragraph: A tiny fraction of the 880,000 doctors and other health care providers who take Medicare accounted for nearly a quarter of the roughly $77 billion paid out to them under the federal program, receiving millions of dollars each in some cases in a single year, according to the most detailed data ever released in Medicare’s nearly 50-year history.

headline: Nets Sweep Heat as Plumlee Blocks James’s Dunk in Final Seconds
abstract: Mason Plumlee’s block put an exclamation point on the Nets’ win, which gave them a 4-0 record against the Heat this season.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The laughter and exaggerated shouting began, as if on cue, as soon as reporters encircled the rookie Mason Plumlee inside the visitors’ locker room at American Airlines Arena late Tuesday.

headline: Month Later, Trade Pays Off for the Rangers
abstract: Martin St. Louis, the reigning N.H.L. scoring champion, recorded three assists as the Rangers defeated Carolina at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: The combination the Rangers were awaiting for more than a month finally clicked Tuesday. Martin St. Louis assisted on both of Brad Richards’s power-play goals and, for good measure, set up Derek Stepan for an even-strength goal, as the Rangers beat the Carolina Hurricanes, 4-1, at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Gen. Carl E. Mundy Jr., Outspoken Marine Corps Leader, Dies at 78
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: General Mundy opposed allowing openly gay people to serve in the armed forces and helped shape the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy.
lead_paragraph: Gen. Carl E. Mundy Jr., who as commandant of the Marine Corps was an outspoken opponent of allowing people who are openly gay to serve in the armed forces and joined other military leaders in shaping the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy as a compromise, died on April 2 at his home in Alexandria, Va. He was 78.

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on April 9, 2014.

headline: How Much Medicare Pays For Your Doctor’s Care
abstract: Use the form below to find a doctor or other medical professional among the more than 800,000 health care providers that received payments in 2012 from Medicare Part B, which covers doctor visits, tests and other treatments. Payments may also cover overhead, such as staff salaries and drug costs. In some cases, when doctors work as salaried employees of group practices, the payments that show up under their names go to their institutions.
lead_paragraph: Use the form below to find a doctor or other medical professional among the more than 800,000 health care providers that received payments in 2012 from Medicare Part B, which covers doctor visits, tests and other treatments. Payments may also cover overhead, such as staff salaries and drug costs. In some cases, when doctors work as salaried employees of group practices, the payments that show up under their names go to their institutions.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 2:45 P.M. (Starz) AMOUR (2012) An elderly French couple, portrayed by Jean-Louis Trintignant and Emmanuelle Riva, above, find their love tested when she has a stroke and he becomes her caretaker in this Oscar winner for best foreign-language film, directed by Michael Haneke. Isabelle Huppert plays their self-centered daughter — like her parents, a musician — whose questions about what she can do to help as her mother becomes increasingly incapacitated ring hollow. Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, called this film “a masterpiece about life, death and everything in between.” And while some viewers may find the movie cold and even cruel, she added, “there’s another point to be made here, namely that all the violence in ‘Amour’ is crucial to Mr. Haneke’s rigorous, liberatingly unsentimental worldview, one that gazes on death with the same benevolent equanimity as life. All of which is to say: Bring hankies. This is a film that will make you weep not only because life ends but also because it blooms.”

headline: Political Ties of Top Billers for Medicare
keywords: ['Medicare', 'Doctors', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: Two Florida doctors who received the nation’s highest Medicare reimbursements in 2012 are both major contributors to Democratic Party causes.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Two Florida doctors who received the nation’s highest Medicare reimbursements in 2012 are both major contributors to Democratic Party causes, and they have turned to the political system in recent years to defend themselves against suspicions that they may have submitted fraudulent or excessive charges to the federal government.

headline: Deutsche Bank Economist to Join China’s Central Bank
abstract: Jun Ma, a 13-year veteran of the German bank, is known as one of the most bullish of the economists who follow China.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Deutsche Bank’s chief China economist is taking up a new role at China’s central bank.

headline: Early Count in Indonesia Favors Largest Opposition Party
abstract: The biggest prize in Wednesday’s balloting is the House of Representatives, where the results will bear directly on the presidential election in July.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Out of power for 10 years, Indonesia’s largest opposition party was leading unofficial vote tallies from Wednesday’s national legislative elections, as the country’s focus now quickly turns to a presidential election in July.

headline: Toyota to Recall 6.4 Million Vehicles
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: The automaker said on Wednesday that the recall was for problems with air bags that may not deploy or seats that could move in a crash.
lead_paragraph: Weeks after agreeing to pay the largest criminal penalty ever by an automaker for hiding safety defects from the public, Toyota on Wednesday announced a wide-ranging recall of nearly 6.4 million vehicles worldwide for problems with air bags that may not deploy or seats that could move in a crash.

headline: Deadly Blast at Fruit Market Shatters Calm in Pakistan’s Capital
abstract: The death toll is expected to rise in the Islamabad attack, which came while the Taliban, which denied any role in the blast, were in talks with the government.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — In the deadliest attack on the Pakistani capital in more than five years, a powerful explosion ripped through a crowded market in Islamabad on Wednesday, killing at least 22 people and suggesting that, after a long stretch of relative calm, the city was back in the firing line of the country’s militants.

headline: Leader Tightens Hold on Power in North Korea
abstract: Kim Jong-un was re-elected as head of his country’s top governing agency as its rubber-stamp Parliament met to help consolidate his power by filling top leadership posts vacated in recent purges.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, was re-elected as head of his country’s top governing agency as its rubber-stamp Parliament met in Pyongyang on Wednesday to help consolidate his power by filling top leadership posts vacated in recent purges.

headline: British Culture Secretary Quits Amid Uproar Over Expenses
abstract: Maria Miller had apologized in Parliament for having overclaimed expenses, but by speaking for just 32 seconds, she prompted an avalanche of criticism.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Politicians rarely like saying sorry, and generally try to put the unpleasant business behind them as quickly as possible. But 32 seconds, it seems, is a bit too quick.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, April 9, 2014
abstract: Can you calculate the percent of yearly revenue paid to football players at Northwestern University if each player received $10 per hour for 50 hours of work per week?

keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The oil company became the first Nigerian firm to have a dual listing in both London and Nigeria, with a market capitalization based on its pricing of £1.14 billion, or about $1.9 billion.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Seplat, an independent Nigerian oil and gas company, said Wednesday that it raised 300.9 million pounds, or about $500 million, in its initial public offering, a dual listing in London and in Nigeria.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Inventive College Courses
abstract: Why are more college professors trying to be more engaging in the classroom?
lead_paragraph: In “10 Courses With a Twist,” Laura Pappano writes about professors teaching in inventive new ways.

headline: Gasps in Court as Prosecution Prods Pistorius
abstract: While cross-examining the athlete Oscar Pistorius, on trial for his girlfriend’s death, the prosecutor displayed a photograph of her bloodied head and all but ordered the defendant to look.
lead_paragraph: PRETORIA, South Africa — The prosecutor in Oscar Pistorius’s murder trial, Gerrie Nel, had just begun his cross-examination, and he was doing everything he could to goad Mr. Pistorius into losing his composure and his temper.

headline: U.N. Ignores South Sudan Camp Crisis, Charity Says
abstract: Doctors Without Borders issued a statement accusing international peacekeeping officials of ignoring squalid conditions at a camp for displaced people in the capital, Juba.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations peacekeeping operation in South Sudan was severely criticized on Wednesday by Doctors Without Borders, the emergency medical charity, over what it called a shameful indifference to the squalid living conditions of 21,000 displaced people forced to shelter in a flooded portion of a peacekeeping base in the capital, Juba.

headline: A Taste of Spring
abstract: How to ease the transition from cold- to hot-weather cooking.
lead_paragraph: April is a transitional season, not only for weather but also for cooking. More produce begins to appear at farmers’ markets, and even supermarket asparagus begins to come from places closer than Peru. In most of the country, though, it’s not yet time for hot-weather eating; we still crave more than a light salad.

headline: How to Think Like the Dutch in a Post-Sandy World
keywords: ['Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Water', 'Floods', 'Levees and Dams', 'Disasters and Emergencies']
abstract: Can Henk Ovink sell Americans on a new approach to flooding — letting the water in?
lead_paragraph: In December 2012, Shaun Donovan, the secretary of Housing and Urban Development, was on vacation in Berlin when he decided to detour to the Netherlands. He wanted to get a firsthand sense of the famed Dutch approach to water management. Hurricane Sandy struck six weeks before, and in the aftermath, President Obama asked him to lead a task force, whose objective was not just to rebuild but also to radically rethink the region’s infrastructure in light of climate change.

headline: Embracing Ambiguity in Israel
keywords: ['Arab-Israeli War (1967)', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Photography', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Frederic Brenner looks at his complex identity through the lens of Israel’s ambiguities and contrasts.
lead_paragraph: Frédéric Brenner has spent his adult life deciphering his own complex identity.

headline: To Whom, or What, Would You Like to Write a Thank-You Note?
abstract: A much-emailed Times article about the art of the thank-you note suggests that the handwritten note showing gratitude is making a comeback in the era of digital communication. If you could pen a handwritten note of thanks to anyone or anything, whom, or what, would you write to? Why?
lead_paragraph: A much-emailed Times article about the art of the thank-you note suggests that the handwritten note showing gratitude is making a comeback in the era of digital communication.

headline: Race for a Top Job in Europe Hits the Road
abstract: Jean-Claude Juncker, seeking to be the next president of the European Commission, embarked on an American-style campaign bus tour.
lead_paragraph: NIVELLES, Belgium — Jean-Claude Juncker, the former prime minister of Luxembourg who helped steer Europe through its currency crisis, sought to strengthen his bid to become the next president of the European Commission this week by taking to the road in an American-style campaign tour bus.

headline: Graft Inquiry Fells Another Ally of Former Security Chief
abstract: The expulsion from the Communist Party of Guo Yongxiang for accepting “huge” bribes could help the government in its investigation of Zhou Yongkang, the former head of internal security forces.
lead_paragraph: A former aide to Zhou Yongkang, until recently the head of China’s internal security forces and said to be the subject of a corruption investigation, has been expelled from the ruling Communist Party for accepting “huge” bribes and referred to the criminal justice system for prosecution.

headline: China Waits for an Apology
abstract: People have started to apologize for abuses they committed during the Cultural Revolution. Will the communist party?
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In 1970, when China was in the grip of the Cultural Revolution, Zhang Hongbing, a 16-year-old in Guzhen, a county in Anhui Province, made a fateful decision. During a family debate that year, his mother, Fang Zhongmou, had criticized Mao Zedong for his cult of personality. Her son and his father, believing her views to be counterrevolutionary, decided to inform on her. She was arrested that same day.

headline: New York Today: Cherries Bloom in Brooklyn
abstract: What you need to know for Wednesday: a sign of spring, more mild weather, and an officer dies of injuries from an arson fire.
lead_paragraph: Good Wednesday morning to you.

headline: Ebola Virus: A Grim, African Reality
abstract: This is not the Next Big One, a pandemic destined to circle the world, as some anxious observers might think.
lead_paragraph: There’s nothing like an outbreak of Ebola virus disease to bring a small, struggling African nation to international notice. One week we couldn’t place it on a map; the next week, after Ebola virus disease strikes, we know the body count and the name of the capital and whether its airport has closed.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing

headline: Vienna Orchestra to Receive $1 Million Birgit Nilsson Prize
keywords: ['Classical Music', 'Music', 'Contests and Prizes', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: Nilsson, an honorary member of the Vienna Philharmonic, made some of her most famous recordings with this ensemble.
lead_paragraph: The Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra played on many of the most celebrated recordings of the Swedish soprano Birgit Nilsson, including the classic set of Wagner’s “Ring” cycle conducted by Georg Solti that immortalized her Brünnhilde. Citing her “countless musical high points,” the orchestra voted unanimously to make her an honorary member in 1999.

headline: Beijing’s Neighbors Resist Transfer of Its Polluting Industries
abstract: Beijing’s latest effort to move energy-intensive, polluting businesses out of the Chinese capital has run into resistance from regional governments who are unenthusiastic about taking more industrial castoffs.
lead_paragraph: Beijing’s latest effort to move energy-intensive, polluting businesses out of the Chinese capital has run into resistance from regional governments who are unenthusiastic about taking more industrial castoffs.

lead_paragraph: 1914: Woman Gets ‘Wireless’ Divorce

headline: How a Start-Up Can Compete With the Big Boys for Talent
abstract: Strategies for companies that can’t afford big salaries and bonuses, in-house chefs, trips to inspiring conferences, or an office with floors connected by slides.
lead_paragraph: Everything about running a tech start-up is tough. We know what we’re trying to achieve but don’t know how long it will take or how much it will cost. We do everything on the cheap because precious investor funding is hard to come by. At the same time, we have to compete with the big boys for everything, most critically talent. But we can’t afford big salaries and bonuses, in-house chefs, trips to inspiring conferences in exotic locations, or an office with floors connected by slides. How can we compete?

headline: Authorities Release German Art Trove
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: The release will allow a team of international experts to begin a yearlong examination of the works in the collection of Cornelius Gurlitt.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The private art collection that sparked an international debate  over Germany’s willingness to address restitution claims for Nazi-looted artworks will be returned to Cornelius Gurlitt, German prosecutors said Wednesday. The release will allow a team of international experts to begin a yearlong examination of the works in the collection in order to help determine their provenance.

headline: Once Around the Diamond With Tyler Kepner
abstract: Tyler Kepner, the national baseball correspondent, gives us a glimpse of what being a baseball columnist is like, how he works and what he’s keeping an eye on.
lead_paragraph: Tyler Kepner, the national baseball correspondent, travels the country, hunting the sport’s best stories. Tyler gives us a glimpse of life as a baseball columnist, how he works and what he’s keeping an eye on this season. Our conversation has been condensed and edited.

headline: Daily Report: Samsung’s Earnings to Decline as Smartphone Sales Slow

lead_paragraph: Samsung Electronics is finding little to revel in these days, Tom Sims and Su-Hyun Lee report.

headline: An Order for Banks to Hold More Capital
abstract: A Fed rule could mean banks need to find an additional $68 billion to limit risk. | The firm chosen to oversee the revamped SAC has links to the fund. | Investors may be souring on I.P.O.’s. | Comcast makes its case for a merger with Time Warner Cable.
lead_paragraph: “Federal regulators on Tuesday approved a simple rule that could do more to rein in Wall Street than most other parts of a sweeping overhaul that has descended on the biggest banks since the financial crisis,” Peter Eavis writes in DealBook. The rule increases to 5 percent, from roughly 3 percent, a threshold called the leverage ratio, which measures the amount of capital that a bank holds against its assets. The rule is scheduled to take effect at the start of 2018.

headline: Questions About Financial Aid?
abstract: Richard Pérez-Peña and Mark Kantrowitz, publisher of Edvisors, answered reader questions on paying for college.
lead_paragraph: With financial aid award letters in hand, families are struggling to make sense of it all by colleges’ May 1 deadline. To supplement his article “What You Don’t Know About Financial Aid (but Should),” Richard Pérez-Peña, a national correspondent covering higher education for The Times, and Mark Kantrowitz, a nationally recognized expert on financial aid and publisher of Edvisors, answered readers’ questions.

headline: What You Don’t Know About Financial Aid (but Should)
abstract: Students have more tools than ever to decipher and compare financial aid packages. But why is it still so confusing, and why can’t you afford what colleges say you can?
lead_paragraph: Marilyn Ferreira has solved her share of financial puzzles — running a business, buying a home and arranging a mortgage, raising six children as a single mother. But none of that compared to the challenge of understanding the cost of sending her brood to college.

headline: Stagnation Without End, Amen (Wonkish)
abstract: Alvin Hansen has his revenge.
lead_paragraph: In 1938 Alvin Hansen, who did more than anyone else to bring Keynesian economics to America, gave a landmark speech to the American Economic Association. (The speech is behind a paywall, but Tim Taylor has a good summary here.) In it, he made the case for “secular stagnation” — a persistently depressed economy. His arguments were pretty good, too: slow population growth and slow technological progress, he argued meant low investment demand — and even very low interest rates wouldn’t be enough to make up for the shortfall.

headline: Police Policy on Fires Is Questioned Amid Grief at Death of a New York Officer
abstract: Dennis Guerra, 38, who responded to a blaze in a high-rise in Coney Island, Brooklyn, became the New York Police Department’s first fire fatality in nearly 30 years.
lead_paragraph: From the outside, there were few signs of a serious high-rise fire. No smoke pouring from windows, no commotion outside the Brooklyn apartment building on Sunday as two New York City police officers rushed inside, grabbing an elevator for the 13th floor.

headline: Student Stabs 21 People at a High School Outside Pittsburgh
abstract: Officials said the suspect, who is in custody, roamed classrooms stabbing and slashing students and staff members at the Murrysville, Pa., school.
lead_paragraph: As classes began at a high school in suburban Pittsburgh on Wednesday morning, a 16-year-old student walked through the hallway stabbing and slashing students with two large knives, the authorities said.

headline: The Uphill Climate Challenge in ‘Years of Living Dangerously’
keywords: ['Disasters and Emergencies', 'Drought', 'Floods', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Weather']
abstract: Some thoughts on the challenges facing a nine-part Showtime series on global warming.
lead_paragraph: Joe Romm, the Center for American Progress climate blogger who’s also one of two chief science advisers for the forthcoming Showtime climate series, “Years of Living Dangerously,” sent a query last night after seeing a Twitter note I posted. My note was about an Op-Ed article in The Times by Michael Shellenberger and Ted Nordhaus of the Breakthrough Institute.

headline: Israel Says It Is ‘Deeply Disappointed’ by Kerry’s Remarks on Peace Talks
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry appeared to lay the blame on Israel for the crisis in the talks, prompting an unusually strong rebuke.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — In an unusually pointed rebuke of an ally, Israel said on Wednesday that it was “deeply disappointed” by Secretary of State John Kerry’s remarks a day earlier that appeared to lay primary blame on Israel for the crisis in the American-brokered Middle East peace talks.

headline: Legacy | A Love Eternal

lead_paragraph: Quora, the question-and-answer website, has raised $80 million in a new venture capital round meant to spur its growth and protect its independence.

headline: Readers Respond: How Should Apple Spend Its Billions?
abstract: Readers offer a wide range of suggestions for how Apple could spend the $159 billion in cash it has on hand.

headline: What Did Medicare Pay Your Doctor?
abstract: Medicare officials release data on doctor payments, and an analysis by The Times uncovers a number of surprises.
lead_paragraph: A small number of doctors, about 2 percent, accounted for nearly a quarter of Medicare spending in 2012, according to a new analysis by The Times. Just one-quarter of the doctors billing Medicare accounted for three-quarters of its payments that year. Read the full story, and search for your doctor’s billings with our online tool.

headline: Student Survey on Academic Advising
abstract: Statistics examine students’ experiences with academic advising.
lead_paragraph: Statistics examine students’ experiences with academic advising.

headline: Greece Dives Back Into the Bond Market
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Government Bonds']
abstract: The plan to sell the first long-term bonds in four years is a symbolic turnaround for Greece, even if legions of jobless Greeks are not cheering.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Europe’s leaders have been preaching austerity for years, arguing that only deep budget cuts will revive the economy and inspire the necessary confidence among investors.

headline: Again, Obama Offers Comfort at Fort Hood After Soldiers Are Killed
keywords: ['Fort Hood Shooting (2014)', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The service for the victims of last week’s rampage proved a haunting repeat of the first mass shooting on President Obama’s watch, in the fall of 2009.
lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex. — Five years later, President Obama was back Wednesday on the same field in front of the same building on the same Army post in the same state, with some of the same faces again grieving for soldiers killed in an act of senseless violence.

headline: Russia Plotting for Ukrainian Influence, Not Invasion, Analysts Say
abstract: Moscow’s goals are focused on a long-range strategy of preventing Ukraine from escaping Russia’s economic and military orbit, political analysts said.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The separatist demonstrations again churning through eastern Ukraine have raised fears of a Crimean-style invasion by the 40,000 Russian troops coiled just over the Russian border. But Moscow’s goals are more subtle than that, focused on a long-range strategy of preventing Ukraine from escaping Russia’s economic and military orbit, according to political analysts, Kremlin allies and diplomats interviewed this week.

headline: Rash of Suicides Underlines Maharashtra Farmers’ Discontent
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Elections', 'Politics and Government', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: The state’s small farmers have reliably voted for the Indian National Congress and its coalition partner, the Nationalist Congress Party, in the past, but the party’s rivals are tapping into the frustration felt by members of this voting bloc.
lead_paragraph: DHANORA, India — In this sleepy village in eastern Maharashtra, about 50 miles south of Nagpur, the sense of desperation is palpable. The dirt road that leads to the village passes through desolate fields, where the winter plantings of cotton, soybean and legumes have been ruined by unseasonal rains, harsh winds and an unusual hailstorm that hit this state and several others in February.

headline: To Slim Down, Procter & Gamble Sells Most of Its Pet Food Brands to Mars
abstract: The $2.9 billion sale of the brands, including Iams and Eukanuba, was championed by the activist investor William A. Ackman.
lead_paragraph: Since A. G. Lafley returned last year for a second stint as chief executive of Procter & Gamble, investors have been waiting for him to make a big move. On Wednesday, they got a small but significant first step.
