headline: Mark Morris Bringing a Handel Work to Mostly Mozart Festival
abstract: The Mark Morris Dance Group will offer a new staging of Handel’s “Acis and Galatea” at the Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center this summer.
lead_paragraph: Mark Morris’s new staging of Handel’s “Acis and Galatea” will have its New York premiere this summer as part of the 48th Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center.

headline: Parents Should Coach Academics as Seriously as They Do Sports
abstract: Train little Seymour for the 2028 Olympics, and people might laugh. But prepare Sofia for the 2028 International Math Olympiad, and they’d think you were crazy.
lead_paragraph: It sometimes seems that the American success ethic stops at the schoolhouse door. We encourage ambition in youth sports and entrepreneurial enterprise, but our families are often suspicious of the value of scholastic competition.

headline: Senate Panel Expresses Caution on Merger of Cable Giants
keywords: ['Cable Television', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The judiciary panel expressed concern over higher costs for consumers if a merger with Time Warner Cable were approved, but a Comcast executive downplayed the likelihood.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Members of the Senate Judiciary Committee expressed concern on Wednesday that the proposed $45 billion merger of Comcast and Time Warner Cable would raise the prices consumers pay for cable television and high-speed Internet service while leaving them with fewer choices for video programming.

headline: Today in Small Business: Yelp Has Been Struggling
abstract: Four things to investigate before you buy a business. Vermont is experimenting with single-payer health insurance. And why this might be a good time to change your passwords.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: In Eastern Ukraine, a One-Building, Pro-Russia Realm Persists Despite Criticism
abstract: A group of protesters who have seized the government headquarters in Donetsk, Ukraine, was urged by local politicians to give up and hand over its weapons.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Nikolai Solntsev, the self-declared commissar of the Eastern Front and a founding father of the newly proclaimed Donetsk People’s Republic, has been waiting 22 years, three months and 14 days for this moment.

headline: Bunny Swap
abstract: Two new picture books would be sweet, sugar-free additions to a child’s Easter basket.
lead_paragraph: As Easter approaches, it’s officially bunny season, and there are some endearing examples of the species out this year (one looks a little different from the others, but more about that later). Both “Found,” written and illustrated by Salina Yoon, and “Here Comes the Easter Cat,” by Deborah Underwood with illustrations by Claudia Rueda, would be sweet, sugar-free additions to a child’s Easter basket. There’s no reason, however, to restrict their consumption to springtime, because both books concern a perennial childhood issue: balancing the desire to do right with the impulse to do just what you want.

headline: Architecture | Striking a Balance
abstract: The French architecture firm Studio KO is making its name by combining reverence for cultural history with forward-thinking design.
lead_paragraph: The fervently followed architects Karl Fournier and Olivier Marty of Studio KO imbue their rigorous modernism with a subtle blend of history and culture.

headline: La Quinta Shares Little Changed on Debut
abstract: Shares of La Quinta, the hotel chain backed by the Blackstone Group, ended the day just slightly above their offering price.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:19 p.m. |

headline: No Comment Necessary: Replacing the A.C.A. With…the A.C.A.?
abstract: Why it’s difficult to come up with the “replace” part of the “repeal and replace” slogan.
lead_paragraph: According to Talking Points Memo, there is “internal dissent” on whether the Republican Party should come up with an alternative to the Affordable Care Act. One congressional aide explained that it’s difficult to come up a replacement, because it would probably end up looking a lot like the A.C.A.:

headline: New Home for a Mural That Reads Like a Menu
abstract: Artwork created in the 1960s for the CBS cafeteria, then removed, is now at the Culinary Institute of America, north of New York City.
lead_paragraph: HYDE PARK, N.Y. — Crisp and white as a chef’s toque, the newest artwork at the Culinary Institute of America made its debut last month as the perfect backdrop for commencement snapshots. Graduates and family members almost instinctively posed before the mural, a sculptural mélange of food-related words and objects.

headline: Low Inflation and Structural Illusions (Wonkish)
abstract: Structural problems, or are we just depressed?
lead_paragraph: The suggestion that only the short-term unemployed matter for wage determination, that the long-term unemployed have been written off, is rapidly congealing into orthodoxy. And it might be true. But I’m with Mike Konczal here: it’s far from being a well-established fact. Mike argues that to the extent it was true at all, it was a temporary phenomenon, and that more recent data don’t support the claim. I’d make a different (although not necessarily conflicting) argument: a lot of the supposed evidence comes from applying Phillips curves estimated over periods of moderate to high inflation, and there are good reasons to believe that such estimates misbehave at low inflation.

headline: Times Minute | Voices From Gaza
abstract: Also on the Minute, looking at Medicare reimbursement and the genetics of exercise.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, looking at Medicare reimbursement and the genetics of exercise.

headline: Times Minute | Voices From Gaza
abstract: Also on the Minute, looking at Medicare reimbursement and the genetics of exercise.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Senate Republicans Block Bill on Equal Pay
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Women and Girls', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: A Democratic-sponsored bill meant to close the pay gap between men and women failed in the Senate, framing an election-year fight over whose policies are friendlier to female voters.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans on Wednesday blocked legislation meant to close the pay gap between men and women, framing an election-year fight between the parties over whose policies are friendlier to women.

headline: Prosecutor Cross-Examines Pistorius
abstract: The Paralympic athlete Oscar Pistorius was cross-examined by the state prosecutor, Gerrie Nel, in the third day of the defendant’s testimony in Pretoria, South Africa.
lead_paragraph: The Paralympic athlete Oscar Pistorius was cross-examined by the state prosecutor, Gerrie Nel, in the third day of the defendant’s testimony in Pretoria, South Africa.

headline: Nets’ Flexible Attack Baffles Heat, but Playoffs Pose a Stiffer Test
abstract: The Nets, an efficient low-post team, gave Miami’s defense trouble during four regular-season wins. But the Heat have had a different intensity in the postseason since LeBron James’s arrival.
lead_paragraph: When the Nets lost Brook Lopez for the season in December, they found themselves without the best low-post scorer in the N.B.A. Or so they thought. This season, the league’s most efficient post scorer, according to the statistics company Synergy Sports, is actually Nets guard Shaun Livingston.

headline: Wheelies: The Focus Edition
abstract: Ford to introduce the all-new Focus at New York auto show; BMW narrows its decision for where to put a new plant in North America.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: A Green Revolution, This Time for Africa
abstract: High-yield wheat and rice produced dramatic gains in harvests in Asia and Latin America. Is it Africa’s turn now?
lead_paragraph: Last month was the 100th anniversary of the birth of Norman Borlaug, the father of the Green Revolution.

headline: Aftermath of Pakistan Market Blast
abstract: Survivors combed through the debris after an explosion at a vegetable market in the outskirts of Islamabad, Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: Survivors combed through the debris after an explosion at a vegetable market in the outskirts of Islamabad, Pakistan.

headline: When L.B.J. Came to Lunch
abstract: On Feb. 6, 1964, Lyndon B. Johnson visited The New York Times Building on 43rd Street for a luncheon with Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the paper’s publisher, and Arthur Hays Sulzberger, the chairman of the board.
lead_paragraph: Today, The Times published two articles related to Lyndon B. Johnson. In one, Peter Baker sets up President Obama’s address on Thursday to the Lyndon B. Johnson Presidential Library and Museum in Austin, Tex., to commemorate the 50th anniversary this year of the Civil Rights Act. In the other, Carl Hulse writes about the Washington politicians traveling to New York to see “All The Way,” the Broadway play portraying the first year of the Johnson presidency.

headline: Latin American E-Commerce Giant to Acquire 2 Real Estate Sites
abstract: MercadoLibre, based in Buenos Aires and traded on the Nasdaq, will pay about $40 million for VMK, a holding company that owns two prominent real estate websites in Latin America.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil – The Latin American e-commerce giant MercadoLibre has acquired VMK, a holding company that owns two major real estate websites, the companies are expected to announce on Wednesday.

headline: How to Study the Numinous
abstract: On Barbara Ehrenreich’s call for further scientific exploration of mystical experience.
lead_paragraph: In an op-ed in the Sunday edition of this newspaper, Barbara Ehrenreich, card-carrying liberal rationalist, writes about her own mystical experiences (the subject of her new book), and argues that the numinous deserves more cutting-edge scientific study:

headline: Alibaba’s Deal-Making Raises a Red Flag
abstract: The e-commerce company is lending one of its founders $1 billion to invest in a digital-TV company. The three-way deal, says John Foley of Reuters Breakingviews, offers a glimpse of the way company insiders mix public and private interests.
lead_paragraph: Powerful insiders are the norm at Internet companies. Alibaba’s tie-up with a digital-TV company adds an extra twist. The Chinese e-commerce group, which is planning a  listing in the United States, has signed a three-step deal with  Wasu Media of China that looks a little too clever for comfort.

headline: Detroit Creditor Shows Court Four Offers for City’s Art
abstract: With city and state officials pushing to keep Detroit’s bankruptcy moving forward toward resolution, a bond insurer threw an obstacle on to the road on Wednesday: four rival offers for the treasures in the city’s art museum.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — With city and state officials pushing to keep Detroit’s bankruptcy moving quickly toward a resolution, a bond insurer threw an obstacle into the proceedings on Wednesday: four potential offers for the treasures in the city’s art museum, which Detroit does not want to sell.

headline: In Cape Town, Local Color Comes in Bright Shades
abstract: To its Muslim culture, the neighborhood Bo-Kaap in South Africa is adding young professionals and gay couples looking for affordable quarters.
lead_paragraph: It’s perhaps the most recognizable of Cape Town’s neighborhoods: a warren of rainbow-bright houses at the foot of Signal Hill, their indigo, fuchsia and lavender facades brightening even the gloomiest days. Bo-Kaap has long been home to Cape Town’s vibrant Muslim community, the Cape Malays, but in recent years, others have been moving into this tight-knit enclave. Young professionals looking for affordable apartments in the city center and gay couples priced out of nearby De Waterkant have been slowly buying up Technicolor real estate.

headline: Michael Cera and Kieran Culkin to Star in ‘This Is Our Youth’ on Broadway
abstract: The new production of Kenneth Lonergan’s play will also include Tavi Gevinson, the Rookie magazine editor and actress.
lead_paragraph: This will do nothing for Michael Cera’s on-screen reputation as a young slacker without peer: this summer, he will make his Broadway debut in a new production of Kenneth Lonergan’s “This Is Our Youth,” one that he and his co-star, Kieran Culkin, have been trying to bring to the stage for nearly five years.

headline: UMass Guard Joins List of Openly Gay Athletes
abstract: Derrick Gordon, a Massachusetts guard, is believed to be the first publicly gay active men’s player in Division I college basketball.
lead_paragraph: Derrick Gordon, a University of Massachusetts guard, revealed that he is gay, joining a fast-growing list of publicly gay male college and professional athletes.

headline: Do the Courts Have a Role to Play in Drone Strikes?
abstract: Judges aren’t acting like it.
lead_paragraph: History will not look kindly on the succession of federal court rulings since the 9/11 attacks that have bowed to government claims of national security to deny meaningful judicial review for extraordinary acts, like rendition and torture.

headline: Two More Pings Detected in Plane Search
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Malaysia Airlines Flight 370']
abstract: Australia’s chief search coordinator, Angus Houston, and the United States team commander, Capt. Mark Matthews, spoke about new signals detected in the hunt for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.
lead_paragraph: Australia’s chief search coordinator, Angus Houston, and the United States team commander, Capt. Mark Matthews, spoke about new signals detected in the hunt for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

headline: Best-Laid Plans for Starry Revival
abstract: Many of us read John Steinbeck’s 1937 novella “Of Mice and Men” in high school, but it has been a lot harder to see it on Broadway, until now.
lead_paragraph: Many of us read John Steinbeck’s 1937 novella “Of Mice and Men” in high school, but it has been a lot harder to see it on Broadway, until now. The show, getting a starry revival at the Longacre Theater, was last on Broadway in 1975, and then for only two months. In the new production, James Franco, whose résumé includes jobs as an actor, poet, professor, filmmaker and more, makes his Broadway debut as George, and Chris O’Dowd (“Bridesmaids”), also on Broadway for the first time, is the simple-minded Lennie in Steinbeck’s Depression-era tale of struggling migrant workers.

headline: Jimmy Beans Wool Decides to Get Back to Knitting
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'E-Commerce', 'Small Business', 'Wool and Woolen Goods']
abstract: The employees who left were great people who did exactly what we asked, says a business owner, but it was an identity crisis. We weren’t ready yet.
lead_paragraph: Last week, we published a case study about Jimmy Beans Wool, a yarn and fabric retailer owned by Laura and Doug Zander. Hoping to transform Jimmy Beans into a $100-million company, the Zanders made several hires and introduced numerous costly marketing initiatives that pulled Ms. Zander, the chief executive, from her role guiding operations. The efforts backfired, however, and the company’s sales growth stopped.

headline: A Must-Have List Changes in Midstream
abstract: Nakul and Courtney Chaturvedi found the space they needed in Jackson Heights, Queens.
lead_paragraph: A few years after his arrival in New York in 2005, Nakul Chaturvedi bought a large alcove studio in Midtown East. He met Courtney Yates at a Halloween party, and they were married two years ago.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 64
abstract: At the 2014 World Cup in Brazil, Japan will have another opportunity to show the world if it can live up to its nickname, the Brazil of Asia.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Sotheby’s Responds to Loeb, With Visual Aids
abstract: Sotheby’s filed a presentation with the Securities and Exchange Commission that defends its board and attacks the record of the activist investor Daniel S. Loeb.
lead_paragraph: In his battle for control of the auction house Sotheby’s, the activist investor Daniel S. Loeb has focused much of his attention on what he calls the inadequacy of its board members.

headline: A First Look at a New Documentary About the Master Gardener Piet Oudolf
abstract: The film highlights the many private and public parks the acclaimed plantsman worked on, including the High Line in Manhattan and the Lurie Garden in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: “I think it’s the journey in your life to find out what real beauty is, of course, but also discover beauty in things that are at first sight not beautiful,” says Piet Oudolf in this trailer for the forthcoming documentary “Piet Oudolf: Fall, Winter, Spring, Summer, Fall.” The Dutch garden designer from Hummelo, the Netherlands, has risen to international acclaim thanks to the many private and public parks he worked on, including the High Line in Manhattan, the Lurie Garden in Chicago’s Millennium Park and Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park in London, which was home to the 2012 Olympic Games and just opened to the public last week. These projects bring the quality of home gardening to public spaces, creating organic environments that feel as though they’ve been growing there, on their own, for years. For his latest undertaking, Oudolf is designing the grounds of the new outpost of Hauser & Wirth gallery, a remodeled 18th-century farmhouse in the rolling hills of the English county of Somerset that is set to open in July. This film, produced by the filmmaker Thomas Piper and Checkerboard Film Foundation, will offer an intimate view of Oudolf’s process, from landscape blueprints to theories on beauty, when it hits the big screen toward the middle of next year.

headline: This Old House
abstract: Hauser & Wirth’s latest gallery space, a house in Somerset, England, celebrates the beauty and lushness of the area.
lead_paragraph: A powerhouse gallery bucks the trend toward ‘important’ architecture in big cities and sets up an outpost in English farm country.

headline: Go Daddy Said to Pick Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan for I.P.O.
abstract: The big Internet registrar has hired Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan Chase to coordinate a stock sale, though it isn’t clear yet how much money the company plans to raise in an I.P.O.
lead_paragraph: The Go Daddy Group, the Internet registrar best known for cheeky, controversial ads, is moving full speed ahead with plans for an initial public offering.

headline: Los Angeles Museum Grants to Promote Art and Technology
abstract: The Los Angeles County Museum of Art awards technology-fueled art projects that go beyond typical museum genres.
lead_paragraph: When the Los Angeles County Museum of Art unveiled the results of its original “art and technology” program in an exhibition in 1971, many visitors were struck by what was missing: women. Of the 46 artists and technology experts pictured on the catalog cover, all were men. Protests ensued.

headline: Impac Dublin Literary Award Narrows Field to 10
abstract: Karl Ove Knausgaard, Marie NDiaye and Juan Gabriel Vásquez are among this year’s finalists for the lucrative literary prize.
lead_paragraph: The International Impac Dublin Literary Award has winnowed its very long list of nominees for the 2014 prize to 10 finalists.

headline: Eat, Stay, Buy Locally: Treading Lightly on the Road
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Eco-Tourism', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: With increasing demand, a number of organizations are helping travelers visit countries conscientiously.
lead_paragraph: Between the intricate shrines of Angkor Wat, the diverse landscapes of the countryside and the kindness of its people — and despite the horrors of its recent history — Cambodia knocks a lot of people off their feet. It certainly had that effect on me when I first visited a few years ago and then again when I returned this winter. Yet it was impossible not to notice the school-age children begging barefoot at the major tourist sites, underage local women escorting Western men on sex tours, and the proliferation of seemingly unsustainable large-scale resorts being built on the pristine southern coast.

headline: A 10-Month Family Trip Around the World
abstract: The Maurers have been everywhere from Asia to Africa on their adventure, sticking to a $150-a-day budget along the way.
lead_paragraph: “It’s much more impacting to learn about the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia than in class,” said Miles Maurer, 15, who instead of attending the ninth grade in Flagstaff, Ariz., this year is traveling around the world. It’s difficult to disagree.

headline: $772 Million Penalty for Bank of America Credit Card Practices
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Consumer Protection', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said that the bank “illegally charged” its customers for credit services that were not received. The bank was ordered to refund more than a million customers.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America has been ordered to pay roughly $772 million in refunds to customers and fines to federal regulators to settle allegations that the bank used deceptive marketing and billing practices involving credit card products.

headline: Nuclear Talks With Iran Need ‘Intensive Work,’ Envoys Say
abstract: A joint statement issued at the end of the latest round of talks on the Iranian nuclear dispute suggested that extensive disagreements remain.
lead_paragraph: Iran and the group of six major powers negotiating a permanent agreement to resolve the Iranian nuclear dispute concluded a two-day round of talks in Vienna on Wednesday, asserting that “a lot of intensive work” remained to complete a draft accord by their self-imposed deadline in three months.

headline: Pain Relievers Tied to Heart Rhythm Disorder
abstract: A new study found that the popular pain relievers known as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, or Nsaids, may increase the risk for the most common type of irregular heartbeat, atrial fibrillation.
lead_paragraph: A new study found that the popular pain relievers known as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, or Nsaids, may increase the risk for the most common type of irregular heartbeat, atrial fibrillation.

headline: Germans Loosen Their Purse Strings
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Fresh statistics on German trade show a sharp increase in imports from the euro zone and the broader European Union.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — When Europe seemed to be falling apart in 2010, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund annoyed Germans by suggesting they should stop hoarding so much of their wealth and instead buy more things from their ailing European neighbors.

headline: Britain Increasingly Invokes Power to Disown Its Citizens
keywords: ['Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Targeted Killings', 'Terrorism', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: The government’s ability to revoke citizenship, and the fact it has used that ability against people who were later killed in drone strikes, has fueled concern.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The letter informing Mohamed Sakr that he had been stripped of his British citizenship arrived at his family’s house in London in September 2010. Mr. Sakr, born and raised here by British-Egyptian parents, was in Somalia at the time and was suspected by Western intelligence agencies of being a senior figure in the Shabab, a terrorist group linked to Al Qaeda.

headline: A New Album From Billy Corgan, but Only 250 Copies
abstract: Billy Corgan of the Smashing Pumpkins will release 250 copies of an “experimental” solo project.
lead_paragraph: Billy Corgan, the imaginative singer and lead guitarist for the Smashing Pumpkins, has undertaken some unusual side projects in recent times, including evenings devoted to synthesizer music inspired by Herman Hesse’s “Siddhartha” and the 13th-century poet Rumi, both at Madame Zuzu’s Teahouse, in Highland Park, Ill., which Mr. Corgan owns. At the moment, Mr. Corgan and his band are at work on two new Smashing Pumpkin albums, which are due to be released in 2015.

headline: When the Criticisms Never End
abstract: Tyrannosaurus parents once ruled the household, and still want to.
lead_paragraph: Five nights a week, Amanda H. and her husband drove to her parents’ upscale continuing care retirement community in suburban Boston. She could feel her anxiety build as they rode the elevator upstairs.

headline: Image of the Day: April 9
abstract: A member of an insurgent group, which has currently suspended operation as part of an agreement with the government, at a polling booth in Manipur.

headline: G.O.P. Seeks Investigation of Ex-Official From I.R.S.
keywords: ['Internal Revenue Service Political Profiling', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: A House panel voted to ask Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. to open an investigation of Lois Lerner over the Internal Revenue Service’s targeting of Tea Party groups.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans on Wednesday formally asked Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. to begin a criminal investigation of Lois Lerner, the former Internal Revenue Service official caught up in the scandal over political targeting of Tea Party groups.

headline: Fed Recognized Change in Unemployment Goal Could Be Misunderstood
abstract: The central bank repeated its plans to slowly lower its stimulus campaign as it gains confidence in the strength of the economic recovery.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Federal Reserve changed the guidelines for its stimulus campaign last month, it did not change its commitment to supporting the economy, according to an account of the decision that the Fed published on Wednesday.

headline: Through a Lens Sharply
abstract: How a camera taught me to savor the awesome details I see in my travels.
lead_paragraph: Recently, I unpacked a box that had been in storage for a long time. It was full of postcards. Hundreds of them. Postcards from every trip I had ever taken. Postcards of famous monuments, famous museums, famous mosques, famous mountains, famous red phone booths. I gazed at my stash — I must have saved them for good reason — and felt ... nothing. They weren’t my London, my Paris, my Istanbul. They were pictures of places that belonged to everyone.

headline: Classical Playlist: Jeffrey Mumford, Mozart, Brahms and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: MUMFORD: ‘Through a stillness brightening’Miranda Cuckson, violinist; Wendy Richman, violist; Julia Bruskin, cellist; Winston Choi, pianist; Argento Chamber Ensemble, conducted by Michel Galante; and others(Albany) Jeffrey Mumford, a distinguished American composer who studied with Elliott Carter and Bernard Rands, among others, has an unerring knack for fashioning rigorous works as changeable as cloudscapes, bursting with color, nuance and poetry. Those qualities are abundantly present in this generous Kickstarter-financed collection of chamber pieces spanning 30 years; sources and sonorities vary, but inspiration and expert advocacy are consistent. Two of the performers involved, the violinist Miranda Cuckson and the cellist Julia Bruskin, will perform works from the collection with the pianist Steve Beck on Sunday at Spectrum on the Lower East Side.(Steve Smith)

headline: Reader Idea | Using the ‘Who Made That?’ Column to Teach Reading Strategies
abstract: A simple, versatile idea for using one of the many products covered in a short, weekly column in The Times Magazine to teach students about how “informational text” works.
lead_paragraph: Occasionally we publish ideas from readers in lieu of our own lesson plans, and, as with the simple, versatile activity we feature below, they often make us wish we were still in the classroom ourselves so we could try them out “IRL,” as the kids say.

headline: Q. and A. on Heartbleed: A Flaw Missed by the Masses
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Open-Source Software']
abstract: Zulfikar Ramzan, the chief technology officer for Elastica, a cloud security start-up, helps explain the security flaw Heartbleed and open-source software, and offers suggestions for how consumers can protect themselves.
lead_paragraph: This week, security researchers publicized a significant security flaw, named Heartbleed, which could expose the personal information that people plug into websites, like passwords and credit card numbers.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Latest Memoir to Be Released in June
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As Mrs. Clinton weighs another run for the presidency, her new book is likely to provide campaign fodder for supporters and critics alike.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s much-anticipated memoir of her time as secretary of state will be released on June 10, her publisher said Wednesday.

headline: Here’s a Story ... of a Mashed-Up Family ...
abstract: “The Bardy Brunch: The War of the Families Partridge and Brady” combines two television series from the 1970s and infuses them with Shakespearean plots.
lead_paragraph: The first shock is that Shirley Partridge has married Reuben Kincaid, the band’s seemingly undesirable manager. Young Danny is distraught, like Hamlet when his mother married his uncle. Then little Cindy Brady is hiding behind the arras when Danny unsheathes his dagger.

headline: App Smart: Off the Beaten Path
abstract: Many apps available for mobile devices can feel like tools on a Swiss Army knife, but there are also many weird and surprising apps that can captivate you.
lead_paragraph: Many apps available for mobile devices can feel like tools on a Swiss Army knife, but there are also many weird and surprising apps that can captivate you.

headline: A Collection of Wonderful and Weird Amusements
abstract: Apps that offer little in the way of information, advice or solutions, but much in the way of oddity and fascination.
lead_paragraph: MOBILE apps can seem a bit like the tools on a Swiss Army knife. Many of them are useful, but some are just fun.

headline: The Obama Deportation Debacle
abstract: President Obama has been spent the last five years deporting the wrong people.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has been spent the last five years deporting the wrong people. The evidence is pretty clear.

headline: Recipes for Kids:  Congee
abstract: Congee is a thick Chinese soup made with rice, which sort of explodes as it cooks.
lead_paragraph: Congee is a thick Chinese soup made with rice, which expands and breaks apart as it cooks. In China congee is eaten for breakfast, but it is delicious for lunch and dinner, too. It is also known as jook.

headline: The Gun Report: April 9, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Nathan Trapuzzano, a 24-year-old software engineer and newlywed with a baby on the way, went out for an early morning walk in his Indianapolis neighborhood. He was approached by two people who attempted to rob him, surveillance video shows. One of the would-be thieves pulled out a handgun and shot him in the stomach, killing him.

headline: Video From Fort Hood Memorial Service
abstract: Video from the memorial service on Wednesday at Ford Hood, where President Obama spoke a week after three soldiers died in a mass shooting.
lead_paragraph: As our colleague, Manny Fernandez and Alan Blinder report, President Obama returned on Wednesday to Fort Hood for a memorial service for three soldiers killed in a mass shooting at the base last week.

headline: Notable Deaths of 2014
abstract: Remembering Maya Angelou, Philip Seymour Hoffman, Shirley Temple Black, Nadine Gordimer, Ruby Dee, Howard Baker, Elaine Stritch, Mickey Rooney, Robin Williams and others who died this year.
lead_paragraph: Remembering Maya Angelou, Philip Seymour Hoffman, Shirley Temple Black, Nadine Gordimer, Ruby Dee, Howard Baker, Elaine Stritch, Mickey Rooney, Robin Williams and others who died this year.

headline: Knives, Not Guns, at a School Near Pittsburgh
abstract: Who would minimize a knife attack in which a single young person was able to injure 20 others with the thought “it could have been a lot worse?” Anyone who has come to expect the verb in the headline to be “shoots,” not “stabs.”
lead_paragraph: As we hear and read more about the violence at Franklin Regional High School in Murrysville, Pa., where authorities say a 16-year-old student walked from classroom to classroom randomly stabbing and slashing 19 students as well as a security guard before being tackled and subdued by a principal and a police officer, the same words keep coming up again and again in different contexts.

headline: European Official Urges ‘Say on Pay’ Requirement for Boards
abstract: The European Union commissioner for financial affairs introduced a plan that that would require a shareholder vote on salaries awarded to directors of about 10,000 companies listed on European stock exchanges.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — A European Union official renewed his efforts to curb excessive pay by introducing a plan on Wednesday that would require a shareholder vote on salaries for directors of publicly traded companies.

headline: Times Should Have Nodded to Wall Street Journal in Medicare Story
abstract: A trove of information on payouts to doctors resulted from legal action.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times led its print edition today with an extensive treatment of an important story: that a small fraction of doctors get a huge share of the billions of dollars paid out under Medicare.

headline: What You Get for ... $900,000
abstract: We compare a contemporary in Iowa, a Tudor in North Carolina and a Dutch Colonial in Idaho.
lead_paragraph: BOISE, IDAHO

headline: AT&T to Switch Its Advertising Message
abstract: The new theme, “Mobilizing your world,” replaces “Rethink possible.” With AT&T’s advertising budget near $2 billion, those words may be hard to miss.
lead_paragraph: Take a look at these three words: “Mobilizing your world.” They could soon become almost as familiar to you as your name or Social Security number.

headline: The Return of a Very Tall Roadside Attraction
abstract: The family that owns the 134-foot “thermometer” in Baker, Calif., commemorating Death Valley’s high temperature record wants to restore it.
lead_paragraph: A now-defunct roadside attraction in remote Baker, Calif., named the world’s tallest thermometer, may be restored. LaRae Harguess, a high school guidance counselor whose family owns the 134-foot-tall concrete tower, said in a telephone interview that the family was working to refurbish it.

headline: Executives Discuss Comcast Merger
abstract: An executive vice president of Comcast, David L. Cohen, and the chief executive of Public Knowledge, Gene Kimmelman, argued their cases before Congress on the proposed merger with Time Warner.
lead_paragraph: An executive vice president of Comcast, David L. Cohen, and the chief executive of Public Knowledge, Gene Kimmelman, argued their cases before Congress on the proposed merger with Time Warner.

headline: Mac DeMarco’s Appetizing ‘Salad Days’
abstract: By way of a release party for his new album, “Salad Days,” Mac DeMarco and his band of enfants terrible played a bouncy late-night show at Baby’s All Right in Brooklyn on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: As a slacker-child of the 1980s, I heard Mac DeMarco’s brand-new album “Salad Days” for the first time and thought: Yes. I get this. The laid-back grooviness, the moments of introspection undermined by cheeky apathy and hints of l’enfant terrible.

headline: Photos: Baseball, Anyone? Anyone?
abstract: Attendance at ballparks can be spotty this time of year because of the weather, but the first week and a half of the 2014 season has produced some bleak scenes.
lead_paragraph: Attendance at ballparks can be pretty spotty this time of year, when it’s often cold and rainy in many big-league towns. But the first week and a half of the 2014 major league season has produced some especially bleak scenes.

headline: Thanks for the Flair, Mom
abstract: Street style in Elmhurst, Queens is as diverse as the neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: Whether you order Vietnamese noodles, Taiwanese bubble tea or Chinese pastries, one way to experience the diversity of Elmhurst is through the restaurants that line the streets. That’s precisely what drew Nora Li, who moved to New York from China three years ago, to the Queens neighborhood on a recent afternoon. She was buying groceries that included shrimp crackers and instant noodles. Ms. Li, an art student, was wearing an oversize coat with suede details, a beanie and cropped pants exposing her socks and loafers. She described her personal style as “saggy.”

headline: In Sicily, Greek History by Bike
abstract: VBT Bicycling and Walking Vacations is offering a trip in Sicily that has a focus on Grecian sites.
lead_paragraph: Travelers can get a double hit of culture with a new biking trip from the Bristol, Vt.-based travel outfitter VBT Bicycling and Walking Vacations, which focuses on Greek civilization in Sicily.

headline: New Dallas Festival Teams Symphony With Artists
abstract: The goal is encouraging artists and musicians to cross boundaries and challenge “traditional perceptions of what Dallas is.”
lead_paragraph: Over the last three decades Dallas has invested billions in its arts district, a one-stop-shopping location for visual art, dance, classical music and theater. And beginning next year, the various creative disciplines will start trying to get together and experiment more often. The Dallas Symphony Orchestra is set to announce the founding of a new annual arts festival, to be called Soluna, that intends to recruit established visual artists to collaborate with the symphony and with other Dallas-based musical companies and ensembles.

headline: A Director Takes on a World of Nefarious People
abstract: A mix of celebrities and New York literary types attended a screening for the new BBC spy thriller, “Turks and Caicos.”
lead_paragraph: Some directors make movies hoping for awards and accolades. Others for money. David Hare, who wrote and directed the new BBC spy thriller “Turks and Caicos,” had a different objective: to bring down the British government and, while he’s at it, Uncle Sam, too.

headline: Officials on Murrysville School Stabbing
abstract: The chief medical officer at Forbes Regional Hospital, Dr. Mark Rubino, and the Murrysville, Pa., police chief, Thomas Seefeld, provided updates after a student stabbed at least 20 at a high school.
lead_paragraph: The chief medical officer at Forbes Regional Hospital, Dr. Mark Rubino, and the Murrysville, Pa., police chief, Thomas Seefeld, provided updates after a student stabbed at least 20 at a high school.

headline: ‘Frozen’ and ‘Happy’ Reign, While Music Sales Continue to Plunge
abstract: The top of the music charts has been unchanged for weeks, but sales over all have continued their long fall.
lead_paragraph: There’s not much news at the top of the music charts this week. The “Frozen” soundtrack is the No. 1 album for a ninth time, with 149,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and Pharrell Williams’s “Happy” is the top single yet again. That lineup has not changed for a month.

headline: House Hunting on ... the Costa del Sol, Spain
abstract: The coastal area was less affected by the crash of the Spanish real estate market than other areas of the country.
lead_paragraph: A VILLA IN A GATED COMMUNITY ON THE COSTA DEL SOL

headline: Leave Rochelle Out of It, a New Lower East Side Bar
abstract: A bar on the Lower East Side that wins points for originality.
lead_paragraph: As bar names goes, Leave Rochelle Out of It wins points for originality. Named after a mutual ex-girlfriend of two of the proprietors, Brett David and Stephen Yorsz, the bar is a celebration of bro-culture that would make Robert Bly proud. There are more than 150 types of whiskeys, deafening music and racy films.

headline: An Evening Full of Bach, the Father and the Sons
abstract: The Akademie für Alte Musik Berlin performed works by Johann Sebastian Bach and his sons Johann Christian and Carl Philipp Emanuel at Zankel Hall.
lead_paragraph: The final, agitated movement of Johann Christian Bach’s Symphony in G minor, written in 1770, does not so much end as kind of check out. A twisting melodic line in the strings spins delicately upward and trails off. On Tuesday night at Zankel Hall, when the acclaimed period-instrument chamber orchestra Akademie für Alte Musik Berlin finished its fleet, incisive performance of this work, there were gasps of delighted surprise from people in the audience, including one audible “Oh, gee!”

headline: Shift From Paper Complicates Giving Treasury Bonds as Gifts
abstract: The paper-less approach makes it harder to give bonds as presents — and also poses a challenge to those without bank accounts or Internet access.
lead_paragraph: Reginna Peckens, a child care provider in Marietta, Ohio, uses the federal government’s online TreasuryDirect system to buy digital savings bonds for herself. But she hasn’t been able to persuade her mother, who is not computer savvy, to use the system to buy savings bonds to give as gifts, something she used to do regularly. Now, “there are extra steps,” Ms. Peckens said.

headline: Fashion in the Age of Instagram
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Photography', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Smartphones', 'Social Media', 'Fashion Shows']
abstract: The photo-sharing app has changed the way fashion is made, seen and shared.
lead_paragraph: In the Dries Van Noten exhibition at the Musée des Arts Décoratifs in Paris is a video that stitches together sequences from 20 years of his runway shows — a “supercut,” in online argot. On a tour of the show not long ago, Mr. Van Noten nodded along as memorable moments flashed: male models pedaling bicycles, women stalking the length of an enormous dinner table. But what stood out most were the ghostly points of light illuminating the audience’s faces in the recent shows.

headline: A Reporter Analyzes the Driving Role of Pakistan in the Afghan War
abstract: “The Wrong Enemy,” by Carlotta Gall, makes the case that Pakistan is the power behind the war in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: On July 7, 2008, insurgents detonated a huge suicide car bomb outside the Indian Embassy in Kabul, Afghanistan, killing 54 people, including an Indian defense attaché. The attack destroyed the embassy’s protective blast walls and front gates, and tore into civilians waiting outside for visas.

headline: He Sees Dead People, but Through a Stoned Haze
abstract: Tyler Labine stars in a new Hulu Plus comedy series about a well-meaning pothead who helps spirits of the dead find peace.
lead_paragraph: Tyler Labine first made an impression on television as the funny guy in a couple of underrated hourlong shows, the science-fiction drama “Invasion” and the ghostbusters comedy “Reaper.” But since then he has become a sitcom guy, one of those who show up about once a year — “Animal Practice” (NBC, 2012), “Mad Love” (CBS, 2011), “Sons of Tucson” (Fox, 2010) — and go away 9 or 13 episodes later, looking for the next pilot.

headline: Reconciliation Held Together With Bleeding Stitches
abstract: “Coexist,” a documentary by Adam Mazo, examines Rwanda 20 years after the genocide and the hard choices behind the reconciliations between the families of the massacred and their killers.
lead_paragraph: As Rwanda and the world note the 20th anniversary of the genocide in that country, much of the focus has been on reconciliations between the Hutu killers who slaughtered Tutsis and the victims’ family members and friends. “Coexist,” a documentary by Adam Mazo, at first seems as if it is merely going to be another effort to draw feel-good stories out of an impossibly ugly moment in history. But it ultimately proves itself much smarter than that, exploring whether forgiveness that is mandated by the government can be genuine.

headline: A New Line | Lou & Grey’s Soft, Laid-Back Staples Debut With a Dreamy Video
abstract: T premieres a short film by Mark Borthwick, starring the model and illustrator Langley Fox Hemingway.
lead_paragraph: Loft, Ann Taylor’s spinoff brand, has hatched a cool little sister: Lou & Grey, featuring a range of soft, lounge-y layers designed to transition from the sofa to the streets. To commemorate the launch of the line, which will be sold online and at 500 Loft store-in-stores, the brand enlisted the model, illustrator and girl-about-town Langley Fox Hemingway as its muse. Here, T premieres a video, shot by the artist Mark Borthwick in his signature hazy style, of Hemingway cavorting along the coastline in Rio de Janeiro.

headline: A Young Star, Poised and Grounded
abstract: Chloë Grace Moretz is making her stage debut in “The Library,” written by Scott Z. Burns and directed by Steven Soderbergh.
lead_paragraph: While audiences are taking their seats for “The Library,” a new play at the Public Theater written by Scott Z. Burns and directed by Steven Soderbergh, its lead actress, Chloë Grace Moretz, is already onstage.

headline: The Three-Seat Strollers
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Children and Childhood', 'Parenting', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Population', 'Suburbs']
abstract: More couples opt for a third child (or more), but stay in the city.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, Brian Berger, the founder of Mack Weldon, an online purveyor of men’s socks and underwear, saw a close friend surrounded by three siblings at a birthday party. “It was just an amazing experience watching the four of them, and to have all those siblings to go through life together with,” recalled Mr. Berger, 40.

headline: There’s Brightness When the Fog Clears
abstract: Trisha Brown’s “Opal Loop/Cloud Installation #72503” and her “Son of Gone Fishin’ ” headline her company’s stop at New York Live Arts on its long farewell tour.
lead_paragraph: Fog machines in dance performances are usually signs of bad taste. But the fog in Trisha Brown’s 1980 work “Opal Loop/Cloud Installation #72503” is something else. It rolls in as if from the sea, a floating and evanescent cloud of water molecules that is somehow under artistic control.

headline: Now Turning Heads: The Sales Staff
abstract: Employees at Dover Street Market are not models for the store’s clothing; they have their own distinctive styles.
lead_paragraph: THE SCRUFFY YOUNG MAN in the Nike sweatpants is there to help you with that Greg Lauren one-of-a-kind $1,250 cape.

headline: As Comfortable as ...
abstract: Adidas brings back Rod Lavers, beloved of a certain sneaker niche.
lead_paragraph: On a recent morning, a friend sent me an email with the subject “Rod Lavers are back in stock.” A link inside the email opened to a page on the Adidas website that prominently featured, from five different angles, the familiar white-mesh and green-soled sneakers, or Lifestyle Shoes, as the company calls them. They cost $65. The question was not whether to buy a pair but how many to buy.

headline: The Many Alternative Computing Worlds of Linux
abstract: An alternative to Windows or OS X, the open-source operating system comes in a number of varieties, ranging from the familiar to the technical.
lead_paragraph: HAVE you ever wondered what happened to Linux? Linux is the free software created through the open source development process that many technology enthusiasts had predicted would revolutionize the world of computing.

headline: Artists Try to Prick Conscience of Drone Operators With Giant Portrait of Orphan in Pakistani Field
abstract: A campaign started this week, “Not a Bug Splat,” sought to draw attention to the human cost of American drone strikes in Pakistan, and to communicate directly with the pilots who guide the bombers to their targets by remote control.
lead_paragraph: While a series of deadly bombings in Pakistan this week threatens to undermine peace talks between the government and the Taliban, a group of rights activists and artists have started a campaign to draw attention to the human cost of another sort of violence — American drone strikes aimed at militants, which have reportedly killed hundreds of civilians in recent years.

headline: What Awaits Banks After the Leverage Ratio
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Basel Committee is considering rules that will affect banks’ business strategies significantly and continue to influence how they strengthen their auditing and compliance teams for years to come, writes Mayra Rodríguez Valladares in Another View.
lead_paragraph: Mayra Rodríguez Valladares is managing principal at MRV Associates, a capital markets and financial regulatory consulting and training firm based in New York. She is also a faculty member at Financial Markets World and the New York Institute of Finance.

headline: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art to Expand Photography Center
abstract: In 2016, the museum will reopen with one of the country’s largest photography galleries.
lead_paragraph: The San Francisco Museum of Modern Art has long been renowned for its photography collection. Now it will have galleries whose size and scope will match the ambitions of that collection.

headline: Can China Cast Off Despotism?
abstract: A relentless parade of political trials raises a giant question: As China revels in its growing power, is it able or willing to discard ancient habits?
lead_paragraph: It’s no longer politically correct to use the word “Oriental” in the West. But nowhere has the word “despotism” fallen out of favor.

headline: In a Fight for Everything Brooklyn
abstract: The Urban Outfitters concept store can be considered a preservationist gesture, a middle-class beachhead against creeping luxury at every turn.
lead_paragraph: Williamsburg is a middle-aged Italian couple with good scarf game buying coffee and strolling by the water in Bushwick Inlet Park. Williamsburg is a dude in head-to-toe Rick Owens thumbing through techno CDs at the new Rough Trade record shop. Williamsburg is a glass-and-steel tower housing a bunch of 30-something marketing executives proud they avoided buying in Dumbo.

headline: Coming Up Big at the Whitehead Women’s Pairs
abstract: Ran Jingrong and Wang Wenfei, a relatively new partnership from China, won the Whitehead Women’s Pairs in Dallas at the spring North American Bridge Championships on March 28.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Ran Jingrong and Wang Wenfei, a relatively new partnership from China, won the Whitehead Women’s Pairs here at the spring North American Bridge Championships on March 28. They finished more than three boards ahead of Kitty Cooper of Lakeside, Calif., and Lynne Feldman of San Diego. Third were Maritha Pottenger of San Diego and Prudence Saunders of Palo Alto, Calif.

headline: Masters Spots Will Tell IBM’s Story in a New Way
abstract: The company is teeing up about 50 commercials that will run just once during the tournament, aimed primarily at so-called C-suite executives.
lead_paragraph: AS a sponsor of the Masters last year, IBM did what most sponsors did and introduced a few new commercials that ran in heavy rotation during the golf tournament. But this year, in the advertising equivalent of a driving range, IBM is teeing up about 50 commercials that will run just once.

headline: With Declines Slowing, PC Sales Still Struggle
abstract: Two technology market research firms said on Wednesday that worldwide shipments of PCs continued to decline, but at a slower pace than in the past. During the first quarter of the year, IDC estimated that PC shipments fell 4.4 percent from the same period in 2013 while Gartner estimated a drop of 1.7 percent
lead_paragraph: The personal computer market’s fever has broken, but the business is still sick.

headline: For an Hour, Dancing Like Beyoncé
abstract: The dancer’s fans try to get fit by mimicking her moves.
lead_paragraph: With its hardwood floors, big windows and mirrored walls, Chelsea Studios looks like a typical dance rehearsal space. One recent night, about 35 people, mostly 20-something women in Lululemon athletic wear, were loosening up and waiting for the music to start.

headline: Volkswagen Halts Sales of Some Cars Over Transmission Leak
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The company said it was discussing a possible recall with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen said on Wednesday that about 25,000 of its 2014 models may leak transmission fluid, and that it had told dealers to stop selling them while it discusses a possible recall with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Judge Allows Christie Aides to Withhold Bridge Emails
abstract: The decision involving Bridget Anne Kelly and Bill Stepien is a major setback in the legislative inquiry into lane closings at the George Washington Bridge.
lead_paragraph: In a major setback to the legislative investigation into the George Washington Bridge lane closings scandal, a New Jersey judge ruled on Wednesday that two of Gov. Chris Christie’s former aides do not have to comply with subpoenas seeking emails and other communications about the closings and attempts to cover them up.

headline: The Woman and the Giant (No Fable)
abstract: Diane Arbus regarded taking her camera into otherwise off-limit settings as “very perverse” and “a sort of naughty thing to do.”
lead_paragraph: When Diane Arbus and Eddie Carmel met in 1960, each had embarked on a career that seemed willfully disreputable. Carmel, who in adolescence had a wild growth surge as a result of an inoperable pituitary-gland tumor, was exhibited as a giant in circuses and sideshows. For a young New Yorker who had attended City College, it was a louche way to make a living.

headline: The Pleasure Is in the Details
abstract: Eight players from the Marlboro Music festival roster brought a varied program to the Peoples’ Symphony Concert Series.
lead_paragraph: Schubert’s hourlong Octet in F for Winds and Strings can have a pleasantly narcotic effect on the listener, each one of its amply proportioned six movements warping sensations of time and purpose like a carefree summer afternoon. So I didn’t think too much of it at first when I found my mind wandering during Saturday evening’s performance of the work by Musicians From Marlboro, an ensemble from that Vermont-based festival, as part of the Peoples’ Symphony Concerts.

headline: Shopping in Your Closet for Coachella Music Festival
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Hats and Caps', 'Dresses', 'Music']
abstract: Pharrell Williams ignites the high-hat look, Drake inspired T-shirts and glamorous friendship bracelets that would look good in the desert.
lead_paragraph: Music festival season kicks off this weekend with the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival. And even though the haters are huffing, and the hoopla around “festival fashion” is excessive, there are good reasons to be excited this year. For one, Outkast is headlining many of the festivals. For another, assembling your rock-fest look will be a piece of cake. Free-floating dresses, folky prints, fringe, tie-dye — a Coachella undercurrent so infected the spring collections that, come festival time, you’re already there. No need to head to the shops; just come as you are.

headline: Corporate Design: An Energizer Versus an Eyesore
abstract: While LG’s new headquarters would mar views of the New Jersey Palisades, Samsung’s new building is a boon to its city, San Jose, Calif.
lead_paragraph: The rivalry between the South Korean tech giants Samsung and LG isn’t just played out over sales of smartphones and curved television screens. Both companies are building new American headquarters, Samsung in north San Jose, Calif.; LG in Englewood Cliffs, N.J. And on this score, the contest isn’t close. Buildings are corporate symbols and advertisements, after all. Samsung comes across as a good citizen here; LG as a lousy neighbor.

headline: An Artist Demands Civility on the Street With Grit and Buckets of Paste
abstract: Tatyana Fazlalizadeh, a painter and illustrator from Brooklyn, takes her public art project, which focuses on street harassment by men, to Georgia.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — With a lick of wheat paste, a roller and a stepladder, Tatyana Fazlalizadeh, a painter and illustrator from Brooklyn, introduced herself to the South, in an unusual way.

headline: Deadly Wave of Blasts Hits Baghdad
abstract: Eight car bombs and two mortar shells killed as many as 25 people in attacks around the city, according to security personnel.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The Iraqi capital, Baghdad, experienced a series of violent attacks on Wednesday when eight car bombs and two mortar shells killed as many as 25 people in episodes around the city, according to security personnel.

headline: Weathering a Technical Glitch With Puckish Spirit and Catchy Songs
abstract: The singer Neil Finn performed songs from his new album, “Dizzy Heights,” and hits from Split Enz and Crowded House at Town Hall on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Neil Finn’s concert on Tuesday night at Town Hall wasn’t the smoothest show of a long career. But technical glitches only underscored the strength of his songwriting and the puckishness of his spirit. His two-and-a-half-hour set included most of the songs from his new album, “Dizzy Heights,” along with a generous retrospective from his bands Split Enz and Crowded House in the 1980s and his other solo and collaborative projects since the 1990s.

headline: Hit and Run at Day Care in Florida Kills a Child
abstract: A silver Dodge Durango collided with a Toyota convertible, causing the Toyota to crash into the day care center with 50 children in a suburb of Orlando. The driver of the Durango fled.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — A hit-and-run crash sent a car barreling through the wooden wall of a crowded day care center on Wednesday in a suburb of Orlando, killing one girl and injuring 15 people, at least 12 of them children, some of them grievously, the authorities said. One adult was also hospitalized.

headline: Massaging Applicators
abstract: Skin-care products that are fun to apply.
lead_paragraph: The latest gimmick in skin care? Products with massaging applicators. Like the vibrating mascara wand before them, they are fun to use, even if the result is indistinguishable from one achieved with your fingertips.

headline: Personalities Beyond Fists and Faces
abstract: Beyond the classic poses of boxers with fists at the ready, Holger Keifel found a spirit that lingered beyond the ring.
lead_paragraph: Beyond the classic poses of boxers with fists at the ready, Holger Keifel found a spirit that lingered beyond the ring.

headline: A Big Job Might Ruin a Good Thing
abstract: Stephen Colbert looks to be the front-runner to take over David Letterman’s late-night spot, and that may not be the best news for fans of Mr. Colbert.
lead_paragraph: It took one week to go from cancel Colbert to coronate him.

headline: As Ally Prepares for Offering, Government Cuts Stake
abstract: The stock sale will raise about $2.4 billion for the government.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:26 p.m. | The federal government is close to shedding the last remnants of its crisis-era bailouts.

headline: New Kids on the Magazine Rack
abstract: A guide to seven new magazines, each offering its own niche perspective on fashion.
lead_paragraph: Walk into any magazine store in New York City these days, and prepare to be flummoxed by a wall of unfamiliar fashion publications. Once-obscure titles like the Gentlewoman and 032C, which pioneered an indie print resurgence, now share shelf space with dozens of newer and even more obscure magazines, each offering its own niche perspective on fashion — from the irreverent to the fearless. Here’s a guide to seven fashion magazines on the cutting edge of print.

headline: Jamie Dimon Writes of ‘Nerve-Racking’ 2013
abstract: “We came through it scarred but strengthened,” the JPMorgan chief executive says in his annual letter to shareholders.
lead_paragraph: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, has reflected in his annual shareholder letter on a year that was marked by the bank pulling out its checkbook to mend frayed relationships with the federal government — a reconciliation that has already cost around $20 billion.

headline: Despite Doubts, a Vote Worth Casting
abstract: An Afghan journalist recalls his conflicted feelings toward the nation’s first peaceful, democratic transition of power.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — It would be easy for me to say I had no fear going into Election Day. But it wouldn’t be true.

headline: Taking on Art Looters on Twitter
abstract: The archaeologist Monica Hanna is using multiple tools, including social media, to curb the rampant theft of artifacts throughout Egypt.
lead_paragraph: Monica Hanna stood inside the Malawi National Museum in Minya, Egypt, last August, armed only with a cellphone and her Twitter account, as looters ran rampant. Nearly all the objects she had loved since childhood — mummies and amulets, scarabs and carved ibises — were gone. In their place lay shattered glass, shards of pottery, splintered wood and the charred remains of a royal sarcophagus.

headline: Hall of Fame Decides Who Rocks, Officially
abstract: The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inductions take place on Thursday in Brooklyn: Just how does the selection process work?
lead_paragraph: In the beginning, it was obvious who should be inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. Elvis Presley, Chuck Berry, Ray Charles, the Beatles, the Rolling Stones, Little Richard, James Brown, Bob Dylan: All were giants whose selection no one could quarrel with.

headline: What She Did for a Warm Towel
abstract: An aluminum bathroom towel rack and warmer was just what a designer wanted for herself.
lead_paragraph: When designers need inspiration for a new product, some simply look around their own homes and consider what’s missing.

headline: Discounts from Sferra, Marimekko, Intérieurs and Rech!
abstract: Reduced prices on ceramics, lighting and linens.
lead_paragraph: Sferra’s sample sale runs through Sunday at Chelsea Market, with up to 70 percent off prices on bed, bath and table linens (a set of four Crest embroidered linen dinner napkins, originally $75, is about $22); 75 Ninth Avenue (West 15th Street), sferra.com.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Syria, Kenya, India and Central Africa Republic.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Kenya, India and Central Africa Republic.

headline: The Name on the Digital Door
abstract: The tradition of home naming makes a comeback, with a 21st-century twist.
lead_paragraph: Sasha Lord has never met the residents of Hell or Namaste, Om shanti, but she has spent a lot of time thinking about them. For a while, every time Ms. Lord, a 32-year-old band promoter in Arlington, Va., posted a photograph on Instagram from her studio apartment, she was reminded of their existence.

headline: Add Seeds and Soil, Then Stir
keywords: ['Gardens and Gardening', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: “The Plant Recipe Book” offers an ingredient-by-ingredient approach to container gardening.
lead_paragraph: “The Plant Recipe Book” (Artisan, $24.95), by Baylor Chapman, is a follow-up to “The Flower Recipe Book,” and like its successful predecessor offers an ingredient-by-ingredient approach to gardening — container gardening, in this case. The suggested chef’s pantry includes a small trowel, coated wire, a watering can, pruning shears and even actual kitchen tools like a skewer and a turkey baster.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the day’s biggest stories.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: All That’s Missing Is a Necktie
abstract: A bedding collection reminiscent of men’s wear.
lead_paragraph: The Oriole Mill was founded eight years ago by Bethanne Knudson, a textile artist, and Stephan Michelson, a statistical analyst and musician. The couple, who took over a 72,000-square-foot former food processing plant in Hendersonville, N.C., produce jacquard fabric and make most everything to dress a bed (they don’t do sheets). They recently introduced four collections. Two (Cape Cod and Colorado Plateau) are in what’s-not-to-like neutrals, and a third (Charleston) has a cheery blue-and-white pattern. The last, Brooklyn, is a dark departure. “It’s a masculine, urban bed that was inspired by a fabric we make that is reminiscent of men’s wear,” Ms. Knudson said. Prices are $150 for a 20-inch-square pillow to $1,350 for a king-size duvet. Information: 828-693-5500 or theoriolemill.com.

headline: Openings, Events and Sales for the Week of April 10
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Perfumes and Fragrances']
abstract: A debut fragrance from Viktor & Rolf, colorful architectural footwear from Nicholas Kirkwood and more.
lead_paragraph: Openings and Events

headline: Squirrels Are Reading This Now
abstract: Bill Adler first wrote about squirrels in 1988. They’re still bedeviling him, and he’s still writing about it.
lead_paragraph: Almost nothing can come between squirrels and the birdseed they gorge on, not even Led Zeppelin music and mild electrical shocks. For three decades, the humor writer Bill Adler Jr., 57, has collected tips for keeping the rodents away from avian meals. He has updated his 1988 volume, “Outwitting Squirrels: 101 Cunning Stratagems to Reduce Dramatically the Egregious Misappropriation of Seed From Your Birdfeeder by Squirrels” (Chicago Review Press, $16.95), for a new, third edition. (His other books include advice for coping with cranky toddlers, ravenous deer, litigious neighbors and incompetent home contractors.) The field has made some technological advances, he reports, but squirrels still have little else to do all day but strategize.

headline: A Gentleman Returns, With Art
abstract: The Lord Baltimore Hotel returns to its elegant past, thanks to new owners.
lead_paragraph: The Lord Baltimore, yet another down-at-the-heels grand hotel, has been returned to its former elegance, thanks to a renovation that was completed in March.

headline: Should I Fix Those Little Hairline Cracks in My Walls?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Do It Yourself', 'Home Repairs and Improvements']
abstract: Applying self-adhesive fiberglass mesh tape can be an easy fix, but call a professional for more extensive repairs.
lead_paragraph: Q. Should I fix those little hairline cracks in my walls before selling my home?

headline: It’s Mourning in America
abstract: Tracy Martin, head of the new Morbid Anatomy Museum, and Vince Clarke, the synth pop musician, live in a house that reflects both their passions.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in Uniontown, Pa., the Hurley twins, Tracy and Tonya, spent most weekends attending funerals with their grandmother. “In our hometown, Sundays were either for funerals or a Steelers game,” said Tracy, who is now Tracy Martin. “And our grandmother was a funeral fly.”

headline: Egg Cups for the Occasion
abstract: In this season devoted to all things egg, a collector finds little cups of all sorts to put them in.
lead_paragraph: When you’re shopping for egg cups, it makes sense to bring some eggs along with you. How else would you try out the egg cups for size?

headline: Women’s Rights Activist Criticizes Brandeis’s Decision to Cancel Her Honorary Degree
abstract: Ayaan Hirsi Ali, a native of Somalia, said she was shocked that Brandeis University had withdrawn its invitation to give her an honorary degree.
lead_paragraph: Ayaan Hirsi Ali, a women’s rights advocate and critic of Islam, said in a statement on Wednesday that Brandeis University had betrayed the principles of freedom of expression and religion by rescinding an invitation to her to receive an honorary degree.

headline: Photo Diary | Milan Design Week 2014: Boffi
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Design Week photo diary of Danilo Scarpati.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Design Week photo diary of Danilo Scarpati.

headline: Prepping the Mower
abstract: What to do before cutting the grass.
lead_paragraph: What to do before cutting the grass.

headline: Homeowners, Start Your Engines
abstract: Admit it: You’ve neglected your lawn mower. Now it’s time to make up for last year’s lapses.
lead_paragraph: Every November there comes a day when I race into the shed with my trusty lawn mower, fling it into a corner and let loose a fist pump that would give Tiger Woods chills. Is it the final cut of the year? Yup. But you never truly know, so it seems like a good idea not to drain the gas, change the oil or do whatever it is the read-the-manual folks do.

headline: I.M.F. Warns of Risk From Emerging-Market Corporate Debt
abstract: A credit bubble in fast-growing economies could burst, a report said, putting American mutual funds and other global investors in danger.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As fears mount about emerging markets, American mutual fund investors with significant exposure to bonds issued by indebted companies in fast-growing economies may be at risk, the International Monetary Fund warned in a report published on Wednesday.

headline: New York City Reducing Role of Tests in Advancing Students to Next Grade
abstract: Under the new policy, test scores would still be used in judging which students to hold back, but they would not be the dominant factor.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s Education Department, in a break with the data-driven policies of former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, moved on Wednesday to reduce the role of standardized exams in deciding which students to hold back each year.

headline: We Need to Talk About the Test
abstract: Why is there a gag rule on educators who administer state exams?
lead_paragraph: I’D like to tell you what was wrong with the tests my students took last week, but I can’t. Pearson’s $32 million contract with New York State to design the exams prohibits the state from making the tests public and imposes a gag order on educators who administer them. So teachers watched hundreds of thousands of children in grades 3 to 8 sit for between 70 and 180 minutes per day for three days taking a state English Language Arts exam that does a poor job of testing reading comprehension, and yet we’re not allowed to point out what the problems were.

headline: Former S.E.C. Official to Join K.K.R. as Compliance Chief
abstract: Bruce Karpati, a former Securities and Exchange Commission official, is joining the giant private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company as its chief compliance officer.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Karpati, a former Securities and Exchange Commission official, is joining the giant private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company as its chief compliance officer, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

abstract: During snowboard expeditions to Alaska, Jeremy Jones looks for team members who are as versatile as they are dependable. No one embodies this better than the crew’s camp cook.

Jones is a professional snowboarder who has been named big mountain rider of the year 10 times by Snowboarder magazine.

abstract: An admirer of motorcycles, Mr. Tamburini designed two of the most desirable motorcycles, the Ducati 916 and MV Agusta F4.
lead_paragraph: They were objects of unalloyed lust.

headline: Los Angeles’s Future at Risk
abstract: A report on the civic health of the city said that it was barely treading water while the rest of the world was moving forward.
lead_paragraph: A report on the civic health of the city said that it was barely treading water while the rest of the world was moving forward.
