abstract: Goalie Adam Wilcox leads Minnesota into Thursday’s Frozen Four men’s Division I national semifinal against North Dakota in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Like so many things involving hockey in Minnesota, Adam Wilcox’s story began with a couple of youngsters playing in a basement.

headline: Obama Mourns Victims at Fort Hood
abstract: President Obama delivered remarks at the base in Texas and mourned with the families and uniformed comrades of those killed in the shooting last week.
lead_paragraph: President Obama delivered remarks at the base in Texas and mourned with the families and uniformed comrades of those killed in the shooting last week.

headline: Benefits of Fake Meats
abstract: An animal welfare group writes about the advantages of substitutes for meat and eggs.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: College for Criminals
abstract: What Gov. Cuomo’s botched prison education effort says about our society.
lead_paragraph: IN February, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York announced plans to underwrite college classes in 10 state prisons, building on the success of privately funded and widely praised programs like the Bard Prison Initiative. Mr. Cuomo pointed out that inmates who got an education had a much better chance of finding a job and were much less likely to menace their neighbors after release. He noted that the cost — $5,000 per inmate per year — would be a bargain compared with the $60,000 it costs to incarcerate a prisoner for a year.

headline: Even New York Drivers Wowed by a White, Winged Commuter
abstract: An odd moment in which a white pigeon races commuters on a New York highway seems a little less odd after some Googling.
lead_paragraph: I had an extraordinary moment on the Palisades Parkway leaving New York City. In medium traffic moving about 50 miles per hour, with end-of-day sun slanting from the west, I could see something white and, seemingly, winged, flitting and darting within the flow of cars up ahead.

headline: M.L.B. Report Highlights Sobering Number of Black Players
abstract: Even as Major League Baseball works to increase on-field diversity, it reported that just 8.3 percent of players on opening day rosters identified themselves as African-American or black.
lead_paragraph: Dave Dombrowski is the head of baseball’s on-field diversity task force, but he is also the president of the Detroit Tigers. In the last year, as he studied ways to give better opportunities to African-Americans, Dombrowski realized the challenge demanded more than a committee of experts with day jobs.

headline: Parenting the Non-Girlie Girl
abstract: Girls who dress as pirates for Halloween are spunky. Girls who dress as Darth Vader make people uncomfortable.
lead_paragraph: There are many possible explanations for why my 5-year-old daughter has yet again asked if she can change her name to Sam. Sam can also be a girl’s name, I explain hopefully. No, she clarifies, sighing at the dullard she has been given for a mother. She wants to be Sam the boy’s name.

headline: Designing an Eco-Friendly Honeymoon
abstract: Cayuga Sustainable Hospitality, which operates lodges in Costa Rica and Nicaragua, is offering couples a chance to design an “eco-honeymoon.”
lead_paragraph: Cayuga Sustainable Hospitality, a Central American eco-lodge operator with eight properties, is looking for newlyweds to help perfect the “eco-honeymoon” experience.

headline: We Should Be in a Rage
keywords: ['Voting and Voters', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: When will we demand the country we deserve? If we don’t like the path we’re on, we can alter it.
lead_paragraph: Voter apathy is a civic abdication. There is no other way to describe it.

headline: Wayne Henderson, a Founder of the Jazz Crusaders, Dies at 74
abstract: Mr. Henderson, a trombonist and composer, was a founding member of the Jazz Crusaders, which blurred the lines between jazz, funk and pop.
lead_paragraph: Wayne Henderson, a trombonist and composer who was a founding member of the Jazz Crusaders, which played straight-ahead bebop beginning in the 1950s and then morphed into leading performers of jazz-funk, died on April 5 in Culver City, Calif. He was 74.

headline: Layers of Mystery for a Steinway Grand
abstract: Rose Gershwin donated a Steinway grand to Hunter College in 1947, but the family history surrounding the piano has left some perplexed.
lead_paragraph: This is a mystery story, but not a conventional whodunit. It has no dead bodies. No smoking guns. No hard-boiled detectives in trench coats and fedoras.

headline: Mary Cheever, a Central Figure in a Literary Family, Dies at 95
abstract: Mrs. Cheever was part of a tumultuous, complicated and well-chronicled suburban world.
lead_paragraph: Mary Cheever, a central figure in a family of prominent American writers whose most notable member was her husband, John, with whom she had a relationship as complex as those he wrote about in his prizewinning short stories and novels, died on Monday at the home they had shared in Ossining, N.Y. She was 95.

headline: James Hellwig, Wrestling’s Ultimate Warrior, Dies at 54
abstract: Mr. Hellwig, a star of the late 1980s and early ’90s, was inducted into the World Wrestling Entertainment Hall of Fame three days before his death.
lead_paragraph: James Hellwig, a professional wrestler known in the 1990s as the Ultimate Warrior — a frenzied mountain of muscle and face paint who was billed as the heir apparent to Hulk Hogan, but who then fell out of favor — died on Tuesday in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 54.

headline: Russia Didn’t Share All Details on Boston Bombing Suspect, Report Says
keywords: ['Boston Marathon Bombings (2013)', 'United States International Relations', 'Inspectors General']
abstract: Two years before the bombings, Russia declined to give the F.B.I. information that most likely would have prompted deeper scrutiny of Tamerlan Tsarnaev, an inspector general’s review said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Russian government declined to provide the F.B.I. with information about one of the Boston Marathon bombing suspects that would most likely have led to more extensive scrutiny of him at least two years before the attack, according to an inspector general’s report.

headline: Northwestern Requests Review of Labor Ruling
abstract: The university called the decision by one of the board’s regional directors “unprecedented” and argued that the ruling ignored legal precedent and threatened the structure of college sports.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Northwestern on Wednesday formally requested a review of the ruling that its scholarship football players are employees and able to form a union.

headline: Where the G.O.P. Gets It Right
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Education (K-12)', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Republicans actually get some big things right about poverty. Too bad their solutions are mostly wrong.
lead_paragraph: Republicans may seem like ultimate Scrooges. Many want to slash food stamps, unemployment benefits and just about any program that helps the needy.

headline: In a Land of On-Time Arrivals, a Tour of Anything But
abstract: Berlin’s new airport is attracting tourists after a series of delays and bungles have driven its cost billions of dollars over budget and pushed its opening back indefinitely.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — In the early days of aviation, it was common for people to visit airports simply to stand on observation decks and watch the planes come and go. This city’s new airport is attracting tourists for the opposite reason: a conspicuous lack of passengers and planes after a series of delays and bungles that have driven its cost billions of dollars over budget and pushed its opening back indefinitely.

headline: Report Finds Los Angeles at Risk of Decline
abstract: A commission delivered a scathing verdict on the civic health of the city, citing widespread poverty, huge pension obligations and paralyzing traffic with no solution in sight.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — From the 73-story skyscraper that just broke ground downtown (the tallest in the West), to the blizzard of office, shopping and apartment complexes rising from there to the Pacific, construction is bustling in Los Angeles. Home prices are up, and the foreclosure rate is declining. Crime is down. There is a new mayor in City Hall. In many ways, Los Angeles, like many once-beleaguered cities across the nation, seems on the upswing.

headline: U.S. Pair Can’t Leave Qatar Amid Appeal
keywords: ['Americans Abroad', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Sentenced to three years in their daughter’s death, Matthew and Grace Huang of Los Angeles have been denied permission to travel.
lead_paragraph: Matthew and Grace Huang, an American couple entangled in Qatar’s criminal justice system over the death of their adopted daughter, have been denied permission to fly home while the appeal of their three-year prison term is pending, and their lawyers said they might be incarcerated as early as Friday.

headline: Free-for-All in the Cafeteria
abstract: Lunch should be free for all New York City public schoolchildren to eliminate the stigma that comes from being identified as poor.
lead_paragraph: More than a million children attend public schools in New York City. About 780,000 of them are poor enough to qualify for a free or reduced-price lunch. Getting into the program requires some paperwork, which is a burden but not a terrible one; the application is just one page. So why do so many eligible children — about 250,000 — not participate?

headline: Banks Ease Hours for Junior Staff, but Workload Stays Same
abstract: In the last six months, many of the major banks have instituted what amounts to a radically new policy of urging junior staff members to take a few days off a month, on the weekends.
lead_paragraph: The biggest investment banks recently signaled a sea change in their corporate culture, telling their most junior employees to ease up a bit on their hard-charging work schedules.

lead_paragraph: Automakers have a long history of trying to maintain their reputations in the face of major recalls.

headline: A Risk to India’s Nuclear Doctrine
abstract: A troubling campaign proposal by the front-running party in the current national elections could mean revising a “no first use” policy.
lead_paragraph: With India’s national elections in full swing, the campaign promises of the Bharatiya Janata Party, the presumed front-runner to lead the next government, are drawing more scrutiny. Among the more troubling proposals in the party’s election manifesto is one to “revise and update” the country’s nuclear doctrine.

abstract: Some of the cars being recalled by General Motors for problems related to the ignition switch that are still being driven by their owners may still pose a danger to the owner and other motorists.
lead_paragraph: There was nothing but the car key on Jacob Hughes’s key ring.

abstract: After 100 days as mayor, Bill de Blasio is sleeping less than six hours a night, stealing downtime with his son and pledging to “focus even more deeply” on the grass-roots-activist style he took to City Hall.
lead_paragraph: He regrets his public-relations headaches, saying he and his team could have done a better job speaking to the public.

lead_paragraph: My NYRB review of Piketty is up.

headline: Users’ Stark Reminder: As Web Grows, It Grows Less Secure
abstract: The bug known as Heartbleed illustrates that the Internet is still in its youth, and vulnerable to all sorts of unseen dangers, including simple human error.
lead_paragraph: It was the computer programming equivalent of misspelling Mississippi — an error at once careless, inevitable and hard for most human eyes to spot.

headline: An Easy Hole? Only for Those Who Play It Perfectly
abstract: Lengthened to account for modern equipment and bolstered by dozens of new and vexing trees, the 15th hole at Augusta is an anomaly of analytics that helps determine the Masters champion.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The 15th hole at Augusta National Golf Club is statistically one of the easiest in the Masters, a 530-yard par 5 whose green can be reached in two shots, with the field routinely averaging a better-than-par score.

headline: Amid ‘Exploding’ Houses and a Wave of Mud, a Maternal Instinct Flared
abstract: When a landslide swept down on Oso, Wash., last month, it propelled Amanda Skorjanc and her infant son about 600 feet, with the couch they had been sitting on swept along with them.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — What Amanda Skorjanc saw on the morning of the landslide in Oso, Wash., looking out her window with her 22-week-old baby in her arms, was the stuff of nightmares.

abstract: Security researchers say consumers should make sure they change their passwords after a flaw on some websites is fixed, but figuring that out may not be easy.
lead_paragraph: A programming mistake from two years ago has forced countless websites to make fixes to protect the sensitive personal information of consumers.

lead_paragraph: In the excitement of detecting four bursts of signals that might have originated from the flight recorders of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, missing for more than a month, Australian officials have waxed optimistic.

lead_paragraph: Although consumers and health experts will be poring over the newly released Medicare data for months, maybe years to come, one startling piece of information has already emerged, demonstrating some of the complexity inherent in the long-fought-over information on 880,000 health care providers across the country.

headline: Syria: Deadly Car Bomb Blasts Hit Homs
abstract: Two car bombs exploded minutes apart near a shop in the central Syrian city of Homs on Wednesday, killing at least 25 people, state news media and an antigovernment monitoring group reported.
lead_paragraph: Two car bombs exploded minutes apart near a shop in the central Syrian city of Homs on Wednesday, killing at least 25 people, state news media and an antigovernment monitoring group reported.

lead_paragraph: Nearly 3,000 ophthalmologists fell in the top 2 percent of Medicare Part B recipients, each receiving more than $470,000 in payments in 2012.

headline: The Medicare Data’s Pitfalls
abstract: Many doctors said they favored the sharing of Medicare payment data but worried that it left out important details.
lead_paragraph: The release on Wednesday of Medicare payment data is getting mixed reviews from doctors. Many say they favor sharing information but worry that the data presented by Medicare omits important details and may mislead the public and paint an unfairly negative picture of individual doctors.

headline: A Bagful of Memories of a Home in Augusta
abstract: Since the late 1990s, when they first rented from a retired teacher, four caddies have spent every Masters week ensconced in a 68-year-old house in Augusta.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Before the Masters began, four caddies carved out a quiet moment to lift their bottles of beer in a toast to their favorite former nun, a Southern woman whose hospitality survived her death.

headline: Sharpton’s Group Seems Undaunted by His F.B.I. Role
abstract: The annual convention of the Rev. Al Sharpton’s National Action Network began with no hint of discord after reports of his being a federal informer in the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: As new details emerged about his four-year stint in the 1980s as a confidential informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Rev. Al Sharpton thought enough of the attention to hold a news conference to address what became front-page fodder for New York tabloids for two days this week.

headline: The Truth About the Pay Gap
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Discrimination', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Income Inequality', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: The problem persists even in workplaces committed to gender equality, and those who stand in the way of fairness do so at their own peril.
lead_paragraph: Women are the primary or co-breadwinner in 6 out of 10 American families. That makes the economic imperative of addressing the wage gap between women and men important, as is every step President Obama can take in that direction.

headline: Last Criminal Trial Stemming From Occupy Wall Street Is Underway
abstract: A woman is accused of assaulting a police officer who arrested her the night people gathered to observe the founding of the movement, six months earlier.
lead_paragraph: By most accounts, Occupy Wall Street’s moment in the cultural spotlight has passed, and headlines about disaffected New York idealists protesting the wide gap between rich and poor have become scarce.

headline: In Houston, Bush 41 Greets Obama, Who Later Assails G.O.P.
abstract: President Obama and the elder President George Bush have long had a respectful relationship despite past tensions between Mr. Obama and his predecessor, George W. Bush.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — President Obama came to this Texas metropolis on Wednesday to raise money for Democrats, but the first person to welcome him to town was the city’s most prominent Republican, the first President George Bush.

headline: Playing 15 Can Play With Your Head
abstract: The 15th hole at Augusta often plays a crucial role in determining the Masters champion.
lead_paragraph: The 15th hole at Augusta often plays a crucial role in determining the Masters champion.

headline: Japan Pushes Plan to Stockpile Plutonium, Despite Proliferation Risks
abstract: Japan is set to push ahead with a program that would produce new stockpiles of weapon-grade plutonium, creating a proliferation risk for decades to come.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Just weeks after Japan agreed to give up a cache of weapons-grade plutonium, the country is set to push ahead with a program that would produce new stockpiles of the material, creating a proliferation risk for decades to come.

headline: He’s Old, Rich and Dying, and Wants His Nephew’s Girl
abstract: “The Heir Apparent,” adapted by David Ives from the early-18th-century French comedy, is slangy, scatological and very heady, but with the reliable rhythms of a minuet.
lead_paragraph: “This place is fun! A wondrous mess! I wish my every day knew such excess!”

headline: Day Trip Destination
abstract: A wave from David Steinberg.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — I thought this one was relatively easy for a Thursday puzzle and there wasn’t much of a trick to the theme, but I did enjoy all the FLAGS waving at me. The theme hangs together very well, and the cluing is tricky.

headline: De Blasio Is Urged to Alter Housing Plans at Brooklyn Park
abstract: A group of elected officials is calling on Mayor Bill de Blasio to halt plans for two residential towers at Pier 6, one of several recreational piers in Brooklyn Bridge Park.
lead_paragraph: Brooklyn Bridge Park, which stretches 1.3 miles along the East River waterfront, was a creation of the administration of Michael R. Bloomberg, with a novel — and contentious — financing mechanism in the form of luxury housing in the park.

headline: In Maryland, a Political Drama Befitting the Show at Its Center
keywords: ['State Legislatures', 'Law and Legislation', 'Web-Original Programming', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Movies']
abstract: A film production subsidy to guarantee that the hit Netflix series “House of Cards” would continue to film in Maryland cast its shadow over the entire legislative session in Annapolis.
lead_paragraph: ANNAPOLIS, Md. — Where was Frank Underwood when he was really needed?

headline: U.S. Attorney Criticizes Cuomo’s Closing of Panel
abstract: A commission on public corruption, whose credibility had been questioned by watchdog groups, was disbanded by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo as part of budget negotiations.
lead_paragraph: Less than two weeks after Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo abruptly shut down a commission he had formed to investigate political corruption in New York State, the United States attorney in Manhattan is sharply questioning the governor’s decision and is taking possession of all of the panel’s case files, according to letters sent to the commission’s members on April 3 and again on Wednesday afternoon.

headline: On Civil Rights Act Anniversary, Bill Clinton Challenges Lawmakers to Be Bold
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Discrimination', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)']
abstract: Former President Bill Clinton, without mentioning the Affordable Care Act, alluded to it in reminding officials of the sacrifices necessary to advance important legislation.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Bill Clinton’s political awakening came against the backdrop of the civil rights movement and the Vietnam War. Fifty years later, Mr. Clinton observed the anniversary of the passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 with a strong reminder about the sacrifices lawmakers must make to advance sweeping and controversial legislation.

headline: Flight 370 Search Brings Satellite Company an Unaccustomed Bit of Fame
abstract: Inmarsat, the company keeping tabs on the flow of information about Flight 370, has found itself thrust, uncomfortably, into the spotlight.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On an enormous electronic map of the globe in the modernist headquarters of a satellite company here, two green hexagons the size of dinner plates hovered off the west coast of Australia, revealing signals from an armada of ships and planes converged in the hunt for any remains of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

headline: Injury and Math Dim Hopes for Knicks
abstract: With four games remaining for each team, any combination of Atlanta Hawks victories or Knicks losses totaling two would end the Knicks’ chance at the postseason.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Another day as a member of the Knicks meant conditioning work and shooting drills, a focus on the immediate future (four remaining games) and a sad reassessment of the team’s playoff odds (slim to none).

headline: Energy Panel Faulted on Information Safeguards
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Inspectors General', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission may not have adequate controls to protect information that could be used to sabotage the power grid, the Energy Department’s inspector general said.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission may not have adequate controls to protect information that could be used to sabotage the power grid, the Energy Department’s inspector general said on Wednesday. The inspector general, Gregory H. Friedman, issued a “management alert” that was a veiled slap at a former chairman of the commission, Jon Wellinghoff, who has been arguing that an attack last year on a California substation was an act of terrorism, a conclusion that the F.B.I. and local law enforcement officials have refused to endorse. Mr. Friedman said that the commission staff had created a presentation that “should have been classified and protected from release.” The commission generated a memo, later described by The Wall Street Journal, that said that simultaneous attacks on a handful of substations around the country could cripple the power grid. The inspector general said he was acting after a complaint from the Energy Department’s ethics officer and letters from the chairwoman and ranking minority member of the Senate Energy Committee. He recommended establishing a classification system, a step he said the current chairwoman of the commission had promised to implement promptly.

headline: Tanaka Has Highs and Lows, but the Yankees’ Bullpen Has Only the Latter
abstract: Masahiro Tanaka settled down and showed flashes of brilliance in his home debut, but reliever Shawn Kelley allowed two ninth-inning runs in Baltimore’s victory.
lead_paragraph: After a solid but unspectacular major league debut last week, Masahiro Tanaka examined video of his outing to determine what he might have done wrong. He found a slight mechanical flaw, which he declined to identify but aimed to correct.

headline: Profiling Rules Said to Give F.B.I. Tactical Leeway
keywords: ['Racial Profiling', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Terrorism', 'Discrimination', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: The long-awaited revisions to the Justice Department’s racial profiling rules would continue to allow the F.B.I. to use that information for national security purposes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.’s long-awaited revisions to the Justice Department’s racial profiling rules would allow the F.B.I. to continue many, if not all, of the tactics opposed by civil rights groups, such as mapping ethnic populations and using that data to recruit informants and open investigations.

headline: ‘The Americans’ Recap: Spy Games Are Exciting, Until They’re Deadly
abstract: What it means when you drink cheap vodka from a nice glass.
lead_paragraph: Charles Duluth, the K.G.B. agent posing as a conservative journalist whom Philip calls upon for help from time to time, is a very strange character. He has a stiff, patrician voice but is a die-hard Marxist. One imagines him growing up among crusty WASP bankers and thus handily learning to despise capitalism. At any rate, he’s not a particularly great spy, and as Episode 7 begins, Philip can’t get a hold of him, and he desperately needs his help in placing a large bug — “the size of a rat,” Philip complains to the new handler, Kate — on a computing system to gather data from the Arpanet, an Internet prototype.

headline: Wheeler and Mets’ Offense Are No Match for Santana in His Braves Debut
abstract: Ervin Santana pitched shutout ball for eight innings, before the Mets’ three-run rally in the ninth fell short.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Eight games into the season, the Mets were already counting moral victories. They had been blanketed for eight innings, held to three hits by Ervin Santana in his Braves debut. But once Santana left the game, they rallied to score three runs in the ninth, before falling short, 4-3, at Turner Field on Wednesday night.

headline: De Blasio: ‘You Can’t Be Passive in a Role Like This’
abstract: Edited excerpts from an interview with Mayor Bill de Blasio conducted on Wednesday by The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Following are edited excerpts from an interview with Mayor Bill de Blasio conducted on Wednesday by The New York Times:

headline: Lost Season at Least Provides Seasoning for Islanders
abstract: The Islanders, coming off their first playoff appearance since 2007, have long been out of contention, but their young players are getting invaluable experience.
lead_paragraph: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — With three games remaining in a disappointing season, the Islanders cannot be blamed for mulling what might have been.

headline: Already, Nets Rookie Has Signature Moment
abstract: Mason Plumlee has gone from an unsteady rookie at the beginning of this season to a key contributor for the Nets.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Mason Plumlee, the Nets’ 24-year-old rookie center, was reclining at his locker here Wednesday afternoon, shaking his head and laughing about the previous night.

headline: Different Sort of Dog Run: Beside Train, Between Boroughs
abstract: A collie mix ran the path of a Hudson Line train from the Bronx to Upper Manhattan before being rescued by Metropolitan Transportation Authority officers.
lead_paragraph: The urban dog has long lived a singular life. Apartment hallways double as exercise hubs. Sidewalks teem with potential snacks, discarded from bodegas on high.

headline: India Election Digest: April 10
abstract: A roundup of the top election-related news for Thursday.
lead_paragraph: What you need to know about India’s elections on Thursday: Voters in 11 states and three union territories go to the polls — Bihar, Chhattisgarh, Haryana, Jammu and Kashmir, Jharkhand, Kerala, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Odisha, Uttar Pradesh and the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, Chandigarh, Lakshadweep and Delhi.

headline: Chinese Exports and Imports Unexpectedly Fell in March
abstract: The significance of the 6.6 percent drop in exports and 11.3 decline in imports was unclear, because traders have been timing shipments to profit from currency market shifts.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s exports unexpectedly fell in March, and its imports dropped even more sharply, but the significance of the data for the Chinese economy was clouded by uncertainty over the extent to which exporters and importers were timing shipments to profit from currency market shifts.

headline: Putin Warns of Restricting Natural Gas Supply to Ukraine
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin and other senior Russian officials also reiterated the Kremlin’s contention that Ukraine owes Russia more than $16 billion in unpaid gas bills and other debts.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin and other senior Russian officials threatened on Wednesday to restrict supplies of natural gas to Ukraine, and they reiterated the Kremlin’s contention that Ukraine owes Russia more than $16 billion in unpaid gas bills and other debts.

headline: The Importance of Being Nicky
abstract: The prolific decorator Nicky Haslam takes the opportunity to play up his extroverted personality in his new home.
lead_paragraph: The legendary Nicky Haslam’s exuberant interiors are the mark of an audaciously unparalleled man. When it came to decorating his own new home, he threw out all the rules of good taste and embraced the phoniest of fakes.

headline: Vintage Studio Portraits of Indian Women From the Peak of British Colonialism
abstract: In the first installment of a new series from the photo editors of T, we gather a group of amazing 19th and 20th-century images that illustrate the cultural tension between India and its occupying power.
lead_paragraph: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: In Milan, Martino Gamper’s Clever Scheme to Showcase Italian Craft Traditions
abstract: The puckish designer curated a show of appealing objects produced by top designers in collaboration with artisans from the city of Vicenza, and introduced a thoughtful model for selling them.
lead_paragraph: People have been talking about the London-based Italian designer Martino Gamper since the opening of his playful, shelving-focused exhibit “Design Is a State of Mind” at the Serpentine Gallery. This week he also brought his irreverent touch to Milan, where visitors to Salone di Mobile can find his latest work at Nilufar Gallery or admire his windows for the department store Rinascente. Gamper also presented a third project, the exhibition “FROM—TO,” in which he was involved less as a designer, and more as a curator.

headline: The Reinvention of Minimalism
abstract: The architect Joseph Dirand’s sexy, modernist style comes through in his Paris apartment.
lead_paragraph: In his elegantly spare Paris apartment, architect-of-the-moment Joseph Dirand introduces sensuous materials and classical elements to sublime effect.

headline: A ‘Code Death’ for Dying Patients
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Doctors', 'Life-Sustaining Support Systems, Withdrawal Of', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: In this new age of technological wizardry, doctors have been taught that they can, indeed must, do everything possible to stave off death, but few learn how to help their patients die.
lead_paragraph: Sadly, but with conviction, I recently removed breathing tubes from three patients in intensive care.

headline: Heroes of Banking Reform
abstract: Progress is being made by advocates of stricter bank regulation, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz professor of entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Word of the Day | dross
abstract: This word has appeared in nine New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: dross•\ˈdräs, ˈdrȯs\• noun

headline: Orioles Are Impressed, if Not Overly So, by Tanaka
abstract: The Orioles rapped seven hits against Masahiro Tanaka, and a few other hard-hit outs. They also took some wild swings on balls in the dirt, underscoring the quality of the Japanese import’s repertory.
lead_paragraph: Nelson Cruz smirked at the question, more irritated than amused by the suggestion that he might have been curious to see Masahiro Tanaka in person. The hype of a $155 million contract and another pinstriped sensation from Japan did not do much for Cruz, the Baltimore Orioles’ left fielder.

headline: Walmart to Sell Organic Food, Undercutting Big Brands
abstract: The retail giant will carry Wild Oats products that will undercut brand-name organic competitors by at least 25 percent.
lead_paragraph: Walmart plans to announce on Thursday that it is putting its muscle behind Wild Oats organic products, offering the label at prices that will undercut brand-name organic competitors by at least 25 percent.

headline: Pro Bowl to Join Super Bowl in 2015
abstract: The N.F.L. Pro Bowl will be played in Glendale, Ariz., next year, a week before the Super Bowl is held there.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. Pro Bowl will be played in Glendale, Ariz., next year, a week before the Super Bowl is held there. It is the first time the Pro Bowl and Super Bowl will be played in the same city since 2010, when both games were held in Miami Gardens, Fla. The N.F.L. said the Pro Bowl would return to Hawaii in 2016, but the league did not say where the game would be after that.

headline: J & R Closes Manhattan Store for a Redesign
abstract: A Lower Manhattan mainstay for 43 years, J & R Music and Computer World says it hopes to reopen next year.
lead_paragraph: J & R Music and Computer World, a mainstay music and electronics store in Lower Manhattan for 43 years, closed its doors on Wednesday to redesign its space on Park Row.

headline: Times Minute | Why L.B.J. Still Matters
abstract: Today on the Minute, commemorating 50 years since President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Civil Rights Act.
lead_paragraph: Today on the Minute, commemorating 50 years since President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Civil Rights Act.

headline: Golfers Hoping for Winning Introduction to Masters
abstract: Twenty-four Masters rookies are in this year’s field, a modern-era record, increasing the chances that someone will become the fourth player to win in his debut.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Twenty-four Masters rookies are in this year’s field, a modern-era record, increasing the chances that someone will become the fourth player to win in his inaugural Augusta National Golf Club appearance.

headline: What’s on Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE BIG BANG THEORY Sheldon (Jim Parsons, above) has a meltdown after deciding that he is wasting his time on string theory. In “The Millers,” at 8:30, Carol (Margo Martindale) adds her dentist to the Miller Family Blacklist for charging a late fee, so Nathan (Will Arnett) must take his personal relationship with her underground. In “Two and a Half Men,” at 9, Walden (Ashton Kutcher) decides that Kate (Brooke D’Orsay) is the One — until he meets Vivian (Mila Kunis). And in “The Crazy Ones,” at 9:30, Simon (Robin Williams) thinks he may have found the One (Pam Dawber) as well, but he becomes disillusioned with love after Gordon (Brad Garrett) and his partner break up. David Copperfield appears as himself.

headline: In I.P.O., a Quest to Satisfy China’s Appetite for Pork
abstract: The public offering of WH Group will offer investors a chance to bet on a business that is trying to marry China’s apparently insatiable demand for the meat with the efficiency of American pork production.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — There is a commodity creating ravenous demand among China’s growing consumer class, one whose pricing is so important that it influences the Chinese central bank’s monetary policy. The commerce ministry even maintains strategic reserves and has been piling them higher in recent weeks in an attempt to stabilize prices.

headline: Corrections: April 10, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on April 10, 2014.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: In French Premier’s Blend of Socialism, Conservative and Centrist Notes
abstract: Prime Minister Manuel Valls is more centrist on social issues, more conservative economically and more combative than President François Hollande, who appointed him.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France’s new prime minister introduced the country this week to his particular brand of Socialist Party politics: more centrist on social issues, more conservative economically and more combative than the man who appointed him, President François Hollande.

headline: What’s Next in the Search for Flight 370
abstract: Investigators have narrowed down the search area for the missing Malaysian jetliner, but it could be weeks or months before they find any trace of the plane.
lead_paragraph: Investigators have narrowed down the search area for the missing Malaysian jetliner, but it could be weeks or months before they find any trace of the plane.

headline: Setting Up an Election in the World’s Largest Democracy
keywords: ['Elections', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Tents', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Voting Machines']
abstract: The chief electoral officer in Uttar Pradesh, India’s most populous state, said the enormous task is “not an ordinary job, but a mission.”
lead_paragraph: MEERUT, India — Raj Singh endured hot winds as he feverishly operated a sewing machine outdoors to repair tents that had ripped in a storm the night before.

headline: Dogged Prosecutor Seeks to Paint Pistorius as a Bully
abstract: The South African athlete Oscar Pistorius, accused of killing his girlfriend, faced new questions from the state prosecutor, Gerrie Nel, about his relationship and his experiences firing guns.
lead_paragraph: Oscar Pistorius, the South African athlete accused of murdering his girlfriend, faced new questions on Thursday from a dogged prosecutor intent on depicting him as a narcissistic bully who routinely berated her and recklessly carried a loaded gun everywhere he went.

headline: Test Yourself | English, April 10, 2014
abstract: Can you choose the best antonym for “contrite,” as it is used in the article?
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: Students End Occupation of Taiwan’s Legislature
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Their departure concludes the most dramatic confrontation over ratification of a trade agreement with China.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:20 a.m.ET | Hundreds of protesters who occupied Taiwan’s legislature for more than three weeks decamped Thursday evening, bringing to an end a standoff over the handling of a trade pact with China.

headline: Piramal to Sell Vodafone India Stake for $1.48 Billion
keywords: ['Indian Rupee (Currency)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Telephones and Telecommunications']
abstract: Piramal Enterprises, the largest minority investor in Vodafone India, has agreed to sell its stake in the telecommunications provider as part of a bid by Vodafone to take full control of the unit.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Piramal Enterprises, the largest minority investor in Vodafone India, said Thursday that it had agreed to sell its entire stake in the business to the British telecommunications company Vodafone.

headline: In Mongolia, a Gift Horse for Hagel
abstract: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel named the horse Shamrock, but the traditional gift from Mongolia to American officials typically does not make its way back to the United States.
lead_paragraph: ULAN BATOR, Mongolia — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel knew even before he landed here that there was no way he could keep the horse.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Student Stabs 20 People at High School Near Pittsburgh
abstract: What do you think officials should do to prevent violence in schools?
lead_paragraph: In “Student Stabs 20 People at High School Near Pittsburgh,” Timothy Williams and Emma G. Fitzsimmons report on a mass knife attack on Wednesday.

headline: Bomb Explodes Outside Greek Central Bank
keywords: ['Bombs and Explosives', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: No one was hurt in the explosion in Athens, which took place hours before Greece was to start issuing long-term bonds for the first time since 2010.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — A large car bomb exploded outside Greece’s central bank Thursday morning, shaking buildings for blocks around but causing no injuries.

headline: European Union Debates Initiative on Embryo Protection
abstract: A hearing was held on a petition bearing 1.8 million signatures that would ban the use of European funds for activities such as stem-cell research.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — A packed hearing on a petition calling for the protection of human embryos led to a rare outbreak of raucous exchanges in the European Parliament on Thursday — a sign that the battles over abortion and stem cell research that divide nations like Spain and the United States are making a serious incursion into European Union affairs.

headline: The Paramedic Murderer of Narrowsburg, N.Y.
abstract: Paul Novak had numerous certified saves. And one kill. How a case of a mysterious death in this small town was finally solved.
lead_paragraph: In the hills around Narrowsburg, N.Y., where second-home owners tend gardens and the Lenape once roamed, people don’t forget a mysterious death. They still talk about the bar owner who shot his waitress in the chest late one night and served just six months in jail after saying it was an accident. Then there was the story about the man who arrived home one night only to notice that his wife, who had been in the back seat, was no longer in the car. Her body was found on the side of a road along the route he’d taken. Charges were never filed.

headline: Personalities Beyond Fists and Faces
abstract: Beyond the classic poses of boxers with fists at the ready, Holger Keifel found a spirit that lingered beyond the ring.
lead_paragraph: Holger Keifel spent eight years as a shadow in the court of boxing royalty, making portraits of fighters, trainers and promoters in the corners of rooms where he did not belong. The best of three or four frames captured in the fleeting moments of a news conference, weigh-in or short breathers between sparring sessions — each was a jab.

headline: Drinking Milk Linked to Arthritis Relief
abstract: A large study has found evidence that milk consumption may slow the progression of knee arthritis.
lead_paragraph: A large study has found evidence that milk consumption may slow the progression of knee arthritis.

headline: Do You Like to Exercise?
abstract: How do feel while you are exercising? What about afterward?
lead_paragraph: A recent genetics study of lab rats seems to suggest that the motivation to exercise — or not — may be partly inherited, at least for small rodents. Perhaps some of us are born to enjoy exercise, while others — not so much.

headline: Group Says It Has Raised Over $1.7 Million for Hillary Clinton
abstract: Ready for Hillary said it is hoping to build a campaign-ready infrastructure and donor base should Mrs. Clinton decide to run for president.
lead_paragraph: Ready for Hillary, the independent group devised to build support for Hillary Rodham Clinton’s potential 2016 presidential campaign, said Thursday that it had brought in 22,000 new donors and raised more than $1.7 million in the three-month period that ended March 31.

headline: New York Today: Take Out the Compost
abstract: What you need to know for Thursday: The city expands compost collection, the fair weather holds, and the mayor reflects on his first 100 days.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday morning to you.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: What you need to know to start your Thursday: civil rights 50 years later, organic food competition, and rock and roll hall of famers.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Free to Be Mean: Does This Student Satire Cross the Line?
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Newspapers', 'Comedy and Humor']
abstract: The Koala, a satirical tabloid at San Diego State, may be the most offensive student publication out there. So why is it still on campus?
lead_paragraph: On a recent cloudless afternoon, a group of young comedy writers — one in Ray-Bans and a floppy wizard hat, another in skateboard sneakers and funky jeans — descended upon San Diego State University’s palm-tree-dotted campus, brandishing copies of their latest creation: a 12-page broadsheet of lewd humor.

headline: Papyrus Referring to Jesus’ Wife Is More Likely Ancient Than Fake, Scientists Say
abstract: The test results do not prove that Jesus had a wife, only that the fragment of papyrus with the phrase, “Jesus said to them, ‘My wife,’” is most likely not a forgery.
lead_paragraph: A faded fragment of papyrus known as the “Gospel of Jesus’s Wife,” which caused an uproar when unveiled by a Harvard Divinity School historian in 2012, has been tested by scientists who conclude in a journal published on Thursday that the ink and papyrus are very likely ancient, and not a modern forgery.

headline: Tesla’s Lightweight Solution to Preventing Model S Fires
abstract: The automaker’s “triple underbody shield” includes a titanium plate, but it does not turn the vehicle into an all-terrain tank.
lead_paragraph: A cloud of doubt lingering over Tesla Motors parted on March 26, when the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration closed an investigation of the Model S begun in response to two cars that were destroyed by fires after striking objects on the highway.

headline: The Trouble With Too Much T
abstract: A female athlete with naturally high testosterone faces humiliating sex testing and worse.
lead_paragraph: In 2009, the South African middle-distance runner Caster Semenya was barred from competition and obliged to undergo intrusive and humiliating “sex testing” after fellow athletes at the Berlin World Championships questioned her sex. Ms. Semenya was eventually allowed to compete again, but the incident opened the world’s eyes to the process of sex testing and the distress it could bring to an athlete who had lived her whole life as a girl. When an endocrinologist, a gynecologist and a psychologist were brought in to determine whether the teenager was really a woman, she simply asserted, “I know who I am.”

headline: Daily Report: As the Internet Grows, It Grows Less Secure
abstract: The bug known as Heartbleed illustrates that the Internet is still in its youth, and vulnerable to all sorts of unseen dangers, including simple human error.
lead_paragraph: It was the computer programming equivalent of misspelling Mississippi — an error at once careless, inevitable and hard for most human eyes to spot, Farhad Manjoo writes in his State of the Art column.

headline: China Sets Hong Kong-Shanghai Trading Deal
abstract: China has announced a plan, seven years in the making, to allow two-way investment between the Shanghai and Hong Kong stock exchanges.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — It was a seven-year wait, but China on Thursday finally announced a plan to allow two-way investment between the Shanghai and Hong Kong stock exchanges.

headline: Who Are Hit Men?
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Organized Crime']
abstract: The most mysterious, the masters, are ghosts who never work where they live.
lead_paragraph: STORNOWAY, Scotland — Everyone starts as a novice, whatever your job. You bumble around, make mistakes, learn by doing. It applies in any walk of life, and the criminal industry isn’t any different. A team from Birmingham City University’s Center for Applied Criminology has carried out the first typological study of British hit men, and it starts, of course, with the novice.

headline: In Our Pages: April 11
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A new invention claims to do away with eavesdropping on the telephone in 1914; an agreement is signed on limiting Algerian immigration to France in 1964.
lead_paragraph: 1914: Eavesdropping End Promised

headline: Photos: The Making of the Masters
abstract: From the photography archive, a sweeping look at the Masters golf tournament and Augusta National Golf Club, which was founded in 1933.
lead_paragraph: When Augusta National Golf Club opened in 1933, there were few hints at the grandeur of its future. Bobby Jones, having retired from golf as an amateur at age 28, wanted a place to play golf in private. After winning 13 major titles, he was swarmed at any golf course he strolled on to, so he sought a course of his own, where he could invite his friends to join as members. Clifford Roberts, an investment banker and friend, helped him acquire the 385 acres that would become Augusta National and together they steered their little club into history.

headline: It’s Official: No Deductible Caps in Small-Business Health Plans
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Small Business']
abstract: The legislative fix may allow small-business owners to shift some of their health care costs to their workers.
lead_paragraph: Tucked inside the so-called Medicare “doc fix” bill — must-pass legislation to forestall steep cuts in payments to doctors — that President Obama recently signed was a separate provision that removed restrictions on deductibles in small-business health plans. As a result, small-business owners may be able to shift some of their health care costs, especially as they increase, to their workers.

headline: Twitter and Facebook Wield Little Influence on TV Watching
abstract: New research suggests that when Americans decide to watch a television show, they’re not paying much attention to social networks.
lead_paragraph: Listen to executives at Twitter and Facebook talk about how we watch television and you might walk away thinking that Americans are chattering nonstop on the social networks while watching their favorite shows.

headline: The Oscar Pistorius I Knew
abstract: In January 2012, Michael Sokolove wrote a profile of Oscar Pistorius, who this week took the stand to defend himself in his murder trial.
lead_paragraph: Michael Sokolove, a contributing writer to The Times Magazine, wrote a cover article in 2012 on Oscar Pistorius, who is now being tried in the shooting death of his girlfriend.

headline: RLM Finsbury Names New President
abstract: RLM Finsbury, a strategic communications firm, said on Thursday that Stephen Labaton would become its United States president.
lead_paragraph: RLM Finsbury, a strategic communications and advisory firm, said on Thursday that Stephen Labaton would become its United States president.

headline: Bank of England Holds Key Rate at 0.5%
abstract: The central bank has not changed its benchmark rate since March 2009. It also left unchanged a stimulus program of holding 375 billion pounds in government bonds.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Bank of England on Thursday left a key interest rate unchanged at a record low, as Britain’s economy continues to recover and inflation remains in decline.

abstract: Today on the Minute, commemorating 50 years since President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Civil Rights Act.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Tachyus, a Data Start-Up for Oil Industry, Raises $6 Million From Founders Fund
abstract: The start-up is an anomaly of sorts in Silicon Valley because it aims to create an array of sensors and mobile applications to help oil and gas producers better record and analyze their wells.
lead_paragraph: Since graduating from Stanford in 2011, Dakin Sloss has already co-founded two start-ups, including the government data analysis company OpenGov.

headline: Authorities Cast Doubt on Signal in Jet Search
abstract: Australian authorities searching for the missing Malaysia Airlines plane said the latest potential signal was probably not from the flight recorders, despite hopes raised earlier.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The Australian authorities searching for the missing Malaysia Airlines plane said Friday that the latest potential signal was probably not from the flight recorders, despite hopes raised the previous day.

headline: Coffee, Tea or Liberation?
abstract: As the final season of “Mad Men” begins, the ’60s wind down, bringing a sour end to seemingly sweet horizons but offering bright promise for all those secretaries.
lead_paragraph: So many momentous things happened in 1969.

headline: Watch Proteins Do the Jitterbug
abstract: The animators who produced the video hit “The Inner Life of a Cell” are back with a look at the messy, chaotic dance performed by molecules in a neuron.
lead_paragraph: If you could shrink down to the size of a molecule and fly into a cell, what would you see?

headline: Morning Agenda: Junior Banker Blues
abstract: Junior bankers are still working long hours despite new policies. | Four rival offers for Detroit’s art could be an obstacle for the city as it tries to resolve its bankruptcy. | Ally prepares for its I.P.O. | Procter & Gamble sells most of its pet food brands to Mars.
lead_paragraph: JUNIOR BANKERS STILL WORK LONG HOURS  |  In the last six months, many of the biggest investment banks have signaled a sea change in their corporate culture, telling their most junior employees to ease up a bit on their hard-charging work schedules and take a few weekend days off. But like other practices on Wall Street, the more things change, the more they stay the same, William Alden and Sydney Ember write in DealBook.

headline: R.B.S. Agreement Opens Door for Future Dividends
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: The Royal Bank of Scotland, which is 81 percent owned by the British government, has agreed to retire a financial structure that entitled the government to preferred dividends.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Royal Bank of Scotland has reached a deal with the British government that will pave the way for it to pay dividends in the future.

headline: All Eyes on Delhi As It Goes To Vote
abstract: The three-way race for the capital’s seven parliamentary seats could be a bellwether of the national elections.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The nation’s capital went to the polls on Thursday in a three-way race for Delhi’s seven parliamentary seats that could be a bellwether of the national elections.

headline: Ending Vitriol, Icahn and eBay Reach a Deal
abstract: Carl Icahn will withdraw his bid for two seats on eBay’s board and end his demand that the company sell a minority stake in its PayPal unit to shareholders. In return, eBay will add a new director both sides agreed on.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Carl C. Icahn appeared ready to take no prisoners in his battle with eBay, calling the online commerce giant among the worst-run companies he had ever seen.

headline: Taking a Risk, Investors Snap Up Once-Shunned Greek Debt
abstract: After investors flocked to its five-year debt offering, Athens said it was a sign that the country was succeeding in turning its economy around.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Investors shunned Greek bonds at the height of the European economic crisis, fearful that the region’s sickest nation would collapse from its financial woes.

headline: Seeking More From Chinese Films
abstract: A jury at the China Film Directors’ Guild awards refused to award the two top prizes — for film and director of the year — saying that Chinese films need to meet “a higher standard.”
lead_paragraph: There was a sting to the China Film Directors’ Guild awards in Beijing this week, when the director Feng Xiaogang, the head of the jury, announced that the guild would not award the top prizes — film of the year and director of the year. The reason? No film in contention was good enough: Chinese films need to meet “a higher standard,” Mr. Feng said.

headline: Massacre in a Nairobi Mall
abstract: The Shabab, an Islamist militant group based in Somalia, took responsibility for the attack, saying it was revenge for Kenya’s military operations in Somalia.
lead_paragraph: The Shabab, an Islamist militant group based in Somalia, took responsibility for the attack, saying it was revenge for Kenya’s military operations in Somalia.

headline: G.M. Places 2 Engineers on Leave in Inquiry
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: The company said the two were suspended with pay as an “interim step” in its investigation of ignition problems that persisted for years.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The ignition-switch scandal at General Motors widened on Thursday as the automaker suspended two engineers and added another repair to its recall of cars with a faulty ignition switch that has been linked to 13 deaths.

headline: The Woman Within
abstract: Reed Birney and Patrick Page, actors in Harvey Fierstein’s new Broadway play “Casa Valentina,” learn the art of cross-dressing.
lead_paragraph: Reed Birney and Patrick Page, actors in Harvey Fierstein’s new Broadway play “Casa Valentina,” learn the art of cross-dressing.

headline: Clothes Make the Man
abstract: Cross-dressers shed their gray flannel suits and bond at a 1960s Catskills resort in Harvey Fierstein’s new play, “Casa Valentina.”
lead_paragraph: Before rehearsals began for the new Broadway play “Casa Valentina,” the seven men in the cast were asked to come to work a few days early. They arrived to find a huge table covered with ladies’ wigs in ’60s-era hairdos — flips, bobs, French twists. Nearby was a long rack of colorful house dresses and white slips and brassieres. Yet no one made a move. The actors shared small talk, sipped coffee, checked their smartphones and looked around as if the room were empty.

headline: Ruth Rathblott, of Harlem Educational Activities Fund, on Seeking Opportunities
keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'Careers and Professions', 'Executives and Management (Theory)']
abstract: Ms. Rathblott says building a skill set is more important than accumulating new titles.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Ruth Rathblott, chief executive of the nonprofit Harlem Educational Activities Fund, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: U.S. Court Seems Split on Utah Gay Marriage Ban
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Appeals Courts (US)']
abstract: Judges sparred with lawyers about how such bans affected the children of same-sex parents and whether preventing gay couples from marrying actually strengthened heterosexual unions.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — The push for same-sex marriage, which has celebrated victory after victory in courtrooms across the country, entered an uncertain stage on Thursday as a federal appeals court appeared divided about whether the socially conservative state of Utah could limit marriage to a man and a woman.

headline: Fast-Growing Sectors Drive a Market Sell-Off
keywords: ["Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Nasdaq Composite Index', 'Dow Jones Stock Average']
abstract: Despite strong data on new claims for unemployment, investors were taking defensive positions and selling so-called momentum stocks.
lead_paragraph: Investors dumped Internet, biotechnology and other fast-growing companies at a dizzying pace on Thursday, dragging down the rest of the stock market and stirring up painful memories of the dot-com bust in 2000.

headline: Michael Lewis: By the Book
abstract: The author of “Liar’s Poker,” “The Blind Side” and, most recently, “Flash Boys” says it’s hard to dramatize the quotidian in a way that makes it fresh for readers: “It’s like describing the air we breathe.”
lead_paragraph: The author of “Liar’s Poker,” “The Blind Side” and, most recently, “Flash Boys” says it’s hard to dramatize the quotidian in a way that makes it fresh for readers: “It’s like describing the air we breathe.”

headline: From Smallest of Clues, Flying Reptiles Reborn
abstract: “Pterosaurs: Flight in the Age of the Dinosaurs,” an exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History, prompts reflection on the unpredictable nature of evolution.
lead_paragraph: About 220 million years ago, as we learn at a thoroughly entrancing new exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History, a fish caught a pterosaur, chewed it up and spit out the pieces. The expelled mass eventually fossilized, creating what is decorously called a “gastric pellet.” We see its cast here: a compact, egg-size mound of spindly, bent, broken and crushed sticks.

headline: Don’t Hoodwink the Help, Dear
abstract: “Hateship Loveship” tells of a new housekeeper for a disturbed Iowa family and the damage that ensues when a prank is played on her.
lead_paragraph: In the first moments of our acquaintance with Johanna Parry — before the opening titles of “Hateship Loveship” appear on screen, and before the first notes of music have sounded — we know some important things about her. We note her kindness as she grants an old woman’s dying wish, and also her practicality and physical strength. Other people will perceive Johanna as drab, passive and unworldly, a person to be quietly mocked or carelessly ignored, but the first shots of Liza Johnson’s new film, adapted from a story by the Canadian Nobel laureate Alice Munro, provide important evidence to the contrary.

headline: Qatar Investment Executive Said to Start Hedge Fund
abstract: Kamel Maamria’s new fund will be one of relatively few based and focused on the Middle East, with offices in both Qatar and Dubai.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A top investment executive at Qatar’s sovereign wealth fund is leaving to start a hedge fund, people briefed on the development said.

headline: Why Students Are Tested, and Why Some Parents Opt Out
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'No Child Left Behind Act', 'Parenting', 'Tests and Examinations']
abstract: Schools haven’t been penalizing families who opt out, whether as an objection to standardized testing or to avoid the anxiety high-stakes testing elicits in some children.
lead_paragraph: Amid protests and debate, “unprecedented” numbers of students opted out of New York State’s English Language Arts testing this month. Some parents opted out as a way to voice their objections over the practice of administering federally mandated standardized tests, others because of concerns over how test results are used to evaluate schools and teachers. Many parents are simply confused about the origin and purpose of the standardized tests all children are required to take and what it means to opt out of them. Consequently, I thought I’d use this week’s column to explain the nuts and bolts of standardized testing and opt-outs.

headline: House Tour | Joseph Dirand
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The architect takes T through his luxuriously minimal Paris apartment and discusses why he favors function over form in decoration.
lead_paragraph: The architect takes T through his luxuriously minimal Paris apartment and discusses why he favors function over form in decoration.

headline: 36 Hours in Seville, Spain
abstract: Go on a tapas crawl, take a high-tech tour and even do a little late-night dancing during a weekend in the Andalusian capital.
lead_paragraph: You don’t have to spend long in Seville to see why so many operas have been set there. A sense of drama pervades the Andalusian capital, from its Moorish royal palaces and extravagant Catholic festivals to the way the strum of a guitar tends to send a whole room into syncopated clapping. Maybe it’s this penchant for pomp that keeps the city dynamic in lean times. At contemporary-minded shops, restaurants and arts spaces that continue to open among Seville’s tangle of narrow stone alleyways, a friendly localism seems to rule the day.

headline: How the Aam Aadmi Party Lost Its Way
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Elections', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: After a surprising victory in the Delhi State elections, a series of strategic mistakes have arrested what at one point seemed the party’s irresistible momentum.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — One morning last December, I traveled from my house to Ramlila Maidan, a sprawling area in central Delhi, where Arvind Kejriwal, the leader of the Aam Aadmi Party, was to be inaugurated as the city’s new chief minister.

headline: Briton Named President of ABC News
keywords: ['Television', 'News and News Media', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: With the promotion, two of the three broadcast network news divisions in the United States will be led by British journalists.
lead_paragraph: ABC put in place the missing piece of its succession plans Thursday, naming James Goldston the president of ABC News, replacing Ben Sherwood.

headline: ScienceTake: Those Clever Crows
abstract: Scientists are trying to understand the limits to the well-established intelligence of crows.
lead_paragraph: Scientists are trying to understand the limits to the well-established intelligence of crows.

headline: The Moral: Aesop Knew Something About Crows
abstract: Researchers set out to see if a crow would raise the water level in a tube by dropping stones in it, as in Aesop’s fable. This video shows the result.
lead_paragraph: Crows and their relatives, like jays and rooks, are definitely in the gifted class when it comes to the kinds of cognitive puzzles that scientists cook up.

headline: Shares in Ally Dip in Their Debut
abstract: Shares in Ally ended down 4 percent below the company’s initial public offering price. Underwriters had already priced the stock sale at the low end of an expected range.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 6:17 p.m. |

headline: Indian Candidate’s Biography Has an Asterisk: A Wife, of Sorts
abstract: Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party has stressed the advantages of his bachelorhood in his run for prime minister, but now he has acknowledged an arranged marriage about 45 years ago.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — At a campaign rally this year, Narendra Modi, leader of the Bharatiya Janata Party, offered this curious qualification for the post of India’s prime minister: He could not possibly be corrupt because he is a bachelor.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘A Poem of Changgan’
abstract: “A Poem of Changgan” by Li Po and the Sunday Review article “Romance at Arm’s Length” by Daniel Jones appear in this Poetry Pairing.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Poetry Pairing features “A Poem of Changgan” by Li Po and the Sunday Review article “Romance at Arm’s Length” by Daniel Jones.

headline: Day 2 of Pistorius Cross-Examination
abstract: The Paralympic athlete Oscar Pistorius returned to the stand to face new questions from the state prosecutor, Gerrie Nel, on the fourth day of the defendant’s testimony in Pretoria, South Africa.
lead_paragraph: The Paralympic athlete Oscar Pistorius returned to the stand to face new questions from the state prosecutor, Gerrie Nel, on the fourth day of the defendant’s testimony in Pretoria, South Africa.

headline: Does the Rock Hall of Fame Matter?
abstract: Amid the usual debate about who belongs in the Hall of Fame and who gets to decide, why should music lovers care?

headline: Will ‘House of Cards’ Deal Elsewhere?
abstract: The show’s producers want Maryland to increase filming subsidies.
lead_paragraph: House of Cards, the Netflix depiction of a Machiavellian America, has been tight with the government of Maryland. So tight, in fact, that it has enjoyed not just $26.7-million in show business tax credits for filming its award-winning production there, but also use of the legislature’s debating floor as an occasional set.

headline: It’s Time for Africa’s Green Revolution, Focused on Corn
abstract: A look at the steps required to spark a green revolution in Africa.
lead_paragraph: I hope you’ll read Tina Rosenberg’s latest Fixes post — “A Green Revolution, This Time for Africa.” The first Green Revolution, in Asia, was centered on rice and wheat. Rosenberg lays out the case for an African focus on corn (known as maize almost everywhere else in the world):

headline: Justice Dept. Accuses Albuquerque Police of Excessive Force
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Police officers, who have killed 23 people in four years, have too often used deadly force against nonthreatening people, and seldom were they reprimanded, a Justice Department investigation found.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — At least 37 times in the last four years, police officers here have responded to threats with bullets, killing 23 people and wounding 14 others. On Thursday, the Justice Department weighed in with a scathing assessment, accusing the Albuquerque Police Department of a “pattern or practice of use of excessive force” that routinely violated people’s constitutional rights.

headline: Today in Small Business: Saving the Family Business
abstract: A small company offers cheaper web hosting than Amazon. South Carolina small businesses prepare for rising sea levels. And Pizza Hut invades Iraq.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: A Picture Becomes a Weapon in a Bank’s Proxy Battle
abstract: An activist investor used a photo of a bank’s chairman napping at a shareholder meeting in an attempt to influence an election for board members.
lead_paragraph: “Below is a picture taken at last year’s annual shareholder meeting of our bank’s chairman,” the two-sentence shareholder letter from the activist investor Joseph Stilwell began. “None of the other board members bothered to wake him up.”

headline: U.N. to Send Peacekeepers to Central African Republic
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: The Security Council passed a resolution authorizing 12,000 peacekeepers to do whatever was necessary to protect civilians in the fractured country.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations Security Council on Thursday voted unanimously to send 12,000 peacekeepers authorized to do whatever necessary to protect civilians in the Central African Republic, where a vicious sectarian conflict has effectively partitioned the country into Christian and Muslim swaths and left a trail of gruesome killings.

headline: Quebec City Festival Offers Music Fans a Summer Bargain
abstract: Festival passes to the 300-performance event in Quebec City go for just $72.
lead_paragraph: The Festival d’été de Québec, now in its 47th year, will offer more than 300 performances in Quebec City, from July 3 to 13, the festival announced on Thursday. The festival bills itself as Canada’s largest outdoor music event (although it presents shows at indoor venues as well). It is also one of the bargains of the festival circuit: a festival pass, which allows access to all shows, is priced at 78 Canadian dollars (about $72); the first 60,000 passes will sell for 68 Canadian dollars (about $62). A spokesman said that 300,000 people attended the festival last summer.

lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department has issued mandatory protocols for officers entering buildings in response to fires, after an officer responding to a blaze in a Brooklyn high-rise died.

headline: Colbert Will Host ‘Late Show,’ Playing Himself for a Change
abstract: Stephen Colbert became the immediate front-runner for the position both because of an increasing recognition of his talent and because he clearly wanted the job.
lead_paragraph: CBS made its choice, quickly and definitively: Stephen Colbert will succeed David Letterman as the host of its late-night franchise, which Mr. Letterman created when he came to the network in 1993.

headline: In Villages Torn by Violence, Traditional Loyalties at Risk
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Elections', 'Hinduism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Hindus in the Muzaffarnagar district of Uttar Pradesh said that they had voted for the Bharatiya Janata Party, in many cases for the first time.
lead_paragraph: FUGANA, India — Sakur Ahmed, an ironsmith, is a member of the only Muslim family left in the village of Fugana, in the northern state of Uttar Pradesh, where violence between Muslims and Hindu Jats erupted in September. When Muslims fled the village, Mr. Ahmed, protected by a Hindu neighbor, chose to stay.

headline: Bomb Explodes Outside Bank of Greece
abstract: The deputy prime minister of Greece, Evangelos Venizelos, spoke after a large car bomb exploded outside Greece’s central bank on Thursday morning.
lead_paragraph: The deputy prime minister of Greece, Evangelos Venizelos, spoke after a large car bomb exploded outside Greece’s central bank on Thursday morning.

headline: Cuomo Caught Up in Rare Conflict With Prosecutor
abstract: Preet Bharara, the top federal prosecutor in Manhattan, said Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo had disbanded a corruption panel prematurely and that his office would pursue unfinished investigations.
lead_paragraph: IRONDEQUOIT, N.Y. — An unusually public confrontation between two of the state’s most powerful officials escalated on Thursday. Preet Bharara, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, not known for engaging in on-air rebukes of elected officeholders, took aim at Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo over his decision to dissolve an anticorruption panel.

headline: Judge Approves SAC Plea, Closing a Painful Chapter
abstract: The agreement with federal prosecutors requires the once-mighty hedge fund run by Steven A. Cohen to pay $1.2 billion to the government while shutting its doors to outside investors.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:40 p.m. | In the span of a week, Steven A. Cohen’s investment firm changed its name, hired a former federal prosecutor and became a felon.

headline: Greenish Shootlets in Southern Europe (Implicitly Wonkish)
abstract: It works out in the long run, but we’re all dead.
lead_paragraph: There are hints of recovery in some of Europe’s austerity-stricken economies. Even Greece is finally showing some signs of an uptick. And you know one thing is going to happen: some people will say, “See — growth despite austerity! Krugman and the Keynesians were wrong!”

headline: Microsoft Touts Data Protection Approval in Europe; Eager for New Customers
keywords: ['Cloud Computing', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Data Storage', 'Law and Legislation', 'Privacy']
abstract: Microsoft’s top lawyer said the company’s cloud computing services had met Europe’s stringent data protection rules, and he used the news as a way to woo potential new customers.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Online privacy is heating up as a selling point, at least in Europe.

headline: House-Passed Budget Shows Parties’ Divergence
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The blueprint, the fourth by Representative Paul D. Ryan, says it would bring the federal budget into balance by 2024 by, in part, cutting $5.1 trillion in spending over a decade.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Rodney Davis won his House seat in 2012 by barely a thousand votes, making him a leading candidate as Target No. 1 for Democrats who are eager to make his support for the latest House Republican budget a centerpiece of the fall campaign.

headline: Evidence Comes Up Short as Egypt Tries 3 Journalists
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'News and News Media', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: A courtroom was shown family photographs and video of trotting horses, but not the supposedly fabricated news videos that underlie the charges.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Prosecutors on Thursday were unable to produce video footage that they say is the basis of their case against three journalists accused of conspiring to broadcast false reports about civil strife in Egypt. Instead, they showed a Cairo courtroom footage of family photographs, trotting horses and Somali refugees in Kenya.

headline: Oversight Committee Censures Ex-I.R.S. Official for Refusal to Take Questions
abstract: Lois Lerner, called to testify about how the agency handled applications for tax-exempt status from conservative political groups, had refused to answer questions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A House committee voted on Thursday to hold a former Internal Revenue Service official in contempt for refusing to answer its questions about her role in holding up applications for tax exemption from conservative political groups before the last election.

headline: Live Nation to Open Outdoor Concert Venue at Manhattan Pier
abstract: JBL Live at Pier 97 will offer concerts starting in July.

headline: Sacrificing Sense for Speed in Markets
keywords: ['High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Today’s stock markets operate at blinding speed, using bewilderingly complicated processes untempered by common sense or accountability.
lead_paragraph: Rube Goldberg: A comically involved, complicated invention, laboriously contrived to perform a seemingly simple operation.

abstract: Rahul Gandhi, leader of the Congress party’s election campaign, cast his vote in New Delhi.

abstract: As a new production of “Of Mice and Men” begins on Broadway, this Text to Text celebrates the friendship at the heart of the novel and poses questions about the role of friendship today.
lead_paragraph: As John Steinbeck’s novel “The Grapes of Wrath” prepares to celebrate its 75th birthday, its oft-taught brother, “Of Mice and Men,” is in previews on Broadway.

abstract: A glimpse at what gals are wearing this season.
