headline: 50 Years Later, Obama Salutes Effects of Civil Rights Act
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: In a much-anticipated speech marking the 50th anniversary of the landmark Civil Rights Act, Mr. Obama said the push for equality opened doors for millions of Americans, including himself.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — For three days, the veterans of a long-ago movement reunited and drew together their spiritual heirs to explore the legacy of the Civil Rights Act a half-century after it transformed America. And then the legacy walked onstage.

headline: No Handouts From These Rabbits
abstract: Full Bunny Contact, a new Easter-themed carnival on the Lower East Side, offers strategic combat with people dressed up like rabbits, a booth where you can dunk Jesus, and more.
lead_paragraph: TIMOTHY HASKELL, he of the slightly twisted imagination who regularly scares people as the creator and director of the “Nightmare“ haunted houses in New York around Halloween, has something new and a bit less diabolical planned for Easter weekend: Full Bunny Contact, a carnival more focused on fun than on fright.

headline: A Series of ‘Cataclysmic Events,’ at Good Prices
abstract: Stargazing of more than one variety is on tap for the weekend at Columbia University and the Kensington library.
lead_paragraph: As a freshman in college, the Miser naïvely chose to fulfill his science requirement with an introductory course in astronomy. He dug space as much as the next guy. A semester of looking at the stars? Compared with balancing equations, calculating vectors or dissecting dead animals, how hard could it be?

headline: Why Liberalism Needs Pluralism
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Segregation and Desegregation']
abstract: How a liberal political framework depends on illiberal elements within.
lead_paragraph: Just to ride a little further on my recent hobbyhorse, pluralism, I thought this Andrew Sullivan analysis of the divide between same-sex marriage supporters over the treatment of Brendan Eich was useful in thinking through some wider political issues as well.

headline: BMW Recalls 156,000 Vehicles With 6-Cylinder Engines
abstract: A problem with the variable camshaft timing unit could cause engine failure.
lead_paragraph: BMW is recalling about 156,000 vehicles equipped with 6-cylinder engines because a defect could cause stalling or engine damage, the automaker said in a news release Thursday. The action comes almost two years after the automaker began fixing the same models in China, according to a report the automaker filed with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: David Gordon Green Narrates a Scene From ‘Joe’
abstract: The director discusses a sequence from his film featuring Nicolas Cage and Tye Sheridan.
lead_paragraph: Nicolas Cage has an intimate moment with a venomous snake in this scene from “Joe,” narrated by the director David Gordon Green and also featuring Tye Sheridan. Mr. Green discusses how the scene was shot using a handful of non-traditional actors and a real cottonmouth snake.

headline: Mike Flanagan on ‘Oculus’
abstract: The director discusses his horror film about a haunted mirror.
lead_paragraph: The director discusses his horror film about a haunted mirror.

headline: Tax Revenue Rockets Up, Helping Lessen the Deficit, Treasury Department Says
abstract: In March, the Treasury collected $216 billion in taxes, up 16 percent from a year ago, helping reduce the deficit for March to $37 billion.
lead_paragraph: The economy may be plodding along. But business is booming for Uncle Sam.

headline: Upgrades for Historic Luxury Hotels
abstract: The Hotel Imperial in Vienna and the Excelsior Hotel Gallia in Milan are among the properties receiving updates through the Luxury Collection of Starwood Hotels & Resorts.
lead_paragraph: After restoring some of its most historic hotels last year, including the Gritti Palace in Venice and the Hotel Maria Cristina in San Sebastian, Spain, the Luxury Collection from Starwood Hotels & Resorts announced a second round of upgrades, this time to two more historic properties, the Hotel Imperial in Vienna and the Excelsior Hotel Gallia in Milan, and two more-modern ones including Santa Marina Resort in Mykonos, Greece, and Grand Hills in Broumana, Lebanon.

headline: The Treasure Rests at the Bottom
abstract: Parmys Persian Fusion in the East Village offers the glory of rice brought nearly to a scorch.
lead_paragraph: How is the English language so impoverished that we do not have a word for the glory of rice brought nearly to a scorch at the bottom of a pot? The Spanish call it socarrat; the Chinese, guo ba. It is graten in Haiti, nurungji in Korea, pegao in Puerto Rico, khao tang in Thailand, xoon in Senegal.

headline: Next Guessing Game: Who Will Replace Colbert?
abstract: Now that CBS has made it official, what will replace “The Colbert Show”?
lead_paragraph: “Stephen Colbert” is dead. Long live Stephen Colbert. One day after I wrote of the downside of replacing David Letterman with Stephen Colbert, CBS went ahead and did exactly that.

headline: N.H.L. Promoted Violence Regardless of Health Risk, Players’ Suit Says
abstract: The lawsuit, which was filed in federal court in Manhattan, is the latest in a string of challenges to the N.H.L.
lead_paragraph: Nine former professional hockey players have filed a lawsuit against the N.H.L. that says the league “intentionally created, fostered and promoted a culture of extreme violence.”

headline: Icahn May Someday Win, and eBay Will Spin Off PayPal
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Boards of Directors', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Mobile Commerce']
abstract: EBay has not ruled out a spinoff forever. More talk from Carl Icahn and heightened scrutiny could bring the day closer, Robert Cyran of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Carl C. Icahn has lost the battle of bluster at eBay. The activist investor is quitting his proxy fight now that the company is appointing one new director and agreeing to talk to him. Considering that Mr. Icahn had “never seen worse governance” and was broadly right about the benefits of eBay separating its PayPal unit, that’s a retreat. But he may yet win the war.

headline: Common Core Gets Strong Defense From State Education Chief
abstract: John B. King Jr., the education commissioner, fought back at criticism of the state’s efforts to adopt the standards and said there was no turning back.
lead_paragraph: Under sustained attack over new standardized tests and learning standards, the New York State education commissioner told an audience on Thursday that “we’re not retreating” and that the constant criticism was damaging an overdue effort to raise student achievement.

headline: Officials Approve U.N. Peacekeeping Unit
abstract: The French and American ambassadors to the United Nations, Gérard Araud and Samantha Power, and the Central African Republic’s foreign minister discussed the United Nations peacekeeping operation.
lead_paragraph: The French and American ambassadors to the United Nations, Gérard Araud and Samantha Power, and the Central African Republic’s foreign minister discussed the United Nations peacekeeping operation.

headline: Living With Cancer: Bedtime Issues
abstract: My cancer support group friends had lost not just sleep, but intimate pleasure and a significant aspect of their identities as women.
lead_paragraph: Like the other women in my cancer support group, I have been trying to salvage aspects of the person I had been before the diagnosis.

headline: Border Capture, Seen From Above
abstract: On a helicopter with its pilot and a Border Patrol chief, a reporter and photographer for The New York Times watched migrants crossing the Rio Grande and turning themselves in.
lead_paragraph: On a helicopter with its pilot and a Border Patrol chief, a reporter and photographer for The New York Times watched migrants crossing the Rio Grande and turning themselves in.

headline: The Early Years of Stockholm’s Mega Home-Design Store
abstract: “Sober and Elegant” explores the minimalist beginnings of Svenskt Tenn, now renowned for its colorful textiles thanks to a creative partnership formed ten years after it opened in 1924.
lead_paragraph: The only way to really understand how much the Stockholm design emporium Svenskt Tenn stands for Swedish style is to go and visit the store. What Hermès and Fortnum & Mason are to Paris and London, respectively — beacons that help foreigners better grasp the culture of the town they’re in — Svenskt Tenn is to their northern and more mysterious sister. At the 90-year-old department store, you can buy almost anything for the home, from one of the deepest production sofas in the world to a doorstop shaped like an acorn — anything, that is, but something boring. It’s fitting that the ground floor of the store includes an art gallery with a rotating schedule of shows.

headline: Obama Pays Tribute to Civil Rights Act
abstract: President Obama delivered remarks on the 50th anniversary of the Civil Rights Act at the Lyndon B. Johnson Presidential Library and Museum in Austin, Tex.
lead_paragraph: President Obama delivered remarks on the 50th anniversary of the Civil Rights Act at the Lyndon B. Johnson Presidential Library and Museum in Austin, Tex.

headline: Icahn’s Feud With eBay Generated Noise, but Slight Bump for Shares
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: In his monthslong battle with eBay, Carl C. Icahn accused the company of failing to generate bigger returns for shareholders. But since the day before eBay announced that Mr. Icahn had acquired a stake, its stock has risen about 2 percent.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:47 p.m. | In his monthslong battle with eBay, Carl C. Icahn accused the online commerce site of failing to generate bigger returns for shareholders.

headline: Eli Manning Has Surgery on Ankle He Injured in Season Finale
abstract: The Giants’ star quarterback, who sustained a left ankle sprain, had an arthroscopic procedure and said he expected to start running in late May.
lead_paragraph: Giants quarterback Eli Manning had arthroscopic surgery on his left ankle Thursday to relieve pain associated with a sprain he sustained in the last game of the season.

headline: Hoping for Asylum, Migrants Strain U.S. Border
abstract: Those who risk a danger-filled journey across Mexico to cross the Rio Grande into Texas are now primarily from Central America.
lead_paragraph: HIDALGO, Tex. — Border Patrol agents in olive uniforms stood in broad daylight on the banks of the Rio Grande, while on the Mexican side smugglers pulled up in vans and unloaded illegal migrants.

headline: A Journey North, From Farther South
abstract: Driven out by deepening poverty but also by gang violence, increasing numbers of Central American migrants are crossing the Rio Grande from Mexico into the United States, where many seek asylum.
lead_paragraph: Driven out by deepening poverty but also by gang violence, increasing numbers of Central American migrants are crossing the Rio Grande from Mexico into the United States, where many seek asylum.

headline: The Gun Report: April 10, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: More than 300 people banned from owning guns—including felons, fugitives and people with histories of mental illness—were able to buy them in Maryland last year because state police were flooded with background check requests, The Baltimore Sun reported yesterday. And because of a loophole that allows gun dealers to release firearms after waiting a week, regardless of whether a check is done, 51,812 guns were handed out prematurely.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: exercise enjoyment, Medicare dollars and pregnancy risks. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: exercise enjoyment, Medicare dollars and pregnancy risks. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Centuries of Judaica From Life and Rites in Muslim Lands
abstract: Two exhibitions, one at the Center for Jewish History and one at the Museum of Jewish Heritage, focus on ritual and household Judaica from the Persian Gulf.
lead_paragraph: Artifacts from Sephardic Jews who fled Muslim countries, typically with few possessions in hand, are re-emerging and being reunited in virtual and tangible forms.

headline: Benghazi: ‘The Administration Has Won’
abstract: Charles Krauthammer urged Republicans to let up on Benghazi-scandal hunting.
lead_paragraph: Remember Karl Rove wandering around the Fox News set on election night 2012, trying to convince his colleagues that Mitt Romney, and not Barack Obama, had won the state of Ohio?

headline: A Journey North, From Farther South
abstract: Driven out by deepening poverty but also by gang violence, increasing numbers of Central American migrants are crossing the Rio Grande from Mexico into the United States, where many seek asylum.
lead_paragraph: Driven out by deepening poverty but also by gang violence, increasing numbers of Central American migrants are crossing the Rio Grande from Mexico into the United States, where many seek asylum.

headline: In Search of ‘Wild’ Costa Rica
abstract: Seeking a more untamed wildlife experience, a family heads to the remote Osa Peninsula on the country’s Pacific coast.
lead_paragraph: By the end of our fourth day on the Osa Peninsula of Costa Rica, we had seen, according to the tally kept by my 9-year-old, Sasha, dozens of species of animals. We had peered at leafcutter ants, army ants and zombie ants. We had been deafened by howler monkeys, beguiled by squirrel monkeys and strangely stirred by capuchin monkeys, whose feet bear an eerie resemblance to human hands. That afternoon, in the national park that covers a third of the peninsula, we had even spied two tapirs, endangered mammals that look like hornless rhinoceroses with long snouts.

headline: An Auctioneer Comes Back to the Business
abstract: Edward Dolman, a former Christie’s chairman, is returning to the auction business as chairman and chief executive of Phillips.
lead_paragraph: The rumors started Sunday, when the Qatar Museums Authority said that Edward Dolman, its executive director and acting chief executive, was stepping down after three years.

headline: De Blasio, Marking 100 Days on Job, Says ‘Grass Roots’ Will Drive Agenda
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio focused on values rather than offering a blueprint for governing in a speech at the Cooper Union in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio, seeking to recapture the energy that propelled him to victory last November, marked his 100th day in office on Thursday with a rhetoric-heavy speech that called on his supporters to help him create a “people-powered government” in New York.

headline: Reverse Mortgage Realities
abstract: The loans often make sense for the elderly, though some heirs may object to a drain on their inheritance.
lead_paragraph: Adult children have reason to be wary when their parents start talking about reverse mortgages. The loans make sense only for those who plan to stay in their homes for the rest of their lives and can afford to pay property taxes and insurance for that long.

headline: Abusing Both Medicare and Politics
abstract: Does anyone doubt that there is a quid pro quo when doctors earning millions of Medicare dollars write big checks to senators and political parties?
lead_paragraph: Campaign finance reformers have long warned that the growing power of big money in politics would produce a giant scandal. But those scandals happen every day, and the trading of campaign donations for political favors has steadily eroded public trust in Washington. The latest illustration of that can be seen in the connection between Medicare fraud and “super PAC” abuse.

headline: Minimalist Show, Minimally Revised
abstract: The Jewish Museum is staging “Other Primary Structures,” an unusually site-specific sequel to a sculpture show it mounted in 1966.
lead_paragraph: Museum art exhibitions are painfully ephemeral. Once they close, they are gone, except for their catalogs and documentary photographs. This has understandably spurred visions of time travel among curators and curators in training.

headline: The Battle for Late Night Viewers on Screens of All Sizes
abstract: As Stephen Colbert takes the reigns of the “Late Show,” CBS’s flagship late-night franchise, he will also need to figure out how to enter the battle for viewers on YouTube and other online video sites.
lead_paragraph: Congratulations, Stephen Colbert! You’ve been crowned one of the kings of late night television, succeeding David Letterman as host of the “Late Show,” CBS’s flagship late-night franchise.

headline: Exploring the Amazon in ‘Rio 2’
abstract: Images from “Rio 2” of sequences set in the Amazon rain forest.
lead_paragraph: Images from “Rio 2” of sequences set in the Amazon rain forest.

headline: A Protégé of James Turrell Makes His New York Debut (With Lasers and Holograms, Naturally)
abstract: In a new show at Johannes Vogt, the artist Matthew Schreiber is showing multimedia works that offer crowd-wowing plays on light.
lead_paragraph: As a child growing up in Ohio, the artist Matthew Schreiber was fascinated by the lasers he saw in “Star Wars” and at the theme park Ontario Place in Toronto, which he visited with his family. Years later, he began incorporating them into his art practice, and today he will unveil those efforts, including a mesmerizing room filled with darting red beams of light, in his first New York solo show, “Sideshow,” on view through May 10 at Johannes Vogt.

headline: Yee I-Lann: ‘Picturing Power’
abstract: Ms. Yee, who lives in Kuala Lumpur, is making her New York debut with a small, tight show of work that reflects and transcends where and when it was made.
lead_paragraph: Tyler Rollins Fine Art

headline: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from India, Indonesia, Israel and Russia.
lead_paragraph: Photos from India, Indonesia, Israel and Russia.

headline: Kristen Morgin: ‘The Super Can Man and Other Illustrated Classics’
abstract: Ms. Morgin uses unfired clay, crayons, ink, graphite and markers to create apparently weathered, used and abused surfaces.
lead_paragraph: Zach Feuer

headline: Peter Buggenhout: ‘Caterpillar Logic II’
abstract: Whatever Mr. Buggenhout’s enormous, bristling ruins of sculptures bring to mind, they are impressive.
lead_paragraph: Gladstone Gallery

headline: Paris-Roubaix’s Quaint Course Is Viciously Bumpy
abstract: The famed Paris-Roubaix cycling race includes about 31 miles of riding over rough, rugged and raw cobblestones.
lead_paragraph: WALLERS, France — On one side, the rock was as flinty and jagged as a chipped tooth. On the other, its edge was caved in, so the surface sheared away sharply. Squatting in the dirt, Clement Huchez examined the stone, rolling it in his hands for a few moments. Then he slid it into the rubble puzzle in front of him and exclaimed, “It’s perfect!”

headline: Greece Returns to the Bond Markets
abstract: The European Union’s competition commissioner, Joaquín Almunia, and the Greek finance minister, Yannis Stournaras, said Greece’s return to the bond markets was good news for the whole euro zone.
lead_paragraph: The European Union’s competition commissioner, Joaquín Almunia, and the Greek finance minister, Yannis Stournaras, said Greece’s return to the bond markets was good news for the whole euro zone.

headline: Joe Sola: ‘American Sex Room and other Works’
abstract: While this show doesn’t include “Studio Visit” (2005), in which Mr. Sola invited curators to his studio, then jumped out the window, it offers a glimpse of his Weltanschauung.
lead_paragraph: Blackston

headline: Letters: Canon Fire
abstract: Readers respond to recent essays about Harold Bloom’s “The Western Canon” and a recent review of Kevin Fong’s “Extreme Medicine.”
lead_paragraph: Canon Fire

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 63
abstract: Mark Geiger will be the first match official from the United States to work at the World Cup since 2002.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Iván Navarro: ‘This Land is Your Land’
abstract: Mr. Navarro’s Madison Square installation invokes surveillance operations in ways that are specific to New York.
lead_paragraph: Madison Square Park

headline: The Cubs of Wall Street
abstract: First-year investment bankers in the post-crisis era combine a sense of superiority with abject insecurity.
lead_paragraph: Imagine you’re a scientist in some sci-fi alternate universe, and you’ve been charged with creating a boot camp that will reliably turn normal but ambitious people into broken sociopaths more or less willing to do anything.

headline: The Justice Gap
abstract: Matt Taibbi argues that this country’s unequal wealth is producing unequal outcomes in criminal justice.
lead_paragraph: “Low-class people do low-class things.” What’s notable in this reflexive dismissal of those with modest means are not the words themselves. Rather, please turn your attention to the person whom Matt Taibbi, in his ambitious new book documenting America’s unequal administration of justice to rich and poor, quotes saying them: a private attorney hired by New York State to defend low-income people in criminal court. We never learn his name, but Taibbi calls him Waldorf because he resembles the grouchy old balcony heckler on “The Muppet Show.”

headline: Demolished Club Casts a Long Shadow
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Organizations, Societies and Clubs', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: The loss of the New York Club upset preservationists. Now, some decry plans for its site.
lead_paragraph: The developer HFZ Capital is proposing a new building for the empty lot at 20 West 40th Street, and the Historic Districts Council is not happy, protesting that the flat-topped 32-story tower is out of place on a street that has long had “a picturesque skyline.”

headline: At One With Their Dogs, Growling and Snapping
abstract: In David Gordon Green’s “Joe,” Nicolas Cage stars as a steely ex-convict who tries to help a boy with an abusive home life.
lead_paragraph: The most indelible scenes in David Gordon Green’s “Joe,” filmed in the backwoods of Texas, have the fierce clarity of illuminations glimpsed in a lightning flash. In one lingering afterimage, a team of mostly African-American laborers, toiling in a desiccated pine forest, methodically poison sickly trees with “juice hatchets” (small axes that squirt deadly herbicide) to kill them off and make room for the planting of hardier species. These woodsmen, played by nonprofessionals, share an easy, rough-hewn camaraderie. They are the least tormented characters in “Joe,” a punishing exercise in Southern miserablism.

headline: An Alfresco Fling Beats Selling Tractors
abstract: Alain Guiraudie’s “The King of Escape” follows a middle-aged gay tractor salesman who finds himself in a heterosexual mood after rescuing a teenage girl, so he runs away with her.
lead_paragraph: Before Alain Guiraudie made his justly lauded “Stranger by the Lake,” he directed “The King of Escape,” a fresh, antic comedy that’s powered just as much by libido. In this case, sex is comedy, and Mr. Guiraudie makes the most of the anarchic freedoms of the genre. Originally shown at Cannes in 2009, “The King of Escape” matter-of-factly sketches out a randy patch of the French countryside, where cruising thrives among butch, gray-haired rustics and where aphrodisiac roots grow in the woods.

headline: Heads or Tails
abstract: The life of a penny.
lead_paragraph: The life of a penny.

headline: No Cause for Shame
abstract: Questions about the privacy of a child, and dealing with puny lies and thank-you notes.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I will soon be reunited with a couple we spent a lot time with in the ’80s, but haven’t seen much of since. Our sons, now both 34, used to play together, so I know the subject of children will come up. But our son has suffered from addiction for years, and lives on the edge of poverty because of the unfortunate choices he’s made. How do we deal with their questions without infringing on his privacy?

headline: What the Sea Took Away, a Daughter Restores
abstract: I wanted most to spare my daughter the realization that there would always be a black hole in the center of our lives.
lead_paragraph: Fourteen years ago, my husband vanished. A talented sculptor whose work was in major collections, he had been in a downward spiral for over a year, unable to finish a single piece of work, tumbling into alcoholism, paralyzed by depression.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about today’s biggest stories.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Art and Style Are Their Lifeblood
abstract: In “Only Lovers Left Alive,” Jim Jarmusch’s celebration of art and style, cultured vampires make up a kind of aesthetic aristocracy.
lead_paragraph: With their finely chiseled clavicles and cheekbones, their nocturnal habits and exquisite taste, Adam and Eve are about the coolest couple you could imagine. (They are played by Tom Hiddleston and Tilda Swinton, which definitely helps.) Adam lives in a vast apartment in the picturesque ruins of Detroit, surrounded by vinyl records and vintage guitars acquired by an eager young gofer named Ian (Anton Yelchin). Eve haunts the alleys of Tangier, speed-reading old books in every known language and lingering in an all-night cafe with Christopher Marlowe, who still regrets, five centuries after the fact, not receiving proper credit for Shakespeare’s plays.

headline: A Week’s Vigil, Then Easter Hallelujahs
abstract: A sampling of musical presentations planned for the Easter holiday season.
lead_paragraph: A sampling of musical presentations planned for the holiday season at churches and other sites in New York, compiled by Anne Mancuso. All are free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations. Unless noted otherwise, church choirs are featured in church concerts.) An expanded listing is available at nytimes.com/arts.

headline: Missing Ingredient on Minimum Wage: A Motivated G.O.P.
abstract: President Obama’s three predecessors signed an increase in the federal minimum wage by forging agreement with a Congress controlled by the opposing party.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Each of the three previous presidents — two Republicans, one Democrat — signed an increase in the federal minimum wage.

headline: For New York City Doormen, Some Closed Doors
keywords: ['Doormen', 'Organized Labor', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Building Service Employees']
abstract: Amid contract negotiations the doormen’s union wants to expand its reach to new condo buildings.
lead_paragraph: It has been more than two decades since the city faced a large-scale strike by the doormen’s union. But this could change when its contract expires on April 20.

headline: 2 Regulators Issue Guidelines on Sharing Cyber Security Information
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: The Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission said that sharing information between companies about threats to cybersecurity is not likely to raise antitrust concerns.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – Sharing information between companies about threats to cybersecurity is not likely to raise antitrust concerns, the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission said Thursday.

headline: Tenor Receives Richard Tucker Award
abstract: Michael Fabiano, a 29-year-old whose burnished tenor has made him one of the opera world’s most closely watched young singers, has won the $50,000 Richard Tucker Award.
lead_paragraph: Michael Fabiano, a 29-year-old whose burnished tenor has made him one of the opera world’s most closely watched young singers, has won the $50,000 Richard Tucker Award, the foundation that gives the award announced on Thursday.

headline: A Delaware Court Flexes a Never-Tested Muscle
abstract: The Delaware Court of Chancery, known as the nation’s business court, has now done something it had apparently never done before in its 222 years — issue an arrest warrant.
lead_paragraph: The Delaware Court of Chancery, known as the nation’s business court,  has now done something it had apparently never done before in its 222 years — issue an arrest warrant.

headline: Banned Group’s Leader Given Pakistani Parliament Seat After Vote Dispute
abstract: A parliamentary seat has been granted to the head of a sectarian group that has long been accused of inciting violence against minority Shiites.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s electoral commission has granted a parliamentary seat to the leader of a banned sectarian group that has long been accused of inciting violence against minority Shiites.

headline: Jazz Singer, Meet Big Band
abstract: Jane Monheit, the Manhattan School of Music Swing Band and Ms. Monheit’s regular trio are doing a program of standards at Birdland.
lead_paragraph: When a jazz singer performs with a large band, transcendence arrives only at the moment that the disparate musical ingredients suddenly click into place, and you feel propelled by the acceleration of a mighty engine whose components all mesh. Such moments were infrequent on Tuesday evening at Birdland, where the singer Jane Monheit appeared with the Manhattan School of Music Swing Band. But the few times the elements jelled, the aligned forces achieved the state of bliss I like to call musical liftoff.

headline: Peeling Back the Layers of Time for a 30th Anniversary
abstract: Stephen Petronio’s company marks its 30th anniversary with two premieres and a look back at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Petronio’s staying power, especially in the financially precarious world of modern dance, is breathtaking. Whether his sinuous, slippery choreography appeals or not — more on that later — he is committed.

headline: Writing a Playbook That Ensures Glory
abstract: Kevin Costner plays the beleaguered general manager of the Cleveland Browns in “Draft Day.”
lead_paragraph: Kevin Costner is one of the great salesmen in American movies, a natural-born closer. He’ll look you in the eye, start in with the pitch, and the next thing you know, you almost believe that Donald Sutherland and Lyndon Johnson killed Kennedy; that if you build a ballpark in the middle of a cornfield, “they will come”; and that “Dances With Wolves” is a better picture than “Goodfellas.” Something about him — the baby blues, the slightly weak chin, the aw-shucks manner, at once aggressive and self-effacing — makes him hard to resist, even when you know you’re being conned. That’s part of the appeal.

headline: Navigating the Art of Japan From a Different Direction
abstract: “Points of Departure: Treasures of Japan From the Brooklyn Museum” is a radically reorienting show at Japan Society Gallery.
lead_paragraph: No compass is needed for “Points of Departure: Treasures of Japan From the Brooklyn Museum,” a radically reorienting show at Japan Society Gallery. Organized around the four cardinal directions, the show gives you a new way to navigate Japanese art — one that emphasizes regional cultures, outside influences and indigenous populations.

headline: Passions, ‘Superstar’ and More
abstract: A sampling of seasonal celebrations planned for the Easter holiday season.
lead_paragraph: A sampling of seasonal celebrations in New York, including drama, readings and processions. Free, unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations.)

headline: Whiffs of Choral Ambrosia
abstract: A sampling of choral works planned for the Easter season.
lead_paragraph: A sampling of choral works for the Easter season in New York. Free, unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations.)

headline: The Breakfast That Preceded ‘The Dinner Party’
abstract: “Chicago in L.A.: Judy Chicago’s Early Work 1963-1974,” at the Brooklyn Museum, looks at the artist’s efforts before her most celebrated work.
lead_paragraph: Love it or hate it, Judy Chicago’s “The Dinner Party” remains a great, enduringly provocative monument of feminist art. Permanently enshrined in a triangular room taking up most of the space allotted to the Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art at the Brooklyn Museum, it consists of a three-sided banquet table with 39 elaborate place settings. Each is dedicated to a famous woman who is represented by the work’s most controversial feature: a fancifully stylized image of a vagina rendered in two or three dimensions on a large dinner plate.

headline: Androgynous Betrayals
abstract: Francine Prose’s “Lovers at the Chameleon Club, Paris 1932” unfolds over 20 years, with characters who initially meet in a cross-dressers’ haven, and their lives intertwine as Europe marches toward a dark chapter.
lead_paragraph: The breadth, nerve and intricacy of Francine Prose’s big new novel should surprise even her most regular readers. A bona fide page turner, “Lovers at the Chameleon Club, Paris 1932” unfolds over 20 years, across an increasingly ominous Europe, among thugs and artists and poseurs who share only the danger that threatens to cramp their partying style. The Chameleon Club is their unofficial Paris headquarters, a cross-dressers’ heaven specializing in innocently filthy humor. But as that “chameleon” in that title indicates, everything here, even the Chameleon Club itself, is subject to wartime change.

headline: Origins Story, Through a Modern Lens
abstract: An abiding interest in early photographic processes is manifest at the Association of International Photography Art Dealers show at the Park Avenue Armory.
lead_paragraph: The photography world has been ruled in recent years by a fascination with abstraction and experimental processes and techniques. You see this everywhere in the current Association of International Photography Art Dealers show at the Park Avenue Armory. Even Hans P. Kraus Jr., who deals in photographic old masters, is showing — alongside vintage prints by Charles Marville, now featured in a show at the Metropolitan Museum, and Eugène Atget — some 19th-century pencil drawings by John Herschel, an important contributor to early photography. The drawings here, of Stonehenge and sights on the European Grand Tour, were made with a camera lucida, an optical device that functions in a manner similar to that of the camera obscura but in full daylight rather than a dark room.

headline: Theater Listings for April 11-17
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Warily, Jordan Assists Rebels in Syrian War
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Foreign Aid']
abstract: Jordan has been quietly providing a staging ground for the rebels and their foreign backers on Syria’s southern front, but many say the aid is not enough.
lead_paragraph: IRBID, Jordan — When rebels want to return to Syria to fight, Jordan’s intelligence services give them specific times to cross its border. When the rebels need weapons, they make their request at an “operations room” in Amman staffed by agents from Jordan, Saudi Arabia and the United States.

headline: Federal Regulators Advise Banks to Protect Their Systems From Internet Security Flaw
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Computer Security', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A group of regulators including the Federal Reserve, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency say banks should upgrade their systems to protect customer information.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:17 p.m. | Federal regulators are advising banks to take steps to protect their systems from the Heartbleed Internet security flaw that could put sensitive customer information at risk.

headline: Lifetime Anguish Is the High Cost of Courage
abstract: Colin Firth stars as Eric Lomax, a British Army officer who served and suffered during World War II, in this movie based on Lomax’s memoir.
lead_paragraph: What place is there nowadays for a solid, old-fashioned movie about war, remembrance and reconciliation? That question occurred to me while watching “The Railway Man,” an unabashedly stodgy, high-minded film in the David Lean tradition (without the grandeur), starring Colin Firth as Eric Lomax, a British Army officer who served and suffered during World War II.

headline: Sebelius Resigns After Troubles Over Health Site
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Ending a stormy five-year tenure marred by the disastrous rollout of President Obama’s signature legislative achievement, Kathleen Sebelius is resigning as secretary of Health and Human Services.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Kathleen Sebelius, the health and human services secretary, is resigning, ending a stormy five-year tenure marred by the disastrous rollout of President Obama’s signature legislative achievement, the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Official on Report on Albuquerque Police
abstract: The acting assistant attorney general for the Justice Department’s civil rights division, Jocelyn Samuels, discussed an investigation that concluded the Albuquerque police used excessive force.
lead_paragraph: The acting assistant attorney general for the Justice Department’s civil rights division, Jocelyn Samuels, discussed an investigation that concluded the Albuquerque police used excessive force.

headline: Photo Diary | Milan Design Week 2014: Salone and Paul Smith
abstract: The photographer Danilo Scarpati documents Milan Design Week, including an event celebrating Paul Smith’s collaboration with Carl Hansen & Son on colorful new Wegner furniture.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Design Week photo diary of Danilo Scarpati.

abstract: A guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Worry About a Smelly Rental
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Storage', 'Smells and Odors', 'Oil Spills', 'Cooperatives']
abstract: This week’s subjects include headache inducing smells; missing closing documentation; and the loss of a coveted storage locker.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Domesticated Macaws Reclaiming Their Wild Side
abstract: In “Rio 2,” a mated pair of blue macaws and their brood leave Rio for the lush perils of the Amazon rain forest.
lead_paragraph: The cinematic equivalent of attack by kaleidoscope, “Rio 2” sucks you in and whirls you around before spitting you out, exhausted. A tropical tornado of cadmium and cobalt, magenta and marigold, Carlos Saldanha’s frantic follow-up to his well-received 2011 animated feature, “Rio,” ups the ante on sound and movement but pays scant attention to story. Prioritizing a sellable soundtrack — and a veiled plug for this year’s World Cup soccer tournament — over an original and engaging narrative might not have been the intent, but it sure feels that way.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for April 7-11
abstract: A selected guide to performances of hip-hop, electronic dance music, dance-pop and more in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.

headline: Seeking Favor Among Those You Regulate
keywords: ['Elections, Attorneys General', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: After finishing third in this year’s Republican primary for attorney general, Barry Smitherman, chairman of the Texas Railroad Commission, returned to his job regulating the oil and gas industry.
lead_paragraph: The strangest things become commonplace in politics, like the ties that bind the oil and gas business and some of its regulators.

headline: Opera & Classical Music Listings for April 11-17
abstract: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Budget Chief Is Obama’s Choice as New Health Secretary
abstract: On Friday, President Obama is to nominate Sylvia Mathews Burwell to succeed Kathleen Sebelius, who is resigning.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even when Sylvia Mathews Burwell was in her early 30s, friends speculated that she might return to her native Hinton, W.Va., and run for governor someday. After all, she had been a Rhodes scholar, and her mother — who later became mayor of Hinton, population 2,600 — had driven her daughter’s interest in politics.

abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.
