lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Spare Times for Children for April 11-17
abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: ‘ISLAND OF LEMURS: MADAGASCAR’

headline: Gathering of Gods From Places Long Forgotten
abstract: “Lost Kingdoms,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, explores religious art of Southeast Asia from the fifth to eighth centuries.
lead_paragraph: When the Metropolitan Museum of Art gives its all to an exhibition in terms of space, money and scholarship, and the art involved is as rich as a massed chorale and as haunting as a single-voice chant, no institution on earth can produce more impressive results. Such is the case with “Lost Kingdoms: Hindu-Buddhist Sculpture of Early Southeast Asia, 5th to 8th Century,” which opens on Monday.

headline: Spare Times for April 11-17
abstract: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.
lead_paragraph: OPENING OF LUNA PARK (Sunday) Veterans of the Cyclone roller coaster — and those who appreciate it best while standing on terra firma — will cheer as Luna Park kicks off another season in Coney Island, Brooklyn, starting at noon. An egg-cream splash on the venerable roller coaster, which turns 87 in June, will set it and the other attractions at the amusement park in motion once again.

headline: On the Wall, Who’s the Deadliest One of All?
abstract: Karen Gillan and Brenton Thwaites play siblings seeking clues to their parents’ fate in a tale alternating between time periods.
lead_paragraph: Don’t try to outwit a haunted mirror: It can see you. That’s the moral of “Oculus,” a derivative but efficient chiller that cribs from “Solaris,” “The Shining” and “The Amityville Horror” yet also shows glimmers of imagination.

headline: Finding the Pleasure in the Details
abstract: Eight players from the Marlboro Music festival roster brought a varied program to the Peoples’ Symphony Concerts.
lead_paragraph: Schubert’s hourlong Octet in F for Winds and Strings can have a pleasantly narcotic effect on the listener, each one of its amply proportioned six movements warping sensations of time and purpose like a carefree summer afternoon. So I didn’t think too much of it at first when I found my mind wandering during Saturday evening’s performance of the work by Musicians From Marlboro, an ensemble from that Vermont-based festival, as part of the Peoples’ Symphony Concerts.

headline: A Light Touch on Ecstasy, Melancholy and Wonder
abstract: The English soprano Lucy Crowe explored Schubert, Berg, Sibelius and a range of British art songs in her program at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The English soprano Lucy Crowe, who made her New York recital debut on Wednesday evening at Weill Recital Hall, is a winsome presence, with long blond hair, a ready grin and bright eyes. They match her bright voice, which suits the early-music repertory for which she has begun to be known in this country.

headline: Digging Up Old Drilling Logs to Strike Not Oil, but Water
abstract: As drought grips most of Texas, researchers are combing the records to map brackish groundwater in the state’s 30 aquifers — hidden resources that could help quench the state’s long-term thirst.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Ortuño pulled a small piece of Texas history from a shelf in a building at the University of Texas at Austin. The yellowing piece of paper said that on Dec. 19, 1951, John L. Boyd began drilling a 1,350-foot-deep oil well through 17 layers of shale and limestone in Crockett County in southwest Texas.

headline: On-Camera Dating
abstract: “Hank and Asha” is the story of an epistolary, long-distance romance that uses video recordings instead of pen and paper.
lead_paragraph: A rare sustained epistolary romance, “Hank and Asha” runs on video recordings instead of pen and paper. Though not very ambitious, this winsome, whisper-thin tale shimmers along with the charming urge to connect and reveal yourself that links its two correspondents.

headline: Breaking Silence on a Monk
abstract: “Thomas Keating: A Rising Tide of Silence” is a reverent collection of interviews and archival speeches about its subject, a Trappist monk.
lead_paragraph: “Thomas Keating: A Rising Tide of Silence” is a loving portrait of the titular Trappist monk and author, directed by Peter C. Jones, his nephew. The film covers Father Keating’s early days in an affluent family in New York City and on Long Island, then progresses through his passionate embracing of the monastic life.

headline: Doctors Shun Insurance, Offering Care for Cash
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Doctors', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: As Texas works to increase the number of residents with health coverage, some doctors have opted to avoid the insurance system’s bureaucracy, saying they can keep costs down with a cash-based model.
lead_paragraph: LAREDO, Tex. — For 12 hours a day, the waiting room at Dr. Gustavo Villarreal’s family practice is packed with patients who pay a flat $50 fee for the convenience — or necessity — of a walk-in, quick-turn doctor’s visit.

headline: U.S. Indicts Ex-Connecticut Governor Again
abstract: Mr. Rowland, who resigned in 2004 in a corruption scandal and was imprisoned, was charged with trying to hide his involvement in House campaigns in 2010 and 2012.
lead_paragraph: John G. Rowland, who resigned as governor of Connecticut 10 years ago in a corruption scandal, was indicted on Thursday on charges that he tried to hide his involvement in congressional campaigns in 2010 and 2012.

headline: Teenagers, Fed Up, Hatch a Deadly Plan
abstract: In “Perfect Sisters,” based on a true story, two Canadian siblings decide to kill their mother.
lead_paragraph: Several times, “Perfect Sisters” shifts its tone so jarringly that you’re left scratching your head. But eventually you realize that Stan Brooks, the director, might be making a point with the incongruity. If so, kudos to him for trying something different in a movie that otherwise could have seemed like an extended episode of any of the scheming-teenager shows that are all over television.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around Texas this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for

headline: Kitchen Table Anarchists Under Siege
abstract: “No God, No Master,” starring David Strathairn, offers a sepia-toned account of the Palmer raids, a time of reds-under-the-bed hysteria and leftist persecution.
lead_paragraph: A stodgy banquet of idealistic speeches and weeping violins, “No God, No Master” presents a fascinating period in modern American history — the infamous 1919-20 raids on anarchist suspects by Attorney General A. Mitchell Palmer — with more earnestness than artistry.

headline: Events in New Jersey for April 13-19, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Latin Rhythms, Exported to the Mideast
abstract: In “Dancing in Jaffa,” the ballroom dancer Pierre Dulaine, whose organization was featured in “Mad Hot Ballroom,” teaches Jewish and Palestinian youngsters steps and courtesies.
lead_paragraph: Pierre Dulaine, a teacher and former champion in ballroom dancing, is the founder of Dancing Classrooms, a nonprofit organization behind the events in Marilyn Agrelo’s 2005 documentary, “Mad Hot Ballroom.” That film concerned Dancing Classrooms’ work with New York students; in Hilla Medalia’s charming “Dancing in Jaffa,” Mr. Dulaine heads to Israel to try to instill mutual respect in 10- and 11-year-old Jewish and Palestinian Israelis through a 10-week course in the movements (and courtesies) of Latin dance.

headline: Rescinding an Honor for an Anti-Islam Activist
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Opposing views on Brandeis’s decision not to honor Ayaan Hirsi Ali.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Finding Meaning in Life
abstract: A reader responds to a Sunday Review essay by Barbara Ehrenreich, “A Rationalist’s Mystical Moment.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Philip Roth, Still Writing (Letters, at Least)
abstract: The novelist responds to a claim made about him in a book review.

headline: Students Reading E-Books Are Losing Out, Study Suggests
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Children and Childhood', 'E-Books and Readers', 'Education (K-12)', 'Parenting', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Researchers find that students’ reading comprehension was lower when they read books on electronic devices.
lead_paragraph: Could e-books actually get in the way of reading?

headline: Exploring the Blot on a Newspaper’s Record
abstract: Samantha Grant’s documentary, “A Fragile Trust,” comes a decade after the fraud scandal at The New York Times perpetrated by the reporter Jayson Blair.
lead_paragraph: At a media ethics talk excerpted toward the end of “A Fragile Trust,” an audience member asks the speaker, Jayson Blair, why anyone should ever believe him. That question isn’t satisfactorily addressed in Samantha Grant’s documentary, a decade-later excavation of the scandal involving Mr. Blair at The New York Times. It’s not as if this superficial accounting of his offenses offered evidence of renewed credibility.

headline: A Man of God, and of Contradictions
abstract: “The Jewish Cardinal,” by Ilan Duran Cohen, traces the life of the Jewish-born French cardinal, Jean-Marie Lustiger.
lead_paragraph: The title of Ilan Duran Cohen’s film “The Jewish Cardinal” may sound like a punch line. But it accurately describes a real man, Jean-Marie Lustiger, the Paris-born son of Jewish immigrants from Poland, who at 13, bar mitzvah age, converted to Catholicism in the fraught year of 1940.

headline: On Madison Avenue, the Word on ‘Mad Men’
abstract: The popular AMC show about fictional advertising men and women of the 1960s begins the first half of its final season on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: FROM the filming of its pilot episode to the disclosure that its seventh — and last — season would be split in two, the AMC series “Mad Men” has intrigued, captivated and sometimes infuriated the real-life counterparts of the show’s fictional advertising men and women of the 1960s.

headline: A View From Hong Kong
abstract: The Hong Kong government responds to an editorial.

headline: Wooing the Boss With a Spicy Dance
abstract: In “Cuban Fury,” the British comic Nick Frost stars as a former child salsa-dancing champ who brushes up on his skills to woo his new American boss.
lead_paragraph: Comedy, romantic and otherwise, has shuttled back and forth across the Atlantic over the years, picking up a band of horny buddies here, some mumbling self-deprecation there. “Cuban Fury” (which has both) stars the British comic Nick Frost as Bruce, a former child salsa-dancing champ. But despite the overblown title, the movie is milder than a Will Ferrell drag vehicle and more of an ordinary shy-guy-makes-good yarn punched up with some recurring bits.

headline: The Question Is Whodunit; the Answer Is Clear
abstract: The shooting deaths of a Sept. 11 conspiracy theorist and his two teenage children were ruled a murder-suicide, but “Unthinkable” takes a different view.
lead_paragraph: “Unthinkable” is unwatchable, which is too bad, because there are certainly enough oddities in the incident it tries to dramatize to have made for a decent conspiracy theory film.

headline: Events on Long Island for April 13-19, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: California: Reward Offered to Solve Attack on Power Substation
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Cyberwarfare', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: With no apparent progress in determining who attacked an electric substation in Silicon Valley a year ago, Pacific Gas & Electric on Thursday offered a $250,000 reward for information.
lead_paragraph: With no apparent progress in determining who attacked an electric substation in Silicon Valley a year ago, Pacific Gas & Electric on Thursday offered a $250,000 reward for information. The utility said that it planned $100 million in security investments in the next three years. The attack did not shut off power but did substantial damage when someone shot out radiators on 17 transformers and clipped fiber-optic telephone lines. Also on Thursday, government and industry officials testified at a Senate committee hearing that they were making progress on improving both physical and cybersecurity on the grid, a subject of rising anxiety.

headline: Like, if You Can’t Beat ’Em, Join ’Em?
abstract: Readers respond to a Sunday Review essay that posited an increased civility in our use of language.

headline: During Hagel Visit, China Showed Its Military Might, and Its Frustrations
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: In his official visit to China, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel encountered combative public warnings and private complaints that Beijing felt besieged by hostile neighbors.
lead_paragraph: ULAN BATOR, Mongolia — When Robert M. Gates visited China in 2011 as the United States defense secretary, the military greeted him with an unexpected and, in the view of American military officials, provocative test of a Chinese stealth fighter jet, a bold show of force that stunned the visiting Americans and may even have surprised the Chinese president at the time, Hu Jintao.

headline: Don’t Stand There. The Dance Cartel Wants You to Shake It!
abstract: The Dance Cartel’s performances embrace an inclusive philosophy that encourages audience participation, and its ragtag artistic sensibility and low ticket prices foster accessibility.
lead_paragraph: HOW do you start a dance craze? The members of the Dance Cartel think the next Nae Nae or Dougie could be the Space Bounce or maybe the Flickitty Poppitty.

headline: Polk Award for Snowden Coverage Draws 2 to U.S.
keywords: ['Polk, George, Awards', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Glenn Greenwald and Laura Poitras, who reported on documents about government surveillance leaked by Edward J. Snowden, will be given the Polk Award.
lead_paragraph: Glenn Greenwald and Laura Poitras, two of the journalists who reported on documents about government surveillance leaked by Edward J. Snowden, plan to return to the United States on Friday to accept a Polk journalism award for national security reporting.

headline: The Tobacco Ties That Bind
abstract: Why doesn’t the cancer society protest all cigarette sales?
lead_paragraph: I DON’T smoke, but if during the day I wanted to buy cigarettes, I could walk into the CVS pharmacy across the street from my office, or the Walgreens two blocks away, and get them. They’re kept right behind the cash register.

headline: Bush Urges Effort to Close Black and White Students’ Achievement Gap
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Equal Educational Opportunities', 'No Child Left Behind Act', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: Former President George W. Bush said both parties should come together to address the problem as the central civil rights issue of the modern era.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Former President George W. Bush called the achievement gap between white and black children “a national scandal” on Thursday and urged both parties to come together to address it as the central civil rights issue of the modern era.

headline: Events in Westchester for April 13-19, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Russia: Lawmakers Want to Investigate Gorbachev
abstract: Five members of the Russian Parliament have asked the prosecutor general to open a criminal case to investigate the breakup of the Soviet Union and the role played by Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
lead_paragraph: Five members of the Russian Parliament have asked the prosecutor general to open a criminal case to investigate the breakup of the Soviet Union and the role played by the former leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev. They contend that he failed to heed a referendum in 1991 that showed that a majority of Soviet citizens wanted to retain the union, and that he illegally formed a committee to study granting sovereignty to the Baltic countries. Mr. Gorbachev, 83, responded that he would cooperate but blamed the leaders of Russia, Ukraine and Belarus for the breakup. This stirring up of history captures an official mood today in Moscow, where many are questioning the legitimacy of former Soviet borders, and President Vladimir V. Putin’s government has twice in five years crossed them with the Russian Army, in Georgia in 2008 and in Ukraine this year.

headline: How to Heal the Heartland
abstract: The way to a viable future for dying counties lies just below ground level, and at the border’s edge: water and immigration.
lead_paragraph: It’s tornado season, the springtime tempest, which means the Big Empty of the United States will get another cameo on the nation’s stage. Prepare for the annual montage of heartbreak and houses tossed to the wind, of schools scalped of their roofs and trailer parks reduced to rubble.

headline: The Grand Jury Indictment
abstract: The United States attorney’s office said John G. Rowland, a Republican who served as governor of Connecticut from 1995 to 2004 and as a congressman from 1985 to 1991, would be arraigned on Friday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: The United States attorney’s office said John G. Rowland, a Republican who served as governor of Connecticut from 1995 to 2004 and as a congressman from 1985 to 1991, would be arraigned on Friday afternoon.

headline: Health Care Nightmares
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid', 'United States Politics and Government', 'States (US)']
abstract: Obamacare is doing just fine. But America is not, thanks to the ugliness brought out into the open by the debate on health reform.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to health reform, Republicans suffer from delusions of disaster. They know, just know, that the Affordable Care Act is doomed to utter failure, so failure is what they see, never mind the facts on the ground.

headline: Shoe Thrown at Hillary Clinton During Speech
abstract: Mrs. Clinton, who was addressing a group in Las Vegas, ducked and laughed off the episode.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton was interrupted during a Las Vegas speech on Thursday, when a woman in the audience threw a shoe at her.

headline: The Moral Power of Curiosity
abstract: “Flash Boys” by Michael Lewis is mostly a book about finance and high-frequency traders. But it’s also a morality tale.
lead_paragraph: Most of us have at one time or another felt ourselves in the grip of the explanatory drive. You’re confronted by some puzzle, confusion or mystery. Your inability to come up with an answer gnaws at you. You’re up at night, turning the problem over in your mind. Then, suddenly: clarity. The pieces click into place. There’s a jolt of pure satisfaction.

headline: NYT Now: Sylvia Mathews Burwell
abstract: Michael D. Shear on President Obama’s new nominee for health secretary.
lead_paragraph: Michael D. Shear on President Obama’s new nominee for health secretary.

headline: Amazon Buys ComiXology
keywords: ['Comic Books and Strips', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Zap! Pow! The acquisition of ComiXology fits nicely into Amazon’s entertainment strategy, which focuses on controlling the means of distribution.
lead_paragraph: Amazon extended its domain over the world of words on Thursday by acquiring ComiXology, the giant digital comics platform. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: At Amen Corner, Masters Scores Turn for the Worse
abstract: Bill Haas, a five-time winner on the PGA Tour, had a one-shot lead after the first round of the Masters.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — When Adam Scott walked to the tee of the treacherous par-3 12th hole during the first round of the Masters, he was at the pivot of the exalted Amen Corner. The crowd awaiting him — among the largest on the grounds of the Augusta National Golf Club — rose in applause.

headline: For Greece, a Sign of Stability
abstract: The country’s return to global capital markets was met with enthusiasm, but its economic struggle is not over.
lead_paragraph: After years of agonizing austerity and the biggest debt restructuring in history, Greece had some good news on Thursday when investors reacted enthusiastically to the country’s return to global capital markets with the sale of five-year bonds, raising 3 billion euros, or about $4.2 billion. The sale attracted more than €20 billion in orders, driving the interest rate down to 4.75 percent, well below expectations.

headline: Israel to Halt Tax Transfers to Palestinians
abstract: The move came in response to the Palestinian leadership’s application last week to join 15 international conventions and treaties.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel will halt the monthly transfer of tax revenues it collects on behalf of the Palestinian Authority and use the money to offset Palestinian debts to Israeli utility companies, a government official said late Thursday.

headline: Mr. Cuomo’s Gift to the Cynics
abstract: So much for the governor’s promise to fight corruption in Albany. He shut down the independent ethics commission before it had a chance to do its job.
lead_paragraph: Nine months ago, Gov. Andrew Cuomo looked New Yorkers in the eye and said, “Trust is everything to me.” Don’t believe it.

headline: Events in Connecticut for April 13-19, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Former Bell, Calif., Official Sentenced on Corruption Charge
abstract: Angela Spaccia, the former assistant city manager, was sentenced to more than 11 years in prison and ordered to pay millions of dollars in restitution to the city she robbed.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The former assistant city manager of Bell, Calif., was sentenced Thursday to more than 11 years in prison on corruption charges, and ordered to pay millions of dollars in restitution to the city she robbed.

headline: Satellites Show Russian Forces Poised Near Ukraine
abstract: A top NATO commander said the satellite photographs showed a menacing force of Russian fighter jets and tanks, along with as many as 40,000 troops, near the border with Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — NATO released satellite photographs on Thursday showing Russian military equipment, including fighter jets and tanks, that it described as part of a deployment of as many as 40,000 troops near the border with Ukraine. The release came the same day that President Vladimir V. Putin reiterated a threat to curtail gas sales to Ukraine.

headline: Telling a U.N. Envoy to Stay Home
abstract: Should the United States deny a visa to Iran's next ambassador to the United Nations because he was involved with the 1979 Tehran embassy takeover?

headline: Anglican Leader, Under Fire for Remarks, Urges Caution on Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'ANGLICAN CHURCHES']
abstract: The archbishop of Canterbury, who earlier appeared to link gay rights to violence against Christians, spoke of mindfulness of global differences.
lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — The archbishop of Canterbury, under fire for appearing to link expanded gay rights in the United States to violence against Christians in Africa, said on Thursday that he is advocating for a slow and deliberative response to same-sex marriage, mindful of the global implications.

headline: Former Massachusetts Senator Announces New Hampshire Run
abstract: Scott Brown seeks to represent a second state in the United States Senate, a feat that has not been accomplished in more than a century.
lead_paragraph: PORTSMOUTH, N.H. — From the Mount Cube Sugar Farm in Orford to the Moose Muck Coffee House in Colebrook, Scott Brown has been testing his message across New Hampshire and, to the surprise of almost no one, has decided that it works.

headline: In eBay Fight, Icahn Chooses Peace Over War
abstract: In an interview, the activist investor discusses his reasons for backing down on his fight to force eBay’s hand on PayPal.
lead_paragraph: It’s not every day that you hear the billionaire activist investor Carl C. Icahn utter the statement, “it’s better to have peace than war.”

headline: Lance Armstrong’s Positive, if Reluctant, Step in a Sport’s Purification
abstract: In a roundabout way, Armstrong may have done something to help clean up the sport of cycling by naming names in a lawsuit about doping.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, Lance Armstrong sat a few feet from me and said he would never “rat out” his friends by publicly revealing who had helped him dope and who had known about his doping. Not a chance. No way. The last thing he would ever do.

headline: Minnesota Lawmakers Vote to Raise Base Wage
abstract: Legislators decided to increase the wage from $6.15 to $9.50 an hour by 2016 for large employers.
lead_paragraph: Minnesota lawmakers voted to raise the minimum wage on Thursday, making it the fifth state to raise base wages this year with midterm elections approaching.

headline: An App to Avoid the Unwelcome on Your List
abstract: Cloak, an app, can be set up so that it alerts you when specific people — a former girlfriend or boyfriend, for instance — are posting to social media.
lead_paragraph: Cloak is the antisocial-media app: It combs your Instagram and Foursquare feeds (and any day now, those of Twitter and Facebook) so you can avoid undesirable people. When someone you’re trying to elude checks in on Foursquare, say, the location shows up on a map within Cloak, alerting you to the whereabouts of your nemesis. You can set the app up so that it alerts you when specific people — a former girlfriend or boyfriend, for instance — are posting to social media, or you can have a broad alert set for when you really just want to be alone. Despite its name, Cloak doesn’t hide you; if you want to hide, don’t post to Instagram.

headline: A Private Equity Titan With a Narrow Focus and Broad Aims
abstract: Vista Equity Partners, whose performance rivals that of the big names in the field, invests exclusively in enterprise software while seeking to transform the companies it holds.
lead_paragraph: One of the best-performing private equity firms of the last 15 years doesn’t have a big name like K.K.R., Blackstone or TPG.

headline: U.S. Agencies ‘Generally’ Acted Properly Before Boston Bombing, Report Says
abstract: The inspector general for the intelligence community concluded that investigators should have more closely scrutinized Tamerlan Tsarnaev after he traveled to Russia in 2012.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal law enforcement and intelligence agencies “generally shared information and followed procedures appropriately” in their investigation of Tamerlan Tsarnaev and his brother, Dzhokhar, in the years leading up to the Boston Marathon bombing, but they should have more closely scrutinized Tamerlan when he returned to the United States from Dagestan in 2012, according to a report by the inspector general for the intelligence community that was released on Thursday.

headline: Keeping Track: Drug Sentences and Crowdfunding
abstract: Updates on a few of the issues we’re following.
lead_paragraph: Shorter Drug Sentences

headline: Mexico: Convicted Trafficker Now Aiding U.S. Officials
abstract: The United States attorney in Chicago said that a top member of the Sinaloa gang had been cooperating with the authorities since he pleaded guilty to drug trafficking charges a year ago.
lead_paragraph: The United States attorney in Chicago said Thursday that a top member of the Sinaloa gang had been cooperating with the authorities since he pleaded guilty to drug trafficking charges a year ago. The man, Jesús Vicente Zambada Niebla, who was arrested in Mexico in 2009, is the son of Ismael Zambada García, believed to be one of the leaders of the Sinaloa gang. Under a plea deal, Mr. Zambada Niebla, 39, could receive a lighter sentence if he continues to cooperate. The agreement describes how he delivered tons of cocaine and heroin from South and Central America to distributors, who then smuggled the drugs to the United States. Also Thursday, the Treasury Department said that it was imposing sanctions on real estate companies in Guadalajara that laundered money for other top figures in the same gang.

headline: Northern Ireland: Man Charged in 1998 Bombing
abstract: Seamus Daly, a well-known Irish Republican, was charged on Thursday with the murders of 29 people in a car bombing in Omagh, Northern Ireland, in 1998.
lead_paragraph: A well-known Irish Republican was charged on Thursday with the murders of 29 people who were killed in a car bombing in Omagh, Northern Ireland, in 1998. The bombing, which was carried out by the Real Irish Republican Army, a splinter group, was the worst single atrocity of the conflict known as the Troubles, and it wounded more than 220 people. But there has never been a criminal conviction in the case. The man charged Thursday, Seamus Daly, 43, was arrested on Monday. He was one of four men ordered to pay more than $2.5 million in damages to the victims’ families in a civil case five years ago. He has always denied involvement in the bombing.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 10, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: April 10, 2014

headline: Radio Clip Shows Different Side of Republican Senate Challenger in Mississippi
abstract: State Senator Chris McDaniel is seeking to topple U.S. Senator Thad Cochran of Mississippi, but first he will have to explain comments he made in his days as a radio broadcaster.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — State Senator Chris McDaniel cuts a smooth-as-silk image as he crisscrosses Mississippi seeking to topple Senator Thad Cochran in the Republican primary.

headline: Lance Armstrong Reveals Names in Lawsuit
abstract: In documents released as part of a whistleblower lawsuit, Lance Armstrong reveals for the first time that several key members of his cycling team knew or aided him in doping.
lead_paragraph: In documents released as part of a whistleblower lawsuit, Lance Armstrong reveals for the first time that several key members of his cycling team knew or aided him in doping.

headline: Gaza Runner, Israeli Hurdles
abstract: The Palestinian Olympic athlete Nader al-Masri has been denied permission by Israel to cross from Gaza to participate in this year’s Palestine Marathon in Bethlehem.
lead_paragraph: The Palestinian Olympic athlete Nader al-Masri has been denied permission by Israel to cross from Gaza to participate in this year’s Palestine Marathon in Bethlehem.

headline: Heartbleed Flaw Could Reach to Digital Devices, Experts Say
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Computer Security', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: Hardware like home routers and printers is connected to the Internet, and the Heartbleed bug is built into some of it.
lead_paragraph: When the Heartbleed bug was disclosed on Monday, the attention focused on the fallout for major Internet companies like Yahoo and Amazon. But security experts said the potential for harm could extend much further, to the guts of the Internet and the many devices that connect to it.

headline: Two Gambles on Outfielders, but One Costs Millions More
abstract: The Yankees spent $153 million to lure away Jacoby Ellsbury from the Red Sox, who made a one-year, $750,000 deal with Grady Sizemore to help replace him.
lead_paragraph: Grady Sizemore played every game in 2007, from opening day through the seventh game of the American League Championship Series. He was on the winning side of the final postseason game at the old Yankee Stadium, but his Cleveland Indians fell short of the World Series. The Boston Red Sox stopped them.

headline: Mideast Tensions Sideline a Gazan Marathon Runner
abstract: Israel, citing “the present diplomatic-security situation,” refuses to let the Olympic athlete Nader al-Masri cross the country to compete in a marathon in Bethlehem.
lead_paragraph: BEIT HANOUN, Gaza Strip — As a boy growing up in this town close to the border with Israel, Nader al-Masri was the neighborhood champion of Catch Me if You Can. “No one could catch me,” he recalled. After soccer matches, young Nader would do laps around the empty field.

headline: A Toast to the Ramps of Spring
abstract: One of the first restaurants in New York City to be serving ramps this year is Tarallucci e Vino, an Italianesque wine bar at 15 East 18th Street.
lead_paragraph: The first wild onions of the season — or ramps, as they are called — are to die-hard food lovers what robins or baseball are to the rest of us: a harbinger of spring. One of the first restaurants in the city to be serving ramps this year is Tarallucci e Vino, an Italianesque wine bar at 15 East 18th Street. “I basically called everyone I knew trying to find them,” said Andrew Welch, the head chef, who eventually scored a batch of ramps from an unnamed forager in South Carolina. That cache, followed by a second from Virginia, caused the restaurant to issue an ecstatic Twitter post two weeks ago: “First ramps of the season!” (The message was concluded by the only-in-the-New-York-food-world hashtag of #omgramps.) So far, Mr. Welch has used his ramps in entrees like the hand-rolled garganelli pasta he was serving the other night with fiddlehead ferns, crushed red pepper and a ramp pesto ($19,) and in appetizers like the one a party of three was enjoying while waiting for a missing fourth person to arrive.

headline: Testimony Still Sought on Shut Lanes at George Washington Bridge
abstract: Investigators in New Jersey say they will begin calling witnesses to testify despite a judge’s ruling that two former aides to Gov. Chris Christie did not have to comply.
lead_paragraph: Legislative investigators in New Jersey say they will begin calling witnesses to testify about the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge last fall, proceeding even though a judge ruled that two former aides to Gov. Chris Christie did not have to comply with a subpoena seeking records related to the scandal.

headline: Answers to Questions About the Con Edison Clock Tower’s Lights and Bingo
abstract: Readers ask about the status of lights at the Con Edison clock tower and bingo’s origins.
lead_paragraph: Q. I am used to seeing the top of the Con Edison clock tower, off Union Square, lighted up. On April 1, the lights went out and stayed out for quite a while. Was that an April Fools’ joke?

headline: The Chanteuse and the Gun Are Loaded
abstract: “Bullets Over Broadway: The Musical,” inspired by Woody Allen’s 1994 film of the same title, is instructive for those determined to translate screen chemistry into crowd-wowing live theater.
lead_paragraph: Some things were never meant to be shouted through megaphones. On the basis of “Bullets Over Broadway: The Musical,” the occasionally funny but mostly just loud new show that opened at the St. James Theater on Thursday night, that would include the wit of Woody Allen.

headline: Things Worn at Home
abstract: Friday fun with Peter Wentz. Once you break into it.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — This one was challenging, as Friday puzzles tend to be, but wow, was it worth it. There is so much good stuff in today’s puzzle by Peter Wentz. I just had to work hard to establish a toehold in order to find it.

headline: Patrons of 2 Stores Ponder a Loss of Music and Color
abstract: J & R, a popular electronics and music store in Lower Manhattan, abruptly shut, at least for now, and the building housing Pearl Paint is for sale.
lead_paragraph: It was where Vincent Moore went to buy Led Zeppelin, Jimi Hendrix and Donna Summer on LPs in the 1970s. It was where he went to buy the first “Die Hard” movie on VHS in the 1980s, and countless compact discs. Later still, it was where he bought his first digital camera.

headline: Partnerships Old, New and Stage-Managed
abstract: A production of “Our Town” opens at George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick on April 22.
lead_paragraph: Pico Alexander, the 22-year-old actor playing George Gibbs in the production of “Our Town” opening at George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick later this month, has sometimes had trouble focusing during rehearsals.

headline: Three Honorary Starters at the Masters, With 13 Green Jackets
abstract: The Masters got off to its traditional start with honorary drives off the first tee by Arnold Palmer, Gary Player and Jack Nicklaus, who won the tournament a combined 13 times.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Tiger Woods is not playing in the Masters for the first time since 1994 because of a back injury, but he has not forgotten about the tournament, which he has won four times. Woods took to Twitter on Thursday after the honorary starters, Arnold Palmer, Gary Player and Jack Nicklaus, hit the first tee shots to open the 78th Masters.

headline: An Arkin Brother’s Standing Commitment
abstract: Bob Arkin, whose older brother is the actor Alan Arkin, has spent his life eking out a living with his bass, playing modest gigs mostly in New York.
lead_paragraph: Bob Arkin had just arrived at the gig, and already the boss was starting in.

headline: Officials Rule Boy’s Death as Homicide
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: An autopsy determined Myls Dobson, 4, died of “child abuse syndrome, including dehydration.”
lead_paragraph: The death of a 4-year-old boy, who prosecutors say was tortured and starved to death by a family friend, has been ruled a homicide by the New York City medical examiner’s officer, paving the way for murder charges to be filed in the case.

headline: Three Aggressive Young Golf Stars Are More Old School Than Not
abstract: The Masters group of Rory McIlroy, Jordan Spieth and Patrick Reed leads a new wave of players who have never seen a tournament field they didn’t think they could dominate.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The young and the restless grouping of Rory McIlroy, Jordan Spieth and Patrick Reed arrived at the par-4 17th hole a combined four under par in the first round of the Masters. All three hit approaches that looked suitable for posing, but two of the balls rolled like tears off the green.

headline: Venezuelan Leader and Opposition Meet in Bid to Ease Tensions
abstract: President Nicolás Maduro and a coalition of opposition leaders met at the presidential palace in Caracas in a televised conference aimed at bridging a bitter political divide.
lead_paragraph: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela and leaders of a coalition of opposition political parties held a dramatic televised meeting on Thursday in a first step aimed at defusing tensions that have escalated during more than two months of antigovernment protests.

headline: Culture Minute | A Weekend Jump-Start
abstract: Some ideas for your off hours. Last chance for the Trisha Brown Dance Company in New York, the final season of “Mad Men” begins, and a Woody Allen-inspired Broadway show.
lead_paragraph: Some ideas for your off hours. Last chance for the Trisha Brown Dance Company in New York, the final season of “Mad Men” begins, and a Woody Allen-inspired Broadway show.

headline: Italian Court Weighs Community Service for Berlusconi
abstract: The court is considering whether former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, convicted of tax fraud, should be placed under house arrest or allowed to fulfill his sentence with community service.
lead_paragraph: ROME — A court in Milan held a sentencing hearing on Thursday for former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, who was convicted of tax fraud in 2012.

headline: In a Queens School, an Early Start on Preparing ‘Responsible Digital Citizens’
abstract: A teacher broaches social media, stressing safety to children who can sign up for Facebook when they turn 13.
lead_paragraph: Janet Elias refers to her students as digital natives, children who have never known a world without computers. She teaches them to search the Internet and create slide-show presentations, and this year she has also added a theme on social media: its applications, its effect on real-world events and the importance of using it safely.

headline: Settlement Ends Dispute Over Rooney’s Remains
abstract: The body of Mr. Rooney, who died Sunday, will be released to the Hollywood Forever Cemetery, where some family members may attend a private ceremony.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Mickey Rooney can finally rest in peace, as a dispute over disposition of his remains was settled on Thursday, according to The Wrap. The settlement came shortly before a court hearing that was to have addressed the matter on Friday morning.

headline: Rangers, in Their Home Finale, Slip Past the Last-Place Sabres
abstract: Rick Nash scored with 1 minute 42 seconds left in regulation to help the Rangers finish with a mediocre 20-17-4 home record.
lead_paragraph: The sign of a confident team, Rick Nash was saying in the Rangers’ locker room Thursday night, is winning the bad games.

headline: Yankees Win in Style, but Most of Focus Is on a Substance
abstract: Michael Pineda had a brownish substance on his pitching hand during a dominant outing. The Red Sox did not object to it, though, and Pineda later said it was dirt.
lead_paragraph: After all the money spent, after the Yankees poached a star Boston outfielder and the Red Sox brought his World Series ring to Yankee Stadium, after all this, the story line in the first meeting of 2014 belonged to Michael Pineda’s right hand.

headline: Rangel and Challengers Meet in First Debate of Primary Campaign
abstract: On Thursday night, Mr. Rangel, the longtime congressman from Harlem, faced two fellow Democrats in a feisty 90-minute debate.
lead_paragraph: The grizzled incumbent trumpeted his experience, pounding on the table for emphasis while insisting, to laughter, that he wouldn’t cling to his seat “till I drop dead.”

headline: House Votes to Deny Visa to Iranian Envoy Linked to ’79 Hostage Crisis
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Visas', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The legislation is a blunt response to Iran’s choice for United Nations ambassador: Hamid Aboutalebi, who played a role in the 1979 American hostage crisis.
lead_paragraph: The House on Thursday unanimously passed legislation approved by the Senate aimed at denying a visa to Iran’s choice for United Nations ambassador. The vote sent what sponsors called a blunt rejoinder to the Iranian government for having selected a nominee who played a role, however minor, in the 1979 American hostage crisis in Tehran.

headline: Steven A. Shaw, 44, Founder of an Early Blog About Food, Dies
abstract: Mr. Shaw’s open-forum websites became online hubs for chefs, serious home cooks, gourmands and people just looking for a new restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Steven A. Shaw, a founder of the influential online culinary discussion forum eGullet and one of the first writers to start his own food blog, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 44.

headline: Newcomer and Powerhouse Reach Final
abstract: Union defeated the five-time national champion Boston College to advance to the Frozen Four final on Saturday against No. 1 seed Minnesota, which won in the final second.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Daniel Ciampini scored a hat trick to lift Union College over Boston College, 5-4, on Thursday at Wells Fargo Center. The Dutchmen (31-6-4) advanced to their first N.C.A.A. final, where on Saturday they will face Minnesota, the No. 1 seed.

headline: Diamond in the Rough
abstract: The self-taught, risk-taking American sculptor Alma Allen has taken the long road from the sidewalks of SoHo to the desert of Joshua Tree to art stardom.
lead_paragraph: From hawking his wares on the sidewalks of SoHo to showing them at the Whitney Biennial, the sculptor Alma Allen has taken the road less traveled to art world stardom.

headline: Three Storied Design Brands Venture Into New Territory
abstract: At this year’s Salone del Mobile in Milan, the Finnish tableware company Iittala ventured into housewares; the Italian housewares maker Kartell moved into tableware; and the German furniture line e15 got serious about lighting.
lead_paragraph: At this year’s Salone del Mobile in Milan, the Finnish tableware company Iittala expanded into housewares; the Italian housewares maker Kartell moved into tableware; and the German furniture line e15 got serious about lighting.

keywords: ['Rock and Stone', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Marble emerges as the material of choice in contemporary design.
lead_paragraph: From monoliths to mosaics, marble has been a staple of regal artistry since the days of ancient Egypt. Now, a new group of designers are carving out their own models.

headline: Itinerary | Joshua Tree’s Artful Excursions
abstract: The sculptor Alma Allen’s Mojave desert neighborhood offers a host of other inspiring attractions.
lead_paragraph: Whether or not you can score a personal invite to the sculptor and designer Alma Allen’s home and studio in Joshua Tree, Calif., the desert respite offers plenty of other sources of art, culture and inspiration (and makes for an ideal escape from the nearby madness that is the Coachella festival). Here, a few highlights.

abstract: Whatever they may say publicly about how human life is priceless, members of Congress regularly make decisions that set values on it, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: 9 Dead and Dozens Injured in California Crash
abstract: A tour bus carrying high school students on a college visit collided with an 18-wheeler on Thursday, killing nine people and injuring dozens more, according to the authorities.
lead_paragraph: A tour bus carrying high school students on a college visit collided with a FedEx 18-wheeler in a fiery crash on Thursday in Northern California that left nine people dead and dozens injured, according to the authorities.

headline: Showing Value at the Plate and on the Bases, Young Leads the Mets to a Win
abstract: Eric Young Jr. had three hits and three steals and scored four runs in the Mets’ victory at Turner Field.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Just before the season, Eric Young Jr. seemed to be the odd man out in the Mets’ outfield, behind Curtis Granderson, Chris Young and Juan Lagares. His speed was his most notable trait, and he was the Mets’ only natural leadoff hitter, but to play, he had to show that the team could not thrive with just anyone leading off.

headline: India Election Digest: April 11
abstract: A roundup of the top local election news for Friday.
lead_paragraph: What you need to know on Friday about India’s elections: Voter turnout was high during the first big phase of the elections, Narendra Modi’s estranged wife expresses hope that he will win, and candidates look for ways to exceed their legal campaign spending limit.

headline: N.B.A. to Play Abroad in Preseason
abstract: The N.B.A. on Thursday announced a slate of international preseason games to be played in October.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. on Thursday announced a slate of international preseason games to be played in October. There will be five games across four countries, including two Nets games in China. The Nets and the Sacramento Kings will play Oct. 12 in Shanghai and Oct. 15 in Beijing. The Nets previously visited China in 2010, playing exhibition games in Beijing and Guangzhou. The San Antonio Spurs will play exhibition games against local clubs in Berlin and Istanbul, and the Miami Heat and the Cleveland Cavaliers will face off in Rio de Janeiro.

headline: Leee Black Childers, Portraitist of a Downtown Demimonde, Dies at 68
abstract: Mr. Childers fell in with the Warhol crowd in the late 1960s, capturing images of artists, drag queens, punk musicians and other late-night characters.
lead_paragraph: Leee Black Childers, whose photographs of Warholians, punk musicians, club kids, drag queens and other denizens of late-night downtown life told an inside story of a vibrant musical era in New York City and elsewhere, died on April 6 in Los Angeles, where he had gone to attend a retrospective of his work. He was 68 and lived in Brooklyn.

headline: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Welcomes Its Newest Members
abstract: Kiss, Nirvana, Hall & Oates and the E Street Band were among inductees honored at a ceremony in Brooklyn on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inducted its new members at a full-scale arena concert on Thursday night at Barclays Center, with its largest live audience by far. It would have been an ideal setting for the band that didn’t perform: Kiss, the hard-rock arena-spectacular showmen in makeup who, until this year, had been snubbed by the hall since becoming eligible in 1999. After Kiss was accepted, its members, past and present, had squabbled with the Hall of Fame and among themselves over which of its lineups, original or current, would perform; no one did.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 12:45 P.M. (HBO) GLORIA: IN HER OWN WORDS (2011) After making headlines as a journalist in the 1960s in New York City with an exposé on the working conditions of Playboy Bunnies, Gloria Steinem felt her political ideals expanding when she covered an abortion hearing for New York magazine in 1969 and learned of the horrifying experiences women had endured. (Ms. Steinem, above in 1969, kept secret the abortion she’d had at 22.) On Aug. 26, 1970, she helped lead the Women’s Strike for Equality on the 50th anniversary of the passage of the 19th Amendment, giving women the right to vote. In 1972 she helped found Ms. Magazine, beginning her ascent as a public face of feminism. This documentary from Peter W. Kunhardt chronicles the life of Ms. Steinem, who turned 80 last month, from her childhood in Toledo, Ohio, and the inspiration for her work, to her battle with breast cancer, her late-in-life marriage and subsequent widowhood. Barbara Walters, Helen Gurley Brown, Phil Donahue and Larry King weigh in.

headline: This Week’s Movies: April 11, 2014
abstract: The New York Times film critics on “Joe,” “Draft Day” and “Only Lovers Left Alive.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics on “Joe,” “Draft Day” and “Only Lovers Left Alive.”

headline: Beijing Court Upholds Legal Scholar’s Sentence
abstract: Xu Zhiyong’s four-year prison sentence for “gathering a crowd to disturb public order” was upheld the same day a Chinese-language collection of his writings was published in Hong Kong.
lead_paragraph: A Beijing court has upheld a four-year prison sentence for Xu Zhiyong, the legal scholar who inspired a campaign for civic participation and social justice in China. Mr. Xu was convicted in January of “gathering a crowd to disturb public order,” in connection with a series of small protests in 2012 and 2013 calling for government officials to disclose their assets.

headline: Panda Transfer Falls Victim to Fallout Over Missing Plane
abstract: Two pandas from Sichuan Province won’t soon be making a planned trip to a zoo in Malaysia amid strained ties between Beijing and Kuala Lumpur.
lead_paragraph: China is not shy about using “panda diplomacy” as a tool of soft power. It has a long tradition of bestowing nations with the bamboo-chomping mammals, most famously in the early 1970s, when Beijing sent two pandas to the National Zoo in Washington amid President Richard M. Nixon’s groundbreaking diplomatic opening to China.

headline: In London, Museum Adds Fashion Conservation Space
abstract: The facility includes an area for public study of the Victoria and Albert Museum’s vast collection.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Scientific advances and technological innovations continue to change textile conservation, but most specialists say the craft still depends on three things: agile hands, good sight — and space.

headline: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, April 11, 2014
abstract: Can you identify the number of commas that belong in the sentence from the article?
lead_paragraph: Use the following question for practice or just for fun.

abstract: What is your reaction to CBS’s choice to replace David Letterman on “Late Show”?
lead_paragraph: In “Colbert to Succeed Letterman on ‘Late Show,’ ” Bill Carter reports on CBS’s announcement of the next host for its flagship late-night program.

headline: When You Are Old Enough to Vote, Will You?
abstract: Do you think voting is important? Is it a civic duty?
lead_paragraph: Young people, ages 18 to 24, are significantly less likely to vote than those over age 35. People who make more than $75,000 a year are much more likely to vote than those making less than $50,000. That means older and wealthier Americans have a greater say in who is running our government — especially during midterm elections like the ones coming up this year. Do you think voting is important? Is it a civic duty?

headline: Look Again, With Love and Liebling
abstract: Jerome Liebling’s career was devoted to the idea that every person has value and dignity. A new exhibit shows that sentiment with lyric beauty.
lead_paragraph: Jerome Liebling’s lyrical vision of everyday life permeates a body of work that combines passionate idealism with sometimes brutal realism. It is a style shaped by a destitute childhood in Depression-era Brooklyn and forged by horrific firsthand experiences during many of the most violent battles of World War II.

headline: New York Today: Their First 100 Days, Too
abstract: What you need to know for Friday and the weekend: Political rookies take stock, cloudy turning rainy, and a festival of bad films.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this warm, cloudy Friday.

abstract: In a new globalist era, the United States is no longer the center of the universe — or of an academic field.
lead_paragraph: Academic politics are so vicious because the stakes are so small.

keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Batteries', 'Laptop Computers', 'Fires and Firefighters']

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Sony on Friday warned of the potential for batteries to burn or catch fire in some of its new Vaio laptop computers and asked owners of the units in question to stop using them immediately.

headline: Co-operative Bank Cancels Bonuses as It Posts Steep Loss
abstract: The embattled lender said that about 4.97 million pounds, or $8.38 million, in bonuses for current and former executives and other employees would not be paid as the bank reported a £1.3 billion pretax annual loss.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Co-operative Bank said on Friday that it would cancel 4.97 million pounds, or about $8.38 million, in bonuses for current and former executives and other employees as the British lender reported a £1.3 billion pretax annual loss.

headline: Why No One Goes to Naples
abstract: Tourism ought to be to southern Italy what oil is to Norway: a blessing and a source of wealth.
lead_paragraph: NAPLES, Italy — Spring is here. In southern Italy, the sun is shining, the sky is blue and the weather is balmy. Orange blossom fragrances mingle with wafts of jasmine. The food is good, the wine is inexpensive, the locals are friendly and beauty is all around. But where are the tourists?

headline: Daily Report: Security Flaw Could Extend to Digital Devices, Experts Say
abstract: Hardware like home routers and printers is connected to the Internet, and the Heartbleed bug is built into some of it.
lead_paragraph: When the Heartbleed bug was disclosed on Monday, the attention focused on the fallout for major Internet companies like Yahoo and Amazon. But security experts said the potential for harm could extend much further, to the guts of the Internet and the many devices that connect to it, Nicole Perlroth and Quentin Hardy report.

headline: Prosecutor Targets Pistorius’s Claims of Safety Fears
abstract: Oscar Pistorius, accused of killing his girlfriend, appeared flustered on Friday as the prosecution zeroed in on discrepancies in his testimony.
lead_paragraph: Oscar Pistorius appeared flustered, agitated and tired at his murder trial on Friday, the third day of cross-examination by a relentless prosecutor who accused him of shooting his girlfriend in the head during an argument.

headline: What Limiting the Employer Mandate Would Mean for Small Businesses
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Law and Legislation', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business']
abstract: One interesting aspect of the bill that passed the House is that both its advocates and opponents seem to overstate its potential effects.
lead_paragraph: The Save American Workers Act of 2014, which seeks to limit the reach of the Affordable Care Act’s employer mandate, has led a charmed life, for a bill. Most of its fellow legislation languishes in committee and never gets a public airing. But the Save American Workers Act was in and out of the House in a matter of months.

headline: Alessandra Stanley: Even the Snobs Say I’m Lucky
abstract: Alessandra Stanley spoke with us about writing about TV, binge viewings, her process and what she’s looking forward to watching next.
lead_paragraph: Alessandra Stanley, once a co-bureau chief for The Times in Moscow and a bureau chief in Rome, has been the chief television critic for The Times since 2003. In her columns, she interprets the latest prime-time obsessions, reality-TV guilty pleasures and major television news events, from debates to awards shows. She spoke with us about her approach to her work. Our conversation has been condensed and edited.

headline: Raising a Moral Child
abstract: The tactics are different from those used for encouraging achievement.
lead_paragraph: What does it take to be a good parent? We know some of the tricks for teaching kids to become high achievers. For example, research suggests that when parents praise effort rather than ability, children develop a stronger work ethic and become more motivated.

lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:11 p.m. | The contrasting fortunes of two of the nation’s biggest banks — JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo — at first glance point to the ascendancy of Main Street over Wall Street.

abstract: Iranians are gradually liberalizing while increasingly orthodox Israelis are drifting toward theocracy.
lead_paragraph: STANFORD, Calif. — Although the Israeli and Iranian governments have been virtually at war with each other for decades, the two countries have much in common.

lead_paragraph: With Moscow bearing down, Kiev seeks an economic rescue.

lead_paragraph: JPMORGAN EARNINGS FALL 18.5%  |  JPMorgan Chase reported an 18.5 percent slump in first-quarter earnings on Friday, as the nation’s largest bank grappled with dual challenges: sluggish revenue from trading and lackluster mortgage lending, Jessica Silver-Greenberg writes in DealBook. Both issues, broadly buffeting the banking industry, damped profits at JPMorgan.

headline: Laemmle’s List: A Mogul’s Heroism
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Movies']
abstract: Carl Laemmle, a founder of Universal Pictures, underwrote or assisted the emigration of many Jews from Germany as the Third Reich grew.
lead_paragraph: Among the pioneering moguls of Hollywood, Carl Laemmle, who commanded Universal Pictures for more than 20 years and who died 75 years ago, was not only less recognizable than the rest, he was also different from the rest. For one thing, he was older than the others and the first to emigrate from Europe to America. For another, he was less autocratic. Laemmle, an elfin man, was informal, unpretentious and cheery. Everyone, including his own son, called him Uncle Carl, and, according to one witness, he would roam the lot at Universal City with a pail in which he would urinate when he felt the urge. Most of the others made a point of declaiming their American-ness. Laemmle kept close ties to his native Germany — he visited Europe each year — and called the country his fatherland.

headline: Unlocking Android With a Glance
abstract: Plus, creating group photo albums on Facebook.
lead_paragraph: Q. Is the face-recognition feature on the Nexus tablet safer than using a password to unlock the tablet’s screen?

headline: Total Taxes on Wages Are Rising

abstract: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development reports that the average tax on wage income is climbing in many countries.
lead_paragraph: AFTER the financial crisis, many countries cut taxes to stimulate their economies. But since 2010, with concerns about government debt rising, the trend has gone the other way.

headline: Italian Asset Manager Raises $961.5 Million in I.P.O.
abstract: Anima priced its offering near the top of the expected range at €4.20 a share, giving it a market capitalization of €1.26 billion, or about $1.75 billion.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Italian asset manager Anima said on Friday that it raised 692.5 million euros, or about $961.5 million, in an initial public offering.

headline: Google Glass Available to Anyone in U.S. — for One Day Only
abstract: Next week Google is running a one-day promotion that will allow anyone in the United States to buy a pair of Google Glass. But some think the price, $1,500, is still too high.
lead_paragraph: Google Glass! On sale! One day only! Just $1,500! Get ’em while they’re hot!

headline: In an Instant, a Bus to College Was a Fiery Trap
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Buses', 'Trucks and Trucking']
abstract: The students in the accident were in a program in which Humboldt State University brings disadvantaged students who have been accepted to visit the campus.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Harley Hoyt, an 18-year-old senior at Valhalla High School in San Diego County, was listening to his headphones to pass the time during the 12-hour bus ride up California’s Interstate 5 when he was catapulted forward, his face smashing against the seat in front of him.

headline: They Died With the Camera On
keywords: ['Movies', 'Video Releases (Entertainment)', 'DVD (Digital Versatile Disc)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Anthony Mann’s “Men in War” examines American soldiers under fire in South Korea. “The Boy From Stalingrad” is grittier than its title suggests.
lead_paragraph: The Hollywood combat films produced during World War II were almost entirely heroic and celebratory. No American died in vain; a better world could be glimpsed beyond the storm clouds. The combat movies made during and soon after the Korean War were scarcely so optimistic.

headline: A Monstrous Wrong Undone in a Blaze of Pastoral Passion
abstract: Christopher Wheeldon’s new full-length adaptation of “The Winter’s Tale” for the Royal Ballet departs from traditional models for classical dance dramas.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the Bohemia scene in the Royal Ballet’s new full-length “The Winter’s Tale,” the very air feels abundantly fresh. The young lovers Perdita and Florizel, high on waves of mutual enchantment, dance both impetuously and experimentally, part of a community whose celebrations have an extraordinary folk vitality. Behind these two sweethearts is a vast greenwood tree laden with strange fruit harvested by the corps onstage, and the range of costumes suggests an eastern Mediterranean idyll, both contemporary and traditional. The music travels from a slow, exotic flute melody to tunes that trip with complex meters and orchestration of changing colors.

headline: The Return of Expansionary Austerity
abstract: Here we go again.
lead_paragraph: Here we go again. There’s now a full-court press of the usual suspects claiming that the recovery in the UK proves that fiscal austerity isn’t contractionary after all, that the IMF had it all wrong, and so on.

headline: Bayern Munich and Real Madrid to Meet in Champions League Semis
abstract: The two favorites to win the UEFA Champions League, Bayern Munich and Real Madrid, were matched against one another in the semifinals in a draw held Friday in Nyon, Switzerland.
lead_paragraph: The two favorites to win the UEFA Champions League, Bayern Munich and Real Madrid, were matched against one another in the semifinals in a draw held Friday in Nyon, Switzerland.

headline: Gone in 0.001 Seconds
keywords: ['High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Books and Literature', 'Financial Brokers', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The author of “Liar’s Poker” and “The Big Short” argues that today’s stock market is rigged in favor of secretive traders.
lead_paragraph: For Brad Katsuyama, then a young equities trader at Royal Bank of Canada, a life-changing revelation about the stock market began in June 2007 with a mystery: Why, when he tried to buy stocks at the offered prices on his computer screen, did the offers instantly vanish and the prices pop higher?

headline: Adding Insult to Gun Injuries, Police Often Handcuff Victims
abstract: People who have been shot and are found by the New York Police Department to have outstanding warrants, even for minor offenses, are usually handcuffed and shackled.
lead_paragraph: Two days after he was shot, Andre Daly woke in a haze with a police officer standing by his hospital bed in Brooklyn.

headline: One Baby, Five Nationalities
keywords: ['Americans Abroad', 'Babies and Infants', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Parenting']
abstract: My infant son is eligible for five citizenships, and the choice of which passports to apply for turned out to be about much more than visas, paperwork and taxes.
lead_paragraph: We opted not to find out our baby’s sex before he was born. The annoyance of not being able to shop for pink or blue clothes, leaving the baby room neutrally white and having have two separate naming discussions was far outweighed by what seemed to be the much more traditional way of doing things: We wanted, like virtually everyone in human history, to learn the gender at the same time we found out whether our baby was hairy and plump or gawky and bald, or whether it had its mother’s toes or its father’s weak chin.

headline: Big G.O.P. Donors Stir Senate Runs
abstract: Democrats in races that will help determine control of the Senate are burning through campaign cash as they fend off attacks from conservative groups.
lead_paragraph: Democrats in races that will help determine control of the Senate are rapidly burning through their campaign cash, whittling away their financial advantage over Republican opponents as they fend off attacks from conservative groups, according to figures released through Friday.

headline: View From the Top
abstract: New books by Ben Horowitz, Margaret Heffernan and Warren Berger.
lead_paragraph: THE HARD THING ABOUT HARD THINGS Building a Business When There Are No Easy AnswersBy Ben Horowitz Harper Business/HarperCollins, $29.99.

headline: The Bottom Line From Both Sides
abstract: A look at some of our reviews of notable books about money throughout the years.
lead_paragraph: The Wall Street-Main Street divide is not just for political slogans. It’s also useful for categorizing literature.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: FAMILY LIFE,  by Akhil Sharma. (Norton, $23.95.) Sharma’s novel, deeply unnerving and tender at the core, charts a young man’s struggles to grow within a family shattered by tragedy and disoriented by its move from India.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: SON OF A GUN: A Memoir,  by Justin St. Germain. (Random House, $16.) In late 2001, St. Germain’s mother — “a former Army paratrooper, the toughest woman I’ve ever known” — was shot and killed in Arizona, apparently by her fifth husband, a wrecked ex-cop. This tale of personal loss and grief drives St. Germain’s searing memoir, but its bigger story concerns the culture of guns, violence and manhood in the American West.

headline: Leaning In Without Falling Over
abstract: A view of the barriers working women face and suggestions for surmounting them.
lead_paragraph: Joan C. Williams has been a longtime laborer in the trenches of women’s work. The founding director of the Center for WorkLife Law at the University of California’s Hastings College of the Law, she boldly attacked the male-dominated workplace in “Unbending Gender” and, with her co-author, Cynthia Thomas Calvert, provided a blueprint for increased labor flexibility in law firms in “Solving the Part-Time Puzzle.” Now, in collaboration with her daughter, Rachel Dempsey, Williams has turned to a different kind of book. Deftly combining sociological research with a more casual narrative style, “What Works for Women at Work” offers unabashedly straightforward advice in a how-to primer for ambitious women.

headline: For All It’s Worth
abstract: An examination of money, its nature and history, as well as its politicization.
lead_paragraph: Most people are used to owing money to others, but few think about what money may owe us: an equitable society, a functioning political system, a peaceful economy that can stay off the exhausting roller coaster of financial booms and crashes.

headline: The Banker, the Visitor, His Wife and Her Lover
abstract: A man whose career and marriage are coming apart receives a surprise guest at his London townhouse.
lead_paragraph: Another month, another bright young star in the firmament of Indian writing.

headline: Analyze That
abstract: In this novel, an affluent Manhattan therapist who writes a book about women who make bad choices is bitten by her own.
lead_paragraph: The first half of Jean Hanff Korelitz’s novel about a New York therapist is less than revelatory, although that turns out to be for excellent reason. Grace Reinhart Sachs, an affluent Upper East Side mother with a thriving couples practice, frets almost generically about such privileged concerns as how much to push her son to continue with his violin lessons. She offers loving descriptions of an ideal husband — a pediatric oncologist — who somehow never gels into either a recognizable type or an intriguingly unique character. The absence of key friends and family members feels underexplained.

headline: Debt Trap
abstract: Bill White wants to restore America’s historical proclivity for balanced budgets.
lead_paragraph: “We cannot mortgage the material assets of our grandchildren without asking the loss also of their political and spiritual heritage.” So said President Dwight Eisenhower in his 1961 farewell address.

headline: Home Improvement
abstract: A corrective to the image of Africa as a hopeless place, and an argument that the best solutions are local.
lead_paragraph: When my family moved to Accra, Ghana, in 1990 just as I was about to start high school, we landed in a country whose G.D.P. was less than one-quarter the size of Delaware’s, despite its plentiful deposits of gold and other precious minerals. A military dictator had ruled it for almost a dozen years. Poverty, hunger and disease stalked the countryside. It felt like a place cut off from the rest of the world. If we wanted to call my grandparents in Wisconsin or Addis Ababa, all five of us would squeeze into a phone booth at the post office. We didn’t have a home phone, and the waiting list to get one was decades long.

headline: Kamikaze Strategy
abstract: Grief and political disagreements impel this novel’s protagonist, a World Bank official, to torpedo his career.
lead_paragraph: The mountain of Purgatory haunts the cover of Peter Mountford’s arresting second novel, “The Dismal Science.” The image, which calls to mind the second volume of “The Divine Comedy,” leads the reader into the book, the stark path curling its way up toward Terrestrial Paradise, symbolized by one lonely but verdant tree.

headline: How Banks Fail
abstract: Two scholars explore the role of politics in the evolution of banking.
lead_paragraph: Five years after the drama that began in 2008 — the failure of one bank after another, the decline in the stock market and the freezing up of finance — we still cannot seem to agree about the causes of the crisis. There are some who like to pin all the blame on the corrupt business practices of Wall Street and the greed of bankers. Then there are those who think it was just one more example of the sort of irrational mass hysteria that gives rise to boom-and-bust cycles in financial markets. Still others focus on the inherent characteristics of banks that seem to make them especially vulnerable to investor panics — the fact, for example, that their loans and investments cannot be liquidated in a hurry, while depositors can withdraw their cash with the click of a mouse.

headline: Statistically Speaking
abstract: An introduction to the numbers economists and governments use to address fiscal questions.
lead_paragraph: In the dark days of the Great Depression, the economist Simon Kuznets set about calculating the total national income of the United States. It was a case of a demand creating its supply, the demand by Congress and citizens to understand the scale of the economic calamity the nation was then experiencing. The same demand for understanding helps explain the public’s interest these days in what might otherwise seem to be dry, uninviting economic statistics. How secure is the recovery from the impact of the 2008 financial crisis? What good is a recovery that benefits only the wealthy minority? Do our children have any hope of seeing their living standards rise as ours did over the late 20th century — or is that dream of progress over?

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Nevada Barr, whose “Destroyer Angel” is No. 8 on the hardcover fiction list, came up with the idea for her mystery series while working as a law enforcement ranger for the National Park Service.
lead_paragraph: Wilderness Adventure: The crime novelist Nevada Barr is a write-what-you-know success story — when she began her Anna Pigeon series, about a National Park Service ranger who frequently stumbles across dead bodies, Barr was herself working as a law enforcement ranger in the park system. “I had a lot of time in the backcountry to think,” she told The Times-Picayune of New Orleans in 2008. “There were a couple of people in the park that needed killing, and I thought about how to get away with it.” (Perhaps unsurprisingly, Barr quit that job once her books started to catch on.) How did Park Service employees respond to the series? Guardedly at first, to judge from a 1995 profile in National Parks magazine that cited Barr’s perceived “disregard for both the agency and the people” who worked in the parks. “I enjoy the stories,” one employee acknowledged, “but some of the cynicism about the Park Service makes me feel like I’m at work.” Things have gotten better since then: In 2011, the National Parks Conservation Association presented Barr with an award for “enhancing public understanding of national parks” and drawing “attention to the invaluable work of National Park Service staff.” The 18th Anna Pigeon mystery, “Destroyer Angel,” enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 8.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Money Issue
abstract: This week, Chris Hayes talks about Kevin Roose’s “Young Money”; Parul Sehgal and John Williams discuss the book business; Timothy Noah on Matt Taibbi’s “The Divide”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Chris Hayes talks about Kevin Roose’s “Young Money”; Parul Sehgal and John Williams discuss the book business; Timothy Noah on Matt Taibbi’s “The Divide”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

lead_paragraph: This week, Chris Hayes and Timothy Noah.

abstract: A California Highway Patrol spokeswoman, Lacey Heitman, gave updates following a deadly collision between a FedEx tractor-trailer and a chartered bus carrying high school students in Orland, Calif.
lead_paragraph: A California Highway Patrol spokeswoman, Lacey Heitman, gave updates following a deadly collision between a FedEx tractor-trailer and a chartered bus carrying high school students in Orland, Calif.
