abstract: Chris Hayes discusses Kevin Roose’s “Young Money,” and Timothy Noah talks about Matt Taibbi’s “The Divide.”
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review’s Money Issue, Chris Hayes reviews Kevin Roose’s “Young Money: Inside the Hidden World of Wall Street’s Post-Crash Recruits.” Mr. Hayes writes:

headline: Detroit Wins Judge’s Nod for Contract Settlement
abstract: A federal judge held up the bankrupt city’s settlement as an example of “the very spirit of negotiation and compromise” that he hoped other creditors would follow.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:38 p.m. | A federal judge on Friday approved this bankrupt city’s latest attempt to extricate itself from some long-term financial contracts that have been costing it tens of millions of dollars a year, holding up its settlement as an example of “the very spirit of negotiation and compromise” that he hoped other creditors would follow.

headline: Inside Baseball
abstract: A whole new view of spring training.
lead_paragraph: Most views of a major-league baseball game are as traditional as the game itself, the cameramen sidelined in pens next to the dugouts. To see the game from some new angles, Mike Escamilla, a photographer and an athlete, went to the Los Angeles Dodgers’ spring-training camp in Glendale, Ariz., and mounted cameras to players’ bats, umpires’ chests, catchers’ face masks and even remote-controlled drones. Some players, who tend to be skittish and superstitious even by the standards of professional athletes, were reluctant to take part. “Getting close to the players on the field was clearly not something photographers did, but after some slow introductions, a few players agreed to help us out,” Escamilla says. “Once we showed them the photos, they were like, ‘Wow, this is rad.’ ” Julie Bosman

headline: Reply All: The 3.30.14 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: THE CHEF AT 15

headline: What Kelis and Paul Newman Have in Common
abstract: The singer on her journey from “Milkshake” to saucier.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, you studied to be a chef. You have a new show on the Cooking Channel called “Saucy & Sweet,” and your new album is called “Food.” How would you describe your philosophy on cooking? As much as my music is very much who I am, so is my cooking. Food has become such a way of life, sort of like what you listen to, who you’re with, what you’re wearing. My character comes through in my cooking.

headline: Can I Spy?
abstract: And the surveillance says …
lead_paragraph: Is it unethical to infiltrate a group, through employment or other means, to learn more about them in order to expose what they do if you don’t agree with their stated aims? The F.B.I., for example, has undercover agents who pretend to be drug dealers. Recently, it has become illegal in some states for animal rights activists to pretend to be prospective employees at livestock farms and slaughterhouses because some were secretly videotaping the conditions. When is it ethical to pretend to be someone you’re not to learn information that could be beneficial to society? TIM DE VALROGER, HOBOKEN, N.J.

headline: Breakfast of Champions
abstract: Plus: Alicia Silverstone’s son is clueless about “Clueless,” and Judge John Hodgman rules on “Game of Thrones” spoilers.
lead_paragraph: Plus: Alicia Silverstone’s son is clueless about “Clueless,” and Judge John Hodgman rules on “Game of Thrones” spoilers.

headline: Spice of Life
abstract: What my mother-in-law knows could fill volumes.
lead_paragraph: Each time my husband, Ismail, returns from visiting relatives in Libya, his suitcase is lined with yellow powder in plastic baggies: the spice mix of his mother, Hajja. As a child, he watched her fill an iron pan with desiccated cloves, fenugreek seeds, withered black peppercorns, cinnamon bark, gnarled turmeric and ginger roots. Using a palm brush over an open fire, she swept the pan with one hand and drew the aroma in with the other. Her nose told her when her spices were ready. She once ground them herself, but now she takes her roasted spices to the mill.

headline: Who Made That Contact Lens?
abstract: Building a better eye.
lead_paragraph: In 1887, a German doctor named Theodor­ Samisch saw a patient whose lower eyelid had been destroyed by carcinoma, leaving his cornea exposed and desiccated and his lashes curling inward. To preserve the patient’s vision, Samisch contracted with two brothers who specialized in artificial eyes. They made a protective shell of handblown glass, transparent in the middle and opaque around the edge, with reddish threads for blood vessels. “I have worn the glass supplied by you continuously, day and night,” the patient wrote the brothers 21 years later, “and my eye has always felt very well with it.”

headline: Elementary School Concert Draws Billy Joel
abstract: Mr. Joel unexpectedly stopped in at a Long Island elementary school as students performed a concert of his songs.
lead_paragraph: It is not unheard of for composers to turn up at concerts of their music, at least in the classical music world. When the composer is a rock star, the likelihood of an appearance drops considerably, and when the concert is at 9:30 a.m., and the performers are kindergarten through second-grade students, well, the odds drop to near zero.

headline: French Bath and Beauty Goods With an Old-World Touch
abstract: Named for a famed Paris chemist, L’Officine Universelle Buly debuts its elegantly packaged, naturally sourced products in a new Paris apothecary.
lead_paragraph: In 1803, the perfumer Jean-Vincent Bully established a distillery on Rue Saint-Honoré in Paris. His signature scented skincare vinegars went on to become the toast of 19th-century Europe, and he even inspired the character of César Birotteau, the titular hero of Balzac’s novel. Now, his legacy is being revisited by Ramdane Touhami, a former co-owner of Cire Trudon, the French luxury candle manufacturer. L’Officine Universelle Buly, as the line has been re-christened, embodies the original’s Old-World elegance and emphasis on natural ingredients. The range of exquisitely packaged, paraben-free products — perfumes, oils, creams, marble-encased candles, scented matches — can be found in the brand’s new Saint-Germain-des-Près apothecary alongside accouterments like sponges, combs and crystals sourced from Morocco.

headline: Above the Brooklyn Heights Promenade
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: An 1859 townhouse with six bedrooms, 1,300 square feet of outdoor space and idyllic views of the Manhattan skyline.
lead_paragraph: A perfectly positioned and expertly renovated historic townhouse perched high above the Brooklyn Heights Promenade with idyllic views of the Manhattan skyline, the Brooklyn Bridge, the Statue of Liberty and beyond, is about to enter the market at $16 million.

headline: In France, a Move to Limit Off-the-Clock Work Emails
abstract: A deal between unions and corporate representatives would cover hundreds of thousands of workers at consulting, computing and polling companies.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Given France’s 35-hour workweek, generous vacations and persistent, if not altogether accurate, reputation for indolence, it may come as a surprise that the French are only now considering limits on the work emails and phone calls that come at all hours of the day and night.

headline: Incendiary Words in Campaigns Draw Ban on Rallies for Two Politicians
abstract: The Indian Election Commission determined the men made “highly inflammatory speeches” that violated its rules.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:50 a.m. | NEW DELHI — The Election Commission of India has banned two politicians, Amit Shah of the Bharatiya Janata Party and Azam Khan of the Samajwadi Party, from holding rallies in the state of Uttar Pradesh for their “highly inflammatory speeches,” the news channel NDTV reported late Friday.

headline: Today in Small Business: Paying Employees to Quit
abstract: Tax revenues soar. Online reviews vanish. And why a New York restaurant does Google searches on customers who make reservations.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Obama Names Health Pick, Veteran of Fiscal Battles
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: In choosing Sylvia Mathews Burwell to lead the Health and Human Services Department, President Obama is hoping to leave the early health law stumbles behind.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Friday that he was nominating his budget director, Sylvia Mathews Burwell, to lead the Department of Health and Human Services, as the administration tries to move beyond its early stumbles in carrying out Mr. Obama’s health law.

headline: They Thought Their Son Was Bipolar. They Were Wrong.
abstract: Desperate parents search for a doctor who can explain why their son goes out of control.
lead_paragraph: Desperate parents search for a doctor who can explain why their son goes out of control.

headline: New York Boomers on Hipster Turf
abstract: Driven by a taste for adventure and a lively urban lifestyle, an older set is moving into neighborhoods colonized by the young and the artistic.
lead_paragraph: Lenore Berner, born at the very tail end of the baby boom generation, turned 50 in February. (Her husband, Dan, had hit the half-century mark the previous year.) A few weeks later, the Berners moved from a two-bedroom apartment in Park Slope, Brooklyn, which they were renting for $4,500 a month, to a 39th-floor waterfront rental in Long Island City, Queens — the price tag a more modest $3,850.

headline: Class Action Complaint Against the N.H.L.
abstract: The complaint by nine retired players said the N.H.L. failed to take adequate steps to warn the players of the dangers of the sport and deliberately promoted violence for profit.
lead_paragraph: The complaint by nine retired players said the N.H.L. failed to take adequate steps to warn the players of the dangers of the sport and deliberately promoted violence for profit.

headline: A Chance for a Market’s Wallflowers to Bloom
abstract: The sell-off is providing a rare moment in the sun for so-called value investors, who focus on out-of-favor stocks with relatively low valuations.
lead_paragraph: In January, Seth Klarman, a billionaire who runs the Boston-based Baupost Group investment partnership, warned in his annual letter to clients that “a skeptic would have to be blind not to see bubbles inflating” and cited the “nosebleed stock market valuations” of companies like Netflix and Tesla Motors.

headline: The Aesthetes | Expats in Tangier
abstract: A group of eccentric expats living in Tangier open their extraordinary homes and share what lured them to the city and kept them hooked.
lead_paragraph: A group of eccentric expats living in Tangier open their extraordinary homes and share what lured them to the city and kept them hooked.

headline: A Dutchman’s Opinion: Henk Ovink Weighs in on Post-Sandy Proposals
abstract: Henk Ovink, a Dutch water management expert, briefly describes each of the 10 proposals that the Hurricane Sandy Rebuilding Task Force has highlighted for possible implementation.
lead_paragraph: Following my profile of Henk Ovink and his work to bring Dutch water-management ideas to bear in the Northeastern United States, I asked Henk to briefly describe each of the 10 proposals that the Hurricane Sandy Rebuilding Task Force has highlighted for possible implementation. Each was spearheaded by a multidisciplinary team in conjunction with local community groups. The next step in the process will see Shaun Donovan, the H.U.D. secretary and chairman of the task force, make a final selection from these visionary approaches.

headline: A Creative Approach to Adjusting to Life in China
abstract: Health care and air quality are always a serious conversation employees consider working in China.
lead_paragraph: My company, iPai, doesn’t offer bonuses for being stationed overseas to any of our executives.

headline: Your Street Style: Dressed for Spring in Winter
abstract: Readers showed us how they stylishly tried to usher in spring weather through their clothes.
lead_paragraph: Readers showed us how they stylishly tried to usher in spring weather through their clothes.

headline: Customers Can Lose When Banks Shuffle Payments
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Checks and Checking Accounts', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: A Pew Charitable Trusts study found some big banks still reorder transactions in a way that maximizes overdraft fees, though changes have been made.
lead_paragraph: THE proverbial $35 cup of coffee that can result from overspending a bank account hasn’t disappeared yet.

headline: Turkish Court Overturns Part of Law on Judiciary, Loosening Government’s Grip
abstract: The Constitutional Court overturned a provision that gave the government of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan greater control over the judiciary.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s highest court on Friday overturned the provision of a new law that gave the government of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan greater control over the judiciary, a law that critics said harmed the country’s separation of powers and was part of a broader effort on the part of Mr. Erdogan to push back against a corruption investigation.

headline: Floyd Cardoz Exits North End Grill
abstract: The executive chef says he wants to open Indian restaurants in New York City and India.
lead_paragraph: Floyd Cardoz, the executive chef at North End Grill in Battery Park City, said Friday that he was leaving the restaurant and its parent company, the Union Square Hospitality Group, where he has worked for nearly 17 years for the restaurateur Danny Meyer.

headline: Muslim, Gay, and Making No Apologies
abstract: For the author Abdellah Taïa, a Moroccan, being gay has been a source of both torment and inspiration.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — HE was born inside the public library of Rabat in Morocco where his dad worked as a janitor and where his family lived until he was 2. For most of his childhood, he hid his sexuality as best he could, but his effeminate demeanor brought mockery and abuse, even as it would later become a source of artistic inspiration.

headline: Pro-Russia Ukrainians Are Promised More Power, but Remain Dubious
abstract: Ukraine’s acting prime minister abandoned threats to forcibly evict pro-Russian demonstrators from government buildings.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Ukraine’s acting prime minister on Friday abandoned threats to forcibly evict pro-Russian demonstrators from government buildings, and assured political and business leaders in the country’s rebellious east that they would get more power to run their own affairs.

abstract: Jeep introduces six concepts for the Easter Jeep Safari in Moab, Utah; Toyota unveils more efficient gasoline engines.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Childhood Dreams Can Inspire Rewarding Second Careers
abstract: To stay engaged and add to their savings, retirees are transforming lifelong passions into new careers in the circus, on-screen and around the world.
lead_paragraph: EVER since Sandra Colony was a child, when she was spellbound by the glossy photographs of exotic places in the pages of National Geographic, she has been driven by the desire to explore the world.

headline: News Alert: The News Alert Is Changing
abstract: In an era of mobile technology and constant news updates, Times news alerts have become an important part of delivering readers the latest and most accurate breaking news.
lead_paragraph: Ian Fisher is an assistant managing editor at The Times. Since coming to the paper in 1990, he has served as bureau chief in Rome, deputy editor on the foreign desk and the day editor on the home page.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
abstract: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: Ryan McDonagh, Rising Star for Rangers, Sweeps Team Honors
abstract: The 24-year-old defenseman was named the Rangers’ most valuable player and picked up the Players’ Player Award.
lead_paragraph: Defenseman Ryan McDonagh’s breakthrough season was capped with two laurels Friday, as his teammates and reporters covering the Rangers awarded him the team’s top honors.

headline: ‘I’m 5’2, but I Identify as Heidi Klum’
abstract: Facebook’s new labels for gender identification cause one to ponder the possibility of so many more.
lead_paragraph: I cannot tell you how delighted I was to read that Facebook is now offering a greatly increased range of user ID labels.

headline: ‘An Addict With Friends’
abstract: Robert Aaron, who had stayed largely in the background as a musician, suddenly became a national news figure when he was presented as the man who sold deadly heroin to Philip Seymour Hoffman.
lead_paragraph: The night the police came for Robert Aaron, he was at home in the Mott Street apartment where he has lived for the last quarter century, making a coconut pudding called tembleque. Mr. Aaron, whose legal name is Robert Aaron Vineberg, is a 57-year-old musician who has played with David Bowie, Wyclef Jean, Mick Jagger and Amy Winehouse, among others, a genial man with a pencil-thin mustache and a grasp of half a dozen languages. He is also a heroin addict who has sometimes sold the drug. On this night, Mr. Aaron said, his visitors did not ring the bell.

headline: Mike Daisey Will Present ‘Dreaming of Rob Ford’ Onstage in Toronto Festival
abstract: Mr. Daisey, best known as a monologist, will open the East End Performance CRAWL, a new festival of site-specific solo shows, in May.
lead_paragraph: When the directors of Crow’s Theater in Toronto invited the monologist Mike Daisey to create a show for the East End Performance CRAWL, the company’s new festival of site-specific solo shows, he settled on an idea quickly and perhaps inevitably, given the festival’s nature and location, and his own passion for topicality. The world premiere of “Dreaming of Rob Ford,” Mr. Daisey’s meditation on the exploits of Toronto’s mayor, will open the festival, which runs from May 21 to June 1.

headline: Great Grain Salads
abstract: The vegetables of early spring and fresh herbs are big elements in these main-dish grain salads, some of them inspired by demonstrations at the “Healthy Kitchens, Healthy Lives” medical education conference recently held at the Culinary Institute of America in Napa Valley.
lead_paragraph: For the next few weeks you’ll be hearing a lot from me about a conference I attended in March at the Culinary Institute of America in Napa Valley. Called “Healthy Kitchens, Healthy Lives,” this conference, presented by the Culinary Institute of America, the Harvard School of Public Health and the Samueli Institute, brings together medical professionals with chefs and nutrition researchers to explore food and its relationship to health. Now in its 10th year, the conference has inspired hospitals to install teaching kitchens. Surgeons whose knowledge of knives had been limited to the scalpel have learned to wield a chef’s knife as they participate in kitchen workshops run by chefs from the Culinary Institute and chefs presenting at the conference.

headline: Irish Republican Ordered Held Without Bail in 1998 Bombing Case
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Seamus Daly has been charged with the murders of 29 people in a car bombing in Omagh, Northern Ireland.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — A dissident Irish Republican charged with 29 counts of murder in the 1998 car bombing in Omagh, Northern Ireland, was ordered held without bail on Friday.

headline: The Aesthetes
abstract: For the legendary expats of Tangier, a life devoted to beauty reaches full flower in this North African hothouse of history and hedonism.
lead_paragraph: For the legendary expats of Tangier, a life devoted to beauty reaches full flower in this North African hothouse of history and hedonism.

headline: For Afghan Journalists, Election Brings a Sense of National Duty
abstract: A news media known for its no-holds-barred criticism has decided to focus on the positive to help foster confidence in the democratic process.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — As the raucous news outlets of Afghanistan — and there are hundreds of them — have come into their own in recent years, they have taken to criticizing government officials and institutions with an enthusiasm that borders on glee. And despite attempts by the powerful to rein in reporters, much of the news media has thrived with an occasionally adversarial approach.

headline: Kentucky Students Catch Breath to Cheer a Derby Hopeful
abstract: Students at the University of Kentucky bred a colt that has a chance to qualify Saturday for the Kentucky Derby.
lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Ky. — The University of Kentucky is renowned for its eight men’s basketball national championships and its three Final Four appearances in the last four years. But the university now finds itself in the unfamiliar, and unlikely, position of having fostered a Kentucky Derby prospect.

headline: Alibaba to Acquire Chinese Mapping Firm as Buying Spree Continues
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Maps', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: AutoNavi Holdings, which holds a rare mapping license from the Chinese government, has agreed to sell itself to the Alibaba Group in a deal that values it at $1.5 billion.
lead_paragraph: The Alibaba Group, a Chinese e-commerce juggernaut, will buy the portion of the mapping and navigation company AutoNavi Holdings that it does not already own, the latest move in an acquisition spree before Alibaba’s expected stock listing in the United States.

headline: Image of the Day: April 11
abstract: A mustard field on the outskirts of Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.

headline: Pope’s Request for Abuse Victims to Forgive Church Draws Calls for Action
abstract: Pope Francis said he was personally asking for forgiveness for the damage done to children.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis said in remarks broadcast on Friday that he was “personally” asking for forgiveness for the damage that priests have done in the sexual abuse of children.

headline: In Sydney, Lively Culture Amid Natural Beauty
abstract: From museums to movies, galleries to art tours, explore the cultural side of a city known for its looks.
lead_paragraph: The late, great Australian art critic Robert Hughes once complained that “Crocodile Dundee” is still regarded by many Americans as a work of social realism. A rhetorical exaggeration, of course, but he had a point. As an Australian living in New York, I’ve long been puzzled at the dominance of charming clichés about the country as a sun-dappled frontier. Advertising campaigns still promote the “ocker” image — Australian for redneck — depicting beer-swilling, happy-go-lucky folk barbecuing steak at the beach.

headline: Wounded by the Language of War
abstract: Rattling sabers and manning the battle stations at the end of life. Why do we say that?
lead_paragraph: When did the language we use to talk about death start to resemble a Pentagon briefing, full of military references and combat analogies?

headline: Pink Dolphins and Sunsets Along the Amazon
abstract: Skiff excursions and jungle walks, hot showers and cold drinks are all part of a luxury river cruise.
lead_paragraph: Sitting on the deck of a small cruise ship called the Aqua, I listened to the never-ending sounds of the Amazonian rain forest. Beside me was a retired executive, a fellow passenger whom I had just met the day before. As the sinking sun bled into the darkening sky and the riverbanks along this tributary of the Peruvian Amazon turned from green to black, he told me of his days in Lagos in the ’70s and Dubai in the ’90s, then lapsed into silence. The moment was all the sweeter because we were playing hooky from an outing to view nocturnal birds, opting for perfectly chilled white wine over mosquitoes.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Joe,’ ‘Draft Day’ and ‘Only Lovers Left Alive’
abstract: Times critics on “Joe,” “Draft Day” and “Only Lovers Left Alive.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on the Texas thriller “Joe,” the sports film “Draft Day” and the vampire drama “Only Lovers Left Alive.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Israeli Military Takes Over Seminary in West Bank Settlement
abstract: Troops moved in after radical settlers clashed with soldiers and destroyed army property at the Od Yosef Chai Yeshiva in the Jewish settlement of Yitzhar.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli military on Friday took over a seminary known for extremism in the Jewish settlement of Yitzhar in the West Bank, moving in a company of border police troops after radical settlers clashed with soldiers and destroyed army property there over the last week.

headline: Obama Nominates Chairman for Humanities Endowment
abstract: Dr. William Adams, known as Bro, has led liberal arts programs and institutions for most of his career.
lead_paragraph: William Adams has led liberal arts programs and institutions for most of his career, slowly training for an opportunity that finally came on Thursday, when President Obama nominated him to be chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities.

headline: Rizzoli Bookstore May Be Better Off Elsewhere
abstract: The building housing Rizzoli Bookstore in Midtown Manhattan is slated for demolition. If area trends continue, the building will most likely be replaced by a huge, glass tower that caters to the wealthy.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday afternoon, two days before its scheduled closing, Rizzoli Bookstore was crowded with the sort of people who, never especially populous in Midtown Manhattan, appear even more like icicles in the desert: gray-haired women with Mohawks or turbans, students, men with indifferent facial grooming, older citizens. Some of them did not know that the building, which has housed the bookstore on West 57th Street for the past 29 years, was slated to be demolished, along with two adjoining buildings. When they were told by a salesperson they expressed the requisite shock and lament.

headline: The Fading Honor Code
abstract: If students fail to report cheaters, can a culture of integrity prevail?
lead_paragraph: The campus tour for prospective Middlebury students stops in a corridor outside a much-frequented eatery at the student center. Here, the guide directs their attention to a glass case exhibiting signatures of every freshman who has signed the honor code, a pledge made during orientation. To high school students fresh out of the SAT and A.P. grind, these signatures suggest that the competition for high scores is over; learning would now be fuller and more meaningful. Lowering their gaze, however, they might notice three trash bins lined up under the display. This juxtaposition looks to be a fitting metaphor for Middlebury’s attitude toward its honor code.

headline: Fast Cash: Work a Reunion
abstract: For the money, and for access to big-hearted alumni.
lead_paragraph: One sign of spring: older folks whizzing around campus in golf carts. Reunion season kicks in on the heels of commencement (and again at homecoming), and somebody has to drive those carts, give directions and tend bar — with an assist from a laminated sheet of cocktail recipes.

headline: Pomp From the Past
abstract: A half-century of commencement inspiration.
lead_paragraph: It’s almost over. The first spring graduates will be walking next week. We share inspiration from commencements of the last half-century.

headline: Steven Pinker’s Mind Games
abstract: The Harvard professor culled exam questions from his course “Psychological Science.” Test your knowledge.
lead_paragraph: The Harvard professor culled exam questions from his course “Psychological Science.” Test your knowledge.

headline: What Makes a Positive College Experience?
abstract: After a decade of research, a sociologist believes he knows what determines how students feel about their time at college.
lead_paragraph: After a decade of research, Daniel F. Chambliss, an organizational sociologist at Hamilton College, believes he knows what most determines how students feel about their time at college. It comes down to factors like dorm design, friends and extracurricular involvement more than what happens in the classroom. In their new book, “How College Works,” Dr. Chambliss and Christopher G. Takacs describe the findings from an ambitious study of Hamilton students and alumni, using interviews, surveys and even an analysis of academic writing samples to tease out how college has affected them. Although Hamilton, a small, selective, expensive liberal arts college in upstate New York, has little in common with the large state universities and community colleges that most students attend, Dr. Chambliss said the lessons learned could apply everywhere.

headline: Ivy League Ups and (Yes) Downs
abstract: Why the number of applications is rising, and falling.
lead_paragraph: It’s not really a popularity contest, but among the Ivies, is anything not competitive? Applications to the University of Pennsylvania rose by more than 14 percent this year and fell by as much at Dartmouth.

headline: Because Ze Said So
abstract: Gender-neutral terms are gaining ground at more liberal campuses.
lead_paragraph: Gender-neutral terms are catching on at more liberal campuses. Here, an essential glossary:

headline: Models With Doctorates
abstract: If a Ph.D. wears it, is it smart fashion?
lead_paragraph: The old joke about the value of higher education — What do you call a Ph.D. in philosophy? Oh, waitress! — is getting a new punch line courtesy of Betabrand, based in San Francisco. The clothier has asked women who are Ph.D.s or doctoral candidates to model “smart new spring fashions” (get it?). So far, 120 have applied and 30 are being featured, said Chris Lindland, the chief executive.

headline: Who Advises Best, Pros or Profs?
abstract: To ensure students graduate on time, many colleges are taking advising away from faculty and putting it in the hands of professionals.
lead_paragraph: Academic advising has always been one of those intractable problems on college campuses. Students rarely think about it until that frantic moment when they need someone to sign the registration form for next semester’s classes.

headline: The Power Broker of N.Y.U.
abstract: During his 16 years as chairman of the board, Martin Lipton has shaped the agenda at New York University.
lead_paragraph: Martin Lipton, chairman of the board of New York University, recently took a trustee to lunch at San Pietro, a pricey Manhattan restaurant frequented by the city’s C.E.O.s. Over a meal that lasted several hours, they discussed Mr. Lipton’s plans to step down next year, after 16 years at the helm. “Marty wants his own replacement there a year in advance,” recalled Evan R. Chesler, chairman of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, a leading New York law firm. The reason, he said: “The new chairman would be responsible for the process that selects the president who will replace John Sexton.”

headline: Who Am I?
abstract: Creative self-portraits by student photographers.
lead_paragraph: Creative self-portraits by student photographers.

headline: Happenings | A New York Pirate Radio Station for the Art Underground Takes Texas
abstract: Know-Wave, the online broadcasting arm of Aaron Bondaroff and Al Moran’s Ohwow gallery, is now in residence at the Dallas Art Fair.
lead_paragraph: Since 2012, the artist, gallerist and publisher Aaron Bondaroff (known to some as the Downtown Don) and Al Moran, his partner in the Los Angeles gallery Ohwow, have been broadcasting Know-Wave, an online radio station that provides a platform for the members of the downtown and L.A. art communities to express themselves, promote their work and interact with each other. It’s a free-form affair: hosts go on-air whenever they want and play whatever they like, be it French gangster rap, underground hip-hop or noise-rock bands you’ve never heard of. Occasionally, they bring in art world personalities for interviews. (Past guests have included Chan Marshall, Rodarte, Dan Colen, Glenn O’Brien and Mykki Blanco.)

headline: Movie Review: ‘Only Lovers Left Alive’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Only Lovers Left Alive.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Only Lovers Left Alive.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘Joe’
abstract: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “Joe.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “Joe.”

headline: An Uproar Over a Diabetes Article, With a Back Story
abstract: Reader reaction to an article was mostly positive; then suddenly the tide turned.
lead_paragraph: Many Times readers, some of whom have Type 1 diabetes, are upset over an article last Sunday in which Elisabeth Rosenthal explored the often extraordinary expense of treating the disease. It was an installment in her series, “Paying Till It Hurts,” about the high cost of medical care in America.

headline: Can a Pop-Up Service Fix It? Probably
keywords: ['Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: An itinerant repair service that fixes broken or malfunctioning items has been, since last June, making appearances in storefronts and at markets.
lead_paragraph: Last Sunday, Adam Sobel approached the Pop Up Repair table at the Greenmarket next to Columbia University, cradling his black espresso machine. A couple of months ago, the steamer wand had started leaking slightly, and Mr. Sobel, a Columbia professor who teaches applied math and earth science, decided to take matters into his own hands. He consulted online instructions and ordered new parts, but found it difficult to properly screw them into the appliance’s hard-to-reach interior nooks and crannies. After his efforts, the machine leaked everywhere.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Draft Day’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Draft Day.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Draft Day.”

headline: Tough Tests Looming in 2016 Raise Stakes for G.O.P. in Midterm Elections
keywords: ['Elections', 'Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The 2016 elections may be far off, but the Tea Party class of 2010 is shaping up to be problematic for the Republicans, raising the possibility that the party could regain the Senate and then lose it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — To understand the Republican imperative to capture the Senate in the midterm elections, look toward 2016, when a narrow victory this year could well be swept away.

headline: Round and Round They Go
abstract: Gifts for bicyclists.
lead_paragraph: Gifts for bicyclists.

headline: Diplomat Who Led Secret Talks With Iran Plans to Retire
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: William J. Burns’s decision to wait until October to step down as deputy secretary of state raised the possibility that he may again play a role on Iran nuclear policy should formal negotiations fall short.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — William J. Burns, a career diplomat who led the Obama administration’s back-channel negotiations with Iran, plans to step down as the State Department’s second-ranking official in October, administration officials said on Friday.

headline: The Gender Wage Gap, by State
abstract: Of the 42 Republican votes to prevent the Paycheck Fairness Act from reaching the Senate floor, 21 were cast by Senators hailing from the 17 states where the gender pay gap exceeds the national average.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday Senate Republicans blocked consideration of the Paycheck Fairness Act, which would help narrow the persistent wage gap between men and women. A dissection of that vote reveals an even bigger betrayal of women’s economic interests than immediately apparent.

headline: There Goes Tokyo, Stomp by Stomp
abstract: Dignity and minutes are restored to “Godzilla” for its 60th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: Sad and stately are probably not the words that come to mind when you think of “Godzilla.” But the Japanese original, restored for its 60th anniversary and playing at Film Forum beginning Friday, should make you think again. The American version, “Godzilla: King of the Monsters!,” released in 1956, was chopped up (40 minutes were cut), rearranged, dubbed and fitted out with new footage with Raymond Burr. The original, a disaster movie and cautionary tale, feels like a different animal, or monster, altogether.

headline: The Great Moderation Is Back
abstract: The Great Moderation — that period of relatively steady growth — is still with us, but it’s a little more nuanced, says Jason Furman, head of the president’s Council of Economic Advisers.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps you remember the Great Moderation, the comforting term economists pinned on the period of relatively steady growth that began in the early 1980s.

headline: After the Squall, Chop Remains for JPMorgan Chase
abstract: In its first quarter without significant special items, JPMorgan Chase still couldn’t make a case for clear sailing, Jeffrey Goldfarb writes for Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase’s clean sheet already looks off-white. For the first time in years, its quarterly earnings weren’t cluttered with special items like big trading losses or legal costs. The bank’s $5.3 billion profit in the three months ended in March fell short of expectations anyway.

headline: Sebelius and Burwell on New Health Roles
abstract: President Obama, the secretary of Health and Human Services, Kathleen Sebelius, right, and the nominee to succeed her, Sylvia Mathews Burwell, discussed the new administration changes.
lead_paragraph: President Obama, the secretary of Health and Human Services, Kathleen Sebelius, right, and the nominee to succeed her, Sylvia Mathews Burwell, discussed the new administration changes.

headline: For Falcone, No Joy in the Sale of Manischewitz
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Kosher Foods and Products', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Philip A. Falcone suffered a loss when his hedge fund sold its position this week to Sankaty Advisors, people close to the matter said.
lead_paragraph: At Seder tables next week, many Passover celebrants will nosh on matzo and gefilte fish made by the Manischewitz Company.

headline: Marcelo Gomes as Romeo
abstract: American Ballet Theatre’s production of Kenneth MacMillan’s “Romeo and Juliet.” Video courtesy of American Ballet Theater
lead_paragraph: American Ballet Theatre’s production of Kenneth MacMillan’s “Romeo and Juliet.” Video courtesy of American Ballet Theater

headline: Brooklyn Dance Parties Coming to Waterfront Park
abstract: Celebrate Brooklyn!, the summer performing arts festival, will present three free dance parties in Brooklyn Bridge Park in May.
lead_paragraph: As a prelude to Celebrate Brooklyn!, the free summer performing arts festival at Prospect Park, the festival’s producer, BRIC, is presenting three dance parties, also free, at Brooklyn Bridge Park. The parties, at Pier 1 on consecutive Thursday evenings (May 8, 15 and 22, at 7 p.m.), will include performances by bands that draw on popular and folk styles from around the globe, as well as D.J. sets and dance lessons.

headline: Appeals Court Overturns Conviction of AT&T Hacker Known as ‘Weev’
abstract: Andrew “Weev” Auernheimer had been sentenced to 41 months in prison for breaching AT&T’s security and obtaining 114,000 email addresses in 2010 before a federal judge threw out the case on Friday.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court on Friday reversed the conviction of Andrew “Weev” Auernheimer, a hacker and self-described Internet troll, who was accused of stealing the personal data of 114,000 Apple iPad users in 2010.

headline: Iran Secretly Convicted Former Marine, Lawyer Says
abstract: The lawyer said his client, Amir Hekmati of Michigan, might be freed after serving three years of his 10-year term, which would be in August.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Amir Hekmati, a former Marine incarcerated here in August 2011 and sentenced to death on espionage charges that were overturned, was secretly retried by a revolutionary court in December, convicted of “practical collaboration with the American government” and given a 10-year prison term, his new lawyer said this week.

headline: Stars of Their Own Screenplay
abstract: The bride’s frequent business trips to California are mere bumps on the path to romance.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, Daniel Grossman was convinced that his fellow New Yorkers Sofia Alvarez, a playwright and screenwriter, and Adam Squires, a graphic designer, would hit it off. They just needed a nudge, or two or three, that he would be only too happy to provide.

headline: Asparagus, Spanish-Style
abstract: Revueltos, an egg and vegetable dish that makes excellent use of spring asparagus, is an easy supper or lunch dish.
lead_paragraph: Once, while traveling in Andalusia, I experienced asparagus Spanish-style.

headline: Marcelo Gomes, the Dancer at Home in Hell’s Kitchen
abstract: For the American Ballet Theater principal dancer, control matters at home as well as on stage.
lead_paragraph: Not long after Marcelo Gomes moved with his dachshund, Lua, into a subcompact (475 square feet) condo in Hell’s Kitchen two and a half years ago, he gave a housewarming party. And as he had done on other break-out-the-champagne occasions, such as his 30th birthday, the Brazilian-born Mr. Gomes, 34, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, gave the guests a gift-buying directive. In this particular instance they were asked to show up with a blue or white vase.

headline: Sweet Tale of Friendship (Sex, Too)
abstract: John Turturro talks about the genesis of his new film, “Fading Gigolo,” in which he and Woody Allen play friends who start a business that provides comfort to lonely women.
lead_paragraph: Ask John Turturro about his newest project, “Fading Gigolo,” and he will excitedly tell you about the streetwalker films, like “The Life of Oharu” or “Midnight Cowboy,” that helped inspire the idea; the Isaac Bashevis Singer short stories that helped him settle on a tone for the script; and the filmmakers, like Michael Cimino, Spike Lee and the Coen brothers, who helped him develop his own directorial style.

headline: A Filmmaker’s ‘Progressive Pathway’
abstract: Marco Bellocchio is the subject of an 18-film retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 50 years, Marco Bellocchio has been one of the cinema’s great poets of rebellion and escape — from family, from the Italian bourgeoisie and from the conformism and hypocrisy they represent. His most recent film, “Dormant Beauty,” plays a variation on this theme: Opportunistic politicians try to keep an accident victim from being taken off life support, preventing her from escaping a 17-year coma.

headline: Big Ticket | A Home in the Sky for $30.5 Million
abstract: A three-bedroom apartment on the 60th floor of the One57 condominium was the most expensive sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A three-bedroom unit on the 60th floor of One57, the Extell Development Company’s 90-story spike of bluish glass that does not scrape the Midtown sky as much as puncture it, sold for $30,551,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Pay the Babysitter Over $1,900 This Year? You Owe It to Her to Put Her On the Books
keywords: ['Child Care', 'Parenting', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Think paying taxes on the babysitter is a “one-percenter” problem? Think again, because if we parents don’t pay taxes on our babysitters, it isn’t just our problem.
lead_paragraph: If you pay a babysitter more than $1,900 in a calendar year, you’re classified as a household employer. That means you have the responsibility to administer the payroll and tax process for your babysitter. We don’t have a full-time babysitter, but it doesn’t take anything close to a full time schedule to hit $1,900. At $20 an hour, a parent owes taxes at 95 hours, or less than 2 hours a week.

headline: A Freewheeling Pursuit of Spontaneity on Film
abstract: The Brooklyn director Nathan Silver has made lively attempts at capturing the flickering, uncertain energies among people in a room with his freely made yet nuanced movies.
lead_paragraph: Many a director has stumbled while chasing after a sense of spontaneity through improvisation. But in a few short years, the Brooklyn filmmaker Nathan Silver, 30, has already made lively attempts at capturing the flickering, uncertain energies among people in a room — pushing boundaries or just sharing space — with his freely made yet nuanced movies. Stumbles and messes along the way are only part of the action, and part of what make up his garrulous, willful characters.

headline: A Mayor of Sorts Meets His Public
abstract: Harvey Fierstein watched a preview performance of his new play, “Casa Valentina,” then enjoyed a preopening celebration.
lead_paragraph: Harvey Fierstein had just finished watching a preview on Wednesday night of his new play, “Casa Valentina,” when he tried, without much success, to make his way to the exit.

headline: Hasidim See Things Through a New Lens
abstract: A muckraking blog written by a former Hasidic Jew reports on a yeshiva that is barring its students from wearing certain styles of glasses.
lead_paragraph: FailedMessiah.com, the muckraking blog written by the once-Hasidic Jew Shmarya Rosenberg, is best known (and, in some quarters, loathed) for posts exposing crimes suspected of being perpetrated by Hasidic and other highly observant Jews.

headline: Weekend Reading: The Other Michael Lewis Backlash
abstract: Michael Lewis, the author of “Flash Boys” and one of the most popular business journalists in the country, has been panned by a number of financial journalists.
lead_paragraph: When Michael Lewis rolled out his new book with an appearance on the CBS show “60 Minutes” and an excerpt in The New York Times magazine, the author was praised by literary critics and panned by high-frequency traders.

headline: Last Night to Bend the Rules
abstract: Dina Litovsky has been photographing bachelorette parties, where brides-to-be confront the tricky rituals of the last night of single life.
lead_paragraph: Dina Litovsky has been photographing bachelorette parties, where brides-to-be confront the tricky rituals of the last night of single life.

headline: Corvette Number Eight Pulled From National Corvette Museum Sinkhole
abstract: The last car to be recovered, a 2001 Mallett Hammer Corvette Z06, probably can’t be saved.
lead_paragraph: The chasm that opened beneath the National Corvette Museum in Bowling Green, Ky., in February — swallowing eight of its prized cars – has at last been emptied of all of its valuable contents. A few of the cars pulled from the sinkhole were in decent condition and others were in worse, albeit salvageable shape.

headline: The Gun Report: April 11, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of January 30, Shawn Harrington, a 38-year-old assistant basketball coach at a high school in Chicago, was stopped at a red light in the Humboldt Park neighborhood when two men opened fire on his car. Harrington shielded his 15-year-old daughter, whom he was driving to school, and was hit by two bullets, one of which passed through his upper back and cracked his vertebrae, leaving him paralyzed from the waist down. Another bullet lodged in the headrest of the seat in which his daughter was sitting.

headline: Syria’s Lost Generation
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Children and Childhood', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: I met so many children older than their years, refugees deprived of a future.
lead_paragraph: SOMETHING about the boy was not right. He seemed disoriented, detached from his surroundings. He barely spoke, and when he did, it was in flat monosyllables, his eyes unfocused and downcast, as if too heavy to roll up from the weight of all they had seen. He was the picture of quiet devastation, of a childhood forever splintered.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 62
abstract: Italy’s Coach Cesare Prandelli has called in 42 players for fitness tests on Monday and Tuesday ahead of his World Cup training camp.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Quinoa Salad for a Crowd
abstract: Melissa Clark makes a quinoa salad with soft roasted carrots and crunchy fried leeks that can serve as a side course or a main dish.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark makes a quinoa salad with soft roasted carrots and crunchy fried leeks that can serve as a side course or a main dish.

headline: Give Your Heart to Quinoa
abstract: Quinoa has numerous admirable traits and also happens to be kosher for Passover. Add fried leeks and roasted carrots for a memorable salad.
lead_paragraph: It took me a while to give my heart to quinoa.

headline: Kathleen Sebelius Was Too Cool and Too Patient
abstract: The health law needed a cheerful warrior who could laugh at the ridiculous distortions and lies Republicans invented about it.
lead_paragraph: Kathleen Sebelius was known for her patience and cool under savage attack by Republicans, who treated her as a stand-in for the health law. She sat through hearings calmly reciting talking points while they fumed and fulminated for their audience.

headline: Police Clash With Squatters in Rio de Janeiro Slum
abstract: The violence, which erupted when officers removed thousands of people from a newly built favela, came just weeks before the World Cup of soccer.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Violent clashes broke out on Friday between police officers and squatters here when the authorities dislodged thousands of families from a newly formed favela, or slum, in a complex of abandoned commercial buildings, focusing attention on the rising tension over surging rents and housing shortages.

headline: Review: 2014 Nissan Rogue SV
abstract: Nissan brings a new Rogue to the compact crossover wars.
lead_paragraph: Nissan brings a new Rogue to the compact crossover wars.

headline: G.M. Documents Reveal Years of Talks on Defect
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Roads and Traffic']
abstract: Files released by House investigators include an email telling Mary T. Barra, now the chief executive, of steering problems in 2011.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Mary T. Barra, the new chief executive of General Motors, told a panel of stern and dubious House members that she first became aware of a serious safety issue with the Chevrolet Cobalt in December, two months before the company announced a recall that would eventually cover 2.6 million cars.

headline: When Cars Ruled the World’s Fair
abstract: The 1939 fair in Queens laid out a glorious automotive vision, with General Motors’ Futurama exhibition depicting the highways of the future. When the fair returned in 1964, that vision was mostly realized.
lead_paragraph: From its humble origins as a Queens garbage dump — inspiration for the valley of ashes in “The Great Gatsby” — Flushing Meadows Corona Park emerged as the site of two world’s fairs, in 1939-40 and 1964-65.

headline: 1964 World’s Fair’s View of the Future
abstract: The World’s Fair in New York promised visitors a glance into the future of automobiles. Automakers like General Motors, Ford and Chrysler put on elaborate displays of their predictions.
lead_paragraph: The World’s Fair in New York promised visitors a glance into the future of automobiles. Automakers like General Motors, Ford and Chrysler put on elaborate displays of their predictions.

headline: Adapting to a New Environment
abstract: The 2014 Nissan Rogue gives the model a new look, an optional third-row seat and improved fuel economy.
lead_paragraph: For those of the mammalian persuasion, evolution has tended to be a leisurely process. This has not been the case among compact crossover utility vehicles, which in the last half-dozen years have made leaps in sophistication while adapting to a changing high-tech environment.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, India, Spain and Italy.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, India, Spain and Italy.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties include co-ops in Beekman and Greenwich Village, and a townhouse in Bedford Stuyvesant.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: On the Market in the Region
abstract: This week’s properties include a colonial in New Canaan, Conn., and a contemporary in Springfield, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: The Sixth Stage of Grief: Buying a Puppy
abstract: My adorable son has grown tall, lean and hairy. This explains, in part, the decision to add something unambiguously cute to our life. But Phoebe distracts us from more than just that.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, I received a puppy for my birthday. The gift, from my wife, Cynthia, was welcome, even if it came around 50 years too late.

headline: Texas Monthly Sues Times Co. Over New Hire
abstract: The magazine accused the Times Company of inducing breach of contract when it hired its editor in chief, Jake Silverstein.
lead_paragraph: The publisher of Texas Monthly filed a lawsuit on Friday against The New York Times Company related to The Times’s hiring of the magazine’s departing editor in chief, Jake Silverstein.

headline: California School Officials on Bus Crash
abstract: Earl Perkins and Tom Waldman of the Los Angeles Unified School District discussed the steps the district will take following the bus crash.
lead_paragraph: Earl Perkins and Tom Waldman of the Los Angeles Unified School District discussed the steps the district will take following the bus crash.

headline: He Tells the Clintons How to Lose a Little
abstract: As Hillary Rodham Clinton contemplates another run for the presidency, few topics receive more scrutiny than her health, turning tabloid attention to the doctor who advises her and the former president.
lead_paragraph: Nine years ago, on their 30th wedding anniversary, Hillary Rodham Clinton gave her husband a gift she hoped would ensure many more years together: Dr. Mark Hyman.

headline: The Mellon Lifestyle as a Brand
abstract: Nicole Hanley Mellon and Matthew Mellon decided early on in their relationship that they would collaborate on clothing, adding to their collective history in fashion.
lead_paragraph: “It’s a good story. Do you want me to start, love?” Nicole Hanley Mellon asked her husband, Matthew Mellon, on a recent Friday. The couple were seated in the living room of their apartment in the Pierre hotel, telling how they met in 2006 at a wedding in Palm Beach, Fla.

headline: He Walked by Night
abstract: In the fall of 2010, Jonno Rattman was a college sophomore. When he started feeling overwhelmed by the troubles of the world, he began taking pictures of New York after dark and found “a deep cacophony of lust and fear.”
lead_paragraph: New York at night is a Rorschach blot: What you see depends on your state of mind. Maybe that street scene in front of you looks like “La Dolce Vita”; maybe it’s “Taxi Driver.”

headline: U.S. Says Iran’s Pick for U.N. Envoy Won’t Get a Visa
abstract: The administration made its position clear after Congress passed a bill to block Iran’s nominee, who participated in the 1979 Tehran hostage crisis.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Friday said it would bar an Iranian diplomat nominated as United Nations ambassador from entering the country, in a rebuke to Iran at a time when the United States is engaged in delicate negotiations with Tehran over its nuclear program.

headline: Kanye Teams Up With Adidas, John Galliano and Oscar De la Renta Break Up and The Met Announces Its Gala Theme
abstract: Plus, James Franco’s new film for Gucci, Bobbi Brown’s Yahoo! gig and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: A Caribbean Resort Goes Solar
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Solar Energy', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The Westin Dawn Beach Resort & Spa on St. Maarten has installed more than 2,600 solar panels to provide energy throughout the property.
lead_paragraph: Blessed by year-round tropical sunshine, the Caribbean seems like a natural candidate for solar power.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Coats Off
abstract: Bill Cunningham reporting on the first truly spring week in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Bill Cunningham reporting on the first truly spring week in New York City.

headline: Belafonte Settles Dispute Over Martin Luther King Documents
abstract: Harry Belafonte settled a dispute with the three surviving children of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. over ownership of three documents.
lead_paragraph: Harry Belafonte and the family of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. have settled their differences over the ownership of documents that Mr. Belafonte said had been given to him by Dr. King; his widow, Coretta Scott King; and a close aide, Stanley Levison. According to a joint statement by Jonathan S. Abady, Mr. Belafonte’s lawyer, and Michael W. Tyler, the lawyer for Dr. King’s estate, “the parties have reached a compromise, the terms of which are confidential and have resulted in Mr. Belafonte retaining possession of the documents.”

headline: Tips to Manage Spending in Retirement
abstract: Experts describe several methods to continually assess funds and expenses to avoid running out of money.
lead_paragraph: ADVISERS put a considerable amount of effort into talking to clients about accumulating a life savings. But advisers and their clients tend to devote less thought to how to spend that money when it’s time.

headline: Offshore and Underground
abstract: Tax havens are a big deal.
lead_paragraph: I had lunch with Gabriel Zucman today, co-author of the startling new paper (pdf) showing that the concentration of wealth at the very top — the 0.1% — is fully back to Gilded Age levels.And he pointed me to another paper that flew under my, and I suspect other peoples’, radar: his demonstration that a lot of wealth at the top is held in offshore tax havens (pdf).

headline: Bill Cunningham | Coats Off
abstract: Bill Cunningham reporting from the first truly Spring week in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Hunt and Gather Finally, spring arrived, in a galvanized bucket of tulips at Union Square and planters full of tulips, daffodils and hyacinth. People stripped off coats for a first peek at spring fashion. And Saturday’s Tartan Day Parade, the city’s shortest (10 blocks, 20 minutes), was alive with tartans, bagpipes and Scotties. Fabergé held an egg hunt: 250 artist-designed eggs placed across the city to be auctioned on April 22 as a benefit for Studio in a School, an arts education group, and the Elephant Family, a global conservation organization.

headline: Tap Universe Shrugs Off Any Notion of Borders
abstract: A “Rhythm in Motion” program at the 14th Street Y Theater underlines that tap now encompasses not just jazz and swing but styles inflected by a range of international forms.
lead_paragraph: If you had to define tap dancing, “Rhythm in Motion” would be a difficult place to start. This celebration of (mostly) new tap choreography, presented by the American Tap Dance Foundation, shows that despite the common denominator of percussive feet, tap today defies easy categorization. Program B, seen on Thursday at the Theater at the 14th Street Y, exhibited the many functions of the form: tap as pure music, as political statement, as nonverbal narrative.

headline: Comedians in Two Realms
abstract: These days, TV stars routinely do making-of videos while their hit shows are still on the air.
lead_paragraph: These days, TV stars routinely do making-of videos while their hit shows are still on the air. Their predecessors didn’t have that luxury, but their recollections are being captured by programs like PBS’s “Pioneers of Television,” which begins a new season on Tuesday (check local listings) with a particularly entertaining episode, “Standup to Sitcom.” The episode includes Jerry Seinfeld, Roseanne Barr, Tim Allen and Bob Newhart, who describe how their sitcoms came about and how they made the transition from doing stand-up to acting on TV. These stars made it look easy, but it’s a challenge. “The difference between the stand-up and the sitcom is you’re going from the least collaborative medium there is to the most collaborative,” Mr. Seinfeld says. “The reason you become a comedian is you’re not a good collaborator, you’re not good with people, you’re not good in social situations or professional situations.”

headline: Global Groove and a Throwback
abstract: Born in the Democratic Republic of Congo and raised in Belgium, the rapper and singer Baloji makes chameleonic African music.
lead_paragraph: Born in the Democratic Republic of Congo and raised in Belgium, the rapper and singer Baloji makes chameleonic African music. His most recent album, “Kinshasa Succursale,” revisited Congolese music past and present. But he also draws on grooves worldwide. His songs and rhymes (largely in French) address political and cultural matters with multilayered wordplay and unmistakable conviction, even as the party continues. (7:30 p.m. Thursday, Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts, Pace University, 3 Spruce Street, Lower Manhattan; 212-346-1715.)

headline: Madness and Movement
abstract: Having a theater to call your own — on the Upper West Side, no less — is practically unheard-of for a choreographer in New York. The rare exception is David Parker.
lead_paragraph: Having a theater to call your own — on the Upper West Side, no less — is practically unheard-of for a choreographer in New York. The rare exception is David Parker, whose company, the Bang Group, has been at the West End Theater for more than a decade. Mr. Parker is generous with the real estate, opening the space to Soaking WET, an eclectic dance series.

headline: Enticing Choices in One Afternoon
abstract: The brilliant British pianist Stephen Hough plays an adventurous program on Sunday at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: The brilliant British pianist Stephen Hough plays an adventurous program on Sunday at Alice Tully Hall. Liszt’s visionary Piano Sonata and Brahms’s Fantasies (Op. 116) are the best-known works he will play. But how often do you get to hear piano pieces by Wagner and Bruckner? (5 p.m., Lincoln Center, 212-721-6500, lincolncenter.org.)

headline: 3,200 Crabs, 1 Unstoppable Man
abstract: Despite being prevented from leaving China, Ai Weiwei manages to maintain a healthy international career.
lead_paragraph: Despite being prevented from leaving China, Ai Weiwei manages to maintain a healthy international career. If one were to judge by news media attention alone, one might think him the only Chinese contemporary artist in existence. His most innovative work has been through various forms of social media, in what might be called a continuing digital version of performance art. (A book of his blog posts, published in 2011, remains his magnum opus.)

headline: ‘I Like to Be Crazy on the Stage’
abstract: A conversation with the Russian soprano Olga Peretyatko, who will make her Metropolitan Opera debut as Elvira in Bellini’s “I Puritani.”
lead_paragraph: If you’re a certain kind of soprano, you end up learning a lot about going insane. Young, agile voices like Olga Peretyatko’s earn mad scene after mad scene.

headline: Machlin Women’s Swiss Teams
abstract: The winners of the Machlin Women’s Swiss Teams in Dallas last month were Gan Ling, Huang Yan, Hu Wen, Wang Hanyong, Li Lixuan and Li Yiting, all from China.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — The winners of the Machlin Women’s Swiss Teams on the final day of the Spring Nationals here last month were Gan Ling, Huang Yan, Hu Wen, Wang Hanyong, Li Lixuan and Li Yiting, all from China. They finished 0.75 victory points ahead of their countrywomen Lu Yan, Wang Hongli, Ran Jingrong, Wang Wenfei, Shen Qi and Zhou Lihua.

headline: A Climate of Complexity
abstract: Harrison Ford provides keen insight on the environment in “Years of Living Dangerously,” a series on Showtime.
lead_paragraph: All this angst about climate change, and the answer’s been there all the time: Indiana Jones.

headline: A Venerable Tapestry, Woven Anew
abstract: The Emerson String Quartet finds that its sound and dynamic are shifting as it adapts to a new cellist, Paul Watkins.
lead_paragraph: The stringent harmonies of Shostakovich’s broody String Quartet No. 12 filled the living room of Eugene Drucker’s Upper West Side apartment on a recent morning as the Emerson String Quartet rehearsed. Mr. Drucker and Philip Setzer, the quartet’s founding violinists, sat on one side of the room opposite the violist Lawrence Dutton. With his back to the window, the cellist Paul Watkins had a view of a bookcase lined with nine Grammy Awards and side tables bristling with framed photographs of musicians paying handwritten tributes to the quartet’s reign in the chamber music pantheon: Bernstein, Levine, Rostropovich.

headline: In Poignant Paeans, Lost Players Live On
abstract: Quartets composed by Shostakovich in memory of lost players might also be viewed as tributes to the dynamics of an enduring ensemble.
lead_paragraph: An eerie tapping sound accompanies parts of Shostakovich’s String Quartet No. 13, which the Emerson String Quartet will perform on April 23 at Alice Tully Hall. Players take turns striking the body of their instruments with the wooden tips of their bows, with the steady, precise motion of someone hammering a small nail. The spooky effect is part of Shostakovich’s bleakly beautiful tribute to Vadim Borisovsky, the longstanding violist of the Beethoven Quartet, who retired from the ensemble in 1964 because of ill health.

headline: Ex-Connecticut Governor Pleads Not Guilty to Campaign-Related Charges
abstract: John G. Rowland, who resigned in disgrace 10 years ago and went to prison, pleaded not guilty to a new federal indictment.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — Ten years after he resigned in disgrace from Connecticut’s highest office, former Gov. John G. Rowland pleaded not guilty on Friday to an indictment on campaign-related charges that could send him back to prison.

headline: Health Reform and Affinity Fraud
abstract: Never mind those elitist “facts”.
lead_paragraph: Over at Talking Points Memo, they seem bemused by the violent reaction on the right to any suggestion that Obamacare is working as well as all the evidence suggests it is. Josh Marshall and Ezra Klein both made a fairly obvious point: Kathleen Sebelius’s resignation was almost surely timed to follow good news, so that her departure wouldn’t be easy to spin as part of a narrative about failed reform. The right, however, went ballistic — not so much expressing skepticism over the good enrollment numbers and the encouraging survey data as expressing total outrage and bewilderment that anyone believes the good news. On the right they know, just know, that it’s a total disaster.

headline: In the Air | Classic Rock
abstract: Marble emerges as the material of choice in contemporary design.
lead_paragraph: Marble emerges as the material of choice in contemporary design.

headline: Wet Spring Weather Requires More Attentive Driving
abstract: As the weather warms and spring rains arrive, roads can become dangerous if motorists do not adapt to the conditions.
lead_paragraph: The rain that tends to arrive in April often makes roads slick and dangerous. Mark Cox, director of the Bridgestone Winter Driving School in Steamboat Springs, Colo., said in a telephone interview that with snow and ice absent from roads, motorists can be lulled into a false sense of security when it is raining.

headline: Friday Night Music: Carolina Chocolate Drops
abstract: Wow. Just wow.
lead_paragraph: Saw them last night at Brooklyn Academy of Music. Totally amazing. Every time you thought they couldn’t surprise you any more with their range, they pulled something else out — and not just by singing in Gaelic. When Rhiannon Giddens kicked off her shoes and starting dancing, the whole audience lost it.

headline: Key to Tougher Teslas: Titanium
keywords: ['Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: The automaker’s “triple underbody shield” includes a titanium plate, but it does not turn the vehicle into an all-terrain tank.
lead_paragraph: A cloud of doubt lingering over Tesla Motors parted on March 26, when the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration closed an investigation of the Model S begun in response to two cars that were destroyed by fires after striking objects on the highway.

headline: Formula One’s New-Age Hybrids Find Their Footing
abstract: Just as the critics were attacking Formula One over an engine change, a tense race last weekend at the Bahrain Grand Prix gave the series a thrilling showcase.
lead_paragraph: Lewis Hamilton, the 29-year-old Englishman who won it, called it “a racer’s race,” perhaps the best ever of his 24 victories, and by the measure of how many others in the sport described it, that was no boast.

headline: Highlighting the Classical, Hitting the Mystical, Flirting With the Demonic
abstract: The pianist Paul Lewis made his New York Philharmonic debut at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday with a Brahms concerto.
lead_paragraph: Almost every season at the New York Philharmonic, gifted artists in their 20s, sometimes even younger, are soloists in concertos. So it was surprising that it took until Thursday night for the superb British pianist Paul Lewis, 41, to make his Philharmonic debut at Avery Fisher Hall. He played a majestic and insightful performance of Brahms’s Piano Concerto No. 1 in D minor with the revered maestro Christoph von Dohnanyi conducting.

headline: Obama, Citing New Laws, Says the G.O.P. Is Moving to Restrict Voting Rights
keywords: ['Voting and Voters', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama tried to rally his political base as he spoke at the annual convention of the Rev. Al Sharpton’s National Action Network in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: President Obama deplored on Friday what he called a Republican campaign to deny voting rights to millions of Americans as he stepped up efforts to rally his political base heading into a competitive midterm campaign season.

headline: Capitalizing on Her Leap to Stardom
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Movies']
abstract: The actress Lupita Nyong’o has capitalized on her fame and gained the financial power and cachet that come with being a brand.
lead_paragraph: It goes without saying that when you’re handed the part of a lifetime, you play it to the hilt. In the case of Lupita Nyong’o, the 31-year old Oscar winner — born in Mexico, raised in Kenya, educated at Yale and vaulted to what seemed like overnight fame — the part of the slave Patsey in “12 Years a Slave” was just a preamble for a far larger role.

headline: The Body as Helix in an Infinite Cosmos
abstract: The choreographer Shen Wei and his company are preparing a revival of “Map” (2005) and a solo featuring Mr. Shen at Judson Memorial Church in Greenwich Village.
lead_paragraph: “Open your joints,” the choreographer Shen Wei quietly exhorted his troupe recently in a large, airy studio at the Mark Morris Dance Center. “Drop your weight, stretch and go down even deeper, so your body is completely free.” Mr. Shen was preparing the dancers for a run of performances of his 2005 work “Map,” opening on April 29 at Judson Memorial Church, a stately neo-Romanesque pile on Washington Square

headline: Amid Flames and Flowers, She Dashes Through Time
abstract: “Orlando,” a monologue at the Alexander Kasser Theater based on Virginia Woolf’s 1928 fantasy, is set to music and features striking visual projections.
lead_paragraph: In “Orlando,” a monologue presented by Peak Performances at Montclair State University, the Scottish actress Judith Williams plays a boy, a young man, a male ambassador and several women, too. Of course, they’re all the same person.

headline: 2 Kenyans Kidnapped in Somalia in 2011 Are Found Alive
abstract: The African Union Mission in Somalia said that the two men, who were working for aid agencies, were rescued in an operation near Somalia’s border with Kenya.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Two Kenyan aid workers who were abducted by the Shabab militant group in 2011 were rescued on Thursday evening by Kenyan troops who are part of a peacekeeping mission in Somalia, officials said Friday.

headline: A Lucky Strike, Indeed
abstract: Since its debut in 2007, “Mad Men” has altered the TV landscape and perhaps even influenced the whisky people drink, the poetry they read and the cigarettes they smoke.
lead_paragraph: “Mad Men” made its debut on AMC in the summer of 2007, the creation of a former writer of “The Sopranos” whose pilot script was rejected by HBO, starring an unknown leading man and residing on a network best known as a second-tier movie channel, one that didn’t cost extra.

headline: East Meets West, Over Cocktails
abstract: The mid-20th-century world of Chinese nightclubs and their racial subtext are the subjects of a new book and gallery show.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — During its heyday in the 1940s, the Forbidden City in San Francisco billed itself as “the world’s most famous Chinese nightclub.” A jacketed doorman greeted visitors outside, drawing them into the club’s grand interior, with its rich tapestries and Mandarin-collared bartenders. On the bandstand sat a large gold Buddha looking down on the audience, which often included celebrities like Bob Hope, Rita Hayworth and Lauren Bacall. Tourists from the Midwest were there, too, lured by articles in Life and Look magazines, and by promises of the club’s “exotic splendor” and “all-star Chinese floor show.”

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about today’s biggest stories.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Katty Kay and Claire Shipman: Learning to Dispense With the Negative
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'News and News Media', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The newswomen Katty Kay and Claire Shipman’s new book, “The Confidence Code,” aims to make women more self-assured.
lead_paragraph: Katty Kay and Claire Shipman hardly seem like victims of self-doubt. Between them, they have covered the Clinton White House and the fall of the Soviet Union (Ms. Shipman), anchors BBC World News America (Ms. Kay) and learned to kiteboard at nearly 40 (Ms. Kay again). And yet both say they have had to work to overcome fears of inadequacy, tendencies to defer to male colleagues and “tortured cycles of useless self-recrimination.” In “The Confidence Code,” to be published on Tuesday, they lay out a path for women to become more self-assured. In phone conversations and at a lunch date (served by Sidra Forman, a Washington chef), Ms. Kay and Ms. Shipman discussed how to swat away creeping negative thoughts and what they are really thinking when they’re on television. (This interview has been edited and condensed.)

headline: Introducing Corporate to Cool
abstract: Katie Longmyer, a “business artist,” introduces young artists to corporate types.
lead_paragraph: On a chilly night not long ago, Katie Longmyer sat behind the D.J. in the Living Room Bar at the W New York Downtown hotel and surveyed her creation: fashion-industry denizens, purveyors of high art and Lower East Side hipsters, all dancing with gleeful abandon.

headline: A Niche No Longer
abstract: There’s a lot to appreciate about the new Nissan Rogue: more room, good fuel economy, impressive crash protection and a zestful approach to a mountain road.
lead_paragraph: There’s a lot to appreciate about the new Nissan Rogue: more room, good fuel economy, impressive crash protection and a zestful approach to a mountain road.

headline: Al Jazeera Series Depicts U.S. Problem
abstract: Al Jazeera America offers a startling change of pace with the series “Borderland,” in which six Americans trace the lives and deaths of immigrants trying to enter the United States illegally.
lead_paragraph: It turns out that there is a reason to watch Al Jazeera America.

headline: You’ll Go Far, My Pet
abstract: Being a pet parent today — nobody uses the word “owner” anymore — means cultivating manners and communication skills the way the parent of, say, a small human might.
lead_paragraph: Not to brag, but we may have a little genius on our hands. Our 6-month-old is up before dawn playing brain games. She knows her way around an iPad and practically devours puzzles, and I’m teaching her to read. Just recently, she mastered an advanced chess toy.

headline: An Eye on the Ball, Even in Tax Season
abstract: Sunday is usually a work day for John R. Lieberman, certified public accountant and personal financial specialist, but he still fits in time for his family and exercise.
lead_paragraph: All you people who haven’t filed your taxes yet, John R. Lieberman’s got your number. A certified public accountant and personal financial specialist who has talked about tax issues on “The Daily Show” and on CNN, he likens April 15 to Christmas Day: There are people who shop early in September, and there are people who show up on Dec. 24. Mr. Lieberman, 55, who is managing director at Perelson Weiner in New York and does a lot of international work, lives on the Upper East Side with Dr. Andrea P. Thau, 54, an optometrist. The couple has two sons, Evan, 24, in his third year at the Sackler School of Medicine in Tel Aviv, and Richard, 21, graduating from Binghamton University this year. Sunday is typically a work day for Mr. Lieberman, especially this time of year, but he tries to get in some tennis; he once aspired to the pro circuit.

headline: Killing Inmates the Old-Fashioned Way
abstract: The Tennessee state senate voted to allow execution by electrocution if lethal-injection drugs are unavailable.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, the Tennessee state senate voted 23-3 to allow execution by electrocution if drugs for lethal injection — the method of choice around the country — are unavailable.

headline: A Perfect Place to Hunt the Living Dead in Queens
abstract: Indoor Extreme Sports in Long Island City is a 38,000-square-foot emporium for nonlethal indoor combat, like zombie laser tag.
