lead_paragraph: As the inhuman shrieks drew near, six survivors of the zombie apocalypse huddled together, scanned the blacklit maze of the asylum and gripped their assault rifles. When a severed arm flew out from around the corner, they screamed and unloaded their weapons into the darkness.

headline: Herbalife Shares Decline on Criminal Inquiry News
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Herbalife shares fell about 14 percent late Friday after a news report linked the diet supplements company to a criminal investigation.
lead_paragraph: Herbalife shares plunged late Friday afternoon after a news report linked the diet supplements company to a criminal investigation.

headline: Vienna Philharmonic Finds Owners of a Nazi Gift
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Art', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Classical Music', 'Music']
abstract: The Vienna orchestra says it has tracked down the rightful owners of a painting that was looted by the Nazis and found in storage.
lead_paragraph: It is a simple oil painting, showing a sailing ship moored in a harbor, an early work by the French artist Paul Signac, made in 1883. For decades it lay hidden away in a storage space of the august Vienna Philharmonic, a 172-year-old institution that is one of the cultural pillars of Europe.

headline: April Is the Cruelest Month
abstract: Audiences can see a preview of the new “Brooklyn Nutcracker” at the Brooklyn Ballet’s latest production.
lead_paragraph: Brooklyn Ballet, which includes classical and street dancers, is an ambitious enterprise. That’s a gentle way of saying it’s all over the map. For “Vectors, Marys, and Snow,” the company’s spring program, seen last weekend at the Actors Fund Arts Center, Brooklyn Ballet unveiled a handful of works, including excerpts from its forthcoming “Brooklyn Nutcracker.” It’s true that there was a bracing chill in the air, but Tchaikovsky in April is just cruel.

headline: Help for the Big Guys
abstract: In 2011, there were 117 tax returns that showed both total income of at least $5 million as well as unemployment insurance income.
lead_paragraph: Even those among us who are doing the best can use a little help now and then.

headline: Trying to Regain Childhood’s Magic
abstract: In “The Shadow of the Hummingbird,” at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, Athol Fugard performs in one of his own plays for the first time in 15 years.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — “I’m sick of my rational existence in the ‘real world,’ ” the elderly man grumbles to his grandson. “I want to live once again in one full of mystery and magic and shadows I can play with.”

headline: Whose Picture Is It, Anyway?
abstract: When a child objects to a parent posting his photograph on social media, who makes the call?
lead_paragraph: Last fall, while on a family bike ride around Central Park, I took a photo of my 9-year-old son. His cheeks were flushed, his big brown eyes were lit with happiness and the golden sun made his light-olive skin appear to glow. It was a great picture and one I wanted to share with my friends online.

headline: Mentally Ill, in Prison and Outside
abstract: Stakeholders respond to an editorial and a news article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Seeing Asian Cultures, Through an Indigo Lens
abstract: An array of woven textiles is a centerpiece for “Seas of Blue: Asian Indigo Dye,” one of three new exhibitions that opened last month in the Charles B. Wang Center at Stony Brook University.
lead_paragraph: A 57-foot-tall blank wall under a skylight beckoned to Jinyoung Jin last fall, when she became associate director of cultural programs at the Charles B. Wang Center at Stony Brook University. “I felt I had to show something on it,” said Ms. Jin, who had a similar impulse about other vast expanses in the Wang Center, the 120,000-square-foot center for Asian and Asian-American arts and culture that she now oversees. “My purpose is to fill up the whole space,” she said recently as she stood on a second-floor bridge that offers a panoramic view of the sunlit white wall, which is no longer empty.

headline: Deciding Where to Set the Limits on Surveillance
abstract: Readers respond to articles about racial profiling and data collection.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Persons of Interest
abstract: This issue is about style and rooms that are intensely personal.
lead_paragraph: This issue is about style and rooms that are intensely personal. Yet the term “personal style” (like the term “lifestyle”) is now so overused in the decorating and design sphere as to be essentially meaningless. The homes, studios and work featured in this issue are personal in the sense that they are intimate — each seems like an organic extension, expressed through space and objects, of their makers. They don’t aim to be expressions of “personal style”; rather they just possess great style, which is always sui generis and, at least in the case of all the places we feature here, from the heart.

headline: Auto Nirvana
abstract: The 1964 New York World’s Fair reflected a world where the automobile had reached the pinnacle of its power and prestige.
lead_paragraph: The 1964 New York World’s Fair reflected a world where the automobile had reached the pinnacle of its power and prestige.

headline: Screening Air Passengers
abstract: The Transportation Security Administration disagrees with an editorial, “Behavior Detection Isn’t Paying Off.”

headline: Tax-Preparer Licensing
keywords: ['Tax Preparers and Preparation', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Institute for Justice disagrees with an Op-Ed essay urging licensing.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Week in Pictures for April 11
abstract: Subjects include an airport workers’ march, smoky haze in New York and some of the first blooms of spring.
lead_paragraph: .media.slideshow.in-page-player .headline { display: none; }

headline: Moments From Pistorius’s Testimony
abstract: A look back at the most dramatic moments from Oscar Pistorius’s testimony as he took the stand in his murder trial in Pretoria, South Africa.
lead_paragraph: A look back at the most dramatic moments from Oscar Pistorius’s testimony as he took the stand in his murder trial in Pretoria, South Africa.

headline: House G.M. Hearing Documents
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: Reference documents compiled as part of an investigation by the House Energy and Commerce Committee into why it took General Motors more than a decade to publicly disclose a dangerous flaw in a small-car ignition switch and to order a recall of the vehicles with the defective switch.
lead_paragraph: Reference documents compiled as part of an investigation by the House Energy and Commerce Committee into why it took General Motors more than a decade to publicly disclose a dangerous flaw in a small-car ignition switch and to order a recall of the vehicles with the defective switch.

headline: Cups With Hitler’s Image Are Investigated in Germany
abstract: Prosecutors in Dortmund, Germany, are looking into how the image of Adolf Hitler came to appear on cups sold at a chain of stores.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Some people think they see statues of saints weeping or an image of Jesus in their toast. A woman in western Germany recently thought she saw Adolf Hitler on a cup, nestled between rose petals and gaudy English writing. It turns out she was not imagining the profile of the man with a toothbrush mustache.

headline: And Now, Kosher Cheeses
abstract: Brent Delman, known as the Cheese Guy, sells about 30 types of certified kosher cheeses, allowing observant Jews to enjoy a delicacy he has always loved.
lead_paragraph: It’s tough for those obsessed with Époisses and other fine cheeses to understand. How is it that, for generations, many ancient, runny or stinky cheeses were not available to those orthodox Jews who adhere to strict kashrut dietary law? Perhaps because those laws forbid meat and milk from being served together and, as a result, dairy products often get short shrift. But now people like Brent Delman, who is known as the Cheese Guy, are letting observant Jews in on a wide world of cheeses.

headline: A Latin Heart Beats Anew
abstract: Corazon de Cuba occupies the former quarters of a restaurant damaged by Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: When I reviewed the Cuban Crocodile in Long Beach in 2012, it was the only Cuban restaurant I knew of on Long Island. It was damaged by Hurricane Sandy, and Corazon de Cuba opened in its former quarters less than four months ago.

headline: Jesse Winchester, Writer and Singer of Thoughtful Songs, Dies at 69
abstract: His music celebrated his Southern roots, even though he could not tour in the United States for years after moving to Canada as a draft resister.
lead_paragraph: Jesse Winchester, a honey-voiced singer who wrote thoughtful songs with deep Southern roots, died on Friday at his home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 69.

headline: Spring Design Issue
abstract: In our spring design issue, T celebrates risk takers, visiting the elegantly spare apartment of the architect Joseph Dirand, the amazing, overstuffed homes of Tangier’s eccentric expats and much more.
lead_paragraph: In our spring design issue, T celebrates risk takers. Leading the way is the architect-of-the-moment Joseph Dirand, whose elegantly spare Paris apartment, with its towering windows and generous slabs of marble, puts a new spin on minimalism. We travel to Tangier — long a refuge for adventurers and free-thinking outsiders — where a merry band of eccentric expats are letting their freak flags fly. We step into the homes of a pair of visionaries: the self-taught sculptor Alma Allen, whose journey as an art star has taken him from the streets of SoHo to the wild borderland of Joshua Tree, Calif., and the madcap designer Nicky Haslam, whose new London flat reflects his flair for the unconventional, and must be seen to be believed. Elsewhere, David Netto makes the case for personality and practicality in interior design; the international art gallery Hauser & Wirth bucks convention by opening an outpost in English farm country; the legendary French fabric house Le Manach gets a new lease on life; and the surrealist director Alejandro Jodorowsky as well as the surprisingly-nimble-in-the-kitchen pop star Kelis snack on gold popcorn while considering the future and blinged-out Louboutins. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: Remember Fort Pillow!
abstract: The obscure military post was the site of the worst atrocity against black troops during the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: On April 12, 1864 — the third anniversary of the firing on Fort Sumter — a Confederate force led by the brilliant and brutal Nathan Bedford Forrest attacked Union troops holding Fort Pillow, an obscure post in West Tennessee. What happened after Forrest’s men captured Fort Pillow remains one of the most notorious and controversial incidents of the Civil War.

headline: U.S. Denies It Knew of Heartbleed Bug on the Web
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Cyberwarfare', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The White House denied that the N.S.A. and other agencies had known about the security flaw that has created fears over the vulnerability of passwords and other data of Internet users.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration denied Friday that the National Security Agency or other parts of the federal government had known about the Heartbleed security vulnerability that has created widespread fears that passwords and other sensitive information belonging to millions of Internet users may have been revealed over the past two years.

headline: Journalists Who Broke News on N.S.A. Surveillance Return to the U.S.
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Polk, George, Awards', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Glenn Greenwald and Laura Poitras revealed the findings of the former government contractor Edward J. Snowden.
lead_paragraph: The journalists had been threatened, cajoled and condemned by the British and American governments. Their work together had set off a hunt for their source and a debate on both sides of the Atlantic about government surveillance.

headline: Local Views, Bucolic and Serene
abstract: Twenty-nine paintings are featured in “Pasture to Pond: Connecticut Impressionism” at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich.
lead_paragraph: Step into the new show at the Bruce Museum these days, and you are instantly transported to a soothing, bucolic world where water burbles, crickets chirp, and calm reigns. And that is before you even look at a single one of the 29 paintings in “Pasture to Pond: Connecticut Impressionism.”

headline: Financial Advice for People Who Aren’t Rich
keywords: ['Financial Planners', 'Personal Finances', 'Customer Relations', 'Start-ups', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The new companies began with the idea of advising young adults on their finances, then discovered that people over 50 also wanted help.
lead_paragraph: For a couple of years now, a number of entrepreneurs have been racing to solve the same problem: the financial services industry’s persistent inability to provide personalized advice and appropriate investments at a reasonable price to customers who are not rich.

headline: Mystery Surrounds Death of Ukrainian Activist
abstract: Oleksandr Muzychko’s gun-waving tactics and anger, largely directed against Russia, won him both admirers and enemies.
lead_paragraph: BARMAKY, Ukraine — For more than 20 years, Oleksandr Muzychko battled and somehow survived Russian power, taking up arms against Moscow-backed rebels in Georgia and Moldova, against Russia’s army in Chechnya and finally against Ukraine’s pro-Russia president, Viktor F. Yanukovych.

headline: Samsung Calls on Google Executive to Defend Innovation
abstract: Google is not officially a defendant in this case, but most of Samsung’s phones include Android, and some of the Apple patents involve features that Google put in Android.
lead_paragraph: In Apple’s latest patent fight with Samsung Electronics, lawyers on both sides are relying on the power of a good story to sway a jury. And Samsung is borrowing one from Google.

headline: Tax Returns Show Drop in Obamas’ Earnings
abstract: President Obama and Michelle Obama paid a total of $98,169, with a 2013 adjusted gross income of $481,098, a sharp decrease since most of Mr. Obama’s income came from his executive salary and not the sale of his books, as in previous years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama and the first lady, Michelle Obama, released their 2013 tax returns on Friday, showing a sharp decrease in their personal income since filing their 2012 returns.

headline: Former Ranger Traces Troubles to 2004 Fight
abstract: The incident involving Dan LaCouture is briefly mentioned in a lawsuit field on behalf of nine former N.H.L. players.
lead_paragraph: Dan LaCouture’s troubles began, he said, on Jan. 5, 2004, when one of his Rangers teammates got into trouble at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Cano’s Fresh Start
abstract: In Seattle, a former Yankee has a new role that he could never really embrace in New York.
lead_paragraph: The baseball experience of my childhood led me to believe in the stability of the baseball family. Even though free agency was alive and well in those years, my favorite players were mainstays. Mike Schmidt, Steve Carlton and Garry Maddox were Philadelphia Phillies legends who showed me that once you are granted the golden ticket to play professional baseball, you can enjoy a long career and be identified mainly with one team.

headline: Idea of New Attention Disorder Spurs Research, and Debate
keywords: ['Research', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder', 'Children and Childhood', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)']
abstract: Powerful figures in mental health are claiming to have identified a new disorder, sluggish cognitive tempo, that could widely expand the ranks of young people treated for attention problems.
lead_paragraph: With more than six million American children having received a diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, concern has been rising that the condition is being significantly misdiagnosed and overtreated with prescription medications.

headline: Pope Francis Asks for Forgiveness
abstract: The pope personally asked for forgiveness for the damage that priests have done “for having sexually abused children.”
lead_paragraph: The pope personally asked for forgiveness for the damage that priests have done “for having sexually abused children.”

headline: Pope Takes Responsibility in Priests’ Abuse Scandal
abstract: Victims’ advocates complained that the unprecedented public statement of papal contrition over the scandal is still just “talk.”
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Pope Francis said on Friday that he took personal responsibility for the harm done by priests who sexually abused children, and he pledged that the Roman Catholic Church would confront the issue unflinchingly and impose sanctions when necessary.

headline: In an Excruciatingly Hip Neighborhood, a Bloody Encounter
abstract: Wakar, an 18-year-old clerk on duty at a meatpacking district gas station, was just following the rules — which led to a testy and ultimately violent dispute with a customer in the early-morning hours.
lead_paragraph: The manager of a Mobil station in Manhattan’s meatpacking district shrugged and shook his head.

headline: Rules Violation at Augusta: Unauthorized Quesadilla
abstract: Bode Miller, a six-time Olympic medalist in ski racing, ran afoul of one of Augusta National’s rigid restrictions Thursday.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Bode Miller, a six-time Olympic medalist in ski racing, was just another face in the gallery at Augusta National Golf Club on Friday. He did, though, look slightly out of place initially, having arrived with a light ski parka to combat the morning chill and a baseball cap promoting not a golf entity but Sölden, an Austrian ski resort.

headline: Blast Survivor Thanks Her Rescuers
abstract: Firefighters found Carmen Quiñones, who was critically injured in a gas explosion in East Harlem, on top of rubble while fires were still smoldering in the debris.
lead_paragraph: In the devastation that followed a gas explosion in East Harlem last month, firefighters found a woman through a break in the smoke: a flash of color amid the debris that was once 1644 Park Avenue.

headline: An Italian Menu to Feed Everyone
abstract: At Sorella, with sepia photographs of the owner’s and employees’ ancestors hang, a pasta-pizza-entree menu and a flexible space aim to accommodate many kinds of diners.
lead_paragraph: Some restaurants just feel great to walk into. Casual but stylish, Sorella occupies a big, high-ceilinged room decorated with sepia photos of the owners’ and employees’ ancestors from the old country and offers views of Hartford’s Old State House. The tripartite floor plan accommodates a lively bar scene, couples dining intimately, and families, in a cozy back space anchored by a colorfully tiled potbellied wood-burning pizza oven.

headline: Battle for the Bigger Screen
abstract: Big chains are adding large-format screens in an effort to find new ways to grow in the United States and Canada, where business has been softening for a decade.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On the surface it’s just an old-fashioned game of Hollywood tit for tat: Cinemark, the nation’s No. 3 theater chain, has been promoting the growth of its network of extra-large movie screens, and Imax, the standard-bearer in the format for decades, has reacted with popped claws.

headline: Bookstores in Seattle Soar, and Embrace an Old Nemesis: Amazon.com
abstract: Though many independent bookstores have blamed the giant online retailer for their struggles, there are signs of a thaw in tensions in Seattle, as many Amazon employees are buying books in brick-and-mortar shops.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — A love of books and bookstores runs deep in the sinews of this city, where gray skies and drizzle can drive a person to drink, or read, or both. A long-running annual survey ranks Seattle the country’s second-most literate big city, behind Washington, D.C., as measured by things like the number of bookstores, library resources, newspaper circulation and education.

headline: In Brazil, Usual Olympics Worry With Unusual Validity
abstract: The criticism of the preparation for the 2016 Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro is rising, and experts say the problems are greater than the ones other host cities have overcome.
lead_paragraph: The smash-hit London Olympics were nearing a close in August 2012, and I found myself in an elevator at the main news media center with a small delegation of observers from the next Summer Games, in Rio de Janeiro.

headline: The Apple Chronicles
abstract: These days, the tech industry is battling over patents instead of new products.
lead_paragraph: So they’re at it again, Apple and Samsung, fighting over patents in a courtroom in San Jose, Calif. They had a similar fight in 2012, in the same courtroom, which Apple won. Samsung has also won its share of these legal battles, including in Australia.

headline: Stage Is Her Playground: Jump-Rope, Fuzzy Tube and Windup Toy
abstract: Amanda Loulaki is bringing “Forested,” the second piece in a trilogy exploring the audience’s gaze, to the Chocolate Factory.
lead_paragraph: In her new solo “Forested,” the second piece in a trilogy exploring the ways an audience’s gaze can be guided and controlled, the dancer and choreographer Amanda Loulaki uses her body as a vessel. Her compact frame has been on trips like this before. Ms. Loulaki, a New York artist born in Crete, is enamored of the choreographic potential of stringing together fragments of movement, gestures and emotions to create an ambiguous whole.

headline: Tom Petri, G.O.P. Congressman From Wisconsin, Is Retiring
abstract: Mr. Petri, 73, has represented the Sixth Congressional District in Wisconsin for 35 years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Tom Petri, Republican of Wisconsin, said Friday that he would not seek re-election after 35 years in Congress.

headline: Hoofing It Into the Future
abstract: Rhythm in Motion, a showcase of tap, was back on Tuesday with the first of two programs at the 14th Street Y.
lead_paragraph: Ask tap dancers what inspires them, and the conversation will probably turn to teachers, mentors, artistic ancestors. Perhaps more than any other, this is a dance form that knows where it came from, reveres its roots and doesn’t relegate its history to the past.

headline: Evoking Creation, Occasionally With a Big Bang
abstract: On Tuesday, the composer Matthias Pintscher conducted the Juilliard Orchestra through the New York premiere of “bereshit,” his conjuring of the biblical account of creation.
lead_paragraph: According to a line of Kabbalistic commentary, Genesis — Bereshit in Hebrew — begins not with the letter bet, the second of the alphabet, but with an invisible aleph, a letter that is inaudible on its own and here represents the sublime and translucent state that preceded the world’s creation. On Tuesday evening the German composer Matthias Pintscher conducted the formidable Juilliard Orchestra at Alice Tully Hall in the New York premiere of his own “bereshit,” a mesmerizing and sophisticated work that grew out of a whispered harmonic played high on a double bass and the barely-there hum of a gong — sounds as amorphous as an aleph.

headline: Utopian Vision Born of a Harsh Truth
abstract: “Aljira at 30: Dream and Reality” at the New Jersey State Museum traces the growth of Aljira, an alternative exhibition space for emerging and underrepresented artists.
lead_paragraph: The exhibition “Aljira at 30: Dream and Reality,” at the New Jersey State Museum in Trenton, starts with a video revisiting the 1967 Newark riots, titled “5 Days in July,” by Chuck Schultz and Esther Podemski. Made in 2007, it was shown that year at Aljira, an alternative exhibition space in Newark for emerging and underrepresented artists. The two-screen piece shows the city on fire and footage of the National Guard overrunning the rebellion of the African-American community after the arrest and beating of a cabdriver for a traffic infraction.

headline: Japan: New Energy Strategy Approved
abstract: Japan’s cabinet approved a new national energy strategy on Friday that designates nuclear power as an important energy source and calls for restarting idled nuclear plants that meet new safety standards.
lead_paragraph: Japan’s cabinet approved a new national energy strategy on Friday that designates nuclear power as an important energy source and calls for restarting idled nuclear plants that meet new safety standards. The new strategy, first proposed by the government of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe two months ago, scraps a promise made by a previous government after the 2011 Fukushima nuclear disaster to phase out atomic energy. Under the new plan, Japan could start as early as August to restart at least some of its 48 operable commercial reactors, which were stopped after the Fukushima accident spread nuclear radiation across northern Japan.

headline: Murder Charge for Teenager in Fire That Killed an Officer
abstract: The teenager, Marcell Dockery, is now accused of second-degree murder and is being held in protective custody at Rikers Island.
lead_paragraph: A teenager who the authorities say set a fire in the hallway of a Brooklyn high-rise last week was charged with second-degree murder on Friday, two days after the death of one of the two New York City police officers who were critically injured in the blaze.

headline: Sebelius’s Slow-Motion Resignation From the Cabinet
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: By Thanksgiving, it was clear that Kathleen Sebelius, the departing Health and Human Services secretary, would eventually have to go.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Everyone knew it was a disaster. After Kathleen Sebelius appeared on “The Daily Show with Jon Stewart” last October, she and her staff at the Department of Health and Human Services felt she had been sandbagged by Mr. Stewart. At the White House, President Obama’s top aides were aghast at her wooden performance.

headline: Chinese Fireball Mystery
abstract: China’s largest energy company has made the country’s first commercially viable shale gas discovery, but the path to energy independence is fraught with risks, as one town has seen first-hand.
lead_paragraph: China’s largest energy company has made the country’s first commercially viable shale gas discovery, but the path to energy independence is fraught with risks, as one town has seen first-hand.

headline: Derailed by Masters Win, Bubba Watson Seeks Another
abstract: Watson, the 2012 Masters champion and the leader after two rounds this year, said it took him a while to recuperate from his first major championship.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Bubba Watson, the 2012 Masters champion, concedes his mind was not on golf last year.

headline: China Takes On Big Risks in Its Push for Shale Gas
abstract: While China is eager to wean itself from energy imports and coal, its extraction of shale gas is likely to be more expensive and dangerous than elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: JIAOSHIZHEN, China — Residents of this isolated mountain valley of terraced cornfields were just going to sleep last April when they were jolted by an enormous roar, followed by a tower of flames. A shock wave rolled across the valley, rattling windows in farmhouses and village shops, and a mysterious, pungent gas swiftly pervaded homes.

headline: Doubly Disabled in Life
keywords: ['Mental Retardation', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Abuse of the Disabled', 'AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT', 'Editorials', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The Rhode Island agreement to end the economic servitude of developmentally disabled people is a promising, and overdue, starting point.
lead_paragraph: Americans with intellectual and developmental disabilities historically have been shuttled far from society’s mainstream into segregated lives and workplace serfdom, earning wages as low as pennies per hour for the most repetitive and menial jobs. The Supreme Court in 1999 pronounced this kind of treatment a civil rights violation under the Americans With Disabilities Act, but abuse and isolation from society have continued to this day.

headline: Inching Forward With Iran
abstract: The controversy surrounding Iran’s nomination of the ambassador to the U.N. should not divert Tehran and Washington from securing a final nuclear deal.
lead_paragraph: There is no doubt that the negotiations between the major powers and Iran over its nuclear program have been productive. All the nations involved — the United States, Britain, France, China, Germany, Iran, even Russia — appear committed to reaching a deal that will go beyond November’s interim agreement and produce a permanent one. The chief negotiators completed a third round of talks in Vienna on Wednesday and plan to meet again on May 13, after which they expect to begin drafting actual text. They hope to wrap it all up by July 20.

headline: It’s Leaving 57th Street, but Rizzoli Bookstore Vows Sequel
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Friday was the bookstore’s last day, and the closing came at the end of a painful week for shoppers who value a particular kind of New York store.
lead_paragraph: Lea Noring of Acworth, Ga., had a destination in mind for her first trip to New York, and it was not one of those crowded places like Times Square or the Empire State Building that the locals disdain as tourist traps.

headline: At Phillips Exeter, a World of Religious Diversity
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Hinduism', 'Buddhism', 'Religion and Belief', 'Private and Sectarian Schools']
abstract: For generations, the prep school in northern New England was a hothouse of upper-class Anglo-Saxon Protestant culture, but now it fosters a welter of faiths.
lead_paragraph: EXETER, N.H. — “Money, prestige, success — they have become slave masters,” Milton Syed, a slight 18-year-old from the Bronx, told his audience. He was wearing a necktie with his collared shirt, as required by the dress code here at Phillips Exeter Academy, alma mater of Daniel Webster and Franklin Pierce, of Gore Vidal and Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg. Mr. Syed, a senior, was preaching a khutbah, the Friday sermon after Muslim prayers, to a group of 10, including several fellow Muslim students, a Muslim math teacher and a blond girl who was not Muslim, just curious.

headline: The Self-Sort
keywords: ['Segregation and Desegregation', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Income Inequality', 'Minorities', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: It’s easy to demonize, or simply dismiss, people you don’t know or see.
lead_paragraph: This week, four presidents journeyed to Austin, Tex., to address the Civil Rights Summit and remark on President Lyndon B. Johnson’s legacy on the 50th anniversary of the passage of the Civil Rights Act.

headline: Torturing Children at School
keywords: ['School Discipline (Students)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Stun Guns', 'Editorials']
abstract: Complaints of dangerous disciplinary practices involving Tasers are cropping up all over the country.
lead_paragraph: Federal investigators have opened an inquiry into the tragic case of a high school student in Bastrop County, Tex., who suffered severe brain damage and nearly died last fall after a deputy sheriff shocked him with a Taser, a high voltage electronic weapon.

headline: A Tour of the Heavens Gets an Upgrade
abstract: At an improved planetarium at the Hudson River Museum, visitors can fly to Saturn’s rings and trace the constellations.
lead_paragraph: The Hudson River Museum, in Yonkers, is already reaping the benefits of its eight-month, $1.5 million planetarium renovation, completed in February. Since the March 8 reopening, school group bookings are up, and so are weekend ticket sales.

headline: Canadian Bankruptcy Court Clears the Way for Furniture Executive to Buy Bike Share Company
abstract: A judge in Montreal ruled that Bruno Rodi, the owner of the furniture company Rodi Design, could purchase Bixi for about $3.6 million.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — A businessman from Quebec has received a court’s approval to purchase the company that provides the bicycles and technology for several major bike-sharing systems, including Citi Bike in New York and Barclays Cycle Hire in London.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 11, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: April 11, 2014

headline: Lobby for Small Brewers, Concerned Over Rule, Finds Friends in Washington
keywords: ['Beer', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Many members of Congress have rallied to the cause of their home-state beer makers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Susan Collins wanted to talk about beer.

headline: Alternative to Shoots
abstract: A brain twister by Mel Rosen.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — By my count, there were seven entries in this puzzle by Mel Rosen that I had to look up, but that’s O.K. I know I have to put in my time to get through a Saturday grid, and this was tough but doable. And the result was an enjoyable solve, so that makes it worthwhile in my book.

headline: Salvadoran General Accused in Killings Should Be Deported, Miami Judge Says
keywords: ['Torture', 'Deportation', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Gen. José Guillermo García is accused of participating in the assassination of an archbishop and the massacre of over 1,000 peasants in El Salvador at a time when Washington was supporting the country’s military.
lead_paragraph: An immigration judge has found that a former defense minister in El Salvador, a close ally of the United States during a civil war there in the 1980s, should be deported because of his involvement in a number of human rights violations, including the assassination of an archbishop and the massacre of more than 1,000 peasants.

headline: Franken’s Campaign Against Comcast Is No Joke
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Television', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: After a failed attempt to block the Comcast-NBC Universal merger, Senator Al Franken again finds himself playing a trustbusting role in Washington.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For Senator Al Franken, the political became personal at a “Saturday Night Live” cast party, of all places.

headline: Take In the Hudson View, Cosmo in Hand
abstract: At Haven Riverfront Restaurant and Bar, where the ambition is palpable, menu choices come with a dash of adventurousness and reflect the chef’s varied experience.
lead_paragraph: Edgewater Harbor, the sprawling residential development across the Hudson River from the Upper West 90s of Manhattan, feels a bit like a place waiting to happen, with gleaming new high-rises cheek by jowl with construction sites, leasing signs in windows and new retail businesses popping up on the ground level.

headline: Student Crossing a Street is Hit by 2 Cabs and Killed
abstract: A college senior visiting New York City for job interviews was crossing an Upper East Side street when she was struck.
lead_paragraph: A college senior who was visiting New York City for job interviews was struck by two taxicabs and killed as she crossed a street on the Upper East Side, the authorities said on Friday.

headline: Excitement Turns Into Exasperation, Even for Stars
abstract: With golfers of every ilk — veterans and amateurs alike — brimming with confidence at the first major of the season, it did not take long for reality to set in.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — After signing his scorecard and speaking to the news media, the South African Branden Grace considered a quick stop in the pro shop Friday to buy six Masters folding chairs. He was going to need them for camping out during the weekend at one of the holes on the back nine at Augusta National.

headline: The Ruling on Gen. José Guillermo García
keywords: ['Deportation', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The decision by a Miami judge, issued on Feb. 26, said that the former Salvadoran defense minister should be deported because of his involvement in a number of human rights violations.
lead_paragraph: The decision by a Miami judge, issued on Feb. 26, said that the former Salvadoran defense minister should be deported because of his involvement in a number of human rights violations.

headline: Greenwald and Poitras Land in New York
abstract: The journalists Glenn Greenwald and Laura Poitras spoke to reporters after arriving at Kennedy Airport.
lead_paragraph: The journalists Glenn Greenwald and Laura Poitras spoke to reporters after arriving at Kennedy Airport.

headline: Hailing Farmers, Fishermen and Legends Past
abstract: At Restaurant North, agricultural partnerships and classic volumes help provide fresh, local food and a few surprises throughout the meal.
lead_paragraph: On the website of Restaurant North, just beneath the headings for “Our Menu” and “Our Wine” is an unexpected category labeled “Loves,” which includes slide show shout-outs to the Mets catcher Gary Carter, the cookbook author James Beard, Jerry Garcia of the Grateful Dead, and the exterior of the Peter McManus Cafe, the enduring tavern in Manhattan.

headline: Amid Storm Over Slurs, Fire Chief Plans Exit
abstract: A fire chief in Westchester County whose firefighters disclosed that he had used anti-Semitic slurs to deride a town supervisor has decided to retire at the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: A fire chief in Westchester County whose firefighters disclosed that on several occasions he had used anti-Semitic slurs to deride a town supervisor has decided to retire at the end of the year.

headline: A Yankees Pitcher’s Hand Revives Arguments Over Pine Tar
abstract: A suspicious-looking substance on the pitching hand of Michael Pineda on Thursday night renewed discussion of the practice of doctoring baseballs.
lead_paragraph: It is used to heal horses’ hooves and to soothe skin ailments on farmyard hens. It has also been used to preserve the wood and rigging on boats in Scandinavia, for hundreds of years, no less. And for almost that long, it seems, it has been used by pitchers to get a grip on the baseball in cold weather.

headline: The World Goes to the Polls
keywords: ['Elections', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Computer Security', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Windows (Operating System)']
abstract: Elections were held this past week in Afghanistan, India and Indonesia.
lead_paragraph: If the first week of April was one that favored cynics, this past week was more attuned to optimists. There were the extraordinary images of Afghans defying Taliban threats and bombs to exercise their hard-won right to transfer power through the ballot. Then Indians embarked on what was billed as the biggest election ever held, followed by Indonesians in what must be the world’s most complicated election, with half a million polling places scattered among 17,000 islands.

headline: City Accused of Dragging Its Feet on Settling Suit in ’89 Jogger Rape Case
keywords: ['Central Park Jogger Case (1989)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Sex Crimes', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: A lawyer for five men whose convictions were vacated in 2002 suggested that city lawyers were perhaps seeking to undermine Mayor Bill de Blasio’s call for a prompt resolution of the case.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio has long said that his administration would swiftly settle the lawsuit by five men convicted in the 1989 rape of a jogger in Central Park. “We will settle the Central Park Five case because a huge injustice was done,” he said in December.

headline: With Hands Spotless and Pitches Filthy, Red Sox’ Lester Shines
abstract: Boston’s 4-2 victory Friday was Jon Lester’s 10th win against the Yankees since 2009, the most by a pitcher in that stretch.
lead_paragraph: A night after Yankees starter Michael Pineda’s dirty right hand overshadowed his effective outing against the Boston Red Sox, Jon Lester made certain the focus remained on his pitching and only his pitching. Lester held the Yankees to two runs and six hits in a 4-2 victory Friday at Yankee Stadium, continuing his recent success against them.

headline: Desperation and Two Stars Fuel Much-Needed Win for the Knicks
abstract: The Knicks scrapped their way to a 108-100 victory against the Toronto Raptors on Friday night, improving their record to 34-45 with three games left to play.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The Knicks may now only be delaying the inevitable. They can only keep trying to eke out victories and keep hoping that the Atlanta Hawks undergo some seismic collapse to cede the Eastern Conference’s final playoff spot.

headline: Coming Soon to MoMA, Lots of Knocking Next Door
abstract: The Museum of Modern Art’s controversial decision to demolish a neighbor, the former American Folk Art Museum, is about to become reality.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Modern Art’s controversial decision to demolish a neighbor, the former American Folk Art Museum, is about to become reality.

headline: Terry Collins Shows Mets How to Compete, and to Endure
abstract: Thanks to his tenacity, Collins, who in his fourth season has taken the Mets to the verge of competing, has become the oldest manager in baseball.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Terry Collins used to have a bet every day with Barry Bonds. When he was the bullpen coach with the Pittsburgh Pirates, Collins would throw Bonds batting practice, and they wagered on the number of home runs Bonds could hit.

headline: City’s Doormen Reach New Labor Agreement
abstract: The new deal would keep in place the current benefits package and increase annual pay for a typical New York City doorman or porter by 2018.
lead_paragraph: Averting what would have been their first strike in nearly 25 years, the union representing 30,000 building service employees said on Friday that they had reached a tentative labor deal with the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations, which represents building owners.

headline: Hawks End Nets’ Home Streak and Move Closer to Playoff Berth
abstract: Led by Paul Millsap’s 27 points, Atlanta maintained a two-game lead over the Knicks, handing the Nets their first loss at Barclays Center in 16 games.
lead_paragraph: The Nets did the Knicks no favors Friday night. The Nets did themselves no favors, either.

headline: ‘Sweet’ Lou Hudson, Jump Shot Master With the Hawks, Dies at 69
abstract: A reliable scorer in the N.B.A., Hudson was a six-time All-Star and named humanitarian of the year in 2003 by an association of retired players.
lead_paragraph: Lou Hudson, a six-time N.B.A. All-Star who was one of the most reliable scorers in the league in a 13-year career, most of it with the Atlanta Hawks, died on Friday in Atlanta. He was 69.

headline: A Finish Rarely Seen on the Ice Is Followed by Elation and Disbelief
abstract: Minnesota’s Justin Holl scored a game-winning goal with 0.6 seconds remaining to beat North Dakota at the Frozen Four on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — In a sport unaccustomed to buzzer-beaters, the reverberations from a game-winning, last-second goal late Thursday were still resounding hours later at Wells Fargo Center.

headline: A Roller-Coaster Season for the Devils Hits Another Low Point
abstract: The Devils failed to make the playoffs for the third time in the past four years, losing their 17th straight shootout on Friday night, 3-2, against the Islanders.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Devils Coach Pete DeBoer could only laugh.

headline: Mobilizing Against a Common Core Test
abstract: Students and parents protested the E.L.A. exam at Public School 11 in Chelsea, Manhattan.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Showtime) DJANGO UNCHAINED (2012) Dr. King Schultz (Christoph Waltz), a German bounty hunter, teams up with Django (Jamie Foxx, above right, with Mr. Waltz), a former slave turned gun for hire, to rescue his wife (Kerry Washington) from a plantation owner (Leonardo DiCaprio) in this action-adventure directed by Quentin Tarantino. Samuel L. Jackson plays a house slave who assists his master. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called this film, which also earned Mr. Tarantino an Oscar for best original screenplay, “crazily entertaining, brazenly irresponsible and also ethically serious in a way that is entirely consistent with its playfulness.” He added: “Mr. Tarantino is a virtuoso of bloodshed, that is for sure, and also more enamored of a particularly toxic racial slur than any decent white man should be. But decency in the conventional sense is not his concern, though in another sense it very much is. When you wipe away the blood and the anarchic humor, what you see in ‘Django Unchained’ is moral disgust with slavery, instinctive sympathy for the underdog and an affirmation (in the relationship between Django and Schultz) of what used to be called brotherhood.”

headline: Russian Conductor’s Carnegie Appearance Draws Protests
keywords: ['Classical Music', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: Valery Gergiev’s friendship with Vladimir Putin led two dozen pro-Ukrainian protesters to turn out when he conducted the Munich Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: As long as the Russian conductor Valery Gergiev maintains his friendship with the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, it appears, protesters will have reason to dog his steps.

headline: Corrections: April 12, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on April 12, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Mets Hit Batter in 11th, Sending Angels to Victory
abstract: Intentional walks gave the Mets a possible forceout at every base, but Jeurys Familia hit Hank Conger with a pitch to force in a run.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — By some quirk in the baseball schedule, the Mets had played a night game in Atlanta on Thursday. They had left as soon as they could and had arrived here, bleary-eyed, around 3 a.m. local time. Now, late Friday night, they were locked in an intense game with the Los Angeles Angels, and it was dragging on, into the 9th, the 10th and beyond.

headline: Police Drop Charges Against Baby in Pakistan
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Police']
abstract: The attempted murder charge against 9-month-old Musa Khan prompted widespread scorn of the Pakistani legal system.
lead_paragraph: A 9-month-old Pakistani boy will not be going to prison on attempted murder charges.

headline: The Ballad of Geeshie and Elvie
abstract: On the trail of the phantom women who changed American music and then vanished without a trace.
lead_paragraph: On the trail of the phantom women who changed American music and then vanished without a trace.

headline: The Ballad of Geeshie and Elvie
abstract: On the trail of the phantom women who changed American music and then vanished without a trace.
lead_paragraph: On the trail of the phantom women who changed American music and then vanished without a trace.

headline: The Most Dangerous Word in Tech
abstract: We see “innovation” almost as a force of nature, a relentless outcome by the work of tech entrepreneurs. In the process, several economists warn, we’re losing sight of social realities about innovation.
lead_paragraph: The most important word in the technology industry is “innovation.” It is also the most dangerous.

headline: Outkast at Coachella
keywords: ['Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival', 'Rap and Hip-Hop']
abstract: Outkast, an uncommon hip-hop band that has covered a lot of ground since its first record in 1994, started a 40-date tour of large-scale shows by headlining at the Coachella Music and Arts Festival on Friday.
lead_paragraph: “I know it’s kind of weird,” said the rapper and singer Andre 3000 of Outkast, dressed in overalls and a hoodie and standing with his partner Big Boi. “But thank y’all for coming.”

headline: Coachella 2014 — day 1
abstract: The first day of this year’s Coachella festival featured performances by Ellie Goulding, Broken Bells and OutKast.
lead_paragraph: The first day of this year’s Coachella festival featured performances by Ellie Goulding, Broken Bells and OutKast.

headline: A 17-Year-Old, Living in New York
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A young woman is tired of the leers and crude remarks she and her friends get on the streets.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: A Talk With Simon Head, Author of ‘Mindless: Smarter Machines Are Making Dumber Humans’
abstract: Mr. Head offers his thoughts on the social landscape of the technology-dominated economy.
lead_paragraph: Simon Head thinks the world has become good for computers, but bad for most humans.

headline: A Whole New Meaning for Food to Go
abstract: Top chefs have been known to open satellite restaurants worldwide. Now a few of the world’s most respected chefs are moving abroad for limited culinary residencies.
lead_paragraph: Top chefs have been known to open satellite restaurants worldwide. Now a few of the world’s most respected chefs are moving abroad for limited culinary residencies.

headline: Analytics: Housing Authority
abstract: Elizabeth Weil’s “envy chain” of San Francisco homeowners inspired an online debate about the Bay Area’s real estate scene.
lead_paragraph: The following Analytics appears on the letters page in the April 13 issue of the magazine.

headline: Wall Street, The City, And Austerity
abstract: Deficit scoldery: ego and self-interest as well as politics.
lead_paragraph: Noah Smith, Simon Wren-Lewis, and I have in effect been having an intermittent, long-distance conversation about the role of the finance industry in promoting a view of our economic problems — one that emphasizes the dangers of deficits and monetary expansion — that has had a seriously damaging effect on policy. The question is why so many people in finance gravitate toward that view, and cling to it despite what is at this point overwhelming evidence that it’s wrong.

headline: Thought Secure, Pooled Pensions Teeter and Fall
abstract: Pensions in multiemployer plans were once believed to be extremely reliable, but changing economic circumstances have left vulnerable the pools and the federal insurance plan meant to support them.
lead_paragraph: The pensions of millions of Americans are being threatened because of trouble in a part of the retirement world long considered so safe that no one gave it a second thought.

headline: 1939: Goldfish Aren’t Safe in Bowls As College Boys Gulp ‘Em Alive
abstract: Goldfish-gulping was the new college craze in the United States, The New York Herald Tribune reported in 1939.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — The silly season has arrived with the advent of a craze far outdoing flagpole-sitting, marathon dancing, chain letter-writing and non-stop beer guzzling for dizziness.

headline: Pay for Performance? It Depends on the Measuring Stick
abstract: Many companies’ pay metrics are ineffective in motivating executives to create shareholder value.
lead_paragraph: Year after year, as executive pay continues its inexorable climb, it’s amusing to watch corporate directors try to justify the piles of shareholder money they throw at the hired help. Check out any proxy filing for these arguments, which usually center on how closely and carefully the executives’ incentive compensation is tied to the performance of company operations.

headline: How Badly Did the Knicks Lose This Season? Let Us Count the Ways
abstract: It’s awfully difficult, if not downright impossible, to single out the Knicks’ worst defeats in a lost season. But here’s a sampling.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks needed two games to absorb their first loss of the season, and it was an excruciating finish as the Chicago Bulls’ Derrick Rose sank a baseline runner for the go-ahead basket in the waning moments. It was Oct. 31, back when the Knicks were still flush with optimism, but the result left them feeling disappointed. It fast became a theme, one that culminated Saturday with their elimination from playoff contention when the Atlanta Hawks defeated the Miami Heat.

headline: Armed Men Seize Police Station in Eastern Ukraine City
abstract: The attackers, wearing camouflage, looted the building in Slovyansk of weapons, as pro-Russian militias stepped up pressure on the central government in Kiev.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Pro-Russian militants attacked police stations and other security facilities in the most populous part of eastern Ukraine on Saturday, in a brush fire of violent unrest that the government in Kiev immediately denounced as Russian “aggression.”

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent articles in the Sports section of The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
abstract: Mel Taub brings one of his best Puns and Anagrams puzzles in a long time.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — I have to remember not to drink any beverages when I’m solving one of Mel Taub’s Puns and Anagrams puzzles. Some of his PandAs are on the corny side, but today’s had a good amount of really clever stuff that almost made me spray my monitor from all the giggling.

headline: Brad Smith of Intuit: Follow the Fastest Beat of Your Heart
abstract: A chief executive says he tells young people looking at careers that “whatever makes your heart beat the fastest is going to give you the most energy to get up in the morning, and then you’re going to learn.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Brad Smith, chief executive of Intuit, the software company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: A Crack in the Laptop’s Screen (and in Customer Service)
abstract: A reader took her computer to Best Buy to repair a cracked screen. After two months, and no final resolution to the problem, she sought the Haggler’s help.
lead_paragraph: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

headline: In Their Hearts and Hopes
abstract: The Canucks team of 1993-94, which lost the Stanley Cup to the Rangers in seven games, still has a strong claim on the allegiance of fans in Vancouver.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — After the Rangers won the 1994 Stanley Cup, the team’s first championship in 54 years, they fulfilled the words of their coach, Mike Keenan: “Win this, and you’ll walk together forever.”

headline: How a Bicycle Maker Saw the Light, and Found Its Balance
abstract: By getting managerial help, a company’s young founders were able to turn their focus toward innovation — including the development of a glow-in-the-dark bike.
lead_paragraph: Cyclists have more ways than ever to make themselves conspicuous when on the road: fluorescent-orange helmets, reflective trench coats, bike horns that mimic car horns, and lighting systems with red lasers that project downward to create a virtual bike lane. Until recently, however, there wasn’t an effective method of illuminating the entire bike frame.

headline: A Rapidly Shifting Philosophy of Infield Play
abstract: As teams compile more and more information on hitters’ trends, managers can predict more accurately than ever where ground balls are most likely to go and can shift around their infielders.
lead_paragraph: Chris Tillman pitches for the Baltimore Orioles, which means he can never assume the location of the infielders behind him.

headline: In the Workplace, Leaders Who Aren’t Always Followed
abstract: New research has uncovered gender bias surrounding office “brokers,” or informal leaders who connect employees in productive ways.
lead_paragraph: Who really makes the changes in an organization? It’s not always the people with the highest executive titles. A growing body of research has pointed to the importance of informal leaders known to researchers as “brokers,” who have the gift of connecting employees in productive new ways.

headline: For the Newest Yankee, Reaching the Majors Was a Family Affair
abstract: It took a long time for Yangervis Solarte, 26, to play in the major leagues. Along the way, he received a lot of help and support from one of his uncles, the former Met Roger Cedeno.
lead_paragraph: More than 20 years later, his aunts and uncles still talk about the way Yangervis Solarte cried the day he watched his uncle get on that plane.

headline: In Jordan Town, Syria War Inspires Jihadist Dreams
abstract: Jordanian analysts and Islamists estimate that 800 to 1,200 Jordanians have gone to fight in Syria, more than double the number who fought in Afghanistan or Iraq.
lead_paragraph: ZARQA, Jordan — Late one night, Abu Abdullah left his whole life behind.

headline: From the Vision to the Gallery
abstract: A curator at the High Museum of Art in Atlanta describes the many detailed challenges of making an exhibition happen.
lead_paragraph: Stephanie M. Heydt, 43, is the curator of American art at the High Museum of Art in Atlanta.

headline: Want Teamwork? Encourage Free Speech
abstract: By seeking — and appreciating — the views of the entire group, a manager can turn dubious followers into active participants in the task at hand.
lead_paragraph: “Is there anyone who’s not ready for me to sign this contract?”

headline: Better Insurance Against Inequality
abstract: The tax system could be tweaked to respond whenever the income gap widens.
lead_paragraph: Paying taxes is rarely pleasant, but as April 15 approaches it’s worth remembering that our tax system is a progressive one and serves a little-noticed but crucial purpose: It mitigates some of the worst consequences of income inequality.

headline: Still No. 1, and Doing What He Wants
abstract: Larry Ellison, the chief executive of Oracle, may not care what you think about his $78.4 million in 2013 compensation, the highest in the Equilar 100 C.E.O. Pay Study.
lead_paragraph: It is good to be the king. It is even better to be Larry Ellison.

headline: Executive Pay: Invasion of the Supersalaries
keywords: ['Executive Compensation', 'Bonuses', 'Income Inequality', 'Boards of Directors', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: The compensation of corporate chief executives, up again in 2013, is drawing more scorn as an engine of income inequality.
lead_paragraph: Corporate America’s well-oiled compensation machine is running like a dream.

headline: How the Pay Figures Were Calculated
abstract: An explanation of the method used by Equilar Inc. to compile and analyze the compensation of chief executives.
lead_paragraph: To measure the amounts that chief executives were paid last year, Sunday Business asked Equilar Inc., an executive compensation data firm, to compile and analyze pay data from corporate filings.

headline: The Pay at the Top
abstract: The list of 100 of the highest-paid chief executives in American business from the Equilar 100 C.E.O. Pay Study for 2013.
lead_paragraph: The list of 100 of the highest-paid chief executives in American business from the Equilar 100 C.E.O. Pay Study for 2013.

headline: A Vote Against Congress in India?
abstract: Times correspondents report on the incumbent Congress party and the key players in the fight to lead the world’s largest democracy.
lead_paragraph: Times correspondents report on the incumbent Congress party and the key players in the fight to lead the world’s largest democracy.

headline: In 3-Hour Show on Palmer, Golf Channel Joins His Army
abstract: “Arnie” is Golf Channel’s attempt at delivering everything, and it arrives with the archival film, video, photographs, letters and talking heads that are the trappings of documentaries.
lead_paragraph: The opening words of “Arnie,” a three-part testimonial to Arnold Palmer on Golf Channel, set the direction of this extravaganza.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 61
abstract: The U.S. international striker Jozy Altidore has fallen on barren times at his English club, Sunderland.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Coalition-Building Season in India
abstract: The path of the front-runner, Narendra Modi, to the prime minister’s office will depend on a group of secondary politicians, including three powerful women.
lead_paragraph: COIMBATORE, India — As a potential political partner, the chief minister of the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu has some drawbacks.

headline: 25 Years After Stadium Disaster, Liverpool Still Mourns
abstract: Liverpool F.C. is in position to win England’s top league for the first time since 1990, but memories of the stadium disaster that killed 96 soccer fans in 1989 still haunt the city.
lead_paragraph: LIVERPOOL, England — In the middle of the bustling city center last week, not far from the merriment of the famed Albert Dock, a man set up a makeshift kiosk to peddle Liverpool F.C. scarves. Over the course of a lunch hour it seemed he always had a customer or two, and to understand the emotions that drive most fans here, one needed to look only at the three scarves displayed prominently across the top of the man’s tent.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, April 12
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Medicare']
abstract: Notable quotes from business articles that appeared in The New York Times last week.
lead_paragraph: “Heartbleed is further evidence that we don’t have our house in order when it comes to Internet security.”

headline: Anaheim Ducks and Their Coach Grow Together
abstract: The Ducks, led by Coach Bruce Boudreau, have their sights set on earning the No. 1 seed in the Western Conference.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — His label as hockey’s Everyman has worn a bit thin, but Anaheim Ducks Coach Bruce Boudreau continues to produce results that are anything but ordinary.

headline: In California, Saving a Language That Predates Spanish and English
abstract: The Yurok Tribe’s extensive campaign to revive the language serves as a model to the many other tribes that are undertaking similar efforts, experts say.
lead_paragraph: EUREKA, Calif. — Sitting in a circle in a classroom at Eureka High School here, Tenayah Norris and a half-dozen other students were learning how to express direction in Yurok, a Native American language that nearly became extinct a few years ago. Growing up on the Yurok reservation about 90 minutes north of here, she sometimes heard her grandfather speak it to his contemporaries, and she studied it, on and off, in the community.

headline: Buyers Find Tax Break on Art: Let It Hang Awhile in Oregon
keywords: ['Art', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Collectors and Collections', 'Museums']
abstract: A lucrative, little-known tax maneuver has produced a startling pipeline of art moving across the United States as collectors cleverly — and legally — exploit the tax codes.
lead_paragraph: EUGENE, Ore. — The Jordan Schnitzer Museum of Art, tucked into a quiet corner of a college campus here in the hills of the Pacific Northwest, is hardly the epicenter of the art world. Yet major collectors, fresh from buying a Warhol or a Basquiat or another masterpiece in New York, routinely choose this small, elegant redbrick building at the University of Oregon to first exhibit their latest trophy.

headline: Durant Adds Steady to Spectacular
abstract: Kevin Durant’s consistency as a one-man team in Oklahoma City could lead to both a league title and most valuable player honors.
lead_paragraph: To say that Kevin Durant has had a breakout season for Oklahoma City would seem ridiculous, given that he led the league in scoring in three of the last four seasons and is a perennial All-Star. But offered less help than he had in the past, he proved up to the task of being a one-man team. His consistently high production has him entering a new stratosphere as a player.

headline: Doing China’s Bidding in Nepal
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Editorials']
abstract: It’s fine for Nepal to pursue ties with China, but the harsh treatment of Tibetan residents and refugees should not be part of that policy.
lead_paragraph: A Human Rights Watch report released this month shows how far Nepal has gone in capitulating to Chinese pressure in cracking down on Tibetan residents and refugees. It details a long list of shameful actions against Tibetans in Nepal, including restrictions on their activities and movements, surveillance and intimidation, arbitrary detention and forcible return to China.

headline: Bankruptcy Beyond the Potholes
keywords: ['Gasoline Tax (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Roads and Traffic', 'States (US)', 'Editorials', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Without a long-term financing solution from Congress, planning, building and repairing infrastructure on state and local levels will suffer.
lead_paragraph: Congress is lurching toward its standard emergency, edge-of-the-cliff deal for the federal Highway Trust Fund, which could run short of money as early as August. The fund pays for the nation’s vitally needed road and transit projects and has operated on an 18.4-cents-per-gallon federal gasoline tax that hasn’t been raised since 1993. Now it is running on fumes, raising about $39 billion a year but facing shortfalls of close to $20 billion annually as more efficient cars pay less into the fund while infrastructure repair costs rise.

headline: My Mother’s Keepers
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Elderly', 'Home Health Care', "Alzheimer's Disease", 'Nursing Homes']
abstract: She lived her last months in another family’s home.
lead_paragraph: WEST SHOKAN, N.Y. — IF my mother had been aware enough to know what we were spending on her care, she would have been aghast. She’d always been frugal. I once noticed the remains of the Easter ham in the refrigerator two months later. “Don’t you think it’s time to throw that out?” I asked. “Ham doesn’t go bad,” she explained. She could make a piece of tinfoil last clear into the next decade. She once made an old corduroy jumper of mine into a seat cover for the rocking chair — perfectly good material, not to be wasted.

headline: Reclaiming the Words That Smear
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Language and Languages', 'Discrimination', 'Slogans and Mottoes', 'English Language']
abstract: Female politicians make dismissive words work for them.
lead_paragraph: AMES, Iowa — “UNBECOMING.” “Miss Congeniality.” Not sufficiently “ladylike.” In politics, these words and phrases have long been used to belittle female candidates. But now, female politicians are increasingly trying to rethink — and reclaim — how language shapes how they are perceived.

headline: Mark My Words. Maybe.
abstract: The ink on my arm says more complicated things about me than I meant it to.
lead_paragraph: MY tattoo kept getting delayed by other people’s weddings: a bachelorette party in Vegas, cliff-top vows in Zion, a ceremony in Westchester. I wasn’t just attending the ceremony in Westchester, I was officiating at the ceremony in Westchester. I couldn’t picture giving my blessing in front of 200 people while my left arm glistened under Saran Wrap. I felt the slightest twinge of resentment. My life seemed perpetually tucked into the pockets of time created between the milestones of other lives.

headline: Diversity and Dishonesty
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: Mozilla and Brandeis may preach pluralism, but it’s a sham.
lead_paragraph: EARLIER this year, a column by a Harvard undergraduate named Sandra Y. L. Korn briefly achieved escape velocity from the Ivy League bubble, thanks to its daring view of how universities should approach academic freedom.

headline: Women’s Unequal Lot
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Men and Boys', 'Parenting', 'Discrimination']
abstract: The 77-cent figure so loosely tossed around misrepresents the pay gap and its roots.
lead_paragraph: I DROPPED in on my sister last week. As usual, I was amazed.

headline: Max Levchin
abstract: On double-layered ear protection and reinventing the genome for molten chocolate lava cake.
lead_paragraph: Max Levchin is a Ukrainian-born computer scientist and serial entrepreneur who co-founded PayPal and Yelp. He is currently president of HVF (Hard Valuable Fun), which is a hybrid think tank/venture capital firm that focuses exclusively on data-driven projects.

headline: Jazz and Real Estate
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Jazz', 'Landlords']
abstract: I never see a downturn until it’s too late. You have to improvise.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND HEIGHTS, Ohio — I WISH my father, a landlord, were alive to read the news about the rental boom. He always liked numbers, particularly when they went up.

headline: The Killers Underfoot
abstract: We need the equivalent of the EpiPen for snakebite.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — IN just over a month, life-giving rains will soak India during the annual monsoons. As welcome as these rains are, they also bring with them injury and death from snakebite. As they do each year, venomous snakes seeking dry ground will slide into people’s homes, gardens and fields; they will curl up in woodpiles, latrines and play areas. Hundreds of thousands of snakebites will cause an estimated 40,000 deaths over the course of the monsoon season.

headline: A Wit for All Seasons
abstract: With a quicksilver wit and basic decency, Colbert’s the real deal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — I DON’T remember much about being on Stephen Colbert’s show.

headline: High-Priced Treatments
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Diabetes', 'Medical Devices', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Readers discuss how to weigh the costs and benefits of medical innovations.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss how to weigh the costs and benefits of medical innovations.

headline: Providing the Balm of Truth
abstract: An angry family member wanted to give a dying woman aloe vera gel. No one had had time to tell her the truth.
lead_paragraph: “What if we gave her some aloe vera gel?”

headline: Parental Involvement Is Overrated
abstract: Most of what we do for our kids at school doesn’t matter.
lead_paragraph: Most people, asked whether parental involvement benefits children academically, would say, “of course it does.” But evidence from our research suggests otherwise. In fact, most forms of parental involvement, like observing a child’s class, contacting a school about a child’s behavior, helping to decide a child’s high school courses, or helping a child with homework, do not improve student achievement. In some cases, they actually hinder it.

headline: Recovery for Whom?
abstract: Many millennials have fallen so far behind that recovering lost ground could be impossible.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve, increasingly optimistic about the economy, is dialing back its stimulus efforts. The International Monetary Fund has raised its forecast for growth in the United States. Congress has long since reduced aid to the economy, with many lawmakers, mostly Republicans, adamant that the economy is better off with less government involvement.

headline: Accusation in Montana of Treating Rape Lightly Stirs Unlikely Public Fight
abstract: Prosecutors in Missoula County are lashing out against a federal inquiry into their record on sexual assault cases.
lead_paragraph: MISSOULA, Mont. — For nearly three years, this college town in the hills of western Montana has lived under the shadow of stories of rapes gone unpunished and complaints that officials minimized or ignored reports of sexual assaults — especially if the suspects played for the University of Montana Grizzlies, the wildly popular football team.

headline: The Coat Speaks for Itself, Clearly
abstract: The winner of the Masters can spend the following year wearing one of the most recognizable prizes in sports.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The Masters green coat that came into vogue in the late 1930s has become what amounts to the world’s most recognizable reversible jacket. Augusta National Golf Club members wear theirs on the grounds to make themselves visible to tournament patrons seeking guidance on the course. And the reigning Masters champion wears it to make himself visible outside the club’s gates to anyone in search of a connection.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 13
abstract: Kathleen Sebelius, the health and human services secretary, resigned this week, just weeks after the Obama administration announced seven million had enrolled in the health care exchanges.
lead_paragraph: Kathleen Sebelius, the health and human services secretary who faced criticism for the flawed rollout of the new health care law, resigned this week. Earlier this month, President Obama announced that more than seven million Americans enrolled in the new health care exchanges. Sylvia Mathews Burwell, currently the director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, is Mr. Obama’s choice to take over the job.

headline: Growing Up at Sea
keywords: ['Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Sailboats and Sailing', 'Parenting', 'Boats and Boating', 'Rescues']
abstract: Life on a boat isn’t without its dangers, but parents shouldn’t be afraid of sharing these adventures with their kids.
lead_paragraph: ONE of my earliest memories is of looking down from the bow of my family’s sailboat and seeing dolphins gliding alongside us through the bright water. That spot at the tip of the bow, called the bow pulpit, was my favorite place when I was a child. It can be difficult to find somewhere to be alone when living with your parents and younger brother on 81 feet of wood and aluminum, but the bow pulpit was always there when I wanted time to myself. My brother preferred to climb the masts.

headline: A Loyal Soldier Doesn’t Deserve This
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Traumatic Brain Injury', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Iraq War (2003-11)']
abstract: Here’s a veteran who risked his life and sacrificed his mind for his country. What are we doing for him in return?
lead_paragraph: THE only reason he is alive, says Mike Yurchison, is his girlfriend, Leigh Anna Landsberger. She sits with him through endless waits at Veterans Affairs, whispering that he’s smarter than she is even if his brain is damaged. She helps him through his seizures, and she nags him to overcome drug addiction.

headline: Go Ahead, Vladimir, Make My Day
keywords: ['Natural Gas', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Global Warming']
abstract: A Russian gas embargo might be just what the world needs. Seriously.
lead_paragraph: SO the latest news is that President Vladimir Putin of Russia has threatened to turn off gas supplies to Ukraine if Kiev doesn’t pay its overdue bill, and, by the way, Ukraine’s pipelines are the transit route for 15 percent of gas consumption for Europe. If I’m actually rooting for Putin to go ahead and shut off the gas, does that make me a bad guy?

headline: Saving Young People From Themselves
abstract: We need to prepare millennials for retirement by mandating savings.
lead_paragraph: RETIREMENT is a financial obligation that today’s younger generations are not handling well. That may be through no fault of their own — they suffer from lower incomes, after being adjusted for inflation, and student debt that makes it a struggle to save. But regardless of the reason, the failure to save for retirement is setting up Americans in their 20s and early 30s for financially stressed golden years.

headline: Standing by our Veterans
abstract: Readers comment on my column about a veteran struggling to adjust to life at home after Iraq.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column looks again at the mental health crisis facing veterans of the Iraq and Afghanistan wars. I was against the Iraq war, but I still think we owe far better after-care to those troops who went and fought there. I tell the story this time through Mike Yurchison, who I mentioned tangentially in a column two years ago after his younger brother (also an Iraq veteran) committed suicide. Now it’s Mike who is in trouble.

headline: Shanahan Made the N.H.L. a Safer Place
abstract: Brendan Shanahan has left his job as the N.H.L.’s chief disciplinarian to become the president of the Toronto Maple Leafs.
lead_paragraph: Brendan Shanahan’s tenure as the N.H.L.’s chief disciplinarian was brief but epic, with the league turning an important corner. He “helped to change the culture of the game,” as Commissioner Gary Bettman said.

headline: Finance Officials Push for Bold Action to Sustain Economic Growth
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: At the World Bank and International Monetary Fund annual spring meetings, finance ministers and central bankers also discussed the possibility of new penalties for Russia.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At the World Bank and International Monetary Fund annual spring meetings, concerns about crisis have given way to concerns about complacency.

headline: At 40, Colon Continues to Defy Time and Weight
abstract: Mets pitcher Bartolo Colon is a large man who has become larger, but his throwing remains bigger than life.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — At some point as Bartolo Colon dominated the Atlanta Braves on Tuesday night, he walked through the dugout, looked down at his bulging belly, grabbed it firmly with his hands and shook it three times. Then, clearly pleased with himself, Colon smiled. He seemed proud of his size, or at least proud that he was talented enough to shut out the Braves for seven innings in spite of it.

headline: Rangers, Primed for Flyers in Playoffs, Rest Top Players
abstract: The Rangers will have home-ice advantage Thursday against Philadelphia in the first round of the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — Now the real hockey season begins, the Rangers were saying after Saturday night’s regular-season finale, a hard-fought, entertaining but ultimately meaningless 1-0 overtime loss to the Montreal Canadiens.
