headline: Arsenal and Wenger Avoid Nightmare and Advance to F.A. Cup Final
abstract: The Gunners have a long history of falling just short in their quest for a trophy, and they came close to extending that dubious run against Wigan.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Arsène Wenger paced. He fidgeted. He squatted then rose then squatted. When he finally stood still, he pulled at the belt loops of his natty suit. For more than two hours Saturday at Wembley Stadium, Wenger looked altogether uncomfortable.

headline: New Hampshire Republicans Get a Preview of 2016
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: What unfolded at the “Freedom Summit” on Saturday was a display of today’s Republican Party in all its dynamism, division and sometimes strange spectacle.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Here in a state where presidential politics are never far from anyone’s mind, three Republicans who are considering a run for the White House — Senators Ted Cruz of Texas and Rand Paul of Kentucky, and Mike Huckabee, the former Arkansas governor — pitched their views on Saturday for how conservatives can retake power in Washington.

headline: Police Kill Gunman, 86, Who Fatally Shot His Daughter
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Jack Calvello was shot and killed after officers responded to his 911 call saying he had shot his daughter, Carolann Matyka, officials said.
lead_paragraph: An 86-year-old man shot and killed his daughter on Saturday at the home they shared in Queens, and was then shot and killed by a police officer, officials said.

headline: New Faces in Middle of Order Power Yanks to a Win
abstract: Jacoby Ellsbury, Carlos Beltran and Brian McCann were brought in to bolster the lineup, and that’s exactly what they did on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The sun shone brightly, and a faint wind began to blow from behind home plate. It was the first such wind of the season, the so-called jet stream at the new Yankee Stadium that favors left-handed hitters. To this point, it had not meant much to Brian McCann, the new Yankees catcher. But he got a good idea of what it could mean to him this season.

headline: Another Prosecutor Is Said to Investigate Port Authority
abstract: The Manhattan district attorney’s office has subpoenaed documents concerning a range of the troubled agency’s major construction projects, a person with knowledge of the matter said.
lead_paragraph: The Manhattan district attorney’s office has subpoenaed documents from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey concerning a range of the troubled agency’s major construction projects, including several that have come under scrutiny as a result of the politically charged George Washington Bridge lane closings, a person with knowledge of the matter said Saturday.

headline: A World Is Reshaped, and Printers Adapt or Die
keywords: ['Printing and Allied Trades', 'News and News Media', 'Newspapers']
abstract: The survivors of the printing industry are increasingly high tech and automated. Many are holding on by moving beyond media publishing and into packaging and labeling.
lead_paragraph: The survivors of the printing industry are increasingly high tech and automated. Many are holding on by moving beyond media publishing and into packaging and labeling.

headline: Leaner and More Efficient, British Printers Push Forward in Digital Age
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Newspapers', 'Printing and Allied Trades', 'Magazines']
abstract: Despite steady declines in revenue, automation has allowed big printing companies to produce magazines and other publications quickly and at less cost.
lead_paragraph: PETERBOROUGH, England — At a media conference a few years ago, the editor of The Guardian newspaper, contemplating the future of print, recalled his paper’s installation of its newest presses in 2005.

headline: Brazil Tracks From Boom to Rust
abstract: Brazil’s economic boom bore big construction projects to empower its impoverished interior. But as the economy cools, many are unfinished, leaving a legacy of division and dislocation.
lead_paragraph: Brazil’s economic boom bore big construction projects to empower its impoverished interior. But as the economy cools, many are unfinished, leaving a legacy of division and dislocation.

headline: Pro-Russian Protesters Build Barricades
abstract: After seizing a police station in Slovyansk, Ukraine, pro-Russian protesters raised the banner of the People’s Republic of Donetsk and constructed barricades around the station.
lead_paragraph: After seizing a police station in Slovyansk, Ukraine, pro-Russian protesters raised the banner of the People’s Republic of Donetsk and constructed barricades around the station.

headline: Grand Visions Fizzle in Brazil
abstract: Projects conceived in boom times stand abandoned, visible symbols of waste and the country’s crippling bureaucracy.
lead_paragraph: Projects conceived in boom times stand abandoned, visible symbols of waste and the country’s crippling bureaucracy.

headline: From Boom to Rust, Lavish Projects Are Languishing in Brazil
keywords: ['Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'World Cup 2014 (Soccer)', 'Bridges and Tunnels', 'Soccer', 'Delays (Transportation)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: An array of projects conceived when economic growth was surging now stand abandoned, stalled or wildly over budget, fueling accusations of waste, incompetence and corruption.
lead_paragraph: PAULISTANA, Brazil — Brazil plowed billions of dollars into building a railroad across arid backlands, only for the long-delayed project to fall prey to metal scavengers. Curvaceous new public buildings designed by the famed architect Oscar Niemeyer were abandoned right after being constructed. There was even an ill-fated U.F.O. museum built with federal funds. Its skeletal remains now sit like a lost ship among the weeds.

headline: It’s Taxing
abstract: A puzzle with a timely theme, by Dan Schoenholz.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — As if we needed a reminder, today’s puzzle by Dan Schoenholz provides us with a timely countdown to the April 15 deadline for filing our taxes. Fortunately it’s a funny reminder, which may help make the medicine go down a bit easier for some of us.

headline: Obama Lets N.S.A. Exploit Some Internet Flaws, Officials Say
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Cyberwarfare', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Computer Security']
abstract: The White House said that information about major Internet security flaws should be shared with computer and software manufacturers so they can be fixed. But it left broad exceptions for cases that involve national security.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stepping into a heated debate within the nation’s intelligence agencies, President Obama has decided that when the National Security Agency discovers major flaws in Internet security, it should — in most circumstances — reveal them to assure that they will be fixed, rather than keep mum so that the flaws can be used in espionage or cyberattacks, senior administration officials said Saturday.

headline: How to Save $68,469 in Taxes
abstract: In some cases, collectors can avoid paying taxes on art they buy if they display it out of state before bringing it home. Here is how one collector navigated the system.
lead_paragraph: In some cases, collectors can avoid paying taxes on art they buy if they display it out of state before bringing it home. Here is how one collector navigated the system.

headline: Tsunami Warning After Earthquake Strikes Near Solomon Islands
abstract: A magnitude 7.6 earthquake was detected offshore near the Solomon Islands in the Pacific Ocean, leading to a tsunami warning for the region.
lead_paragraph: A strong earthquake struck offshore near the Solomon Islands in the Pacific Ocean on Sunday morning, causing officials to issue a tsunami warning for the area. There were no immediate reports of damage.

headline: Conservatives Clash With G.O.P. Leaders on Hood County Water Needs
abstract: Lake Granbury, a reservoir in Hood County, is only 53 percent full and the Hood County Tea Party is using the issue as a rallying cry against the state’s establishment Republicans.
lead_paragraph: Since the beginning of the Tea Party movement in Texas in 2009, state Republicans have harnessed its appeal to voters who are demanding less government spending and more local control. But when it comes to water policy, a hotly debated issue given the state’s severe drought and growing needs, conservatives worry that establishment Republicans have not stuck to those principles.

headline: Rivka Haut, Dies at 71; Championed Rights of Orthodox Jewish Women
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', "Women's Rights", 'Rabbis']
abstract: Ms. Haut fought to make it easier to obtain divorces in rabbinical courts and organized prayers at the Western Wall in Jerusalem.
lead_paragraph: Rivka Haut, a prominent champion of Orthodox Jewish women fighting for divorce in rabbinical courts and seeking to pray together as a group, died on March 30 in the Bronx. She was 71.

headline: Rail Transport of Crude Oil Increases as Pipeline Falls Short
abstract: In Texas, a crude-by-train boom has led to the construction of facilities to help deliver oil to Gulf Coast refineries. It has also raised concerns about the safety of moving such volatile materials across the state.
lead_paragraph: In December, a new terminal in the Port of Beaumont welcomed its first customer: a train carrying 43,000 barrels of crude oil from Colorado. Workers at the terminal, the Jefferson Transload Railport, transferred the crude to a barge, which traveled down the Neches River to a nearby refinery.

headline: Augusta’s Designated Fill-In Bests Rory McIlroy
abstract: A 51-year-old who teed off in the third round of the Masters, Jeff Knox, shot a 70 before the huge galleries attracted by McIlroy, his playing partner.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Miguel Ángel Jiménez, whose six-under-par 66 Saturday was the low round of the week, is one of seven players 50 or older who teed off Saturday at the Masters. There were six touring professionals and Jeff Knox, the tournament representative and course record-holder, who played as the marker for the two-time major champion Rory McIlroy, the 51st competitor to make the cut.

headline: North Carolina Shows Strains Within G.O.P.
keywords: ['Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Political Advertising']
abstract: In North Carolina’s high-profile Republican primary for Senate, the divisions gripping the party nationally are playing out loudly and expensively.
lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C. — There is a Tea Party candidate who talks about the Constitution and has the backing of Senator Rand Paul. There is a Baptist pastor, endorsed by Mike Huckabee, who wears a “Jesus First” lapel pin and has led the fight against same-sex marriage. And there is a Republican state lawmaker — supported by the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and $1 million from Karl Rove’s American Crossroads group — standing up for the party establishment.

headline: Lingering Power of Hostage Crisis Short-Circuits Iranian Nominee
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Visas']
abstract: Washington’s decision to deny Hamid Aboutalebi, Iran’s choice for its next United Nations ambassador, a visa highlights the distrust that still infects the United States-Iran relationship.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When Iranian militants seized the United States Embassy and took dozens of Americans hostage on an overcast Sunday morning in November 1979, I assumed it was just a brief anti-American sit-in. My main concern, I told my editors at Newsweek, was not how dangerous Tehran would be. It was whether it would still be a story by the time I arrived there from Paris the next day.

headline: Carol Grimaldi, Co-Founder of Lauded Brooklyn Pizzeria, Dies at 76
abstract: Her good-natured enforcement of the customer code — no slices, no deliveries, no credit cards — became part of the lore of Grimaldi’s Pizzeria.
lead_paragraph: Carol Grimaldi, the co-owner with her husband, Pasquale, of the original Grimaldi’s Pizzeria in Brooklyn, which for many years was hailed as one of the best pizza restaurants in a city of pizza connoisseurs, died on Thursday in Queens. She was 76.

headline: Revived Soriano Remains Consistently Streaky Force for Yankees
abstract: Alfonso Soriano was hitless in his first four games this season, but he has been hot since recording his first hit, continuing a career resurgence with the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: Alfonso Soriano was so successful in anticipating the start of his hot streak this season that he wondered whether he should apply those predictive skills to the lottery.

headline: Schools Chancellor Details Initiatives for Schools
abstract: At a speech on Saturday, Carmen Fariña said she would aim to reduce class sizes and curb the use of suspensions at the city’s public schools.
lead_paragraph: Schools Chancellor Carmen Fariña on Saturday called for a “back-to-basics approach” to educating New York City’s 1.1 million public school students, and said she would work to reduce class sizes, curb the use of suspensions and pair more local universities and cultural institutions with public schools.

headline: A Nightclub Reflecting ’80s Dallas Is Revisited
abstract: A new documentary captures a cultural milepost that sprung up at the intersection of conservatism and dance parties.
lead_paragraph: Among Dallas residents of a certain age, the Starck Club is often recalled with a mix of nostalgia and wonder: How did such a thing ever exist?

headline: Bubba Watson Falters, and a 20-Year-Old Ties for the Lead
abstract: Jordan Spieth, a Masters rookie, posted his second consecutive 70 to move into a tie for first with Watson, the 2012 champion.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Experience is worth a couple of strokes at Augusta National Golf Club. Everybody says so, and sure enough, the top-10 leader board after 54 holes of the Masters includes two players past their 50th birthdays, Miguel Ángel Jiménez and Fred Couples, as well as the 2012 champion, Bubba Watson.

headline: Aid to Schools Is Goal of Push to Raise Taxes
abstract: An effort to raise taxes on business properties seems aimed at putting money into schools and other government programs that depend on property tax revenue.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Thailand’s Political Tensions Are Rekindling Ethnic and Regional Divisions
abstract: Three governments have been removed from power since 2006, and for the last five months, protesters in Bangkok have demanded the overthrow of the government and a reduction in the influence of the Shinawatra clan.
lead_paragraph: LAMPHUN, Thailand — Each time Muean Chimoon leaves his wooden house in northern Thailand, he pays homage to a portrait of King Bhumibol Adulyadej, a father figure and long a symbol of national unity.

headline: Search for Tiger Woods’s Successor Skips a Generation
abstract: Youngsters such as Jordan Spieth may hold the key to the mystery of who will take over for the sport’s longtime king.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Tiger Woods is missing from this year’s Masters, and so are all the people we once expected to replace him.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 12, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: April 12, 2014

headline: Blue Grass Stakes Winner Isn’t Likely to Run in Kentucky Derby
abstract: Dance With Fate’s trainer said the horse did not have the power to run on dirt like that at Churchill Downs.
lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Ky. — Officials at Keeneland Race Course have been criticized for their decision to return to a dirt surface after their eight-year use of Polytrack led to a significant reduction in deaths. But the result of the Blue Grass Stakes on Saturday pointed to at least one reason for the change, which will occur at the end of the spring meet.

headline: Damascus and Rebels Trade Blame in Gas Attack
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: The attack on a rebel-held Syrian village reportedly sickened more than 100 people.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian state television and antigovernment activists reported Saturday that poison gas had been used in a rebel-held village in the central province of Hama, with each side blaming its enemies for an attack they both said sickened more than 100 people.

headline: Knicks’ Playoff Hopes End as Hawks Cruise Past Heat
abstract: After three straight postseason appearances, the Knicks will be done after the regular season, as the Hawks earned a 98-85 home victory over the Heat.
lead_paragraph: The end for the Knicks came in unlikely fashion on Saturday night, with the Atlanta Hawks beating the Miami Heat, of all teams, to nail down the eighth and final playoff spot in the Eastern Conference.

headline: Xenophobic Chill Descends on Moscow
abstract: From the moment that Russia’s invasion and annexation of Crimea cast a new, bitter chill over relations with the West, a sinister jingoistic vibe has pervaded Russia’s capital.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The huge banner was unfurled on Friday morning outside one of Moscow’s biggest bookstores, Dom Knigi, a grand emporium of the written word on Novii Arbat Street across from a Citibank, a Baskin-Robbins and a Dunkin’ Donuts, and down the block from a big movie theater where the main feature at the moment is “Captain America: The Winter Soldier.”

headline: Vows: The Perfect Fire
abstract: Susan Levin lost her life’s work of art and all her possessions when her house burned down in a wildfire. She ordered new things online — and fell in love with the FedEx delivery woman.
lead_paragraph: Susan Levin lost her life’s work of art and all her possessions when her house burned down in a wildfire. She ordered new things online — and fell in love with the FedEx delivery woman.

headline: Fred Ho: The Music Lives On
abstract: The baritone saxophonist Fred Ho died on April 12th after a years-long battle with cancer. Mr. Ho’s music is known for straddling the line between classical and jazz.
lead_paragraph: The baritone saxophonist Fred Ho died on April 12th after a years-long battle with cancer. Mr. Ho’s music is known for straddling the line between classical and jazz.

headline: Fred Ho, Composer and Musician in ‘Popular Avant-Gard,’ Dies at 56
abstract: Mr. Ho, who considered himself a “popular avant-gardist,” mixed jazz with popular and traditional elements of what he called Afro-Asian culture.
lead_paragraph: Fred Ho, a composer, saxophonist, writer and radical activist who composed politically charged operas, suites, oratorios and ballets that mixed jazz with popular and traditional elements of what he called Afro-Asian culture, died on Saturday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 56.

headline: Flurry of Goals Gives Union First Title
abstract: The Union Dutchmen scored three goals during a two-minute stretch en route to winning their first Division I men’s hockey championship, beating five-time champion Minnesota.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Union College toppled the five-time champion Minnesota, 7-4, on Saturday at Wells Fargo Center to win its first N.C.A.A. men’s hockey title.

headline: My TEDx Talk: We Are Perfect, With a Hefty Asterisk
keywords: ['Disasters and Emergencies', 'Earthquakes', 'Geology', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Tidal Waves and Tsunamis']
abstract: I propose a shift in goals from numbers to traits that can help us shape a “good” Anthropocene.
lead_paragraph: I just gave a talk at TEDx Portland — a daylong event focused on various interpretations of the word “perfect.”

headline: The Triumph of Personal Style
abstract: In decorating, the trend these days is to choose — and stick to — a popular design style. Unfortunately, a lot of individualism gets lost along the way.
lead_paragraph: The pressure to stick to one particular style in interior decorating can yield a space that looks good in photographs but isn’t necessarily a particularly pleasant place to call home. Using his own Hamptons getaway as an example, the author makes the case for the considerations of real life.

headline: Fawn Jiang, Brendan McGinty
abstract: The bride was a marketing coordinator; the groom is a senior campaign manager at an advertising agency.
lead_paragraph: Fawn Vera Jiang and Brendan John McGinty were married Saturday at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Sarah J. Ritchie, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated.

headline: Rina Parmeshwar, Prabhu Balasubramanian
abstract: The bride is a medical intern; the groom is a senior project manager at Google.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Rina Parmeshwar and Prabhu Shankar Balasubramanian are to be married Sunday morning at the Santa Clara Marriott in Santa Clara, Calif. Pandit Agoram Sivaramakrishnan will lead the ceremony with Krishnan Ganapathy Sastrigal participating; they are both Hindu priests.

headline: John Gordon, Justin Zaremby
abstract: A curator and a lawyer marry in New Haven.
lead_paragraph: John Stuart Gordon and Justin Scott Zaremby were married Saturday at the Elizabethan Club, a private literary club in New Haven. Judge José A. Cabranes of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, for whom Dr. Zaremby served as a law clerk in 2010 and 2011, officiated.

headline: Sarah Stein, Alex Koppelman
abstract: The bride is an associate editor at Riverhead Books; the groom is the news editor at U.S. edition of The Guardian US.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Jenny Stein and Alex Ritter Koppelman were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Lee Friedlander at Skylight One Hanson in Brooklyn.

headline: Mary Allison, Louis Ferrara
abstract: A wedding in Arizona at a family home.
lead_paragraph: Mary Patricia Allison and Louis Michael Ferrara were married Saturday at the home of Alfredo and Jennifer Dreyfus, a sister of the bride, in Gilbert, Ariz. John T. Johnson, a bishop of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, performed the ceremony.

headline: Erica Fink, Arel Lidow
abstract: The bride is a senior producer for CNN’s website; the groom is a senior director at AppNexus, an online advertising firm.
lead_paragraph: Erica Blair Fink, the daughter of Nancy F. Fink and Jonathan J. Fink of New York, was married Saturday evening to Arel Ives Lidow, a son of Diana D. Lidow and Derek B. Lidow of Princeton, N.J. Rabbi Jonathan A. Stein officiated at the Essex House in New York.

headline: Kim Carlson, Jeanne Graham
abstract: The owner of a real estate management firm and a company that produces software applications and a United States magistrate judge are married in Minneapolis.
lead_paragraph: Kim Elizabeth Carlson and Jeanne Jo Graham were married Saturday evening at the 112 Eatery Restaurant in Minneapolis. Kathryn L. Quaintance, a Hennepin County District Court judge in Minneapolis, officiated.

headline: Candice Chiu, Alex Wong
abstract: The couple met at Harvard.
lead_paragraph: Candice Chiu and Alex Nelson Wong were married Saturday evening at the DAR Memorial Continental Hall in Washington. The officiant was Sandra Day O’Connor, the retired United States Supreme Court justice, for whom the bride was a clerk from July 2011 to July 2012. The couple met at Harvard, from which the bride graduated and each received a law degree.

headline: Erin Muckey, Alexander Cavin
abstract: The bride is studying for a joint medical degree and M.B.A. at Columbia; the groom is a marketing project manager for a biopharmaceutical company.
lead_paragraph: Erin Joy Muckey and Alexander William Cavin were married Saturday at the Beach Club at Sea Ranch Lakes in Sea Ranch Lakes, Fla. Joseph E. Falit, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Mock Trials Lead to Real Romance
abstract: The couple met at Syracuse University, where they were on the mock trial team.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Lynne Miller and Joshua Herbert Frost were married Saturday evening at the Bourne Mansion, an event space in Oakdale, N.Y. Justice Milton A. Tingling Jr., of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, officiated.

headline: Sandra Sanchez, Jacob Angel
abstract: The bride is a graduate student at Columbia; the groom is a website developer.
lead_paragraph: Sandra Sanchez, a daughter of Sandra L. Sanchez and Alejandro Sanchez of Chula Vista, Calif., was married Saturday evening to Jacob Daniel Angel, a son of Gail A. Angel and the Rev. Stephan E. Angel of Chicago. The groom’s father, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at the Metropolitan Building in Long Island City, Queens.

headline: Kimberly Resnick, Adam Thaler
abstract: The bride is a doctor; the groom is an anesthesiologist.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Kimberly Sue Resnick, the daughter of Lanie Resnick and Gerald A. Resnick of New York, was married Saturday evening to Dr. Adam Michael Thaler, the son of Sharon Kitain Thaler and Dr. Bruce J. Thaler of Philadelphia. Rabbi Howard K. Cove officiated at the Ashford Estate, an event space in Allentown, N.J.

headline: Christie Wilson, John Bonasera
abstract: The bride works in legal recruiting and the groom in pharmaceutical sales.
lead_paragraph: Christie Michelle Wilson and John James Bonasera were married Saturday at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. George M. Witt, a Roman Catholic priest and the pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

headline: Elizabeth Hyon, Aaron Rubin
abstract: Two lawyers are wed in Central Park.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Susan Hyon and Aaron Grant R Rubin were married Saturday evening at the Loeb Central Park Boathouse in New York. The Rev. Jesse D. Hendrich, a Spiritual Humanist minister, officiated.

headline: Olivier Cassegrain, Troy Miller
abstract: The United States director of Longchamp is wed to a freelance theater director.
lead_paragraph: Olivier Philippe Cassegrain and Robert Troy Miller were married Saturday in Paris at the city hall for the Seventh Arrondissement. The arrondissement’s mayor, Rachida Dati, officiated.

headline: The Complete Package
abstract: After several deliveries, a FedEx courier falls for an artist.
lead_paragraph: Margie Ellen Ashley and Susan Barbara Levin are to be married Sunday at the Marin Art and Garden Center in Ross, Calif. Marsha R. Angus, a Universal Life minister, will officiate.

headline: Kathleen Milazzo, Travis Johnson
abstract: The couple met at Rice University.
lead_paragraph: Kathleen Marie Milazzo and Jay Travis Johnson were married Saturday evening at the Holy Family Catholic Church in Chicago. The Rev. Jeremiah M. Boland, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Webster University Clings to Its Title at Final Four
abstract: For the second year in a row, Webster University of St. Louis won the Final Four of chess, although Texas Tech almost pulled an upset.
lead_paragraph: Chess had its own version of the Final Four last week, with Webster University of St. Louis taking the title, known as the President’s Cup, for the second year in a row.

headline: The Toddler Who Survived, and the Cop Who Became Her Mom
abstract: As a baby, Christina Rivera survived a massacre in Brooklyn whose 10 victims included her mother. Police Officer Joanne Jaffe cared for her that night, the first link in a bond that led Ms. Jaffe to adopt Christina.
lead_paragraph: The bodies were discovered throughout the first-floor railroad flat in Brooklyn, a bizarre still-life of death. Many of the victims remained seated in chairs or couches; one woman’s hands still held a spoon and a small can of pudding.

headline: Corrections: April 13, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on April 13, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Mets Absorb a Staggering Blow but Deliver the Final One
abstract: After Jose Valverde allowed a game-tying three-run homer to Raul Ibanez in the bottom of the ninth, Anthony Recker homered in the 13th, lifting the Mets past the Angels.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Jose Valverde was crouched over, his hands on his knees, as he watched Raul Ibanez’s three-run homer sail into the night. The shot, which tied the score at 6-6 in the bottom of the ninth, spoiled a solid start by Jon Niese and forced the weary Mets to play on. They had flown here from Atlanta two nights before, had battled the Los Angeles Angels for 11 innings and lost the previous night, and now this.

headline: Climate Efforts Falling Short, U.N. Panel Says
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: The countries of the world have dragged their feet so long on global warming that only an intensive push in the next 15 years can stave off potential disaster, United Nations-appointed experts said.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Delivering the latest stark news about climate change on Sunday, a United Nations panel warned that governments are not doing enough to avert profound risks in coming decades. But the experts found a silver lining: Not only is there still time to head off the worst, but the political will to do so seems to be rising around the world.

headline: In Our Pages: April 14
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: England crushes France in their annual rugby match in 1914; Nikita S. Krushchev is reported dead in 1964, but he’s alive at a party at the Kremlin.
lead_paragraph: 1914: England Crushes France in Annual Rugby Match

headline: Ukraine Forces Storm a Town, Defying Russia
abstract: The Ukrainian government on Sunday for the first time sent in its security services to confront armed pro-Russian militants who took over a police station in the country’s east, Ukrainian officials said.
lead_paragraph: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — The Ukrainian government on Sunday for the first time sent its security services to confront armed pro-Russian militants in the country’s east, defying warnings from Russia. Commandos engaged in gunfights with men who had set up roadblocks and stormed a Ukrainian police station in Slovyansk, and at least one officer was killed, Ukrainian officials said.

headline: Partial Afghan Results Portend a Runoff as Fraud Is Cited
abstract: Official results of 10 percent of votes cast in 26 of Afghanistan’s 34 provinces showed that two candidates were leading. A runoff election appeared more certain.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — In the first official report of partial results from the Afghan presidential election, the candidates Abdullah Abdullah and Ashraf Ghani appeared to be leading a race in which a runoff election was increasingly certain, according to data released by the Independent Election Commission on Sunday.

headline: I Have No Idea How Many Calories Are in My Grandmother’s Gefilte Fish
abstract: For my daughters, food isn’t a troublesome source of calories demanding its weight in exercise. It’s holidays, it’s funny stories, it’s seasons. It’s my grandmother’s gefilte fish, and all of us cooking it together.
lead_paragraph: Passover is coming, and so is my Nanna. At 98, an age when most of her contemporaries (I’d say “many” of her contemporaries, except the truth is, Nanna has outlived most of her generation) are in bed or assisted living, my Nanna, Faye Frumin, will board a plane from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to Philadelphia, where she will supervise the ritual making of the gefilte fish, one of the centerpieces of the Seder feast.

headline: Nations’ Handling of New Climate Report Presages Divisions in Treaty Effort
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: Wrangling over wording of the summary of the latest U.N. climate report foreshadows worse to come in treaty talks.
lead_paragraph: Justin Gillis’s news story from Berlin on the latest report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change — the one on the world’s options for limiting global warming — tells you all you need to know about the familiar contents. The chart of trending news in the United States above tells you all you need to know about how much people are tuning in. (Click to learn more about how Newsmap works.)

headline: Bend It, Charge It, Dunk It: Graphene, the Material of Tomorrow
abstract: The material has the potential to change the electronics industry, and recently researchers have focused on how to produce it commercially.
lead_paragraph: I just want to say one word to you. Just one word.

headline: Coachella 2014: Day 2
abstract: The second day of this year’s music and arts festival in Indio, Calif., featured performances by Warpaint, Lorde and Pharrell Williams.
lead_paragraph: The second day of this year’s music and arts festival in Indio, Calif., featured performances by Warpaint, Lorde and Pharrell Williams.

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (MTV, Logo, VH1) 2014 MTV MOVIE AWARDS Conan O’Brien, above, hosts this ceremony, broadcast live from the Nokia Theater at L.A. Live, which bestows Golden Popcorn statuettes on winners in “best” categories like kiss, villain, fight and shirtless performance. Andrew Garfield, Emma Stone and Jamie Foxx will unveil a sneak peek of “The Amazing Spider-Man 2”; Ellen Page will introduce a clip from “X-Men Days of Future Past.” Presenters include Lupita Nyong’o, Jessica Alba, Chris Pratt, Seth Rogen, Seth MacFarlane, Mila Kunis, Shailene Woodley, Cameron Diaz, Leslie Mann, Kate Upton and Nicki Minaj. Mark Wahlberg will be honored with the annual MTV Generation Award. Eminem, Rihanna, Ellie Goulding, Zedd and Twenty One Pilots are scheduled to perform.

headline: Monday Rush Will Test Pulaski Skyway Shutdown
abstract: The shutdown, which began Saturday and is part of a reconstruction project, will affect roughly 40,000 vehicles daily in and around Jersey City and Newark, disrupting a key link to New York City.
lead_paragraph: The planned two-year shutdown of the northbound lanes on the Pulaski Skyway faces its first major test on Monday morning as thousands of drivers in New Jersey turn to alternative routes or public transportation for travel between Newark and Jersey City.

headline: An Artist Takes His Pay in Coffee and Community
abstract: David Ellis, whose other work often fetches tens of thousands of dollars, is giving back to his neighborhood by painting a large mural in a bodega in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: David Ellis is painting what could be his biggest commission ever — assuming he lives long enough, since he’s being paid in coffee and tobacco.

headline: A Letdown in London for a British Olympic Champion
abstract: The Olympic track medalist Mo Farah finished eighth in his first marathon, saying, “My legs were getting heavier and heavier and heavier.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — If it had gone in the storybook fashion that much of Britain willed, Mo Farah, a hero for winning the 5,000 and 10,000 meters at the 2012 London Olympics and the 2013 world championships, would have won on his marathon debut here Sunday.

headline: Slide Show: Scenes From Coachella
abstract: Photographs from the second day of the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in Indio, Calif.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from the second day of the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in Indio, Calif.

headline: Cartoon Birds Can’t Stop Captain America
abstract: “Captain America: The Winter Soldier” was No. 1 movie in North America for the second weekend in a row, taking in an estimated $41.4 million.
lead_paragraph: “Rio 2” got its wings a bit clipped at the weekend box office by a still-speeding superhero, while Kevin Costner was humiliated by a micro-budgeted horror flick. “Captain America: The Winter Soldier” (Walt Disney Studios) was the No. 1 movie in North America for the second weekend in a row, taking in an estimated $41.4 million, for a two-week domestic total of $159 million, according to Rentrak, which compiles ticketing data. “Rio 2” (20th Century Fox), an animated avian musical, was close behind with a solid $39 million, on par with the opening-weekend total for its series predecessor. But analysts and Fox, which backed “Rio 2” with a sizzling social media marketing campaign, had been predicting slightly higher totals. “Excellent weather across the middle of the country and the Northeast suppressed grosses in general yesterday and especially for matinees,” Chris Aronson, Fox’s president of domestic distribution, wrote in an email on Sunday morning. “Rio 2” has unusually light animated competition in the weeks ahead, Mr. Aronson noted.

headline: Liverpool Closes In on Championship That It Last Won 24 Years Ago
abstract: If Liverpool wins its four remaining games, it will claim the title of England’s top league for the first time since 1990.
lead_paragraph: LIVERPOOL, England — They sang “You’ll Never Walk Alone” and “We Shall Not Be Moved” and, over and over, “Liiiiiverpool.” The fans at Anfield seemed never to go quiet once the game began on Sunday, and soon, perhaps, they will sing about being champions.

headline: Pistorius Versus the Pit Bull: Fierce Prosecutor Shares Stage
abstract: Gerrie Nel, whose cross-examinations have earned him the nickname pit bull, has turned his judicial laser on Oscar Pistorius, who is charged in the murder of his girlfriend.
lead_paragraph: PRETORIA, South Africa — It was a corruption trial that had transfixed South Africa, and the prosecutor was in no mood for mercy. The defendant was the nation’s top police official, a figure of such international stature that he had once led Interpol. But when he took the stand, his testimony — his wife, he said, had accidentally shredded evidence — was rejected outright by his inquisitor.

headline: Fire Races Through Hills of Chilean Port City
abstract: The blaze started on Saturday and forced the evacuation of thousands of people from the steep, crowded hills above Valparaiso, Chile.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — A voracious fire that spread through the hills of the port city of Valparaíso left at least 12 people dead and more than 500 families homeless on Sunday, a day after it forced the evacuation of thousands of others.

headline: Diving Into the Strange, Retrieving Its Beauty
abstract: The pianist Jeremy Denk played an eclectic program of Mozart, Ligeti and Schumann at the Peoples’ Symphony Concerts series on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The pianist Jeremy Denk recently picked up the prestigious Avery Fisher Prize to go along with the MacArthur Foundation fellowship that he received last year. This is what you call being on a roll. These honors were in recognition not just of his excellence as a pianist but also of his adventurousness as an artist. Both qualities were on display on Saturday night, when Mr. Denk played a recital at Washington Irving High School, part of the very affordable Peoples’ Symphony Concerts series.

headline: Somber Army in Blue Gathers in Queens to Mourn a Fallen Officer
abstract: A wake was held for Dennis Guerra, 38, a married father of four who died last week after responding to a fire in a high-rise building.
lead_paragraph: They slipped hands into white gloves and shed blue caps, smoothed gold-buttoned uniforms and fell into a hush, one by one, as they joined the long line of police officers filing into the funeral home. Passing the flowers and the children dressed in black, they paused at the open coffin of their fellow officer, whose shield number — 5711 — glittered in gold from a badge-shaped wreath of white flowers.

headline: ECO 348, The Great Recession: Unemployment, Structural or Cyclical?
abstract: Slackers, quitters, and structuralists.
lead_paragraph: Slides here (pdf).

headline: The Kentucky Derby Dartboard: Week 3
abstract: Ranking the top contenders for the Kentucky Derby on May 3 after another weekend of major prep races.
lead_paragraph: Update: Constitution, the undefeated winner of the Florida Derby, will miss the Kentucky Derby and the other Triple Crown races because of a shin fracture, said Elliott Walden, president and chief executive of WinStar Farm. Also, the trainer Kiaran McLaughlin withdrew Cairo Prince from consideration because of an injury to his left front ankle.

headline: Ellsbury Batting Third for Yankees Without Fitting Profile
abstract: Jacoby Ellsbury has done well when third in the order — the spot of Ruth, Mantle, Mattingly and O’Neill — but he is known more for scoring runs than for driving them in.
lead_paragraph: Paul O’Neill. Don Mattingly. Mickey Mantle.

headline: Deadly Flames in Chile
abstract: A fire that swept through the hills of Valparaíso in Chile left at least 11 dead and charred homes and cars in its wake. President Michelle Bachelet called in troops to maintain order.
lead_paragraph: A fire that swept through the hills of Valparaíso in Chile left at least 11 dead and charred homes and cars in its wake. President Michelle Bachelet called in troops to maintain order.

headline: Surge in Narcotic Prescriptions for Pregnant Women
abstract: More pregnant women are being prescribed opioid painkillers, whose risks to fetuses are unknown, a move that surprises some doctors and researchers.
lead_paragraph: Doctors are prescribing opioid painkillers to pregnant women in astonishing numbers, new research shows, even though risks to the developing fetus are largely unknown.

headline: Visiting Another Country, No Longer Heard From
abstract: In “Red Love,” Maxim Leo describes how East Germany first inspired his grandparents, then disillusioned his parents, then left his own generation numb with despair.
lead_paragraph: A quarter-century has passed since the Berlin Wall came down and the German Democratic Republic disappeared. That’s more than half the life span of the East German state, a smoke-and-mirrors contraption conjured from the rubble of World War II that has become, for those who lived there, an increasingly distant and improbable memory.

headline: What a Foul Mouth You Have, Grandma
abstract: The Brits Off Broadway festival brings a double bill of “A Respectable Widow Takes to Vulgarity” and “Clean” to 59E59 Theaters.
lead_paragraph: The nervous young man has almost escaped from the funeral reception when the genteel widow thanks him for coming. It’s only decent to offer a kind word about her husband.

headline: A Showcase Highlights Newcomers’ Evolution
abstract: At E-Moves at Harlem Stage, new choreographers classified as “E-Merging” or “E-Volving” presented their works to the public.
lead_paragraph: For artists known as “emerging,” what determines when they’ve emerged? Experience? Recognition? Number of grant applications completed?

headline: Man Kills 3 at Jewish Centers in Kansas City Suburb
abstract: A man identified as a former Ku Klux Klan leader is accused of opening fire outside a Jewish community center and a nearby retirement community in Overland Park, Kan.
lead_paragraph: A man opened fire outside a Jewish Community Center and a nearby retirement community in a suburb of Kansas City, Mo., on Sunday afternoon, killing three people before he was taken into custody.

headline: Investigative Reporter Leaves NBC News
abstract: Michael Isikoff, whose work included coverage of the government’s war on terror and other national issues, said his departure was amicable.
lead_paragraph: Michael Isikoff, an investigative reporter who has broken numerous national news stories, has left NBC News. His last day was Friday.

headline: Fouéttes and Pirouettes to the Southern Banjo and Fiddle
abstract: The Carolina Chocolate Drops were joined by New York City Ballet dancers who presented the “Cornbread Duet,” five songs choreographed by Twyla Tharp.
lead_paragraph: “Tradition is a guide, not a jailer.” That quotation from W. Somerset Maugham is the motto of the Carolina Chocolate Drops, an African-American string band.

headline: A Feast With Some Unusual Pairings
abstract: The annual Youth America gala featured stars of many different dance companies in full and mixed program.
lead_paragraph: In the parlance of Youth America Grand Prix, a ballet convention and competition now in its 15th year, one purpose of its gala shows is for its young participants, the “stars of tomorrow,” to be inspired by “the stars of today,” the ballet luminaries who perform. The young dancers watching the closing night celebration at the David H. Koch Theater on Friday, an affair more than three hours long, could be inspired without being dispirited by flawlessness.

headline: Mussing Up a White-Linen-Tablecloth Vibe With Jazz Provocation
abstract: Jeff (Tain) Watts’s quartet opened Minton’s Redux, a new music series at Minton’s supper club in Harlem.
lead_paragraph: The standout tune in the early set at Minton’s in Harlem on Wednesday night was a new one, “Brainlifter,” composed by the drummer Jeff (Tain) Watts and briskly demolished by his four-piece band. Built over a gear-shifting groove, it was a maze full of trapdoors through which Mr. Watts and his crew barreled with aplomb. Only during a forcefully swinging tenor-saxophone solo by Troy Roberts did the action on the bandstand begin to feel like a developing story rather than an unassailably sturdy truth.

headline: On Shaky Ground
abstract: The 1989 earthquake that shook San Francisco sent out a wake-up call that continues to echo across the country.
lead_paragraph: The 1989 earthquake that shook San Francisco sent out a wake-up call that continues to echo across the country.

headline: Leading the Honor at the Imp Pairs in Dallas
abstract: Scott Levine and Aaron Silverstein of New York City entered the last session of the Lebhar Imp Pairs on March 22 in the lead at the Spring North American Championships.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Scott Levine and Aaron Silverstein of New York City entered the last session of the Lebhar Imp Pairs on March 22 in the lead at the Spring North American Championships here. In that session, though, their opponents held most of the cards and made few mistakes. Levine and Silverstein slipped to sixth.

headline: Awards for Jennifer Lopez and Norman Lear
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexual', 'Music', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: Ms. Lopez and Mr. Lear were among those honored at the 25th annual Glaad Media Awards presented on Saturday in Los Angeles by the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Lopez and Norman Lear were among those honored at the 25th annual Glaad Media Awards presented on Saturday in Los Angeles by the group formerly known as the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation. Ms. Lopez was given the Vanguard Award in recognition of her efforts to increase the visibility and understanding of gays, lesbians, bisexuals and the transgendered. She is also an executive producer on the ABC Family series “The Fosters,” which focuses on a lesbian couple and their children and was named outstanding drama series. Mr. Lear, who produced television series like “All in the Family” and “The Jeffersons” was the recipient of the Pioneer Award. The actress and transgender activist Laverne Cox received the Stephen F. Kolzak Award for her work in the Netflix series “Orange Is the New Black.” Other honorees included the Canadian pop duo Tegan and Sara for their album “Heartthrob”; the comic book series Young Avengers, by Kieron Gillen, Jamie McKelvie and Mike Norton from Marvel Comics; and Fuse’s reality series “Big Freedia: Queen of Bounce.” More awards are to be presented on May 3 at a ceremony in New York City.

headline: Choreographer Named to Montclair State Project
abstract: The choreographer Heidi Latsky has been selected as the first participant in a new short film series focusing on dance and choreography.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Heidi Latsky has been selected as the first participant in a new short film series focusing on dance and choreography. The project, Dance for Film on Location at Montclair State University, in New Jersey, will be underwritten by a $450,000 grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation and is to include three films by three different choreographers. The other two participants will be named later. Each work will be shown along with a live repertory that will become part of Peak Performances at Montclair State. In a statement, Jedediah Wheeler, the executive director of Peak Performances, said that the project is designed so that “the camera will not be used as a tool to document a performance, but rather as a collaborator to create a dance especially for film.”

headline: Another Vote for Colbert
abstract: Conan O’Brien has joined the choir of late night television hosts who have praised CBS’s decision to name Stephen Colbert as the successor to David Letterman on “Late Show.”
lead_paragraph: Conan O’Brien has joined the choir of late night television hosts who have praised CBS’s decision to name Stephen Colbert as the successor to David Letterman on “Late Show.” Mr. O’Brien told The Associated Press on Friday while backstage at a rehearsal for the MTV Movie Awards that Mr. Colbert is “fantastic,” and that he was looking forward to his work on “Late Show.” “I’m glad that it’s the right person getting it,” he said. Jimmy Fallon, the host of “The Tonight Show” on NBC, and Jimmy Kimmel, the host of his own show on ABC, had already voiced their approval of Mr. Colbert’s appointment. Mr. O’Brien, who hosted “The Tonight Show” for seven months before he was replaced by Jay Leno in 2010, denied any speculation that he had been a candidate for the “Late Show” appointment. “I wasn’t up for it,” Mr. O’Brien said and added that he was happy with his show, “Conan,” on TBS, which was renewed last year through November 2015. “I get to do what I want,” he said.

headline: Poised on the Cusp of Womanhood
abstract: LeeSaar the Company presented the New York premiere of “Princess Crocodile,” a dance about women making the leap from adolescence to womanhood.
lead_paragraph: Hyerin Lee, a dancer with LeeSaar the Company, is the first to appear onstage at the Baryshnikov Arts Center. Sitting on the floor with a knee bent in front of her torso, she gazes soulfully into a high corner of the space like a model whose motivation is to ponder the Dalai Lama. A spotlight, aimed at her, grows to fill the entire stage. While Stravinsky’s “Apollo” plays, she alternates between dreamy, beatific poses — touching her head, she angles her chin with razor precision — and self-inflicted thrashing. She smacks her ribs with her elbows.

headline: Promises of Preparedness Followed Devastating Earthquakes. And Yet.
abstract: Questions remain over whether vulnerable areas of California and the Pacific Northwest are adequately prepared for the Big One.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to imagine any people, collectively, being better prepared for earthquakes than the Japanese. Their country is one long seismic zone, which at any moment could, literally, rock and roll. Every Sept. 1, across the archipelago, Japanese engage in exercises devoted to disaster awareness: what to do should the worst happen. The occasion resonates with history. On that date in 1923, the Great Kanto earthquake devastated Tokyo and nearby Yokohama, unleashing fire and fury that left more than 100,000 people dead. After that, Japan resolved that it would prepare for whatever cataclysm nature might throw at it.

headline: Two Works That Challenge a Pianist to Go the Distance
abstract: Mitsuko Uchida played a Schubert sonata and Beethoven’s “Diabelli” variations at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: “It’s not a very good piece,” the gentleman sitting behind me at Carnegie Hall pronounced on Wednesday evening after Mitsuko Uchida had performed Schubert’s Piano Sonata in G (D. 894). From the same source, after Ms. Uchida had played the other work on the program, Beethoven’s 33 Variations on a Waltz by Diabelli (Op. 120), came the verdict, “That’s a great piece.”

headline: Bringing Shostakovich Off the Bench
abstract: A change in the Ensemble MidtVest lineup followed a change in its program at Merkin Concert Hall.
lead_paragraph: When David Samuel, the violist of the Ensemble MidtVest, took ill just a few hours before the group’s performance on Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, his colleagues scrambled to replace him. They found a willing musician, Gregory Luce, but they simply didn’t have time to rehearse with a newbie the two planned works with viola.

headline: Death Knell for Opera in San Diego After 49 Years
abstract: Barring a last-minute reprieve, the San Diego Opera was scheduled to close on Sunday after the final performance of Massenet’s “Don Quixote.”
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Molly Whittaker is a chorus member with the San Diego Opera, where she has performed for almost 10 years. But the other evening she could be found outside the opera hall, wearing a bright red T-shirt reading “Fight for San Diego Opera,” and thrusting pamphlets and stickers at patrons as they arrived for a performance of Massenet’s “Don Quixote.”

headline: Maestro Stands In, Despite Protests
abstract: Valery Gergiev substituted for Lorin Maazel at Carnegie Hall on Friday, despite the presence of people outside opposed to his friendship with Vladimir V. Putin.
lead_paragraph: The two programs of the Munich Philharmonic Orchestra at Carnegie Hall over the weekend, in their ambition, their grandiosity and their striving for effect, spoke eloquently of the musical personality of their planner, Lorin Maazel, the ensemble’s music director since 2012. It was Munich’s favorite son, Richard Strauss, all the way, on the 150th anniversary of his birth, with a grandiloquent work on each program: “Also Sprach Zarathustra” on Friday evening and “Ein Heldenleben” on Saturday.

headline: A Playwright Seeks Healing With His Work
abstract: Marcus Gardley’s play “The Box: A Black Comedy” examines black men in prison and the justice system that puts them there.
lead_paragraph: Marcus Gardley had been rewriting through the night. The next morning, it was time for a pep talk to the five actors in a scruffy rehearsal space who were clutching Draft 18 of “The Box: A Black Comedy,” his satire about black men and prisons both literal and metaphorical.

headline: Pacers Can Still Be No. 1, Even After Floundering
abstract: The Pacers, coming off a blowout by Miami, produced a balanced effort to beat the Oklahoma City Thunder and can secure the Eastern Conference’s top seed with another win or a Heat loss.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Sunday was Fan Appreciation Day at Bankers Life Fieldhouse, and before the Pacers took on the Oklahoma City Thunder, several Indiana players addressed the crowd, thanking fans for their support this season and imploring them to be loud during the game.

headline: Famous Debate Words
abstract: A lesson from Gareth Bain.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — I believe I could safely wager that crossword puzzle solvers are probably the most pedantic when it comes to spelling errors. I know this because all I have to do is make a typo in this space, and there are many sharp-eyed readers who are, shall we say, willing to help me find it. And that’s totally fine, really. If ever there should be a place where words are spelled correctly, it should be a blog about the crossword puzzle.

headline: The Precarious Foundation of a Dream House
abstract: In Richard Maxwell’s “Isolde,” plans by a contractor and an actress to build the perfect vacation home become complicated by a love triangle as primal instincts rise to the surface.
lead_paragraph: Richard Maxwell looks at the world with X-ray eyes. Watching the plays of this rigorously inventive auteur, we are encouraged to see the plasterboard behind the wallpaper, the skin under the greasepaint and the skulls beneath the skin. Or in the case of “Isolde,” his smashing new work at the Abrons Arts Center, the beams and blueprints — and light and air — that go into the imagining of something as substantial and transitory as a dream house. Or, come to think of it, a play.

headline: More Higher-Priced Deals
abstract: Companies are staying private longer and investors are eager to write big checks. As a result, enormous venture capital rounds are becoming common.
lead_paragraph: Companies are staying private longer and investors are eager to write big checks. As a result, enormous venture capital rounds are becoming common.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 60
abstract: Football Manager 14 predicts the results of this summer’s World Cup based on its database.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Treasury Auctions for the Week of April 14
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Income Tax', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The following tax-exempt, fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday and an auction of five-year inflation-protected securities on Thursday.

headline: Suicide Prevention Sheds a Longstanding Taboo: Talking About Attempts
keywords: ['Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: For decades, mental health organizations have featured speakers with various disorders. But until now, discussing suicide attempts has been virtually off limits.
lead_paragraph: The relationship had become intolerably abusive, and after a stinging phone call one night, it seemed there was only one way to end the pain. Enough wine and pills should do the job — and would have, except that paramedics barged through the door, alerted by her lover.

headline: For Grown-Up Watson, the Jacket Still Fits
abstract: Bubba Watson, who has focused on improving as a person as well as a golfer, shot a three-under 69 to hold off Jordan Spieth and win the Masters for a second time.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — A few hours before he went out to try to win a second green jacket, Bubba Watson conducted a Masters trivia contest Sunday for his million-plus Twitter followers. The game helped unclutter Watson’s mind and clarify his purpose. One of the questions asked how many of the last 23 champions had come from the final pairing.

headline: Shots Fired in Kramatorsk
abstract: Men dressed in camouflage and armed with assault rifles fired on the Police Headquarters in Kramatorsk, Ukraine, on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Men dressed in camouflage and armed with assault rifles fired on the Police Headquarters in Kramatorsk, Ukraine, on Saturday.

headline: An Institution Exploring the Political Left Is Closing
abstract: The Brecht Forum, which began in 1975 as the New York Marxist School, announced that it could not survive the economic climate and the real estate market.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 40 years the Brecht Forum has held classes, lectures, symposiums, musical performances and art exhibitions, all organized around the aim of examining the role of the political left in American society.

headline: Elections in India
abstract: But many of the faces remain the same.
lead_paragraph: But many of the faces remain the same.

headline: Big Banks’ Earnings Reports, and E.U. to Act on Bank Laws
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Company Reports', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Citigroup, Bank of America, Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs will report earnings, and the E.U. is expected to pass laws aimed at reducing nations’ vulnerability to the problems of their big banks.
lead_paragraph: MORE BANKS TO REPORT FIRST-QUARTER EARNINGS

headline: My Ideas, My Boss’s Property
keywords: ['Intellectual Property', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Corporations', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Science and Technology', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Workers are being forced to sign over their ideas to their employers.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — THE big story in Silicon Valley these days is a class-action lawsuit alleging that several major tech companies, including Google and Apple, agreed not to try to hire away one another’s employees — thereby hindering workers from seeking out better-paying jobs.

headline: Secret Drugs, Agonizing Deaths
abstract: Prison officials are hindering public debate about lethal injections.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — FACING a critical shortage of lethal injection drugs, prison officials in a number of states have recently engaged in an unseemly scramble to obtain new execution drugs, often from unreliable and even illegal sources. Not only does this trend raise serious questions about the constitutionality of executions, it also undermines the foundations of our democratic process. In the name of security, states are now withholding vital information about their death penalty procedures — from death row prisoners’ lawyers and from judges, whose stamp of approval they need to impose the ultimate sanction, as well as from the public, in whose name the sentence is carried out.

headline: Surviving the Finish Line
abstract: Runners, spectators and volunteers who were at the finish line of the Boston Marathon when the bombs exploded reflect on how their lives have been affected. Here are their stories of transformation.
lead_paragraph: Runners, spectators and volunteers who were at the finish line of the Boston Marathon when the bombs exploded reflect on how their lives have been affected. Here are their stories of transformation.

In addition, the violation, what the authorities said was a sexual assault, occurred in 2009, when the kicker was a freshman, and his punishment was not determined until his athletic career had ended this past winter.

lead_paragraph: I.

headline: Bruins Coach Eschews Negativity and Builds Winners
abstract: After Claude Julien was abruptly fired by the Devils in 2007, he wondered whether he would ever get another chance in the N.H.L. Now, he leads the league’s top team into the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — On the first Monday of April 2007, the Devils had a 47-24-8 record. They were in first place in the Atlantic Division with the second-best record in the Eastern Conference. They had won four of their past five games and appeared well positioned for a deep playoff run.

headline: In New York, Hard Choices on Health Exchange Spell Success
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: More than 900,000 residents signed up for health plans, and premiums have dropped, though the state limited consumers’ choices.
lead_paragraph: In contrast with the early stumbles in most of the country, New York State, almost from the start, has provided a textbook lesson in how to make the Affordable Care Act work. But it has done so by making some tough decisions.

headline: Sanctions Are Eased; Iran Sees Little Relief
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Analysts say foreign business interest in Iran has remained extremely limited amid a temporary deal allowing increased economic ties.
lead_paragraph: Halfway through a six-month nuclear deal between Iran and major world powers that was meant to allow time to reach a comprehensive agreement, the Iranians have seen little in the way of a boost from the sanctions relief they had been expecting, trade lawyers and diplomatic analysts say.

headline: 3 Straight Homers Set Off Angels’ Rout
abstract: Starter Bartolo Colon gave up home runs to Mike Trout, Albert Pujols and Raul Ibanez in the first inning, as Los Angeles collected eight extra-base hits and nine runs in five innings off him.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Mets starter Bartolo Colon adjusted his cap, fiddled with his belt and kicked the dirt as the Los Angeles Angels’ Raul Ibanez rounded the bases. The fans at Angel Stadium were on their feet, cheering. In a stretch of seven pitches in the bottom of the first inning on Sunday, three Angels connected for solo home runs: Mike Trout, Albert Pujols and Ibanez.

headline: Obama Effect Inspiring Few to Seek Office
keywords: ['Elections, State Legislature', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Volunteers and Community Service']
abstract: A State Senate candidate in Massachusetts is one of President Obama’s few former aides who is running for office; far more have joined the ranks of high-paid consultants.
lead_paragraph: LUDLOW, Mass. — Eric Lesser was shaking hands with diners in a Portuguese restaurant last week when he spotted the owner of Manny’s TV & Appliances. “Oh, I’ve got to get a picture,” Mr. Lesser eagerly said, draping his arm over Manny Rovithis, whose low-budget commercials have run for decades in Western Massachusetts. Mr. Lesser’s giddiness about meeting the local celebrity had not faded when he sat down for lunch.

headline: The Poetry of the Trading Floor, Going Beyond Bears and Bulls
abstract: Popular opinion has it that bankers think of nothing but profit, but their brains are fixated on linguistic creativity.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Finance is such a picturesque business, but nobody seems to notice.

headline: Three Expensive Milliseconds
keywords: ['High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'United States Economy', 'Trans-Hudson Passenger Rail Tunnel (ARC Tunnel)']
abstract: We’re giving huge sums to the financial industry while receiving little or nothing in return.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago Chris Christie, the governor of New Jersey, abruptly canceled America’s biggest and arguably most important infrastructure project, a desperately needed new rail tunnel under the Hudson River. Count me among those who blame his presidential ambitions, and believe that he was trying to curry favor with the government- and public-transit-hating Republican base.

headline: Tightness in Jeter’s Leg Keeps Him Out for Second Game in a Row
abstract: Yankees Manager Joe Girardi said Derek Jeter experienced tightness in his right quadriceps against Boston on Friday, so he was giving Jeter three days off as a precaution.
lead_paragraph: Derek Jeter was held out of Sunday’s lineup for a second straight day after Manager Joe Girardi revealed that Jeter experienced tightness in his right quadriceps during the Yankees’ 4-2 loss to the Red Sox on Friday.

headline: Yahoo Rolls the Dice on TV
abstract: Winning in the distribution of high-end content is about mining an audience, and you can’t blame technology companies for believing they have relevant skill sets.
lead_paragraph: Yahoo, a company that seems like a permanent adolescent in search of an identity, is about to try a new persona: high-quality television programmer.

headline: Win No. 688 May Be Brodeur’s Last as a Devil
abstract: Martin Brodeur, the longtime face of the franchise, will become an unrestricted free agent in July.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Amid a sea of fans wearing red and black plus a smattering of old-school Devils green, goaltender Martin Brodeur played perhaps his final game for the franchise, a 3-2 victory Sunday against the Bruins.

headline: Beaming Good Cheer to a Norwegian Town’s Dark Days
abstract: Three giant mirrors on a mountain reflect sunlight onto a small Norwegian town that gets very little of it in the winter. But not everyone is happy with the project.
lead_paragraph: RJUKAN, Norway — Yearning for sunlight has been a part of life in this quaint old factory town in central Norway for as long as anyone can remember. Here, the sun disappears behind a mountain for six months of the year.

headline: The College Faculty Crisis
keywords: ['Community Colleges', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Editorials', 'Part-Time Employment']
abstract: Community colleges have to do a better job of screening the part-time instructors they hire, because they far outnumber full-time faculty members.
lead_paragraph: The public colleges and universities that educate more than 70 percent of this country’s students were burdened by rising costs and dwindling state revenues long before the recession. They reacted by raising tuition, slashing course offerings and, sometimes, by cutting enrollment.

headline: Rich Start-Ups Go Back for Another Helping
abstract: As investment money continues to pour into Silicon Valley, start-ups already flush with cash are being given sizable additional rounds of venture capital.
lead_paragraph: Quora, a question-and-answer website, didn’t need to raise money. It had barely touched $60 million in venture capital that it accepted just two years ago.

headline: A Gossipy Newsletter Aims Higher
keywords: ['Newsletters', 'Celebrities', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Magazines', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The weekly email Popbitch has used a business model others are now catching up to, but it has entered new waters with an iPad magazine for $2.99 an issue.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Every Thursday the Popbitch newsletter, written in a typewriter font redolent of the early Internet, lands in the inboxes of hundreds of thousands people in Britain and around the world.

headline: Seeking a Plan to Rein In the Floodwaters Through the South Mountain Reservation
abstract: A massive dam, which is among several proposals to mitigate flooding of nearby towns, would submerge up to 110 acres during major rainstorms.
lead_paragraph: MILLBURN, N.J. — Striding through the South Mountain Reservation, a patch of wilderness in an otherwise highly developed corner of New Jersey, Fred R. Profeta Jr. does not see the stands of oaks and maples or the shimmering streams so much as their absence.

headline: Keep the Carriage Horses
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio vowed to abolish carriage rides in Midtown. That is one campaign promise he would do better to break.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio noted his 100th day in office last week with a big speech and a proud recitation of campaign promises kept: universal prekindergarten, an end to unconstitutional policing, paid sick leave, among other things. There is one prominent pledge he would do better to break.

headline: A Year After the Boston Marathon Bombings, Injured Brothers Endure
abstract: J. P. and Paul Norden each lost a leg in the Boston Marathon bombings one year ago, but they do not want to be defined by a single moment of violence.
lead_paragraph: STONEHAM, Mass. — When two bombs transformed last year’s Boston Marathon into a war zone, the Norden family absorbed a double dose of grief. J. P., 34, and his brother Paul, 32, both strapping construction workers in their prime who were there to cheer on a friend, each lost a leg in the carnage.

headline: Echoes of the Superpredator
abstract: Many states continue to punish juveniles as harshly as they can despite evidence that doing so actually increases recidivism.
lead_paragraph: Remember “superpredators”? Nearly 20 years ago, they prowled into the American consciousness — a menacing new breed of children, born of crack-addled mothers and absent fathers, and programmed solely for murder and mayhem.

headline: Stepping Into the Shoes of a Ravaged Singer
abstract: “Lady Day at Emerson’s Bar and Grill,” starring Audra McDonald, takes place in the months before Billie Holiday died, set in a city that she had reason to loathe.
lead_paragraph: When Billie Holiday sang, history attests, her audiences tended to clam up. Even in the bustling nightclubs where she mostly performed, Holiday often insisted on total quiet before she would open her mouth. The quiet usually held, as one of the great singers of the last century turned jazz songs and standards into searching, and searing, portraits of life and love gone wrong that cast a shimmering spell.

He was 59.

abstract: Viewers watched on-demand television programming an average of 8.7 hours a month in 2013, according to Rentrak. Free broadcast and cable TV shows accounted for 6.4 of those hours. Most viewers, 66 percent, watched a show at least four days after it was originally broadcast.
lead_paragraph: Viewers watched on-demand television programming an average of 8.7 hours a month in 2013, according to Rentrak. Free broadcast and cable TV shows accounted for 6.4 of those hours. Most viewers, 66 percent, watched a show at least four days after it was originally broadcast.

headline: In Monte Carlo, the First All-Organic Restaurant to Receive a Michelin Star
abstract: Elsa, at the Monte Carlo Beach Hotel, serves healthful haute cuisine in an inspired seaside setting.
lead_paragraph: In Monaco, carrots just might be the new caviar. “For me, luxury is eating baby peas that were picked an hour earlier or maybe a carrot that was just pulled out of the ground,” says the chef Paolo Sari, whose cooking at Elsa — a sunny restaurant at the suavely bohemian, India Mahdavi-designed Monte Carlo Beach Hotel — recently won him the first Michelin star ever awarded to a 100 percent organic establishment.

headline: Opportunity for All and Social Innovation: Obama’s Policy Agenda
abstract: The federal government is trying to involve private investors in programs that seek to solve societal problems, an economist and a White House official write.
lead_paragraph: Laura D’Andrea Tyson is a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley, and headed the Council of Economic Advisers and the National Economic Council under President Bill Clinton. Jonathan Greenblatt is a special assistant to President Obama and director of the Office of Social Innovation and Civic Participation at the White House.

headline: A Number That May Not Add Up
abstract: As a measure of overweight, obesity and health, the body mass index has plenty of drawbacks, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: In July 1998, the National Institutes of Health changed what it means to be overweight, defining it as a body mass index of 25 or greater for adults. The cutoff had been 28 for men and 27 for women, so suddenly about 29 million Americans who had been considered normal became overweight even though they hadn’t gained an ounce.

headline: A Chance for Retro Reinvention
abstract: Neve Campbell is among the latest additions to an unlikely roster of veteran television stars who have found recurring roles on “Mad Men,” reinventing themselves in period clothing and hairstyles.
lead_paragraph: For the “Mad Men” protagonist, Don Draper, the melancholy if alluring young widow he met on a plane ride in Sunday’s season premiere could be just a passing flirtation or perhaps a new flame who will share in his extramarital escapades.

headline: Yankees Find Another First Baseman in a Pinch, Then Beat Boston
abstract: Carlos Beltran made his career debut at first base Sunday night and recorded three hits, including a two-run home run, to help the Yankees to a 3-2 win.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees signed Carlos Beltran this off-season to help bolster their offense. On Sunday night, the Yankees also needed Beltran to help save their infield defense. Beltran made his career debut at first base after several injuries had left Manager Joe Girardi with a ravaged roster.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (13) THE TRIALS OF MUHAMMAD ALI (2013) In 1967 — after changing his name from Cassius Clay, joining the Nation of Islam and refusing to be inducted into the United States military because of his religious opposition to the Vietnam War — Muhammad Ali, above, was convicted of draft evasion. Stripped of his world heavyweight championship and banned from boxing, he spent the next four years fighting legal battles. In 1971, his case for being a conscientious objector reached the United States Supreme Court. In this “Independent Lens” presentation, the director Bill Siegel combines interviews with Louis Farrakhan; Mr. Ali’s second wife, Khalilah Camacho-Ali; the journalist Robert Lipsyte; Mr. Ali’s loyal brother, Rahman; and a clerk from the Supreme Court proceedings to address Mr. Ali’s challenges then and now, including his battle with Parkinson’s. “The film falls short of explaining Mr. Ali, who, like many outspoken individuals, can stubbornly repel scrutiny, nor will it pacify the many who opposed his conscientious objections,” Nicolas Rapold wrote in The New York Times. “But it also underlines one enduring quality: namely, that he probably couldn’t care less what people think.”

headline: Despite Frustrating Week, McIlroy Meets His Diminished Goal
abstract: Rory McIlroy, who shifted his expectations after a second-round 77 at the Masters, finished tied for eighth, his best showing at Augusta National.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — At the start of the week, nothing short of a Masters victory would do for Rory McIlroy, the former world No. 1 from Northern Ireland. After a five-over-par 77 in the second round, he revised his goals, lowering the bar to try to clear the top 15. That would beat his career best here, a tie for 15th in 2011, when McIlroy entered the final round with the lead.

abstract: Officials said that after six days with no new possible black-box signals, it was time to take the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 underwater.
