headline: Last Night to Bend the Rules
abstract: Dina Litovsky has been photographing bachelorette parties, where brides-to-be confront the tricky rituals of the last night of single life.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the secret world of the bachelorette party. For you first-timers, please, don’t be alarmed. There is a set of rituals that transpire throughout the evening, starting with ensuring that you have relinquished any responsibilities that may distract you from having fun: check. Getting yourself pampered and dressed up more provocatively than for the average night out: check. And most important, figuring out how to get the bride-to-be to enjoy her final moments of being an unmarried woman.

headline: After Delays, Syria Completes Another Shipment of Chemical Arms
abstract: The chemical weapons watchdog said that Syria had sent nearly two-thirds of its arsenal for destruction, but that it was uncertain if it would meet its deadline.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — After lengthy delays in loading its chemical weapons for destruction abroad, Syria has completed delivery of another shipment that brings the total to almost two-thirds of its arsenal, the international watchdog overseeing the process reported on Monday.

headline: Ardian to Sell Food Ingredients Maker to Symrise for $1.8 Billion
abstract: Symrise, a German maker of flavors and scents, said it had made a binding offer to acquire Diana from the private equity firm Ardian, which was spun off from the French insurer AXA Group last year.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Symrise of Germany has offered to buy the Diana Group, a maker of food ingredients, from the private equity firm Ardian for 1.3 billion euros, or about $1.8 billion.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: What you need to know to start your Monday: Pistorius cross-examined, an Ohio same-sex marriage ruling, and a total lunar eclipse.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: New York Today: Casting a Warm Spell
abstract: What you need to know for Monday: one more nice day before the rain comes, a new roller rink, and fireworks will return to the East River.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this warm, breezy Monday.

headline: Arrest Order for Fugitive Hong Kong Tycoon Reaffirmed
abstract: A Hong Kong judge has upheld the arrest warrant for the newspaper tycoon Ma Sik-chun, who fled to Taiwan 36 years ago after being charged with drug trafficking.
lead_paragraph: A Hong Kong judge declined on Monday to set aside an arrest warrant for a local newspaper tycoon who fled to Taiwan 36 years ago after being charged with drug trafficking.

headline: Ukraine Falters in Drive to Curb Unrest in East
abstract: Ukraine’s failure to enforce its own ultimatums and its appeal to the United Nations to send peacekeepers laid bare a grim reality for the shaky government in Kiev.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Ukraine’s failure to enforce its own ultimatums and its appeal on Monday to the United Nations to send peacekeepers laid bare a grim reality for the shaky government in Kiev, where political leaders and security forces have few reliable ways to confront Russian-backed separatists in the restive east.

headline: Huge New York Development Project Becomes a Data Science Lab
abstract: The developers of the Hudson Yards on Manhattan’s West Side are forming a partnership with the researchers at N.Y.U.’s Center for Urban Science and Progress to create a “quantified community” that uses data science to study and improve the urban environment.
lead_paragraph: Hudson Yards is a huge estate development project, the largest in New York since Rockefeller Center. It is to include office towers, apartments, shops, a luxury hotel, a public school and acres of public space. Construction began at the end of 2012, and has picked up recently.

headline: What I Learned About Business as a South Georgia Bottom Fisher
abstract: Do you know your business? Do you have resident knowledge of the ins and outs of the business that others don’t have? The answers to those questions are among the strongest indicators of future success.
lead_paragraph: When I tell people the first business lesson I ever learned was with Louisiana Pinks, they often think I was in the nail polish or lipstick businesses, or maybe rose bushes. Sorry, not at the age of 15 living in rural southern Georgia. I was in none of those businesses. I was selling worms.

headline: Looking Back at the Publishing Beat With Julie Bosman
abstract: Julie Bosman is soon to become one of The Times’s new Midwest correspondents. Before she does, she reflected on her time as the publishing reporter.
lead_paragraph: Julie Bosman recently wrote about the declining number of bookstores in New York City. Before she decamps to Chicago to become one of our Midwest correspondents, we asked her to reflect on the state of the publishing industry and share some of her reading habits.

headline: City Says Water Meets Safety Standards, But Residents Remain Cautious
abstract: Officials in the northwestern Chinese city of Lanzhou have declared that a faulty pipeline was repaired and that the water supply now meets safety standards.
lead_paragraph: Officials in the northwestern Chinese city of Lanzhou have declared that a faulty pipeline was repaired and that the water supply now meets safety standards, days after tests showed levels of a cancer-causing chemical more than 20 times national safety limits.

headline: Silicon Valley’s Funding Feast
abstract: Already-rich start-ups are piling on investment dollars. | Earnings season for big banks has begun. | Pooled pensions teeter and fall. | Herbalife shares plunge on news of F.B.I. criminal inquiry.
lead_paragraph: There can never be too much money in the bank. Such appears to be the thinking behind a new dynamic that is reshaping Silicon Valley. Start-ups, already flush with cash, are piling on investment dollars, David Gelles and Michael J. de la Merced write in DealBook. Of the 100 largest venture capital fund-raising rounds on record, 88 were issued within the last five years, according to CrunchBase, which tracks venture funding. Each delivered more than $50 million to the companies.

lead_paragraph: Season 7, Episode 1

headline: The Pampered Passenger
abstract: On-the-go grooming is in high demand at airports around world, and airlines are trying to add amenities after takeoff.
lead_paragraph: Spending a night in an airplane cabin is hardly the path to a luminous complexion and tidy hair. At 30,000 feet, your skin is more likely to resemble a lizard’s. But there are ways for business executives to look and feel polished when walking off a plane and into a boardroom.

lead_paragraph: Investors and analysts feared the worst from Citigroup, the global bank that has been besieged for months by regulatory problems and an industrywide trading slump.

headline: Obamacare, The Unknown Ideal, Continued
abstract: It’s not just the Fox-watchers who don’t know what’s happening.
lead_paragraph: The current state of public opinion on health reform is really peculiar. If you’ve been following the issue at all closely, you know that the Affordable Care Act is one of the great comeback stories of public policy: after a terrible start, it has dramatically exceeded expectations. But hardly anyone seems to know that.

headline: Lessons for the Largest Democracy From a Much Smaller One
abstract: The author says a message of peace from Oscar Arias, the former president of Costa Rica, offered some ideas that resonate during India’s election season.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI – A couple of weeks ago, I thought of Tony, a burly, cheerful, Costa Rican who drove a friend and me in his Toyota south along the highway from the Tortuguero National Park to the border with Panama. In fluent if ungrammatical English he told us he was taking us somewhere that would tell us more about his country, one of the longest-running democracies in Central America.

lead_paragraph: David Gelles and Michael J. de la Merced report that across Silicon Valley, start-ups, already flush with cash, are piling on the investment dollars.

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Personal Finances']

lead_paragraph: The large retirement investment firm TIAA-CREF said on Monday that it had agreed to buy Nuveen Investments, an investment management firm, for about $6.25 billion, to become one of the country’s top money managers.

headline: Possible Banksy Mural About Surveillance Pops Up in Britain
abstract: Banksy, the elusive graffiti artist, who is known for political messages, is believed to be behind the artwork in Cheltenham, England, where one of Britain’s intelligence agencies has its headquarters.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A mural depicting secret agents eavesdropping on a telephone booth, thought to be the work of the elusive graffiti artist Banksy, has appeared in the city of Cheltenham, where one of Britain’s intelligence agencies has its headquarters.

lead_paragraph: Glide down the Mekong River and traverse tumbling waterfalls.

headline: Under Cover: In Pursuit of an Unearthly Record
abstract: Chris King, the owner of the record, “Last Kind Word Blues” by Geeshie Wiley, featured on this week’s cover, talks about how he acquired the rare record.
lead_paragraph: What inspires a music collector to search high and low and pay large sums of money to acquire one record? Obsessiveness, says Chris King, who owns the record “Last Kind Word Blues,” by Geeshie Wiley, that appears on this week’s cover.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: John Jeremiah Sullivan on the Search for Geeshie and Elvie
abstract: An interview with John Jeremiah Sullivan, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story on the search for the two women behind a legendary 1930s blues record.
lead_paragraph: John Jeremiah Sullivan, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story about searching for the two women behind a legendary 1930s blues record. He is the author of “Pulphead.”

abstract: Endurance Specialty Holdings, a provider of casualty and property insurance, made an unsolicited $3.2 billion takeover bid for Aspen Insurance Holdings.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 2:31 p.m. |

headline: Suvir Saran’s Guacamole With Toasted Cumin
keywords: ['Avocados', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Recipes', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: A chunky guacamole that shows how Indian and Mexican flavors overlap.
lead_paragraph: The chef Suvir Saran says that “avocados make people happy,” and he’s right. He adds toasted cumin seeds, which he refers to as “Indian bacon bits,” to his chunky guacamole. This guacamole has all the flavors of a Mexican guacamole – illustrating yet again how Indian, Middle Eastern, Mediterranean and Mexican cuisines overlap. In fact, the ingredients here are identical to those that I have always used in my guacamole; but this recipe has the added delight of texture, as the ingredients aren’t mashed up.

headline: Chilean Cabbage and Avocado Slaw
abstract: This is a simple yet addictive mix of salted cabbage and puréed avocado.
lead_paragraph: Coleslaw meets guacamole here in this utterly simple mix of shredded cabbage, salt, lemon, and puréed avocado. The chef Iliana de la Vega, who was born in Oaxaca, Mexico, served it at a delicious Latin-themed lunch she prepared at the “Healthy Kitchens, Healthy Lives” conference this year at the Culinary Institute of America in Napa Valley. I couldn’t get enough of it. I sat with Iliana at the lunch and asked her about the salad. “Just salt the cabbage, let it sit for a while, then add lots of lemon juice and the mashed avocado,” she said. That really is all there is to it. Shred the cabbage thin and for best results let it sit, after salting generously, for an hour or more, to tenderize it and draw out strong-tasting juices.

headline: Roasted Tomatillo-Poblano-Avocado Salsa
keywords: ['Avocados', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Recipes', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: A salsa with a balance of char, heat, acid and creamy, based on a recipe by Kim Sunée.
lead_paragraph: One of my favorite new cookbooks of this season is “A Mouthful of Stars” (Andrews McMeel), by Kim Sunée. The book is a memoir, travelogue and cookbook all rolled into one, written by an author who earlier published another compelling memoir with recipes,“Trail of Crumbs.” Kim is a poetic world traveler who loves many cuisines. She is a big fan of taco trucks and loves salsa, the spicier the better. This salsa is based on her recipe for roasted tomatillo-poblano salsa. I love its balance of char, heat, acid and creamy. I’m a moderate when it comes to heat, but you can make this hotter by adding more chiles.

headline: Chunky Avocado-Papaya Salsa
keywords: ['Avocados', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Recipes', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: This salsa is closer to a salad, with a fusion of Thai and Mexican flavors.
lead_paragraph: This is based on a recipe in Kim Sunée’s wonderful new book, “A Mouthful of Stars” (Andrews McMeel). Her recipe is more of a salad, a fusion of Thai and Mexican flavors. I loved the idea of combining avocado and papaya, two subtle, creamy fruits, with crunchy, bright-tasting Asian pears and spicy chiles. The first time I saw the recipe I wanted to test it right away, but I didn’t have Asian pears. So I used an apple, and loved it. It’s the sweet, crunchy fruit that does the trick, and apples and Asian pears both work. There are onions in the original recipe but I’ve made them optional.

headline: Avocado and Roasted Tomatillo Salsa
keywords: ['Avocados', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Recipes', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Roasting the tomatillos produces a salsa with a deliciously charred flavor.
lead_paragraph: I have been making tomatillo and avocado salsa for years, but I usually simmer the tomatillos rather than roasting them. Roasting the tomatillos, chiles and garlic – toasting really, as I use a skillet for this, on top of the flame – produces a salsa with a delicious charred flavor. I learned something recently from the chef Iliana de la Vega, who demonstrated the recipe at the “Healthy Kitchens, Healthy Lives” conference in Napa Valley in March: she says, in no uncertain terms, that you should not add water to tomatillo salsas. Without the water, this is a more intense salsa with pleasing density. You can use it as a sauce to serve with chicken or fish, or as a dip with chips or other vegetables.

headline: U.N. Leaders Discuss Ukraine Crisis
abstract: The American, Russian and Ukrainian ambassadors to the United Nations discussed the escalating crisis in Ukraine at a Security Council emergency meeting on Sunday night.
lead_paragraph: The American, Russian and Ukrainian ambassadors to the United Nations discussed the escalating crisis in Ukraine at a Security Council emergency meeting on Sunday night.

headline: Nigeria Blast Kills Dozens as Militants Hit Capital
abstract: A bombing that killed at least 71 people in the capital may indicate that the extremist group Boko Haram is stepping up efforts to destabilize state institutions.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — Militants struck near the heart of the Nigerian state early Monday, bombing a bus station in the capital, Abuja, just miles from the seat of government in one of the worst attacks in years in the country’s struggle with insurgents.

headline: Investors Trying to Beat the System Invariably Are Disappointed
abstract: The more the risk, the better the reward. Changing the nature of a stock, a bond or cash is ultimately fruitless, a financial planner writes.
lead_paragraph: Let’s start with a parable.

keywords: ['Automobiles', 'New York International Auto Show', 'Javits, Jacob K, Convention Center (NYC)']
abstract: The New York International Auto Show, which starts two days of press previews on Wednesday, promises dozens of new and updated models.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 New York International Auto Show is billed, rightly so, as a showcase for dozens of new and significantly changed automobiles. But more than that, it is also a showcase for the quickening pace of change in the auto industry.

headline: Moving Water to Birds, Painkillers During Pregnancy, To Love and Hate Bugs
abstract:
A new program is using crowdsourced data to select rice fields for bird rest stops; the numbers of women who take opioid drugs for pain during pregnancy is rising, but what are the risks?; a new book looks into the philias and phobias surrounding insects.
Subscribe to the Podcast »

headline: ‘Book of Mormon’ Wins Big at Olivier Awards
abstract: The Broadway hit “The Book of Mormon” won four awards, including best new musical, at the Olivier Awards, London’s equivalent of the Tonys.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway hit “The Book of Mormon” dominated the Tony Awards in 2011, winning nine (including for best musical), and on Sunday night the show was a powerhouse at the Olivier Awards, London’s equivalent of the Tonys. The West End production of “Mormon,” which opened there last year, won for best new musical, best actor (Gavin Creel as Elder Price), best supporting actor (Stephen Ashfield as Elder McKinley), and best choreography (Casey Nicholaw).

headline: Twitter’s Biggest Shareholders Say They Won’t Sell Stock
abstract: Top officers and directors of the social network, as well as its largest outside shareholder, say they will hang on to their shares when they get their first chance to sell in May. That could prop up the stock, which is trading at half its record high, set in December. The post also used an older name for the Benchmark venture capital firm. The firm, long known as Benchmark Capital, changed its name to Benchmark in 2012.
lead_paragraph: Updated | Added comment from JP Morgan Asset Management and updated the total amount of stock owned by shareholders that say they won’t sell.

headline: In China, a Big Jet Becomes a Status Symbol
abstract: Among China’s business elite, bigger appears to be better, as sales of corporate jets are rising despite a dearth of airports to handle private flights.
lead_paragraph: IN the United States, public reaction to the corporate use of business jets can be scathing when instances of obvious excess become publicized, such as the day in 2008 when the top executives of the Detroit automakers each used a private jet to fly to Washington to argue for $25 billion in taxpayer bailouts.

headline: When Not to Speak Your Second Language to Your Children
abstract: As I fed, changed and rocked our daughter, I practiced my Tagalog phrases—until I sat in on a conference session on early language development, and found out that that’s exactly what I shouldn’t do.
lead_paragraph: I never thought of myself as having much in common with Spanish-speaking immigrants to the United States. I was born in Iowa, to parents of Western European ancestry, and I am a classic example of the monolingual American whose only exposure to another language came from a brief high school foreign-language class.

headline: Sol Golomb’s Rectangle Puzzle
abstract: A rectangle puzzle based on an original by the National Medal of Science recipient Solomon Golomb.
lead_paragraph: This week’s puzzle is based on an original by Solomon Golomb, a major figure in communication theory and a legendary professor at the University of Southern California. Dr. Golomb is also a prolific puzzle creator; I was introduced to his precise and insightful challenges by the physicist, electrical engineer and mathematician Nelson Blachman, who consumed puzzles of all types and particularly enjoyed those by Dr. Golomb.

headline: Asian Cultural Council Divides the Prize for Rockefeller Awards
abstract: For the first time, the John D. Rockefeller 3rd Award was divided among three winners.
lead_paragraph: The Asian Cultural Council, which was founded in 1963 to encourage cultural exchanges between the United States and Asian countries, normally gives its $50,000 John D. Rockefeller 3rd Award to a single artist every year. This year the council is splitting the award for the first time, the council announced on Monday. The winners are the composer Chinary Ung, the choreographer and dancer Pichet Klunchun, and an arts administrator in Indonesia, Amna Kusumo. They will each receive $50,000.

headline: Beans and Peas Lower Cholesterol
abstract: A review of studies found that consuming a few legumes a day appeared to reduce levels of “bad” cholesterol.
lead_paragraph: Eating modest amounts of legumes — peas, chickpeas, beans and lentils — appears to reduce levels of LDL, the so-called bad cholesterol.

headline: Paying Farmers to Welcome Birds
abstract: Conservationists and bird watchers are tracking migratory shorebirds and restoring habitat by paying rice farms in the birds’ path to keep their fields flooded with irrigation water.
lead_paragraph: WHEATLAND, Calif. — The Central Valley was once one of North America’s most productive wildlife habitats, a 450-mile-long expanse marbled with meandering streams and lush wetlands that provided an ideal stop for migratory shorebirds on their annual journeys from South America and Mexico to the Arctic and back.

headline: JWT to Bring Back the Classic J. Walter Thompson Name

headline: As Cubs Wander Into the Bronx, They’ve Never Been Worse

The team was built to endure, too, with future Hall of Famers at first base, second base and shortstop, and another Hall of Famer on the mound.

headline: U.N. Official Condemns Use of Torture in Syrian War
keywords: ['Torture', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: A report also records torture by some armed opposition groups and serious allegations of torture and the ill-treatment of children.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations human rights chief, Navi Pillay, condemned the rampant and routine use of torture by the Syrian authorities in a paper released by her office on Monday, which also records torture by some armed opposition groups and serious allegations of torture and the ill-treatment of children.

headline: No Comment Necessary: New Hampshire’s Senator From Massachusetts
abstract: At a rally introducing Scott Brown, John Sununu called Jeanne Shaheen the “third senator from Massachusetts.”
lead_paragraph: Scott Brown announced last week that he would run to unseat Jeanne Shaheen as senator from New Hampshire. Which of the two deserve the label “third senator from Massachusetts”?

headline: Wildfire Rages in Chile
abstract: Firefighters struggle to contain a massive wildfire in Valparaíso, Chile, that has destroyed thousands of homes since Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Firefighters struggle to contain a massive wildfire in Valparaíso, Chile, that has destroyed thousands of homes since Saturday.

headline: New Dave Eggers Novel Coming in June
abstract: Mr. Eggers’s latest effort involves a NASA astronaut taken to an abandoned military base.
lead_paragraph: Dave Eggers’s latest novel will be published on June 17, just eight months after the appearance of his last, the social-media cautionary tale “The Circle.” The new book’s title is a two-sentence mouthful: “Your Fathers, Where Are They? And the Prophets, Do They Live Forever?”

headline: New York Times Wins Two Photography Pulitzers
abstract: The Times swept the 2014 prizes for photography.
lead_paragraph: The Times swept the 2014 prizes for photography.

headline: New Collection of Shirley Jackson Works to Be Published
abstract: The new collection, “Garlic in Fiction,” includes fiction as well as work that appeared in women’s magazines of the 1940s and ’50s.
lead_paragraph: In the competition to bring previously unpublished works of Shirley Jackson to readers, Random House has prevailed, in a far less bloody manner than her classic short story “The Lottery” would suggest. Random House said on Monday that it had acquired a new collection of works by Ms. Jackson, the National Book Award-nominated author of “The Haunting of Hill House,” compiled primarily from her papers at the Library of Congress.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Lady Day’
abstract: Audra McDonald sings “What a Little Moonlight Can Do” from “Lady Day at Emerson’s Bar and Grill,” about the life of the singer Billie Holiday.
lead_paragraph: Audra McDonald sings “What a Little Moonlight Can Do” from “Lady Day at Emerson’s Bar and Grill,” about the life of the singer Billie Holiday.

headline: Image of the Day: April 14
abstract: The Golden temple at dawn on the occasion of Baisakhi festival in Amritsar, Punjab..

headline: Imagining Charles (Finally) in Charge
abstract: “King Charles III,” a new play that imagines Prince Charles as Britain’s king in a conflict with Parliament, has set London buzzing.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Queen is dead. Charles, paranoid and power obsessed, dissolves Parliament and parks a tank outside Buckingham Palace. While Prince William dithers, his steely and pragmatic wife, Kate, orchestrates a palace coup to save the monarchy and prevent Britain from sliding into civil war.

headline: Michael Phelps Plans Return to Competitive Swimming
abstract: A 22-time Olympic medalist, Phelps is scheduled to take part this month in the Arena Grand Prix in Mesa, Ariz.
lead_paragraph: There is no Olympic design behind Michael Phelps’s comeback, if you can call it that. At this stage, Phelps’s coach, Bob Bowman, would prefer that people not read too much into his return to competition next week at the Arena Grand Prix in Mesa, Ariz.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: April 11-13, 2014
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: For the last month, a serial shooter has been wreaking havoc on highways in the Kansas City, Mo., area. Three people have been wounded in as many as 20 shootings, calling to mind the terror that paralyzed the Washington, D.C., area in 2002, when a pair of snipers killed 10 people.

headline: Too Much Family Love
abstract: Every patient needs a moment alone, as one woman with a terminal illness and a large band of affectionate relatives made clear.
lead_paragraph: For 15 years Anna was a solitary figure sitting at the far end of our waiting room for her annual checkups, having shaved a half-hour off her workday so she could hustle over before we locked our doors.

headline: Alexa Ray Joel Recovering After Collapsing at Café Carlyle Show
abstract: Ms. Joel fell ill onstage at the final performance of a two-week run, but is recovering, a spokeswoman said.
lead_paragraph: Alexa Ray Joel, the 28-year old daughter of the singer Billy Joel and the model Christie Brinkley, and a singer, pianist and songwriter in her own right, was two songs into her set at the Café Carlyle on Saturday evening  – the final performance in a two-week run that opened on April 1 – when she suddenly collapsed. She was taken to the emergency room at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital.

headline: White House Pressed to Protect Ailing Monarch Butterflies
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Butterflies and Moths', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Pesticides']
abstract: The White House is sent a fresh pitch for a push to restore monarch butterfly habitat and food on public and private lands.
lead_paragraph: All too often, species that humans care about only get attention when they are in crisis. Such is the case with monarch butterflies. The insect, famed for its remarkable annual migrations, faced declines in habitat on both the Mexican and American ends of its range for decades, but now is the focus of an urgent push for a rescue. The latest step is a letter sent on Monday to President Obama and relevant cabinet members by a group of scientists, educators, farmers, and other concerned citizens organized by the Xerces Society and other conservation groups focused on these butterflies. The letter (read it here) describes policies the administration could pursue on both public and private land along the butterfly’s migratory path.  In February, after about 20 naturalists, poets and other monarch defenders pressed for international action in an open letter, the plight of the butterfly was addressed by President Obama and his Mexican and Canadian counterparts at a summit. The leaders agreed to create a working group to study ways to protect the butterfly at both ends of its range. A recent article by Richard Conniff in Yale Environment 360 describes what farmers can do to help monarchs. I also recommend a recent feature in The Times by Michael Wines describing efforts by various groups to restore habitat:

headline: A Son’s Deafness Prompts a Scientific Journey
keywords: ['Deafness', 'Hearing Aids', 'Ears and Hearing', 'Children and Childhood', 'Books and Literature', 'Language and Languages']
abstract: A look at the crucial relationship between sound, language and the development of literacy.
lead_paragraph: Like almost all newborns in this country, Alex Justh was given a hearing test at birth. He failed, but his parents were told not to worry: He was a month premature and there was mucus in his ears. A month later, an otoacoustic emission test, which measures the response of hair cells in the inner ear, came back normal.

headline: India Won’t Use Nuclear Weapons First
abstract: India’s Bharatiya Janata Party has clarified its stated plan to “revise and update” the country’s nuclear weapons doctrine.
lead_paragraph: India’s Bharatiya Janata Party, the presumed front-runner to lead the next government, has clarified its stated plan to “revise and update” the country’s nuclear weapons doctrine.

headline: Best Selling Science Books
abstract: Titles, fundamentally based on the sciences, as selected by the science editors from all adult nonfiction books reported to The New York Times for the month.
lead_paragraph: 1 DAVID AND GOLIATH by Malcolm Gladwell. Little Brown. How disadvantages can work in our favor, from the author of “The Tipping Point” and “Outliers.” (Last month’s ranking: 1.)

headline: Citi’s Stock Seems Priced for More Mediocrity
abstract: Despite Citi’s strong earnings, the bank is trading at just 83 percent of its tangible book value, the only major financial firm currently stuck at less than its net worth, Antony Currie writes in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Citigroup’s stock looks perfectly priced – for more mediocrity.

headline: Laughter Amid the Tears — A Cubs Quiz
abstract: With the Cubs heading to the Bronx to play the Yankees — a rare event — it’s a good time to bone up on some Cubs lore with this quiz.
lead_paragraph: With the Cubs heading to the Bronx to play the Yankees — a rare event — it’s a good time to bone up on some Cubs lore with this quiz.

headline: Long in the Tooth
abstract: Do our teeth linger after we die? Why?
lead_paragraph: Q. Why, after 5,000 or so years under ice, would the teeth of the so-called Iceman of the Alps still look pretty good? How long do teeth last?

headline: Hunt for Missing Plane to Go Underwater
abstract: Angus Houston, who is coordinating the search for the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, announced that teams plan to use a submersible vehicle to hunt under the ocean.
lead_paragraph: Angus Houston, who is coordinating the search for the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, announced that teams plan to use a submersible vehicle to hunt under the ocean.

headline: A Sea of Blue and Mourning at an Officer’s Funeral
keywords: ['Funerals and Memorials', 'Police', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Fires and Firefighters']
abstract: Hundreds of mourners and officers from the New York Police Department honored Officer Dennis Guerra, who died after responding to a fire in a high-rise in Coney Island.
lead_paragraph: The police sharpshooters stood atop an apartment tower on Beach 84th Street in Far Rockaway on Monday morning. They were there by way of protocol, but the view must have been striking. It was a fitting vantage point for the funeral of an officer who died in a high-rise building fire.

headline: Next Residents of a Luxury Building: Police Horses
abstract: This summer, a dozen horses and 20 officers from the New York Police Department will move to a new stable at Mercedes House apartments on Manhattan’s Far West Side.
lead_paragraph: The newest residences at Mercedes House, a ziggurat of luxury rentals on Manhattan’s Far West Side, provide tenants with creature comforts found nowhere else in the city.

headline: N.H.L. Teams Suffer Post-Olympic Blues
abstract: A study by a sports economist shows that the N.H.L. teams that send the most players to the Olympics tend to struggle in the second half of the season.
lead_paragraph: The so-called Olympic effect seems to have struck N.H.L. teams again.

headline: How Fruit Flies Are Like Helicopters
abstract: High-tech analysis of the movement of the insects shows how they can quickly change direction to escape.
lead_paragraph: Apparently it is not just speed that makes a fly so hard to swat. In the face of danger, fruit flies execute surprisingly nimble maneuvers to pitch and roll out of harm’s way, researchers say.

headline: In Many Cities, Rent Is Rising Out of Reach of Middle Class
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: More households are being priced out of more areas: An analysis found 90 cities where the median rent is more than 30 percent of the median gross income.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — For rent and utilities to be considered affordable, they are supposed to take up no more than 30 percent of a household’s income. But that goal is increasingly unattainable for middle-income families as a tightening market pushes up rents ever faster, outrunning modest rises in pay.

headline: An Acidic Wine Calls for Duck and Rhubarb
abstract: The rhubarb plays off rosy, meaty duck magret rimmed with creamy fat.
lead_paragraph: Rhubarb, like the lean Napa cabernet sauvignons, is defined by bright acidity and modest fruit flavors. And happily, the first rhubarb of the season is showing up in the market. The rhubarb plays off rosy, meaty duck magret rimmed with creamy fat. A touch of blood orange in the sauce contributes more fruit and acid.

headline: Bullets, Blood and Then Cry of ‘Heil Hitler’
keywords: ['Hate Crimes', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Jews and Judaism', 'ANTI-SEMITISM']
abstract: Until Sunday’s shootings, Frazier Glenn Miller was vocal about his views that Jews should be killed, but had not acted on them.
lead_paragraph: OVERLAND PARK, Kan. — After the Sunday afternoon mayhem, the handcuffed suspect was led to a gun-gray police car, his beard salt and pepper, his T-shirt a striking white. He looked like who he was, in part: a retiree who was said to have just spent part of his weekend at a casino. Then, from the back seat, he shouted a hoary phrase tinged with a Southern inflection:

headline: The Bulls May Have a Role Model for Anthony
abstract: If Carmelo Anthony’s success depends on whom he plays with, he could do worse than the Bulls’ Joakim Noah, a model leader and ideal teammate.
lead_paragraph: After reporters covering the Chicago Bulls had finished interviewing Coach Tom Thibodeau on Sunday night, they headed to the team’s locker room at Madison Square Garden and went en masse to one player, Joakim Noah, who was finishing dressing with his back to them.

headline: Maazel Withdraws From Boston Symphony Concerts
abstract: Lorin Maazel will be replaced by Charles Dutoit in conducting concerts in Boston this month and on an Asian tour in May.
lead_paragraph: April should have been a banner month for Lorin Maazel, the 84-year-old former director of the New York Philharmonic. He was to have brought the ensemble he currently directs, the Munich Philharmonic Orchestra, to Carnegie Hall over the weekend, but had to withdraw from the performances because he was ill. (Valery Gergiev and Fabio Luisi filled in for him.) Now the Boston Symphony Orchestra has announced that he has had to bow out of concerts in Boston, from Thursday through April 26. He was also to have taken the orchestra on an Asian tour, with concerts in China, which the orchestra last visited in 1979 (it was the first American orchestra to perform there after the normalization of relations), and Japan, which the Bostonians last visited in 1999.

headline: Obama Speaks About Kansas Shootings
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The president honored those killed in shootings at two Jewish centers in Kansas, saying no one should have to worry about their security while praying with their fellow believers.
lead_paragraph: The president honored those killed in shootings at two Jewish centers in Kansas, saying no one should have to worry about their security while praying with their fellow believers.

headline: New York Times Wins Two Photography Pulitzers
keywords: ['Boston Marathon Bombings (2013)', 'Magazines', 'Nairobi, Kenya, Westgate Mall Shootings (2013)', 'Photography', 'Pulitzer Prizes']
abstract: The Times swept the 2014 prizes for photography. Tyler Hicks won for his coverage of a terrorist attack at a Nairobi mall. Josh Haner was honored for his images of the slow and painful recovery process of a Boston Marathon bombing survivor.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times has swept the 2014 Pulitzer Prizes for photography. The staff photographer Tyler Hicks won the 2014 Pulitzer Prize in breaking news photography for his coverage of a terrorist attack at an upscale mall in Nairobi, Kenya, that left more than 60 people dead. Josh Haner was awarded the Pulitzer in feature photography for his images of the slow and painful recovery process for a survivor of the Boston Marathon bombing.

headline: GrafTech Drama Headed for Proxy Fight
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Boards of Directors', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: After being ousted from the board of GrafTech International, Nathan Milikowsky is expected to wage a proxy fight to elect himself and five proposed directors to the board.
lead_paragraph: The war of words between GrafTech International, a small steel company, and its largest independent shareholder, Nathan Milikowsky, is heating up, and a proxy fight is on the horizon.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Harvick Wins Another Nascar Crown Jewel
abstract: Kevin Harvick took the lead after a late-race caution; Marc Marquez won the MotoGP event in Austin, Tex.
lead_paragraph: `Kevin Harvick passed Dale Earnhardt Jr. with one lap to go to win the Southern 500 Nascar Sprint Cup race at Darlington, S.C., Saturday. Harvick has now won all of Nascar’s most prestigious races, including the Daytona 500, the Brickyard 400 and the Coca-Cola 600.

headline: Pulitzer Prizes Awarded for Coverage of N.S.A. Secrets and Boston Bombing
keywords: ['Pulitzer Prizes', 'News and News Media', 'Nairobi, Kenya, Westgate Mall Shootings (2013)', 'Boston Marathon Bombings (2013)']
abstract: The Washington Post and The Guardian U.S. won the Pulitzer Prize for public service for coverage of Edward J. Snowden’s leaked documents. The Boston Globe won the breaking news prize.
lead_paragraph: The Washington Post and Guardian U.S. on Monday won the Pulitzer Prize for public service, among the most prestigious awards in journalism, for their articles based on National Security Agency documents leaked by the former government contractor Edward J. Snowden.

headline: Two Photography Pulitzers
abstract: Tyler Hicks won for his coverage of a terrorist attack at a Nairobi mall. Josh Haner was honored in feature photography for his images of the recovery of a Boston Marathon bombing survivor.
lead_paragraph: Tyler Hicks won for his coverage of a terrorist attack at a Nairobi mall. Josh Haner was honored in feature photography for his images of the recovery of a Boston Marathon bombing survivor.

headline: Mozilla Names Interim Chief
abstract: Mozilla, the maker of the popular Firefox web browser, announced Monday that it had appointed Chris Beard the interim chief executive of the company.
lead_paragraph: Mozilla, the maker of the popular Firefox web browser, announced Monday that it had appointed Chris Beard the interim chief executive of the company.

headline: Rossana Orlandi, the Queen of Design
abstract: T’s design editor Tom Delavan interviews the Italian designer, who discusses her show at Salone del Mobile.
lead_paragraph: T’s design editor Tom Delavan interviews the Italian designer, who discusses her show at Salone del Mobile.

headline: A Tiny Discovery in Australia’s Swamps
abstract: Scientists have discovered a tiny, elusive crayfish living in eastern Australia.
lead_paragraph: Researchers have discovered a tiny new species of crayfish in Australia. Weighing just over seven grams, the Gramastacus lacus is one of the world’s smallest freshwater crayfishes, and is distinguished by a large male genital papilla and raised ridges above the eyes. Described in the open-access journal ZooKeys, it resides in swampy areas on the eastern coast of Australia from Wamberal Lagoon to Wallis Lake, where it periodically burrows into the water table to survive dry periods, effectively hiding from scientists seeking to study it.

headline: The 2015 Nissan Murano: Dialing Back From a Striking Design
abstract: The company introduces the third generation of its midsize crossover, toning down the striking design of the concept shown at the 2013 Detroit show.
lead_paragraph: What is it? The 2015 Nissan Murano is the third generation of the company’s midsized crossover.

headline: VW Golf SportWagen: A Station Wagon Concept
abstract: The company previews a bigger and more fuel-efficient replacement for the Jetta SportWagen.
lead_paragraph: What is it? According to Volkswagen, the Golf SportWagen Concept previews a bigger, more spacious and more fuel-efficient replacement for the Jetta SportWagen.

headline: Total to Proceed With Angola Ultra-Deepwater Project
abstract: The French oil company said it would move ahead with a giant project called Kaombo in deep waters off the coast of Angola.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After more than a year’s delay, the French oil company Total said on Monday that it had found the cost savings needed to move ahead with the giant ultra-deepwater Kaombo project off the coast of Angola, setting a start date of 2017.

headline: Still Nothing on the I.R.S.
abstract: Chris Wallace asked Representative Charles Boustany if he had “any evidence, after a year of investigation.”
lead_paragraph: Some readers objected last week when I wrote that “Fox News Sunday” is the place where Republican politicians go to make empty accusations without fear of follow-up questions. So I wanted to note that the show’s host, Chris Wallace not only asked follow-ups, but tough ones, in an interview on Sunday with Representative Charles Boustany, Republican of Louisiana.

headline: Napa Cabernets From a Cold, Wet Year
abstract: The best wines had earthy, mineral qualities not ordinarily associated with many Napa reds.
lead_paragraph: Outside of a few pockets of fog, California is the land of warmth and sunshine. This has led some to conclude that California wines must always show evidence of this privileged climate through plush textures and opulent fruit.

headline: With Purchase of Drone Maker, Google Sees a Fleet of Satellites
abstract: Following in Facebook’s footsteps, Google said Monday that it had purchased Titan Aerospace, the maker of high-altitude drone satellites, which will be used to take photos of the earth and to connect people to the Internet.
lead_paragraph: Google is reaching for the sky.

headline: Michael Kaiser to Become Co-Chairman of IMG Artists
abstract: Mr. Kaiser, who will step down as president of the Kennedy Center in September, will join the performing arts management agency IMG.
lead_paragraph: Michael M. Kaiser is adding another position to his résumé.

headline: Budget Office Lowers Estimate for the Cost of Expanding Health Coverage
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: A Congressional Budget Office report shows the Affordable Care Act costing less in part because of the broad slowdown in the growth of health care costs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The insurance expansion under the Affordable Care Act will cost $1.383 trillion over the next decade, more than $100 billion less than previous forecasts, the Congressional Budget Office said Monday.

headline: E-Cigarettes Are Targeted at Youths, Report Says
abstract: Lawmakers said a survey of electronic cigarette producers found that hundreds of giveaways and sponsorships took place at youth-oriented events.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An investigation by Democratic members of Congress into the marketing practices of electronic cigarette companies has found that major producers are targeting young people by giving away free samples at music and sporting events and running radio and television advertisements during youth-oriented programs.

headline: MTV Movie Awards Red Carpet
abstract: At the MTV Movie Awards, guests like Lupita Nyong’o in a colorful Chanel dress and Rita Ora in a plunging neckline Barbara Casasola dress, shined on the red carpet.
lead_paragraph: At the MTV Movie Awards, guests like Lupita Nyong’o in a colorful Chanel dress and Rita Ora in a plunging neckline Barbara Casasola dress, shined on the red carpet.

headline: It Pays to Pay Addicts to Get Vaccinations
abstract: A British study has found that paying drug addicts was effective in getting them vaccinated against hepatitis B.
lead_paragraph: Paying heroin addicts the equivalent of $50 each to have a series of three injections in a month was very effective in getting them fully vaccinated against hepatitis B, a new British study has found.

headline: Learning From What Lincoln Had to Say
keywords: ['Television', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: “The Address,” a Ken Burns documentary, captures schoolboys with learning problems as they face the challenge of memorizing Lincoln’s Gettysburg Address.
lead_paragraph: Ken Burns, the documentarian who gave us “The Civil War,” knows quite a lot about the Gettysburg Address, but in his latest film, he turns his attention to a group of boys who are just learning about it. The result is “The Address,” a documentary Tuesday night on PBS that has little to do with the war but is quietly revelatory, just as that earlier work was.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 59
abstract: The World Cup trophy’s world tour lands in the United States this week.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Rossana Orlandi, the Queen of Design, on Her Salone Exhibition
abstract: During Milan’s design week, the Italian madre of all things chic and a supporter of fledgling designers, discusses her “Untold” show, in which modern pieces complement their 19th-century surroundings.
lead_paragraph: Last Thursday, in the middle of Salone del Mobile, Rossana Orlandi hosted a cocktail party at the Bagatti Valsecchi Museum. Champagne flowed as the see-and-be-seen crowd piled in to admire the “Untold” exhibition she curated there, which she explains in the above video interview with our design editor, Tom Delavan. Displaying contemporary pieces in the historic 19th-century house allowed Orlandi to “show how modern pieces are perfect and can have a fabulous dialogue with an old palace,” she says. The video opens with the light installation that she and Vionnet’s creative director, Goga Ashkenazi, commissioned from the artist Jacopo Foggini for the show. Orlandi, who was once a fashion designer and loathes the “trendsetter” label often tacked onto her globally-recognized name, is now famous for championing the careers of designers on the rise, a category Foggini fell into not long ago. “When I find a designer, first of all I want to be sure that this designer — he will grow up,” she explains. Cast in the fashion house’s signature shade of blue, Foggini’s installation set the tone for the queen of design’s fête — a high point during an action-packed week.

headline: Flavors of the South From One of Its Own
abstract: “Down South,” by Donald Link, has recipes from the Texas Hill Country to the Mississippi Delta.
lead_paragraph: I met Donald Link for the first time three weeks after Hurricane Katrina drowned New Orleans. He was mucking out the walk-in at Herbsaint, his sophisticated restaurant in the city’s central business district. Hauling rotted pig heads to the curb in a city that had just lost hundreds of people was awful work. But it had to be done, and he was one of the first chefs to do it.

headline: The Making of Pulitzer Prize-Winning Photos
abstract: Today, two Times journalists, Tyler Hicks and Josh Haner were awarded Pulitzer Prizes for photography in 2013.
lead_paragraph: Today, two Times journalists, Tyler Hicks and Josh Haner, were awarded Pulitzer Prizes for photography in 2013.

headline: 2014 Pulitzer Prize Winners in Journalism, Letters, Drama and Music
abstract: The prizes, which are administered at Columbia University, were announced on Monday.
lead_paragraph: FICTION

headline: They Crawl Right Into Your Head
abstract: An entomologist who discovered he has a crippling fear of bugs writes a book about the human reaction to insects.
lead_paragraph: Trained as an entomologist, Jeffrey A. Lockwood discovered 12 years into his career that he was phobic about the very subject he had chosen as his life’s work.

headline: When a Game Turned Into a Disaster
abstract: An ESPN documentary examines the disastrous 1989 soccer match in England in which 96 fans died.
lead_paragraph: “Hillsborough,” Tuesday night on ESPN, is a soccer movie with very little soccer in it. It’s about a match played 25 years ago at the Hillsborough stadium in Sheffield, England, that ended after just six minutes — when the realization set in that amid the festive atmosphere of an F.A. Cup semifinal, fans were being crushed to death a few yards behind the west goal.

headline: Zombies in the Garden, Killing Themselves Slowly
abstract: Certain parasites can take over their hosts’ behavior, forcing them to act against their own interest in order to benefit the parasites.
lead_paragraph: Scientists say they have identified a protein that causes zombielike behavior in plants.

headline: Obesity Studies Tell Two Stories, Both Right
abstract: A new study disputes findings that obesity among young children has declined, but because both sets of research used different time frames, both may be right.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Researchers at the University of North Carolina published a paper last week that introduced another wrinkle into the debate about childhood obesity. They disputed recent findings that obesity among young children had fallen since 2004, arguing that a longer view — using data all the way back to 1999 — showed that these youngsters were not really getting any thinner.

headline: Bikini (and Hoop Skirt) Season Is Here, and Not a Moment Too Soon
abstract: Works choreographed by Rebecca Brooks and Anna Azrieli come to Danspace at St. Mark’s Church.
lead_paragraph: Say you decide to make a dance about the isolation of grief: How would you represent the boredom of solitude without boring a spectator? That’s one of the challenges that Rebecca Brooks and her collaborators have set themselves in “Still Left on This Rock.” And at Danspace Project in the East Village this weekend, on a double bill with Anna Azrieli’s “third skirt scrum,” much of the 45 minutes of “Still Left” slipped from languor into longueurs.

headline: In Performance: Adrian Lester
abstract: Adrian Lester performs a scene from Lolita Chakrabarti’s play “Red Velvet,” a drama about the 19th-century black actor Ira Aldridge. The show runs through April 20 at St. Ann’s Warehouse.
lead_paragraph: Adrian Lester performs a scene from Lolita Chakrabarti’s play “Red Velvet,” a drama about the 19th-century black actor Ira Aldridge. The show runs through April 20 at St. Ann’s Warehouse.

headline: Coachella Festival Style: Predictable and Pin-Worthy
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival', 'Music']
abstract: Some of our favorite, although expected, moments from the first weekend at the 2014 Coachella Music Festival.
lead_paragraph: Some of our favorite, although expected, moments from the first weekend at the 2014 Coachella Music Festival.

headline: Chia-Seed Pudding for Breakfast: Tart, Sweet and Good for You
abstract: This pudding from El Rey, a coffee bar on the Lower East Side, has the appeal of tapioca, but is easier to make and slightly more exciting.
lead_paragraph: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tested and tweaked for home cooks.

headline: Spying on a Grown-Up World
abstract: “Casebook,” by Mona Simpson, sees a fracturing family through the eyes of a teenager.
lead_paragraph: Family is the North Star for Mona Simpson’s characters: It defines who they are, chaperones their choices, shapes their views of the world. Her dazzling debut novel, “Anywhere But Here” (1986), gave us an indelible portrait of a girl’s emotionally fraught relationship with her impossible, narcissistic mother. “The Lost Father” (1992) followed that same heroine’s obsessive search for the father who abandoned her. And “A Regular Guy” (1996) depicted another abandoned daughter trying to come to terms with her father — in this case, a rich, eccentric entrepreneur (who bore more than a passing resemblance to Ms. Simpson’s real-life brother, Steve Jobs).

headline: Pulitzer-Winning Play ‘The Flick’ to Reopen in New York
abstract: Annie Baker’s play won the Pulitzer Prize for drama on Monday, and will open at Barrow Street Theater in the near future.
lead_paragraph: Annie Baker’s play “The Flick,” which ran Off Broadway last year and won the 2014 Pulitzer Prize for drama on Monday, will be remounted at Barrow Street Theater in the near future, according to a spokesman for its producer, Scott Rudin.

headline: Etsy Artisans Reach Retailers
abstract: Etsy is giving small business owners, like the woodworkers Shelli and Seth Worley of South Carolina, the opportunity to sell to retailers through a wholesale website.
lead_paragraph: Etsy is giving small business owners, like the woodworkers Shelli and Seth Worley of South Carolina, the opportunity to sell to retailers through a wholesale website.

headline: Etsy, Home of the Handmade, Takes On a Wholesaler’s Role
abstract: The company, known for its small-scale artisans and handmade goods, will help some sellers get bigger, and take a commission.
lead_paragraph: Amy Hamley of Redraven Studios makes jewelry and delicate home décor items out of porcelain, like hanging planter sets and necklaces in the shape of arrow heads. For three years, she worked out of her basement and tried to break into the wholesale market.

headline: Still Sensing the Presence of a Departed Composer
abstract: The avant-garde opera composer Robert Ashley died in March, but his presence is strongly felt in presentations at the Whitney Biennial and other recent re-envisionings of his work.
lead_paragraph: I wasn’t ready for Robert Ashley to be gone. Associates and intimates had shared news, quietly, of the deteriorating health that would lead to his death on March 3 at 83. Still, I’d thought, no way would karma, destiny or what have you allow Ashley to be taken before the conclusion of his three-opera series underway at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

headline: 5 Things to Know About Quinoa

headline: Not Merely Dead, Most Sincerely Dead
abstract: The video game FTL: Faster Than Light explores the newish frontier of permadeath.
lead_paragraph: A single death is not a tragedy in most video games. Instead, it’s something closer to an irritant — not even a paper cut, more like a chipped nail. Death is so cheap that a new word — “permadeath” — has been coined to describe games that turn your demise into something more than a speed bump on the road to victory.

headline: Artists and Spectators, Not So Far Apart
abstract: Now in its 15th year, the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, in Indio, Calif., blurs the line between performer and fan.
lead_paragraph: INDIO, Calif. — The age of the pop performer being somehow distinct from or greater than the audience is almost over; the audience has grown much more powerful, mostly through the forces of the Internet and social media. Nowhere is this more apparent perhaps than at last weekend’s Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, whose audience — cultivated over 15 editions in 15 years — has all that soft power and money, too: Tickets cost at least $375. The audience members have been called tastemakers, but let’s see that generalization and raise it. Let’s call them artists.

But should this necessarily be the case? On Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall, Stephen Hough, a pianist consistently thoughtful about the works he presents, offered an alternate notion. His recital included three pieces that might fairly be termed trivial, yet, in context, those works held valid interest.

lead_paragraph: DURING his run for mayor, Bill de Blasio pledged to eradicate the Central Park horse-drawn carriage business. He called the industry inhumane, and proposed to replace the retired horses with electric-powered replicas of vintage cabs. Since taking office, he has not agreed to meet with the operators or hear their views. In a Google Hangout on Friday, the mayor affirmed his commitment to a ban: “We expect action on it this year.”

headline: The Book That Didn’t Exist
abstract: No, the absence of ‘Goths’ in bookstores is no great hole in the world.
lead_paragraph: Seventeen years ago I wrote a book, which you can find on Amazon and Google and elsewhere online. This is unusual only because my book was never published. It’s called “Goths,” fitting for a title that has left its traces on the Internet but does not exist. The traces themselves are ghostly. Other than the title, Amazon lists only the publisher (Random House Trade), language (English) and ISBNs (one with 10 digits, the other with 13). Google goes further by giving the publication date (March 1, 1998) and promising a cover image — but it turns out to be a placeholder. And unlike Amazon, Google neglects to mention that the book is a hardcover. Google admits, “We haven’t found any reviews in the usual places,” which in this case would be the planet Earth. “Be the first to review this item,” Amazon encourages, but has as yet found no takers.

headline: Daniel Radcliffe Remains a Draw on Broadway
abstract: With the power of Daniel Radcliffe’s name, Martin McDonagh’s 1996 dark comedy, “The Cripple of Inishmaan,” sold nearly every seat for its first two preview performances.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Radcliffe’s star power on Broadway remains intact. After helping generate million-dollar weekly grosses as the leading man in the 2011 revival “How to Succeed In Business Without Really Trying,” Mr. Radcliffe – best known as the eponymous boy wizard in the “Harry Potter” movies – returned to Broadway last week as the title character in Martin McDonagh’s 1996 dark comedy, “The Cripple of Inishmaan.” For its first two preview performances, “Inishmaan” grossed $155,234 – or 95 percent of the maximum possible amount, with nearly every seat sold.

abstract: Ms. Frelich starred on Broadway in 1980 in “Children of a Lesser God,” a play she had inspired Mark Medoff to write.
lead_paragraph: Phyllis Frelich, the actress who made a groundbreaking and Tony-winning Broadway star turn in 1980 in “Children of a Lesser God,” Mark Medoff’s play — written with her and her husband’s help — about the courtship and marriage of a deaf woman and a man who can hear, died on Thursday at her home in Temple City, Calif., near Los Angeles. She was 70.

headline: 2 Pakistanis Suspected of Cannibalism After Head Is Found

lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — In a macabre case that has transfixed and horrified Pakistanis, the police on Monday arrested a man suspected of cannibalism after they found an infant’s head at his home.

headline: Utah Garage Cleaning Turns Up Boxes of Suffocated Infants
abstract: Megan Huntsman said she killed six of her babies immediately after giving birth, interring them in the garage of her family’s home.
lead_paragraph: PLEASANT GROVE, Utah — The infants were found in cardboard boxes, each one rolled up in a shirt or towel and tucked into a plastic bag. One had been stillborn, their mother, Megan Huntsman, told the police. The other six, she said, she had strangled or smothered immediately after giving birth, and interred them in the garage of her family’s brick home here.

headline: Canada’s Lonely Standard-Bearers in the N.H.L. Playoffs
abstract: For the first time since 1973, only one Canadian team, the Montreal Canadiens, has reached the Stanley Cup playoffs.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — Perhaps it is just a random quirk of probability, but the numbers are eye-opening nonetheless. For the first time since 1973, only one Canadian team — the Montreal Canadiens, fittingly — qualified for the Stanley Cup playoffs, which begin Wednesday. Six of the seven Canadian teams will not play in the postseason, while 15 of the 23 teams based in the United States will.

headline: Iran: U.N. Is Asked to Resolve Envoy’s Visa Dispute
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Visas']
abstract: Iran on Monday said it had complained to the United Nations over the refusal by the United States to grant a visa to its choice for ambassador, Hamid Aboutalebi.
lead_paragraph: Iran on Monday said it had complained to the United Nations over the refusal by the United States to grant a visa to its choice for ambassador, Hamid Aboutalebi, a career diplomat who once worked as an interpreter for the revolutionary group that seized the American Embassy in Tehran in 1979. The deputy foreign minister for European-American affairs, Majid Takht-e Ravanchi, was quoted by the official Islamic Republic News Agency as saying that Iran had asked the Committee on Relations with the Host Country to examine the issue and that Secretary General Ban Ki-moon should intervene if necessary. But United Nations officials said that neither Mr. Ban’s office nor the committee had yet received any written complaint from Tehran or its United Nations mission. An official at the mission of Cyprus, which currently leads the committee, said that after it received a written complaint it could take up the issue at its next, yet-to-be-scheduled quarterly meeting. The committee can only make recommendations.

headline: Mexico: Homicides Decline Near Border, Report Says
abstract: Murders in Mexico declined in 2013, and they decreased significantly in several cities near the border with the United States, according to a new report.
lead_paragraph: Murders in Mexico declined in 2013, and they decreased significantly in several cities near the border with the United States, according to a new report from the Justice in Mexico Project at the University of San Diego to be released Tuesday. Using preliminary police data, researchers identified a homicide decrease of about 16 percent, with some of the biggest drops in murders in Ciudad Juárez and Monterrey, notoriously dangerous cities that have recently calmed down as the war between criminal gangs and the government has declined in intensity. Still, experts warn, it is not clear whether the decline is attributable to an overall weakening of organized crime: The number of gun-related murders has held steady as other kinds of killing have declined, and homicides have sharply risen in states farther south. Extortion and kidnapping have also increased nationwide. But with overall murder rates down for the second year in a row from their 2011 peak, some parts of Mexico appear to be on the mend, said David A. Shirk, an author of the report. “The decrease in violence that the government in Mexico is trying to convince people of is in fact real,” he said.

headline: In the Middle East, Time to Move On
abstract: The United States has been fully committed to a two-state solution, but now it must devote its attention to other international challenges like Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The pointless arguing over who brought Israeli-Palestinian peace talks to the brink of collapse is in full swing. The United States is still working to salvage the negotiations, but there is scant sign of serious purpose. It is time for the administration to lay down the principles it believes must undergird a two-state solution, should Israelis and Palestinians ever decide to make peace. Then President Obama and Secretary of State John Kerry should move on and devote their attention to other major international challenges like Ukraine.

headline: Red-Hot Brewers Win by Swinging Freely, Always

headline: Apparent Hate Crime Aimed at Jews Instead Strikes Christians
keywords: ['Hate Crimes', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: Although the shooting suspect was a known racist and anti-Semite, the victims who were gunned down on Sunday were all Christians devoted to their families, to their churches and to serving their communities.
lead_paragraph: William L. Corporon was a longtime family doctor, but to his family, he was Popeye, a nickname bestowed by a grandson, Reat Underwood.

headline: A Deadline for Grandfathered Weapons
abstract: Gun activists are trying to convince law-abiding gun owners in New York to disobey a sensible law that requires the registration of their assault weapons.
lead_paragraph: Weeks after a demented gunman killed 20 children and six adults in a Newtown, Conn., school, Gov. Andrew Cuomo and New York legislators passed the SAFE Act, a strong gun-control law that included a broad ban on semiautomatic assault weapons. Those who already owned such weapons could keep them if they agreed to register the guns with State Police by midnight Tuesday.

headline: Preventing Painkiller Overdoses
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Naloxone (Drug)', 'Editorials', 'Pain-Relieving Drugs']
abstract: With thousands of fatal overdoses from pills and heroin, the federal and state governments are trying new initiatives to save more lives.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration earlier this month approved a hand-held device that can quickly reverse the effects of an overdose and prevent deaths from opioid painkillers and heroin. The easy-to-use injector delivers a dose of the drug naloxone, a treatment that is typically delivered in hospitals but can now be used by family members or emergency responders at the scene of an overdose.

headline: Schimmel Brings Flair and Pride in Heritage to W.N.B.A.
abstract: Louisville guard Shoni Schimmel was taken eighth over all by the Atlanta Dream on Monday night, making her the highest Native American drafted in the W.N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: UNCASVILLE, Conn. — On Monday afternoon, Shoni Schimmel, a member of the Confederated Tribes of the Umatilla in eastern Oregon, sat inside the lobby of the Mohegan Sun hotel, surrounded by Native American-inspired décor and steps away from a souvenir shop selling dream catchers.

headline: DNA and Insurance, Fate and Risk
abstract: Should insurers be barred from seeing genetic tests for life, disability and long-term care coverage, so people can be tested without fear that the results would be used against them?

headline: Florida Lawmakers Proposing a Salve for Ailing Springs
keywords: ['Water Pollution', 'Environment', 'Law and Legislation', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'ALGAE', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Fertilizer']
abstract: An effort to clean up waterways plagued by agricultural runoff and other pollutants is meeting some legislative opposition.
lead_paragraph: CHIEFLAND, Fla. — To the untrained eye, Manatee Springs is an idyllic refuge in Central Florida: The cool water is so clear in parts that the sand glistens like polished aluminum. A vast series of underwater caves beckons thousands of divers. Deer wander by as do manatees, turtles, owls. Eagles soar overhead.

headline: Yankees’ McCann Cleared by X-Ray
abstract: Brian McCann’s hand was found to be uninjured after being struck by a deflected pitch, but Francisco Cervelli was placed on the disabled list after a scan of his injured leg.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees reported mixed results from the medical tests performed on two players  Monday.

headline: Testimony From Britain May Be Used in Terror Trial
abstract: A key government witness in the terrorism trial of an Islamic cleric may testify from Britain via a closed circuit television connection, a federal judge in Manhattan said in a ruling released on Monday.
lead_paragraph: A key government witness in the terrorism trial of a radical Islamic cleric may testify from Britain via a closed circuit television connection, a federal judge in Manhattan said in a ruling released on Monday.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, April 15, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, April 15, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “It’s the Jewish madeleine. It’s that food that has the ability to transport you in time and connect you to your lineage.”

headline: Maple Leafs Turn to Shanahan to Give Team Identity
abstract: Brendan Shanahan, the Toronto franchise’s new president, is no stranger to winning: He raised three Stanley Cups while playing for the Detroit Red Wings and has an Olympic gold medal.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Brendan Shanahan won three Stanley Cups and an Olympic gold medal during his playing days, and the Maple Leafs hope that winning culture will transcend to a club that collapsed late in the season.

headline: Don’t Skimp on Legal Training
abstract: Talk of a crisis in legal education risks pushing law schools into hasty and ill-considered reforms.

headline: In the Bronx, Supporters Go Against Rep. Rangel
abstract: State Senator Adriano Espaillat picked up a number of important endorsements on Monday in his second attempt to unseat Representative Charles B. Rangel.
lead_paragraph: State Senator Adriano Espaillat picked up a number of important endorsements on Monday in his second attempt to unseat Representative Charles B. Rangel, the 22-term Harlem Democrat, gaining the support of the Bronx borough president, Ruben Diaz Jr., and several other members of the Bronx Democratic establishment.

headline: Publicizing of Veterinary Files Is Urged for Triple Crown Events
abstract: Ogden Mills Phipps, the chairman of the Jockey Club, said the goal was to ensure that the horses were sound and not under the influence of unnecessary drugs.
lead_paragraph: The chairman of the Jockey Club, one of horse racing’s most influential groups, called Monday for the veterinary records of every horse competing in this year’s Triple Crown races to be made public immediately. He said the goal was to ensure that the horses were sound and not under the influence of unnecessary drugs and that the races were run safely and fairly.

headline: Fourth of July Fireworks Show Will Move Back to East River
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio said the arrangement would mean somewhat higher security costs, because expenses would no longer be shared with New Jersey jurisdictions.
lead_paragraph: In the half-hour on the Fourth of July when the electrifying palette of fireworks dances and dazzles across the night sky, Lisa Ricca said that the familiar mantra of real estate — location, location, location — applied to her apartment complex in Weehawken, N.J., and not because she is a sales agent who has brokered deals for at least 50 units there.

headline: Corrections: April 15, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on April 15, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Mets’ Record Is Better Than Play Has Been
abstract: For a team that was batting only .207 entering Monday night’s game against the Diamondbacks, the Mets might have been considered fortunate to be 5-7.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — The schedule was not kind to the Mets over the first two weeks of the season. They faced the Washington Nationals, the Cincinnati Reds, the Atlanta Braves and the Los Angeles Angels, four teams that are considered contenders. Four teams with more star power than the Mets had, all with higher payrolls. These were teams built to win now, unlike the Mets.

headline: Bystander, 13, Shot in Brooklyn
abstract: A 13-year-old boy was shot twice in the head on Monday in Brooklyn, apparently a bystander in a dispute between two men, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A 13-year-old boy was shot twice in the head on Monday in Brooklyn, apparently a bystander in a dispute between two men, the police said.

headline: Worker Dies After Falling From Building
abstract: A construction worker died on Monday after he fell onto scaffolding at an office building near Pennsylvania Station in Midtown Manhattan, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A construction worker died on Monday after he fell onto scaffolding at an office building near Pennsylvania Station in Midtown Manhattan, the police said.

headline: Landlords to Repay Over $1 Million in Fees
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Landlords']
abstract: Westbrook Partners and Normandy Real Estate must resolve thousands of building violations and provide tenants with rebates for illegal fees and overcharges.
lead_paragraph: Ben Warren, a retired theatrical prop designer, had lived in his Bronx tenement for more than 30 years when the building changed owners in 2007. Soon, heat and hot water became sporadic, repairs went undone and tenants started being harassed.

headline: Pulling Tricks From Everyone’s Sleeves
abstract: The Rev. Al Sharpton has Muhammad Ali’s ability to slip a punch; dodging the latest accusations offered child’s play.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio can swell with enthusiasm for people and movements and moments progressive.

headline: Officer Testifies About Encounter With Occupy Wall Street Protester
abstract: At the last trial resulting from the protests, Officer Grantley Bovell said he was struck in the eye while trying to escort a protester from Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: It was St. Patrick’s Day 2012, and after spending his afternoon looking for intoxicated people at Pennsylvania Station, Officer Grantley Bovell was deployed to Lower Manhattan to help clear Zuccotti Park of scores of protesters who had gathered to mark the six-month anniversary of the Occupy Wall Street movement.

headline: Inmate Gets Life in Prison for Plotting to Behead a Judge and a Prosecutor
abstract: Joseph Romano was in jail for fraud when he consulted with a jail mate and arranged to pay a hit man $40,000. Both turned out to be working for the government.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Romano seemed like just another post-recession white-collar criminal when he went to jail for fraud two years ago — a Long Island man with a wife and three children, a volunteer at his children’s school, a Navy veteran who liked vintage cars and had gotten too greedy.

headline: Prices Soaring for Specialty Drugs, Researchers Find
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Generic Brands and Products']
abstract: A report says that even as prescription costs have plummeted, a small slice of the population with serious illnesses is being asked to shoulder more of the cost of expensive treatments.
lead_paragraph: Even as the cost of prescription drugs has plummeted for many Americans, a small slice of the population is being asked to shoulder more and more of the cost of expensive treatments for diseases like cancer and hepatitis C, according to a report to be released on Tuesday by a major drug research firm.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (ABC) CELEBRITY WIFE SWAP  Isabella Hofmann, the former girlfriend of the actor Daniel Baldwin, trades places with Halima Rashid, the wife of the musician Jermaine Jackson (above right with Ms. Rashid) in this Season 3 opener. After struggling with drug addiction for a decade, Mr. Baldwin is sober and trying to rebuild his relationship with Ms. Hofmann, who lives in a modest home in the Hollywood Hills area of Los Angeles with their autistic son, Atticus (above left with Mr. Baldwin and Ms. Hofmann). Ms. Rashid, meanwhile, lives in a grand estate with plenty of room for her racks of clothing and shoes, as well as the couple’s show dog, Fiji. Despite the differences in their lifestyles, the women seem to welcome the change. The men? Not so much.

headline: India Election Digest: April 15
abstract: A roundup of local election-related news for Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: What you need to know on Tuesday about India’s elections: A group dedicated to stamping out superstition challenges fortune tellers to predict the outcome of the elections, the daughter of Prime Minister Manmohan Singh expresses anger at the publication of a memoir by a former aide to the prime minister, and a former Coal Ministry official writes a memoir about his time in the government.

headline: Adding Design to His Business Duties
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Handbags and Purses']
abstract: Santiago Gonzalez, president of the Nancy Gonzales exotic handbags brand, now is concentrating on his own men’s accessories line.
lead_paragraph: Cali, Colombia’s third largest city, has overcome much of its reputation as a violent place overrun with crime and drug cartels. But it still surprises many to learn it is the home of a luxury accessories brand with a new men’s line.

headline: Mets’ Win Does Not Come Without Its Costs
abstract: Lucas Duda and Zack Wheeler led the Mets, who lost Juan Lagares with a strained hamstring and Curtis Granderson with rib and forearm injuries.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Juan Lagares and Curtis Granderson had started the season on opposite paths. Lagares was the young, exciting center fielder who was finally hitting enough to make a case to play every day. Granderson was the newly acquired, highly paid veteran who was in a slump.

headline: Times Minute | Boston Bombing Tribute
abstract: The national correspondent Katharine Q. Seelye reports from Boston ahead of events to commemorate the anniversary of the marathon bombing.
lead_paragraph: The national correspondent Katharine Q. Seelye reports from Boston ahead of events to commemorate the anniversary of the marathon bombing.

abstract: The national correspondent Katharine Q. Seelye reports from Boston ahead of events to commemorate the anniversary of the marathon bombing.
