headline: The Death That Kindled the Uprising at Tiananmen Square
abstract: The death in 1989 of Hu Yaobang, a former general secretary of the Communist Party who had been accused of being too soft on student protests, became a vehicle for the Chinese public to voice discontent.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:57 a.m.ET| Rarely has the timing of an ousted leader’s death been so consequential. In 1989, Hu Yaobang, a former general secretary of the Chinese Communist Party, was attending a meeting of the Politburo when he became pale and shaky, asked to be excused and crumpled with a heart attack. Twenty-five years ago, on April 15, he died after a week in the hospital, an event that unleashed a cascade of demonstrations centered on Tiananmen Square, which culminated in the armed crackdown of June 3-4.

headline: Expatriate Indians Return Home to Have Their Say
keywords: ['Elections', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: This is the first parliamentary election in which Indian expatriates, also known as nonresident Indians, can vote in their home country.
lead_paragraph: Sajid Aboobacker, 35, flew to Kozhikode, in the southern state of Kerala, from Dubai on a chartered flight on April 7 with 145 other Indians, desperate for their voices to be heard in a historic Indian parliamentary election that could see the triumph of the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party and its prime ministerial candidate, Narendra Modi.

headline: Submersible’s First Scan for Jet Wreckage Is Cut Short
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Submarines and Submersibles']
abstract: A safety mechanism halted the first deployment of an unmanned submersible in the hunt for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, officials said Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — The search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 has moved to the dark depths of the Indian Ocean with the first deployment of an unmanned submersible to scan the seabed for signs of wreckage, officials said Tuesday.

headline: Reading Valentine’s Card, Pistorius Leaves the Stand
abstract: Oscar Pistorius’s defense lawyer began to rebuild his case after days of grueling interrogation by the prosecutor, who has accused the athlete of lying and changing his testimony.
lead_paragraph: PRETORIA, South Africa — It took just nine minutes on Tuesday for Oscar Pistorius’s defense lawyer to release him from anguished days and hours on the stand, and he did so with a last, loving message from the woman he is accused of murdering.

headline: Hong Kong I.P.O. Structure Is Fine as Is, Investor Survey Finds
abstract: After Hong Kong loses Alibaba’s initial public offering, a survey shows that more than 90 percent of respondents oppose allowing partnership control structures like Alibaba’s in Hong Kong.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Hong Kong may have lost Alibaba’s giant initial public offering to the United States, but for some large investors in this Asian financial hub, that’s just fine.

headline: From Ordinary Life, Extraordinary Images
abstract: Chang Chao-Tang didn’t think much of his images of everyday life in Taiwan. More than five decades later, an exhibit highlights the purity of his images, showing “real people and places.”
lead_paragraph: Chang Chao-Tang was a high school student in 1959 when he borrowed his older brother’s Aires Automat 120 twin-lens reflex camera without much thought. He liked going for long walks with the camera after school; it eased the burden of his homework. Eventually, he found himself taking photos with the camera every day, photos of common people and places in Taiwan, like youngsters poking out of street corners or at beaches, farm animals, and dolls.

headline: Tracy Morgan: ‘You Got to Watch What You Say’
keywords: ['Comedy and Humor', 'Families and Family Life', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Television']
abstract: The “30 Rock” star thinks stand-up comedy has changed — but he has, too.
lead_paragraph: The comedian Tracy Morgan talks to Dave Itzkoff about his return to stand-up, reflects on the limits of free speech and offers some advice to his former “30 Rock” colleague Alec Baldwin.

headline: Chinese Military Newspaper Likens Lost Jet to Pearl Harbor
abstract: A commentary in the Liberation Army Daily sought to draw military lessons from the loss of Flight 370, citing the surprise 1941 attack by Japan that led America into World War II.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the search for the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, commentators have groped for analogies to convey the enigma of how a Boeing 777-200 could disappear without a trace. China’s official military newspaper, the Liberation Army Daily, may well be the first to liken the aircraft’s loss to the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor.

headline: Tribute and Mourning Year After Boston Bombings
abstract: Boston began a week of events to remember those killed and hurt in the bombings at the marathon, culminating next Monday with this year’s run.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — It may be one of the biggest cities in the country, but Boston was a small town on Tuesday as it mourned the losses it suffered in carnage a year ago and honored the sense of community that emerged from the ashes.

headline: Norway Returns a Rare Silent Film to China
abstract: A print of “The Cave of the Silken Web,” released in 1927, is believed to be the only existing copy of the film, which was directed by Dan Duyu and is based on an episode from the Chinese classic novel “Journey to the West.”
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:55 a.m.ET | In a gesture that could help ease relations between Norway and China, strained since the awarding of the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize to the imprisoned democracy advocate Liu Xiaobo, the National Library of Norway has returned a long-lost Chinese silent film.

headline: India’s Supreme Court Recognizes 3rd Gender
keywords: ['Gender', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Transgender and Transsexual']
abstract: In a landmark ruling, the Supreme Court directed the central and state governments to give full legal recognition to transgender people.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:29 p.m. | NEW DELHI — In a landmark ruling on Tuesday, the Supreme Court of India allowed transgender people to identify as a third gender and directed the central and state governments to give full legal recognition to them.

headline: New York Today: Tax Day Ritual Recedes
abstract: What you need to know for Tuesday: no more frenzy at the main post office, soaking rains, and a monument to an early baseball star.
lead_paragraph: Good soggy Tuesday to you.

abstract: What you need to know to start your Tuesday: Passover security tightens, a cold spell descends, and Tax Freedom Day cometh.

headline: The Mazda Miata Turns 25
abstract: Tom Voelk, who produces the Times’s video reviews, reveals what’s in his garage: a first edition Mazda Miata. Here’s his personal take on how the car was received when it hit the market 25 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Tom Voelk, who produces the Times’s video reviews, reveals what’s in his garage: a first edition Mazda Miata. Here’s his personal take on how the car was received when it hit the market 25 years ago.

headline: A 25-Year Affair With a Mazda Miata, Still Going Strong
abstract: Tom Voelk continues to drive the 1990 Miata he bought new. It was a purchase that opened up a new career for him.
lead_paragraph: A lot of now-significant pop culture appeared in 1989: Nintendo gave the world the Game Boy; “The Seinfeld Chronicles” were first broadcast on NBC (and yes, they quickly renamed it); Mazda rolled out what has become, for many, the most popular sports car ever produced, the 1990 MX-5 Miata.

headline: Animal Rights Group to Turn Bear-Bile Farm Into Sanctuary
abstract: More than 130 bears are to be turned over to the nonprofit Animals Asia Foundation by a state-owned company in China to be rehabilitated.
lead_paragraph: A state-owned company that raises bears to extract bile for use in traditional Chinese medicine says it will hand over 130 bears to an animal rights group, and the farm where they were raised will be turned into a rehab center. The move marks a major success in the campaign to end the practice of bear-bile farming, which animal rights campaigners call cruel and abusive.

headline: Hedge Fund Manager Makes Lonely Defense of G.M.
abstract: J. Kyle Bass, the hedge fund manager who made a name for himself betting against subprime mortgages, is now betting on General Motors despite its recent troubles.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:42 p.m. |

headline: In Annual Letter, BlackRock Chief Says Firm Will Keep Speaking Out
abstract: Laurence D. Fink wrote that he planned to continue to use the firm’s financial might in speaking out for investors on matters like corporate governance.
lead_paragraph: Over the last 26 years, BlackRock has become one of the biggest investment managers around, with more than $4 trillion under management.

headline: A Non-Techie Tries to Build a Tech Company
abstract: I didn’t know what a line of code looked like, but every potential investor asked the same question: “How are you going to build this?”
lead_paragraph: As a non-techie, I was daunted by the task of starting a technology company, Posse. I had an ambitious idea to build a social network that connects customers and retailers but I didn’t know what a line of code looked like, let alone what language we should use or how to tell a good engineer from a bad one. Like many entrepreneurs, I had a vision but no clue how to execute it.

headline: Motorola Solutions to Sell Enterprise Business for $3.5 Billion
abstract: Zebra Technologies, whose products help companies to track items in the supply chain, will buy much of a Motorola Solutions unit that manufacturers everything from bar-code scanners to radio frequency technologies.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:14 a.m. |

headline: F.B.I. Video Warns of Efforts to Recruit American Students as Spies
abstract: The bureau says it wants American students preparing to be able to recognize when they might be the targets of recruiting efforts by foreign intelligence agencies.
lead_paragraph: The United States government has released a 28-minute video about the case of Glenn Duffie Shriver, an American who took money from Chinese intelligence officers while living in Shanghai and was convicted of trying to acquire United States defense secrets for them.

headline: European Parliament Approves Laws on Banking Overhaul
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The move put in place the final pieces of a landmark plan for managing a banking system whose troubles have dented the bloc’s economic prospects.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — After countless late-night meetings and political skirmishes, the European Union on Tuesday put in place the final pieces of a landmark plan for managing a banking system whose troubles have done so much to dent the bloc’s economy.

headline: Daily Report: Etsy Seeks Wholesaler’s Role in Handicraft Sales
abstract: The company, known for its small-scale artisans and handmade goods, will help some sellers get bigger, and take a commission.
lead_paragraph: Etsy, the popular e-commerce site for handmade, vintage and other artisan items, now has over a million sellers of goods, and the company says it generated $1.35 billion in sales last year. Still, although Internet retailing is a growing market, more than 90 percent of retail commerce still takes place in physical stores, and like many retailers that started online, Etsy wants a piece of that action. Instead of opening locations, Elizabeth A. Harris reports, Etsy wants its sellers to take wholesale orders, so that through them, Etsy can be in thousands of stores at once without ever cutting a rent check.

headline: Ukraine Sends Force to Stem Unrest in East
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'International Relations', 'Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Ukrainian forces stormed an airport outside of Slovyansk that had been held by separatists since Sunday.
lead_paragraph: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — The Ukrainian military landed airborne troops at an airport about 25 miles south of here on Tuesday, raising tensions with Russia in the opening phase of what the government in Kiev called a wider military operation to confront pro-Russian militants in the eastern part of the country.

headline: In Performance: Adrian Lester of ‘Red Velvet’
abstract: The actor performs a scene from Lolita Chakrabarti’s drama about the 19th-century African-American actor Ira Aldridge.
lead_paragraph: This week’s video features Adrian Lester in a scene from Lolita Chakrabarti’s “Red Velvet,” a drama about the 19th-century African-American actor Ira Aldridge. In this scene Mr. Lester, who plays Aldridge, reflects on a painful incident that happened during his days as a young actor. The show, directed by Indhu Rubasingham, continues through April 20 at St. Ann’s Warehouse.

headline: Save the Subjunctive!
abstract: The subjunctive can be tricky to get right. The forms are often hard to distinguish from other verb forms, and the rules for when to use it are complicated. Here are a few recent lapses.
lead_paragraph: Here’s the latest in my series of quixotic pleas on behalf of a dying verb mood.

headline: Fast Home Wireless: A Content Weapon?
abstract: Following a recent announcement by Qualcomm, another semiconductor maker announces a huge upgrade in the speed of wireless home routers. The Broadcom offering is expected to allow all sorts of devices to send video at speeds that make transmitting content as easy as changing channels.
lead_paragraph: Consumers will ultimately choose the winners in the competition among cable companies, television networks, tech giants and others to supply our digital entertainment. We may do it, however, in a way we don’t expect: by the speed of our home networks.

headline: Adding a Religious Holidays Calendar
abstract: Plus how to limit the powers of Windows XP users.
lead_paragraph: Q. Is there any add-on or overlay to add a comprehensive Jewish calendar to my Macintosh Calendar app on OS X 10.9 Mavericks? The current calendar offers a few religious holidays, but by no means all.

headline: Dreaming of Corporate Tax Breaks
abstract: A look at some corporate tax loopholes. | Zebra Technologies is buying Motorola Solutions’ enterprise business. | A courtroom illustrator captures the downfall of Wall Street criminals. | A hedge fund manager bets on G.M. | Google buys a drone maker.
lead_paragraph: A LOOK AT CORPORATE TAX LOOPHOLES  |  Individuals have long sought to take advantage of dozens of tax deductions and loopholes, but corporations have excelled at this game, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column.

headline: 3 Former ICAP Brokers Appear in British Court in Libor Manipulation Case
abstract: At a brief hearing in Westminster Magistrates’ Court, the former brokers Danny Martin Wilkinson, Darrell Paul Read and Colin John Goodman spoke only to confirm their identities.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:13 a.m. | LONDON – Three former brokers at the British financial firm ICAP appeared in court on Tuesday on charges that they conspired to manipulate a global benchmark interest rate.

headline: Desalination Plant Said to Be Planned for Thirsty Beijing
abstract: The project could supply much of the capital’s drinking water by 2019, the state media reported, suggesting a major push to alleviate water shortages.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A coastal desalination plant planned for east of Beijing could provide a large portion of the drinking water for the parched Chinese capital by 2019, the state news media quoted officials as saying on Tuesday. The reports indicated that the government and state enterprises were investing heavily in desalination projects to alleviate a dire water shortage in northern China.

headline: Believe It or Not, a Skeptic’s Journey
abstract: In “Living With a Wild God,” Barbara Ehrenreich traces her mystical side.
lead_paragraph: There are many writers who I wish would declare, as Barbara Ehrenreich does at the start of her new book, “I will never write an autobiography.” But she is not among them.

headline: City University of New York Announces Dance Initiative
abstract: The City University of New York announced on Tuesday a new residency program that will provide choreographers with rehearsal and performance space at the university’s campuses across the five boroughs.
lead_paragraph: It won’t come as a shock to New York-based choreographers to learn that a 2010 report from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation cited “a critical need for affordable dance rehearsal space” in the city. But it might be a surprise to learn that the City University of New York has responded to that report with a new residency program, announced on Tuesday, that will provide rehearsal and performance space at the university’s campuses across the five boroughs.

headline: Troubled Italian Bank May Seek Larger Share Sale
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Monte dei Paschi will try to raise 5 billion euros instead of the expected €3 billion, Italian news reports said, sending shares lower.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Shares of Monte dei Paschi di Siena fell sharply on Tuesday after a report that the troubled Italian bank was seeking to raise substantially more cash than investors had been expecting.

headline: President of Algeria Seeks Fourth Term
abstract: Abdelaziz Bouteflika, president of Algeria for 15 years, is running for another term despite his apparent frail health.
lead_paragraph: Abdelaziz Bouteflika, president of Algeria for 15 years, is running for another term despite his apparent frail health.

headline: The Decision: One Child, One School
keywords: ['Anxiety and Stress', 'Children and Childhood', 'Education (K-12)', 'Education (Pre-School)', 'Families and Family Life', 'Parenting']
abstract: Parents are notoriously anxious yet clueless with their first child. With the preschool decision, I felt additional pressure because after a recent ectopic pregnancy, it looks as if Zee will be our only child.
lead_paragraph: Jon and I binge-read the emails. We had applied to nine preschools for our daughter, and the decisions rolled in: We were in, off earlier wait lists, on new wait lists, we got into the synagogue. (Phew!) One lottery school that rejected us right away invited us to start the entire process from the top. Not happening.

headline: Census Survey Revisions Mask Health Law Effects
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Population']
abstract: Changes to the Census Bureau’s annual survey on health insurance will make it hard to gauge any shift in the number of uninsured; an internal paper called the timing “coincidental and unfortunate.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Census Bureau, the authoritative source of health insurance data for more than three decades, is changing its annual survey so thoroughly that it will be difficult to measure the effects of President Obama’s health care law in the next report, due this fall, census officials said.

headline: Now Screening | Tribeca Premieres Documentary About Raf Simons’s Dior Debut
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Tribeca Film Festival (NYC)']
abstract: For “Dior & I,” the filmmaker Frédéric Tcheng went behind the scenes as the Belgian designed his first collection for the 68-year-old house.
lead_paragraph: “With Raf, we had what you could call a reluctant protagonist,” says the director Frédéric Tcheng of Christian Dior’s artistic director of two years, Raf Simons. “He had always purposefully stayed away from the public eye.” In “Dior & I,” which premieres this week at the Tribeca Film Festival, Tcheng documents the creation of Simons’s first couture collection for the house in spring 2012. Having previously worked on fashion films like “Valentino: The Last Emperor” and “Diana Vreeland: The Eye Has to Travel,” Tcheng was able to gain access to Simons’s famously cloistered world, documenting him as he studied Dior’s s archives, worked in his atelier and visited his childhood home.

headline: The Collections | The Top 10 Moments at Milan Design Week
abstract: T’s design editor rounds up his favorites from this year’s Salone del Mobile.
lead_paragraph: Salone del Mobile, Milan’s annual design week, concluded Sunday. As is custom, the official Salone event — where the biggest furniture companies introduce their latest designs all under one roof, in one of the largest convention centers in the world — was punctuated with a series of special exhibitions called Fourisalone (meaning “outside salone”), put on by local showrooms, shops and museums. And this year, a few underlying themes unified the whole experience. For starters, everyone, it seems, played up the contrast between new and current designs against the historic backdrop of the city. At the center of it all was Rossana Orlandi’s much-talked-about exhibition of contemporary works at the Museo Bagatti Valsecchi, a 19th-century palazzo. “I wanted to create a dialogue between the new and the old,” Orlandi said about the show, “Untold.”

headline: U.N. Cites Abuses in Crimea Before Russia Annexation Vote
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Referendums']
abstract: United Nations officials urged Crimean authorities to account for killings, torture and arbitrary arrests in the buildup to the March referendum.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Amid fears of escalating violence in eastern Ukraine, the United Nations called on Tuesday for action to counter misinformation and hate speech used as propaganda and urged the authorities in Crimea to account for killings, torture and arbitrary arrests in the buildup to the March referendum that led to its annexation by Russia.

headline: Reopening of Picasso Museum in Paris Delayed Again
abstract: The official date has yet to be determined by the Culture Ministry.
lead_paragraph: PARIS – The reopening of the Musée Picasso – closed for more than four years during a renovation and expansion – has been delayed yet again, a museum spokeswoman said Tuesday. Andréa Longrais, the spokeswoman, said no date had been set for its opening and declined to give an explanation for the delay. Since the Picasso museum is under the stewardship of the French government, the official date has to be determined by the Culture Ministry. The building site is all but ready, the lights for the art works are in place and except for a few minor technical items, everything is done, Ms. Longrais added.

headline: Video: Robert Coover Talks About ‘The Brunist Day of Wrath’

lead_paragraph: In “The Read Around,” authors talk about the when, where and how behind their books. Above, Robert Coover discusses “The Brunist Day of Wrath,” a sequel to his 1966 novel “The Origin of the Brunists,” which introduced the fictional religious cult of the title.

headline: Rising Sun
abstract: Why don’t we hear more about the solar revolution?
lead_paragraph: Joe Romm draws our attention to the third slice of the latest IPCC report on climate change, on the costs of mitigation; the panel finds that these costs aren’t that big — a few percent of GDP even by the end of the century, which means only a trivial hit to the growth rate.

headline: How Working Women Help the Economy
abstract: The shift of women into the workplace is one of the less heralded drivers of economic expansion. If American women didn’t work, the economy would be about 11 percent smaller.
lead_paragraph: If someone asked you to name the most important economic trends of the last 30 years, you would probably respond with rising inequality, increasing globalization and fast-paced technological change.

headline: Facebook Requires Users to Install Separate Messaging App
abstract: The social network is removing messaging from its smartphone app, requiring users to install a separate piece of software to restore the feature. Facebook says the strategy will speed up the user experience.
lead_paragraph: You’ve heard of shotgun weddings? Well, Facebook is imposing a shotgun upgrade on everyone who uses its mobile apps. But the company swears you’ll live happier ever after.

headline: Video and Social Media Posts on the Anniversary of the Boston Marathon Bombings

lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:13 p.m. On the first anniversary of the Boston Marathon bombings, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. was among the officials speaking on Tuesday at a tribute for the victims and survivors, as my colleague Katharine Q. Seelye reports.

headline: Supply, Demand, and Unemployment Benefits
abstract: “Regular economics” fails again.
lead_paragraph: Ben Casselman points out that we’ve had a sort of natural experiment in the alleged effects of unemployment benefits in reducing employment. Extended benefits were cancelled at the beginning of this year; have the long-term unemployed shown any tendency to find jobs faster? And the answer is no.

headline: Gallery | Inside the Homes and Studios of the World’s Finest Designers
abstract: In her new book, the photographer Leslie Williamson documents a pilgrimage to the living and working spaces of iconic European talents like Le Corbusier and Alvar Aalto.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Leslie Williamson’s new book, “Modern Originals: At Home With Midcentury European Designers,” out from Rizzoli today, offers an intimate look at the homes and studios of some of Europe’s best known designers, including Le Corbusier, Alvar Aalto, Carlo Mollino, Gae Aulenti and Finn Juhl, alongside lesser known names like Roland Rainer, Joseph Nemec and Renaat Braem. It follows Williamson’s first book, “Handcrafted Modern: At Home With Midcentury Designers” (Rizzoli, 2010). Both titles are part of a larger project Williamson began almost 10 years ago. “I made a dream list of the homes of all the architects and designers I wanted to visit in my lifetime,” she explains. “I’ve always been a fan of design, and I was curious to see how these people — whose work I love and am inspired by — lived themselves.”

abstract: Not all criminal investigations of a company are alike, and there are telltale signs about how serious a threat one may present, writes Peter J. Henning in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: Say a company finds out that it is under investigation for possible criminal violations. Its challenge is to figure out the chances that the investigation will result in charges and the possible impact of those charges on its business. Not all investigations are alike, and there are telltale signs about how serious a threat one may present.

headline: Listen Up | Coachella Newcomer Courtney Barnett on Playing ‘Slacker Rock’ and Life in the Fast Lane
abstract: The buzzy Australian singer-songwriter, who made her U.S. festival debut last weekend, premieres a video from her newly re-released double EP.
lead_paragraph: Speaking before last weekend’s edition of Coachella, Courtney Barnett sounded wiped out. The 26-year-old Australian songwriter, who specializes in a lackadaisical style of slide-guitar music which she has described as “slacker-rock,” had just disembarked in Los Angeles after a 16-hour flight from Melbourne, her hometown, en route to Coachella, her first-ever major festival date. “It’s kind of terrifying, but I haven’t processed it,” she said of her appearance in Indio, which she’ll reprise next Sunday during the festival’s second weekend.

headline: Iran Escalates Dispute Over U.N. Envoy
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Visas', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Even if Iran does have legal grounds to argue that its new ambassador’s rights have been violated, there is little it can do, experts said.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Iran’s increasingly angry protests over the American decision to not grant a visa to its new United Nations ambassador, and the uncertainty over how far the dispute will go, have not only rubbed feelings on both sides raw. They have laid bare the limits of global law when its provisions clash with the interests of the host country, the United States.

headline: A Green Group Sees Hope in ‘The End of China’s Coal Boom’
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Coal', 'Environment', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Temperature', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: Greenpeace sees growing signs that China is heading toward peak coal, putting climate targets within sight.
lead_paragraph: Through much of its history, Greenpeace has been big on what I call “woe is me, shame on you” messaging on the environment. As I explained at a TEDx event in Portland, Ore., over the weekend, fingerpointing (including Greenpeace’s) is appropriate in many instances, but doesn’t work well with human-driven global warming. The blame game too often ends up resembling a circular firing squad.

headline: Yahoo Earnings Offer a Peek at Alibaba’s Big Growth Ahead of Its I.P.O.

headline: A Spicier N.H.L. Playoff Recipe
abstract: With reseeding gone, the league’s postseason now offers fans a bracket resembling the N.C.A.A. tournament. Here’s a look at each series in the first round.
lead_paragraph: Under a new format this season, the N.H.L. playoffs are arranged by division, with no reseeding after each round, resembling an N.C.A.A. tournament bracket. Even though some teams face more difficult matchups than they would have under the previous format, the league got exactly what it wanted: matchups with plenty of spice and the renewal of some good rivalries.

headline: In the Kitchen With Clémentine and Ruth
abstract: The restorative powers of 170 recipes and an old cookbook.
lead_paragraph: Ruth Levy is no pushover. A Bronx native of firm opinions and great vivacity, she decoded Nazi intercepts during World War II and went on to a career in publishing. Along the way she learned to channel her flamboyant sensibilities into sculpture, and somehow managed to badger the redoubtable Martha Graham into teaching her to dance. Though later blind and almost deaf, she has lived on her own, with the help of a health aide, in her Chelsea apartment of 50 years.

headline: Yahoo Profit Is a Footnote to Alibaba’s Huge Gains
abstract: Yahoo’s shareholders are far more excited about what the company owns — namely, 24 percent of Alibaba — than anything the company runs.
