lead_paragraph: Tavern on the Green reopens April 24 after two years of work inside and out on the historic, nearly 150-year-old structure designed by Calvert Vaux and Jacob Wrey Mould.

headline: New York Drops Unit That Spied on Muslims
abstract: A surveillance program begun in 2003 that recorded where people ate and prayed and that was criticized for sowing distrust of law enforcement is no longer functioning, the New York Police Department said.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department has abandoned a secretive program that dispatched plainclothes detectives into Muslim neighborhoods to eavesdrop on conversations and built detailed files on where people ate, prayed and shopped, the department said.

headline: M.I.T.’s Alex Pentland: Measuring Idea Flows to Accelerate Innovation
abstract: Alex Pentland says data, sensors and smartphones are opening the door to what he calls social physics. It is the subject of his new book, about the implications of being able to monitor and measure the flow of ideas in companies, markets and communities as never before. The payoff, he says, should be the acceleration of the pace of innovation.
lead_paragraph: In the 1970s, when he was a student at the University of Michigan, Alex Pentland worked on a government-financed research project that used satellite imaging to study animal life on earth. The focus was the beaver population and the animal’s movements in Canada.

headline: Echoes of ‘Downton Abbey’ on Vacation in England
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Television']
abstract: A trip to Cliveden House opens a window onto the estate’s rich history and evokes scenes from the PBS drama.
lead_paragraph: “Look down there,” my 22-year-old daughter, Harriet, said to me pointing to a window beside us. We were approaching the south terrace of Cliveden House, an estate in Buckinghamshire, England, that for more than 300 years has been the home of dukes, earls, viscounts and, for a short period in the 1700s, Frederick, the Prince of Wales. I turned and caught the quick flash of a knife in the basement kitchen and watched as a young man wearing a navy apron and white uniform expertly peeled shells off langoustines.

headline: Britain’s Working Men’s Clubs Succumb to Modern Life
abstract: Founded more than 150 years ago, these clubs once thrived, with many becoming neighborhood institutions. But, over the past 30 years, half of the clubs have been lost.
lead_paragraph: On a recent evening, over a couple of half-pints of lager (served rather icy, by British standards, at £1.50, or $2.45, each), the writer Ruth Cherrington reclined in the maroon upholstered lounge of the Langham Working Men’s Club in North London. The scene was quiet. The barmaid hovered near the bar’s sole patron: a white-haired gentleman in a leather coat who was watching the BBC’s “Great British Bake Off” on TV. Walls were cluttered with dartboards, billiard scores, trophies and advertisements for bingo nights. “People want something more trendy, that’s the thing,” said Ms. Cherrington, with an apologetic look around the empty space.

headline: A Fresh Take on Easter
abstract: Instead of the usual cured ham, a succulent version that elegantly evokes spring.
lead_paragraph: Norman Van Aken, the Miami chef and restaurateur, will spend Easter weekend this year with family, he said, in Key West, where his career began. On the menu: “Ham for a horde.”

headline: Flailing, Befuddled Youth
abstract: Images of some of the movies in the Tribeca Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: Images of some of the movies in the Tribeca Film Festival.

headline: Yellen Suggests That Fed Will Push to Shore Up Market for Short-Term Debt
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The chairwoman of the Federal Reserve said that the Fed was actively considering measures to strengthen that potential weak spot.
lead_paragraph: A crucial part of Wall Street still keeps federal regulators up at night. But Janet L. Yellen, the chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, said on Tuesday that the Fed was actively considering measures to strengthen that potential weak spot.

headline: Intel’s Profit Slips, but Investors Are Still Turning Toward Tech’s Staid Stalwarts
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: With PC sales falling, the semiconductor maker reported a drop in year-over-year quarterly earnings, to $1.95 billion.
lead_paragraph: For now, in technology stocks, it is nice to be a little old-fashioned.

headline: Italian Touch, With a Taste of Cognac
abstract: Simone Forti and Charlemagne Palestine performed in “Illlummminnnatttionnnsssss!!!!!!!” Sunday at the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Simone Forti and the composer Charlemagne Palestine are old friends. They met in 1970 at the California Institute of the Arts and soon began improvising together in performances called “Illuminations.” But when they gathered together in a fourth-floor gallery at the Museum of Modern Art on Sunday evening, it had been nearly 40 years since they had last staged one of these “Illuminations” in New York. So it was a signal event, with a new title: “Illlummminnnatttionnnsssss!!!!!!!”

headline: Photos That Cross Borders and Challenge Perceptions
abstract: Janet Jarman has followed Marisol from her childhood in Mexico to life as a young mother in the United States, making images that now educate teachers and doctors about immigrant life.
lead_paragraph: Janet Jarman has followed Marisol from her childhood in Mexico to life as a young mother in the United States, making images that now educate teachers and doctors about immigrant life.

headline: Oliver North, Now in the Service of TV’s K.G.B.
abstract: Mr. North provided the producers of “The Americans” with so much detail and color for an upcoming episode that he earned a story credit.
lead_paragraph: When the producers of the FX series “The Americans,” an espionage thriller set in the early 1980s, began preparing a story line about the government’s covert efforts to help contra rebels in Nicaragua, they wanted to consult with someone well versed in this chapter of recent history.

headline: An Ache, and Pluck, That Linger in a Heart
abstract: Ashley Monroe, a country singer and member of the Pistol Annies, appeared at Joe’s Pub on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Somewhere past the halfway point of Ashley Monroe’s second show at Joe’s Pub on Monday night, nestled between puckish but armored tunes called “Dixie” and “Unhappily Married,” there came a bittersweet new song with a softer story to tell. It was a ballad, “From Time to Time,” in the form of a dead father’s message to his daughter. “Someday you’ll be fine, sweet as wine,” Ms. Monroe sang in the chorus. “It’s all right to remember/From time to time.”

headline: Narcissism (Smile!), Set to a Thumping Beat
abstract: The Chainsmokers, a dance music duo, performed their hit “#Selfie” and other numbers at the Highline Ballroom.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps every social trend gets the anthem it deserves, but the selfie generation deserves something a little more imaginative and nurturing than “#Selfie,” by the New York dance music duo the Chainsmokers.

headline: Where Humbert Humbert Might Whisper in Your Ear
abstract: At the Mid-Manhattan Library, actors performed provocative scenes from books once banned in the United States as part of the library’s exhibition, “Secret Society of Forbidden Literature.”
lead_paragraph: There was something strange going on at the Mid-Manhattan Library on Monday night. If regular patrons glanced up, they might wonder why a blond girl in a colorful sundress and two long fishtail braids was walking people over to a corner, making them swear an oath against animal cruelty, then running away. Or why a man took groups of two behind a bookshelf to show them a beetle and talk about Franz Kafka.

headline: Notes of Orange, Apple and Brooklyn
abstract: What’s that in the air — spring? Ah, no, it’s the scents from Twisted Lily and Atelier Cologne, two new perfume shops in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: “THIS ROOM DIFFUSER IS LIKE EXCALIBUR,” said Ginger Partington, the tall and bodacious vendeuse at Twisted Lily, an upscale perfume store that has been inexorably wending its way around (I’m not going to say choking) the longtime essential-oil purveyors of Boerum Hill, Brooklyn.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about today’s biggest stories.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Architects Mourn Former Folk Art Museum Building
abstract: Tod Williams, one of the architects of the former Folk Art Museum, spoke Tuesday about the Museum of Modern Art’s decision to tear it down.
lead_paragraph: As scaffolding went up around the former Folk Art Museum building on Tuesday, one of its two architects broke his silence to say how devastated he and his partner are about the Museum of Modern Art’s decision to tear down “one of our most important buildings to date.”

headline: Moelis & Co. Prices Its I.P.O. at $25 a Share, Below Expectations
abstract: The pricing suggests that not even a strongly performing investment bank can escape the chill that has entered the I.P.O. market.
lead_paragraph: Shares in publicly traded investment banks haven’t fared well so far this year. Investors are betting that Moelis & Company, a seven-year-old boutique founded by a veteran deal maker, will do better.

headline: Getting a College Degree in Prison
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Education (K-12)', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: Readers, speaking from their experiences as a prison teacher, an inmate and a parent, laud education programs for prisoners.

headline: Angelika Taschen on the Ever-Changing Magic of Berlin
abstract: To mark the release of her new book “Berlin Street Style,” the L.A. expat shares her favorite places for eating, shopping and taking in the fashion scene in her adopted hometown.
lead_paragraph: When Angelika Taschen speaks of Berlin, her passion is palpable. Words like “outstanding” and “beautiful” are affectionately spun into the conversation, and her soft German accent bounces with enthusiasm. “This city has risen from the ashes to become something very magical,” she says. “It is constantly changing, so there is always something new to discover – I love it.”

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
abstract: Notable properties that have been recently listed for sale, sold or leased.
lead_paragraph: RECENT SALE

headline: Free School Lunch for All
abstract: Samuel E. Abrams of Teachers College, Columbia University, responds to an editorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Medicare and Eye Doctors
keywords: ['Cataracts', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare', 'Surgery and Surgeons', 'Doctors']
abstract: The American Society of Cataract and Refractive Surgery responds to a news article, “Sliver of Medicare Doctors Get Big Share of Payouts.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Comcast-Time Warner Cable Deal
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Television', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Cable Television', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: David Balto, an antitrust lawyer, lists the benefits of a merger.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Teaching Children to Be Kind and Compassionate
abstract: Readers react to a Sunday Review article about raising children.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: His Résumé Before the Age of 4: ‘I Saw Jesus on a Horse’
abstract: The 2010 best-selling book “Heaven Is for Real” has made it to the screen, starring Greg Kinnear.
lead_paragraph: The wooing of religious moviegoers — a delicate operation, as the “Noah” backlash attests — has been ramping up lately, with major players like Ridley Scott and Ben Kingsley mining the Bible for box office gold. But if there’s such a thing as a safe bet in this genre, it’s “Heaven Is for Real,” a Christian sermon that even the most doctrinaire believer can applaud.

headline: In Corporate Monitor, a Well-Paying Job but Unknown Results
abstract: A compliance supervisor is hired ensure that a company accused of wrongdoing does not break the law again, but the concept is problematic, writes Steven Davidoff in the Deal Professor.

headline: PET Scans Offer Clues on Vegetative States
abstract: A study found that a significant number of people labeled vegetative had received an incorrect diagnosis and actually had some degree of consciousness and the potential to improve.
lead_paragraph: People with severe brain injuries sometimes emerge from a coma awake but unresponsive, leaving families with painful questions. Are they aware? Can they think and feel? Do they have any chance of recovery?

headline: In Nigeria, Terrorism Moves South
abstract: Our government needs whatever help it can get.
lead_paragraph: ABUJA, Nigeria — LATE last month, a workman on his way to my house rang to explain that he was running late because of the mayhem caused by a bomb blast in the city. Instantly, I was skeptical. There couldn’t possibly be another bomb in Abuja. Not with all the tedious checkpoints on major streets here, and the thorough checks at the entrance to public buildings.

headline: Two Artistic Outlooks, Heightened Side by Side
abstract: Two artists, Mary Frank and Tacita Dean, play roles in two documentaries being shown together at Film Forum.
lead_paragraph: The artists Tacita Dean and Mary Frank might not make the most obvious pair, but they share space — and explore it — in a portmanteau program at Film Forum. Ms. Dean’s latest film experiment, “JG,” traces time in stark outlines with desolate landscapes, triptychs and some dazzling cutout techniques, all of which are followed by “Visions of Mary Frank,” a comradely portrait of that sculptor by the musician and documentarian John Cohen.

headline: Tensions Boil Over on Camera in Ukraine’s East and West
abstract: Video shot by local journalists showed a general and a politician being beaten by mobs in the east and the west of the country.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Andrew Kramer reports, Ukraine moved to blunt the momentum of separatist rebels in the east of the country, launching a military operation to secure an air base in Kramatorsk, where the police headquarters was seized last weekend.

headline: Steven B. Greenberg
abstract: Mr. Greenberg is a founder and the president of the Greenberg Group, a real estate advisory and brokerage company that focuses on retailers.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Greenberg, 67, is a founder and the president of the Greenberg Group, a real estate advisory and brokerage company based in Hewlett, N.Y., that focuses on retailers. Clients include the luxury brands Gucci and Façonnable.

headline: Nasal Spray Holds Hope in Fighting Flu Epidemic
abstract: A new method, still being tested, would coat receptors in the throat and nose before influenza viruses attach.
lead_paragraph: Scottish and American scientists have found a new way to prevent flu infections that could, in theory, be used to fight an epidemic long before a vaccine is ready.

headline: Chevrolet Trax: The Big News Is Old News
abstract: The mini S.U.V. is already sold in 140 countries, and it’s coming to the United States next year.
lead_paragraph: Chevrolet doesn’t have a lot to talk about at this year’s New York auto show, but the company is making the most of what’s at least partially new in its lineup.

headline: Days of Tea and Honey: Memories of a Quiet Iraq
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A look back at a time when Marines thought Iraq had finally achieved a tentative peace and were able to take time to simply share a meal with elders.
lead_paragraph: Six months ago, a suicide bomber killed 13 children at a school playground in Qabak, Iraq, a town near Tal Afar in the northern province of Nineveh. I was dismayed to read the news. My platoon visited Qabak often during our deployment in 2009. It was quiet then. Iraq, we thought, had finally achieved a tentative peace.

headline: A London Guide for 1 Police Plaza
abstract: The influence of Sir Robert Peel, the father of the British capital’s police force, is evident throughout the department led by William J. Bratton.
lead_paragraph: Since returning as commissioner of the New York Police Department, William J. Bratton has been generous in thanking those who helped him get here: the mayor, Bill de Blasio, for the job; his wife, Rikki Klieman, for her support; even a children’s book, for igniting his boyhood fascination with the police.

headline: Tech Leaps, Job Losses and Rising Inequality
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Income Inequality', 'Wages and Salaries', 'United States Economy', 'Science and Technology', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: For 50 years, economic consensus has held that new machines lift demand for skilled workers. But what if technology has become a substitute for labor?
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to overstate the excitement of tech people about what is on the verge of happening to the practice of medicine.

headline: Veterans and White Supremacy
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Terrorism', 'Neo Nazi Groups', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Hate Crimes']
abstract: The Kansas shooter had a long history of hate. Why wasn’t he stopped?
lead_paragraph: EVANSTON, Ill. — WHEN Frazier Glenn Miller shot and killed three people in Overland Park, Kan., on Sunday, he did so as a soldier of the white power movement: a groundswell that united Klansmen, neo-Nazis and other fringe elements after the Vietnam War, crested with the bombing of the Oklahoma City federal building in 1995, and remains a diminished but potent threat today.

headline: The Civil War Death Toll, Reconsidered
abstract: Have the horrors of America’s bloodiest conflict been overblown — or at least misunderstood?
lead_paragraph: What did the Civil War’s death toll mean to those who lived through it? We are now told that wartime deaths were unprecedented and overwhelming, and constituted one of the fundamental experiences for the wartime generation. But is this really true?

headline: Changes in Store for ‘American Masters’ on PBS
abstract: The series will broaden its focus from arts and culture to include science and industry.
lead_paragraph: “American Masters,” the award-winning 28-year-old PBS biography series that has traditionally chronicled the lives of prominent Americans in arts and culture, is getting a broader purview as well as a new executive producer.

headline: Sir Robert Peel’s Nine Principles of Policing
abstract: The principles, often cited by Police Commissioner William J. Bratton, define the basic mission of the police as prevention.
lead_paragraph: Police Commissioner William J. Bratton lists the following guidelines on his blog. There is some doubt among scholars that Sir Robert Peel actually enunciated any of his nine principles himself — some researchers say they were formulated in 1829 by the two first commissioners of London’s Metropolitan Police Department.

headline: When Is Foreign Aid Meddling?
abstract: With the revelations that a U.S. agency secretly developed a Twitter-like network for Cuba, we ask experts if the United States is justified in using assistance to promote democracy and other political changes abroad?

headline: Marine Is Disciplined for Drinking on Presidential Trip
keywords: ['ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Cpl. Korey Nathan Pritchett was removed from embassy security detail after he consumed alcohol in the hours before reporting for duty in the Netherlands, where President Obama attended a summit meeting last month.
lead_paragraph: The Marine Corps has removed a Marine from embassy security detail after he broke a rule against consuming alcohol in the hours before reporting for duty in the Netherlands, where President Obama attended a summit meeting last month, a spokesman said. The Marine, Cpl. Korey Nathan Pritchett, had been drinking within eight hours of working security as part of a temporary assignment for the president’s trip, the spokesman said Tuesday. Corporal Pritchett has been reassigned from duty at the embassy in Montenegro, but details of his new posting were not announced. The spokesman also declined to discuss other disciplinary measures against Corporal Pritchett.

headline: Early Data in E-Cigarette Study May Raise Safety Concerns
abstract: The study, still in a preliminary stage, found that lung cells exposed to e-cigarette vapor showed cancerous reactions similar to cells exposed to tobacco smoke.
lead_paragraph: A laboratory study presented early this year reported that the nicotine-laced vapor generated by an electronic cigarette promoted the development of cancer in certain types of human cells much in the same way that tobacco smoke does.

headline: In Yonkers, a Shuttered Jail Becomes Part of a Budding Art Scene
keywords: ['Art', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Museums']
abstract: The renovation of the Yonkers City Jail into an art space is part of a push by Mayor Mike Spano to develop the waterfront and make it a place where young people want to live.
lead_paragraph: YONKERS — Mayor Mike Spano looked out at the waterfront here and decided it was no place for a jail. So last year he put the Yonkers City Jail up for sale.

headline: For Hockey’s Version of Pairs Skaters, Points Aren’t for Style
abstract: As coach of the Montreal Canadiens in the 1970s, Scotty Bowman introduced the idea of high-chemistry center-wing combinations and an interchangeable third forward.
lead_paragraph: Ryan Getzlaf and Corey Perry were born in Canada six days apart. They were drafted by Anaheim in the first round of the 2003 N.H.L. draft nine picks apart. They made the Ducks together in 2006-7.

headline: Not the Same Old, Same Old
abstract: We’re not dealing anymore with your grandfather’s Israel, and they’re not dealing anymore with your grandmother’s America either.
lead_paragraph: At first, the article in The Jerusalem Post last week seemed like the same old, same old: A picture of a ransacked Israel Defense Forces post in the West Bank. Then a quote from Defense Minister Moshe Yaalon: “The State of Israel will not tolerate such criminal activity, which is terrorism in all respects.” Those Palestinians will never quit.

headline: Milan Court Gives Berlusconi a Year of Community Service
abstract: The former prime minister’s sentence, of four hours a week at a home for the elderly, was imposed as an alternative to a year in prison for tax fraud.
lead_paragraph: ROME — For a man who attracted headlines — and legal trouble — for cavorting with bevies of young, and sometimes very young, women, being forced to spend time with people closer to his own age may be a bitter pill for Silvio Berlusconi.

headline: Washington Retail District’s Future Rides on Streetcars
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Cable Cars and Trams', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: This summer, after 65 years, streetcars will again travel the former H Street NE shopping district and hopes are high that they will drive development.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The streetcars stopped running in 1949, replaced by buses. In the wake of the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. the 1968 riots devastated the commercial corridor. Only in recent years has revitalization occurred and gentrification taken hold.

headline: Sue Townsend, Creator of Adrian Mole Books, Dies at 68
abstract: Ms. Townsend beat the odds of a difficult early life to become one of Britain’s most popular writers.
lead_paragraph: Sue Townsend, who beat the odds of a difficult early life to become one of Britain’s most popular writers and social critics, chronicling life on the economic fringes of post-imperial Britain with insight and wit, died on Thursday in Leicester, England. She was 68.

headline: Talk About Income Inequality: De Blasio Is No Bloomberg, Tax Returns Confirm
abstract: Newly released documents revealed the stark contrast between Mayor Bill de Blasio and his billionaire predecessor, Michael R. Bloomberg, as well as Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.
lead_paragraph: No beachfront acquisitions in the Hamptons. No lavish household expenses.

headline: Unpaid Interns Gain the Right to Sue
keywords: ['Internships', 'Law and Legislation', 'Discrimination', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio signed a bill that extends harassment and discrimination protections to many of the unpaid young workers who flock to New York City in the summer.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of interns poised to flood New York City’s offices and institutions this summer may be unpaid. But come June, their legal standing will be improved.

headline: Tech Companies Commit to Offering a ‘Kill Switch’ for Preventing Phone Theft
abstract: CTIA, the industry trade group that represents wireless carriers, said over a dozen companies were dedicated to offering free antitheft software on cellphones.
lead_paragraph: To combat phone theft, several lawmakers over the last year have put pressure on manufacturers and wireless carriers to include smarter antitheft technology on smartphones. A group of tech and phone companies on Tuesday said they were on board with the idea.

headline: A Tough Transition for Women’s Triathlon
abstract: The N.C.A.A. in January adopted women’s triathlon as an “emerging sport,” giving it a decade to attract at least 40 varsity teams, but so far, universities’ commitment has been lacking.
lead_paragraph: Triathlons can be grueling tests of endurance and grit, but the sport itself is facing a challenging course among N.C.A.A. programs.

headline: ‘Turketarian’ or ‘Meatatarian’? It’s All in the ‘Framily’
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Online Advertising', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'English Language']
abstract: Campaigns featuring coined and made-up words are increasingly prevalent on television, in print, online and in social media.
lead_paragraph: THE saying “the Greeks had a word for it” is getting a Madison Avenue makeover as marketers serve up more words of their own in place of real ones.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 15, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Bloomberg Plans a $50 Million Challenge to the N.R.A.
abstract: Michael R. Bloomberg, the former mayor of New York City, said that gun control advocates had to learn from the National Rifle Association and punish those politicians who fail to support their agenda.
lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg, making his first major political investment since leaving office, plans to spend $50 million this year building a nationwide grass-roots network to motivate voters who feel strongly about curbing gun violence, an organization he hopes can eventually outmuscle the National Rifle Association.

headline: Parking Rules
abstract: Alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Because of Good Friday (Orthodox), alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Friday. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: Otto Petersen, the Voice of Vulgarity, Dies at 53
abstract: Mr. Petersen was the flesh-and-blood half of Otto and George, a comedy team whose act was so scurrilous that it once proved too much for a historically thick-skinned crowd.
lead_paragraph: Otto Petersen, a ventriloquist who was the flesh-and-blood half of Otto and George, a comedy team renowned for vulgarity so stunning as to make Rabelais look like a church picnic, died on Sunday at his home in Keyport, N.J. He was 53.

headline: Texas Twins Campaign, but They Aren’t Sure for What
keywords: ['Hispanic-Americans', 'Elections', 'Voting and Voters', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: While Mayor Julián Castro of San Antonio and Representative Joaquin Castro have projected a fresh Latino face for the Democratic Party, some are concerned they are too politically cautious.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO, Tex. — Mayor Julián Castro of San Antonio faced off in a televised debate on Tuesday against a Republican candidate for Texas lieutenant governor, even though Mr. Castro, officially anyway, is not running for anything at all.

headline: Look-Up Line Would Warn Danger’s Ahead for Amateur Hockey Players
abstract: The Look-Up Line would warn players they are near the boards, where severe head and neck injuries frequently occur.
lead_paragraph: Despite a series of rule changes and awareness campaigns aimed at eliminating spinal cord trauma, amateur hockey players continue to sustain paralyzing injuries from crashing into the boards. Tom Smith of Swampscott, Mass., had the extraordinary misfortune to incur two separate spinal injuries, in 2008 and 2009.

headline: Fresh Off Pulitzer Win, The Globe Tentatively Toasts Its Future
keywords: ['Newspapers', 'News and News Media', 'Pulitzer Prizes', 'Boston Marathon Bombings (2013)']
abstract: The Boston Globe won a Pulitzer on Monday for its reporting on the marathon bombing. The muted ceremony was also a celebration of the resiliency of New England’s largest paper.
lead_paragraph: When The Boston Globe won a Pulitzer on Monday for its reporting on the bombing at the city’s marathon last year, the newspaper’s editor, Brian McGrory, asked for a minute of silence before praising the journalists involved in the coverage, each one by name.

headline: City Explores Ways to Curb Taxi Speeds
keywords: ['Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Speed Limits and Speeding']
abstract: The Taxi and Limousine Commission has issued a request for information concerning “anti-speeding vehicle technologies,” including anti-speeding devices for cars.
lead_paragraph: For generations, the back-seat drivers of New York City have coached their cabbies to step on it. Soon, a very different message may be coming from the front seat.

headline: Mr. Putin’s Power Play
abstract: The Russian president claims to see chaos and threats in Kiev and Ukraine, but nobody outside Russia is buying his story.
lead_paragraph: When President Vladimir Putin of Russia talks about what is happening in Ukraine these days, it is as if he’s looking into a mirror. He says fascists and nationalists are running amok in Kiev, even as Crimea is annexed in the name of Great Russia; he says Russians are threatened in eastern Ukraine, even as Russia directs secessionists there to seize administrative buildings and arms; he calls on President Obama to use his influence to prevent the use of force in Ukraine, even as he puts a major military force on the Ukrainian border.

headline: Better Rules for Bad Lawyers
keywords: ['Legal Profession', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'States (US)', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Editorials']
abstract: New York needs to adopt uniform standards for disciplining lawyers if citizens are to have confidence in those who represent them.
lead_paragraph: In 2009, a lawyer in New York helped his client settle a claim for $30,000. The lawyer then had the check issued in his own name, deposited it into his own account and used all of the funds for himself. The client demanded his money to no avail.

headline: Across Athens, Graffiti Worth a Thousand Words of Malaise
abstract: The five-year economic collapse in Greece has spawned a new burst of creative energy that has turned Athens into a contemporary mecca for street art in Europe.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — The young man climbed a 30-foot scaffold on a building in central Athens and dipped a brush into a tray of gray paint. With rapid flicks of his wrist, he outlined a haunting image: a baby with two faces, looking simultaneously into an abyss and toward the sky, its vacant eyes searching for a future that was not there.

headline: Video of Suspect in Shooting Case
abstract: The police are seeking the public’s help to identify a suspect who shot two people, including a 13-year-old bystander, on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn on Monday at around noon.
lead_paragraph: The police are seeking the public’s help to identify a suspect who shot two people, including a 13-year-old bystander, on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn on Monday at around noon.

headline: After Being Shot, Boy Comforted Family
abstract: A 13-year-old Brooklyn boy who was shot twice in the head on Monday stands a 90 percent chance of losing his right eye, his family said.
lead_paragraph: A 13-year-old Brooklyn boy who was shot twice in the head stands a 90 percent chance of losing his right eye, his family said Tuesday. But they added that luck saved him from even worse harm.

headline: Pineda Set to Face Unwanted Scrutiny
abstract: There will be no way for the Yankees’ Michael Pineda to sidestep what lies ahead, when he pitches against the Cubs, after a substance was spotted on his pitching hand in his last outing.
lead_paragraph: There will be no way for Michael Pineda to sidestep what lies ahead Wednesday night, when he pitches against the Chicago Cubs. For all he has accomplished this season in finally returning to the major leagues and performing effectively, he will find himself being scrutinized because of the mysterious substance that was spotted on his pitching hand during his outing last week against the Boston Red Sox.

headline: Russia Is Quick to Bend Truth About Ukraine
abstract: Misinformation, exaggerations, conspiracy theories, overheated rhetoric and outright lies about the political crisis in Ukraine have emanated from the highest echelons of the Kremlin.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Facebook post on Tuesday morning by Prime Minister Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia was bleak and full of dread.

headline: A Cleanup Plan for a Toxic River
abstract: It is past time to rehabilitate the Passaic River in New Jersey, one of America’s oldest industrial dumping grounds.
lead_paragraph: The inventory of pollutants at the bottom of the Passaic River, which meanders for 90 miles through northern New Jersey, is long and truly frightening. More than a century of industrial activity has deposited PCBs, pesticides and other contaminants into sediment that, in some places, is 15 feet deep. Among the worst of the poisons is dioxin, generated in part by a plant in Newark that produced Agent Orange and other deadly pesticides during the 1960s.

headline: Cruel Truths Always Survive a Shooting
abstract: “The Library,” the director Steven Soderbergh’s maiden outing on the New York stage, opened on Tuesday at the Public Theater.
lead_paragraph: Toxic dread floods the opening minutes of “The Library,” which opened on Tuesday night at the Public Theater, and good luck to the audience member who prefers not to be disturbed. It isn’t just the sight of the girl on the table, laid out like a corpse at a mortuary, which greets theatergoers arriving at Scott Z. Burns’s new play.

headline: Game of Drones
abstract: It just might be the right time for a “Top Gun” sequel, considering we’re already on the highway to the danger zone.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It will be tough to go into the big battle against drones without the irrepressible Goose.

headline: Headline of April 16, 1912
abstract: A sober reminder from Michael Dewey.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle by Michael Dewey is an acknowledgment of the tragedy that befell the people aboard the TITANIC in the early morning hours of April 15, 1912. Mr. Dewey tells us more about why the puzzle is running now in his notes below, so let’s move on to the puzzle.

headline: G.M. Chief Cites New Safety Moves and Says Repairs Are Now Underway
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Consumer Protection', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: In her first public appearance since receiving withering criticism from Congress, Mary T. Barra said General Motors was making changes to ensure that addressing safety defects would never again be so delayed.
lead_paragraph: General Motors’ chief executive, Mary T. Barra, reiterated her vow on Tuesday to root out the cause of the long delay in its recall of defective cars and to make sure that safety defects are never again buried in the automaker’s bureaucracy.

headline: More Talks Expected in ‘Central Park Five’ Lawsuit
keywords: ['Central Park Jogger Case (1989)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Sex Crimes', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: Lawyers for New York City said in a court filing on Tuesday that they expected to resume settlement talks in the lawsuit by five men convicted in the 1989 rape of a jogger in Central Park.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for New York City said in a court filing on Tuesday that they expected to be able to resume settlement talks shortly in the protracted lawsuit by five men convicted in the 1989 rape of a jogger in Central Park, and would work to resolve the case by the end of May.

headline: General and Former Defense Official Urge Nonlethal Military Aid for Ukraine
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Foreign Aid']
abstract: Gen. Wesley K. Clark and Philip A. Karber say that equipment like body armor and night goggles could help Ukraine face a Russian attack.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ukraine’s military has an urgent need for nonlethal military assistance like body armor, night-vision goggles, communications gear and aviation fuel to defend against a potential Russian attack, according to a new analysis by a former NATO commander and a former Pentagon official.

headline: More Shipments, New Accidents and Calls for Safety
keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A sharp increase in rail shipments of oil over the past decade has been accompanied by accidents and derailments that have renewed the debate about regulating transportation of hazardous materials. The shipments are regulated by federal authorities; state and local officials have little say. Despite warnings of safety risks, measures to restrict or ban such transportation have been defeated.
lead_paragraph: A sharp increase in rail shipments of oil over the past decade has been accompanied by accidents and derailments that have renewed the debate about regulating transportation of hazardous materials. The shipments are regulated by federal authorities; state and local officials have little say. Despite warnings of safety risks, measures to restrict or ban such transportation have been defeated.

headline: Despite Rise in Spills, Hazardous Cargo Rides Rails in Secret
keywords: ['Railroads', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Railroad Accidents and Safety', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: As alarmed communities complain about dangerous cargo running on the tracks through their towns, new rules for handling such cargo are set to take effect.
lead_paragraph: Jodi Ross, town manager in Westford, Mass., did not expect she would be threatened with arrest after she and her fire chief went onto the railroad tracks to find out why a train carrying liquid petroleum gas derailed on a bridge in February.

headline: Social Messages on Athenian Walls
abstract: The anguish of the times has increasingly crept into the elaborate stencil work and multitude of large, colorful murals found all over the city.
lead_paragraph: The anguish of the times has increasingly crept into the elaborate stencil work and multitude of large, colorful murals found all over the city.

headline: Arizona: Law Signed to Allow Surprise Inspections at Abortion Clinics
abstract: Gov. Jan Brewer on Tuesday signed the bill allowing health inspectors to carry out the inspections without a court-approved warrant.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Jan Brewer on Tuesday signed a bill allowing health inspectors to carry out surprise inspections on abortion clinics without having to get a court-approved warrant. The law, which passed Arizona’s Republican-led Senate last week on a partisan vote, subjects abortion clinics to the same inspection requirements applied to other medical facilities, to which warrantless inspections are the norm. Opponents argued that it invites harassment in a state hostile to abortions. Arizona is regarded as having one of the most restrictive set of abortion controls in the nation.

headline: Brazil’s Star, Petrobras, Is Hobbled by Scandal and Stagnation
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Foreign Investments', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Petrobras has recently come to symbolize disarray in Brazil’s sluggish economy and the reassessment of growth prospects in emerging markets.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — No company has embodied Brazil’s rise like the oil giant Petrobras.

headline: In Syria, a Show of Democracy Amid Destruction
abstract: The plans for elections reflect a growing assurance by President Bashar al-Assad that insurgents no longer pose a credible threat to overthrow him.
lead_paragraph: HOMS, Syria — The center of this city is a blockaded, insurgent-held war zone, its skyline jagged with broken concrete. Ringing it is a patchwork of scarred neighborhoods, some functioning but fearful, some crammed with the displaced, others reduced to bombed-out shells where only soldiers move. Much of Homs is scarcely fit for human habitation, never mind a safe and peaceful exercise in democracy.

headline: At U.N., a Grim Viewing of Alleged Syrian Torture
keywords: ['Torture', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Photography']
abstract: A panel of experts hired by the Qatar government says pictures of mutilated, skeletal corpses are direct evidence of killings of detainees.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Members of a deeply divided United Nations Security Council spent two hours on Tuesday morning looking at pictures of mutilated, skeletal corpses that were said to have been taken by a former Syrian Army photographer.

headline: As Credit Dries Up, Smaller Companies in China Feel the Pinch
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Interest Rates', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: Exorbitant interest rates and a scarcity of loans have turned financing into a challenge for those without the political connections to borrow at regulated rates.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Hunan Xinwei Bags Company, a manufacturer of knapsacks and handbags, is struggling to survive. The Chinese economy is slowing. Wages are rising amid a shortage of blue-collar workers. And competition from countries like Vietnam is growing.

headline: Britain: New Surveillance Chief Named
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Britain on Tuesday named Robert Hannigan as the next director of its electronic surveillance agency, GCHQ.
lead_paragraph: Britain on Tuesday named Robert Hannigan as the next director of its electronic surveillance agency, GCHQ, which last year came under scrutiny for widespread spying alongside the United States’ National Security Agency. Mr. Hannigan, 49, who has been director general of defense and intelligence at the Foreign Office since 2010, will take over from Iain Lobban when he steps down in the fall, Foreign Secretary William Hague announced. Officials have denied that Mr. Lobban’s departure is linked to the controversy over the close relationship between GCHQ and the N.S.A., which was revealed in documents leaked by the former American intelligence contractor Edward J. Snowden. Under pressure to be more transparent, Mr. Lobban became the first head of the agency last November to give evidence in public before lawmakers.

headline: The Hague: Charges Stand for Mladic
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Judges on Tuesday refused to throw out two charges of genocide against the former Bosnian Serb military commander Ratko Mladic, saying there is enough evidence for his war-crimes trial to continue on all counts.
lead_paragraph: Judges on Tuesday refused to throw out two charges of genocide against the former Bosnian Serb military commander Ratko Mladic, saying there is enough evidence for his war-crimes trial to continue on all counts. Under tribunal rules, charges can be dropped if evidence is seen as insufficient after the prosecution rests its case, which it did this year. Over the course of 200 hours, prosecutors brought 164 live witnesses and used thousands of documents — including Mr. Mladic’s own war logs — to make their case. Among other charges, Mr. Mladic, 72, is accused of waging a campaign of ethnic cleansing to drive non-Serbs from ethnically mixed regions of the former Yugoslavia, and of involvement in the mass killing of more than 7,000 unarmed men in Srebrenica.

headline: Canada: 5 Students Killed in Alberta
abstract: A guest at an end-of-semester party in Calgary, Alberta, stabbed and killed five other university students early Tuesday morning, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A guest at an end-of-semester party in Calgary, Alberta, stabbed and killed five other university students early Tuesday morning, the police said. Rick Hanson, Calgary’s police chief, said no obvious event or remark seemed to lead to the killings. The four men and one woman who died were each stabbed several times with a knife their attacker found in the house, and the police said they were all students at the University of Calgary in their 20s. Officers arrested a man near the house who was described as an invited guest and the son of a veteran of the police force. News reports said the suspect was a law student at the university.

headline: Mets’ Lagares Takes Detour to the Disabled List
abstract: After raving about Juan Lagares for weeks, the Mets placed him on the 15-day disabled list after he pulled his right hamstring running to first base Monday.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — The Mets had raved about Juan Lagares for weeks. How he was maturing as a hitter. How he knew the strike zone. How he was coming into his own.

headline: Growth Rose 7.4% in First Quarter, China Reports
abstract: The year-on-year growth was the slowest since the third quarter of 2012.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Confirming the concerns of investors and economists, the Chinese government announced on Wednesday morning that the country’s inflation-adjusted economic output in the first quarter was up 7.4 percent from a year ago — and had risen much less than that, compared with the previous quarter.

headline: A New York Rivalry Takes an Uneven Turn
abstract: The stage was set before the season for heated conflict between the Knicks and the Nets, but the competition never materialized, mostly because only one team was any good.
lead_paragraph: It was the sight of Carmelo Anthony in street clothes Tuesday at Barclays Center that emphasized how diminished the supposed rivalry between the Knicks and the Nets had become over this regular season.

headline: Abortion Endures as a Political Tripwire
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision)']
abstract: While same-sex marriage has lost some of its potency as an electoral issue, opponents of Roe v. Wade are getting bolder.
lead_paragraph: Why is there such a difference in the durability of two foundational issues of American conservatism: gay marriage and abortion?

headline: As Season Nears End, Wizards Can Rise or Fall
abstract: The Wizards, the sixth seed entering Tuesday’s games, could rise to No. 5 or fall to No. 7 depending on the results of the remaining games.
lead_paragraph: The 16 playoff teams are already known, but heading into the N.B.A.’s final day of the regular season on Wednesday, there is still jockeying to be done. No team has more to gain, or lose, than the Washington Wizards.

headline: SoftBank Shares Get Lift From Alibaba, Too
abstract: Yahoo isn’t the only company tagging along for Alibaba’s magic carpet ride. Shares in the Japanese telecommunications company closed 8.5 percent higher in Tokyo.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Yahoo isn’t the only company tagging along for Alibaba’s magic carpet ride.

headline: ‘Fargo’ Recap: Making Way for Marge and Lester
abstract: In Fargo, winter never leaves.
lead_paragraph: In Fargo, winter never leaves. The premiere of “Fargo” on FX resurrects all those parkas, earflaps and never-ending white fields of the stuff we grew so tired of this year.

headline: The Three Breakout Stars of the Milan Furniture Fair
abstract: While this year’s Salone offered tons of star power, there were also promising young talents if you knew where to look, most notably Ferréol Babin, Vera & Kyte and David/Nicolas.
lead_paragraph: At last week’s Milan Furniture Fair, you couldn’t turn around without bumping into a project by a heavy hitter like Patricia Urquiola, Scholten & Baijings, Barber Osgerby, Konstantin Grcic or the Bouroullec brothers. With many design manufacturers still struggling five years after the financial crisis, it’s little wonder that they are relying more than ever on star power. But even so, the rise of blogs, e-commerce and limited-edition design has made it easier than ever for young, independent talents to flourish, and they are producing and exhibiting their own work without having to wait around for big brands to show interest. There was no shortage of up-and-comers in Milan last week if you knew where to look, from the halls of Rossana Orlandi’s gallery to the Lambrate district to the Satellite section of the Salone itself. Here are three of this year’s standouts.

headline: Revised SAT Won’t Include Obscure Vocabulary Words
abstract: The College Board plans to release many details of its revised test on Wednesday, including sample questions and explanations of the research and goals behind them.
lead_paragraph: The College Board on Wednesday will release many details of its revised SAT, including sample questions and explanations of the research, goals and specifications behind them.

headline: Younger Skin Through Exercise
abstract: Exercise appears to slow and even reverse the effects of aging on the skin.
lead_paragraph: Editors’ note: We’re featuring thes article again because who doesn’t want to look younger?

abstract: On the Minute, the New York Police Department suspends its Muslim spying program, new research on “vegetative” patients and Oliver North helping shape the story line of “The Americans.”

headline: Rescuers Rush to South Korean Ferry Accident
abstract: A ferry carrying hundreds of high school students to a resort island listed and began sinking off the southwestern tip of South Korea.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — At least one person died when a ferry that was carrying hundreds of high school students to a resort island listed to one side and began sinking off the southwestern tip of South Korea, the maritime police said on Wednesday.

headline: More Ex-Players Sue N.H.L.
abstract: Three more retired hockey players have sued the N.H.L. alleging that the league allowed fighting and promoted violence while minimizing the risk of head injuries.
lead_paragraph: Three more retired hockey players have sued the N.H.L. alleging that the league allowed fighting and promoted violence while minimizing the risk of head injuries. The three are Dave Christian, who was on the United States Olympic team for the 1980 Miracle on Ice and who played 1,009 N.H.L. games; Reed Larson, the highest-scoring American defenseman in N.H.L. history when he left the league in 1990; and Bill Bennett.

lead_paragraph: An accusation against Jameis Winston, a marquee quarterback for Florida State, did not prompt an in-depth inquiry by either the university or the police. By the time prosecutors got the case it was nearly a year old.

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on April 16, 2014.

headline: A Conversation With: Author Sanjaya Baru
abstract: Sanjaya Baru, author of “The Accidental Prime Minister,” spoke with India Ink about dynastic politics and the failures and successes of Manmohan Singh.
lead_paragraph: In writing his book “The Accidental Prime Minister,” Sanjaya Baru, the former media adviser to Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, was trying to defend his former boss, who he said was consistently undermined by Sonia Gandhi, the president of the Indian National Congress, over his two terms.

headline: What’s on Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (13, 49) TOUCHING THE WILD Joe Hutto — the writer, artist and naturalist — has parented a clutch of wild turkey hatchlings and embedded with a herd of Rocky Mountain bighorn sheep. This “Nature” special, based on Mr. Hutto’s book “Touching the Wild: Living With the Mule Deer of Deadman Gulch,” journeys to the Wind River Mountains of Wyoming, not far from Mr. Hutto’s ranch, where a chance encounter with a young buck led him to spend seven years living among the members of a mule deer family. “He returned an upward nod of the head, and I looked away and I nodded my head, and he returned the gesture again,” Mr. Hutto, above, recalls. “That deer was willing to see me as an individual, and he very clearly saw that I granted him his individuality. I was not seeing something, I was seeing someone.”

headline: Nieuwenhuis, in Season Debut, Powers Mets Over Diamondbacks
abstract: Kirk Nieuwenhuis, called up from the minors before the game, had three hits and drove in three runs in a 9-0 romp.
lead_paragraph: By Tim Rohan

headline: National Security Commission Meets for the First Time
abstract: Comments by President Xi Jinping suggested that the new commission would have the power to reach into nearly every aspect of domestic and foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: President Xi Jinping has presided over the first meeting of the recently established National Security Commission, and his remarks suggested that the commission would have the power to reach into nearly every aspect of domestic and foreign policy.

headline: Students Among Hundreds Missing After South Korean Ferry Sinks
abstract: Rescuers were searching for nearly 300 people, most of them high school students, who remained unaccounted for after a ferry that was carrying them to a resort island sank.
lead_paragraph: JINDO, South Korea — The parents waited in dread through the night, huddled under blankets in this South Korean port town, staring out to sea for a sign that rescuers had found any of the 281 people, many of them high school students, still missing after a ferry sank on Wednesday.

headline: A Story of Displacement in Gujarat Comes to Mumbai
abstract: Mallika Sarabhai, an Indian classical dancer, has organized a festival to pay tribute to river residents forced to leave their homes for the sake of development in Ahmedabad, in the western state of Gujarat.
lead_paragraph: AHMEDABAD, India — When the noted Indian classical dancer Mrinalini Sarabhai and her husband, Vikram, founded the Darpana Academy of Performing Arts in 1949, the couple took care to avoid displacing any of the residents who lived next to their property on the western banks of the Sabarmati River in this city.

headline: A Top Player Accused, and a Flawed Rape Inquiry
abstract: At Florida State, an accusation against a star athlete prompted neither immediate action, nor an in-depth inquiry, by the university or the Tallahassee Police Department. By the time local prosecutors got the case it was nearly a year old and missing important evidence.
lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — Early on the morning of Dec. 7, 2012, a freshman at Florida State University reported that she had been raped by a stranger somewhere off campus after a night of drinking at a popular Tallahassee bar called Potbelly’s.

headline: Credit Suisse Profit Falls 34% in First Quarter
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Company Reports', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The bank reported quarterly earnings of 859 million Swiss francs, or about $976 million, compared with profit of 1.3 billion francs in the year-earlier period.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Credit Suisse said on Wednesday that profit fell 34 percent in the first quarter as the Swiss bank shed assets and streamlined its investment banking operations as part of an overhaul of its business.

headline: Official Praises Eviction Workers as ‘Most Lovable’
abstract: The official, a district Communist Party secretary in the Henan Province city of Xinyang, has been criticized nationally after praising demolition crews carrying out one of the most controversial policies in China.
lead_paragraph: China’s demolition workers, the people who tear down houses and move residents — often against their will — to make way for new construction, have been called many things. But they have rarely received a paean like that from a district official in Xinyang, in the central province of Henan.

headline: Pistorius Trial to Adjourn This Week Until May 5, Days Before Election
abstract: The judge in the trial of Oscar Pistorius, the double-amputee track star accused of murdering his girlfriend, said that proceedings would be postponed after hearings ended on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: PRETORIA, South Africa — The judge in the trial of Oscar Pistorius, the double-amputee track star accused of murdering his girlfriend, said on Wednesday that proceedings would be postponed after hearings ended on Thursday until May 5, two days before South Africa’s national election.

headline: Photos That Cross Borders and Challenge Perceptions
abstract: Janet Jarman has followed Marisol from her childhood in Mexico to life as a young mother in the United States, making images that are educating teachers and doctors about the complexities of immigrant life.
lead_paragraph: Beyond prizes, page views or any other measure of prestige, Janet Jarman has a newfound appreciation for the impact of photojournalism. A project that began 18 years ago in a Mexican dump has taken her on a journey across borders with a family whose lives illustrate the complexities of immigration. But rather than be content that it will reach some abstract audience, she is excited that the project is being used by teachers and medical professionals in North Carolina to understand the lives of Latin American immigrants who are remaking the region.

headline: Comfort Food Grows Up
abstract: With a hint of cumin and orange in the sauce, these are not your childhood meatballs.
lead_paragraph: Here is a recipe that plays as well to children as to the most sophisticated of palates, on date nights and family nights alike. It is for crisp-tender lamb meatballs, seared before being cooked through in a fragrant, vaguely North African tomato sauce zipped up with orange juice and warm spices, then topped with feta and mint. You can cook it in an hour’s time, not all of it spent working.

headline: How the President Got to ‘I Do’ on Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)', 'Voting and Voters', 'Presidential Election of 2008', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The real story of Obama’s tentative, anxious, heavily scripted and occasionally blundering “evolution.”
lead_paragraph: By presidential fund-raising standards, the dinner at the St. Regis hotel in Washington in April 2011 was an intimate one. President Obama made the rounds, moving among the dozens of people in attendance, including Chad Griffin, a 37-year-old political operative known for his ability to raise money in Hollywood and for his work on trying to legalize same-sex marriage. It was Griffin who persuaded the conservative lawyer Theodore B. Olson and the liberal attorney David Boies, adversaries in the 2000 Bush v. Gore case, to bring a federal lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of California’s Proposition 8, the amendment banning same-sex marriage that voters approved in 2008.

headline: Metso Board Rejects Merger Approach by Scottish Rival
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Stocks and Bonds']

lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Finnish company Metso said Wednesday that it had rejected an offer by its Scottish engineering rival, the Weir Group, to open merger discussions.

headline: German Firm Sells Heat Exchanger Operations to Funds Advised by Triton
abstract: GEA Group said the deal valued the unit at about $1.8 billion and was part of its strategy to focus on supplying systems to the food industry.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – GEA Group of Germany said on Wednesday that it had sold its heat exchangers business to funds advised by the private equity firm Triton Partners, in a deal that valued the unit at 1.3 billion euros, or about $1.8 billion. GEA had announced plans last year to sell the unit, which involves components for heating, air conditioning and ventilation systems.

abstract: What you need to know for Wednesday: a freezing morning, a police unit that spied on Muslims is disbanded, and a birthday party for scary dolls.

abstract: The cash-and-stock deal calls for Citic to sell almost all of its operating assets to its Hong Kong-listed unit, Citic Pacific.
lead_paragraph: The Citic Group, one of China’s biggest state-owned conglomerates, said on Wednesday that it had reached a formal deal for what amounts to a backdoor listing in Hong Kong valuing the company at about $36.5 billion.

headline: Ukraine Push Against Rebels Grinds to Halt
abstract: Pro-Russian militias commandeered vehicles from the Ukrainian Army as a military operation by the Kiev government in the eastern part of the nation fell apart.
lead_paragraph: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — A military operation that the Ukrainian government said would confront pro-Russian militants in the east of the country unraveled in disarray on Wednesday with the entire contingent of 21 armored vehicles that had separated into two columns surrendering or pulling back before nightfall. It was a glaring humiliation for the new government in Kiev.

headline: Candidates Exploit Loopholes to Skirt Spending Limits
keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Campaign Finance', 'Elections', 'Social Media', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: The parliamentary elections in Bangalore show the gap between candidates’ actual expenses and spending statements. For example, one way around the campaign limit is to spend money before filing nomination papers.
lead_paragraph: BANGALORE, India — The cost of a cardamom garland: $36, or 2,200 rupees.  A day’s chair rental: 11 cents.  A polyester flag: 16 cents.  A silk shawl: $11.

headline: Software That Helps Small Businesses Ship Like Amazon
abstract: To develop EasyPost, Jarrett Streebin talked to lots of small-business owners about their postage and shipping pain points.
lead_paragraph: In his spare time two years ago, Jarrett Streebin operated a gift-card reselling business that required his customers to send their gift cards to him. He wanted to give them preprinted, prepaid shipping labels to make the process easy, but it proved more complicated and took longer than he expected.

headline: Daily Report: Growth of Alibaba Propels Interest in Yahoo
abstract: An after-hours rise in Yahoo’s stock price was because its shareholders were far more excited about what the company owns — namely, 24 percent of Alibaba — than anything the company runs.
lead_paragraph: Investors were already salivating over the initial stock offering of Alibaba Group, the giant Chinese e-commerce company. On Tuesday, they got a glimpse of Alibaba’s tremendous growth that is sure to whet their appetite even more, Vindu Goel reports.

headline: Bank of America, Weighed by Legal Costs, Posts Loss
abstract: Bank of America recorded a $276 million loss in the first quarter, a sign it is still paying for its mortgage problems nearly six years after the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:30 p.m. | Bank of America delivered an unwelcome surprise to its investors, as the bank disclosed larger-than-expected legal expenses in the first quarter stemming from the financial crisis.

abstract: The vessel was carrying 477 passengers and crew, including 325 high school students.

headline: The Future of Facebook May Not Say ‘Facebook’
abstract: The company’s strategy includes unbundling its mammoth social network into discrete and nimble components.
lead_paragraph: In the two years since its rocky initial public offering, Facebook has become a strong business that regularly releases financial results that set investors’ hearts aflutter. Despite every hipster prediction otherwise, the company’s user base keeps growing, and nearly a fifth of the time that Americans spend on their smartphones is spent on Facebook. That surpasses the amount of time we spend on any other single service by a wide margin — and beats just about anything else we do on our phones, or perhaps in our lives, period.

headline: Can Facebook Innovate? A Conversation With Mark Zuckerberg
abstract: Facebook’s co-founder and chief executive explains the company’s plan to stay innovative in the mobile age.
lead_paragraph: For my column this week about Facebook’s new approach to creating social apps, I spent some time talking to Mark E. Zuckerberg, the company’s co-founder and chief executive. We met in a conference room at Facebook’s headquarters in Menlo Park, Calif., on a sunny Friday earlier this month.

headline: Sebelius Said to Weigh Run for Kansas Senate Seat
abstract: Several Democrats said that Kathleen Sebelius, who resigned as secretary of health and human services, had been mentioned as someone who could wage a serious challenge to Senator Pat Roberts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In her darkest hour last fall, Kathleen Sebelius suffered one of the deepest cuts from an old family friend who accused her of “gross incompetence” over the rollout of the Affordable Care Act and demanded that she resign as secretary of health and human services. Now she is weighing revenge.

headline: Bank of America’s Big Loss

The bank said its litigation expenses increased to $6 billion in the quarter, showing how Bank of America is still paying for its mortgages missteps nearly six years after the financial crisis.

headline: Raising the Curtain on This Year’s Tribeca Film Festival
abstract: The downtown Manhattan festival, now in its 13th year, is chock full of music documentaries, high-profile premieres and smart talks with some of film and TV’s finest writers.
lead_paragraph: Get your popcorn ready. The Tribeca Film Festival, now in its 13th year, returns to downtown Manhattan today to host 12 days of obsessive moviegoing and compelling conversation about film. Co-founded in 2002 by the actor Robert De Niro with his producing partner Jane Rosenthal and the real estate financier Craig Hatkoff, the festival was originally conceived as a cultural response to Sept. 11. And while its reach has expanded significantly over the years — a staggering 6,117 films were submitted for this year’s festival, increasing both the quality and diversity of the offerings (fans will remember, though they might prefer not to, that “Star Wars Episode II: The Clone Wars” premiered at the inaugural fest) — the spirit of the original outing has remained intact.

headline: ‘Active Cleanup’ of Oil Spill Is Ended on Louisiana Coast
abstract: Coast Guard officials stressed that a more narrow cleanup response to the 2010 Deepwater Horizon oil spill would continue.
lead_paragraph: The cleanup efforts on the Gulf Coast in response to the Deepwater Horizon oil spill have entered a new phase, with the oil company BP announcing that it is ending its “active cleanup” of Louisiana’s coast almost four years after the disaster.

headline: An Ex-Mayor, in His Own Words
abstract: Michael R. Bloomberg says that to be most effective, it helps to be single-minded. His issue, he says, is guns.
lead_paragraph: In one of his first interviews since leaving office, Michael R. Bloomberg was by turns restless, wry, entirely lacking in self-doubt and, at least for now, reticent to pass judgment on his successor. He mused about his accelerated entry into heaven and his “rock star” reputation. The following is an extended version of Mr. Bloomberg’s interview with The New York Times, in which he also discusses the political potency of the National Rifle Association, the types of gun control he thinks are effective and ineffective, and his post-mayoral life.

He runs the Gaza branch of OneVoice, a group that promotes a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. In the Gaza Strip, where more than half the 1.7 million residents are classified as refugees, and the ruling Hamas party of Islamic militants opposes negotiations with Israel, Mr. Masri often feels that his is the one voice of pragmatic realism.

headline: On View | Turning Ancient Craft Techniques Into Modern Fashion
abstract: A show at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston explores the work of the Mexican artist and designer Carla Fernández, and offers weaving and patternmaking workshops to the public.
lead_paragraph: Carla Fernández is an artist and activist whose medium is fashion. She works with traditional textiles from her native Mexico to create contemporary designs, supporting and nurturing artisan communities in the process. Now her work gets the museum treatment in a new show, “The Barefoot Designer: A Passion for Radical Design and Community,” the first-ever fashion exhibit at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston. Through fashion photographs and drawings, garments, video and performance, the show explores the techniques of master artisans from each of Mexico’s five states, and Fernández’s method for designing with them using the rectangular and square patterns of indigenous garments, a technique she calls “the square root.” By incorporating these ancient methods into a modern fashion line, “we are fast-forwarding tradition,” she says.

The number conceals big differences of opinion, of course: while 66 percent of Democrats feel this way, the number drops to 49 percent for Republicans.

headline: Making the Most of Time

lead_paragraph: Time works so differently for children. While harried adults flutter about getting ready for this or that, children tend to get lost in their books, their Lego metropolises, their imaginary games. And when it’s suddenly time to go to school, or to soccer practice or, heaven forfend, to bed, they’re astonished. Where did the time go?

headline: The Gun Report: April 16, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, 73-year-old Frazier Glenn Miller opened fire outside a Jewish Community Center in a Kansas City, Mo., suburb, killing three people. William Lewis Corporon, 69, was taking his grandson, Reat Underwood, 14, to an audition for KC SuperStar, a talent competition for high school students, when they were gunned down in the parking lot. Terri LaManno, 53, was visiting her mother at a nearby retirement complex. LaManno worked as an occupational therapist for visually impaired children. Yesterday was her 25th wedding anniversary.

Yellen, reiterated on Wednesday that she expected interest rates to remain very low until the recovery is on a more secure footing and the American economy is more fully involving available workers and other resources.

lead_paragraph: For older Americans, high blood pressure is a fact of life. By one common estimate, more than 70 percent of those over age 70 contend with it. That means medication to lower blood pressure has become a fact of life, too.

headline: Classical Playlist: Beethoven, Mahler, Aaron Copland and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: ‘COMPOSING AMERICA’: Works by John Adams, William Bolcom, Aaron Copland and Paul MoravecThe Lark Quartet(Bridge)The Lark Quartet offers an engaging traversal of folk and pop-influenced music by American composers, beginning with John Adams’s foot stomping “5 Pages From John’s Book of Alleged Dances.” The disc also includes William Bolcom’s “Billy in the Darbies” and Copland’s “Two Pieces for String Quartet.” The Lark is joined by the pianist Jeremy Denk for Paul Moravec’s texturally rich Piano Quintet. (Vivien Schweitzer)

headline: Ford Celebrates the Old Mustang With a New Pony
abstract: The original Mustang was introduced at the 1964 World’s Fair, and Ford marked the event by presenting the Mustang 50 Year Limited Edition at the New York auto show on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The people at Ford are all misty eyed about Mustang’s 50th anniversary, which falls on media day at the New York auto show. It’s an emotional time for them as they celebrate the birthday of the Mustang and a milestone marketing effort in the city where it all started at the 1964 World’s Fair. To mark the anniversary on Wednesday, the company placed a 2015 Mustang on the Observation Deck of the Empire State Building.

headline: For Obamacare, What Counts As Success?
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Medicaid', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The law’s supporters should define what kind of specific outcomes they expect.
lead_paragraph: Ezra Klein, in his new capacity as one of the impresarios behind Vox, has written a pair of attention-grabbing posts — here, and then here — defending the proposition that Obamacare has, in some sense, “won,” and that conservatives who can’t come to terms with that victory can’t come to terms with reality itself. Reading them, it struck me that this argument would benefit from laying down some specific markers for the near future, because Klein seems to move back and forth between two definitions of success. At times, as when he writes that Obamacare “has won its survival” and allows that that “there are still many good critiques to make” of the law, he seems to be using a narrow definition, with which I mostly agree — the law won’t collapse under its own weight, the enrollment levels are high enough to make a return to the coverage status quo ante unlikely, etc. But when he uses language like “the individual mandate … is working” and “the law is back on its expected track,” and concludes that “[Kathleen Sebelius] can leave with the law she helped build looking, shockingly, like a success,” it implies a stronger definition of victory, in which Obamacare isn’t just continuing, isn’t just unlikely to be swiftly repealed, but is clearly succeeding as a policy in basically the way its advocates predicted that it would.

headline: Dee Dee Myers to Join Warner Bros. as Head of Communications
abstract: Ms. Myers, a former White House press secretary under Bill Clinton, will become an executive vice president reporting directly to Warner’s chief executive.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Dee Dee Myers, once the White House press secretary to Bill Clinton, will be joining Warner Bros. as executive vice president for worldwide corporate communications and public affairs, the studio said on Wednesday.

headline: Climate Change, the Musical
abstract: “The Great Immensity” asks the big-time question of whether man can change his destructive ways before the planet goes kablooey.
lead_paragraph: Steve Cosson and Michael Friedman had a highbrow hit in the fall collaborating on Anne Washburn’s “Mr. Burns: A Post-Electric Play.” They are reunited for the latest production from the inventive, inquisitive theater troupe the Civilians, in residence at the Public Theater as part of the low-price, low-frills Public Lab series. “The Great Immensity,” written and directed by Mr. Cosson with songs by Mr. Friedman, asks the big-time question of whether man can change his destructive ways before the planet goes kablooey.

keywords: ['Kentucky Derby', 'Florida Derby (Horse Race)', 'Horse Racing', 'Jockeys, Drivers and Trainers', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)']

headline: Stealth Taxes Are Still Income Taxes
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Payroll Tax', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The Affordable Care Act imposes economic burdens that are the equivalent of taxes, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: A Bohemian Getaway in the Heart of Mumbai
abstract: At Abode, the area’s first boutique hotel, rooms range from small and hostel-like to large and luxurious.
lead_paragraph: Until this year, Mumbai didn’t have a single boutique hotel. There was the Taj Palace, with its iconic confectionary grandeur; some characterless, midrange hotels scattered around Colaba, the core of historic South Mumbai; the Oberoi and the Trident in their 1970s concrete boxes. But there was no hotel that captured both the rich visual heritage of historic Bombay and the intense aesthetic energy of contemporary Mumbai. Now, there’s Abode.
