headline: The East Village: In the Thick of Things
abstract: Michelle and Andrew Gasparovic wanted their home and social lives in the same neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: Shortly before their marriage around two years ago, Michelle and Andrew Gasparovic moved to New York from Boston. With just a few days to find a place, they rented a one-bedroom with a balcony at Tribeca Pointe, on the waterfront at the north end of Battery Park City.

headline: Competing Views of Teacher Tenure Are on Display in California Case
abstract: In a case that has drawn national attention, lawyers have been arguing over whether California’s laws on teacher tenure, firing and layoffs violate students’ constitutional right to an education.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — These are two vastly different portraits of California’s education system. In one, poor and minority students are frequently placed in front of incompetent teachers whose blackboards are filled with basic misspellings and who play irrelevant movies instead of devising lesson plans for class time. In the other, the vast majority of teachers are providing students with all they need to learn, and well-run school districts are able to ferret out and dismiss the ones who are not.

headline: Incorporating a Touch of ‘Cabaret’ Into Your Wardrobe
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Lingerie and Underwear', 'Dresses', 'Hats and Caps', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Theater']
abstract: Pale-pink chemises, lace-trimmed bras, and feather headbands to top off a Sally Bowles inspired look.
lead_paragraph: On April 24, when the Roundabout Theater Company revival of “Cabaret” opens, a negligee-clad Michelle Williams will make her Broadway debut as Sally Bowles, and Alan Cumming, in those fetishistic suspenders, will reprise his Tony-winning performance as the master of ceremonies. After an evening at the Kit Kat Klub at Studio 54, you may be tempted to draw on the tea-rose-colored chemises, sexy black underpinnings and flapper-style accessories worn at the decadent Weimar-era Berlin nightclub for your own wardrobe. Here are some ways to do it — and not for a costume party.

abstract: Why is this book different from any other book?
lead_paragraph: I’m going to be commenting on Thomas Piketty later today, and I thought I would write up my thoughts in advance; this may or may not be what I actually end up saying.

headline: Samsung Saw Death of Apple’s Jobs as a Time to Attack
abstract: According to an email exchange presented in court, Samsung executives saw the death of Steven P. Jobs in 2011 as an opportunity to attack the iPhone.
lead_paragraph: .big-quote { color: #444; padding: 20px 40px 10px 40px; box-shadow: inset 0 0 5px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.15); margin: 20px 0 20px 0; position: relative; font-size: 17px; line-height: 35px; background-color: #fffff5; } .big-quote .story-body-text { font-size: 16px !important; line-height: 21px !important; font-family: nyt-franklin, arial, helvetica, sans-serif !important; font-weight: 200 !important; } .big-quote .page-promo { display: none; position: absolute; bottom: 20px; right: 20px; color: #eeeeee; background-color: rgba(0,0,0,.65); padding: 8px 15px 8px 15px; font-family: nyt-franklin, arial, helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 15px; font-weight: bold; border-radius: 4px; } .big-quote:hover .page-promo { display: block; }

headline: Post Holdings Reaches $2.5 Billion Deal for Michael Foods
abstract: The deal allows Post, known for brands like Raisin Bran and Honey Bunches of Oats, to expand into egg whites and potatoes.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:35 a.m. | The cereal maker Post Holdings has reached a deal to buy Michael Foods, a food processing and distribution company, the companies announced on Thursday.

headline: Obamacare Truthers at MSNBC
abstract: Casual vileness against hard-working civil servants.
lead_paragraph: Just a quick note in support of government statisticians. They do an incredibly important job, and by and large do it very well. They’ve also maintained a well-deserved reputation for staying out of the political fray, of acting as civil servants, not party apparatchiks.

headline: Bank of America Not Alone in Reporting Anemic Results
abstract: Bank of America’s $276 million loss provides some valuable perspective on the difficulties in running a big bank these days, Antony Currie of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Anemic results underscore how little fun it is to run a big bank these days. The $276 million loss that Bank of America announced on Wednesday, however, at least provides some valuable perspective.

headline: What You Get for... $1,400,000
abstract: This week’s properties include contemporaries in California and Texas and an old stone farmhouse in Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: SANTA BARBARA, CALIF.

headline: Bloomberg’s $50 Million Investment in Fear
abstract: The former mayor of New York is starting a new gun-safety group.
lead_paragraph: Fourteen years ago, hundreds of thousands of women and their families rallied along the National Mall in the Million Mom March, demanding greater gun safety for their children and touching off a grass-roots political challenge to the National Rifle Association’s grip on Congress. Yet their campaign has only grown more difficult since then despite the steady, grisly flow of carnage.

headline: Korean Coast Guard Video of Ferry Rescue
abstract: Video released by the South Korean Coast Guard showed survivors being plucked from a sinking ferry by helicopter and boat as the ship slowly capsized.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Choe Sang-Hun reports, more than 280 passengers, most of them students, were still unaccounted for Wednesday night as coast guard and navy divers searched a ferry that sank hours earlier off the southwestern tip of South Korea.

headline: Terry Riley Music Among Highlights of River to River Festival
abstract: Music by the minimalist master and performances by the Trisha Brown Dance Company will be part of the free festival in Lower Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Music created and inspired by Terry Riley, the minimalist master, will be played at Federal Hall. The Trisha Brown Dance Company will perform on the East River waterfront.  The Haitian songwriter Bélo, who calls his music “Ragganga,” will play at the South Street Seaport.

headline: ‘Happy’ and ‘Frozen’ in Place at No. 1
abstract: The soundtrack to Disney’s animated film topped the chart for a tenth week, while “Happy” held on as top single.
lead_paragraph: Disney’s “Frozen” soundtrack is once again the No. 1 album in the country, with sales of 133,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan.

headline: Organize Photos on Your Phone
abstract: Molly Wood tests three apps, including the new Carousel by Dropbox, that help you sort and share the overwhelming number of photos on your mobile device.
lead_paragraph: Molly Wood tests three apps, including the new Carousel by Dropbox, that help you sort and share the overwhelming number of photos on your mobile device.

headline: For Young Traders, a Market Where Air Jordans Are Blue Chips
keywords: ['Sneakers', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Collectors and Collections', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows']
abstract: Bartering and selling at conventions and online, the thousands of mostly teenage “sneakerheads” have perfected the art of trading up.
lead_paragraph: With sneakers slung around their shoulders and pockets full of cash, young boys huddle in hotel ballrooms and high school gyms, shouting and bartering as if they belong on a trading room floor.

headline: The Best Photo Organizing App? I’m Still Looking
abstract: A new entrant from Dropbox, Carousel, looked promising, but fell short. A raft of others all have strengths, but nothing offers everything you want.
lead_paragraph: I HAVE about 2,500 photos stored on my smartphone, and who knows how many more on previous phones and other devices I use. I need an organizing principle, stat.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival: New York Via Park City or Berlin
abstract: The Tribeca Film Festival is known for its world premieres, but some touted films from other prominent festivals are also on the program.
lead_paragraph: The 13th edition of the Tribeca Film Festival gets under way on Wednesday with some 100 offerings to choose from. How is a film fan to decide?

headline: British Government Seeks Lift From Economic Data
abstract: The Conservative-led coalition government hopes voters see the new growth as a vindication of austerity policies.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain crossed an important economic and psychological threshold on Wednesday when growth in paychecks caught up with inflation after years of financial crisis, austerity and an accompanying dip in living standards.

headline: Scene City: A Public Display of Affection
abstract: Michael Douglas, Catherine Zeta-Jones and Chloë Grace Moretz attend opening of “The Library” at the Public Theater.
lead_paragraph: Michael Douglas, Catherine Zeta-Jones and Chloë Grace Moretz attend opening of “The Library” at the Public Theater.

headline: BMW X4
abstract: A look at BMW’s new “Sports Activity Coupe,” the X4
lead_paragraph: A look at BMW’s new “Sports Activity Coupe,” the X4

headline: Cohen Gets to Trade for 90 Days Before Paying SAC Penalty
abstract: That is longer than the 30 days recommended by federal probation officials, but it is the time frame that lawyers for SAC and federal prosecutors agreed to in November.
lead_paragraph: Even when he loses, the billionaire investor Steven A. Cohen manages to find a way to win.

headline: The X4 Is Another Utility Player From BMW
abstract: BMW keeps building on its models, steadily producing new variations. This new crossover, part of the new 4 Series line, is like an X6, but without the swagger.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Wednesday: 2015 BMW X4

headline: A Scottish Trail Will Celebrate John Muir
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: John Muir Way, a 134-mile marked trail that will honor the conservationist, will open in Scotland on April 21.
lead_paragraph: To celebrate the spirit, work and legacy of the  conservationist John Muir, Scotland will officially unveil the John Muir Way on April 21.

headline: Taliban End a Cease-Fire With Pakistan
abstract: The group said it would continue to pursue peace talks after accusing the military of torturing prisoners and killing 50 militants during the cease-fire.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — The Pakistani Taliban said Wednesday that they were ending a six-week-old cease-fire but would continue peace talks with the Pakistani government.

headline: In Germany, Strong Words Over Google's Power
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Mathias Döpfner, a leading publisher, lashed out a week after the Google chairman, Eric E. Schmidt, mounted a spirited defense of Google's practices.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A trans-Atlantic war of words — and profits — over the future of the Internet heated up on Wednesday when the head of Germany’s largest publisher admitted that “we are afraid of Google” and suggested that European authorities were colluding with the American Internet giant to develop a “business model that in less honorable circles would be called extortion.”

headline: Court Deportations Drop 43 Percent in Past Five Years
abstract: The statistics present a different picture of President Obama’s policies from the one painted by many immigrant advocates, who have called him the “deporter in chief.”
lead_paragraph: New deportation cases brought by the Obama administration in the nation’s immigration courts have been declining steadily since 2009, and judges have increasingly ruled against deportations, leading to a 43 percent drop in the number of deportations through the courts in the last five years, according to Justice Department statistics released on Wednesday.

headline: Tanaka Lets Neither Cubs Nor the Cold Get to Him
abstract: Despite fierce wind and frigid temperatures, Masahiro Tanaka looked better than ever, striking out 10 in eight innings while allowing only two hits — both bunt singles — in the Yankees’ win in the first game of a doubleheader.
lead_paragraph: Joe Girardi has been careful about how he handles Masahiro Tanaka. Nothing is trifling in this, Tanaka’s debut month in the major leagues, and Girardi, an obsessive planner, seemed to have Tanaka’s initial starts lined up at the ideal times.

headline: Seeking Young Viewers, Pivot Bolsters Its Original Programming
abstract: In a pitch to advertisers, the cable channel introduced new shows with the actor and composer Lin-Manuel Miranda and the commentator Meghan McCain.
lead_paragraph: A small, somewhat new cable channel is wooing additional viewers and advertisers by beefing up its original programming, including what would be its first original scripted series.

headline: Jasmin Shokrian Dives Into the Burgeoning Dallas Art Scene
abstract: The designer, whose sculptural clothes draw a strong gallery-girl following, shares snapshots from her recent trip to the Texas city’s art week.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles-based designer Jasmin Shokrian makes quietly striking, sculptural clothes beloved by women in the art world. During last week’s Dallas Art Fair, the owners of Tenoversix — the L.A. boutique that last year opened an outpost in (and served as a design consultancy for) Dallas’s art-filled Joule Hotel — invited Shokrian to hold a trunk show in their space. The event offered an ideal excuse for Shokrian to explore the metropolis and its booming cultural scene over the weekend. “It felt like kind of a magical city,” she says. Yes, she’s talking about Dallas. Here, she shares some highlights, including a joint exhibition by Julian Schnabel and Richard Phillips at Dallas Contemporary and an accompanying dinner, a spin through the fair, a gallery opening co-hosted by the model and Dallas native Erin Wasson and a party called the Eye Ball.

headline: Yellen Discusses Fed’s Coming Decision
abstract: Speaking at the Economic Club of New York, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, Janet L. Yellen, said the Fed’s coming decision on interest rates would depend on employment and inflation thresholds.
lead_paragraph: Speaking at the Economic Club of New York, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, Janet L. Yellen, said the Fed’s coming decision on interest rates would depend on employment and inflation thresholds.

headline: The Birth of a Conspiracy Theory
abstract: Some on the right speculate that the Obama administration is trying to politicize the census.
lead_paragraph: If you spend enough time on the Internet you’ll eventually encounter a conspiracy theory. If you watch closely enough, sometimes you can actually see one being born.

headline: ‘Fargo’ on FX Debuts to an Audience of More Than 4 Million
abstract: The viewing totals represent a promising start for the series, which is a loose adaptation of the Coen brother’s film.
lead_paragraph: The new FX drama “Fargo” got off to a promising start on Tuesday, with ratings across several broadcasts that added up to more than four million viewers.

headline: Clip: ‘Proxy’
abstract: A scene from the film “Proxy,” directed by Zack Parker.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film “Proxy,” directed by Zack Parker.

headline: Cut the Clutter in Your Social Media Accounts
abstract: There are simple ways to make platforms like Twitter and Facebook more useful, like making lists and trimming back groups.
lead_paragraph: BEING active on social media platforms like Twitter and Facebook is kind of like having a basement in the suburbs. These accounts can quickly become so cluttered that you might as well shut the door and say goodbye — you’re never finding anything you need again.

headline: ‘In the Garden of Souls’ and Gardens of Childhood
abstract: Ballet NY showcased little-seen works at Ailey Citigroup Theater on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: One worthy mission of Ballet NY, a chamber troupe founded in 1997 and still hanging on, is to offer chances, and trained dancers, to budding choreographers. So it might have been disappointing that the company’s program at Ailey Citigroup Theater on Tuesday featured no new works. Three out of the four pieces had been made for other groups. Yet this, too, was part of a worthy mission: allowing the creations of lesser-known choreographers to be seen again, embodied and interpreted by different dancers, giving those works a chance at an extended life.

headline: Earnings and Sales From Google Disappoint
abstract: As Internet users migrate to mobile devices, Google earns less on its ads, and as the dominant player, growth opportunities are increasingly rare.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Alexander the Great is said to have wept because he ran out of kingdoms to conquer. Google is eager to avoid such a miserable fate.

headline: Acura TLX: All-Wheel Steering Tries for Another Comeback
abstract: A new TLX advances Acura’s identity as a high-tech showcase.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Wednesday, April 16: 2015 Acura TLX

headline: One-Man Hollywood in the Midwest
abstract: The filmmaker Zack Parker, who is based in Richmond, Ind., has shot four disturbing features in that area, including his latest, “Proxy.”
lead_paragraph: The concepts are high. The budgets are low. The themes are unnerving. That’s the best way to describe the films made by Zack Parker, a native of the Midwest who takes a more-than-meets-the-eye approach to his moviemaking. Mr. Parker is based in Richmond, Ind., a small town on the eastern side of the state that wouldn’t exactly be the first location choice for many directors. But he has shot four disturbing features in that area.

headline: Conquering Displacement With Words
abstract: The Spanish-Argentine writer Andrés Neuman, a protégé of Roberto Bolaño, now has his second novel to appear in English: “Talking to Ourselves,” a contemporary family drama and unflinching story of grief.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — When he was just 22, the Spanish-Argentine writer Andrés Neuman was anointed by no less a luminary than the Chilean writer Roberto Bolaño, who had a discriminating eye for talent and wasn’t lukewarm when he found it. “The literature of the 21st century,” Bolaño proclaimed, “will belong to Neuman and a few of his blood brothers.” Bolaño said he felt like weeping when he discovered such a young, gifted writer; Mr. Neuman’s first novel, “Bariloche” (1999), Bolaño wrote, had “enthralled” and “hypnotized” him for the uncanny ease of its writing.

headline: Profit and Revenue Slip at IBM as Hardware Sales Fall and Layoff Costs Rise
abstract: It is the eighth consecutive quarter in which the company’s revenue has slipped, with this quarter hit hard by a falloff in its hardware business.
lead_paragraph: IBM is investing heavily in the future. It has placed multibillion-dollar bets on businesses to deliver computing remotely over the Internet cloud, on sophisticated data-analysis software and on its Watson artificial-intelligence technology.

headline: Incubator Arts Project to Close
abstract: The experimental performance company Incubator Arts Project announced that it would close in July.
lead_paragraph: The Incubator Arts Project, a well-regarded experimental performance company, announced on Wednesday that it would close in July after deciding not to renew its lease at St. Mark’s Church in the East Village. In a statement, Incubator’s leaders were vague about the reasons for the decision but others involved with the company said the closing was due to the difficulty of raising money and generating revenue – a challenge faced by many theaters of all budget sizes.

headline: Credit Sought by ABC News for Pulitzer, but Rejected
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Pulitzer Prizes']
abstract: ABC News is seeking recognition for its work on a prize-winning investigation into sick Appalachian miners who were denied medical care and benefits.
lead_paragraph: It was a moment of triumph for accountability journalism. An investigation on sick Appalachian miners being denied medical care and benefits by the coal industry was honored on Monday with one of the highest awards in journalism: the Pulitzer Prize for investigative reporting.

headline: Leaping Off the Screen: Nelson George Talks About ‘Soul Train’
abstract: Mr. George’s new book, “The Hippest Trip in America,” is a history of the landmark TV dance show.
lead_paragraph: Nelson George’s new book, “The Hippest Trip in America,” documents the history of “Soul Train,” the landmark television dance show that had its premiere in 1971. “Soul Train,” which was created in Chicago then moved to Los Angeles, showcased and deeply influenced African-American music, dance and fashion, hosting artists like Stevie Wonder and James Brown and starting the careers of dancers like Rosie Perez and Jody Watley. In a recent email interview, Mr. George discussed his earliest memories of “Soul Train,” why certain stars wouldn’t appear on the program, the show’s possible return and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: For Diabetics, Health Risks Fall Sharply
abstract: Rates of heart attacks, strokes, kidney failure and amputations dropped over the past two decades, federal researchers said.
lead_paragraph: Federal researchers on Wednesday reported the first broad national picture of progress against some of the most devastating complications of diabetes, which affects millions of Americans, finding that rates of heart attacks, strokes, kidney failure and amputations fell sharply over the past two decades.

headline: A Filmmaker Relishes His Next Act(s)
abstract: On opening night of “The Library,” no second thoughts from Steven Soderbergh about retirement.
lead_paragraph: Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones were sitting in the mezzanine of the Public Theater on Tuesday night, discussing whether Steven Soderbergh would make good on his promise of retirement. The director has said that he is finished directing movies.

headline: A Cultural Bazaar in Doha, Qatar
abstract: Meet Fahad al-Obaidly at the Souk Waqif in Doha, where traditional meets modern.
lead_paragraph: The Souk Waqif (“standing market”) in Doha, Qatar, has been rebuilt within the last decade into a shopping hub that includes architectural elements of the original century-old souk. At the Qatari market, you can shop for spices, traditional garments and kitchenware, or just enjoy a sip of Arabic coffee or a smoke from a hookah. The area’s blend of traditional and modern elements also manifests itself in the ways people dress to go shopping, ranging from women wearing a niqab to a colorful head scarf, to saris to jeans. Fahad al-Obaidly, a fashion designer, was in the area on a recent afternoon wearing a traditional floor-length coat with a black pair of jeans. Speaking through an interpreter, he credited the cultural mix of the area as a source of fashion inspiration. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: Combative Director, Even in Letters
abstract: “The Selected Letters of Elia Kazan” shows the stage and film director as demanding and manipulative in both his personal and professional lives.
lead_paragraph: Elia Kazan’s 1988 “A Life”  arguably remains the most raw, soul-searching memoir ever written about a career in show business. And his story remains polarizing, whether for his naming names to the House Un-American Activities Committee or for his candor about the pain he inflicted on those who loved him.

headline: Beauty Bars That Offer Quick Touch-Ups
abstract: The next iteration of the blow-dry business model moves to makeup and beyond.
lead_paragraph: The actress Stephanie March, who plays the assistant district attorney Alexandra Cabot on “Law & Order: SVU,” was talking on a recent afternoon about a perk of her job: getting her makeup done professionally. “My lawyer makeup was like me only better, which was a revelation to people who saw me after work,” said Ms. March, 39.

headline: In a Choreographer’s Imagination, a Kiss Is Never Just a Kiss
abstract: Ballet Hispanico danced a New York premiere of “El Beso” (“The Kiss”) by Gustavo Ramírez Sansano at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: When Eduardo Vilaro took the job of the artistic director of Ballet Hispanico in 2009, he left the company he had founded in Chicago, the Luna Negra Dance Theater, in the hands of the Spanish choreographer Gustavo Ramírez Sansano. Five years later, with Luna Negra having folded, Mr. Vilaro and Mr. Sansano have crossed paths again. On Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, Ballet Hispanico unveiled its first commission for Mr. Sansano, “El Beso,” which was also his New York debut as a choreographer.

headline: Songs of the Dead (and Others), Alive and Kicking
abstract: At the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Phil Lesh and his cohort (including Warren Haynes of the Allman Brothers Band) covered Grateful Dead songs and more.
lead_paragraph: Combinations and recombinations, the familiar and the strange, the chance to find something new within old songs, the camaraderie among musicians onstage and between longtime performers and loyal fans — all the jam-band elements were in place when Phil Lesh and Friends played the last of 10 area shows, the second of two concerts at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Tuesday night.

headline: A Little Zaniness and a Little Cabaret
abstract: Lucie Arnaz intertwines a blithe history of her romantic and professional life in her nightclub show at Café Carlyle.
lead_paragraph: As Lucie Arnaz, her eyes aflame, swiveled onto the stage of Café Carlyle on Tuesday evening and spat out the lyrics to the sizzling Lena Horne hit “Love,” she emulated the attitude of combative challenge that was a Horne signature. No matter that Ms. Arnaz, 62, is not as glamorous as Horne was even in her 80s, or that her voice isn’t as full-bodied or her manner as insinuating. The Horne tribute was still a smart, effective opening salvo in her show “Spring Is Here.”

headline: True King of Late Night? He Might Raise Eyebrows
abstract: Under Jon Stewart, “The Daily Show” has become a premier incubator of comedy talent.
lead_paragraph: After the latest upheavals in late-night television, with Stephen Colbert being picked to replace David Letterman, Jimmy Fallon establishing an early lead on Jimmy Kimmel, and the futures of Chelsea Handler and Craig Ferguson suddenly up in the air, the new king of comedy might be the star making the fewest headlines.

headline: After Years of Writing, an Author’s Own Epic Fantasy Comes True
abstract: Brandon Sanderson, who once completed 12 novels with nothing to show for it but publisher rejections, has hit No. 1 with “Words of Radiance.”
lead_paragraph: The fantasy writer Brandon Sanderson’s reputation is finally as big as his novels — and that’s saying a lot.

headline: Despite Hurdles, House Democrats Hold Edge in Small Donations
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: A surge in online fund-raising has helped House Democrats raise nearly $20 million more than Republicans so far this election cycle among so-called small-dollar donations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Democrats are winning the early battle for small donors, raising nearly $20 million more than Republicans so far this election cycle among so-called small-dollar donations.

headline: Jordanian Jets Strike Vehicles Trying to Enter From Syria
abstract: Jordan’s armed forces said in a statement that warplanes fired on the three vehicles after they failed to heed security forces’ demands to stop.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Jordanian warplanes on Wednesday destroyed three vehicles trying to enter the country from neighboring Syria in an unusual strike that underscored Jordan’s intensive efforts to maintain control over a border crisscrossed by smugglers, Syrian insurgents and refugees.

headline: Sky Ferreira: A Rebel, When Time Permits
abstract: She takes pride in her many roles: writer, musician, model and more.
lead_paragraph: Around 3 in the morning after the last Met Ball, the singer Sky Ferreira met one of her idols, Madonna. “By ‘met,’ I mean ‘attacked,’ ” said Ms. Ferreira, 21, over iced tea at a Cuban restaurant in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, where she lives. “I think I sat in her lap at one point.” She showed a photo of the two of them on her phone.

headline: Rating Men in New York
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A man was overheard talking about another in terms of ones and zeros, but he was not discussing binary code.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Silodor Open Pairs at the Spring Nationals
abstract: At the Spring Nationals in Dallas last month, the Silodor Open Pairs was won by John Diamond of Boca Raton, Fla., and Geoff Hampson of Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — At the Spring Nationals here last month, the Silodor Open Pairs was won by John Diamond of Boca Raton, Fla., and Geoff Hampson of Las Vegas. They finished more than four boards ahead of Richard Budd of Portland, Me., and Zach Grossack of Newton, Mass. Third were Jill Levin of Henderson, Nev., and Jill Meyers of Santa Monica, Calif.

headline: Bookshelf | Homes Inspired by the Creative Lives of their Owners
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: In a new book, “The Inspired Home: Nests of Creatives,” two creative types with a good eye for design share images of 17 homes, handpicked for their owners’ personal style.
lead_paragraph: In the new book “The Inspired Home: Nests of Creatives” (Rizzoli, $55), Kim Ficaro and Todd Nickey prove that the most inspiring homes are not always the ones dreamed up by architects, designers or the incredibly wealthy. And they should know: Ficaro has styled props and interiors for Bon Appétit, Town & Country, Elle, Harper’s Bazaar and Domino, while Nickey co-owns a successful design company in L.A. Rather than choosing homes simply because they struck their fancy, the co-authors first rounded up a trove of creative types — artists, writers, musicians, stylists, art directors — who had interesting personal style, and then hoped their homes would follow suit. Their instincts proved correct, and the 17 nests featured in this beautiful coffee-table book, shot by the Danish photographer Ditte Isager, reveal the inspiring combination of natural light and accidental, lived-in beauty. And despite the authors’ professions, Ficaro and Nickey opted not to style or decorate any of the interiors before they were photographed. “We wanted to let the places breathe on their own,” explains Ficaro.

headline: BMW 4 Series Gran Coupe: Playing by the Numbers
abstract: BMW was famed for its 3 Series models, but has rebranded its compact coupe and convertible as the 4 Series instead. Now comes a 4 Series hatchback.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Wednesday, April 16: 2015 BMW 4 Series Gran Coupe

headline: Deals by the Incoming La Scala Chief Cause a Stir
abstract: An agreement to purchase four opera productions from the Salzburg Festival, without approval from the opera house’s board or Italian authorities, has turned into a scandal in Milan.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Alexander Pereira hasn’t even begun his first season as general manager of La Scala and his stewardship is already generating controversy. Mr. Pereira, who is scheduled to take over the Milan opera house on Oct. 1, signed an agreement to buy four productions for La Scala from the Salzburg Festival, where he is the director, without the approval of the Italian authorities, according to La Scala and the mayor of Milan.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, South Korea, India and Bosnia.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, South Korea, India and Bosnia.

headline: In All the Spring Fashion Looks, a Balance
abstract: On the runways, it seemed, the objective was to highlight and reinforce contrasts, but the trick is in finding a balance for a single, riveting look.
lead_paragraph: It takes a steady compass to navigate the sea of contradictory impulses defining fashion now. Go big, the merchants, designers and trend forecasters will tell you as they tout the charms of outsize pants, crop tops and calf-grazing dresses, while in the same breath trumpeting the sexiness of tiny shapes.

headline: Spring Fashion: Hand Yourself Bouquets
abstract: Shrug off the woolly layers. It’s finally time for some floral mood lifters.
lead_paragraph: There was nothing temperate about Stephanie Solomon’s spring fashion forecast. “Your tights, throw them out,” she urged. “Get rid of your hats, your scarves, but most of all those hose. You never want to see them again.”

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about today’s biggest stories.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: A Rose Is a Rose Is a Song Is a Song
abstract: A songwriter and a theater’s artistic director join hands to bring Gertrude Stein’s rhymes and repetitions to the stage in “The World is Round.”
lead_paragraph: What do Gertrude Stein and Prince have in common? “They’re both androgynous,” said the songwriter-musician Heather Christian playfully, after rehearsals for the new theater piece, “The World is Round,” based on Stein’s children’s book of the same name. They also have a tendency to repeat themselves. Particularly Stein, whose famed circular line “rose is a rose is a rose is a rose” comes from that 1938 book.

headline: 2 Hedge Fund Titans Agree to Buy the Milwaukee Bucks
abstract: The new owners, Marc Lasry and Wesley Edens, have a taste for distressed assets. So the Bucks, the basketball team that currently holds the worst record in the N.B.A., is right up their alley.
lead_paragraph: Two Wall Street bigwigs, Marc Lasry and Wesley Edens, have a taste for distressed assets.

headline: A Homecoming of Sorts for Mark Fields of Ford
abstract: The chief operating officer of Ford Motor delivered the keynote speech as the New York auto show opened for press previews.
lead_paragraph: The opening keynote address at the New York International Auto Show by Mark Fields, chief operating officer of Ford Motor, unsurprisingly promoted innovation and technology, but it sidestepped any discussion of rumors that the company would soon take a new direction with one of its most visible technologies.

headline: From Madonna to Hedwig, Dressing the Divas of Rock
abstract: Veteran fashion stylist Arianne Phillips, makes her Broadway debut in costume design for “Hedwig and the Angry Inch.”
lead_paragraph: ARIANNE PHILLIPS KNOWS from fashion-savvy divas. A veteran fashion stylist and costume designer with a score of films and two Oscar nominations to her name (for Walk the Line and W.E.), she is still best known for styling Madonna, working on her music videos, films and last five world tours.

headline: An Easier Way to Delay Cutting the Cord
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Medicine and Health', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: An awkward maneuver in the delivery room may be unnecessary.
lead_paragraph: Doctors in the delivery room are increasingly urged to hold off cutting the umbilical cord of a newborn. Delayed clamping, as it’s called, allows blood to continue flowing from the placenta, improving iron stores in the baby.

headline: Aston Martin Vantage GT: A Blue Light Special, Comparatively
abstract: An ultraluxury Aston for less than $100,000 may be hard to believe, but its beauty and upper-crust heritage may entice more buyers to the brand.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Wednesday, April 16: 2015 Aston Martin Vantage GT

headline: Sights and Sounds From the Furniture Fair
abstract: The 53rd International Milan Furniture Fair had more than 350,000 visitors from some 160 countries.
lead_paragraph: The 53rd International Milan Furniture Fair had more than 350,000 visitors from some 160 countries.

headline: Square Feet: 84. Possessions: 305.
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Sustainable Living', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: After a heart attack, Dee Williams downsized. Way down.
lead_paragraph: From time to time, Dee Williams does a possession count. The last tally was 305.

headline: Discounts at Broadway Panhandler and Lightology
keywords: ['Lighting', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Cooking and Cookbooks']
abstract: Deals on cooking supplies and lamps.
lead_paragraph: Holiday cooking essentials are up to 65 percent off at Broadway Panhandler, through Sunday or while supplies last (a Wusthof five-inch Santoku knife, originally $135, is about $50; a Le Creuset round skillet grill, regularly $220, is about $120); 65 East Eighth Street (Broadway), 212-966-3434 or broadwaypanhandler.com.

headline: Should We Remove Wall-to-Wall Carpeting?
keywords: ['Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Floors and Flooring', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Do It Yourself']
abstract: Consider replacing it with hardwood flooring and area rugs.
lead_paragraph: Q. We have worn carpet in our bedrooms and hardwood floors in the rest of the house. Should we replace the carpet, change it to hardwood or leave it as is?

headline: Your Trainer Saw That
abstract: Tracking devices like Fitbit and Up24 are increasingly being used by gyms to monitor clients’ activity.
lead_paragraph: Angela Harrigan, a personal trainer at Life Time Fitness, sees each client maybe two hours per week, but she knows exactly how much of the other 166 hours they’ve spent furthering — or undoing — their efforts.

headline: Gather Round the Fire, Wherever You Want It
abstract: The Dude is a fire pit you can take on the road.
lead_paragraph: Behold the Dude: the first truly portable fire pit and grill from the Salt Lake City-based Cowboy Cauldron Company. This 45-pound vessel, the smallest of the company’s four hemispherical braziers, was designed with migratory outdoor entertaining in mind.

headline: A Cold One Wrapped in Plastic
abstract: Govino introduces an affordable yet classy beer glass.
lead_paragraph: Govino, a company known for making plastic wineglasses you wouldn’t be embarrassed to use in public, recently introduced something similar for beer. “Craft brew is huge right now,” said Joseph Perrulli, the creative director. “We saw an opening, went back and forth on designs and settled on a classic pilsner shape.”

headline: Study Finds No Evidence of Heartbleed Attacks Before the Bug Was Exposed
abstract: Researchers found a way to trace whether attackers have used Heartbleed and found that, since January, nobody was exploiting the bug before its disclosure last week.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Ever since the Heartbleed bug was exposed last week, the question everyone has been asking is: Did anyone exploit it before a Google researcher first discovered it?

headline: Symbolism Meets Modern Life
abstract: Amy Reichert’s custom-made Judaica blends the Torah’s directions with modern needs and her own artistic sense.
lead_paragraph: Amy Reichert, an architect and exhibitions designer in Chicago, devotes part of her time to creating custom-made limited-edition Judaica, a challenge that requires adapting ancient synagogue fittings to modern clients’ needs, and then explaining them to craft artists who may never have attended a Seder. She has turned floating brass flowers into menorahs, has decorated silver Sabbath goblets with pearls and has had elm Seder plates carved to resemble desert dunes.

headline: Their Game, Now Ours
abstract: Soccer, particularly England’s Premier League, is being adopted by the creative circles in the United States.
lead_paragraph: What, you didn’t catch Liverpool storm back against Manchester City last week? You missed Wayne Rooney’s 58-yard wonder goal against West Ham United?

headline: When Our Maids Lived In
abstract: “Manhattan Classic: New York’s Finest Prewar Apartments” will have Manhattanites longing for the prewar era.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a real estate hound, “Manhattan Classic: New York’s Finest Prewar Apartments” (Princeton Architectural Press, $50) is either a twist of the knife or a handy resource, depending on your point of view and your bank account. A total of 85 apartment houses built from the 1880s to the 1930s, the city’s first building boom, are collected here, along with floor plans and some interior photos. An index organizes buildings by architect or developer.

headline: Bentley Flying Spur V8: A Smaller Engine Arrives for North America

And she has produced a collection of furniture for Decca. So she knows how essential an occasional table is when you’re entertaining.

headline: In Milan, Putting a Pretty Face on It
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows']
abstract: At the recent furniture fair, a challenged industry resorts to the ultimate strategy: making livable, or at least lovable, products.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — At the 53rd International Furniture Fair here, which ended on Sunday, the German designer Konstantin Grcic introduced a chair for the Finnish company Artek. Running into him midweek, I congratulated him on the piece. “You’ve gotten in touch with your inner girl,” I said.

headline: Luxury Oral-Care
keywords: ['Toothbrushes and Toothpaste', 'Teeth and Dentistry', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries']
abstract: Three above average toothpastes creating competition for beloved Italian brand Marvis.
lead_paragraph: When celebrities are asked about their personal grooming habits, they often cite Marvis as their preferred toothpaste. But this beloved Italian brand is facing competition in the luxury mouth-freshening department.

headline: Dutch Design, Up for Bid
abstract: On April 23, three dozen Droog pieces will be offered at Heritage Auctions in Dallas.
lead_paragraph: The Cosmopolitan of Las Vegas, a glass slab of casino halls and 3,000 hotel rooms, once had an avant-garde attraction as well: a street-level showroom devoted to the Dutch design company Droog, whose signature witticisms (dresser drawers roped together, rags stacked to form chairs, milk bottles clustered into chandeliers) were shown on a translucent white floor.

headline: Witness to History, Searching for Dignity
abstract: Twenty years after the genocide in Rwanda, David Turnley dug through his archives to confront not just ghastly images of atrocity, but also glimmers of human dignity and hope.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years after the genocide in Rwanda, David Turnley dug through his archives to confront not just ghastly images of atrocity, but also glimmers of human dignity and hope.

headline: An Indecent Burial
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'McCutcheon v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'ABORTION', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: A recent campaign finance ruling by the Supreme Court shows the extent to which the free speech claim has become an engine of deregulation.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-five years ago this month, with the Supreme Court’s support for the right to abortion shrinking rapidly, the justices heard a case from Missouri that invited them to disavow Roe v. Wade, the precedent that 16 years earlier had given women the constitutional right to terminate a pregnancy. A month after the argument, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist circulated to his colleagues a proposed majority opinion that would have overturned Roe in all but name, upholding the challenged regulations under such a relaxed standard of judicial review that states in the future would have been able to impose nearly any obstacle to abortion that they might think of.

headline: Gee, Perfect Through Four Innings, Sparkles as Mets Sweep Diamondbacks
abstract: Dillon Gee pitched seven scoreless innings, but he was pulled after 72 pitches, leaving some concern about his ability to pitch deep into games.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — For four innings, Dillon Gee was perfect, and through six innings, he was still cruising. In the seventh, however, he began to look human, and soon his day was done.

headline: The Deepwater Horizon Threat
keywords: ['Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Not enough has been done to prevent a blowout at another well.
lead_paragraph: FOUR years ago this Sunday, BP’s Macondo well in the Gulf of Mexico blew out, destroying the Deepwater Horizon drilling rig, killing 11 workers and setting off an uncontrolled oil gusher lasting 87 days. By the time the flow was stopped, an estimated 200 million gallons of oil had entered the ocean.

headline: Openings, Events and Sales for the Week of April 17

headline: America’s Urban Future
keywords: ['Suburbs', 'Urban Areas', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Transit Systems', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Our cities are booming. So why do we still subsidize suburbs?
lead_paragraph: FOR all of the attention showered on hipster enclaves like Williamsburg, Brooklyn and Portland, Ore., America is only in the beginning stages of a historic urban reordering. After over a half-century of depopulation, cities have been filling up — and not just with young millennials, but with families and even older workers and retirees.

headline: Minimum Wage, Maximum Outrage
abstract: Even if both parties are playing politics with this issue to some degree, which side would you rather be on?
lead_paragraph: No one should ever endure the kind of economic humiliation that comes with working a full-time job and making a less-than-living wage.

headline: James Murdoch Joins Board of Advertising Start-Up
abstract: The appointment comes as True[X], a venture capital-backed start-up, refreshes its board, bringing in industry expertise as it grows.
lead_paragraph: James Murdoch, the co-chief operating officer of 21st Century Fox, has joined the board of True[X] Media, an advertising company based in New York.

headline: My Father’s Strength
abstract: A New York City tunnel worker, he always relied on his body, until he was told he had Parkinson’s.
lead_paragraph: On the afternoon before my college graduation in 1999, there was a ceremony for graduates who were getting department prizes. My father was a New York City tunnel worker (a “sandhog”) and at that time he was working on Roosevelt Island, a 20-minute drive from Barnard’s campus. He always showered before leaving the job site, and on that day he’d brought khakis, a freshly pressed shirt and tie and the new jacket my mother had gotten him for his 55th birthday. I remember what he was wearing because it was the first time I noticed him holding a handkerchief, which he used throughout the ceremony to dab the corners of his mouth. After, when we were discussing where to have dinner, I spotted a narrow river of saliva traveling down the side of his chin.

headline: Obama Speaks on Jobs in Pennsylvania
abstract: President Obama spoke about job training at the Community College of Allegheny County in Oakdale, Pa.
lead_paragraph: President Obama spoke about job training at the Community College of Allegheny County in Oakdale, Pa.

keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: OAKDALE, Pa. — President Obama, seeking to shore up support for midterm elections that threaten to cost his party control of the Senate, vowed Wednesday to improve federal job training programs and chastised Republicans for blocking an overhaul of immigration law.

headline: Former Senator Is Selling the Bucks After Three Decades
abstract: Herb Kohl, a former U.S. senator from Wisconsin, is selling the N.B.A. Milwaukee Bucks for $550 million.
lead_paragraph: Herb Kohl, who retired last year as a United States senator from Wisconsin after four terms, announced Wednesday that he was set to end his long run as the owner of the Milwaukee Bucks.

abstract: Has fear come to play too big a role in government policy and the level of protection Americans seek?

headline: Precision to Meet Brute Force
abstract: The Rangers and the Flyers both started the season slowly but worked their way into the playoffs with a strong finish.
lead_paragraph: When the first-round playoff series between the Rangers and the Flyers begins Thursday at Madison Square Garden, the assumption is that Philadelphia will try to thump, crash and physically intimidate the Rangers. The evidence? First, the Flyers accumulated the most penalty minutes in the N.H.L. this season, while the Rangers finished 22nd. And then there is the whole Broad Street Bullies tradition.

lead_paragraph: Alfa Romeo attempts a comeback in the United States.

headline: Boston Police to Bolster Presence Before Marathon
keywords: ['Marathon Running', 'Boston Marathon Bombings (2013)', 'Police', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Boston Marathon']
abstract: The police said they would increase their visibility near the finish line ahead of the race after a tribute on Tuesday to the victims of last year’s attack was marred by a bomb scare.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Police officials pledged Wednesday to step up their presence near the finish line before next week’s Boston Marathon, after Tuesday’s day of tribute to the victims of last year’s attack was marred by a bomb scare that shut down the area for hours.

headline: Suburbs Try to Prevent an Exodus as Young Adults Move to Cities and Stay
abstract: A report found that counties like Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk faced tough competition from New York City for young people, perhaps because of less diversity and a dearth of modest rentals.
lead_paragraph: It is a well-trod trail: Suburban youngsters enter their early 20s, leave their parents’ comfortable Tudors or colonials for the pizazz of the city, dawdle a few years until they find mates and begin having children and then, seeking more space and good public schools, move back to the suburbs and into their own Tudors or colonials.

headline: A Quick, Satisfying Drive in the 2015 Honda Fit
keywords: ['Small Cars (Compact, Subcompact and Microcars)', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'New York International Auto Show']
abstract: The Fit features sharper styling and a revised interior layout that makes it feel much larger than it is.
lead_paragraph: True to its name, the 2015 Honda Fit just fits. It’s a small car, and accordingly, weaves through tight urban spaces with ease. But for something so tiny, it has a lot of space inside – not just the kind that looks good in brochures, but the sort that makes drivers feel at ease, like they have finally escaped the womblike experience so many automakers offer, even on much larger cars.

headline: A Settlement on Soured Mortgages May Raise Questions on What Is Enough
abstract: A $950 million settlement that involves Bank of America indicates that, in some cases, the banks could have been made to pay more than they have.

headline: What the Huracán and the Honeycomb Have in Common

Lamborghini’s Huracán LP 610-4 was shown Tuesday at Bathhouse Studios, a former site of public baths on the Lower East Side that has been turned into a photo studio and event space.

headline: It’s Official: Yahoo’s Former No. 2 Made a Lot More Than His Boss
abstract: Henrique de Castro, who was fired as Yahoo’s chief operating officer in January, received about $96 million for his 15 months of service. Yahoo’s chief executive, Marissa Mayer, was awarded only $62 million in roughly the same time period.
lead_paragraph: Henrique de Castro, who was fired in January as Yahoo’s chief operating officer, was paid handsomely for his largely unsuccessful efforts to turn around the company’s flailing advertising business.

headline: Between Obama and Putin, a Game of He Said, He Said

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia telephoned President Obama on Monday afternoon to discuss the escalating crisis in Ukraine. On that, the White House and the Kremlin agree. On just about everything else, the two sides are hopelessly at odds.

headline: Nissan Offers Owners of the Leaf E.V. Free Electricity
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'New York International Auto Show']
abstract: The company said at the New York auto show that charging will be free for two years in several markets for new Leaf customers.
lead_paragraph: Nissan has sold more than 110,000 Leaf battery electric cars around the world and almost 50,000 in the United States, but it obviously wants to increase that. Americans respond to “free gas” promotions, so the company is trying something similar with electricity. Fred Diaz, senior vice president in Nissan’s sales and marketing after-sales operation, said Wednesday at the New York show that charging is going to be free for two years to new Leaf customers, first in 10 top markets, and later in 25.

lead_paragraph: For its most provocative investigative target, an anticorruption commission appointed last year by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo set out to scrutinize the millions of dollars earned by New York legislators who also have other jobs.

headline: Weibo, a Chinese Answer to Twitter, Prices Its Offering at $17
abstract: The microblogging service set a price at the bottom of its expected range, and will carry a value well below that of Twitter when it begins trading on the public markets.
lead_paragraph: Weibo, the microblogging service formed by the Sina Corporation, has been called the Twitter of China. But the company will carry a value well below that of its American counterpart when it begins trading on the public markets.

headline: Russia Economy Worsens Even Before Sanctions Hit
abstract: With the country’s long-troubled economy teetering on the edge of recession, average Russians are feeling the pinch, even before the bite of Western sanctions over Crimea.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Margarita R. Zobnina, a professor of marketing here, has been watching the Russian economy’s gathering woes with mounting alarm: friends who have moved abroad with no plans to return; others who put off new business ventures because of rising uncertainty. Meanwhile, Ms. Zobnina and her husband, Alexander, also a professor, have rented a safe deposit box to hold foreign cash as a hedge against the declining ruble.

headline: Spying at the N.Y.P.D.

abstract: The commissioner of the New York Police Department did the right thing when he disbanded the unit that spied on law-abiding Muslim citizens.
lead_paragraph: Commissioner William Bratton took an important step toward restoring trust in the New York Police Department this week when he disbanded a unit used by his predecessor, Raymond Kelly, to conduct an indefensible program of spying on law-abiding Muslims in neighborhoods and houses of worship.

headline: Pensioners in Detroit Rejoice, Though Deal Is Far From Done
abstract: A day after Detroit scaled back the large pension benefit cuts it had proposed, the bankrupt city fended off charges that it had caved in to retirees in ways that could come back to haunt it.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The relief was palpable.

headline: Rangers and Coach Are Lost No Longer
abstract: Coach Alain Vigneault has adapted to New York, and the Rangers, on a hot streak entering the playoffs, have adapted to him.
lead_paragraph: Rangers Coach Alain Vigneault needed a few months to adjust to New York after moving from Vancouver. There was the time he turned his car uptown trying to get to his Upper West Side apartment, but he did it on Dyer Avenue. He wound up at the other end of the Lincoln Tunnel, in New Jersey.

headline: Talks a Chance for Russia to Step Back on Ukraine
abstract: The talks on Ukraine that are set to begin in Geneva on Thursday are a pivotal test of Russia’s intentions before the United States and European nations decide whether to impose more economic sanctions.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The high-level talks on Ukraine that are set to begin here on Thursday have emerged as a pivotal test of Russia’s intentions in the region before the United States and European nations decide whether to impose additional economic sanctions on Moscow, American officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Syrian War Takes Heavy Toll at a Crossroad of Cultures
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'ARCHAEOLOGY', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Fighting has damaged Palmyra and other archaeological sites, and made it easier for thieves to smuggle hundreds of antiquities out of the country.
lead_paragraph: PALMYRA, Syria — The imposing stone colonnades still stand, below stark hills dotted with tombs. They still glow peach-pink in the afternoon sun, impassive, as if unimpressed by what is, after all, not their first war.

headline: Criminalizing Expectant Mothers
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Law and Legislation', 'State Legislatures', 'Editorials']
abstract: A bill awaiting the governor’s signature in Tennessee could make pregnant women who use illegal drugs too scared to seek medical care.
lead_paragraph: Even by the standards of the growing Republican assault on the lives and rights of women, a new bill passed by bipartisan majorities in both houses of Tennessee’s Legislature recently stands out for being meanspirited and counterproductive.

abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Officer Stands by His Account of Scuffle at Occupy Wall Street Protest
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Attacks on Police', 'Traffic and Parking Violations']
abstract: Officer Grantley Bovell admitted in court Wednesday that he had fixed several traffic tickets before 2011, but said that he had told the truth about being assaulted by a protester in 2012.
lead_paragraph: A New York City police officer admitted in court on Wednesday that he had fixed several traffic tickets before 2011, but said that he had told the truth about being assaulted by an Occupy Wall Street protester in 2012.

abstract: Critics claim the central bank has lost its independence under Gyorgy Matolcsy, whose policies have included aggressive rate cuts.

headline: Reining In Predatory Schools
abstract: The Obama administration should strengthen its new rules against for-profit colleges that saddle poor students with crippling debts.
lead_paragraph: The for-profit college industry is pressuring the Obama administration to water down proposed new rules that would deny federal student aid to career training programs that saddle students with crippling debt while giving them useless credentials.

headline: In Ukraine, Seeking U.S. Aid
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Ukrainians have been bullied relentlessly by Russia. Why aren’t we doing more to stand up for them?
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — For decades, Ukrainians have been starved, oppressed and bullied by Russians, and, with Russia now inciting instability that could lead to an invasion and dismemberment of eastern Ukraine, plenty of brave Ukrainians here say they’ve had it and are ready to go bear-hunting.

headline: Hey, George, We Made It Back to Broadway
abstract: James Franco and Chris O’Dowd both make Broadway debuts in the respectable, respectful and generally inert revival of John Steinbeck’s “Of Mice and Men.”
lead_paragraph: See those two guys sitting up there on the stage — the big, slow feller and his smaller, quicker pal? Don’t you somehow get the feeling they’ve been crouched at that campfire forever? And that you’ve been watching them for just about as long?

headline: Carefully Consider
abstract: Mary Lou Guizzo, ably mentored by Jeff Chen, smiles at us.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — How often do you find your daily crossword puzzle grinning at you? Is that a friendly, “Come solve me” look, or a strange, off-season jack-o’-lantern?

headline: In Ukraine, Russia Plays a Weighted Word Game
abstract: If one ignores the images of masked men armed to the teeth and just listens to Russian television, the drama in eastern Ukraine can seem like a quarrel among constitutional scholars.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — If one ignores the images of masked men armed to the teeth and just listens to Russian television, the drama in eastern Ukraine can sometimes seem little more than a quarrel among constitutional scholars. The gunmen, denounced by the Ukrainian government as violent separatists, are invariably referred to by Russian officials and their state-controlled news media simply as “supporters of federalization.”

headline: After 2 Years, M.T.A. and Union Close In on a New Contract
abstract: Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union was likely to receive a sizable raise for 34,000 transit employees as the agency appears to have moved away from its demands for a wage freeze.
lead_paragraph: More than two years after its contract expired, the union representing New York City’s subway and bus workers is involved in intense negotiations with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and appears on the cusp of reaching a new contract, union and government officials said Wednesday.

headline: Central African Republic: Aid Sought for Those Fleeing Unrest
abstract: The United Nations refugee agency said Wednesday that it was working to seek $274 million in emergency donations to support refugees fleeing violence in the Central African Republic.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations refugee agency said Wednesday that it was working with 14 other humanitarian relief groups to seek $274 million in emergency donations to support the swelling population of refugees fleeing violence in the Central African Republic, one of Africa’s most dysfunctional countries. The refugee agency said nearly 200,000 residents had escaped to neighboring countries over the last four months. More than 600,000 people were displaced inside the Central African Republic because of communal violence that has effectively partitioned the country into Christian and Muslim sectors. António Guterres, the United Nations high commissioner for refugees, said in a statement that all relief agencies working in the region were “dramatically underfunded” and that his own agency was far outspending what it had expected. “This cannot be sustained,” he said.

headline: Gaza: Blasts Kill Hamas Militants
abstract: Three militants were killed Wednesday and five people were wounded when several explosions ripped through a Hamas facility in the southern Gaza Strip.
lead_paragraph: Three militants were killed Wednesday and five people were wounded when several explosions ripped through a Hamas facility in the southern Gaza Strip. The cause of the explosions was under investigation, but officials of Hamas, the militant Palestinian faction that controls Gaza, said they were the result of a “jihad mission,” a term that refers to militants felled in work accidents or during training. The dead were identified as members of Hamas’s armed wing. Four of the wounded were firefighters or others who rushed to the scene.

headline: Pineda’s Line: No Runs Allowed, and No More Talk
abstract: Michael Pineda, who drew attention because of a substance on his hand in his last start, allowed four hits in six innings as the Yankees shut out the Cubs in the second game of a doubleheader.
lead_paragraph: The attention on Michael Pineda started with the integrity of his right hand. It soon transitioned to the electricity of his right arm.

headline: ‘The Americans’ Recap: Who’s Good?
abstract: Good has many definitions — often contradictory ones.
lead_paragraph: Is anyone on “The Americans” a good person?

headline: India Election Digest: April 17
abstract: A roundup of the local election-related news for Thursday.
lead_paragraph: What you need to know about India’s election on Thursday: The fifth and biggest round of India’s national elections gets underway, with 121 constituencies across 12 states and union territories going to vote. What’s at stake: 28 seats in Karnataka, followed by Rajasthan (20), Maharashtra (19), Uttar Pradesh and Odisha (11 each), Madhya Pradesh (10), Bihar (seven), Jharkhand (six), West Bengal (four), Chhattisgarh (three), Manipur and the state of Jammu and Kashmir (one each).

headline: Boston Police on Suspicious Backpacks
abstract: The Boston police superintendent for the night command said that a man was arrested and charged after two backpacks were found near the marathon finish line.
lead_paragraph: The Boston police superintendent for the night command said that a man was arrested and charged after two backpacks were found near the marathon finish line.

headline: Woodson Is Looking to Next Season, but Others’ Eyes Are on Him
abstract: Before the Knicks’ season finale, a 95-92 win over Toronto, Coach Mike Woodson gave his players advice for the off-season, even though his future was uncertain.
lead_paragraph: Before the Knicks played the Toronto Raptors on Wednesday night, Mike Woodson wore black as he met with the news media, perhaps for the final time as Knicks coach. He used the word “unfortunately” in response to four separate questions.

headline: Alan Davie, Painter With a Global Bent, Dies at 93
abstract: Mr. Davie appropriated mythical and mystical imagery from various cultures, including Navajo, Celtic, Caribbean, aboriginal Australian and ancient Egyptian.
lead_paragraph: Alan Davie, a Scottish-born painter whose audacious and colorful abstractions put a personal stamp on Pollock-like expressionism and seized on mythical and mystical imagery from cultures around the globe, died on April 5 at his home in Hertfordshire, north of London. He was 93.

headline: F. Reid Buckley, Novelist and Columnist, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Buckley, brother to former Senator James L. Buckley and the conservative commentator William F. Buckley Jr., preferred the South to New York’s literary scene.
lead_paragraph: F. Reid Buckley, a novelist, columnist, founder of a school of public speaking and, in family lore, the most literary of Aloise and William F. Buckley Sr.’s 10 children, including former Senator James L. Buckley and the conservative commentator William F. Buckley Jr., died on Monday in hospice care in Columbia, S.C. He was 83.

headline: Spring Shape-Up Secrets From the Fashion Crowd’s Favorite New Gym
abstract: The trainer Stephen Cheuk, owner of the sleek workout center S10 Training in TriBeCa, shares five different regimens to upgrade various areas of the body in time for the warm season.
lead_paragraph: Rare is the gym that can be described as aesthetically pleasing. Yet that’s just what the trainer Stephen Cheuk has assembled at S10 Training, his recently opened fitness center in the TriBeCa neighborhood in New York. Designed by Samuel Amoia Associates, which has previously undertaken projects for André Balazs and Ian Schrager, it features mirrored changing-room cubes, brick walls with a lime-wash finish and a prominently placed photograph by Jim Mangan. The stylish look suits Cheuk’s roster of clients, which includes the Alexander Wang design team, the actor-slash-designer Waris Ahluwalia and a host of other downtown fashion types. “It’s a visually beautiful gym, which doesn’t hurt when you’re working out,” notes Ahluwalia, who has trained with Cheuk for years.

headline: A Rare Look at a Fashion Photographer’s Personal Body of Work
abstract: In this installment of a new series from the photo editors of T, we gather a group of images from Alasdair McLellan’s new book, a collection of his photographs of young men and landscapes in and around his native Yorkshire.
lead_paragraph: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: The End of Our Financial Illusions
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Much progress has been made on overseeing the largest banks, but a good deal more must be done to toughen standards and end government subsidies, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz professor of entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: The Antidepressant Generation
keywords: ['ANTIDEPRESSANTS', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Youth']
abstract: A growing number of young adults are taking psychiatric medicines for longer and longer periods, at the very age when they are also consolidating their identities, making plans for the future and navigating adult relationships.
lead_paragraph: “I think our experiment failed,” the young graduate student told me, referring to our attempt to take her off the antidepressant she’d been on for seven years. She was back in my campus office after a difficult summer break, and as she talked about feeling unsettled and upset, I wondered about the broader experiment playing out on college campuses across the country.

headline: Times Minute | What Will Stop Russia?
abstract: With tensions between Kiev and Moscow at new heights, two approaches are being tried in Geneva and Washington this week to calm the crisis.
lead_paragraph: With tensions between Kiev and Moscow at new heights, two approaches are being tried in Geneva and Washington this week to calm the crisis.

headline: Nets Get 6th Seed and Will Face Raptors
abstract: The Nets lost to the Cavaliers, 114-85, allowing the Wizards to pass them for the Eastern Conference’s fifth seed. Washington will face the Bulls in the first round of the playoffs while the Nets will travel to Toronto.
lead_paragraph: Dwane Casey, the Toronto Raptors’ coach, laughed off the notion Wednesday afternoon that any Eastern Conference teams might have conspired during the final days of the regular season to establish more favorable playoff positions. There were too many variables and possible outcomes, particularly among the conference’s No. 3 to No. 6 seeds, he said.

headline: The 2014 New York Auto Show
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'New York International Auto Show', 'Javits, Jacob K, Convention Center (NYC)']
abstract: The auto show displays some of the newest models from Alfa Romeo, Hyundai, Ford and Toyota. There’s also a peek at what’s to come in the next-generation Mazda Miata. Above, the Jaguar F-Type R.
lead_paragraph: The auto show displays some of the newest models from Alfa Romeo, Hyundai, Ford and Toyota. There’s also a peek at what’s to come in the next-generation Mazda Miata. Above, the Jaguar F-Type R.

headline: Warren Forma, Documentary Filmmaker, Is Dead at 90
abstract: Mr. Forma profiled nearly two dozen artists on “Artists at Work,” a series of television programs. Some of his films were screened at museums.
lead_paragraph: Warren Forma, a documentary filmmaker who profiled nearly two dozen artists for a series of television programs called “Artists at Work,” died on March 26 in Manhattan. He was 90.

headline: What’s On Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Fuse) PIRATE RADIO (2009) The time: Britain in the mid-1960s, when the BBC, aided by the government, kept official radio channels mostly free of rock ’n’ roll. The place: a tanker off the British coast, where rebel broadcasters (Philip Seymour Hoffman, Bill Nighy and Rhys Ifans, above at microphone) blasted the Stones, the Kinks, Jimi Hendrix and the Who over the airwaves. This angers a government minister (Kenneth Branagh) who wants to keep listeners safe with high culture and educational programming. The director of this movie, Richard Curtis, “isn’t concerned with exploring why gatekeepers might want to maintain the divide between high and popular culture,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “He wants to party. So he piles on the comic high jinks, lobs the jokes and cranks the splendid tunes.” Mr. Nighy can also be seen as a financially distressed British retiree lured to Jaipur, India, in John Madden’s “Best Exotic Marigold Hotel” (2012), at 4:45 on MoreMax, and as the washed-up rock star Billy Mack, angling for a comeback, in Mr. Curtis’s “Love Actually” (2003), at 8 on Showtime.

headline: Workers Strike at Shoe Factory Over Benefits Dispute
abstract: Workers at one of the world’s largest shoe manufacturers are on strike in the southern Chinese city of Dongguan in a dispute over benefits.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of workers at one of the world’s largest shoe manufacturers are continuing a strike in the southern Chinese city of Dongguan in a dispute over benefits.

headline: An April Doubleheader (Snow Included)
abstract: The Yankees and Cubs played a day-night twin bill in the Bronx on Wednesday that included snow that made it look like February, winds that made it feel like March, and baseball that was, well, sort of predictable.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees and Cubs played a day-night twin bill in the Bronx on Wednesday that included snow that made it look like February, winds that made it feel like March, and baseball that was, well, sort of predictable.

headline: Question of Identity at Heart of Jharkhand’s Politics
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Indigenous People', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Politics and Government', 'Rural Areas']
abstract: All the major parties in the state favor a domicile policy, which would set aside government jobs and offer university admission preferences to Jharkhandis, but voters are split on who qualifies as a Jharkhandi.
lead_paragraph: RANCHI, India — The eastern state of Jharkhand is a study in contrasts: On one hand, the state is immensely rich in natural resources and contains about 40 percent of India’s mines and mineral reserves, but on the other hand, the region struggles with endemic poverty and rampant unemployment.
