abstract: Corrections appearing in print on April 17, 2014.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: U.S. Activist Investor Turns Eyes Toward Europe
abstract: Jason N. Ader, the chief investment officer of SpringOwl, is using a proxy battle to bring change to Bwin.Party, the British online gambling company.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:34 a.m. | It was only a matter of time before United States activist investors turned their focus to European companies.

headline: An Internet ‘Big V’ Opts for Abject Contrition
abstract: China released Charles Xue, an American businessman highly visible on Chinese microblogs who was detained in August on sex charges. He then appeared in state-run media endorsing the authorities’ treatment of him.
lead_paragraph: Charles Xue, an American businessman who once embodied the raucous energies testing Internet censorship in China, has returned to prominence as the opposite: a contrite prisoner endorsing the government’s determination to cleanse and control the Web. In a display recalling the Communist Party’s past ideological offensives, Mr. Xue was shown on state-run television on Thursday, repenting his misdeeds, endorsing the campaign against him and thanking officials for their mercy.

headline: European Car Sales Strengthen on Manufacturer Incentives
abstract: Registrations of new passenger cars, a proxy for sales, grew 10.6 percent last month, the European Automobile Manufacturers’ Association says.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The European car market continues to grow, according to industry data published on Thursday, with manufacturers’ incentives contributing to a seventh straight monthly gain in March.

headline: Talk About Your History, Oliver Stone Tells Chinese
abstract: The director Oliver Stone dropped a bombshell at the Beijing International Film Festival when he said that China had to face its history in order to stir creativity, a sensitive topic in a country where censorship is the norm.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:07 a.m. ET | The film director Oliver Stone, never one to shy from controversy, dropped a verbal bomb at the Beijing International Film Festival on Thursday, saying that China had to face the truth about its history and criticize Mao Zedong if it wanted to become truly creative.

headline: It’s the End of the World as We Know It . . . and He Feels Fine
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Environment', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: After decades of fervent environmental activism, Paul Kingsnorth decided it’s too late — collapse is inevitable. So now what?
lead_paragraph: Late one night last August, on the chalk downlands of southern England, Paul Kingsnorth stood in a field beside an old-growth forest, two yurts and a composting toilet. Kingsnorth is 41, tall, slim and energetic, with sweeping brown hair and a sparse beard. He wears rimless glasses and a silver stud in his ear, and he talks with great ardor, often apologizing for having said too much or for having said it too strongly.

headline: Witness to History, Searching for Dignity
keywords: ['Archives and Records', 'Photography', 'Pulitzer Prizes', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Volcanoes', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Twenty years after the genocide in Rwanda, David Turnley dug through his archives to confront not just ghastly images of atrocity, but also glimmers of human dignity and hope.
lead_paragraph: David Turnley photographed the Rwanda genocide and its aftermath in 1994 while working for The Detroit Free Press. He won the Pulitzer Prize in 1990, for his coverage of political upheaval in the Eastern bloc and China, including the fall of the Berlin Wall and Tiananmen Square. He has won the World Press Picture of the Year award twice, and the Robert Capa Award for Courage.

headline: Ukrainian Forces Kill 3 Pro-Russian Demonstrators
abstract: The firefight in the city of Mariupol, the most lethal so far in eastern Ukraine, underscored the worsening security situation a day after government forces were humiliated by militants.
lead_paragraph: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — Ukrainian security forces killed three pro-Russian activists, wounded 13 and took 63 captive in a firefight overnight in the eastern city of Mariupol, the interim Ukrainian interior minister said on Thursday. The clash was the most lethal so far in the east of the country.

headline: New York Today: Chilly Critters
abstract: What you need to know for Thursday: animals sleep through the cold, mostly sunny skies, and the Port Authority’s whimsical side.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday morning to you. It’s still cold — 38 degrees, with a wind chill below freezing.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: What you need to know to start your Thursday: Ukraine talks, ferry survivor search, and a Chinese I.P.O.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Away From Show of Diplomacy in Geneva, Putin Puts On a Show of His Own
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin said he hoped invasion of what he called “new Russia” would not be necessary. He also said for the first time that Russian forces had been sent to Crimea.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Even as the world’s top diplomats were gingerly drafting a tentative accord to “de-escalate tensions” in Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin was on national television here, brashly declaring Russia’s historical claims over Ukrainian territory, reiterating a threat to use military force and generally sounding a defiant, even mocking, tone toward the United States.

headline: In Bihar, Economic Concerns Are Tied Up in Caste Politics
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Elections', 'Hinduism', 'Income Inequality', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Politics and Government', 'Poverty', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Development has become a central issue in this year’s elections, but voters are also mindful of how the state government makes decisions based on caste.
lead_paragraph: PATNA, India — In Bihar, one of the poorest states in India, voters in this year’s elections have the economy foremost on their minds, but in a state where the most socially disadvantaged sections of society make up a majority of voters, even economic issues are tied up with caste politics.

headline: For China and Japan, the Economic Challenges Ahead Are Similar
abstract: Analysts and investors are keeping a close watch as both countries work to push through far-reaching changes to their economies.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Japan and China do not always see eye to eye on politics. But when it comes to economic policy, Tokyo and Beijing have remarkably similar goals: Both want to push through far-reaching changes in their economies in the face of mounting debt and rapidly graying populations.

headline: The Problem With Giving Employees a Stipend to Buy Health Insurance
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Small Business']
abstract: If an employer pays each worker the same amount of money to cover health insurance premiums, older employees will have to pay a larger share of their premiums than their younger colleagues. Is that legal?
lead_paragraph: Paul Downs, my You’re the Boss colleague, recently posed a question: If he were to replace the health insurance he offers his employees with a cash payment that they could use to buy their own insurance, would he be committing age discrimination?

headline: Human Error Suspected as Hope Fades in Korean Ferry Sinking
abstract: Evidence is growing that human error contributed to one of South Korea’s worst disasters in recent decades, a ferry sinking from which 271 people are still missing.
lead_paragraph: JINDO, South Korea — The captain was among the first to flee. Only a couple of the 44 life rafts aboard were deployed. The hundreds of passengers were instructed over the intercom to “stay inside and wait” as the ship leaned to one side and began to sink, dragging scores of students down with it.

headline: Daily Report: Google’s Results Disappoint as Ads Are Less Profitable
abstract: As Internet users migrate to mobile devices, Google earns less on its ads, and as the dominant player, the company is finding that growth opportunities are increasingly rare.
lead_paragraph: Alexander the Great is said to have wept because he ran out of kingdoms to conquer. Google is eager to avoid such a miserable fate, David Streitfeld reports.

headline: Morgan Stanley’s Earnings Increase 18%
abstract: Morgan Stanley’s results were driven in part by surprisingly strong performance in the bank’s fixed-income division, which trades bonds, derivatives and commodities.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 11:49 a.m. | Morgan Stanley’s efforts to re-establish itself as a Wall Street powerhouse since the financial crisis gained some ground on Thursday, when the bank reported that first-quarter earnings rose 18 percent from the period a year earlier.

headline: U.S. and Russia Agree on Pact to Defuse Ukraine Crisis
abstract: The foreign ministers of the United States, Russia, Ukraine and European Union reached an agreement in Geneva after more than five hours of talks.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United States, Russia, Ukraine and the European Union reached an agreement here on Thursday evening that calls for armed pro-Russian bands to give up the government buildings they have seized in eastern Ukraine and outlines other steps to de-escalate the crisis.

headline: Perry Evans of Closely, on Craftsmanship and Early Rising
abstract: Mr. Evans, chief and founder of Closely, a digital marketing firm, says he regularly awakes at 4 a.m. and spends “two hours every morning just calibrating what’s going on in my market.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with Perry Evans, chief executive of Closely, a digital marketing firm, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Cannes Film Festival Announces Lineup
abstract: The list of 49 films ranges from an offbeat western directed by Tommy Lee Jones to a tale set inside Hollywood by David Cronenberg.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Cannes Film Festival on Thursday unveiled its picks for its 67th competition. The 49 films include an offbeat western directed by Tommy Lee Jones, a thriller set in Hollywood by David Cronenberg, as well as movies by Mike Leigh, Olivier Assayas, Ken Loach, Jean-Luc Godard and the directorial debut of Ryan Gosling.

headline: A Comment’s Path to Publication
abstract: Bassey Etim, the community manager for NYTimes.com, explains how and why we moderate all reader comments.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Etim is the community manager for NYTimes.com.

abstract: The Blackstone Group’s results soar as the firm and the industry take advantage of buoyant stock markets to sell their investments and collect performance fees.

abstract: The fund, which will focus on investments in North America, attracted $6.5 billion from outside investors, exceeding its target of $6 billion, a person briefed on the matter said.
lead_paragraph: Bain Capital, the big private equity firm based in Boston, has finished raising its latest flagship buyout fund with $7.3 billion in capital, a person briefed on the matter said.

headline: Plants That Practice Genetic Engineering
abstract: Long ago, a new paper suggests, a fern took a useful gene from a neighboring hornwort, an acquisition that allowed ferns to thrive in shade.
lead_paragraph: In the debate over genetically modified crops, one oft-said word is “unnatural.” People typically use it when describing how scientists move genes from one species into another.

headline: Shape-Shifting Into Success
abstract: Embodying a raft of clones? No problem. But having a show with a large following and critics’ accolades makes Tatiana Maslany of “Orphan Black” blush.
lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — When John Fawcett and Graeme Manson, the creators of BBC America’s cult series “Orphan Black,” recall the moment they realized the central conceit of their twisty science-fiction conspiracy drama might actually be believable, they point to a bar scene in the third episode. In it, a bespectacled, dreadlocked Ph.D. student named Cosima has a lengthy conversation with Sarah, a street-savvy British grifter.

headline: Profit and Revenue Drop at Goldman Sachs
abstract: Goldman Sachs reported on Thursday that first-quarter profit declined to $2.03 billion, reflecting a drop in its fixed-income unit and overall revenue, but its results exceeded expectations.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:59 a.m. | Goldman Sachs reported on Thursday that first-quarter profit declined to $2.03 billion, reflecting a drop in overall revenue and a continued slump in its fixed-income business.

keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Parenting', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']

headline: A Big Day for Earnings
abstract: Profit drops at Goldman Sachs but rises at Morgan Stanley. | Blackstone earnings rise 30 percent. | Weibo poised to begin trading. | James Murdoch joins the board of an advertising start-up. | Hedge fund titans buy the Milwaukee Bucks.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs reported a drop in first-quarter profit on Thursday, to $2.03 billion, reflecting declines in its fixed-income unit and overall revenue, Rachel Abrams writes in DealBook. The profit, which translated to $4.02 a share, compared with a profit of $2.2 billion, or $4.29 a share, in the period a year earlier. Wall Street analysts had been expecting $3.44 a share in the first quarter.

headline: Video of Snowden Asking Putin About Surveillance
abstract: Video of the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden asking President Vladimir V. Putin about surveillance during a call-in program on Russian television was quickly posted online by a state-owned broadcaster.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 5:11 p.m. | As my colleague David Herszenhorn reports, the former National Security Agency contractor Edward Snowden made a surprise appearance on Russian television Thursday, asking President Vladimir Putin a question about surveillance during an annual call-in program in which Russia’s leader fields questions from the public for up to four hours.

abstract: Metropolitan Diary: In a quiet moment on the subway, he was reading sheet music, and she was concentrating on a book about a murder spree.

headline: Twitter Goes After a Facebook Cash Cow
abstract: The social network will begin offering “app install ads,” which prompt smartphone users to try new games and other apps. The category has been a lucrative franchise for Facebook.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes the rivalry between Twitter and Facebook is like a children’s game of copycat. Facebook copied Twitter’s hashtags and trending topics. Twitter copied Facebook’s profile page design and automatic display of images in the feed.

headline: Pistorius Trial Adjourns With Key Witness in Doubt
abstract: The trial of Oscar Pistorius, the double-amputee track star accused of murdering his girlfriend, adjourned amid reports that a defense witness will not take the stand.
lead_paragraph: PRETORIA, South Africa — After 25 days of testimony, the trial of Oscar Pistorius, the double-amputee South African track star accused of murdering his girlfriend, adjourned on Thursday amid a report that a crucial defense witness will not take the stand when it resumes on May 5.

headline: G.O.P. Discovers Useful Voter Outreach Tool: Gun Sweepstakes
abstract: Online weapon giveaways have become one of the fastest growing ways for Republican candidates to build up donor lists and expand support.
lead_paragraph: Hand over your email address to a political campaign, and typically all you can expect in return is an endless stream of solicitations for money.

headline: Little House in the Backyard
abstract: After a heart attack, Dee Williams downsized, trading her big house in Portland, Ore., for an 84-square-foot cottage on her friends’ property.
lead_paragraph: After a heart attack, Dee Williams downsized, trading her big house in Portland, Ore., for an 84-square-foot cottage on her friends’ property.

headline: Running Against Republicans, and the Environment
abstract: Senator Mary Landrieu of Louisiana touts her pro-energy bona fides in a new ad.
lead_paragraph: How far should Democrats be prepared to go to keep control of the Senate in November’s election? If they win because one of their members repudiates everything they stand for, is it worth the victory? That’s the troubling question raised by a new re-election campaign ad for Senator Mary Landrieu of Louisiana. Her victory is crucial to preventing a Republican takeover of the Senate, but the environmental positions she takes in the ad sound far more Republican than Democratic.

headline: In Our Pages: April 18
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Britain bans experiments on dogs in 1914; President de Gaulle is well after an operation in 1964.
lead_paragraph: 1914: Dogs Bill Passes in Commons

headline: India’s Biggest Election Day
keywords: ['Elections', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, State Legislature', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: In the country’s fifth and largest phase of polling, 12 states went to vote, with more than one-fifth of the parliamentary seats up for grabs.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — In the country’s fifth and largest phase of polling, 12 states went to the polls Thursday, with more than one-fifth of the parliamentary seats up for grabs.

headline: Bibi van der Velden’s Whimsical Fine Jewelry Collection
abstract: The clever designer, whose fans include Kanye West and Sienna Miller, just debuted a new range at Bergdorf Goodman and Dover Street Market New York.
lead_paragraph: “Fine jewelry,” says the designer and sculptor Bibi van der Velden, “should be taken with a dose of humor.” A thread of whimsy runs through the work of the New York-born, Amsterdam-based designer, whose handcrafted pieces have been collected by the likes of Kanye West and Sienna Miller. Though she started her line in 2006, her work is gaining new attention this season; it recently debuted at Bergdorf Goodman and Dover Street Market in New York and will launch on Net-a-Porter on June 9th. Her spring collection, carved from 40,000-year-old mammoth tusks that emerged from the Russian tundra thanks to global warming, includes such designs as a pendant depicting a cloud raining thunderbolts, a necklace strung with dodo egg-shaped “pearls” and a wraparound dragon ring that features a tiny man clutching a diamond emerging from the jaws of the beast. The natural world is a leitmotif for van der Velden, who likes to tell the story of how an owl once soared through the room at one of her runway shows. For fall, her pieces will incorporate actual scarab wings. “I am fascinated by nature and its beauty,” she says. “I hate to see such beauty go to waste.”

headline: Sometimes a Bad Birthday Gift Has Its Uses
abstract: The singer-songwriter Jill Sobule needed inspiration for a new album and found it in a charm bracelet once owned by a woman she knew nothing about.
lead_paragraph: THE deeper an artist gets into her career, the harder it can be for her to find inspiration, as Jill Sobule can tell you.

headline: Chief of British Conglomerate Calls 2013 Results ‘Disastrous’
abstract: Some chief executives like to sugarcoat bad results, but the interim chief executive of the Co-operative Group felt no such need when reporting the firm’s results.
lead_paragraph: Some chief executives like to sugarcoat bad results, but the interim chief executive of the Co-operative Group felt no such need when reporting the firm’s results on Thursday.

headline: Robin Roberts: By the Book
abstract: The “Good Morning America” anchor and author of “Everybody’s Got Something” calls Maya Angelou her literary hero: As a teenager in Mississippi, “I identified with her quest for independence.”
lead_paragraph: The “Good Morning America” anchor and author of “Everybody’s Got Something” calls Maya Angelou her literary hero: As a teenager in Mississippi, “I identified with her quest for independence.”

headline: The Party Decides, Unless It Can’t
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Notes on a frontrunner-less Republican field.
lead_paragraph: Right now, the most striking thing about the public polling on the 2016 Republican nomination isn’t just the absence of a clear frontrunner: It’s the absence of a clear pair or trio or even a quartet of frontrunners. The latest Iowa poll has Mike Huckabee in the pole position with eleven percent, and then eight (!) others — all of whom are more serious figures than some of the characters who briefly polled well last time around — bunched between six and ten percent; the national polling average isn’t quite that compressed, but it’s close. This can’t last, but everyone recognizes that the situation is historically unusual (as, on the other side, is Hillary Clinton’s extraordinary advantage); the question is, how unusual, and what does it mean for the normal way that these things shake out?

headline: Pregnancy Weight Gain Predicts Child’s Obesity
abstract: Gaining too much weight during pregnancy is associated with an increased risk that your child will be obese as a preschooler, new evidence shows. Gaining too little weight may have the same effect.
lead_paragraph: Gaining too much weight during pregnancy — or too little — is associated with an increased risk that your child will be obese as a preschooler, new evidence shows.

headline: Walmart Will Enter Cash Wiring Business
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Checks and Checking Accounts']
abstract: Fees for the service will be $4.50 for up to $50 transferred and $9.50 for amounts above that, up to $900.
lead_paragraph: In a move that threatens to upend another piece of the financial services industry, Walmart, the country’s largest retailer, announced on Thursday that it would allow customers to make store-to-store money transfers within the United States at cut-rate fees.

headline: Bangalore’s Enthusiastic Young Voters Reflect New Kind of Politics
abstract: Candidates in this year’s elections have been eager to be perceived as presentable, articulate, performance-oriented and of significance in their parties.
lead_paragraph: BANGALORE, India — Sanketh Jain, 22, was excited as he stood in line behind his grandparents outside a crowded polling place in a Bangalore school, ready to vote for the first time in a general election.

headline: What to Do When Your Child Wants Marijuana Stocks
abstract: What to do about a child who wants to buy stock in marijuana companies? Should the fact that we probably don’t want our kids consuming the stuff mean that they shouldn’t try to make money off of it either? Three things to think about when it comes to children’s investing decisions.
lead_paragraph: Some parents consider stock-market investing part of the mandatory household financial literacy curriculum, and they set their children up with a brokerage account at the age of 13. Others follow their children’s lead and help them buy shares whenever they indicate interest.

headline: App for Spotting and Disputing Dubious Charges
abstract: BillGuard helps users track activity across all their credit and debit card accounts and makes approving or contesting a charge as simple as a swipe.
lead_paragraph: XAVIER PLASENCIA knows he should check his credit card and bank account transactions regularly to spot any questionable charges.

headline: SOPA Defeat Haunts Efforts to Rein In Illegal Copying, British Official Says
keywords: ['Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Michael Weatherly, a member of Parliament and adviser to Prime Minister David Cameron, says copyright owners will look to efforts beyond legislation.
lead_paragraph: “It’s going to be five years before anybody puts his head above the parapet again.” That’s how Michael Weatherly, a member of the British Parliament and intellectual property adviser to Prime Minister David Cameron handicapped the prospects for a fresh legislative push against online piracy in the United States.

headline: Basil A. Paterson, 87, a Power in Harlem With Statewide Reach, Dies
abstract: Mr. Paterson, the father of former Gov. David A. Paterson, influenced black political power in New York City and the state for decades.
lead_paragraph: Basil A. Paterson, one of the old-guard Democratic leaders who for decades dominated politics in Harlem and influenced black political power in New York City and the state into the 21st century, when he saw his son David A. Paterson rise to the governor’s office, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 87.

headline: De Blasio’s 2013 Promise to Muslims
abstract: Bill de Blasio, then a mayoral candidate, said at a rally in Brooklyn in October that New York City public schools should recognize the Muslim holidays Eid al-Fitr and Eid al-Adha.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio, then a mayoral candidate, said at a rally in Brooklyn in October that New York City public schools should recognize the Muslim holidays Eid al-Fitr and Eid al-Adha.

headline: French Court Dismisses Hate Speech Case Against Dylan
abstract: An interview with Rolling Stone resulted in a charge against Bob Dylan that has now been dropped.
lead_paragraph: The preliminary charge brought against Bob Dylan in Paris last November for what a Croatian organization said was hate speech comparing Croats to Nazis or the Ku Klux Klan has been dropped by a French court, the French television news station France24 reported.

headline: 2016 Audi A3 TDI Sportback: The A3 Family Gets a Wagon
abstract: The station wagon complements the company’s A3 lineup of small cars, which are all about the size the A4 was about a generation ago.

headline: Muslims in New York City Unite on Push to Add Holidays to School Calendar
abstract: The city’s Muslims do not often work together politically, but they have found common ground in the fight to close public schools for Eid al-Fitr and Eid al-Adha.
lead_paragraph: The meeting opened with a pledge from the podium to try to end, God willing, by the hour of the evening prayer. Clusters of colorfully veiled women kept watch over jittery young children. Rows of men conversed in a jangle of languages.

keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']

lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The Australian authorities looking for the missing Malaysia Airlines jet said Thursday that an oil slick detected in the search zone and collected by the Australian vessel Ocean Shield was not engine oil or hydraulic fluid from an aircraft.

headline: A Majorca Trip for Competitive Cyclists
abstract: The Cycling House is offering endurance camps for cyclists in Majorca.
lead_paragraph: Competitive cyclists who want a hint of vacation in their training schedule might turn to the Cycling House for assistance.

abstract: An ad by Ending Spending Action Fund supports Scott Brown, the former Massachusetts senator, and appeals to New Hampshire voters who oppose President Obama’s health care law.
lead_paragraph: An ad by Ending Spending Action Fund supports Scott Brown, the former Massachusetts senator, and appeals to New Hampshire voters who oppose President Obama’s health care law.

lead_paragraph: An advertisement produced by Americans for Prosperity thanked Representative Steve Southerland for his vote against the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Political Ads, Often Negative, Try Instead to Accentuate the Positive
keywords: ['Political Advertising', 'Political Action Committees', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Some of the best-known “super PACs” are making an effort to also cast their candidates in an appealing way instead of solely attacking opponents.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Outside political groups, long known for their negative advertisements featuring ominous music and foreboding narration, are trying something new this campaign season: a pivot to the positive.

headline: Mac DeMarco on Wearing Women’s Clothing and the Elements of No-Fuss Style
abstract: The fast-rising 23-year-old indie rocker endorses the Canadian tuxedo, putting on lipstick when you’re drunk and buying lots and lots of white shirts from Walmart.
lead_paragraph: Last Tuesday, in the bathroom of his dressing room (the only place he was permitted to smoke), before playing a set at the Williamsburg music venue Baby’s All Right, the rising musician Mac DeMarco imparted insight into his no-fuss style. The key to his look, he confessed, is to avoid overthinking — in other words, to stock up on white Hanes T-shirts and floppy brimmed hats. Effortlessness is central to the 23-year-old Canadian’s approach to pretty much everything. “Take my advice,” he sings on the song “Brother,” from his album “Salad Days,” “to take it slowly, brother.” If that’s your plan this summer, read on to dress the part.

headline: N.B.A. Players Reset Union Search With Kevin Johnson as Point Man
abstract: Kevin Johnson, a former Suns player and the mayor of Sacramento, is leading the search for an executive director for the N.B.A.’s players union, which has been without one since February 2013.
lead_paragraph: It should have been no surprise that when Chris Paul, the N.B.A. players union’s president, went looking for someone to lead the search for the union’s next executive director, he was sold on the purposeful hands of another point guard, Kevin Johnson.

headline: Europeans Look Beyond Their Borders
abstract: To gain traction, many European tech founders often focus on their individual home markets, but that strategy is starting to change.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN – How many people need to use your product before it’s a success?

headline: Arab-Israeli Activist Is Moved to House Arrest
abstract: The Israeli citizen, a Palestinian rights activist, was detained after a visit to Lebanon, on suspicion of an unauthorized visit to an enemy state.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — An Arab citizen of Israel who was detained by the Israeli authorities over the weekend after a visit to Lebanon was released Thursday but ordered to be kept under house arrest. He was being held on suspicion of conducting an unauthorized visit to an enemy state and contact with a foreign agent, according to his lawyers and Israeli security officials.

lead_paragraph: Clashes between Ukrainian forces and pro-russian separatists lead to reports of fatalities in Eastern Ukraine. Also on the Minute, using guns to lure votes and a warning about buying Cheerios.

headline: It’s Showtime. Watch the Closing Doors, Please.
abstract: In Platform, a new series at the New York Transit Museum, artist-commuters perform work inspired by their experiences on the city’s subways and buses.
lead_paragraph: I ENTERED the thronged train and at once noticed the man with long hair. He stood near the center of the car, telling some story about some man who had come back into his life: “He leaned down. I could feel his breath on my face” and “I knew what was going to happen before he told me what was going to happen.”

headline: Lawsuit Aims to Derail New York Library Plan
abstract: A petition filed in New York State Supreme Court claims that the city’s environmental approval process was faulty.
lead_paragraph: In the latest effort to stop the New York Public Library’s renovation of its flagship building on Fifth Avenue, a group of scholars filed a lawsuit on Wednesday, arguing that the Bloomberg administration approved the project without fully evaluating its environmental impact.

headline: Back Onstage, With Fewer Secrets
abstract: Michael C. Hall, who became a television star on “Six Feet Under” and “Dexter,” is back on Broadway in Will Eno’s “The Realistic Joneses.”
lead_paragraph: Michael C. Hall has made a career of playing men with something to hide, the sort who manage their anxieties by pouring themselves into their work, which in the case of his two best-known television roles happened to include embalming and burying the dead (on “Six Feet Under”) and violently avenging the dead (on “Dexter”). Onstage now in the playwright Will Eno’s gnomic, desperate comedy “The Realistic Joneses,” Mr. Hall plays John, a man with plenty to hide but no real trade to busy his hands and thus to take his mind off a mortal secret he carries.

headline: A Bid to Park Recalled G.M. Cars Is Denied
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: A federal judge denied a motion that would have forced General Motors to advise the owners of the 2.6 million recalled cars to keep them off the road until they are fixed.
lead_paragraph: General Motors may be losing the public relations battle in its recall of defective cars, but the company scored a victory on Thursday in its escalating legal war.

headline: Facebook’s New Twist on Location Sharing Puts Users in Control
abstract: The social network is rolling out a new feature, Nearby Friends, that allows mobile users to broadcast their general location to their friends. But simple privacy controls give users the power to decide how much more to share.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Facebook is taking the wraps off a new feature, under development for four years outside and inside the company, that allows mobile users to share their location with their friends on the service.

abstract: After a nearly two decade absence from the United States, the Italian automaker returns with a hot little car, but with not much of a dealer network to sell it.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Wednesday, April 16: 2015 Alfa Romeo 4C sport coupe.

abstract: Admiral Robin K. Dhowan, is appointed as the new chief of the Indian Navy.

headline: Two Out-of-Towners, Happily So

lead_paragraph: When the playwright Catherine Trieschmann comes to New York, she wants dim sum. In the small Kansas town where she lives, turnip cake is scarce. Walks on the High Line tempt Eric Coble, a dramatist who makes his home in Cleveland.

headline: Witness to History, Searching for Dignity
abstract: Twenty years after the genocide in Rwanda, David Turnley dug through his archives to confront not just ghastly images of atrocity, but also glimmers of human dignity and hope.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years after the genocide in Rwanda, David Turnley dug through his archives to confront not just ghastly images of atrocity, but also glimmers of human dignity and hope.

headline: F.D.A. Discourages Procedure in Uterine Surgery
abstract: The procedure, power morcellation, poses a risk of spreading cancerous tissue, the agency said Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Doctors should stop using a procedure performed on tens of thousands of American women a year in the course of uterine surgery, because it poses a risk of spreading cancerous tissue, the Food and Drug Administration said Thursday.

headline: Jabari Parker of Duke Declares for N.B.A. Draft
abstract: Parker, an all-American as a 6-foot-8 freshman, made his announcement in an essay in Sports Illustrated and is expected to be one of the top three players drafted.
lead_paragraph: Jabari Parker, a 6-foot-8 freshman forward at Duke, announced Thursday that he had played his final college basketball game and would enter the 2014 N.B.A. draft.

headline: 36 Hours in Prague
abstract: Many locals still haven’t heard of all the next big things: flashy new art galleries, dynamically developing old neighborhoods, great bars — beyond and including beer — and new restaurants.
lead_paragraph: For people who haven’t traveled to Prague recently, the Czech capital might seem like a known quantity: a city with a thousand years of architecture, cheap beer and often boring restaurants where the most unusual ingredients are the doughy dumplings. But Prague is developing so quickly that many locals still haven’t heard of all the next big things: flashy new art galleries, dynamically developing old neighborhoods, great bars — beyond and including beer — and new restaurants with flavorful offerings from classic steaks and chops to Asian spice. In fact, so many new developments have appeared in Prague that you could spend an entire weekend visiting only those places that have opened in the past couple of years. See Prague Castle, Charles Bridge and all the other classic attractions. But finish out your stay with some of the vibrant newcomers.

headline: In Lecce, Making Magic With Humble Ingredients
abstract: In and around this city in Italy’s heel, a crop of culinary schools and teachers is encouraging travelers to embrace la cucina povera, or “the food of the poor.”
lead_paragraph: La cucina povera. Often translated as “the food of the poor,” the term seems unlikely to make mouths water or inspire serious foodies to blow their vacation budget on a cooking course.

headline: Portraits on the Page of Paris, London and Venice
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: If you’re the type of traveler who likes to go beyond guides to develop a sense of place, one of these recently published or about-to-be-published books could be for you.
lead_paragraph: Paris, London, Venice: hardly the most mysterious places on the planet. Yet beyond Notre Dame, Big Ben and the Basilica di San Marco lie hidden iterations of these well-trodden cities: obscure corners, faded histories and the daily pleasures and aggravations of those who live there. A 19th-century Parisian photographer, a former musician in London and a novelist in Venice are among those who offer unexpected insights in six recently published or about-to-be-published books. Some urge you to visit, others beg you to stay away, all are likely to trigger the wanderlust of those eager to get closer to the authentic heart of a place.

headline: The Personification of Legends
abstract: The carefully cultivated public personas of Billie Holiday and Louis Armstrong reach the stage in two productions, “Satchmo at the Waldorf” and “Lady Day at Emerson’s Bar & Grill.”
lead_paragraph: Louis Armstrong, who always knew how to make an entrance, gets a doozy of an opening scene in “Satchmo at the Waldorf,” a one-man show now playing at the Westside Theater. It’s March 1971 and dark as night in the trumpeter and singer’s dressing room at the Waldorf-Astoria, except for a Hopperesque shaft of light streaming through the door. A muffled ovation rises and falls in the distance, and then in he comes, lurching wheezily toward an oxygen tank across the room.

headline: BlackRock Profit Rises as It Attracts More Money From Investors
abstract: The giant asset management firm BlackRock said its profit rose 20 percent to $756 million in the first quarter, as it attracted more money to its mutual fund products.
lead_paragraph: The giant asset management firm BlackRock said its profit rose 20 percent in the first quarter, as it attracted more money to its mutual fund products.

headline: Goldman Says It Has No Plans to Exit Dark Pool Business
keywords: ['High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Harvey Schwartz, the chief financial officer of Goldman Sachs, told analysts that he had “no strategic plans” to close the bank’s dark pool trading business known as Sigma X.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs is not quite ready to get out of the pool.

headline: Uber Faces Rebukes in Europe
abstract: The company’s global problems add to the bumps the company face in the United States, including opposition from taxi groups and driver complaints.
lead_paragraph: Updated to add more on the decision not to enforce the injunction in Berlin.

headline: Vision of Home
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Museums', 'Art', 'ARCHAEOLOGY', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: It’s a new life for many repatriated antiquities, back on display in their countries of origin.
lead_paragraph: AIDONE, Sicily — The ruins of the ancient Greek city of Morgantina sit high on a hill in eastern Sicily. There are cherry trees, wildflowers and total stillness, save for the sound of bird song. The area has long been sacred to Persephone; legend has it that Hades pulled that goddess into the underworld by a nearby lake.

headline: Suit Accuses Director of New ‘X-Men’ Film of Sexual Assault
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Sex Crimes', 'Movies', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: The suit against Bryan Singer involves events said to have taken place 14 years ago.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The filmmaker Bryan Singer, whose big-budget “X-Men: Days of Future Past” is set for release next month by 20th Century Fox, was accused in a federal lawsuit filed on Wednesday of drugging and raping an underage boy here and in Hawaii more than 14 years ago.

headline: In Effort to Fight Overdoses, Staten Island Officers Will Soon Carry Heroin Antidote
abstract: All police officers in the borough, and emergency medical workers across New York City, will be equipped with naloxone, a drug that can reverse the effects of an overdose.
lead_paragraph: Police officers across Staten Island will soon be equipped with and trained to use a nasal spray that reverses the effects of a heroin or opioid pill overdose, the authorities said on Thursday.

headline: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 56
abstract: Demand for tickets to the tournament is soaring among Americans, according to viagogo, a worldwide ticket exchange.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Snowden Asks Putin About Surveillance
abstract: Edward J. Snowden, the former United States government contractor, asked President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia a question about surveillance during a call-in session broadcast on Russian television.
lead_paragraph: Edward J. Snowden, the former United States government contractor, asked President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia a question about surveillance during a call-in session broadcast on Russian television.

headline: Cast of ‘Fun Home’ Heading to South Carolina Amid Dispute Over Book
abstract: The College of Charleston has been threatened with a budget cut after providing all incoming students for 2013-14 with a copy of Alison Bechdel’s memoir, “Fun Home.”
lead_paragraph: The cast of the recent Off Broadway musical “Fun Home” will travel to South Carolina next week to perform scenes from the critically acclaimed show at the College of Charleston, which has been threatened with a state budget cut because the school encouraged freshmen to read Alison Bechdel’s memoir on which the musical is based.

headline: Hayden Dunham and Meriem Bennani: ‘Paste’
abstract: Assemblages made from medical supplies, water bottles, ribbons of painted paper and ceramics propose the idea of objects as conduits to other worlds.

abstract: On a road trip through the Mississippi Delta, Ms. Meisner tracked down and filmed people and places associated with blues music.

headline: General Mills Amends New Legal Policies
keywords: ['Social Media', 'ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The company said the policy, which said consumers “joining our online communities” could not sue the company, did not apply to its Facebook and Twitter accounts.
lead_paragraph: General Mills, the multibillion-dollar food company behind brands like Cheerios and Pillsbury, said on Thursday that an update to its new legal policies, which stated that consumers “joining our online communities” could not sue the company, did not apply to people who visit its Facebook pages and Twitter accounts.

headline: Kenya’s Wide Net Against Terror Sweeps Up Refugees
abstract: Thousands of undocumented refugees, immigrants and Kenyan citizens have been arrested, with a sprawling stadium in Nairobi turned into a police station to hold large numbers of them.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Fardos Osman sat on the concrete floor of a crammed room in a sprawling stadium next to scores of other women, many hiding their faces. She said she had been at the stadium for four days. Her refugee document had expired, she said, and she feared that she would be sent back to war-torn Somalia.

headline: Ali Banisadr: ‘Motherboard’
abstract: Mr. Banisadr’s paintings usually depict epic battles between vast imperial forces, with banners fluttering overhead and bloody skirmishes below.
lead_paragraph: Sperone Westwater

headline: Scientists Find an ‘Earth Twin,’ or Perhaps a Cousin
abstract: A planet known as Kepler 186f, 500 light-years away, is the closest match to our own yet discovered, astronomers say.
lead_paragraph: It is a bit bigger and somewhat colder, but a planet circling a star 500 light-years away is otherwise the closest match of our home world discovered so far, astronomers announced on Thursday.

headline: Deciding How Much Information and Flexibility to Give Employees
abstract: One company offers employees the freedom to choose how many vacation days they take.
lead_paragraph: At the most recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, the owners continued their conversation about how best to motivate employees. Deirdre Lord, who owns the Megawatt Hour, said that in addition to being transparent — and offering free food — employers can take other steps to keep employees engaged. “I’ve always been a believer in giving people equity,” she said.

headline: As East Village Gallery Closes, a Dispute Lingers
abstract: A Gathering of the Tribes, a fixture in the East Village, is shutting down after a landlord-tenant dispute and an argument over who controlled a wall painted by the artist David Hammons.
lead_paragraph: Little by little, another fixture in the East Village that helped define the neighborhood’s mix of creativity and grit has been disappearing.

headline: If a Driver Has an Accident While Wearing Google Glass, Should Google Get Sued?
abstract: Lawmakers in various states are introducing legislation to ban the use of Google Glass while driving.
lead_paragraph: Because no one in her right mind wants to be on the road with drivers who might be watching YouTube videos, lawmakers in various states are introducing legislation to ban the use of Google Glass and other similar devices while behind the wheel.

headline: An Athlete Tackles Cancer
abstract: My youth was all sports. Now, at the age of 30, with Stage IV gastric cancer, I find myself relying on lessons I learned then.
lead_paragraph: “It’s not a sprint, it’s a marathon.” I heard those words often during my years as a soccer player at Drexel University. The mantra reminded me of my goals, and helped me endure the pain of practice and the mental stress of competition.

headline: McLaren 650S: A Supercar of Hard Edges and Curves

headline: American Academy of Arts and Sciences Names New President
abstract: Jonathan F. Fanton, the former president of the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, will follow Leslie Cohen Berlowitz, who stepped down last year.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan F. Fanton, the former president of the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation and of the New School, will be the new president of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, academy officials announced on Thursday. Dr. Fanton, 70, is currently the interim director and Franklin D. Roosevelt visiting fellow at the Roosevelt House Public Policy Institute at Hunter College. He was elected a fellow of the Academy in 1999.

headline: Flyers Make No Secret About Testing Rangers’ McDonagh
abstract: Ryan McDonagh, the Rangers’ top defenseman, who recently recovered from a shoulder injury, said he was healed and not concerned about being targeted by the Flyers.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to a game between the Rangers and the Philadelphia Flyers, punishment is an almost inevitable theme. The run-up to Game 1 of their first-round N.H.L. playoff series Thursday at Madison Square Garden is no exception.

headline: Google Uses Algorithms to Create SLR-Like Photos
abstract: Google is lifting up the hood of its new Lens Blur feature for its camera app, showing how the company can make a photo taken on a smartphone look like it was shot with an SLR camera.
lead_paragraph: One of the hardest concepts to grasp as a photographer is depth of field.

headline: Performance of Play in New York and Rwanda To Commemorate Genocide
keywords: ['International Relations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The actor Jay O. Sanders is the author of “Unexplored Interior,” which will be performed on May 11.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Jewish Heritage, in New York, and the Kigali Genocide Memorial Center, in Rwanda, will jointly mark the 20th anniversary of the Rwandan genocide with a performance of Jay O. Sanders’s “Unexplored Interior,” a play inspired by the massacre of tens of thousands of Tutsi tribesman by Hutu extremists.

headline: A Chef in the Field | Duck Eggs
abstract: With more fat and cholesterol than a chicken egg — and a larger, lusher yolk —it’s no wonder that a single duck egg makes a plate of simple potato hash feel special, even decadent.
lead_paragraph: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food — from its original source to a place on your table.

headline: Obamacare, Deficits and Empirics
keywords: ['Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Assessing yet another potential metric for the health care law’s success.
lead_paragraph: In my post yesterday on potential metrics for assessing Obamacare’s claim to be a policy success, I didn’t directly address the law’s eventual impact on the deficit. So I’m grateful to Jonathan Chait for raising the issue, in the course of a post explaining why the Obamacare debate proves (yet again, he would say) that liberals are more empirical and data-driven than conservatives. Noting that many Republicans had alleged that the law’s promise of deficit reduction was based (in Paul Ryan’s words) on “gimmicks and smoke and mirrors,” Chait cites a new C.B.O. estimate on the cost of the law’s coverage expansion and announces that reality has spoken, and the case is closed:

headline: Charges Are Said to Be Near Over Kickbacks in Exports of Luxury Cars to China
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: An investigation by New York authorities is part of a broad national crackdown on businesses seeking to turn a quick profit by exporting luxury cars from the United States to China.
lead_paragraph: New York authorities appear to be getting closer to filing charges in connection with an investigation into accusations of kickbacks being paid to salesmen at high-end car dealerships in the New York area. The investigation is part of a broad national crackdown on businesses seeking to turn a quick profit by exporting luxury cars from the United States to China.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — British retirees may soon receive a novel kind of financial advice, courtesy of the state: They could be told when they are likely to die.

lead_paragraph: The latest campaign gimmick among conservative lawmakers is free gun giveaways. Ron Paul recently announced that he was giving away an assault rifle through his lobbying group, Campaign for Liberty, because “there can be no freedom without the ability to defend it.” The drawing will take place on April 30, and the winner will receive an M4 carbine rifle, front and rear sights and two AR-15 magazines.

lead_paragraph: Things to do this weekend include the Tribeca Film Festival, which is in full swing in lower Manhattan. There’s also a new Ai Weiwei exhibition in Brooklyn, and Olga Peretyatko makes her Met debut.

headline: Is God Just Not That Into Me?
keywords: ['Religion and Belief', 'Buddhism', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Modern Love (Times Column)']
abstract: A boyfriend’s makeshift altar on the radiator cover prompts a search for answers.
lead_paragraph: I never thought much about God, certainly never wondered whether God was thinking about me, until I fell in love with a Zen Buddhist priest. I met him on an online dating site, an environment of tactical omission. I just knew he was a Buddhist, as he knew I was a writer.

headline: Video: Ai Weiwei and the Tribeca Film Festival
abstract: A look at some of the cultural highlights in New York this week.
lead_paragraph: This week in The Times’s Culture Minute: The Tribeca Film Festival is in full swing in Lower Manhattan; the Russian soprano Olga Peretyatko makes her Metropolitan Opera debut on Thursday; and a new Ai Weiwei exhibition opens in Brooklyn.

headline: My Daughter, Profoundly Disabled, Needs a School for Children Like Her
abstract: The consensus that children with disabilities are best educated in an inclusive classroom is in danger of hardening into dogma that risks re-stigmatizing children with severe or profound disabilities.
lead_paragraph: A Civil War historian, I never thought I’d use the word “segregationist” to describe myself, but my daughter’s public school has changed all that. I’m not talking about racial segregation — her school is one of the most economically and ethnically diverse in our town. I’m talking about self-contained education for children with disabilities, which, in the United States, is increasingly rare.

headline: Creation in Personal Utopias
abstract: “When the Stars Begin to Fall: Imagination and the American South” is an engrossing but unresolved show at the Studio Museum in Harlem.
lead_paragraph: The “insider-outsider” exhibition has been a major trend of the past few years, with works by folk and self-taught artists turning up at the 55th Venice Biennale and in galleries that normally showcase young, brazenly careerist people with M.F.A.s. In theory, everyone benefits; long-marginalized or forgotten artists get exposed to a wide audience, and contemporary artists receive a kind of authenticity by osmosis. But it doesn’t always work out that way.

headline: Morgan Stanley Gets Most Relief From First-Quarter Earnings
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Company Reports', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Morgan Stanley’s chief executive, James P. Gorman, presided over a far better start to the year than in 2013, and momentum seems to be building toward increasing the firm’s return on equity, writes Antony Currie of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Few banks have reported much to crow about in their first-quarter earnings. But Morgan Stanley can claim relief, at least, from the $1.45 billion in net income it reported on Thursday.

headline: Colm Toibin Named Chairman of PEN World Voices Festival
abstract: Mr. Toibin will take over the duties from Salman Rushdie beginning in 2015.
lead_paragraph: The PEN American Center has announced that Colm Toibin will serve as the chairman of the PEN World Voices Festival of International Literature beginning in 2015. Salman Rushdie has been the chairman since founding the festival in 2005.

headline: New Banksy Work Goes From Wall to Boys’ Club to Museum
abstract: A work by Banksy that appeared on a wall in Bristol, England, is claimed by a boys’ club leader and then by the city.
lead_paragraph: Another day, another Banksy work – and, naturally, another ownership dispute. On Tuesday a large Banksy piece, this one showing a couple embracing while also checking their cellphones behind each other’s back, appeared on a wall near the Broad Plain Boys’ Club in Bristol, England, the artist’s hometown. The piece, which also appears on the artist’s website, was apparently on plywood and screwed to the wall – not Banksy’s usual approach, which is to paint directly onto the surface.

headline: Enrollments Exceed Obama’s Target for Health Care Act
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Eight million people have signed up for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act, including what the White House said were a sufficient number of young, healthy adults needed to maintain the plan’s viability.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama announced Thursday that eight million people have signed up for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act, including what the White House said were a sufficient number of young, healthy adults, a critical milestone that might counter election-year attacks by Republicans on the law’s success and viability.

headline: One-Fifth of China’s Farmland Is Polluted, State Study Finds
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning']
abstract: Rapid industrialization, agricultural mismanagement and metals production are all contributing to contamination that is raising alarms about food and physical health.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese government released a report on Thursday that said nearly one-fifth of its arable land was polluted, a finding certain to raise questions about the toxic results of China’s rapid industrialization, its lack of regulations over commercial interests and the consequences for the national food chain.

headline: 2015 Infiniti Q70 and QX80: Two Big Boys Receive an Upgrade
abstract: The Q70L and a restyled Q70 are sleek with well-defined lines, achieving nice front to rear flow. But a lot of chrome and detail render the QX80 Limited and the redesigned QX80 a bit busy.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Thursday, April 17: 2015 Infiniti Q70 and QX80

headline: Divine Decadence
abstract: Francine Prose’s new novel, about a cross-dressing French racecar driver who collaborates with the Nazis, is recounted by various alternating narrators.
lead_paragraph: It’s a daring thing to write about an evil person, especially in this day of autobiographical fiction, when readers assume most characters are thinly veiled self-portraits. And yet evil characters are usually dynamic and fascinating, upstaging all the goody-goodies. Think of Milton’s blazing, sexy Satan; Balzac’s scheming, driven master criminal, Vautrin; or Shakespeare’s Iago. Despite the allure of such characters, writers today usually avoid them, maybe because the whole category of Evil seems too theological or because modern psychology assumes that every bad act can be traced to childhood neglect or abuse and thus be explained away. I have to give my students an assignment to write about bad guys in order to get them to do it. But when they do write about them, it’s such a release!

headline: Updike at Rest
abstract: Adam Begley’s biography of John Updike surveys his work as well as his life.
lead_paragraph: At first, he wanted to be a graphic artist. In 1954, John Updike — age 22, newly married and fresh out of Harvard, where he’d studied English literature and taken art courses — was awarded a fellowship to study abroad, and decided to apply to the Ruskin School of Drawing and Fine Arts in Oxford, England. Asked to explain this decision, Updike replied, “It’s always been my ambition to be the next Walt Disney.” During his childhood in Shillington, Pa., where he lived until the age of 13 and which his readers know through his Olinger stories, his mother, Linda, arranged for her prodigiously talented son to take lessons from a local artist. Later, when they moved to Plowville, 11 miles from Shillington, to a farmhouse he would describe in his novel “Of the Farm,” Updike — now 14 or 15 — began sending his drawings and cartoons to The New Yorker and other publications. For Updike, who was interested in drawing but also, like his mother, in writing, to be published in The New Yorker had been an ambition, if not an obsession, from the moment the magazine first entered the household when he was 12.

headline: Sea Change
abstract: As America’s influence in the Western Pacific diminishes, China’s power rises, along with the potential for geopolitical conflict.
lead_paragraph: This is the latest in a series of insightful books, like “The Revenge of Geography” and “The Coming Anarchy,” in which Robert D. Kaplan, the chief geopolitical analyst at the global intelligence company Stratfor, tries to explain how geography determines destiny — and what we should be doing about it. “Asia’s Cauldron” is a short book with a powerful thesis, and it stands out for its clarity and good sense from the great mass of Western writing on what Chinese politicians have taken to calling their “peaceful development.” If you are doing business in China, traveling in Southeast Asia or just obsessing about geopolitics, you will want to read it.

headline: Live and Love for Today
abstract: Addressing old flames, bathroom phone conversations, a bully and a clean break.
lead_paragraph: I fell in love with a girl in high school. Nothing happened romantically between us, but we did hang out a few times. Eight years later, walking through a grocery store with my partner, I saw her again. She didn’t acknowledge me; she may not have seen me. But I felt a torrent of emotions. We are different people now, and I am with someone I care for deeply. But something about seeing her unsettled me. Whatever I felt for her, I’ve never felt again. And several times a year, I imagine my life with her in it. What should I do?

headline: Jets’ Newly Signed Running Back Denies Report That His Injured Knee Is Arthritic
abstract: Running back Chris Johnson, signed on Wednesday, laughed on Thursday when told of the ESPN report and said he would not have passed his physical if the Jets had any concerns.
lead_paragraph: Chris Johnson, signed by the Jets to be the breakaway runner they lacked, on Thursday disputed an ESPN report that he had developed arthritis in his surgically repaired right knee.

abstract: East Village Meat Market, opened by Julian Baczynsky in 1970 and a vestige of the old Eastern European community, is contending with scores of customers at its busiest time of year, the weeks just before Easter.

lead_paragraph: Gabriel García Márquez, the Colombian novelist whose “One Hundred Years of Solitude” established him as a giant of 20th-century literature, died on Thursday at his home in Mexico City. He was 87.

lead_paragraph: Some travelers will go to any length for the type of rest and relaxation that makes them feel 10 years younger.

headline: A Provocateur’s Medium: Outrage
abstract: “Ai Weiwei: According to What?,” at the Brooklyn Museum, makes a persuasive case for this artist’s ability to reconcile art and ideals and life.
lead_paragraph: The 2012 survey of the courageous Chinese artist Ai Weiwei seen at the Hirshhorn Museum in Washington has finally arrived in New York, and is much improved. The show, “Ai Weiwei: According to What?,” which opens Friday at the Brooklyn Museum, has been beefed up throughout, but most notably by two installation pieces completed in 2013. One, “S.A.C.R.E.D.,” is perhaps the best work of art Mr. Ai has yet made.

headline: Chelsea Clinton Says She Is Expecting
abstract: Ms. Clinton made the surprise announcement during an event in New York that she and her husband, Marc Mezvinsky, are expecting a child this fall.
lead_paragraph: Chelsea Clinton said Thursday that she and her husband, Marc Mezvinsky, are expecting their first child this fall, giving Hillary Rodham Clinton an additional line in her biography as she contemplates another run for the presidency: grandmother.

headline: MoMA Plans a Robert Gober Retrospective
abstract: Robert Gober’s first retrospective in an American museum will open on Oct. 11 at the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: It seems almost inconceivable that there has never been a Robert Gober retrospective in an American museum. This 59-year-old artist, who rose to prominence in the mid-1980s, is perhaps best known for his creepy sculptures of body parts — a cast wax leg or torso with individually applied hairs on them — as well as his signature sinks fashioned from plaster painted with enamel.

headline: Putin on Eastern Ukraine
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia addressed the escalating crisis in Ukraine during his annual televised question-and-answer session with the public in Moscow.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia addressed the escalating crisis in Ukraine during his annual televised question-and-answer session with the public in Moscow.

headline: Adjusting for Price Inflation Isn’t Enough
abstract: The minimum wage should be adjusted upward according to increases in average wages.
lead_paragraph: In recent blog posts I have explained why the Democrats’ proposed increase in the minimum wage — to $10.10 an hour by 2016 — is too low. Even the much-lauded provision to annually adjust the minimum wage upward for price inflation is less than meets the eye.

headline: Sign on the Digital Dotted Line
abstract: Technology for paperless closings has long been available, an now lenders have new incentives to adopt it.
lead_paragraph: In an electronic age, mortgage closings stand out as particularly cumbersome transactions. Come closing day, hundreds of pages of paper land in a thump before the borrower, who must then physically sign and initial them in dozens of places.

headline: What Eight Million Means
abstract: The Obamacare news keeps coming in good.
lead_paragraph: Sorry about blog silence — real life intruded, plus I did have to write a column. But I shouldn’t let the day pass without mentioning the latest big Obamacare news. Final enrollment for 2014, we now know, will be more than 8 million. The age mix has also improved, with more young people signing up at the end; as Jonathan Cohn points out in the linked article, the age mix in Obamacare’s first year is now just about identical to the age mix in Romneycare’s first year. Goodbye, death spiral.

headline: A Cozy Foursome, United in Rough-Hewed Harmony
abstract: The Manhattan String Quartet performed in “100 Years of the String Quartet” at the Tenri Cultural Institute on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: In her 2011 book “Alone Together,” the social scientist Sherry Turkle describes our world as one in which technology has rendered us increasingly isolated when it comes to substantive interactions. We “friend” instead of making friends.

headline: Virtu Financial Said to Shelve I.P.O. Plans
abstract: The decision is said to have stemmed from recent negative attention on the high-frequency trading industry and the stock market performance of companies similar to Virtu.
lead_paragraph: The high-frequency trading firm Virtu Financial, which had expected to go public this month, has decided to postpone those plans indefinitely, a person briefed on the matter said on Thursday.

headline: Shattering in a Space of Healing
abstract: Taisha Paggett begins her performance piece “Underwaters (we is ready, we is ready)” at the Whitney Museum by smashing plates against the wall.
lead_paragraph: In her works that bridge dance and visual art, Taisha Paggett has deconstructed the fitness craze Zumba, blindfolded herself while drawing on the walls of a room and performed as Fila Buster, a character inspired by the filibuster of the Kansas-Nebraska Act of 1854. For her latest piece, “Underwaters (we is ready, we is ready),” Ms. Paggett, shifting among four personas, holds the floor — for hours on end — as part of the 2014 Biennial at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

keywords: ['Company Reports', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hepatitis', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']

headline: The Separate Kitchen Makes a Comeback
abstract: When it comes to dinner events and holidays, owners want a more defined space.
lead_paragraph: When Ashley Mabbitt was growing up in a four-bedroom house outside Chicago, her grandmother gave her this advice: “When I have people over, I like to feel I’m coming to a party. I like to take off my apron, put on lipstick, and step into a separate space.”

headline: Clinging to Minimalism, in Shadows and Whispers
abstract: FKA twigs, a.k.a. Tahliah Barnett, who has released two EPs in the last 18 months, performed at Glasslands Gallery in Brooklyn on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: Tahliah Barnett sings with clear voice, and she sings with her body, but on Wednesday night at Glasslands Gallery, she began her show with a whisper.

headline: Elizabeth Gilbert’s New Chapter Begins
abstract: An eclectic Italianate Victorian in Frenchtown, N.J., owned by the author of “Eat, Pray, Love.”
lead_paragraph: An Italianate Victorian mini-estate built in 1869 on a hilltop above the Delaware River by a descendant of John Reading — Colonial New Jersey’s first native-born governor — is about to enter the market at $999,000. The house has been owned for the last six years by the author Elizabeth Gilbert, whose best-selling memoir, “Eat, Pray, Love,” revolutionized the concept of self-actualization for its fans. The annual property tax is $13,688.

headline: Clip: ‘Transcendence’
abstract: A scene from the film.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film.

headline: I Am My Own Monster (Technology Rules!)
abstract: “Transcendence” stars Johnny Depp as an artificial-intelligence genius whose wife uploads his consciousness into a supermachine after anti-technology extremists shoot him.
lead_paragraph: Johnny Depp, who’s built a brilliant career despite many of his lamentable film choices, may not be the first actor you think of to play a genius — much less humanity’s destroyer or savior. But he’s weirdly perfect in “Transcendence,” an inelegant, no doubt implausible (maybe not) science-fiction film about a futurist whose consciousness is uploaded onto the Internet. There, he (or a mysterious vestige of his being) expands like the universe, growing larger and mutating into a being who is godlike and yet far from divine, sort of like a star at the apex of his popularity.

headline: His Win Obscured, Runner Left Mark Off the Course
abstract: Lelisa Desisa’s victory in the 2013 Boston Marathon became a footnote to a horrific afternoon, but his response to the bombings resonated widely.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — It was October, six months after Lelisa Desisa of Ethiopia won the stricken 2013 Boston Marathon. He had returned for another race. On his way to dinner with friends, he had a request. He wanted to cross the finish line again on Boylston Street to reclaim in a private moment a triumph made irrelevant by tragedy.

headline: Remembering the Life and Work of Gabriel García Márquez
abstract: A look at The Times’s coverage of Gabriel García Márquez, who died on Thursday at 87.
lead_paragraph: Gabriel García Márquez died on Thursday at 87. Over the years, as his work was reviewed in The New York Times, numerous luminaries took the opportunity to consider the great author and his work, including William Kennedy, Robert Stone and Thomas Pynchon.

headline: Even Vampires Pass the Velvet Rope
abstract: The Midnight program of the Tribeca Film Festival will features such science-fiction and horror titles as “Zombeavers” and “Summer of Blood.”
lead_paragraph: It wouldn’t be fair to call “Zombeavers” a “Sharknado” rip-off: The zombie-beavers film wrapped production in March 2013, four months before the shark-tornado film created a vogue for over-the-top-cheesy B movies with compound titles. But it would be fair to guess that the Tribeca Film Festival, where “Zombeavers” has its world premiere on Saturday night, wouldn’t mind if a little of that “Sharknado” magic rubbed off.
