headline: In an Uneven Economy, an Opening in the Service Sector Beckons
abstract: John Turturro stars in and directs “Fading Gigolo,” a comedy about a New Yorker who is losing his job and is urged to try prostitution.
lead_paragraph: The title character in “Fading Gigolo,” a low-key, low-energy comedy about New York haves and have-nots, is Fioravante, a melancholic bookstore employee played by the film’s director, John Turturro. When you first meet Fioravante, he’s packing up boxes, on the verge of becoming an ex-bookstore employee. His boss, Murray (Woody Allen), has been forced to shutter his charming shop, a painful and all-too-frequent occurrence in the real New York. In a moment of inspiration, or really creative contrivance, Murray suggests — ta-da — that Fioravante take up hooking.

headline: Chelsea Clinton Announces Her Pregnancy
abstract: Ms. Clinton said that she and her husband were expecting their first child this year.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Clinton said that she and her husband were expecting their first child this year.

headline: Mazda Commemorates the Miata’s Birthday With a Gathering of Its Classics
abstract: The company also brought to New York the MX-5 Miata 25th Anniversary Edition and the chassis of the next generation car.
lead_paragraph: Anniversary celebrations are a recurring theme at this year’s New York auto show, and Mazda joined the party on Wednesday. Mazda’s birthday child was the Miata, the nimble two-seat sports car that set a new tone for the brand when it had its premiere at the Chicago auto show a quarter century ago. The Mazda festivities showcased a lot of what is old, with some classic and race-veteran Miatas, a bit of what is genuinely new with a chassis-only preview of the next-generation Miata and some of what is just a wee bit new in the MX-5 Miata 25th Anniversary Edition.

headline: Found Everything, Tried Everything, All His Own Way
abstract: Get confused is the first and last message of “Alibis: Sigmar Polke 1963-2010” at the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: Get confused is the first and last message of “Alibis: Sigmar Polke 1963-2010” at the Museum of Modern Art. And if you think, as I do, that some degree of continuing bafflement is a healthy reaction to art, this disorienting contact high of a show is for you.

headline: A Labor Leader’s Devotion to His Cause
abstract: “Cesar’s Last Fast,” about Cesar Chavez, centers on a 36-day fast he endured to call attention to farmworker conditions.
lead_paragraph: “I think I know what my mission is,” says the labor leader Cesar Chavez in “Cesar’s Last Fast.” “Righting the wrongs that were committed against workers for 100 years.” Chavez  (1927-1993), a founder of what became the United Farm Workers union, faced brutal odds, as this compelling documentary demonstrates.

headline: Comedy Listings for April 18-24
abstract: A guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Theater Listings for April 18-24
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Movie Listings for April 18-24
abstract: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select film series.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for April 18-24
abstract: A selected guide to performances of hip-hop, electronic dance music, folk-pop, indie-pop and more in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Jazz Listings for April 18-24
abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Opera and Classical Music Listings for April 18-24
abstract: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: Reviews of classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Competing to Be a Phallic Symbol
abstract: In the documentary “The Final Member,” two men vie to have their penises entered into the Icelandic Phallological Museum as its first human specimen.
lead_paragraph: Sigurdur Hjartarson has a preoccupation with phalluses. It started in 1974, when he was given a bull penis as a joke, popped it in formaldehyde and decided it needed companions.

headline: SpongeBob, the Carnivore
abstract: Scientists did not realize until 1995 that some sponges were carnivorous. Researchers say they have identified four new North American species.
lead_paragraph: The oceans are full of predators, but nobody thought sponges were among them until 1995, when scientists first realized that not all of these sedentary animals spent their days just filtering out bacteria and other micro-organisms from seawater.

headline: Dance Listings for April 18-24
abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for April 18-24
abstract: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Waiting for ‘Waiting for Guffman,’ Sort Of
abstract: Writers in Los Angeles waiting to be published are the title characters in “Authors Anonymous.”
lead_paragraph: One day, someone will make a brilliant mockumentary about a team of filmmakers struggling to make their own Christopher Guest mockumentary. Until then, there is “Authors Anonymous,” directed by Ellie Kanner from a screenplay by David Congalton, but entirely in the vein of Mr. Guest’s “Waiting for Guffman.” The sendup’s target is a group of Los Angeles writers who meet weekly, waiting to be published.

headline: Spare Times for Children for April 18-24
abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: ‘MR. CHICKEE’S FUNNY MONEY’

headline: Spare Times for April 18-24
abstract: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.
lead_paragraph: EASTER PARADE AND EASTER BONNET FESTIVAL (Sunday) Pedestrians will be able to step off the curb into the throng of strollers, street performers and photographers filling Fifth Avenue, from 49th to 57th Streets, for this annual event.

headline: In the City, a Fresh, Crisp Breath of Summer From the Mountains
abstract: Graduates, faculty and performers from the Aspen Music Festival brought a taste of the summer program there to SubCulture on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The title of the program at SubCulture on Wednesday night was playfully ambiguous: “The Complete Aspen Music Festival and School (abridged).” Sounds like fun, right?

headline: In Europe, Auto Sales Are Still Low, But They Are Rising
abstract: New car sales are up by more than 10 percent in Ireland, Greece, Spain and Portugal, which signals stronger economic growth there, even if sales are still far below 2007 levels.
lead_paragraph: European auto sales figures for March, reported today, show that slightly more new cars were sold in the euro zone during the most recent 12 months than had been sold a year earlier. The increase was a tiny one, just 0.4 percent.

headline: A Bear, Her Cubs and the Wilderness
abstract: Disney’s “Bears” is the chronicle of a year in the hungry life of one bear and her two cubs in the Alaskan wilderness.
lead_paragraph: Disney’s experience in the animal documentary business (as opposed to the business of talking animated animals) stretches back over half a century. Before there was today’s “Bears” there was “Bear Country,” an Academy Award winner in 1954. The newer ursine chronicle looks at one hungry year in the life of an Alaska mother and her two cubs, with typically simple storytelling and the drumbeat of the hunt for enough food to survive the winter.

headline: Global Sounds, Woven Together
abstract: Uusinta performed at the Kitchen on Wednesday as part of the MATA Festival.
lead_paragraph: If there is one thing that sets the MATA Festival apart from many of the other contemporary-classical bounties New York regularly produces, it might be a robust international representation, which seems to have grown sharply since Yotam Haber — a Dutch-born global citizen and the festival’s artistic director from 2009 until this year — has been at the helm. This year’s series, the 16th since MATA began in 1996, includes composers from 17 countries.

headline: This Week’s Movies: April 18, 2014
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Transcendence,” “Fading Gigolo” and “Manakamana.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Transcendence,” “Fading Gigolo” and “Manakamana.”

headline: Once Again, Fires Burn and Caldrons Bubble
abstract: In its first scripted series, “Salem,” WGN America adds a little eye of newt for flavor.
lead_paragraph: Well, there’s nothing halfway about WGN America’s entry into the scripted-series world. The witch-infested “Salem,” its initial offering, which has its premiere on Sunday, is brash and well executed and expensive-looking. And if you strip away the various questions and back stories involving the station’s strategy and just look at “Salem” as a television show, you’ve got to admit that it’s perversely entertaining.

headline: Deadbeat on the Range
abstract: Most ranchers honorably play by the rules. Then there’s Cliven Bundy.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a vendor on the National Mall, selling burgers and dogs, who hasn’t paid his rent in 20 years. He refuses to recognize his landlord, the National Park Service, as a legitimate authority. Every court has ruled against him, and fines have piled up. What’s more, the effluents from his food cart are having a detrimental effect on the spring grass in the capital.

headline: From Andreessen, a Lesson in Corporate Finance
abstract: In a series of Twitter messages on Thursday, the prominent venture capitalist Marc Andreessen offered a framework for thinking about technology company valuations.
lead_paragraph: The valuations of highflying technology companies can seem baffling to those not initiated in the ways of Silicon Valley.

headline: Capitalism and the Dalai Lama
abstract: He’s practical and empathetic. The lesson? Pass the bread.
lead_paragraph: WHAT can Washington, D.C., learn from a Buddhist monk?

headline: Horse Owners and Trainers Say They’ll Release Veterinary Records
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Jockeys, Drivers and Trainers', 'Horses', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare']
abstract: More than 40 horsemen have agreed to turn over records for the two weeks before any graded stakes races, which will be made available to the public two hours before post time.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to restore integrity and transparency to a sport battered by scandal, some of horse racing’s most prominent owners and trainers pledged Thursday to make public the veterinary records of their horses competing in high-level stakes races, including the Kentucky Derby.

headline: Abolish Horse-Drawn Carriages?
abstract: Readers discuss whether Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York should fulfill a campaign pledge.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Benefits of Hospice Care
keywords: ['Hospice Care', 'Elder Care', "Alzheimer's Disease", 'Nursing and Nurses', 'Death and Dying']
abstract: A nurse responds to a Sunday Review article about how a stranger gave tender care to the writer’s ill mother.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Politics, a Cold Streak Can Make Loyalty Vanish
abstract: Texans for Lawsuit Reform supported a longtime friend, Lt. Gov. David Dewhurst, through the primary election. After he finished second, however, the group switched to his runoff opponent.
lead_paragraph: The standard for good old-fashioned treachery in politics is pretty low — in fact, many people think politics is a synonym for treachery. Even with that, the latest move by one of the state’s biggest business groups against the sitting lieutenant governor was breathtaking.

headline: More Senseless Gun Deaths
abstract: A reader assails the “outdated” Second Amendment.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Unlikely Superstar Swap Could Aid Knicks
abstract: If they really want to contend for a title, maybe the Knicks should try a trade with the Los Angeles Lakers: Carmelo Anthony for Kobe Bryant.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks completed another disappointing season Wednesday night, beating the playoff-bound Toronto Raptors before a Madison Square Garden crowd that snacked on complimentary boxes of popcorn — a thank you from the organization to fans for enduring a 41st consecutive season without a championship.

headline: ESPN Sees Continued Profitability Despite Competition
abstract: The Walt Disney Company on Thursday said profits at its ESPN-dominated cable networks unit would grow on an annual basis for the next three years.
lead_paragraph: Aiming to squelch smoldering concerns about ESPN’s continued profitability amid rising sports rights costs, the Walt Disney Company on Thursday said profits at its ESPN-dominated cable networks unit would grow in the “high single digits” on a compounded annual basis for the next three years.

headline: Mock Gefilte Fish
abstract: The cookbook author Joan Nathan tells how some Jews use substitutes when the proper ingredients are not available.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Pope’s Comments on Abuse
abstract: A Georgetown University professor praises Pope Francis for directly addressing the issue.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Extend the Mideast Talks
abstract: The American Jewish Committee says the impasse between Israel and the Palestinians should not mean an end to negotiations.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Soaring Trips to a Temple in Nepal
abstract: The faces in “Manakamana,” by Stephanie Spray and Pacho Velez, stare into the camera, out into space and, perhaps, into the great beyond.
lead_paragraph: The faces in “Manakamana,” a transporting ethnographic film set in a green sliver of Nepal, stare into the camera, out into space and, perhaps, into the great beyond. The faces are sometimes creased and weathered, sometimes smooth as pebbles. A few look etched with worry, as if they were weighed down by a heavy burden, although they may also be seized with fear. That’s because for 10 or so minutes at a time, these faces are floating hundreds of feet above a lush Nepali forest in a cable car that takes pilgrims to and from the temple that gives this film its rhythmic title.

headline: Iran Gets an Unlikely Visitor, an American Plane, but No One Seems to Know Why
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The presence of a United States-flagged aircraft in Iran is highly unusual these days, especially when it’s owned by a small Utah bank.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has warned that Iran is not open for business, even as the United States has loosened some of its punishing economic sanctions as part of an interim nuclear pact.

headline: Time Is Short for High-Risk Rescue Effort
abstract: Experts said that even if passengers aboard the capsized South Korean ferry found air pockets, time was short and the risk of hypothermia was high.
lead_paragraph: With rising waves and swift currents off the southern coast of South Korea having largely stymied search operations around a capsized ferry late Thursday night, the fate of 271 people still missing was unknown. It was unclear even how many might still be aboard the vessel — which was underwater save for a small section of its keel — and if so whether any were in areas with pockets of air.

headline: Dierdorf, Ex-Wolverine, Joins Michigan Radio
abstract: Dan Dierdorf, 64, who played offensive tackle for Michigan under Bo Schembechler, announced his return to broadcasting with a three-year contract as the radio analyst for Wolverines football.
lead_paragraph: When Dan Dierdorf called his final N.F.L. game for CBS Sports in January, he expected to retire from full-time work. He had two artificial hips, two artificial knees and a back in dire need of surgery.

headline: A Plea for Equal Pay for Equal Pedaling
abstract: In this documentary, Kathryn Bertine, an athlete and former ESPN columnist, questions the male-dominated world of professional cycling.
lead_paragraph: You can’t exactly call “Half the Road” an infomercial for women’s cycling. It’s more like a political campaign ad disguised as a public service announcement, and the message is: Get rid of the U.C.I.’s current leaders. That’s the Union Cycliste Internationale, the organization that its detractors can’t just walk away from, because it has the power to award Olympic qualification points.

headline: Demands That Jews Register in Eastern Ukraine Are Denounced, and Denied
abstract: The Donetsk People’s Republic, along with other pro-Russian groups, denied having anything to do with fliers purporting to demand registration.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Worshipers at the Bet Menakhem-Mendl synagogue in this eastern Ukrainian city confronted a horrifying scene as they left a Passover service this week: masked men on a sidewalk handing out leaflets demanding that Jews register and pay a fine or leave the area, witnesses said.

headline: Blood Ties Between Cop and Killer
abstract: A mentally fragile cop pursues a gang of mask-wearing robbers in “That Demon Within,” a film out of Hong Kong by Dante Lam.
lead_paragraph: Pulp done with passion can be its own reward, as the veteran Hong Kong filmmaker Dante Lam shows with his feverish cop thriller “That Demon Within.” Full of blood, tears and fire — from guns and gas explosions — this corpse-ridden movie wrenches us through an overheated plot involving a demon-mask-wearing gang of robbers and a mentally fragile cop. It’s none too subtle in either its sickly-green color schemes or its melodramatic logic, as timid it’s not.

headline: Merely Rich and Superrich: The Tax Gap Is Narrowing
keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Capital Gains Tax', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: The wealthy face tax increases that are greater for investment income, much of which goes to the superrich.
lead_paragraph: Will this be the year that the superrich finally pay higher taxes than the very rich?

headline: Virginia Law Phasing Out ‘Fox Pens’ Vexes All Sides
keywords: ['Hunting and Trapping', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Dogs', 'Law and Legislation', 'Foxes']
abstract: Fenced enclosures in which hounds pursue wild foxes will be phased out over 40 years, angering hunters and pen owners, but also animal rights activists who want quicker action.
lead_paragraph: STONY CREEK, Va. — Emerson Poarch Jr., 72, says his father went to his grave incredulous that hunters would pay a fee to run their hounds in a “fox pen.”

headline: When the Circus Descends
abstract: Right-wing talk radio hosts and left-wing interest groups are teaming up to defeat the most sensible school reform movement in a decade.
lead_paragraph: We are pretty familiar with this story: A perfectly sensible if slightly boring idea is walking down the street. Suddenly, the ideological circus descends, burying the sensible idea in hysterical claims and fevered accusations. The idea’s political backers beat a craven retreat. The idea dies.

headline: A Lost Soul’s Wanderings
abstract: “Soft in the Head” follows Natalia, an alcoholic, as she bounces around harsh New York streets between two surrogate families, drinking, acting out, seeking refuge and being self-destructive.
lead_paragraph: Nathan Silver’s “Soft in the Head” opens in medias res, as Natalia (Sheila Etxeberría) explains to her abusive boyfriend (Nick Korbee) that she’s having a holiday dinner with her friend Hannah’s family. When this scene turns into a violent breakup, Mr. Silver disorientingly cuts to the opening titles, shown over an Orthodox Jewish candle-lighting ceremony. A sense of worlds colliding seems fundamental to the film.

headline: University of Chicago Economist Who Studies Media Receives Clark Medal
abstract: The American Economic Association said Matthew Gentzkow’s work cuts across academic disciplines to address concerns at the crossroads of “economics, political science and sociology.”
lead_paragraph: Matthew Gentzkow, an economics professor at the University of Chicago Booth School of Business who has done innovative work analyzing issues like bias in the press and the impact of the media on society, has been awarded the 2014 John Bates Clark Medal, the American Economic Association announced Thursday.

headline: Muslim Cleric ‘Was Committed to War,’ Prosecutor Says in Terrorism Trial
abstract: Mostafa Kamel Mostafa is on trial in New York on charges of helping to orchestrate a kidnapping, planning a terrorist training camp in Oregon and helping Al Qaeda in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Mostafa Kamel Mostafa, an Egyptian-born cleric who became prominent for his fiery sermons at a British mosque, was more than just a preacher, a federal prosecutor said on Thursday. “He was a trainer of terrorists, and he used the cover of religion so he could hide in plain sight in London.”

headline: Volvo XC90: The First of a New Breed
abstract: The XC90 is an S.U.V. that is the first of a new line of vehicles from the Swedish automaker that will include a new connected-car system that works with Apple’s CarPlay. app.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Thursday, April 17: Volvo XC90

headline: After Tension, Lions Gate Consolidates Its Movie Marketing
abstract: Tim Palen, top marketer at the studio’s Lionsgate label, will take over the responsibilities of Nancy Kirkpatrick of the Summit label, who is leaving.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Lions Gate Entertainment on Thursday announced the resignation of one movie marketing chief and the promotion of another, ending one of Hollywood’s tensest working arrangements.

headline: Taxi Driver Charged in $28,000 Toll Fraud
abstract: For nearly two years the driver sneaked through toll plazas by “piggybacking” on the driver in front of him, according to Metropolitan Transportation Authorities.
lead_paragraph: Back and forth the driver went. A thousand times over the Robert F. Kennedy Bridge. Three thousand trips through the Queens-Midtown Tunnel.

headline: Stranded by the Fight Over a Border’s Future
abstract: The influx of people into the Ras Khamis neighborhood of East Jerusalem is straining city services, and City Hall has shown little inclination to help.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Abutting Israel’s separation wall, the blackened shell of a factory building known by local Palestinian residents as the station serves as a den for drug dealers and addicts. Out front, at a bend in the road, rotting trash smolders in an unofficial garbage dump as children pass on their way home from the nearby elementary school.

headline: Libraries Seek High-Speed Broadband
abstract: As more people use their local libraries to connect to the Internet, libraries are requesting funding for better services.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal E-Rate program has been a boon for schools and public libraries across the country, helping them acquire Internet access and telecommunications products at affordable or vastly discounted rates. But the sleek new computers, laptops and tablets do not mean much without high-quality broadband service to match.

headline: He Took the Dare to Change His Life
abstract: A decent man in debt, hoping his troubles will end, agrees to fulfill a series of 13 dares, each rewarded with an escalating sum of money.
lead_paragraph: A study of desperation and the evil within, Daniel Stamm’s “13 Sins” is an empty, efficient thriller that leaves you as cold as most of its characters. Based on the 2006 Thai movie “13: Game of Death,” this disappointing remake is held together primarily by Mark Webber’s charged central performance as Elliot, a wimpy insurance salesman.

headline: In a Reunion, 2 Rangers and a Flyer Recall Glory
abstract: The playoffs will reunite the Rangers’ Brad Richards and Martin St. Louis with a former teammate, the Flyers’ Vincent Lecavalier. The three formed the core of the Lightning’s 2004 championship team.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, Brad Richards, Martin St. Louis and Vincent Lecavalier were integral to the Tampa Bay Lightning’s Stanley Cup run.

headline: 2014 Soleil Anadi: Adding Some Elegance to the Corvette
abstract: The Anadi is a supercar handbuilt in Italy on a Corvette C6 platform.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Thursday, April 17: 2014 Soleil Anadi

headline: Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs Adjust to New Banking Climate
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Company Reports', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Morgan Stanley’s solid first quarter provides evidence that it has adapted better to a stricter regulatory environment than rivals like Goldman Sachs, which reported an earnings decline.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs had not reported earnings on the same day since the darkest phase of the financial crisis in 2008, but they did so again on Thursday.

headline: At 2014 New York Auto Show, Just Click to Kick the Tires
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Computers and the Internet', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'New York International Auto Show']
abstract: Using Google’s Street View technology, sponsors of the New York International Auto Show are creating a virtual exhibition online.
lead_paragraph: SOON after Google Street View, the Google Maps feature that provides pedestrian-level views of cities worldwide, was introduced in 2007, people who chanced to see the image-capturing cars with 360-degree cameras mounted on their roofs began to post pictures of the sightings online with the fervor of bird-watchers.

headline: Study Chides U.S. Over Loan Default by Solar Business
abstract: The critical report was issued as the Obama administration prepared to offer as much as $8 billion in additional loan guarantees.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Long before the Energy Department lost $68 million on Abound Solar, a manufacturer that went bankrupt two years ago, it should have known that the company’s chance of repaying the loan it had guaranteed was deteriorating, according to a report by the department’s inspector general.

headline: Taking the Man Out of Oklahoma, Maybe
abstract: “Home, James,” by Jonathan Rossetti, is a hymn to love and to Tulsa, Okla.
lead_paragraph: In “Home, James,” James is a photographer who makes most of his money as a driver for hire who transports the dissolute late-night souls of Tulsa, Okla., when they’ve had one or three too many. That’s how he first meets Cooper, a hard-drinking rich girl.

headline: The 42-Month Typo
abstract: President Obama used his clemency power to fix an obvious error in a man’s prison sentence, but only after the Justice Department tried to block the man’s claim.
lead_paragraph: No one disputes this fact: Ceasar Huerta Cantu was wrongly sentenced to three and a half extra years in federal prison because of a typo on a court document. Not his lawyer, not the prosecutor, not the judge. And yet it still took President Obama’s intervention to fix the error — two years after Mr. Cantu himself discovered it.

headline: In Scripted Surprise, Putin Answers Snowden on Spying
abstract: In a poke at the White House, Edward J. Snowden asked President Vladimir V. Putin about Russia’s surveillance practices during a televised question-and-answer session.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The setup could not have been more perfect.

headline: Turkey’s Battle With Twitter
abstract: Prime Minister Erdogan attacks social media as part of his campaign against critics and political opponents.
lead_paragraph: Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the combative prime minister of Turkey, has called Twitter “the worst menace to society,” and he seems intent on intimidating its users.

headline: Mayor Details New Hurricane Sandy Aid Reforms
abstract: More residents will be eligible to receive compensation from the government for repairs and some could receive the full value of their property if they decide to vacate.
lead_paragraph: For thousands of New Yorkers whose homes were damaged or destroyed by Hurricane Sandy, the rebuilding process has been a slog of navigating the federal bureaucracy and an alphabet soup of municipal agencies, with residents of Staten Island and the Rockaways accusing the city of paralysis and, in some cases, neglect.

headline: No Spring Break for the Unemployed
keywords: ['Unemployment Insurance', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: While Congress is away, 2.3 million Americans are left to worry about whether lawmakers will ever act to renew unemployment benefits.
lead_paragraph: As members of Congress enjoy their extended spring break, 2.3 million unemployed Americans have been left to worry about whether lawmakers will ever get around to renewing federal unemployment benefits, which expired at the end of 2013. Every week that Congress fails to act, another 70,000 jobless workers will find there is no longer a federal program to turn to.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 17, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbersfor New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: April 17, 2014

headline: Women’s Soccer League Tries to Connect and Survive
abstract: Considering the triumphs of the U.S. women’s national team and the benefits of Title IX, one would think the National Women’s Soccer League would be a certain success. But two previous female soccer leagues have failed.
lead_paragraph: GERMANTOWN, Md. — Natalie Lennartsson, a perky fourth grader who is 10 going on 17, said she didn’t learn “a ton” of new things Wednesday at a soccer clinic hosted by the Washington Spirit, the local women’s professional team.

headline: Automakers Let the Good Times Roll
abstract: With sales and optimism rising, several companies threw lavish parties tied to the New York Auto Show.
lead_paragraph: It’s a banner time in the car industry. The products are flowing and sales numbers are high. That flush feeling coincides with the New York International Auto Show, and has prompted automakers to stage many outside events spilling over from the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center into museums, restaurants and landmarks across the city.

headline: Hollywood Begs for a Tax Break in Some States, Including California
abstract: A battle for filmmaking tax credits has begun in several states — including in California, the home of Hollywood — and has led to cutbacks in others like Maryland.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The San Fernando Valley has served as home to award-winning movies like “E.T.,” “Boogie Nights” and “Crash.” But Raul Bocanegra, a state lawmaker representing a large swath of the valley, worries about the collapse of film and television production in his district and across Hollywood’s home state.

headline: Sandy Recovery Still Lagging
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio promised to attack the neglected program to rebuild communities with an urgency and more money.
lead_paragraph: The hardest test of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s vision and competence might end up being something quite different from expanding prekindergarten or affordable housing. It might just be his ability to restore normality to the lives of tens of thousands of New Yorkers in the Hurricane Sandy zone, from the Rockaways to Staten Island, whose homes and businesses were washed away or ruined a year and a half ago. And, once that job is done, preparing the city to weather the inevitable and potentially disastrous storms to come.

headline: Salvation Gets Cheap
keywords: ['Solar Energy', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: The incredible recent decline in the cost of renewable energy, solar power in particular, have improved the economics of climate change.
lead_paragraph: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, which pools the efforts of scientists around the globe, has begun releasing draft chapters from its latest assessment, and, for the most part, the reading is as grim as you might expect. We are still on the road to catastrophe without major policy changes.

headline: Passover in the Confederacy
abstract: Why did many Southern Jews fight for the right to own slaves?
lead_paragraph: For at least one night each spring during the Civil War, in places like Louisiana and South Carolina and Georgia and Virginia, Confederate Jews commemorated how God freed the children of Israel from slavery. They retold the story of when God is said to have sent down 10 plagues to help free the Hebrews from their bondage, the last of which was the slaying of all Egyptians’ firstborn children, and how the Jews marked their door posts with the blood of a slaughtered lamb so the Angel of Death would know to “pass over” them. Thus, they celebrated their liberation more than 3,000 years ago from slavery in ancient Egypt, and their exodus.

headline: Don’t Just Pass the Joint, Sell It
abstract: “Kid Cannabis” tells a drug empire tale based on the real-life story of an Idaho teenager who organized a smuggling operation that brought marijuana in from Canada.
lead_paragraph: Selling or using marijuana remains illegal in plenty of states, but on screen, the underground marijuana business is already being treated with a “Happy Days” glow of nostalgia. That’s the tone of “Kid Cannabis,” a rollicking tale of border-running teenage pot entrepreneurs based on the real-life story of Nate Norman.

headline: Toe to Toe With the N.R.A.
abstract: What will Michael Bloomberg's planned $50-million campaign for gun control need to do to succeed?

headline: Live, and Online: Poison
abstract: Millions of Chinese are watching live interactive web entertainment, like the popular karaoke performer seen in this clip, who goes by the stage name Poison.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Chinese are watching live interactive web entertainment, like the popular karaoke performer seen in this clip, who goes by the stage name Poison.

headline: Lucrative Stardom in China, Using a Webcam and a Voice
abstract: Companies across the globe have long tried to attract viewers to live Internet broadcasts, with X-rated sites the only real success stories. China appears to have cracked the code.
lead_paragraph: ZIGONG, China — Dolled up with makeup and a blond wig, the pretty young Chinese woman sat at home in her bedroom on a quiet Sunday evening and began singing karaoke.

headline: Measure to Repeal Death Penalty Fails by a Single Vote in New Hampshire Senate
abstract: The 12-12 tie vote on Thursday leaves the current law intact and New Hampshire as the lone state in New England that allows the execution of anyone convicted of a capital crime.
lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N.H. — In a tie vote, the New Hampshire Senate deadlocked Thursday on whether to repeal the death penalty, leaving the current law intact and New Hampshire as the lone state in New England that allows the execution of anyone convicted of a capital crime.

headline: Nigeria Fears Captive Girls Will Be Held as Sex Slaves
abstract: The girls were kidnapped early Tuesday from a state school in the heartland of the Boko Haram insurgency, startling a country already numbed by a steady drumbeat of horrific episodes attributed to the Islamist militant group.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — Dozens of schoolgirls abducted by armed militants in northeastern Nigeria this week remained missing on Thursday amid fears that they would be turned into “sex slaves and cooks” if they were not rescued, a top official in the region said.

headline: After the Violence, the Real Pain Begins
abstract: The brutal indie film “Proxy” is a puzzle box of grief, passion and psychology.
lead_paragraph: A bizarre puzzle box of twisted passions and psychological sickness, Zack Parker’s “Proxy” presents us almost immediately with a scene of such repulsive brutality that the film seems to be daring us to keep watching. If you accept, you’ll find yourself wading waist-deep into the swampy center of an original if overlong story about manufactured grief and disturbingly bad mothering.

headline: Entwining Tales of Time, Memory and Love
abstract: Gabriel García Márquez — who died on Thursday at his home in Mexico City, at the age of 87 — used his fecund imagination and exuberant sleight of hand to conjure the miraculous in his fiction.
lead_paragraph: The Magus of magical realism, Gabriel García Márquez — who died on Thursday at his home in Mexico City, at the age of 87 — used his fecund imagination and exuberant sleight of hand to conjure the miraculous in his fiction: plagues of insomnia and forgetfulness, a cluster of magical grapes containing the secret of death, an all-night rain of yellow blossoms, a swamp of lilies oozing blood, a Spanish galleon marooned in a Latin American jungle, cattle born bearing the brand of their owner.

headline: Tip Well: It’s Your Waiter’s Last Night
abstract: The romantic comedy “Tasting Menu” focuses on diners who are enjoying the final meals served in a closing restaurant.
lead_paragraph: “Tasting Menu” cites as inspirations the 2011 closing of El Bulli, the acclaimed Catalan restaurant that showcased its visionary chef, Ferran Adrià, as well as culinary cinema like “Big Night” and “Babette’s Feast.” Unfortunately, Roger Gual’s half-baked film hopes to split the difference between romantic comedy and foodie delight but fails at both.

headline: Gotta Dance (Together)
abstract: In “Make Your Move,” a rivalry between Brooklyn dance clubs, and their owners, threatens to keep apart two dancers who are meant to be together.
lead_paragraph: O.K., it’s not Montagues and Capulets, it’s rival Brooklyn dance clubs: the gritty, underground Static and the more upper-crust Oto. The star-crossed lovers are Donny (Derek Hough), a street dancer and parolee from New Orleans, and Aya (the South Korean pop star BoA), a Korean dancer-drummer raised in Japan. Static’s owner is Donny’s foster brother, Nick (Wesley Jonathan), who had a falling-out with his partner, Kaz (Will Yun Lee of “Hawaii Five-O”), Aya’s overprotective brother. Kaz went to work at Oto, which is owned by the Wall Street knave Michael (Jefferson Brown), who has designs on Aya and wants her at his beck and call.

headline: Mummy Dearest, Back for More
abstract: Charles Ludlam’s two-actor gothic farce, “The Mystery of Irma Vep: A Penny Dreadful,” is back in a production from Red Bull Theater, directed by one of the play’s original stars.
lead_paragraph: As soon as a playhouse announces a Charles Ludlam comedy, how sellers of Velcro and cheap wigs must rejoice. When Ludlam died in 1987, he left behind a flamboyant, genre-defying oeuvre that depends on outrageous, easily doffed costumes. In “The Mystery of Irma Vep: A Penny Dreadful,” revived by Red Bull Theater at the Lucille Lortel Theater, two stalwart actors (Arnie Burton and Robert Sella) shift gowns, trousers, fezzes and the occasional wooden leg faster than laws of space and time would seem to permit.

headline: In the Spotlight, Finding His Religion
abstract: “Act One” at Lincoln Center stars Tony Shalhoub and Santino Fontana and Matthew Schechter as the theater artisan Moss Hart, from his Bronx childhood to Broadway glory.
lead_paragraph: If only the Tony Awards nominating committee would see fit to expand its categories, I could confidently predict at least two eminently deserving winners. For best performance by two actors in the same role ... (hold your breath, nibble your nails) ...sorry, no suspense here, folks.

headline: Fame-Hating Lewis Carroll Letter Lands in Los Angeles
abstract: A Lewis Carroll letter lamenting attention from fans is bought by the University of Southern California.
lead_paragraph: A letter by Lewis Carroll declaring his hatred for fame and sometime wish that he had never written “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland” has now found a home in the epicenter of the global celebrity hellscape: Los Angeles.

headline: Learn to Teach
abstract: In which I get flummoxed by James Mulhern.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — I just barely got a toehold in James Mulhern’s puzzle today. The clues seemed unusually cryptic for my money (not cryptic crossword style, just out of my reach). That’s not a bad thing. Most solvers like to wrap their brains around some difficult cluing and new, crunchy words, and this puzzle delivers.

headline: A Chip Off the Old Engine Block
abstract: In Joel Surnow’s “Small Time,” a son opts for working at his father’s used-car business instead of going to college.
lead_paragraph: In the deadly voice-over that begins Joel Surnow’s “Small Time,” a man declares: “This is the story about my father and the summer we spent together many years ago. It was the summer that changed my life.”

headline: Obama on Ukraine Pact
abstract: After a diplomatic agreement to ease tensions in Ukraine was reached, the president expressed skepticism about Russia’s promise to de-escalate the volatile situation.
lead_paragraph: After a diplomatic agreement to ease tensions in Ukraine was reached, the president expressed skepticism about Russia’s promise to de-escalate the volatile situation.

headline: Deal is Reached to Ease Tension in East Ukraine
abstract: The United States, Russia, Ukraine and the European Union reached an agreement on Thursday that called for armed pro-Russian bands to surrender the government buildings they have seized.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United States, Russia, Ukraine and the European Union reached an agreement on Thursday evening that called for armed pro-Russian bands in eastern Ukraine to surrender the government buildings they have seized and that outlined other steps to defuse a crisis that has rattled the international community.

headline: That Thing He Had for the Boss’s Wife
abstract: “A Promise,” the first English-language film by the French director Patrice Leconte, tells the story of an industrialist, his wife and his assistant.
lead_paragraph: An unconsummated long-distance passion that resists the erosion of time and memory is the subject of the Austrian writer Stefan Zweig’s posthumously published novella, “Journey Into the Past.” When addressed in the movies, this kind of longing is usually diluted into soap opera and its darker psychological implications suffocated by a gauzy romanticism. The French director Patrice Leconte’s film, “A Promise,” adapted from the novella, is no exception.

headline: Unmoved, Anthony Is Still on Fence Over Future
abstract: Knicks players conducted exit interviews on Thursday with Phil Jackson, the team’s new president.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Not so long ago, Carmelo Anthony made a public appearance in which he expressed his desire to test free agency. He wanted to explore his options, he said, although he emphasized that his preference was to remain with the Knicks.

headline: Rancher Says Utility Put Power Line in Wrong Place
abstract: The Public Utility Commission is set to consider a rancher’s complaint that a 345-kilovolt power line that a transmission operator erected is 150 feet north of where it was originally mapped.
lead_paragraph: RHOME, Tex. — Johnny Vinson is not your typical underdog. At 82, he is a rancher who has sold more land than most rural Texans could imagine owning. And he has plenty left to stand on, including more than 3,500 acres in Wise County that have ample room for dozens of gas wells, grazing cattle, a ranch house and staff living quarters.

headline: Oil and Water Mix, Then Emotions Flare
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)']
abstract: The documentary “Vanishing Pearls” looks at the small Gulf community of Pointe à la Hache, La., where the oyster industry has been devastated by the Deepwater Horizon oil spill.
lead_paragraph: As the fourth anniversary of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill approaches, on April 20, arguments will rage about who should have done what and when. The advocacy documentary “Vanishing Pearls,” which opens on Friday in New York and Los Angeles and will have one-night engagements in cities across the country over the next three months, makes an impassioned case that the spill’s effects still linger.

headline: Christie Appoints an Ombudsman
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie said that he would propose legislation in New Jersey making it a crime for government officials not to report official misconduct by others.
lead_paragraph: Continuing his efforts to move past the scandal surrounding the George Washington Bridge lane closings, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey on Thursday named an ombudsman to strengthen ethics policies in his office, and eliminated the department that an internal investigation found had rewarded and punished mayors across the state depending on whether they supported the governor’s re-election.

headline: Clinton Backer Pleads Guilty in a Straw Donor Scheme
abstract: Sant Singh Chatwal, who owns the Chatwal and the Dream hotels and the Bombay Palace restaurant chain, admitted illegally funneling $180,000 to three candidates.
lead_paragraph: As Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton ran for president in 2008, one of her most enthusiastic financial supporters was Sant Singh Chatwal, an Indian-American hotel and restaurant owner, whose relationship with the Clintons dated back years.

headline: U.N. Council Takes Up Question of Rights in North Korea
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The United Nations appeared to move a step closer on Thursday to holding North Korea’s government accountable for what an investigative panel has called a history of crimes against humanity.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations appeared to move a step closer on Thursday to holding North Korea’s government accountable for what an investigative panel has called a history of crimes against humanity and egregious human rights abuses, as the Security Council convened a special session to hear the panel’s views on what should be done.

headline: A Couple of Heirs of Travis Bickle
keywords: ['Movies', 'Video Releases (Entertainment)', 'DVD (Digital Versatile Disc)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Two video releases examine pathologies: Martin Scorsese’s “The King of Comedy” concerns celebrity worship; Abel Ferrara’s “Ms .45” takes aim at homicidal revenge.
lead_paragraph: A 34-year-old messenger still living at home, Rupert Pupkin (Robert De Niro) dreams of becoming a stand-up comedy star. To force fate’s hand, he stalks and kidnaps his idol, the TV talk show host Jerry Langford (Jerry Lewis). Martin Scorsese’s 1983 movie “The King of Comedy” not only told a story but identified a malaise. Call it Pupkinitis.

headline: Turkey: Intelligence Bill Approved
abstract: Turkey’s Parliament on Thursday passed a bill that increases the powers of the national spy agency and strengthens its immunity.
lead_paragraph: Turkey’s Parliament on Thursday passed a bill that increases the powers of the national spy agency and strengthens its immunity, a move that critics said would allow Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan to bolster his control over state institutions. The measure, which requires presidential approval before it becomes a law, would give the National Intelligence Organization, known by the initials of its Turkish name M.I.T., access to information collected by public and private institutions without a court order and would expand its ability to carry out covert operations. Government officials said the changes would make the agency more efficient and provide protections for its personnel. Mr. Erdogan has been tightening his grip on state agencies as his government deals with accusations of corruption and has tried to block or control access to the Internet, Twitter and YouTube. “With this legislation, the M.I.T. is no longer a national intelligence agency but has become the prime minister’s intelligence agency,” said an opposition lawmaker, Sezgin Tanrikulu.

headline: Congo: Park Director Survives Shooting
abstract: Emmanuel de Merode, an internationally recognized Belgian conservationist who has been working to protect rare mountain gorillas in the Democratic Republic of Congo, was attacked Tuesday by unknown assailants.
lead_paragraph: Emmanuel de Merode, an internationally recognized Belgian conservationist who has been working to protect rare mountain gorillas in the Democratic Republic of Congo, is recovering from gunshot wounds after being attacked Tuesday by unknown assailants, officials said Thursday. Mr. de Merode, 43, the director of the Virunga National Park, Africa’s oldest national park, was attacked by the gunmen as he drove near Goma, not far from the border with Rwanda. He was taken to a hospital in Goma, where he underwent surgery. Mr. de Merode, above, is a Belgian prince and is married to Louise Leakey, a Kenyan paleontologist and the granddaughter of the archaeologist Louis Leakey, known for his studies on human evolution in Africa. Virunga National Park was established in 1925 by Belgium, which then governed Congo.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Sabathia Overcomes an Ace and a Dome, With Help From a Triple Play
abstract: C. C. Sabathia, in his best start this season, allowed two runs, only one of them earned, in seven innings. He gave up seven hits and struck out six to even his record at 2-2.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Yangervis Solarte has had many firsts since joining the Yankees this year, including his first major league game and his first hit. On Thursday, he added to his collection with his first major league home run and his first triple play at any level.

headline: Senate Seat That Davis Leaves Behind Looks Crucial
abstract: With State Senator Wendy Davis running for governor of Texas, her district is shaping up as a potentially decisive one for Republicans.
lead_paragraph: The two Republicans campaigning to replace State Senator Wendy Davis, the Fort Worth Democrat who is running for governor, are locked in a tight primary runoff battle.

headline: Cost of Treatment May Influence Doctors
abstract: Some of the most influential medical groups in the nation are recommending that doctors weigh the costs, not just the effectiveness of treatments that they recommend for patients.
lead_paragraph: Saying they can no longer ignore the rising prices of health care, some of the most influential medical groups in the nation are recommending that doctors weigh the costs, not just the effectiveness of treatments, as they make decisions about patient care.

headline: After Hit to Mouth, Rangers Draw First Blood
abstract: Brad Richards and Derek Stepan scored on a four-minute power play in the third period, propelling the Rangers over the Flyers in Game 1 of their playoff series.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers took full advantage of a rookie’s mistake and a teammate’s bloodied mouth to break open their Stanley Cup opener Thursday night.

lead_paragraph: Officials discussed the latest developments in the search for passengers trapped inside the ferry that sank in the waters off southwestern South Korea.

abstract: Action from the Rangers’ 4-1 victory over Philadelphia in the opener of their Eastern Conference series.
lead_paragraph: Action from the Rangers’ 4-1 victory over Philadelphia in the opener of their Eastern Conference series.

headline: Sebelius Says She’s Not Interested in Senate Run
abstract: Kathleen Sebelius, who is ending her tenure as health and human services secretary, had been sought out to challenge Senator Pat Roberts, a Republican.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Kathleen Sebelius, the soon-to-be former secretary of the Health and Human Services Department, said through a spokeswoman on Thursday that she was not interested in running for the Senate in Kansas, despite recent entreaties from Democrats.

headline: Messages From Students on South Korean Ferry
abstract: Texts sent by Danwon High School students as their ferry began sinking on Wednesday morning express love, fear and despair.
lead_paragraph: As a South Korean ferry began sinking with 475 people believed to be aboard — 325 of them students from Danwon High School — passengers reached for their cellphones and began sending messages to their loved ones. The following are transcripts of those exchanges.

headline: García Márquez, Magical Realism Master
abstract: Gabriel García Márquez, the Nobel laureate Colombian author whose “One Hundred Years of Solitude” established him as a giant of 20th-century literature, died on Thursday at his home in Mexico City.
lead_paragraph: Gabriel García Márquez, the Nobel laureate Colombian author whose “One Hundred Years of Solitude” established him as a giant of 20th-century literature, died on Thursday at his home in Mexico City.

headline: Alternative to Carriage Has Little Horsepower
keywords: ['Horses', 'Carriages', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'New York International Auto Show', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare']
abstract: A group unveiled the eCarriage, a potential successor to Central Park’s horse-drawn carriages at the New York International Auto Show.
lead_paragraph: The horse of the future could be an electric car with an “ah-ooga horn” and seating for eight.

headline: Three Pitches, Nine Outs
abstract: The Yankees’ last three triple plays have come with C. C. Sabathia on the mound.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees’ last three triple plays have come with C. C. Sabathia on the mound.

headline: Another Charge in Navy Bribe Case
keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Ships and Shipping', 'Defense Contracts', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A Navy enlisted man was charged in a complaint unsealed Thursday with accepting $1,000-a-month in cash, trips and consumer electronics for supplying a Malaysian contractor with sensitive Navy ship schedules.
lead_paragraph: A Navy enlisted man was charged in a complaint unsealed Thursday with accepting $1,000-a-month in cash, trips and consumer electronics for supplying a Malaysian contractor with sensitive Navy ship schedules. The petty officer, Dan Layug, 27, was the fourth Navy employee arrested in the case, which has also led to charges against the contractor, Leonard Glenn Francis, for conspiring to bribe officials to inflate his billings. Prosecutors say Mr. Layug, who was released on a $100,000 bond, deposited payments from Mr. Francis’s company, Glenn Defense Marine Asia, in a bank account in the name of his infant daughter.

headline: Officials in Rhythmic Gymnastics Judging Scandal Are Said to Be Exonerated
abstract: The ruling by the Court of Arbitration for Sport cited a lack of evidence, annulling a decision by the international gymnastics federation.
lead_paragraph: Citing a lack of evidence, the Court of Arbitration for Sport has exonerated six officials who were implicated in a judging scandal, annulling a decision by the governing body for rhythmic gymnastics.

headline: A New, Cowboy-Inspired Fashion Frontier
abstract: For spring, designers took cues from Wild West dressing for their denim-heavy, turquoise-studded, fringe-accented collections.
lead_paragraph: Then and now, the rugged on-screen apparel of the cinematic heroes Clint Eastwood and John Wayne serves as an iconic expression of American style. This season, their characters’ Wild West legacy lives on in fashion’s frontier as the influence for spring collections by the likes of Junya Watanabe, Paco Rabanne, Creatures of the Wind and Valentino. Designers took visual cues from the cowboy uniform — distressed denim, fringe, turquoise, embroidery and, of course, boots — to create separates that come together for a fully transportive look. But if a head-to-toe Annie Oakley-influenced ensemble isn’t your modus operandi, pairing any of these individual items with monochromatic basics — a white tee with Junya Watanabe jeans or a black dress with a cashmere Elder Statesman bandana — will keep things relevant and fresh.

headline: Police Capture and Question Suspect in Shooting of Brooklyn Teenager
abstract: Kareem Potomont, 21, was taken into custody hours after the police identified him and released photographs of him.
lead_paragraph: New York City detectives on Thursday night were questioning a suspect in a daytime shooting in Brooklyn that severely wounded a 13-year-old bystander this week, the police said.

headline: India Election Digest: April 18
abstract: What you need to know on Friday about India’s elections.
lead_paragraph: What you need to know on Friday about India’s elections: Voter turnout rose in most districts in the fifth phase of the elections compared with 2009, the Indian National Congress appears to be missing its youth unit, and voters at the world’s highest polling station remain optimistic that someday a politician will visit them.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Nat Geo Wild) CESAR MILLAN: LOVE MY PIT BULL Once upon a time, the pit bull was a popular family pet beloved by President Theodore Roosevelt, Gen. George S. Patton and Helen Keller. Today, these dogs are more closely associated with gangs and dogfighting, and have been responsible for a large percentage of fatal dog attacks on humans. Pit bulls are often abused or abandoned, and are euthanized at a higher rate than other dogs, with an estimated one million put down each year in the United States. In this special, Mr. Millan chronicles the history of the pit bull as a herder and companion — in Britain, the Staffordshire bull terrier was nicknamed “the nanny dog” for its sweet disposition with children — and with his own pit bull, Junior (above, with Mr. Millan), makes the case for the dogs as loyal and loving, given the right training for both animals and humans. “All dogs are great companions,” he says. “Communication creates a partnership, and dogs have the simplest communication on the planet. For them, everything is about trust, respect and love.”

headline: Scandal Downs Chairman of a Top Chinese State Company
abstract: The downfall of Song Lin, former head of China Resources, has the trappings of a late-night drama, including accusations of illicit riches, extramarital sex and pictures taken in a bedroom.
lead_paragraph: For a year, the chairman of one of China’s biggest state corporations, China Resources, seemed immune to allegations that he had embroiled the company in corruption. That was until a reporter went public with the additional accusation that the chairman, Song Lin, kept a mistress who laundered his money.

headline: A Fractured Vote in Old Delhi Market
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Elections', 'Elections, State Legislature', 'Hinduism', 'Law and Legislation', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Voting and Voters']
