abstract: I expect to be ambushed by improvements in technology. I expect to be rendered helpless by upgrades. But by zippers?
lead_paragraph: I’m so glad it’s spring because I won’t get stuck in my down coat anymore. Several times I had to put my hands over my head and get peeled out of it — once at a restaurant.

headline: Assad Campaigns for Re-election in Syria
abstract: Officials in Damascus have declared that a presidential vote will be held within months. President Bashar al-Assad is expected to win.
lead_paragraph: Officials in Damascus have declared that a presidential vote will be held within months. President Bashar al-Assad is expected to win.

headline: Facebook’s Existential Crisis
abstract: Is Facebook’s main service still relevant? An argument for why it feels fusty, and why Mark Zuckerberg seems to know it.
lead_paragraph: Lately, I have found myself on Facebook, mindlessly scrolling through links to listicles, clicking through bizarre photo albums of cute snail portraits and halfheartedly skimming updates from people whose names I no longer recognize with little to no recollection about how I ended up on the site or why.

headline: Mortgage Reform Is Worth the Small Extra Cost to Borrowers
abstract: The higher cost for borrowers in a Senate bill reforming Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac corresponds to the protection for taxpayers that was missing in the old system, writes an economist.
lead_paragraph: Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department from 2006 to 2009.

headline: April 18, 1923: Yankee Stadium Opens to Public
abstract: Ninety-one years ago today, Yankee Stadium opened to the public in the Bronx
lead_paragraph: It took 11 months and cost $2.5 million to build the original Yankee Stadium. And when it opened 91 years ago, the team announced that 99,200 fans showed up, with 25,000 turned away. Babe Ruth hit a home run, driving in three runs in the Yankees’ 4-1 victory over the Boston Red Sox. Here is how The Times covered the game.

headline: Daily Report: Stardom in China Takes a Webcam and a Voice
abstract: The success of typically low-budget productions offers a potential path for the rest of the world, which is struggling to move profitably into online programming.
lead_paragraph: Dolled up with makeup and a blond wig, the pretty young Chinese woman sat at home in her bedroom on a quiet Sunday evening and began singing karaoke, David Barboza reports.

headline: ‘Ai Weiwei: According to What?’
abstract: A look at the Ai Weiwei survey at the Brooklyn Museum.
lead_paragraph: A look at the Ai Weiwei survey at the Brooklyn Museum.

headline: ScienceTake: Killer Sponges
keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Oceans and Seas']
abstract: Sedentary sponges have evolved some fearsome weapons for trapping and devouring small prey.
lead_paragraph: Sedentary sponges have evolved some fearsome weapons for trapping and devouring small prey.

headline: The Works of Cornelia Gurlitt
abstract: An exhibition in Germany is dedicated to the little-known artworks of the sister of a Nazi-era art dealer whose trove of masterpieces was seized in Munich.
lead_paragraph: An exhibition in Germany is dedicated to the little-known artworks of the sister of a Nazi-era art dealer whose trove of masterpieces was seized in Munich.

headline: Jacques Servier, 92, Dies; Accused of Hiding the Risks of Drugs
abstract: Laboratoires Servier, the pharmaceutical company founded by Mr. Servier, was hailed as a champion of French business until its diabetes drug was withdrawn.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Jacques Servier, who created one of the biggest pharmaceutical companies in France but whose life’s work was overshadowed by allegations that he concealed the dangers of drugs that he helped develop, died on Wednesday at his home in a suburb of Paris. He was 92.

headline: New Batch of Clinton Documents Is Released
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2008', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: The topics in the Clinton administration documents include the conflicts in Somalia and Rwanda, Middle East peace talks, the Oklahoma City bombing and the attempt to overhaul the health care system.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The National Archives on Friday released its largest batch yet of previously withheld documents from the Clinton administration, with topics including the conflicts in Somalia and Rwanda, Middle East peace negotiations, the Oklahoma City bombing and public figures as varied as Richard M. Nixon and Oprah Winfrey.

headline: Deadliest Day: Sherpas Bear Everest’s Risks
abstract: An avalanche that left at least 12 dead has focused attention on the Sherpas, skilled high-altitude climbers who put themselves at great risk for the foreign teams that pay them.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Sherpas always go first, edging up the deadly flank of Everest while international clients wait for days in the base camp below.

headline: Gag Order From Israeli Court Raises Questions
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The legal situation is murky, but it caused a delay in an article’s publication.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:42 a.m.

headline: Sympathy for a Rat
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: Empathy with a dirty rodent created a lingering sense of guilt about why there was no similar feeling for the homeless.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Listen Up | Oh Land, the Pop Star Who Can’t Forget Her Moment as a Ballerina
abstract: In a video for her song “Cherry on Top,” which premieres here, the Swedish chanteuse comes to terms with the loss of her previous career as a dancer.
lead_paragraph: Before she came to public attention as the ethereal electro-pop siren Oh Land, the Danish musician Nanna Fabricius was a small-town girl who dreamed of becoming a ballerina. She left home for Stockholm at age 15 to pursue those ambitions until a back injury ended her career. Still, she often dreams about her first creative pursuit. An actual dream, in fact, inspired her new music video for “Cherry on Top,” a twinkling ballad on her 2013 album “Wish Bone,” produced by TV on the Radio’s Dave Sitek. In it, she went into a dance studio — only to discover that she wasn’t a dancer, she was a piano player. The dream seemed an apt expression for the song, which, she explains, is about “taking off the blinders and seeing the world all around you.”

headline: Obama in Asia
abstract: The pivot to Asia is yet again weighed down with baggage.
lead_paragraph: The pivot to Asia is yet again weighed down with baggage.

headline: A Hidden Art Trove and a Lost Relative
keywords: ['Art', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'World War I (1914-18)', 'Collectors and Collections']
abstract: A new exhibition in Germany focuses on the work of Cornelia Gurlitt, an Expressionist artist who was also the sister of a Nazi-era art dealer whose trove of masterpieces was recently seized in Munich.
lead_paragraph: HOCHSTADT, Germany — Last November, Hubert Portz was at his home in Hochstadt, southwest of Mannheim, reading a story in the morning newspaper when he came across a familiar name, causing his heart to skip a beat.

headline: Clinton Publisher Settles on Title for New Memoir
abstract: “Hard Choices,” which recounts Hillary Rodham Clinton’s years as secretary of state as she emerges as a potential presidential candidate, is due out in June.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s coming memoir about her tenure as Secretary of State will be titled “Hard Choices,” her publisher said early Friday.

headline: Most G-7 Nations Still Trying to Recoup Lost Jobs
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Unemployment', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: Of all the major industrialized countries, only Germany and Japan have managed to return to their 2007 employment levels.
lead_paragraph: MORE than six years after the Great Recession began, people in most industrialized countries are still less likely to be employed than they were before the downturn.

headline: Study of Moon’s Atmosphere Ends With Planned Crash
abstract: The Lunar Atmosphere and Dust Environment Explorer slammed into the moon early Friday, ending a successful six-month mission, if a few days early.
lead_paragraph: NASA’s Lunar Atmosphere and Dust Environment Explorer spacecraft slammed into the moon early Friday morning, as planned, but a few days earlier than NASA officials expected.

headline: Pro-Russian Insurgents Balk at Terms of Pact in Ukraine
abstract: A U.S.-backed deal to settle the crisis in eastern Ukraine fell flat but appeared to arrest, at least temporarily, the momentum of separatist unrest in the region.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — An American-backed deal to settle the crisis in eastern Ukraine fell flat on Friday as pro-Russian militants vowed to stay in occupied government buildings, dashing hopes of a swift end to an insurgency that the authorities in Kiev portray as a Kremlin-orchestrated effort to put Ukraine’s industrial heartland under Russian control.

headline: Coachella 2014: Selfies (and Outkast) in the Desert
abstract: Jon Caramanica talks to Ben Ratliff, who reviewed the festival for The Times.
lead_paragraph: Now that the Coachella dust has been washed down 90,000 shower drains by the disappearing California water supply, it’s time to apply some music criticism and lifestyle journalism in this week’s Popcast.

headline: On Geeshie Wiley’s Trail
abstract: Caitlin Love worked with John Jeremiah Sullivan to research the story of Geeshie Wiley and Elvie Thomas, two women who changed American music and then vanished without a trace. Here, Love talks about one of her research dead-ends.
lead_paragraph: When I first started doing research for John Jeremiah Sullivan for his article about Geeshie Wiley and Elvie Thomas, two women who changed American music and then vanished without a trace, I kept Wiley’s song “Last Kind Words Blues” on repeat for days. I hadn’t listened closely to her songs before this project, but I was aware of the mythology around them. Now, I found myself hearing something new: a haunting, a mystery.

headline: Slopestyle Asks, When Is a Risky Sport Too Dangerous?
abstract: A comment by the head of scientific activities for the International Olympic Committee threw a spotlight on the tension between spectacle and safety in the Winter Games.
lead_paragraph: No sports discipline — not even boxing — has been dropped from the modern Olympics because it was too dangerous, and it would still be quite a surprise if slopestyle became the first.

headline: Who Made That Relief Pitcher?
abstract: And how a changed statistic changed the bullpen.
lead_paragraph: In April 1903, a writer for Sporting Life described what might have been a baseball first: “Manager McGraw has originated a new plan,” the paper said, referring to John McGraw, the successful skipper of the New York Giants. “He will use two pitchers in every game, one being in the points five innings and the other four. No manager but one who has originality and nerve would attempt any such innovation, but McGraw has both.”

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Transcendence,’ ‘Fading Gigolo’ and ‘Manakamana’
abstract: Times critics on “Transcendence,” “Fading Gigolo” and “Manakamana.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “Transcendence,” “Fading Gigolo” and “Manakamana.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: How Payday Lenders Prey Upon the Poor — and the Courts Don’t Help
abstract: A $600 loan and the struggle to even the playing field between businesses and their customers.
lead_paragraph: In 2003, Tonya Burke was living in North Carolina with her two children when she got into financial trouble. She had fallen $500 behind on her rent and utilities, and neither of her boys’ fathers was able to chip in. Then she needed to take time off from work when her younger son, who was only 8 months old, had to have emergency intestinal surgery. After his recovery, she started working for $11 an hour as a secretary, “but my paychecks weren’t enough to cover the back bills and the new ones too,” she says. “I was at a point in my life where I didn’t want to ask anyone else for help.” There was a payday lender across the street from her office. “It seemed like a good solution.”

headline: The Million-Dollar Manhattan Apartment
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: If $1 million is all you can spend, expect slim pickings.
lead_paragraph: With a budget of about $1 million, Patricia Marx began looking for a two-bedroom, two-bath apartment in Manhattan last fall. She soon realized just how limited her options were.

headline: What Made Me | Hugue Dufour
abstract: The French-Canadian head chef of M. Wells Dinette and M. Wells Steakhouse reflects on his fondness for his wife, the borough of Queens and cooking veal brains for customers.
lead_paragraph: The French-Canadian head chef of M. Wells Dinette and M. Wells Steakhouse reflects on his fondness for his wife, the borough of Queens and cooking veal brains for customers.

headline: From Fan Letter to Pen Pal
abstract: “Fare Forward” collects letters written by the experimental-fiction writer David Markson to a fan turned friend.
lead_paragraph: In 2003, the poet Laura Sims wrote a gushing fan letter to the experimental-fiction writer David Markson. (“ ‘Perfect’ is the one word I would choose to describe your work as a whole,” she wrote.) “Fare Forward,” a new book, collects Markson’s side of their ensuing correspondence, which continued until 2010, when he died at 82.

headline: Lives of the Poets
abstract: New books about Marianne Moore, E. E. Cummings, William and Dorothy Wordsworth, and Tennyson.
lead_paragraph: HOLDING ON UPSIDE DOWN  The Life and Work of Marianne Moore  By Linda Leavell  Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $30.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: WHO OWNS THE FUTURE?,  by Jaron Lanier. (Simon & Schuster, $17.) Lanier follows up the boldly predictive “You Are Not a Gadget” (2010) with a jeremiad against the concentration of money and power in our digital networks. Chief among his targets are “Siren Servers” — social media, financial institutions, intelligence agencies — that depend on accumulating and evaluating consumer data without acknowledging a monetary debt to the people mined for all this “free” information.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: MONEY: The Unauthorized Biography,  by Felix ­Martin. (Knopf, $27.95.) Examining the nature and history of money, as well as its politicization, an economist and former World Bank official argues that it is a “social technology.”

headline: At Brooklyn Museum’s Artists Ball, Some Words From Ai Weiwei and Unusual Doughnuts
abstract: Ai Weiwei delivered remarks via video at the Brooklyn Museum’s Artists Ball.
lead_paragraph: Ai Weiwei, Jenny Holzer and Kehinde Wiley were among the honorees at the Brooklyn Museum’s Artists Ball, an annual benefit gala that draws a mix of the cultural and civic establishment and young up-and-coming artists. The real estate leaders and philanthropists Jane and David Walentas, developers of Dumbo and Jane’s Carousel, were also honored at the Wednesday event; the fountain in front of the museum was named in their behalf.

headline: Dream Girls
abstract: Two ambitious friends come of age in 1950s Kentucky, but a rift forms when one moves to Harlem.
lead_paragraph: What to do with the teenage girl as subject? She has been much maligned in the pages of our literature — Shirley Jackson’s homicidal Merricat in “We Have Always Lived in the Castle,” or Jeffrey Eugenides’s suiciding sisters. Even in less lethal incarnations, young girls in novels take advantage or are taken advantage of. The question of innocence is central — there is always virginity, literal and metaphorical, to be considered — and virtue is prized above all else.

headline: Innocence Project
abstract: Raised by utopian parents, this novel’s brother and sister find it hard to navigate the world.
lead_paragraph: Hindsight is a wonderful thing. But in fiction it can take on a whole new power — blunderingly obvious or brightly illuminating, depending on how imaginatively it’s applied. Rare is the contemporary novel that doesn’t set out, at least in part, to examine the effects of past behavior on present outcomes. While this can lead to pungent and suspenseful storytelling, it requires a delicate balance, keeping the reader engaged in the narrative momentum of an unknown future that’s already in the past. In her perceptive, empathetic and often emotionally gripping new novel, Leah Hager Cohen — author of the acclaimed “The Grief of Others” — has managed the trick very deftly.

headline: Three Siblings and a Murder
abstract: This novel, set against the backdrop of 1960s London, abounds with political corruption and sexual scandal.
lead_paragraph: Peter Ackroyd’s new book begins like a fairy tale: “In the London borough of Camden, in the middle of the last century, there lived three brothers.” And a wondrous set of boys they are, having been born at precisely midday on May 8 of three successive years. This coincidence — only the first of many in Ackroyd’s breezy contrivance of a novel — signals an “invisible communion” among the brothers that will link their fates even as they set out on radically different paths through life. In the end, true to the Grimm Brothers template, only one will endure his personal ordeal and emerge relatively unscathed; the other two wind up succumbing to the wiles of the true hero of the piece — the city of London itself, the only character in the book the author actually seems to care about.

headline: Predator and Prey
abstract: In Nevada Barr’s Destroyer Angel,” the National Park Service ranger Anna Pigeon must revert to her animal nature to survive.
lead_paragraph: Nevada Barr has been brooding about the primal bonds between man and nature ever since her first mystery, “Track of the Cat,” came out more than 20 years ago. While respectfully acknowledging the forces of nature (the rampaging forest fire in “Firestorm” comes to mind, as does the harsh terrain of “Winter Study”), she has always found humans to be the more savage. In DESTROYER ANGEL (Minotaur, $26.99), Barr takes this insight to a disturbing new level by allowing her series detective, the National Park Service ranger Anna Pigeon, to test her belief that “animals were better people than people.” In order to survive, can she revert to her own animal nature, hunting and killing other human beings?

headline: Let’s Have a Dialogue
abstract: A philosophical inquiry imagines Plato on an American book tour in the 21st century.
lead_paragraph: Plato has begun to appear in some unexpected places. On the first track of Jay-Z and Kanye West’s hip-hop album, “Watch the Throne” (2011), you can pick out the line, “Is Pious pious cause God loves pious?” This, as classicists will instantly recognize, is an allusion to a dilemma posed in Plato’s dialogue “Euthyphro,” in which Socrates asks, “Is the pious loved by the gods because it is pious, or is it pious because it is loved by the gods?” In Rebecca Newberger Goldstein’s new book, “Plato at the Googleplex: Why Philosophy Won’t Go Away,” Plato turns up not only at the search engine’s headquarters in Mountain View, Calif., but also with the obstreperous host of a cable news talk show, as a consultant to an advice columnist, and in several other places a long way from ancient Athens. In Goldstein’s neat finale, the pupil of Socrates and teacher of Aristotle eagerly disappears into the magnetic bowels of an fM.R.I. scanner to have his brain probed.

headline: Missing Links
abstract: In tracing ancient DNA, a paleogeneticist uncovered a relationship between Neanderthals and modern humans.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1981, a Swedish graduate student named Svante Paabo filled a laboratory at the University of Uppsala with the stench of rotting liver. Paabo was supposed to be studying viruses, but he had become secretly obsessed with a more exotic line of research: extracting DNA from Egyptian mummies. No one at the time had any idea if the desiccated flesh of pharaohs still contained any genetic material, so Paabo decided to run an experiment. He bought a piece of calf’s liver and put it in a lab oven at about 120 degrees for a few days to approximate mummification. In the dried, blackened lump of meat, he succeeded in finding scattered fragments of DNA.

headline: Taken for a Ride
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Tour de France (Bicycle Race)', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Doping (Sports)']
abstract: Lance Armstrong and the win-at-all-costs world of pro cycling.
lead_paragraph: Last year, after admitting he had used performance-enhancing drugs during his professional cycling career, Lance Armstrong sat down with the New York Times reporter Juliet Macur to defend his legacy. He reminded her that many riders had used such drugs. What distinguished Armstrong, in his view, was his competitive will. “I definitely wanted to win at all costs,” he told Macur.

headline: Spare the Advice
abstract: The world’s poor have been betrayed by the technocrats in charge of global development, William Easterly says.
lead_paragraph: Almost from the birth of “development” as a concept in modern political economy, poverty has been regarded as a problem in search of technical solutions. The key, we’re told, is finding the correct mixture of policies to promote agriculture, reform financial markets or improve health. With the right mix of prescriptions, results come down mostly to ­implementation.

headline: The Women Behind the Bomb
abstract: This novel imagines married life at a secret atomic testing facility in remote Los Alamos.
lead_paragraph: Curious about the strange happenings on New Mexico’s Pajarito Plateau in the early 1940s, some of us might have read Robert Jungk’s “Brighter Than a Thousand Suns.” Or Richard Rhodes’s “The Making of the Atomic Bomb.” Perhaps, wishing for a more personal touch, we picked up Peggy Pond Church’s beautiful remembrance, “The House at Otowi Bridge,” learning about the enigmatic Edith Warner and her teahouse, which counted among its customers J. Robert Oppenheimer and Niels Bohr. Maybe, turning to Jennet Conant’s “109 East Palace,” we relived the Los Alamos story through the eyes of Dorothy McKibben, the widow who met the arriving scientists at a storefront one block from the Santa Fe Plaza, the first stop on what would be a long, strange ride.

headline: Language Without a Country
abstract: A Catalan writer held on to his 1918-19 diary for almost half a century, revising it and creating a portrait of the times.
lead_paragraph: Like many admired writers from small countries, Josep Pla is largely unknown outside his native Catalonia. Not that Catalonia is a country as such, but the Catalan language has long been a proud symbol of the region’s separate identity from the rest of Spain. And Pla, who died in 1981 at the age of 84, is a recognized master of this language. Yet only now is any of his immense body of work being translated into English.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: “The Opposite of Loneliness,” new on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 11, is a collection of essays and stories by Marina Keegan, the 22-year-old writer who died in a car accident two years ago.
lead_paragraph: The Best Years of Our Lives: New on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 11 is “The Opposite of Loneliness,” by Marina Keegan, the 22-year-old writer who died in a car accident two years ago. A precocious poet, playwright and fiction writer who had graduated from Yale just days before, Keegan was on her way to her father’s 55th-birthday party when her boyfriend lost control of the car they were riding in. The car hit a guardrail and flipped over twice. He escaped unharmed, but she died at the scene.

headline: Japan Plans to Resume Whaling Program, With Changes to Address Court Concerns
abstract: A Japanese official said that a new plan for research whaling would address objections by an international court and allow Japan to restart its annual hunts in 2015.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In a move likely to bring renewed international criticism, Japan said Friday that it wants to resume its research whaling in the Southern Ocean next year under a redesigned program that would address objections raised by an international court.

headline: Today in Small Business: Bacon-Filled Chocolate Bunnies
abstract: The H&R Block of divorce. How to invoice properly. And a one-hour delivery service for condoms with a social mission.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Italian Bank Increases Planned Share Sale to $6.9 Billion
abstract: Monte dei Paschi di Siena is fighting to avoid nationalization and bracing for stress tests of its balance sheet by European regulators.
lead_paragraph: ROME – Monte dei Paschi di Siena, Italy’s third-largest bank, plans to offer investors as much as 5 billion euros, or $6.9 billion, in new stock as it fights to avoid nationalization and braces for stress tests of its balance sheet by European regulators, the lender announced on Friday.

headline: A Formal Setting
abstract: In the silverware my mother gave me, I saw her hopes for my future. I just couldn’t quite comply.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, when I was tidying my apartment, my vacuum bumped against something under the bed. Curious, I moved the bed and discovered two wooden chests of silverware, and within them, funny, long-winded notes from my mother, detailing how many knives, forks and baby spoons each one held.

headline: How Hollywood Killed Death
abstract: The shifting economic logic of the movie business has spawned a resurrection boom.
lead_paragraph: Death in the blockbusters of 2013 played out something like this:

headline: Don’t Get Too Cute With Your Bloody Mary
abstract: Just make it bloody good.
lead_paragraph: I didn’t always like bloody marys. I blame an early childhood incident in which we coated our collie with tomato juice after a run-in with a skunk. (The juice was supposed to make the stench go away.) But my mother, who considered the viscous vermilion swill a tonic for nearly any affliction, loved them. So I was more than happy to make them for her now and then: All it took was a good slug of Smirnoff (the only vodka we had in the house, and one I still like), a can of tomato juice (or, as my mother sometimes preferred, Clamato), a shake of Lea & Perrins Worcestershire sauce, a heaping teaspoon of grated horseradish, a few shakes of black pepper, a good stir with ice, a lemon wedge for garnish, and that was that.

headline: Reply All: The 4.6.14 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: THE WOLF HUNTERS OF WALL STREET

headline: I Can’t Sue the Rain
abstract: Jazz for tots; Kate Upton vs. Upton Sinclair.
lead_paragraph: Jazz for tots; Kate Upton vs. Upton Sinclair.

headline: Does Everyone Have the Right to Conjugal Visits?
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: New rules in Mississippi prisons; the billable multitasked hour.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, the Mississippi Department of Corrections decided to stop offering hourlong conjugal visits, depriving about 155 inmates (out of more than 22,000 statewide) the opportunity to cozy up with their husbands or wives. Officials cited budgetary constraints and prison pregnancies as the reasons for ending conjugal visits. Is it ethical to suddenly deny prisoners conjugal visits when they’ve been offered them before? Relatedly, is it ethical for taxpayers to carry the costs associated with the incarcerated mother’s pregnancy and delivery? Would it be ethical to allow only conjugal visits for those who agreed to use birth control? R.J.W., WYNNEWOOD, PA.

headline: Isle of No Man
abstract: Photographs from North Brother Island, New York’s miniature Detroit.
lead_paragraph: North Brother Island is New York’s miniature Detroit, without the industry — a 20-acre, un-High Line-ed wilderness of trees and vines and abandoned, crumbling buildings in the treacherous tidal strait where the waters of New York Harbor trade places with those of Long Island Sound. It has been uninhabited for 50 years and off limits to all but biologists for more than a decade; the city manages it as a nature preserve. While it has always felt secret-filled, it now has a new one, which can be glimpsed in the photographer Christopher Payne’s new book, “North Brother Island: The Last Unknown Place in New York City”: When a vast swath of trees was recently cut down in the Bronx for development, the island’s forest, created by neglect, became the largest in the South Bronx. ﻿Robert Sullivan

headline: Sia Furler, the Socially Phobic Pop Star
abstract: One of the biggest hitmakers in music is writing for herself again. But that doesn’t mean she’ll be embracing public life.
lead_paragraph: Sia Furler walked into the Silver Lake studio 10 minutes late, ignoring the 22 keyboards and six guitars and giant speakers on her way to the blue velour sofa in the back. There she pulled a MacBook Air from her white Goyard bag and called up “Living Out Loud,” a song she had just started writing. As the music played, Furler began scat-singing: “Ha-ha-ha-ha!”

headline: On the Liberal Bias of Facts
abstract: Still true after all these years.
lead_paragraph: “The facts have a well-known liberal bias,” declared Rob Corddry way back in 2004 — and experience keeps vindicating his joke. But why?

headline: 2015 Subaru Outback: Some Pizazz for a Redesigned Wagon
abstract: The Outback gets a bit more interior room, increased cargo capacity, additional creature comforts and a dose of exterior pizazz.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Thursday, April 17: 2015 Subaru Outback.

headline: Think Back: New York World’s Fair, 1964
abstract: The organizers of the New York World’s Fair billed the event as one for the ages, but it failed to leave a lasting mark on the culture. The Times’s Sam Tanenhaus explains why.
lead_paragraph: The organizers of the New York World’s Fair billed the event as one for the ages, but it failed to leave a lasting mark on the culture. The Times’s Sam Tanenhaus explains why.

headline: Ferry Inquiry Focuses on Captain
abstract: As the search for victims entered its third day, Park Jae-Uk, the senior investigator, said the ship’s captain was not at the steering house when the ferry started sinking.
lead_paragraph: As the search for victims entered its third day, Park Jae-Uk, the senior investigator, said the ship’s captain was not at the steering house when the ferry started sinking.

headline: The King Can No Longer Afford Queens
abstract: Home prices in Queens have risen significantly. In some sense it isn’t the new Brooklyn so much as it has become the old Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Far too often, over the past few years we have read about Brooklyn as a marketable commodity — its aesthetic, lifestyle and twee products coveted and exportable. But the 50th anniversary of the 1964 World’s Fair in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park would seem an appropriate time to reflect on Queens: The Brand.

headline: The Fair to End All Fairs
abstract: In hindsight, the 1964 New York World’s Fair, thought at the time to be a celebration of modernity, seems instead like the tail end of something, the petering out of what was essentially a 19th-century phenomenon.
lead_paragraph: When you drive by on the Van Wyck Expressway or the Grand Central Parkway, the space-age towers of the New York State Pavilion, among the few remaining traces of the 1964 New York World’s Fair, rise up from the trees like a relic of some vanished, Jetsonian civilization, and the people who built them seem much more than 50 years distant from us. They were people apparently inspired by the idea of progress, and by a now quaint-seeming faith in the future, who actually believed in things like world’s fairs. Who would think of organizing such an event now? Who would pay for it? Who would bother to go?

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Asia’s Cauldron’
abstract: This week, Robert D. Kaplan discusses “Asia’s Cauldron”; Parul Sehgal and John Williams discuss this year’s Pulitzer Prizes; William Easterly talks about “The Tyranny of Experts”; and Parul Sehgal has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Robert D. Kaplan discusses “Asia’s Cauldron”; Parul Sehgal and John Williams discuss this year’s Pulitzer Prizes; William Easterly talks about “The Tyranny of Experts”; and Parul Sehgal has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: 50 Years After the New York World’s Fair, Recalling a Vision of the Future
abstract: Fairgoers share memories of family outings and moments of inspiration at the 1964 New York World’s Fair.
lead_paragraph: Fairgoers share memories of family outings and moments of inspiration at the 1964 New York World’s Fair.

headline: Under Cover: The President and the Bouquet
keywords: ['Photography', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Daan Brand, an Amsterdam-based photographer, discusses some of the thinking behind his photo illustrations for Jo Becker’s cover story chronicling the Obama administration’s shift on same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: Daan Brand, an Amsterdam-based photographer, draws inspiration from the vivid imagery of cartoons to create his photo illustrations. So when the magazine’s photo department asked Brand to illustrate Jo Becker’s cover story chronicling the Obama administration’s shift on same-sex marriage, Brand imagined a series of photo illustrations that would maintain the reader’s focus on the key players in Becker’s narrative, especially President Obama and Vice President Biden.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Asia’s Cauldron’
abstract: This week, Robert D. Kaplan and William Easterly.
lead_paragraph: This week, Robert D. Kaplan and William Easterly.

headline: What Made Me | Hugue Dufour, Head Chef at M. Wells Dinette and M. Wells Steakhouse
abstract: In this new video, the unorthodox French Canadian culinary pioneer reflects on his fondness for his wife, the borough of Queens and cooking veal brains for customers.
lead_paragraph: “Cooking for people doesn’t necessarily mean cooking what they want,” says Hugue Dufour. “They need to be told what they want, so they can enjoy better than they thought they would.” The French Canadian chef has taken the borough of Queens by storm in recent years with his idiosyncratic, unfussy, meat-loving M. Wells restaurants — the original, which closed in 2011, M. Wells Dinette in MoMA PS1 and the recently opened M. Wells Steakhouse. In the latest installment of the “What Made Me” video series by Poppy de Villeneuve, Dufour talks about the influence of his wife and co-conspirator Sarah Obraitis, getting kicked out of culinary school in Quebec and the pleasures of cooking veal brains in a diner.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: And Then It Came to an End
abstract: After the 1964 New York World’s Fair closed on Oct. 17, 1965, the fair was carefully and willfully dismantled.
lead_paragraph: One day, the New York World’s Fair, with its architecture flavored by the Space Age, was the future. Then the next day, it was history. After the debt-plagued fair closed on Oct. 17, 1965, the destruction began. Over the course of a year, as these striking images from 1965 and ’66 attest, the fair was carefully and willfully dismantled: Cranes were brought in to remove the exhibitions, buildings were demolished, and even before the official closing, people picked over the grounds, yanking plants from their beds as souvenirs.

headline: O Youth and Beauty (and After That)!
abstract: The boundary-blurring choreographer Miguel Gutierrez has created a number of evening-length works that reveal the angst of a generation through movement, music and text.
lead_paragraph: Over the years, the boundary-blurring choreographer Miguel Gutierrez has created a number of evening-length works that reveal the angst of a generation through movement, music and text. Now 42, he’s suffering from a little burnout. “Age & Beauty Part 1: Mid-Career Artist/Suicide Note or &:-/,” presented as part of the 2014 Biennial at the Whitney Museum of American Art, is the first in a series of dances that focus on the challenges of being in midcareer.

headline: Hip-Hop Bête Noire Changes Again
abstract: Just five years ago, a rapper like Riff Raff would have been unthinkable.
lead_paragraph: Just five years ago, a rapper like Riff Raff would have been unthinkable. Known for gleaming non sequitur verse, Oscar-worthy Vine videos and a magical capacity for physical transformation, he is a hip-hop changeling for the Tumblr age, an appealing nuisance.

headline: Humans Fighting for Earth’s Health
abstract: In the beginning, it was about the dams.
lead_paragraph: In the beginning, it was about the dams. The naturalist John Muir and the forester Gifford Pinchot waged war in the early 1900s over the flooding of the magnificent Hetch Hetchy Valley in Yosemite National Park. Decades later, the proposed damming of the Colorado River prompted public outrage, and the environmental movement was born. Today some two million organizations worldwide work on behalf of social justice and the environment.

headline: Every Number Tells a Story
abstract: In a series called Collected Stories, the composer David Lang curates an alluring set of programs that explore the idea of storytelling in music.
lead_paragraph: In a series called Collected Stories, the composer David Lang curates an alluring set of programs that explore the idea of storytelling in music. Six multigenre, wide-ranging concerts feature works from the medieval age to the present, including Irish folk music and Tuvan throat singing.

headline: A Family Reunion, Thanks to Goya
abstract: The public knows him best as “Red Boy,” Francisco de Goya’s portrait of the beguiling 5-year-old Manuel Osorio Manrique de Zuñiga, dressed in red from head to toe, with his pet magpie.
lead_paragraph: The public knows him best as “Red Boy,” Francisco de Goya’s portrait of the beguiling 5-year-old Manuel Osorio Manrique de Zuñiga, dressed in red from head to toe, with his pet magpie. The painting, which has been in the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s collection since 1949, is one of its most popular images. But few visitors are aware that the child is the son of the Count Altamira, governor of what was the Banco de San Carlos (now the Banco de España) and that between 1786 and 1788 the count commissioned Goya to paint that portrait, along with three others.

headline: Eternal Life, Thanks to Angels and Abs
abstract: A visit to the set of “Supernatural” reveals the secrets that have kept the CW show, now in its ninth season, alive.
lead_paragraph: SURREY, British Columbia — The first episode of the scary-monster show “Supernatural,” in which a college student came home and found his girlfriend on the ceiling, roasting like a blond marshmallow, was shown by the WB network on Sept. 13, 2005.

lead_paragraph: Ratking

headline: At Bolshoi, the Battle for Ballet Still Rages
abstract: A preview of five performances in Moscow ahead of appearances in Washington and in New York points to a company teetering in several different directions.
lead_paragraph: The Bolshoi Ballet of Moscow is emerging from the worst ballet scandal in recent history. Its artistic director, Sergei Filin, is still undergoing operations to restore his eyesight after the severe injuries he suffered in a shocking acid attack in January 2013. Since he became director in 2011, the list of Bolshoi dancers has changed considerably: New stars have been imported, while existing ones have left in a wide range of circumstances — some for other companies (claiming the Bolshoi repertory held them back) and others as part of the fallout from the scandal.

headline: Around the Unisphere at the World’s Fair, Lives Changed
abstract: Fifty years ago, the first fairgoers arrived to see the future. Little did they know, then, how one trip to the fair — or dozens — would affect their own lives.
lead_paragraph: All paths once led to the Unisphere, a magnet for the masses.

The festival runs from May 2 to 25 at all three of La Mama’s theaters – the Ellen Stewart Theater (66 East Fourth Street), the Club and the First Floor Theater (74A East Fourth Street).

lead_paragraph: The Nets sat all five starters in their final game of the regular season, content to drop to the sixth seed in the Eastern Conference playoffs to rest their aging roster. They will need all the energy they can muster against the young, feisty Toronto Raptors.

headline: Goldman, Citi, UBS ... and a Guy in an Office
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Paul J. Taubman has single-handedly accounted for $175 billion in deals over the last year, which has had Wall Street bankers buzzing with a mix of admiration and envy.
lead_paragraph: Anyone looking at the mergers and acquisitions “league tables” — the Wall Street equivalent of Major League Baseball’s standings — during this hot year for merger activity would find the usual suspects: Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs vying for the top spot, with other big brand-name firms jockeying to fill the coveted top 10.

headline: Stirring the Automotive Melting Pot
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'North American International Auto Show', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: With the opening of the New York International Auto Show at the Javits center, it’s hard not to notice that automakers are increasingly thinking in global terms.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Italy’s role in any American auto show was clearly understood: to weaken the knees of enthusiasts with largely unattainable Ferraris, Lamborghinis and Maseratis. But new and unexpected forms of Italian exotica took starring roles this year at press previews of the New York International Auto Show.

headline: Tribeca First-Timers: Lou Howe
abstract: Lou Howe, the writer and director of “Gabriel,” discusses his film premiering at the Tribeca Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: This is one in a series of posts on debuts at the Tribeca Film Festival.For his first feature film, the writer and director Lou Howe charged into dark and complex emotional waters. He paints a portrait of mental illness from an intimate perspective in “Gabriel,” which stars Rory Culkin in the title role of a young man returning home to his family after spending time in a mental health facility. Battling personal demons, he is also in search of a lost love.

lead_paragraph: How about a real “Streetscapes” — not about buildings, but the streets themselves? The roadways of New York have long been the subject of turf battles among cars, horses, bikes and pedestrians. But the history of what they’re fighting over is multilayered — literally.

headline: The Pretend Complexity of the Nevada Cattle-Grazing Dispute
abstract: This is a pretty straightforward situation—unless you’re an anti-government libertarian, or an anti-government libertarian who aspires to one day run the government.
lead_paragraph: The Nevada rancher Cliven Bundy owes the government over $1 million in unpaid fines, incurred for grazing his cattle on protected public land. When the Bureau of Land Management tried to confiscate his cattle in early April, he resisted, attracting armed supporters clearly itching for a violent confrontation. “We were actually strategizing to put all the women up front,” said one of his backers, the Tea Party leader Richard Mack. “If they were going to start shooting, it’s going to be women that are going to be televised all across the world getting shot.” Not nearly as histrionic or rash as Mr. Bundy and Mr. Mack, the B.L.M. backed down and said it would “work to resolve the matter administratively and judicially.”

headline: Sheraton Expands Its Club Level Service
abstract: Sheraton Hotels and Resorts is planning to appoint more than 300 managers to assist guests in its club level lounges.
lead_paragraph: Sheraton Hotels and Resorts is planning to appoint more than 350 V.I.P. club managers to its club level lounges over the next few months.

headline: Applause for Avocados
abstract: This is the best time of the year for picking up some Hass avocados, the most common type in grocery stores, and putting together these innovative avocado-based dishes.
lead_paragraph: Lately I’ve been reveling in Hass avocados, and now I understand why, having just discovered an article that David Karp, fruit expert extraordinaire, wrote in The Los Angeles Times a few years ago about the optimal time for ripeness in avocados. The California Avocado Commission sets Nov. 28 as the start of the Hass avocado harvest, meaning that the oil content in the fruit is high enough for picking.

headline: In Uruguay, Team and Country Are Unified Behind Coach
abstract: Under Óscar Tabárez, the national soccer team for Uruguay has undergone a slow revolution, finishing third at the 2010 World Cup and winning the 2011 Copa América.
lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay — It was a telling gesture when Greg Dyke, the chairman of the English Football Association, slid his forefinger slowly across his throat moments after England was drawn in Group D of the World Cup.

abstract: As insurers embrace big data, your premiums may go up or down based not only on your driving record, but also your voting record and credit score.
lead_paragraph: IT’S no surprise that car accidents, speeding tickets and where you live all affect how much you pay for automobile insurance. But consumer groups say that other, apparently unrelated, factors are unfairly being used to set rates.

lead_paragraph: Erich Segal, a Yale classics professor who moonlighted as a screenwriter, had written a screenplay about two star-crossed lovers. His literary agent, Lois Wallace, thought it could also work as a novel and suggested that he turn it into one before the movie was made.
