headline: Chinese Official Urges Russia and Central Asian Allies to Control Internet
abstract: Guo Shengkun, China’s minister of public security, said that Russia and Central Asian countries must prevent “external forces” from trying to overthrow governments and provoke revolutions.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Guo Shengkun, China’s minister of public security, said at a six-nation security conference in Tajikistan that Russia and Central Asian countries must strictly control the Internet and prevent “external forces” from trying to overthrow governments and “provoke a new wave of color revolutions,” according to news agency reports on Friday.

headline: Spilling Blood as if They Were Kids
abstract: The thriller “Blue Ruin,” written and directed by Jeremy Saulnier and starring Macon Blair, is the pair’s latest collaboration; they’ve done films together since childhood.
lead_paragraph: For decades, sociologists have struggled to pinpoint the exact impact of childhood exposure to violent movies, but one fact is clear. In extreme cases, the cycle of violence repeats itself. Sometimes, kids steeped in extreme cinematic mayhem grow up to become hyperviolent filmmakers themselves.

headline: Biking Hercules’ Way in France
abstract: The historian Graham Robb contends that the ancient route follows the course of the sun at the solstices. Regardless of his theory, the rugged path is a perfect for cycling.
lead_paragraph: The Gauls, a Celtic tribe that inhabited what is now France, were a boorish bunch before Julius Caesar arrived in 58 B.C. and ushered in civilization. At least, that is the historical explanation Graham Robb, a literary historian best known for the books “The Discovery of France” and “Parisians,” had accepted along with most French people.

headline: Stone Lifting as Sport in the Basque Country
abstract: Rural sports like wood chopping, hay bale tossing and stone lifting are part of a cultural fabric that’s still visible today.
lead_paragraph: It was 10 o’clock on a bright Thursday morning when I washed up in a cafe in Leitza, a Basque village in a rugged, green valley south of San Sebastián, in search of directions. The barista and both of her customers, two elderly men wearing traditional Basque berets, knew whom I was looking for before I asked. Iñaki Perurena is the Michael Jordan of harrijasotzaile, or stone lifting, considered a herri kirolak, or rural Basque sport that has been an integral part of the Basque culture for 100 years, and I had come to Leitza in search of his hilltop museum and sculpture garden dedicated to this unusual athletic pursuit.

headline: Selected Documents Released From the Clinton Archives
abstract: The National Archives made public on Friday afternoon another trove of secret documents detailing the inner workings of Bill Clinton’s White House.
lead_paragraph: The National Archives made public on Friday afternoon another trove of secret documents detailing the inner workings of Bill Clinton’s White House.

headline: Left With the Crumbs? Lucky You
abstract: Homemade bread crumbs put the sawdust in the can to shame. It’s far better to make your own — and then turn them into a garlicky, savory pasta dish.
lead_paragraph: Bread crumbs are easy to take for granted. In most recipes, they barely register. They’re a crunch-intensifier or a garlic-and-cheese holder (ah, stuffed mushrooms), but never the main ingredient. They may not seem like something that demands to be homemade.

headline: Poison Pill’s Relevance in the Age of Shareholder Activism
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Hedge Funds', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: The lawsuit by Daniel S. Loeb against Sotheby’s may well be the tipping point in how far companies can go to defend themselves against shareholder activists, writes Steven M. Davidoff.
lead_paragraph: When we look back 20 years from now, the lawsuit by Daniel S. Loeb and his Third Point hedge fund against Sotheby’s may well be the tipping point in how far companies can go to defend themselves against shareholder activists.

headline: Can We Get a ‘No Standing’ Sign?
abstract: Subjects include: A wish for open curb space in front of a co-op; problems with a neighbor’s aggressive dog; and concern over a rental’s dirty windows.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 55
abstract: The United States men’s national team will set up training camp for the World Cup at Stanford University.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: A Trove of Old Film Footage, Now Online
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: British Pathé has posted on YouTube about 85,000 film clips, including newsreels and little-seen footage from all over the world.
lead_paragraph: In days of yore – or at any rate, from the dawn of cinema into the 1960s or so – going to the movies was more than just settling into a plush seat with nearly a gallon of soda and a truckload of popcorn, and then getting blasted against the wall with insanely overamplified sound. You’d get a cartoon or a short feature, and a few decades back you’d also get a newsreel. Sometimes it was actual news, although the growth of television rendered such films beside the point. Often it was a soft feature – footage of a celebrity wedding, a daredevil stunt, an exotic sports event or perhaps an interview with a music or film star.

headline: Faces of Ukraine, on the Eve of Tumult
abstract: The coming Hot Docs festival in Toronto offers a number of new documentaries shot in Ukraine before Russia’s annexation of Crimea.
lead_paragraph: In July 2010, young, lighthearted Ukrainians packed Kiev’s Independence Square for a concert by a drag queen singing frothy pop songs over techno beats.

headline: Yet Another Pretty Face
abstract: Supermodels have long been cast in movies, but not all of them make a second career of it.
lead_paragraph: By what metric are we to determine whether a model is “super”? If it is name recognition, Forbes list position, magazines covered, campaigns fronted or some algorithm of them all, Kate Upton probably qualifies. In 2013 Ms. Upton, a 21-year-old from Melbourne, Fla., was named model of the year and appeared on the cover of the Sports Illustrated swimsuit issue for the second straight year. This year she was demoted to the inside cover, pictured wearing a bikini in zero gravity.

headline: Horseless, Not to Mention Senseless
abstract: NYClass wants to replace horse-drawn carriages with electric cars. Bad idea.
lead_paragraph: Give the folks at NYClass, the advocacy group that wants to eliminate horse carriages from New York City, credit for recognizing the consequences of their campaign, and for having a plan.

headline: How Do You Say “Nobody Could Have Predicted” In Swedish?
abstract: Gratuitous deflation.
lead_paragraph: A correspondent points me to the news from Sweden, which has stopped flirting with deflation and moved right in. Here’s inflation excluding food, energy, tobacco, and alcohol:

headline: 40th Anniversary Special for ‘Saturday Night Live’
abstract: NBC said it would salute the enduring late-night show with a three-hour special in February.
lead_paragraph: “Saturday Night Live,” among the most influential of television shows, will get a full dose of NBC’s gratitude next February, when the network celebrates the show’s 40th anniversary with a three-hour special — live from New York, of course.

headline: 30 Seconds With Mike Fratello
abstract: The TV analyst and former N.B.A. coach sizes up the playoffs and talks about coaching Ukraine’s national basketball team.
lead_paragraph: Mike Fratello coached the Atlanta Hawks, the Cleveland Cavaliers and the Memphis Grizzlies in the N.B.A. With a 667-548 record, he is 18th on the N.B.A. career wins list and 19th in games coached. His teams qualified for the playoffs in 11 of his 15 seasons.

headline: Love and the Stick-On Nipple
abstract: There is a lot you can do with artificial nipples after breast reconstruction. And a lot you can’t.
lead_paragraph: I am not big on accessories: I wear the same ring, watch, bracelet and earrings day after day. Still, there is one special item I was thrilled to find and really thought I would wear daily: my fabulous, lifelike, press-on nipples. They were not something I had ever planned on needing, but then I never planned on having breast cancer and a double reconstruction, or as it is known these days, the Angelina Jolie surgery.

headline: Together With Songs in Their Hearts
abstract: Two theater producers married in a colorful ceremony that incorporated Hindu and Christian traditions.
lead_paragraph: When Shanta Thake, now the director of Joe’s Pub at the Public Theater in NoHo, was in her 20s, her work in the performing arts scene in the city left her constantly entertained during the day and frequently alone at night.

headline: Sherpa’s Family on Avalanche
abstract: Even as rescue teams attempted to reach victims of the Mount Everest avalanche, Dawa Yanju, the sister-in-law of a survivor, Dawa Tashi, described what happened.
lead_paragraph: Even as rescue teams attempted to reach victims of the Mount Everest avalanche, Dawa Yanju, the sister-in-law of a survivor, Dawa Tashi, described what happened.

headline: For Stone Phillips, a Focus on the Home Front
abstract: A broadcaster turns the camera on his parents.
lead_paragraph: Originally, Stone Phillips told me, he intended to shoot a kind of home movie.

headline: Prisoner Whose 1988 Conviction Is Under Review Is Granted Parole
keywords: ['Probation and Parole', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Robert Hill, whose murder conviction is being reviewed because of questions about the lead detective in the case, will be released next month after 26 years in state prison.
lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn man whose 1988 murder conviction is under review because of questions about the lead detective in the case will be released on parole next month, his lawyer said.

headline: Learning to Set a Goal for the Long Run
abstract: In a conversation they have had countless times since his reading disability was diagnosed in elementary school, a mother and her teenage son search for ways to set goals and “do something that really distinguishes me.”
lead_paragraph: It was early winter and my son and I were taking the dogs on their nightly stroll. Something was clearly on his mind. “Anything you want to talk about?” I asked.

headline: Wheelies: The Welcome Back Maybach Edition
keywords: ['Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Daimler has plans to bring back the Maybach brand; AT&T strikes a connected-car deal with a global automaker.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: In NoHo: Squeezing In, With Some Creativity
abstract: Developers of a new boutique co-op in NoHo contend with an odd-shaped lot and a land lease, among other obstacles.
lead_paragraph: The housing market in New York seems to bring out the fearlessness in some developers.

headline: An Obituary or an Appraisal? Thursday Night’s Debate.
abstract: Dean Baquet, the managing editor of The Times, talks about the debate in the newsroom Thursday night over how to treat the death of Gabriel García Márquez, the Colombian novelist.
lead_paragraph: Dean Baquet, the managing editor of The Times, talks about the debate in the newsroom Thursday night over how to treat the death of Gabriel García Márquez, the Colombian novelist.

headline: In the Works of García Márquez, Finding a Link to Home
abstract: The death of Gabriel García Márquez set off a flurry of obituaries and appraisals, as well as appreciations from Latin American readers in New York who grew up in the world Mr. García Márquez described.
lead_paragraph: Under the fluorescent lights of a check-cashing store in Jackson Heights, Queens, a man recited the opening lines of “One Hundred Years of Solitude,” in Spanish, on Thursday night.

headline: Robin Leach Rolls on in Las Vegas
abstract: ‘A lot of people only see the garish glitz and the ghastly glamour, all the cliché hackneyed things,’ says Mr. Leach. ‘I see the biggest entertainment, dining and travel stories of our time.’
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Robin Leach, 72, wobbled up to Citizens Kitchen and Bar here looking neither rich nor famous.

headline: U.S. Delays Final Call on Keystone XL Pipeline
keywords: ['Keystone Pipeline System', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: The State Department will wait to decide whether to allow construction of the pipeline until it has a clearer idea how legal challenges to the route through Nebraska will be settled, sources said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department will delay its decision on construction of the Keystone XL pipeline until it has a clearer idea of how legal challenges to the pipeline’s route through Nebraska will be settled, State Department officials said Friday.

headline: Thunder’s Lofty Hopes Rest on a Fragile Hinge
abstract: Title hopes in Oklahoma City depend on Kevin Durant and the health of Russell Westbrook’s right knee, which was injured in a strange play a year ago and required three operations.
lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — It was nearly 12 months and 3 surgeries ago that guard Russell Westbrook hurt his right knee in the N.B.A. playoffs, ending the championship expectations of the top-seeded Oklahoma City Thunder. It was a fluky play, a sideswiping collision after a timeout, hardly anything that looked serious.

headline: Female in Gaza
abstract: Growing up in Gaza isn’t easy. Surveillance defines your existence.
lead_paragraph: I have been photographing in Gaza for several years, initially to cover the conflict with Israel, but over time returning because I am mesmerized by the women, and their strength.

headline: Years After a Bitter Fight, Prince and Warner Bros. Make a New Deal
abstract: More than 20 years after changing his name in a battle with his label, a new deal gives Prince ownership of old recordings and will include reissues of old albums.
lead_paragraph: More than 20 years after Prince protested against Warner Bros. Records by writing “slave” on his face and changing his name to an unpronounceable glyph, he has reconciled with that label through a new deal that gives him ownership of his old recordings and will include a major reissue campaign.

headline: How to Run on Health Reform
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Editorials']
abstract: Now that the Affordable Care Act is proving to be even more successful than expected, it’s time for Democrats to stand up for it.
lead_paragraph: The Republican attack machine, fueled by millions of dollars from the Koch brothers, has Democrats so rattled about the health reform law that many don’t want to talk about it. They’re happy to run on equal pay for women, or a higher minimum wage, or immigration reform — all of which provide important contrasts with a do-nothing Republican Party — but they haven’t said much about the biggest social accomplishment of the Obama administration.

headline: Will and Kate (and Uncle Sam) Studied Here
abstract: The University of St. Andrews in Scotland has seen a rise in visibility in the United States, thanks in part to two high-profile alumni, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge.
lead_paragraph: ST. ANDREWS, SCOTLAND — It was hardly your typical college party. Set under a heated white tent the size of a football field (tables covered in chilled bottles of Nicolas Feuillatte Champagne and goody bags stuffed with vouchers from Hackett and Jack Wills), it seemed more like a New York gala than a student event in a college town on the North Sea. But when the University of St. Andrews 2014 charity fashion show began, so did the party.

headline: Protests Continue Against Dropbox After Appointment of Condoleezza Rice to Board
abstract: After Dropbox appointed Condoleezza Rice, the former secretary of state, to its board of directors, some users have complained about her views on Internet surveillance.
lead_paragraph: The decision by Dropbox this month to appoint Condoleezza Rice, the former secretary of state, to the company’s board of directors sparked a heated online debate about her views on Internet surveillance and the role of the National Security Agency.

headline: The Gun Report: April 18, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, a legislator in Iowa floated a bill to lower the age at which children can legally shoot handguns. While anyone 20 or younger must be under the direct supervision of a parent or instructor to practice with a pistol or revolver, current state law prohibits children younger than 14 from handgun use, even with a parent around. Rep. Joe Riding, a Democrat from Altoona, wanted to lower that to 12.

headline: Program to Destroy Syria’s Chemical Weapons Is 75% Complete, Group Says
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: An official from the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons said Syria might not finish the job by a revised deadline of April 27, but might do so soon after.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — As the deadline looms for the destruction of Syria’s chemical weapons, the international organization overseeing the process reported Friday that the country had delivered another shipment of toxic agents for destruction abroad, bringing the program three-quarters of the way to completion.

headline: When Bravo Came to Charleston
abstract: Bravo’s reality show “Southern Charm,” set in Charleston, has led some of its residents to question why the cast is doing what they do on national television in their beloved city.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — For the last few years Charleston has been getting the sort of high praise it has not seen since before Reconstruction.

headline: In the Battle for Best Smartphone, Apple Still Beats Samsung
abstract: Samsung’s newest phone, the Galaxy S5, is a very nice device. But it falls far short of Apple’s iPhone.
lead_paragraph: Over the last couple weeks, many of my colleagues in the tech press have published reviews of the Galaxy S5, Samsung’s newest top-of-the-line smartphone. They all arrived at more or less the same conclusion: The S5 is a very nice device.

headline: What to Expect When a Clinton Is Expecting
abstract: Most pregnant women make a birth plan, but Chelsea Clinton’s might involve disguises, security consultants and public relations strategy.
lead_paragraph: In some alternate universe, a distant political galaxy unlike our own, Chelsea Clinton might be able to have her first child quietly. No one would care about the size of her baby bump. If and when Hillary Rodham Clinton announces a presidential run, her status as a grandparent would receive exactly the same scrutiny as her male predecessors who were grandfathers.

headline: 13 Quit Board of San Diego Opera
abstract: Karen Cohn, the president of the board, led a contingent of 13 board members in resigning.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – Less than a week after the board of the San Diego Opera reaffirmed its decision to shut it down, the embattled company was hit with a new wave of turmoil on Thursday as Karen Cohn, the president of the board, led a contingent of 13 board members in resigning.

headline: A Mustang Option: Matching Nail Polish
abstract: Ford is using nail polish colors inspired by the Mustang to market the pony car to women.
lead_paragraph: The Ford Motor Company is using a distinct new palette to market the Mustang to women at the New York International Auto Show: a line of nail polish colors. The Ford Mustang by OPI Collection features six colors inspired by the 50th anniversary of the car.

headline: What $5 Can Get at a Film Festival
abstract: Clara Mamet, the 19-year-old daughter of the playwright David Mamet, was in New York Wednesday for the Tribeca Film Festival, where her debut film, “Two-Bit Waltz,” is showing.
lead_paragraph: Clara Mamet’s table at Barbuto wasn’t ready. It was 8 p.m. Wednesday, and Ms. Mamet, the 19-year-old daughter of the playwright David Mamet and the half-sister of the actress Zosia Mamet, was in New York for the Tribeca Film Festival, where her debut film, “Two-Bit Waltz,” would be shown later in the week.

headline: First You Spend, Then You Save
abstract: The BMW 535d is indeed a fuel miser, but even a staunch proponent of diesel engines may notice the financial commitment required to buy the car.
lead_paragraph: The psychology of saving fuel can get complicated, especially when it involves splurging to go from Point A to Point B.

headline: Premium Fuel Efficiency, and a Price to Match
abstract: The BMW 535d can exceed 40 miles per gallon on the highway, and the performance is impressive for a diesel. But do the fuel savings make up for the higher sticker price?
lead_paragraph: The BMW 535d can exceed 40 miles per gallon on the highway, and the performance is impressive for a diesel. But do the fuel savings make up for the higher sticker price?

headline: Rules of Style | Sleigh Bells’ Alexis Krauss on Dressing for Coachella, Melt-Proof Makeup and the Virtues of Normcore
abstract: The noise-pop frontwoman discusses what she packed for the festival, her beauty arsenal and the importance of covering one’s rear.
lead_paragraph: In 90-degree heat among a crowd of 90,000, it’s tough for anyone — even a bona fide rock star — to keep their look together. But Alexis Krauss, the inky-tressed frontwoman of the Brooklyn indie noise-pop band Sleigh Bells, has a way of always staying cool, even during her frenetic stage shows. Here, the singer — who plays Coachella this weekend and will be touring the U.S. and Europe all summer long — shares her secrets to braving warm-weather festivals in style.

headline: Amorality à Deux, Circa 1932
abstract: “Trouble in Paradise,” at IFC Center Sunday, offers the sparkling innuendo and Continental sophistication that define “the Lubitsch touch.”
lead_paragraph: “Steal, swindle, rob, O.K.” pleads the pickpocket Lily (Miriam Hopkins) to her paramour, the thief Gaston (Herbert Marshall), in Ernst Lubitsch’s “Trouble in Paradise,” “but don’t become one of those useless, good-for-nothing gigolos!” Lily has reason to fear: the debonair Gaston has insinuated himself into a job with a perfume heiress (Kay Francis), and though he and Lily have designs on her riches, Gaston may be falling for his boss.

headline: From Rags to Riches to Rags
abstract: Many Americans are likely to be exposed to both prosperity and poverty during their lives.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — BY now most of us know the basic facts of America’s rising income inequality: Since the early 1970s, the gap between the top and bottom of the income distribution has expanded significantly; what’s more, the only group to have experienced real economic gains during this period has been those in the top 20 percent, with gains heavily concentrated in the top 10, 5 and — most famously — 1 percent.

headline: The Trouble With Rice
abstract: The rice plant is one of nature’s great metal scavengers, with potential health consequences for consumers.
lead_paragraph: For the past few years, Mary Lou Guerinot has been keeping watch over experimental fields in southeast Texas, monitoring rice plants as they suck metals and other troublesome elements from the soil.

headline: Snowden Defends His Part in Putin Forum
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: One day after he took part in a stage-managed forum with President Vladimir Putin on Russian state television, the former National Security Agency contractor Edward Snowden defended his participation.
lead_paragraph: One day after he took part in a stage-managed forum with President Vladimir V. Putin on Russian state television, the former National Security Agency contractor Edward Snowden defended his participation, in an essay published by The Guardian.

headline: Giving Snapshots the Gonzo Treatment
abstract: Ralph Steadman’s art stars in the documentary “For No Good Reason” and at the Red Bull Studio New York in Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: “I really thought what I would do, if I ever learned to draw properly, was I would try to change the world,” the British artist Ralph Steadman explains in “For No Good Reason,” Charlie Paul’s documentary about him, opening Friday.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about today’s biggest stories.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Bar and Bathroom Lines, Molto Adagio
abstract: Concert-hall intermissions were not always what they are today, and some people would like to see them reconsidered.
lead_paragraph: When the curtain went down on Act II of Puccini’s “La Bohème” at the Metropolitan Opera on a recent evening, close to 100 stagehands sprang into action. To the sound of beeping machinery, hammer strokes and intermittent warning shouts, they carried props, bundled drops, unfurled scrims, navigated the enormous wagon rolling the next set into place and secured escape stairs to the floor in what looked like brisk, efficient choreography.

headline: A Beer Vacation Is On Tap in Chicago
abstract: Lagunitas Brewing Company, which will open a facility in Chicago in May, is partnering with the JW Marriott in the city for a “Beercation” travel package.
lead_paragraph: Lagunitas Brewing Company, the Northern California beer maker with a penchant for live music, has expanded its operations to Chicago, where it will open a  300,000-square-foot facility early next month.

headline: Week in Pictures for April 18
abstract: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes a spring scene at Brooklyn Botanic Garden, a meat market in the East Village and the funeral for a New York police officer.
lead_paragraph: .media.slideshow.in-page-player .headline { display: none; }

headline: New York Bridal Fashion Week | Spring 2015
abstract: Wedding dress designers debuted their spring 2015 collections last weekend. Here, a selection of photos.
lead_paragraph: Wedding dress designers debuted their spring 2015 collections last weekend. Here, a selection of photos.

headline: Delayed Viewing Plumps Up ‘Mad Men’ Audience
abstract: Three days of recorded viewing indicated that the show added close to 75 percent more viewers in some categories.
lead_paragraph: Fans of “Mad Men” alarmed by the surprising ratings falloff for this season’s premiere may take some comfort in the first results of delayed viewing for the episode.

headline: The Re-education of a Brash Young Stock Picker
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Personal Finances', 'Mutual Funds']
abstract: Despite all his success picking stocks, Randy Kurtz now mostly buys index and exchange-traded funds for his clients.
lead_paragraph: Nine years ago, Randy Kurtz made an extraordinary bet on himself, the stock market and his ability to pick a few winners.

headline: Lace Shows Its Strength
abstract: The more bridal dresses change, the more they don’t. The latest collections showed few new wrinkles.
lead_paragraph: “It’s very important to me that these not be viewed just as wedding gowns,” said Vera Wang, the pre-eminent wedding-gown designer for a generation. She was on the phone discussing her decision not to hold a live show during the recent presentations of bridal collections in New York, a kinder, gentler and briefer version of Fashion Week, with profusions of curling-ironed hair, platform pumps and champagne flutes twinkling in broad daylight.

headline: An Indian From India Photographs Both
abstract: After encountering confusion over her roots, an Indian photographer created a set of diptychs in which she recreated classic poses of Native Americans.
lead_paragraph: After encountering confusion over her roots, an Indian photographer created a set of diptychs in which she recreated classic poses of Native Americans.

headline: How to Make a Perfect Piece of Toast
abstract: To end up with a good piece of toast, aim for the perfect color (golden), the perfect texture (it should have a little “give” in the center) and the perfect temperature (hot).
lead_paragraph: There may be more pressing issues in the food world, or more ambitious projects to tackle, but I am here to talk about perfecting the simplest of kitchen basics.

headline: What Is Putin’s ‘New Russia’?
abstract: In a Q. and A. session, President Vladimir V. Putin referred repeatedly to southeastern Ukraine as “Novorossiya,” a historical term meaning “New Russia.”
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, appearing cool and confident on national television during a four-hour question-and-answer show on Thursday, referred repeatedly to southeastern Ukraine as “New Russia,” a historical term for the area north of the Black Sea that the Russian empire conquered in the 1700s. “God knows” why the region became part of Ukraine in the 1920s, he said in response to a questioner, a strong signal that he would gladly correct that error.

headline: Eric Korsh to Run the Kitchen at North End Grill
abstract: Mr. Korsh, who was the chef and a partner at Calliope in Manhattan, will replace Floyd Cardoz, who is leaving on April 30.
lead_paragraph: Eric Korsh left Calliope, the French bistro in the East Village, where he was the chef and a partner, in late January, but he did not spend a great deal of time in the wilderness. He will be the new executive chef at North End Grill in Battery Park City, replacing Floyd Cardoz, who is departing on April 30.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from South Korea, Central Africa Republic, India and Germany.
lead_paragraph: Photos from South Korea, Central Africa Republic, India and Germany.

headline: Allowing a Puritan to Marry for Love
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera’s revival of Bellini’s “I Puritani” includes the Met debut of the Russian soprano Olga Peretyatko.
lead_paragraph: If you are going to savor the Metropolitan Opera’s welcome revival of Bellini’s “I Puritani,” it is best to put out of mind that this 1976 production was mounted for Joan Sutherland, Luciano Pavarotti, Sherrill Milnes and James Morris. Such an astounding four-star cast is not likely to come along again anytime soon.

headline: Pharrell’s Next Collaboration, Karl Lagerfeld’s Destination Fashion Show and Alexander Wang’s First Instagram
abstract: Plus, the latest in shopping technology, Tavi Gevinson’s upcoming TV appearance and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Economist Receives Rock Star Treatment
keywords: ['Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Books and Literature', 'Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: The reception for his “Capital in the 21st Century” has led the French economist Thomas Piketty to Washington’s halls of power and New York’s media outlets.
lead_paragraph: French economists who boldly question the dominance of capital over labor — and call for a progressive global tax on wealth — visit the American halls of power about as often as French rock stars headline Madison Square Garden.

headline: Music From ‘Madama Butterfly’
abstract: A clip from Act 1 of “Madama Butterfly” from the Metropolitan Opera. The clip features Kristine Opolais, the soloist, as the character of Cio-Cio-San. She is accompanied by members of the Metropolitan Opera Chorus, including Jean Braham.
lead_paragraph: A clip from Act 1 of “Madama Butterfly” from the Metropolitan Opera. The clip features Kristine Opolais, the soloist, as the character of Cio-Cio-San. She is accompanied by members of the Metropolitan Opera Chorus, including Jean Braham.

headline: When Gabriel García Márquez Went Back to Aracataca
abstract: The writer thought he would die young and “in the street.”
lead_paragraph: The novelist and maestro Gabriel García Márquez died Thursday , mourned by the world at the ample enough age of 87. But for a time during his youth in Colombia — when he was inhaling three packs a day — he was sure that he would die young, dissolute “and in the street,” as he put it in his 2003 memoir “Living to Tell The Tale.” At that point, his mother, Luisa Santiaga Márquez, appeared unexpectedly in the city of Barranquilla, determined to rescue her law-school dropout son from a wasteful life as a mere writer. She convinced him to travel with her to the desolate, hellishly hot Caribbean town of Aracataca, where he was born in 1927.

headline: Lost in Literary History: A Tale of Courage in the South
abstract: “All God’s Dangers,” a sharecropper’s story that won a National Book Award in 1975, still rings true 40 years later.
lead_paragraph: Nineteen seventy-four was a good year for nonfiction writing in America. Robert A. Caro’s monumental biography of Robert Moses, “The Power Broker,” came out. So did Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein’s “All the President’s Men.” So did “Working,” by Studs Terkel, and Robert M. Pirsig’s “Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance.”

headline: Including the Young and the Rich
keywords: ['Philanthropy', 'White House Building (Washington, DC)', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows', 'Youth']
abstract: The White House hosts “next generation” philanthropists about to step into billions.
lead_paragraph: On a crisp morning in late March, an elite group of 100 young philanthropists and heirs to billionaire family fortunes filed into a cozy auditorium at the White House.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Spring Frenzy
abstract: Runners wearing colorful tutus, a bulldog skating and a wall of forsythia in Central Park: New York comes to life with whimsical touches of color.
lead_paragraph: Runners wearing colorful tutus, a bulldog skating and a wall of forsythia in Central Park: New York comes to life with whimsical touches of color.

headline: On Its Return, Band Goes Right Back to the Basics
abstract: A reunited Loop makes its first United States tour since 1990.
lead_paragraph: Loop’s concert on Thursday night at Le Poisson Rouge started, of course, with a drone: a guitar note looped for continuous sustain, almost meditative. But not for long. Soon the clobbering began: The repeating two-chord riff of “Soundhead,” basic and primal, blasted in unison on guitar, bass and drums. “I hear that sound! I hear that sound!,” Robert Hampson sang.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Two-Tone Spring
abstract: The contrasts of spring in New York and Paris.
lead_paragraph: The contrasts of spring in New York and Paris: It looked like a basket of jelly beans at the women’s half-marathon in New York last Sunday, with many runners in tutus. Shop windows were filled with chicks, rabbits and decorated eggs. Big Bird sat on a bench near a wall of forsythia. Magnolias blossomed at the Frick, and a dog went skateboarding in a park. In Paris, where fashion still rules, black-and-white made a big sophisticated statement.

headline: Love Those Royal Family Photos? It All Started With Victoria.
abstract: “A Royal Passion: Queen Victoria and Photography,” at the Getty Museum in Los Angeles, reveals a monarch who quickly adopted a new art form and used it for her own purposes.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Today, as the formal boundaries between the British royal family and the public narrow, pictures of 9-month-old Prince George are posted daily on the Facebook pages of Prince William and the Duchess of Cambridge, the former Kate Middleton. But, in fact, photography has been promoting the royal brand since its inception in the 19th century, as an exhibition on view at the Getty Center here shows. Fame may seem a 20th-century phenomenon, but Queen Victoria was the first public figure to exploit its promotional potential and the earliest — and least likely — international celebrity of the photographed world.

headline: A TV Opera, Live. Olé!
abstract: Two parts of Robert Ashley’s “Perfect Lives,” in a Spanish incarnation translated by Javier Sainz de Robles, were shown at the Whitney Museum on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The relationship of language to music, and plot to text, is an intriguing element of Robert Ashley’s “Perfect Lives,” a complex and meditative sequence featuring a hypnotic, sung-spoken narrative that unfolds with myriad cadences.

headline: Evening Hours | April, Come What May
abstract: From opera and ballet to children and birds.
lead_paragraph: From opera and ballet to children and birds.

headline: Auto Show in the Round
abstract: A 360-degree look at some of the auto show’s new models.
lead_paragraph: The Automobiles team, working with the photographer Benjamin Norman, selected some of the new models at the New York International Auto Show for 360-degree interactive views.

headline: Versatility Is a Virtue in Fantasy of Identity
abstract: When one of the clones gets a leading role in a play, yet another identity is born for Tatiana Maslany, the star of “Orphan Black.”
lead_paragraph: If you pay more attention than you should to television critics or the pop-culture gossip mills, you may have heard that you should be watching “Orphan Black” on BBC America, which returns for a second season on Saturday night.

headline: A Silver Anniversary for Mazda’s Blue-Ribbon Sports Car
abstract: The Mazda Miata appeared 25 years ago, favoring a poised chassis over sheer speed. The car established a man-machine connection few automobiles can match.
lead_paragraph: British automakers like Austin-Healey, Lotus and MG may have originated the tidy, nimble roadster, but it was Mazda, a Japanese company, that mastered the formula decades later.

headline: Honing the Hybrids and Diesels
abstract: BMW, long a proponent of diesel engines, has come to see the plug-in hybrid as a smart solution to meeting fuel-economy mandates. Coming soon is the X5 eDrive.
lead_paragraph: BMW has long promoted diesel engines as an important element of its plan to reduce carbon dioxide output. The automaker is still a champion of diesel power, but now it is embracing electric drive, too.

headline: Turkish Women Use Twitter to Fight Sexual Harassment
abstract: Thousands of Turkish women have taken part in a Twitter campaign to voice outrage at men who invade their space by spreading their legs while sitting next to them on buses and trains.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Saturday, 1:52 p.m. | Thousands of Turkish women have taken part in a Twitter campaign to voice outrage at men who invade their space by spreading their legs while sitting next to them on buses and trains.

headline: Moving In? Beware the Other Residents
abstract: Marlon Wayans stars in “A Haunted House 2,” his second stop in this horror-spoof franchise.
lead_paragraph: Run in fright. Marlon Wayans’s comedy “A Haunted House” unaccountably made $40 million at the domestic box office, so we have “A Haunted House 2,” which, like its predecessor, pays parodic tribute to horror films including “Dark Skies” and the “Last Exorcism” movies, among countless others. Already the franchise displays a sputtering exhaustion.

headline: The Secrets and the Magic Are in the Details
abstract: Vicky Shick’s “Pathétique/Miniatures in Detail” is playing at the West End Theater as part of the Soaking Wet series.
lead_paragraph: In the program note for the current installment of Soaking Wet, the dance series that David Parker directs at the West End Theater on the Upper West Side, he speaks of presenting the work of Vicky Shick as a longtime dream come true. It seemed to him that her “exacting, poetic work” would be a perfect match for the “funky, mysterious space” on the second floor of a church. The debut on Thursday of Ms. Shick’s “Pathétique/Miniatures in Detail” proved him right.

headline: Added Attractions Through the Years
abstract: Special editions of the Mazda Miata are nothing more than color and trim packages, but their low production numbers can make them more attractive to collectors.
lead_paragraph: Special editions of the Mazda Miata that are nothing more than color and trim packages may not improve the driving experience, but their low production numbers can make them more attractive to collectors.

headline: Watch Out, iTunes. Vinyl Still Lives.
abstract: Record Store Day, now in its seventh year, highlights the perseverance of independent stores around the country.
lead_paragraph: The story usually told about record stores is a sad one that just keeps getting sadder.

headline: Jordan Chodorow and Karen Allison Play at Bridge Base Online
abstract: The diagramed deal was played during a pair game at Bridge Base Online.
lead_paragraph: Online bridge has certainly made it easier and cheaper for everyone to play. The diagramed deal was played during a pair game at Bridge Base Online (bridgebase.com). North was Jordan Chodorow of Los Angeles and South was Karen Allison of Las Vegas, who has won five national championships.

headline: Woman Is Sought After Attempt to Kidnap an 8-Month-Old
abstract: Authorities say a woman with a history of trying to abduct children targeted an 8-month-old boy on a Manhattan street but was thwarted when a delivery driver intervened.
lead_paragraph: The authorities were searching on Friday for a woman with a history of trying to abduct young children, saying she had tried to kidnap an 8-month-old boy in the Chelsea section of Manhattan.

headline: A Polish Painter Reconsiders His Calling
abstract: “Our God’s Brother,” a 1949 play written by Karol Wojtyla, who became Pope John Paul II, is being revived at the Theater of the Church of Notre Dame.
lead_paragraph: On April 27, the Vatican will live-stream a ceremony elevating Karol Wojtyla, later known as Pope John Paul II, to sainthood. Storm Theater and Blackfriars Repertory Theater have devised an alternative way to celebrate the pope, reviving his 1949 play, “Our God’s Brother,” translated by Boleslaw Taborksi, at the Theater of the Church of Notre Dame.

headline: The Faces May Be Familiar, but the Sounds Are Original
abstract: The marimba featured prominently in a concert of new music, part of a series at the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: With its new-music series, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center offers its patrons a change of perspective. Held in the Kaplan Penthouse, with its floor-to-ceiling windows that afford sweeping views of the city against a darkening evening sky, the concerts present familiar artists from the society’s ranks engaging with new works by living composers — and, often, with instruments rarely seen in traditional chamber music settings.

headline: Two Schemers, Crossing All Kinds of Boundaries
abstract: “Ubu Sings Ubu” mixes a Google Translate version of the 1896 scatological satire “Ubu Roi” with songs by the experimental rock band Pere Ubu.
lead_paragraph: Fair warning: If feeling a stranger’s bare buttocks pressed into your upper back is more than you’re willing to risk for an evening of theater — if, perhaps, this is exactly the sort of personal-boundary crossing that creeps you out about immersive performance — then you may want to think carefully before deciding to see “Ubu Sings Ubu” at the Abrons Arts Center.

headline: Airbnb Said to Close Fund-Raising Deal With Group Led by TPG
abstract: Airbnb has closed a new round of financing from a group led by TPG Growth that values the home-sharing company at about $10 billion, people briefed on the matter said.
lead_paragraph: Airbnb has closed a new round of financing from a group led by TPG Growth that values the home-sharing company at about $10 billion, people briefed on the matter said on Friday.

headline: Don’t Know Much About History, Rand Paul Edition
abstract: Reaganite fantasies.
lead_paragraph: I can easily understand it when people don’t know the facts about economic statistics; you need a fair bit of background knowledge even to know how to look these things up. It’s more surprising when people don’t know what they don’t know — when they make confident assertions that can be proved false in a few seconds by anyone who does know these things.

I think what I love about it is the chemistry of the cast — they interact with each other so well it’s as if they’re all one person. Oh, wait …

headline: The World’s Fairgrounds, Then and Now
abstract: A few structures from the fair stand in good condition; others have have fallen into disrepair or have been reinvented.
lead_paragraph: What was once an ash heap in Corona, Queens, became the site of the 1939 World’s Fair. Its avenues, in turn, provided the layout for the 1964 World’s Fair. Despite Robert Moses’ intention of making Flushing Meadows-Corona Park a jewel of the city after the event, its evolution has been fitful. A few structures from the fair stand in good condition; others have fallen into disrepair; and still others have been reinvented.

headline: Scones, Finger Sandwiches and Tea
abstract: For enthusiasts, taking afternoon tea is an affirmation of food, drink and civility. A roundup of New Jersey tearooms suggests where to go for a proper spot.
lead_paragraph: Raising one’s pinkie finger may be a faux pas — “Nobody does that,” according to Susan Peterson, co-owner of Teaberry’s Tea Room in downtown Flemington.

headline: Twin Shocks Shake Foundation of German Power
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Revelations of American spying and the crisis in Ukraine have left Germany feeling that the established rules of the 21st century have been broken.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — If there are two qualities prized by modern Germans, they surely are Ruhe (peace and quiet) and Ordnung (order).

headline: Davis Is Traded to Pirates
abstract: The Mets traded first baseman Ike Davis to the Pittsburgh Pirates, jettisoning a homegrown prospect they once viewed as a potential cornerstone.
lead_paragraph: After months of speculation, the Mets traded first baseman Ike Davis to the Pittsburgh Pirates on Friday night, jettisoning a homegrown prospect they once viewed as a potential cornerstone of their lineup for years to come.

headline: ‘2 Milk Hollow’? That’s Code for Bunnies at Aigner Chocolates
abstract: At a family-run shop in Queens, the choices include old-fashioned cordials and a truffle laced with hazelnut and malted milk balls.
lead_paragraph: If Beatrix Potter ran a chocolate shop, it would look like Aigner Chocolates, a little confectioner on the corner of Metropolitan Avenue and 71st Road in the middle of Queens.

headline: For Pizza, 800 Degrees of Separation
abstract: Three pizza parlors in Connecticut set themselves apart by burning wood in their ovens and offering choices that go well beyond the norm.
lead_paragraph: If pizza is the ultimate comfort food, then Connecticut must be a very comfortable state. With pizzerias in virtually every town across the state, and many towns possessing several, it can be difficult to decide where to dine. The three parlors listed below set themselves apart by burning wood in their ovens, and also by offering choices that go well beyond the norm.

headline: A Timely Gift of Hot Truffled Chickpeas
abstract: At a former pizzeria, locavores can experience quirky yet appealing farm-to-table fare, and detail-oriented service.
lead_paragraph: Nothing makes me grumpier than getting stuck with the worst table at a restaurant. Such was the case at the Twisted Oak in Tarrytown on a recent night: We were led through the bustling front room to a gloomy rumpus room better suited for darts or air hockey or a low-stakes poker game.

headline: A Way of Tracking Deer Helps the Police Follow Their Prey in the Subway
keywords: ['Subways', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Deer', 'Bridges and Tunnels', 'Cameras', 'Copper, Brass and Bronze']
abstract: New York City police use “trophy cameras,” optical equipment more commonly used to track deer after dark, to catch subway copper thieves.
lead_paragraph: Bushnell, the maker of optical equipment for hunters, sells a “trophy camera” that tracks deer after dark. Mounted to a tree and armed with a motion detector, the camera silently snaps infrared pictures of passing animals that don’t see a thing.

headline: Ukraine Seeks Inquiry Into Killings
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: Ukraine has asked the International Criminal Court to investigate the deaths of civilians on its territory that occurred from Nov. 21, 2013, to Feb. 22, covering the period when more than 100 people were killed during antigovernment protests.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine has asked the International Criminal Court to investigate the deaths of civilians on its territory that occurred from Nov. 21, 2013, to Feb. 22, covering the period when more than 100 people were killed during antigovernment protests. It excludes the period shortly afterward when Russia annexed Crimea. It was not immediately clear whom Ukraine was accusing of the deaths. Initially, Parliament sought to single out the former president, Viktor F. Yanukovych, but other groups may also be included. Because Ukraine is not a member of the court, it has formally given it jurisdiction with respect to the period in question. That step, which was apparently taken in early April, was announced in a court statement issued late Thursday. Ukraine’s application said it expected “that the court shall duly study the case.” But a court spokesman emphasized that it would be up to a prosecutor to decide whether to proceed, and then the court’s judges would be asked to approve the decision. An investigation is not expected any time soon.

headline: Swim to Sea? These Salmon Are Catching a Lift
abstract: California’s drought has left rivers too shallow for salmon, so the government is trucking and barging them to the sea in the hope they will return.
lead_paragraph: RIO VISTA, Calif. — As the Merva W puttered down the Sacramento River, it looked like any other dowdy fishing vessel headed toward the Golden Gate Bridge. But no other boat had as surprising a cargo or as unusual a mission: The Merva W was giving 100,000 young salmon a lift to the Pacific in the hope of keeping them alive.

headline: Michaels Stores’ Breach Involved 3 Million Customers
abstract: The company said that two security firms had found evidence of a breach at Michaels, a crafts retailer, and at a subsidiary, Aaron Brothers, a framing company.
lead_paragraph: Michaels Stores, the arts and crafts retailer, estimates that data on three million of its customers’ payment cards may have been stolen in a breach over several months.

headline: Obama Signs Bill That Bars Iran’s Envoy
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Law and Legislation', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: President Obama signed a bill into law on Friday that would prohibit anyone who has engaged in espionage or terrorism against the United States from obtaining a visa to enter the country as a representative to the United Nations.
lead_paragraph: President Obama signed a bill into law on Friday that would prohibit anyone who has engaged in espionage or terrorism against the United States from obtaining a visa to enter the country as a representative to the United Nations. Congress passed the bill last week after Iran named Hamid Aboutalebi as its ambassador to the United Nations; Mr. Aboutalebi was an interpreter for the militant student group that stormed the American Embassy in Tehran in 1979 and held Americans hostage for 444 days. Iran has insisted that the United States has no right to dictate whom it may choose to represent it. Mr. Obama said the Constitution gave him exclusive discretion to receive or reject ambassadors, and if a case arose where the law would interfere with his exercising that discretion, he would treat it as advisory.

headline: Sheriffs Limit Detention of Immigrants
keywords: ['Immigration Detention', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Police', 'Deportation', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: The announcement by sheriffs in nine Oregon counties adds to growing resistance nationwide to the Obama administration’s use of local immigration enforcement.
lead_paragraph: Sheriffs in nine Oregon counties announced this week that they would no longer hold people in jail based on requests from federal immigration authorities after a United States magistrate judge in Portland ruled that an immigrant’s rights had been violated when she was held in a county jail on such a request.

headline: Readers Share Their Memories of 50 Years Ago in Queens
abstract: The Times asked readers to share their memories of the 1964 New York World’s Fair. Here is an edited selection of those stories.
lead_paragraph: For the 50th anniversary of the opening of the 1964 New York World’s Fair, we asked readers to share their memories and photographs from their visits to the fair. Here is an edited sampling of memories and photographs submitted by readers.

headline: Live Longer and Heirs Will Prosper in New York
keywords: ['High Net Worth Individuals', 'Personal Finances', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Wills and Estates']
abstract: A new estate and gift tax law that went into effect on April 1 will create enormously complex financial planning problems for a few years.
lead_paragraph: DYING is going to have lower tax consequences in New York — if you can wait five to eight years. But in the meantime, the new estate and gift tax law that went into effect on April 1 is going to create enormously complex financial planning problems for all sorts of people.

headline: Ex-Marine Held in Iran Asks Official for Help
abstract: Amir Hekmati, an American incarcerated in Iran since August 2011, recently wrote to its foreign minister seeking help in gaining his release.
lead_paragraph: Amir Hekmati, an American incarcerated in Iran since August 2011, recently wrote to its foreign minister seeking help in gaining his release, after Mr. Hekmati learned from his new lawyer that he had been secretly tried and sentenced to 10 years imprisonment on a charge of collaborating with the United States government, family members reported Friday.

headline: Heartbleed Highlights a Contradiction in the Web
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Open-Source Software', 'Computer Security', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: The bug that rattled the Internet last week exposed the paradox that some of the web’s most crucial coding depends on the efforts of volunteers.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The Heartbleed bug that made news last week drew attention to one of the least understood elements of the Internet: Much of the invisible backbone of websites from Google to Amazon to the Federal Bureau of Investigation was built by volunteer programmers in what is known as the open-source community.

headline: Saving Minds Along With Souls
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Evangelical Movement', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists']
abstract: After a personal loss, an evangelical leader hopes to provide more help.
lead_paragraph: EASTER is a time of new beginnings. It is the answer, the pastor Rick Warren remarks, to loss and despair. A few weeks ago, one year after his son took his life while struggling with depression, Mr. Warren, the founding pastor of Saddleback Church, one of the nation’s largest evangelical churches, teamed up with his local Roman Catholic Diocese and the National Alliance on Mental Illness for an event that announced a new initiative to involve the church in the care of serious mental illness.

headline: New York Police Department Tells Officers to Avoid Elevators in Burning Buildings
abstract: The department has placed further limits on how officers should respond to fires after issuing guidelines just a week ago.
lead_paragraph: Tightening guidelines it had issued after the death of an officer in a Brooklyn high-rise fire this month, the New York Police Department has barred officers from using elevators in burning buildings and recommended they not enter smoke-filled hallways.

headline: OpenSSL and Linux: A Tale of Two Open-Source Projects
abstract: For years, Linux has enjoyed the backing of a range of big tech companies. How has Linux flourished while other open-source efforts have begged for resources?
lead_paragraph: The Heartbleed bug has cast a bright and not entirely flattering light on the open-source movement’s incentive model.

headline: Learning From Korea’s Disaster
abstract: Few great catastrophes have one single explanation.
lead_paragraph: PLAINSBORO, N.J. — With hope fading for the rescue of 271 passengers, most of them high school students, who remain missing after the South Korean ferry Sewol capsized and sank Wednesday, it is not too early to draw lessons from the disaster. South Korea’s early response was to point to “human error” and seek the arrest of the ferry’s captain, first mate and another crew member. But it’s worth keeping three points in mind as investigations proceed.

headline: In Detroit, Judge Takes Offbeat Tack in Hiring Help
abstract: Judge Steven W. Rhodes, who is overseeing this city’s bankruptcy case, is looking for someone who can analyze Detroit’s final bankruptcy plan.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — It was not your standard job interview.

headline: And the Race Is Off
keywords: ['Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Kathleen Sebelius may be saying that she is not going to enter the Kansas race, but she is still adding to this year’s saga of women running for the U.S. Senate.
lead_paragraph: Maybe Kathleen Sebelius should reconsider that Senate thing.

headline: Greed and the Wright Brothers
keywords: ['Inventions and Patents', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: In the years that followed that famed first flight, their failure as businessmen offers lessons for today.
lead_paragraph: Lawrence Goldstone’s new book, “Birdmen,” is about the origins of the airplane, from the early experiments with gliders in the 1890s, to the famous first powered flight by the Wright brothers in December 1903, to the wild next decade — a decade of daring by the early pilots eager to show off both their airplanes and their skill. A good part of the story Goldstone tells is about the rise of airshow exhibitions that swept America — exhibitions in which flamboyant pilots performed death-defying stunts before tens of thousands of spectators. Although, as the author points out, many of those pilots did not, in the end, defy death. On the contrary, death is a constant theme of the early years of flight.

headline: Snowden Defends Query to Putin on Surveillance
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Edward J. Snowden insisted that he had been trying to hold Russia’s government to account over its surveillance practices, as he did with the Obama administration.
lead_paragraph: Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor whose exposure of a vast trove of his government’s secrets made him a hero and even a celebrity in certain circles, suddenly found himself on the defensive a day after he took part in a televised and carefully orchestrated question-and-answer session with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

headline: In Queens, Chickens Clash With the Rules
abstract: Officials at Forest Hills Gardens, a private neighborhood, are citing century-old regulations to make a resident get rid of her chickens.
lead_paragraph: Sylvia Saye held a basket of multicolored eggs.

headline: Turning Up the Intensity
abstract: The N.B.A. playoffs begin Saturday, with familiar teams occupying some of the top seeds. In a league that often seems obsessed with the future, the focus will decidedly be on the present.
lead_paragraph: In the N.B.A. playoffs, everyone is looking to win it all, and no one, thankfully, is thinking about the lottery. So after all the talk during the regular season about which teams were tanking in hopes of landing top draft picks, it will be refreshing to watch game after game in which the only objective is to score the most points.

headline: Obamacare Bashing or Bust
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: Regardless of whether you agree with the Democrats or Republicans on health reform, it could have profound implications on the midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: Thursday, President Obama delivered a compendium of positive news about the Affordable Care Act:

headline: Slow Start Spurs Shift for Towers Near Arena
keywords: ['Atlantic Yards (Brooklyn)', 'Building (Construction)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Mixed-Use Developments', 'Affordable Housing', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: Forest City Ratner, the developer of Atlantic Yards, plans to bring in a new partner and accelerate construction of its first residential building.
lead_paragraph: The first residential tower at the sprawling Atlantic Yards development near Downtown Brooklyn rises only five of its intended 32 floors nearly a year and a half after construction started, making it one of the slowest-moving projects in a city with an unquenchable thirst for housing.

headline: Health Care Spending’s Recent Surge Stirs Unease
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Economy', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: Policy experts wonder whether the government and private businesses can control spending as the economy gets stronger and millions more Americans gain coverage.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It’s back.

headline: In a Hole, Golf Considers Digging a Wider One
abstract: The golf world has lost five million players in the last decade, spurring a growing revolution to create alternative forms of the game.
lead_paragraph: GREENSBORO, Ga. — Golf holes the size of pizzas. Soccer balls on the back nine. A mulligan on every hole.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 18, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: April 18, 2014

headline: A Generational Divide Worn on Their Heads
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hats and Caps', 'Religion and Belief', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Easter and Holy Week', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: For black women of years past, dressing up for church, particularly with a fabulous hat, was essential. Society has changed, and fashions, too.
lead_paragraph: When Lydia Calviness died two years ago at the age of 93, she bequeathed her church hats to her grandniece Monica Moss. Genealogically speaking, Ms. Moss did not qualify as the closest female relative. Ms. Calviness had arranged the inheritance because Ms. Moss, like her, was what the lexicon of black Christianity calls a “first lady” — the pastor’s wife.

headline: Paper Shows U.S.-Flagged Plane in Iran Has Ties to Ghana
abstract: The ownership ties between a Utah bank and a Ghanaian company raise questions about the role of sanctions.
lead_paragraph: New details emerged on Friday about an American plane, owned by a small community bank in Utah and mysteriously parked this week at Tehran’s airport, showing that it had been leased by a Ghanaian mining company owned by a brother of Ghana’s president.

headline: Terror Watch Lists Run Amok
abstract: The Justice Department removed a Malaysian professor from the overbroad no-fly list after eight years of confounding litigation.
lead_paragraph: After eight years of confounding litigation and coordinated intransigence, the Justice Department this week grudgingly informed Rahinah Ibrahim, a Malaysian architecture professor, that she was no longer on the federal government’s vastly overbroad no-fly list.

headline: Finding Open Space and Fresh Air
abstract: The Fresh Air Fund camping program gave one Bronx boy the outdoor activities he couldn’t find in his neighborhood park. Readers can help others like him this summer.
lead_paragraph: Before participating in the Fresh Air Fund camping program, Edgar Saavedra and his two brothers spent summer days inside their home in the Bronx or in the library. Their neighborhood park was too crowded for playing soccer, so once or twice a week their parents put the boys on a bus for a 45-minute ride to a safer, greener park. “In the city, you can’t do much,” Edgar said. “There are only buildings. There’s no grass.”

headline: Awesome Con Fans Try to Break Record
abstract: As part of the convention kickoff in Washington, attendees tried to break the world record for the largest gathering of people dressed as comic book characters but fell short of the record, 1,530.
lead_paragraph: As part of the convention kickoff in Washington, attendees tried to break the world record for the largest gathering of people dressed as comic book characters but fell short of the record, 1,530.

headline: Two Ministers Forge Friendship Across a Church Divide
abstract: A friendship between two ministers is being hailed as one of the most unexpected and intriguing developments in a bitter feud that has split the Episcopal Church in the decade since the denomination elected an openly gay bishop.
lead_paragraph: FAIRFAX, Va. — The two ministers were foes before they ever met, partisans in a war they did not start, but partisans nonetheless.

headline: Putting One’s Cards on the Table
abstract: A brain cruncher by Stu Ockman.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — The last time we saw Stu Ockman over a year ago, he was calling out to us, but this time he has seen fit to twist our brains with a difficult Saturday puzzle.

headline: Viral Disease Spreads to Southeast Asia
abstract: The viral disease known as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome has reached Asia, according to reports from Malaysia and the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: The viral disease known as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome has reached Asia, according to reports from Malaysia and the Philippines. The Malaysian Health Ministry said a 54-year-old man recently back from a pilgrimage to Mecca, Saudi Arabia, died of it on Sunday, and a Filipino nurse was quarantined, along with his family, after a positive blood test. The nurse appeared healthy but, before returning to Manila on Tuesday, had been in contact with a Filipino paramedic in the United Arab Emirates who died of MERS. On Wednesday, the Emirates reported 10 new cases, all among health workers who treated a MERS patient who died April 10. Since the disease was discovered in 2012, there have been 243 confirmed cases with 93 deaths, the World Health Organization said. The coronavirus that causes MERS appears to originate in bats and is widespread in Middle Eastern camel herds. It occasionally infects humans and can spread among them, usually only after close contact.

headline: Tips Lead to Arrest in Series of Roadway Shootings Around Kansas City
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Mohammed P. Whitaker, 27, faces 18 felony counts including two of shooting at a vehicle and striking someone, which carries a maximum penalty of life in prison.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Weeks went by last month and the only evidence that victims of a spate of roadway shootings here could offer the police were the loud pops they had heard and the bullet holes in their cars. Someone was shooting vehicles as they drove on the southern edge of this city and in neighboring suburbs, and this metropolitan area of more than two million people was on edge.

headline: Richards Shows Rangers That Confidence Is Contagious
abstract: Last season’s struggles and this season’s fresh approach combined to forge a better player and a better team.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The Rangers achieved only one victory against the Philadelphia Flyers on Thursday, but it is impossible to measure the value of a rejuvenated Brad Richards to the Rangers’ confidence.

headline: A Day of Chants, Bells, a Bike
abstract: On Sundays Bora Yoon, who writes and performs music that combines ancient and modern elements, gets paid to sing at the Church of the Ascension in Greenwich Village.
lead_paragraph: Bora Yoon writes and performs music that combines ancient and modern elements, including 12th-century liturgical chants and abstract electronic “sound architecture.” On Sundays she gets paid to sing at the Church of the Ascension in Greenwich Village. Her new album, “Sunken Cathedral,” explores the structural parallels between the vaulted construction of a church and its organ and that of a human chest, with both producing sound by moving air through pipes. She will perform much of the album at the Asia Society on Wednesday. Ms. Yoon, 33, lives in Astoria, Queens, with “a great friend that I found through Craigslist,” she said.

headline: An Orange Jumpsuit for Lent
abstract: A part-time youth minister in Texas dresses like a convict for 40 days to highlight the obstacles inmates face on returning to society.
lead_paragraph: Kent McKeever has been summoned for jury duty twice. The second time was on March 17, more than a week into Lent, so he had no choice but to wear his orange prison jumpsuit. As he entered the McLennan County courthouse in Waco, Tex., two sheriff’s officers stopped him.

headline: Can Paradise Be Planned?
abstract: To regain its appeal and improve its future, suburbia can’t just look to the past.
lead_paragraph: When the architect Robert A. M. Stern was a kid in the ‘40s, he used to spend his Sundays perusing The New York Times real estate section. In those days, recalls the self-described “modern traditionalist” best known for buildings like 15 Central Park West and the George W. Bush Presidential Library, “It was all about new houses that were being built in suburbia. I would look at them and redraw the plans. At the basic level I thought they were so damn bad and I thought I could do better.”

headline: Health Officials to Propose Tighter Monitoring of Water Tanks
abstract: Recent surveys by New York City’s health department found that nearly 60 percent of landlords had not complied with existing rules requiring annual inspections.
lead_paragraph: In a reversal, New York City health officials are proposing stronger oversight of rooftop water tanks, which supply drinking water to millions of residents and workers each day but are often neglected by their owners.

headline: Algerian President Wins a Fourth Term
abstract: President Abdelaziz Bouteflika has won a fourth term as Algeria’s leader, receiving 81.5 percent of the vote, officials said Friday.
lead_paragraph: President Abdelaziz Bouteflika has won a fourth term as Algeria’s leader, receiving 81.5 percent of the vote, officials said Friday. Opposition leaders who boycotted the election immediately cast doubt on the results, accusing Mr. Bouteflika, left, and his supporters of widespread fraud and of inflating the turnout, which was officially 51.7 percent. His strongest challenger, former Prime Minister Ali Benflis, won only 12 percent of the vote. Mr. Bouteflika, 77, has been largely incapacitated since suffering a stroke last year, but he has managed to retain a strong grip on power and has avoided the democratic changes prompted by the Arab Spring uprisings elsewhere in North Africa. He cast his ballot in the presidential election on Thursday from a wheelchair.

headline: Dressed to Lead the Pack
abstract: Costello Caldwell created a dog-walking company with a strict uniform code for its staff because, he said, “I’m a walking advertisement.”
lead_paragraph: “Come on, we got the light, kids,” said the wolf pack leader, as traffic stopped and he guided five well-groomed dogs across Riverside Drive.

headline: Go Forth and Conquer, but Postpone the Selfie
abstract: Bryant University in Rhode Island has told its graduating seniors not to take pictures of themselves with their cellphones when they come onstage for their diplomas next month.
lead_paragraph: Sign of the times: Bryant University in Rhode Island has told its graduating seniors not to take selfies when they come onstage for their diplomas next month.

headline: In Pistorius Trial, Critics See a Justice System Favoring the Rich and Famous
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: The murder trial of the double-amputee sprinter has highlighted the wide gap between celebrity justice and the treatment meted out to ordinary South Africans.
lead_paragraph: PRETORIA, South Africa — Before the murder trial of the double-amputee sprinter Oscar Pistorius opened, a judge who ruled that most of it could be broadcast said his decision would counter the notion that South African justice treated the rich and famous “with kid gloves” while it was “harsh on the poor and vulnerable.”

headline: 5 Episodes in a Pivotal Year in New York
abstract: Landmark events are discussed in “New York City 1964: A Cultural History,” architecture as healing art in “Build, Memory” and urban courtesy in “NYC Basic Tips and Etiquette.”
lead_paragraph: A half-century ago, a progressive municipal administration took office with an ambitious agenda. Through the prism of five seminal events, in “New York City 1964: A Cultural History” (McFarland), Lawrence R. Samuel, an author and business consultant, explores the seething city that the administration of John V. Lindsay inherited after the election of 1965.

headline: Covert Inquiry by F.B.I. Rattles 9/11 Tribunals
abstract: The F.B.I.’s inquiry became the focus of the pretrial hearings at Guantánamo this week, after the contractor who was visited by the F.B.I. disclosed it to the defense team.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two weeks ago, a pair of F.B.I. agents appeared unannounced at the door of a member of the defense team for one of the men accused of plotting the 9/11 terrorist attacks. As a contractor working with the defense team at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, the man was bound by the same confidentiality rules as a lawyer. But the agents wanted to talk.

headline: Nets Enter Playoffs With Toughness Spawned by Last Year’s Exit
abstract: After an early exit from last year’s playoffs, the Nets retooled this season, bringing in players like Kevin Garnett and Paul Pierce in hopes of making a title run.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The genesis of this Nets team can be traced to last May. Forty-nine regular-season victories were quickly rendered meaningless by an inglorious first-round playoff elimination.

headline: Senseless Deaths on a Ferry, and by a Gunman’s Hand
keywords: ['Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Ferries', 'Global Warming']
abstract: This week had its share of tragedies great and small.
lead_paragraph: The struggle for Ukraine continued to generate the most tension and passion over the past week. Though Russian, Ukrainian, American and European Union foreign ministers were meeting in Geneva to agree on steps to de-escalate the tensions, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia appeared to take little heed, provocatively noting on television that in czarist times, southeastern Ukraine was a Russian province called “Novorossiya,” literally “New Russia.” The possibility that he would annex it, as he had annexed Crimea, remained very real.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,302 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 2,302 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Journeyman Seems at Home, Nearly No-Hitting the Mets
abstract: Aaron Harang no-hit the Mets for seven innings before David Wright singled against a Braves reliever for the Mets’ only hit in a shutout defeat at Citi Field.
lead_paragraph: Aaron Harang was known as a low-ball pitcher and a strike thrower when the Mets had him for four starts last September. He was like duct tape for a faltering rotation at the end of a disappointing season, but he was a veteran with enough reason to prove he could still pitch. After the season, the Mets let him leave.

headline: U.S. Plans Military Drills in Eastern Europe
abstract: The moves in Poland and Estonia are part of a broader effort to strengthen NATO’s air, sea and land presence in the region in response to Russia’s military actions in and near Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States plans to carry out small ground-force exercises in Poland and Estonia in an attempt to reassure NATO’s Eastern European members worried about Russia’s military operations in and near Ukraine, Western officials said Friday.

headline: Documentary Producer to Lead City’s Film Office
abstract: Cynthia López, named the new commissioner of the Mayor’s Office of Media and Entertainment, says she wants to build on the legacy of her predecessor.
lead_paragraph: Filling a post much discussed from Burbank, Calif., to Brooklyn, Mayor Bill de Blasio on Friday named Cynthia López, a co-executive producer of the award-winning documentary series “POV,” the new commissioner of the Mayor’s Office of Media and Entertainment.

headline: A Brownsville Sanctuary, 100 Years and Counting
keywords: ['Libraries and Librarians', 'Books and Literature', 'Children and Childhood', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)']
abstract: The Stone Avenue branch of the Brooklyn Public Library is celebrating its anniversary and reflecting on its mission as a haven for children within a tough neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of children gathered outside the Brownsville Children’s Library the night it opened its doors in September 1914. Designed to look like a fairy tale castle, the branch, which was financed by Andrew Carnegie, was among the first free-standing children’s libraries in the nation.

headline: Yankees’ Bullpen Comes Undone Along With Their Lead
abstract: Hiroki Kuroda helped the Yankees establish a 4-3 lead over five and two-thirds innings, but his relief allowed eight runs in two innings as Tampa Bay rallied.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Concerns surrounding the Yankees’ bullpen entering this season appeared to have been erased through the first 16 games.

headline: N.B.A. Playoff Predictions
abstract: With the playoffs getting underway, The New York Times’ staff predicts who will emerge from each conference to meet in the N.B.A. Finals.
lead_paragraph: With the playoffs getting underway, The New York Times’ staff predicts who will emerge from each conference to meet in the N.B.A. Finals.

headline: Corrections: April 19, 2014
