abstract: Corrections appearing in print on April 19, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (HBO) BILLY CRYSTAL: 700 SUNDAYS (2014) In this adaptation of his Broadway show, taped in January, Mr. Crystal, right, pays tribute to his father, Jack, who ran a record store in Times Square, produced concerts for jazz greats like Billie Holiday and died when Mr. Crystal was 15. The set evokes his childhood home in Long Beach, N.Y.; home movies are projected onstage; and an animated family fight, in which Mr. Crystal portrays all the characters, is done in mime. “ ‘700 Sundays’ is itself a love letter to the past,” Jason Zinoman wrote in a review of the production in The New York Times. Still, “all the reverent stories don’t add up to a flesh-and-blood character. Jack Crystal remains remote, larger than life, which may be where Mr. Crystal wants to keep him. It’s the kind of show that you wish your son made about you.”

headline: Cheo Feliciano, Debonair Salsa Singer, Dies at 78
abstract: The Puerto Rican-born musician helped introduce Latin music to mainstream America.
lead_paragraph: Cheo Feliciano, a leading salsa singer renowned for both his love songs and his upbeat improvisations, died in an automobile accident on Thursday in San Juan, P.R. He was 78.

headline: Michael Janeway, Former Editor of The Boston Globe, Dies at 73
abstract: Mr. Janeway was also executive editor of The Atlantic Monthly and the author of two books on the decline of democracy and journalism.
lead_paragraph: Michael C. Janeway, a former editor of The Boston Globe and executive editor of The Atlantic Monthly who wrote two books chronicling what he saw as the intertwined decline of democracy and journalism in the United States, died on Thursday at his home in Lakeville, Conn. He was 73.

headline: Four Men Are Arrested in New Jersey Gunfight
abstract: The Elizabeth police pursued a group of robbery suspects on Friday, exchanging gunfire, but one man remained at large Friday night.
lead_paragraph: Four men robbed an auto salvage shop in northern New Jersey on Friday and exchanged gunfire with police officers who foiled their attempt to get away in a U-Haul truck, the police said. The four were quickly arrested, though a fifth man involved in the robbery remained at large Friday night.

headline: The Stations of the Cross in Red Hook
abstract: A cross was prepared for the Good Friday procession at the Visitation of the Blessed Virgin Mary Church of Red Hook, Brooklyn, on Friday. The Gothic church, built in 1855, is still struggling to make repairs from the damage caused by Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: .media.slideshow.in-page-player .headline { display: none; }

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 19, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, April 19, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “The day-to-day life is very tense. We never know what will happen.”

headline: Deadly Clash Reported on Border of China and Vietnam
abstract: Seven people died during the gunfight Friday, which began after migrants grabbed one or more assault rifles from the guards and began firing, the reports said.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Five Chinese civilians and two Vietnamese border guards died Friday during a clash between Vietnamese border guards and Chinese citizens who were trying to enter Vietnam illegally, according to official Vietnamese news reports on Friday and Saturday.

headline: Analytics: Is Unfair Trading Fair Game?
abstract: Nearly 500 readers commented on Michael Lewis’s article about high-frequency trading. Here’s what they said.
lead_paragraph: The following Analytics appears on the letters page in the April 20 issue of the magazine.

headline: Deadliest Day: Sherpas Bear Everest’s Risks
abstract: An avalanche that left at least 13 dead has focused attention on the Sherpas, skilled high-altitude climbers who put themselves at great risk for the teams that pay them.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Sherpas always go first, edging up the deadly flank of Everest while international clients wait for days in the base camp below.

headline: Captain and Two Crew Members Are Arrested in Korean Ferry Sinking
abstract: The captain, Lee Jun-seok, 69, was charged with abandoning the boat and its passengers at a time of crisis, among other counts, according to prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: JINDO, South Korea — The captain and two crew members of a ferry that capsized, leaving more than 270 people — most of them students — missing, were arrested early Saturday, the authorities said.

headline: How Urban Anonymity Disappears When All Data Is Tracked
abstract: At some point very soon, a large amount of public information, like a car license plate, will be part of a mosaic portraying personal lives. At that point, believers in technology say, we’ll build a better society by eliminating deceit. Some say, however, that deferral to data comes at the expense of people making real choices about how to behave.
lead_paragraph: Cities are our paradises of anonymity, a place for both self-erasure and self-reinvention. But soon, cities may fall first in the disappearance, or at least a radical remaking, of privacy.

headline: Divers Begin Bringing Bodies Out of Capsized Ferry
abstract: As the death toll from the South Korean disaster reached 58, with more than 200 people still missing, officials said they expected weeks of grim recovery operations.
lead_paragraph: JINDO, South Korea — After days of rescue efforts stymied by strong currents and poor visibility, divers made their way into a capsized South Korean ferry on Sunday and began bringing out bodies, starting what officials said would probably be weeks of grim recovery operations.

headline: A Swarm of Ant-Sized Robots, at Your Service
abstract: SRI International has developed a technology that can make a swarm of “Micro-Robots” build small things on small scales.
lead_paragraph: While the robots imagined in science fiction novels have often looked like humans, today’s robotic armies are emerging in all shapes and sizes.

headline: European Debt Deflation
abstract: Low inflation/deflation precisely where it does the most harm.
lead_paragraph: As I noted yesterday, Sweden is now experiencing deflation, which is bad for a number of reasons — including the fact that household debt is very high, and deflation (or even low inflation) increases the burden of that debt. (This makes it even more ironic that the Riksbank’s justification for ignoring Econ 101 and raising rates in a depressed economy was concern about excessive household debt and financial stability.) Lars Svensson, who has been a prophet without honor throughout, offers more.

headline: Leveled by Landslide, Towns Mull How to Rebuild
abstract: Oso, Wash., faces a delicate discussion, balancing mourners’ needs against those of businesses.
lead_paragraph: OSO, Wash. — A sometimes awkward, invariably agonized conversation about the future has begun here at the site of last month’s devastating landslide, about what might be rebuilt and what was perhaps forever lost that day.

headline: When Delight Turns to Reality, It’s Goodbye, Easter Bunny
keywords: ['Rabbits', 'Easter and Holy Week', 'Pets', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare']
abstract: Easter is a trying time for rabbit advocates, as parents caught up in the whimsy of Easter bunny buying soon realize their new pet needs a lot of care and attention.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Calif. — Back in 1988, when the seven founders of the House Rabbit Society first came together at a dining table in Alameda, Calif., just south of here, the idea of keeping a rabbit as an indoor pet was considered fairly smirk-worthy.

headline: Dorsett Is Feisty Key to Rangers’ Fourth Line
abstract: Derek Dorsett and his linemates Brian Boyle and Dominic Moore will probably again face the Flyers’ top line in Game 2 of their N.H.L. playoff series against Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: It was November on the Prairies, and the Medicine Hat Tigers’ team bus was rolling down the cold highway out of Alberta, headed for Saskatoon to play the Blades. But it took an unfamiliar turn, and the players asked Coach Willie Desjardins, “Where are we going?”

headline: Michelle Peluso of Gilt Groupe: I Don’t Need an Ivory Tower (or an Office)
abstract: A chief executive, explaining why she does not have an office, says: “When you’re sitting in the open with everybody, you pick up a lot.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Michelle Peluso, chief executive of Gilt Groupe, the online shopping site, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Banks Cling to Bundles Holding Risk
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Banks are fighting imposition of a part of the Volcker Rule that restricts trading in collateralized loan obligations, or C.L.O.s.
lead_paragraph: The Volcker Rule doesn’t go into effect until 2015, but that hasn’t stopped big bankers and their supporters in Washington from trying to undermine it.

headline: One Lousy Seat, a Fitting Tribute
abstract: On Friday the Milwaukee Brewers will unveil a statue of Bob Uecker in the last row of the upper deck, in Section 422, where home plate is little more than a rumor.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — The corner of a baseball dugout, where the tunnel to the clubhouse intersects with the bat rack, ought to have a friendly greeter. At Miller Park, the home of the Milwaukee Brewers, his name is Bob Uecker. Everyone stops to say hi to him, and Uecker greets all with gusto.

headline: Inspired by an Eclipse
abstract: Rubina Isaac, who works at Adler Planetarium in Chicago, says a solar eclipse she saw as a girl in India inspired her interest in astronomy.
lead_paragraph: Rubina Isaac, 26, works with educational programs and tours for children at Adler Planetarium in Chicago.

headline: Variety: An Acrostic That Leaves
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon deliver an acrostic that leaves.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — To borrow from Joyce Kilmer, I think that I shall never see a puzzle lovely as a tree. Oh, there are some that come close, especially those by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.

headline: In Slovakia, Real Lottery Prize Goes to Tax Man
abstract: The idea of a new lottery in Slovakia is to encourage citizens to collect sales receipts and register them with the government, forcing restaurant and shop owners to pay the taxes they owe.
lead_paragraph: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia — When Jozef Lazarcik, a 35-year-old factory worker, heard his number called on national television here recently, he pumped his fists, hardly believing his luck.

headline: Weeding Out the Bad Reference
abstract: A job applicant rejected because of a less-than-enthusiastic reference from a former boss asks how to avoid similar situations in the future.
lead_paragraph: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: Democrats Confront Vexing Politics Over the Health Care Law
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Elections', 'Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Democrats may ultimately see political benefit from the law. But people helped by it are among the least likely to vote.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — When Franklin D. Roosevelt established Social Security, he created generations of loyal Democrats. When Lyndon B. Johnson signed Medicare into law, he built on that legacy, particularly with older Americans. And when George W. Bush instituted a new prescription drug benefit for Medicare, it helped reclaim elderly voters for Republicans.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: House Calls Are Making a Comeback
abstract: Visits by palliative care specialists let medical professionals monitor patients’ physical and emotional health and arrange help with needed tasks.
lead_paragraph: A relic from the medical past — the house call — is returning to favor as part of some hospitals’ palliative care programs, which are sending teams of physicians, nurses, social workers, chaplains and other workers to patients’ homes after they are discharged. The goal is twofold: to provide better treatment and to cut costs.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, April 19
abstract: Notable quotes from business articles that appeared in The New York Times last week.
lead_paragraph: “You’ll see us exploring new areas that we felt we didn’t have the room to do before.” Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Facebook, who has been working on revamping the way the company creates and distributes new services, focusing on apps.

headline: My Head Talks Piketty With Bill Moyers
abstract: Discussing the book of the hour.
lead_paragraph: By the way, the man himself pronounces it pick a TEA.

headline: When Diamonds Are Dirt Cheap, Will They Still Dazzle?
abstract: Technology has the potential to affect the value of items that are now rare and expensive, everything from diamonds to paintings and autographs.
lead_paragraph: As a seventh grader, I was lucky to land the job of ball boy for the Brooklyn Dodgers during their annual late-March exhibition games in Miami. The experience left me with fond memories — of Roy Campanella smoking a cigar as he stroked line drives in the batting cage, of a young Sandy Koufax throwing harder than seemed humanly possible and of an aging Jackie Robinson struggling to remain in the lineup.

headline: An Overdue Haircut
abstract: Shearers work on a Montana ranch during sheep-shearing season.
lead_paragraph: It’s sheep-shearing season across much of the United States, and recently a team of five shearers descended on Lehfeldt Land & Livestock near Lavina, Mont., to remove a year’s worth of growth from about 3,000 ewes and bucks. The work took just over three days; the shearers have an incentive to work quickly because they are paid per sheep. After the wool is removed, it is placed in nylon bales weighing around 500 pounds each and shipped to a warehouse in Billings. Eventually a clothing maker or a mill will bid on it.

headline: From the Fishbowl to the Garden
abstract: Coach Alain Vigneault of the Rangers has worked in the unrelenting spotlight on the N.H.L. teams in Montreal and Vancouver.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Pressure — what pressure? That is what Coach Alain Vigneault was saying last week before the Rangers started their opening-round series against the Philadelphia Flyers. Leading the Rangers is a pressure-filled job, he said, but not as much as coaching an N.H.L. team in Canada.

headline: Shearing Season
abstract: The springtime business of removing wool from sheep in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The springtime business of removing wool from sheep in the United States.

headline: Obamacare Versus The Wusses
abstract: What ever happened to being tough-minded?
lead_paragraph: One of the odd rituals of American punditry — the most famous example is Karl Rove’s tantrum in 2012, but it happens all the time — is the way pundits and operatives keep spinning after the polls have closed. Never mind the vote totals, and let’s dispute the network projections; my guy is still winning!

headline: When Swastikas on Uniforms Meant Luck
keywords: ['Baseball', 'Symbols and Symbolism', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: At the 1914 opening day game between the Brooklyn Dodgers and the Boston Braves at Ebbets Field, the visitors wore caps adorned with what would later become an infamous symbol: the swastika.
lead_paragraph: Why were the Boston Braves wearing a swastika on their caps when they opened the 1914 season against the Brooklyn Dodgers?

headline: Comcast’s Real Repairman
abstract: David Cohen, Comcast’s executive vice president, is the point man for moving deals like the one for Time Warner Cable past regulatory hurdles.
lead_paragraph: One morning late last month, David L. Cohen took a seat in a conference room atop Comcast’s corporate headquarters in Philadelphia, the tallest building in the city, and was handed a binder of architectural drawings. The plans were for a second Comcast skyscraper, taller than the first, because the growing company needs more space.

headline: Taking On Adam Smith (and Karl Marx)
keywords: ['Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Income Inequality', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: With his book “Capital in the Twenty-First Century,” Thomas Piketty has written a blockbuster in the world of economics.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Thomas Piketty turned 18 in 1989, when the Berlin Wall fell, so he was spared the tortured, decades-long French intellectual debate about the virtues and vices of communism. Even more telling, he remembers, was a trip he took with a close friend to Romania in early 1990, after the collapse of the Soviet empire.

headline: Breaking Proud Tradition, Captains Flee and Let Others Go Down With Ship
abstract: Lee Jun-seok became the second sea captain in two years to flee a sinking vessel when he left a South Korean ferry as terrified passengers were still struggling to get off.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the Titanic sank on its maiden voyage, carrying its captain and many of the passengers with it, the notion that the captain goes down with his ship has been ingrained in popular culture.

headline: Familiar Face Shines With a Mets Affiliate
abstract: After taking the 2013 season off, Bobby Abreu signed a minor league deal with the Mets in late March and has played well for the Las Vegas 51s.
lead_paragraph: RENO, Nev. — Bobby Abreu leaned against the concrete wall outside the modest visitors’ clubhouse last Thursday at Aces Ballpark, discussing how he had landed at this point in his baseball career with the Las Vegas 51s, the Mets’ Class AAA affiliate. When his teammates walked past, he smiled and joked and offered fist bumps.

headline: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 54
abstract: The last time the World Cup was held in Brazil, in 1950, India was poised to make its first appearance in the tournament.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: French Journalists Are Freed in Syria
abstract: After 10 months in captivity in Syria, the French journalists were released on the Turkish-Syrian border on Friday.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Four French journalists who were held captive for 10 months in Syria were released on the Turkish-Syrian border late Friday and were on their way home to France, President François Hollande said Saturday.

headline: Fright Nights in the N.B.A.
abstract: The Oklahoma City Thunder’s visiting opponents usually stay in the Skirvin Hilton Hotel, where a housekeeper’s ghost may or may not leave them shaken and bleary-eyed.
lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — The roster of the Oklahoma City Thunder has championship-caliber talent, but the team’s playoff hopes may rest — though not in peace — with one bit player who remains largely unseen.

headline: A 12-Year-Old’s Trek of Despair Ends in a Noose at the Border
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Children and Childhood', 'Smuggling', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Human Trafficking']
abstract: In the care of smugglers, a 12-year-old girl set out from Ecuador to join her parents, who had immigrated illegally to New York. She made it to Mexico before she died.
lead_paragraph: Noemi Álvarez Quillay took the first steps of the 6,500-mile journey to New York City from the southern highlands of Ecuador on Tuesday, Feb. 4, after darkness fell.

headline: Marx Rises Again
keywords: ['Socialism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'Books and Literature', 'Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: Old ideas are having a comeback in the new Gilded Age.
lead_paragraph: IN the season of resurrection, it’s fitting that he’s with us once again — bearded, prophetic, moralistic, promising to exalt the humble and cast down the mighty from their thrones.

headline: Being ‘Good’ Isn’t the Only Way to Go
keywords: ['Nonprofit Organizations', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Careers and Professions', 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: Corporate day jobs can provide meaningful, purpose-driven work.
lead_paragraph: LAST September, the networking site LinkedIn added a feature that allowed its members to say whether they wanted to volunteer or serve on the board of a nonprofit. In just eight months, one million members raised their virtual hands.

headline: Torment on the Stand, but Is It an Act?
abstract: Oscar Pistorius is either a traumatized person or a good actor. His histrionics are hard to read.
lead_paragraph: AGAIN and again over days of brutal cross-examination in a Pretoria courtroom, Oscar Pistorius, the South African track star, broke down on the witness stand. He retched. He cried, then sobbed, then grew hysterical. It got so bad that at times the judge, Thokozile Matilda Masipa, had to adjourn the court while Mr. Pistorius regained his equilibrium.

headline: Reader Complaints, Behind the Scenes
abstract: How to address the concerns detailed in 1,000 emails a week? With a bit of triage.
lead_paragraph: JACKIE McCaffrey, a Times reader, sounded frustrated.

headline: Still Getting Wolf Whistles at 50
abstract: Ford repeats a King Kong of a stunt with its iconic Mustang.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — IT’S weird to be jealous of your car.

headline: The Risks of Everest Are Deadlier for Some
keywords: ['Sherpas (Himalayan People)', 'Mountain Climbing', 'Avalanches', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Life Insurance', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Sherpas deserve better on the world’s highest peak.
lead_paragraph: ON a bright afternoon in June of 1922, the Mount Everest pioneer George Mallory was leading a group of 17 men tied together in three separate rope teams toward the North Col of the mountain when he heard an ominous sound, and turned to see an avalanche fracturing the steep slope above them.

headline: Tolstoy and Miss Daisy
abstract: On the eve of Easter, my family’s happy journey came into focus.
lead_paragraph: IF you were on I-85 near Atlanta on Wednesday morning or I-95 near Baltimore on Thursday afternoon, there’s a chance you spotted them. You’d remember, especially if she was driving when they lumbered by. It’s not often that you see an 18-year-old girl behind the wheel of a gold-colored Cadillac so enormous, so archaic. And it’s not usually a 79-year-old man you find beside her, her lone companion on the long road.

headline: Randall Copeland
abstract: The Southern Baptist at the Manischewitz kosher food company on bulldogs, koi ponds and walkie-talkies.
lead_paragraph: Randall Copeland, a Southern Baptist married to a Catholic, is the vice president of operations at the Manischewitz Company, the nation’s largest manufacturer of kosher foods including such Passover staples as matzo and gefilte fish.

headline: The Part-Time Faculty
abstract: Readers discuss an editorial about the quality and pay of adjunct professors.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss an editorial about the quality and pay of adjunct professors.

headline: How to Get a Job at Google, Part 2
keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'Careers and Professions', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: New graduates may be intrigued by a hiring guru’s advice.
lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — HOW’S my kid going to get a job? There are few questions I hear more often than that one. In February, I interviewed Laszlo Bock, who is in charge of all hiring at Google — about 100 new hires a week — to try to understand what an employer like Google was looking for and why it was increasingly ready to hire people with no college degrees. Bock’s remarks generated a lot of reader response, particularly his point that prospective bosses today care less about what you know or where you learned it — the Google machine knows everything now — than what value you can create with what you know. With graduations approaching, I went back to Google to ask Bock to share his best advice for job-seekers anywhere, not just at Google. Here is a condensed version of our conversations:

headline: They Hook You When You’re Young
abstract: The lifetime effect of an early World Series victory.
lead_paragraph: HOW do events from our childhood shape our adult preferences?

headline: Abandon (Nearly) All Hope
abstract: Faith and optimism can be forms of denial that only prolong our suffering.
lead_paragraph: With Easter upon us, powerful narratives of rebirth and resurrection are in the air and on the breeze. However, winter’s stubborn reluctance to leave to make way for the pleasing and hopeful season leads me to think not of cherry blossoms and Easter Bunnies but of Prometheus, Nietzsche, Barack Obama and the very roots of hope. Is hope always such a wonderful thing? Is it not rather a form of moral cowardice that allows us to escape from reality and prolong human suffering?

headline: A Way for Artists to Live
keywords: ['Cooperatives', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Bed-and-Breakfast Lodgings', 'Culture (Arts)']
abstract: How a co-op bed and breakfast helped a writer survive in New York.
lead_paragraph: THE bedroom was no wider than a subway car, painted Q-train yellow, and had a window facing a construction site that jackhammered at all hours. But I couldn’t wait to move in. I’d answered a Craigslist ad to join a new communal home, and though I wasn’t sure I was the communal-home type, I was also in a phase of reconsidering what type of person I might be. My six housemates planned to open a collectively owned and operated bed-and-breakfast in our building. If our projected costs and occupancy rates were correct (and if the jackhammering would let up), each partner would work 10 to 15 hours a week at the co-op to cover our rent, utilities and shared groceries, freeing up time to pursue the low-to-zero-pay projects we all had in music, art, education and writing.

headline: In Dad’s Hometown, European Souls
abstract: In a village in southwest Ukraine, the kids may know how to speak Russian, but they say they’d rather sing to Taylor Swift.
lead_paragraph: KARAPCHIV, Ukraine — TO understand why Ukrainians are risking war with Russia to try to pluck themselves from Moscow’s grip, I came to this village where my father grew up.

headline: Let Them Drink Chocolate
keywords: ['Milk', 'Children and Childhood', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Lunch and Breakfast Programs']
abstract: Controlling kids’ eating may be misguided.
lead_paragraph: I AM a vegetarian, and it’s Passover. So until Tuesday night I am abstaining not only from all kinds of meat — beef, chicken, fish — but also from my usual low-fat alternatives, like bread, cereal and pasta. The holiday strictures laid out by Leviticus, added to my usual ethics, leave me this week with a heart-hostile diet of eggs, cheese, buttered matzo and my wife’s flourless chocolate cake.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 20
abstract: As runners prepare for the Boston Marathon on Monday, several lawmakers will discuss the new security measures at the race, one year after an explosion killed three people at the finish line.
lead_paragraph: The Boston Marathon kicks off Monday morning,  one year after a bomb exploded near the finish line of the race, killing three people and wounding hundreds. Gov. Deval Patrick of Massachusetts will discuss security at the marathon on CBS’s “Face the Nation.”

headline: Hockey Players’ Concussion Suits Follow Path Charted in N.F.L. Cases
abstract: The accusations of negligence and fraudulent concealment are similar in both sets of cases, as are the injuries the former players contend are related to head trauma.
lead_paragraph: Someone once said that three makes a trend, and now that three concussion-related lawsuits have been filed by nearly two dozen former hockey players against the N.H.L., a trend has emerged.

headline: Republicans See Political Wedge in Common Core
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Tests and Examinations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'States (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: The Common Core, a set of national educational standards, is seen by some conservatives as federal overreach. But in contrast to the Affordable Care Act, it has Republican defenders.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The health care law may be Republicans’ favorite weapon against Democrats this year, but there is another issue roiling their party and shaping the establishment-versus-grass-roots divide ahead of the 2016 presidential primaries: the Common Core.

headline: This Time, Get Global Trade Right
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'North American Free Trade Agreement', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Editorials']
abstract: The country needs new trade agreements, but they can be negotiated to be smarter and stronger.
lead_paragraph: Many Americans have watched their neighbors lose good-paying jobs as their employers sent their livelihoods to China. Over the last 20 years, the United States has lost nearly five million manufacturing jobs. In that same time, however, the prices that Americans pay for basic goods like T-shirts and televisions have fallen. The cost of clothing is down 8.2 percent since 1993, as “made in China” and “made in Bangladesh” labels have crowded out “made in U.S.A.” on the shelves of the local mall.

headline: In Cold War Echo, Obama Strategy Writes Off Putin
abstract: President Obama wants to isolate Russia by cutting off its economic and political ties to the outside world, limiting its expansionist ambitions and effectively making it a pariah state.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even as the crisis in Ukraine continues to defy easy resolution, President Obama and his national security team are looking beyond the immediate conflict to forge a new long-term approach to Russia that applies an updated version of the Cold War strategy of containment.

headline: So These Professors Walk Into a Comedy Club ...
keywords: ['Comedy and Humor', 'Research', 'Books and Literature', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: An algorithm identified Chicago as the nation’s funniest city.
lead_paragraph: NOT long after the physicist Werner Heisenberg (not the guy from “Breaking Bad”) identified the uncertainty principle in the early 20th century, E. B. White — in a somewhat similar vein — warned against meddling with what defines funny.

headline: Jokes From the Top 10 Cities
abstract: A sampling of the humor uncovered during research into the 10 funniest cities.
lead_paragraph: Researchers from the Humor Research Lab and Peter McGraw and Joel Warner, the authors of “The Humor Code: A Global Search for What Makes Things Funny,” asked more than 900 residents of the top 10 funniest cities to recount their favorite joke. Their responses revealed unique “humor profiles” for each city. Below is a sampling of representative jokes from each place.

headline: Pro-Russian Forces Work on Consolidating Power
abstract: In areas of eastern Ukraine under militant control, pro-Russian forces are stifling the news media and political dissenters.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Just before the most important religious holiday of the year for both Ukrainians and Russians, the Orthodox Christian Easter celebration on Sunday, pro-Russian militant groups have paused what had been the daily expansion of their territory in eastern Ukraine.

headline: White Sox, Furthering Legacy, Provide Warm Home for Cubans Amid Chill
abstract: The Chicago White Sox are the center of an expanding universe of Cuban defectors in Major League Baseball.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Alexei Ramirez wore a winter cap, the kind with a fuzzy pompom on top, in the Chicago White Sox clubhouse last Wednesday. It was warm enough in there, but Ramirez took no chances. Stiff wind and icy air would await him on the field.

headline: Blowing the Dust Off a Century-Old Woe
abstract: In 23 pitches, Cesar Cabral gave up three hits, three runs and hit three batters, all without recording an out, a line last seen in 1914.
lead_paragraph: In 23 pitches Friday night against Tampa Bay, Yankees reliever Cesar Cabral pieced together an unsightly outing, one that also has a place in the record books.

headline: Looking at the Ukraine-Russia Crisis from my Ancestral Village
abstract: A bit more of the Kristof family background in Ukraine, and reader comments on my column from my father’s native village
lead_paragraph: For my Sunday column, I returned to the village near Chernivtsi, Ukraine, where my father grew up. What struck me there was the deep yearning for connections to the West, for a future tied not with Russia but with Western Europe. Obviously, one encounters somewhat different sentiments in eastern Ukraine, but overall this popular yearning for a future in Europe runs both deep and broad.

headline: Taunts Fly in Toronto, but Nets Get Last Word
abstract: The Toronto Raptors’ general manager, Masai Ujiri, directed an expletive toward the Nets before Game 1 began, but the Nets came away with the victory.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — It was only halfway through the first game of the N.B.A. playoffs, and Masai Ujiri, the general manager of the Toronto Raptors, was already apologizing to children.

headline: Flyers’ Mason Will Miss Game 2 Against Rangers
abstract: Steve Mason, Philadelphia’s No. 1 goalie, has not played since he was hurt in the next-to-last game of the regular season.
lead_paragraph: Philadelphia goalie Steve Mason confirmed after practice Saturday that he was not ready to return to play for Game 2 of the Flyers’ first-round playoff series against the Rangers on Sunday at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Coach’s Return Is Fraught With Complications
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Child Pornography', 'Coaches and Managers', 'ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION']
abstract: An arbitrator ordered Todd Hoffner reinstated after two seasons away after Minnesota State fired him when a video was found on Hoffner’s phone of his three young children dancing naked.
lead_paragraph: MANKATO, Minn. — Todd Hoffner did no coaching at the Minnesota State football practice on Friday, three days after he was reinstated as the team’s coach. Dressed in a purple Mavericks top and black pants, he stood on the periphery, talking to friends and boosters while assistants ran the 1-hour-40-minute session on a windswept afternoon. With the team three weeks into spring drills, Hoffner did not want to disrupt the routine.

headline: Battle Rages in Homs, Hub of Revolt Against Assad Government
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Syrian insurgents and antigovernment activists are reporting near-continuous bombardment of the Old City and the nearby neighborhood of Waer.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Deadly battles are raging in Homs, the central Syrian city that was long a hub and a symbol of the revolt against President Bashar al-Assad, with both soldiers and insurgents saying they have lost many fighters in recent days as the government presses an all-out assault on the last few rebel-held areas in the Old City of Homs.

headline: Critic of Pakistani Military Wounded in Karachi Attack
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The brother of the Pakistani journalist who was shot accused the chief of Pakistan’s intelligence service of being responsible for the attack.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Hamid Mir, a prominent Pakistani journalist and a critic of the nation’s powerful military, was wounded by gunmen in the southern port city of Karachi on Saturday evening, according to police officials and local news media reports.

headline: Woman Arrested in Attempted Kidnapping of 8-Month-Old
abstract: Tara Anne McDonald, suspected several times in similar cases, tried to take the boy from his nanny in Manhattan, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A 46-year-old woman with a history of trying to abduct young children has been arrested in connection with the attempted kidnapping of an 8-month-old boy in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan, the police said on Saturday.

headline: A Tennis Player Learns to Be Aggressive for Health’s Sake
abstract: Alexandr Dolgopolov has been ranked as high as No. 13 in the world, even though he has Gilbert’s syndrome, a genetic disorder of the liver.
lead_paragraph: MONTE CARLO — Combining unconventional shotmaking and graceful, almost balletic footwork, Alexandr Dolgopolov is one of the most watchable players on the ATP Tour and the best Ukrainian player in a generation.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
keywords: ['Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Sidewalks', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: Questions about Wyatt Earp’s wife, and electrical cords and sidewalks.
lead_paragraph: Q. A friend of mine told me that Wyatt Earp’s wife was a Jewish girl from New York. True?

headline: Ferry Captain and Crew Questioned
abstract: The captain of the Sewol has been charged with abandoning passengers, among other counts, after the ferry carrying more than 400 people sank off South Korea. Two crew members were also arrested.
lead_paragraph: The captain of the Sewol has been charged with abandoning passengers, among other counts, after the ferry carrying more than 400 people sank off South Korea. Two crew members were also arrested.

headline: Zhou Family Ties
abstract: Several members of Zhou Yongkang’s family have made investments in companies with ties to the China National Petroleum Corp., the state oil company formerly run by Mr. Zhou.
lead_paragraph: Several members of Zhou Yongkang’s family have made investments in companies with ties to the China National Petroleum Corp., the state oil company formerly run by Mr. Zhou.

headline: In a Mansion’s Interior, a Study in Contrasts
abstract: “Fabulous Interiors by Elsie de Wolfe and Charles Duveen, 1915-1945” traces their careers and the impact they had on the home owned in the early 20th century by William Robertson Coe, an insurance magnate, and his second wife.
lead_paragraph: Elsie de Wolfe favored flowery painting on walls and furniture, mirrored surfaces to reflect light and an overall brightness for the rooms she designed. Charles Duveen’s trademarks included wood-paneled walls, furniture upholstered in deep red damask or velvet and rooms brimming with dark-hued antiques. Both designers helped create the look of different parts of Coe Hall, the mansion at the heart of the 409-acre Planting Fields Arboretum State Historic Park in Oyster Bay. And now both are the subjects of a new exhibition, “Fabulous Interiors by Elsie de Wolfe and Charles Duveen, 1915-1945,” which traces their careers and the impact they had on the home owned in the early 20th century by William Robertson Coe, an insurance magnate, and his second wife, Mai Rogers Coe, a Standard Oil heiress.

headline: On Wheels
abstract: Elizabeth C. Gorski gets some extra mileage out of today’s puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Another triumph from the Queen of Visual puzzles, Elizabeth C. Gorski. One thing Ms. Gorsi forgot to mention in her comments below is that New Yorkers will go to extreme lengths to find parking for their cars, even if it means pulling your fender right up against the car in front of you. Or sometimes on top.

headline: Investigating Family’s Wealth, China’s Leader Signals a Change
abstract: A corruption inquiry targeting the retired Communist Party leader Zhou Yongkang and his family could challenge a tacit rule that has allowed elite clans to accumulate vast wealth.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — His son landed contracts to sell equipment to state oil fields and thousands of filling stations across China. His son’s mother-in-law held stakes in pipelines and natural gas pumps from Sichuan Province in the west to the southern isle of Hainan. And his sister-in-law, working from one of Beijing’s most prestigious office buildings, invested in mines, property and energy projects.

headline: Suburban Jazz Club Attracts Star Lineups
abstract: The Turning Point in Rockland County has jam sessions that bring together established artists and budding talent.
lead_paragraph: The drummers Eliot Zigmund and Richie Morales are known for their performances on the world’s big stages — Mr. Zigmund with cool-jazz innovators like the pianist Bill Evans and the trumpeter Chet Baker; Mr. Morales with fusion pioneers like the guitarist Al Di Meola and the group Spyro Gyra.

headline: Legal Twist in Bid to Reclaim Nazi-Looted Hospital
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Reparations', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: An Austrian case has become, depending on who is doing the talking, an example either of wrongful imprisonment, naked avarice or how feuds among heirs can complicate Holocaust restitution cases.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Stephan Templ was hoping to right a historic wrong when he fought to reclaim part of an imposing Victorian hospital that was looted from his family by the Nazis in 1938, he says. Instead, he now faces three years behind bars.

headline: Submersible Seeking Jetliner May Soon Finish First Sweep
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Submarines and Submersibles']
abstract: The search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 will continue even if the unmanned vessel combing the ocean floor off Western Australia finds nothing on its initial run, officials said.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — An unmanned submersible vehicle searching the ocean floor off Western Australia for signs of the missing Malaysia Airlines plane could finish an initial sweep of the area within five to seven days, search organizers said on Saturday.

headline: Adrianne Wadewitz, 37, Wikipedia Editor, Dies in Rock Climbing Fall
abstract: Ms. Wadewitz, a literature scholar, completed more than 49,000 edits on the online encyclopedia, focusing on women’s biographies.
lead_paragraph: Adrianne Wadewitz, a scholar of 18th-century British literature who became one of the most prolific and influential editors of the online encyclopedia Wikipedia, died on April 8 in Palm Springs, Calif. She was 37.

headline: A Play About a Play Reveals Racial Tensions
abstract: “Trouble in Mind,” a 1955 comedy-drama by Alice Childress, is about racism in the theater world and has been rediscovered in recent years.
lead_paragraph: “Trouble in Mind,” originally produced Off Broadway in 1955, has been rediscovered by major regional companies in recent years — and rightly so. Currently staged by Two River Theater in Red Bank, Alice Childress’s play is a semisatirical study of racism in the theater world that proves fascinating on several levels. It is a sometimes acrid backstage comedy, a frank look at mid-1950s social attitudes and also a commentary on the discomfort between blacks and whites that remains relevant to some degree today.

headline: Gene Estess, Who Left Wall Street to Aid the Poor, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Estess left the financial world to lead the Jericho Project, which serves homeless, mentally ill and addicted people in Harlem and the South Bronx.
lead_paragraph: Gene Estess worked on Wall Street for two decades and came to feel that he never had really good days. “I didn’t come home with stories to tell or satisfaction or a feeling I’d done anything to help anybody except myself and my family,” he said in an interview with The New York Times in 2003.

headline: Inspired by a Broadway Classic
abstract: “West Side Story” has great meaning for the writer, and the characters, of “Somewhere,” now at Hartford Stage.
lead_paragraph: Salsa music fills the air. Clotheslines strung with laundry crisscross the space overhead. When you take your seat at Matthew Lopez’s “Somewhere” at Hartford Stage, all that’s missing from the old San Juan Hill neighborhood of Manhattan is the scent of frying sofrito.

headline: Making the Most of Opponents’ Mistakes
abstract: Romain Edouard won the Dubai Open Chess Championship by taking advantage of other competitors’ many miscalculations.
lead_paragraph: Being good is not always enough. It helps to be lucky. That was the case for Romain Edouard, a French grandmaster, who won the Dubai Open Chess Championship last week.

headline: Jacob Birnbaum, Civil Rights Champion of Soviet Jews, Dies at 88
keywords: ['ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Mr. Birnbaum sought to improve the lives of Soviet Jews and contributed to legislation that liberalized Moscow’s emigration policies.
lead_paragraph: Just as the civil rights movement began with students challenging segregation at lunch counters, the movement to free Soviet Jews began with students demonstrating at the Soviet Mission to the United Nations.

headline: Early Bloomer, Aptly Named
abstract: Evolution has guided the skunk cabbage to a series of highly unusual adaptations through which the plant attracts spring’s earliest insect pollinators.
lead_paragraph: Plants offer pollinators many rewards — nectar, pollen, even perfumes for attracting the perfect mate. Not many offer heat. During the cold days of spring, the Eastern skunk cabbage offers insects a warm, dark place to eat and sleep.

headline: Budget Stress Actually Rises as Money Does
abstract: If economic forecasts prove correct, the Texas Legislature will be busy with the difficult decisions of how to spend its available funds.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Overseer Meant to Settle Disputes Is Subject of One
abstract: The decision to appoint a master to oversee water usage deepens divisions along the drought-plagued Brazos River in Texas.
lead_paragraph: For decades, water wars have been rare in East Texas, where annual rainfall can be twice that of West Texas.

headline: As High Schools Change, Technical Colleges Prepare to Expand
abstract: A shift in the state’s secondary school curriculum to include diploma “endorsements” in specialized areas has technical colleges partnering with high schools on courses.
lead_paragraph: Higher education officials largely stayed on the sidelines last year when the Texas Legislature debated and ultimately passed a bill that led to a significant overhaul of the state’s high school curriculum.

headline: Working to Prove Innocence of Inmates
abstract: The Innocence Project of Texas is pushing for all similar clinics in the state to use a centralized intake system for letters of state prisoners and a single process for identifying viable cases.
lead_paragraph: LUBBOCK, Tex. — In the back of the Cotton Exchange building in Lubbock’s dusty downtown, the Innocence Project of Texas keeps more than 10,000 files from state prisoners in dozens of blue, purple, and white plastic boxes.

headline: Warriors Win in Next Stage of a Season of Hostilities
abstract: Harrison Barnes’s late block of Chris Paul started a crucial fast break that propelled Golden State to a Game 1 victory over the Los Angeles Clippers.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — More than an hour before Saturday’s game, Stephen Curry sat alone on the Golden State Warriors’ bench. He looked like a boxer waiting to go to work, covered from head to toe in workout gear, a hooded sweatshirt shrouding most of his head, his eyes peeking out and fixed straight ahead.

headline: Sending Alerts Instead, G.M. Delayed Car Recalls
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: A Times analysis shows that General Motors repeatedly used technical service bulletins as a stopgap safety measure instead of ordering timely recalls.
lead_paragraph: The first word from General Motors that the Chevrolet Cobalt had a dangerous safety problem came nine years ago, in a letter to dealers warning them that the cars could suddenly stall because of faulty ignition switches.

headline: U.N. Struggles to Stem Haiti Cholera Epidemic
abstract: The United Nations, facing a shortage of supplies to handle the epidemic, refuses to address whether its peacekeepers brought a deadly strain of the disease into the country.
lead_paragraph: CHAPOTEAU, Haiti — For three years, the United Nations has refused to address whether its peacekeepers brought a deadly strain of cholera to Haiti, insisting instead that it was more important to help the country stanch the disease once and for all.

headline: Ex-Officer Killed Wife, Police Say; Children Ran for Help
abstract: A former New York City transit officer fatally shot his wife while their two young children were in the house, according to the police and neighbors.
lead_paragraph: A former New York City police officer fatally shot his wife in their Queens home on Saturday while their two young children were in the house, according to the police and neighbors.

headline: Colon Bounces Back and Duda Soldiers On, but Neither Does Quite Enough
abstract: Bartolo Colon, recovered from back spasms, lasted seven solid innings in a loss to the Braves at Citi Field.
lead_paragraph: All through spring training, as Lucas Duda and Ike Davis competed to start at first base, they insisted they were close friends. Even after Duda was named the starter early this season, they had their own handshake: They would high-five and then pretend to punch each other in the gut.

headline: In a Thrashing, No Yankee Is Safe on the Mound (Not Even an Infielder)

lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — A little shake of the arm and a wince were all it took to get Joe Girardi bounding out of the dugout as a bad night of baseball turned into something worse.

Pepe of Rye Brook, N.Y., was married in New York Saturday evening to Seth Aaron Gold, the son of Jayne E. Gold and Dr. Lee K. Gold of West Bloomfield, Mich. Benjamin Marlan, an interfaith minister, officiated at the Yale Club of New York.

lead_paragraph: Laura Stacy Passmore and Stephen Laslett Scribner were married Saturday evening at the Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center in Austin, Tex. Erik Dawe, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

lead_paragraph: Jane Dena Mattson and Steve Herbert Shapiro were married Saturday evening at Bernard’s, a restaurant in Ridgefield, Conn. Rabbi Mark Lipson officiated.

lead_paragraph: Allegra Brett Asplundh-Smith and Evan Briggs McGarvey were married Saturday at the Breakers Hotel in Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Emily Jane A. Lemole, a great-aunt of the bride and a minister of the Swedenborgian Church of North America, officiated.

headline: It Just Needed Time to Brew
abstract: Like the beer-making process itself, the courtship between the owners of a beer-brewing shop in Brooklyn took a while to come all together.
lead_paragraph: Erica Ruth Shea, a daughter of Nancy K. Shea of Georgetown, Mass., and Kevin B. Shea of Boston, was married Friday to Stephen Paul Valand, a son of Randi J. Valand and Olav R. Valand of Brooklyn. Jordan Saia, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the Green Building in Brooklyn.

headline: Amy Turitz, Milan Ranka
abstract: The bride is a maternal fetal medicine fellow; the groom is a pediatric ophthalmology fellow.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Amy Lauren Turitz and Dr. Milan Prakash Ranka were married Saturday evening at the Venetian, an event space in Garfield, N.J. The Rev. Stuart Dangler, a United Methodist minister, officiated. Earlier in the day the couple took part in a Hindu blessing ceremony led by Pandit Devendra Shukla, a Hindu priest, at Milan Banquets, another event space in Garfield.

headline: ‘Orphan Black’ Recap: Season 2 Begins
abstract: It’s the corporate one percent versus the desperate clones.
lead_paragraph: The stock science fiction concept of human cloning at the core of “Orphan Black” on BBC America, not only provides a showcase for the versatility of its star, Tatiana Maslany, who portrays Sarah Manning and an ever-increasing number of clones, but it also grants the show’s creators, Graeme Manson and John Fawcett, the freedom to quickly bounce from one genre to the next.

headline: General Mills Reverses Itself on Consumers’ Right to Sue
keywords: ['ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'Customer Relations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Liability for Products']
abstract: The company had a change of heart after consumers had a negative reaction to its new arbitration rules.
lead_paragraph: General Mills, one of the country’s largest food companies, on Saturday night announced in a stunning about-face that it was withdrawing its controversial plans to make consumers give up their right to sue it.

headline: 1914: Easter Scenes In Paris
abstract: During the Holy Week in Paris in 1914, streams of Parisians left the city for the Easter vacation, while tourists arrived to explore the capital.
lead_paragraph: Two distinct streams of people could have been noticed outside the various Paris railway termini yesterday, the first consisting of Parisians about to quit the city for the Easter vacation, and the second, composed of English, German and other tourists, who had just arrived bent upon passing the same gay period in exploring the French capital. The result of the ingress of tourists was that the boulevards and main streets of Paris presented an even more cosmopolitan appearance than usual. Fortunately fine weather favored the sightseers and the guides reaped a rich silver harvest. Groups of energetic Teutons made an almost military inspection of the Louvre and decided with unanimity that the Mona Lisa’s smile is as over-rated as it is ambiguous.The char-à-bancs were all crowded, the majority of the passengers wearing caps. At dusk a group of English tourists, who had probably crossed the Channel for the sake of higher mental culture, marched contentedly up the avenue de l’Opéra to the immortal strains of “You made me love you,” supplied by the youngest visitor’s richly toned mouth-organ. The Frenchmen who had remained in Paris gazed upon their progress with unspeakable admiration and drank a thoughtful aperitif to the eternal durability of the “Entente Cordiale.” — The New York Herald, European edition, April 12, 1914.

headline: In Our Pages: April 21
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: in 1914 Britain’s King George V and Queen Mary visit France in their first official visit since the coronation; in 1964 a massive power failure in London cancels the launch of the BBC 2 television channel.
lead_paragraph: 1914: King George V. and Queen Mary Visit France

headline: Fire Kills Two 4-Year-Old Siblings in the Rockaways
abstract: The house fire late Saturday in Far Rockaway, which killed two 4-year-old half siblings and injured three other people, may have started when a child was playing with a lighter, the police said.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday afternoon, Jai’Launi and Aniya Tinglin, both 4, and their sister were outside in the sun, playing and riding scooters around their grandfather’s home on Bay 30th Street in a working-class and polyglot corner of Far Rockaway, Queens.

headline: Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, Boxer Found Wrongly Convicted, Dies at 76
keywords: ['Boxing', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Mr. Carter, whose case gained international attention, was twice convicted of murder and imprisoned for 19 years before the charges were dismissed.
lead_paragraph: Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, a star prizefighter whose career was cut short by a murder conviction in New Jersey and who became an international cause célèbre while imprisoned for 19 years before the charges against him were dismissed, died on Sunday morning at his home in Toronto. He was 76.

headline: Friends, and Influence, for Sale Online
abstract: By using social media bots, celebrities, politicians and others can falsely inflate the number of friends and followers they have, possibly swaying public opinion about a new song — or a policy position.
lead_paragraph: Whoever said, “Money can’t buy you friends,” clearly hasn’t been on the Internet recently.

headline: When the Fair Came Down
abstract: After the New York World’s Fair closed on Oct. 17, 1965, the exhibitions and buildings were carefully and willfully dismantled.
lead_paragraph: After the New York World’s Fair closed on Oct. 17, 1965, the exhibitions and buildings were carefully and willfully dismantled.

headline: Clues to Family’s Business Ties Found in Public Paper Trail
abstract: Documenting the Zhou family investment tree to assess the vast wealth accumulated by the family of the former national security chief, who also ran the giant China National Petroleum Corp.
lead_paragraph: Tombstones in China often record the names of both living and dead family members. The five tablets dedicated to the Zhou family in the hamlet of Xiqiantou list the nation’s former security chief, Zhou Yongkang, by his childhood name, Zhou Yuangen. They also record the names of his first and second wives, his two sons and his two brothers, their wives and their two sons.

headline: Hamilton Grabs 3rd Straight Win in Formula One
abstract: Lewis Hamilton led from start to finish for his third straight victory this season as his Mercedes team finished 1-2 again.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — There is an easy way to measure just how much the Mercedes team is dominating the new Formula One season: At the Chinese Grand Prix outside Shanghai on Sunday, for the fourth race in a row, Mercedes beat its nearest rival by nearly half a minute.

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (WGN America) SALEM The network’s first original scripted series explores the happenings that incited the infamous witch trials in 17th-century Massachusetts through the characters of Mary Sibley (Janet Montgomery, above), Salem’s unexpectedly pregnant head witch; her beau, John Alden (Shane West), who disappeared for seven years to fight Indians; her mysterious accomplice, Tituba (Ashley Madekwe); and Cotton Mather (Seth Gabel), the town’s spiritual leader. “You’ve got to admit that it’s perversely entertaining,” Neil Genzlinger wrote in The New York Times. “Though witchery is a favorite theme of shows aimed at teenagers, this series aspires to a grown-up audience. You can tell that from the sex and nudity (the somewhat demure basic-cable variety, but still, there’s a lot of flesh here). More important, you can tell it from the writing. When ‘Salem’ isn’t being deliberately outrageous, it’s cultivating a dynamic that could be fruitful as things move along. Here in the 21st century, science and reason rule, but in a world of sorcery, clinging to rationality just makes you stupid.”

headline: Asking How Much Opera Singers’ Work Is Worth
abstract: The 80 members of the chorus at the Metropolitan Opera have been asked to accept a roughly 16 percent pay cut.
lead_paragraph: It was Monday morning and somewhere along the Henry Hudson Parkway, Jean Braham was already singing. She was gliding up and down the octaves as she headed down the highway in her Honda Accord.

headline: Fractured State of Pakistani Taliban Calls Peace Deal Into Question
abstract: Infighting between commanders appears to be impeding talks with government negotiators, and recent bombings raise the possibility that the very idea of making peace has divided the Taliban.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When the Pakistani Taliban said they were willing to make peace, many Pakistanis were skeptical that the militants had truly abandoned their dream of transforming the country into an Islamic caliphate.

headline: The Evergreen State: Washington Readies for Legal Marijuana Sales
abstract: Marijuana distributors in Washington State are eagerly awaiting licenses to sell the drug, now that the state has legalized production and possession.
lead_paragraph: Marijuana distributors in Washington State are eagerly awaiting licenses to sell the drug, now that the state has legalized production and possession.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 19, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: April 19, 2014

headline: Another Faithful Hit for Hollywood: ‘Heaven Is for Real’
abstract: That film became Hollywood’s fourth overtly faith-based hit of the year over the Easter weekend, taking in an estimated $21.5 million at North American theaters.
lead_paragraph: “Heaven Is for Real” became Hollywood’s fourth overtly faith-based hit of the year over the Easter weekend, taking in an estimated $21.5 million — double the dismal ticket sales that Johnny Depp mustered for his latest big-budget effort. But God still could not beat a superhero: The No. 1 movie at North American theaters was again “Captain America: The Winter Soldier” (Disney), which sold about $26.6 million in tickets, for a three-week domestic total of $201.5 million, according to Rentrak, which compiles box-office data.

headline: Nova Is Probably Facing Tommy John Surgery
abstract: A magnetic resonance imaging test showed Ivan Nova had a partly torn ulnar collateral ligament in his right elbow; if he has Tommy John surgery, he will miss about a year.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — When Yankees starter Ivan Nova described to Shawn Kelley the sensation he felt in his elbow Saturday night, Kelley knew. Soon after the conversation, Nova was on his way to have a magnetic resonance imaging test, but Kelley could have saved him the trouble.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Violet’
abstract: Sutton Foster sings “Lay Down Your Head” from the musical “Violet,” on Broadway at the American Airlines Theater.
lead_paragraph: Sutton Foster sings “Lay Down Your Head” from the musical “Violet,” on Broadway at the American Airlines Theater.

headline: More Than 40 People Killed in Bus Accident in Pakistan
abstract: At least 42 people, including 13 children, were killed after a bus collided with a trailer truck in southern Pakistan in one of the nation’s worst traffic accidents in years, officials said.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — At least 42 people were killed Sunday morning in southern Pakistan after a bus slammed into a tractor-trailer in one of the worst traffic accidents in this country in recent years, officials and rescue workers said.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking: April 18, 2014
abstract: This week, Joe discusses C.E.O. pay.
lead_paragraph: It’s been seven years since the financial meltdown, and more than 10 million people are still out of work across the country. What can we do to get out of this rut? This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Diane Brady of Bloomberg Businessweek discuss new ideas to get the economy moving again.

headline: Further Notes on Sweden
abstract: What went wrong?
lead_paragraph: I’m still thinking about Sweden’s slide into deflation, which actually offers several lessons relevant to the rest of us.

headline: Flyers Put End to One Skid and Keep Another One Going
abstract: The Flyers, who overcame a two-goal deficit to tie the series, 1-1, stopped a nine-game losing streak at the Garden and handed the Rangers their seventh straight loss in Game 2s.
lead_paragraph: There is a fine line between winning and losing, Rangers Coach Alain Vigneault said after his team fell to the Philadelphia Flyers, 4-2, at Madison Square Garden on Sunday afternoon.

headline: Kidd Says Decision to Sit Kirilenko Was Matter of Flow
abstract: Andrei Kirilenko, who never made it onto the court in the Nets’ Game 1 win over the Raptors on Saturday, said he understood Coach Jason Kidd’s decision.
lead_paragraph: Someone was notably missing from the Nets’ exciting Game 1 win over the Toronto Raptors on Saturday afternoon: Andrei Kirilenko.

headline: Shootout Underscores Fragile Truce in Ukraine
abstract: At least three people were killed Sunday at a checkpoint run by pro-Russian militants near the town of Slovyansk in eastern Ukraine, days after a settlement was reached calling on insurgents to disarm.
lead_paragraph: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — A shootout at a checkpoint run by pro-Russian militants near the town of Slovyansk left at least three people dead on Sunday, highlighting the fraying here in eastern Ukraine of a truce reached days earlier by diplomats in Geneva.

headline: Meshing Talents for a Dense and Strenuous Sound
abstract: “Matra” received its premiere from Neue Vocalsolisten and the International Contemporary Ensemble of New York at the MATA Festival.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday evening the German vocal ensemble Neue Vocalsolisten joined the International Contemporary Ensemble of New York at the Kitchen in the American premiere of Oscar Bianchi’s cantata “Matra” as part of the MATA Festival of new music. Before we continue, a brief glossary:

headline: Dryly Sharing a Stage and Musicians, but Little Else
abstract: The Miller Theater’s Bach, Revisited series continued with a program of works by Bach and Joan Tower, although the latter composer saw little connection between their respective music.
lead_paragraph: Joan Tower, composer, pianist and educator, is evidently no philosopher. The subject of a Composer Portrait at the Miller Theater in 2011, she was given another showcase at the Miller on Thursday evening, with excellent performances of her “Big Sky” (2000) for piano trio, “In Memory” (2002) for string orchestra and “White Water” (2011), her String Quartet No. 5.

headline: Key Suspect in Art Scheme Is Under Arrest in Spain
abstract: An art dealer was taken into custody in connection with a swindle that led collectors to spend more than $80 million on phony masterworks. The United States is expected to request his extradition.
lead_paragraph: A Spanish art dealer identified by the authorities in the United States as a central figure in one of the most sweeping art swindles in the last decade has been arrested in Spain, and a government official there said on Sunday that he expected the United States to request his extradition.

headline: Love, and Warring Parents
abstract: Abhishek Varman’s “2 States,” a romantic Bollywood comedy, centers on a southern girl, a northern boy and their bickering parents.
lead_paragraph: Love is a communal thing in Abhishek Varman’s “2 States,” a Bollywood romantic comedy about a southern girl (she’s Tamilian) and a northern boy (Punjabi) who have to overcome their parents’ bickering and prejudices to find a happy ending.

headline: A Gimlet-Eyed Grunt, Soldiering Balefully Through a War’s Horrors
abstract: In the newly translated memoir “Poilu,” a Frenchman offers acidic observations on trench warfare while serving on the Western Front.
lead_paragraph: A century after the guns of August first boomed, World War I has lost none of its power to boggle the mind. The numbers are simply too big: 65 million men under arms, 37 million casualties, 12,000 miles of trenches on the Western Front, 1.45 billion shells fired. Rather than a human event, it often seems like an immeasurable abstraction, like negative infinity.

headline: Bonding With the Chauffeur
abstract: In the class-conscious drama “Bends,” a society woman and her driver both have something to conceal.
lead_paragraph: “Bends,” Flora Lau’s restrained debut feature, seesaws between the painful limbos of an upper-class Hong Kong housewife and her driver, who lives on the mainland. Shot in sleek tones by Christopher Doyle, the film melds class-conscious melodrama with malleable mood piece, but keeps threatening to fade from understatement into stasis.

headline: Norway Faces Germany in Dutch Tournament Finals
abstract: One of the biggest international junior events is the White House tournament held annually in the Netherlands.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest international junior events is the White House tournament held annually in the Netherlands.

headline: Riding New York City’s Desire Line
abstract: Desire lines, says architecture critic Michael Kimmelman, are marked by economic development and evolving travel patterns. He plots today’s desire line along the waterfronts of Brooklyn and Queens.
lead_paragraph: Desire lines, says architecture critic Michael Kimmelman, are marked by economic development and evolving travel patterns. He plots today’s desire line along the waterfronts of Brooklyn and Queens.

headline: How This Renoir Used to Look
keywords: ['Art', 'Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: When conservators at the Art Institute of Chicago wanted to find the missing pigment in a portrait by Pierre-Auguste Renoir, they used laser light to reveal the original hues.
lead_paragraph: Conservators at the Art Institute of Chicago wanted to solve the mystery of the missing pigment.

headline: From Liszt’s Soliloquies to Labor Blues
abstract: Gilles Vonsattel played works by Beethoven, George Benjamin, Liszt, Messiaen, Heinz Holliger and Frederic Rzewski on Friday at Bargemusic.
lead_paragraph: Bargemusic, the cozy floating concert hall moored just south of the Brooklyn Bridge, presents more than 200 concerts a year. It’s easy to take for granted this invaluable workhorse of New York’s music scene.But where else, I ask you, is it possible to hear two different pianists over the course of a few days play “Winnsboro Cotton Mill Blues,” Frederic Rzewski’s musically rich, politically astute 1980 solo?

headline: Back to ‘The Boondocks,’ Minus Its Creator’s Touch
abstract: The long-delayed fourth and final season of “The Boondocks” begins Monday night on Adult Swim, without the involvement of its longtime producer, Aaron McGruder.
lead_paragraph: “The Boondocks” is back, and the less said about it the better, really. Aaron McGruder painstakingly produced three seasons of the sharply satirical animated show over the course of five years, from 2005 to 2010. He wasn’t involved in the long-delayed fourth and final season, which begins Monday night on Adult Swim, and it shows. Is a mediocre “Boondocks” better than no “Boondocks” at all? Maybe. As the show’s moral center, the 10-year-old black-militant ninja Huey Freeman, told the sad striver Tom DuBois when Usher stole his wife in Season 2: “Could be worse. Could be Omarion.”

headline: They Disprove Claims
abstract: John Lieb tries to disprove a claim.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — This was a puzzle where I had to make sense of the theme after I finished solving. That usually doesn’t happen to me on Mondays but, hey, it’s a brand new week, and anything can happen here at Wordplay.

headline: Javier Camarena in ‘La Cenerentola’
abstract: Javier Camarena sings Ramiro’s aria, “Si, ritrovarla io giuro,” from Act II of Rossini’s opera, at the Met.
lead_paragraph: Javier Camarena sings Ramiro’s aria, “Si, ritrovarla io giuro,” from Act II of Rossini’s opera, at the Met.

headline: The Met as Mosh Pit for a Fill-In Star
abstract: After a recent star turn, the Mexican tenor Javier Camarena returns sooner than expected, standing in for Juan Diego Flórez in “La Cenerentola.”
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera’s production of Rossini’s Cinderella story, “La Cenerentola,” a revival of which opens Monday, ends with the happy couple embracing atop a giant wedding cake. During a brief lull in a rehearsal last week, the Mexican tenor Javier Camarena, who plays the dashing Prince Ramiro to Joyce DiDonato’s humble Angelina, mimed leaping from the cake into the mosh-pit arms of the chorus.

headline: Malaysia Airlines Jet Makes Emergency Landing
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The plane returned safely to Kuala Lumpur after blowing a tire on the main landing gear during takeoff.
lead_paragraph: A Malaysia Airlines flight made an emergency landing Monday morning, returning safely to Kuala Lumpur International Airport after a problem with the plane’s landing gear, airline officials said.

headline: Brooklyn to Queens, but Not by Subway
keywords: ['Transit Systems', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Cable Cars and Trams']
abstract: The vision of a streetcar route between Red Hook and Astoria would provide much-needed transit to areas where millennials and thousands of less affluent New Yorkers live.
lead_paragraph: There’s a wonderful term for the dirt trails that people leave behind in parks: desire lines.

headline: Yankees Find Their Offense in the 12th Inning
abstract: On a day when the Yankees needed someone to give their starting rotation a jolt, Vidal Nuno threw five scoreless innings in a hard-fought Yankees victory against the Rays.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Late Saturday night, Dean Anna was, by his own admission, not having fun. A utility infielder, he had been asked to pitch the final inning of a blowout loss to save the pitching staff, and despite the unique situation, he did not enjoy it.

headline: With Clouds Ahead, Heat Seize the Moment
abstract: While Miami’s victory in its playoff opener felt familiar, this postseason seems different for the two-time defending champion Heat, who could be tiptoeing toward uncertain times.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Seconds before the opening tip, Dwyane Wade ambled toward one of the baselines at American Airlines Arena, turned to the crowd and raised his arms. The fans gobbled up the theatrics, a grand celebration Sunday afternoon before the Heat had played a single minute of their first-round playoff series against the Charlotte Bobcats.

headline: $250,000 Grant to Finance Website Tied to PBS Series
abstract: The Knight Foundation plans to give money to the PBS series “How We Got to Now” to create a site aimed at encouraging idea-sharing among civic leaders, urban planners, designers and others.
lead_paragraph: The coming PBS series “How We Got to Now,” based loosely on Steven Johnson’s book “Where Good Ideas Come From,” will be a history program, examining innovation and its role in creating social change, including such topics as how 18th century English coffeehouses spurred the age of enlightenment.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 53
abstract: The Barcelona star Neymar, who was injured last week, said he would be ready to play for Brazil in the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: The Enduring Legacy of Terri Schiavo
abstract: The controversy over Terri Schiavo’s case elevated a family matter into a political battle that continues to frame end-of-life issues today.
lead_paragraph: The controversy over Terri Schiavo’s case elevated a family matter into a political battle that continues to frame end-of-life issues today.

headline: An Evolutionary Family Drama
keywords: ['Evolution (Biology)', 'Herring', 'Levees and Dams', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: I went out rowing each morning, unaware that a grand evolutionary experiment was taking place beneath my hull.
lead_paragraph: OLD LYME, Conn. — WE would see amazing things if we could learn to be travelers in our own neighborhoods, Henry David Thoreau once suggested. Lately, I have come to think that this is more true than I had imagined.

headline: From Private Ordeal to National Fight: The Case of Terri Schiavo
abstract: To this day, the name Schiavo is virtually a synonym for epic questions about when life ends and who gets to make that determination.
lead_paragraph: Her surname in Italian means “slave,” and is pronounced skee-AH-vo. Grim as it may be, the word could apply to Theresa Marie Schiavo, even with its Americanized pronunciation: SHY-vo. For 15 years, Terri Schiavo was effectively a slave — slave to an atrophied brain that made her a prisoner in her body, slave to bitter fighting between factions of her family, slave to seemingly endless rounds of court hearings, slave to politicians who injected themselves into her tragedy and turned her ordeal into a national morality play.

headline: A Bright and Colorful Easter Sunday
abstract: New Yorkers across the city dressed to impress to celebrate Easter on a cheerful Sunday. Blooming trees, strollers on Fifth Avenue and Brooklyn churchgoers all looked grand under the gleaming sun.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers across the city dressed to impress to celebrate Easter on a cheerful Sunday. Blooming trees, strollers on Fifth Avenue and Brooklyn churchgoers all looked grand under the gleaming sun.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Black women and their hair have been a topic of discussion for years by people like Maya Angelou, Al Sharpton and Salt-N-Pepa.

headline: Should Parents Be Less Involved?
abstract: Readers criticize a Sunday Review article suggesting that many forms of parental involvement do not improve their children’s achievement.

headline: A Lead Grows, but Runoff Is Likely in Afghan Race
abstract: The candidate Abdullah Abdullah widened his lead, but neither of the top contenders seemed to be on track to win more than 50 percent of the vote.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — With half the votes counted in the Afghan presidential race, the candidate Abdullah Abdullah widened his lead, but a runoff seemed likely between the top two contenders, according to data released Sunday by the Independent Election Commission.
