keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Government Bonds', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The following tax-exempt, fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: To Reduce Inequality, Start With Families
keywords: ['Child Care', 'Children and Childhood', 'Family Leaves', 'Income Inequality', 'Paid Time Off', 'Parenting', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Bipartisan agreement about making daily life easier for working parents could have a profound effect on long-term economic trends.
lead_paragraph: The French economist Thomas Piketty swept across the United States last week with a dire warning: Income inequality isn’t going to go away, and it probably will get worse. Only policies that directly address the problem — in particular, progressive taxation — can help us change course.

headline: The Public Health Crisis Hiding in Our Food
abstract: A new British study shows many lives can be saved by cutting salt.
lead_paragraph: IF you have high blood pressure, you’re in good company. Hypertension afflicts 67 million Americans, including nearly two-thirds of people over age 60. But it isn’t an inevitable part of the aging process. It’s better to think of it as chronic sodium intoxication. And, as an important new study from Britain shows, there’s a way to prevent the problem — and to save many, many lives.

headline: Granderson Finally Puts an End to His Otherwise Forgettable Day
abstract: Curtis Granderson finished 0 for 6, grounded out with the bases loaded and made a horrible throwing error. But his sacrifice fly drove in the winning run.
lead_paragraph: The home crowd seemed anxious as Curtis Granderson came to bat in the bottom of the 14th, with one out and the winning run on second.

headline: Bankrupt City Fighting to Open a Crack in California’s Pension Agency
keywords: ['Bankruptcies', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Local Government', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Government Employees']
abstract: After having declared bankruptcy, San Bernardino wants to make a deal with Calpers to reduce the amount of money it owes the pension system.
lead_paragraph: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif. — When this bankrupt, working-class city took the unprecedented step in 2012 of stopping its required pension contributions — arguing that it could not otherwise make payroll — other financially stressed California cities took notice: Could San Bernardino defy Calpers, the powerful agency that administers the state’s huge pension system?

headline: Many Auto Show Visitors Unfazed by G.M. Recalls
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'New York International Auto Show', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: One reason for an apparent lack of concern, analysts said, is that all of the 2.6 million cars recalled because of ignition switch problems are out of production.
lead_paragraph: Louis Monetti pulled a tape measure from his back pocket and stretched it across the Chevrolet Cruze’s trunk to make sure his bicycle would fit. Then he crouched for a good look at the car’s rear suspension. It all seemed fine, he said on Saturday at the New York International Auto Show, adding that he probably would buy the Cruze over the Ford Fusion.

headline: Surviving the Mount Everest Avalanche
abstract: Kaji Sherpa is a climber who survived the avalanche Friday on Mount Everest. From a hospital bed in Katmandu, he recounted the disaster that killed at least 13 Sherpas.
lead_paragraph: Kaji Sherpa is a climber who survived the avalanche Friday on Mount Everest. From a hospital bed in Katmandu, he recounted the disaster that killed at least 13 Sherpas.

headline: New Mayor and a New Agenda, but Little Change Within the Ranks
abstract: While Mayor Bill de Blasio continues to stock the top levels of his administration, city records show the next rung of crucial decision-makers are mostly holdovers from his predecessor.
lead_paragraph: Four months into his first term, Mayor Bill de Blasio continues to stock the top echelons of his administration with senior aides and commissioners who share his desire to break sharply from the policies and tone set by Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: After Everest Disaster, Sherpas Contemplate Strike
abstract: As the Sherpas, who put themselves at great risk to guide affluent clients up Mount Everest, mulled an unprecedented strike, some would-be climbers said their passion for the ascent was gone.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The 22 Sherpas who set out together toward Mount Everest’s Camp 2 on Friday morning were “full of joy and excitement,” but Kaji Sherpa was apprehensive: They were crossing a notoriously dangerous ice field, and they were moving too slowly.

headline: Sweden Turns Japanese
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Deflation (Economics)', 'Interest Rates', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The sadomonetarists, with their gut dislike of low interest rates, have claimed another victim.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago Sweden was widely regarded as a role model in how to deal with a global crisis. The nation’s exports were hit hard by slumping world trade but snapped back; its well-regulated banks rode out the financial storm; its strong social insurance programs supported consumer demand; and unlike much of Europe, it still had its own currency, giving it much-needed flexibility. By mid-2010 output was surging, and unemployment was falling fast. Sweden, declared The Washington Post, was “the rock star of the recovery.”

headline: In Silicon Valley Thriller, a Settlement May Preclude the Finale
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: Four leading tech companies are pushing to settle a class-action suit with several noteworthy angles, including questions over employee rights and the death of a programmer who helped set the case in motion.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — After years of legal skirmishes, four leading Silicon Valley companies are scheduled to go on trial next month on claims of conspiring to keep their employees down.

headline: Starting in June, ‘Today’ Will Simulcast on SiriusXM
abstract: NBC is announcing a deal with the satellite radio service that will bring all four hours of its franchise morning news show to radio.
lead_paragraph: The “Today” show is moving to radio — or, more exactly, expanding to radio.

headline: From Behind the Plate, a Dutiful Master Orchestrates the Cardinals
abstract: The Cardinals’ Yadier Molina is considered not only a master of pitch selection but also of improvisation, based on the clues he reads from his pitchers and opposing hitters.
lead_paragraph: Baseball on television is nothing like basketball and football. In those sports, the primary camera angle shows most, if not all, of the participants. In baseball, you mostly see just two of the defensive players on every pitch.

headline: Sexual Abuse Lawsuits Are Expected to Expand
abstract: The lawyer whose client says he was drugged and raped in 1999 by Bryan Singer, the “X-Men: Days of Future Past” director, said defendants in the new suits had ties to Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The next round in a widening legal fight over sexual abuse accusations in Hollywood is now set for 2 p.m. on Monday. At that time, the lawyer who in a lawsuit last week accused the filmmaker Bryan Singer of drugging and raping his client in 1999 expects to announce additional lawsuits at a news conference in Beverly Hills.

headline: When Wrigley Opened, Yanks Were Different. Well, Not Totally.
abstract: Though he was not the hitter that Derek Jeter is, the young and scrappy Roger Peckinpaugh served the same role in 1914 as Jeter does today: team captain.
lead_paragraph: This week, as Chicago’s Wrigley Field marks its 100th anniversary, Yankees fans may be wondering what their own team was like in 1914, before it become a powerhouse franchise, nine years away from its first World Series championship.

headline: Errors Mounted as Chaos Ruled Capsizing Ferry
abstract: A portrait of chaos is emerging from crew members, survivors and a transcript of the vessel’s final 40 minutes of communications with emergency dispatchers.
lead_paragraph: JINDO, South Korea — Of all the images from the loss of a ferry in the cold waters off the southwest coast of South Korea last week, perhaps none have angered South Koreans more than those of the captain and his key crew members awkwardly and quickly fleeing their half-submerged vessel to the safety of a rescue boat, even as hundreds of their passengers remained trapped inside.

headline: Aereo Case Will Shape TV’s Future
keywords: ['Television', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: A lot of people will be watching to see how the Supreme Court rules over the legality of Aereo because of what it could mean for the broader media ecosystem.
lead_paragraph: Throughout America’s business history, the victories and spoils went to the visionaries who made all manner of things — actual things like cars, pharmaceuticals and entertainment.

headline: Focusing America’s Attention on Asia
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials']
abstract: A trip to Asia offers a chance to clarify President Obama’s plans for greater engagement.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Raise the subject of President Obama’s Asia policy here and an American can expect to be bombarded with questions.

headline: The Next Juvenile Justice Reform
abstract: States could bring more young offenders into the mainstream if they did a better job of educating them while they were in juvenile facilities.
lead_paragraph: Research has long shown that locking up young people puts them at greater risk of dropping out of school, joining the unemployment line and becoming permanently entangled in the criminal justice system. States and municipalities have thus been sending fewer young offenders to juvenile institutions and more of them to community-based programs that keep them connected to their families and reduce the risk that they will engage in further crime. The number of children held in custody plummeted from about 107,000 in 1995 to less than 71,000 in 2010 and is still falling.

headline: A Rare G.O.P. Battle Forces an Incumbent to Look Left
abstract: In California, Art Moore’s bid for Representative Tom McClintock’s Fourth Congressional District seat has drawn anger from members of the Tea Party.
lead_paragraph: AUBURN, Calif. — A moderate Republican trying to unseat a conservative congressman from his own party, Art Moore sat a little stiffly at a Sizzler restaurant here during the monthly meeting of the Auburn Area Republican Women Federated. Appearing after the meeting’s agenda was already set, Mr. Moore was not invited to speak before the group — not that it would have made much of a difference.

headline: Running Out of Time
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Editorials']
abstract: There are years, not decades, left to start reducing greenhouse gas emissions, and American leadership is urgently needed.

Strenuous denials from the Kremlin have closely followed each accusation by Ukrainian officials that the world was witnessing a stealthy invasion by Russian forces.

lead_paragraph: TWIN BRANCH, W.Va. — When people visit with friends and neighbors in southern West Virginia, where paved roads give way to dirt before winding steeply up wooded hollows, the talk is often of lives that never got off the ground.

Stacey King, an announcer for the team, fondly calls the Bulls a collection of “heart, hustle and muscle.”

headline: Brooklyn’s Most Beloved Ice Cream Shop Creates a Special Flavor for T
abstract: On the occasion of the release of its first cookbook, Ample Hills Creamery shares the recipe for its limited-edition "T Time" flavor.
lead_paragraph: Spring’s arrival in Brooklyn means longer days, cherry blossoms flowering in the Botanic Garden — and blockbuster, out-the-door lines at Ample Hills Creamery, Brian Smith and Jackie Cuscuna’s three-year-old artisanal ice cream shop. Warmer weather drives crowds to the Prospect Heights storefront, which may explain why the couple are debuting another, bigger location later this spring in Gowanus — complete with a party space, a roof deck and an industrial-size kitchen that will let them produce pints for retail sale. They have also just published “Ample Hills Creamery: Secrets and Stories from Brooklyn’s Favorite Ice Cream Shop” ($24.95, Stewart, Tabori & Chang) with the writer and illustrator Lauren Kaelin, a longtime employee and creator of the smart Benjameme blog.

headline: Summerstage Plans Are Announced
abstract: The annual program free, live performances presented by the City Parks Foundation all over New York City will offer music, theater, film, dance and a couple of circuses.
lead_paragraph: SummerStage, the annual festival of free, live shows presented by the City Parks Foundation all over New York City, will offer performances of nearly every style of music – opera, hip-hop, R&B and jazz, for starters – as well as theater, film, dance and even a couple of circuses. The festival opens on June 3, with a performance by Ty Dolla Sign at Red Hook Park, in Brooklyn, and ends on Aug. 24, with a concert in Central Park by the Fania All-Stars (tickets are required for this one), part of a celebration of the 50th anniversary of Fania Records, the Latin music label, that will run through the festival.

headline: Afghan Newlyweds, Facing Threats, Find Brief Respite in Mountains
abstract: Mohammad Ali and Zakia, running from her family and the police, were welcomed into the home of distant relatives until their location was revealed.
lead_paragraph: HINDU KUSH RANGE, Afghanistan — They eloped from their village in the Bamian Valley on the first day of spring, but their month on the run has taken them back into winter as they fled higher into these rugged mountains in central Afghanistan. They stayed in the homes of friends when they could, and they slept rough in caves when they could not.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 3 P.M. (FX Movie Channel) HEREAFTER (2010) Clint Eastwood imagines what happens after people die by braiding together three story lines, each involving a collision between the living and the dead. In San Francisco, George Lonegan (Matt Damon, above), who receives messages from the deceased loved ones of anyone he touches, chooses a life of obscurity instead of exploiting his gift. In London, a solemn boy named Marcus feels the presence of his twin, Jason, whose violent death has left him adrift. (The brothers are played by George and Frankie McLaren.) And in Paris, Marie Lelay (Cécile de France), who nearly died in the 2004 tsunami in South Asia, is convinced that she has seen a metaphysical reality the world is determined to ignore. “Persuasion is not really the point, though if anyone could make me believe in ghosts, it would be Clint Eastwood,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times of this film, written by Peter Morgan. He added: “What does seem new — newly strange, newly beautiful — is what ‘Hereafter’ makes of the here and now. It is a curious movie in both senses of the word: an unusual experience and an open-ended inquiry into something nobody can really claim to understand. It leaves you wondering, which may be the most fitting way of saying that it’s wonderful.”

lead_paragraph: Glenn D. Lowry, who will soon begin his 20th year running the Museum of Modern Art, has a longstanding practice of taking time each week to visit artists’ studios. Which is why he could be found one recent morning along the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn, watching the glass-blowing sculptor Josiah McElheny and assistants fashion a vessel from molten lumps, a process almost Elizabethan in its rituals.

headline: Naples, a Haven of Hand Work
abstract: Tailors, including those at Rubinacci and Kiton, find inspiration in their relationships with clients around the world.
lead_paragraph: NAPLES, Italy — In a basement room on a street where motor bikes and honking horns drown out even the insistent church bells, Davide Tofani is working on a typical Neapolitan soft jacket. “When I make a suit, it is like shaping a second skin of my customer,” the tailor says. “I cannot imagine making a suit without knowing the body that will use it.”

headline: Arrests of 4 More Crew Members Sought in Korean Ferry Sinking
abstract: Three of the ship’s mates and a chief engineer were detained, and prosecutors asked the court to allow them to arrest the four on a charge of contributing to the death of passengers.
lead_paragraph: JINDO, South Korea — Prosecutors sought to arrest four more crew members on Monday from the South Korean ferry that sank last week as they raced to unravel the mysteries surrounding the sinking, which left more than 300 people dead or missing in one of the country’s worst peacetime disasters.

keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Monkeys and Apes']

lead_paragraph: China Southern Airlines, a major state-owned carrier that in March announced it would no longer transport monkeys to laboratories in the United States, has agreed to pay a fine for violating an American animal welfare law, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

headline: China to Allow the Blind to Take College Entrance Exams
abstract: The Education Ministry’s decision to allow blind people to take the regular “gaokao,” or university entrance examinations, has been welcomed by the blind and their advocates.
lead_paragraph: China’s Education Ministry has told its staff to provide more “humane” service in this year’s university entrance examinations, or “gaokao,” and allow disabled people, particularly the blind, to take part. Advocates said this was the first time that the state had clearly spelled out that the blind could take the regular university examination, and how.

headline: A Ray of Literary Hope on Italian TV
abstract: In recent decades television has done major cultural damage, but it may be our best tool for change.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — Last November, I found myself in a glass elevator speeding to the top of the  Mole Antonelliana tower in Turin. I wasn’t there for the view: I had exactly 59 seconds to persuade Antonio Pennacchi, one of Italy’s most important writers, to read my novel. Even more nerve-racking: My elevator pitch was live on camera.

headline: For Boston, a New Beginning After a Safe Ending to Its Marathon
abstract: More than 35,000 runners participated in the Boston Marathon, a year after three people were killed and more than 260 wounded in a bombing at the race.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — When the digital clocks along Boylston Street flashed 2:49 on Marathon Monday, nothing out of the ordinary happened. And that was reason for joyous celebration.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | April 21, 2014
abstract: On Mondays, we publish a Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by posting about what you see, and why. A live discussion is offered from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. Eastern time.

headline: Editorials, From Start to Finish
abstract: Juliet Lapidos, editor of the Opinion section blog Taking Note, demystifies the editorial pages.
lead_paragraph: Before I started working at The New York Times, I hadn’t spent much time pondering the question of how editorials came into the world. For all I knew they were delivered by stork. Roughly two years ago I was hired to start a blog for the editorial page, called Taking Note, and more recently I’ve started writing editorials as well. So I can now demystify the process. Storks have no involvement and, contrary to what some people on Twitter believe, neither does the Democratic National Committee.Editorials represent the opinion of The Times (unlike Op-Ed essays, which are written by outside contributors who represent their own opinions, and not that of the paper).

headline: 1904: The Easter supplement
abstract: Between 1898 and 1904, the New York Herald published Easter supplements. Here is the cover of the 1904 Easter supplement.

The supplements included short stories by famous writers, colorful illustrations, culture guides, and advertisements for luxury hotels or the latest fashion boutiques. Here is the cover of the 1904 Easter supplement.

headline: Airbnb’s Huge Valuation
abstract: Airbnb’s new fund-raising round values the company at $10 billion. | A lone guy in an office joins brand-name firms on a list of top deal makers. | A look at the poison pill’s relevance. | More fighting over the Volcker Rule.
lead_paragraph: Airbnb is said to have closed a $475 million round of financing from a group led by TPG Growth that values the home-sharing company at about $10 billion, Michael J. de la Merced writes in DealBook. At the value assigned by the investment, Airbnb — a website and app where homeowners and apartment dwellers rent their homes, spare rooms or couches to travelers — would be worth more than some established hotel chains like Wyndham Worldwide or Hyatt.

headline: Russia Accuses Kiev of Flouting Ukraine Accord
abstract: Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov’s accusations suggested the Kremlin was creating a basis to justify a territorial grab in eastern Ukraine similar to its annexation of Crimea.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Russia’s foreign minister accused the interim authorities in Kiev on Monday of flagrantly violating the international accord reached last week aimed at defusing the crisis in eastern Ukraine, in remarks that suggested Russia may be further preparing the groundwork for a military intervention.

headline: Class, Oligarchy, and the Limits of Cynicism
abstract: Both parties listen to plutocrats, but one more than the other.
lead_paragraph: A recent paper (pdf) by Martin Gilens and Benjamin Page is getting a lot of attention, and deservedly so. Gilens and Page look at a number of issues over the past 30+ years where polling data let us identify public policy preferences, which can be compared with elite and interest-group preferences. And what they find is that politicians don’t seem to care very much about what the public thinks: when elite preferences and popular preferences are different, the elite almost always wins.

headline: In ‘Dutch Doubles,’ 4 Choreographers, Inspired by 4 Artists
abstract: The new program at the Dutch National Ballet adroitly combines tutus, Mozart and Beethoven, as well as high-profile collaborations with creatives in other fields.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — Like most big ballet companies today, the Dutch National Ballet has to carefully tiptoe between conservation and innovation — presenting works that signal “classical ballet” to audiences (“Swan Lake”!), and commissioning new pieces that say “we are relevant to contemporary culture.” Ted Brandsen, who has been directing the company since 2003, has been particularly proactive about new work, with a keen eye for talented dance makers. In a new program, “Dutch Doubles,” which opened last week at the Het Muziektheater, he adroitly combines tutus, Mozart and Beethoven, as well as high-profile collaborations with modern artists and designers.

headline: Rotating a Smartphone Video

abstract: Investment banks, which rushed into the new territory of physical commodities starting at the turn of the century, are now beating a retreat.
lead_paragraph: Investment banks, which rushed into the new territory of physical commodities starting at the turn of the century, are now beating a retreat.

headline: Bookshelf | In Architecture, Small is Big
abstract: A new book from Taschen, “Small Architecture Now!”, explores innovative buildings with diminutive footprints.
lead_paragraph: In architecture as in so much of life, bigger often seems better. Yet these days, contemporary architects — and their clients — are under stricter than ever budgetary, environmental and aesthetic constraints. As the editor and critic Philip Jodidio writes in his introduction to Taschen’s new book, “Small Architecture Now!” ($60), “small buildings often provide a degree of freedom to architects that cannot be obtained in gigantic public or corporate projects.”

headline: U.A.W. Drops Appeal of VW Vote in Tennessee
abstract: The United Automobile Workers appeal of a vote against union representation at a Volkswagen plant in Tennessee had been scheduled to be heard Monday.
lead_paragraph: The United Automobile Workers union unexpectedly announced on Monday that it was dropping its effort to have a new unionization vote ordered at the Volkswagen plant in Chattanooga, Tenn.

headline: Mumbai’s Business Community Tries New Enterprise: Politics
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Elections', 'Financial Brokers', 'Hinduism', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Members of the white-collar elite who have shunned participating in past campaigns are now motivated to stump for Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — At Priyadarshini Park in the Malabar Hill neighborhood of south Mumbai, under the shade of neatly aligned coconut trees, a platoon of middle-aged stock brokers discussed the volatility of the Indian stock markets as they went on their regular power walk along the frothy shoreline of the Arabian Sea.

headline: Chinese Court Orders Seizure of Japanese Vessel
abstract: The ship, the Baosteel Emotion, is a bulk carrier owned by Mitsui O.S.K. Lines, which the court said had failed to pay compensation resulting from a 1930s contractual obligation.
lead_paragraph: A court in Shanghai has ordered the seizure of a Japanese ship over legal claims dating to before World War II, adding a point of contention to the sometimes rancorous relationship between Japan and China.

headline: Assessing the Impact of a Profit-Sharing Plan
abstract: The plan began with the second quarter of 2013, and the business made a profit in three of the four quarters that followed.
lead_paragraph: In August, I wrote a series of posts about the design and implementation of a profit-sharing plan for my business. I decided to try this because my company has a long history of producing poor (or no) profits.

headline: Oh, the Stories Wrigley Field Could Tell
abstract: In 100 years, the ballpark has withstood the assault of time and bad baseball, housing a team that has the longest championship drought in North American professional team sports.
lead_paragraph: When the ballpark that became Wrigley Field opened in Chicago in 1914, it soon hinted at the checkered baseball history made there in the next 100 years.

headline: Wrigley Field Turns 100
abstract: Despite the team’s disappointing record, the century-old home of the Chicago Cubs continues to draw fans.
lead_paragraph: Despite the team’s disappointing record, the century-old home of the Chicago Cubs continues to draw fans.

headline: Justice Stevens Suggests Solution for ‘Giant Step in the Wrong Direction’
keywords: ['Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'McCutcheon v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Campaign Finance', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: In his new book, Justice John Paul Stevens proposes six amendments, one of which would address the Citizens United ruling on campaign finance.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice John Paul Stevens, who turned 94 on Sunday, is a mild man with an even temperament. He has a reverence for the Supreme Court, on which he served for almost 35 years until his retirement in 2010, and he is fond of his former colleagues.

headline: Manchester United’s Moyes Is Out, According to Reports
abstract: David Moyes, the handpicked successor to Alex Ferguson, has overseen United’s tumble from Premier League champions to seventh place in his first season.
lead_paragraph: David Moyes was supposed to be the long-term successor to Alex Ferguson at Manchester United, one veteran Scottish manager passing control to his handpicked heir last May. But after a calamitous season that sees United heading toward its worst finish in the Premier League, it now appears that Moyes will not even last until this summer.

headline: Knicks Fire Mike Woodson as Coach
abstract: A week after Coach Mike Woodson and the team finished with a hugely disappointing 37-45 record that left them out of the playoffs, the dismissal came as little surprise.
lead_paragraph: Mike Woodson was 109-79 in his two-plus seasons as the Knicks’ coach. His regular-season winning percentage of .580 is the third highest in franchise history. Still, it was no surprise Monday when the Knicks announced that he had been dismissed, less than a week after he and the team finished the 2013-14 season with a hugely disappointing 37-45 record that left them out of the playoffs.

headline: K.K.R.’s Acquisition of an Affiliate Encounters Opposition
abstract: The plan by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts to acquire KKR Financial Holdings is opposed by an organization that advises union pension funds, but others are supporting it.
lead_paragraph: A plan by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts to acquire an affiliate has encountered opposition from a group that advises investors.

headline: U.S. Ordered to Release Memo in Awlaki Killing
abstract: The Justice Department document provided the legal justification for the killing of Anwar al-Awlaki, an American citizen who was said to have joined Al Qaeda and died in a drone strike in Yemen.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals panel in Manhattan ordered the release on Monday of key portions of a classified Justice Department memorandum that provided the legal justification for the targeted killing of a United States citizen, Anwar al-Awlaki, who intelligence officials contend had joined Al Qaeda and died in a 2011 drone strike in Yemen.

headline: In Our Pages: April 22
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: American painter Henry Mosler’s works to be exhibited in Paris in 1889; the French government will need 17 billion francs to pay rearmament bill in 1939.
lead_paragraph: 1889: American Art to Show in Paris

headline: Another Coach Spun Out the Garden’s Revolving Door
abstract: The Knicks have fired another head coach, and to this we may all shrug and say, What else is new?
lead_paragraph: The Knicks have fired another coach, and to this we may all shrug and say, What else is new?

headline: Rockets Fired From Gaza Draw Airstrikes From Israel
abstract: Palestinian militants and Israeli forces exchanged fire as an April 29 deadline for peace talks drew near.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Seven rockets fired from the Gaza Strip landed in southern Israel on Monday morning, prompting Israeli airstrikes that hit at least one training site of Hamas, the militant Palestinian faction that rules Gaza.

headline: Quiche With Red Peppers and Spinach
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Recipes', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health', 'Eggs']
abstract: Spinach is plentiful and gorgeous this time of year, and slow cooking makes even the blandest red peppers sweet.
lead_paragraph: The real spring vegetable here is the spinach, lush and beautiful at this time of year. You can always get red peppers in a supermarket, and when you cook them for a while, as you do here, even the dullest will taste sweet. I make the pepper mixture first, then wilt the spinach in the same pan and line the tart shell with the savory mix. If you can, make the pepper and spinach filling a day ahead. It dries out a little if it sits overnight in the refrigerator and is less likely to dilute the custard.

headline: Roasted Asparagus and Scallion Quiche
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Recipes', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health', 'Eggs']
abstract: Roasting asparagus makes it succulent even when it’s hidden inside a quiche.
lead_paragraph: I’ve made many a spring quiche filled with asparagus and herbs, yet I’d never thought about roasting the asparagus instead of steaming it. But lately I’ve been buying thick stalks of asparagus, and all I want to do is roast it; roasting intensifies the flavor and the stalks become incredibly succulent, more so than when the asparagus is steamed. This quality isn’t lost even when the sliced stalks are hidden inside a quiche.

headline: Cabbage and Spring Onion Quiche With Caraway
abstract: Seasonal onions and a winter stalwart, cabbage, make a deliciously sweet filling.
lead_paragraph: Spring onions found their way into several of this week’s quiches. For this one, I cooked the onions with cabbage – even a half a head of cabbage that has been lingering in your refrigerator will work here – until both vegetables were soft, lightly colored and sweet. I added caraway seeds to the mix because I love the flavor of caraway with cabbage. I used 1/2 teaspoon, just enough so that people noticed; they couldn’t recognize what it was (“Cumin?” they asked) right away, but they liked it. I made the filling a day ahead and let it sit uncovered overnight in the refrigerator.

headline: Scallion and Celery Quiche
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Recipes', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health', 'Eggs']
abstract: An underappreciated vegetable, celery, is the star of this tart.
lead_paragraph: I’ve written before that I consider celery an underrated vegetable, capable of contributing nuance and texture to a dish. But it would have never occurred to me to have it as one of the main vegetables in a quiche if I hadn’t heard the restaurant critic Jonathan Gold discussing a tarte au céleri that he’d had at Church & State in downtown Los Angeles, a sort of tarte flambée in which celery, celery root and apples stood in for the traditional onions and bacon. I figured if it worked so well in that dish, it could also in a quiche. It does.

headline: Whole-Wheat Pie Dough
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Recipes', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health', 'Eggs']
abstract: This dough, made with half whole-wheat flour, has a nutty, rich flavor that works well for a savory tart.
lead_paragraph: Most of the vegetable tarts that I post on Recipes for Health call for a yeasted olive oil crust that I love to work with. With French quiches, however, I prefer a crust that resembles classic French pastry. However, I always use at least half whole-wheat flour – which is not so French – not only for its nutritional superiority, but also because it gives the resulting shell a nuttier, richer flavor that is particularly welcome in a savory tart. This dough, adapted from Jacquy Pfeiffer’s recipe for pâte brisée in “The Art of French Pastry,” involves more butter than you’re used to seeing in my recipes, but an occasional butter-based crust, especially when it’s made with whole-wheat flour and contains a filling that is all about vegetables, is not going to kill us. Instead, it’s a vehicle for the foods that we want to move toward the center of our plates.

headline: Justices Take Case on Status of Jerusalem in Passports
abstract: The Supreme Court agreed to decide whether Congress may require the State Department to treat Jerusalem as the capital of Israel in American passports.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to decide whether Congress may require the State Department to treat Jerusalem as the capital of Israel in American passports, in a case that touches on generations of conflict in the Middle East, as well as the dueling roles of Congress and the president in the conduct of foreign affairs.

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Recap:  The (Madison Avenue) Gods Must Be Crazy
abstract: Valentine’s Day upends everyone: Pete thinks he’s in Purgatory, Peggy believes her flowers are cursed and even Don isn’t up to his usual tricks.
lead_paragraph: Season 7, Episode 2

headline: No Time For Sargent
abstract: Some immutable principles aren’t.
lead_paragraph: I’m a little late to this, but there’s lately been some buzz about the unearthing of Tom Sargent’s 2007 graduation speech, in which he briefly laid out 12 principles of economics. For the most part the speech is getting favorable attention. So let me be a spoilsport. It’s not so much that what Sargent said is wrong, although some of his principles are by no means universally agreed upon, even in normal times. What’s so striking about Sargent’s points is that it’s hard to think of a worse time to cite them. And the people citing that old speech clearly have ulterior motives.

headline: Food Curated: Brooklyn Bouillon
abstract: Rachael Mamane thought she could generate extra income for farmers who raise animals by creating a line of stocks from discarded bones. Brooklyn Bouillon was born from the idea.
lead_paragraph: Rachael Mamane thought she could generate extra income for farmers who raise animals by creating a line of stocks from discarded bones. Brooklyn Bouillon was born from the idea.

headline: Video: Brooklyn Bouillon
abstract: Inside the small-batch company from Rachael Mamane that produces rich stock from the discarded bones generated by New York State farms.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, when Rachael Mamane was working for the greenmarkets in New York City, she noticed that none of the farm stands offered high-quality stock to home cooks on a consistent basis. She had the idea to help farmers who raise animals to generate extra income by creating a line of stocks from their “waste,” like discarded bones. It was an opportunity no one else had seized.

headline: Listen Up | Newcomer King Avriel Makes Neo-Soul That Doesn’t Shy Away From Big Ideas
abstract: The buzzed-about 24-year-old newcomer makes sonically adventurous pop with a social and political conscience.
lead_paragraph: “I have a really short attention span,” says Avriel Epps. “I’m always trying to get to the next thing, and that’s how I feel about music, too. The only thing that’s going to stay consistent … is the depth of my message.” The singer, who goes by the gender-bending moniker King Avriel, has only released a few songs so far, all for free via her Soundcloud account. But she has already garnered attention for her use of sultry electro production to explore big themes like gender inequality and consumerism.

headline: A New Zealand Trail Is Open for Cyclists
keywords: ['Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Hikes and Hiking', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The Heaphy Track, one of New Zealand’s Great Walks, will be open to cyclists beginning May 1.
lead_paragraph: New Zealand’s Heaphy Track, the longest of the country’s nine famed Great Walks, is now open to cyclists.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival:  Students Get a Starring Role in Times Square
abstract: A short film made by fellows from the Tribeca Film Institute is being shown on Times Square billboards every night this month.
lead_paragraph: At 11:57 each night this month, 40 electronic billboards in Times Square simultaneously spring to life with what, at first glance, might be mistaken for a shoe commercial. Six teenagers pull on Nikes, Uggs, lace-up boots and brogues in neighborhoods from Bushwick to Tribeca, then set off on the subway — destination: Washington Square Park — eventually converging with friends in a group hug.

headline: Toronto Gets an Art Fair With a Name Change
abstract: The newest offshoot of the Affordable Art Fair will open next month in Toronto, where it will be called Love Art.
lead_paragraph: The newest offshoot of the Affordable Art Fair, a franchise that originated in London in 1999 and has generated multiple offspring around the world, is coming to Toronto in May. After opening with a private preview on May 7, at the Direct Energy Center, it runs for the next four days.

headline: Brain, Teen: Brain, Child Magazine Devotes an Issue to Parents of Teenagers
abstract: The magazine that brought many parents of my vintage through the toddler years has invited writers, including Ann Hood, to cast the eyes that once focused on potty training and sleepless nights onto sexuality, grit, college tours — and more sleepless nights.
lead_paragraph: The single, No. 1 request from readers of this blog is “more about teenagers, please.” That vexing subset of children is also the most challenging for parents to write about, from a personal perspective: that toddler who was quite cheery about having her foibles unmasked for readers can quickly become a teenager highly protective of even the smallest of online mentions. Advice and more distant commentary is far easier to come by than essays from parents truly “in the trenches.”

headline: Tricky Dice
abstract: How can you design a set of three dice that work like the rock-paper-scissors game?
lead_paragraph: Our puzzle this week is about a tricky kind of relationship — one that’s a bit counterintuitive. Normally, when we compare several things, we expect something like the following: your friend Agnes weighs more than Beatrice, and Beatrice weighs more than Clarissa, then we’d expect Agnes to outweigh Clarissa. This makes sense. This kind of relationship would also work for heights, ages, and other single-dimension measures. This also works for containers: a dime is in a small pouch in Clarissa’s purse, so the dime is in the purse.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Jo Becker on Reporting the Fight for Marriage Equality
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Jo Becker, a Pulitzer Prize-winning investigative reporter for The Times, discusses her new book, “Forcing the Spring: Inside the Fight for Marriage Equality,” to be published this month by Penguin Press.

headline: Tributes to Avalanche Victims in Nepal
abstract: Family, friends and climbers gathered in Katmandu, Nepal, to pay respect to the Sherpas killed in an avalanche on Mount Everest.
lead_paragraph: Family, friends and climbers gathered in Katmandu, Nepal, to pay respect to the Sherpas killed in an avalanche on Mount Everest.

headline: Boston Marathon Day
abstract: Scenes from the Boston Marathon on Monday, a year after two bombs exploded near the finish line.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Boston Marathon on Monday, a year after two bombs exploded near the finish line.

headline: Elizabeth Spencer Wins Rea Award
abstract: Ms. Spencer, 92, won the award for short fiction for work that is “alert to the otherwise unobserved vital nuances of our most secret selves.”
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Spencer, whose body of work includes “The Light in the Piazza” (1960), has been awarded the 2013 Rea Award for short fiction.

headline: Times Minute | Tech Earnings Preview
abstract: Apple, Microsoft and Amazon will issue quarterly reports this week. Also on the Minute, the effect of California’s water crisis and celebrating 100 years of Wrigley Field.
lead_paragraph: Apple, Microsoft and Amazon will issue quarterly reports this week. Also on the Minute, the effect of California’s water crisis and celebrating 100 years of Wrigley Field.

headline: Counting Death in the Movies
abstract: For characters that die and stay dead, the website Movie Body Counts keeps track of deaths in movies.
lead_paragraph: In last week’s Riff, Alexander Huls bemoans the death of death in Hollywood films. “Of course action films have saccharine subplots that exist only to lend meaning to their staggering body counts,” he writes. “But in recent years, killing a major character in your average blockbuster has become inert thanks to the increasing use of formulas to create stakes.”

headline: Times Minute | Tech Earnings Preview
abstract: Apple, Microsoft and Amazon will issue quarterly reports this week. Also on the Minute, the effect of California’s water crisis and celebrating 100 years of Wrigley Field.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: A Year Later, It’s Old Glory in Boston Marathon
abstract: Meb Keflezighi, 38, on Monday became the first American man to win the race since 1983. Rita Jeptoo of Kenya won the women’s race in 2:18:57, a course record.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Something unusual happened when Meb Keflezighi, far ahead of his competitors, began passing some of the elite women who had started before the men on Monday in the Boston Marathon. As he charged by, many of the women — exhausted and in pain — cheered him on.

headline: Lawmakers Broadening Their Focus to Fight Against an Array of Sex Crimes
abstract: As the congressional fight over military sexual assault recedes, lawmakers are broadening their focus to crimes like college campus assaults, child predators and human trafficking.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the high-profile congressional fight over military sexual assault recedes, lawmakers are broadening their focus to an array of sex crimes like college campus assaults, preying on child and human trafficking.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: Doris Day crops up in a promotional spot for “Louie.”
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Public Relations and Publicity']
abstract: Winners of the O’Toole Awards for Creative Excellence and Media Excellence included BBDO and Baldwin&, and LatinWorks of Austin, Tex., opened nTrigue.
lead_paragraph: Allscope Direct was opened by Allscope Media, New York, and Joe Shain, a longtime direct response marketing executive, who will be chief executive of Allscope Direct.

headline: Interpublic Group Joins Ranks of Publishers With Report in Magazine Form
abstract: A printed corporate citizenship report offers a look inside the advertising agency holding group.
lead_paragraph: Who says print is dead? Not the Interpublic Group of Companies, one of the world’s largest agency holding groups, which is publishing its corporate citizenship report, called Stronger, in magazine form in addition to a digital version available online.

headline: Image of the Day: April 21
abstract: HTC, a company based in Taiwan, unveiled new smartphones at a function in New Delhi.

headline: Today in Small Business: What Start-Up Founders Pay Themselves
abstract: Are you a bad boss? Loyalty punch cards are becoming obsolete. Twenty-four cool small businesses in Washington.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Waiting, Hoping and Coming Unraveled
abstract: Disappointment mounts as a couple pursues infertility treatments in Israel.
lead_paragraph: “Do you want to do a retrieval?” my doctor asked.

headline: A Controlling Light Inside the Brain, Diet Doesn’t Matter to Cancer
abstract:
Optogenetics allows the use of light to switch specific brain activity on and off — so what does that tell us? A new look at the effect of nutrition on cancer suggests there’s not much effect at all.
Subscribe to the Podcast »
lead_paragraph:
Optogenetics allows the use of light to switch specific brain activity on and off — so what does that tell us? A new look at the effect of nutrition on cancer suggests there’s not much effect at all.

headline: Syrian Election Announced; Rebels Report New Weapons
abstract: The election, which will almost certainly award Bashar al-Assad a new term, was criticized by the opposition and the United Nations.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Although more than a third of Syria’s population has been displaced by war, the government said Monday that it would conduct a presidential election on June 3, an announcement denounced by the opposition as absurd and criticized by the United Nations as a new subversion of peace efforts.

headline: Spurning Merger Approaches, AstraZeneca Pursues Own Path
abstract: A deal with Pfizer would have been one of the biggest ever in the pharmaceutical industry. But whether such a deal makes sense is another matter.
lead_paragraph: The British drug company AstraZeneca said no to a tie-up with Pfizer, turning down the possibility of one of the biggest drug mergers in recent history.

headline: InBloom Student Data Repository to Close
abstract: The student data warehousing venture that became a lightning rod for some parents’ data privacy and security concerns, announced it would close.
lead_paragraph: In a setback for the nearly $8 billion prekindergarten through 12th-grade education technology software market, inBloom, a non-profit corporation offering to warehouse and manage student data for public school districts across the country, announced on Monday morning that it planned to shut its doors.

headline: Brain Control in a Flash of Light
abstract: Karl Deisseroth is among a group of scientists who have been working on a way to turn brain cells on and off using genetic engineering and light.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Dr. Karl Deisseroth is having a very early breakfast before the day gets going at the annual meeting of the Society for Neuroscience. Thirty thousand people who study the brain are here at the Convention Center, a small city’s worth of badge-wearing, networking, lecture-attending scientists.

headline: Group Led by TPG to Buy Health Care Company for $461 Million
abstract: The offer for Chindex International, a United States company that does business in China, is for $24 a share in cash from a group of investors that outbid a rival suitor.
lead_paragraph: A United States health care company that does business in China has agreed to be sold to a group of investors for $461 million after the investors raised their bid in the face of a rival offer.

headline: Birth Control at 7-Eleven
abstract: Cardinal Timothy Dolan said the birth-control mandate is unnecessary because it’s possible to buy contraceptives at “any shop on any street in America.”
lead_paragraph: There was something illuminating about Cardinal Timothy Dolan’s obtuse remarks on the so-called birth-control mandate.

headline: Washington Company Cancels Russian Theater Festival
abstract: The Woolly Mammoth Theater Company said Russian funding had been withdrawn and corporate sponsorship was hard to find.
lead_paragraph: Citing a rise of anti-American sentiment and a yanking of Russian funds, the Woolly Mammoth Theater Company of Washington has canceled a festival of experimental plays from Moscow that were set to run this fall as part of the company’s 35th anniversary season.

headline: Behind the Poster: ‘Gidion’s Knot’
abstract: School bus colors inspired artwork for a production of Johnna Adams’s play at Kitchen Dog Theater in Dallas.
lead_paragraph: The suicide of a young boy named Gidion pits mother against teacher in Johnna Adams’s dark drama “Gidion’s Knot.” Set inside a primary school classroom, the play unfolds in real-time as the two women discuss the boy’s suspension and other events in the hours before he shot himself to death. The conversation turns into an emotionally fraught confrontation that tackles the issues of parental responsibility, youth violence and schoolyard bullying, with a strange detour into the world of medieval poetry.

headline: ‘Fortress of Solitude’ Musical Among Highlights of New Public Theater Lineup
abstract: A musical based on Jonathan Lethem’s novel “The Fortress of Solitude” will be part of the Public Theater’s 2014-15 schedule.
lead_paragraph: A new musical based on Jonathan Lethem’s acclaimed novel “The Fortress of Solitude,” as well as another new musical by the creators of the Tony Award-winning show “Passing Strange,” are among the productions in the Public Theater’s 2014-15 season line-up that the theater announced on Monday.

headline: 2 Executions in Oklahoma Are Stayed, Ending Tussle
abstract: After a successful challenge of the legality of Oklahoma’s secrecy in obtaining lethal drugs, the State Supreme Court has granted a stay of execution to two men.
lead_paragraph: The Oklahoma Supreme Court stayed the imminent executions of two murderers late Monday, ending a Kafkaesque legal showdown in which courts argued over jurisdiction even though the prisoners had successfully challenged the legality of the state’s secrecy in obtaining lethal drugs.

headline: How a Song Written by Sia Furler Becomes a Hit
abstract: Steve Knopper shares some of Sia Furler’s stories about what it took for her to write chart-topping hits for boldface names of pop music.
lead_paragraph: Last weekend’s magazine featured Steve Knopper’s profile of Sia Furler, who has written songs for artists like Beyoncé, Christina Aguilera and Flo Rida. Below, Knopper shares some of Furler’s stories about her experiences writing what would become hits for some boldface names in pop music.

headline: Holiday Weekend Gun Report: April 18-20, 2014
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: • On Friday, 27-year-old Mohammed Whitaker was charged with 18 felony counts in connection with a dozen shootings that wounded three people on highways in the Kansas City, Mo., area in the past month. Police said more than 100 tips from victims and witnesses poured in, and the suspect had been under surveillance since April 11. They did not reveal a motive.

headline: Ivan Orkin’s Ramen Restaurant to Open on the Lower East Side
abstract: After long construction delays, Ivan Ramen will offer a deeper menu than its sibling at Gotham West Market.
lead_paragraph: Occasionally a chef will do a pop-up in a borrowed kitchen to preview a new restaurant. But Ivan Orkin, the first American chef to open his own ramen shop in Tokyo, has had months of trial runs with his more casual Slurp Shop in the Gotham West Market. “It wasn’t supposed to happen like that,” he said as he was showing off his nearly finished Lower East Side restaurant, called Ivan Ramen. “This place was supposed to come first and the Slurp Shop would be the spinoff.”

headline: Russian Says Ukraine Violated Accord
abstract: Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, accused Ukraine of violating the Geneva agreement and said pro-Russian civilians were asking to be saved.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, accused Ukraine of violating the Geneva agreement and said pro-Russian civilians were asking to be saved.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Hamilton Picks Up a Prize, Prematurely
abstract: Lewis Hamilton took his third Formula One victory this season in a race with an unusual ending; Toyota took the top two slots in the Silverstone endurance race.
lead_paragraph: Lewis Hamilton, driving for Mercedes AMG, held on to beat his teammate, Nico Rosberg, in Sunday’s Chinese Grand Prix. The win came despite an error by the flagman, who waved the checkered flag a lap early.

headline: Obama Names White House Counsel
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama is naming W. Neil Eggleston, a veteran Washington lawyer, as his next White House counsel, according to administration officials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama announced Monday that he was naming W. Neil Eggleston, a veteran lawyer with extensive experience representing government officials in congressional and criminal investigations, as his next White House counsel.

headline: Magic in Service of Truth
abstract: Gabriel García Márquez’s fantastical stories gained dramatic and emotional force from their deep roots in reality.
lead_paragraph: Gabo lives. The extraordinary worldwide attention paid to the death of Gabriel García Márquez, and the genuine sorrow felt by readers everywhere at his passing, tells us that the books are still very much alive. Somewhere a dictatorial “patriarch” is still having his rival cooked and served up to his dinner guests on a great dish; an old colonel is waiting for a letter that never comes; a beautiful young girl is being prostituted by her heartless grandmother; and a kindlier patriarch, José Arcadio Buendía, one of the founders of the new settlement of Macondo, a man interested in science and alchemy, is declaring to his horrified wife that “the earth is round, like an orange.”

headline: A Wine Critic’s Realm Isn’t a Democracy
abstract: A look at the debate over personal opinions versus neutrality on a wine’s style.
lead_paragraph: Heady discussions about the role of the wine critic may strike many people as navel gazing. Yet one issue has bubbled up on social media and blogs repeatedly in the last few months: Should wine critics allow their personal preferences to color their critical views? Or should they remain neutral on questions regarding a wine’s style, regardless of how they feel about it?

headline: Interview: Chris Messina on ‘Alex of Venice’
abstract: The actor Chris Messina discusses his directorial debut “Alex of Venice.”
lead_paragraph: This was one of a series of posts on debuts that originally ran during the 2014 Tribeca Film Festival.

headline: Should Supreme Court Justices Play Politics With Retirement?
abstract: Former Justice John Paul Stevens said it was “appropriate” to consider who one’s successor might be.
lead_paragraph: Former Supreme Court Justice John Paul Stevens’ new book — Six Amendments: How and Why We Should Change the Constitution — comes out tomorrow, and has been getting as much attention as you might expect for a book by a former justice calling for multiple controversial constitutional fixes.

headline: White House Easter Egg Roll Kicks Off
abstract: President Obama and the first lady, Michelle Obama, hosted the annual Easter Egg Roll on the South Lawn of the White House.
lead_paragraph: President Obama and the first lady, Michelle Obama, hosted the annual Easter Egg Roll on the South Lawn of the White House.

headline: Planning a Trip That’s Socially Acceptable
abstract: Two new travel apps are harnessing the power of Facebook to help friends spend some time together.
lead_paragraph: Two new travel apps are harnessing the power of Facebook to help friends spend some time together.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 52
abstract: Ivory Coast is going to Brazil with a star-studded roster, but an aging one.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Ambulances Were Dispatched Late to Fatal Fire in Queens, Official Says
abstract: The cause of the 8-minute delay has yet to be determined, Fire Commissioner Salvatore J. Cassano said.
lead_paragraph: The New York City fire commissioner said on Monday that ambulances were dispatched later than they should have been to a Queens fire that killed two 4-year-old children and injured three other people late Saturday night.

headline: Banking Troubles, but Not a Word About Fraud Claims
abstract: Readers object to euphemistic language about Bank of America’s legal woes.
lead_paragraph: Reading The Times’s coverage of Bank of America’s quarterly loss last week, I almost felt sorry for the financial behemoth. It has mortgage troubles, you see. It has onerous legal costs.

headline: Be Wary of a Big Mining Merger
abstract: Barrick Gold’s incoming chairman will need to persuade shareholders that such a merger with Newmont won’t be another value-destroyer, writes Kevin Allison of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Barrick Gold’s interest in a $33 billion merger with Newmont Mining deserves a skeptical eye.

headline: With Planning Out of the Way, Time to Enjoy the Moment
abstract: Setting fundamental goals, not micromanaging finances, can provide structure without rigidity, a financial planner writes.
lead_paragraph: When we think of financial planning, we naturally focus on the future. We start by getting really clear about where we are today, then we spend time thinking about where we want to be 10, 20 or even 30 years from now. Part of the process includes deciding how much we’ll want to spend, when we’ll want to spend it and how much we can save. Someone has to decide when the plan will end, too, and estimate a year of death, perhaps for two people.

headline: Attackers Said to Single Out South Sudanese by Background
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: In a report, the United Nations confirmed that rebel forces killed hundreds of civilians based on their ethnic origins and nationality.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Hundreds of civilians were killed when South Sudanese rebels took control of a strategic oil-producing town last week, the United Nations confirmed on Monday.

headline: Bucket List Item: White House Easter Egg Roll
keywords: ['White House Building (Washington, DC)', 'Easter and Holy Week']
abstract: Some 30,000 people crowded onto the South Lawn for the 136th annual event, including families whose names were chosen by lottery.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Everly Deml could barely sit still atop her father’s shoulders, her tiny pink shoes bouncing against his chest. President Obama and Michelle Obama had just arrived for the 136th annual White House Easter Egg Roll, but Everly, 2, was angling for a better view of a six-foot-tall Easter bunny on the South Lawn.

headline: For These Females, No Such Thing as Penis Envy
abstract: The females of a kind of Brazilian cave insect have male organs, the males have female genitalia, and sex lasts 40 to 70 hours, a study has found.
lead_paragraph: A Brazilian cave insect has done a most unusual sex-role reversal, a new study finds: Females have penises, and males have vaginas.

headline: Chimps Are Particular About Where They Rest
abstract: A new study shows that chimpanzees in Uganda selected a resilient, high-quality wood to create the nests they used for sleeping in trees.
lead_paragraph: Chimpanzees select firm, resilient wood to make their daily beds in trees, according to a new study in PLOS One. The researchers found that wild chimps at the Toro-Semliki Wildlife Reserve in Uganda used Cynometra alexandri, or Ugandan ironwood, in 73.6 percent of their nests, even though it constituted only 9.6 percent of trees in the study area. Weaving a bed from high-quality wood allows the chimps to safely rest in a prone position. Above, an adult chimp in a C. alexandri tree.

headline: Guidance on Cleaning Mushrooms
abstract: The specks and smears of compost on store-bought mushrooms are basically safe to eat, an expert says.
lead_paragraph: Q. It is often hard to wash off the growing medium from store-bought mushrooms. Is it safe to eat? Should the stems be further trimmed?

headline: Indie Fashion Icons Jennifer Mankins and Jane Mayle on the Evolution of N.Y.C. Style
abstract: The founder of the cult Brooklyn boutique Bird and the beloved women’s wear designer, who is creating a capsule collection for Bird’s 15th anniversary, discuss their reunion and the state of contemporary fashion.
lead_paragraph: “Have I made your life crazy?” the retailer Jennifer Mankins asks the British-born fashion designer Jane Mayle as she greets her in the lounge of New York’s Marlton Hotel. The two have come together on the occasion of the 15th anniversary of Mankins’s Bird, the chain of Brooklyn boutiques that helped popularize a style of easygoing bohemian chic now worn by women in every cool neighborhood in America.

headline: The Trail of Tears, and of Damaged Skulls
abstract: The forced marches of Native Americans in the 19th century left evidence that the stress interfered with the normal growth of their skulls.
lead_paragraph: Evicted from their Southeastern homeland by the federal government in the 1830s, Native Americans were sent on forced marches to eastern Oklahoma that became known as the Trail of Tears, an ordeal of disease, starvation and death. Now a study of Cherokee remains suggests that the stress interfered with the normal growth of their skulls.

headline: Growing Sales for ‘Beautiful’ and ‘Rocky’ on Broadway
abstract: Both new musicals grossed more than $1 million for the first time last week.
lead_paragraph: The new Broadway musicals “Beautiful” and “Rocky” grossed more than $1 million for the first time last week, with the producers of “Beautiful” even sending out a news release on Monday to crow about the box office tally – at a time when “Beautiful” and other shows are trying to show signs of momentum heading into this year’s Tony Awards races. The competition for the best musical Tony is wide open for the first time in years, and four or five nominations for the award will be announced on April 29.

headline: In Performance: Julia Bullock

lead_paragraph: Julia Bullock, a rising soprano from Juilliard, sings “Canción de Cuna Para Dormir a un Negrito.” She is accompanied by the pianist Renate Rohlfing.

headline: An Abridged Version of an Age-Old Story, With a Supper (but Gluten-Free)
abstract: “The Mysteries,” a five-and-a-half hour event at the Flea Theater, uses dozens of actors and writers to condense and perform the Bible.
lead_paragraph: If Ed Sylvanus Iskandar had found himself in the Garden of Eden, he would surely have eaten the forbidden fruit — then made pies from the rest of the apples and served them to all comers. Having distilled the complete works of Sophocles into a single evening of theater (“These Seven Sicknesses”), this ambitious, savvy young director has now commissioned more than 40 playwrights to condense the Old and New Testaments into “The Mysteries,” a five-and-a-half-hour event at the Flea Theater that is both gratifying and grueling.

headline: Ackman and Valeant Prepare Unusual Hostile Bid for Maker of Botox
abstract: The effort to do a deal for Allergan, with a market value of $42 billion, puts together one of the most prominent hedge fund managers with Valeant, a drug maker known for its serial acquisitions.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:12 p.m. | Activist investors are exerting ever more influence on corporate America, pressing companies to cut costs, replace executives and strike deals. On Monday, William A. Ackman, among the brashest men on Wall Street, made perhaps the boldest move yet for an activist.

headline: HBO Renews ‘Silicon Valley’ and ‘Veep’

lead_paragraph: Auto China, held every two years in Beijing to showcase new models directed at the growing Chinese market, opened Sunday in Beijing with a media preview that featured a surprisingly robust display of debutantes from Chinese, European and American automakers.

headline: There Goes the Sun
abstract: Liberals like it, so kill it.
lead_paragraph: Like just about everyone who has looked at the numbers on renewable energy, solar power in particular, I was wowed by the progress. Something really good is in reach.

abstract: The question, analysts say, is how a payments start-up like Square can make itself into more than just another middleman.
lead_paragraph: The payments start-up Square has been considered one of the hottest young companies in Silicon Valley, with a multibillion-dollar valuation. But it now appears to be facing some growing pains.

headline: ECO 348, The Great Recession: Long-Run Fiscal Prospects
abstract: CBO Oh-oh.

headline: If It’s Possible, It Happened
abstract: In his new book, Max Tegmark compellingly argues that everything that can happen does happen — in at least one of an infinite number of universes.
lead_paragraph: Zooming through a Stockholm intersection on his bicycle one morning, 18-year-old Max Tegmark never saw the truck that hit him. The blast of a horn, the screech of tires and a sickening thud followed in quick succession, extinguishing a young life filled with promise.

headline: An Apple a Day, and Other Myths
abstract: The gap grows between food folklore and science on cancer.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — A trip to almost any bookstore or a cruise around the Internet might leave the impression that avoiding cancer is mostly a matter of watching what you eat. One source after another promotes the protective powers of “superfoods,” rich in antioxidants and other phytochemicals, or advises readers to emulate the diets of Chinese peasants or Paleolithic cave dwellers.

headline: Brain-Mapping Milestones
abstract: In further indications of cooperative progress in brain mapping, two separate projects make strides in the creation of cerebral connection atlases.
lead_paragraph: As the Brain Initiative announced by President Obama a year ago continues to set priorities and gear up for what researchers hope will be a decade-long program to understand how the brain works, two projects independent of that effort reached milestones in their brain mapping work.

headline: For Audiences as Varied as an Ark Full of Animals
abstract: The children’s exhibition “Noah’s Ark,” at the Skirball Cultural Center in Los Angeles, helps exemplify that center’s mission to record Jewish heritage and serve a diverse audience.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As you push on metal bars, a towering 16-foot giraffe with a mosaic body stretches its head. Flamingos with fly-swatter feet and pink-purse bodies promenade past, guided by puppeteers. A child turning a crank sets off sparks of lightning, signaling an approaching storm. And a moving rubber ramp lifts small animals, two by two, into an enormous ark made of unpainted fir.

headline: Not Just Playing Around Anymore
abstract: The Games for Change Festival, in partnership with the Tribeca Film Festival for the first time, seeks to use video games to bring about social change.
lead_paragraph: This year, a United Nations program devoted to urban planning in countries affected by poverty or natural disasters began developing a sports field in the slums of Kibera, Kenya, designing it in the popular sandbox video game Minecraft. The game, which allows players to build entire worlds out of cubes in a 3-D environment, helped the project leaders create a visual representation of the field that could be easily understood by the neighborhood’s residents.

headline: Cancer Vaccine Proves Effective in H.I.V. Patients
keywords: ['Human Papillomavirus (HPV)', 'Women and Girls', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Cervical Cancer', 'Gardasil (Vaccine)', 'Vaccination and Immunization']
abstract: Vaccines against cervical cancer work well even in sexually active women with H.I.V., a new study has found.
lead_paragraph: Vaccines against cervical cancer work well even in sexually active women with H.I.V., a new study has found. It also found that women who already have one or two strains of the cancer-causing virus can be protected against others.

headline: Literary Lives Laid Bare by the Nanny
abstract: “Love, Nina” is a collection of letters by Nina Stibbe from when she worked for Mary-Kay Wilmers, longtime editor of The London Review of Books.
lead_paragraph: I do judge books by their covers, sometimes, and the one on “Love, Nina” made me place it in the “probably not” pile. Its bright watercolor artwork (kids, bicycle, vaguely European street scene) suggests a book that’s trying too hard, in the Peter Mayle vein, to be adorable. The subtitle, “A Nanny Writes Home,” doesn’t dispel this impression.

headline: Finding Lyricism in the Contemporary Canon
abstract: The Juilliard School’s contemporary-music ensemble Axiom performed works by Pierre Boulez and Stockhausen on Thursday at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: The scores for “Refrain,” Stockhausen’s 1959 work for three musicians, provoked some titters when they were carried onstage at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday evening. Each of the players was allotted sprawling sheets, a few feet long by a few feet wide, secured on cardboard by binder clips, and half of each sheet was given over to oddly curved musical staves.

headline: Portuguese Drone Program Off to Nonflying Start
abstract: The Portuguese Navy’s fledgling drone program attracted international attention last week because of footage of the failed maiden voyage of a new reconnaissance craft.
lead_paragraph: As the Lisbon daily Público reported, the Portuguese Navy’s fledgling drone program attracted international attention last week because of footage of the failed maiden voyage of a new reconnaissance craft that was quickly viewed hundreds of thousands of times online.

headline: Their Surprise Route to Popularity

lead_paragraph: In sitcoms, it’s been the season of the embarrassing dad. Michael J. Fox, Robin Williams, Christopher Meloni, J. K. Simmons, Beau Bridges, Martin Mull and Peter Riegert have all played lovably messed-up fathers in new shows. (That could be the cast of a pretty good production of “Glengarry Glen Ross.”)

headline: Alone in a Prison Cell With a Tiny Window
abstract: “Solitary Nation,” Tuesdays on PBS, goes inside a prison in Maine where a warden wants to reduce solitary confinement.
lead_paragraph: “Solitary Nation” is about as hopeless an hour of television as you can imagine, which is exactly the reason to watch it. Whatever picture you might have in your mind of the nature of solitary confinement will be changed by this “Frontline” documentary (Tuesday night on PBS stations), and any notions you might have that it could be eliminated will be dimmed.

headline: Mets’ Ron Darling Pitches ‘That Should Be a Word’ Submission
abstract: The magazine hit the pop-culture big time last Friday night, when Ron Darling dropped a One-Page Magazine reference during the Mets’ broadcast.
lead_paragraph: Several months ago, a lot of people around here were absolutely giddy when The New York Times Magazine became a plot device on “House of Cards,” with actual cameos by Matt Bai, our chief political correspondent back then. But for my money, our little publication didn’t really hit the pop-culture big time until last Friday night, when Ron Darling dropped a One-Page Magazine reference during the Mets’ broadcast.

headline: Architect Helps Shape Future of a Building He Had to Leave
abstract: Steven Harris left his TriBeCa loft, the only residence he had ever known in New York, in 2011, but not before he agreed to stay on to shape the building’s future into another luxury loft apartment.
lead_paragraph: One of the happiest moments of the architect Steven Harris’s career arrived as he was being evicted in 2011 from his TriBeCa loft, his home of 34 years.

headline: ‘Saudi America’: Mirage?
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The United States, Canada and Mexico — for different reasons — show renewed promise as producing nations, if significant hurdles can be overcome.
lead_paragraph: At a time when Russia is saber-rattling and the Middle East is in turmoil, a welcome geopolitical trifecta could be in the making. The United States is poised to surpass Saudi Arabia and Russia as the world’s top oil producer. Canada’s oil sands have vaulted the country to energy superpower status. Mexico is embarking on a historic constitutional energy overhaul that its president promises will propel the country’s economy.

headline: Valeant’s History of Deal-Making
abstract: Valeant Pharmaceuticals, which was forged from the merger of Valeant and Biovail in 2010, is known as a serial acquirer.
lead_paragraph: Valeant Pharmaceuticals, which said on Monday that it was teaming up with the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman to bid for the maker of Botox, is no stranger to deal-making.

headline: Tomorrow’s America, in Queens
abstract: How the 1964 World’s Fair previewed a changing country.
lead_paragraph: WHEN the New York World’s Fair opened 50 years ago today in Flushing Meadow Park, in Queens, its president, Robert Moses, hailed it as an immediate success. And while it failed to turn a profit, more than 51 million people visited it over its two six-month seasons, drawn to its shiny corporate pavilions and space age optimism as a welcome distraction for a nation still mourning the death of President John F. Kennedy.

headline: Focus Turns to Samsung’s Patents at Trial

lead_paragraph: Before Monday, the focus of the latest Apple and Samsung patent trial was whether Samsung copied Apple. But on Monday, Samsung said Apple has done some copying of its own — including a method for transmitting video over wireless devices.

headline: Cameron’s Description of Britain as ‘Christian Country’ Draws an Angry Response
keywords: ['Religion and Belief', 'Easter and Holy Week', 'ANGLICAN CHURCHES', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Immigration and Emigration']
