headline: Keystone Pipeline May Be Big, but This Is Bigger
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Keystone Pipeline System', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Global Warming']
abstract: The proposed pipeline’s effect on emissions would be negligible — nascent regulations on emissions from coal and cars would have a far greater impact on global warming.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THE Keystone XL pipeline is a great political symbol. The proposed 1,700-mile pipeline, which would carry 830,000 barrels daily of carbon-heavy crude from Canada’s Alberta oil sands to Gulf Coast refineries, has galvanized environmental activists, who call it a litmus test for President Obama’s commitment to fighting climate change. It is a political weapon against Mr. Obama for Republicans, who call it a symbol of job creation and energy security. It has motivated liberal donors, led by the California billionaire Tom Steyer, who has personally urged Mr. Obama to reject the pipeline.

headline: Autism and the Agitator
abstract: Jenny McCarthy got a crazy amount of traction. She shouldn’t get a whitewash.
lead_paragraph: What do you call someone who sows misinformation, stokes fear, abets behavior that endangers people’s health, extracts enormous visibility from doing so and then says the equivalent of “Who? Me?”

headline: Defendant Killed by Court Officer at Utah Trial
abstract: The defendant in a long-running gang prosecution was shot and killed by a United States marshal in Salt Lake City after he lunged to attack a witness testifying in his trial, federal authorities said.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — With stunned jurors looking on, a defendant in a long-running gang prosecution was shot and killed by a deputy United States marshal in the federal courthouse here on Monday morning after he lunged to attack a witness testifying in his trial, federal authorities said.

headline: Drones Are Becoming Energy’s New Roustabouts
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Energy and Power', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: Drones are now being used to monitor power lines, inspect oil and gas pipelines, check wind turbines for defects and pinpoint malfunctioning solar panels.
lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — THE egg white drone lifted off from its ground station at a hospital construction site here, hovered for an instant, then zoomed off, sounding like a five-pound bee as it buzzed around the cranes towering over the six-acre project.

headline: Ice or Molten Salt, Not Batteries, to Store Energy
abstract: Batteries have their uses for storing electricity, but accumulating power at night when the wind blows or during the day when the sun shines is still not economically feasible on a large scale.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — ENERGY storage is crucial to transforming the electric grid into a clean, sustainable, low-emissions system, the experts say. And it’s happening already, just not the way most consumers would expect.

headline: Skeptical Justice Scolds Coca-Cola on Juice Label
keywords: ['Labeling and Labels', 'Soft Drinks', 'Consumer Protection', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: A lawyer for Coca-Cola remained poised under sometimes harsh questioning on its Pomegranate Blueberry juice blend, which contains only notes of either fruit.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Not long after a lawyer for Coca-Cola started to defend its label for a blended fruit juice at a Supreme Court argument on Monday, Justice Anthony M. Kennedy subjected her to a series of unusually harsh questions.

headline: We Could See You in the Gas Tank Later, Alligator
abstract: Chemists and engineers at the University of Louisiana, Lafayette, have been investigating the possibility of producing biodiesel from an unusual source: alligators.
lead_paragraph: PRODUCTION of biodiesel as an alternative to fossil fuels is on the rise in the United States, and one reason, proponents say, is that it can be made from a long list of raw materials.

headline: When Lending a Player Can Be Self-Defeating
abstract: When Chelsea lent goalkeeper Thibaut Courtois to Atlético Madrid, it could not have imagined the teams would meet in a Champions League semifinal.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Imagine that you own an unusually large number of sand buckets. You have so many, in fact, that when you go to the beach one morning, someone immediately asks if they can borrow one, and you happily agree. It is one fewer to carry, after all, and you probably would not have used it anyway.

headline: The End, or Something
abstract: I knew what was going to happen, I just didn’t write it down – like George Costanza in a board meeting, know when you’ve peaked and get out fast.
lead_paragraph: My new editor and I were sharing a celebratory drink at a swanky Lower Manhattan bar, like a pair of characters in my first novel, which she would publish in less than a year. She said that everyone loved it, there was only one concern: It did not have an ending. I explained that it did have an ending, it was just an ambiguous one.

headline: Shunning Gas Hogs, Athletes Green Their Rides
keywords: ['Athletics and Sports', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming']
abstract: Some of the best-paid athletes, who can afford any car, are shunning gas guzzlers and driving hybrids and electric vehicles with minimal or no tailpipe emissions.
lead_paragraph: JEREMY GUTHRIE considers himself easygoing and comfortable with his beliefs, including how he feels about the environment.

headline: Boy Scout Troop Loses Charter Over Gay Leader
abstract: The decision bars a church-sponsored troop in south Seattle from using logos, uniforms or names associated with the Boy Scouts as long as the gay scoutmaster remains in charge.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The Boy Scouts of America, which voted last year to allow gay scouts but not openly gay scout leaders, has revoked the charter of a church-sponsored troop here for refusing to fire its adult gay scoutmaster.

headline: Supreme Court Weighs Aid to Holders of Argentine Debt
abstract: Holders of defaulted Argentine bonds are seeking subpoenas to document its assets and collect on court judgments.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday seemed inclined to offer at least modest help to Argentina’s creditors.

headline: Iran Disputes Reports of Violent Crackdown in Prison’s Political Detainee Block
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Political Prisoners', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: News accounts of more than 30 detainees being injured or placed in solitary confinement set off a rare protest outside Parliament on Sunday, but officials deny the reports.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s penal authorities sought on Monday to discredit reports of a violent clash last week inside the political detainee block in Tehran’s Evin Prison, calling them fabrications fomented by enemies of the government.

headline: Vietnam Returns Migrants to China After Deadly Border Clash
abstract: A photograph suggests the migrants may be part of the Uighur ethnic minority, whose members complain of oppression in China.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Vietnamese authorities have returned to the Chinese government 11 Chinese migrants and the bodies of five others after members of the group were involved in a deadly clash with Vietnamese border guards last Friday, according to a Vietnamese news report.

headline: Linking the Los Angeles Airport
abstract: A surge of rail construction could bring a project closer to fruition after years of disagreements.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The two concrete nubs, dotted with rusted sticks of rebar, that protrude from the elevated rail tracks near Aviation Boulevard are reminders of the unfulfilled promise that came nearly 25 years ago with the restart of a rail system here.

headline: Answering an Emergency Call: Yes, There Is a Doctor on Board
abstract: Suber Huang, a retinal surgeon at University Hospitals Case Medical Center in Cleveland, said he once looked after a woman needing care on a flight.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I travel, I try to remember a quotation often attributed to William Butler Yeats that there are no strangers, only friends you have not yet met.

headline: Pakistan: Unicef Workers Freed
abstract: Two Unicef staff members who were abducted last week in Pakistan’s southern port city of Karachi have been released.
lead_paragraph: Two Unicef staff members who were abducted last week in Pakistan’s southern port city of Karachi have been released, a spokesman for the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, said Monday. The spokesman, Stéphane Dujarric, said the two were safe and well, but he had no other details. It was not clear who had abducted them or why they had been freed. Foreign aid workers in Pakistan have been increasingly singled out by jihadist insurgents for kidnappings and attacks. At least 12 United Nations staff members have been killed in Pakistan since January 2009. Some of the assaults have been tied to Taliban retributions for efforts by Unicef and other international aid groups to vaccinate children against polio, which has been spreading in Pakistan, particularly in the northwest tribal areas. Some Taliban leaders have said vaccine workers are Western spies using the guise of humanitarian aid to gather intelligence information.

headline: The Value of Unused Tickets? Airlines Won’t Say
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Airport Security', 'AIRPORTS']
abstract: Ralph Nader, the consumer activist, is pushing airlines to disclose the size of the windfall from expired tickets.
lead_paragraph: HERE is the explanation for why I booked two one-way trips for the same day, from two different cities 2,500 miles apart. It involves parrots and construction workers.

headline: The Tyranny of the Glass Boxes
abstract: The city’s Landmarks Preservation Commission needs to revise the process for protecting the old buildings that give New York City its character.
lead_paragraph: One57, the luxury condominium skyscraper under development just south of Central Park, lists several neighborhood attractions on its website. Among them is the Rizzoli Bookstore, which for decades operated out of a roughly 100-year-old neo-French Classical townhouse at 31 West 57th Street.

headline: Yes, Tanaka Can Still Remember How It Feels to Lose
abstract: The rookie pitcher Masahiro Tanaka of the Yankees is scheduled to make his Fenway Park debut Tuesday while riding a 30-0 streak he began in Japan in August 2012.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The feeling Masahiro Tanaka had Aug. 19, 2012, must have been so bad that he resolved not to feel it again for a long, long time. That was the date of Tanaka’s last loss in a regular-season game.

headline: Netflix Says It Opposes Comcast’s Merger Bid
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Cable Television', 'Television', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Net Neutrality']
abstract: It was the clearest statement on the merger from Netflix, nearly two months after it agreed to pay Comcast for a more direct connection to the cable operator’s Internet backbone.
lead_paragraph: Netflix on Monday voiced strong opposition to Comcast’s planned $45 billion takeover of Time Warner Cable, even while confirming that it was raising subscription prices.

headline: The Leadership Emotions
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Consultants', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Political leaders have come to rely primarily on consultants’ carefully crafted, poll-based political advice, which can obscure the moral impulses necessary for leadership.
lead_paragraph: Throughout American history, most presidents had small personal staffs. They steered through political waters as amateurs, relying on experience, instinct and conversations with friends.

headline: No Corrections: April 21, 2014
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on April 21, 2014.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print.

headline: Wage Theft Across the Board
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'United States Economy', 'Editorials', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: An antitrust lawsuit filed by highly paid software engineers shows that the problem of wage theft is not confined to service-sector employees.
lead_paragraph: When labor advocates and law enforcement officials talk about wage theft, they are usually referring to situations in which low-wage service-sector employees are forced to work off the clock, paid subminimum wages, cheated out of overtime pay or denied their tips. It is a huge and underpoliced problem. It is also, it turns out, not confined to low-wage workers.

headline: For a New Burt’s Bees Line, Check Your Calendar
abstract: The personal care brand Burt’s Bees is promoting anti-aging products in messages that will appear as appointments in electronic calendars.
lead_paragraph: WHILE it may seem that advertising is everywhere, one place marketers have not infiltrated is the popular calendar software on computers, smartphones and tablets. But now, in what Burt’s Bees says is a marketing first, the natural personal care brand is introducing promotional messages that will appear as appointments in electronic calendars like those by Microsoft, Apple, Google and Yahoo.

headline: Investigated by China’s Leaders, Powerful Family Has a Defender: Its Hometown
abstract: As China pursues a graft investigation against the family of Zhou Yongkang, many in its home village are quick to dispute reports.
lead_paragraph: XIQIANTOU, China — Older villagers knew the eel fisherman’s boy who would become one of China’s most fearsome men. Until recently, his two younger brothers were their neighbors. “All three brothers were good people,” said a 69-year-old woman who lived next door. “They would not do bad things.”

headline: Transparency on Targeted Killings
keywords: ['Targeted Killings', 'Freedom of Information Act', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: In an important decision, a federal appeals court panel refused to go along with the Obama administration’s claim to secrecy and unilateral authority.
lead_paragraph: For years now, the Obama administration has been playing a self-serving and duplicitous game over its power to kill people away from any battlefield and without judicial oversight or accountability. It has trotted out successive officials and doled out tidbits of information attesting to the legality of President Obama’s claim to unilateral authority to carry out such killings, while withholding information essential to evaluating that aggressive claim of executive power.

headline: The Real Port Authority Scandal
abstract: Should we be financing empty office space in a half-filled building or upkeep on our roads and bridges?
lead_paragraph: This is a column about the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, but you won’t read a word in here about the lane-closing scandal in Fort Lee, N.J. This is about another scandal, one that has been going for on so long that people don’t even think of it as scandalous. Indeed, it involves no illegality whatsoever. But that doesn’t mean it isn’t a scandal.

headline: Oklahoma Supreme Court Ruling to Stay Executions
abstract: The Oklahoma Supreme Court stayed the imminent executions of two murderers who had successfully challenged the legality of the state’s secrecy in obtaining lethal drugs.
lead_paragraph: The Oklahoma Supreme Court stayed the imminent executions of two murderers who had successfully challenged the legality of the state’s secrecy in obtaining lethal drugs.

headline: Hamish Maxwell, Philip Morris Empire Builder, Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Maxwell’s acquisitions helped Philip Morris become a consumer products giant.
lead_paragraph: Hamish Maxwell, whose acquisitions of food companies in the 1980s turned Philip Morris into a consumer products colossus, died on Saturday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 87.

headline: The Lives of Emma Edmonds
keywords: ['Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The amazing story of a woman who went undercover as a man to spy for the Union.
lead_paragraph: In 1864, with huge casualties from battles in Virginia’s Shenandoah Valley, the Union enlisted thousands of volunteer nurses from the North, among them a reclusive 23-year-old woman named Sarah Emma Edmonds. But this wasn’t the first time Edmonds had volunteered for service. Nor was there any indication that this shy woman nursing soldiers in West Virginia had spent years behind enemy lines as a spy

headline: Battling for a Safer Bangladesh
keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Rana Plaza Building Collapse, Bangladesh (2013)', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Rival factions of retailers are trying to prevent another catastrophic collapse or fire, but they don’t see eye to eye.
lead_paragraph: After the Spectrum sweater factory collapsed in 2005, killing 64 workers, hardly anything changed to improve factory safety in Bangladesh.

headline: Looking at Costs and Risks, Many Skip Health Insurance
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Americans who have chosen to be uninsured cited cost, frustration and ideology as some of the reasons they sat out the first open enrollment period of the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Steve Huber, an affable salesman who is still paying off an unexpected medical bill, was not among the millions of Americans who signed up for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act during the enrollment period that ended March 31.

headline: Panel Tells Port Authority to Lessen Governors’ Sway
abstract: “There should be no secret votes,” said one of the panelists invited to suggest ways to fix the beleaguered bistate agency.
lead_paragraph: For an agency that has conducted most of its business behind closed doors for decades, the meeting the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey held on Monday morning was indisputably extraordinary.

headline: A Restorative Triumph After the Bomb Blasts
abstract: No runners showed more resilience at the Boston Marathon than a group of 28 who were injured in last year’s bombing and ran Monday as a form of therapy and a show of defiance.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The white T-shirts said 4.15 Strong on the front and Survivor on the back.

headline: Companies Built on Sharing Balk When It Comes to Regulators
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Start-ups', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Entrepreneurship']
abstract: In the sharing economy, safety issues, taxes and regulation have tended to be an afterthought. But now, regulators and officials are questioning the practices of start-ups like Airbnb and Uber.
lead_paragraph: In the newfangled sharing economy, questions about safety, taxes and regulation have tended to be an afterthought. That has helped propel companies like Uber, Airbnb and Lyft into the stratosphere.

headline: Under Russia, Life in Crimea Grows Chaotic
abstract: A month after the lightning annexation of Crimea, residents find themselves in a state of confusion, with few institutions functioning normally, including banks, courts and foreign businesses.
lead_paragraph: SIMFEROPOL, Crimea — After Russia annexed Crimea practically overnight, the Russian bureaucrats handling passports and residence permits inhabited the building of their Ukrainian predecessors, where Roman Nikolayev now waits daily with a seemingly mundane question.

headline: Indictment Details How to Forge a Masterpiece
abstract: The case upended the art world, where many dealers, collectors and experts were duped by Pei-Shen Qian’s deft forgeries of Abstract Expressionist masters and by the actions of two largely unknown art dealers.
lead_paragraph: The painting caught Pei-Shen Qian’s eye, but it was the price that affected him deeply.

headline: Dancing Gertrude Stein, Surrounded by Wonders
abstract: Gertrude Stein’s “The World Is Round,” a 1930s children’s book about a girl named Rose, is brought to life by the Ripe Time ensemble at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: In her 1934 lecture “Plays,” Gertrude Stein wondered, “What is the use of telling a story since there are so many and everybody knows so many.” You might ask the same question, gently, of Ripe Time’s “The World Is Round,” a tender and sassy adaptation of Stein’s opaque children’s book at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Fisher Theater.

headline: A Journey to Intimacy That’s Nobody’s Business but Their Own
abstract: “Your Mother’s Copy of the Kama Sutra,” a new play by Kirk Lynn, involves an unusual yearlong test on the way to a marriage that might or might not happen.
lead_paragraph: If the title “Your Mother’s Copy of the Kama Sutra” doesn’t give you the heebie-jeebies (isn’t your mother’s copy of “Fifty Shades of Grey” mortifying enough?), rest assured that something in this new play by Kirk Lynn certainly will.

headline: Watch Out: The Ex-Wife Has Arrived, and She’s Got Lots of Baggage
abstract: Sharr White’s new play, “Annapurna,” often feels like a scruffier version of a Lifetime television movie about love gone wrong.
lead_paragraph: Plays with just two characters usually move in one of two directions: from animosity to comity, or vice versa. “Annapurna,” a new play by Sharr White starring Megan Mullally and Nick Offerman, is definitely the kind that begins in full battle.

headline: Talking Mom Out of Bombing the Brownstone
abstract: “The Velocity of Autumn,” starring Estelle Parsons and Stephen Spinella, is a wispy but amiable comedy-drama about the ravages of getting older.
lead_paragraph: Estelle Parsons, the great actor who stars as an embattled but indomitable Brooklyn painter in “The Velocity of Autumn,” a new play by Eric Coble, seems to be living an eternal springtime. Now 86, Ms. Parsons has lost little, if any, of her energy, and absolutely none of her ability to bring sustained, animated life to a well-drawn character. She never leaves the stage during this 90-minute, two-character play, which opened on Monday night at the Booth Theater, and yet she seems daisy-fresh at the curtain call, as if ready to run a half-marathon as an encore.

headline: It May Be Read to a Miscreant
abstract: Ed Sessa keeps our eyes moving.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — You are getting sleepy … keep your eyes on the circled/shaded squares in Ed Sessa’s puzzle and when you are feeling really, really relaxed, make the check out to me and send it to … never mind. Just kidding.

headline: U.S. Drones and Yemeni Forces Kill Qaeda-Linked Fighters, Officials Say
abstract: Yemen’s Interior Ministry said Monday that as many as 55 militants had been killed in one of the largest such attacks there in months.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American drones and Yemeni counterterrorism forces killed more than three dozen militants linked to Al Qaeda’s affiliate in Yemen over the weekend in one of the largest such attacks there in months, officials from both countries said Monday.

headline: Do the Rich Call the Shots?
abstract: Has the United States become more of an oligarchy than a democracy, with the economic elite holding more influence than the public on policy?

headline: Waiting Lists for Kindergarten Drop by Half, New York City Says
abstract: In some neighborhoods, the process of applying for kindergarten has come to resemble a mini-Ivy League, with parents hiring consultants, touring scores of schools and inundating online forums.
lead_paragraph: The number of students placed on waiting lists for kindergarten dropped by half this year as New York City’s Education Department used a new strategy for matching students with schools, officials said on Monday.

headline: As Jets Start Workouts, They Hope to Build on a Positive Ending
abstract: The Jets have not finished with a winning record or reached the postseason for three seasons running, and their quest to deliver began Monday, the first day of off-season voluntary workouts.
lead_paragraph: The Jets had last assembled the day after their season ended at Miami, where they toasted the present and the future — the victory that evened their record at 8-8 and the news that their beloved coach, Rex Ryan, had been retained. They filed into their New Jersey practice complex on Monday, nearly four months later, with a comparable level of excitement, to hear what could be construed as a continuation of Ryan’s post-mortem speech from December.

headline: Mexico Honors a Colombian Writer Whom Many Considered One of Their Own
keywords: ['Funerals and Memorials', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: For some writers and admirers, it seemed fitting that the first public memorial service for Gabriel García Márquez took place in Mexico City, where he had lived for many years.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Every March, often with a yellow flower pinned to his lapel, Gabriel García Márquez stood on the stoop of his home here to greet well-wishers on his birthday.

headline: Analysis of Airbnb Listings
abstract: In an affidavit filed in New York State Supreme Court, the director of research for the state attorney general noted that of the more than 19,500 listings on Airbnb in New York at the end of January, the majority were for an entire apartment.
lead_paragraph: In an affidavit filed in New York State Supreme Court, the director of research for the state attorney general noted that of the more than 19,500 listings on Airbnb in New York at the end of January, the majority were for an entire apartment.

headline: Mayoral First Couple Talk About Love and Hard Times
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio and his wife, Chirlane McCray, visited ABC’s daytime talk show “The View” on Monday and spoke of personal hard times, city initiatives and love.
lead_paragraph: In his first few months as mayor of New York, Bill de Blasio has rarely passed up a chance to dote on his wife, Chirlane McCray, from behind a lectern. On Monday he took his wife and his mushy, gushy expressiveness to the couch — and the nationwide audience — of ABC’s daytime talk show “The View.”

headline: Ukrainian Roma Face Threats and Violence
abstract: Roma in Ukraine said that the homes of seven of the 150 Roma families in Slovyansk were robbed by masked, armed men over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: Roma in Ukraine said that the homes of seven of the 150 Roma families in Slovyansk were robbed by masked, armed men over the weekend.

abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: April 21, 2014

headline: When It Comes to Fatherhood, It Seems Christie Knows Best
abstract: A nonprofit group surprises Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey — and his four children — with an award that dates to the 1940s.
lead_paragraph: This has not, suffice it to say, been a season of accolades for Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey.

headline: A Driver’s Bloody Run-In With an Angry Detroit
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Assaults', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: After a driver hit a 10-year-old boy, a crowd beat him until he was unconscious, stopping only when a retired nurse intervened. Five young men face charges in the case.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Steve Utash had driven the same streets through this city for years on the way to his tree trimming jobs or his home in the suburbs. But one afternoon this month, along this familiar route, he found a side of Detroit he had never encountered, a Detroit where racial tension, churning just below the surface, can break into lawlessness in broad daylight. He found a side where people sometimes talk about meting out justice on their own, mostly because they say they cannot be sure when, or if, the police will show up.

headline: Boy Who Hid in Plane’s Wheel Well Beat Long Odds in Surviving 5 ½-Hour Flight
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Airport Security', 'AIRPORTS']
abstract: The 15-year-old runaway apparently spent most of the flight unconscious in the freezing, low-oxygen, wheel storage compartment.
lead_paragraph: Jumping a deteriorating airport fence, running across the airport unobserved in the darkness and climbing into the wheel well of a parked Boeing 767, as a California teenager did on Sunday, is not all that difficult, according to experts, but surviving the trip — in this case, a five-and-a-half-hour flight from San Jose, Calif., to Maui, Hawaii — is extraordinary.

headline: Nets’ Anderson Has World of Experience in Pressure Situations
abstract: Alan Anderson is one of five Nets players making his N.B.A. postseason debut, but during a nine-year professional career, he has played for teams in eight countries.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Alan Anderson is one of five players on the Nets’ roster making his N.B.A. postseason debut during the first-round series against the Toronto Raptors. But to lump him with the other playoff initiates would be a mistake.

headline: Nepalese Government to Set Up Relief Fund for Sherpas
keywords: ['Sherpas (Himalayan People)', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Mountain Climbing', 'Avalanches', "Workers' Compensation Insurance", 'Mountains']
abstract: A day after Sherpas threatened to cancel expeditions up Mount Everest, the government announced that some of the revenue from the treks would be set aside for future aid.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The government of Nepal has agreed to create a relief fund for Sherpa mountain climbers who are injured or killed in accidents and to make other concessions to the Sherpas, according to an official at the Ministry of Culture, Tourism and Civil Aviation. The official, Sushil Ghimire, said some of the revenue the government gets from expeditions to Mount Everest would be set aside for the fund.

headline: Seeking a Museum With a Funny Bone, Starting From Scratch
abstract: A museum of humor is being proposed, and an advisory panel, which includes a clown, has been assembled.
lead_paragraph: Gabrovo, Bulgaria, is the home of the celebrated House of Humor and Satire. Odessa in Ukraine plays host to the famed Humorina festival. A Museum of Comedy is being planned for a church crypt in London.

headline: Intelligence Chief Issues Limits on Press Contacts
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The Obama administration has barred officials at 17 agencies from speaking to journalists about unclassified intelligence-related topics without permission, according to a newly disclosed directive.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has barred officials at 17 agencies from speaking to journalists about unclassified intelligence-related topics without permission, according to a newly disclosed directive.

headline: Mejia Shows Why Mets Can Rely on the Rotation
abstract: Jenrry Mejia struck out seven Cardinals and improved to 3-0 in his first start since he left a game with a blister.
lead_paragraph: The home fans stood and applauded Jenrry Mejia as he walked off the field during the seventh inning Monday night. He had held the Cardinals scoreless, at times baffling them, and seemed to have grown up a little. This was perhaps his best start this season. He crossed his heart, kissed his hand and pointed to the sky.

headline: Voices From Donetsk
abstract: In Donetsk, Ukraine, pro-Russian residents spoke out about Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s visit and America’s role in the conflict between Russia and Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: In Donetsk, Ukraine, pro-Russian residents spoke out about Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s visit and America’s role in the conflict between Russia and Ukraine.

headline: Beleaguered Albuquerque Department Reports Another Fatal Shooting by Police
abstract: Days after the Justice Department criticized Albuquerque police for its repetitive, “unconstitutional use of deadly force,” an officer fatally shot a suspected car thief.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — An Albuquerque police officer fatally shot a suspected car thief on Monday during a foot chase in which, officials said, the suspect pointed a gun at the officer as he closed in on her. The shooting occurred 11 days after the Justice Department rebuked the Police Department for engaging in a “pattern or practice of unconstitutional use of deadly force.”

headline: Russia Displays a New Military Prowess in Ukraine’s East
abstract: Russian forces skillfully employed 21st-century tactics that combined cyberwarfare, an energetic information campaign and the use of highly trained special operation troops in its annexation of Crimea.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry has accused Russia of behaving in a “19th-century fashion” because of its annexation of Crimea.

headline: Decades in Prison Sought for CityTime Scheme
abstract: Federal prosecutors, saying the financial crime was one of the worst against New York City, asked a judge to impose sentences of 105 years, 80 years and up to 40 years on three defendants.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have asked a judge to impose sentences of 105 years, 80 years and up to 40 years on three men who the government has said became “unbelievably rich” in connection with New York City’s scandal-marred payroll modernization project known as CityTime.

headline: Rangers Calmly Disagree With Two Diving Penalties
abstract: The Rangers are 3 for 12 on power plays in the series, but two offsetting diving penalties in Game 2 cost them.
lead_paragraph: Any small advantage, gained or lost, can deeply affect a series as close as the first-round playoff matchup between the Rangers and the Flyers, which continues Tuesday with Game 3 in Philadelphia.

headline: Obama’s Strategic Shift to Asia Is Hobbled by Pressure at Home and Crises Abroad
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: President Obama is expected to announce an agreement with the Philippines next Monday that would help facilitate a stronger American military presence there, but the deal could antagonize China.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama is expected to announce an agreement with the Philippines next Monday that would give American ships and planes the most extensive access to bases there since the United States relinquished its vast naval installation at Subic Bay in 1992.

headline: Even With Dying Boxer’s Appeal, a Tough Road Ahead for Convicted Man
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: Shortly before dying, Rubin (Hurricane) Carter made one last plea for the Brooklyn district attorney to revisit the 1986 murder and kidnapping conviction of David McCallum, who says he is innocent.
lead_paragraph: It was the dying wish of the former prizefighter Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, a man whose life had come to symbolize how the justice system can go terribly awry: to see David McCallum, a Brooklyn man who had written to him from prison and asked for his help in overturning his murder conviction, go free.

headline: Official Denies F.B.I. Was Investigating Manifesto Leak
abstract: A Justice Department official denied Monday that the F.B.I. had investigated how a manifesto by Khalid Shaikh Mohammed ended up at The Huffington Post.
lead_paragraph: A Justice Department official denied Monday that the F.B.I. had investigated how a manifesto by Khalid Shaikh Mohammed ended up at The Huffington Post. It came to light last week that agents had approached a member of the defense team for a detainee facing trial before a military commission over the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. He was asked to sign a confidentiality agreement, something the defense lawyers said improperly made him an informant. The disclosure derailed a week of pretrial hearings, and the special trial counsel, Fernando Campoamor-Sanchez, an assistant United States attorney, is leading an investigation into the matter. It was widely speculated that the subject of the F.B.I. inquiry was how the 36-page manuscript by Mr. Mohammed — the self-described architect of the attacks — had been leaked. But in a public court filing on Monday, Mr. Campoamor-Sanchez said that was not true. He did not identify the investigation’s actual subject, although he apparently offered greater details to the judge in an accompanying classified filing.

headline: Two Wounded in National Zoo Shooting
abstract: Two people were wounded in a shooting Monday evening that shut down the National Zoo on an unusually busy day.
lead_paragraph: Two people were wounded in a shooting Monday evening that shut down the National Zoo on an unusually busy day. At least one suspect — initial reports said there were two — was being sought in the shooting, which occurred at the zoo’s entrance just before 6 p.m., the Washington police said. The police said the victims’ injuries were not life-threatening, but both were taken to a hospital for treatment. Police officials said they did not know what led to the shooting.

headline: Student Loans Can Suddenly Come Due When Co-Signers Die, a Report Finds
abstract: Even borrowers with spotless records are facing demands for early repayment of their loans, and some are being forced into default, a federal consumer protection agency said.
lead_paragraph: For students who borrow on the private market to pay for school, the death of a parent can come with an unexpected, added blow, a federal watchdog warns. Even borrowers who have good payment records can face sudden demands for full, early repayment of those loans, and can be forced into default.

headline: Word of the Day | suffragist
abstract: This word has appeared in 28 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: suffragist• \ˈsəf-ri-jist\• noun

headline: Utility Poles Generate Heat From Long Island Residents
abstract: Despite assurances that the 70-foot poles will resist storms better and increase power transmission, many people are outraged.
lead_paragraph: PORT WASHINGTON, N.Y. — Rich Bentley first noticed them in Manhasset Valley Park, and thought they were for coming field lights. Other homeowners on the North Shore of Long Island began spotting them, too: towering wooden poles with big round pulleys that resemble dream catchers, outside their windows in the thick of newly amputated trees.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13, 49) A FIERCE GREEN FIRE (2013) At one time, it was about the dams. The naturalist John Muir and the forester Gifford Pinchot waged war in the early 1900s over the flooding of the magnificent Hetch Hetchy Valley in Yosemite National Park. Decades later, the proposed damming of the Colorado River prompted public outrage, and the environmental movement was born. Today some two million organizations worldwide work on behalf of social justice and the environment. In this Earth Day tribute, “American Masters” chronicles issues (pollution, whaling, conservation of the Amazon rain forest, climate change) within the fight and the players who made a difference (Lois Gibbs, who rallied on behalf of Love Canal; David Brower, above, the first executive director of the Sierra Club; and Paul Watson and Rex Weyler, the founders of Greenpeace). “The environmental movement is about nature versus humanity,” says Robert Redford, who with Meryl Streep, Ashley Judd, Van Jones and Isabel Allende narrates this documentary, directed by Mark Kitchell. “It arose at a time when our industrial civilization has grown so powerful it threatens the natural world on which we depend for survival. It has become the battle for a living planet.”

headline: If a Bubble Bursts in Palo Alto, Does It Make a Sound?
abstract: Silicon Valley’s isolation from the rest of the economy guarantees it can’t hurt us (or help us) much.
lead_paragraph: This year, Facebook purchased the mobile-messaging application WhatsApp for $19 billion, or about $350 million per employee and $40 per user, only some of whom even pay the $1 annual fee for the advertisement-free platform. But what was perhaps most remarkable about Facebook’s acquisition of WhatsApp was that the start-up was making any money in the first place. In recent years, Facebook has shelled out 10-figure sums for Instagram and the virtual-reality headset maker Oculus V.R., both of which had scant or no revenue. Ditto for the safe-sexting-enabler Snapchat, which reportedly turned down a $3 billion offer from Mark Zuckerberg.

Her body was a wreck, and she said the race was more painful than childbirth. Yet she scores it as one of the best experiences of her life.

To take the Senate and consolidate their control of Congress, Republicans need only extend their stranglehold on Dixie to Arkansas, Louisiana and North Carolina, all of which voted for Mitt Romney in the 2012 presidential election.

To read about the machinery behind our model — how it combines polls, analyzes other information and deals with uncertainty — we have put together an FAQ.

headline: Back Story: How We Found the Income Data
abstract: For 15 years, an economics writer sought a data set that compared incomes across countries.
lead_paragraph: Late last year, while reading a new book by the economist Angus Deaton, I came across a sentence that hinted at a solution to one of my biggest frustrations as an economics journalist.

headline: Charles Rangel, the veteran New York Democrat, wants you to know that he’s the tops.
abstract: But there’s a significant catch: The rankings are based on a single, misleading metric.
lead_paragraph: His official site, using the less-than-subtle URL of rangel.house.gov/NumberOne, proclaims that Mr. Rangel ranks first in productivity among members of Congress, according to a list generated by TrackBill, a legislative research service. But there’s a significant catch: The rankings are based on a single metric — the percentage of bills sponsored that have passed. So the list is dominated by lawmakers holding committee and subcommittee chairs, which are the gatekeepers for most bills. Of Mr. Rangel’s 41 pieces of legislation that have passed since 2003, when TrackBill started counting, only one was passed in the past three years. Most occurred while he was chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, which has jurisdiction over tax issues.

abstract: It’s easy to fall into the trap of putting too much weight on small differences in probabilities on either side of 50 percent.

We think the better way to describe the race is as a toss-up, and we suggest keeping two things in mind:

headline: Inequality 1992

lead_paragraph: I happened to notice Greg Mankiw citing some bogus claims that the one percent is an ever-changing group, not a persistent elite, and I thought “Wait — didn’t we deal with that one long ago?” And that brought to mind the piece I wrote for the American Prospect 22 years ago, “The rich, the right, and the facts.” (It doesn’t say this on the Prospect site, but it was indeed published in 1992). headline: Class-Ridden America
abstract: The rich think differently from you and me.
lead_paragraph: Via Mark Thoma, Larry Bartels produces the ultimate anti-Santorum argument. Santorum, you may recall, declared that we have no classes in America — even the term middle class, he says, is “Marxism talk“. The usual response is to point to the data and say that objectively we are indeed a class society.

headline: Ackman’s Botox Ambitions
abstract: William A. Ackman and Valeant are bidding for Allergan, the maker of Botox. | Novartis announced a major overhaul. | AstraZeneca says no to a deal with Pfizer. | Barclays is set to exit its commodities business.
lead_paragraph: William A. Ackman, one of the brashest men on Wall Street, has come up with perhaps the boldest move yet for an activist: He has teamed up with the health care company Valeant to bid roughly $50 billion for Allergan, the maker of Botox, David Gelles, Michael J. de la Merced and Alexandra Stevenson write in DealBook. The offer by Valeant is expected to be announced Tuesday morning.

headline: This simple table summarizes our story on American living standards.
abstract: A quick look shows what has happened to incomes in recent decades.
lead_paragraph: In 1980, the American rich and middle class and most of the poor had higher incomes than their counterparts almost anywhere in the world. But incomes for the middle class and poor in the United States have since been growing more slowly than elsewhere. Why? Among the reasons: This country has lost its once-wide lead in educational attainment. Other countries have increased their workers’ skill levels more quickly, helping create well-paying jobs. The United States also tolerates more inequality: The minimum wage is lower here. Executives make more money. The government redistributes less of it. By 2010, the poor in several other countries had pulled ahead. And Canada’s median income had reached a virtual tie with that of the United States. Since 2010, other data suggest Canada has moved ahead.

headline: About the Data
abstract: A look at where the numbers came from and the assumptions that underlie them.
lead_paragraph: The data in today’s article on income comes from LIS, a group that maintains the Luxembourg Income Study Database. Staff members at LIS — based in Luxembourg and at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York — gather data on household income from around the world and harmonize the statistics, so that numbers from different countries can be compared. Government agencies typically conduct the underlying income surveys.

headline: Ackman and Valeant Drum Up Stealth Activism
abstract: William A. Ackman of Pershing Square Capital Management and Valeant Pharmaceuticals quietly set up to make a hostile bid for Allergan if necessary, Robert Cyran and Richard Beales write for Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Remember the dawn raid, when a would-be acquirer built up a stake before the target realized it was under attack? The activist investor William A. Ackman has come up with a kind of drone strike version. His Pershing Square Capital Management hedge fund and Valeant Pharmaceuticals have teamed up to grab a potential 9.7 percent stake in Allergan, with a hostile takeover by Valeant ready for deployment.

headline: Permira to Acquire German Chemical Maker CABB International
abstract: Funds advised by Permira will acquire the German specialty chemical company CABB International from the private equity firm Bridgepoint Capital for an undisclosed amount.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The European private equity firm Permira said on Tuesday that it had agreed to acquire the specialty chemical company CABB International of Germany.

headline: Comcast Reports Strong Earnings as Cable TV Subscribers Hold Steady
abstract: The cable operator’s quarterly report could bolster its fight to acquire Time Warner Cable.
lead_paragraph: Comcast, already the largest cable operator in the country, is trying to become even larger with a proposed takeover of Time Warner Cable. But even without that enormous planned acquisition, Comcast is growing.

headline: An Online Meeting Place for Creative Types
abstract: The innovative two-month-old networking website Unique Board aims to shrinks the global creative community down to a single URL.
lead_paragraph: After graduating from New York University in 2013 with a degree in film and television, Dan Kim found himself in an entirely unexpected situation: a friend asked him to help shoot a music video, an incredible opportunity at the time, and Kim had to turn him down. “I was in film school, but I didn’t know anybody who could help,” he explains, referencing his then-nonexistent set of industry contacts. “I thought it was insane that there was no space for people like me to share their ideas. People still use Craigslist!” The realization drove Kim to create Unique Board, a website where artists working in seven different categories – cinematography, fashion, design, music, art, dance/performance and technology/programming – can find each other for different projects. “We’re digitizing the collaboration process, making it simple but effective by cutting off all the extra steps of networking,” Kim explains about the site, which has amassed over 200 members — many based in New York, many others international — since going live in February.

headline: I Am Not a Thief

headline: Court Backs Michigan on Affirmative Action
abstract: The Supreme Court on Tuesday upheld a Michigan voter initiative that banned racial preferences in admissions to the state’s public universities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a fractured decision that revealed deep divisions over what role the judiciary should play in protecting racial and ethnic minorities, the Supreme Court on Tuesday upheld a Michigan constitutional amendment that bans affirmative action in admissions to the state’s public universities.

abstract: At a funeral for three men killed at a checkpoint on Sunday, residents of the pro-Russian city of Slovyansk, Ukraine, held leaders in Kiev responsible for the deaths.
lead_paragraph: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — Hundreds of residents of this eastern Ukrainian city under the control of pro-Russian militants came to the Orthodox Church of the Holy Spirit on Tuesday for the funerals of three men killed in a shootout at a roadblock on Sunday.

abstract: The New York State Pavilion, one of the last relics of the 1964 fair in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, received the designation on the fair’s 50th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years after the 1964 World’s Fair opened, the New York State Pavilion, one of the last architectural vestiges of the fair, was named a “National Treasure” on Tuesday by the National Trust for Historic Preservation.

headline: Introducing the Reader Spotlight: A Teacher’s View of Common Core
abstract: Heidi Reich looks for a deeper treatment of opposition to education standards.
lead_paragraph: As I’ve noted, I get mail. Fairly often, a reader’s view, sent to me, stands quite well on its own and deserves a wider audience. Toward that end, I’ll occasionally feature here a letter – possibly lightly trimmed or edited for style – that fits that description.

headline: Scuba Diving in Brooklyn
abstract: As part of an unusual internship, nine high school students work in a tropical reef, located at the end of the F subway line in Coney Island.
lead_paragraph: As part of an unusual internship, nine high school students work in a tropical reef, located at the end of the F subway line in Coney Island.

headline: Mariss Jansons to Resign From Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra
abstract: Mr. Jansons, 71, will resign his post after the 2014-15 season.
lead_paragraph: Mariss Jansons, who has been the chief conductor of the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra for nearly a decade, plans to resign his post there after the 2014-15 season, the orchestra announced on Tuesday.

headline: Equipped to Dive, Students Make Aquarium Their Classroom
abstract: Some students at the Urban Assembly New York Harbor School, which has a focus on marine science and technology, are doing an internship that takes them to the New York Aquarium in Coney Island.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Sutchen, 18, was keeping his head down, trying to ignore the fish. It was hard to concentrate on the task at hand: underwater housekeeping for the New York Aquarium in Coney Island. “They kept biting my hair,” he said. “I felt a tug and saw that one had pulled some out.”

headline: Marine Vacth, the Frequently Unclothed Star of François Ozon’s ‘Young and Beautiful’
abstract: The French actress, a successful model in her native country, reflects on her provocative performance and becoming a mother.
lead_paragraph: In his new film, “Young and Beautiful” (opening April 25 in New York), François Ozon introduces his star, the newcomer Marine Vacth, with a tableau that’s typical of the French auteur: she appears lying naked on a beach in the South of France, seen through the lenses of a pair of binoculars. The voyeuristic shot establishes her character, the affluent high school student Isabelle, as an unknowable object of desire whose motives remain inscrutable even when she starts working nights as a high-class prostitute in Paris hotels (a plot device reminiscent of “Belle de Jour”). The role’s abundant nudity and questionable morality is certain to rocket Vacth into the consciousness of American art-house audiences.

headline: Allergan Bid Adds to Spate of Pharmaceutical Deals
abstract: Not counting the $45.6 billion bid for Allergan, mergers and acquisitions in the pharmaceutical industry stand at $47.1 billion so far this year, the highest year-to-date total since 2009.
lead_paragraph: The early pairing of the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman with Valeant Pharmaceuticals International to bid for the Botox maker Allergan allows Mr. Ackman to leapfrog over a traditional step for activist investors.

headline: Reports of Fraud and Violence Temper Joy Over Election in Chaotic Afghan District
abstract: Afghanistan hailed news of high turnout in the Andar district as a triumph for democracy, but interviews with villagers near polling sites offered a stark contrast to the government narrative.
lead_paragraph: ANDAR, Afghanistan — The turbulent district of Andar has been caught in one kind of crossfire or another for years: between American forces and insurgent leaders, between warring militant factions, between those hostile to the national government and those courting it.

headline: Lorde Postpones Australian Tour
abstract: The singer said on Twitter that her parents and support team told her she had to take a break to recover.
lead_paragraph: Lorde, the teenage pop star, has had to postpone her scheduled concert tour of Australia because of a chest infection, Billboard magazine reported.

headline: Oscar Producers Will Be Back in 2015
abstract: Craig Zadan and Neil Meron will return to produce the Oscar show for the third consecutive year.
lead_paragraph: Craig Zadan and Neil Meron, whose production of this year’s largely successful Academy Awards eclipsed their Seth MacFarlane-led show of 2013, will return to produce the Oscar show for the third consecutive year. Where the 2013 show might be best remembered for Mr. MacFarlane’s flat-footed musical ode to actresses’ bare breasts, the 2014 show’s most-enduring image was of the star-filled selfie, above, snapped by a sunny Ellen DeGeneres. This year’s show also drew 45.4 million viewers, according to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, the most in 10 years. Dawn Hudson, the Academy’s chief executive, said in a statement that Mr. Zadan and Mr. Meron were “masters at tapping into the zeitgeist and capturing the hearts of movie fans around the world.” Mr. Zadan and Mr. Meron have a long history of bringing Broadway musicals to the big and little screens: They produced the film versions of “Chicago” and “Hairspray,” are in the process of producing “Pippin,” and for television have made “Annie,” “Rogers & Hammerstein’s Cinderella” and “Gypsy.” The 87th Academy Awards will be next Feb. 22, at the Dolby Theater in Hollywood. No host has been named.

headline: Is It O.K. to Mine Real Relationships for Literary Material?
abstract: Francine Prose and Leslie Jamison discuss what they make of writers mining actual relationships for material.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. When Robert Lowell used his ex-wife’s letters for his poetry, Elizabeth Bishop told him, “Art just isn’t worth that much.” This week, Francine Prose and Leslie Jamison discuss what they make of mining actual relationships for literary material.

headline: The Diminishing American Edge
keywords: ['Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Income Inequality', 'Nineteen Hundred Nineties', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Taxation', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The slipping economic advantages of the American middle class.
lead_paragraph: Last week, in a tax day post defending the virtues of light taxation, I discussed the various economic advantages that the United States of America has reaped from its lower-than-average tax burden, and the evidence that not only the U.S. but also our developed-world peers have benefited from the American style of free market capitalism. But I concluded by allowing that this argument would look that much weaker the longer the U.S. economy goes without delivering on the second half of the basic American “more risk and more inequality for more growth and jobs and self-sufficiency” bargain — a combination which has held historically, but not so much of late.

headline: No Time to Waste: Students Pursue Environmental Progress Instead of Exam Grades
keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'ANIMALS', 'Circuses', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Elephants', 'Factory Farming', 'Invasive Species', 'Solar Energy', 'Wind Power']
abstract: College students get out of the classroom and pursue environmental initiatives with partners in surrounding communities.
lead_paragraph: This is an Earth Day shout-out to the dozen undergraduate students in the inaugural semester of our new Pace University Environmental Policy Clinic, a year-round course in which student teams, instead of studying for tests, work with nonprofit groups, communities or other partners to pursue achievable environmental goals.

headline: With Eyes on a Possible Clinton Run, Debate on a 2-Woman Ticket
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: A nomination of Hillary Rodham Clinton for president would likely block the paths for other women running for the White House, and for those who would like to be vice president.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Few doubt that Hillary Rodham Clinton’s nomination for president would be good for women. But her candidacy would also probably block the paths for other women running for the White House, and, notably, for those who would like to be vice president.

headline: Chernin Teams With AT&T in Online Video Investment Venture
abstract: Peter Chernin, the former News Corporation president, has joined with AT&T to commit more than $500 million to a new investment vehicle for online video.
lead_paragraph: Peter Chernin was stymied in his effort last year to buy Hulu, the online video streaming service. But now, Mr. Chernin, the former News Corporation president, is teaming up with his partner in that bid to form a new investment venture.

headline: Image of the Day: April 22
abstract: Women cleaning the Dal Lake, in Jammu and Kashmir, on the occasion of Earth Day.

headline: Sherpa Guides Abandon Everest Climbing Season
abstract: Following the worst single-day death toll in the history of Mount Everest, a group of Sherpas announced that they decided to abandon this year’s climbing season.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 1:51 p.m. | Following an avalanche on Friday that produced the worst single-day death toll in the history of Mount Everest, a group of Sherpas announced on Tuesday that they decided to abandon this year’s climbing season, disrupting plans of hundreds of climbers, many of them waiting at the mountain’s base camp.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival: Gia Coppola Looks Back With Compassion
abstract: Her film “Palo Alto” looks at cosseted, disaffected teens with empathy even though the filmmaker found her teenage years difficult.
lead_paragraph: In “Palo Alto,” a feature based on James Franco short stories and  screening at the Tribeca Film Festival this week, first-time filmmaker Gia Coppola follows the lives of a group of cosseted, disaffected teens as they gambol from one soccer game, one hookup and one party to the next.

headline: Moscow Court Rules Navalny Libeled Politician
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Libel and Slander', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: The ruling against Aleksei A. Navalny, a prominent opposition figure, could land him in prison as he awaits trial in another case.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A Moscow court ruled on Tuesday that Aleksei A. Navalny, the prominent Russian opposition figure, had libeled a governing-party politician, and it fined him about $8,400. The ruling may lead to the reinstatement of a suspended sentence from a previous conviction, landing Mr. Navalny in prison as he awaits trial in a third case.

headline: Obama Tours Site of Deadly Landslide
abstract: Fear and pain remain raw in a community that lost 41 people in a devastating landslide one month ago, and many wonder what could have been done differently.
lead_paragraph: OSO, Wash. — One month after a landslide devastated this community, President Obama promised residents that the nation was still with them in grieving and rebuilding, and would be for the long haul.

headline: Fighting Words Are Rarer Among British Doctors
abstract: While American patients are urged to “battle” at the end of life, a new analysis showed doctors in Britain telling patients about the “journey.”
lead_paragraph: Is a journey better than a battle?

headline: Striving for School-Mom Perfection
abstract: As a child, I wished my mother could spend more time involved with my school and activities, but that’s not who she was. I hoped to do better, but I wasn’t sure what that would look like.
lead_paragraph: My eyes nearly popped from my head as I walked into the brunch: of the 12 admitted preschool students’ parents, 3 of us had gone to the same high school, even pre-K—in Canada! I was delighted (this was home) and shocked (was this too “home”?). Mostly, though, I was thrown. At this inaugural parents’ reception I’d hoped to be “school mom extraordinaire.” But seeing myself through the eyes of people I’d known from my childhood, I questioned whether I could really ace parent involvement – something that didn’t come naturally.

headline: Biden Offers Strong Support to Ukraine
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. told members of Ukraine’s parliament that the United States was ready to support them in securing a unified Ukraine but warned against the “cancer of corruption.”
lead_paragraph: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. told members of Ukraine’s parliament that the United States was ready to support them in securing a unified Ukraine but warned against the “cancer of corruption.”

headline: The Vice President Who Pulled a Gun on Truman
abstract: Whatever your views on guns, this 1938 photograph of Vice President John Nance Garner and Senator Harry Truman has some element of shock.
lead_paragraph: Whatever your views on gun rights and gun safety, this 1938 photograph of a joking vice president, John Nance Garner, thrusting two pistols into Missouri Senator Harry Truman’s chest probably has some element of shock.

headline: Why Economics Failed Us, in 297 Words
abstract: An economist’s famously brief 2007 graduation speech is accurate, but its omissions presage the policy failures in the crash that would soon follow.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Sargent’s 2007 speech to Berkeley graduates is making the rounds on the Internet. Business Insider called it the “greatest graduation speech ever.” Ezra Klein over at Vox says it “teaches everything you need to know about economics in 297 words.”

headline: Forty-Four Years of Earth Day
abstract: By a number of measures, the United States is cleaner than it was on the first Earth Day in 1970.
lead_paragraph: When environmentalists proclaimed the first Earth Day, on this date in 1970, the air was filled with doomsday predictions. At the initial rallies to mark the day, people warned of overpopulation, a denuded planet, hundreds of millions of people starving to death, a new Ice Age or the greenhouse effect. Many — though not all, obviously — of those forecasts were off.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Vote for Me or I’ll Shoot
abstract: Alabama State Representative Steve Hurst is fighting off a Republican primary challenge—with a smoker shaped like a gun.
lead_paragraph: Alabama State Representative Steve Hurst is fighting off a Republican primary challenge—with a smoker shaped like a gun.

headline: Allergan Bid Charts New Territory in Takeovers
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: The $45.6 billion unsolicited offer for Allergan could ignite a battle over the laws governing takeovers and activism, Steven M. Davidoff writes in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: The $45.6 billion unsolicited offer for Allergan by Valeant Pharmaceuticals and William A. Ackman’s hedge fund is many things, including bold, novel and mega in all ways. It is a new twist in the struggle between companies and shareholder activists, and could ignite a furious battle not just for Allergan but over the laws governing takeovers and activism.

headline: Claims of Chlorine-Filled Bombs Overshadow Progress by Syria on Chemical Weapons
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The unconfirmed reports of the weapons came as international monitors said that nearly 90 percent of the chemicals in Syria’s arsenal had now been exported.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 90 percent of the chemicals in Syria’s arsenal have now been exported and only a few shipments remain, international monitors reported Tuesday, but the progress was overshadowed by growing concerns that the Syrian military may be dropping bombs filled with chlorine, a common industrial compound not on the list of prohibited poisons.

headline: Justices Skeptical of Aereo’s Business
keywords: ['Television', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations']
abstract: Television broadcasters are challenging Aereo, an Internet start-up that uses arrays of small antennas to stream over-the-air signals to subscribers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court signaled on Tuesday that it was struggling with two conflicting impulses in considering a request from television broadcasters to shut down Aereo, an Internet start-up they say threatens the economic viability of their businesses.

headline: MCC Season Will Feature LaBute World Premiere
abstract: The season also includes New York premieres of plays by Simon Stephens and Jennifer Haley.
lead_paragraph: World premieres of new hot-button comedies by Neil LaBute and Robert Askins will bracket MCC Theater’s 2014-15 season, the theater announced on Tuesday.

headline: For start-ups looking to disrupt regulated industries, the new strategy is: Ask forgiveness, not permission.
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Airbnb’s legal tussle with New York State is only the latest example of digital companies running afoul of regulators.
lead_paragraph: Airbnb, the service to let people rent out their basement apartments and spare bedrooms to short-term visitors, is in court on Tuesday fighting an effort by New York State regulators to get a list of clients. The state thinks Airbnb may be violating New York City’s law on short-term rentals. It’s part of a bunch of tangles that digital companies like Uber and Lyft are having with various state and local authorities as they try to disrupt highly regulated industries.

headline: American Reporter Held by Ukraine Separatists
abstract: The Vice News reporter Simon Ostrovsky, who has produced a series of vivid dispatches from Ukraine in recent weeks, was detained by pro-Russia separatists in the town of Slovyansk on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, Wednesday, 3:11 p.m. | Foreign correspondents in the eastern Ukrainian town of Slovyansk, including my colleague Andrew Roth and Roland Oliphant of The Telegraph, report that one of their number, the Vice News reporter Simon Ostrovsky has been detained by pro-Russia separatists who seized power in recent days.

keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Building (Construction)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Urban Areas']

lead_paragraph: WILMINGTON, Del. — Hoping to generate interest in rejuvenating urban areas, Delaware’s governor wants to offer modest development grants for proposed projects in 15 districts around the state.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John Boozman, the junior senator from Arkansas, had unplanned heart surgery on Tuesday morning and was recovering in an Arkansas hospital, his spokeswoman said.

headline: Labor Case Filed by Injured Player in ’70s Has Echoes Today
keywords: ["Workers' Compensation Insurance", 'Football (College)', 'Sports Injuries', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'College Athletics', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: In 1982 an appeals court declared that as a football player, Fred W. Rensing should be considered an Indiana State employee, but the state’s Supreme Court reversed the ruling the next year.
lead_paragraph: BELLEVILLE, Ill. — In a drill at a college football practice, Fred W. Rensing charged downfield, lowered his white helmet and drilled the punt returner in the chest for a thunderous hit. Rensing did not get up, and he never walked again.

headline: The Pregnancy I Endured, and the One I Missed
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Parenting', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: I didn’t want to be pregnant, and at the time, I couldn’t enjoy it on any level. Now, watching friends anticipate birth, I want what I know what I missed.
lead_paragraph: It might have been the photo of the onesie with the due date circled. It might have been the confidential email I got. It might have been all the ultrasound photos, seemingly within days of one another, popping up on my Facebook feed. It might have been when one friend told me her obstetrician said she was a champ, or the day another friend talked about getting 78 pounds of maternity clothes from her best friend, some still unopened, or the latest email from the yoga place that I never go to anymore advertising the prenatal yoga class I never took. It might have been any of those things, or it might just have been the all-too-common effects of depression combined with sleep deprivation, but suddenly I broke down in tears.

headline: Digital Public Library of America Marks a Year of Rapid Growth
abstract: The project, aimed at providing online access to the nation’s cultural repositories, has tripled in size since opening in 2013.
lead_paragraph: The Digital Public Library of America, a project aimed at providing free online access to the nation’s cultural repositories, has tripled in size to more than seven million items from more than 1,300 institutions since it opened a year ago, the group has announced.

headline: E.J. Burke
abstract: Mr. Burke is chairman of the Mortgage Bankers Association, a national organization based in Washington that represents the real estate finance industry.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Burke, 58, is chairman of the Mortgage Bankers Association, a national organization based in Washington that represents the real estate finance industry. He is also a newly named co-president of KeyBank’s community bank, specializing in commercial and private banking. KeyBank is based in Cleveland.

headline: Senator Chuck Schumer leaped to the defense of Niagara Falls on Monday.
abstract: A population sinking below 50,000 people can put a city at risk of losing federal assistance — unless it has a powerful senator on its side.
lead_paragraph: The possibility that some New York cities will get less federal dollars because of declining populations has prompted the New York senator to preserve a carve-out. Cities with at least 50,000 people are eligible for direct community development grants from the federal government, while smaller cities must rely on a pool of money administered by each state. That’s a big concern for Niagara Falls and Troy. (As well as Joplin, Mo.) Each city has slipped under the 50,000 mark, according to Census Bureau estimates, meaning greater competition for the money is likely.

headline: A Craft-Beer Pub Crawl in the ‘Kitchen of Japan’
abstract: Osaka, Japan’s third-largest city, is increasingly the place to taste domestic craft brews.
lead_paragraph: For a long time, drinking beer in Japan meant implicitly supporting one of the country’s four major producers: Asahi, Kirin, Suntory and Sapporo. But in the mid-1990s, when a law prohibiting the operation of small-scale breweries was abandoned, the door was opened for Japanese craft beer, known as ji-biru. Even today, there are only about 200 craft breweries in Japan, so finding domestic microbrews takes some effort. (For comparison, the United States had nearly 2,500 craft breweries in operation as of June 2013, according to the Brewers Association.) But increasingly, the place to taste these relatively rare — but deliciously well-crafted — beers is Osaka, Japan’s third-largest city.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival Directors’ Most Memorable New York Minutes
abstract: For some, being in New York feels like being in the movies — and those who actually make the movies couldn’t agree more.
lead_paragraph: It is often said that being in New York City feels like starring in your own movie. Maybe it’s because the Big Apple has set the scene for so many unforgettable films that we can’t help but register its urban landscape as a backdrop for the story of our lives. Or maybe it’s that in this metropolis of eight million — with its screaming energy and melting pot of cultures — “only in the movies” events seem to happen on a daily basis. Here, 14 directors — each of whom is showing a film at the Tribeca Film Festival, which continues through Sunday — recall New York moments when life imitated (their) art.

headline: Monday’s Boston Marathon provides yet more data illustrating that arbitrary numbers can serve as motivating goals.
abstract: Running marathons as an insight into human psychology and investor behavior.
lead_paragraph: George Wu, who is not only a keen student of the sport, but also a professor of behavioral science at the University of Chicago, spent Monday night downloading the official times of all 31,805 finishers. The distribution of finishing times follows the same pattern I highlighted in this morning’s column, with a statistically improbable clumping of runners finishing just before their goals of 3, 3.5 or 4 hours, and an accompanying “gap” with far fewer runners finishing just minutes after their goals. Befitting Boston’s reputation as a race for truly competitive runners, there’s less evidence of such goals mattering for those aiming to beat 5 or 6 hours.

headline: Hotel Review: Vander Urbani Resort in Ljubljana, Slovenia
abstract: The 16-room Vander is centrally located near city sights, offers not-to-be missed views and even comes with a love story.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: Restaurant Report: The Coalhouse in Gower, Wales
abstract: This spot, which opened last summer, serves locally sourced fare in a stylish spot by the sea.
lead_paragraph: Let’s face it: Wales isn’t exactly known as a culinary destination. In fact, the country’s diet — high in starches and meats — gets its fair share of criticism. But the Coalhouse on Oxwich Beach, which opened last summer on the gorgeous, windswept Gower Peninsula in South Wales, defies that reputation in a stylish setting.

headline: One Plate, Two Plates, Small Plates All
abstract: At Telepan Local, a serving can be too much or too little.
lead_paragraph: Something happened to me recently at the Cleveland, a small restaurant downtown, that struck me as both unprecedented and inevitable. After a friend and I had finished a small opening snack, the server brought our appetizers and main courses.

headline: Carcillo Offers the Rangers a Tougher Look
abstract: Daniel Carcillo made his first appearance in the series against the Flyers in Game 3, in a move that seemed calculated to goad Philadelphia into taking more penalties.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — There were hints at the Rangers’ morning skate before Game 3 on Tuesday night against the Flyers that Daniel Carcillo might enter the lineup for the first time in this series.

abstract: We selected from almost 5,000 entries to choose our favorite student editorials.
lead_paragraph: Update | Dec. 9, 2014: In late January or early February of 2015 we will be announcing our second annual Student Editorial contest.

lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:02 p.m. | Preet Bharara’s perfect record, 80 insider trading convictions without a single defeat, is in jeopardy.

headline: At the Auto Show, Vehicles With a New York Connection
abstract: Two gubernatorial limousines, a classic Corvette and a custom Harley-Davidson have come down from Albany.
lead_paragraph: Most of the spotlight at the New York auto show is, of course, on the new models on the floor of the Jacob K. Javits center. But a handful of classics are sitting in the center’s front hall. Taken from the collection at the New York State Museum, which is in Albany, all four cars are associated with New York governors.

lead_paragraph: Rock in Rio, the huge Brazilian music festival, is coming to the United States. It will make its American debut over two weekends in May 2015 in Las Vegas, according to Billboard.

headline: Tribeca First-Timers: Bérénice Marlohe
abstract: The actress Bérénice Marlohe discusses her work in the film “5 to 7,” the first movie she has acted in at the festival.

headline: Up for Discussion: How to Create an Advisory Board
abstract: Should advisers be compensated?
