abstract: The new Lytro Illum camera offers photographers a range of new features, while still allowing them to refocus a photo after the fact
lead_paragraph: When the Lytro camera debuted in 2012, it was the talk of techies and photographers. What else would you expect from a camera that was developed in Silicon Valley and used both photography expertise and a lot of fancy programming code?

headline: Slovyansk Buries 3 Killed in Unrest
abstract: Residents in the eastern Ukrainian city of Slovyansk buried three men killed in a gunfight at a roadblock on Easter Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Residents in the eastern Ukrainian city of Slovyansk buried three men killed in a gunfight at a roadblock on Easter Sunday.

headline: Study Linking Illness and Salt Leaves Researchers Doubtful
abstract: Scientists found declines in heart attack and stroke risk in Britain after salt in processed food was restricted, but their work has several drawbacks.
lead_paragraph: The former commissioner of health for New York City, Dr. Thomas A. Farley, has raised anew questions about the health risks posed by salt in the American diet, citing a new  study from Britain showing significant declines in heart attack and stroke risk after health officials there limited the amount of salt in processed foods.

headline: The Gun Report: April 22, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Seven people in Houston have been convicted of running guns into Mexico, where they were used to fuel that nation’s drug wars. State police discovered the pipeline last October, when a trooper in Kingsville stopped a car containing 35 military-style rifles stashed in a hidden compartment. Seven of them were missing serial numbers. Drivers confessed to making 100 trips across the border in six months.

headline: Accusations in Hollywood Sexual Abuse Case Broaden
abstract: Michael Egan, who in a lawsuit last week accused the director Bryan Singer of sexually abusing him, has filed separate suits making similar accusations against three entertainment executives.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Michael Egan, who in a lawsuit last week accused the director Bryan Singer of drugging him and sexually abusing him, has filed separate suits making similar accusations of forced sex and drug use against three entertainment executives: Garth Ancier, Gary W. Goddard and David A. Neuman.

headline: Beneath the Surface of China’s Great Urban Rush
abstract: Can China’s urbanization push sidestep the Western pattern of pollution and sprawl, and can it consider the rights of displaced citizens?
lead_paragraph: At The New York Times Cities for Tomorrow event today, I led a discussion of some big social and environmental issues that lie beneath the surface of China’s urban rush.

headline: Lax Oversight Cited as Factor in Deadly Blast at Texas Plant
keywords: ['Fires and Firefighters', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Explosions', 'Fertilizer', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: A preliminary report on a deadly fire and blast in West, Tex., by the Chemical Safety Board notes that there are no regulations for the storage of ammonium nitrate.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Federal investigators have determined that a lack of oversight and regulations at the local, state and federal levels contributed to the deadly fertilizer plant explosion that devastated a rural Texas town last year.

headline: Do You Want a Girl Toy or a Boy Toy? McDonald’s Says Workers Won’t Ask
abstract: McDonald’s gave one economist’s daughter a “girl toy” too many.
lead_paragraph: I thought it was just me.

headline: Testing the Limits of Inside Information Cases
abstract: The question is how far down the chain of information can prosecutors go in bringing insider trading charges, Peter J. Henning writes in his White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: Much like the game of telephone, the final recipient of inside information may know little about who started the process or how many steps it took before arriving. When prosecutors want to pursue charges against the recipients of confidential information — the “tippees” — the issue is often how far down the chain they can go before they can no longer prove a violation.

headline: How Valeant Can Raise Its Bid for Botox Maker
abstract: Valeant thinks it can cut $2.7 billion in costs from Allergan. With a single-digit tax rate, that could be worth $25 billion, writes Robert Cyran of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Valeant Pharmaceuticals has plenty of room to raise its bid for Allergan.

headline: Answers on Affirmative Action Depend on How You Pose the Question
abstract: Using the phrases “special preferences” or “preferential treatment” in a survey tends to reduce support for the policy.
lead_paragraph: Polling about affirmative action and racial issues is inherently difficult, and responses differ rather widely based on question wording.

headline: Caesars Making Bid for Casino in Upstate New York
abstract: The gambling company, based in Las Vegas, is seeking one of the four licenses that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has pushed as a way to revive the state’s economy.
lead_paragraph: For more than two years, the major Las Vegas gambling companies have resisted Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s call to consider building a casino resort in New York to help him revive an upstate economy wracked by unemployment and declining opportunities.

headline: Paul Takes His School-Choice Message to Chicago
abstract: Senator Rand Paul spoke of the importance of giving parents more flexibility to decide where their tax dollars go, and labeled those who stand in the way of greater choice “dead-enders.”
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Senator Rand Paul on Tuesday brought his vision for education reform to Josephinum Academy, a small all-girls Catholic high school here. And true to form, he made no attempt to mask his libertarian brand of politics, even in President Obama’s adopted hometown.

headline: Clippers See Griffin’s Growth
abstract: After playing 19 minutes and fouling out in Game 1, Blake Griffin shot 13 of 17 for 35 points in a Game 2 rout as the Clippers tied their series with the Warriors.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Before the you-gotta-see-this dunks, before the droll television commercials and before Blake Griffin realized what basketball might bring to a child from the Oklahoma City suburbs, he viewed the sport as an almost academic exercise.

headline: Piketty, Doom Loops and Haymarket
keywords: ['Corporate Taxes', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Some thoughts on the likelihood of near-future inequality-driven upheavals.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column, on Thomas Piketty’s revival of the old argument that capitalism tends to enrich the capital-rich Few much, much faster than the laboring Many, didn’t take a position on the plausibility of the French economist’s basic forecast, which foresees upper-tail inequality rising forever absent a sustained political disruption. (For a more qualified observer’s critique of that forecast, Tyler Cowen’s review and follow-up are the place to turn.) Instead, I argued against the view that such a trend would necessarily lead to such political disruptions, or indeed be particularly destabilizing to the developed world’s societies. So long as a rich country’s Many see some real gains, I suggested, whether through modest growth and/or modestly-increasing redistribution, we aren’t likely to see anything remotely like the kind of literal class warfare that the last gilded age produced.

headline: The Broadband Revolution Is Not Nigh
abstract: A handful of cable companies still dominate this important market.
lead_paragraph: Is America on the cusp of a broadband revolution? You might get that impression from AT&T’s announcement on Monday that it is considering providing Internet service of up to 1 gigabit, or 1 billion bits, a second to 21 metropolitan areas including Atlanta, Chicago, Los Angeles and San Francisco.

headline: Five Great New York Breads
abstract: The Dining section tasted 20 assorted loaves from recently opened bakeries to find five you should put on your table.
lead_paragraph: The Dining section tasted 20 assorted loaves from recently opened bakeries to find five you should put on your table.

headline: How An Exuberant ’80s Designer Shaped Fashion Today
abstract: A new show at the Philadelphia Museum of Art honors the work of Patrick Kelly and explores his influence on the contemporary streetwear label Gerlan Jeans.
lead_paragraph: The life and career of the designer Patrick Kelly were as brief as they were brilliant. A singular force in the 1980s fashion scene known for his jarringly bright and playful clothes, Kelly passed away on the first day of 1990 at 35 due to complications from AIDS. This weekend, the Philadelphia Museum of Art opens “Patrick Kelly: Runway of Love” (on view through November 30), the first retrospective of the designer’s prolific output since the Brooklyn Museum’s 2004 exhibition of his works. The show brings together eighty complete looks from his ten collections produced between 1985 and 1990, gifted to the museum by the late designer’s partner in business and life, Bjorn Guil Amelan, and Amelan’s current partner, the choreographer Bill T. Jones.

headline: Three Recipes to Savor to the Last Crumb
abstract: Bake white bread, English muffins and walnut bread in your own kitchen.
lead_paragraph: White Slices, Rich and Moist, Sporting a Milk-Sweet Crust

headline: Abbas Renews Threat to Dissolve Palestinian Authority if Peace Talks Fail
abstract: Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, said that Israel had deprived him of any real power to govern the West Bank and that he was considering giving it back to Israel.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, issued a renewed warning on Tuesday that if the American-sponsored Middle East peace talks fail, he may dissolve the authority and hand sole responsibility for the West Bank back to Israel.

headline: Abbas Renews Warning to Israel on Talks
abstract: Mahmoud Abbas, president of the Palestinian Authority, renewed warnings that Israel would have to take on the responsibility of governing Palestinian lands if peace talks did not continue.
lead_paragraph: Mahmoud Abbas, president of the Palestinian Authority, renewed warnings that Israel would have to take on the responsibility of governing Palestinian lands if peace talks did not continue.

headline: Everybody Is Playing Somebody Else Here
abstract: “James Franco: New Film Stills,” at Pace Gallery, restages Cindy Sherman’s “Untitled Film Stills.”
lead_paragraph: Perhaps James Franco should just stick to acting. He remains embarrassingly clueless when it comes to art.

headline: What Business Spends to Open Washington’s Doors
abstract: The Chamber of Commerce spent $19 million on lobbying in just the first three months of 2014.
lead_paragraph: The next time a lawmaker or a corporate executive tries to persuade you that Washington is an even playing field, responsive to the concerns of all constituents, feel free to point them to the quarterly lobbying report of the United States Chamber of Commerce. Its most recent report, filed on Monday, shows the staggering amount of money that the business sector spends to influence legislation and regulation in Washington. No other competing interest group comes remotely close.

headline: Tartine’s Country Bread: Be Patient, Perfection Is Near
abstract: Chad Robertson’s recipe has reached cult status among passionate home bakers.
lead_paragraph: Chad Robertson’s recipe for country bread, from Tartine, his bakery in San Francisco, has reached cult status among passionate bakers for good reason: As bread recipes go, it’s nearly perfect.

headline: Racial Equality Loses at the Court
abstract: In upholding a ban on affirmative action in Michigan, the Supreme Court failed to see, as Justice Sonia Sotomayor pointed out, that “race matters.”
lead_paragraph: A blinkered view of race in America won out in the Supreme Court on Tuesday when six justices agreed, for various reasons, to allow Michigan voters to ban race-conscious admissions policies in higher education.

headline: Mixing It Up, Where the Bloody Mary Is Concerned
abstract: Rosie Schaap, the magazine’s Drink columnist, offers some variations on the Bloody Mary, despite her penchant for keeping things simple.
lead_paragraph: I think I make it pretty clear in my latest Drink column that where the bloody mary is concerned, I like to keep things simple (a poached-shrimp garnish notwithstanding). The drink itself is a study in balance: When you break it down, there’s a lot going on in a good bloody, and the idea is to bring all those components together into one bracing — some would say restorative — cocktail. Then do it up with those garnishes.

headline: Let’s Start With Bread and Water
abstract: At many restaurants, what once was free now must be requested. This must change.
lead_paragraph: Some people are nostalgic for foam-topped egg creams or Grandma’s buttermilk biscuits or defunct brands of children’s cereal. I miss bread and water.

headline: Against the Grain
abstract: Artisanal baking goes renegade, combining snail-pace, primordial techniques with a cutting-edge approach.
lead_paragraph: Zachary Golper gets a strange look in his eyes when he talks about his miche.

headline: Reviews: Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes, FarmVille 2: Country Escape and Monument Valley
abstract: New releases include a portion of the next chapter in the Metal Gear Solid series; a FarmVille 2 with the mobile gamer in mind; and a premium perceptual puzzle game.
lead_paragraph: METAL GEAR SOLID V

headline: One-Piece Wonder
abstract: Layered over a sporty T-shirt or jacket, the men’s jumpsuit lends a certain street credibility to spring wardrobes.
lead_paragraph: In spite of its many runway interpretations this season, the jumpsuit is still, for most men, an incredibly daunting full-body statement. Consider it when worn unzipped over a sporty layer, though, and it takes on a thoroughly urban, street-ready appeal — like the tracksuits you see on kids in the London neighborhood of Brixton.

headline: Auto China Opens to the Public in Beijing
abstract: Volkswagen showed off its redesigned Touareg S.U.V., and Japanese automakers made a push into the Chinese market.
lead_paragraph: Auto China 2014 officially opened to the public on Monday at the China International Exhibition Center, Beijing’s convention center, with a glittering, seemingly endless array of new transportation offerings that underscored the growing importance of the Chinese market in the automotive industry.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about today’s biggest stories.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Hating Humanity, on Two Wheels
abstract: In Philippe Le Guay’s “Bicycling With Molière,” the chance to play Alceste in “The Misanthrope” tempts a retired actor.
lead_paragraph: “When I see men treat each other as they do, I see nothing but base flattery, injustice, treachery, selfishness and deceit.”

headline: Rooftop Films Sets Summer Lineup
abstract: An abortion romantic comedy is among the opening-weekend films.
lead_paragraph: A sneak preview of “Obvious Child,” a Sundance favorite that happens to be an abortion rom-com, will be among the films kicking off this summer’s Rooftop Film series, which begins in Brooklyn on May 16.

headline: Hotel Brands Share Real Estate, Sometimes Uneasily
abstract: As developers squeeze into metropolitan areas, more hotel brands are sharing buildings and amenities while trying to maintain their individuality.
lead_paragraph: In hotels these days, it’s the haves versus the have-nots.

headline: Execution Case Roils Oklahoma Courts
abstract: A case involving two death row inmates, which has led to open conflict between Oklahoma’s two top courts, reached a new level of confusion Tuesday when the governor stepped in.
lead_paragraph: The legal wrangling in Oklahoma over the planned executions of two convicted murderers reached a new level of confusion on Tuesday as the State Supreme Court quickly rejected the attorney general’s claim that it had exceeded its power by granting stays of execution, only to have Gov. Mary Fallin assert that she was taking control and would arrange for the men to be put to death next week.

headline: Upsetting the Gentility That the South Lays Claim To
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Books and Literature', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Slavery', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Two rancorous and still-evolving disputes involving race and sexual orientation have shaken the College of Charleston in recent months.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — In keeping with this city’s veneration of things old, stately and Southern, the College of Charleston remains a genteel enough place that for spring commencement exercises, male students don white dinner jackets while women slip into white dresses.

headline: A Quiet Moment Among Neighbors
abstract: A photographer moved to a small town to understand what people hold dear. In time, she found herself drawn to subtler, quieter scenes.
lead_paragraph: A photographer moved to a small town to understand what people hold dear. In time, she found herself drawn to subtler, quieter scenes.

headline: Acceleration Is Forecast for Spending on Health
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Economy', 'Medicaid']
abstract: The Affordable Care Act may well be on track to meeting its primary goal, but reining in health care spending still appears well beyond the grasp of the law.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Standing before a roomful of economists, policy makers and health care experts earlier this month, Amitabh Chandra, director of Health Policy Research at Harvard’s Kennedy School of Government, closed a presentation about the slowdown in health care spending over the last decade by citing an article in The New York Times.

headline: 30,000 Golf Carts and 4,000 Heavy Duty Ford Trucks Recalled
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Consumer Protection', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The golf carts were recalled after an out-of-control unit injured its user; the trucks were recalled for a transmission defect.
lead_paragraph: About 30,000 golf carts and buggies are being recalled because the steering wheel may be loose, according to the Consumer Product Safety Commission. Ford is recalling almost 4,000 of its heavy-duty pickup trucks because they might go into reverse when the driver wants to move forward.

headline: ABC Posts Another Ratings Victory Over NBC in Nightly News
abstract: NBC has been the leader, but in the last two weeks ABC has managed to draw more viewers among the audience that advertisers favor.
lead_paragraph: The long run of dominance for NBC’s “Nightly News” is showing some cracks, as ABC’s “World News” last week again climbed to the top in the crucial audience category.

headline: Reviving the House Coltrane Built
abstract: The reactivation of Impulse Records, the storied former home of the saxophonist John Coltrane, reflects a larger turnaround for major-label jazz divisions.
lead_paragraph: Henry Butler, the New Orleans jazz pianist, released his debut album, “Fivin’ Around,” in 1986. And along with ratifying a major talent — a smartly rampaging virtuoso whose engagement in New York soon afterward drew a smattering of notable pianists — it signaled the reactivation of Impulse Records, the storied former home of the saxophonist John Coltrane, which had then been dormant for nearly a decade. “We had a nice little hand in reviving the label at that time,” Mr. Butler recalled this week.

headline: Barter, Haggle, Close, Rest
abstract: “Down East Dickering,” a reality series on the History channel, goes to Maine to observe the practitioners of a throwback barter-and-haggle economy.
lead_paragraph: Consider these eerie similarities between Bitcoin, the supposedly cutting-edge digital currency, and the world of “Down East Dickering,” a History channel reality series about a throwback barter-and-haggle economy:

headline: Why Slavery Is Not Like Carbon Emissions
abstract: There are key economic and political differences between abolition and carbon limitations. We all have an incentive to reduce extraction of fossil fuels.
lead_paragraph: In the new issue of The Nation, the MSNBC host Chris Hayes treads on the dangerous ground of comparing the effort to limit carbon emissions to the campaign for the abolition of slavery.

headline: Pelham Bay, the Bronx: A Blend of Urban and Suburban
abstract: A working- and middle-class Bronx community that doesn’t live up to its namesake, but the waterfront is not too far away.
lead_paragraph: Anyone seeking a large body of water in Pelham Bay would be quickly frustrated: The neighborhood’s namesake no longer exists. Instead, you would find a tidy community with rows of two-story brick homes bearing awnings and grillwork fences immediately adjacent to the city’s largest park.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, South Korea, Washington and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, South Korea, Washington and India.

headline: Dear Mr. Editor: Oy, the Tsoris I’ve Seen
abstract: “A Bintel Brief” is Liana Finck’s graphic rendering of poignant letters written by Jewish immigrants a century ago to an advice columnist at The Jewish Daily Forward.
lead_paragraph: With all but the most old-fashioned comics, the eye occasionally hesitates over which panel or word balloon to read next. Proceed across? Down instead?

headline: Comcast Seeks to Divest Subscribers to Win Approval for Time Warner Cable Deal
abstract: Discussions with Charter Communications could lead to a sale and a swap involving millions of cable subscribers.
lead_paragraph: Comcast is laying the groundwork to divest nearly four million subscribers as part of its efforts to appease antitrust regulators scrutinizing the proposed acquisition of Time Warner Cable.

headline: Make Them Fit, Please!
abstract: Women are demanding foot surgery so they can wear designer shoes in comfort.
lead_paragraph: When Dr. Ali Sadrieh, a podiatrist, started Evo Advanced Foot Surgery in Beverly Hills, Calif., 13 years ago, he thought it seemed a little vain for women to ask for surgery because their feet hurt wearing fashionable shoes.

headline: Gilead Revenue Soars on Hepatitis C Drug
abstract: Gilead Sciences reported $2.3 billion in sales of Sovaldi, a new hepatitis C drug that has raised an outcry over its $1,000-a-pill price.
lead_paragraph: Record sales of a new hepatitis C drug pushed the first-quarter earnings of Gilead Sciences far beyond expectations, the company reported on Tuesday, but could also heighten concerns about the high cost of the drug, known as Sovaldi, and the ability of the health care system to pay for it.

abstract: The actor-director clarifies which Jackson Pollock biography he relied on most for his film.

abstract: No longer the ugly stepbrothers of the beauty industry, men’s facial moisturizers have upgraded with better textures and ingredients.
lead_paragraph: No longer the ugly stepbrothers of the beauty industry, men’s facial moisturizers have upgraded with better textures and ingredients. Enough so that we wondered if they may better some women’s products. Below, this female reporter tests four.

headline: Taming the Digital Wild West
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'E-Commerce', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: The web may be changing business, but regulations still apply.
lead_paragraph: THE Internet has grown up. It is no longer just about providing information but about fundamental changes in the way we go about our daily lives.

headline: Harvey, Asked to Delete Post, Leaves Twitter
abstract: The Mets asked Matt Harvey to remove a post that showed a photograph of Harvey making an obscene gesture the day he had elbow surgery. Harvey responded by deleting his account.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday morning marked six months since Matt Harvey had Tommy John surgery, and the Mets ace wanted to celebrate. He dug through photographs from that day in October, found one that made him chuckle, and posted it to his Twitter account.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 51
abstract: Thierry Henry scored 51 goals for France, but none was more memorable than the one he set up on the final day of qualifying for the 2010 World Cup.
lead_paragraph: Thierry Henry scored 51 career goals for France, but none was more memorable — or controversial — than the last one he set up for Les Bleus.

headline: JetBlue Airways’ Pilots Vote to Join Union
abstract: Pilots at JetBlue, after rejecting unionization twice, agreed to be represented by the Air Line Pilots Association.
lead_paragraph: After twice rejecting bids to unionize since 2009, JetBlue Airways pilots overwhelmingly agreed to be represented by the Air Line Pilots Association, the union said on Tuesday.

headline: Letterman Introduces His Successor on ‘Late Show’
abstract: Stephen Colbert, who will succeed Mr. Letterman next year on “Late Show With David Letterman,” appeared on the show Tuesday night and did not bring out his satirical character.
lead_paragraph: David Letterman introduced his successor, Stephen Colbert, on his “Late Show With David Letterman” Tuesday night on CBS with a monologue joke and some cordial conversation — but no measuring of the drapes.

headline: Pakistan Is Asked to Shut Down News Channel
keywords: ['Television', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'News and News Media', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Defense Ministry asked the government to close the country’s largest television news station, whose anchorman was shot on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The attempted killing of a prominent Pakistani journalist has prompted a bruising public dispute between Pakistan’s powerful army spy agency and the largest media group that has exacerbated tense relations between the country’s civilian and military leaders.

headline: Why Care About McCutcheon?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Campaign Finance', 'McCutcheon v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Farm Bill (US)', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)']
abstract: It’s the same argument used to defend the marketing of junk food to children.
lead_paragraph: In the food world, change from the ground up is all well and good. We desperately need cooks, gardeners, farmers and teachers. But we also need legislation. The recently passed and almost uniformly abysmal Farm Bill is a lesson in how legislation affects those of us working to change the chaotic so-called food “system.” Pittances were tossed at supporters of local and organic food, fortunes’ worth of agribusiness subsidies were maintained, and much-needed support for the country’s least well-off was slashed.

headline: It’s All About May 25
abstract: The revolution that started in Tahrir Square in Cairo has moved to the Maidan in Kiev. The first big test for Ukrainians will come with their presidential elections next month.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — The word “maidan” means “square” in Ukrainian and in Arabic. And the “Independence Maidan” of Kiev, like the “Tahrir Maidan” of Cairo, has been the scene of an awe-inspiring burst of democratic aspirations. The barricades of piled cobblestones, tires, wood beams and burned cars erected by Ukrainian revolutionaries are still there — indeed, it looks as if it could be the set of “Les Misérables” — and people still lay fresh flowers at the makeshift shrines for the more than 100 people killed in the Maidan by the old and now deposed regime here. Walking through it, though, I tried to explain to my host that, while I was incredibly impressed, a lot of Americans today have “Maidan fatigue” — too many dashed hopes for democracy in too many squares — from Afghanistan to Iran, Iraq to Egypt, Syria to Libya.

headline: In a Tie, Atlético Madrid Can Still Declare Victory
abstract: Atlético, a team that has a payroll of almost $90 million less than the other three teams remaining in the Champions League tournament, is one game from a place in the final.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — There are, technically, hundreds of professional soccer clubs in Spain. Yet for much of the rest of the world, there have really been only two. Barcelona and Real Madrid. Real Madrid and Barcelona. Los Blancos. La Blaugrana. For years, they have felt like monoliths passing trophies back and forth while everyone else jockeyed for a sniff.

headline: Rise of the Milkbots
abstract: At a farm near Albany, N.Y., robots milk the cows. Dairy operations across New York have been leading the country’s charge into a brave new world of automated milking systems.
lead_paragraph: At a farm near Albany, N.Y., robots milk the cows. Dairy operations across New York have been leading the country’s charge into a brave new world of automated milking systems.

headline: Making Airfares Less Transparent
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Editorials']
abstract: Lawmakers in the House are pushing legislation that would mislead travelers about the true cost of flying.
lead_paragraph: A bipartisan group of lawmakers in the House is pushing legislation that would make it easier for airlines to deceive travelers about the true cost of flying.

headline: Abu Ghraib, 10 Years Later
keywords: ['Detainees', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Alien Tort Statute (1789)', 'Torture', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Editorials']
abstract: A correct ruling by an appeals court in Virginia would give four victims, who were brutalized in the prison, a long-delayed chance for justice.
lead_paragraph: Baghdad’s infamous Abu Ghraib prison now stands empty. Its closure, prompted by fears that it could be overrun by Sunni insurgents, along with the transfer of its 2,400 prisoners, was announced last week by the Iraqi government, which resumed control of the facility in 2006.

headline: A.N.C.’s Stature Wanes as Disenchantment Grows in South Africa
abstract: The venerated African National Congress is expected to win in the coming election, though unemployment and abuses of power are among the issues stirring opposition forces.
lead_paragraph: PRETORIA, South Africa — Isaac Ramaifo works as a functionary in the Union Buildings, the seat of state power here, and is a member of the governing African National Congress. But as South Africa approaches watershed elections next month, he, like many, is torn between an instinctive loyalty to the party that has ruled for the 20 years since the end of apartheid and worries about its ability to deliver prosperity.

headline: Rookies in Their First Playoffs Are Already Looking Seasoned
abstract: Nathan MacKinnon, a center for the Colorado Avalanche, is among the rookies excelling in the postseason.
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — The most dominant forward in the early stages of the N.H.L. playoffs is an 18-year-old from Nova Scotia who lives in a teammate’s basement.

headline: Lesson for the Police: Be Careful What You Tweet For
abstract: Rather than heartwarming neighborhood scenes or pictures of tourists with mounted officers, many posts tagged #myNYPD showed violent interactions with civilians or other unflattering incidents.
lead_paragraph: When the New York Police Department asked Twitter users on Tuesday to share their photographs with police officers, they were perhaps expecting a few feel-good neighborhood scenes or tourists with police horses in Times Square.

headline: At Stake in the Aereo Case Is How We Watch TV
keywords: ['Television', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations']
abstract: The case has a little bit of everything, including the first big test at the Supreme Court of who owns and has rights to things stored in the cloud.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For most of its two years, Aereo has been an obscure start-up that gained little traction with consumers, partly because it took something that was traditionally easy — watching the broadcast networks — and made it sound complicated. It grabs local over-the-air signals on an array of tiny antennas that users can stream through the Internet to watch and record programming for $8 to $12 a month. Got that?

headline: Passport Diplomacy
abstract: The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to hear a case that touches on Congress’s authority over foreign policy. When is Congress justified in overriding the president’s policy?

headline: G.M. Seeks to Fend Off Lawsuits Over Switch
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Bankruptcies', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The company asked a federal bankruptcy judge to dismiss dozens of lawsuits over its handling of a defective ignition switch in millions of cars, and to bar similar cases in the future.
lead_paragraph: General Motors moved on Tuesday to prevent future safety lapses by expanding its oversight of problematic vehicles even as the automaker continued to take an aggressive legal posture in dealing with its past missteps.

headline: Homs Emerges as Turning Point in Shaping Syria’s Future
abstract: For both the government and opposition, the central Syrian crossroads city, practically reduced to rubble during the civil war, will play a crucial role in stitching the country back together.
lead_paragraph: HOMS, Syria — On the edge of the Old City here, children play beside a house blown open by shelling. An antique wood-framed mirror leans against the wall, so that soldiers can watch for threats from around the corner. A block closer to one of the city’s last front lines, trash, rubble and rusted cars litter streets of charred and sagging buildings.

headline: Manning Says Ankle Will Heal for Camp
abstract: After having arthroscopic surgery earlier this month, Giants quarterback Eli Manning said he will be “100 percent” when training camp begins in July.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The dreadful 2013 Giants season ended with the left ankle of Eli Manning in a hard boot, protection against the serious sprain that the franchise quarterback sustained in the final game.

headline: With a Mouthful, A&W Hopes to Draw Baby Boomers’ Offspring
abstract: The restaurant chain, which peaked in the 1960s and ’70s, hopes a campaign that includes a 304-character hashtag will attract the younger generation.
lead_paragraph: THE popularity of the A&W Restaurants chain in the United States peaked in the 1960s and 1970s, when the number of locations — many with carhop service — swelled to 2,400, so it is no wonder that the brand stirs nostalgia in the baby boomer generation. But now A&W, which has about 700 restaurants, wants to make an impression on those boomers’ children, and the brand is increasingly turning to social media to do so.

headline: Colleges Seek New Paths to Diversity After Court Ruling
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'AFFIRMATIVE ACTION', 'Colleges and Universities', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Income', 'Minorities', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: Many people in the affirmative action debate envision admissions criteria moving away from race and toward factors such as income.
lead_paragraph: Leaders in higher education, upset by Tuesday’s Supreme Court decision upholding Michigan’s ban on race-based preferences in college admissions, said the ruling would nudge them further along the path of finding alternative means to promote diversity in their student bodies.

headline: New York’s Case Against Airbnb Is Argued in Albany
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Subpoenas', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: Little ground was given in an Albany court by New York regulators or by Airbnb, the apartment sharing service that is fighting a state subpoena.
lead_paragraph: There was no room for agreement, and no agreement about rooms, in court on Tuesday in Albany.

headline: Who Will Win the Senate?
abstract: Leo, our election-forecasting machine, gives Republicans a 52% chance of taking a majority.
lead_paragraph: When Americans go to bed on election night this year, there is a real chance that they won’t know which party has won control of the Senate. For that matter, the country may not know who has won a Senate majority at any time in November.

headline: A Double Standard in Doping Punishments
abstract: Lance Armstrong can never again compete in an Olympic sport, while three of the people who helped facilitate doping in the peloton will be free to return in eight years or less.
lead_paragraph: What does it take to receive a lifetime ban from cycling for breaking antidoping rules?

headline: Sherpas Move to Shut Everest in Labor Fight
abstract: Last week’s deadly avalanche has prompted Mount Everest’s Sherpas to threaten to cancel the season unless the government shares proceeds from what has become a multimillion-dollar industry.
lead_paragraph: KATMANDU, Nepal — Over the years, as Mount Everest attracted larger crowds of amateur climbers from the West, the Sherpas adjusted: to a slower ascent, to traffic jams, to bulging loads of gear. Every spring some new frustration would get them talking, then recede with the end of the season.

headline: D’Souza Case Is Political, Lawyer Says
abstract: The lawyer Benjamin Brafman filed court papers claiming his client, the author and filmmaker Dinesh D’Souza, was targeted by the government for consistently criticizing President Obama.
lead_paragraph: When the conservative author and filmmaker Dinesh D’Souza was charged in January with illegally using straw donors to contribute to a 2012 New York Republican Senate campaign, his lawyer denied that he had acted with any corrupt or criminal intent.

headline: Korea Confronts Tendency to Overlook Safety as Toll in Ferry Sinking Grows
keywords: ['Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Ferries']
abstract: Amid a list of errors that appeared to have contributed to the disaster, South Koreans are expressing shame and anger at how far their country still has to go to address inadequate safety measures and lax regulation.
lead_paragraph: JINDO, South Korea — As Navy divers recovered the bodies of dozens of teenagers drowned waiting for a rescue of their doomed ferry, South Korea has begun a national bout of hand-wringing over the country’s tendency to overlook safety precautions in its quest for economic success.

headline: Qatar: Sentence of U.S. Couple Was Based on Lesser Charge
keywords: ['Sentences (Criminal)', 'ADOPTIONS', 'Eating Disorders', 'Human Trafficking', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: A panel of judges that found an American couple guilty in the death of their adopted daughter convicted them on the charge of jeopardizing the child, and not the original charge of murder.
lead_paragraph: A panel of judges in Qatar who found an American couple guilty last month in the January 2013 death of their adopted daughter convicted them on the charge of jeopardizing the child, and not the more serious original charge of murder, according to a translation of the verdict provided Tuesday by the couple’s lawyers. The defendants, Matthew and Grace Huang of Los Angeles, who have not been permitted to leave Qatar, are appealing their three-year sentence, which was announced on March 27. But until Tuesday, their lawyers were unsure how to proceed with the appeal because the judges had never explained the reduced charge. Prosecutors had accused the Huangs of starving their daughter, Gloria, 8, and originally suspected them of being child traffickers because the defendants are of Asian heritage and the child was African. The Huangs, who attributed the child’s death to an eating disorder, said the prosecution was based on flawed evidence, racial prejudices and misunderstandings about Western adoption.

Some of us go for the big real estate and build the large Sunday puzzles. Some of us hoist the triple stacks. I like to think of the Saturday constructors as the executioners.

headline: India: Court to Hear Appeal Over Restoration of Ban on Gay Sex
abstract: The announcement by India’s Supreme Court that it would hear an appeal of its ruling in December that re-criminalized gay sex is unlikely to lead to a serious reconsideration of the decision.
lead_paragraph: India’s Supreme Court announced Tuesday that it would hear an appeal of its decision in December that re-criminalized gay sex. The hearing is largely a formality and is unlikely to lead to a serious reconsideration of the decision. A lower court ruled in 2009 that an 1861 law mandating a 10-year sentence for “carnal intercourse against the order of nature with man, woman or animal” was unconstitutional. But the Supreme Court overturned the lower court’s decision, holding that only Parliament had the power to change that law.

lead_paragraph: If this were a melodrama called “Bullets Over the Bronx,” the second act of the production would remain in the genre of mystery. But, spoiler alert: The story probably will not end with a shootout.

lead_paragraph: BOSTON — After Zeituni Onyango, the woman President Obama once called Auntie, died in a South Boston nursing home this month, her closest relatives gathered her belongings at her nearby apartment. There, framed photographs of her with the president covered the wall.

He was 83.

headline: Brazil: Deadly Violence Erupts in Rio
keywords: ['Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: At least two people died on Tuesday after a day of violence in a slum that abuts the Copacabana tourist district of Rio de Janeiro.
lead_paragraph: At least two people died Tuesday after a day of violence in a slum that abuts the Copacabana tourist district of Rio de Janeiro. Local news media reported that the deaths occurred in the slum, or favela, called Pavão-Pavãozinho. The disturbances began after a young man who was a dancer on a television variety show was found dead and residents charged that he had been killed by a police officer, according to the reports. The police said that they were investigating, but that marks on the man’s body indicated that he could have fallen to his death. A protest turned violent, and several officers became trapped in the favela. An elite squad then arrived. Copacabana residents reported hearing gunshots and what sounded like small explosions. A second man was later found fatally shot. Separately, a police officer was shot in another favela in the north of the city. The violence comes less than two months before Rio and other cities in Brazil are to host the World Cup.

headline: Inside a Remote Island Made of Marble, an Artist’s New Abode
abstract: On his own island near Patagonia, Chile, Not Vital carved out a truly organic space, the NotOna Tunnel, instead of building a home the traditional way (of course he did).
lead_paragraph: In the middle of the Lago General Carrera, a lake that stretches from Chile to Argentina, the Swiss artist Not Vital has crafted another minimalist yet innovative home for himself. He bought one of the 13 islands there in 2008 — “It is not big, and it is not small,” he says — and has been working on it since 2009. This month, he finally finished the quiet little island, which he has named NotOna, the first photos of which are featured here.

headline: Misfortune Leaves Student Loan Borrowers on the Hook
abstract: In some cases, the death or bankruptcy filing of a co-signer can mean a loan default, even if the borrower has paid consistently and on time.
lead_paragraph: You have been faithfully making your student loan payment each month, and are making steady progress paying down the balance. But then your parent — who co-signed your loan — dies, or files for bankruptcy protection. All of a sudden, your lender is demanding that you repay the loan in full, even though you have never been late with a payment.

headline: New York City Housing Push Should Aim at Poorest, Report Says
keywords: ['Affordable Housing', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Scott M. Stringer, the New York City comptroller, said affordable-housing efforts needed to focus on the poorest households and the vanishing cheaper apartments that are hardest to replace.
lead_paragraph: The New York City comptroller, Scott M. Stringer, is recommending that the city focus its affordable housing efforts on the most burdened residents — those in households making $40,000 or less a year — and also invest in “stabilizing” a crumbling public housing system that has risen in importance as fewer low-income New Yorkers can afford to live in private apartments.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 5:05 P.M. (Starz Cinema) CHICKEN WITH PLUMS (2012) A celebrated but tormented violinist, Nasser-Ali (Mathieu Amalric, above), in 1958 Tehran retreats to his bed to end his life after his prized instrument is broken, in this drama from Marjane Satrapi and Vincent Paronnaud, based on Ms. Satrapi’s graphic novel of the same title. But in flashbacks — and flash-forwards — starring Nasser-Ali’s wife (Maria de Medeiros) and children (Mathis Bour and Enna Balland; Chiara Mastroianni and Christian Friedel portray them as adults), it soon becomes clear that his melancholy is rooted in a deeper heartache: his long-ago love, Irane (Golshifteh Farahani). “Not that ‘Chicken With Plums’ is gloomy,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Like its swooning, madly melodramatic musical score (by Olivier Bernet), the film takes an almost giddy pleasure in unhappiness, turning even pedestrian moments of boredom or discomfort into occasions for wild invention.” The result, which features a naked Sophia Loren and Edouard Baer as the Angel of Death, “is captivating, but not exactly moving.”

headline: Egypt: U.S. to Deliver Helicopters
abstract: The United States will deliver to Egypt 10 Apache helicopters that were held up last year after President Mohamed Morsi was deposed.
lead_paragraph: The United States will deliver to Egypt 10 Apache helicopters that were held up last year after President Mohamed Morsi was deposed, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel told the Egyptian defense minister on Tuesday. Mr. Hagel said the helicopters would be used in Egypt’s efforts against terrorism in the Sinai, the Defense Department said in a statement. In a separate call, Secretary of State John Kerry told Egypt’s foreign minister, Nabil Fahmy, that he is certifying to Congress that Egypt is living up to the terms of the 1979 peace treaty with Israel, a move that allows the release of some aid to Cairo, a State Department spokeswoman said.

headline: 10,000 ‘Olympic Babies’ Strain the Beijing System
abstract: Six years after China hosted the Olympic Games in 2008, a surge of children entering elementary school in Beijing is putting pressure on the system, but the state has enough places for them, an official said.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 11 p.m. ET| “Olympic Babies are Coming,” read a headline in Beijing News on Wednesday. With thousands more children than usual born in Beijing in 2008, a year considered by many to be lucky both for the number eight and for being the year that China hosted the Olympic Games, the state is scrambling to find enough school spaces for all the 6-year-olds heading to first grade this fall — about 10,000 more than last September.

headline: Colbert Visits Letterman on ‘Late Show’
abstract: Once upon a time, the transfer of power from one monarch to another would involve some pomp and ritual, maybe even a passing of a crown. For Stephen Colbert and David Letterman, the ritual took the form of a selfie.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, the transfer of power from one monarch to another would involve some pomp and ritual, maybe even a passing of a crown. But when Stephen Colbert visited David Letterman Tuesday night on “The Late Show,” the comedy franchise he will inherit next year, they commemorated the occasion in grand 2014 style: With the taking of a selfie. The comedy titans flashed broad smiles, with Mr. Colbert leaning forward.

headline: A Quiet Moment Among Neighbors
abstract: A photographer moved to a small town to understand what people hold dear. In time, she found herself drawn to subtler, quieter scenes.

She has interned with The San Francisco Examiner, The Fayetteville Observer in North Carolina and The Flint Journal in Michigan. Ms. Justice, 26, studied photojournalism and sociology at the University of Cincinnati. Her conversation with James Estrin has been edited.

headline: Should a Chimp Be Able to Sue Its Owner?
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Monkeys and Apes', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Steven Wise is arguing for the legal “personhood” of chimps and other animals. And no one is laughing him out of the courtroom.
lead_paragraph: Just before 4 p.m. on Oct. 10, Steven Wise pulled his rental car in front of a multiacre compound on State Highway 30 near the tiny Adirondack hamlet of Gloversville, N.Y., and considered his next move. For the past 15 minutes, Wise had been slowly driving the perimeter of the property, trying to get a better read on the place. An assortment of transport trailers — for horses and livestock, cars, boats and snowmobiles — cluttered a front lot beside a single-story business office with the sign “Circle L Trailer Sales” set above the door. At the rear of the grounds was a barn-size, aluminum-sided shed, all its doors closed, the few small windows covered in thick plastic.

headline: ‘Animals Are Persons Too’
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Monkeys and Apes']
abstract: A short documentary follows the lawyer Steven Wise’s effort to break down the legal wall that separates animals from humans.
lead_paragraph: How does a thing become a person? In December 2013, the lawyer Steven Wise showed the world how, with a little legal jujitsu, an animal can transition from a thing without rights to a person with legal protections. This Op-Doc video follows Mr. Wise on his path to filing the first-ever lawsuits in the United States demanding limited “personhood” rights for certain animals, on behalf of four captive chimpanzees in New York State.

But Beijing’s firm rejection of President Obama’s comments on Wednesday about islands claimed by both China and Japan underscored the maritime tensions that continue to trouble Asia.

abstract: President Obama, who began a four-country tour on Wednesday, will encounter leaders under pressure from angry, often grief-stricken constituents.

It was a fitting start, given that everywhere on this trip, he will witness the lingering fallout of disasters, natural and human-made.
