The article, headlined “50 Years Later, Hardship Hits Back,” was the first in a series about the poor in America called “Caught in Poverty.”

headline: Anglo-Irish Retailer Primark to Make U.S. Landfall in Boston
abstract: The low-cost retailer Primark is the latest import to the United States market for basic and affordable clothing.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Seeing the recent success of Topshop, Uniqlo and other overseas low-cost retailers among United States consumers, the Anglo-Irish retailer Primark said on Wednesday that it planned to open its first store in the country next year.

headline: In Our Pages: April 24
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: in 1889, a fight breaks out at a fair in Vincennes; British Foreign Secretary talks about the similarities between British and U.S. citizens in 1964.
lead_paragraph: 1889: Fight at a French Fair

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
abstract: Details of the methods behind the public opinion poll.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Upshot/Kaiser Family Foundation Poll of four Southern states is based on telephone interviews conducted April 8 through April 15 with 4,152 adults. Of these, 3,594 said they were registered to vote: 857 in Arkansas, 891 in Kentucky, 946 in Louisiana, and 900 in North Carolina.

headline: British Financial Regulator Adds 2 Senior Advisers
abstract: The Financial Conduct Authority has appointed two senior advisers – David Saunders, a former head of Britain’s Competition Commission, and Gunner Burkhart, a former executive at Goldman Sachs.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Financial Conduct Authority of Britain has added a former head of Britain’s Competition Commission and a former executive at Goldman Sachs and Lehman Brothers Holdings to its ranks as it looks to increase its expertise.

headline: Big Pharma’s Deal Bonanza
abstract: Pharmaceutical companies are on the prowl for deals. | The Allergan bid charts new territory for takeovers. | Preet Bharara’s perfect record is in jeopardy. | Comcast looks to divest subscribers.
lead_paragraph: The pharmaceutical industry is regaining its swagger, Michael J. de la Merced, David Gelles and Rachel Abrams write in DealBook. On Tuesday alone, pharmaceutical companies announced $74 billion worth of potential deals, including an unconventional $45.6 billion bid for Allergan, the maker of Botox, and a flurry of swaps and sales between Novartis of Switzerland and GlaxoSmithKline of Britain. More deals in the cash-rich industry are expected.

headline: Australia Examines Material Washed Ashore for Link to Missing Jet
abstract: The agency overseeing the hunt for the wreckage of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 did not specify what the find was or why it was of interest.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Investigators are examining whether material that washed ashore near the southern end of Western Australia is connected to the missing Malaysia Airlines aircraft, Australian search organizers said on Wednesday.

headline: Russia Warns Ukraine of Potential Military Response
abstract: Sergey V. Lavrov, the Russian foreign minister, continued to ratchet up pressure on Kiev, drawing comparisons to the 2008 conflict with Georgia.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia continued Wednesday to ratchet up pressure on the government in Kiev, warning that events in eastern Ukraine could prompt a military response and again accusing the United States of directing events there.

headline: On Combating Government Secrecy: One Step Forward, One Leap Back
abstract: A court ruling provides a press-rights victory; a new government directive chokes off information; and James Risen waits.
lead_paragraph: To put it mildly, President Obama’s early promises of transparency in government haven’t exactly turned out that way.

headline: Australia to Bolster Air Force With More Lockheed Jets
keywords: ['F-35 Airplane', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Aircraft', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The country will buy 58 more F-35 fighter jets for $11.6 billion, in a deal the prime minister called one of Australia’s largest military purchases.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — In a $11.6 billion deal, Australia is ordering 58 more F-35 fighter jets built by Lockheed Martin, increasing the total fleet to 72, Prime Minister Tony Abbott said Wednesday.

headline: Former Executive Sells Aam Aadmi Party as Pro-Business
keywords: ['Affordable Housing', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Elections', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Microfinance', 'Politics and Government', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Taxation']
abstract: Meera Sanyal, a candidate in Mumbai who once headed the Indian unit of the Royal Bank of Scotland, contends her party’s anticorruption platform is good for entrepreneurs.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — As a truck festooned with broomsticks, the symbol of the Aam Aadmi Party, wheezed in a narrow lane in Kamathipura, the red-light district in south Mumbai, women in floral nightgowns appeared on their doorsteps, curious about the commotion.

headline: Post Office Rules
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A mild request by postal clerks, updated for the digital age, is seen on a sign in Queens.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Now Nattering on His Own Throne
abstract: On Sunday John Oliver, the “Daily Show” veteran, will launch “Last Week Tonight,” his new satirical news show on HBO.
lead_paragraph: Felicitous timing has powered the steeply ascendant television career of John Oliver since the day he landed in New York from London — July 16, 2006 — and, just 24 hours later, sweaty and jet-lagged, found himself mocking Tony Blair in an exchange with Jon Stewart on “The Daily Show.”

headline: An Artist’s View of Brussels
abstract: On the occasion of the Belgian capital’s art week, an American artist currently living there offers a guide to the city’s best under-the-radar pleasures.
lead_paragraph: Brussels may be a hub for international business, but the Belgian capital — whose Art Brussels contemporary art fair kicks off Friday — is also full of unexpected pleasures. Creative types are drawn to the city’s relatively low cost of living, multicultural flavor and vibrant art scene, anchored by the Wiels Contemporary Art Center. Here, on the eve of the fair, the New York-based artist Megan Marrin — currently an artist in residence at Wiels — lists a few of her favorite cultural gems in the city.

headline: Amazon to Stream Original HBO Content
abstract: In a deal believed to be worth at least $300 million, Amazon is forming an alliance with HBO.
lead_paragraph: Amazon will stream a selection of HBO series, mini-series and original movies as part of its Prime subscription service, the latest alliance between technology and entertainment companies trying to capture viewers who are moving online.

headline: Amazon.com is learning the hard way that people care more about price than brand loyalty.
abstract: Surveys have shown that people will gladly leave a site for another that offers free shipping or a price that is even a few dollars lower.
lead_paragraph: In states where Amazon has been forced to begin charging sales tax, households decreased their expenditures on the site by 9.5 percent and by 24 percent on purchases of more than $299, according to a new study by Ohio State University researchers. Although bricks-and-mortar retailers and state governments pushed for Amazon to collect sales tax, they did not necessarily benefit. Sales increased only 2 percent at local stores, but rose nearly 20 percent at competing online retailers that do not charge sales tax. For expensive purchases, the rivals saw a 24 percent increase.

headline: U.S. Military Exercises to Begin in Eastern Europe
abstract: The deployments, in response to events in Ukraine, are a reflection of American commitment to defense within the NATO alliance, a Pentagon official said.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — American military exercises in Eastern Europe are to begin Wednesday as part of a move to ease the anxieties of eastern European countries alarmed by Russia’s efforts to reassert its hegemony in the region, Western officials said.

headline: A ‘Lyons’ Reunion at the Vineyard
abstract: Nicky Silver is back with a new play about a celebrated actress, played by Linda Lavin, having a whole lot of trouble with the pressure of playing Medea.
lead_paragraph: Why mess with success? In 2011, the Vineyard Theater produced a new Nicky Silver family play with a juicy role for Linda Lavin. “The Lyons,” in which she played a neurotic New York wife looking forward to the death of her husband, became an Off Broadway hit and transferred to Broadway. Now, the prolific Mr. Silver is back with a new play, “Too Much Sun,” which starts performances on May 1 at the Vineyard. It once again stars Ms. Lavin.

headline: Justice Dept. Expands Eligibility for Clemency
keywords: ['Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Mandatory Sentencing']
abstract: Nonviolent felons will be eligible if they have served 10 years in prison and would have received significantly lower sentences under today’s laws.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department announced a plan on Wednesday to canvass the entire federal prison population for the first time to find inmates who committed low-level crimes and could be released early.

headline: Degrees of Influence Peddling in China and U.S.
abstract: Two recent articles show the differences — and the similarities — of how favors and connections are used by the powerful.
lead_paragraph: To understand how money and politics intertwine in the world’s two largest economies, look no further than two important articles in The Times in the last few days.

headline: Pay Gap Is Because of Gender, Not Jobs
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Women and Girls', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Discrimination']
abstract: A majority of the pay differential between men and women comes from differences within occupations, not between them, according to a Harvard labor economist.
lead_paragraph: Are women paid less than men because they choose to be, by gravitating to lower-paying jobs like teaching and social work?

headline: Poetry Profiles: Louisiana State University Press
abstract: An interview with MaryKatherine Callaway, the director of LSU Press.
lead_paragraph: The latest in a series of occasional profiles of poetry publishers. These questions were answered by MaryKatherine Callaway, the director of LSU Press.

headline: Why Do the Boy Scouts Still Ban Gay Troop Leaders?
abstract: The organization’s new president, Robert Gates, should speak out against the rule.
lead_paragraph: Robert Gates, the former defense secretary and Eagle Scout, will in May begin a two-year term as president of the Boy Scouts of America. At the Pentagon, Mr. Gates backed President Obama’s call to end the unjust “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy that barred gay men and women from serving openly in the military. If he cares to build on that record of inclusion, he could start by publicly voicing disapproval of the B.S.A.’s mistreatment of Geoff McGrath.

headline: Flights of Fancy
abstract: Two new books remind us that children’s outsize desires are often best fulfilled imaginatively.
lead_paragraph: Mired in reality as adults are, they can find it hard to remember that children’s outsize desires are often best fulfilled imaginatively. Two entertaining new books make this point with a light touch. “The day I discovered I could fly, I knew that I was special,” begins Michaël Escoffier in “The Day I Lost My Superpowers,” illustrated by Kris Di Giacomo. The speaker is a preschooler (seemingly a girl, though boy readers will find there’s nothing to prevent them imagining themselves in her place) who is convinced — in a way quite rightly — of her own superpowers. These include the ability to launch herself off the playground slide into the sandbox, to make cupcakes disappear by sheer force of concentration, and to direct plants and inanimate objects to do her will by staying in one place.

headline: A Fresh Setback for VW in Its Bid for Full Control of the Truck Maker Scania
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Boards of Directors', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Trucks and Trucking']
abstract: The Swedish pension fund Alecta, which holds about 2 percent of Scania’s capital, is the latest shareholder to reject Volkswagen’s $9.3 billion cash offer to take full control of Scania.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The German automaker Volkswagen faced a fresh setback on Wednesday in its bid to take full control of the Swedish truck maker Scania.

headline: Palestinian Rivals Announce Unity Pact, Drawing U.S. and Israeli Rebuke
abstract: The deal between Hamas and the Palestine Liberation Organization appeared more serious than past attempts, experts said, and came as hopes faded for a resolution to peace negotiations with Israel.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The faltering Middle East peace process was thrown into further jeopardy on Wednesday, with Israel and the United States harshly condemning a new deal announced by feuding Palestinian factions, including the militant group Hamas, to repair their seven-year rift.

headline: Malaysia on Unidentified Debris on Beach
abstract: Malaysian officials said they were waiting for verification on whether unidentified material that washed up on the Australian coastline is from missing Flight 370.
lead_paragraph: Malaysian officials said they were waiting for verification on whether unidentified material that washed up on the Australian coastline is from missing Flight 370.

headline: A Man of Magic in the Real World
abstract: An impresario remembers Gabriel García Márquez.
lead_paragraph: In 1983 I was a young would-be film distributor at the Cannes Film Festival looking to find a movie to make my mark. I had gone to film school, I had studied Godard, Truffaut, Visconti and Fellini, and I had stars in my eyes. I wanted to follow in the great tradition of Don Rugoff, the president of Cinema 5, who was everybody’s idol in the film distribution world. But there I was, trying to go to various screenings and having no connections whatsoever with anyone.

headline: Euro Zone Deficit Hits Target for First Time Since 2008
keywords: ['Euro (Currency)', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: While the data was a bright spot, the euro zone’s total debt rose to 92.6 percent of gross domestic product — well above the 60 percent target.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Euro zone governments have hit an important goal, bringing their combined budget deficits for 2013 in line with their target for the first time since 2008, official data showed on Wednesday. But for some economists, meeting that cost-cutting goal has not been worth the price paid in lost jobs and feeble growth.

headline: With Vaults and Domes, Two Architects Left Their Imprint on City
abstract: The work of the Guastavino Fireproof Construction Company adorns some of the greatest spaces in New York, like Pennsylvania Station and Grand Central Terminal.
lead_paragraph: If you think the old Pennsylvania Station has completely disappeared, get off a No. 1 train at 34th Street-Penn Station, walk to the southernmost exit and press your nose to the safety-glass panel at the top of the landing. Then look up.

headline: Six First Ladies Together Backstage
abstract: These strong women all helped to modernize the role, but the 1994 imagery was still retro.
lead_paragraph: Here are six first ladies, 20 years ago next month, at a joint fund-raising appearance at the United States Botanic Garden in Washington. The body language seems revealing. Hillary Rodham Clinton, the incumbent president’s wife, confers with the widow of L.B.J., a Big Daddy for modern Democrats. Betty Ford turns to Barbara Bush, wife of the young Texan whose career her husband, Jerry, had once promoted, and away from Rosalynn Carter, whose Jimmy had thwarted Gerald Ford’s re-election. Former actress Nancy Reagan seems to be waiting for their cue to perform.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Divider Effect
abstract: Finding your first office. Sharing a desk with a cat. Do small businesses really need accountants?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Despite Poll, Problems Lurk for Democratic Incumbents in South
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters', 'Elections, Senate', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: The surveys were of registered voters, a measure that often overestimates Democratic support, and vulnerabilities remain over disapproval of the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: The new New York Times Upshot/Kaiser Family Foundation poll offers some encouraging news for Democrats. The incumbent Democratic senators in three states — Arkansas, Louisiana and North Carolina — still hold at least nominal leads. Perhaps the best news for Democrats comes in Arkansas, where the polls show Mark Pryor ahead by a surprising 10-point margin.

headline: Led Zeppelin Releases Two Previously Unheard Recordings
abstract: The two tracks are “Keys to the Highway,” recorded in 1970, and an early version of “Whole Lotta Love.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Led Zeppelin guitarist Jimmy Page clearly likes to be in control. The British rock group, which is reissuing its first three albums on June 3, has just released two previously unheard recordings that Mr. Page, 70, found while going through the band’s archives.

headline: Piketty’s Book on Wealth and Inequality Is More Popular in Richer States
abstract: Did a book by a French economist begin a broad national conversation about inequality, or is it only attracting attention in the East Coast liberal echo chamber?
lead_paragraph: Thomas Piketty’s tome “Capital in the Twenty-First Century” is currently the top-selling book at Amazon.com. It’s also been the subject of intense media coverage from publications with New York, Washington and Wall Street in their names. But has Mr. Piketty kicked off a broad national conversation about inequality, or is the book being read mostly in the East Coast liberal echo chamber?

headline: Health Law’s Middle-Ground Approach Leaves It Unloved
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicare']
abstract: A new poll finds that conservatives dislike the government’s involvement in the Affordable Care Act; liberals wanted more.
lead_paragraph: The legacy achievement of the Obama administration has also become its largest political conundrum. Many Americans disapprove of the Affordable Care Act — but for different reasons, coming from different sides.

headline: A Briton’s View of Paris: Martin Parr at the Maison Européenne de la Photographie
abstract: The British photographer’s hyper-real images of visitors to the French capital stand in striking contrast to the familiar, romanticized notion of tourists in Paris.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In January, the soon-to-be-elected mayor of Paris, Anne Hidalgo, set off a minor wave of cross-Channel outrage when, piqued by the claim of her London counterpart, Boris Johnson, that his city attracted more tourists than hers, she dismissed London as a ‘‘suburb of Paris.’’ (She later tamped down her comment in an open letter in The Guardian.)

headline: FIFA Suspends Barcelona Transfer Ban
abstract: Barcelona will be allowed to sign new players this summer while it appeals an 18-month sanction handed down by soccer’s governing body.
lead_paragraph: Barcelona will be allowed to sign new players during this summer’s transfer window after FIFA on Wednesday suspended a ban on acquisitions while the club pursues its appeal.

headline: Philanthropist Admits Stealing More Than $1 Million From Charity
abstract: William E. Rapfogel, a community leader with ties to the New York State Assembly speaker, admitted that he stole from the Metropolitan Council on Jewish Poverty while he was its executive director.
lead_paragraph: For most of his long and very public life as a philanthropist, William E. Rapfogel has been surrounded by powerful friends and politicians, chief among them Sheldon Silver, the New York State Assembly speaker.

headline: A Different Kind of Super Power
abstract: The cartoonist Scott McCloud’s next project, “The Sculptor,” coming in February 2015, is about a man who asks for a special power: To be able to sculpt anything with his bare hands.
lead_paragraph: The cartoonist Scott McCloud, who wrote about what makes comic books tick in “Understanding Comics” and speculated about their future in “Reinventing Comics,” is returning to fiction for his next project, “The Sculptor,” a graphic novel to be published in February 2015 by First Second.

headline: Gallery | Emerging Fashion and Photography Talents From the Hyères Festival
abstract: On the eve of the venerable French fete honoring leading young international creatives, a preview of some of its top prize contenders.
lead_paragraph: Starting Friday, the 29th International Festival of Fashion and Photography at Hyères in the South of France will be showcasing its annual roundup of young talents to watch and awarding prizes in the fashion and photography categories. The fashion jury, led by the Opening Ceremony founders and Kenzo designers Carol Lim and Humberto Leon, also included Spike Jonze and Chloë Sevigny; the 10 finalists will display their work at seaside runway shows during the festival weekend. The photography jury was presided over by the legendary lensman Steve Hiett. Winnowed from 743 entries, the work of the 10 finalists will be on view at the Villa Noailles in a group show running through May 25.

headline: Underwater Search for Ferry Victims
abstract: A senior official with the South Korean Coast Guard said rescuers were mobilizing an underwater robot to help with night operations as they hunted for missing passengers.
lead_paragraph: A senior official with the South Korean Coast Guard said rescuers were mobilizing an underwater robot to help with night operations as they hunted for missing passengers.

headline: Why Criticism of Poll Is Misguided
abstract: Polling aficionados are looking for an explanation for a strong Democratic showing. They think they’ve found the problem: respondents’ self-reported vote in the 2012 presidential election.
lead_paragraph: The new New York Times Upshot/Kaiser Family Foundation surveys offer some pretty good results for Democrats — with caveats — so it’s no surprise that polling aficionados are scouring the details for an explanation. They think they’ve found the problem: respondents’ self-reported vote in the 2012 presidential election, which generally found President Obama faring far better than he did in that race. This critique is understandable, but misguided.

headline: Tough Sell for Chinese Pork Producer’s I.P.O.
abstract: The WH Group’s reluctance to reduce the share price won’t tempt investors turned off by the valuation, Una Galani writes for Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: The WH Group’s chopped initial public offering still looks unappetizing.

headline: Bangladesh’s Chance to Get It Right
keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Rana Plaza Building Collapse, Bangladesh (2013)']
abstract: Amid the efforts to improve garment-factory safety after the Rana Plaza collapse, some lessons from a shipbuilding company.
lead_paragraph: Bangladesh is hardly known for its workplace safety. But one unlikely success story can be found in a leading shipbuilding company called Western Marine, based in the port city of Chittagong. Western Marine makes ships for the domestic market but has also sold vessels to Germany and Denmark.

headline: Editorial Contest Winner | The War on Drugs
abstract: For the next 10 days we will be honoring each of the Top 10 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing an essay a day, in the order of submission. Up first, a piece by Brody F.
lead_paragraph: For the next 10 days we will be honoring each of the Top 10 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing an essay a day, in the order of submission.

headline: Justin Bieber Apologizes After Visiting Japanese War Shrine
abstract: Mr. Bieber posted two Instagram photos from the Yasukuni shrine to Japan’s war dead, sparking protests from Chinese officials.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Justin Bieber got a nasty lesson in Asia’s tangled emotions over history on Wednesday when he apologized to irate Chinese fans for posting photos of himself visiting a controversial Tokyo war shrine.

headline: Film at 9/11 Museum Sets Off Clash Over Reference to Islam
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Museums', 'Terrorism', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Movies']
abstract: An advisory group of religious leaders said a documentary at the soon-to-open National September 11 Memorial Museum was offensive to Muslims and could generate prejudice against them.
lead_paragraph: Past the towering tridents that survived the World Trade Center collapse, adjacent to a gallery with photographs of the 19 hijackers, a brief film at the soon-to-open National September 11 Memorial Museum will seek to explain to visitors the historical roots of the attacks.

headline: Times Minute | Easing Prison Sentences
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Vigilantes', 'International Relations']
abstract: Also on the Minute, Syria’s humanitarian crisis, and the risks people take to find their iPhones.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, Syria’s humanitarian crisis, and the risks people take to find their iPhones.

headline: Classical Playlist: Carter, Rand Steiger, Mozart and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: CARTER, SESSIONS AND ECKARDTMiranda Cuckson, violinist, and Blair McMillen, pianist(Urlicht AudioVisual)The violinist Miranda Cuckson and the pianist Blair McMillen, who are individually brilliant and adventurous artists, bring out the best in each other in their frequent collaborations, including their latest recording of contemporary works. Their incisive, animated playing cuts through the density and complexity of Carter’s Duo for Violin and Piano to reveal the music’s wit and fancifulness. Jason Eckardt wrote his glistening, jittery and playfully frenetic “Strömkarl” last year as a companion piece for this recording. Ms. Cuckson is outstanding in Sessions’s magisterial, technically challenging Sonata for Solo Violin (1953). (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Times Minute | Easing Prison Sentences
abstract: Also on the Minute, Syria’s humanitarian crisis, and the risks people take to find their iPhones.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: A Letter to the National September 11 Memorial Museum
abstract: A letter sent to Alice M. Greenwald, the director of the museum, from an interfaith advisory group of religious leaders. The letter detailed their concerns about the film “The Rise of Al Qaeda.”
lead_paragraph: A letter sent to Alice M. Greenwald, the director of the museum, from an interfaith advisory group of religious leaders. The letter detailed their concerns about the film “The Rise of Al Qaeda.”

headline: Ice Climbing in an Alaskan Glacial Paradise
keywords: ['Ice Climbing', 'Hikes and Hiking', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: A family trip to one of the least-visited national parks leads to exhilarating climbs and mesmerizing views of white and blue.
lead_paragraph: Standing on a glacier, you expect the world to be a vast expanse of white.

headline: Chasing Elusive Flowers in South Africa
keywords: ['Flowers and Plants', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Seasons and Months']
abstract: She envisioned heading out from Cape Town for a few hours and then being engulfed by a rainbow of flowers. Here’s how the trip actually turned out.
lead_paragraph: It was supposed to be straightforward: Drive north from Cape Town for a few hours until, voilà, I’m engulfed by a rainbow of flowers. That’s what I envisioned when an acquaintance urged me to witness the blooming spring landscape of the Western and Northern Cape: “Never-ending carpets of wildflowers,” he promised.

headline: A New Class of American Academy Fellows
abstract: The American Academy of Arts and Sciences has elected 204 new members, including Al Pacino and Jules Feiffer.
lead_paragraph: The actor Al Pacino, the bluegrass musician Ralph Stanley, the novelists Annie Proulx and John Irving, and the historian Jill Lepore are among the 204 newly elected fellows of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.

headline: The Republican Party’s Senate Problem
abstract: In a close race, reasons to bet against the G.O.P.
lead_paragraph: After yesterday’s feature on the American middle class’s (relative) decline, the big newsmaker over at The Upshot today is new polling on four red-state Senate races, which shows Mark Pryor, the Democratic incumbent, with a surprisingly large lead over Tom Cotton in Arkansas, and races in North Carolina, Louisiana and Kentucky all effectively in dead heats.

headline: Race in ‘Waxman’ Primary Involves Donating Dollars
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Campaign Finance', 'Political Action Committees', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Representatives Frank Pallone and Ana Eshoo have been giving colleagues thousands of dollars in campaign contributions in a race to win the top Democratic spot on a powerful committee.
lead_paragraph: The congressional Democrats Frank Pallone and Anna Eshoo have been helping their friends this year, and making new ones, with an eye on a potential payback in 2015. Mr. Pallone, from New Jersey, and Ms. Eshoo, from California, have been giving their colleagues thousands of dollars in campaign contributions as part of what could be called the Waxman Primary.

headline: U.S. Workers Losing Ground in Leisure Time, Too
abstract: Other countries are closing the income gap while working less than Americans.
lead_paragraph: The American middle class is losing ground in more ways than one.

headline: Midsummer Night Swing Offerings Range From Afro-Cuban to Classic Rock
abstract: The outdoor ballroom near Lincoln Center will include 15 nights of live music and dancing.
lead_paragraph: Midsummer Night Swing, Lincoln Center’s annual celebration of dance music, will set up its outdoor ballroom at Damrosch Park on June 24 for a performance by Vince Giordano and the Nighthawks, with  Cécile McLorin Salvant, the first of 15 nights of music and dancing at the park. The festival runs through July 12, and includes evenings of African and Cuban dance music, disco, Latin and classic rock, with dance lessons in the style of the evening at each performance.

headline: Risqué Names Reap Rewards for Some Companies
abstract: Nowadays, the bar for grabbing attention has moved higher — or, more precisely, lower.
lead_paragraph: Corin and Brian Mullins thought they had a good name for their debut product, a nonallergenic, high-fiber breakfast cereal, until a supremely satisfied customer called to praise the product’s effectiveness.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival: The Worst Soccer Loss Ever and a Hollywood Ending
abstract: The documentary “Next Goal Wins” follows the American Samoan national team as it tries to rebound from a legendary debacle.
lead_paragraph: Mike Brett and Steve Jamison know what it’s like to be underdogs playing soccer. (From here we’ll call it football.) The future filmmaking partners met as footballers at Cambridge University and went on an Asian tour with the Cambridge squad that included a match against the Thai national team, then ranked 60th in the world.

headline: IBM Opens Chip Architecture, in Strategy of Sharing and Self-Interest
abstract: The first server designs resulting from IBM’s decision to open up its Power chip technology are being announced on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: IBM’s chip business needs help. So the company has opened up the technology of its Power microprocessors, inviting others to modify and manufacture Power-based designs pretty much as they see fit. This open, liberal licensing initiative is conducted under the auspices of the OpenPower Foundation, which was incorporated in December.

headline: So Many Art Fairs. So Little Time.
abstract: Scheduling the new Los Angeles installment of the the Paris contemporary art fair FIAC was harder than expected.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – Scheduling a new art fair these days is nearly as challenging as setting a release date for a feature film in Hollywood, given the steep competition.

headline: New York Financial Regulator Uses Dodd-Frank to Sue Auto Lender
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Benjamin M. Lawsky, New York State’s superintendent of financial services, accused the Condor Capital Corporation of siphoning millions of dollars away from borrowers’ accounts.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:22 p.m. | By his own admission, even New York’s top financial regulator did not know he could use the Dodd-Frank law to enforce consumer protections until very recently.

headline: Federal Prosecutor to Help Lead Justice Dept.’s Criminal Division
abstract: Marshall L. Miller, a longtime federal prosecutor in Brooklyn, will help oversee a broad caseload and about 600 attorneys at the Justice Department.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department’s criminal division, which oversees some of the biggest investigations into Wall Street and corporate crime, is adding to its ranks.

headline: Queen’s Day Becomes King’s Day in the Netherlands
abstract: The Netherlands’ biggest celebration has a new date and name this month, when the former Queen’s Day, held since 1890, becomes King’s Day.
lead_paragraph: The Netherlands’ biggest celebration has a new date and name this month, when the former Queen’s Day, held since 1890, becomes King’s Day, or Koningsdag.

headline: Plea Agreement for William E. Rapfogel
abstract: An agreement that Mr. Rapfogel entered into with the attorney general’s office in which he agreed to plead guilty. He also promised to pay $3 million in restitution.
lead_paragraph: An agreement that Mr. Rapfogel entered into with the attorney general’s office in which he agreed to plead guilty. He also promised to pay $3 million in restitution.

headline: Dodge Poetry Festival Set to Return to Newark
abstract: The festival will include former poets laureate and a tribute to Amiri Baraka.
lead_paragraph: And they said it wouldn’t last.

headline: Are Risqué Company Names Good for Business?
abstract: Or is the risk of offending people just too great?
lead_paragraph: We’ve just published an article that recounts the experiences of several companies that have sought to attract attention by giving themselves outrageous names. In fact, several of the companies aren’t sure they would exist if not for their creative names.

headline: Court Information for William E. Rapfogel
abstract: Mr. Rapfogel pleaded guilty to charges contained in a Superior Court Information document drawn up by the attorney general’s office.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Rapfogel pleaded guilty to charges contained in a Superior Court Information document drawn up by the attorney general’s office.

headline: Gallery | Vintage Posters Bring Art-House Appeal to the Auction House
abstract: Over 250 modernist posters offer cinephiles, cultural history buffs and Warhol worshippers a chance to grab rare ephemera from days past.
lead_paragraph: Nicholas Lowry, the president and principal auctioneer of New York City’s Swann Auction Galleries, was reminded of the weighty value of niche memorabilia at last year’s Modernist Posters auction: a poster advertising Andy Warhol’s Exploding Plastic Inevitable, a multimedia event held at the Chrysler Art Museum in Provincetown, Mass. in 1966, fetched nearly nine times its estimated selling price — despite not actually having been designed by Warhol himself. “All of a sudden, people who have similar things at home are saying, ‘Wait a minute, this piece of paper is worth $7000?'” says Lowry, who has received a constant stream of inquiries and offers leading up to this year’s sale, happening tomorrow at Swann. “Warhol created such a successful cult of personality around him that it has long succeeded his death.”

headline: Court Information for David Cohen
abstract: Mr. Cohen plead guilty to the charges contained in the Superior Court Information document.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Cohen plead guilty to the charges contained in the Superior Court Information document.

headline: New York Police Twitter Backlash Spreads Around the World
abstract: A New York Police Department effort to engage users on Twitter turned into an international social media campaign.
lead_paragraph: What began as an effort by the New York Police Department to get people to share favorable photos of city police officers on Twitter has turned into an international social media campaign about police abuse.

headline: Image of the Day: April 23
abstract: Arvind Kejriwal, chief of the Aam Aadmi Party, filed his nomination to contest a seat from the temple town of Varanasi in the northern state of Uttar Pradesh.

headline: Recipes for Kids: Tzatziki
abstract: Tzatziki is a Greek dip that is often served as a snack or appetizer. It tastes great on burgers or tomato sandwiches, too.
lead_paragraph: Tzatziki (za-DZEE-kee) is a Greek dip that is often served as a snack or an appetizer. It is also great on burgers or tomato sandwiches.

headline: Anthony Can Expect Lower Offer
abstract: Phil Jackson, the team president, left little doubt on Wednesday that Steve Kerr was his top choice as coach and made a case for players sacrificing financially to upgrade the roster.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Phil Jackson’s first postseason news conference began with the statement that “there is no news.” But Jackson, the Knicks’ new $60 million team president, has been a longtime newsmaker, an N.B.A. lightning rod. He almost cannot help it.

headline: Returning to an ‘Impossible’ Role
abstract: A conversation with Amber Gray about terrifying musicals, biracial identity and playing a difficult scene.
lead_paragraph: Leaning against an upright piano, Amber Gray bent her voice and body to a song’s harmonies — tapping her feet, drumming her fingers, bowing her head, and turtling her chin forward and back.

headline: Springing Forward, and Its Consequences
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Spring (Season)', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Flowers and Plants']
abstract: With rising temperatures and carbon dioxide changing seasonal timetables, many plants are flowering earlier and longer.
lead_paragraph: This is a busy time of year for Richard B. Primack, a biologist at Boston University. He and his colleagues survey the plants growing around Concord, Mass., recording the first day they send up flowers and leaves.

headline: A Deeper Look at a Study Finding High Leak Rates From Gas Drilling
abstract: A closer look at a hot study on high gas leak rates in Pennsylvania’s fracking zone raises coal questions.
lead_paragraph: Updated below with Skype chat with the study lead author, 10:07 p.m. | Most efforts to slow the natural gas drilling boom in the United States have focused on questions about the environmental impacts of the process called hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, which occurs deep underground after a well is drilled.

headline: Researchers See New Importance in Y Chromosome
abstract: Two surveys have reconstructed the full history of the shrunken male chromosome, which provides regulatory genes that play a role throughout the body.
lead_paragraph: There is new reason to respect the diminutive male Y chromosome.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Casa Valentina’
abstract: A scene from Harvey Fierstein’s new play about cross-dressers at a 1960s Catskills resort. The show is on Broadway at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.
lead_paragraph: A scene from Harvey Fierstein’s new play about cross-dressers at a 1960s Catskills resort. The show is on Broadway at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.

headline: A Renter Does the Math
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Rent can amount to a hefty annual outlay. Owning began to seem like a better bet.
lead_paragraph: Soon after his arrival in New York from San Francisco two years ago, David Park took a rental at the Beatrice, rising high above the Eventi Hotel on West 29th Street. He loved his small studio, 475 contemporary square feet with a great view and a central location.

headline: Proposal to Limit Prosecutions of Marijuana Cases in Brooklyn
abstract: The borough’s district attorney, Kenneth P. Thompson, wants to find alternatives to court for people arrested on charges of possessing small amounts of the drug.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn district attorney’s office will stop prosecuting people arrested on charges of possessing small amounts of marijuana, according to a confidential policy proposal that the district attorney, Kenneth P. Thompson, sent to the New York Police Department this month.

headline: What You Get for ... $2,500,000
abstract: Island houses in Washington and Rhode Island and a lake house in Georgia.
lead_paragraph: ORCAS ISLAND, WASH.

headline: Mixed Signals: Exploring the Science Behind Nutrition and Disease
abstract: In this lesson, students explore the science behind nutrition and disease — how strong are the connections between diet and conditions such as heart disease, obesity and even cancer?
lead_paragraph: Overview | The news can sometimes seem as if it is full of conflicting reports on the connection between diet and health: Are fats good for you, or bad for you? What about sugar, chocolate and caffeine? And what kinds of evidence do scientists use in making dietary recommendations? In this lesson, students can explore the science behind nutrition and disease — how strong are the connections between diet and conditions such as heart disease, obesity and even cancer?

headline: Ackman’s Pershing Square Subsidiaries Hint at Future Moves
abstract: William A. Ackman’s hedge fund has recently created four subsidiaries — beyond the one that the billionaire activist investor used to build a stake in Allergan.
lead_paragraph: The hedge fund billionaire William A. Ackman may be plotting his next big stock move, even as he is on the media circuit explaining his decision to partner with Valeant Pharmaceuticals to make a $45.6 billion hostile bid for the Botox manufacturer Allergan.

headline: Justices Rule Child Pornography Restitution Is Too High
abstract: The Supreme Court ruled that a $3.4 million award to a victim who had sought restitution from a man convicted of viewing images of her was too much, returning the case to the lower courts to find a different amount.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday set aside a $3.4 million award to a victim of child pornography who had sought restitution from a man convicted of viewing images of her. That figure was too much, Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote for a five-justice majority, returning the case to the lower courts to apply a new and vague legal standard to find a lower amount that is neither nominal nor too severe.

headline: Experian Study Highlights Differences Between Hybrid and E.V. Owners
keywords: ['Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Automobiles', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: The study outlined the economic backgrounds and buying habits of people who bought vehicles powered by alternative energy sources.
lead_paragraph: While it may seem natural to want to shove people who buy electric vehicles and hybrids into the same pigeonhole, there are some slight differences between them.

headline: Genting Group Says It Is Vying for a Casino License
abstract: The company, one of the biggest gambling interests in the world, said it had paid the $1 million application fee and was considering sites in the Catskill and Hudson Valley regions.
lead_paragraph: The Genting Group, among the biggest gambling interests in the world, announced on Wednesday that it was vying for one of the four licenses that will be available to open a casino in upstate New York.

headline: Nets Dictating Play as the Raptors Rely on a Backup
abstract: Despite being tied, 1-1, in their playoff series against the Raptors, the Nets have done much to dictate the play, mostly with their defense.
lead_paragraph: After two games, patterns are emerging in the first-round playoff series between the Nets and the Toronto Raptors. The teams are tied at one victory each, but so far it is the Nets who have forced the Raptors to make adjustments.

headline: Tribeca First-Timers: Nate Parker
abstract: The actor Nate Parker discusses his films at the Tribeca Film Festival, “About Alex” and “Every Secret Thing.”
lead_paragraph: This is one in a series of posts on debuts at the Tribeca Film Festival.

headline: Etsy Buys Grand St., a Boutique Electronics Start-Up
abstract: Etsy is poised to acquire a Brooklyn start-up called Grand St., an online boutique for electronics. The company did not disclose terms of the deal, which is still closing.
lead_paragraph: Etsy, the online marketplace for handmade and vintage goods, is poised to acquire a Brooklyn start-up called Grand St., an online boutique for electronics.

headline: Two New Music Festivals to Enliven New York Stages
abstract: The Tribeca New Music Festival will focus on the local music scene, while the Mise-en festival will present music from far corners of the world.
lead_paragraph: Two contemporary music festivals – one built largely around stars of the burgeoning downtown and Brooklyn scenes, and one examining unusual corners of the composition world – will keep New York concert stages animated in May and June.

headline: Reporting on Love in the Hindu Kush
abstract: Rod Nordland, the Afghanistan bureau chief for The New York Times, discusses reporting on a couple on the run from authorities and families who do not approve of their marriage.
lead_paragraph: Rod Nordland, the Afghanistan bureau chief for The New York Times, discusses reporting on a couple on the run from authorities and families who do not approve of their marriage.

headline: Iranian Prison Chief Is Removed After Reports of Attack on Inmates
abstract: The move by the judiciary, called a promotion, came amid criticism over a violent raid on political prisoners at Evin, Tehran’s largest prison facility.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — The head of Iran’s judiciary removed the country’s highest prison official on Wednesday, after what human rights advocates said was a violent raid on political prisoners in Tehran’s largest prison facility.

headline: Study Finds Less Green in the Congo Rain Forest
abstract: Scientists say that a long drought that has affected trees in Central Africa could help them understand how global warming may harm vegetation.
lead_paragraph: Years of drier conditions in the Congo River basin in central Africa appear to be affecting trees in the region’s vast rain forests, scientists reported on Wednesday.

headline: Siri and Google Now, Meet Cortana
abstract: Molly Wood tests out mobile virtual assistants, including Microsoft’s Cortana, to see if Siri has met her match.
lead_paragraph: Molly Wood tests out mobile virtual assistants, including Microsoft’s Cortana, to see if Siri has met her match.

headline: A Discreetly Charming Women’s Wear Line from Perugia
abstract: After nearly a decade spent quietly honing her craft, Sara Lanzi is having a New York moment.
lead_paragraph: What do women want? Whether the aim is to explore modes of self-expression or to feel invisible, what resonates in fashion today are clothes that feel deeply personal. Perhaps that’s why Sara Lanzi — a self-taught Italian designer based not in the fashion capital of Milan but in the romantic university town of Perugia — is now, after nearly a decade spent quietly producing her pieces, having something of a New York moment. The influential online retailer La Garçonne and the Comme des Garçons store in Chelsea, among others, have picked up her spring collection, a range of softly textured dresses and separates whose clean lines and muted tones are lightened by an exuberant fluidity. “My background is the underground movement of the ’90s,” Lanzi explains. “‘Do it yourself’ was the mood; that’s where it all comes from.” The line, she says, is “a balance of imperfection and rigor. I have a sort of graphic attitude that drives me; nevertheless, I am far from minimalism.” It’s an approach that should please street-style peacocks and normcore enthusiasts alike.

headline: In Allergan Bid, a Question of Insider Trading
abstract: William A. Ackman is sitting on a paper profit of more than $1 billion, leaving some to wonder whether the windfall comes as result of what feels like insider trading.
lead_paragraph: One trading day after announcing the news that the huge hedge fund he runs, Pershing Square Capital Management, had partnered with Valeant Pharmaceuticals International to make an unsolicited $45.6 billion cash and stock takeover bid for Allergan, William A. Ackman is sitting on a paper profit of more than $1 billion on the Allergan shares and options he had been secretly buying over the past two months.

headline: Windows Phone 8.1 Finally Catches Up to Its Rivals
abstract: With the addition of Cortana, Microsoft’s answer to Siri and Google Now, the mobile operating system can be considered an equal in most areas.
lead_paragraph: WINDOWS PHONE 8.1 is a very good mobile operating system.

headline: Entertainment Executive Denies Sexual Abuse Accusation
abstract: Gary Goddard, through his lawyers, joined other entertainment figures who explicitly reject the claims of sexual abuse filed by a once-aspiring actor.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Gary W. Goddard, an entertainment executive, has now joined three other entertainment figures who explicitly deny the claims of sexual abuse filed against them over the last week by a once-aspiring actor.

headline: N.H.T.S.A. Investigates 60,000 Chevrolet Impalas for Braking Problem
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: A single complaint prompted the agency to investigate the 2014 model over a problem with the forward-collision warning system.
lead_paragraph: Based on a single complaint, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating whether the forward-collision warning system on about 60,000 Chevrolet Impalas from the 2014 model year may malfunction and slow or stop the vehicle when a collision is not imminent.

headline: Scene City: Stars Align, Just North of TriBeCa
abstract: Sophia Loren, Julianne Moore and others stars attend annual Tribeca Film Festival dinner hosted by Chanel.
lead_paragraph: Sophia Loren, Julianne Moore and others stars attend annual Tribeca Film Festival dinner hosted by Chanel.

headline: Coloring In a Hitchcock Profile
abstract: “The Lovesong of Alfred J. Hitchcock,” part of the Brits Off Broadway series at 59E59 Theaters, looks into the filmmaker’s youth and early career for clues to his later cinematic obsessions.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes the best refuge from real trauma is simulated terror. The English playwright David Rudkin remembers cowering under his bunk in an air-raid shelter as a child. It was the early 1940s, and German bombs were raining on his hometown, Birmingham. What dreams may come to a child who fears for his life? Menacing images from Alfred Hitchcock thrillers like “Rebecca,” “Suspicion” and “Foreign Correspondent,” naturally.

headline: The Gun Report: April 23, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: This afternoon, Georgia Gov. Nathan Deal signed into law the “Safe Carry Protection Act,” which allows guns in more public places than at any time in the past century, including churches, bars, and government buildings that do not have security checkpoints. Which is why critics call it the “Guns Everywhere Bill.”

headline: G.M.’s Bankruptcy Will Probably Shield It From Most New Claims
keywords: ['Bankruptcies', 'Fifth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Liability for Products', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: It’s hard to see how a court can allow any claims without altering the basic terms of a 2009 bankruptcy deal, Stephen J. Lubben writes in his In Debt column.
lead_paragraph: General Motors’ liability for defective ignition switches in its cars is complicated by its bankruptcy in 2009. The federal bankruptcy judge in New York approved a sale order that shielded the “new” company from liability for incidents that took place before July 10, 2009, the day the sale became effective.

headline: Ilaria Urbinati: The Stylist for the Quieter Half of the Red Carpet
abstract: Ms. Urbinati counts a number of Hollywood’s A-list actors as clients, drawing on their personalities.
lead_paragraph: The New York designer Michael Bastian works with his fair share of stylists. But there is only one for whom he’ll not only roll out the racks, but also move the heavens. “I’ve pulled stuff from my own closet to ensure she has what she needs,” Mr. Bastian said from his office in Chelsea on one chilly afternoon. “She’s the only one I would do that for.”

headline: House Hunting in ... the Canadian Rockies
abstract: Prices are a bit lower than pre-recession levels, but sales volume has picked up, with some full-price offers.

headline: Southerners Don’t Like Obamacare. They Also Don’t Want to Repeal It.
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: A poll showed broad distaste for the law, but found that people would rather have it improved than repealed.
lead_paragraph: Despite strong dislike of President Obama’s handling of health care, a majority of people in three Southern states – Kentucky, Louisiana and North Carolina – would rather that Congress improve his signature health care law than repeal and replace it, according to a New York Times Upshot/Kaiser Family Foundation poll.

headline: Clip: ‘Locke’
abstract: A scene from the film featuring Tom Hardy.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film featuring Tom Hardy.

headline: U.S. Sends Troops to Eastern Europe

lead_paragraph: The Pentagon press secretary, Rear Adm. John F. Kirby, discussed U.S. military exercises in Eastern Europe, and the Ukrainian first deputy prime minister, Vitaly Yarema, expressed gratitude.

headline: The Soul of TriBeCa, if Not the Place
abstract: The Tribeca Film Festival honors artists at its annual star-studded dinner.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t difficult to find the Tribeca Film Festival’s annual artists dinner on Tuesday night. All you had to do was search out police barricades, the flash of cameras and impermeable masses of assembled fans, all of which required the blockage of an entire city street.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival: Bronies, Now a Movie Genre
abstract: “A Brony Tale” delves into the world of men who like the children’s cartoon “My Little Pony,” and the director acknowledges he had some preconceptions going into the project.
lead_paragraph: “We’re supposed to chug beer, ride motorcycles, be degrading to women and like explosions,” the handlebar-mustachioed man says. “That’s what’s ingrained in our brains from the minute you’re born and put into a blue crib.”

headline: Musings on Identity, From the Assimilated Exile to the Meaning of ‘Maria’
abstract: Ballet Hispanico’s two-week season at the Joyce Theater explores themes like identity, “the Marias in all of us” and “the nuances of a kiss.”
lead_paragraph: If you want a quick thematic summary of any piece in Ballet Hispanico’s repertory, just look at the program notes for its current two-week season at the Joyce Theater. Annabelle Lopez Ochoa’s “Mad’moiselle,” for instance, explores “iconic male/female images and gender identity in Latin American cultures.” Eduardo Vilaro’s “Hogar” is a “moving meditation on immigrant identity and the meaning of home.”

headline: Connie Marrero, 102, Dies; Pitcher Starred in Cuba and the Majors
abstract: Mr. Marrero was 39 when he reached the major leagues with the 1950 Washington Senators and the oldest former major leaguer before he died.
lead_paragraph: Connie Marrero, a chunky right-hander from Cuba with a windmill delivery and a wicked curveball, was nearly 39 years old when he reached the major leagues with the 1950 Washington Senators.

headline: Richard Serra Wins Architectural League Prize
abstract: The sculptor was awarded the Presidentʼs Medal, the first time the prize has been given to an artist.
lead_paragraph: Richard Serra has been awarded the Presidentʼs Medal from the Architectural League of New York, the first time the prize has been given to an artist.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 50
abstract: Diego Forlán, the ageless Uruguyan striker now playing in Japan, continues to find the back of the net with consistency.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Ukraine’s Military Drive in East Enters Neutral Gear, as Pact on Crisis Is Tested
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: A Geneva accord to defuse the crisis frayed further as the United States and Russia exchanged accusations of meddling in the region.
lead_paragraph: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — The promised Ukrainian military effort to reassert control over the restive eastern part of the country barely registered on Wednesday, but the Geneva agreement to defuse the crisis in the country frayed even further as the United States and Russia exchanged warnings and accusations of meddling in the region.

headline: ‘Frozen’ Soundtrack Sees Biggest Sales Week Yet
abstract: The Disney soundtrack held at No. 1 for an 11th week, with 259,000 copies sold.
lead_paragraph: The sales numbers for most hit albums follow a basic pattern. They crest in the first week they go on sale, a result of front-loaded marketing campaigns, and then trail downward from there; they can lose up to 80 percent of sales in their second week, and rarely recover.

headline: A Boy and His Tall Imaginary Friend Are Back
abstract: The second season of “Moone Boy,” the charming Irish-British television series, will be posted on Hulu beginning Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Martin Moone, Irish seventh grader: “Do you see what I see?”

headline: Aspirin Benefits Some at Risk for Colon Cancer

lead_paragraph: Many studies have found that regular aspirin use reduces the risk for colon cancer. Now scientists have found that aspirin may benefit some people far more than others.

headline: Obama’s First Order of Business in Tokyo: Sushi From the Master

lead_paragraph: To all the perks afforded the leader of the free world, add this one: Within about 90 minutes of arriving in Tokyo on Wednesday, President Obama sat down for a meal prepared by an octogenarian sushi chef whom some regard as the master of all masters.

headline: Camping by Night, Riding by Day
abstract: In order to ride a steep face that received minimal sunlight, Jeremy Jones and Ryland Bell spent an evening nestled on a ledge thousands of feet above their base camp in Alaska’s Fairweather Range.
lead_paragraph: In order to ride a steep face that received minimal sunlight, Jeremy Jones and Ryland Bell spent an evening nestled on a ledge thousands of feet above their base camp in Alaska’s Fairweather Range.

headline: Video: Camping by Night, Riding by Day
abstract: To ride a steep face that received minimal sunlight, Jeremy Jones and Ryland Bell spent an evening nestled on a ledge thousands of feet above their base camp in Alaska.
lead_paragraph: In the past six years, Jeremy Jones has collaborated with Teton Gravity Research to create a trilogy of films: “Deeper,” “Further” and “Higher.” The films document his efforts to explore and snowboard mountains around the world under his own power. In this companion piece to its “Higher Unplugged” series, Teton Gravity Research provides a glimpse into “Deeper.”

headline: Facebook Profit Tripled in First Quarter
abstract: The company reported 1.28 billion monthly users, most on mobile devices, and easily exceeded analysts’ expectations for revenue and profit.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As Facebook reported another quarter of strong revenue and profit growth on Wednesday, its executives made one thing very clear: The company’s money machine has just begun to spit out the cash.

headline: Teamwork Rules the Night
abstract: Producing a party is often a joint effort. A breakdown of who those people are and their club duties.
lead_paragraph: Giving a party these days, it seems, takes a village.

headline: App Smart: Selfies
abstract: Kit Eaton dives into three apps that can take selfies to the next level.
lead_paragraph: Kit Eaton dives into three apps that can take selfies to the next level.

headline: Richard H. Hoggart, ‘Lady Chatterley’s’ Savior, Dies at 95
abstract: In a landmark obscenity case, Professor Hoggart testified in defense of a novel censored in Britain for more than three decades.
lead_paragraph: Richard H. Hoggart, a pioneering British cultural historian who was most widely known outside academia as the star witness for “Lady Chatterley’s Lover” in a 1960 trial that ended British censorship of that novel, died on April 10 in London. He was 95.

headline: Making Your Selfies the Talk of Instagram
abstract: Most people take photos of themselves with the standard apps on a smartphone, a shame when there are specialized apps that can elevate the pictures.
lead_paragraph: MILEY CYRUS has done many things recently, but I think my favorite among them is elevating the “selfie” photo to something like a modern art form.

headline: S.E.C. Settles With Ex-Nvidia Employee in Insider Trading Case
abstract: Regulators said they reached a settlement with a former Nvidia employee who was the source of inside information about the chip maker’s earnings for two hedge fund traders.
lead_paragraph: The former Nvidia employee who the authorities contend supplied inside information about the chip maker’s earnings to a group of hedge fund traders and analysts has reached a settlement with securities regulators, the regulators said on Wednesday.

headline: Seeking to Grow, Chobani Secures $750 Million Loan
abstract: The fresh capital, in a loan from the private equity firm TPG Capital, is intended to help Chobani add new products and expand overseas.
lead_paragraph: The yogurt maker Chobani has struck a deal with private equity.

headline: 25 Years After Tiananmen, Calls for Officials to Disclose Assets Still Unmet
abstract: On April 18, 1989, protesting students demanded that Chinese leaders reveal their financial assets. Twenty-five years later, on April 18, 2014, that demand remained unmet as four more members of a group calling for the public disclosure of officials’ assets were sentenced to prison.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-five years, two events, one plea: A quarter-century after the crushing of the Tiananmen democracy movement, which was driven in large part by the desire to end corruption, people are still calling on China’s wealthy leaders and their families to reveal their financial assets.

headline: Felix Salmon to Take On Web-Based Role at Fusion
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Mr. Salmon, a prominent writer on finance who is leaving Reuters, will take up a web-based role at Fusion that runs across multiple media.
lead_paragraph: Felix Salmon, a prominent writer on finance and other topics who announced this week that he was leaving Reuters, will join the cable network Fusion on Monday in a web-based role that runs across multiple media.

headline: Hamas and the P.L.O.’s Latest Accord
abstract: The two main Palestinian groups in the West Bank and Gaza agreed on Wednesday to form a unity government.
lead_paragraph: The two main Palestinian groups in the West Bank and Gaza agreed on Wednesday to form a unity government.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about today’s biggest stories.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Albuquerque Police Yet to Find Video of Shooting
abstract: The police chief said that an officer’s lapel camera had not captured the shooting of a 19-year-old woman, but declined to say whether the officer had switched it on, as required.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — Albuquerque’s police chief said on Wednesday that the authorities had not been able to find conclusive videotape footage of the fatal police shooting this week of a 19-year-old woman who was the 24th person killed since 2010 by members of the department, which is under federal and state investigation for violating use-of-force rules.

headline: 2 Women Who Offer Life Lessons in Very Different Ways
abstract: Two new network television shows, “Bad Teacher” and “Black Box,” feature female characters who are torn in various ways.
lead_paragraph: “Bad Teacher,” based on the Cameron Diaz movie by the same name, is a CBS sitcom about a middle-school teacher who is a sexy, unscrupulous gold digger.

headline: Bayern Munich Controls All but the Final Score
abstract: Real Madrid won the first leg of its two-game Champions League semifinal even though Bayern had the ball for two-thirds of the game and took 13 corner kicks.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Bayern Munich got the ball, again and again and again. But Real Madrid got the goal.

headline: Telling Stories, From ‘Beowulf’ to the Hobo Life
abstract: The composer David Lang is organizing Carnegie Hall’s six-concert series “collected stories,” at Zankel Hall. Tuesday’s program paired medieval and modern works.
lead_paragraph: As the composer David Lang points out in his program note for “collected stories,” a fascinating series of concerts he has put together through the auspices of Carnegie Hall, music has long been called upon to help tell different kinds of tales. In planning this six-concert series, which opened on Tuesday night at Zankel Hall before a packed house, Mr. Lang was a far-ranging and visionary collector of stories.

headline: Justice Department on Clemency Program
abstract: James Cole, a deputy attorney general, announced an initiative that encourages inmates sentenced for drug crimes to apply for clemency.
lead_paragraph: James Cole, a deputy attorney general, announced an initiative that encourages inmates sentenced for drug crimes to apply for clemency.

headline: Apple’s Profit Still Climbs, but Pressure is Growing
abstract: The slowdown in earnings has put pressure on the company to release products in new categories — perhaps with a so-called smart watch.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple’s remarkable growth streak — now more than a decade old — is starting to fade a little.

headline: In War-Torn Country, Laughing to Keep From Crying
abstract: At first, “Holy Land” suggests how ordinary people might make sense of life under the duress of armed conflict, but then the story becomes buried in symbolism and violence.
lead_paragraph: Jesus has been declawed. In “Holy Land,” the French-Algerian playwright Mohamed Kacimi’s vaguely absurdist disquisition on the dehumanizing effects of war, now playing at Here, Jesus is a tabby cat who frightens a soldier. The soldier retaliates by maiming his paws.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from South Korea, Poland, Ukraine and the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: Photos from South Korea, Poland, Ukraine and the Philippines.

headline: The Real Reason Red States Won’t Expand Medicaid
abstract: Hint: It’s not about money.
lead_paragraph: By now it’s pretty clear that the states refusing to expand health coverage under Medicaid aren’t really worried about the expense. They’re motivated entirely by ideological stubbornness — “for no other reason than political spite,” as President Obama said last week.

headline: Full Results of The New York Times/Kaiser Family Foundation Poll
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: In four southern states, there are complex and often contradictory views of President Obama’s principal domestic legislation four years after it became law.
lead_paragraph: In four southern states, there are complex and often contradictory views of President Obama’s principal domestic legislation four years after it became law.

headline: Final of White House Junior International Teams
abstract: The final of the White House junior international team event in the Netherlands on April 4 was between Germany A and Norway.
lead_paragraph: The final of the White House junior international team event in the Netherlands on April 4 was between Germany A (Marie Eggeling, Raffael Braun, Paul Grünke and Vemund Vikjord) and Norway (Christian Bakke, Kristoffer Hegge, Harald Eide and Kristian B. Ellingsen).

headline: A Sad and Remarkable Life: Breanne Fahs Talks About ‘Valerie Solanas’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Women and Girls', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Ms. Fahs discusses the life and work of the radical thinker who shot Andy Warhol.
lead_paragraph: Valerie Solanas is most famous for shooting Andy Warhol on June 3, 1968. Solanas, a radical thinker whose “SCUM Manifesto” called for the elimination of the male sex, knew Warhol and was angry because she believed he was going to film a play she wrote without paying her for it. She was also afflicted with paranoid schizophrenia and spent time in several psychiatric institutions. In “Valerie Solanas,” Breanne Fahs, an associate professor of women and gender studies at Arizona State University, argues that Solanas is interesting for reasons other than her notoriety for shooting Warhol and her psychological troubles. In a recent email interview, Ms. Fahs discussed Solanas’s relationship with Warhol, why Solanas’s work is still relevant, the difficulties she encountered in researching the biography, and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation.

headline: Some Setbacks for the Sharing Economy
abstract: San Francisco is suing two landlords, saying they illegally evicted tenants so they could make their apartments into places for well-heeled tourists. New York State is investigating Uber for price-gouging during storms.
lead_paragraph: Scrutiny of the so-called sharing economy seems to increase every day.

headline: A Badly Bruised Soccer Team Tries to Beat a Reputation
abstract: In “Next Goal Wins,” a new coach arrives in American Samoa to work with a World Cup-hopeful squad known as the “worst soccer team in the world.”
lead_paragraph: That American Samoa has a soccer team, much less one that aspires to compete in world championships, is fairly momentous. In terms of population, it’s something like Pontiac, Mich., or Lynchburg, Va., putting together a local group and sending it to the Olympics. So the nickname “worst soccer team in the world” doesn’t seem that shameful.

headline: Prince George Ascending to the Throne of Trendsetter
abstract: At 9 months old, the son of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge demonstrates his ability to sell clothes.
lead_paragraph: The Duchess of Cambridge, the former Kate Middleton, wears a dress, and it sells out. The so-called Kate Effect has been noted for years, and though plenty of attention has been paid to the dresses she has worn on the royal family’s tour in Australia and New Zealand (Prince William reportedly said that she looked “like a banana” when she wore a yellow Roksanda Ilincic dress in Sydney), she’s not the only one in the family. On the trip, the royal family has introduced a new teeny style icon: Prince George, who, as a 9-month-old, is already having a big impact on some fashion businesses.

headline: All Aboard the Orient Local
abstract: Constructing a contemporary version of the old Orient Express route through Europe, the author cuts across the Continent, encountering a variety of personalities along the way.
lead_paragraph: During one of last summer’s final high-season weeks, I struck up a conversation with an American backpacker in Milan’s Centrale train station. She was 18, in Europe for the first time, and the itinerary she reeled off resembled a similar trip I took some 15 years ago: Amsterdam, Berlin, Vienna, Venice, Madrid. The difference was that, with my Eurail Pass, I’d made a continuous swoop of it; her backpack, garlanded with luggage tags, revealed that she had availed herself of discount airfare for a more higgledy-piggledy route. I had once arrived in Venice from Munich using the pass; my journey had taken 10 hours. She’d come in from Lisbon in 90 minutes.

headline: Future, the Voice of Hip-Hop Today
abstract: With his second album, “Honest,” Future seals his star quality and his popularity as a collaborator.
lead_paragraph: The old rap star metrics of greatness? Future has no use for them. In his songs, he employs few true narratives, no real wordplay or punch lines. He raps mainly in free associative snippets, which, taken as pure text, can read as mundane.

headline: F.C.C., in a Shift, Backs Fast Lanes for Web Traffic
keywords: ['Net Neutrality', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Movies', 'Television', 'Music']
abstract: Planned new rules would allow an Internet provider to negotiate separately with content companies like Disney or Google and charge for priority service.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The principle that all Internet content should be treated equally as it flows through cables and pipes to consumers looks all but dead.

headline: Spring Shopping: Return to the Trenches, but Softly
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Coats']
abstract: The newest trench coat has a softer, less structured shape; Bonobos introduces AYR, a women’s label; new jewelry and more spring shopping.
lead_paragraph: Milder April temperatures are bringing out a profusion of chic trench coats, which this season look freshest in softer, less structured shapes. The quintessential transition piece, a breezy trench will be a welcome antidote to your winter outerwear, which got way too much play this year. Throw one on with jeans and an easy T-shirt for the weekend, as did Karlie Kloss (shown here), who wore a slouchy gray style and ballet flats to pal around with Taylor Swift, and wrap one over tailored pieces for work or a silky dress or jumpsuit for evening.

headline: Music Mix: Spirituality and Protest
abstract: “Rebel Music” by Hisham D. Aidi, describes the eagerness of young Muslims in every culture to find musical expression that feels like a safe haven in a combative world.
lead_paragraph: The subject matter of “Rebel Music: Race, Empire and the New Muslim Youth Culture” could not be more far-reaching unless its author, Hisham D. Aidi, had unearthed data about youth culture and musical influences on other planets. As far as Earth goes, his highly original and ambitious book has got it covered.

headline: Growlers Finding a Refuge in Dance
abstract: Rappers with rough voices, like Lil Jon and Waka Flocka Flame, are increasingly finding dance music to be far more hospitable than hip-hop.
lead_paragraph: The days of abrasion are seemingly gone in hip-hop — smoothness of various stripes rules the radio, thanks to years of cross-pollination with R&B and pop. For rappers with real tension and grit in their voices, this shift has made for something of a mini-crisis — they’re no longer welcome in their old home.

headline: Sightseeing With Ears Wide Open
abstract: In “The Sound Book: The Science of the Sonic Wonders of the World,” Trevor Cox makes the case for more mindful listening with all kinds of sound.
lead_paragraph: Have you planned your summer vacation yet? Any thoughts as to what places you’d like to hear this year?

headline: From Japan, a Jazzy Interpretation of Gershwin
abstract: The New York Philharmonic played a Gershwin and Bernstein program featuring the pianist Makoto Ozone at Avery Fisher Hall.
lead_paragraph: Here’s something you don’t see every night at Avery Fisher Hall: the members of the New York Philharmonic tapping their feet and nodding their heads, smiling, during a concerto’s cadenza. And here’s another: the orchestra’s principal trombonist, Joseph Alessi; its bassist David J. Grossman; and the saxophonist Allen Won coming to the front of the stage to join the soloist in a Thelonious Monk encore.

headline: After the BP Oil Spill
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration']
abstract: The American Petroleum Institute responds to an Op-Ed article, “The Deepwater Horizon Threat.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: De Blasio’s City Managers
abstract: A former Department of Transportation official writes that the new mayor uses a thoughtful process in staffing his government.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: World’s Fair Memories
abstract: A reader who grew up in Brooklyn recalls a special outing.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Newly Released Books
abstract: Anger, anguish, infidelity and the limits of wealth are among the themes explored in six new novels this month.
lead_paragraph: This month’s new fiction, including novels in translation and a story collection, explores love and the theater in the 1970s, terminal illness, memory loss, winning the lottery and the plight of a small pig.

headline: Turning Away the Talented
abstract: A former president of the LaGuardia High School Parents Association says test scores should not determine who gets admitted.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Greatest Good Cause
abstract: A reader suggests that there is value in whatever kind of work we choose.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Limiting the Use of Affirmative Action
abstract: Readers have varying reactions to the Supreme Court decision.

headline: Cellphone Cases to Prepare You for Anything, Even a Flat Tire
abstract: These cases can add speakers, encryption, a hard drive and even a bike repair kit.
lead_paragraph: PROTECTIVE phone cases have become practically a necessity since the introduction of smartphones. After all, why pay hundreds of dollars for a phone and not spend a little bit more to protect it?

headline: Apple’s Stock Split: Attracting the Wrong Crowd?
abstract: Although splitting shares should make no difference, one study suggests it creates a shift toward short-term investors.
lead_paragraph: Suppose I have a delicious pie (apple, let’s say), that is divided into four slices. And then I decide to divide it again, into eight slices. Do the individual slices become more delicious?

headline: Q. and A. | Christo on Jeanne-Claude, the Art of the Process and Trying to Drape a River in Fabric
