abstract: The legendary environmental artist who, with Jeanne-Claude, erected “The Gates” and “The Umbrellas,” shares memories about his late partner and discusses the status of several works in progress.
lead_paragraph: Christo probably isn’t the first name you think of when considering quintessentially New York artists. Yet he landed in the city nearly 50 years ago, arriving from France with his late spouse and creative partner Jeanne-Claude. They moved into a warehouse in SoHo in the early 1960s, converting the building into a residence, studio, gallery and corporate headquarters, complete with its own generator. (The power didn’t go out during Sandy.)

headline: Lions to the Ballot Box
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'Voting and Voters', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Much political power plays out on the state and local level, so it’s negligent to stay home when legislatures are being elected.
lead_paragraph: The time for complaining is at an end. Action must be taken. Accountability must be demanded. Muscle must be flexed. Power must be exercised.

headline: The Folly of Saving What You Kill
abstract: New York has a tragicomic record of architectural salvage.
lead_paragraph: SCAFFOLDING went up last week around the former American Folk Art Museum building on West 53rd Street. It was the first step in the Museum of Modern Art’s widely reviled plan to demolish that admired work of contemporary architecture, which MoMA purchased in 2011. Although most of the building will land in a Dumpster, the saga of dismemberment will be prolonged for the Folk Art Museum’s intimately monumental 82-foot-high facade. In response to protests, MoMA has said it would detach and preserve the facade’s 63 textured copper-bronze panels.

headline: Openings, Events and Sales for the Week of April 24
abstract: Gap and P.S. — I Made This host a D.I.Y. party, spring sales at Scoop NYC and more.
lead_paragraph: Events

headline: At the Met Gala, a Strict Dress Code
abstract: Anna Wintour puts out the call for full evening attire.
lead_paragraph: Gone are the fabled society queens and their blue-blood escorts, replaced by quarterbacks, mannequins and Jimmy Fallon. Forgotten, too, are the days when the fashionable elite made their stately ascent of the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s broad stairway, all the Nans and Pats and Micas stopping for air kisses along the way.

headline: The Next Big Thing in Fashion? Big Things
abstract: Huge silhouettes bring to mind giant lizards without predators or monarchs without a clue.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Rihanna arrived at Heathrow Airport in London wearing a humongous star-spangled backpack. In its immensity, it was akin to the giant sack used to pilfer all of Whoville’s gifts in “How the Grinch Stole Christmas.”

headline: Conjuring Images of a Bionic Future
abstract: As they work more closely with our mobile computers, devices that once simply fixed whatever ailed us will begin to do much more.
lead_paragraph: Dick Loizeaux recently found himself meandering through a noisy New York nightclub. This was unusual; Mr. Loizeaux, a 65-year-old former pastor, began suffering hearing loss nearly a decade ago, and nightclubs are not really his scene. “They’re the absolute worst place to hear anybody talk,” he said.

headline: Port Authority Again Delays Vote on 80-Story Tower at World Trade Center Site
abstract: The board’s failure to agree on additional financing reflects a wider debate on whether it has strayed too far from its core mission of transportation infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: After failing to gain enough support to provide additional subsidies to complete the stalled construction of a $2.3 billion, 80-story tower at the site of the former World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey decided on Wednesday to once again delay a decision on the matter.

headline: Charles James and Me
abstract: As the Met Costume Institute prepares to exhibit clothes by the designer, a woman recalls the thrill of wearing one of his pieces in 1975.
lead_paragraph: When the Metropolitan Museum of Art Costume Institute opens “Charles James: Beyond Fashion” on May 8, the exhibition will have 70 outfits, making it the largest show devoted to the designer, who died in 1978 at age 72. Among them are the Taxi dress, designed in 1929, which wrapped around the body and fastened with Bakelite clasps, so that a woman could slip into it while in the back of a taxi, and the Clover Leaf dress of 1952, which did not touch the floor but undulated while the woman walked.

headline: Following Armenia’s Global Diaspora
abstract: Scout Tufankjian has been traveling the world photographing Armenian communities large and small, where traditions endure amid diversity.
lead_paragraph: Scout Tufankjian has been traveling the world photographing Armenian communities large and small, where traditions endure amid diversity.

headline: Zynga Founder Leaves Daily Role at Struggling Game Maker
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Computer and Video Games']
abstract: The once-hot social gaming company said that Mr. Pincus decided to give up all operational responsibilities, though he will remain Zynga’s chairman and largest shareholder.
lead_paragraph: Mark Pincus, the founder of Zynga, is stepping back from the once-hot social gaming company as its new leader seeks a turnaround.

headline: Welcome to Comcast Country
abstract: Philadelphia has become a company town where the cable TV giant wields vast influence.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — COMCAST’S executive vice president, David L. Cohen, did not seem fazed when Senator Al Franken warned at a recent Judiciary Committee hearing that the company’s proposed acquisition of Time Warner Cable would “result in fewer choices, higher prices and even worse service for my constituents.” Comcast argues that the merger will not decrease competition among cable television or broadband Internet providers because the two companies do not directly compete — though the reason for that is that they already maintain virtual monopolies in many of their service areas.

headline: Estimate of Where Obama Lacks White Support
abstract: Obama lacks support from white voters in part of the South.
lead_paragraph: Obama lacks support from white voters in part of the South.

headline: Hot Spots: The Early Buzz
abstract: Only a quarter of the way into the 2014 election cycle, a variety of political ads are making waves not just for their effectiveness, but also for their zaniness.
lead_paragraph: Only a quarter of the way into the 2014 election cycle, a variety of political ads are making waves not just for their effectiveness, but also for their zaniness.

headline: Southern Whites’ Loyalty to G.O.P. Nearing That of Blacks to Democrats
keywords: ['Voting and Voters', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Elections', 'Minorities', 'Population']
abstract: The shift is a problem for Democrats, but also for Republicans.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s landslide victory in 2008 was supposed to herald the beginning of a new Democratic era. And yet, six years later, there is not even a clear Democratic majority in the country, let alone one poised for 30 years of dominance.

headline: Ads Look to Stand Out Amid the Political Clutter
abstract: The 2014 election cycle has ushered in a rush of political advertising, with campaign ads airing as early as last spring and record-shattering spending for the first quarter of the election year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The 2014 election cycle has ushered in a rush of political advertising, with campaign ads airing as early as last spring and record-shattering spending for the first quarter of the election year. Between television commercials (some top-notch nuggets of narrative storytelling) and web ads (which allow for a more madcap approach), nearly every day seems to bring about a new visual treat. Here is a look at some ads that managed to cut through the clutter: the good, the bad, and the zany.

headline: Working-Class Fathers Shouldn’t Be So Easily Dismissed
abstract: Single motherhood may be a rational economic choice for working-class women, but it’s a choice based on limited options with consequences for the mothers, fathers and children.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a headline that appears on Slate: “White Working-Class Women Should Raise Kids Alone.” (The full headline when you open the article reads: “Just Say No/For white working-class women, it makes sense to stay single mothers.” The “should” headline appears as you scroll.)

headline: Gawkers, Welcome: House and Garden Tours
keywords: ['Gardens and Gardening', 'Design', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Celebrities', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: A welcome mat for those seeking access, however fleeting, to some of the country’s most beautiful homes.
lead_paragraph: Speculating about what lies behind the closed doors and garden gates of homes owned by celebrities — or those who just have money and taste — is something of a national pastime. But once a year, in the spring and summer, many of those properties are open to the public, as house-and-garden tours are organized around the country. In many cases, the tours raise funds for nonprofit organizations. So it’s time to stop wondering and start exploring.

headline: The Unsettling Thing About Ellen
keywords: ['ARCHITECTURE', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Television']
abstract: Ellen DeGeneres has recently bought, decorated, occupied and sold more than half a dozen California homes, each a personal labor of love.
lead_paragraph: Oh, to be Ellen DeGeneres’s decorator. Or her architect. Or her real estate agent. Or even her movers.

headline: Our Mother, the Dictator
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A family bends to the will of the interior designer among them, with only occasional mutinies.
lead_paragraph: David Adler accepts the trade-offs of being married to an interior designer. For the pleasure of living in beautifully decorated homes, he cedes nearly all creative control to his wife, Amie Weitzman, a principal of the Manhattan firm Weitzman Halpern.

headline: Essentially Japanese
abstract: “Wa: The Essence of Japanese Design,” written by Kenya Hara, presents classic objects created over the past six centuries.
lead_paragraph: Up until the 15th century, Japan embraced showy ornamentation like other powers. That changed when a shogun with a taste for simplicity moved the country toward the spare aesthetic for which it has become renowned.

headline: Big Fish, in Any Size Pond
abstract: What is it about koi that ignites the passions?
lead_paragraph: Japanese koi are domesticated carp prized for their size, color, patterns and luster. They are coldblooded, but the people who nurture them in backyard ponds and enter them in competitions are as passionate as any Pekingese owner. Mat McCann, 40, the British-born manager at Quality Koi Farm, a 43-acre business owned by Joseph Zuritsky, in Carneys Point, N.J., uses Japanese stock and methods to breed international champions. (This ambition is not unlike perfecting American truffles, mozzarella and soccer players.) The farm is open to the public from spring through autumn, and collectors travel from all points to peer into its mud ponds. (The interview was edited and condensed.)

headline: A Return to Nigeria
abstract: What was I doing in America, when there was another land and a people that rightfully claimed me?
lead_paragraph: When I was 7 years old my father bought me a Bag of Laughs. It was the early 1980s and, as with most every school morning in Lagos, Nigeria, we were stuck in traffic. My father was at the wheel, listening to Bob Marley on the eight-track. I sat in the back, staring at the street peddlers walking in between lanes jostling can openers, batteries and other random items at car windows.

headline: A Star Awaits Its Applause
abstract: David Rockwell’s latest theatrical gesture is a luminous design for the Rug Company.
lead_paragraph: Spotlight Silver, David Rockwell’s latest design for the Rug Company, seems like a not-so-subtle nod to his theatrical leanings. After all, Mr. Rockwell has created sets for Broadway shows like “Hairspray” and “Kinky Boots,” not to mention the Academy Awards. But in a recent interview, he was more focused on the technical details of the hand-knotted rug, pointing out that its gray shades become darker the farther they radiate from its shimmering silk center. The spotlight motif “came from experimentation, playing with that transition from silk to wool, so it feels like one continuous ombré,” he said.

headline: Embellishments With a Serious Goal
abstract: Housing Works’ annual benefit, Design on a Dime, opens Friday.
lead_paragraph: More than 60 designers, including Barclay Butera, Sara Gilbane, Miles Redd and James Huniford, have created room vignettes for Design on a Dime, Housing Works’ annual benefit. There’s a party Thursday night, and starting Friday, you can shop those rooms, with prices up to 70 percent off retail. Proceeds go to Hull Street, a housing development for formerly homeless New Yorkers living with H.I.V./AIDS. Since Mr. Huniford conceived the event a decade ago, it has raised $6 million. “It was important from the beginning that the money went directly to the cause,” he said. “I always worked hard to find sponsors to pay for the operating part of it.” (This year’s sponsor is Elle Decor magazine.) The Pierre Frey table, donated by Bungalow 5, and shown in a room by Arlene Angard Designs, is $290. Metropolitan Pavilion, 125 West 18th Street (Avenue of the Americas); 347-473-7457 or housingworks.org.

headline: Discounts at Gretel Home, John Robshaw, A+R and Miraval
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Discount Selling', 'Beds and Bedding', 'Textiles', 'Pillows', 'Lamps and Lampshades']
abstract: Deals on kitchenware, lamps and pillows.
lead_paragraph: Clocks, kitchenware, textiles and many other items are up to 50 percent off at Gretel Home while supplies last (a peeler by Normann Copenhagen, regularly $17, is about $12; a Toc-Toc clock by Koziol, regularly $79, is about $55); 786-247-9003, gretelhome.com.

headline: Jewish Designers and Modernism
abstract: A San Francisco exhibition looks at the relationship of 34 famous Jewish designers and architects to the most important aesthetic movement of the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: “Designing Home: Jews and Mid-Century Modernism,” opening Thursday at the Contemporary Jewish Museum in San Francisco, offers a multilayered look at the close relationship between Jewish architects and designers and the avant-garde. Curated by Donald Albrecht, the show unpacks a history of American-born and European creators, several connected to the Bauhaus, who were drawn to six nodes of progressive culture in America, including Black Mountain College in North Carolina, the Institute of Design in Chicago and Pond Farm Workshops in Northern California. Its 34 exemplars, including Henry Dreyfuss, Marcel Breuer and Anni Albers, found respectful supporters in these socially conscious institutions that fostered a network that sustained their visions. Featured are more than 120 items, including Julius Shulman’s photo of Richard Neutra’s 1946 Kaufmann House, and Alvin Lustig’s 1949 chair for Paramount Furniture. Until Oct. 6. Information: 415-655-7800 or thecjm.org.

headline: Japanese Design: Conflict in the Far East
abstract: You expect it to be simple, but there’s a “crazed energy,” too.
lead_paragraph: Japanese furnishings have inspired legions of designers. But while most praise the simplicity of form, Joey Roth, an industrial designer based in Southern California, sees something more.

headline: Puzzled but Positive, Giants Learn Offense That Has Shades of Green Bay
abstract: The system installed by the Giants’ new offensive coordinator, Ben McAdoo, is expected to overhaul the way Eli Manning communicates with receivers.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — For 10 years, the Giants’ offensive system was largely unchanged, as familiar to the team’s fans as their work commutes — and, in the end, about as beloved.

headline: Operating Earnings Rise 12% at Boeing
abstract: The company increased its profit outlook for the year as its first-quarter revenue rose. Net income, however, fell 13 percent after a shift in the company’s pension plan.
lead_paragraph: Boeing said on Wednesday that its core operating earnings rose 12 percent in the first quarter, beating analysts’ expectations as the company continued to capitalize on the demand for new passenger planes.

headline: Steve Backer, a Force for Jazz at Major Labels, Dies at 76
abstract: Mr. Backer, who ran jazz programs at major record labels, shaped the careers of musicians like Anthony Braxton and Henry Threadgill, as well as crossover bands like the Brecker Brothers.
lead_paragraph: Steve Backer, who ran successful jazz programs at several major record labels, shaping the careers of visionary avant-gardists like the saxophonist-composers Anthony Braxton and Henry Threadgill as well as potent crossover bands like the Brecker Brothers, died on April 10 in Englewood, N.J. He was 76.

headline: Vermont Will Require Labeling of Genetically Altered Foods
abstract: Vermont’s approval was hailed by food-safety advocates. Meanwhile, the biotech industry has drafted federal legislation to pre-empt any such state initiatives.
lead_paragraph: Going further than any state so far, Vermont on Wednesday passed a law requiring the labeling of foods that contain genetically engineered ingredients.

headline: Eastern Europe Frets About NATO’s Ability to Curb Russia
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: NATO’s Eastern European members are growing increasingly nervous about Russia’s moves and the alliance’s ability, or even willingness, to counter them.
lead_paragraph: OVER CONSTANTA, Romania — High over the Romanian border, a sophisticated NATO surveillance plane kept a close watch on Russian movements below. Its radar screens came alive with a cat-and-mouse game between a Russian surveillance jet buzzing an American guided missile destroyer in the Black Sea and a squadron of NATO fighter jets that chased it away.

headline: As Wine Fetches Staggering Sums, Fakery Claims Rise
keywords: ['Wines', 'Collectors and Collections', 'Counterfeit Merchandise', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: Connoisseurs driving up the prices of rare and collectible wines have spurred a wave of counterfeiters who target collectors eager to flaunt their trophies.
lead_paragraph: When the Atlanta wine collector Julian LeCraw Jr. spent $91,400 on a single bottle in 2006, he was convinced that the 1787 vintage from the renowned Chateau d’Yquem in France was worth the lofty price, then the highest ever for a white wine. Now, Mr. LeCraw says he has been left with the bitter aftertaste of a fake.

headline: Trying to Bolster the Image of Frozen Meals as Sales Lag
abstract: Stouffer’s is introducing commercials that aim to shift the perception of some consumers that processed frozen meals are not as tasty or nutritious as freshly prepared ones.
lead_paragraph: A NEW campaign is trying to reverse the declining sales of frozen meals in recent years.

headline: Sweeping Measure Expanding Rights of Gun Owners Is Signed Into Georgia Law
abstract: The law signed by Gov. Nathan Deal allows gun owners with concealed-carry permits to take weapons into bars and certain areas of airports.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — A plan to bolster the legal rights of gun owners that opponents have derided as the “guns everywhere” bill was signed into law on Wednesday by Gov. Nathan Deal.

headline: Yanks’ Pineda Ejected After Pine Tar Is Spotted
abstract: Michael Pineda, who denied using pine tar on his pitching hand during a game against the Red Sox on April 10, is subject to suspension.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — After his start against the Boston Red Sox on April 10, Michael Pineda’s denial that his hand was covered in pine tar was mostly disregarded as absurd. Television cameras clearly showed a brown substance, and no matter what Pineda claimed afterward, people recognized it for what it was: an illegal attempt to get a better grip on the baseball.

headline: Alistair MacLeod, a Novelist in No Hurry, Dies at 77
abstract: Mr. MacLeod, a Canadian author, won the International Impac Dublin Literary Award in 2001 for his novel “No Great Mischief.”
lead_paragraph: Alistair MacLeod, a Canadian writer whose only novel — composed over 13 years and extracted from him only after a campaign by his publisher involving surveillance, subterfuge and outright bribery — brought him literary fame, a lucrative prize and a bottle of Scotch, died on Sunday in Windsor, Ontario. He was 77.

headline: Meet Me at the Fair
abstract: Fifty years after the 1964 New York World’s Fair, many predictions were not that far off.
lead_paragraph: Let’s talk future.

headline: In Return to the Pool, Phelps Talks About Fun
abstract: The most-decorated swimmer in history found he missed the competition and the team camaraderie.
lead_paragraph: MESA, Ariz. — Around noon Wednesday, the teenage swimming prodigy Michael Andrew met Michael Phelps, many of whose national age-group records Andrew has broken. After shaking Phelps’s hand and hearing Phelps say, “Nice to meet you,” Andrew walked away beaming. “That was pretty cool,” he said.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 23, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: April 23, 2014

headline: Hynes’s Lack of Curiosity May Come at a Cost
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: Charles J. Hynes was the head of the Brooklyn district attorney’s office when Jabbar Collins was prosecuted and wrongly imprisoned.
lead_paragraph: Tracking the explanations of the former Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, for his office’s malpractices is like hunting a rabbit: The prey keeps bouncing here and there before disappearing under a hedgerow.

headline: Colombia’s President Reinstates a Mayor He Ousted
abstract: President Juan Manuel Santos restored Gustavo Petro as the mayor of Bogotá a month after removing him from office to comply with a decision by the inspector general.
lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Residents of this capital city may feel as if they are suffering political whiplash after President Juan Manuel Santos on Wednesday reinstated the mayor that he had removed from office only a month earlier.

headline: A Road Movie, but With No Rest Stops
abstract: In “Locke,” a film praised for its minimalist values, the director Steven Knight shot it almost entirely in the same car and with only one on-screen character.
lead_paragraph: How interesting can a film that takes place almost entirely inside a car be? The writer-director Steven Knight asked himself that question when conceiving his road movie “Locke,” which spends its 85-minute running time with just one on-screen character (Tom Hardy in the title role) as he drives to London from Birmingham and conducts phone conversations that are by turns distressing and contemplative.

headline: Strict Cost-Cutters Who Want to Spend $45 Billion on a Takeover
abstract: Valeant’s chief, J. Michael Pearson, has slimmed down the pharmaceuticals company, but been an aggressive acquirer, spending more than $19 billion on companies.
lead_paragraph: Visitors to the New Jersey offices of Valeant, the ambitious pharmaceuticals company, are confronted with an unusual sight when they walk through the front door: a basketball court.

headline: Moldova, the Next Ukraine
abstract: The gutsy government of this neighbor to Ukraine and Romania needs Western support as Russia gets poised to make a move.
lead_paragraph: CHISINAU, Moldova — If there were an Olympic competition for bravest country in the world, the gold medal might well go to Moldova. Wobbly politicians from Europe and America should come here to get spinal transplants.

headline: Fixes for the Port Authority
abstract: A panel of outside experts gave sound ideas on how to limit patronage in the agency. The time to put them into practice is right.
lead_paragraph: In what is certainly a departure from standard practice, the normally secretive commissioners at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey are asking publicly for advice about how to do their job.

headline: Nepal Tries to Save Season as Everest Tourists Depart
abstract: Tourism officials planned to visit the Mount Everest base camp Thursday to try to salvage the expedition season even as Sherpas and tour operators, shaken by last week’s avalanche deaths, began packing up and heading home.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A delegation of government officials from Nepal’s Ministry of Culture, Tourism and Civil Aviation will visit the Mount Everest base camp on Thursday in an attempt to salvage the expedition season even as Sherpa mountain guides, support staff and foreign tour operators, shaken by an avalanche that killed over a dozen Nepalese guides last Friday, begin to pack up their gear and head home.

headline: Haiti in the Shadow of Cholera
abstract: Despite all kinds of planning, a campaign to fight the cholera epidemic is not going well.
lead_paragraph: The problem of ending Haiti’s cholera epidemic does not stem from an absence of planning. There is a 10-year plan to eradicate cholera from Hispaniola, the island Haiti shares with the Dominican Republic, by 2022. Within the 10-year plan is a two-year plan to get the 10-year plan up and running. The United Nations has its own two-year plan to support that two-year plan. To tackle the crisis immediately, with treatment, vaccinations and other prevention efforts, there was a one-year plan for last year, and a new one for 2014.

headline: Reviving Clemency, Serving Justice
keywords: ['Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Mandatory Sentencing', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Editorials', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: The Justice Department’s plan to reinvigorate the clemency power to deal with thousands of people who were sentenced under harsh drug laws is encouraging news.
lead_paragraph: Throughout American history, presidents from Abraham Lincoln to Harry Truman to Gerald Ford have used the power of executive clemency to help bring an end to war, or to promote national healing in its aftermath.

headline: Five Men Are Charged in a Brooklyn Beating
abstract: Prosecutors said five Hasidic men indicted in the brutal attack on a gay black man in Williamsburg were associated with a Hasidic neighborhood patrol. The patrol disputed that assertion.
lead_paragraph: Five men who prosecutors said were associated with a Hasidic neighborhood watch group in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, were indicted on Wednesday in connection with a brutal beating of a gay black man in December.

headline: At Northwestern, a Blitz to Defeat an Effort to Unionize
abstract: As soon as a National Labor Relations Board official ruled that scholarship football players had the right to unionize, the university began a wide-ranging campaign to defeat a vote.
lead_paragraph: EVANSTON, Ill. — A National Labor Relations Board official took a historic step last month in ruling that Northwestern’s scholarship football players should be considered employees of the university and therefore had the right to unionize like other workers.

headline: On Whiteboards, in Black Ink, Grim Descriptions of Those Lost as Ferry Sank
abstract: The descriptions, some rendered in forensic detail, are the only evidence that many parents of the teenagers who died on South Korea’s doomed ferry have of their children’s fate.
lead_paragraph: JINDO, South Korea — No. 150, a boy, had a snaggletooth. No. 111, a girl, was wearing pink slippers, and an elastic hairband on her right wrist. No. 87 had on pajama pants with teddy bears.

headline: Balloon Lets Builders Check Out Future Towers’ Views
abstract: A big white balloon seen hovering over parts of Manhattan this week is photographing potential views from skyscrapers for architects and real estate developers.
lead_paragraph: A big white balloon appeared in New York this week. First on the Lower East Side, then uptown, where 57th Street meets the East River.

headline: Turkey Offers Condolences to Armenians Over Killings
keywords: ['Armenians', 'World War I (1914-18)', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s office posted a web statement, but the government stood by its position that the killings of at least 1.5 million Armenians in 1915 were not a genocide.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — For the first time, the Turkish government offered condolences on Wednesday to the descendants of Armenians who were killed by the Ottoman Army in 1915. But it stood by its official position that the events were not a genocide, as they have been called by several Western governments and international organizations.

headline: New Labor Contract Will Cost M.T.A. $525 Million
abstract: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said it would pay for raises by redirecting some money from pension and health care funds.
lead_paragraph: When Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo revealed to great fanfare last week that a deal on a new labor contract had been reached with New York City’s subway and bus workers, officials did not reveal how much it would cost.

headline: Contradictory Reports on North Korea’s Nuclear Preparations
abstract: Though a South Korean official said North Korea had nearly completed all preparations it would need to conduct a nuclear test, a website run by the U.S.-Korea Institute said a test was unlikely this weekend.
lead_paragraph: A senior South Korean Defense Ministry official said Wednesday that North Korea “has virtually completed all preparations” it would need to conduct a nuclear test. On Tuesday, amid reports of increased activity at a nuclear test site in the North, the website 38 North, run by the U.S.-Korea Institute at Johns Hopkins University, said the country appeared unlikely to conduct a nuclear test during President Obama’s visit to Seoul this weekend. Using commercial satellite imagery, it said that recent operations at Punggye-ri, a test site, had not reached the high level of intensity that occurred before past detonations. The South Korean official, who was speaking on the condition of anonymity at a news briefing, said that the United States and South Korean officials used more powerful spy satellite imagery.

headline: New York Police Twitter Strategy Has Unforeseen Consequences
abstract: A departmental campaign, meant to elicit smiling snapshots, instead attracted tens of thousands of less flattering images of officers.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department has long seen its crime-fighting strategies emulated across the country and around the world.

headline: Kenya: Bomb in Nairobi Kills Two Police Officers
abstract: The bomb exploded outside a police station in Nairobi on Wednesday evening, the Interior Ministry said.
lead_paragraph: A bomb exploded outside a police station in Nairobi on Wednesday evening, the Interior Ministry said, killing two officers. The bombing is the latest in a series of attacks to rock Kenya since last month. There have been no claims of responsibility, but many believe that Al-Shabab, a Somali Islamist group, is responsible.

headline: Wrigley Field at 100: Futility’s Friendly Confines
abstract: The Chicago Cubs celebrated the 100th birthday of Wrigley Field in typical fashion on Wednesday ... with a loss.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — For Wrigley Field’s 100th birthday, baseball’s schedule makers could have included one of the National League’s most senior franchises — the Cincinnati Reds, or the Giants, once of New York and now from San Francisco — to play the Cubs. But they settled on the Arizona Diamondbacks, an expansion team in 1998.

headline: A Place to Slip Into Something Comfortable
abstract: In “Casa Valentina,” Harvey Fierstein’s new play on Broadway, men gather in a Catskills resort to free their feminine side.
lead_paragraph: A beguilingly gentle magic whispers amid the speechifying of “Casa Valentina,” Harvey Fierstein’s prolix play about cross-dressing in the Catskills in the early 1960s. This intermittent, quiet enchantment is generated by men who otherwise tend to obstreperousness. But put any one of them in front of a mirror, with a tube of lipstick and some eyeliner, and he falls into a wordless rapture, as silent and luminous as a newly lighted candle.

headline: On the Lookout
abstract: Stan Newman’s back.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Stanley Newman is the editor of the nationally syndicated Newsday Crossword and the author/editor of more than 150 books. When last we saw him here in The New York Times, he was making us laugh with a quip theme inspired by his son Marc, and he’s back today with a theme that resides inside the grid.

headline: Britain: Blair Speaks Out on Islamic Extremism
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Tony Blair, the former British prime minister, said Wednesday that the spread of Islamic extremism represented “the biggest threat to global security of the 21st century.”
lead_paragraph: Tony Blair, the former British prime minister, said Wednesday that the spread of Islamic extremism “represents the biggest threat to global security of the 21st century.” Mr. Blair, who is Middle East envoy for the United States, the European Union, Russia and the United Nations, spoke of “a titanic struggle” going on “between those who want the region to embrace the modern world” and “those who instead want to create a politics of religious difference and exclusivity.” Mr. Blair also embraced the military government in Egypt that overthrew the elected president, Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood, calling it “the absolutely necessary rescue of a nation” despite the repression that has followed.

headline: Debris Not Connected to Missing Malaysian Jet, Officials Say
abstract: Objects that washed ashore at a small coastal town in Western Australia have been ruled out as debris linked to the missing Malaysia Airlines jet, the authorities said Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Objects that washed ashore at a small coastal town in Western Australia have been ruled out as debris linked to the missing Malaysia Airlines jet, the authorities said Thursday. The material was found on a beach more than a thousand miles from the part of the Indian Ocean where the search for the plane continues. On Wednesday, the Malaysian government said it was forming an international investigation team to assess what had happened to the plane.

headline: For Cuomo and de Blasio, Still Some Good Old Days
abstract: Historically the nature of the governor’s relationship with New York City’s mayor has always been something of an arranged marriage, but like many couples, the governor and the mayor do seem to enjoy each other’s company, at least when they are not fighting.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — With disaster recovery as a backdrop, Mayor Bill de Blasio and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo played exceedingly nice here on Wednesday during a daylong conference on Hurricane Sandy, adding a brief but mostly sunny chapter to New York’s most hot-and-cold political relationship.

headline: A Defiant Rancher Savors the Audience That Rallied to His Side
abstract: For now, Cliven Bundy appears to have won his standoff with the federal government over cattle grazing in Nevada. But if the authorities have moved on, Mr. Bundy has not.
lead_paragraph: BUNKERVILLE, Nev. — Cliven Bundy stood by the Virgin River up the road from the armed checkpoint at the driveway of his ranch, signing autographs and posing for pictures. For 55 minutes, Mr. Bundy held forth to a clutch of supporters about his views on the troubled state of America — the overreaching federal government, the harassment of Western ranchers, the societal upheaval caused by abortion, even musing about whether slavery was so bad.

headline: New York City Council Seeks Bigger Police Dept. and Free School Meals
abstract: The Council is urging Mayor Bill de Blasio to offer free lunch to all public school students and hire 1,000 more police officers.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Council is urging Mayor Bill de Blasio to offer free lunch to all public school students, hire 1,000 more police officers and expand the summer job program for teenagers.

headline: Miller Hopes to Bring a Bit of Miami Back to Memphis
abstract: Mike Miller was with the Grizzlies for three unproductive playoff appearances starting in 2003, then went to Miami for three seasons before returning to Memphis.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — When Mike Miller dressed for work on Wednesday morning, he faced the usual dilemma: blue sweatpants or gray sweatpants? He went with gray.

headline: F.B.I. Informant Is Tied to Cyberattacks Abroad
abstract: While it is unclear whether the F.B.I. ordered the attacks by Hector Xavier Monsegur, the agency may have used hackers to gather intelligence even as investigators were trying to dismantle hacking groups.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An informant working for the F.B.I. coordinated a 2012 campaign of hundreds of cyberattacks on foreign websites, including some operated by the governments of Iran, Syria, Brazil and Pakistan, according to documents and interviews with people involved in the attacks.

headline: Finally Settled, St. Louis Has Found His Form
abstract: Martin St. Louis slumped while transitioning to a new team toward the end of the regular season, but he has led the Rangers in the playoffs, with five points.
lead_paragraph: After nearly two months as a Ranger, Martin St. Louis is finally back to being Martin St. Louis. With two goals and three assists in the first three playoff games against the Philadelphia Flyers, St. Louis is back to the form that won him two N.H.L. scoring titles and a Hart Trophy as the league’s most valuable player.

headline: Red Wings’ Speed Trumped by Brains and Brawn
abstract: The top-seeded Bruins have used their defense and experience to shut down the young Red Wings and take a 2-1 series lead.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The narrative for the Bruins-Red Wings series was plausible and logical. Boston, the winner of the Presidents’ Trophy for the N.H.L.’s best record, would be the aggressor, using its burliness and noted agitators like Brad Marchand to set the tone. Detroit, which survived an injury-marred regular season to squeak into the playoffs as the Eastern Conference’s eighth seed, would use its youthful speed to counterattack.

headline: Forecast Cut on Spending for Health
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'States (US)']
abstract: The new cost estimate could help state officials and others pushing for the expansion of Medicaid undue the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Congressional Budget Office has reduced by one-third its estimate of how much more states will spend on Medicaid in the coming decade because of the Affordable Care Act.

headline: ‘The Americans’ Recap: the Oliver North Story
abstract: Philip bares his teeth and rips up a Bible. Did that seem believable?
lead_paragraph: With Oliver North sharing story credit, Episode 9 finds Philip and Elizabeth finally making it onto the secret United States military base that they’ve had in their sights for months. Considering the number of people they’ve killed to get there, one hopes that their attempt to gather secrets concerning Operation Martial Eagle — the name of the show’s fictional United States military camp that trains Contras to crush Nicaragua’s Sandinista government — is successful.

headline: On a Gusty Night, the Mets Preserve a Victory With a Whirlwind Play
abstract: A pinpoint relay to the plate in the ninth inning resulted in an out, upheld on review, that helped seal a win over the Cardinals.
lead_paragraph: For the Mets to preserve their lead in the ninth inning of Wednesday’s game against the St. Louis Cardinals, three things needed to happen over the course of about 10 seconds, Manager Terry Collins said.

headline: What Female Voters Say About Women’s Safety in Mumbai
keywords: ['Elections', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Law and Legislation', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Police', 'Sex Crimes', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Women from all walks of life talk about how secure they feel in India’s financial capital.
lead_paragraph: While India’s financial capital has long prided itself on being relatively safe for women, the gang rape of a photojournalist in an abandoned mill building in August brought that reputation into question.

headline: Boy, 9, Is Found Dead in the Bronx
abstract: A 9-year-old boy was found dead on Wednesday outside a 46-story high-rise.
lead_paragraph: A 9-year-old boy was found dead on Wednesday outside a 46-story high-rise in the Bronx, the authorities said.

headline: A Photographer’s Tender Exploration of Fatherhood
abstract: In this installment of a new series from the photo editors of T, we gather a group of never-before-seen images from Jesse Burke’s new “Wild and Precious” project, another body of work from the photographer that centers on masculinity.
lead_paragraph: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: F.D.A. Will Propose New Regulations for E-Cigarettes
keywords: ['E-Cigarettes', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Law and Legislation', 'Smoking and Tobacco', 'Pipes, Smoking', 'Nicotine', 'Cigars']
abstract: The proposed rules would extend the federal government’s regulatory authority from cigarettes to electronic cigarettes, cigars and tobacco pipes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration will propose sweeping new rules on Thursday that for the first time would extend its regulatory authority from cigarettes to electronic cigarettes, popular nicotine delivery devices that have grown into a multibillion-dollar business with virtually no federal oversight or protections for American consumers.

headline: Times Minute | Regulating E-Cigarettes
abstract: On the Minute, the push to regulate e-cigarettes, Northwestern’s football players to vote on a union and Amazon to stream HBO series.
lead_paragraph: On the Minute, the push to regulate e-cigarettes, Northwestern’s football players to vote on a union and Amazon to stream HBO series.

headline: Word of the Day | substantive
abstract: This word has appeared in 337 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: substantive•\ˈsəb-stən-tiv\• adjective

headline: Why Chocolate Is Good for Us
abstract: Our digestive system has trouble with chocolate, which is why it may be good for us.
lead_paragraph: This column appears in the April 27, 2014, issue of The New York Times Magazine.In recent years, large-scale epidemiological studies have found that people whose diets include dark chocolate have a lower risk of heart disease than those whose diets do not. Other research has shown that chocolate includes flavonols, natural substances that can reduce the risk of disease. But it hasn’t been clear how these flavonols could be affecting the human body, especially the heart. New findings from Virginia Tech and Louisiana State University, however, suggest an odd explanation for chocolate’s goodness: It improves health largely by being indigestible.

headline: Investors Bet on Live-Streamed Spinning Classes in the Home
abstract: Peloton, which will announce a $10.5 million funding infusion on Thursday, sells a stationary bicycle with a tablet and then broadcasts classes to clients’ homes.
lead_paragraph: At first blush, Peloton’s spinning classes appear little different from those at better-known outfits like SoulCycle: enthusiastic exercise buffs pedaling under pounding loud music and energetic instructor exhortations. But a session last Friday revealed something different: video cameras recording the instructor, Marion Roaman, for the benefit of customers following along at home on their Peloton bikes.

headline: Times Minute | Regulating E-Cigarettes
abstract: On the Minute, the push to regulate e-cigarettes, Northwestern’s football players to vote on a union and Amazon to stream HBO series.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Wright-Phillips’s Hat Trick Leads Red Bulls
abstract: Bradley Wright-Phillips scored his first goal of the Major League Soccer season, added a second before halftime and then capped his hat trick by converting a penalty kick in the second half.
lead_paragraph: Bradley Wright-Phillips scored his first goal of the Major League Soccer season, added a second before halftime and then capped his hat trick by converting a penalty kick in the second half as the Red Bulls defeated Houston Dynamo, 4-0, Wednesday night at Red Bull Arena in Harrison, N.J. Wright-Phillips, 29, had not been expected to play after missing training on Tuesday with the flu.

headline: Anti-Corruption Group Finds Fault With European Union
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: A report by Transparency International, calling for a more open approach to policy making, might provide fuel for the union’s critics.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — A prominent anti-corruption group on Thursday plans to report serious shortcomings in the management and governance of the European Union’s core institutions, as public confidence in Brussels remains at a low before elections next month.

headline: India Election Digest: April 24
abstract: A roundup of local election-related news for Thursday.
lead_paragraph: What you need to know about India’s parliamentary elections on Thursday: In the sixth phase of the vote, 117 seats across 11 states and the union territory of Puducherry are at stake. The regions that are going to vote: Bihar (7 seats), Madhya Pradesh (10), Assam (6), Chhattisgarh (7), Jammu and Kashmir (1), Jharkhand (4), Maharashtra (19), Rajasthan (5), Tamil Nadu (39), Uttar Pradesh (12), West Bengal (6), Puducherry (1).

headline: Ex-Head of Blue Angels Faces Inquiry
keywords: ['Sexual Harassment', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'Hazing', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Capt. Gregory McWherter, who left the post in 2012, was removed from duty at a San Diego base over accusations of tolerating sexual harassment during his time with the group.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The former commanding officer of the Blue Angels naval squadron was removed from duty at a San Diego base last week after being accused of tolerating sexual harassment and hazing while in charge of the famous aviators’ group, the Navy said Wednesday.

headline: Up Close on Baseball’s Borders
abstract: An interactive map of the geography of baseball fandom.
lead_paragraph: An interactive map of the geography of baseball fandom.

headline: A Map of Baseball Nation
abstract: Facebook data reveals the most popular team in every ZIP code.
lead_paragraph: Facebook data reveals the most popular team in every ZIP code.

headline: Tainted Food in China Cited in Cyclist’s Failed Doping Test
abstract: The cyclist Michael Rogers tested positive for clenbuterol, which is used by farmers in China to produce leaner meat.
lead_paragraph: An Australian cyclist who tested positive for a performance-enhancing drug has had a potential ban from the sport lifted after the sport’s governing body said he probably consumed the substance accidentally during a race in China.

headline: Report Finds Widespread Water Pollution in China
abstract: The majority of areas being monitored for water pollution by the Chinese government had “very poor” or “relatively poor” underground water quality.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 60 percent of areas being monitored for water pollution last year by the government had “very poor” or “relatively poor” underground water quality, according to a report by the Chinese Ministry of Land and Resources.

headline: What’s on Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7 A.M. (Oxygen) ATONEMENT (2007) Saoirse Ronan received an Oscar nomination for her portrayal of Briony, a 13-year-old aspiring playwright who accuses the son (James McAvoy, above, with Ms. Ronan) of a family servant — and the lover of her older sister (Keira Knightley) — of a crime in this drama directed by Joe Wright and based on the Ian McEwan novel. Romola Garai and Vanessa Redgrave play Briony at different times in her life. “The main casualty of the film’s long, murky middle and end sections is the big moral theme — and also the ingenious formal gimmick — that provides the book with some of its intensity and much of its cachet,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “As the title suggests, ‘Atonement’ is fundamentally about guilt and the attempt to overcome it, and about the tricky, tragically imperfect power of art to compensate for real-life crimes and misdemeanors.” The film received six more Oscar nominations, including one for best picture, and won for Dario Marianelli’s score, featuring the pianist Jean-Yves Thibaudet and a clacking typewriter.

headline: Corrections: April 24, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on April 24, 2014
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Tamil Nadu Warms Up to Modi and His Party
abstract: The Bharatiya Janata Party is hoping that a growing urban population, voter disaffection with incumbents and Mr. Modi’s charisma will help it make some headway in a state that it has found impossible to crack in the past.
lead_paragraph: CHENNAI, India — It will take him 12 to 15 hours on a bus, but S. Dorai, a 38-year-old cabdriver in the capital of Tamil Nadu, said he was determined to travel to his native Kanyakumari, at the southernmost tip of India, to cast his vote on Thursday.

headline: Americans Die in Grim Trend in Afghanistan
abstract: Officials said the gunman appeared to be a police officer who reacted when seeing a group of Americans, raising fears of a new wave of shootings spurred by deepening Afghan resentment.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Three Americans were killed at a private hospital in Kabul on Thursday morning when an Afghan police officer turned his gun on them, officials said, in the latest in a string of attacks against Western civilians here.

headline: Obama Suffers Setbacks in Japan and the Mideast
abstract: While offering security assurances to Japan, President Obama did not take sides over who has sovereignty over islands that are also claimed by China.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — President Obama encountered setbacks to two of his most cherished foreign-policy projects on Thursday, as he failed to achieve a trade deal that undergirds his strategic pivot to Asia and the Middle East peace process suffered a potentially irreparable breakdown.

headline: Test Yourself | English, April 24, 2014
abstract: Can you choose the word pair that best completes the sentences from the article?
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: Britain Moves to Prevent Young People From Joining Syrian War
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Terrorism', 'Police', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: The campaign reflects growing concern in Europe that jihadists returning home from the conflict represent a “great danger.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British police said on Thursday that officers would work with charitable organizations to prevent British Muslims from traveling to Syria as fighters in the civil war, urging women in particular to report would-be jihadists “so that we can intervene and help.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Equipped to Dive, Students Make Aquarium Their Classroom
abstract: When have you had an interesting internship? Would you want to specialize in professional diving in high school if you had the opportunity?
lead_paragraph: In “Equipped to Dive, Students Make Aquarium Their Classroom,” Lisa W. Foderaro writes about an unusual internship that some New York City high school students have.

headline: Mumbai’s Slum Dwellers Wary of Recycled Promises
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Elections', 'Politics and Government', 'Poverty', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Every election year, parties pledge to help redevelop the sprawling slums in the city, but the residents in these densely packed neighborhoods see little progress.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India – The slum dwellers who make up 60 percent of this city’s 18 million people are too diverse to vote as a bloc, but they all have one thing in common: their cramped homes, which usually lack running water and electricity.

headline: Do You Support Affirmative Action in College Admissions?
abstract: Should public universities be allowed to use race and ethnicity as factors in deciding who is admitted?
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday that Michigan’s ban on affirmative action at public universities was constitutional. Other states have similar bans, and more may follow suit.

headline: The Real House Candidates of Beverly Hills
keywords: ['Elections, State Legislature', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Endorsements']
abstract: Inside the race to represent California’s absurdly wealthy — and sometimes just absurd — 33rd District.
lead_paragraph: Brent Roske lives on a 45-foot yacht off the coast of Marina del Rey, which is technically on the Pacific Ocean, but for jurisdictional purposes is considered part of the city of Los Angeles and, more to the point, the 33rd Congressional District of California. In January, Henry Waxman, the liberal stalwart who has represented the district with little resistance since the year after Roske was born, announced that he would not seek re-election. Now Roske, who is 39, is part of a field of 18 candidates hoping to represent the heartland of Beverly Hills, Malibu and Bel-Air in the United States Congress.

headline: Following the Global Armenian Diaspora
keywords: ['Armenians', 'Families and Family Life', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Photography']
abstract: Scout Tufankjian has been traveling the world photographing Armenian communities large and small, where traditions endure amid diversity.
lead_paragraph: Scout Tufankjian recalls childhood afternoons at her grandmother’s house, paging through Armenian magazines and wondering about the people she saw in photos from all over the globe.

headline: New York Today: The Nanny Van
abstract: What you need to know for Thursday: A project to help domestic workers, brush-fire weather, and marijuana tolerance in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this breezy Thursday.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: What you need to know to start your Thursday: Asian trade talks stall, new rules for e-cigs and the Internet, and an earnings parade.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Wartime Claim Paid, China Releases a Japanese Vessel
abstract: The seizure of the ship raised the prospect of China’s seeking compensation for claims stemming from its conflict with Japan before and during World War II.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A court in Shanghai released a Japanese commercial ship from impoundment in eastern China on Thursday, after the ship’s owner paid a civil compensation claim dating back to the wartime invasion that remains a source of bitterness in China.

headline: Russia to Start Drills, Warning Ukraine Over Mobilization
abstract: Russia announced military exercises along the border with Ukraine on Thursday, prompting a warning from Secretary of State John Kerry that Moscow would face additional sanctions if it does not act to ease tensions.
lead_paragraph: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — Defying warnings from Moscow not to confront pro-Russian militants entrenched in towns across eastern Ukraine, government forces on Thursday revived a stalled operation to regain control by force but had little to show for their efforts other than Russian military drills on Ukraine’s border and heightened alarm about Moscow’s next move.

headline: Alstom Denies Report of G.E. Takeover Bid, but Its Shares Surge
abstract: Shares of the French industrial conglomerate Alstom soared after a news report said General Electric was seeking to buy the company for about $13 billion. Alstom said it was not aware of any takeover bid.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:11 a.m. | PARIS – Shares of the French industrial conglomerate Alstom, which makes high-speed trains and energy turbines, soared on Thursday on a report that General Electric was seeking to buy the company for about $13 billion.

headline: Newlyweds on the Run: A Challenge in Reporting
abstract: The story of the two lovers from Bamian, which we began working on last February, would have been hard enough to get without all the photographers along.
lead_paragraph: Since March, The Times has reported on Zakia and Mohammad Ali, a young Afghan couple whose families have fought to keep them apart because of religious differences. Now, as newlyweds they are on the run, fearing for their safety. Afghan laws and customs have made coverage a challenge for the reporter Rod Nordland, the photographers Mauricio Lima and Diego Ibarra Sánchez and the video journalist Ben C. Solomon.

headline: Photos: The Relays That Never Stopped Running
abstract: About 22,000 runners and 110,000 fans are expected this week at the Penn Relays in Philadelphia. The event is being held at the same site for the 120th consecutive year.
lead_paragraph: When the Penn Relays kick off Thursday, with an expected 22,000 runners and 110,000 fans crowding into Franklin Field in Philadelphia for the three-day event, it will be held on the same site for the 120th straight year. It is quite a run, so to speak, for an event that started as a single relay and was aimed at keeping the University of Pennsylvania’s track team from falling into oblivion.

headline: Offering Thanks to China’s Business Groundbreakers
abstract: The businessman told me that if it hadn’t been for groundbreakers like him, I never would have been able to do business in China.
lead_paragraph: In the Phoenix airport, en route to China, I recently had an encounter with a reader of this blog.

headline: Bieber Apology Over Shrine Visit Falls Flat in China
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Despite efforts by the pop star Justin Bieber to make amends after his visit to the Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo, Chinese online commenters seemed skeptical about his sincerity.
lead_paragraph: Even after his apology for posting photos of himself visiting the Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo, which honors thousands of Japan’s military dead but also Class A war criminals, Justin Bieber remains a target of outrage in China.

headline: Trying to Bring Baldwin’s Complex Voice Back to the Classroom
abstract: James Baldwin, the Harlem-born author of the classic “Go Tell It on the Mountain,” was born 90 years ago this year, and educators are trying to inspire renewed interest in his work.
lead_paragraph: James Baldwin’s 1953 novel, “Go Tell It on the Mountain,” about a Harlem teenager’s search for meaning, quickly became a classic, along with his searing essays about race published a decade later in the book “The Fire Next Time.” But in recent years Baldwin’s presence has diminished in many high school classrooms.

headline: Daily Report: F.C.C. to Propose a Web Fast Lane
abstract: Planned new rules would allow an Internet provider to negotiate separately with content companies and charge them for priority service.
lead_paragraph: The principle that all Internet content should be treated equally as it flows through cables and pipes to consumers looks all but dead, Edward Wyatt reports.

headline: Hurt by Vehicle Recalls, G.M.’s Profit Falls 85%
abstract: Costs from safety recalls and a one-time charge for Venezuelan currency changes weighed on the country’s largest automaker.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — General Motors, the nation’s largest automaker, reported on Thursday that its net income in the first quarter fell about 85 percent, mostly because of costs associated with the recalls of millions of vehicles.

headline: The Cloud Industry Needs Aereo to Win. But Consumers Need Something Better.
abstract: The Supreme Court battle over Aereo could cast a pall over the cloud computing industry. For consumers, though, Aereo is too inefficient to become a useful service.
lead_paragraph: The best way to think about Aereo, the company at the center of this week’s Supreme Court battle over the future of computing, is as an example of legal performance art. Aereo is based entirely on a legalistic leap of faith: If it’s legal to set up an antenna and record a TV show at your own house, which it is, shouldn’t it also be legal to rent an antenna and server space at a big data center, and then stream the show over the Internet to your computer, tablet or set-top box?

headline: Cutting Costs and Plotting Mergers
abstract: Valeant’s unusual corporate culture comes into focus. | Using Dodd-Frank to sue an auto lender. | Investors bet on live-streamed spinning classes. | Chobani gets a $750 million loan from TPG Capital.
lead_paragraph: “Visitors to the New Jersey offices of Valeant, the ambitious pharmaceuticals company, are confronted with an unusual sight when they walk through the front door: a basketball court,” David Gelles writes in DealBook. “The building was previously home to a Y.M.C.A, which deemed it too run-down to host community activities. So when the Y.M.C.A. moved to a new building, Valeant moved in.”

headline: Bare Knuckles at Sotheby’s Auction House
abstract: Daniel S. Loeb, the biggest shareholder of Sotheby’s, has nominated himself and two others to the board of the auction house, which holds its annual meeting on May 6.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:24 p.m. | Directors of Sotheby’s gathered in their wood-paneled boardroom with an urgent goal: how to mollify Daniel S. Loeb, the outspoken hedge fund mogul who is the auction house’s largest shareholder.

headline: CreatureCast: Cuttlefish Camouflage
abstract: Cuttlefish can alter their color, texture, and apparent shape. This extraordinary camouflage allows them to hide in plain sight against many different backgrounds.
lead_paragraph: Cuttlefish can alter their color, texture, and apparent shape. This extraordinary camouflage allows them to hide in plain sight against many different backgrounds.

headline: A Cloak of Near Invisibility in an Underwater World
abstract: For many animals, being noticed can mean being eaten or scaring away a would-be meal. Cuttlefish deal with this in an extraordinary way.
lead_paragraph: For many animals, being noticed can mean being eaten or scaring away a would-be meal. From the tiger’s stripes to the snowy owl’s downy white feathers, camouflage allows animals to hide in plain sight and avoid these perils. But camouflage is often about more than color. Some animals have skin texture that matches the texture of their environment. Other animals have shapes that make it hard to spot the outlines of their bodies.

headline: Most Wanted and Most Haunted
abstract: Two New York exhibitions focus on Andy Warhol, one on his little-known work for the 1964 World’s Fair and the other on his images of Jacqueline Kennedy.
lead_paragraph: A half-century ago this week, the 1964 World’s Fair opened in Flushing Meadows, Queens. With Belgian waffles, Michelangelo’s “Pietà” and a Tent of Tomorrow, the event was a last postwar blast of guilt-free consumption, Sunday school piety and faith in the future as a good place to be. It was also the scene of a smashup in progress, as the America of the 1950s ran into the 1960s.

headline: Plan to Sell Condoms in Schools Encounters Resistance
keywords: ['Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Condoms', 'Education (K-12)', 'Sex', 'Sex Education', 'Youth']
abstract: Middle schools in Xi’an in Shaanxi Province should sell condoms, education officials have said. Family planning officials say they know the move is controversial, but hope it will help stop the spread of H.I.V.
lead_paragraph: Officials in Xi’an, the capital of Shaanxi Province, want secondary schools to sell condoms on campus to help combat the spread of H.I.V./AIDS, stirring a heated controversy among parents and educators.

headline: Companies Back Initiative to Support OpenSSL and Other Open-Source Projects
abstract: The Heartlbleed bug that weakened the security of millions of web servers and Internet-connected devices also exposed a flaw in open-source software maintenance that many have promised to fix.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The nonprofit Linux Foundation and more than a dozen prominent technology companies are to announce an initiative on Thursday to fund crucial open-source projects.

headline: K.K.R. Profit Falls, but Tops Estimates
abstract: The private equity giant Kohlberg Kravis Roberts reported economic net income of $630 million in the first quarter, as it reaped gains from selling some of its investments.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:36 p.m. | The private equity giant Kohlberg Kravis Roberts reaped gains in the first quarter from selling some of its investments, reporting profit that beat expectations on Thursday.

headline: Darren Aronofsky on Floods, Fanaticism, the Big Bang, Warming and More
abstract: The director of “Noah” and other films about obsession explores his views of global warming, fanaticism and the uncomfortable intersection of religion and science.
lead_paragraph: I hope you’ll take 40 minutes to catch my onstage interview on Tuesday with Darren Aronofsky, the filmmaker known for his obsession with obsession, whether it’s in a mathematician, ballerina or — most recently — Noah. Also weighing in at the capping event at The Times’s Cities For Tomorrow meeting was Ari Handel, Aronofsky’s co-writer on “Noah,” “Black Swan” and “The Fountain” (and a neuroscientist).

headline: Zimmer Holdings to Buy Biomet for $13.35 Billion
abstract: The deal is just the latest in a spree of consolidations in the health care industry, driven in part by the Affordable Care Act and an aging U.S. population.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:47 p.m. | Health care costs are rising as America’s population ages. More people are opting to pay for elective procedures as the economy gradually improves. And the Affordable Care Act is prompting some health care companies to find safety by scaling up.

headline: The Times Co. Reports a 2.6% Rise in Revenue
abstract: Despite the sales gains, The New York Times Company said first-quarter profit was down because of costs related to new digital subscription products.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Company said on Thursday that its first-quarter revenue rose from a year ago, with an increase in advertising sales and the addition of digital subscribers, but quarterly profit declined because of spending on growth initiatives.

headline: Piketty at CUNY
abstract: Economists talking inequality.

headline: ECO 348, The Great Recession: Crisis Stories
abstract: Tales of two small countries.
lead_paragraph: Slides here (pdf).

headline: Glad He Became an Auxiliary Police Officer
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A man recalled the sense of accomplishment in helping an elderly woman soon after joining the auxiliary force.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Art Matters | An L.A. Fair Explores the Possibilities of Photography
abstract: In only its second year, Paris Photo Los Angeles, opening this weekend, has become a must-see for its extensive array of photographic work — and has already inspired an alternative fair, Photo Independent.
lead_paragraph: For proof that photography can open your world, look no further than the boundary-pushing second edition of Paris Photo Los Angeles, which runs from Friday to Sunday at Paramount Pictures Studios. Like the medium itself — which freed experience from geography and time, so that viewers no longer had to actually be there in order to see something happen — the very structure of the event is a paean to fluidity. The art fair started 17 years ago in Paris and now has an annual outpost in Los Angeles on a backlot replica of New York City. “The history of photography is made of ambiguity,” says the event’s director, Julien Frydman. “If you look at photography as a self-contained medium you lose 50 percent of it, maybe more. Photography is nourished by other forms of art and in dialogue with other forms of art.”

headline: U.S. Plan for Internet Fast Lanes Contrasts With European Rules
abstract: A proposal in the United States that would allow Internet providers to charge companies for more powerful transmission of web traffic is in sharp contrast to new rules in Europe that outlaw that kind of premium access.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The battle over whether Internet content should be treated equally is heating up.

headline: On Gattopardo Economics
abstract: Is conventional economics incompatible with worrying about inequality?
lead_paragraph: FT Alphaville sends us to Thomas Palley on Piketty and his boosters. Palley raises an interesting point, one that I’m hearing from some other people on the left: they’re disappointed that Piketty’s book relies mainly on conventional, mainstream economics.

headline: In Our Pages: April 25
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A blast in Nuevo Laredo in 1914 destroys public buildings ; in 1939, British newspaper the Daily Telegraph starts printing news, not ads, on its front page.
lead_paragraph: 1914: Blast in Nuevo Laredo

headline: A Ticket to Fame, With Relish
abstract: Lloyd Handwerker discusses his documentary “Famous Nathan,” about Nathan Handwerker, his grandfather, who started Coney Island’s quintessential hot-dog stand.
lead_paragraph: JOHN, an inebriated panhandler with a voice pitched somewhere between Harvey Fierstein’s and a dental drill, sprawled recently on the patio of Nathan’s Famous in Coney Island. He delivered a monologue at top volume while, at the next table, Lloyd Handwerker, a grandson of Nathan Handwerker, who founded the place in 1916, tried telling me about “Famous Nathan,” the documentary he made about his grandpa, showing on Friday and Saturday at the Tribeca Film Festival.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘The Salutation’
abstract: “The Salutation” by Thomas Traherne and the Well blog post “Ah, There’s Nothing Like New Baby Smell” by Douglas Quenqua appear in this Poetry Pairing.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Poetry Pairing features “The Salutation” by Thomas Traherne and the Well blog post “Ah, There’s Nothing Like New Baby Smell” by Douglas Quenqua.

headline: The Downside of Registering Outrage
abstract: American officials’ rush to denounce the anti-Semitic fliers from eastern Ukraine risks giving more oxygen to a bogus issue.
lead_paragraph: Should the United States be devoting so much effort to criticizing the anti-Semitic fliers that appeared last week in Ukraine?

headline: Today in Small Business: How to Monitor Your Competitors
abstract: How Starbucks excels at social media marketing. How local businesses can compete with chains. Protecting your business from a Bring Your Own Device lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today:

headline: Thinking of Requesting a Specific Teacher for Your Child? Think Twice
abstract: A parent asks, “How hard should I push to get my daughter the teachers I think will best fit with her learning style?”
lead_paragraph: Dear Mrs. Lahey,

headline: Angus Davis of Swipely, on Working Around Flaws
abstract: Mr. Davis, the chief executive of Swipely, which sells software, says his flaws are “part of who I am, and it’s part of how we get things done.“
lead_paragraph: This interview with Angus Davis, chief executive of Swipely, which sells customer-related software to merchants, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Three Shot Dead at Kabul Hospital
abstract: Witnesses describe the scene after three Americans were shot dead at a hospital in Kabul, Afghanistan, by an Afghan police officer.
lead_paragraph: Witnesses describe the scene after three Americans were shot dead at a hospital in Kabul, Afghanistan, by an Afghan police officer.

headline: India’s Weather Agency Forecasts Weaker Monsoon
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Drought', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'El Nino Southern Oscillation', 'Gross National Product (GNP)', 'Monsoons', 'Rain', 'Rural Areas', 'Weather']
abstract: India’s meteorological department predicted that rainfall would be below average this monsoon season, which could have wider effects on the economy.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — As political pundits predict a change of administrations in Delhi after these elections, India’s weather forecasters are already identifying what could be the first serious challenge for a new government — a possible agricultural crisis in the form of a weak monsoon.

headline: Editorial Contest Winner | Stop ‘I Spy’ Game With Allies
abstract: We’re publishing one of the Top 10 winners of our Student Editorial Contest each day. This essay is by Edgar Hu.
lead_paragraph: We will be honoring each of the Top 10 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing an essay a day, in the order of submission. As we go, we’re tagging them all “editorial winner” so that you can find them all here.

headline: Nine Playwrights to Attend Sundance Theater Lab
abstract: The theater lab provides fellowships, rehearsal space, an acting company and creative advisers.
lead_paragraph: Nine playwrights have been selected to participate in the Sundance Institute’s 2014 Theater Lab, the institute announced on Thursday. The lab, one of 10 overseen by Sundance, runs from July 7 to 27 at Sundance’s resort in Utah. The playwrights, who are given fellowships based on specific projects, are provided with rehearsal space, an acting company, dramaturges and creative advisers to help them hone their works. The program is overseen by Philip Himberg, the artistic director, and Christopher Hibma, the producing director.

headline: Even After Setbacks, a Musician Insists That the Show Will Go On
abstract: Since having two strokes, Hamiet Bluiett, 73, was advised by his doctors to take it easy, but he’ll be picking up his baritone saxophone for a show on Saturday night.
lead_paragraph: Hamiet Bluiett should not have even shown up, let alone picked up his musical instrument. He’s had two strokes in the past two months and his doctors have urged him to take it easy.

headline: Israel Halts Talks, Citing Palestinian Unity Agreement
abstract: The Israeli government said that it would not under any circumstances negotiate with a Palestinian government that was backed by Hamas, the militant Islamic group.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli government decided on Thursday to suspend American-brokered peace talks with the Palestinians because of the agreement the Palestinians announced on Wednesday between two rival factions, one of which refuses to recognize Israel’s right to exist.

headline: Memories of Religious Riots Overshadow Vote in Bihar
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Elections', 'Hinduism', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: In the district of Bhagalpur, Muslim voters weighed a choice between two political camps to counter the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party.
lead_paragraph: BHAGALPUR, India – An eruption of religious violence in this district nearly 25 years ago, some of the worst that independent India has seen, weighed on the minds of Muslim voters as they prepared for Thursday’s vote.

headline: Berlin Philharmonic Starts Its Own Record Label
abstract: The orchestra has long been associated with some of the most prestigious labels in the industry.
lead_paragraph: The Berlin Philharmonic has long been associated with some of the most prestigious labels in what was once called the record industry — from Deutsche Grammophon, which released a box set last year celebrating a century of its recordings with the orchestra, to Sony, which helped launch the CD era with its recordings of Herbert von Karajan conducting it.

headline: Are Med School Grads Prepared to Practice Medicine?
abstract: Each July at teaching hospitals across the country, freshly minted M.D.s take their place as interns at the bottom of the ladder. Are they ready to practice medicine?
lead_paragraph: One night early in my internship, I received a frantic page for help from a fellow intern.

headline: Happenings | Designer Miles Redd Channels Matisse for a Worthy Cause
abstract: At Design on a Dime, the nonprofit organization Housing Works’ annual benefit for people who have H.I.V./AIDS, the designer has created a room that is inspired by the work of the French artist.
lead_paragraph: For the last 10 years, the New York-based organization Housing Works has been raising money for people who have H.I.V./AIDS by selling consignment clothing and furniture through its high-end nonprofit thrift stores. For six of those years, the designer Miles Redd, the former creative director of Oscar de la Renta Home, has lent his time and talent to the organization’s annual Design on a Dime benefit by assembling entire rooms from donated merchandise, all of which is sold at the event.

headline: Looking for Stories of Non-College-Bound Kids
abstract: We’re looking for stories from parents of children who aren’t interested in college (or the “children” themselves).
lead_paragraph: In last week’s Open Thread, a reader asked:

headline: Seven Works Attributed to Banksy to Be Auctioned
abstract: The works have been removed from public walls and buildings by the Sincura Group.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Seven artworks attributed to the street artist Banksy will go on display at the Me London Hotel  until Sunday, before being sold at auction. The works have been removed from public walls and buildings by the Sincura Group, which previously organized the removal and sale of Banksy’s “Slave Labor.” The Sincura Group, described on its own website as “market leaders in V.I.P. concierge, lifestyle, tickets and events,” will auction the works on April 27. Tony Baxter, the director of Sincura, said in a statement that the group does not “steal art, nor do we condone any acts of wanted vandalism or theft.”

headline: Attending Vanity Fair Party, de Blasio Navigates New Terrain: The Red Carpet
abstract: A star-studded bash for the Tribeca Film Festival was not exactly a natural setting for Mayor Bill de Blasio, but he quickly found his niche.
lead_paragraph: Flashbulbs popped as Anna Wintour greeted Robert De Niro and Harvey Weinstein. Courteney Cox and Christy Turlington caught up by the bar. John McEnroe and Ron Howard posed for pictures nearby.

headline: Daley, Former White House Chief of Staff, Joins Hedge Fund
