abstract: The former JPMorgan Chase executive has been named a managing partner and the head of United States operations at Argentière Capital, a Swiss hedge fund founded less than a year ago.
lead_paragraph: William M. Daley, a former White House chief of staff, has joined an upstart hedge fund based in Switzerland in a return to the financial industry.

headline: How Can the Opinions of 1,000 People Possibly Represent the Entire Country?
abstract: Every member of the population has to have an equal or at least a known chance of being chosen for a survey.

headline: Clintons Again Pick Long Island for an August Vacation
abstract: Bill and Hillary Clinton plan to vacation in Amagansett, a Long Island beach town with a more low-key scene than other parts of the Hamptons.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to have a laid-back vacation when you are Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton, but the former first couple have chosen the comparatively low-key Long Island beach town of Amagansett for their August break.

headline: Co-Founders of Pussy Riot to Appear at Frieze Art Fair
abstract: Maria Alyokhina and Nadezhda Tolokonnikova will join a conversation with the New Yorker editor David Remnick.
lead_paragraph: Maria Alyokhina and Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, two of the unmasked founders of Pussy Riot, will appear at the Frieze Art Fair next month in New York, in conversation with the New Yorker editor David Remnick, organizers announced on Thursday.

headline: The Autumn of a Patriarch
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Elections', 'Politics and Government', 'Tamils (Ethnic Group)', 'Telephones and Telecommunications']
abstract: As Muthuvel Karunanidhi, the chief of the Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam in Tamil Nadu, plots a resurgence in the 2014 elections, there is the feeling that this may prove to be a comeback too far for the grand old man of Indian politics.
lead_paragraph: CHENNAI, India — On Monday evening, Muthuvel Karunanidhi, the 89-year-old chief of the Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam, arrived in Anna Nagar, a middle-class neighborhood here, to speak at an election rally. Mr. Karunanidhi was campaigning for Dayanidhi Maran, his grandnephew.

headline: Tribeca First-Timers: Kate McKinnon
abstract: Kate McKinnon talks about her first substantial film role, in “Intramural,” at the Tribeca Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: This is one in a series of posts on debuts at the Tribeca Film Festival.

headline: For Women in Tech, Pay Gap Is Unusually Small
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Female computer scientists make 89 percent of what men in the same occupation make, a significantly better percentage than in other professions.
lead_paragraph: Technology, with its bro culture, has not been a particularly welcoming profession for women. So it is surprising that in the tech sector, the pay gap between women and men is one of the smallest.

headline: Voting Fraud Hangs Stubbornly Over Afghan Elections, With Runoff Likely
abstract: Preliminary election results, which are due Saturday, will not be official until the Electoral Complaints Commission rules on 746 complaints of serious fraud in the presidential race.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Ahmed Zia proudly recalled how he voted in the Afghan presidential election on April 5, for the first time in his 18 years.

headline: Matthew Weiner: By the Book
abstract: The creator of “Mad Men” cites the impact of John Cheever’s fiction on the show: “Cheever has a voice filled with irony and comedy and pain that, on some level, I’m always seeking to emulate.”
lead_paragraph: The creator of “Mad Men” cites the impact of John Cheever’s fiction on the show: “Cheever has a voice filled with irony and comedy and pain that, on some level, I’m always seeking to emulate.”

headline: From an Apple a Day to ‘Energy Balance’ in Cancer Research
abstract: With hopes dimming for a cancer-preventive foods, scientists are focusing on obesity, which is emerging as one of the biggest risk factors.
lead_paragraph: In my recent Raw Data column about whether fruits and vegetables are crucial to avoiding cancer, I referred to two thick reports, published in 1997 and 2007 by the American Institute for Cancer Research and its affiliate, the World Cancer Research Fund. Sitting side by side on my desk, the books look similar: One cover is blue and the other green, and both are adorned with images of fruits, vegetables, legumes and grains interspersed with people working and playing, all apparently enjoying good health. Presiding over the scene is an image of Mother Earth.

headline: Barclays Shareholders Vent Frustration Over Bonuses
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bonuses', 'Executive Compensation', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)']
abstract: At the Barclays annual meeting on Thursday, shareholders questioned a decision to increase compensation at the bank, which is in the midst of a painful restructuring.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – For nearly three hours on Thursday, shareholders of Barclays aired their grievances with the British bank’s top management, ranging from complaints about the security of debit cards to the length of the lines to get into its annual meeting.

headline: Dodge Viper Repair Requires Mechanics With Small Hands
abstract: About 3,700 Dodge Vipers from the 2003-4 model years were recalled for an air-bag problem, and the repair will be difficult for mechanics.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 3,700 owners of 2003-4 Dodge Vipers have been waiting 14 months for a recall intended to prevent the air bags from deploying without an accident. Chrysler is now ready to make the repair, but owners should hope the dealership has a mechanic with small hands.

headline: A Little Night Snorkeling
abstract: Sugar Beach, a Viceroy resort in St. Lucia, is offering night snorkeling to guests.
lead_paragraph: Scuba divers have long had the opportunity to see nocturnal creatures living among reefs by taking night dive excursions. Now snorkelers can try it too.

headline: Bob Evans Investor Agitates for Change, Again
abstract: The activist investor Sandell Asset Management nominated eight candidates to the restaurant chain’s board in its push for change at the company.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 6:17 p.m. |

headline: Rancher’s Views on Race Send Supporters Fleeing
abstract: Senator Rand Paul joined a line of Republican and Democratic leaders in denouncing Cliven Bundy, the Nevada rancher at the center of a standoff with the federal government over land use.
lead_paragraph: BUNKERVILLE, Nev. — The coalition of supporters for Cliven Bundy, the Nevada rancher battling the federal government’s attempt to remove his cattle from public land, began crumbling on Thursday over his suggestion that African-Americans might have been better off in slavery.

headline: An iPhone Engineer-Turned-Game Maker Shares His Apple Story
abstract: Francisco Tolmasky’s experience building software for the original iPhone offers a rare window into the company’s start-up-like product development.
lead_paragraph: When Francisco Tolmasky was just 20 years old and started working for Apple, he took on a challenging task: to create a rich mobile web browser for the original iPhone, back when the device was still a pile of circuits.

headline: The Women of ‘A Raisin in the Sun’
abstract: A conversation with LaTanya Richardson Jackson, Anika Noni Rose and Sophie Okonedo, now starring with Denzel Washington in the Broadway revival of Lorraine Hansberry’s drama.
lead_paragraph: The famous name above the title in the current Broadway revival of “A Raisin in the Sun” is Denzel Washington, but LaTanya Richardson Jackson gets the nicest dressing room at the Ethel Barrymore Theater, where Kenny Leon’s new production opened this month.

headline: Wheelies: The Sinkhole Museum Edition
abstract: The National Corvette Museum discusses keeping some sinkhole-wrecked Corvettes on display; Tesla seeks workers for a new California plant.

headline: Loosening the Rules on Insider Trading
abstract: An appellate court seems inclined to change the rules on insider trading in a way that will make it easier for professional traders to escape liability.
lead_paragraph: Insider trading laws used to be for amateurs. Professional traders knew how to avoid being caught.

headline: Christine Lagarde is throwing shade at Larry Summers.
abstract: Ms. Lagarde said “virtually everyone” thought Janet Yellen “by far the most qualified” candidate to lead the Federal Reserve.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Lagarde, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, wrote a profile of Janet Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, for the latest issue of the Time 100, Time magazine’s annual list of the most influential people in the world.

headline: Can Hamas-Fatah Unity Lead to Mideast Peace?
abstract: Will a reconciliation between Fatah and Hamas improve the chances of Arab-Israeli peace, which have dimmed as U.S.-backed talks foundered?

headline: Ben Heppner to Retire From Singing
abstract: Mr. Heppner, the leading Wagnerian tenor of his generation, said that he is retiring from opera and concert singing.
lead_paragraph: Ben Heppner, the leading Wagnerian tenor of his generation, announced Thursday that he is retiring from singing.

abstract: Talking with Christopher Denham, whose “Preservation” is playing in the Tribeca Film Festival.

headline: Stephanopoulos Signs Long-Term Contract With ABC News
abstract: The agreement will keep him in anchor positions on two important programs, “Good Morning America” and “This Week.”
lead_paragraph: ABC News has signed George Stephanopoulos to a long-term contract, solidifying its anchor positions on two important programs.

headline: The Documents You Need, When You Need Them
keywords: ['Elder Care', 'Living Wills and Health Care Proxies', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: The American Bar Association has developed a smartphone app intended to make health care directives quickly and easily accessible.
lead_paragraph: Few things drive an emergency room staff quite as nuts as a patient who has, yes, carefully considered her preferences, designated a health care decision-maker should she become incapacitated, and documented all that information in an advance directive — which is sitting in a locked safe deposit box or stashed in an bureau drawer at home.

headline: Times Minute | 3 Americans Shot in Kabul
abstract: On the Minute, 3 Americans are killed in Kabul, the latest on net neutrality and an interactive graphic detailing baseball’s biggest rivalries.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: That Little Lost Boy in Red, Back With His Family
abstract: “Goya and the Altamira Family,” at the Metropolitan Museum, reunites for the first time four portraits by Goya, including that of the famous boy in red.
lead_paragraph: Manuel Osorio Manrique de Zuñiga, the little red-suited boy in the Metropolitan Museum’s prize Goya portrait, died in childhood while his parents were still living. But in the Met’s European Paintings galleries, he has long been an orphan, separated from his mother, whose portrait traditionally hangs in the museum’s Robert Lehman wing, and his father, in Spain.

headline: Searching for Poetry in Prose
abstract: Create your own blackout poem from a recent New York Times story.
lead_paragraph: Create your own blackout poem from a recent New York Times story.

headline: After Blast, East Harlem Tenants Are Worried About Dust
abstract: Concerns over asbestos-laced grime in their apartments have prompted some of the families displaced after a deadly March 12 gas explosion to file suit against the landlord and the city.
lead_paragraph: In Minerva Mendoza’s fourth-floor apartment at 89 East 116th Street in East Harlem, there is tan dust in the cabinets, in the refrigerator and on the floor. Dust covers her 17-year-old son’s television stand, her younger children’s bunk beds and a stroller folded against the wall. The family comes to the apartment to grab things they need, but they live in a nearby apartment provided by the New York City Department of Homeless Services.

headline: Recognizing Outstanding Photojournalism Overseas
abstract: The Overseas Press Club has honored several photographers for their coverage of conflicts that have spanned decades, or almost escaped attention.
lead_paragraph: The Overseas Press Club has honored several photographers for their coverage of conflicts that have spanned decades, or almost escaped attention.

headline: Legal Memo Defends Ackman’s Actions in Allergan Bid
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Insider Trading', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: An independently issued memo from Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton reaffirms how William A. Ackman’s unusual hostile bid was within the legal bounds.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of this week’s unusual hostile bid for Allergan, one of the most pressing questions has been whether William A. Ackman, the activist investor who runs Pershing Square Capital Management, engaged in insider trading.

headline: Gorilla Birth Alert!
abstract: Two western lowland gorillas were born at the Bronx Zoo’s gorilla forest in recent weeks.
lead_paragraph: The Bronx Zoo’s gorilla forest was the site of not one but two blessed events recently: Julia, a 33-year-old western lowland gorilla, had a baby on March 10. Her colleague Tuti, 19, gave birth just last Thursday.

headline: Why the Housing Market Is Still Stalling the Economy
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'United States Economy', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Millions are living with parents or friends and just not setting up households.
lead_paragraph: If the economy still feels stuck, blame the housing market.

headline: Opera Philadelphia to Take On Andy Warhol
abstract: “ANDY: A Popera,” is planned for 2015, but parts of the work will be performed in the months ahead.
lead_paragraph: Opera Philadelphia, the company that earlier this year announced its plan to stage Daniel Schnyder’s opera about the jazz saxophonist Charlie Parker in 2015, is pushing further into the world of popular culture in its search for unusual subjects. The company’s plans for 2015 also include “ANDY: A Popera,” a work about Andy Warhol with music by Heath Allen, a Philadelphia composer and pianist.

headline: Snapping Good Photos With Your Phone
abstract: A contract photographer for The Times offers his tips, from angles to apps, for getting the most out of your phone’s camera.
lead_paragraph: Every family has its designated vacation photographer, so it was, to put it mildly, a moment of sheer horror when I arrived at the Naples airport last summer with my wife and two children for a brief stay on the Amalfi Coast and realized that I had forgotten my camera.

headline: Digital Mapping May Be Nokia’s Hidden Jewel
abstract: Though a laggard in smartphone location apps, Nokia’s Here mapping system is a leader in car navigation and might be a tantalizing takeover target.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — For the first time in more than three decades, Nokia faces the future without being a player in the global phone business. On Friday, the company completes the sale of its beleaguered handset business to Microsoft for $7.5 billion.

headline: Frances Mayes on the Lure of Southern Landscapes
abstract: The author of “Under the Tuscan Sun,” who returned to the South in 2007, talks about islands, swamps and the power of the land.
lead_paragraph: “Turns out Thomas Wolfe was wrong: you can go home again.”

headline: Musical Surprises: Schubert
abstract: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, presents a surprising turn in Schubert’s Sonata in B-flat, D.960.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, presents a surprising turn in Schubert’s Sonata in B-flat, D.960.

headline: 22 Companies Apply to Open 4 Casinos in New York State
abstract: A state panel said 22 applicants paid a $1 million application fee, the first significant step in the bidding process for four new upstate casinos.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — The panel charged with choosing the locations of four new casinos in New York State said on Thursday that 22 companies had submitted proposals, each paying an initial $1 million application fee, in the first step of what is expected to be an intense bidding process.

headline: Musical Surprises: Wagner
abstract: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, presents a surprising turn in Richard Wagner’s “Tristan und Isolde.”
lead_paragraph: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, presents a surprising turn in Richard Wagner’s “Tristan und Isolde.”

headline: Image of the Day: April 24
abstract: In the sixth phase of parliamentary elections on Thursday, 117 constituencies across 12 states went to the polls.

headline: Things Aren’t Always What They Seem
abstract: At Rosette, on the Lower East Side, the most interesting dishes have a slightly through-the-looking-glass cast.
lead_paragraph: The avocado is still warm from the oven, under improbable layers of puffed rice, yogurt spiked with fermented chile and a brawl of bonito flakes jittery with heat. It has been roasted briefly, enough to absorb some smoke, and with the scaffolding of crunch, cream and brine, it suggests an extraterrestrial’s brilliant mistranslation of a baked potato.

headline: New Tool to Fight Deadly Tsetse Fly
abstract: Sequencing the genome of one tsetse species took a decade, partly because tsetses have unusual biology and partly because of global health politics.
lead_paragraph: After 10 years of effort, a team led by scientists at Yale has finally decoded the genes of the tsetse fly, a bloodsucking scourge of Africa.

headline: Asked and Answered: Commenting on Your Comments
abstract: Bassey Etim answers reader questions about the comment moderation process.
lead_paragraph: Readers are passionate about their comments on NYTimes.com. Last week on Times Insider, Bassey Etim, the community manager for The Times, explained the guidelines for moderating reader comments. Predictably, his piece drew many comments and questions. Here is a selection of your questions and Mr. Etim’s answers. They have been condensed and edited.

headline: Musical Surprises: Beethoven
abstract: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, presents a surprising turn in Ludwig Van Beethoven’s Sonata No. 13 in C minor, “Pathetique.”
lead_paragraph: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, presents a surprising turn in Ludwig Van Beethoven’s Sonata No. 13 in C minor, “Pathetique.”

headline: More ‘Pinocchios’ for the Koch Brothers, Please
abstract: New ads from Americans for Prosperity deliberately twist the truth about health-care reform.
lead_paragraph: The health care ads being run by Americans for Prosperity — one of the many frantically waving arms of the Koch brothers — are a gift to fact checkers everywhere. Because they deliberately twist the truth to persuade people to “stop supporting Obamacare,” they have become a machine for producing “Pinocchios,” the mendacity rating system used by Glenn Kessler at The Washington Post.

headline: Musical Surprises: Beethoven
abstract: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, presents a surprising turn in Ludvig Van Beethoven’s Sonata No. 31 in A-flat, Op. 110.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, presents a surprising turn in Ludvig Van Beethoven’s Sonata No. 31 in A-flat, Op. 110.

headline: Prosecutors Cite Stowage and Design in Korean Disaster
abstract: Prosecutors officially attributed the sinking of a South Korean ferry to an improper stowage of cargo and a loss of stability caused by a change in the vessel’s design.
lead_paragraph: JINDO, South Korea — Prosecutors on Thursday officially attributed the sinking of a South Korean ferry to an improper stowage of cargo and a loss of stability caused by a change in the vessel’s design.

headline: Musical Surprises: Debussy
abstract: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, presents a surprising turn in Claude Debussy’s “Golliwog’s Cakewalk.”
lead_paragraph: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, presents a surprising turn in Claude Debussy’s “Golliwog’s Cakewalk.”

headline: Radetsky to Depart American Ballet Theater
abstract: Sascha Radetsky has been a soloist since 2003, and will step away in July.
lead_paragraph: Sascha Radetsky’s performance as Franz in the American Ballet Theater’s production of “Coppélia” at the Metropolitan Opera House on July 3 will be his farewell to the troupe, the company announced on Thursday. Mr. Radetsky, 37, joined the American Ballet Theater as an apprentice in 1995, became a member of its corps de ballet the following year, and has been a soloist since 2003.

headline: Recognizing Outstanding Photojournalism Overseas
abstract: The Overseas Press Club has honored several photographers for their coverage of conflicts that have spanned decades, or almost escaped attention.
lead_paragraph: Tyler Hicks of The New York Times has won the Robert Capa gold medal from the Overseas Press Club for the “best published photographic reporting from abroad requiring exceptional courage and enterprise.”  The award was given to him in recognition of his coverage of the Nairobi mall terrorist attack last September.

headline: A ‘Corporate Raider’ Tries to Correct the Record
abstract: T. Boone Pickens, in the latest issue of Time magazine, discusses his friend Carl C. Icahn and the labels they have picked up over the years.
lead_paragraph: In 1985, T. Boone Pickens, a force in the burgeoning business of hostile takeovers, appeared on the cover of Time magazine. He was fresh off an audacious tender offer for Gulf Oil, and the cover illustration showed him playing poker with oil derricks printed on the cards.

headline: American Journalist Released by Ukraine Separatists
abstract: Separatist rebels in eastern Ukraine released the American journalist Simon Ostrovsky on Thursday, three days after he was taken prisoner in Slovyansk while reporting for Vice News.
lead_paragraph: Separatist rebels in eastern Ukraine released the American journalist Simon Ostrovsky on Thursday, three days after he was taken prisoner in the town of Slovyansk while filming a video report for Vice News. The Brooklyn-based news organization confirmed his release in a statement, which was followed by a tweet from the correspondent.

headline: Investors Enthusiastic About Zimmer’s Deal for Rival
abstract: Zimmer’s stock value soared after it announced that it would acquire Biomet as shareholders bet on growth in the market for medical devices, Robert Cyran writes in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: American investors are seeing yet another big acquisition. Zimmer Holdings promises that its $13.4 billion deal for its rival, Biomet, will yield savings.

headline: United Nations Report on Delivery of Humanitarian Relief in Syria
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: A report that is part of the United Nations’ assessment of how the Syrian government and rebels have complied with a Security Council resolution ordering them to allow humanitarian aid to enter besieged towns.
lead_paragraph: A report that is part of the United Nations’ assessment of how the Syrian government and rebels have complied with a Security Council resolution ordering them to allow humanitarian aid to enter besieged towns.

headline: U.N. Finds Humanitarian Aid Still Blocked in Syria, Despite Resolution
keywords: ['Humanitarian Aid', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of Syrians have no access to medical supplies, blocked by the warring sides, a report concludes.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of Syrians have no access to medical supplies because the warring sides in the country’s civil war are blocking humanitarian relief, according to an advance copy of a report from the United Nations secretary general.

headline: Google Plus Boss Vic Gundotra Leaving Google
abstract: Mr. Gundotra, who has been a strong proponent for Google’s social network, did not detail what he planned to do after leaving the company.
lead_paragraph: UpdatedVic Gundotra, Google’s senior vice president for social and one of the creators of Google Plus, is leaving the Googleplex.

headline: Moments from Obama’s Visit to Japan
abstract: President Obama kicked off his Asia tour in Japan, meeting with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and Emperor Akihito to improve relations in the Asia-Pacific region.
lead_paragraph: President Obama kicked off his Asia tour in Japan, meeting with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and Emperor Akihito to improve relations in the Asia-Pacific region.

headline: Dial Down Your Anger
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Parties (Social)']
abstract: Questions of etiquette in difficult situations.
lead_paragraph: I had a friend for 30 years who lives three blocks away from me. In 2011, I became seriously ill and fell into a coma. She was in touch with my husband by email and knew about my condition, but never followed up to see how I was doing or even if I was still alive. I was devastated by this and cannot forgive her. I keep hoping to run into her in the neighborhood to tell her how I feel so I can move past it, but that has yet to occur. What should I do?

headline: Living With Cancer: Practicing Loss
abstract: People with cancer experience varying types of loss — of their health, of body parts, of freedom. Is there a way to practice for the losses that really matter? Susan Gubar asks in this week’s Living With Cancer column.
lead_paragraph: At times when I consider my losses, I feel like a loser in the battle against self-pity. Like many diseases, cancer has everything to do with loss: of a breast or a leg, of a chunk of liver or lung, of continence, of mental capacity, of life itself.

headline: Folk Art Museum to Open Queens Annex
abstract: The facility in Long Island City will include lots of storage space, as well as room for exhibitions.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the Museum of Modern Art announced that it was going to raze its next-door neighbor, the former home of the American Folk Art Museum, the building has been getting more attention than the Folk Art museum itself. But now that museum has news of its own. The American Folk Art Museum is opening an annex for its collection and library in Queens, near the LaGuardia Performing Arts Center in Long Island City.

headline: Next time you’re at Citizens Bank Park, remember, it’s a hoagie you want.
abstract: Finding unexpected links between terms for a sandwich and baseball loyalties.
lead_paragraph: What are you really capturing when you make a map of baseball fans on Facebook, as we did earlier today? It’s something more than just the number of Likes sorted by ZIP code. It’s relationships between things we never saw before. Take the map here, which mashes up the Mets/Phillies rivalry border with the border between people who say “sub” and people who say “hoagie.” Our dialect quiz last year found a significant regional difference. The dividing lines are pretty much the same.

headline: Photos: Buy Me Some Pine Tar and Cracker Jack
abstract: Whether it be with cork, pine tar, thumb tacks, sandpaper, or whatever else you might find in a garage or medicine cabinet, baseball players have been cheating for decades.
lead_paragraph: Billy Martin had one of the best eyes in baseball for catching people who were potentially up to no good.

headline: Ultra Violet, Pop Artist, Has Exhibition at Dillon Gallery
abstract: Ultra Violet, the muse of Salvador Dalí and the darling of Andy Warhol’s Factory, is being celebrated in an exhibition at Dillon Gallery.
lead_paragraph: The Miser is away enjoying warmer climes, so we rifled through his inbox and found a couple of thrifty activities for the weekend.

headline: When the Seven Sisters Had a Bigger Welcome Mat
abstract: A dive into the 1964 Times archive shows a stark change in college admissions rates.
lead_paragraph: The Times will soon convert all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. (Nonsearchable images of every New York Times newspaper published before Dec. 31, 1980, can be seen in full on the Times Machine.)

headline: The Gun Report: April 24, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Federal funding for research on gun violence has been frozen since 1996. Shortly after Newtown, President Obama urged Congress to allocate $10 million for new research, but Republicans in Congress recently refused, likening the effort to “funding propaganda.”

headline: My Illness, the Third Partner in Our Relationship
abstract: Her curiosity was piqued; she became a voyeur, wanting to know where the scar would be.
lead_paragraph: She was my professor. I was her graduate student. She was 17 years my senior, with a husband and children. And she risked it all to be by my side and in my bed as I closed in on a kidney transplant.

headline: Feeling For | In Madrid, An All-Organic Menu Meets Striking, Surrealist Design
abstract: Mama Campo, a restaurant and market in the old neighborhood of Plaza de Olavide, boasts pieces by 40 designers, including Tom Dixon and Patricia Urquiola.
lead_paragraph: When Manolo Yllera first told me last year that he was opening a market and restaurant in Madrid, I had an inkling that the Spanish interiors photographer would create something worthy of any lens. And of course Mama Campo is the kind of bright, airy and quirky place that could only be brought to life by a set of hands belonging to a person with a good eye for design.

headline: Yankees Get Sloppy Win; Pineda Gets Suspension
abstract: Yankees pitcher Michael Pineda was suspended for 10 games on Thursday for using pine tar to help him grip the ball, but he may miss only one start.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The mess that was smeared across Michael Pineda’s neck on Wednesday was nothing compared with the slop that was on display at Fenway Park one night later. The Yankees and the Boston Red Sox resumed their rivalry Thursday minus the controversy about the pine tar that Pineda applied to his neck, but the game was one of the worst played in the major leagues this season.

headline: The New York Athletic Club: A Proud Sponsor of Meb Keflezighi
abstract: Corporate sponsorships have rendered a function of the elite athletic club obsolete, making the N.Y.A.C.’s relationship with the Boston Marathon winner something of a relic.
lead_paragraph: When Meb Keflezighi won the Boston Marathon at age 38 Monday, the logo of his shoe sponsor, Skechers, was not the only unusual symbol he was wearing. Ironed onto his red and white jersey was the winged foot of the elite New York Athletic Club, a rare sight these days in the lead pack of major marathons, which are usually dominated by swooshes and stripes.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: pricey pills, high altitudes and avocados. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: pricey pills, high altitudes and avocados. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Wedding Q. and A.
abstract: Questions about shower thank you notes and wedding invitations.

headline: The Office Space We Love to Hate
abstract: Nikil Saval’s new book, “Cubed,” explains the history of the modern office, and what it means that about 60 percent of us wound up in cubicles.
lead_paragraph: “The white-collar people slipped quietly into modern society,” C. Wright Mills writes in “White Collar” (1951), his classic sociology text, as if he were describing a race of wan termites. Nikil Saval’s excellent new book, “Cubed: A Secret History of the Workplace,” was inspired by Mills’s book, and it’s a fresh and intellectually omnivorous extension of its themes.

headline: Senate Panel Faults Ex-Homeland Security Watchdog for Failing to Be Independent
keywords: ['Inspectors General', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The panel found that the official, Charles Edwards, “jeopardized the independence” of the inspector general’s office by delaying reports or alerting department officials about their contents.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Senate subcommittee has found that the official who served as the Department of Homeland Security’s acting inspector general from 2011 to 2013 “jeopardized the independence” of his office by delaying reports and alerting department officials about their contents.

headline: James Earl Jones to Star on Broadway in ‘You Can’t Take It With You’
abstract: Mr. Jones will return in the first Broadway revival of “You Can’t Take It With You” in 30 years.
lead_paragraph: James Earl Jones will star in a Broadway revival of the Pulitzer Prize-winning comedy “You Can’t Take It With You” beginning in August, with Scott Ellis on board to direct, the producers of the show announced on Thursday.

headline: Bourbon’s Affinity for Ginger
abstract: Three cocktails combining two crisp and refreshing ingredients.
lead_paragraph: We all know how well fresh mint goes with bourbon. Sean Josephs, one of our panelists, opened my eyes (and palate) to bourbon’s affinity for ginger. The Nor’easter he serves at Maysville and Char No. 4 is a simple, lightly sweetened example of bourbon and lime, topped off with a splash of ginger beer. On the same wavelength, at Philip Marie in Greenwich Village, there’s the Bufala Negra, a bourbon drink seasoned with balsamic vinegar and finished with ginger beer, a slight variation on the original made with balsamic syrup and ginger ale, which was created by Jerry Slater of H Harper Station in Atlanta.

headline: Tarantino’s Infringement Lawsuit Against Gawker Is Dismissed
abstract: The director accused the company of helping to leak an unpublished script, but a judge said his lawyers had offered no evidence of copyright abuse.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge has agreed to dismiss a lawsuit by the director Quentin Tarantino that accused Gawker Media of helping to leak his unpublished script, “The Hateful Eight.”

headline: China’s Legislature Votes to Toughen Environmental Protection Law
abstract: The revised law, which will take effect next year, will allow for stricter punishments of companies or individuals caught polluting the environment.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese legislature decided Thursday to revise the country’s environmental protection law to allow for stricter punishments against companies or individuals caught polluting the environment, according to a report by Xinhua, the state news agency.

headline: A Maine Lighthouse Welcomes Guests
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: For the first time, the Cuckolds — a pair of granite islands a half mile off the coast of Southport Island, Maine — will be open to guests for overnight stays.
lead_paragraph: For the first time, the Cuckolds — a pair of granite islands a half mile off the coast of Southport Island, Maine — will be open to guests for overnight stays beginning June 27.

headline: Oregon Panel Recommends Switch to Federal Health Exchange
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Repairing the state’s troubled website would be far more expensive in a year when the Democratic governor, John Kitzhaber, is already dealing with political fallout.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With encouragement from the Obama administration, an Oregon panel recommended Thursday that the state scrap the website for its beleaguered health insurance exchange and use the federal marketplace instead.

headline: Phelps Finishes Second in Return, and Winner Is Glad He’s Back
abstract: In his first race since 2012, Michael Phelps posted the fastest time in the preliminary heats of the 100-meter butterfly and then finished second to Ryan Lochte in the final.
lead_paragraph: MESA, Ariz. — Michael Phelps’s possible pursuit of a fifth Olympics has the swimming world abuzz, but first things first. Before Phelps could entertain thoughts of defending his 100-meter butterfly title in Brazil, there was the matter of qualifying for the national championships in Southern California in August.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Blue Ruin’
abstract: The writer and director Jeremy Saulnier narrates a sequence from his film featuring Macon Blair.
lead_paragraph: The writer and director Jeremy Saulnier narrates a sequence from his film featuring Macon Blair.

headline: Climbers Leave Everest Amid Regrets and Tensions Among Sherpas
abstract: As most Western climbers decided to return home, they described a menacing atmosphere among Sherpas in base camp, including threats to those who planned to continue.
lead_paragraph: KATMANDU, Nepal — Climbers who had hoped to reach the summit of Mount Everest have instead begun the long journey home: a teenager with epilepsy who wanted to inspire others like himself; a banker who quit his job, sold his apartment and used up most of his savings to pay for the trip; a builder from California who was carrying the ashes of his younger brother.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘Blue Ruin’
abstract: Jeremy Saulnier, the writer and director of “Blue Ruin,” narrates a sequence from his film.
lead_paragraph: In this video, the writer and director Jeremy Saulnier narrates a sequence from his revenge thriller “Blue Ruin,” starring his best friend Macon Blair. He discusses a getaway that doesn’t quite go the way his protagonist would have hoped.

headline: Video of Rancher Cliven Bundy’s Remarks on Race
abstract: The rancher Cliven Bundy’s remarks on race, slavery and abortion at a news conference on Saturday were captured on video.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Adam Nagourney reports, on Saturday the Nevada rancher Cliven Bundy veered away from his fight with the federal government to share his views on race, slavery and abortion in remarks to supporters and journalists at a news conference.

headline: Tech Giants Settle Antitrust Hiring Suit
keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Apple, Google, Intel and Adobe reached an agreement with plaintiffs over charges that the companies conspired not to hire one another’s employees.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The workers of Silicon Valley have won an important victory over their bosses. What they did not win is a lot of money.

headline: Nothing to Cheer About
abstract: An examination of the 2006 Duke lacrosse ordeal, and the dangerous balance between academics and college athletics.
lead_paragraph: It has become possible, these past several decades, to think of Duke as consisting of a professional basketball team to which, bizarrely, a research university has attached itself. But it is the “non­revenue” sports at Duke — and the school’s relentless, aggressive and very expensive campaign to build them into powerhouse brands — that have most radically changed the tenor of that campus. The strange centrality of the athletic program in the life of an academically excellent institution, and the many unintended consequences this situation has wrought, is the subject of William D. Cohan’s “The Price of Silence: The Duke Lacrosse Scandal, the Power of the Elite, and the Corruption of Our Great Universities.” The book is at once a masterwork of reporting and a devastating critique of a university that has lost its way.

headline: Bourbon’s Masters of the Craft
abstract: Small, independent distillers have presented the spirit as an attractive option to those who have moved toward vodka and single-malt Scotches.
lead_paragraph: With the approach of the Kentucky Derby, you can bet a lot of bourbon will be consumed. Nowadays, that’s nothing new.

headline: Caroline Kennedy Says She Will Back Hillary Clinton in a Run for President
abstract: Ms. Kennedy, whose endorsement of Barack Obama in 2008 was a setback for Hillary Rodham Clinton, said she would “absolutely” support Mrs. Clinton should she decide to run for president again.
lead_paragraph: Caroline Kennedy, whose endorsement of Barack Obama in 2008 was a major setback for Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign, as well as a personal blow, said Thursday that she would “absolutely” support Mrs. Clinton should she decide to run for president again.

headline: Eyes on the Prize
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: In “Forcing the Spring,” Jo Becker offers a fly-on-the-wall account of the challenge to California’s anti-gay-marriage Proposition 8.
lead_paragraph: Big Supreme Court cases produce big books: “Gideon’s Trumpet,” “Simple Justice.” On June 26, 2013, the Supreme Court decided two big ­cases. In United States v. Windsor, it struck down a part of the federal Defense of Marriage Act as unconstitutional, while in Hollingsworth v. Perry it sidestepped the challenge to California’s anti-gay-marriage Proposition 8 on a technicality, leaving the trial court’s original ruling — that Prop 8 was unconstitutional — in effect.

headline: Massachusetts Maverick
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Senator Elizabeth Warren describes her life, her academic and political work, and her meteoric rise in the Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: A couple of months ago, on Connecticut Avenue not far from the White House, I passed a crowd of 20-somethings wearing distressed denim and hoodies. They looked more Williamsburg than Washington and carried placards that read: “I’m from the Elizabeth Warren wing of the party.”

headline: Mind Over Matter: Mastering Daunting Moves
abstract: Three amateur athletes set high goals, and find ways to achieve them, with some one-on-one help.
lead_paragraph: OVERACHIEVERS, beware: In the pursuit of a challenging sport or discipline, there will come a time when you confront a move that your mind embraces but your body protests.

headline: This Weekend: Two Warhol Exhibitions
abstract: This weekend in New York: two Andy Warhol exhibitions, Neil Patrick Harris playing a transgender rock star and Ballet Preljocaj’s “Snow White.”
lead_paragraph: This weekend in New York: two Andy Warhol exhibitions, Neil Patrick Harris playing a transgender rock star and Ballet Preljocaj’s “Snow White.”

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties include a three-bedroom in Bayside with a sauna, a one-bedroom co-op in Tudor City and a loft duplex in Williamsburg.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: This Weekend: Two Warhol Exhibitions
abstract: This weekend be sure to check out the two Andy Warhol exhibitions, Neil Patrick Harris playing a transgender rock star or Ballet Preljocaj’s “Snow White.”
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: On the Market in the Region
abstract: This week’s properties include a four-bedroom renovated home in Yonkers and a five-bedroom with adjacent cottage in Old Greenwich.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: The Dumb Jock Stereotype Can Be a Self-Fulfilling Prophecy
abstract: Thinking about the stereotypes about “dumb jocks” and academics may cause student-athletes to underperform on tests.
lead_paragraph: Social scientists know that in research studies, minority and female students appear to be vulnerable to the phenomenon called “stereotype threat.” Aware that the group to which they belong is often stereotyped as intellectually inferior, their anxiety that a poor showing on a test will confirm the stereotype actually depresses their performance on the test, creating a self-fulfilling prophecy.

headline: A Law and the Face of the City
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Building (Construction)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: Mandatory facade inspections protected people, but some feared for architecture.
lead_paragraph: On May 19th, it will be 35 years since Grace Gold, a Barnard College freshman, was struck and killed by a falling piece of masonry at 115th Street and Broadway. Her death sparked in 1980 what was then called Local Law 10, requiring facade inspections. Preservationists warned that wholesale stripping of architectural ornament would result. A survey of Upper West Side buildings in 1993 and today indicates otherwise.

abstract: Subjects include: a potential squatter, co-op roof deck rights and meeting traditional income requirements for rentals.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Turkey, India and Japan.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Turkey, India and Japan.

abstract: Ms. explores a vacuous bit of art world parlance: the phrase “Love your work,”finding hidden reserves of meaning.
lead_paragraph: On Stellar Rays

headline: The Case of the Disappearing Chintz
abstract: Linda Fairstein has changed careers and paint colors a time or two.
lead_paragraph: When Linda Fairstein moved in with her future husband, Justin Feldman, in 1986, she was less than enchanted with the décor of his one-bedroom rental. It was a symphony in brown and brown.

headline: Amazon’s Revenue Grew 23 Percent in First Quarter, Nearing $20 Billion
abstract: The company had earnings per share of 23 cents, exactly hitting forecasts. Last quarter, analysts expected more than twice that amount.
lead_paragraph: Amazon defines corporate prosperity in terms of sales growth rather than profit. By its definition, which has been embraced on Wall Street, the big Internet merchant had a strong first quarter.

headline: Sara Cwynar: ‘Flat Death’
abstract: The artifice of photography has allowed many younger artists to build on the achievements of the early-1980s Pictures Generation.
lead_paragraph: Foxy Production

headline: Undie Rock, With a Soupçon of Broadway
abstract: The scantily clad Skivvies have built a following with musical mashups blending obscenity and innocence.
lead_paragraph: IT was almost 11 p.m. in the packed subterranean space of 54 Below, and Lauren Molina, a petite actress with a mop of curls, was onstage in red underwear, straddling a cello. “You guys like Britney Spears?” she asked the audience, confidingly.

headline: A Glorious Front Yard
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A rare opportunity to buy a palatial apartment in the two-towered 1930 landmark.
lead_paragraph: A nine-room apartment with palatial proportions, a wraparound terrace and 70 feet of direct Central Park frontage at the venerable San Remo, the twin-towered 1930 landmark at 145 Central Park West at 74th Street, is poised to enter the market for the first time in 35 years.

abstract: Since 1974, the German artist Peter Dreher has painted nearly 5,000 versions of the same picture.
lead_paragraph: Koenig & Clinton

headline: Warburg Pincus to Invest in PayScale, a Compensation Data Firm
abstract: Warburg Pincus, said on Thursday that it would invest up to $100 million for a majority stake in PayScale, a cloud-based software company that collects compensation data and offers the information to businesses.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to paying employees, companies keep a close eye on what rivals are doing. To that end, one private equity firm is betting that companies might want more precise data.

keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Some foreign governments based in quiet, elegant buildings on the Upper East Side hope to cash in on the run-up of home prices.
lead_paragraph: There is an expansive, 13-room duplex at 730 Park Avenue where time has stood still.

lead_paragraph: A scene from the film.

headline: Two 40-Year-Olds Set Example for the Mets
abstract: Bartolo Colon allowed a run and four hits in seven innings, striking out eight, and Bobby Abreu doubled.
lead_paragraph: The repetitive number pairing 40-40 typically refers to one of baseball’s greatest single-season achievements — hitting 40 home runs and stealing 40 bases. The feat has been accomplished by only four players, all in the primes of their careers.

headline: Officials on Suspended Talks in Mideast
abstract: Officials from Israel, the Palestine Liberation Organization and Hamas discussed Israel’s decision to suspend negotiations with the Palestinians after a Gaza deal between the factions Fatah and Hamas.
lead_paragraph: Officials from Israel, the Palestine Liberation Organization and Hamas discussed Israel’s decision to suspend negotiations with the Palestinians after a Gaza deal between the factions Fatah and Hamas.

headline: No, Obama Didn’t Win One-Third of White Voters in Deep South
keywords: ['Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: A look at how we calculated President Obama’s support among white voters in the South, and a definition of what constitutes the Deep South.
lead_paragraph: This morning, I published an article on the decline of Democratic support among white Southerners from West Texas to the Atlantic Coast. In that region, Mitt Romney often won by margins so large that they rivaled President Obama’s advantage among black voters. Larry Bartels, writing for The Washington Post’s Monkey Cage blog, disputes my argument and claims Mr. Obama had widespread white support in the south.

headline: A Rocket Is Aimed at Detroit (Run! Jump!)
abstract: “Brick Mansions,” directed by Camille Delamarre, comes tantalizingly close to being a high-impact allegory of race, class and real estate in a postindustrial, new-Gilded Age America.
lead_paragraph: As is not uncommon with movies of this kind, a certain amount of the dialogue in “Brick Mansions” consists of excited elaborations of the obvious, perhaps for the benefit of viewers who missed something while texting or dozing. During a foot chase, when the pursued parties have succeeded in locking a door from the outside, one of the pursuers remarks, “They locked the door from the outside!” In the midst of a later chase (there are a lot of them), when the guys who locked that door are hiding on an abandoned school bus, someone shouts, “They’re on the bus!” And when it is revealed that one of the chief villains is in possession of a military-grade rocket, the strangeness of this fact does not go unnoticed: “Only a crazy person would have a rocket!”

headline: California Senate Rejects Smartphone ‘Kill Switch’ Law
abstract: A California bill that sought to require smarter antitheft security on smartphones was rejected in a close vote in the State Senate.
lead_paragraph: The California Senate on Thursday voted down a state measure that would require smarter antitheft security on smartphones.

headline: Nets’ Bench Is Taking Back Seat in Playoffs
abstract: Aside from Mirza Teletovic, who had 14 points in Game 2, no reserve has scored in double figures in the playoffs for the Nets, whose depth played a key role in their resurgence this season.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Toronto Raptors were more precise in distributing the minutes of their reserves in their Game 2 victory over the Nets on Tuesday night, resulting in greater contributions from a smaller pool of players.

headline: Global Entry and Company: Worth the Price?
keywords: ['Airport Security', 'Budget Travel', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Programs like Global Entry, T.S.A. PreCheck and CLEAR can save you time at the airport — for a cost. The Frugal Traveler looks at whether paying that price truly pays off.
lead_paragraph: Time versus money — there’s no more fundamental trade-off in budget travel. Nonstop or layover, taxi or public bus? Stand in line for half-price theater tickets or buy full-price at the click of a mouse?

headline: Clip: ‘The Quiet Ones’
abstract: A scene from the film.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film.

headline: More Public Art for Governors Island
abstract: Governors Island is expanding its displays of public art, with installations by Mark Handforth, a sound piece by Susan Philipsz and a concrete structure by Rachel Whiteread.
lead_paragraph: When a new 30-acre park opens at the southern end of Governors Island on May 24, it will boast a grove of hammocks, two ball fields, a formal garden and play areas with climbable structures and spray showers. It will also be part of an ambitious backdrop for a new public art program taking shape on this 172-acre island, the former Army and Coast Guard base in New York Harbor. The city took control of Governors Island in 2010, and each year there’s more to do and see, attracting thousands of visitors during the summer months.

headline: Possessed by Demons, and a Nutty Professor
abstract: In “The Quiet Ones,” a professor and his aides experiment with a possible cure for a haunted young woman in an isolated house.
lead_paragraph: The title of “The Quiet Ones,” the latest horror movie about supernatural doings set in the 1970s, is explained fairly late. By then its director, John Pogue, has made a modest racket with the usual bumps in the night, some cackling and screaming, a bit of door slamming and table knocking. A fair amount of this noise seems to emanate from Jane Harper (Olivia Cooke), a hollow-eyed young patient of Professor Coupland (Jared Harris). An Oxford University lecturer, Coupland believes that the supernatural occurrences in Jane’s bleak, lonely life have been created by her mind and is using every bad idea he has — including curing her through sleep deprivation — to prove it.

headline: Letters: Another Look
abstract: Readers respond to a recent Visuals column and more.
lead_paragraph: Another Look

headline: Tracking Future and Hip-Hop’s Growlers
abstract: Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss the rapper Future and the evolution of vocal style in hip-hop.
lead_paragraph: Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss the rapper Future and the evolution of vocal style in hip-hop.

headline: Slavery Nostalgia Is Real, and It’s Dangerous
abstract: In the South, even some powerful people seem to miss the days of the Confederacy.
lead_paragraph: Northerners may be a little shocked that anyone could feel a bit nostalgic for slavery, in the manner of the government-hating Nevada rancher, Cliven Bundy. But in the South, such sentiments are hardly unheard of, even if they are usually muttered in private over a few bourbons rather than spoken at a news conference.

headline: Current Events Imperil Ukrainian Museum Show
abstract: Sketches and poetry by Taras Shevchenko, a hero of Ukrainian culture, are expected for an exhibition at the Ukrainian Museum commemorating the 200th anniversary of his birth.
lead_paragraph: Works by the 19th-century Ukrainian poet and painter Taras Shevchenko are tentatively scheduled to arrive in Manhattan next week, in time for a retrospective opening May 11 at the Ukrainian Museum. But fingers are crossed.

headline: Mom, That Fugitive Nazi Is Making Eyes at Me
abstract: “The German Doctor,” directed by Lucía Puenzo from her own novel, imagines Josef Mengele’s time in South America and his interest in an Argentine family.
lead_paragraph: The quietly jittery art house thriller “The German Doctor” opens in Patagonia in 1960, with a man watching a group of girls playing along a dusty road. Coolly, he zeros in on one child with long, blond hair, his light, clear eyes tracking her as she awkwardly scrambles into her family’s car. He trails after her, pleasantries are exchanged, and the man, who’s moving to a nearby town, arranges to follow the family in his car. Soon after they hit the road, he is murmuring in German, and there’s no doubt that Helmut Gregor (Alex Brendemühl, suave and unnerving), as he calls himself, is no ordinary stranger. Not too long after, he’s setting up an office and measuring the girl’s head.

headline: Microsoft’s Profit Dips Less Than Expected as It Reshapes Itself
abstract: The attention of investors seems to be less on the solid financial results and more on a series of bold bets to reshape the company, including the acquisition of Nokia.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Microsoft on Thursday again demonstrated its gift for weathering the turmoil in the personal computer industry, turning in solid financial results for a company playing catch-up in several important markets.

headline: Short Sales on the Decline
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Short Selling', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: Wary borrowers await debt-forgiveness extension.
lead_paragraph: The expiration of a federal tax exemption for forgiven mortgage debt appears to be scaring borrowers away from pursuing short sales.

abstract: Residential towers are rising all over New York City. Some projects had been on developers’ back burners since the recession so rudely interrupted, awaiting the right moment to resume.
lead_paragraph: New York City is awash in development, with skyscrapers rising above the cityscape seemingly at random, especially in neighborhoods in Manhattan.

headline: Prickly but Puppyish in San Francisco
abstract: “Energy That Is All Around: Mission School,” at the Grey Art Gallery, displays the youthful work of five artists who came of age in the Mission District of San Francisco in the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: Youth, they say, is wasted on the young, but it wasn’t on the five artists featured in “Energy That Is All Around: Mission School,” an exhibition at the Grey Art Gallery that bristles infectiously with youthful urgency.

headline: What We’re Reading Now
abstract: A roundup of food, health and ag news, in case you missed it.
lead_paragraph: Poisons: Scientists condemn a new F.D.A. study claiming BPA, a chemical present in certain plastics, is safe, saying it borders on scientific misconduct.

headline: Trying to Outrun Age, in Spiky Heels
abstract: Jealousy is the overriding theme of Angelin Preljocaj’s “Snow White,” presented by his company at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: There’s a mirror on a wall and a stepmother who wants to look younger than her daughter. Is it just another day in the life of a dressing room at Forever 21, or Angelin Preljocaj’s version of “Snow White”?

lead_paragraph: This week in The Times’s Culture Minute: Two Andy Warhol exhibitions; Neil Patrick Harris as a transgender rock star in “Hedwig and the Angry Inch”; and Ballet Preljocaj’s “Snow White.”

headline: No Time for Audiobooks: He’s on the Road to His Destiny
abstract: “Locke,” a drama starring Tom Hardy, is set almost entirely within a car in a hypnotic landscape.
lead_paragraph: A truism about cinema and television, two tributaries that increasingly flow into one image stream, is that together they have turned the human face into our favorite destination spot. The ubiquity of close-ups, particularly in broadcast television, with its parade of bobbling heads and babbling mouths, could have drained movie faces of their power. Yet we can’t seem to get enough of other people’s faces, whether they’re as frozen as masks or changeable as churning water. We trace stories across these familiar landscapes, becoming geographers of emotion.

headline: Humanity and Hope in a Southern Prison
abstract: Confederate prisons were hellish places — except the one at Cahaba.
lead_paragraph: For more than the obvious reasons, Civil War soldiers in both armies despised military prisons. Not only were the inmates held against their will, but the hunger, filth, vermin, rampant disease, overcrowding, brutal treatment and soul-crushing ennui made prison camps slaughterhouses of slow death. Andersonville, the infamous Georgia prison, was the ultimate abattoir; during the summer of 1864 nearly one in three Union inmates died. In other Confederate prisons, the average mortality rate was 15.5 percent; in Union prisons, 12 percent.

headline: Aftermath of Ukraine Photo Story Shows Need for More Caution
abstract: Photographs under scrutiny led to a follow-up article on Russian military activity in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The Times led its print edition Monday with an article based in part on photographs that the State Department said were evidence of Russian military presence in popular uprisings in Ukraine. The headline read: “Photos Link Masked Men in East Ukraine to Russia.”

headline: June 4th Museum Set to Open in Hong Kong
abstract: A museum that aims to preserve memories of the 1989 Tiananmen protests is scheduled to open this weekend, despite the threat of a lawsuit from the building owners’ committee.
lead_paragraph: In April 1989, tens of thousands of young protesters assembled on Tiananmen Square, in the heart of Beijing, demanding greater political freedoms and an end to corruption. The protests ended in bloodshed when tanks and troops were deployed the night of June 3-4 to clear the square. By most estimates, hundreds were killed.

headline: How to Kill the Minimum Wage Movement
abstract: A surprising debate in Seattle: is $15 an hour too much, too soon?
lead_paragraph: On a visit to the capital a few weeks ago, I was struck by how politically inert the place was. Not just empty, lifeless, devoid of activity in the chambers where great politicians once roamed. Not just a do-nothing Congress living up to its pledge to do even less this year than last. Not just the usual government-by-corporate lobbyists. At the moment, Washington is a dead town.

headline: Putting Pen to Paper, and a Friendship to the Test
abstract: “Address Unknown” is a stage adaptation of a book about two German friends who exchange letters in the early days of Hitler’s reign.
lead_paragraph: Do you miss stamps? Or stationery? Or messages free from emoticons? “Address Unknown,” in a brief run at Gould Hall at the French Institute Alliance Française, could make you a lot less nostalgic for letter writing. Based on Kathrine Kressmann Taylor’s short epistolary novel, it concerns two German friends, Max and Martin, on the eve of World War II.

Hotton, the former stockbroker notorious for defrauding Broadway producers, is arguing that his employer, Oppenheimer & Company, withheld critical evidence during an arbitration hearing and should be held liable.

headline: Italy’s Mob Extends Reach in Europe
abstract: Organized crime groups, which many still view as mostly a southern Italian problem, have used their vast wealth to gain sway in both economic and government circles.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The small businesses were sprinkled throughout the Italian capital: One restaurant was only a few blocks from the Senate. A cafe was at the edge of the upscale diplomatic district, while a gelato shop was near the Pantheon. There was even a hotel not far from the hilltop statue of Giuseppe Garibaldi, the hero of Italy’s unification.
