abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: FOOD BOOK FARM

headline: The Insider | Advice From, and For, First-Time Filmmakers
abstract: Fifteen talents making their directorial debuts at the Tribeca Film Festival share tips and tales from the front lines.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to realizing a work of art, few processes are more challenging than that of making a feature film. Never mind that unlike most art forms, movies are a largely collaborative medium — paintbrushes don’t have egos — but even in our age of digital cameras and home editing suites, filmmaking can get expensive. Not only does a director have to believe in the project from page to screen, but so do the people paying for it. Being a filmmaker, especially in the beginning, is risky business. Here, 15 directors — each of whom are showing their first feature at the Tribeca Film Festival, which runs through Sunday — share with T how they did it.

headline: France Joins Gay Couples by Thousands, Amid Gripes
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: Despite the protests that accompanied passage of the law allowing same-sex marriage, more than 7,000 such ceremonies have been performed in the last year — sometimes by reluctant officiants.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Same-sex marriage has been gaining acceptance in France a year after a law allowing such unions was passed following vociferous public opposition and heated debate in Parliament.

headline: Spare Times for April 25-May 1
abstract: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN: SAKURA MATSURI (Saturday and Sunday) At last, the cherry trees are in bloom, and the dancers and musicians who will be part of this annual festival of traditional and contemporary Japanese arts are ready to welcome visitors into a garden of earthly delights. More than 60 events will be featured, along with a marketplace and activities for children. Hours are 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. The garden is at 990 Washington Avenue, at Eastern Parkway, Prospect Heights, 718-623-7200, bbg.org; $25; $20 for those 12 to 17 and 65+; free for children under 12 and members. Let the cherry blossom petals fall where they may. (Anne Mancuso)

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Just an After-School Job
abstract: “Young & Beautiful,” by François Ozon, looks at adolescent female sexuality in a tale of a middle-class teenager who chooses to be a prostitute.
lead_paragraph: “Young & Beautiful,” the latest movie from the French director François Ozon, begins with a shot, through binoculars, of a young woman sunbathing topless on a beach. Voyeurism is clearly on the agenda, and Mr. Ozon seems to be teasing out some of its creepy implications when he reveals that the binoculars belong to the sunbather’s younger brother. But what is most striking about this movie is how un-self-conscious it is as it conducts a prurient and superficial inquiry into adolescent female sexuality.

headline: A Bit Naughty, This Boy Band
abstract: 5 Seconds of Summer, four hair-product-happy pieces of teenage jerky from Australia, have a new major-label debut EP and a very keen understanding of what a cool racket they’ve got going.
lead_paragraph: Boys will be boys, and sometimes boys will be men, but most often boys will be struggling to figure out how much of each they should be, so they can get away with the most stuff.

headline: What a Life: Bus Tables, Buss Prince
abstract: Among the many productions of the Cinderella tale in New York, the Juilliard School is staging Massenet’s “Cendrillon.”
lead_paragraph: Perhaps it’s just coincidence. Or maybe, with the recent public discourse about the struggling middle class, this seems an apt moment to revisit a fairy tale about a good-hearted young woman, miserably oppressed by her family, who finds an unlikely soul mate in a loving prince.

headline: An Opera, Without Singing, in a Museum
abstract: Opera as the composer Robert Ashley defined it, his spoken multimedia interrogation of Anne Opie Wehrer, is revived at the Whitney Museum.
lead_paragraph: In 1974 the writer and actress Anne Opie Wehrer, the subject of Robert Ashley’s “The Trial of Anne Opie Wehrer and Unknown Accomplices for Crimes Against Humanity,” wrote to the Whitney Museum of American Art proposing that it present the work as a “living sculpture.”

headline: Silent, Clumsy Avenger Gets to Work
abstract: Jeremy Saulnier’s film “Blue Ruin” stars his friend Macon Blair as a near-silent, homeless shadow awakened to a long-percolating vengeance.
lead_paragraph: Dwight (Macon Blair) isn’t your typical movie avenger, but then “Blue Ruin” — partly named for Dwight’s battered blue Pontiac — isn’t your typical revenge movie. Concealed behind a hill-country beard and shapeless clothing, Dwight is a near-silent, homeless shadow who sleeps in his car on a Delaware beach. When we first see him, he’s enjoying a bath in a stranger’s home, dismayed when the owners arrive unexpectedly. A tidy intruder, Dwight doesn’t like to leave a mess.

headline: Clip: ‘The Other Woman’
abstract: A scene from the film.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film.

headline: Neanderthals Are People, Too
keywords: ['Genetics and Heredity', 'Neanderthal Man', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Denisova Hominid', 'Research', 'Stem Cells']
abstract: We shouldn’t bring them back to life with genetic technology, any more than we should our grandparents.
lead_paragraph: LEIPZIG, Germany — I NEVER met my paternal grandfather. He died of the Spanish flu in 1919 at the age of 30, before his children and grandchildren ever got to know him. He was a brilliant mathematician and, as a scientist myself, I feel curious about what he was like. I take consolation from the fact that he lives on in me; after all, a quarter of my genes come from him.

headline: It’s Not You — It’s That You Want to Stay in My Apartment
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Baby Boomers', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: I had a guest in my one-bedroom apartment for four nights last week, and I did not once tell her how much I wanted to kill her and throw her body into the Hudson.
lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg, the former mayor of New York, told a reporter last week that he’s done so much good that if there’s a heaven, he won’t have to stop for an interview, he’ll walk right in.

headline: A Female Cooperative Based on Revenge
abstract: In “The Other Woman,” a comedy directed by Nick Cassavetes, Cameron Diaz plays a lawyer who learns that her lover is not only married, but has other girlfriends as well.
lead_paragraph: It takes a lot of heavy weather to snuff out the spark of Cameron Diaz who, at 41, still has the twinkle and bounce of an impish high school cheerleader. With her cornflower-blue eyes and mischievous feline grin, she remains every guy’s ultimate gal pal. One of her gifts as an comic actor is a light touch.

headline: Schwab Agrees to Drop Effort to Prevent Class-Action Lawsuits
abstract: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority, Wall Street’s self-regulator, said on Thursday that the discount brokerage firm had also agreed to pay a $500,000 fine.
lead_paragraph: The discount brokerage firm Charles Schwab & Company has agreed to pay a $500,000 fine and give up an effort to prevent customers from participating in class-action lawsuits.

headline: A Ferocious Satirist, With Ink as His Weapon
abstract: “For No Good Reason” strives to depict the life and work of the British cartoonist and illustrator Ralph Steadman, who spent much of his career alongside Hunter S. Thompson.
lead_paragraph: In 1969, Ralph Steadman, a British cartoonist and illustrator, was invited by the editors of Scanlan’s Monthly to attend the Kentucky Derby in the company of Hunter S. Thompson, who was writing an article about the race. This assignment marked the beginning of a long, fruitful and frequently volatile collaboration. Nine years after Thompson’s death, it is nearly impossible to think of his prose without conjuring visions of Mr. Steadman’s drawings — nightmarishly funny compositions in which spidery lines intersect with clouds of spilled and sprayed ink.

headline: Pro-Russian Rebels on Checkpoint Attack
abstract: Pro-Russian separatists described the scene after a clash with Ukrainian forces at a checkpoint outside Slovyansk, Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Pro-Russian separatists described the scene after a clash with Ukrainian forces at a checkpoint outside Slovyansk, Ukraine.

headline: Cliven Bundy Accidentally Explained What’s Wrong With the Republican Party
abstract: A rancher in dispute with the government over grazing fees offers unexpected insight into the G.O.P.’s challenge in appealing to minorities.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, Cliven Bundy, the Nevada rancher who has risen to prominence because of his dispute with the Bureau of Land Management, held forth about “the Negro,” and how black people may have been better off under slavery than now.

headline: Paths to Stopping Painkiller Overdoses
abstract: Readers offer views on approaches to preventing deaths from painkiller overdoses.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 49
abstract: Brazil’s Ministry of Sport has launched a website that offers visitors a guide to the 12 host cities.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Blithely Risking Discovery of Her May-December Fling
abstract: “Bright Days Ahead,” starring Fanny Ardant, portrays a 60-year-old woman with a devoted husband who takes a handsome young lover.
lead_paragraph: Oh, those French! When it comes to adultery, they apparently know how to indulge without tears or recriminations. That is the reassuring but unconvincing message of “Bright Days Ahead,” a lighter-than-air carnal romance.

headline: Pakistan, Ending Its Observance of Cease-Fire, Launches Airstrikes Against Taliban
abstract: The airstrikes dealt a new blow to Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif’s faltering efforts to engage the militants in peace talks.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Putting an abrupt end to the Pakistani government’s adherence to a cease-fire with the Taliban on Thursday, military jets launched heavy airstrikes against militants in the Khyber tribal region bordering Afghanistan, officials said.

headline: End College Legacy Preferences
abstract: There is no moral or legal justification for favoring alumni children.
lead_paragraph: SOMEONE reading about the Supreme Court’s decision upholding Michigan’s ban on affirmative action — and by extension similar measures passed by voters in California, Texas, Florida and Washington — might develop the misimpression that affirmative action is on the wane. In fact, it’s alive and well: Public and private colleges routinely give preferential treatment to children of alumni.

headline: Searching for the Life That Belonged to a Body
abstract: In “Who Is Dayani Cristal?,” Gael García Bernal traces the footsteps of a man who died in a desert trying to cross into the United States.
lead_paragraph: A kind of forensic memorial, “Who Is Dayani Cristal?” pieces together the background of a Central American migrant worker who died trying to cross into the United States. With its compellingly multifaceted approach, its earnest compassion and a celebrity presence in the form of the actor Gael García Bernal, the documentary could be enlisted in the perennial battle over immigration law. But for the same reasons, the movie is also in danger of battling itself to a draw.

headline: NYU Langone Reopens Emergency Room That Was Closed by Hurricane Sandy
abstract: The Manhattan hospital unveiled its rebuilt and revamped operation, which is now triple its former size.
lead_paragraph: A striking sight appeared earlier this week outside the emergency room of NYU Langone Medical Center: an ambulance. Then another. And then many more.

headline: Mind the Gap? That’s the Least of Their Worries
abstract: The minimally plotted “Last Passenger” finds a group of strangers trapped on a runaway train that has just left London.
lead_paragraph: Like a hard-up version of a 1970s disaster movie, “Last Passenger” drops a disparate group of people in the path of a calamity, then watches as they wriggle to escape. But instead of being on a sinking ship or in a blazing tower block, these unfortunates are trapped on a late-night commuter train that has just left London. And if that’s not terrifying enough, they’re headed for the snooty borough of Tunbridge Wells.

headline: China: Legislature Toughens Environmental Law
abstract: The Chinese legislature decided Thursday to revise the country’s environmental protection law to allow for stricter punishments against companies or individuals caught polluting the environment, according to a report by Xinhua, the state news agency.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese legislature decided Thursday to revise the country’s environmental protection law to allow for stricter punishments against companies or individuals caught polluting the environment, according to a report by Xinhua, the state news agency. Under the new law, expected to take effect next year, fines against companies would be increased, and company executives deemed responsible for pollution could be detained for up to 15 days. Local officials who cover up for polluting companies can be demoted or fired. Companies that have been ordered by officials to stop polluting but avoid doing so can be penalized with fines that accumulate daily. Until now, the companies had been assessed a one-time fine, Xinhua reported. The legal revisions were approved Thursday by the National People’s Congress, a legislative body that generally agrees to policies already made by Communist Party leaders.

headline: This Week’s Movies: April 25, 2014
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Brick Mansions,” “The German Doctor” and “For No Good Reason.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Brick Mansions,” “The German Doctor” and “For No Good Reason.”

headline: Provision Could Limit U.S. Food Aid
keywords: ['Food Aid', 'Ships and Shipping', 'Law and Legislation', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: A new law would require that three-quarters of United States food aid, instead of one-half, be sent on American vessels, potentially preventing nations in need from receiving it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An obscure provision tucked inside a Coast Guard spending bill could prevent millions of people in troubled countries around the world from receiving American food aid and cost taxpayers millions of dollars in shipping costs, the Obama administration said this week.

headline: If Assad Wins War, Challenge From His Own Sect May Follow
keywords: ['Alawite Muslims', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Some loyalists of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria would be likely to push for a bigger share of power if they came to feel safe from the threat of insurgent revenge.
lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria — As President Bashar al-Assad seeks re-election and promises victory over insurgents by year’s end, Syrian loyalists and regional analysts say that his success, if it materializes, could set him up for a new challenge: demands for change from core supporters who believe he owes his survival mainly to them.

headline: ‘Zero Motivation’ and ‘Point and Shoot’ Take Top Prizes at Tribeca Film Festival
abstract: “Zero Motivation,” which depicts a unit of female Israeli soldiers, won best narrative film; “Point and Shoot,” following an American filmmaker in the Libyan civil war, was named best documentary.
lead_paragraph: Military-themed films won top prizes at this year’s Tribeca Film Festival, which announced its awards Thursday night: “Zero Motivation,” which depicts the trials and tedium endured by a unit of young female Israeli soldiers, won best narrative film, and “Point and Shoot,” wherein an American filmmaker records his foray into the Libyan civil war, was named best documentary.

headline: Something’s Burning, and Comedy Isn’t Pretty
abstract: Pain is everywhere in “Ape,” a knife-edged portrait of a struggling stand-up by Joel Potrykus that looks at the allure of humiliation.
lead_paragraph: Pain is everywhere in “Ape,” but it starts with the light. From the bright stab of morning after a rough night to the merciless glare of the spotlight in a pitch-black comedy club, this knife-edged portrait of a struggling stand-up uses agony like a silent soundtrack.

headline: Clip: ‘The German Doctor’
abstract: A scene from the film directed by Lucía Puenzo.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film directed by Lucía Puenzo.

headline: Ladies’ Home Journal to Become a Quarterly
abstract: The Meredith Corporation announced that the women’s magazine will no longer publish monthly.
lead_paragraph: Ladies’ Home Journal, whose very name evokes a bygone era of women’s service magazines, will no longer publish as a monthly after a 130-year run, its owner, the Meredith Corporation, announced on Thursday.

headline: De Blasio Names Chief of Agency Overseeing Sick Pay Law
abstract: Julie Menin, a former regulatory lawyer and chairwoman of Manhattan Community Board 1, will head New York City’s Department of Consumer Affairs.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Thursday the appointment of a former regulatory lawyer, well known for her efforts to revitalize Lower Manhattan after the Sept. 11 attacks, to head the Department of Consumer Affairs — an agency enforcing compliance with New York City’s paid sick leave law.

headline: N.C.A.A. Ensures Athletes Will Get All They Can Eat
abstract: Over-the-top food spreads have become another way for universities to compete in the ongoing college sports arms race.
lead_paragraph: When the University of Mississippi wanted to improve its athletic performance, Athletic Director Ross Bjork went beyond having the weight room renovated or updating the training facilities. He also drafted plans to build a state-of-the-art cafeteria.

headline: Battling Illness and Royalty for Love
abstract: In “The Girl and Death,” a young Russian doctor arriving at a secluded hotel falls for one of the guests: a prince’s kept mistress.
lead_paragraph: “The Girl and Death” is primarily set in that most durable of mysterious settings: a secluded, well-appointed hotel from another era. This particular establishment, tucked outside Leipzig, in post-World War II Germany, has its dotard guests and their routines, its officious and stiffly uniformed staff, and its intimations of secrets and riches. Most important, as discovered by a young visiting Russian doctor, Nicolai, it hosts Elise, the lovely kept mistress of a wealthy prince.

headline: Enemies One Year, Teammates the Next
abstract: “We Could Be King” recounts an arduous struggle to combine two football teams after a budget shortfall that led to widespread school closings in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: Last year, the School District of Philadelphia, facing a shortfall of more than $300 million, instituted a “doomsday” budget that ultimately closed 24 schools. Those included the 99-year-old Germantown High School, whose students would attend Martin Luther King High, its former bitter rival.

headline: Students File Complaints on Sexual Assaults at Columbia University
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'School Discipline (Students)', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Sex Crimes', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: Twenty-three students signed onto three separate complaints, each alleging violations of a different federal law, against the university and the affiliated Barnard College.
lead_paragraph: Pressure on Columbia University to overhaul its approach to sexual assault and harassment reached a new pitch on Thursday, when a group of students filed complaints with the federal government, charging systematic mishandling of assault claims and mistreatment of victims.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Gone Fishing With Dad, Often on Silent Mode
abstract: “Marvin, Seth and Stanley,” written and directed by Stephen Gurewitz, aims to be a deadpan travels-with-my-wacky-dad story.
lead_paragraph: “Marvin, Seth and Stanley” aims to be a deadpan travels-with-my-wacky-dad story, but the father in it is almost an afterthought. It still has sublime moments, but it leaves you wanting more of them.

headline: In a Scary Uniform, Subverting a March to Death
abstract: “Walking With the Enemy” is based on the real-life story of a Hungarian Jew who saved lives during World War II by posing as a Nazi officer.
lead_paragraph: “Walking With the Enemy” is based on the real-life deeds of Pinchas Rosenbaum, a Hungarian rabbi’s son who was able to save Jews from the Nazis and their collaborators by disguising himself in enemy garb.

headline: A Supplement Retailer Pumps Up Consumers
abstract: A new advertising campaign by GNC called “Beat average” plays to the unwillingness of many people to identify as below the median.
lead_paragraph: MOST people consider themselves above average, something psychologists call illusory superiority and, less formally, the Lake Wobegon effect, a reference to the fictional town of Garrison Keillor’s radio monologues, where he says “all the children are above average.”

headline: Struggling to Escape the Bronx’s Grasp
abstract: In “Grand Slammed,” an aspiring pitcher is hampered by bad luck and bad friends in his attempt to reach a better life.
lead_paragraph: To say that Mikey (Alexander Emmet), the embattled protagonist of “Grand Slammed,” has hit a rough patch understates the matter gravely. An aspiring pitcher, he blows his chance in front of a talent scout, leaving blood spattered on home plate from a wild pitch. That evening, he serves as a getaway driver when his buddy Pete (Dimitri Meskouris) hops out of the car for an unexpected gangland shooting.

headline: Into Africa
abstract: Sylvia Caminer’s “Tanzania: A Journey Within” documents a trip a young American woman takes with her Tanzanian friend, back to his homeland.
lead_paragraph: The documentary “Tanzania: A Journey Within” is two travel diaries woven together. One is somber and moving. The other is distractingly annoying.

headline: A Face of a Brutal Sport Is Trying to Change Its Image
abstract: Jon Jones, the U.F.C. light heavyweight champion, wants the rapidly growing sport to be viewed as an artful blend of martial arts rather than modern-day barbarianism.
lead_paragraph: Jon (Bones) Jones, the U.F.C. light heavyweight champion, made the rounds earlier this week in Manhattan, promoting his fight Saturday against Glover Teixeira.

headline: A Partnership to Help the Tallest Residents in Yosemite Park
keywords: ['National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Philanthropy', 'Trees and Shrubs']
abstract: Philanthropic organizations known for lending a helping hand are funneling millions of dollars into the nation’s major national parks.
lead_paragraph: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif. — In an otherworldly grove of cinnamon-colored giant sequoias, workers in June will jackhammer an old mistake: a road and parking lot that impinge on the hallowed forest.

headline: The Regeneration of ‘Degenerate Art’
keywords: ['Art', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Editorials']
abstract: An exhibition testifies to Hitler’s persecution of artists and to the eventual triumph of their art.
lead_paragraph: Even on the coolest mornings, the long and patient lines of people outside the Neue Galerie, a small gem of a New York museum, have testified to the unintended consequences of Adolf Hitler’s dictatorial tastes in art. “As for the degenerate artists,” the Nazi leader decreed as he rose to power, “I forbid them to force their so-called experiences upon the public.” He targeted them as criminals — modern masters like Otto Dix, Max Beckmann and George Grosz — and obsessively purged them from sight.

headline: 2 Journalists in Lebanon Are Charged by Tribunal
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'News and News Media', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations']
abstract: The international tribunal dealing with the killing of a former Lebanese prime minister has charged two journalists with contempt of court and obstruction of justice.
lead_paragraph: The international tribunal dealing with the killing of former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri of Lebanon has charged two leading Lebanese journalists with contempt of court and obstruction of justice over the publication of confidential information about possible witnesses for the prosecution.

headline: A Questionable Decision on Egypt
keywords: ['Foreign Aid', 'United States International Relations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Military Aircraft', 'Editorials']
abstract: The repressive military-dominated government will surely see a vote of confidence from the United States after the Obama administration agreed to deliver 10 Apache helicopters.
lead_paragraph: American policy toward Egypt continued on its tortured, confusing path this week when the Obama administration resumed some aid to what has become an increasingly repressive state. No matter how American officials try to spin it, the decision will come across as a vote of confidence in a military-dominated government with an authoritarian agenda and a track record of violent crackdowns on dissenters and political opponents.

headline: For E-Cigarettes, the Regulatory Battle Now Begins
keywords: ['Smoking and Tobacco', 'E-Cigarettes', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Proposed rules postponed tricky issues like whether flavors should be banned or television advertising limited.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At last, Washington is moving to police the multibillion-dollar business of electronic cigarettes.

headline: Tiny Jockeys, Galloping in a Cloud of Despair
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Camels', 'Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: The documentary “Desert Riders” details the horrific lives of children who work as camel jockeys in the Middle East and South Asia.
lead_paragraph: “There were some men there,” the small boy with the large brown eyes tells us. “You would go and give them your body.” Others around him nod in agreement — and corroborate in more explicit language — but “Desert Riders,” a deeply troubling account of child camel jockeys in the United Arab Emirates, is not primarily concerned with sexual abuse. There are too many other abuses demanding its attention.

headline: Seattle Mayor Says Effort to Build Agreement on $15 Minimum Wage Has Faltered
abstract: Mayor Ed Murray said he was as committed as ever to a $15 minimum wage, more than twice the federal rate.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Mayor Ed Murray of Seattle said Thursday that his effort to build consensus behind raising the city’s minimum wage to $15, more than twice the federal rate, had faltered amid continuing differences between business leaders and labor unions that had been advising him on the issue.

headline: Museumgoers Wonder: Why Doesn’t the Whale Fall?
abstract: Visitors to the American Museum of Natural History have long asked that question about the giant blue whale over their heads. The answer is hidden.
lead_paragraph: It is one of the biggest attractions — literally — at one of New York City’s most famous destinations: the 94-foot-long blue whale at the American Museum of Natural History. Untold numbers gaze in awe every day at the 21,000-pound creature poised majestically in midair above the Hall of Ocean Life.

headline: Trailing Canada, U.S. Starts a Push for Safer Oil Shipping
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Railroads', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Railroad Accidents and Safety', 'Transportation', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Canada has passed new rules for transporting oil by rail and the United States is expected to follow later this year.
lead_paragraph: A day after Canada issued stringent new rules for the transportation of oil by rail, federal regulators in the United States said on Thursday that they would push forward their own tank standards next week, potentially resolving a critical safety issue that has been mired in regulatory limbo for years.

headline: House Majority PAC Ad
abstract: An ad in West Virginia stressed that so-called black lung benefits for miners could be lost if the law is repealed.
lead_paragraph: An ad in West Virginia stressed that so-called black lung benefits for miners could be lost if the law is repealed.

headline: A Bid for Governor
abstract: Representative Allyson Y. Schwartz, a Democrat running for Pennsylvania governor, in an ad saying how proud she is of the health law.
lead_paragraph: Representative Allyson Y. Schwartz, a Democrat running for Pennsylvania governor, in an ad saying how proud she is of the health law.

headline: Support for Alaska Senator
abstract: Lisa Keller is a mother, a runner, a lifelong Alaskan and a cancer survivor. She says she has health insurance again because of Mark Begich, her Democratic senator.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Keller is a mother, a runner, a lifelong Alaskan and a cancer survivor. She says she has health insurance again because of Mark Begich, her Democratic senator.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 24, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: April 24, 2014

headline: The Piketty Phenomenon
abstract: The reaction to Thomas Piketty’s new book says more about class rivalry within the educated classes than it does about expanding opportunity.
lead_paragraph: Many people join the political left driven by a concern for the poor. But, over the past several years, the Democratic Party has talked much more about the middle class than the poor. Meanwhile, progressive political movements like Occupy Wall Street directed their fervor at the top 1 percent. Progressive movies and books have focused their attention on conspiracy and oligarchy at the top, not “Grapes of Wrath” or “How the Other Half Lives” stories at the bottom.

headline: A Fight to Keep College Athletes From the Pain of Injury Costs
keywords: ['College Athletics', 'Sports Injuries', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Football (College)', 'Basketball (College)']
abstract: A key front in the effort to reform the N.C.A.A. is medical coverage for college athletes, some of whom have become burdened with costs to treat their injuries.
lead_paragraph: Kyle Hardrick lost his basketball scholarship at Oklahoma after he tore his meniscus.

headline: Rand Paul and Wealthy Libertarians Connect as He Weighs Running
keywords: ['Libertarianism (US Politics)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: Mr. Paul is reaching out to people who have largely donated their money to nonprofit groups and colleges, not to politicians.
lead_paragraph: Frayda Levin, a New Jersey libertarian activist and former small-business owner, is a woman of many passions: promoting liberty, ending marijuana prohibition and opposing her state’s recent minimum-wage increase. But Ms. Levin has added another cause as well. At gala benefits for free-market research institutes and at fund-raisers for antitax groups, she has urged like-minded donors to help send Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, to the White House.

headline: In Florida Tomato Fields, a Penny Buys Progress
abstract: A group of dedicated farmworkers enlisted companies like McDonald’s, Walmart and Yum Brands to press tomato growers for better conditions.
lead_paragraph: IMMOKALEE, Fla. — Not long ago, Angelina Velasquez trudged to a parking lot at 5 each morning so a crew leader’s bus could drop her at the tomato fields by 6. She often waited there, unpaid — while the dew dried — until 10 a.m., when the workers were told to clock in and start picking.

headline: Efforts to Snub the Other Party Rarely Go Well
abstract: State Senator Dan Patrick said that if elected lieutenant governor, he might not allow Democrats to head committees, but that could backfire as it has in the past.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Democratic Candidates Grow More Vocal in Supporting Health Law
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Political Advertising', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: More Democratic candidates are making support of the health care law a campaign issue, particularly the negative consequences if Republicans succeed in repealing it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Allyson Y. Schwartz, Democrat of Pennsylvania, did the seemingly unthinkable on Tuesday: She ran a television ad expressing how proud she was of President Obama’s signature health care law.

headline: The Piketty Panic
abstract: New scholarship by the French economist is a bona fide phenomenon, and the right is terrified.
lead_paragraph: “Capital in the Twenty-First Century,” the new book by the French economist Thomas Piketty, is a bona fide phenomenon. Other books on economics have been best sellers, but Mr. Piketty’s contribution is serious, discourse-changing scholarship in a way most best sellers aren’t. And conservatives are terrified. Thus James Pethokoukis of the American Enterprise Institute warns in National Review that Mr. Piketty’s work must be refuted, because otherwise it “will spread among the clerisy and reshape the political economic landscape on which all future policy battles will be waged.”

headline: D.W.I. Charge for Detective Who Shot Colleague
keywords: ['Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Detective Jay Poggi was arrested after accidentally shooting his partner in the wrist while in their unmarked patrol car, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A New York police detective who accidentally shot his partner in the wrist on Thursday while in their unmarked patrol car was later arrested and charged with drunken driving, the authorities said.

headline: Amid Overhaul, Case Questions Agency’s Foster Care
abstract: As Texas Child Protective Services is working on an overhaul, a trial is set to hear a case brought by an advocacy group that says the agency keeps children in foster care too long.
lead_paragraph: As Texas Child Protective Services is working to streamline its foster care system, a lawsuit in federal court could force officials back to the drawing board, costing taxpayers millions of dollars.

headline: U.S. Confronts Consequences of Underestimating North Korean Leader
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Cyberwarfare']
abstract: As President Obama visits South Korea, he will be confronting the question of whether his strategy of “strategic patience” with the North and its leader, Kim Jong-un, is irrelevant.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Almost everything American intelligence agencies and North Korea-watchers thought they understood two years ago about Kim Jong-un, the North’s young leader, turns out to have been wrong.

headline: Lobbying Efforts Intensify After F.C.C. Tries 3rd Time on Net Neutrality
keywords: ['Net Neutrality', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: The sparring will be closely watched by every company that depends, even peripherally, on the Internet — which is to say, just about every company.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the nine weeks since the Federal Communications Commission said it would try, for a third time, to write new rules to secure an open Internet, at least 69 companies, interest groups and trade associations — over one a day — have met with or otherwise lobbied commission officials on what the rules should specify.

headline: A Right-to-Bear-Arms Twist: Rallying With a Gun in Hand
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Law and Legislation', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Gun rights advocates have taken to carrying their weapons into the streets, drawing criticism from gun control supporters who say that such methods are unnecessarily provocative.
lead_paragraph: When advocates for tighter restrictions on guns rallied last week in Austin City Hall, a small group of opponents staged a counter-rally outside, carrying firearms and waving a flag emblazoned with an assault rifle and the caption “Come and Take It.”

headline: Missing on Mound: A Dab of Discretion
abstract: The Yankees’ Michael Pineda was suspended for 10 games on Thursday after being ejected at Fenway Park for having pine tar brazenly smeared on his neck.
lead_paragraph: The circle in the middle of a baseball diamond may as well be in a spotlight on a Broadway stage. Everybody watches the pitcher, because nothing happens until he delivers the ball. Yet with all those eyes on him, in the ballpark and at home, few can really see what he does.

headline: Creating a Two-Speed Internet
keywords: ['Net Neutrality', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Editorials']
abstract: The F.C.C.’s proposal that would allow phone and cable companies to charge fees to content providers for faster delivery of video and data would harm competition and cost consumers.
lead_paragraph: Dividing traffic on the Internet into fast and slow lanes is exactly what the Federal Communications Commission would do with its proposed regulations, unveiled this week. And no amount of reassurances about keeping competition alive will change that fact.

headline: Judge Rejects New York Limit on Donations to ‘Super PACs’
abstract: The decision voiding New York’s $150,000 annual limit was largely expected, because the United States Supreme Court had previously struck down a cap on campaign contributions.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Thursday struck down New York State’s limit on contributions to independent groups that spend money supporting political candidates, a move that could unleash large spending by so-called super PACs in state races.

headline: Alternative to Pap Test Is Approved by F.D.A.
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration approved a new primary method for detecting cervical cancer developed by the pharmaceutical company Roche.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved the first alternative to the long-used Pap test as a primary screening method for cervical cancer, in the face of opposition from some women’s groups and health organizations.

headline: Gang Leader From Mexico Gets Life Term
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Drug Cartels', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: According to U.S. officials, Arturo Gallegos Castrellón, 35, ordered hundreds of killings as cartels battled over control of Ciudad Juárez.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — A gang leader was sentenced to life in prison on Thursday for his role in ordering the 2010 murders of three people associated with the United States Consulate in Ciudad Juárez, killings that rattled both sides of the border as drug violence engulfed the city.

headline: An Ivy League Newspaper May Be Going Mostly Online
abstract: The Columbia Daily Spectator, the university’s student-run newspaper, will stop printing daily and switch to a weekly edition beginning in the fall.
lead_paragraph: The battle over the future of newspapers has found an unlikely flash point, above a Pinkberry on the fringes of Columbia University’s Morningside Heights campus.

headline: Labor Board to Review Northwestern Football Case
abstract: As expected, the National Labor Relations Board said it will examine the question of whether scholarship athletes should be considered university employees.
lead_paragraph: The National Labor Relations Board in Washington announced Thursday that it would review last month’s landmark decision that held that Northwestern University’s scholarship football players should be considered employees. The board said the case raised “substantial issues.”

headline: Justice Dept. Seeks Mortgage Deal With Bank of America
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Mortgages', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: The Justice Department made Bank of America an opening settlement offer of roughly $20 billion several weeks ago, according to people briefed on the matter.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department, building on a multibillion-dollar mortgage settlement with JPMorgan Chase last year, is now aiming for a deal with Bank of America.

headline: Old Chums Return, Where Club Is Home
abstract: The Roundabout’s production of “Cabaret” is back at Studio 54 — now with Michelle Williams as Sally Bowles.
lead_paragraph: Hot diggity dachshund, it’s old home week on the campus at Weimar Berlin, otherwise known as the Kit Kat Klub. And if we take off our glasses and squint, we can pretend that life is just as divinely, dangerously decadent as it was when we were all 16 years younger.

headline: Climate Change Onstage: Singing of the Extinction of Fauna
abstract: “The Great Immensity,” at the Public Theater, features some hilariously depressing tunes about the dire state of the world and its beleaguered creatures.
lead_paragraph: The drumbeat of dire reports about climate change has grown so rhythmically regular over the past few years that it’s almost surprising that someone hasn’t set it to song, at least within the confines of a musical. That day has now come. If you’ve long been hankering to hear the bad news about global warming given the full Brecht, hop on that bike and head to the Public Theater, where “The Great Immensity” opened on Thursday.

headline: Puzzle Solver’s Complaint
abstract: Next-to-impossible task of the day: trying to choose only one thing to like about Joel Fagliano’s puzzle.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s Friday, the beginning of the weekend, and it’s going to be tough to decide whether we want to CHILLAX or CATERWAUL and RAISE HELL. Let’s let constructor Joel Fagliano help us make up our minds.

headline: Kerry Rejects ‘Absurd’ Russian Claims
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry denounced Russian actions in Ukraine but stopped short of announcing measures in response.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry denounced Russian actions in Ukraine but stopped short of announcing measures in response.

headline: Effort to Remove Landlord Who Made Units Unlivable
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Landlords', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Kitchens', 'Rent Control and Stabilization']
abstract: Officials said families were forced to move into a homeless shelter after a Brooklyn landlord wrecked apartments to drive out tenants.

headline: Bulls Star With Brooklyn Roots Is the Same as Ever: Different

lead_paragraph: Joakim Noah was an accomplished basketball player at Poly Prep Country Day School in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. He did many things well. He rebounded. He scored. He led the Blue Devils to two league titles.

headline: Blue-Footed Boobies, a Galápagos Treasure, Under Threat
abstract: The population of boobies, known for their brightly colored feet and signature mating dance, has halved, researchers say, though it’s not clear why breeding activity is so low.
lead_paragraph: Blue-footed boobies are among the Galápagos Islands’ most beloved boldfaced names. But because of a lack of breeding, their numbers in the region are in serious decline, a new study says.

lead_paragraph: NEWARK — A small white sticker has been slapped onto the portable batting cage that sits just beyond the center-field wall of Riverfront Stadium, among the weeds and a few winter-ruined baseballs. “Auction,” the sticker says. “Lot Number 163.”

headline: Robert Gray, a Powerhouse in Washington, Dies at 92
abstract: Mr. Gray, a Washington lobbyist and public relations expert, was a regular on the capital’s social scene and well known for his powerful connections.
lead_paragraph: Robert Gray, a powerful Washington lobbyist and public relations expert who began building connections while working in the Eisenhower administration and rose to the peak of his influence when his friend Ronald Reagan became president, died on April 18 in Miami. He was 92.

lead_paragraph: Michael Glawogger, an Austrian filmmaker known for globe-trotting documentaries that show people grappling with horrendous circumstances, died on Wednesday in Liberia, where he was planning his next movie. He was 54.

headline: What’s on Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13) MATTHEW BOURNE’S SLEEPING BEAUTY In 1992, Mr. Bourne, the British choreographer, reinterpreted “The Nutcracker,” the first of three classic ballets set to scores by Tchaikovsky; in 1995, he unveiled his setting for “Swan Lake.” He completes the endeavor with this reimagining of the fairy tale about a princess who sleeps under a spell for 100 years, originally choreographed by Marius Petipa in 1890. Mr. Bourne’s version, taped at the Bristol Hippodrome in England, begins in that year with the birth of the heroine, Aurora (danced by Hannah Vassallo, above center, with Edwin Ray, left and Danny Reubens), who falls in love not with a prince but a gardener, Leo (Dominic North), and eventually awakens in the modern day. He also provides Leo with a rival, Caradoc (Adam Maskell), the dashingly vengeful son of the evil fairy who curses Aurora to death. “The love story that Mr. Bourne substitutes isn’t any more emotionally compelling than the original,” Brian Seibert wrote in his review of the production, presented here by Great Performances, in The New York Times. “Poetically, it’s a diminishment. The battle between good and evil is reduced to a tussle between the nice guy and the bad boy.” Still, he said, “Mr. Bourne is not an ungrateful recipient of the gift of Tchaikovsky’s score. He dedicates his ‘Sleeping Beauty’ to the composer, whose work will survive this version. It’s more than 100 years old and still likely to last as long as the undead.”

headline: India Election Digest: April 25
abstract: A roundup of local election-related news for Friday.
lead_paragraph: What you need to know on Friday about India’s elections: Mumbai’s voter turnout was the highest since 1989, the Aam Aadmi Party finds fans in Punjab, and villagers see the “none of the above” option as a means of protest.

headline: People’s Daily Editorial Fanned Flames of 1989 Protest
abstract: Players in the confrontation that convulsed China in 1989 have long wondered how differently events might have played out without a truculent editorial that appeared in People’s Daily on April 26 that year.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-five years ago, on the night of April 25, editors in newspaper offices across China received an editorial that was to run in People’s Daily the next morning, and their papers were ordered to reprint on their front pages the Communist Party newspaper’s pronouncement on the student demonstrators who had occupied Tiananmen Square for nine days.

headline: Real Communist Mouthpiece Rages Against Fake Communist Mouthpiece
abstract: In a statement that read as if it were a self-parody, People’s Daily demanded “immediate rectification” from a Twitter account that pokes fun at state-sponsored media.
lead_paragraph: The official mouthpiece of the Chinese Communist Party is in a rage over a parody Twitter account that for years has poked fun at the foibles of the Leninist state.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | The American Middle Class Is No Longer the World’s Richest
abstract: Are you concerned by the results of The Times’s analysis? Should the United States be worried that its middle and low income families are not fully sharing in the benefits of the country’s economic growth? Why?
lead_paragraph: In “The American Middle Class Is No Longer the World’s Richest,” David Leonhardt and Kevin Quealy report on how American incomes are losing their edge, except at the top.

headline: Defying Moscow, Ukraine Threatens to Blockade Pro-Russian Militants
abstract: As tension mounted, the interim authorities said any crossing of the country’s borders by Russian troops would be treated as an invasion.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — The interim central government in Kiev threatened to blockade the eastern city of Slovyansk on Friday, defying warnings from Moscow not to confront pro-Russian militants entrenched in towns across eastern Ukraine.

headline: How Common Is Drug Use in Your School?
abstract: Do you think your school’s administrators and teachers should be alarmed?
lead_paragraph: This week prosecutors in an affluent suburb of Philadelphia announced the arrests of eight people on charges of distributing drugs in five public and private high schools and in three colleges. The headmaster at one of the private schools said in an interview that he was “shocked and appalled” by the charges and would re-examine the school’s drug policy.

headline: Far Out and Close Up
abstract: Larry Fink moved to Greenwich Village from suburbia in 1958, finding like-minded renegades among the Beat Generation.
lead_paragraph: The San Francisco Chronicle columnist Herb Caen, who coined the term “beatnik” in 1958, saw them as a mass phenomenon, with hordes of young “bearded kats and kits” overrunning a party in North Beach and “slopping up” free booze. The poet Kenneth Rexroth, who introduced the first major reading of Beat poets, dismissed the whole phenomenon as a creation of the Luce magazine empire, carping that “after the first five writers, it produced nothing.” And when the writer Hettie Jones was asked about the Beat generation, she joked that “everyone identified with it could fit into my living room.”

lead_paragraph: JINDO, South Korea — Prosecutors on Friday barred eight current and former officials from a maritime inspection agency from leaving South Korea, as the investigation of the ferry sinking last week that left more than 300 people dead or missing shifted to the agencies responsible for certifying ships as safe to travel.

headline: Switzerland’s Toxic Prosperity
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Dyes and Dyestuffs']
abstract: The chemical industry of Basel once dumped its wastes into the Rhine, a practice it later brought to the United States and China.
lead_paragraph: On a warm midsummer night, a few months after my book about industrial pollution in the New Jersey town of Toms River was published, I watched a fireworks show over the Rhine River celebrating Swiss National Day. I was in Basel, the city where the chemical industry first took root more than 150 years ago.

headline: The Global Diabetes Epidemic
keywords: ['Diabetes', 'Medicine and Health', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: In the West, it’s a manageable chronic condition. In places like India, it’s a different story.
lead_paragraph: Twelve years ago, my husband and I packed up all of our belongings and moved to Trivandrum — a steamy, tropical town at the southern tip of India in Kerala. At the time, I was a medical student interested in studying stroke. For the next six months I dressed in a sari and walked to work on jungle roads. At the hospital, I immediately began seeing a steady stream of young patients affected by strokes, many of whom were so severely disabled that they were unable to work. I initially suspected the cause was tuberculosis or dengue fever — after all, this was the developing world, where infections have long been primary culprits for disease. But I soon learned that my hunch was wrong.

headline: Daily Report: Lobbying Surges After F.C.C. Tries Again on Net Neutrality
abstract: The sparring will be closely watched by every company that depends, even peripherally, on the Internet — which is to say, just about every company.
lead_paragraph: In the nine weeks since the Federal Communications Commission said it would try, for a third time, to write new rules to secure an open Internet, at least 69 companies, interest groups and trade associations — more than one a day — have met with or otherwise lobbied commission officials on what the rules should specify, Edward Wyatt reports.

headline: Blurring Boundaries and Meaning
keywords: ['Movies', 'Video Releases (Entertainment)', 'DVD (Digital Versatile Disc)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The Criterion Collection releases two films in dual-format editions: Ingmar Bergman’s “Persona” and Carl Theodor Dreyer’s silent “Master of the House.”
lead_paragraph: The course of Ingmar Bergman’s reputation is a saga all its own. Indifferently received in his native Sweden, Bergman’s early films were championed in France. Jean-Luc Godard hailed him as “the most original of directors” after “Summer With Monika” — a sort of Neo-Realist “Rebel Without a Cause” enlivened by Harriet Andersson’s skinny-dipping and originally released in the United States as an exploitation film — played in Paris in the mid-’50s.

headline: Follow the Money: Gretchen Morgenson on Wall Street

lead_paragraph: Gretchen Morgenson, a Times reporter and business columnist, won a Pulitzer Prize in 2002 for beat reporting. Her column, Fair Game, appears in the Sunday Business section. We asked her to talk about her career and how she works.

headline: Hello, Stranger
abstract: The casual social interactions we often avoid may actually make us happier.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve ever been on a subway or public bus, you know the rules. Don’t make eye contact, stay as far away from other people as the space allows, and for the love of God, don’t talk to anyone. But what if the rules are wrong?

lead_paragraph: You can tell a lot about a country by its croissants. At least you can tell a lot about America, where croissants don’t rest on their laurels or cling to fussy, Old World norms. Here they innovate. They disrupt.

abstract: A study of soil, water and rice grown around a metals smelter in Hunan Province shows high levels of toxic pollutants, adding to a growing body of evidence that China’s soil is badly degraded in many areas.
lead_paragraph: Soil in China’s leading rice-producing region shows high levels of heavy metal contamination, in a study that suggests that the proximity of mining and industry to agricultural areas is posing serious threats to the country’s food chain.

headline: Using the Foreign to Grasp the Familiar
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Language and Languages', 'English Language']
abstract: An expanding flock of novelists is writing in second languages, enriching and expanding the literature of their host cultures.
lead_paragraph: In “The Other Language,” the title story of Francesca Marciano’s new collection, an Italian teenager named Emma falls in love with English. The attraction has a lot to do with the person speaking it, an intriguing English boy at the Greek beach resort where Emma is staying with her family, but it’s hard to separate the strands of desire. Is the boy her entry ticket to English, or vice versa?

headline: Piketty and Pareto
abstract: Dynasties aren’t forever, but they can last a long time and get very, very rich.
lead_paragraph: Well, it’s Piketty day at the Times, with David Brooks and yours truly even having more or less matching headlines. And David’s take reminds me of something I’ve been meaning to do: explain one important point in Piketty that even economist readers have, it seems, tended to miss.

headline: New Vehicles and Recalls Cut Ford Profit

lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The rising tide of recalls has made it more expensive for automakers to do business, even in the absence of a major crisis like the ignition switch recall at General Motors.

headline: Guest Post | Get Ready for College Writing by Learning to Revise
abstract: Do you have your students revise their essays? In this post a guest blogger from Haverford College offers advice to bridge the gap between high school and college writing by teaching students the process of revision.
lead_paragraph: Do you have your students revise their essays? If so, is their process mostly a matter of adding some commas and correcting spelling errors — or are they actually rethinking their writing to make it clearer and stronger?

headline: A Single Adoptive Mother — in 1937
abstract: In 1937, the editors of Ladies Home Journal published an essay, “I Just Adopted a Baby!” It was just another piece about the joys and challenges of family life — but this time, from the perspective of a single working parent.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes it’s hard to remember that adoption (the kind that doesn’t involve orphanages and gruel) is more than a contemporary phenomenon. Reading today’s human-interest stories on the topic can make it seem like adoption is a parenting challenge of our time, like baking gluten-free snacks or finding story books friendly to same sex parenting.

headline: Obama Offers Support to South Korea at a Moment of Trauma and Tension
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Ferries', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: During a tour of Asia, the president expressed his condolences for the recent ferry sinking, and said that he would consider new sanctions against Pyongyang.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — President Obama arrived here on Friday offering solace to a country traumatized by the sinking of a ferry that killed scores, and showing solidarity at a time when the Korean Peninsula is rife with tension.

headline: Harrods Displays the World According to Prada
abstract: In a new installation, the London department store is displaying the history of the Milanese brand’s forays into art, film and architecture — and selling a special capsule collection inspired by Prada’s greatest hits.
lead_paragraph: Art, film, architecture and fashion are frequent bedfellows, but no one has blended the genres as poignantly or provocatively as Miuccia Prada. Now, the legendary London department store Harrods is putting Prada’s interdisciplinary collaborations on display in a monthlong exhibit titled “Pradasphere,” opening April 30. Curated by the graphic designer Michael Rock, who lent his conceptual aesthetic to the house’s spring 2014 runway show, the installation traces Miuccia Prada’s trajectory of influence through fashion, art, architecture, cinema and even sports. Visitors can view a Prada history wall with images from the house’s Fondazione and its partnership with America’s Cup. A screening room will show short films made in collaboration with directors like Wes Anderson and Roman Polanski. The brand’s iconic architectural projects with Rem Koolhaas/OMA and Herzog & de Meuron will also be exhibited. And, naturally, there’s plenty of fashion to see and buy: an on-site pop-up will sell a special capsule collection of clothing, bags, shoes and accessories, inspired by archival designs from the brand’s first 100 years — even before Miuccia joined the family business.

headline: Public Grooming
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A subway rider’s ingenious use of plastic wrap reminded another passenger of the virtue of doing his grooming in private.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary,

headline: Bharatiya Janata Party’s Message Is Muddled By Polarization
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Hinduism', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: In the past week, some politicians associated with the BJP have made public divisive comments, even as prime ministerial candidate Narendra Modi tries to project a more positive image.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — Even as the Bharatiya Janata Party’s candidate for prime minister, Narendra Modi, has attempted to distance himself from his party’s right-wing Hindu nationalist ideology and focus on economic development, polarizing speeches by party members and allies dominated headlines early this week.

headline: Report Says N.J. Transit, Not Port Authority, Should Run PATH Lines
abstract: Handing over control of the train system to the state-run agency could open up money for large infrastructure projects, according to the Citizens Budget Commission report.
lead_paragraph: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey should turn the money-losing PATH commuter rail system over to New Jersey’s state-run transit agency to free up money for big infrastructure projects, a report released on Friday recommended.

headline: Bombshells Felt in the Balcony
abstract: Anthony Tommasini wrote about several musical passages he found surprising, and asked for suggestions from readers. Their responses reflect an impressive diversity.
lead_paragraph: Of all the surprise turns in musical compositions, one stands out as practically a non sequitur. It comes well into the choral finale of Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony, the composer’s setting of Schiller’s “Ode to Joy.” As part of a recent interactive project I invited readers to share their choices of great surprises in music, and several suggested this unexpected episode in this Beethoven work.

headline: Rarely One for Sugarcoating
abstract: The artist Kara Walker, known for her silhouettes invoking history, race and power, has created a mammoth art installation for a soon-to-be-demolished building in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The smell hits you first: sweet but with an acrid edge, like a thousand burned marshmallows. Then you’re struck by the space, five stories high and more than a football field long. The storage shed of the Domino sugar factory, on the East River in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, was built in 1927 to hold mountains of raw sugar due for whitening. The plant was shuttered a decade ago, yet its crumbling walls still drip with molasses.

headline: Tracking Future and Hip-Hop’s Growlers
abstract: Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss the rapper Future and the evolution of vocal style in hip-hop.
lead_paragraph: Popcast this week: how Future became one of hip-hop’s most influential vocal stylists.

headline: Mookie Wilson on Life After the Mets
abstract: And, of course, Bill Buckner.
lead_paragraph: The former New York Mets outfielder Mookie Wilson talks to Dave Itzkoff about his new book, ‘‘Mookie: Life, Baseball, and the ’86 Mets,’’ his career after the Major Leagues and that infamous grounder down the first-base line.

headline: Frustrations of the Heterodox
abstract: Why hasn’t mainstream economics been toppled?
lead_paragraph: It’s kind of a sideshow in the larger scheme of things, but something worth noting is taking place on the fringes (literally) of economic discussion: an upwelling of frustration on the part of heterodox economists. You see it in Thomas Palley’s complaint about gattopardo economics, which I discussed yesterday; you see it in the demands for a radical change in the economics curriculum, which Simon Wren-Lewis wrote about yesterday.

headline: A Country in Bloom
abstract: Celebrating the cherry blossoms in Japan.
lead_paragraph: Every spring millions of Japanese visit parks to take in the brief but magnificent bloom of their country’s cherry trees. They gather for so-called hanami parties, setting out elaborate meals of bento boxes with sake. (A smaller celebration in Washington marks the flowering of trees given to the city by the Tokyo mayor in 1912.) In some places, the scene is rowdy with people in their 20s; in others, families wander quietly among trees illuminated by paper lanterns. The photographer Matthew Pillsbury captured the cherry blossoms at their peak in several places in Japan this month. “The crowds are unlike anything I’ve ever seen,” he says. “You see groups of elderly people sitting next to groups of teenagers. They all clap when the blooms start falling off the tree. They’re basically having the very same party.” Julie Bosman

headline: Reply All: The 4.13.14 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
