headline: Occupy My Condo
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Mortgages', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Foreclosures', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Identification Devices']
abstract: Case foreclosed; age adjusted.
lead_paragraph: I know of someone who has lived mortgage-free for three years while the bank foreclosed on his apartment. During that time, the man paid his monthly maintenance to the building but did not pay his mortgage. His rationale: He had been in the furniture business and lost much of his income with the financial crisis, and not one of the bankers responsible for the meltdown has gone to jail. And furthermore, as a result, his apartment was worth less than he paid for it. Does any of that matter? Is strategic loan default ethical? NAME WITHHELD

headline: Could You Repeat That?
abstract: A new name just under the legal limit; tech specs take on a composer.
lead_paragraph: A new name just under the legal limit; tech specs take on a composer.

headline: Playing the Cards
abstract: Our son’s life at the poker table baffles us, but we know something about high-stakes bets.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, I found out that my son, Isaac, won $300,000 playing online poker the previous day. His mother, Francie, was pleased to hear about this on her way out the door for work. The next day, I learned that he won another $62,000.

headline: Who Made That Packing Peanut?
abstract: The journey from “spaghetti.”
lead_paragraph: In 1960, a research chemist named Maurice Laverne Zweigle packed a raw egg and a few handfuls of skinny, bendy, polystyrene noodles into a small cardboard box, sealed the flaps and tossed it off a third-floor roof. His invention worked: The egg was unscathed.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Brick Mansions,’ ‘The German Doctor’ and ‘For No Good Reason’
abstract: Times critics on “Brick Mansions,” “The German Doctor” and “For No Good Reason.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on the action film “Brick Mansions,” the drama “The German Doctor” and the documentary “For No Good Reason.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: A Cube With a Twist: At 40, It Puzzles Anew
abstract: The 40th anniversary of the Rubik’s cube is being celebrated with a $5 million exhibition at Liberty Science Center in Jersey City.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — A Rubik’s cube can be twisted and twiddled in 43,252,003,274,489,856,000 different ways, and 43,252,003,274,489,855,999 of them are wrong.

headline: How to Get Better Insurance Data, Without Encouraging Conspiracy Theories
abstract: The lack of a detailed monthly tally of the uninsured is a big hole in the nation’s statistics.
lead_paragraph: It has been a week since opponents of health-care reform accused the Obama administration of conspiring with the Census Bureau to undercount the number of uninsured Americans in an attempt to make the Affordable Care Act look more successful than it really is.

headline: Varieties of the Visible World
abstract: The mystical moments described in Barbara Ehrenreich’s new memoir would not have shocked William James.
lead_paragraph: In Barbara Ehrenreich’s new memoir, “Living With a Wild God,” reviewed this week by Parul Sehgal, the author describes a startling moment she experienced as a teenager when “something peeled off the visible world, taking with it all meaning, inference, association, labels and words.”

headline: Vision Quest
abstract: An atheist applies her investigative skills to a mystical experience she had as a teenager.
lead_paragraph: In May of 1959, Barbara Ehrenreich was taken into the mountains in Northern California by a boy looking for dynamite. They spent the night in the car, and in the morning, she wandered into town on foot. It happened then and there — an onrush of mystical visions — something she’d experienced before but never quite so brilliantly. “The world flamed into life,” she writes in her new book, “Living With a Wild God.” “Something poured into me and I poured out into it.”

headline: Why Everyone’s Talking About the Great Lime Shortage
keywords: ['Limes', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: And what the problem teaches us about the Federal Reserve.
lead_paragraph: We will all tell our children of the dark days of the Great Lime Shortage of 2014, when Mexican restaurants raised their margarita prices and otherwise respectable bars committed the blasphemy of serving gin and tonics with a slice of lemon. The shortage has become the subject of news media fascination, with the latest piece on the front page of Friday’s Wall Street Journal.

headline: An Unwanted Reprise Riles a Soviet Rocker
abstract: Before Russia’s annexation of Crimea, a Kremlin-backed television station used a 1980s song by the underground band Aquarium, drawing the ire of its founder, Boris Grebenshikov.
lead_paragraph: IN the days before Russia’s annexation of the Crimean Peninsula last month, a state-sponsored television network broadcast a bellicose video montage of events in Ukraine set to “This Train’s on Fire,” a song by the celebrated underground Soviet rock band Aquarium.

headline: Obama’s Comments in South Korea
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Nuclear Tests']
abstract: President Obama discussed North Korea’s nuclear threat and offered condolences to the families who lost loved ones in the South Korean ferry incident.
lead_paragraph: President Obama discussed North Korea’s nuclear threat and offered condolences to the families who lost loved ones in the South Korean ferry incident.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival: Emmanuelle Seigner Turns the Tables on Roman Polanski
abstract: The actress and singer stars in in director-husband’s new film, an adaptation of “Venus in Fur,” and also hired him to oversee her next music video.
lead_paragraph: Emmanuelle Seigner, the French actress, singer and former model, has a multilayered appreciation for the film “Venus in Fur,” in which she stars as a sadomasochistically savvy, table-turning seductress.

headline: Today in Small Business: Seattle’s Minimum Wage Plan Falters
abstract: How to build employee satisfaction. A forecast concerns the Maine lobster industry. And Amazon tests its own delivery network.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Rite of Summer Series to Bring Eclectic Music to Governors Island
abstract: The concerts on Governors Island will begin on May 31 with a performance by Dawn of Midi, an acoustic trio performing electonica-inspired music.
lead_paragraph: Rite of Summer, an outdoor series of free classical music concerts with an emphasis on contemporary works, will open its fourth season on May 31 with a performance by Dawn of Midi, a Brooklyn piano, bass and percussion trio that performs electronica-inspired music on acoustic instruments. The festival, which is directed by the pianists Blair McMillen and Pam Goldberg, will be held at Colonel’s Row on Governors Island, with performances at 1 and 3 p.m.

headline: Treating Appendicitis Without Surgery
abstract: For many years, immediate surgery has been considered the only proper treatment for appendicitis in children. Now a small study suggests that in some cases, antibiotics alone may be better.
lead_paragraph: For many years, immediate surgery has been considered the only proper treatment for appendicitis in children. Now a small study suggests that in some cases, antibiotics alone may be better.

headline: Unsustainable Living
abstract: A love affair unfolds and crisis hits a family farm on the high plains in Julene Bair’s memoir.
lead_paragraph: A story of land, water, relationships and love, “The Ogallala Road” is the 100-year history of a farming family in Kansas as well as the second of Julene Bair’s memoirs. The first, “One Degree West: Reflections of a Plainsdaughter,” was well received, but this new one is more polished, touching and engaging.

headline: Ganglands
abstract: A novel of spiritual discovery featuring Meyer Lansky, an American journalist and the murder of an Israeli poet.
lead_paragraph: There’s no way around it. To exercise power is to be ridden with guilt. To step is to step on. This, among other things, is the paradox of modern Israel. A nation meant to harbor and normalize the Jews has, in the process, entangled this ancient people with the brutality of sovereignty in a way so old it’s new. For a lot of us, it’s been a thrilling, maddening, disorienting 65-plus years. It’s this mood — pride wrapped in fear, the quest for the ordinary pitted against prophecy — and the violence that accompanies it that Zachary Lazar explores in his brilliant new novel, “I Pity the Poor Immigrant.”

headline: The Upshot, and 45 That Didn’t Make the Cut
abstract: We ran through a lot of ideas — Crux, anyone? — before arriving at our name.
lead_paragraph: In keeping with the spirit of this site — which we hope includes transparency, engagement with our readers and, yes, a willingness to publish lists when lists are called for — we’re publishing a comprehensive roster of runners-up for our name.

headline: Director’s Cut
abstract: The early days of the movie industry, told through the lives of an inventor and his two sons.
lead_paragraph: A recent Harper’s Index offers the following juxtaposed statistics: In the last 20 years, seven Academy Award winners have thanked God in their acceptance speeches, whereas 30 have thanked Harvey Weinstein. If this troubles you, allow me to offer two thoughts: (1) Relax. While you are in heaven snorkeling through a sea of mai tais, the sinners (Hollywood stars, Harvey, this reviewer) will be stuck in a warmer place for the duration, where only the explicitly Christian films of the former “Growing Pains” heartthrob-turned-evangelist Kirk Cameron are shown, and only fake butter is available at the concession stand. (2) Skip David Grand’s “Mount Terminus,” an impressively conceived, often very entertaining novel that celebrates the oversize talents and ambitions of two cinema pioneers, the (fictional) half brothers Simon Reuben and Bloom Rosenbloom, even as it explores the destruction wrought to construct a home for their fledgling industry. Grand has written a work from which Harvey Weinstein might make a terrific, multilayered film.

headline: Let Us Remember
abstract: Peter Matthiessen’s novel about a Zen retreat at Auschwitz.
lead_paragraph: “The tall young men” was Irwin Shaw’s name for the squad of just-­graduated Ivy Leaguers who showed up at his Paris apartment in the American arrondissement in the early 1950s to beat him in tennis, drink his booze and bask in the afterglow of Hemingway and Stein. One of these urbane aspiring writers was 24-year-old Peter Matthiessen, fresh out of Yale and wrestling with his first novel, who, along with George Plimpton, William Styron, Harold Humes, Thomas Guinzburg and a few other hard-partying expats, would go on to start The Paris Review in 1953.

headline: Favorite Sins
abstract: Thirteen stories of physical and spiritual struggle.
lead_paragraph: Kyle Minor wants you to know that “Praying Drunk” — his second story collection, after “In the Devil’s Territory” — is not actually, or only, a collection. In the epigraph, he warns: “These stories are meant to be read in order. This is a book, not just a collection. don’t skip around.”

headline: Status Update
keywords: ['Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Books and Literature', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media']
abstract: A report on teenagers’ online lives portrays them as neither passive consumers nor pliant sex objects.
lead_paragraph: Since the word “teenager” was coined 70 years ago, adults have defined adolescents by one extreme or another. They are rebels without causes or activist leaders, mindless consumers or cultural kingpins, digital natives or naïfs. Enter Danah Boyd, a principal researcher at Microsoft Research and a research assistant professor at New York University. In life, Boyd retains the spirit of a youthful rebel, with her pierced tongue and name spelled in anti-Establishment lowercase. And perhaps in part thanks to its author’s identification with youth, “It’s Complicated” avoids many of the typical either-or clichés about adolescence. Boyd’s new book is layered and smart.

headline: Apocalypse Again
abstract: A sequel to Robert Coover’s 1966 novel of a small-town cult.
lead_paragraph: “The Origin of the Brunists,” published in 1966, is Robert Coover’s first novel, and also his most well behaved. In 1979, he described it as an attempt to “pay dues . . . to traditional fiction,” and as such, it offers a realist account of a cult that develops around Giovanni Bruno, the damaged survivor of a small-town mining disaster. Bruno’s group fixes on April 19 as the date for the Rapture, but as the title’s Darwinian allusion suggests, nothing divine will happen on their chosen mountain. Instead, the book’s climax is a primal eruption of violence, dark testimony to “another flaw in the evolution of mind.”

headline: The Man and the Message
abstract: In this biography, the labor leader Cesar Chavez emerges as a visionary yet tragically flawed figure.
lead_paragraph: In an essay entitled “Reflections on Gandhi,” George Orwell wrote: “Saints should always be judged guilty until they are proved innocent.” While he acquitted Gandhi, he might have been harder on Cesar Chavez, the great farmworker leader. Certainly in this engrossing biography Miriam Pawel, a former editor and reporter with Newsday and The Los Angeles Times, is out to show both the good and bad. In the 1960s and early ’70s, Chavez did seem like a version of Gandhi. Organizing the dispossessed, our own untouchables, he fasted to the point of death, staged mass marches up and down California that resembled religious pilgrimages, and defeated growers with nationwide boycotts that even Gandhi would have found hard to duplicate. Back then, many of the best and saintliest of America’s young quit their jobs or dropped out of school to join up with Chavez and live lives of voluntary poverty.

headline: Retreat and Advance
abstract: Two reappraisals of Gen. Douglas MacArthur, from the fall of the Philippines to the occupation of Japan.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 2, 1945, Japan formally ended World War II by surrendering to the Allies aboard the American battleship Missouri in Tokyo Bay. As a reminder of Japan’s brutality to captured Allied soldiers, Gen. Douglas MacArthur placed two skeletal survivors of Japanese prisoner-of-war camps — United States Gen. Jonathan Wainwright, whose troops had endured the infamous Bataan Death March, and British Gen. Arthur Percival, who surrendered Singapore — in the Japanese delegation’s direct line of sight.

headline: An N.H.L. Champion Pursues Another Cup, This Time in Russia
abstract: Two decades after winning the Stanley Cup with the Rangers, Mike Keenan is trying to become the first North American coach to win the K.H.L.’s Gagarin Cup, with Metallurg Magnitogorsk.
lead_paragraph: PRAGUE — When Mike Keenan and the Rangers hoisted the Stanley Cup in 1994, four Russian-born players became the first from their country to achieve the honor. Two decades later, Keenan is trying to become the first North American coach to win a Gagarin Cup title in the Kontinental Hockey League.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
abstract: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: In the Garden
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'Flowers and Plants']
abstract: New books by Alain Baraton, Ruth Kassinger, Carol Wall and Jeanne Nolan.
lead_paragraph: THE GARDENER OF VERSAILLES  My Life in the World’s Grandest Garden  By Alain Baraton  Translated by Christopher Brent MurrayRizzoli, $26.95.

headline: Double Game
abstract: An account of Pakistan’s role in the Afghanistan war, and an argument that the country’s intelligence service supports the Taliban.
lead_paragraph: In December 2006, Carlotta Gall visited Quetta in Pakistan, close to the border with Afghanistan, to trace the families of Taliban suicide bombers. Her investigations were not welcome to the powerful Inter-Services Intelligence (ISI), the main intelligence arm of the Pakistan military, which was determined to hide its close relations with the Taliban. Plainclothes intelligence agents smashed open the door of her hotel room and seized her notebooks, computer and cellphone. She protested when one of the agents grabbed her handbag, and he promptly punched her twice in the face, knocking her down. The officer in charge accused her of trying to interview Taliban members, which he said was forbidden. She learned later that her rough treatment had been ordered by the head of the ISI press department to discourage her from reporting ISI-Taliban links.

headline: Hostile Climate
abstract: Through the lives of three Afghans, a journalist looks at American policy and the missed opportunities in the war in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: For the first time since 2001, more Americans believe it was a mistake to send troops to Afghanistan than see it as the right call, at least according to a recent Gallup poll. Almost 13 years after the attacks of Sept. 11, we’re conflicted about what we are still doing in Afghanistan and confused about what happened there. Americans are tired of America’s long war, especially as it drones on.

headline: Art Matters | How to Buy a Famous Artist’s Work for $350
abstract: At Incognito 10, the 10th-anniversary benefit of the Santa Monica Museum of Art’s benefit sale, small works whose authorship is kept secret — many made by stars in the field — sell for an unheard-of price.
lead_paragraph: An exhibition and sale tomorrow night at the Santa Monica Museum of Art mounts a challenge to that pervasive problem of taste: The beholder may have the eye, but not the means. At Incognito 10, the museum’s annual benefit, the walls will be lined with 700 pieces of art — donated by more than 550 artists — whose authorship will be kept anonymous until after each work is sold.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE THIRD COAST: When Chicago Built the American Dream,  by Thomas Dyja. (Penguin, $18.) Dyja’s robust history weaves together the stories of the artists, styles and ideas that made Chicago a crucible for culture and innovation before and after World War II: Mies van der Rohe’s Modernist architecture, Ray Kroc’s McDonald’s franchise, the Chess brothers’ supercharged rock ’n’ roll — all of which flourished despite violent segregation and a rugged, often corrupt, political scene.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Brick Mansions’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Brick Mansions.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Brick Mansions.”

headline: Who Killed Anna Mae?
abstract: Nearly 40 years ago, a Native American activist turned up dead, and still no one knows who was responsible. She had a lot of enemies, but her friends may have been more dangerous.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 24, 1976, a rancher in South Dakota was installing a fence on land situated along the edge of Pine Ridge Indian Reservation when he spotted a body at the bottom of a 30-foot embankment. The badly decomposed corpse, in jeans and a maroon ski jacket, lay with knees pushed up toward chest. A coroner later determined that the woman had been dead for more than two months. The back of her head was matted with blood, and there was a single bullet wound at the base of her skull. She had been shot at close range.

headline: Reading Message Headers in Gmail
abstract: Plus rebooting a cable box and DVR.
lead_paragraph: Q. How do you see the full delivery path of a message in Gmail on the web?

headline: New York City in 17 Syllables
abstract: The New York Times asked readers to write a haiku about New York City. The response was as impressive as the city itself. A panel of judges chose their favorite entries.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times asked readers to write a haiku about New York City. The response was as impressive as the city itself. A panel of judges chose their favorite entries.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: LOVERS AT THE CHAMELEON CLUB, PARIS 1932,  by Francine Prose. (Harper, $26.99.) Prose, a subtle psychologist, has created a genuinely evil character in Lou Villars, a cross-dressing French racecar driver and Nazi collaborator.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Gabrielle Zevin says her novel “The Storied Life of A. J. Fikry,” which features a cranky bookseller, is “the closest I’ll ever come to owning a bookstore.”
lead_paragraph: Behind the Counter: The protagonist of Gabrielle Zevin’s novel “The Storied Life of A. J. Fikry” — new at No. 15 on the hardcover fiction list — is a cranky bookstore owner, depressed after the death of his wife and the theft of a prized volume, who gradually perks up while caring for a baby abandoned in his shop. Book buyers, it turns out, like to read about booksellers. In the past few years, other best-selling examples include “The Marriage Bargain,” by Jennifer Probst (a billionaire proposes to a bookstore owner), “Murder of a Bookstore Babe,” by Denise Swanson (death by shelving), and “Mr. Penumbra’s 24-Hour Bookstore,” by Robin Sloan (a web designer finds a night job at a mysterious shop). Yet Zevin recently told readers of The National Post in Canada that as appealing as the idea of running a bookstore is in theory, in reality she’s just not interested. “I think this is the pet pipe dream of many of us who love books,” she said. “I sometimes like to imagine the kind of bookstore I would run. I have, for instance, a deeply impractical idea for a performance art space/minimalist bookstore. The bookstore would only sell one title a month, and there would be a play or art installation of some kind based around that book. However, this is all just fantasy. Running a bookstore is ridiculously difficult, and the challenges bookstores face — e-books, online competition — are enormous. I suspect the closest I’ll ever come to owning a bookstore is having written ‘The Storied Life of A. J. Fikry.’ ”

headline: On Their Death Bed, Physical Books Have Finally Become Sexy
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'E-Books and Readers', 'Longevity', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: Explaining the rise of the fetishized bookshelf.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, I started noticing a small wave of a new kind of book: highly displayable coffee-table books about the display of books. They had names like “At Home With Books” and “Books Do Furnish a Room,” and felt a bit like an adjunct to that classic, recursive “Seinfeld” gag: Kramer’s coffee-table book about coffee tables that could double as a coffee table.

headline: When the Iron Horse (Almost) Played Tarzan
abstract: Lou Gehrig fell short as the Ape Man but wound up conquering Hollywood anyway — after his death.
lead_paragraph: Seventy-five years ago this Fourth of July, Lou Gehrig, known as the Iron Horse, suffering from the fatal neurodegenerative disease that now bears his name, retired at 36 from baseball. Standing in Yankee Stadium before more than 60,000 fans, he made his unforgettable declaration that despite his “bad break,” he was “the luckiest man on the face of the earth.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘For No Good Reason’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “For No Good Reason.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “For No Good Reason.”

headline: Monty Python Reunion Show to Be Screened in Theaters
abstract: The final night of the troupe’s reunion run at London’s 02 Arena will be beamed in HD to 1,500 movie theaters around the world.
lead_paragraph: If you were dying to catch Monty Python’s reunion show at the 02 Arena in London but were not able to score a ticket, cheer up: the final night of the run, July 20, will be beamed in HD to 1,500 movie theaters around the world. Picturehouse Entertainment announced on Thursday that it had secured the international distribution rights to the show, which will be directed by Aubrey Powell and produced by Fiz Oliver.

headline: Movie Review: ‘The German Doctor’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “The German Doctor.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “The German Doctor.”

headline: Obama on Halt of Mideast Peace Talks
abstract: President Obama said he does not expect a prompt restart to the talks on Middle East peace, saying that neither Israelis nor Palestinians have shown the will to make tough decisions.
lead_paragraph: President Obama said he does not expect a prompt restart to the talks on Middle East peace, saying that neither Israelis nor Palestinians have shown the will to make tough decisions.

headline: Collapse of Peace Talks Gives Israel Easy Exit, but Leaves It in a Precarious Spot
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu avoided a crisis in his governing coalition with the suspension of the talks with Palestinians, but the longer picture contains risks for Israel.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Less than a month ago, Israel was in Secretary of State John Kerry’s cross hairs, accused of sabotaging the peace process he had championed by continuing construction in West Bank settlements and balking on a promise to release long-serving Palestinian prisoners. But when Israel suspended the stalemated negotiations on Thursday, it did so with Washington’s tacit blessing, providing a fractured government not fully committed to peace a low-risk exit strategy.

headline: A Policy-Making Mystery in the Renminbi’s Decline
abstract: Observers question whether the drop in the value of China’s currency to its lowest levels since 2012 is a result of central bank intervention or a weakening economy.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — As President Obama visits Asia in a bid to shore up American alliances, he faces an emerging challenge from the region’s behemoth, China, whose currency has experienced a gradual but unrelenting decline over the last 10 days.

headline: Election Watchdog Fights Lonely Battle on Paid News Coverage
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Elections', 'Law and Legislation', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Media', 'News and News Media', 'Newspapers', 'Political Advertising']
abstract: Paying for media coverage is one of the biggest threats to a clean voting process in India because it is not only extremely difficult to police, it’s also perfectly legal.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — One of the biggest threats to a clean voting process in India, as identified by the Election Commission, is not only extremely difficult to police, it’s also perfectly legal.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Duke Lacrosse Case
abstract: This week, William D. Cohan talks about “The Price of Silence”; Parul Sehgal and John Williams discuss the week’s literary news; Amy Chozick discusses Elizabeth Warren’s “A Fighting Chance”; Ms. Sehgal on Barbara Ehrenreich’s “Living With a Wild God”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, William D. Cohan talks about “The Price of Silence”; Parul Sehgal and John Williams discuss the week’s literary news; Amy Chozick discusses Elizabeth Warren’s “A Fighting Chance”; Ms. Sehgal on Barbara Ehrenreich’s “Living With a Wild God”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: CreepShield Claims to Out the Creeps in Online Dating
abstract: Facial recognition software is pushing the boundaries of our privacy. But what if it is not always correct?
lead_paragraph: As facial recognition software proliferates, some developers are bound to test our comfort level with the notion of strangers seeking to put a name to our faces whether we’re online or on the street.

headline: Quiche Meets Whole Wheat
abstract: In this week’s Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman uses butter, whole-wheat flour, eggs, milk and cheese — in moderation — for an old vegetarian mainstay.
lead_paragraph: I agree wholeheartedly with the Tufts nutrition professor Alice H. Lichtenstein’s recent letter to the editor in this newspaper, in which she writes, “Particularly in an era when dietary restraint is not our strong suit, returning to butter and fatty cuts of meat may likewise return us to the high rates of heart disease we had decades ago.”

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Duke Lacrosse Case
abstract: This week, William D. Cohan, Amy Chozick and Parul Sehgal.
lead_paragraph: This week, William D. Cohan, Amy Chozick and Parul Sehgal.

headline: Haiku Challenge: A Poet’s Picks
abstract: Marie Howe, the state poet of New York, reflects on writing haiku and The Times’s Haiku Challenge.
lead_paragraph: Marie Howe, the state poet of New York, reflects on writing haiku and The Times’s Haiku Challenge, which asked readers to submit a 17-syllable poem about New York City.

headline: The Most Important Question You Can Ask
abstract: What generates an enduring experience of meaning and satisfaction in our work is the sense that what we’re doing really matters — that we’re truly adding value in the world, Tony Schwartz writes in his Life@Work column.
lead_paragraph: When I heard this week that Michael Phelps was planning to return to competitive swimming, my first reaction was to feel a little sad for him. I honor Mr. Phelps for the discipline, grit and passion he needed to win a record 18 gold medals. But I also sense that he’s going back to swimming because he’s chasing a high that hasn’t held up.

headline: Pakistani Censorship, by Other Means
abstract: Almost every journalist reporting on conflict within Pakistan, addressing government corruption, or investigating the actions of the military intelligence service, the ISI, has faced repeated threats.
lead_paragraph: Raza Rumi, a prominent Pakistani journalist, narrowly escaped death on March 28 when his car was riddled with bullets in Lahore. His driver, Mustafa, a 25-year-old newlywed, was killed in the ambush, which took place as they were driving away from the set of Raza’s weekly television show on Express News. The topic that day had been how the country’s blasphemy laws are misused to persecute religious minorities in Pakistan, a regular subject for Raza.

headline: Steamed Clams With Spring Herbs
abstract: Melissa Clark makes steamed clams with fresh tarragon and minced chives.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark makes steamed clams with fresh tarragon and minced chives.

headline: Fewer U.S. Graduates Opt for College After High School
abstract: From a high point of 70.1 percent in 2009, the percentage of new graduates going to college dropped to 65.9 percent last year, the lowest figure in a decade.
lead_paragraph: THE proportion of new American high school graduates who go on to college — a figure that rose regularly for decades — now appears to be declining.

headline: Grilling Jon Favreau
abstract: In a cellphone video, The Times’s David Carr captured a bit of a recent interview with the director and star of the new film “Chef.”
lead_paragraph: In a cellphone video, The Times’s David Carr captured a bit of a recent interview with the director and star of the new film “Chef.”

headline: Jimmy Elliott, a Senior JPMorgan Deal Adviser, to Retire
abstract: Mr. Elliott, who is the global chairman of investment banking, will leave in June to spend more time on his ranch in Texas, according to the memo from Jeff Urwin, a co-head of global banking at the firm.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Elliott, one of JPMorgan Chase’s most senior deal makers, plans to retire, the firm announced in an internal memorandum on Friday.

headline: Pasta Is Not Their Only Habitat
abstract: Steamed clams will take to whatever seasonings you’re in the mood for — and spring calls for a bracing mix of tarragon, chives and lime.
lead_paragraph: My usual destination for a mound of steamed clams is on top of a bowl of pasta. Linguine with white clam sauce has such a lusty, garlicky appeal that I tend to forget that there are other equally tempting ways to eat clams.

headline: International Prosecutor Weighs Case in Ukraine Killings
abstract: The International Criminal Court prosecutor said she was weighing a formal inquiry into the killings of protesters under Ukraine’s deposed president.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The prosecutor of the International Criminal Court announced Friday that she would consider whether grounds exist to open a formal criminal investigation into the killings of civilians during antigovernment protests in Ukraine in the last months of President Viktor F. Yanukovych’s tenure.

headline: Andrew Cuomo’s Tantrum
abstract: The governor went off about the corruption investigation that he cancelled suddenly last month.
lead_paragraph: After promising repeatedly that he would clean up Albany, Gov. Andrew Cuomo suddenly cancelled the Moreland Commission to Investigate Public Corruption last month—before the Commission was anywhere near finished digging into details about how politicians and lobbyists do business in New York State.

headline: Hot Off the Grill, Steak and a Movie
abstract: The actor and filmmaker Jon Favreau prepares a meal with skills left over from his new movie, “Chef,” a small film he is serving up between blockbusters.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The grill on the balcony was hot, the steaks had been rubbed with coarse salt and pepper, and the berries were soaking in Grand Marnier. The only thing needed was a cook.

headline: Wheelies: The Mazda’s Money Edition
abstract: Mazda surpasses its annual operating profit goal and projects record profits for the future; Tesla’s chief executive takes a pay cut.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Ex-Finance Chief at Bank of America to Pay $7.5 Million in Settlement
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The New York State attorney general accused accused the bank’s top executives of withholding material information related to its 2008 merger with Merrill Lynch.
lead_paragraph: The New York State attorney general announced Friday that the office had reached a $7.5 million settlement with Joe L. Price, the former chief financial officer for Bank of America, over allegations that the bank’s management withheld material information related to its 2008 merger with Merrill Lynch.

headline: Donating, and Making Sure the Money Is Put to Work
abstract: Researching a charity does not guarantee your money will end up doing what you want it to. Some organizations, though, are working toward more transparency.
lead_paragraph: Each year, we file a report card on our financial lives. It tells us what we earned, a bit about what we saved, some details on what we own and often includes a tally of our generosity. True, most people don’t read their tax returns this way, but it’s helpful to think of them as a conversation starter and a guide to what we can do better next year.

headline: Mexican Zoo Welcomes Zonkey
abstract: A zoo in northern Mexico said a zonkey, a rare cross between a zebra and a donkey, was born on Monday and given the name of Khumba.
lead_paragraph: A zoo in northern Mexico said a zonkey, a rare cross between a zebra and a donkey, was born on Monday and given the name of Khumba.

headline: In Lagos, the 1% Takes Stock
abstract: A burgeoning wealthy class is settling into one of Africa’s fastest-growing cities, attracting designers, world-class architects and a growing creative community that seeks to preserve its culture through art and fashion.
lead_paragraph: A burgeoning wealthy class is settling into one of Africa’s fastest-growing cities, attracting designers, world-class architects and a growing creative community that seeks to preserve its culture through art and fashion.

headline: A Paris Hotel Offers Cultural Excursions for Kids
abstract: Children’s programs at Le Royal Monceau Raffles Paris include walking tours of bakeries and scavenger hunts in the Louvre.
lead_paragraph: Hotels offering inventive in-house children’s programs is a well-established trend, but Le Royal Monceau Raffles Paris goes a step further with activities that take kids between the ages of 5 and 15 out of the property and around the city.

headline: Alaskans: Mark Begich is using his clout.
abstract: Facing a tough re-election challenge, the Alaska Democrat wants his constituents to know that he’s putting senatorial power to work, favoring the term “Begich Uses Clout.”
lead_paragraph: Facing a re-election challenge, Begich, a Democrat, wants his constituents in Alaska to know that he’s putting senatorial power to work. Three times in April his office has issued news releases that begin with “Begich Uses Clout” and went on to describe Mr. Begich’s interventions with federal agencies. Although such clout-wielding might seem a part of the job, most recent congressional statements have avoided using the word. It has been used in the title of a Senate news release just one other time in the current Congress, when the New Hampshire Republican Kelly Ayotte posted a Concord Monitor article about potential cuts at the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival: Aliens, Romance and the Vicious Brothers
abstract: A Q&A with the directors of the new science fiction film “Extraterrestrial.”
lead_paragraph: Alien abduction films and romantic comedies are the Harry Reid and John Boehner of movies. They’re just two different people. But the mismatched genres blend in unexpected ways in “Extraterrestrial,” a new science-fiction film written by Stuart Ortiz and Colin Minihan, a k a  the Vicious Brothers (“Grave Encounters”), and directed by Mr. Minihan.

headline: North Korea Says It Detained U.S. Tourist Seeking Shelter There
abstract: The North’s official news agency reported that the American, identified as Miller Matthew Todd, 24, was being held for his “rash behavior” while passing through customs on April 10.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — A 24-year-old American tourist who said he was seeking shelter in North Korea has been detained there for more than two weeks and is being held on charges of a “gross violation of its legal order,” the country’s official Korean Central News Agency reported on Friday.

headline: Image of the Day: April 25
abstract: A woman trying to douse a fire that broke out in a slum in south Delhi.

headline: Amazon’s Shrinking Profit Sets Off a Seismic Shock to Its Shares
abstract: For a second quarter in a row, the Internet retailer’s stock fell sharply after its earnings report, suggesting that investors may be growing wary.
lead_paragraph: Is a 20-year honeymoon coming to an end?

headline: 36 Hours in Belo Horizonte, Brazil
abstract: The World Cup is coming soon to this lively industrial capital of Brazil’s second most populous state. Here’s some of what soccer fans — and other visitors — can expect to find.
lead_paragraph: Belo Horizonte, the lively industrial capital of Brazil’s second most populous state, Minas Gerais, has always attracted hordes of visitors — the kind who carry briefcases and laptops, that is. But more and more leisure travelers have been stopping by on their way to one of the art world’s most seductive new attractions, the Instituto Inhotim, a fantasy landscape of world-class contemporary art 35 miles outside of town. Soccer fans aren’t far behind, with the World Cup coming to town in June: six matches will be held in the city’s overhauled stadium, the Mineirão. Both categories of visitors may be surprised at what else they find: a set of brand-new museums housed in neo-Classical-style palaces that until 2010 housed state government agencies; an almost overwhelming number of night-life options; and new and old takes on the state’s soul-comforting cuisine. So what if the hotels still lean toward business over boutique?

headline: A Spiritual Legacy Endures in Healthy Eating
abstract: Followers of the spiritual master Sri Chinmoy, who died in 2007, carry on his teachings at vegetarian restaurants and other businesses.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — I ordered the California omelet. It was fresh and capably cooked, with ample, bright green slices of avocado. The service was cheery and efficient. Were it not for the video of an older Bangladeshi immigrant performing heroic acts of strength that was playing on a loop on a flat-screen television, I would have remembered Silence-Heart-Nest, in the Fremont neighborhood of Seattle, as just an above-average vegetarian brunch spot.

headline: Pharrell Williams Wrote a Book. Now He Needs Your Help.
abstract: A web game promoting Mr. Williams’s new book, “Inspiration,” invites fans to fill in the blanks of his manuscript.
lead_paragraph: Singalongs seem kind of quaint these days, but the singer Pharrell Williams – whose current hit, “Happy,” has a chorus that seduces listeners into joining in – has come up with a new twist. He has completed a book, “Inspiration,” and has invited fans to participate in a write-along while they wait for it to be published.

headline: Along the Oslo Fjord, an Arts District Springs Up
abstract: Tjuvholmen, a tiny island with art every which way, has become the most-talked-about area in the Norwegian capital.
lead_paragraph: Some neighborhoods change overnight, but Tjuvholmen (“Thief’s Island” in Norwegian) didn’t exist until about a year and a half ago. Between strategic urban planning and fast-tracked construction, the trendy arts district emerged fully formed on a tiny island along the Oslo Fjord and, in equally short order, became the most-talked-about area in the Norwegian capital. With art every which way, from water sculptures to outdoor installations, sleek galleries and the Renzo Piano-designed Astrup Fearnley Museum, it’s easy to overlook the other draws: a man-made beach, a sculpture garden, a slew of restaurants and many an opportunity to people-watch the nouveau riche crowd. And with the city center a short walk away, the island is never too removed from the rest of town.

headline: Massaging Your Soul
abstract: From an astrology reading to the Psychic Massage to a session called the Equine Experience, exploring the inner side of spa treatments and resort activities in Arizona.
lead_paragraph: I felt a nap coming on, but I was late for class. I should be totally upfront here and confess that the class was on sleeping. For $75 and an hour and a half of my day, a registered nurse named Sheryl went through a few pro tips on how to get the most restful seven hours possible.

headline: Waiting Game Follows Union Vote by Northwestern Players
keywords: ['Organized Labor', 'College Athletics', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Football', 'Football (College)', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Northwestern’s scholarship football players voted whether to unionize on Friday, but the outcome may not be known for months.
lead_paragraph: EVANSTON, Ill. — Northwestern’s scholarship football players voted Friday on whether to certify the first union in college sports, a landmark day that was closely watched by the N.C.A.A., college administrators and politicians across the country.

headline: Times Minute | State of Play in Ukraine
abstract: Andrew Roth reports from Eastern Ukraine and David Herszenhorn reports from Moscow as Ukraine looks for an end to the standoff between Russia and the West.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Roth reports from Eastern Ukraine and David Herszenhorn reports from Moscow as Ukraine looks for an end to the standoff between Russia and the West.

headline: On the Road to Matrimony, a Detour for a President
abstract: They traveled across country, twice, drama-free. Marriage followed.
lead_paragraph: Portia Wells grew up in rural Washington State doing crafts in 4-H and entering her art projects in county fairs. In college, she majored in wood and furniture design.

headline: Times Minute | State of Play in Ukraine
abstract: Andrew Roth reports from Eastern Ukraine and David Herszenhorn reports from Moscow as Ukraine looks for an end to the standoff between Russia and the West.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Harley-Davidson, Jaguar and Mazda Issue Recalls
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Some recent Harley models may have a fueling defect; some Jaguar models are prone to a suspension issue; Mazda recalls cars with regenerative braking.
lead_paragraph: Harley-Davidson is recalling about 9,100 motorcycles because they can unexpectedly run out of fuel and stall, while Jaguar is recalling almost 300 vehicles because “prolonged, aggressive driving” could cause rear suspension failure, according to reports posted on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

headline: Girl Fatally Stabbed at School in Connecticut on Day of Prom
abstract: Milford police took a student into custody after Maren Sanchez was attacked in the hallway shortly before classes were to begin.
lead_paragraph: MILFORD, Conn. — A 16-year-old student was stabbed to death in the hallway of a high school here on Friday morning, the day of the school’s junior prom.

headline: An Eye for Design, Passed Through the Bloodlines
abstract: A show of works by three generations of the Bugattis reveals talents that extended far beyond automobile design.
lead_paragraph: A show of works by three generations of the Bugattis reveals talents that extended far beyond automobile design.

headline: 10 Years Later, the Clique Still Reigns
abstract: Ten years after it hit theaters, the movie “Mean Girls” continues to resonate on Twitter, on fan sites and in related projects.
lead_paragraph: In the 2004 film “Mean Girls,” Regina George, iron-fisted ruler of the high school in-crowd, snaps at her sidekick, Gretchen Wieners, over some newfangled slang Gretchen is testing out. “Stop trying to make ‘fetch’ happen,” Regina snarls. “It’s not going to happen.”

headline: Alstom Split Would Energize Its Business Units
keywords: ['Energy and Power', 'High-Speed Rail Projects', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Selling the power division of Alstom, the French engineering group, to G.E. would help the remaining company financially and strategically, Olaf Storbeck writes in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Ending the days of Alstom as an unwieldy conglomerate would end many of its headaches. Given time, the group could probably take care of its problems on its own. Outside help would allow it to speed up the recovery. And General Electric could be a powerful catalyst for the transformation.

headline: Netflix vs. Amazon, and the New Economics of Television
abstract: To succeed today, you need to control either the content or the pipes.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a busy week for the companies in the business of trying to revolutionize how we watch television.

headline: Big Ticket | For $13.4 Million, Hitching Post Included
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A historic brick-and-limestone carriage house on the Upper East Side, with 5,058 square feet of space, that once served as a home for horses was the most expensive sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A quaint brick-and-limestone carriage house at 165 East 73rd Street that spent 110 years under the ownership of one family sold for $13.4 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: The Horseless eCarriage Is an Option for a Horse-Free Central Park
abstract: The 7,500-pound Horseless eCarriage, which was displayed at the New York auto show, was conceived as a potential replacement for horse-drawn carriages.
lead_paragraph: Horse-drawn landau carriages have long been part of the scenery in Central Park, but if animal rights activists have their way that will stop. Detractors of the coaches say that keeping horses in New York City, and driving the carriages through traffic from stables on the West Side, is cruel to the horses.

headline: A Portrait and the History It Holds
abstract: “Belle” explores the life of Dido Elizabeth Belle, an 18th-century black woman raised in an aristocratic family who may have helped influence the British debate over ending slavery.
lead_paragraph: While she was an undergraduate at the University of St. Andrews in Scotland in the 1990s, Misan Sagay visited the nearby Scone Palace, where a rare double portrait caught her eye. Painted in the Gainsborough style of aristocratic figures in an Arcadian landscape, the canvas showed two young women swathed in lustrous satin, gleaming pearls circling their swan necks. The vivacious one on the left is biracial; her unhurried companion is white.

headline: 25 Dead Cats Found Hanging in Yonkers Trees
abstract: The authorities said that the cats, found in bags, died from blunt force trauma and that the killings may have started as long as a year ago.
lead_paragraph: Glenn Stefanik was working with his crew from the Yonkers Department of Public Works on Thursday morning, clearing debris from a wooded area overlooking the Hudson River, when he caught sight of something strange.

headline: Limes Too Expensive? Try an Upshot Gimlet
abstract: What cocktail is lime green with a citrus flavor but contains no limes? We present our first cocktail of the week.
lead_paragraph: It has been a long week. It’s time for an Upshot Gimlet.

headline: Clip: ‘Ida’
abstract: A scene from the film directed by Pawel Pawlikowski.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film directed by Pawel Pawlikowski.

headline: Stumbling Onto Reminders of Holocaust
abstract: In two new movies, filmmakers from Poland and Argentina reframe the now-familiar narrative of the Holocaust by telling the story from the perspective of gentiles.
lead_paragraph: A young man stands inside a hole sheathed in dense forest, shoveling dirt, as two women — one young, the other middle-aged — silently watch. The older woman sinks down, taking off her glove to accept a small object just beyond the shot. As the young man bends over, his hat respectfully removed, the woman takes off her scarf to wrap the object — a tiny skull.

headline: Was Your Grandmother Your Bridesmaid?
abstract: The Times is seeking couples who chose their grandmothers as attendants for a coming article.
lead_paragraph: Traditionally, grandmothers received little more recognition on a grandchild’s wedding day than an escort down the aisle, a corsage and a front row seat. But as grandmothers live longer (and livelier), nontraditional brides who are close with their grandmothers are choosing them as bridesmaids and in some instances, as flower girls.

headline: Fear Is in the Forecast, Whatever the Weather
abstract: Two new series on the Weather Channel observe humans up against the worst challenges nature can mete out.
lead_paragraph: Lately, the Weather Channel has been using the slogan “It’s amazing out there!” A more accurate one might be: “You should be terrified at all times, of all sorts of things, not just the weather. But especially the weather.”

headline: Vow of Freedom of Religion Goes Unkept in Egypt
abstract: The architects of the military takeover promised religious tolerance and pluralism, but nine months later not much has changed.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The architects of the military takeover in Egypt promised a new era of tolerance and pluralism when they deposed President Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood last summer.

headline: In Store | An Oasis of Design on the Fringes of L.A.’s Chinatown
abstract: Two conceptual brands — the boutique Iko Iko and the bag line Building Block — are establishing a joint retail outpost in an unexpected location.
lead_paragraph: Now that downtown L.A. has arrived, where to next? A pair of cult brands are making a case for Chinatown as the city’s new style frontier. After a recent joint pop-up downtown proved successful, Iko Iko — the concept store run by Kristin Dickson and Shin Okuda — and Building Block, Kimberly and Nancy Wu’s buzzy line of minimalist bags, are together establishing a permanent retail space along the neighborhood’s industrial northern edge. (The location, about halfway between downtown and the leafy creative-class enclave of Mount Washington, isn’t quite the cultural desert it may seem: the vast Shareen vintage warehouse, a stylists’ haunt, is downstairs, and the annual FYF music festival has traditionally taken place at Los Angeles State Historic Park just down the road.)

headline: Still the Gershwins, but Dig That Pace
abstract: Michael Feinstein welcomed Vince Giordano and the Nighthawks, as well as three guest singers, to a tribute concert to George Gershwin at the Appel Room, Jazz at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: Michael Feinstein has been preaching the gospel according to George and Ira Gershwin for so many years that you might think he would run out of things to say or ways to present their work. But “The Music of George Gershwin,” the season-opening concert of his jazz and popular song series at the Appel Room at Jazz at Lincoln Center on Wednesday evening, was a gusher in which the great vintage-jazz band Vince Giordano and the Nighthawks and three guest singers examined the Gershwins’ legacy through a focused nostalgic lens.

headline: Burma Calling
abstract: I’m looking for suggestions for topics to cover on my annual win-a-trip journey
lead_paragraph: For my annual win-a-trip journey, I’ve decided to travel to Burma, along with win-a-trip winner Nicole Sganga of Notre Dame and video journalist Adam Ellick of the Times. We’ll try to do a mix of Burma-specific articles and video reporting, and also global health/nutrition/development pieces that just happen to have a Burma angle. I’d welcome your suggestions for places for us to go and themes for us to cover. What columns or videos would you like to read/see? And what should Nicole blog about?

headline: In Tonys Derby, ‘Inishmaan,’ ‘Cabaret,’ ‘Hedwig’ and ‘Violet’ Eligible as Revivals
abstract: Committee rules that notable works that have never been on Broadway can’t compete against brand-new plays or musicals.
lead_paragraph: The producers of “The Cripple of Inishmaan,” the critically acclaimed Broadway play starring Daniel Radcliffe, had a decision to make before Friday morning’s meeting of the Tony Awards eligibility committee. The producers could ask the committee to rule that the drama was eligible for the 2014 Tony for best play – a category that has no front-runner – or leave it for the play revival category, considering that “Inishmaan” was written in 1996 and frequently produced (including twice Off Broadway). The downside to being in the revival category would be such strong competitors as “A Raisin in the Sun,” “The Glass Menagerie,” and “Twelfth Night.”

headline: A Sonic Explorer Tries a Solo Turn
abstract: Damon Albarn, who sang in the bands Blur and Gorillaz and immersed himself in African music and Chinese opera, will release his first solo album.
lead_paragraph: For most of the show that he played on a recent Thursday night at the Highline Ballroom in Manhattan, Damon Albarn focused on introspective and autobiographical music spanning his pop-music career of some 25 years. Then, as he wound down the set, Mr. Albarn brought out a gospel choir to accompany him on a new song, “Mr. Tembo,” a cheerful tune that includes the refrain, “It’s where he is now, but it wasn’t what he planned.”

headline: Earl Morrall Is Dead at 79; Led 2 Teams to Super Bowl
abstract: Replacing Johnny Unitas and then Bob Griese, Morrall led the Baltimore Colts and the Miami Dolphins to Super Bowls in the 1960s and ’70s.
lead_paragraph: Earl Morrall, who threw 161 touchdown passes in 21 N.F.L. seasons but was best remembered as the backup quarterback who led the Baltimore Colts and the unbeaten Miami Dolphins to Super Bowls in the 1960s and ’70s, died on Friday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 79.

headline: Answering Readers’ Questions About the Baseball Maps
abstract: Although Facebook data must be taken with a grain of salt, the results broadly match up with findings from other sources.
lead_paragraph: The Upshot published interactive maps on Thursday detailing the geography of baseball fandom, based on Facebook data. The reader response was tremendous, and we wanted to answer a couple of good questions that were raised.

headline: Health Care Apps Offer Patients an Active Role
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Doctors', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Mobile applications and devices let people take pictures of moles or record a heartbeat and then communicate accordingly with their doctor.
lead_paragraph: IF you have young children, you’ve most likely endured caring for an ear infection or two. Or perhaps you’ve experienced a mysterious rash. Those situations generally mean a trip to the doctor’s office and time away from your job, if you work outside the home.

headline: Giving New Voice to Troubled Relationships
abstract: This week: “The Way and Color” by Teen; “Bailar en la Cueva” by Jorge Drexler; “Put Your Needle Down” by the Secret Sisters; and “Woman to Woman” by Esmé Patterson.
lead_paragraph: Teen

headline: The Gun Report: April 25, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Some parts of Chicago have become so violent that the city has earned a new nickname: “Chiraq,” a reference to last decade’s bloody military quagmire in the Persian Gulf. The moniker has been floating around for the past couple of years, but in the Daily Beast this week, Michael Daly explores the crescendo of gun violence plaguing the city’s black neighborhoods.

headline: Friends Can Be Dangerous
keywords: ['Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Friendship']
abstract: Even teenage mice binge-drink with peers.
lead_paragraph: I’M not sure whether it’s a badge of honor or a mark of shame, but a paper I published a few years ago is now ranked No. 8 on a list of studies that other psychologists would most like to see replicated. Good news: People find the research interesting. Bad news: They don’t believe it.

headline: Weekend Reading: Unusual Bid Makes Strange Bedfellows
abstract: William A. Ackman’s unconventional hostile bid for the maker of Botox has surprised corporate America and brought out some unexpected alliances.
lead_paragraph: William A. Ackman’s unconventional hostile bid for the maker of Botox has surprised corporate America and brought out some unexpected alliances.

headline: Baseball’s Second-Place Favorites: Go, Mets
abstract: A map based on Facebook data by ZIP code shows there is a limit to fan acrimony.
lead_paragraph: Even in Upshot-land, where map lovers as a percent of the staff approaches 100 percent, there is such a thing as map overload. We don’t want to get to that point. But this map of second-favorite teams in each ZIP code is too good not to share.

headline: A Harmonic Drone Subsides in Britain
abstract: With the decline in organized religion, many parishes no longer even have organs, and organists have suffered declines in influence and pay.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Next door to the Royal Albert Hall here is an impressive building that is still sometimes referred to as the Royal College of Organists — as indeed it was in the days when organists had weight to throw around and needed premises that told you so. Founded in 1864, the college was grand, its membership as powerful as that of any London club, and its examinations recognized throughout the world.

headline: A Certain Something
abstract: The Porsche Cayman doesn’t make much of a case for itself strictly on numbers, but it exudes a cool factor that’s hard to quantify.
lead_paragraph: The Porsche Cayman doesn’t make much of a case for itself strictly on numbers, but it exudes a cool factor that’s hard to quantify.

headline: Grand Performances in the Seats
abstract: On the eve of Lincoln Center’s spring dance season, Alastair Macaulay reflects on the singular passions of ballet’s fiercest partisans.
lead_paragraph: Lincoln Center’s spring ballet season — this year’s begins with New York City Ballet’s opening night on Tuesday — is a regular phenomenon, but its scale still makes it extraordinary. Part of what’s astonishing is the audience: Thousands of people attend each performance, some of them having traveled hundreds of miles or more. When the David H. Koch Theater and the Metropolitan Opera House are sold out simultaneously — this year, dance companies occupy both houses from May 12 through June 29 — nearly 7,000 people will be turning up at showtime on many nights, crossing Lincoln Center’s central plaza in tides. And some religiously turn up for nine performances a week.

headline: Daniel Anker, Maker of Powerful Documentaries, Dies at 50
abstract: Mr. Anker was known for documentaries that he directed or produced, including those about the “Scottsboro boys” and Hollywood’s response to the Holocaust.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Anker, a filmmaker whose sober documentaries brought unsensationalized narrative power to subjects including the trials of the Scottsboro boys and Hollywood’s treatment of the Holocaust, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 50.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 48
abstract: Brazil’s coach said he knows the makeup of his 23-man World Cup roster.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Recapturing the Past, and Then Revising It
abstract: The work of Julian Schnabel deserves renewed attention, and two shows have started the process.
lead_paragraph: At the moment, Julian Schnabel’s painting seems to be the art that dares not speak its name. Its influence is widely visible but rarely cited. You can see it in the work of artists from Joe Bradley to Oscar Murillo and all sorts of painters who emphasize chance or accident and like to work big, using unconventional materials.

headline: Private Citizen Bloomberg on Philanthropy
abstract: When it comes to giving away his fortune, Michael R. Bloomberg, the former mayor of New York City, says he seeks causes others may have overlooked and ways to test new ideas.
lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg has given billions of dollars to charity and plans to give tens of billions more. His foundation, Bloomberg Philanthropies, has been ranked among the most innovative organizations in the country. And he has been willing to finance programs that could be controversial if they failed — like teaching high school graduates in Tanzania to perform appendectomies and cesarean sections.

headline: Unlimited Koch Cash Comes to New York
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'McCutcheon v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)']
abstract: Judge Paul Crotty reluctantly allowed unlimited contributions to independent political groups in New York State.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Judge Paul Crotty, who sits on the federal district court in Manhattan, reluctantly allowed unlimited contributions to independent political groups in New York State. “Reluctantly,” in fact, doesn’t begin to describe how clenched the judge’s teeth were in writing this remarkable opinion, which eloquently describes the dangers of the very act he was allowing.

headline: In a World Filled With Zombies, 2 Girls Still Find Magic at the Mall
abstract: The next chapter of The Last of Us video game, titled Left Behind, has two teenagers investigating a shopping mall in a world threatened by zombies.
lead_paragraph: The Last of Us: Left Behind is the best new video game so far this year, or at least the only one that I can’t stop thinking about. A coming-of-age story about two teenage girls during a zombie apocalypse, it’s approachable and contained, designed to be played in a single sitting of two or three hours. It’s also inexpensive, selling for about $15.

headline: South Sudan Releases Four Accused of Plotting Coup
abstract: The accusation of the coup plot was a pivotal event that quickly led to the civil war pulling the young country apart.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The government of South Sudan on Friday released four political figures accused of plotting a coup last December, a contested but pivotal event that quickly led to the civil war pulling the young country apart.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Iraq, South Korea, Syria and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Iraq, South Korea, Syria and India.

headline: Resisting the 911’s Gravitational Pull
abstract: The Porsche Cayman may never beat its big brother, the 911, but it’s an appealing choice among midengine coupes, and midengine coupes are the stuff of greatness.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve been keeping up with Neil deGrasse Tyson’s “Cosmos: A Spacetime Odyssey” on Fox, you may be familiar with the concept of the multiverse — the idea that our universe is just one among a potentially infinite number of others. If true, there could be some alternate universe almost just like ours, but slightly different.

headline: Peas, Emerging From the Deep Freeze
abstract: Most peas are eaten straight from cold storage, but when given the chance to taste sweet fresh green peas, you can notice the difference.
lead_paragraph: Which cuisine do you think of when you think about peas? French, with petits pois aux laitues? Italian, which offers piselli con prosciutto? Indian, and its mutter paneer? British, with buttered peas with mint?

headline: Not Flared Nostrils, but Nostrils With Flair
abstract: Automotive grilles tend to get a lot of attention from designers, but they have lately been shifting their focus to the air intakes in the sides of the front bumpers.
lead_paragraph: For years, auto designers lavished attention on the grilles of cars, both for their function and for their brand identity. Now designers seem to be lowering their sights.

headline: In Your Fascia
abstract: Vehicles’ faces seem to be showing larger and more expressively formed nostrils, to judge from many models at the New York International Auto Show.
lead_paragraph: Vehicles’ faces seem to be showing larger and more expressively formed nostrils, to judge from many models at the New York International Auto Show.

headline: The Ever-Expanding Uzbek Flower
abstract: At Nargis Cafe in Brooklyn, groups endure waiting for a convivial meal of multiple courses, blending flavors from Asia, the Middle East and the Mediterranean.
lead_paragraph: On a warm evening in Sheepshead Bay, under a dark canopy of Brooklyn sky, a crowd gathered on the corner of Coney Island Avenue and Kathleen Street, beside a midnight blue awning three storefronts long, enjoying, at last, a gentle spring that augured the tender lamb and other Central Asian delicacies awaiting inside.

headline: Tuvan Throat Singers, Together in Spirit With Arvo Pärt
abstract: The “collected stories” series continued at Zankel Hall on Wednesday with performances by Tuvan throat singers and a rendition of Arvo Pärt’s “Passio.”
lead_paragraph: In a promotional letter, the composer David Lang called “collected stories,” the weeklong series of programs he is overseeing at Zankel Hall, “a little festival of odd music.” The house was full again on Wednesday, as it had been for the first concert, on Tuesday, and probably few of those present would have disputed Mr. Lang’s characterization.

headline: Private Equity Takes Steps Toward Wooing Smaller Investors
abstract: A plan envisions a market where investors in private equity funds can sell their stakes to individuals whose net worth falls far below the usual threshold.
lead_paragraph: One of Wall Street’s most exclusive investment products is inching toward the mainstream.

headline: In China, Dawn of a Gilded Age
abstract: China has become an important automotive market, and the Beijing auto show reflects that. More than 1,000 new models are expected to be on display during the show.
lead_paragraph: There’s a gold rush in China’s automobile market, it would seem, judging by the huge array of new vehicles on display at Auto China 2014 in Beijing.

lead_paragraph: Representative Michael G. Grimm, a former F.B.I. agent and Marine who capitalized on his straight-arrow image to win a seat in Congress, was expected to be indicted on federal fraud charges after a lengthy corruption investigation, people with knowledge of the case said on Friday.

lead_paragraph: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

abstract: A big of old favorite uplift.
lead_paragraph: Busy week, I’m actually very tired, and have been indulging in old favorites to get me through. So an old performance, emotionally uplifting, from the band that got me into indie music.

lead_paragraph: In the preliminary Daily Bulletin for the White House junior international tournament in the Netherlands, its editor, Dennis Stuurman, mentioned that the longtime junior coach in the Netherlands, Kees Tammens, had asked the players under his charge to write up particularly memorable deals.

headline: Despite Missing Economic Goals, Greece Manages to Meet a Bailout Target
abstract: The European Commission said in a report on Friday that Greece had made enough progress to warrant disbursing 6.3 billion euros that had been held back.
lead_paragraph: Greece’s mountain of debt will decline more slowly than previously expected, the European Commission said in a Friday report.

headline: Flip Sides of a Troupe as It Returns for a 45th-Anniversary Season
abstract: Dance Theater of Harlem kicked off its 45th-anniversary season on Wednesday at Lincoln Center’s Rose Theater.
lead_paragraph: Dance Theater of Harlem’s 45th-anniversary season, currently underway at Lincoln Center’s Rose Theater, is in some ways only its second. It was just last year that the troupe re-emerged after a nine-year hiatus, under the new artistic direction of Virginia Johnson. If the company looks uneven — sometimes scintillating, sometimes struggling — as it did on Wednesday, that’s probably because it is still in transition, training a new crop of dancers, figuring out what it wants to be.

headline: Taking a Spin: The Dream Outcome for Democrats
abstract: Our model gives Democrats only a 3 percent chance of ending up with 54 Senate seats. But it’s still possible, and this will be a weekly lesson in probability.
lead_paragraph: A lot can and will change in the battle for control of the Senate over the next six months. Fortunately, Leo, the Senate model for The Upshot, has a great tool to help illustrate probability: spinners that generate election possibilities in accordance with Leo’s odds. I have wasted an inordinate amount of time spinning these spinners over the last few weeks. I have seen some crazy things.

headline: Bill Cunningham | On the Right Foot
abstract: Elaborately decorated sneakers are playing a starring role.
lead_paragraph: Elaborately decorated sneakers are playing a starring role.

headline: Mixing and Matching Youth and Middle Age, and Sequins and Tulle
abstract: Miguel Gutierrez was joined by Mickey Mahar in a new work about aging and vitality as part of the Whitney Biennial.
lead_paragraph: It is still a novelty, and thus a big deal, for a choreographer to be in the Whitney Biennial. The last Biennial, in 2012, was the first to include choreographers, and Sarah Michelson and Michael Clark responded with big statements, spreading their dances across an expanse of the Whitney Museum of American Art’s fourth floor.

headline: It Took a Little Piece of Their Hearts
abstract: An Off Broadway run of “A Night With Janis Joplin” was canceled just 48 hours before it was to start. Those involved see it as another instance of producers toying with artists.
lead_paragraph: Assured by producers that their jobs were safe, actors skipped auditions for other musicals. Band members signed apartment leases. Investors wrote more checks for the show.

headline: A Leap Forward, Here With Chamber Music
abstract: With live music, Taylor 2 — the junior ensemble of the Paul Taylor Dance Company — is performing at the Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts at Pace University.
lead_paragraph: When the Paul Taylor Dance Company announced its big plans last month — to reinvent itself in the coming year as Paul Taylor’s American Modern Dance — few definitive details made clear what this enterprise would look like. Perhaps the most concrete news: The company, from here on, will perform (sometimes) with live music.

headline: Seven Ways to Dance to a Tony Award
abstract: A dance critic says the dancing in seven new Broadway musicals is good enough for any of them to be contenders for a Tony choreography nomination.
lead_paragraph: The choreography of seven new Broadway musicals I’ve recently seen falls into the category of “good generic.” In each case — efficiently, pleasingly, vividly — it’s taken me somewhere I’ve been before.

headline: New System Allows Artists Seeking Instruments to Borrow, Not Beg
keywords: ['Music', 'Classical Music', 'Violins and Violas', 'Musical Instruments', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The violinist Helena Baillie is the beneficiary of an unusual new lending model intended to insulate musicians from patrons and institutions alike.
lead_paragraph: If there was ever a symbol of the growing disparity between the costs of great instruments and the wages of the musicians who know how to play them, it is the astronomical $45 million that sellers are seeking this spring for a rare Stradivari viola.

headline: Oh, How They Like to Dish
abstract: A conversation with Liz Smith, a gossip columnist, and Jess Cagle, editorial director of People magazine about celebrity, ambition and the difference between gossip and news.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve ever found yourself intrigued by the meltdowns of Lindsay Lohan and Charlie Sheen, puzzled by Jennifer Aniston’s seemingly endless difficulty in finding romantic bliss, fascinated by the endless woes of the even more endless “Real Housewives,” or hungry for any scrap of news about Brangelina, Kimye or TomKat, chances are you are deeply familiar with the work of Liz Smith and Jess Cagle, who have 90 years of gossip columns and entertainment news between them.

headline: A Formal Breakup With Prom Wear
abstract: Prom looks now include vintage clothing and styles from the red carpet.
lead_paragraph: Soon to attend her junior prom at Garrison Forest School in Owings Mills, Md., Lindy Wittenberg has decided to make a statement with her outfit. “I want to punch prom in the face by wearing pants,” she said.

headline: Better Homes and Hipsters
abstract: Kinfolk Magazine has gained a foothold with the design-foodie elite for its elegant white pages showing dreamy young people doing earthy things.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, Portland, Ore., has contributed its fair share to the trend one could call Rustic Artisanal Twee, with food trucks offering items like free-range kimchi tacos; idiosyncratic businesses like Stumptown Coffee Roasters and the Ace Hotels; and bespectacled urban eco-hipsters satirized on “Portlandia.”

headline: Feuding in 140 Characters
abstract: Does the medium by which we hold grudges and wage feuds affect the shelf life of those grudges and feuds?
lead_paragraph: In days of yore, if you were famous and hot under the collar, you stumbled over to your nemesis’ booth at the Musso & Frank Grill and hurled a martini or Sidecar into the object of your opprobrium’s face. By the 1960s, your arena had changed: You deployed the jeweled rapiers and poisoned darts of your animus on “The Dick Cavett Show” or in the letters section of The New York Review of Books. Today, you turn on your iPhone and tweet, “miley is a byotch!”

headline: Bill Cunningham | On the Right Foot
abstract: Elaborately decorated sneakers are playing a starring role.
lead_paragraph: Elaborately decorated sneakers are playing a starring role. A trend not unlike the highly embellished women’s handbags at the turn of this century, it is definitely a men’s thing, although women are showing variations. This winter, Saks Fifth Avenue devoted five prime windows just to sneakers. Some with wings echo Mercury, and others are decorated with chains or bones, and then there are sneakers with contrasting laces.

headline: Boy George: Still on the Scene, Despite Lady Gaga
abstract: Trading a diet of drugs for raw foods and a vegan restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Boy George ordered the cauliflower and sweet-corn polenta, along with an avocolada smoothie and a “cheese” plate made of fermented cashews.

abstract: Spring celebration season kicks into gear.
lead_paragraph: Spring celebration season kicks into gear.

abstract: A federal judge ruled on Wednesday that Carmen M. Segarra had not shown that she was fired over refusing to change certain findings about Goldman Sachs.
lead_paragraph: A former bank examiner with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York lost a lawsuit against her former employer after a federal judge ruled on Wednesday that she had not shown that she was fired over refusing to change certain findings about Goldman Sachs.

abstract: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes the New York State Pavilion in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, high school scuba divers in Coney Island and a chicken coop in Forest Hills, Queens.

headline: Iraqi Militants Stage Political Rally, Then Bombs Go Off
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Terrorism', 'Shiite Muslims', 'Sunni Muslims', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: Bombs killed over 30 at a political rally in Baghdad by a Shiite militant group, Asaib Ahl al-Haq, and the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, a Sunni group, claimed responsibility.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A campaign rally at a ramshackle old soccer stadium on Friday afternoon began with open-air theater that crossed centuries of Shiite lore, from the martyrdom of a revered religious figure to the fight today against Sunni extremists, played by actors dressed as fighters for the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, a radical Islamist group.
