headline: Welcoming Love at an Older Age, but Not Necessarily Marriage
keywords: ['Marriages', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Income', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Single Persons', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Retirement']
abstract: A couple can lose crucial pensions and benefits that they had before they tied the knot.
lead_paragraph: FOR years, Stephen Ward, 68, struggled as his wife suffered from multiple sclerosis and died. Then in 2007, he met Phyllis Kellerman, 70, and they started dating. The retired couple discovered that they had much in common. Both loved the theater. Both had long happy marriages and children. Mr. Ward and Ms. Kellerman’s late husband had been teachers in the New York area. The couple soon fell in love. Ms. Kellerman moved into Mr. Ward’s house in Boynton Beach, Fla.

headline: Matt Harvey: A Day Off (in a Year Off)
abstract: This season Harvey of the Mets is doing rehab after surgery on his right elbow. When the team isn’t playing, he hangs out on Sundays in the East Village, his neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: During a stellar season pitching for the New York Mets last year, Matt Harvey, now 25, was the National League’s starter in the All-Star Game and rejuvenated the team’s frustrated fans. This season he is doing rehab in New York and in Port St. Lucie, Fla., after Tommy John surgery on his right elbow. When the team isn’t playing, he hangs out on Sundays in the East Village, his neighborhood, trying on suits, watching sports with his buddies and shopping for cheese. “I’m with my team a lot,” he said, “so any chance I get to spend with my friends outside of baseball and have a normal weekend day is always nice.”

headline: Under Cover: What Does It Take for a Woman to Become a Chimp?
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Monkeys and Apes', 'Photography', 'Puppets']
abstract: When the magazine’s photo editors dreamed up this week’s cover image of a courtroom scene with a chimpanzee as plaintiff, they realized they could not possibly use a real animal during the photo shoot. They used an animatronic one instead.
lead_paragraph: When the magazine’s photo editors dreamed up this week’s cover image of a courtroom scene with a chimpanzee as plaintiff, they realized that they could not possibly use a real animal during the photo shoot.

headline: National Advocacy Group Takes Local Political Turn
abstract: Americans for Prosperity, a force in this year’s midterm congressional elections, has surprised people in Columbus, Ohio, with a campaign against a tax increase to benefit the local zoo.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Americans for Prosperity is a national force in this year’s midterm congressional elections, but the organization showed again this week that it is willing to monkey around with local issues as well.

headline: With Philadelphia Shortfall, Schools Face Renewed Cuts
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']
abstract: About 2,350 jobs could be eliminated next year unless the district finds funding to bridge its new shortfall, the superintendent said.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — A $216-million budget shortfall could force Philadelphia’s public schools to make further staffing cuts next year, school officials said on Friday.

headline: Infertility, Endured Through a Prism of Race
keywords: ['Infertility', 'Minorities', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Women and Girls', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Black women face infertility more often than white women but are less likely to seek medical help, and their struggles are compounded by cultural issues.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Like many single women, Heather Lawson hoped she would meet the right man with enough time to get married and have a child. But a failed relationship at 38 changed her plans, and Ms. Lawson realized that if she wanted to be a mother, she might have to explore other options.

headline: Qatar: U.S. Couple Seeks Respite
abstract: A Los Angeles couple convicted last month of child endangerment, not the original charge of murder they had faced, in the 2013 death of their adopted daughter will seek permission from an appellate court to go home while their appeal is pending, defense lawyers said this week.
lead_paragraph: A Los Angeles couple convicted last month of child endangerment, not the original charge of murder they had faced, in the 2013 death of their adopted daughter will seek permission from an appellate court to go home while their appeal is pending, defense lawyers said this week. They will make their request at their first hearing, scheduled for Monday, the lawyers said. The couple, Matthew and Grace Huang, and their lawyers learned only this week of the legal grounds cited by the lower court for the guilty verdict. The lawyers said they were baffled by the child endangerment conviction, which carries a three-year prison term and was never part of the original case presented by prosecutors. “Everybody on our team was scratching their heads,” said Randy Papetti, one of the lawyers. “This is simply out of left field.” The Huang case has come to symbolize what critics call the arbitrary system of criminal justice in Qatar, where foreign workers constitute a majority of the population. The Huangs have said their daughter, Gloria, 8, suffered an eating disorder and was not denied food as asserted by prosecutors, who suspected the parents were child traffickers because they are of Asian heritage and Gloria was from Ghana. The exact cause of her death was never established.

headline: I Was Taught That Getting Pregnant Is Easy for Black Girls — Too Easy. But It Wasn’t for Me.
abstract: When I grew up on the South Side of Chicago, I was taught that my mission was to get out of high school without a baby. I thought that once I was ready, those babies that came too easily, and too early, for many girls I knew would come readily to me. That didn’t happen.
lead_paragraph: Enduring infertility as a woman of color is different. Why? I’ve had far longer than I wanted to consider that question, and the answer I’ve come up with is this: Infertility is hard as a black woman because no one expects a black woman to have trouble conceiving — not even other black women.

headline: Ecuador: A U.S. Office Is Closed
abstract: The government of Ecuador has told the United States Embassy to shut down a military cooperation office staffed by about 20 people from the Defense Department, an embassy spokesman said Friday
lead_paragraph: The government of Ecuador has told the United States Embassy to shut down a military cooperation office staffed by about 20 people from the Defense Department, an embassy spokesman said Friday. The office, which included military and civilian staff members, worked with Ecuadorean military personnel to promote cooperation on efforts to fight drug trafficking, terrorism, human trafficking and other international crimes, said the spokesman, Jeffrey M. Weinshenker. The office will close by the end of the month and its staff members will leave the country, Mr. Weinshenker said. He said that the embassy’s military attaché office was not affected by the order. President Rafael Correa, a leftist, has often criticized the United States and its influence in the region. In January, Mr. Correa said that the United States had too many military officers assigned to its embassy in Ecuador and that he planned to order some to leave.

headline: Sheriff Joe Arpaio Embraces His Hollywood Moment
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Movies', 'Racial Profiling', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: An unflattering documentary portrays the divisive Arizona lawman as a skillful media manipulator, while critics say the film is just one more example.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Sheriff Joe Arpaio, at once hailed and reviled as America’s toughest sheriff, sauntered into famously liberal Hollywood on Wednesday, traveling hundreds of miles from his home turf and disconcerting legal problems in Arizona to promote a documentary that offers, at best, an unflattering portrayal of his troubled 21 years in office.

headline: Chen Yizi, a Top Adviser Forced to Flee China, Dies at 73
abstract: Mr. Chen, a close ally of Zhao Ziyang, sought to rally intellectuals and party moderates to support the student protests at Tiananmen Square.
lead_paragraph: Chen Yizi, who helped reshape China’s economy in the 1980s but who was deemed a counterrevolutionary after defending the student-led protests that filled Tiananmen Square in 1989, died in exile on April 14 in Los Angeles. He was 73.

headline: Hey, Big Thinker
abstract: The economist Thomas Piketty is the newest version of a now-familiar specimen: the overnight intellectual sensation whose stardom reflects the fashions and feelings of the moment.
lead_paragraph: It is unclear how many people have actually read Thomas Piketty’s treatise “Capital in the Twenty-First Century” — 577 pages of text and graphs plus 78 pages of notes and, for added clarity, an appendage called “Contents in Detail.”

headline: Douglas L. Coleman, 82, Dies; Found a Genetic Cause of Obesity
abstract: Dr. Coleman upset scientific dogma by discovering that genes — not willpower, eating habits or other behaviors — could cause obesity in some people.
lead_paragraph: Douglas L. Coleman, a Canadian-born scientist who upset scientific dogma by discovering that genes — not willpower, eating habits or other behaviors — could cause obesity in some people, died on April 16 at his home in Lamoine, Me. He was 82.

headline: Phone Company Bid to Keep Data From N.S.A. Is Rejected
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Telephones and Telecommunications']
abstract: A judge upholds an earlier ruling that there was no Fourth Amendment protections for metadata — information like the numbers dialed and the duration of a call, but not its contents.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A telephone company asked the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court in January to stop requiring it to give records of its customers’ calls to the National Security Agency, in light of a ruling by a Federal District Court judge that the N.S.A. program is likely unconstitutional, according to court papers declassified on Friday.

headline: Piketty and the Petits Rentiers
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Gifts', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Income', 'Income Inequality', 'Parenting', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: What “Capital in the Twenty-First Century” Gets Right.
lead_paragraph: Having expressed some predictable skepticism about elements of Thomas Piketty’s argument in “Capital in the Twenty-First Century,” I want to usher in the weekend by highlighting something significant I think that he gets right. His book, as the title suggests, is notable among recent treatments of inequality for its elevation of wealth and capital (as opposed to just income), and particularly for its discussion of the re-emergence of inheritance as a force for class stratification in the West. The book’s frequent references to 19th century fiction notwithstanding, Piketty concedes that there are likely to be fewer extraordinarily large estates (relative to the wealth of society as a whole) in 21st century Europe and America than there were in, say, his native France two hundred years ago. But he argues that there will be, and indeed already are, enough large-ish estates to return us to a state of affairs where wealth is channeled through patrimonies to a remarkable, quasi-Victorian extent:

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Buffett Punts on Pay
abstract: The Oracle of Omaha gives excessive executive compensation a pass when he had the chance to take a stand.

abstract: Was it race-related? Probably. This is America, after all.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — AS Detroit burned to the ground on a hot summer night in July 1967, my grandparents stood on their front lawn listening to the sounds of our civic suicide.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Savannah Harbor Expansion Project has friends in all the right places.

headline: New York Will Keep Affordable Care Act Health Plans Restricted
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid']
abstract: An out-of-network requirement would make it difficult for health exchange plans with roots in the Medicaid system to compete, according to state officials.
lead_paragraph: New York State health officials said on Friday that they would not require out-of-network coverage on Affordable Care Act health plans next year, a decision likely to disappoint customers who have complained that they can no longer use their favorite doctors and hospitals.

headline: Saving China’s Elephants
abstract: Efforts to save China’s few hundred wild elephants appear to have been successful although visitors to the Yunnan Province Wild Elephant Valley Park are unlikely to see one.
lead_paragraph: Efforts to save China’s few hundred wild elephants appear to have been successful although visitors to the Yunnan Province Wild Elephant Valley Park are unlikely to see one.

headline: Immigration Resurfaces in Tough Talk by Speaker
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: An exasperated John A. Boehner, who lashed out at conservative House members who continued to block his efforts at reform, said he was “hellbent” on dealing with the issue this year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speculation about Speaker John A. Boehner’s intentions in overhauling the nation’s immigration laws intensified Friday after he mocked the most conservative House members for thwarting his attempts to fix the system, shore up the borders and address the legal status of the country’s 11 million illegal immigrants.

headline: In Land That Values Ivory, Wild Elephants Find a Safe Haven
abstract: Government protections are helping Asian elephant numbers rise, but forests are rapidly giving way to rubber and other cash crops.
lead_paragraph: XISHUANGBANNA, China — At a time when tens of thousands of elephants across Africa are being slaughtered to feed the Chinese appetite for ivory, it turns out the best place to be a wild elephant may be here in the tropical forests of southwest China.

headline: Young Center Takes Hard Route to N.H.L.
abstract: Joey Hishon has joined Colorado after overcoming two concussions and a groin injury. Not to mention the broken foot and sprained knee injuries he sustained earlier in his career.
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — Joey Hishon, a fourth-line center for the Colorado Avalanche, played only 6 minutes 31 seconds in a 2-1 loss to the Minnesota Wild on Thursday night in Game 4 of their first-round series. But those eight shifts, in Hishon’s N.H.L. debut, represented a significant victory.

headline: Street Style in Oakland, California
abstract: In the Grand Lake neighborhood of Oakland, Calif., Sarah Barnekow, 24, aid that her style usually errs on the side of masculine.
lead_paragraph: In the Grand Lake neighborhood of Oakland, Calif., it is hard to ignore the bustling scene where scores of people are lined up in front of food trucks or going in and out of the hip restaurants, bars and salons. Among the foot traffic is a colorful display of relaxed Northern California style: vintage button-down shirts and scarves, tattoos and piercings and hoodies with the logos of local brands . Originally from Chicago, Sarah Barnekow moved to the area three years ago and has undergone a style transformation, most recently chopping 10 inches off her hair and dying it a white-and-gray hue. Sporting brown combat boots, a scarf she bought while traveling in India, a bracelet she recently purchased at a local flea market and a tattoo of the Wi-Fi sign, Ms. Barnekow said that her style usually errs on the side of masculine.

headline: Given a Choice, Athletes May Prefer None and Done
abstract: It may be time to do away with the one-year rule, which since 2006 has effectively required players to spend at least a year in college before entering the N.B.A. draft.
lead_paragraph: Long before Julius Randle was a 6-foot-9, 250-pound wall of muscle and a certain N.B.A. lottery pick, he was a toddler who slept with a basketball clutched to his chest.

headline: European Firms Seek to Minimize Russia Sanctions
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Natural Gas', 'Energy and Power']
abstract: As businesses, particularly in the energy sector, campaign to maintain ties with Moscow, the world’s seven wealthiest nations said on Friday that they would impose additional sanctions on Russia resulting from its military action in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — With the showdown over Ukraine escalating and President Obama warning Moscow of a tough new round of sanctions, Russia and its allies in the European private sector are conducting a separate campaign to ensure that they can maintain their deep and longstanding economic ties even if the Kremlin orders further military action.

headline: Where Nutella Has a Big Role, Even at Dinner
abstract: The chocolate-hazelnut spread is practically a food group at Zuppa, an Italian restaurant near the Yonkers waterfront.
lead_paragraph: The couple at the bar were having an intimate conversation, their foreheads nearly touching except for an occasional break to sip cocktails or munch on small plates of cheese and olives. On the other side of the room, an extended family sat around a table draped in a white tablecloth, trading stories and large plates of freshly made pasta and roasted meats as they made their way through a three-course meal.

headline: Airbnb Host Welcomes Travelers From All Over
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A Queens resident with a spare bedroom has rented it out over the past 10 months to scores of guests, taking in almost $18,000.
lead_paragraph: The vacationing couple from Hattingen, Germany, showed up at Michael Naess’s shipshape Queens apartment at the end of February. They had never met before. Nonetheless, here they were, digging into scrambled eggs, sipping coffee and chatting companionably with him on a Saturday morning. A German radio station, plucked from the Internet, rendered a flavor of home.

headline: As Parents Make Their Own Baby Food, Industry Tries to Adapt
abstract: Sales of commercially prepared baby food have been steadily falling since 2005 as parents take a do-it-yourself approach.
lead_paragraph: Dylan DeNeve of Brooklyn dined on homemade baby food of vegetable purées, delicately seasoned with leeks, red peppers, cumin and thyme, prepared by her mother, Alexandra, a lawyer. In Atlanta, Wes and Hadley Stewart enjoyed homemade mashed-up kale, butternut squash and ancient grains.

headline: Suit Claims Drug Free Sport Mishandled Tests
abstract: A former vice president said she was terminated after reporting her concerns over the handling of an N.F.L. player’s positive test to her boss at the National Center for Drug Free Sport.
lead_paragraph: A senior executive at the company that oversees drug testing for the N.C.A.A., the N.F.L., the N.B.A., Major League Baseball and several other top sports organizations claimed in a lawsuit filed this week that she was fired after she voiced concerns about the handling of a football player’s positive drug test.

headline: A Walmart Fortune, Spreading Charter Schools
abstract: The foundation led by the family that built Walmart has spent more than $1 billion on some of the fastest-growing, and most divisive, trends in education.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — DC Prep operates four charter schools here with 1,200 students in preschool through eighth grade. The schools, whose students are mostly poor and black, are among the highest performing in Washington. Last year, DC Prep’s flagship middle school earned the best test scores among local charter schools, far outperforming the average of the city’s traditional neighborhood schools as well.

headline: Tea Bars, a New Kind of Watering Hole
abstract: Several new establishments seek to spread the sublime delights of teatime with workshops, tastings and special events.
lead_paragraph: At Infuse Tea Bar in West Sayville on a recent evening, Kristine Henderson, 42, the owner, demonstrated the “slurp, swish and swallow” technique to six would-be aficionados. “You aerate the tea in your mouth and you coat the taste buds, so you can experience all the aromas and subtle flavors,” she said as the class sampled the first of six Japanese teas.

headline: Refugees of Irish Famine to Get a Proper Burial
keywords: ['Cemeteries', 'Irish-Americans', 'Famine', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: On Sunday, deceased immigrants, who died in quarantine after sailing into the New York Harbor, will be given a more formal ceremony at Moravian Cemetery on Staten Island.
lead_paragraph: James Riley, 40, died of dysentery after 21 days in a hospital on Staten Island. The year was 1849, and across the ocean the Irish potato famine was at its peak, sending tens of thousands of starving people onto ships bound for New York City.

headline: Nigerian Movie Appears to Hit Nerve Over War
abstract: “Half of a Yellow Sun” was scheduled to open in Nigeria on Friday, but the country’s film censorship board has refused to issue the movie a certificate, effectively banning it.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — A Nigerian film dealing with one of the most searing episodes in the nation’s history, its civil war, and uniting some of Nigeria’s major cultural figures, has been effectively banned there, the film’s director said Friday evening.

headline: Kebabs With a Side of Belly Dancing
abstract: A Waterbury restaurant evokes an Ottoman sumptuousness, offering unusual entertainment along with generous servings.
lead_paragraph: It was my good fortune to be at Sultans Turkish Restaurant in Waterbury on a Saturday night, when a belly dancer performs. My appetizer of izgara kalamar had just been served, but my scant attention to those tender morsels of charbroiled squid had less to do with the shapely young woman gyrating by my table than with the razor-sharp saber she was brandishing above our heads.

headline: A Test of Togetherness That One Team Is Passing
abstract: The word “together” has become loaded in the Grizzlies-Thunder series, which involves teams with different philosophies. One operates a sharing-is-caring offensive system, while the other relies on a superstar tandem.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — Before Russell Westbrook fulfilled his obligations with the news media on Friday, he pulled a pair of long camouflage shorts over his practice shorts. It seemed less like a fashion statement — always a possibility with Westbrook — than a strategic decision as the Oklahoma City Thunder sought to defend themselves from questions about their predicament in the first round of the playoffs.

headline: New York’s Medicaid Challenge
keywords: ['Medicaid', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Editorials', 'Emergency Medical Treatment']
abstract: The state will need to make sure that an infusion of federal funds generates real reform.
lead_paragraph: New York State will receive a welcome infusion of $8 billion in federal funds over the next five years to improve the delivery of health care for the state’s poorest residents while saving billions in unnecessary hospital and emergency room costs. The money will be allocated to providers throughout the state, but it could be especially helpful in salvaging and reshaping failing hospitals in Brooklyn whose threatened closures have sparked community protests and brought pledges of assistance from Mayor Bill de Blasio and Gov. Andrew Cuomo.

headline: Casinos in the Exurbs
abstract: The new operations should be placed only in communities that want them, and not close to New York City.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has championed adding casinos in New York as a way to revive the upstate economy. There are plenty of concerns about whether giant casinos would actually bring well-paid jobs and sustained economic vitality to desolate areas. However, voters approved a constitutional amendment last year to allow seven casino complexes; a companion bill allowed four to be built over the next few years in upstate counties, but not in New York City or on Long Island.

headline: A Pantheon of the Feasts of Greece
abstract: The tiny restaurant, which has only seven tables, offers traditional dishes like skordalia, souvlaki and baklava.
lead_paragraph: Despite the crowds, the plastic-topped tables and the fake grapes hanging from the fake terra cotta tiles, you should dine at the Greek Village. The tiny restaurant, with only seven tables but a large takeout clientele, has been stubbornly resisting changes to its décor and, happily, its menu since opening in 1998.

headline: U.S. Says It Built Digital Programs Abroad With an Eye to Politics
abstract: The United States built Twitter-like programs in Afghanistan and Pakistan, but like a similar program in Cuba, they were shut down for lack of money, officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States built Twitter-like social media programs in Afghanistan and Pakistan, like one in Cuba, that were aimed at encouraging open political discussion, Obama administration officials said Friday. But like the program in Cuba, which was widely ridiculed when it became public this month, the services in Pakistan and Afghanistan shut down after they ran out of money because the administration could not make them self-sustaining.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 25, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: April 25, 2014

headline: Double Standards in Bankruptcies
keywords: ['Bankruptcies', 'Personal Bankruptcies', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Foreclosures', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Editorials']
abstract: In Detroit’s bust, even pensioners have to negotiate new terms; in the housing bust, banks did not have to negotiate with homeowners.
lead_paragraph: Developments in the Detroit bankruptcy have exposed a double standard in federal bankruptcy law, an injustice in urgent need of congressional reform.

headline: Retro Setting, Modern Diner Fare
abstract: Schnackenberg’s Luncheonette, a vintage spot reopened in December, serves a classic diner menu with a contemporary twist.
lead_paragraph: Schnackenberg’s Luncheonette, a vintage spot reopened in December by Joyce Flinn and her husband, Eugene, has chrome fixtures, an old-fashioned penny-tile floor and soda jerks behind the counter outfitted in bow ties and caps. But apart from the retro flavor and the friendly staff, it has little in common with the burger franchise Johnny Rockets, Ms. Flinn said. “If smiling, cheerful employees are the point of comparison, I don’t mind. But we’re a very different kind of restaurant,” said Ms. Flinn, 53, of Weehawken. “We’re not a chain. Nothing we have is prepackaged. Everything is made on the premises.”

headline: Wise Controls on E-Cigarettes
keywords: ['E-Cigarettes', 'Nicotine', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Smoking and Tobacco', 'Editorials']
abstract: The rules proposed by the F.D.A. would lay the foundation to protect the public from devices whose risks are largely unknown.
lead_paragraph: The rapidly growing electronic-cigarette business would finally be brought under regulatory supervision under long-delayed rules proposed by the Food and Drug Administration on Thursday. If the rules go into effect substantially as written, they will lay the foundation to protect the public from devices whose risks and benefits are largely unknown.

headline: Philadelphia Newspapers to Be Sold to Insiders
abstract: A judge ruled Friday that The Philadelphia Inquirer, Philadelphia Daily News and Philly.com would be sold at an auction open only to its existing owners.
lead_paragraph: A judge ruled Friday that The Philadelphia Inquirer, Philadelphia Daily News and Philly.com would be sold at an auction open only to its existing owners. It is the latest legal milestone in a battle between the wealthy, politically connected men who formed a partnerships to buy the publications in 2012, but have since fallen out over accusations of inappropriate influence exerted on the newsroom, and thrown them into turmoil. The ruling, by Delaware Chancery Court Judge Donald F. Parsons, was seen as a victory for one of the men, George E. Norcross III, a businessman and Democratic power broker in New Jersey. Another of the owners, Lewis Katz, the former owner of the New Jersey Nets, had fought for a public sale open to anyone. Mr. Norcross was accused of installing his daughter at the head of Philly.com and of influencing the dismissal of The Inquirer’s editor, William K. Marimow. He has denied any inappropriate behavior.

headline: Of Fox and the Cattle
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Land Use Policies', 'Ranches', 'Cattle', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: We have got to do something, people, to protect the word “freedom.” Did you hear how Crazy Rancher Guy used it in his defense?
lead_paragraph: So, what have we learned from the Crazy Rancher Guy saga?

headline: Pujols Issues a Reminder of His Place in History
abstract: In a resurgent year, the Angels’ Albert Pujols, who hit his 500th home run on Tuesday at 34, continues to put himself in exclusive statistical company.
lead_paragraph: The scoreboard at Tempe Diablo Stadium had to be wrong. That is what Raul Ibanez thought this spring, during an exhibition game for his new team, the Los Angeles Angels. Albert Pujols was hitting, and the statistics on the board startled Ibanez.

headline: A Rancher’s Romantic Revisionism
abstract: Fantasies about slavery must be met unequivocally with the strongest rebuttal, not given over to political squabbling.
lead_paragraph: It appears that Cliven Bundy, the 68-year-old rancher and freeloader, doesn’t reject only the federal government; he rejects history.

headline: A Veil, Rather Than a Mirror
abstract: Fresh and crunchy, by Evan Birnholz.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Dense and flavorful. That’s not my impression of a loaf of bread, but it’s how I felt about Evan Birnholz’s puzzle. Almost every entry I guessed turned out to be wrong, but when I was able to solve them correctly, I admired this puzzle greatly for the excellent, but tough, fill.

headline: Guard Is Changing, but a Sport’s Warden Remains the Same
abstract: Michael Phelps has brought attention to the pool; now it is up to swimmers like Justin Lynch and Michael Andrew to rise to the challenge of sending him back into retirement.
lead_paragraph: MESA, Ariz. — Lane 8 was where the future and the past of American men’s swimming converged Friday at a USA Swimming Grand Prix meet at Skyline Aquatic Center. In the three seeded preliminary heats of the men’s 50-meter freestyle, 17-year-old Justin Lynch gave way to the 22-time Olympic medalist Michael Phelps, who gave way to 15-year-old Michael Andrew.

headline: Republican Resigns From Bloomberg Gun Safety Group
abstract: Tom Ridge, George W. Bush’s secretary of homeland security, resigned from the board of Michael R. Bloomberg’s gun control group, citing his discomfort with the group’s political work.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Tom Ridge, the Homeland Security secretary under President George W. Bush, has unexpectedly resigned from the board of Michael R. Bloomberg’s new gun control effort, citing his discomfort with some of the political work the group has been planning.

headline: Tensions Mount in Bolivia as Soldiers Protest Career Obstacles
abstract: The military has dismissed 702 low-ranking officers who were protesting to draw attention to the advancement challenges they face in the armed forces.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Hundreds of soldiers continued street demonstrations as tensions mounted in Bolivia on Friday, a day after the military dismissed 702 low-ranking officers who were protesting to draw attention to the obstacles to advancement they face in the armed forces.

headline: City Suspends Dispatchers Over Ambulance Delay in Fatal Fire
keywords: ['Fires and Firefighters', 'Accidents and Safety', 'AMBULANCES', 'Emergency Medical Treatment']
abstract: Department investigators focus on why dispatchers failed to send ambulances to a home in Far Rockaway when firefighters confirmed a fire.
lead_paragraph: The city has suspended four emergency service dispatchers who were on duty in Queens last Saturday night when there was a delay in sending ambulances to a fire that killed two children in the Rockaways.

headline: Ice Cream Cones for Children and Loot for a Thief
keywords: ['Robberies and Thefts', 'Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts', 'Food Trucks']

lead_paragraph: His smile never wavers above his bright red bow tie. This is not a serious man — he has an ice cream cone for a head. And yet in the cheery world of Mister Softee, there are rules.

headline: Sensing Slight by Mayor, City Council Asserts Its Role in Land Use Process
keywords: ['Land Use Policies', 'Affordable Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'City Councils', 'Zoning', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: A week until Mayor Bill de Blasio presents a plan for affordable housing, the administration floated an idea that would give the mayor greater control over the byzantine land-use process.
lead_paragraph: For most of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s first few months in office, the City Council has been a reliable ally and cheerleader for his agenda of paid sick leave, prekindergarten expansion, and other ways to tackle income inequality. But some cracks have begun to show in the unified front that the mayor and the Council have presented since taking office in January.

headline: Detroit and Retirees Reach Deal in Bankruptcy Case
abstract: The deal adds to pacts already reached with pension fund leaders and others, and brings Detroit closer to paying back some of its overwhelming debts and emerging from bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: A court-appointed committee of Detroit retirees has reached a tentative agreement with the bankrupt city on cuts to their pensions and benefits. The deal adds to pacts already reached with pension fund leaders and others, and brings Detroit closer to paying back some of its overwhelming debts and emerging from bankruptcy.

headline: Flyers Even Series as Rangers Follow a Playoff Pattern
abstract: Steve Mason, the Flyers goalie, “owned his crease,” and the Rangers once again failed to take a two-game lead in a playoff series.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Making his first start of the playoffs, Philadelphia Flyers goalie Steve Mason stopped 37 of 38 shots by the Rangers on Friday night in a 2-1 victory at Wells Fargo Center that evened their opening-round playoff series at two games each, but the Rangers were not about to give Mason a lot of credit.

headline: Hans Hollein, Inventive Architect Who Designed With Wit, Dies at 80
abstract: Mr. Hollein, a Pritzker Prize winner, used not just line but unusual surfaces to make his artistic points.
lead_paragraph: Hans Hollein, a Pritzker Prize-winning architect who breathed witty postmodernist life into everything from buildings to pianos to tea trays, died on Thursday in his native Vienna. He was 80.

headline: Flyers, Up or Down a Man, Appear Headed in the Right Direction
abstract: The Flyers leaned on their special teams to win Game 4 against the Rangers, evening their series at two games each on a Jake Voracek power-play goal.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — When it was presented to Wayne Simmonds on Friday morning that the Flyers’ power play had been struggling for a while, he politely disagreed. It has been good all season, he said. The confidence is still there, he added.

headline: Nets Avoid Collapse and Put the Raptors in a Hole
abstract: The Raptors, who entered the fourth quarter trailing by 11, trimmed the Nets’ lead to 97-96 but fell behind in the series, 2-1.
lead_paragraph: Based on the quiet tones and the disappointed stares in the Nets’ locker room late Friday night, no one would have guessed that they had defeated the Toronto Raptors, 102-98, or that they had turned Barclays Center into a rollicking party, or that they had earned a critical 2-1 lead in their best-of-seven playoff series.

abstract: The New York City mayor has seemingly avoided Central Park and is struggling to turn public attention toward other issues on his agenda: housing and wages.
lead_paragraph: It is the iconic green space of New York City, internationally renowned and beloved by generations of natives and visitors alike.

lead_paragraph: The Yankees arrived in New York at 3 a.m. on Friday after an eventful seven-game trip in which they lost one starting pitcher to injury, lost another starter to suspension and played two draining series against division rivals, the Tampa Bay Rays and the Boston Red Sox.

headline: Turkish Leader Signs Bill Expanding Spy Agency’s Power

lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s president signed legislation on Friday that granted more authority to the national spy agency, a measure that critics say will bolster Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s control over state institutions.

headline: Rare Encore at the Met as Mexican Tenor Stirs Crowd

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9:40 A.M. (Starz Cinema) A WOMAN, A GUN AND A NOODLE SHOP (2010) In this faithful remake of Joel and Ethan Coen’s “Blood Simple” (1984), the director Zhang Yimou moves the action from modern-day Texas to a desolate valley in northwest China in the feudal past, above, where the wife (Yan Ni) of a rich and sexually sadistic noodle-shop owner, Wang (Ni Dahong), is carrying on with one of his employees (Xiao Shenyang). Then Zhang (Sun Honglei), a detective hired by Wang to kill the adulterous couple, arrives on the scene, and all hell breaks loose. “Though it begins with some exaggerated, almost clownish business and includes a handful of clean and mordant sight gags, ‘A Woman, a Gun and a Noodle Shop’ has a gravity that is surprising, given that it is basically the pastiche of a pastiche,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “But by working through the self-conscious genre imitation that was something of a novelty in ‘Blood Simple,’ Mr. Zhang uncovers the primal, mythic intensity of the story and also changes the tone of its essential nihilism. The Coens posit a universe without order or meaning, and while Mr. Zhang does not necessarily quarrel with this view, he treats it less as a cosmic joke than as a grim folk tale.”

headline: Trying to Save a Quiet Place on Staten Island
abstract: Despite demonstrations and a plea to Pope Francis, Mount Manresa, a retreat center for prayer and meditation since 1911, was sold to Savo Brothers, which plans to build 250 townhouses on the site.
lead_paragraph: For more than a century, rich and poor Catholics alike came to Mount Manresa, a Jesuit retreat center on Staten Island a mile from the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. From bricklayers to lawyers, from the poet Joyce Kilmer to Malcolm Wilson, the former New York governor, they stepped out of the workaday world and entered a silent space of prayer and meditation.

lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Australian authorities are likely to widen the underwater search for wreckage from the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 because an unmanned search vehicle has so far failed to find any trace of the missing jet on the seabed in a remote patch of the Indian Ocean, officials said Saturday.

headline: Sainthood for 2 Predecessors Allows Pope to Straddle Divide
abstract: John XXIII, revered by Roman Catholic liberals, and John Paul II, beloved by conservatives, will be recognized as saints at a Mass on Sunday as Pope Francis pushes his own vision of a church under a big tent.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Pope John XXIII was the rotund Italian pontiff with a common touch, who told jokes, embraced the poor and became beloved as “the Good Pope.” To many liberal Catholics, he is still revered for the Second Vatican Council, the landmark event of the 1960s that sought to move the Roman Catholic Church into the modern age.

abstract: Notable quotes from business articles that appeared in The New York Times last week.

Companies are selling social bots, lines of code built to behave like people on social media sites, to provide things like Twitter retweets and Facebook “likes.”

abstract: To a 22-year-old actor, a job at a popular Manhattan bar sounded enticing — and lucrative. But a degenerative eye disease quickly got in her way.

headline: Afghan Voters Signaling a Turn

lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Abdullah Abdullah, a longtime opponent of President Hamid Karzai and an ardent supporter of the United States, emerged Saturday as the clear front-runner in Afghanistan’s presidential election.

headline: Suspect in Stabbing at Connecticut School Is Described as Popular
abstract: The young man, who is accused of killing a classmate at a high school on the morning of the junior prom, is being held at a medical facility under psychiatric evaluation, his lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: MILFORD, Conn. — Jonathan Law High School has not known much tumult. Students here are often too involved in sports, music or volunteer work to get in much trouble, staff members said, and the biggest source of friction is the annual game between the school football team, known as the Lawmen, and its crosstown rival.

headline: Afghan Panel Claims to Find Secret Prisons
abstract: The commission appointed by President Hamid Karzai said it discovered unlawful prisons run by American and British forces.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A commission appointed by President Hamid Karzai to investigate detention facilities run by American and British forces in southern Afghanistan claimed Saturday to have uncovered secret prisons on two coalition bases, an allegation that could not be immediately confirmed but that was likely to further complicate relations between the Afghan government and its allies.

headline: Variety: Split Decisions

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking: April 25, 2014
abstract: This week, Joe discusses Warren Buffett’s failure to take a stand against excessive executive compensation.
lead_paragraph: Warren Buffett is perhaps the country’s most respected investor, known for making thoughtful, common-sense decisions. Which is why this week the business world took note when he abstained from voting against a pay package for executives at Coca-Cola that he called excessive. This week on Money Talking, regular contributors Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar weigh in on Buffett’s motivation and what it says about the state of corporate boards in America. Plus, a discussion of why a 700-page book — “Capital in the Twenty-First Century” by French economist Thomas Piketty — is topping the charts on Amazon.

headline: Laying Foundation With Playoff Frenzy
abstract: Paul Pierce and Kevin Garnett were brought to Brooklyn for moments like Friday’s Game 3, the former bringing his trademark cool in the clutch and the latter generating his heat to fire up the masses.
