headline: The Bodies That Guard Our Secrets
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Kosher Foods and Products', 'Slaughterhouses', 'ANATOMY AND PHYSIOLOGY', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: I went to a kosher slaughterhouse, for a lesson on anatomy and mortality.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I was a medical student elbow deep in the abdominal fat of my cadaver, and neck deep in the Latin names of body parts, I decided to visit a kosher slaughterhouse. I wanted to get some real-life perspective on all the anatomical terms I had been painstakingly memorizing for exams. And what better way to get perspective on anatomy than to learn how muscles become meat? Cattle and humans have similar anatomy, after all — the muscles just have different names. Cattle have the filet mignon, and we have the psoas major muscle. They have the rib eye, and we have the erector spinae.

headline: For Some, the Effort to Keep Up on the Ice All Season Begins in Sweltering Heat
abstract: Several N.H.L. players, including the Rangers’ Martin St. Louis and Brad Richards, endure intense off-season workouts to sustain their fitness through a long N.H.L. season.
lead_paragraph: DARIEN, Conn. — The veteran forwards Martin St. Louis and Brad Richards are thriving for the Rangers in the N.H.L. playoffs, and their intense summer workouts may be one reason.

headline: A Winning Braves Recipe No Matter the Ingredients
abstract: Atlanta began the season missing three-fifths of its starting rotation but their replacements have helped the Braves stay in first in the N.L. East with the league’s top E.R.A.
lead_paragraph: The Atlanta Braves had reason to feel confident in early March. They were coming off their third playoff appearance in four seasons and had signed several core players to long-term contract extensions.

headline: Vapor Boomtown
keywords: ['E-Cigarettes', 'Smoking and Tobacco', 'Nicotine', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Consumer Protection', 'Smoking - tips on how to quit']
abstract: With little regulation, Oklahoma City has become an e-cigarette boomtown where “vapers” flock to vapor shops to buy the smoking alternative products, which include nicotine liquids.
lead_paragraph: With little regulation, Oklahoma City has become an e-cigarette boomtown where “vapers” flock to vapor shops to buy the smoking alternative products, which include nicotine liquids.

headline: Slow, Grinding Strategy of Inflicting Syria Misery
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The government may have the upper hand, but its forces are worn down, heavily dependent on outside assistance and unable to reclaim large sections of the country from rebels.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In the Syrian village of Tamana, residents braced themselves as the sound of a helicopter overhead signaled an impending attack. A barrel bomb fell, but after its familiar, destructive blast, an unexpected noxious gas filled the air.

headline: Where Vapor Comes Sweeping Down the Plain
keywords: ['E-Cigarettes', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Smoking and Tobacco', 'State Legislatures', 'Series']
abstract: Regulators may be starting to circle, but in Oklahoma, the e-cigarette industry is going full steam ahead.
lead_paragraph: Nick Whitson, who is 32 and covered with enigmatic tattoos — the number 13, an upside-down cross — stood in front of a table scattered with dozens of bottles of colorful liquids and a handful of syringes, preparing to mix Trevor Curren his usual.

headline: Reporter Digging Into Scandal Hits a University’s Raw Nerve
abstract: The University of North Carolina has been at odds with a journalist for a Raleigh newspaper over his exposés of academic malfeasance at the university, some of it relating to athletes.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — There have been violent threats, angry screeds, Twitter flame campaigns and an entire website predicated on the putative hideousness of Dan Kane’s existence. Someone sent Kane an email wishing him a lingering death by bone cancer. Someone else tweeted him a photograph of a noose.

headline: Writing in a Nonstop World
abstract: Our interactions with computers have gone from brief and long to frequent and glancing. That difference is changing how we write, how we relate to each other, and how we build things. What happens when the interactions become nonstop?
lead_paragraph: We give time a hard time. We take it, steal it, spend it and waste it. Thanks to computers, now we’re chopping time up into ever-smaller fragments.

headline: Governor With Eye on 2016 Finds His Rise Under Scrutiny
abstract: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, a potential Republican contender for president, has steadily gained prominence assisted by his knack for recognizing and seizing political opportunities.
lead_paragraph: STURTEVANT, Wis. — Scott Walker is nothing if not consistent.

headline: Clinging to Mets in a Rising Tide of Yankees Fans
abstract: Facebook data shows that the Yankees are favored over the Mets throughout New York, even in neighborhoods close to Citi Field.
lead_paragraph: Michael Zampino leaned in and lowered his voice to a whisper, so that maybe his customers would not hear him. There was a long line forming outside his shop, the Lemon Ice King of Corona, on Tuesday afternoon, and he did not want to offend anyone.

headline: Exhaustion Prevails; So Does Generosity
abstract: The scene at this year’s Boston Marathon was filled with a compassionate spirit similar to the days after the 9/11 terrorist attacks.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Joan Benoit Samuelson, the 1984 Olympic champion, had simple but practical advice for a first-timer at the Boston Marathon.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 27
abstract: Faltering peace negotiations in the Middle East and escalating tensions in eastern Ukraine will keep the Sunday shows conversations focused on foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli government halted peace negotiations with the Palestinians on Thursday because of a unity agreement announced on Wednesday between two rival Palestinian factions, the Palestine Liberation Organization and the militant group Hamas.

headline: The Feast of Pain
abstract: It is a joy to discover that most everyone is secretly as wretched as I am.
lead_paragraph: LAST week my friend Mishka and I, wistful about a popular sedative of the 1970s that neither of us even got the opportunity to resist the temptation to take, went to search for “Do they still make ’ludes” on the Internet. Before we could finish typing the words “do they” the search engine autofilled “still make quaaludes.”

headline: A Time of Soul-Searching, Not Cynicism
abstract: “South Pacific,” Rodgers and Hammerstein’s classic tale of love, race and acceptance, is in fine form at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn.
lead_paragraph: They don’t bring down the house in “South Pacific.” But boy, do they light up the room.

headline: Attack on Journalist Starts Battle in Pakistani Press
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Accusations that the country’s spy agency was involved in the attack have led to a divisive debate and demands that a television station be shut down.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For a time, Pakistan’s journalists were seen as messy champions of democracy: brave if sometimes flawed truth-tellers who helped oust the military ruler Gen. Pervez Musharraf and held up a critical mirror to their tempestuous country.

headline: Union Effort at Northwestern May Not Mean Much for Public Colleges
keywords: ['College Athletics', 'Organized Labor', 'Collective Bargaining', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Football (College)', 'Basketball (College)']
abstract: The vast majority of Division I universities are public but the National Labor Relations Board has no power over them, only over private-sector employers like Northwestern.
lead_paragraph: Many football and basketball players at Michigan State, Connecticut and other state universities are no doubt wondering what the Northwestern decision means for them.

headline: Is A Banking Ban The Answer?
abstract: Interestin, but problematic.
lead_paragraph: OK, a genuinely interesting debate on financial reform is taking place. I’m not even sure where I stand. But it’s certainly worth talking about.

headline: The Media Has a Woman Problem
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Women and Girls', 'Newspapers', 'Careers and Professions']
abstract: A new study shows a stubborn gender disparity.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THEY were, to a man, men. All were white; all in their 40s or thereabouts; most had dark hair. It was the mid-1990s, and I was interviewing at The Washington Post for the job of managing editor of the Sunday magazine. A morning of intimidating meetings with newsroom officials had given way to lunch with the magazine’s editors and elite staff writers.

headline: Obama’s High-Profile Tour of Asia Hits Speed Bumps
abstract: No trade agreement with Japan, and vitriol from China.
lead_paragraph: A week in which President Obama had intended to add force to his strategic pivot to the East instead marked some pivotal setbacks to his foreign agenda. The president’s long-delayed trip to Asia failed to yield a trade deal with Japan and ran up against a new threat from North Korea, while both the Middle East peace process and a tentative agreement on Ukraine foundered in acrimony.

headline: A Birdbath-Size Hole and the Future of Golf
abstract: The stewards of golf might want to think twice before tinkering with the golf hole.
lead_paragraph: SOME dimensions are sacred. From home plate to first base is always 90 feet, a distance arrived at perhaps accidentally on some 19th-century cow field in upstate New York but one that has endured despite all the changes in baseball. A basketball hoop is still 10 feet off the floor even though giants now play the game and stuff the ball downward while dangling off the rim. And a golf hole is four and a quarter inches in diameter, a measurement officially sanctioned in 1893 by the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews in Scotland but one that probably goes back long before that. The R & A, which is to golf what Moses was to the tablets, settled on four and a quarter inches because that’s how big the holes were at Musselburgh, where they began playing golf back in the 17th century.

headline: Unrelenting Will Toward Victory Drives Teenager
abstract: Katie Ledecky, 17, broke the world records in the 800 and the 1,500 freestyles at last summer’s world championships.
lead_paragraph: BETHESDA, Md. — The 25-yard freestyle taxed Katie Ledecky, who stopped three times during the 8-and-under girls’ race, clutching the lane line to catch her breath and wipe her nose. After finishing, Ledecky, then 6, climbed out of the pool and conducted an on-deck interview with her father, Dave. The home-video footage, which made Ledecky laugh when she watched it last week, foreshadowed the women’s distance swimming renaissance she spearheaded less than a decade later.

headline: Deborah A. P. Hersman
abstract: A safety expert’s life shaped by Nancy Drew mysteries and competitive country dancing.
lead_paragraph: Deborah A. P. Hersman stepped down this past week as chairwoman of the National Transportation Safety Board. The public will remember her as the cool presence on the ground after major aviation, rail, marine, highway and pipeline accidents. She leaves to become president and chief executive officer of the National Safety Council, a nonprofit devoted to preventing injuries and deaths through education and outreach.

headline: The Koch Attack on Solar Energy
keywords: ['Solar Energy', 'Taxation', 'Editorials', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Political Action Committees', 'Sales and Excise Taxes', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: The Koch brothers and other big polluters are spending heavily to block state incentives for renewable energy.
lead_paragraph: At long last, the Koch brothers and their conservative allies in state government have found a new tax they can support. Naturally it’s a tax on something the country needs: solar energy panels.

headline: A Master’s in Chick Lit
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: ‘Muscular prose’? I’ll take shirtless men instead.
lead_paragraph: I’m a genre writer. Gary Shteyngart hasn’t blurbed any of my novels, and Marion Ettlinger has never photographed me for a book jacket. I’m more at ease with the sequins and shirtless men at the Romantic Times conference than I am with the serious eyewear at poetry readings. When critics describe my work, which is basically chick lit, they don’t say it’s emotionally astute, sweeping or a tour de force. They call it “a fast-paced screamer.”

headline: Meaningful Progress With Iran
abstract: Investing in negotiations over Iran’s nuclear program is proving to be worth the risk.
lead_paragraph: With three months to go before the July deadline for a final agreement, Iran and the six major powers are still searching for ways to resolve differences over Iran’s nuclear program. Even so, the negotiations keep confounding skeptics by making steady progress and showing that investing in this process is worth the risk.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Our Choices for Schools
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Equal Educational Opportunities', 'Charter Schools']
abstract: Readers react to a letter calling for greater support of public schools rather than “school choice.”
lead_paragraph: Readers react to a letter calling for greater support of public schools rather than “school choice.”

headline: Disarmament for Spousal Abusers
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Law and Legislation', 'Domestic Violence', 'Editorials', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: A new law in Washington State will require spouses under domestic abuse orders to surrender their guns, and surprisingly, the N.R.A isn’t fighting against it.
lead_paragraph: The National Rifle Association’s annual convention this weekend in Indianapolis is featuring the usual array of tens of thousands of gun customers and dealers marveling at the latest in deadly weapons adapted for civilian life from the battlefields of war. Outside the massive gathering, a contingent from a gun safety group, Moms Demand Action for Gun Sense in America, planned to raise awareness about the gun crisis.

headline: The Angel in Larry Kramer
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Movies', 'Theater']
abstract: With an HBO movie of “The Normal Heart,” a complicated hero gets the tribute he’s due.
lead_paragraph: I LEARNED long ago to open my inbox with trepidation. A journalist is a magnet for complaints.

headline: The Pope’s Phone Call
abstract: Expectations of doctrinal changes on subjects like divorce and communion are growing, and that presents perils for Pope Francis.
lead_paragraph: THIS weekend in Rome, the Catholic Church is celebrating a double canonization — two popes, two sainthoods, 2,000 buses full of pilgrims — that serves as a kind of capstone on Pope Francis’s first year in office, and an illustration of his agenda for the church.

headline: Who Will Influence Whom?
abstract: As Russia pushes Ukraine, Ukraine pushes Europe.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — SOMETIMES the simplest question speaks the biggest truth. I was meeting with some Maidan activists here in Kiev last week, and we were talking about Russian President Vladimir Putin’s insistence that Ukraine was part of Russia’s traditional “sphere of influence” and “buffer zone” with the West, and, therefore, America and the European Union need to keep their hands off. At one point, one of the activists, the popular Ukrainian journalist, Vitali Sych, erupted: “Did anyone ask us whether we wanted to be part of his buffer zone?”

headline: Religion for $1,000, Alex
abstract: Americans are a nation of believers, all right. But do they really know what they’re believing in?
lead_paragraph: WITH Easter and Passover freshly behind us, let’s test your knowledge of the Bible. How many mistakes can you find:

headline: For Drugs That Save Lives, a Steep Cost
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Sovaldi (Drug)', 'Naloxone (Drug)', 'Medicine and Health', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Cost is the great taboo in U.S. health care. And we pay dearly.
lead_paragraph: THIS month, amid great fanfare, the Food and Drug Administration approved a portable pocket-size device that injects a drug called naloxone to rescue people who become unconscious from overdoses of heroin and other opiates. Wider dissemination of this antidote, long used in emergency rooms and by some first responders, will certainly save lives.

headline: A Tempestuous Manager Confronts a Challenging Week
abstract: Two matches in the next four days may determine whether Jose Mourinho will return as Chelsea’s manager.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — There are few more mercurial men in soccer than José Mourinho, and there have been few more mercurial moments for him than now, at a make-or-break point in the closing weeks of his first year back at Chelsea. Two matches in the next four days will determine whether Mourinho’s return to the manager’s job at Stamford Bridge will be triumphant, or an emblem of high promise unfulfilled.

headline: Getting Into the Ivies
abstract: Why is it harder than it used to be? Colleges are globalized.
lead_paragraph: Ask just about any high school senior or junior — or their parents — and they’ll tell you that getting into a selective college is harder than it used to be. They’re right about that. But the reasons for the newfound difficulty are not well understood.

headline: Answering Questions About New York
abstract: Readers ask about the significance of a lamppost, and a Horn & Hardart with waitress service.
lead_paragraph: Q. The space known as the Biltmore Room (a.k.a. the Kissing Room) has a history associated with Grand Central Terminal. The chalkboard schedule of long-defunct trains makes sense. But there is also a tall lamppost, with two streetlights, in a corner by the tracks and beside the chalkboard. What is its significance?

headline: Slaves to Prejudice
abstract: Home, home on the racist range, where the cows and the antelope play (for free).
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — WHEN a cranky anarchist in a cowboy hat starts a sentence saying “I want to tell you one more thing I know about the Negro,” you can be dang sure it’s going downhill from there.

headline: N.B.A. Investigating Racial Remarks Tied to Clippers Owner
abstract: The N.B.A. has started an investigation into racially charged comments allegedly made in a recording by Donald Sterling, the owner of the Los Angeles Clippers.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — The N.B.A. has promised a swift investigation into remarks attributed to the Los Angeles Clippers’ owner, Donald Sterling, after the release Friday night of an audio recording on the gossip website TMZ.com in which a person TMZ identified as Mr. Sterling admonished a female friend to avoid being seen in public with black people.

headline: Scott Walker’s Prospects
abstract: Wisconsin’s governor, Scott Walker, is being seen as a possible presidential candidate in 2016, and yet five years ago he was little known even in parts of his own state.
lead_paragraph: Wisconsin’s governor, Scott Walker, is being seen as a possible presidential candidate in 2016, and yet five years ago he was little known even in parts of his own state.

headline: Unlikely Cast for Yanks Pieces Together a Win
abstract: The Yankees used a start from Vidal Nuno, a solid relief outing from Dellin Betances and John Ryan Murphy’s best day in the majors to defeat the Los Angeles Angels.
lead_paragraph: Despite all the Yankees’ off-season spending, there will be days when they will have to piece together a win with parts culled from the minor leagues.

headline: Militants Resist Calls to Free European Military Observers Held in Eastern Ukraine
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Detainees']
abstract: At least seven officers from Germany, Poland, Sweden, the Czech Republic and Denmark were said to have been detained at a checkpoint outside of Slovyansk. The rebels suggested that they would consider a prisoner exchange.
lead_paragraph: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — Antigovernment militants in eastern Ukraine on Saturday rebuffed international calls for the release of a group of European military observers, but suggested that they would consider a prisoner exchange.

headline: Team Founded by Unhappy Fans May Buy the Club They Abandoned
abstract: Katamon, the first fan-owned soccer club in Israel, formed in 2007 when it walked away from the more established Hapoel Jerusalem. Now the two clubs are negotiating a reunion.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Breaking up the soccer club they loved was hard for fans of Hapoel Katamon Jerusalem. Putting it back together may prove even more difficult.

headline: Paul Cedes Some Control, at Least Until Game Is on the Line
abstract: Guard Chris Paul has learned to reserve that instinct to control every detail on the court, but he is still the Clippers frontman and the one who takes over down the stretch.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles Clippers guard Chris Paul is widely regarded as the premier point guard of his generation, a Hall of Fame contender who is a genius with the ball in his hands and a disruptive defensive presence. He has made first team all-N.B.A. three times and finished in the top five in most valuable player voting four times. But for all his accolades, Paul lags behind his peers in postseason accomplishments.

headline: Wizards Relish the Playoffs and the Long Lines
abstract: Some fans are suddenly aware that the Wizards exist and that the young team is the buzz of the N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Richard Galiffa went to grab a snack during halftime of Friday’s Washington Wizards game, he noticed something strange clogging the concourse of Verizon Center: dozens of men standing in a line.

headline: Coaching Duo Adjusts for Family
abstract: Clarkson won the N.C.A.A. women’s title last month under the husband-and-wife team of Matt and Shannon Desrosiers. But Shannon is stepping down to devote more time to their family.
lead_paragraph: One of hockey’s more unusual coaching arrangements turned out to be one of the most successful, as Clarkson won the N.C.A.A. women’s title last month under the husband-and-wife team of Matt and Shannon Desrosiers.

headline: Recapturing Heart of a Derby Upset
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Movies', 'Mine That Bird (Race Horse)', 'Kentucky Derby', 'Jockeys, Drivers and Trainers']
abstract: “50 to 1” details the hard-to-believe victory of Mine That Bird in the 2009 Kentucky Derby, and the rough-hewed cast that surrounded the horse.
lead_paragraph: When the filmmaker and horse owner Jim Wilson watched on television as the gelding Mine That Bird squirted through a hole on the rail in the homestretch to run away with the 2009 Kentucky Derby, he knew the story was movie material. An even deeper story emerged as Mine That Bird’s jockey, Calvin Borel, succumbed to his emotions, and the horse’s connections, the trainer Chip Woolley and the owners Mark Allen and Dr. Leonard Blach, gathered in the winner’s circle.

headline: Predictable Partings
abstract: Predictable partings, by John Lampkin.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Some people have a high tolerance for puns, and others have a much lower threshold. I consider Tom Swifty-style puns to be the “pie-in-the-face,” slapstick form of puns, because they are just so obvious.

headline: World Champion Shows Vulnerability in Azerbaijan
abstract: Magnus Carlsen lost last week to Fabiano Caruana after making a mistake that left him vulnerable.
lead_paragraph: It once seemed almost impossible to defeat a world champion.

headline: In California, a Fevered Rush for Gun Permits
abstract: The flood shows the frustration of California gun owners and the complicated politics of weapon regulation in a state with a large catalog of gun control legislation.
lead_paragraph: SANTA ANA, Calif. — Pete Alexander celebrated the news that a federal court in California had thrown out this state’s strict requirements for obtaining a concealed-handgun permit — among the toughest in the nation — by calling the Orange County Sheriff’s Department to apply for a permit he had long wanted.

headline: Nature Is All Around, but an Ornate House Is a Draw in Islip
abstract: Some visitors to the Suffolk County Environmental Center are drawn less by the outdoor attractions than by the 27-room mansion on the grounds.
lead_paragraph: The Suffolk County Environmental Center in Islip sees far more outdoor than indoor visitors. Nature enthusiasts flock to the 70-acre property’s expansive salt marsh, forests and freshwater wetlands, as well as to the outdoor education programs put on by the Seatuck Environmental Association, the nonprofit conservation group that runs the center for the county.

headline: Old Story in Politics Resonates in New Era
abstract: A documentary called “All About Ann: Governor Richards of the Lone Star State” is to premiere on Monday on HBO.
lead_paragraph: An ambitious female politician, well-regarded by her constituents but not very well known outside of Texas, delivers a galvanizing speech that thrusts her into the national spotlight. Seizing her political moment, she runs for governor — and soon finds herself in a knock-down, drag-out fight with the male, Republican-establishment candidate.

headline: Yonkers as Gallery
abstract: Yonkers Arts Weekend aims to showcase the breadth of artistic activity throughout the city with exhibitions, performances and public art.
lead_paragraph: A video installation in a pop-up gallery, a fashion show in a garden, artist studio tours — these and more are part of the first Yonkers Arts Weekend. Organized by the City of Yonkers, the event next weekend aims to showcase the breadth of artistic activity throughout the city with exhibitions, performances and public art.

headline: Once a Legislator, Now an Underdog Trying to Return
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Norma Chávez, a former state representative known as a divisive figure, is facing a former congressional staffer in a May 27 runoff, and she is hoping her new perspective will attract voters.
lead_paragraph: EL PASO — In a modest office in east central El Paso, former State Representative Norma Chávez spoke recently of her spiritual journey and weekly prayer group, and how she is 30 pounds lighter after adopting a healthier lifestyle. It is all part of a new perspective on life that she hopes will usher her back into the State Legislature after four years away from Austin.

headline: How a Gulf Settlement That BP Once Hailed Became Its Target
keywords: ['Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: In ads, interviews and court filings, BP officials have insisted that their good intentions in settling the 2010 Gulf of Mexico spill were being hijacked by greedy lawyers and underhanded claimants.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Four years ago the Deepwater Horizon oil rig caught fire and exploded, killing 11 men, spewing millions of barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico and staining, seemingly indelibly, the image of BP, the international energy giant responsible for the well.

headline: New Law Is Limiting Standardized Tests, but Not Prep Work
abstract: Despite a provision to reduce the time Texas students spend practicing for standardized tests in the classroom, there are continued concerns about an overemphasis on test preparation.
lead_paragraph: When Texas legislators passed a law in 2013 that sharply reduced standardized testing for public high school students, they included a provision aimed at easing the pressure of high-stakes exams for students in lower grades as well.

headline: Easy to Target, but Often Hard to Send Packing
abstract: A Texas House committee is considering whether Wallace Hall, the University of Texas System regent appointed by the governor, should be impeached.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: A Marriage of Visual Masters
abstract: The Katonah Museum of Art is offering an exhibition showcasing work from the decades-long relationship of the master printer John Lund and the artist Jasper Johns.
lead_paragraph: “Take an object. Do something to it. Do something else to it.” These oft-cited instructions were written by Jasper Johns as directives to himself, and they are particularly suited to his work in printmaking, with its multi-stepped process and its toolbox of techniques. But to “do something” and then “do something else” when printing requires skilled assistance.

headline: The History of Religion, Beginning with Noah and his Wife, Joan of Arc
abstract: The backdrop for my column about the ongoing relevance of religious knowledge
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column looks at the importance of humanities, not least an area that even humanities enthusiasts sometimes scoff at–religious knowledge. My column argues that if we want to understand the world, it helps to know a bit about the world’s religions, including the world of Pentecostals and evangelicals that rarely make the news. I became interested in the role of religion in part in 2000 when I covered the campaign of George W. Bush, for it was clear that he was connecting to a large number of Americans through his faith, and I had only the vaguest idea at the time what an evangelical was. Then in covering America and the developing world alike, I was struck by the extraordinary surge in Pentecostal churches, and by their influence over so many people around the world.

headline: My Head Talks Yet Again
abstract: Will no one silence it?
lead_paragraph: On Stephanopoulos tomorrow. As I understand it, William Kristol and I will debate whether multiplicative shocks to wealth accumulation really do cause the right tail of the distribution to approximate a power law.

headline: The Elegance of Clattering Machines
abstract: The exhibition “Click! Clack! Ding! The American Typewriter,” at the New Britain Museum of American Art, tells a story about the incremental way in which technology progresses.
lead_paragraph: The labels alone make a racket: Meiselbach, Blickensderfer, Bar-Lock. No wonder the show-namers at the New Britain Museum of American Art call their fabulous little exhibition of antique typewriters “Click! Clack! Ding!”

headline: One Mother, 7 Dead Newborns and a Stunned Community in Utah
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: The tale of a profoundly troubled woman and her dead children has again cast a national glare on the most intimate and inexplicable kind of crime.
lead_paragraph: PLEASANT GROVE, Utah — For Megan Huntsman, life was a miserable struggle. Her marriage decayed into substance abuse and violence, she told people close to her. Her ailing father’s suicide pitched her into despair and heavy drinking. Illness ravaged her family. She lost her job at a supermarket bakery and spent recent days alone at her boyfriend’s trailer home.

headline: In Poorest States, Political Stigma Is Depressing Participation in Health Law
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Political Advertising', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Officials say the health care law has been stigmatized for many it could help, especially in states that are medically underserved but hostile to President Obama.
lead_paragraph: HUNTINGTON, W.Va. — Inside the sleek hillside headquarters of Valley Health Systems, built with a grant from the health care law, two employees played an advertisement they had helped produce to promote the law’s insurance coverage for young, working-class West Virginians.

headline: A Hidden Chapter in World War II History
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Theater']
abstract: Roger Grunwald is bringing “The Mitzvah,” his one-man play about the Holocaust, to three locations in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: In 2009, Roger Grunwald, an actor, traveled to Los Angeles to interview his aunt, Anne M. Bodenheimer, about her experiences in World War II, including in the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp. His mother, Lotte, Mrs. Bodenheimer’s sister, had survived Auschwitz and had often spoken to young people about her history.

headline: Mollusks, but No Tiles, No Trains
abstract: The Brooklyn outpost of the Grand Central Oyster Bar caters to new and old neighbors alike.
lead_paragraph: This is not your commuter’s Grand Central Oyster Bar. What gave it away? Is it that at the Brooklyn outpost of the Grand Central Oyster Bar there’s actual space to relax and a decibel level conducive to conversation?

headline: Scots Ponder: Should They Stay or Should They Go?
abstract: Over the last six months the momentum has shifted toward independence, but some fear the fervor that it is creating on either side of the campaign.
lead_paragraph: EDINBURGH — The Royal Lyceum Theater here has a modest hit on its hands, a slightly scabrous play that tells the story of Scotland’s parliamentary vote to dissolve itself and join the kingdom of England in 1707.

headline: New York Finds Space for 3 Charter Schools
abstract: The schools had been at the heart of a battle between Mayor Bill de Blasio and Eva S. Moskowitz, the leader of a high-performing charter network.
lead_paragraph: The office of Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York announced on Saturday that it has found space for three charter schools that had been at the heart of a battle between the new mayor and Eva S. Moskowitz, the leader of a high-performing charter network.

headline: Bruins Advance and Are Set to Rekindle Rivalry
abstract: The resilient Red Wings made things interesting, but the Bruins never trailed in a 4-2 victory that set up a series against the hated Canadiens.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Chants of “We Want the Cup” reverberated through TD Garden on Saturday in the final minutes of the Boston Bruins’ 4-2 Game 5 victory over the Detroit Red Wings. But while the fans were happy to usher the Red Wings out of the arena and the series, they were no doubt looking toward the Bruins’ next matchup, against the vaunted and hated Montreal Canadiens.

headline: George McDonald, 90, Dies; Union Leader Helped Save Newspaper Jobs
abstract: Mr. McDonald helped navigate organized labor’s orderly retreat from its peak of power in the industry in New York and, by some accounts, helped preserve the city’s surviving tabloids.
lead_paragraph: George E. McDonald, a union leader who helped navigate organized labor’s orderly retreat from its peak of power in the New York newspaper industry at the end of the century and, by some accounts, helped save the city’s surviving tabloids, died last Sunday in Monmouth Park, N.J. He was 90.

headline: South Korean Prime Minister Offers to Resign Over Deadly Ferry Disaster
abstract: Prime Minister Chung Hong-won, the No. 2 official in the South Korean government, offered “an apology to the people.”
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Prime Minister Chung Hong-won, the No. 2 official in the South Korean government, apologized and offered to resign on Sunday, as the country remained angry and saddened over the sinking of a ferry that left 302 people, a vast majority of them high school students, dead or missing.

headline: N.B.A. Commissioner Promises Swift Investigation of Remarks
abstract: Adam Silver said the league would move quickly as it tried to prove the authenticity of racially charged statements reportedly made by Donald Sterling, the Clippers’ owner.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver said Saturday night that the league planned to pursue a swift investigation of the Los Angeles Clippers’ owner, Donald Sterling, after the release of an audio recording in which Sterling was alleged to have made racially charged remarks.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 26, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: April 26, 2014

headline: Mahmoud Abbas Shifts on Holocaust
abstract: The president of the Palestinian Authority issued a formal statement calling the Holocaust “the most heinous crime to have occurred against humanity in the modern era.”
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority issued a formal statement on Sunday calling the Holocaust “the most heinous crime to have occurred against humanity in the modern era” and expressing sympathy with victims’ families.

headline: ‘Orphan Black’ Recap: The Clones Versus the Monitors
abstract: Mrs. S shows her true colors.
lead_paragraph: As he lay dying, a wise man once told Agent Scully on “The X-Files” to “Trust no one.”

headline: David W. Burke, Trusted Aide to Powerful Men, Dies at 78
abstract: An adviser to politicians and businessmen, Mr. Burke became president of CBS News and was appointed chairman of the Broadcasting Board of Governors by President Bill Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Senator Edward M. Kennedy had a habit of taking long walks with his closest aide, David W. Burke, before making big decisions. As secretary to Gov. Hugh L. Carey, Mr. Burke helped New York City navigate the 1970s fiscal crisis, partly by recommending that he hire Felix Rohatyn as financial wizard in chief.

headline: Annual NYC Sikh Day Parade
abstract: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio participated in the Sikh day festivities on Madison Avenue.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio, third from left, attended the Annual NYC Sikh Day Parade in Midtown on Saturday.

headline: A Young Pitcher and Catcher Show They Still Need Work
abstract: Saturday’s outing proved Jenrry Mejia is still an unfinished product as he unraveled in the sixth inning, giving up five earned runs and relinquishing the Mets’ 5-1 lead.
lead_paragraph: Travis d’Arnaud, the Mets’ 25-year-old second-year catcher, is only eight months older than starting pitcher Jenrry Mejia, but d’Arnaud knows that his input is just as crucial to Mejia’s growth as the blazing fastballs that come out of his electric right arm.

headline: A Disturbing Tape and a Potential Moral Quandary
abstract: Should the allegations of racist comments made by Clippers owner Donald Sterling turn out to be true, it will be fascinating to see how players on the Clippers and around the league respond.
lead_paragraph: In one of his popular songs of black consciousness, Curtis Mayfield asked: “If you had a choice of colors, which one would you choose, my brothers? If there was no day or night, which would you prefer to be right?”

headline: Reaction to the Remarks Linked to Donald Sterling
abstract: A report attributing racial remarks to the L.A. Clippers owner set off intense reaction on social media about Donald Sterling’s future as his team competes in the N.B.A. playoffs.
lead_paragraph: President Obama condemned the “incredibly offensive racist statements” attributed to the Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling during a press conference on Sunday in Malaysia.
