lead_paragraph: Clara Bingham and Joseph Gregory Finnerty III were married Saturday at the River Café in Brooklyn. Mayor Bill de Blasio officiated.

headline: Counterpoints to Offensive Remarks
abstract: A report that Donald Sterling made offensive remarks about black players elicited swift reaction on social media. Current and former players, entertainers and ordinary people chimed in using hashtags like #DonaldSterling, #Sterling and #boycottclippers.
lead_paragraph: A report that Donald Sterling made offensive remarks about black players elicited swift reaction on social media. Current and former players, entertainers and ordinary people chimed in using hashtags like #DonaldSterling, #Sterling and #boycottclippers.

headline: Superstars Come Second to Culture at Jazzfest
abstract: Now in its 45th year, Jazzfest is joyously obsessed with the cultural traditions of New Orleans and Louisiana, and the regional flavor comes through in virtually everything a visitor encounters.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — If you talk to someone in the music business these days about outdoor festivals, you’ll probably hear a lot about electronic dance music, or E.D.M. Big name-D.J.’s have become part of the formula for any major pop festival, and there is even a publicly traded company, SFX Entertainment, devoted to attracting corporate sponsors to dance events.

headline: Sanctions Revive Search for Secret Putin Fortune
abstract: President Obama’s response to the Ukraine crisis, while derided by critics as slow and weak, has reinvigorated a 15-year global hunt for the Russian leader’s hidden wealth.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Obama administration imposed sanctions on individual Russians last month in response to Moscow’s armed intervention in Ukraine, one of the targets was a longtime part-owner of a commodities trading company called the Gunvor Group.

headline: Corrections: April 27, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on April 27, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: China Orders 4 U.S. Shows Off Streaming Sites
abstract: After years of allowing foreign TV shows on Chinese streaming video websites, skirting broadcast censorship, the government is moving to close the loophole.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Chinese regulators have ordered streaming video websites nationwide to take down four popular American TV series, a move that precedes new regulations seeking to close a loophole that has allowed foreign shows to flourish online, even as censors have limited them on broadcast television.

headline: South Korean Leader Accepts Resignation of Premier Over Ferry Disaster
abstract: President Park Geun-hye accepted the resignation of Prime Minister Chung Hong-won but asked him to stay in his post until the government completed its rescue operations, an official said.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Prime Minister Chung Hong-won, the No. 2 official in the South Korean government, apologized and offered to resign on Sunday, as the country remained angry and saddened over the sinking of a ferry that left 302 people, the vast majority of them high school students, dead or missing.

headline: In Malaysia, Obama Works to Mend Troubled Ties
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Rohingya (Ethnic Group)', 'Malaysia Airlines Flight 370']
abstract: President Obama’s visit to Malaysia underscored the change in the country’s attitude toward the United States, from deep suspicion to a desire for cooperation.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — The last time a top American official visited this Southeast Asian nation was in 1998, when Vice President Al Gore publicly rebuked its leaders for suppressing freedom and embraced “reformasi,” the rallying cry of the student-led protest movement.

headline: In Our Pages: April 28
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Events to popularize French cheese are held in New York in 1939; United States restricts advertising for cigarettes in 1964.
lead_paragraph: 1939: Cheese Parties in N.Y. to Promote French Products

headline: A Fully Wrought Life – Stones Pianist, Tree Farmer, Green Blog Pioneer
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Environment', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: A rock keyboard luminary talks about his environmental website and love of growing and using trees.
lead_paragraph: Any time you think you’re packing as much into your life as is humanly possible, you meet someone who has taken things to another level.

headline: On Historic Day, John XXIII and John Paul II Become Saints
abstract: Before large, joyous crowds in Rome, Pope Francis performed a joint canonization on Sunday for his papal predecessors, whom he portrayed as “men of courage” with a shared place in history.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Pope Francis made history on Sunday, elevating to sainthood John XXIII and John Paul II, two of his most famous papal predecessors, in a ceremony bearing themes of hope and reconciliation for the world’s one billion Roman Catholics.

headline: When a Working Grandma Can’t Afford to Babysit, a Tradition Ends
keywords: ['Child Care', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Grandparents', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: My great-grandmother cared for my mom and aunt while my grandparents worked. My grandmother cared for me and my sister while my parents worked. But my mom can’t afford to do the same for me.
lead_paragraph: My mother trudged down the stairs of her Staten Island townhouse this past Christmas Day, head slumped down, Eeyore-style. Even with my inherited poor eyesight, I could see from her modest kitchen table that the lenses on her dark, plastic glasses, a pair only a hip 57-year-old could pull off, were fogged up.

headline: France Defers G.E. Plan to Buy Energy Business
abstract: The French economy minister said economic sovereignty was at stake and that Siemens – Alstom’s German rival – was making an offer of its own.
lead_paragraph: PARIS – The French government on Sunday sought to put the brakes on General Electric‘s bid for Alstom, one of the largest industrial companies in France, warning that national interest was in play and that the state would have a say in the outcome.

headline: For Fitness Bands, Slick Marketing but Suspect Results
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Exercise', 'Mobile Applications', 'Watches and Clocks', 'Wearable Computing']
abstract: Despite rising demand, many devices claiming to monitor fitness and health probably overpromise and underdeliver.
lead_paragraph: My Nike FuelBand read lazy. My friend’s read fit.

headline: U.S. and Philippines Agree to a 10-Year Pact on the Use of Military Bases
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'Military Aircraft', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The accord will give American warships, planes and troops greater access to bases in the Philippines, returning the United States to a visible presence there for the first time since 1992.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — The United States has reached a 10-year agreement with the Philippines that will give American warships, planes and troops greater access to bases in the archipelago, American officials said Sunday.

headline: What’s On Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (OWN) RUNNING FROM CRAZY (2013) Mariel Hemingway — in her own words: “tall blonde, no problems” — discusses the famous ancestry and mental health challenges of her family, including the suicides of her grandfather Ernest Hemingway and her sister Margaux, in this documentary directed by Barbara Kopple and commissioned by Oprah Winfrey’s OWN channel. Ms. Kopple follows Ms. Hemingway, above, while she visits her family, including her daughters, Dree and Langley, and other sister, Joan, a.k.a. Muffet; gives speeches on her wellness regime; and works out with a male companion. “ ‘Running From Crazy’ — the title is Ms. Hemingway’s phrasing — doesn’t entirely escape the dangers of the confessional profile,” Nicolas Rapold wrote in The New York Times. “But Ms. Kopple shows how people in Ms. Hemingway’s position, with a family history of mental health problems, confront a foreboding mirror, whether or not it also reflects a literary heritage and a Kennedy-grade bone structure.”

headline: A String Quartet Sits, in Solidarity, and Delivers Shostakovich
abstract: The Emerson String Quartet, adopting an unusual posture, presented a program of Britten and Shostakovich on Wednesday at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: The Emerson String Quartet, according to its standard biography, “stands apart in the history of string quartets.” It’s a wink toward one of the things that makes this venerable ensemble special: cellist aside, its members stand, rather than sit.

headline: ‘The Other Woman’ Tops the Box Office But Overall Sales Drop
abstract: Receipts for the top 10 films were down 17.1 percent from last weekend.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:52 p.m. | Moviegoers took a break this weekend as receipts for the top 10 films dropped 17.1 percent from last weekend, to $96.4 million.

headline: Butterflies (Nearly) Over Brooklyn
abstract: A crowd of about 10,000 in Prospect Park saw Judy Chicago’s pyrotechnic display, “A Butterfly for Brooklyn.”
lead_paragraph: To Judy Chicago’s list of accomplishments add control of the weather. The rain ended in Brooklyn on Saturday night just in time for a crowd of about 10,000 in Prospect Park to see her pyrotechnic display, “A Butterfly for Brooklyn.” And it started up again just after most spectators would have made it to the subway for the trip home.

headline: Syria Misses New Deadline as It Works to Purge Arms
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Although Syria has made “significant progress,” it missed a second deadline, April 27, for the destruction of its arsenal of chemical weapons, international monitors said.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Syria missed a revised deadline on Sunday for completing the export or destruction of chemicals in its weapons arsenal, but the government of the war-ravaged country may be only days away from finishing the job, according to international experts overseeing the process.

headline: Detainees in Ukraine Uncertain of Return
abstract: A group of European military observers, detained since Friday, appeared before journalists in a news conference in Slovyansk on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: A group of European military observers, detained since Friday, appeared before journalists in a news conference in Slovyansk on Sunday.

headline: Pro-Russian Forces in Ukraine Free One of 8 Detainees
abstract: The self-appointed mayor of Slovyansk in eastern Ukraine presented the men at a news conference Sunday, calling them “prisoners of the situation,” before releasing one member for health reasons.
lead_paragraph: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — The self-appointed mayor of this breakaway city in eastern Ukraine on Sunday displayed eight detained members of a European military observer mission and later released one for health reasons, but otherwise refused to discuss conditions under which the others might go free beyond mentioning a possible prisoner exchange.

headline: National Pride Swells the Crowds for a Polish Saint
abstract: St. Peter’s Square was awash with Polish flags as pilgrims celebrated the canonization ceremony of John Paul II, the first Polish pope.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Thousands of Polish pilgrims traveled to Rome on Sunday for the canonization ceremony of John Paul II, driven by reverence for a towering historic figure and by national pride.

headline: In New Home, Bronx Dance Academy Seeks to Step Up Its Presence
abstract: The Bronx Academy of Arts and Dance, which recently moved to Westchester Square, is hoping to attract new audiences and supporters.
lead_paragraph: Arthur Aviles knows how to balance. He can jump onto a pedestal, strike a loose-limbed pose then leap to the ground. Once upon terra firma, he confronts an even more delicate balance: how to ensure the future of his group, the Bronx Academy of Arts and Dance, as it settles into a new home and a new neighborhood and — he hopes — attracts new audiences and backers.

headline: Vows: Orchestrating a Proposal
abstract: Peter Chan proposed to Kate Hubert with a musical flourish just nine months after they met.
lead_paragraph: Peter Chan proposed to Kate Hubert with a musical flourish just nine months after they met.

headline: After Pushing Flyers to Brink, Rangers Look to Hone Killer Instinct
abstract: Their inability to press the advantage was foremost in their minds after taking a 3-2 lead in their opening-round series against Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers defeated the Philadelphia Flyers, 4-2, at Madison Square Garden on Sunday and grabbed a 3-2 lead in their opening-round playoff series. But if they hope to close out the series when it shifts to Philadelphia on Tuesday night, they will have to face down not only the Flyers, but also their own baffling inability to press an advantage.

headline: New Space, New Conversations for ICP
abstract: The International Center for Photography may be moving, but its director fully intends to keep it at the center of conversations that explain and explore image-making in the 21st Century.
lead_paragraph: The International Center for Photography may be moving, but its director fully intends to keep it at the center of conversations that explain and explore image-making in the 21st Century.

headline: A European Energy Executive’s Delicate Dance Over Ukraine
abstract: The Italian energy giant ENI is the biggest distributor of Russian gas in Europe, but its chief is risking Moscow’s wrath by trying to help Kiev.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — European executives, especially in the energy industry, have been notably wary of ratcheting up economic tensions with Russia over the Ukraine crisis. They see their business interests as too intertwined to risk stiffer sanctions.

headline: A Matriarch With Stories to Tell and a Love of Swing to Share
abstract: Barbara Cook, backed by a quartet, shared personal anecdotes and a warm authority on Saturday evening.
lead_paragraph: “What a life!” “I’m in heaven!” “Look at what I’ve got!”

headline: Fleeing Conflict in South Sudan
abstract: Mackenzie Knowles-Coursin, a photographer, followed one family’s harrowing escape to safety.
lead_paragraph: Mackenzie Knowles-Coursin, a photographer, followed one family’s harrowing escape to safety.

headline: After a Drowning, Musical Bones Wash Ashore
abstract: The composer David Lang’s “collected stories” series at Zankel Hall on Thursday highlighted a particularly gruesome Celtic folk song about sibling rivalry.
lead_paragraph: Tragic love stories, whether real or fictional, have provided fodder for poets, playwrights and composers for millenniums. An installment of the composer David Lang’s “collected stories” series at Zankel Hall on Thursday evening highlighted a particularly gruesome story of love gone awry, with a Celtic folk song about sibling rivalry.

headline: Amid Uproar, Clippers Silently Display Solidarity
abstract: Amid a controversy surrounding racist remarks attributed to Donald Sterling, the Clippers’ owner, the players made a statement by wearing their shirts inside out before facing the Warriors.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — The Los Angeles Clippers, reacting to recordings of racist remarks attributed to Donald Sterling, the team’s owner, took the court for their playoff game Sunday with a statement, one of both fashion and politics.

headline: Two Brothers in the Icy Grip of Midlife
abstract: In Michael Cunningham’s latest novel, “The Snow Queen,” two brothers yearn for a sense of purpose in midlife.
lead_paragraph: Michael Cunningham’s resonant new novel, “The Snow Queen,” takes its title from the Hans Christian Andersen fairy tale of the same name about the redemptive powers of love and its ability to melt even the chilliest of hearts.

headline: Celebrating a Poem and a Novel by James Baldwin, With Movement
abstract: At New York Live Arts, Dianne McIntyre’s “Time Is Time” interpreted “Song (for Skip)” and Charles O. Anderson’s “Restless Natives” drew from “Another Country.”
lead_paragraph: With its annual Live Ideas festival, New York Live Arts, an institution generally devoted to dance, opens its doors to a wider range of programming. The curatorial approach, so far, involves unpacking the work of a cultural figure who bridges many fields of inquiry, the body included. Last year’s theme was “The Worlds of Oliver Sacks.” This year, it’s “James Baldwin, This Time!” (with “This” underlined for emphasis). That Harlem-born writer and activist would have been 90 this August, and Live Arts is one of several New York organizations celebrating “The Year of James Baldwin,” an extended (and timely) reflection on his social and literary achievements.

headline: Swiss Teams at the Sagamore Bridge Club in Syosset, N.Y.
abstract: In a recent column, I mentioned that bridge club attendance has been hurt by the online sites.
lead_paragraph: In a recent column, I mentioned that bridge club attendance has been hurt by the online sites. This is true even in the New York City area and New Jersey, which, according to the American Contract Bridge League, together had five of the top nine most successful clubs in North America in terms of tables in play last year.

headline: Confidence on the Rise for Gee and the Mets
abstract: After winning a series against Miami, the Mets’ record was at 14-11. At this rate, they are on pace to win about 90 games — the bar that General Manager Sandy Alderson set in spring training.
lead_paragraph: When General Manager Sandy Alderson declared before the season that the Mets’ goal was to win 90 games, the statement was mocked and ridiculed (and it may still be). Some fans wondered if the Mets were delusional.

headline: ‘Chef’ and ‘Keep On’ Win Tribeca Audience Awards
abstract: At the Tribeca Film Festival on Saturday, audience awards were handed out to “Chef,” for best narrative feature, and “Keep On Keepin’ On,” for best documentary.
lead_paragraph: At the Tribeca Film Festival on Saturday, audience awards were handed out to “Chef,” for best narrative feature, and “Keep On Keepin’ On,” for best documentary. The two films were chosen by festivalgoers who cast ballots on their way out of screenings.

headline: Hoping to End a Dubious Streak
abstract: “The Glass Menagerie” could receive a Tony nomination on Tuesday, something that has eluded this Tennessee Williams play for decades.
lead_paragraph: One of the most famous and popular American plays, it turns out, is also one of the most slighted in Broadway history.

headline: A Conductor, Rehired, Now Must Rebuild
abstract: Osmo Vanska, the Finnish conductor who will return as music director of the Minnesota Orchestra, acknowledges the need for rebuilding but predicts that things may go fast.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Osmo Vanska is suddenly a man in a hurry. Mr. Vanska, the Finnish conductor, bode his time as music director of the Minnesota Orchestra through the first year of management’s lockout of the players (which eventually ran to 16 months, ending in February) during a contract dispute, but resigned out of frustration in October. He was reinstated last Thursday, to start officially this Thursday.

headline: A Gaming Company Devoted to Narrative Tackles ‘Thrones’
abstract: Telltale Games, an independent video game studio, has developed an intense following by prizing nuance and narrative. It is working on a video game version of “Game of Thrones.”
lead_paragraph: SAN RAFAEL, Calif. — Behind closed doors and papered-over windows here, a half-dozen storytellers have been scrambling to conjure a fantasy world with compelling characters, fierce dialogue and an intricate plot. But this is no ordinary writers’ room: It’s Telltale Games, an independent video game studio that has developed an intense following by prizing nuance and narrative in an industry more often associated with clattering machine guns and screeching getaway cars.

headline: Star Stand-Ins
abstract: The return of Jim Modney.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — And the award for Longest Hiatus Between Published Puzzles goes to … Jim Modney! I understand how life can get in the way of constructing, but I really think Mr. Modney deserves a round of applause for his nearly 30-year break in puzzle-making.

headline: Museum Draws Donatello From Italy
abstract: The Museum of Biblical Art will host a trove of seldom-shared Renaissance art next year while the Duomo museum, its home in Florence, Italy, is expanded.
lead_paragraph: New York City, home to a stunning number of Renaissance treasures, has never had a work in a permanent collection by one of the era’s foremost sculptural masters, Donatello, and major pieces by him rarely leave Europe. But for a few months next year, the city will become a veritable Donatello feast, the one stop for a small show of works from the Duomo museum in Florence, Italy, including several sculptures instantly recognizable from art history textbooks but never before seen in America.

headline: A Caper by the Coens, With a Fake Monet
abstract: “Gambit,” a remake of the 1966 art caper that starred Michael Caine and Shirley MacLaine, was written by the Coen brothers and stars Colin Firth and Cameron Diaz.
lead_paragraph: Silently slipped into a single theater like a heist in reverse, “Gambit” is getting the sort of American release you might not expect given its cast and a screenplay written, at some point in the film’s hot-potato history, by the Coen brothers. This nominal remake of the 1966 art caper that starred Michael Caine and Shirley MacLaine has all the fizz of flat soda, but it’s not catastrophically worse than any number of films that open widely.

headline: Updates on Tech Companies and Job Numbers
abstract: Twitter plans to release its first-quarter earnings, Nokia will announce a new strategy and chief, and data on hiring and unemployment is expected from the Labor Department and from Eurostat.
lead_paragraph: INVESTORS WATCH TWITTER FOR FURTHER STAGNATION

headline: Years After Chernobyl, Building Progress
abstract: At the Chernobyl nuclear plant, a rising arch is a sign of a cleanup’s progress, and the remains of Pripyat, a city once home to 45,000, is a reminder of the devastation of 1986.
lead_paragraph: At the Chernobyl nuclear plant, a rising arch is a sign of a cleanup’s progress, and the remains of Pripyat, a city once home to 45,000, is a reminder of the devastation of 1986.

headline: Forced to Flee Radiation, Fearful Japanese Villagers Are Reluctant to Return
keywords: ['Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Radiation', 'Evacuations and Evacuees']
abstract: Three years after the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear accident, the government has reopened the evacuated community of Miyakoji. But many do not want to come back.
lead_paragraph: MIYAKOJI, Japan — Ever since they were forced to evacuate during the accident at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant three years ago, Kim Eunja and her husband have refused to return to their hilltop home amid the majestic mountains of this rural village for fear of radiation.

headline: Few Consumers Are Buying Premise of Mobile Wallets
abstract: While numerous solutions are in the market, none have won widespread adoption, as consumers are either unaware of the option — or unimpressed by it.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Millions of Americans use smartphones for tasks like hailing a taxi or checking in for a flight. But for buying something in a store? That mostly remains a tech entrepreneur’s dream.

headline: Kerr Says He Discussed Knicks Job With Jackson
abstract: Steve Kerr said Sunday that he had spoken twice with Phil Jackson about filling the Knicks’ coaching vacancy.
lead_paragraph: Steve Kerr dined with the new Knicks president, Phil Jackson, in Manhattan on Friday to discuss the team’s head-coaching vacancy, Kerr said Sunday at Barclays Center, where he was preparing to work as an analyst for TNT for a playoff game between the Nets and the Toronto Raptors.

headline: ECO 348, The Great Recession: Secular Stagnation
abstract: Now is the discontent of our Summers.
lead_paragraph: Slides here (pdf).

headline: Qaddafi Son Appears on Screen at His Trial
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi is accused of aiding his father Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in the brutal suppression of Libya’s uprising three years ago.
lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, facing accusations that he aided his father, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, in the brutal suppression of Libya’s uprising three years ago, was not allowed to appear in court in person on Sunday to answer the charges.

headline: Wheeldon’s ‘Alice’ to Play in New York
abstract: “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland,” with choreography by Christopher Wheeldon, is to run from Sept. 9 to 14.
lead_paragraph: The Joyce Theater Foundation and the National Ballet of Canada plan to announce on Monday that they will present the New York premiere of “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland” with choreography by Christopher Wheeldon. Set to an original score by Joby Talbot and with costume and set designs by Bob Crowley, the production of the Lewis Carroll classic is scheduled to run from Sept. 9 to 14 at the David H. Koch Theater in Lincoln Center. Mr. Wheeldon’s interpretation of “Alice” had its premiere at the Royal Opera House in London in 2011. Tickets go on sale Monday and will be available at davidhkochtheater.com and by calling 212-496-0600.

headline: New Challenges Chip Away at Cable’s Pillar of Profit
keywords: ['Television', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cable Television', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations']
abstract: A future where consumers will be able to assemble an à la carte menu of entertainment suddenly seems much closer.
lead_paragraph: For decades, cable television has been an almost magical source of profits, in large part because of the bundle, the packaging of channels that compels subscribers to buy a lot of programming they never watch.

headline: Nuclear Industry Gains Carbon-Focused Allies in Push to Save Reactors
abstract: Environmentalists are pushing to preserve old nuclear reactors whose economic viability is threatened but that produce no greenhouse gases, which could help meet national climate goals.
lead_paragraph: Environmentalists and the nuclear industry are beginning a push to preserve old nuclear reactors whose economic viability is threatened by cheap natural gas and rising production of wind energy. They argue that while natural gas and wind are helpful as sources of electricity with little or no production of greenhouse gases, national climate goals will be unreachable if zero-carbon nuclear reactors are phased out.

headline: Putin Rival Takes Message to East Ukraine
abstract: Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the Russian tycoon, flew to Donetsk to see whether the standoffs were as hard and dangerous as they seem from a distance.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Not for the first time in his life, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the Russian former tycoon suddenly freed from jail in December by President Vladimir V. Putin, was on a somewhat quixotic mission.

headline: John Houbolt, NASA Innovator Behind Lunar Module, Dies at 95
abstract: Dr. Houbolt argued for a smaller and less expensive option for a moon shot — a Chevrolet, not a Cadillac, he liked to say — called a lunar orbit rendezvous.
lead_paragraph: On May 25, 1961, President John F. Kennedy told Congress that the United States should commit to landing a man on the moon before the end of the decade.

headline: On Bridges in Paris, Clanking With Love
abstract: Romantics from around the world affirm their love by affixing padlocks to certain bridges in Paris. But some see not a touching symbol of commitment, but an eyesore.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Johannes and Melissa. David and Michaela. Ben and Justin.

headline: Despite Big Ambitions, New York’s Tech Scene Is Still Starting Up
abstract: While the city’s new tech firms continue to attract plenty of venture capital, Silicon Alley has a long way to go before it rivals the Valley.
lead_paragraph: Predicting that your city will be the next Silicon Valley is simple. But actually making it the next Silicon Valley is something else entirely — as New York is slowly finding out.

headline: Soured Mortgages Attract Institutional Dollars
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: A Wall Street executive who helped Goldman Sachs make more than a billion dollars betting against mortgages now wants to buy up troubled home loans.
lead_paragraph: A Wall Street executive who helped Goldman Sachs make more than a billion dollars betting against mortgages now wants to buy up troubled home loans.

headline: Home Décor Retailer CB2 Invites Pinterest Users to Furnish Apartment
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Online Advertising', 'Social Media']
abstract: Professional designers will offer several options for furnishings, and site visitors will vote to decide what will be used.
lead_paragraph: MORE visitors to the website for CB2, the home décor chain owned by Crate & Barrel, come from Pinterest, the virtual bulletin board, than any other social network. Now CB2 is turning to Pinterest users to weigh in on decorating an apartment the company has rented in New York.

headline: Cholera and Clean Water
abstract: Lisa Schechtman of WaterAid discusses the epidemic in Haiti.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What Does Buddhism Require?
abstract: The reality of rebirth may not be necessary. But believing in it probably is.
lead_paragraph: This is the fifth in a series of interviews about religion that I am conducting for The Stone. The interviewee for this installment is Jay L. Garfield, who has taught philosophy at several universities and is currently the Kwan Im Thong Hood Cho Temple Professor of Humanities, Yale-NUS College in Singapore. He is at work on a book called “Engaging Buddhism: Why Buddhism Matters to Contemporary Philosophy.”

headline: The Role of the Clergy in Helping the Mentally Ill
abstract: Two readers have opposing views of efforts by the clergy to address mental illness.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Should Doctors Care About Cost?
keywords: ['Medicine and Health', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Doctors', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)']
abstract: Readers, including doctors, are on both sides.

headline: By Digitizing Images, Museum Opens a Window Into the Past
abstract: The American Museum of Natural History in New York is making thousands of illustrations that were previously only accessible at the museum’s Manhattan location available online.
lead_paragraph: Fully a century before Sarah Palin declared that Alaska was “just right over the border” from Russia, an expedition fielded by the American Museum of Natural History in New York sought to prove that the first people to reach the Americas had indeed migrated across the frozen Bering Strait.

headline: The War on Truth in Ukraine
abstract: In the absence of hard facts, disinformation and manipulation win.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For a moment last week, war seemed imminent. A day after Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, warned Ukraine’s leaders against using force in the crisis there, the Ukrainian military attacked a checkpoint outside the separatist-held town of Slovyansk. Russian forces across the border responded with maneuvers labeled “exercises,” coupled with statements from the Kremlin that amounted to “you were warned.” Russian television made Slovyansk look like Guernica; Ukrainian news media reported that separatist militants were using kindergartners as human shields.

headline: Epix Plans to Introduce Film on Altman
abstract: The television and digital movie channel Epix plans to surround the documentary about the candid director with several of his works.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Altmanesque: Possessing a mysterious quality that makes you want to watch more movies.

headline: Health Law’s Pay Policy Is Skewed, Panel Finds
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Hospitals', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: A report criticizes federal pay-for-performance policies as being unfair to doctors and hospitals that treat poor people.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal policies to reward high-quality health care are unfairly penalizing doctors and hospitals that treat large numbers of poor people, according to a new report commissioned by the Obama administration that recommends sweeping changes in payment policy.

headline: The Wire Next Time
keywords: ['Net Neutrality', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Local Government', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: Municipal networks are the answer to the end of net neutrality.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — LAST week’s proposal by the Federal Communications Commission to allow Internet service providers to charge different rates to different online content companies — effectively ending the government’s commitment to net neutrality — set off a flurry of protest.

headline: ‘Smart’ Firearm Draws Wrath of the Gun Lobby
abstract: A handgun that can identify its user so no one else can fire it has met with the same uproar that has stopped many seeking tougher weapons laws.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Belinda Padilla does not pick up unknown calls anymore, not since someone posted her cellphone number on an online forum for gun enthusiasts. A few fuming-mad voice mail messages and heavy breathers were all it took.

headline: A Versatile Shark Quietly Makes a Major Difference
abstract: Sharks forward Joe Pavelski has been under the radar for several years, but this season has been quite different.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — San Jose Sharks forward Joe Pavelski has shown as much talent for avoiding the limelight as he has for eluding opposing defensemen.

headline: Milq Aims to Separate Wheat From Social Media Chaff
abstract: Milq, which makes its debut on Monday, lets users organize bits of media around common themes, resulting in something like collaborative mixtapes.
lead_paragraph: Social media users know the frustration: a deluge of videos, images and music clips flows through their news feeds all the time, some of it precious (Miles Davis discussing Prince!), but mostly not (Here’s what I ate for breakfast!).

headline: U.S. Weighs Harder Line on Russia Than European Allies
abstract: The White House has become entangled in a debate over how much emphasis to put on unity with European allies reluctant to take stronger economic actions against Moscow, while pro-Russian forces in Ukraine continue to defy demands.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Obama and his national security team struggle to increase pressure on Russia over its intervention in Ukraine, they have become entangled in a tense debate over how much emphasis to put on unity with European allies more reluctant to take stronger economic actions against Moscow.

headline: Supreme Court Taking Up Police Searches of Data Troves Known as Cellphones
abstract: The high court on Tuesday will consider two cases about whether the police need warrants to search the cellphones of the people they arrest.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a major test of how to interpret the Fourth Amendment in the digital age, the Supreme Court on Tuesday will consider two cases about whether the police need warrants to search the cellphones of the people they arrest.

headline: Verbatim: What Is a Photocopier?
keywords: ['Recording Equipment', 'Supreme Courts (State)', 'Legal Profession', 'Office Supplies and Equipment']
abstract: In this dramatization of transcripts from a legal deposition, a lawyer becomes embroiled in an absurd argument about the definition of a photocopier.
lead_paragraph: In this dramatization of transcripts from a legal deposition, a lawyer becomes embroiled in an absurd argument about the definition of a photocopier.

headline: Veteran Rangers Center Provides Big Lift
abstract: The well-traveled center Dominic Moore scored an unassisted second-period goal Sunday to put the Rangers ahead, 3-0, in a game they held on to win, 4-2.
lead_paragraph: Dominic Moore added an exclamation point to his memorable comeback season when he scored an unassisted second-period goal Sunday afternoon that proved to be the winner in the Rangers’ 4-2 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers.

headline: Despite Twitter Backlash, New York Police Dept. Plans to Expand Social Media Efforts
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Photography', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Search and Seizure', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Commissioner William J. Bratton is determined to use social media to promote the New York Police Department, even after encountering a flood of negative attention on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: For the first few months of his second tour as commissioner of the New York Police Department, William J. Bratton has been consumed in large part with reshaping perceptions of officers.

headline: ‘Verbatim: What Is a Photocopier?’
keywords: ['Supreme Courts (State)', 'Office Supplies and Equipment', 'Recording Equipment', 'Legal Profession']
abstract: In this dramatization of transcripts from a legal deposition, a lawyer becomes embroiled in an absurd argument.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, on my Facebook feed, I stumbled across a hilarious excerpt from a legal transcript. In a deposition in Ohio, a lawyer became embroiled in an absurd argument about the definition of a photocopier.

headline: One Therapist, $4 Million in 2012 Medicare Billing
keywords: ['Physical Therapy', 'Medicare', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Doctors']
abstract: Physical therapy is a big recipient of national Medicare dollars — and physical therapists in Brooklyn are among the biggest billers of all, government data indicates.
lead_paragraph: A few miles from the Coney Island boardwalk in Brooklyn stands an outpost of what, on paper, is a giant of American medicine.

headline: Recovery Has Created Far More Low-Wage Jobs Than Better-Paid Ones
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Recession and Depression', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy', 'Minimum Wage', 'Fast Food Industry']
abstract: The strongest employment growth after the recession has been in low-wage work, at places like strip malls and fast-food restaurants, according to a new report.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The deep recession wiped out primarily high-wage and middle-wage jobs. Yet the strongest employment growth during the sluggish recovery has been in low-wage work, at places like strip malls and fast-food restaurants.

headline: No Accounting Skills? No Moral Reckoning
keywords: ['ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: Our financial illiteracy is costing us much more than we realize.
lead_paragraph: SOMETIMES it seems as if our lives are dominated by financial crises and failed reforms. But how much do Americans even understand about finance? Few of us can do basic accounting and fewer still know what a balance sheet is. If we are going to get to the point where we can have a serious debate about financial accountability, we first need to learn some essentials.

headline: In Venezuela, Protesters Point to Their Scars
abstract: President Nicolás Maduro, fearing efforts to overthrow him, said he held the opposition responsible for the violence that, by some accounts, had claimed more than 40 lives.
lead_paragraph: VALENCIA, Venezuela — Clipso Martínez was shot at such close range by a soldier at a protest that his surgeon said he had to remove pieces of the plastic shotgun shell buried in his leg, along with the shards of keys Mr. Martínez had in his pocket, shattered by the blast.

headline: In Complex Mess, a Question of Who Has Leverage
abstract: The racist comments possibly made by Donald Sterling, the owner of the Los Angeles Clippers, could give the union a chance to expand its role in how the N.B.A. conducts its affairs.
lead_paragraph: Of the two most leveraged presidents to have weighed in on the Donald Sterling audio imbroglio, a fairly loquacious Barack Obama was the less significant voice. What little Chris Paul, president of the National Basketball Players Association, had to say could potentially have far more impact on how the league might proceed on this complex, evolving and exceedingly troubling story.

headline: Gay Rights Push Shifts Its Focus South and West
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Discrimination', 'Law and Legislation', 'Elections', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: In a drive to win more rights and protections, gay advocates are setting their sights on Southern and Western states, where the movement’s rapid progress has largely eluded gay men and lesbians.
lead_paragraph: The country’s leading gay rights groups and donors, after a decade focused on legalizing same-sex marriage, are embarking on a major drive to win more basic civil rights and workplace protections in Southern and Western states where the rapid progress of the movement has largely eluded millions of gay men and lesbians.

headline: Experimental Efforts to Harvest the Ocean’s Power Face Cost Setbacks
keywords: ['Tidal and Wave Power', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: The shuttering of an ambitious project is the latest setback for the nascent wave energy sector in the United States.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — At the Port of Portland sits a 260-ton buoy filled with technology that can turn the movement of the ocean into electricity to power 100 homes. It rolled off an assembly line to great fanfare two years ago and received the nation’s first commercial license to operate.

headline: Caution Ahead for Municipal IDs
abstract: If done right, the benefits of a municipal photo-ID card for all New Yorkers, including illegal immigrants, are many.
lead_paragraph: Two New York City Council members, Daniel Dromm and Carlos Menchaca, have introduced a bill to create a municipal photo-ID card that all New Yorkers could use, even those without legal immigration status. This excellent idea has the strong support of the Council speaker, Melissa Mark-Viverito, and Mayor Bill de Blasio, so it seems likely that New York will soon join cities like San Francisco and New Haven in achieving a goal that immigrant-rights advocates have long striven for: documenting the undocumented.

headline: Treasury Auctions for the Week of April 28
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes the regular Monday auction of new three- and six-month bills and auctions of four-week bills, one-year bills and two-year floating rate notes on Tuesday.

headline: One Year After Rana Plaza
keywords: ['Rana Plaza Building Collapse, Bangladesh (2013)', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Editorials']
abstract: It is taking longer than it should to make reparations and improve workplaces in Bangladesh.
lead_paragraph: A horrendous building collapse last April in Bangladesh killed more than 1,100 garment workers. Labor groups, Western clothing companies, the Bangladeshi government and others have made some progress toward preventing similar tragedies, but more needs to be done.

headline: Given Cause to Make a Stand, the Clippers Settle for a Gesture
abstract: The Clippers players turned their jerseys inside out during a practice. You wonder, in years to come, if these proud men and splendid athletes will think that was enough of a response.
lead_paragraph: Why not remain seated?

headline: Smartphones and the 4th Amendment
abstract: The police should need a warrant to search mobile phones, because they contain enormous amounts of personal information.
lead_paragraph: More than 90 percent of American adults own a mobile phone, and more than half of the devices are smartphones. But “smartphone” is a misnomer. They are personal computers that happen to include a phone function, and like any computer they can store or wirelessly retrieve enormous amounts of personal information: emails, photos and videos; document files; financial and medical records; and virtually everywhere a person has been.

headline: High Plains Moochers
keywords: ['Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Land Use Policies', 'Ranches', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: At the heart of the Cliven Bundy standoff was a perversion of the concept of freedom.
lead_paragraph: It is, in a way, too bad that Cliven Bundy — the rancher who became a right-wing hero after refusing to pay fees for grazing his animals on federal land, and bringing in armed men to support his defiance — has turned out to be a crude racist. Why? Because his ranting has given conservatives an easy out, a way to dissociate themselves from his actions without facing up to the terrible wrong turn their movement has taken.

headline: A Young Mayor Who Likes to Share His View From the Top
abstract: Personal photographs taken by Mayor Eric Garcetti shed light on Los Angeles and new ways for politicians to use social media.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When Eric Garcetti ran for mayor of Los Angeles, his campaign created an Instagram account to feed voters a daily stream of campaign pictures: candidate shaking hands, candidate touring park, candidate giving a speech. Unremarkable, unrevealing and uncontroversial — and destined to fade away with Election Day, which it did.

headline: Chernobyl: Capping a Catastrophe
abstract: A 32,000-ton arch that will end up costing $1.5 billion is being built in Chernobyl, Ukraine, to all but eliminate the risk of further contamination at the site of the 1986 nuclear reactor explosion.
lead_paragraph: A 32,000-ton arch that will end up costing $1.5 billion is being built in Chernobyl, Ukraine, to all but eliminate the risk of further contamination at the site of the 1986 nuclear reactor explosion.

headline: U.S. Caught Up in Islands Dispute
abstract: The rising international racket over islands in the South China Sea.
lead_paragraph: The rising international racket over islands in the South China Sea.

headline: Vortex of Outrage Has Long Trailed Clippers’ Owner
abstract: A recording of racist remarks attributed to Donald Sterling has drawn attention to his history of discrimination lawsuits, ugly pay disputes and extramarital affairs.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When Kim Hughes, then an assistant coach for the Los Angeles Clippers, was found to have prostate cancer on the eve of training camp in 2004, he learned what it was like to work in Donald Sterling’s world.

headline: A Smuggler of Immigrants Dies in Prison, but Is Praised in Chinatown
abstract: Despite putting passengers on faulty ships, and using kidnapping and torture to collect her fees, Sister Ping was seen by many as a tireless, self-sacrificing fighter for her fellow Fujianese.
lead_paragraph: To the authorities, Cheng Chui Ping was the “mother of all snakeheads,” a ruthless businesswoman who smuggled thousands of Chinese emigrants into the United States.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 27, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: April 27, 2014

headline: Suspect in School Attack Once Turned to Victim for Help, Friends Say
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Friends close to the 16-year-old accused of fatally stabbing a fellow high school student sifted through clues, saying he had seemed detached and in need of help.
lead_paragraph: MILFORD, Conn. — Nobody ever had to ask Maren Sanchez to help. She was simply there with a smile, gathering an armload of books someone had dropped in the hallway of Jonathan Law High School, greeting strangers like old friends, offering to lend a hand when a classmate got stuck on homework.

headline: When She Was Venus and Nellie Forbush
abstract: It takes three singers to fill the shoes of the title character in “Inventing Mary Martin,” at the Theater at St. Peter’s.
lead_paragraph: Can you blame theater people for trying to raise the dead?

headline: All Books Not Equal to Squabbling Family
abstract: In “The Substance of Fire” at the Second Stage Theater, a family of publishers fights over printing academic books versus sexy novels.
lead_paragraph: Although it’s roughly the age of a recent college graduate, Jon Robin Baitz’s play “The Substance of Fire” at times seems to have grown some gray whiskers. Watching the sure-footed new revival of the play that opened at the Second Stage Theater on Sunday night, featuring standout performances by the Australian actor John Noble and the ever-vibrant Charlayne Woodard, I kept thinking of dramas about family, money and morality written way back in the early years of the 20th century by Harley Granville Barker.

headline: Should Affirmative Action Be Based on Income?
abstract: Will the Supreme Court decision on race-based preferences push colleges to resort to less effective methods to promote to diversity?

headline: Recreational Bicycling vs. Delivery Bicycling
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: Two cyclists crossed paths on a spring Sunday, one in a color-coordinated racing outfit, the other in work clothes and balancing a bag of food.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: Record Store Day, which began in April 2008, is a self-styled celebration of the “unique culture” surrounding independent record stores. Some titles released on vinyl for the April 19 event, like “Because the Internet,” saw revitalized sales weeks after a release on CD.
lead_paragraph: Record Store Day, which began in April 2008, is a self-styled celebration of the “unique culture” surrounding independent record stores. Some titles released on vinyl for the April 19 event, like “Because the Internet,” saw revitalized sales weeks after a release on CD.

headline: Foursquare Chief Apologizes for Wife’s Fake Boston Marathon Bib
abstract: The wife of Foursquare’s chief executive used someone else’s bib number to run the 2014 Boston Marathon with her husband, prompting backlash on social media.
lead_paragraph: A co-founder of Foursquare, a popular location-sharing mobile app, issued an online apology after an investigation of unauthorized runners in the Boston Marathon found that his wife had used a fake bib to participate in the race last Monday.

headline: For Politician, an Indictment Looms, and So Does a Campaign for Re-election
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: Representative Michael G. Grimm is expected to face federal charges of fraud, which creates a difficult scenario for New York City Republicans trying to retain their only seat in Congress.
lead_paragraph: Republican Party leaders in Staten Island had long heard murmuring about Representative Michael G. Grimm’s possible legal troubles. But Mr. Grimm maintained his innocence, and party leaders stood behind his bid for a third term this November.

headline: Two Horses, 59 Years Apart, Inspire One Trainer
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Kentucky Derby', 'Santa Anita Derby', 'Jockeys, Drivers and Trainers']
abstract: The trainer Art Sherman, 77, was an exercise rider for the 1955 Derby winner, Swaps, but he has never had a Derby entrant until California Chrome, the race favorite.
lead_paragraph: LOS ALAMITOS, Calif. — On a recent morning, as the sun rose over the edge of the grandstand, the trainer of the expected Kentucky Derby favorite leaned against a railing as he waited for his prized colt to emerge for his daily gallop.

headline: Pfizer Move for AstraZeneca Seen
abstract: Such a move would be aimed at putting pressure on the British drug maker, which has turned down a number of informal takeover approaches.
lead_paragraph: Pfizer is close to publicly unveiling its interest in acquiring AstraZeneca of Britain, a person briefed on the matter said on Sunday, in what would be one of the biggest deals among drug makers.

headline: Yanks Have Only Praise for Cano Before His First Return
abstract: Robinson Cano will play in Yankee Stadium on Tuesday for the first time since he signed a 10-year contract with the Seattle Mariners.
lead_paragraph: In the course of his 20-year career, Yankees shortstop Derek Jeter has seen many players come and go. He is no longer surprised at the business of baseball.

headline: Chef Seeks to Buy Contessa Food Business
abstract: Ina Garten, the celebrity chef known as the Barefoot Contessa, says she is putting together an investor group to buy the frozen food business that carries her name from Contessa Premium Foods.
lead_paragraph: Ina Garten, the celebrity chef known as the Barefoot Contessa, is hoping to buy the frozen food business that carries her name and brand from Contessa Premium Foods, an unaffiliated food company.

headline: Nets Fizzle Late, Allowing Raptors to Tie Series

lead_paragraph: Kevin Garnett made a pair of free throws with 4 minutes 58 seconds left in Sunday night’s game. He pumped his fist, and the fans in the sellout crowd erupted as the Nets inched to a precious 1-point lead over the Toronto Raptors.

abstract: A 16-year-old boy was shot to death in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, on Saturday, hours before a 19-year-old woman was fatally stabbed in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: After the daylight shooting of a 16-year-old on a residential block in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, there were no major rallies. No public outcry from local politicians.

lead_paragraph: Michael Heisley, the billionaire financier who bought the N.B.A.’s floundering Vancouver Grizzlies in April 2000 and soon moved them to Memphis, where he revitalized the franchise, died on Saturday in Illinois. He was 77.

abstract: Mr. Robeson aimed to teach new generations about his father’s radical politics and criticized those he thought misrepresented his life.
lead_paragraph: Paul Robeson Jr., who worked to preserve the legacy of his father, the actor, singer and civil rights advocate, since his death almost four decades ago, died on Saturday in Jersey City. He was 86.

headline: String of Deadly Storms Hits Across Midwest and South
abstract: A violent weather system lashed the Midwest and South with tornadoes on Sunday, killing at least nine people and leaving vast destruction.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — A violent weather system lashed the Midwest and South with tornadoes on Sunday, killing at least nine people, according to some reports, and leaving vast areas of destruction. Forecasters warned that additional severe storms were likely on Monday.

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Goodman Fielder, one of Australia’s biggest consumer food products companies, said on Monday that it had rebuffed a takeover bid by Singapore’s Wilmar International and Hong Kong’s First Pacific Company.

headline: After 7-Year Makeover, Bronx Links of Legend Try to Reclaim the Past
abstract: Opened in 1895, the Van Cortlandt Park Golf Course in the North Bronx, which was once a favorite spot for celebrities, has had a $5 million renovation.
lead_paragraph: When William Larkin, a hip-hop producer-turned-golf pro, accepted the position of general manager of the Van Cortlandt Park Golf Course in the North Bronx in 2007, it was because he thought the course could live up to its history.

headline: North Korean Peace Group Insults South Korean Leader
abstract: The North’s Committee for the Peaceful Reunification of Korea described Park Geun-hye in misogynic terms and called President Obama her “pimp.”
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea’s committee for peaceful reunification with South Korea, an official mouthpiece, has not been espousing peace lately, and its mouth has turned foul.

headline: Comme des Garçons Creates a Fragrance with Two Art-World Heavy-Hitters
abstract: The brand has collaborated with Serpentine Galleries on a new spring scent, with packaging designed by Tracey Emin.
lead_paragraph: Comme des Garçons is back with another fragrance collaboration — and this time, it involves two of the heaviest hitters in the art world. In honor of Serpentine Galleries‘ new Serpentine Sackler space designed by Zaha Hadid, the fashion label has partnered with the London institution on a new fragrance with a bottle and packaging designed by the artist Tracey Emin. The release, simply called “Serpentine,” is the first in an ongoing artist commission project for the Comme des Garçons scent line. A blend of iris leaf, juniper wood and nutmeg, the scent reflects Serpentine’s location amongst the green grass and fresh flowers at Kensington Gardens.

headline: Pop Lighting
abstract: Water bottles transform into brightly-colored pendant lamps in Alvaro Catalán de Ocón’s new collection, on view at the Design Museum in London.
lead_paragraph: Trash was the inspiration for Alvaro Catalán de Ocón’s vibrant line of pendant lamps, now on display at the Design Museum in London as part of its “Designs of the Year” exhibition. In 2011, while working on a project to combat pollution in Colombia, the Spanish industrial designer came up with the PET collection, its title a playful abbreviation of the polyethylene terephthalate bottles that contain soft drinks and water. He then hired Bogotá artisans to weave colored fibers into the repurposed bottles.

headline: A Stroke You Must Have
abstract: It’s never too late to learn how to swim, a crucial skill, as more than 70 percent of the drowning victims in the United States each year are adults.
lead_paragraph: My father-in-law had been fishing from rowboats without incident since early childhood. But in August 1970, at age 66, alone on a Minnesota lake, he apparently fell out of the boat and drowned. He couldn’t swim a stroke, yet never wore a life jacket.

headline: What’s On Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 1 P.M. (Showtime 2) MARGOT AT THE WEDDING (2007) In this cutting comedy from Noah Baumbach two sisters — Margot (Nicole Kidman, above left, with Jennifer Jason Leigh), an accomplished novelist, and the neurotic, needy Pauline (Ms. Leigh) — come together at their family home on Long Island for Pauline’s wedding to the unimpressive Malcolm (Jack Black). The result, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, is “a pileup of exposed secrets, buried lies and moral failures expressed in a cacophony of screams, tears and furious whispers” and a film that is “frequently brilliant, finally baffling.”

headline: Anthony Marriott, Author of ‘No Sex Please, We’re British’, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Marriott was best known for farcical work, like the long-running play “No Sex Please, We’re British.”
lead_paragraph: Anthony Marriott, a onetime actor who hit the jackpot as a playwright when he plugged into the British penchant for loopiness and naughty bits, co-writing a farce that became the longest-running comedy in the history of theater in England, died in London on April 17. He was 83.

headline: Pitch Bounces Yankees’ Way, Allowing the Run That Beats the Angels
abstract: A wild pitch in the eighth inning allowed Jacoby Ellsbury to dash home and seal a victory for the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: The pitch that sent the Yankees to a 3-2 win on Sunday against the Los Angeles Angels struck the ground several inches short of home plate and caromed toward the backstop. Angels reliever Nick Maronde had attempted a breaking ball in a duel against Brian McCann in the eighth inning of a tie game. It was a pitch that clearly did not break enough, or did not even have enough time to break at all.

headline: India Election Digest: April 28
keywords: ['Boycotts', 'Elections', 'Hinduism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: A roundup of election-related news for Monday.
lead_paragraph: What you need to know on Monday about India’s elections: In a Muslim neighborhood in Gujarat, Bharatiya Janata Party members leave out any mention of Narendra Modi in their speeches; the top aide to Mr. Modi denies trying to appeal to the Hindu vote; and Priyanka Gandhi’s more visible role may mean she’s being groomed for something larger in the Indian National Congress party.

abstract: Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia said Monday that the search for debris from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 would enter a “new phase,” focusing on a much larger area underwater.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia announced on Monday an end to the search by air for debris from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, but he said the underwater search would be intensified and expanded.

headline: Storms Carve Deadly Path Through South and Midwest
abstract: For Vilonia, Ark., the tornado that touched down on Sunday was a nightmare revisited: Nearly three years ago to the day, another twister swept through the city.
lead_paragraph: VILONIA, Ark. — Ryan Henry stood outside his brick home and saw the tornado nearing his neighborhood, razing much of this small city in central Arkansas as it went. He dashed inside, grabbed a bedspread and headed for the bathroom, where his three daughters were already in the tub. He placed his body over the girls — twin 9-year-olds and an 8-year-old — and waited.

lead_paragraph: The French pharmaceutical company Sanofi said on Monday that its experimental vaccine for dengue fever had succeeded in its first late-stage clinical trial. The results could help pave the way for the introduction of the first vaccine to prevent a disease that afflicts an estimated 50 million to 100 million people a year.

lead_paragraph: The International Center of Photography recently announced that it would be leaving its museum space on Sixth Avenue in Midtown Manhattan at the end of this year. It has not yet disclosed plans for temporary or permanent exhibition space. Mark Lubell, the former director of Magnum Photos, became executive director of ICP in November 2013. He spoke with James Estrin about the future of I.C.P. on Friday. The conversation has been edited.

headline: Saving China’s Elephants
abstract: Efforts to save China’s few hundred wild elephants appear to have been successful, although visitors to the Yunnan Province Wild Elephant Valley Park are unlikely to see one.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to cute and cuddly marketing mascots, it’s hard to compete with the giant panda — especially when you have rough, saggy skin, weigh four tons and occasionally stomp to death your admirers. That hasn’t stopped officials and entrepreneurs in the southwestern Chinese province of Yunnan from embracing the Asian elephant as a tourist attraction and merchandising bonanza. Jinghong, the capital of Xishuangbanna Prefecture, is flecked with dancing, prancing elephant statues. Each day, thousands of visitors crowd into a local nature preserve, where they hope to spot a real, live creature — although they are invariably disappointed and end up going home with a stuffed, plush facsimile.

lead_paragraph: Senator Kay Hagan of North Carolina seems as if she should be part of the firewall in the Democrats’ bid to retain the Senate, considering that incumbents tend to win re-election in states that are competitive in presidential elections.

headline: British Library Opens Renovated Newspaper Collection
abstract: The library’s $56 million newsroom officially opened on Monday, and offering more than 750 million pages of newspapers and magazines in digital form and on microfilm.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — An English-language newspaper published in 1620 in Amsterdam and the scandal-hit News of the World are just some of the journals to be made available to the public as part of an overhaul of the British Library’s newspaper collection.

headline: Thinking of Wine as Food With Eric Asimov
abstract: Eric Asimov, the chief wine critic for The Times, shared some of his experiences from writing about wine.
lead_paragraph: Eric Asimov, the chief wine critic at The Times, writes three columns: “The Pour,” “Wines of The Times” and the recently started “Wine School,” in which he chooses one type of wine a month and discusses it with readers online. He came to The Times in 1984, joining the national desk as a copy editor, and has edited and written for the Living, Styles, Weekend and Dining sections. He wrote the $25 and Under reviews of inexpensive restaurants from 1992 to 2004, when he became the chief wine critic.

headline: When Amazon Collects Sales Tax, Some Shoppers Head Elsewhere
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'E-Commerce', 'Sales and Excise Taxes', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Small Business']
abstract: Research shows that many of these consumers are going to Amazon’s online competitors to spend their money.
lead_paragraph: For years, Amazon watchers — especially Amazon’s competitors and opponents — have wondered just how much the company has benefited from not having to collect sales tax on most of its transactions. Now, three economists appear to have answered the question with a new study: In states that recently forced the online behemoth to begin collecting those taxes, Amazon’s sales have fallen sharply.

headline: Macroeconomics and Class Warfare
abstract: Why Piketty trumps Keynes.
lead_paragraph: Back when Obama was proposing a spending plan to boost the economy, and some of us were pleading for a bigger plan, it was common to hear people from both the right and the crazy center declaring that it was all a ruse, an attempt to smuggle in liberal priorities under the guise of fiscal stimulus. This was, as it happens, completely false – and in the case of the right-wingers, a case of projection. After all, Obama didn’t try to sell permanent spending increases as short-run stimulus – but Bush did exactly that when pushing his tax cuts.

abstract: The e-commerce giant’s deal for a minority stake in Youku Tudou extends a recent frenzy of acquisitions in China’s fast-growing technology sector.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG – Alibaba and Yunfeng Capital, a private equity company controlled by Alibaba’s founder, Jack Ma, agreed to acquire a combined 18.5 percent stake in Youku Tudou, which broadcasts a series of popular television programs and other videos over the Internet.

headline: A ‘Midsummer’ Is Headed for China
abstract: Tim Robbins and the Actors’ Gang, a Los Angeles ensemble theater troupe, will bring their production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” to audiences in China this summer.
lead_paragraph: Tim Robbins and the Actors’ Gang, a Los Angeles ensemble theater troupe, will bring their production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” to audiences in China this summer. Mr. Robbins, the actor who has served as the company’s artistic director for more than three decades, will direct the performances scheduled to take place June 10 to 15 at the National Center for the Performing Arts in Beijing as part of its Shakespeare festival and June 19-21 at the Zendai Himalayas Art Center in Shanghai.

headline: Annual Profit Falls 52 Percent for Angry Birds Maker Rovio
abstract: The Finnish gaming company has diversified its efforts in recent years into movies, animation and theme parks to reduce its reliance on online gaming. Profit was $37 million last year, compared with $77 million in 2012.

headline: France Stalls G.E.’s Alstom Bid
abstract: France puts the brakes on General Electric’s bid for Alstom. | Investors are looking for other ways to profit from the aftermath of the housing crisis. | Pfizer continues its pursuit of AstraZeneca. | Elizabeth Warren seeks a level playing field.
lead_paragraph: The French government on Sunday sought to discourage General Electric’s bid for Alstom, one of the largest industrial companies in France, warning that economic sovereignty was at stake, David Jolly writes in DealBook. G.E. is looking to buy Alstom’s energy business, and France’s economic minister had been scheduled to meet on Sunday with Jeffrey R. Immelt, the chief executive of G.E.

headline: A Monetary Puzzle
abstract: Why do people think that it’s news that banks create money?
lead_paragraph: OK, color me puzzled. I’ve seen a number of people touting this Bank of England paper (pdf) on how banks create money as offering some kind of radical new way of looking at the economy. And it is a good piece. But it doesn’t seem, in any important way, to be at odds with what Tobin wrote 50 years ago (pdf) — indeed, the BoE paper cites Tobin extensively. And I have always thought of money in Tobinesque terms, even if I sometimes use shorthand descriptions that can be misread if you take them out of context; the same is true of many economists.

headline: Sina Apologizes, Twice, for Posting Porn
abstract: The national antipornography office found that the influential Chinese website had 20 articles and four videos that contained “lewd and pornographic content.”
lead_paragraph: Sina Corporation, owner of one of China’s most visited websites, is sorry. Very sorry. So sorry, in fact, that it has apologized not once but twice to its readers and the national antipornography office, which last week found that lewd material had made its way onto the Sina site.

headline: Doing the Math of a Bank of America Settlement
abstract: Bank of America was always expected to pay more than JPMorgan Chase’s $13 billion settlement. But how much more?

headline: How ‘Verified Commenters’ Earn Their Status at The Times, and Why
abstract: It’s all done by algorithm, without human involvement, and some don’t like it.
lead_paragraph: Times readers, especially those who comment frequently on articles, often ask me to explain how members of that special class known as verified commenters get their stripes (or their check marks, to be more precise). The comments of these 478 readers are posted without going through the Times’s moderators – about a dozen people who read comments and decide whether they should be posted. The idea is to expedite the process of getting at least some comments posted, which also lowers the overall number of comments that need moderation in advance.Some don’t like it. Michael Simmons, for one, calls it “unfair and wrong.” In a comment on my recent Sunday column, he wrote: “This has created a hierarchy of commenters wherein the same handful of readers have their comments posted before everyone else — sometimes many hours before everyone else can be vetted. This has led to abuse of the comments section, including verified commenters wishing readers happy holidays on occasion. I’m tired of reading the same commenters at the top of the Reader’s Picks by virtue of the fact that they were able to post before everyone else. This system is undemocratic.”

headline: Wounded Mayor Is Both Colorful and Powerful, Loved and Loathed
abstract: The shot that almost killed Mayor Gennady A. Kernes may yet prove fatal to Kharkiv as it seeks to maintain a fragile political balance in the weeks ahead without his guiding hand.
lead_paragraph: KHARKIV, Ukraine — Fed up with the lifeless and unflattering photographs taken of him by press photographers, Gennady A. Kernes, the mayor of Kharkiv, decided to take matters into his own hands.

headline: Charges in Libor Case for 3 From Barclays
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Interest Rates', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Britain’s Serious Fraud Office said the three men, all former employees of Barclays in New York, would face charges of conspiracy to defraud.
lead_paragraph: Regulators in Britain said on Monday that they had begun criminal proceedings against three additional former Barclays employees suspected in the manipulation of a global benchmark interest rate.

headline: Managing Partner of Leonard Green to Step Down
abstract: Peter J. Nolan will become a senior adviser at Leonard Green & Partners, the Los Angeles-based private equity firm, and will continue to serve on the boards of several of its portfolio companies.
lead_paragraph: One of the three managing partners of Leonard Green & Partners, a private equity firm based in Los Angeles, plans to step down from that role.

headline: Fans Paint U.S. Shows as Friendly to the Party
keywords: ['Censorship', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Television', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: As news that four popular American television shows had been banned from Chinese streaming sites, fans took to social media. Several posts displayed a flair for politically correct rhetoric as users argued to keep other favorite shows online, if only as cautionary lessons for Chinese viewers.
lead_paragraph: Chinese fans of American TV shows that government censors recently ordered removed from video websites have put their frustrations to creative use, writing parody descriptions of shows they hope to save from the ax by incorporating Communist Party-friendly phrases.

headline: Bank of America Finds a Mistake: $4 Billion Less Capital
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: After Bank of America reported its error, the the Federal Reserve required the bank to suspend a share buyback and a planned increase in its quarterly dividend.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:03 p.m. | Bank of America disclosed on Monday that it had made a significant error in the way it calculates a crucial measure of its financial health, suffering another blow to its effort to shake its troubled history.

headline: All the Rage | Fly Like Rich People
abstract: New air-travel services are about to make helicopters and airlines (almost) as accessible as cabs.
lead_paragraph: Air travel is going the way of Uber. EvoLux Transportation, a new helicopter service, will offer ride-share options and on-call private flights from an array of operators. The program is starting in New York and Miami this month, with other American cities to be added in the fall. Also in the works is FlyJets, through which customers with a little tech savvy and a lot of cash will be able to bid on private jet routes, Priceline-style, or book a standard rate immediately without all the auction fuss. In other flight news, JetBlue, the most democratic of airlines, is getting in on the cabin caste system. Starting in June, flights between J.F.K. and LAX will feature first-class seats and amenities, from lie-flat beds to Saxon & Parole-curated tapas.

headline: Grimm, Staten Island Lawmaker, Is Charged With Fraud
abstract: Representative Michael G. Grimm was charged with underreporting wages and payroll while running an Upper East Side restaurant.
lead_paragraph: For more than two years, federal investigators delved into the background of Representative Michael G. Grimm, a Republican from Staten Island now in his second term. They looked into his campaign finances, and examined the potential mob ties of one business associate and the illegal doings of another.

headline: Ads Remind Desert Residents Water Doesn’t Grow on Trees
abstract: The campaign from the Southern Nevada Water Authority encourages awareness of the critical need to conserve water in the region.
lead_paragraph: An effort to promote water conservation among people who live and work in Southern Nevada offers a practical perspective rather than, say, the jocular suggestion during the 1960s to “save water, shower with a friend.”

headline: Forest Labs to Buy Furiex Pharmaceuticals
abstract: The deal, for up to $1.46 billion, expands Forest Laboratories’ position in gastroenterology as it prepares to be acquired for $25 billion by Actavis.
lead_paragraph: The wave of deal-making in the drug industry continued on Monday when Forest Laboratories agreed to acquire Furiex Pharmaceuticals for up to $1.46 billion.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: Thoughts on coining a word, and the new Maxwell House campaign.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Public Relations and Publicity']
