lead_paragraph: Bonfire Labs, San Francisco, hired three employees. They are John Hunt, producer; Judy Leung, designer; and Tim Pries, executive producer.

headline: Cannes Film Festival Announces Feature Film Jury
abstract: The jury includes the actresses Carole Bouquet of France, Leila Hatami of Iran and Jeon Do-yeon of South Korea; the Mexican actor and director Gael García Bernal; and the director Sofia Coppola, among others.
lead_paragraph: The director Sofia Coppola and the actor Willem Dafoe will be among the nine feature-film jurors at the 67th annual Cannes Film Festival, the festival announced on Monday. The New Zealand director Jane Campion will preside over the jury, which will also include the actresses Carole Bouquet of France, Leila Hatami of Iran, and Jeon Do-yeon of South Korea; the Mexican actor and director Gael García Bernal; the Chinese director Jia Zhangke and the Danish director Nicolas Winding Refn. The festival runs May 14 to May 25. Last year’s jury awarded the Palme d’Or to “Blue Is the Warmest Color,” directed by Abdellatif Kechiche, and “Inside Llewyn Davis,” directed by Joel and Ethan Coen, won the second honor, the Grand Prix.

headline: Obama Gives Condolences to Storm Victims
abstract: President Obama offered his condolences to the families of victims after a series of tornadoes caused deaths and widespread destruction in the Midwest and the South on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: President Obama offered his condolences to the families of victims after a series of tornadoes caused deaths and widespread destruction in the Midwest and the South on Sunday.

headline: The Indictment Against Congressman Michael G. Grimm of Staten Island
abstract: The indictment against Mr. Grimm comes after a more than two-year investigation.
lead_paragraph: The indictment against Mr. Grimm comes after a more than two-year investigation.

headline: Daily Report: New York Tech Has a Lot of Money, but No Big Winner
abstract: The most successful start-ups connected to New York are related to the city’s already well-established major industries, like media, advertising and commerce.
lead_paragraph: Predicting that your city will be the next Silicon Valley is simple. But actually making it the next Silicon Valley is something else entirely — as New York is slowly finding out, reports Jenna Wortham on Monday.

headline: U.S. Levies New Sanctions on Russia
abstract: In Manila, President Obama said new sanctions against Russian individuals and companies were “the next stage in a calibrated effort” to change President Vladimir V. Putin’s behavior in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: In Manila, President Obama said new sanctions against Russian individuals and companies were “the next stage in a calibrated effort” to change President Vladimir V. Putin’s behavior in Ukraine.

headline: Swiss Chard and Rhubarb Dress Up Sausage for Spring
abstract: Rhubarb adds a bracing, tart note that cuts the oily richness of the sausage and brightens the earthiness of the greens.
lead_paragraph: What’s for Dinner? answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

headline: Lawmakers Return to Congress With Modest Agenda
keywords: ['Elections', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: With an eye on the midterms, House and Senate leaders will take up workaday legislation rather than tackle contentious issues.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When members of Congress are campaigning for re-election in their districts, they are calling for legislation to address big problems with immigration, taxes, health care, worker pay, climate change and the country’s aging infrastructure. But as they return to Washington on Monday after a two-week break, there is almost no prospect for new legislation in those areas until after Election Day.

headline: India and Pakistan Under Prime Minister Singh
abstract: Though the departing prime minister cannot point to any groundbreaking achievements, political analysts say his policy on Pakistan was pragmatic and saw moderate success despite some serious setbacks.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — As Indian politicians ramp up their campaign efforts, one prominent party leader has been conspicuously missing this election season: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, the leader of India for the past 10 years.

headline: Another Season of ‘Dynasty’ for Voters
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Americans like members of prominent political families more than they’re willing to admit.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it’s time for Americans to admit that we like the familiar faces and names of politicians from famous families.

headline: George Washington’s Weakness: His Teeth
abstract: As he tried to build credibility in a fledgling nation, Washington strove to project dignity and strength. But his dentures were a mortifying sign of frailty.
lead_paragraph: When George Washington opened his mouth 225 years ago this Wednesday at New York’s Federal Hall to take the oath as the first president of the United States, he wore awkward-fitting, painful, face-disfiguring dentures. For years, he had suffered from dental problems; that morning he had swollen, burning gums and only a single original tooth in his mouth. He wore this particular set of dentures during the last nine years of his life. They clacked and creaked open and shut on tight wire springs.

headline: ‘To Kill a Mockingbird’ Finally Becoming an E-Book
abstract: Harper Lee has agreed to let “To Kill a Mockingbird,” one of only a few classics currently available only in print, to be published as an e-book in July.
lead_paragraph: The author Harper Lee has agreed to release her Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, “To Kill a Mockingbird” — one of only a few remaining classics currently available only in print — as an e-book on July 8, HarperCollins Publishers has announced.

headline: Museum Makes Wide Collection of Images Available Online
abstract: The American Museum of Natural History in New York will make thousands of images accessible to the public that were previously only viewable at its research library.
lead_paragraph: The American Museum of Natural History in New York will make thousands of images accessible to the public that were previously only viewable at its research library.

headline: N U M + B E R = P L A Y

lead_paragraph: This week’s challenges were suggested by the mathematician Bill Gosper, the brilliant and largely self-taught computer programmer and researcher considered by many to be a modern-day Ramanujan. I asked Mr. Gosper about this comparison and he responded by email with his usual humility:

headline: Search for Flight 370 Enters New Phase
abstract: Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia said that the chance of finding floating debris from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 was highly unlikely and that the search would shift to the ocean floor.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia said that the chance of finding floating debris from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 was highly unlikely and that the search would shift to the ocean floor.

headline: The Illogic of Active Trading
abstract: Studies show that investors who trade a lot experience reduced returns. In fact, the more they trade the worse their return is likely to be.
lead_paragraph: Individual investors have been busy the last few months. TD Ameritrade saw a 30 percent jump in daily trading volume compared with the same period last year. Other discount brokers reported a similar increase in daily trading volume.

headline: Paul Simon and Edie Brickell in Court Over Domestic Dispute
abstract: The singer-songwriters Simon and Brickell told a judge they were not a threat to each other, after they were both arrested over the weekend in a domestic dispute. The judge decided not to issue protective orders.
lead_paragraph: The singer-songwriters Paul Simon and Edie Brickell held hands in a Connecticut courtroom on Monday and told a judge they were not a threat to each other, after they were both arrested over the weekend in a domestic dispute.

lead_paragraph: More than nine years ago, Gail Dosik started One Tough Cookie, a specialty decorated-cookie company, in her West Village kitchen.

abstract: Gail Dosik operates her specialty decorated-cookie company out of her kitchen in the West Village.
lead_paragraph: Liza de Guia is a video journalist whose blog, Food. Curated., profiles people who produce interesting food in New York and beyond.

headline: In Store | With a New Collection and Installation, Dior Homme Tweaks Its Image
abstract: The designer Kris Van Assche collaborated with the art direction duo M/M Paris on a special installation in the brand’s Greene Street store meant to launch the “Autumn” line as a distinct collection.
lead_paragraph: There is a certain kind of man — often barely out of boyhood — who studies Dior Homme like a holy text, pointedly adhering to the strict minimalism, dark palettes and monastic attention to detail of the collections by the designer Kris Van Assche. These gents — who thronged the brand’s “Autumn” presentation in SoHo last Thursday in sunglasses and complicated ties, with a dedication to black that would be the envy of the Night’s Watch from “Game of Thrones” — should take note: Van Assche was wearing blue jeans. Not black. Blue.

abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Hitler rejects Roosevelt’s plea for peace in 1939.
lead_paragraph: 1939: Hitler Says ‘No’ to Peace Appeal

abstract: Stock linked to Vernon Davis, the San Francisco 49ers tight end, opened for trading on Monday on an exchange operated by Fantex, a start-up.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 2:38 p.m. | The football star Vernon Davis has arrived on Wall Street.

headline: Sit-Down Comic Takes His Place as Anchorman
abstract: John Oliver’s new show, “Last Week Tonight,” on HBO, is the “All Things Considered” to Jon Stewart’s evening news.
lead_paragraph: John Oliver, a graduate of “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart,” didn’t exactly break the mold when he rolled out his new show, “Last Week Tonight,” late on Sunday on HBO; he just tugged at it a bit. If Mr. Stewart’s current-events-based comedy is the equivalent of the evening news, Mr. Oliver gave us a satirical “All Things Considered.”

headline: ‘I Wish People Had More Respect’
Russia and Iran Reported in Talks on Energy Deal Worth Billions
abstract: The deal, reportedly worth $8 billion to $10 billion, could undercut the efficacy of American-led sanctions against Iran.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration’s strategy of punishing Russia with economic sanctions over the Ukraine crisis encountered a new complication on Monday with word that the Russians are negotiating an $8 billion to $10 billion energy deal with Iran, another country ostracized by American-led sanctions, which partly depend on Moscow’s cooperation to be effective.

headline: Why Pfizer Needs to Do More to Win AstraZeneca
abstract: If the British drug company AstraZeneca cannot make Pfizer go away, it can certainly make it pay, Neil Unmack of Reuters Breakingviews contends.
lead_paragraph: Pfizer will need to pile on more pressure if it wants to buy AstraZeneca. Pfizer has confirmed that it made a $99 billion cash-and-stock approach in January for AstraZeneca, its British rival, and is now renewing its suit. AstraZeneca’s chief executive, Pascal Soriot, may ultimately struggle to resist a takeover, but he ought to be able to extract a better proposal.

headline: Jack Ramsay, Who Led Blazers to 1977 N.B.A. Title, Dies at 89
abstract: One of pro basketball’s keenest coaching minds, Ramsay, who was known as Dr. Jack, spent more than 60 years in basketball as a player, head coach and broadcast analyst.
lead_paragraph: Jack Ramsay, the Hall of Fame coach who took the Portland Trail Blazers to their only N.B.A. championship and who was regarded as one of pro basketball’s keenest coaching minds, died on Monday in Naples, Fla. He was 89.

headline: Pear Smoothie With Spinach, Celery and Ginger
keywords: ['Recipes', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Ginger adds zest and banana contributes substance to this kefir — or yogurt-based drink.
lead_paragraph: I have to admit, this began as a “clean out the refrigerator and (aging) fruit bowl” smoothie. I salvaged some spinach that had seen better days and finally used up the last of the pears I’d bought a few weeks ago for another set of recipe tests. I went out to my garden and grabbed some bolting arugula and some mint. I’ve been drinking kefir, a fermented milk product much like yogurt but thinner and tangier, so that went in, giving the smoothie a pleasantly acidic edge. The two ingredients that the drink needs in order for it to taste like something other than a bland green drink are the half banana and the ginger. If you let your bananas ripen completely, then freeze them, they’ll contribute not only flavor, sweetness and texture but also ice to your smoothies.

headline: Blueberry Kefir Smoothie With Greens
keywords: ['Recipes', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: A green drink, rich in anthocyanins, that doesn’t look green, thanks to blueberries.
lead_paragraph: This green smoothie is really more blue than green, as the color of the blueberries predominates. . But the greens are there, so in my mind it’s still a green drink. Half a banana wasn’t quite enough to punch up the flavor of the drink, but I found that a whole banana did the trick. I used a baby greens mix that included baby kale, chard (red and green), and spinach.

headline: Green Smoothie With Pineapple, Arugula, Greens and Cashews
keywords: ['Recipes', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: The pineapple stands up well to the arugula and greens, and ginger pumps up the flavor.
lead_paragraph: Pineapple can stand alone as a fruit to combine with greens in a smoothie. No bananas are required. I did add a piece of ginger to this smoothie and loved the way it pumped up the flavor. I didn’t use any dairy in this one, just orange juice. And I found that it required no additional sweetener, though you could add a teaspoon of agave nectar or honey if you wish. It’s best to use the pungent, feathery wild arugula for this. I used a baby greens mix that included kale, chard and spinach.

headline: Pineapple-Basil Smoothie
keywords: ['Recipes', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: This may look strange, but pineapple marries well with peppery basil.
lead_paragraph: I’m not sure that I would order this just based on the name. But believe me, you’ll be pleased by this herbal concoction. Pineapple has so much sweetness and flavor on its own, and it marries well with the peppery, anisy basil. Very little else is required (no banana in this smoothie). I like to use kefir, but yogurt will work too. Pistachios and chia seeds bulk up the drink nicely, and the pistachios contribute to the pale green color.

headline: Green Smoothie With Cucumber and Cumin
keywords: ['Recipes', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: This savory smoothie resembles an Indian lassi with added spice.
lead_paragraph: This smoothie, the only savory drink in this week’s Recipes for Health, is a bit like an Indian lassi, with a little heat from the pinch of cayenne, and some lovely spice. I used a mix of baby greens – chard, baby kale and spinach, as well as parsley and mint. It makes for a filling lunch.

headline: Hey, Whiny Modern Parents, Tell Us What You Love About the Gig
abstract: Do today’s parents spend more time whining about our lives than our forebears? Time for the still-active Boomer parents, Gen X and the Millenials to defend our status as “fun.”
lead_paragraph: Here’s one for us to run with from  a commenter on last week’s open thread,  Lee Leander:

headline: Why Ron Paul Supporters Were Removed from G.O.P. Leadership in Iowa
abstract: Money from big donors was drying up, and the state’s Republican Party was falling behind in its fund-raising.
lead_paragraph: The ouster of Ron Paul’s backers from Iowa’s Republican Party leadership this weekend might help the state party raise money.

headline: Optimism as Detroit Makes Pacts on Finances
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Collective Bargaining', 'Bankruptcies', 'Government Employees', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: While many issues remain, a deal with representatives of current city workers is one of a number of agreements the city is making to climb out of bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — As the list of deals being struck by this city grows, the chances of a relatively smooth, swift exit from bankruptcy do, too, city officials say. On Monday, Detroit added tentative agreements with some of its unions to pacts already reached with retiree groups, pension funds and several financial creditors, moving the city closer to a plan that would allow it to emerge from bankruptcy by mid-October.

headline: N.B.A. Announcement on Clippers Owner to Come Tuesday
abstract: The N.B.A. said on Monday that it would address its inquiry of the Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling on Tuesday in a news conference.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. will make an announcement Tuesday about its investigation of the Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling, the league said in a statement Monday. League officials will hold a news conference in New York at 2 p.m. Eastern time.

headline: A Website’s Chief Plays Down China’s Curb on American Shows
abstract: The Sohu chief remained hopeful that an order to remove several shows was a one-time tactic, and not the start of a worrisome trend for video sites.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — After recent Chinese government orders to remove four popular American television shows from websites, the chief executive of one company played down the move’s impact on the industry, even as news emerged that the state broadcaster planned to show one sitcom.

headline: Jay Z and Beyoncé to Tour North America This Summer
abstract: The couple will headline a joint tour stopping in 16 cities across the United States and Canada.
lead_paragraph: Most married couples and families hope to get away in the coming months for a calm and quiet summer vacation, but Beyoncé and Jay Z are, safe to say, not a typical married couple. On Monday, they officially announced their summer plans: a joint North American stadium tour called “On the Run.”

headline: As His Tenure Winds Down, Obama Turns Focus to Executive Branch
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: For the remainder of President Obama’s term, what matters most to his success is what Washington watches least: competent governmental management.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John Podesta got a brief burst of attention from his hiring in a White House “shake-up,” Sylvia Mathews Burwell will be in sharp focus in coming confirmation hearings to be health and human services secretary and the cameras loved Jacob J. Lew, the Treasury secretary, during the debt-ceiling wars.

headline: Israel Appears to Raise New Peace Talks Issue With U.S.
abstract: The Israelis suggested that the Obama administration had agreed years ago that there could be absolutely no negotiations with any Palestinian government backed by Hamas.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Days after suspending American-brokered Middle East peace talks because of a reconciliation pact reached between the Palestine Liberation Organization and its rival Hamas, the Islamic militant group, Israel on Monday raised a new source of potential tension with the United States over Washington’s approach to the unity government planned by the Palestinians.

abstract: People who share status updates, photos, videos, fiction or digital art may not realize the reuse rights they are granting to their creative work, according to a new study of 30 popular websites by researchers at Georgia Tech.
lead_paragraph: On Twitter, Facebook and other sites that promote sharing of content, users can typically choose whether they want to post their updates publicly to everyone or carefully select their audience.

headline: Is It Time to Broaden the Definition of Insider Trading?
abstract: William A. Ackman’s actions in the bid for Allergan have raised questions about how well the insider-trading rules have protected investors, Peter J. Henning writes in White Collar Watch.
lead_paragraph: William A. Ackman and Valeant Pharmaceuticals’ hostile bid for Allergen is giving the public a close look at how nonpublic information can be used without breaking insider trading rules.

abstract: Living Symphonies is a sound installation which grows in the same way as a forest ecosystem. Portraying the thriving activity of the forest’s wildlife, plants and atmospheric conditions, it creates a never-ending symphony heard amongst the forest itself.
lead_paragraph: Living Symphonies is a sound installation which grows in the same way as a forest ecosystem. Portraying the thriving activity of the forest’s wildlife, plants and atmospheric conditions, it creates a never-ending symphony heard amongst the forest itself.

headline: Congressman Shown on Video Kissing Aide Won’t Seek Re-election
abstract: Representative Vance McAllister, Republican of Louisiana, has held his seat for only five months.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Vance McAllister, Republican of Louisiana, who was caught on camera kissing a female staff member who was not his wife, will not seek re-election to the seat he has held for only five months, his office said on Monday.

headline: Even a Few Pills Can Put a Dent in the Malaria Rate
abstract: Doctors Without Borders finds that small, cheap doses of medicine helped children significantly during the rainy season in West Africa.
lead_paragraph: A new way to prevent malaria in areas where it waxes and wanes with the weather appears to be working in West Africa, the medical aid organization Doctors Without Borders said last week.

headline: Iraq’s Ailing President Talabani Is Shown Casting a Vote
abstract: Video of the ailing president of Iraq, Jalal Talabani, surfaced just as some voting got underway for the first parliamentary elections since the United States withdrawal in 2011.
lead_paragraph: Video of a rare appearance of the ailing president of Iraq, Jalal Talabani, has surfaced on social media pages, just as some voting gets underway for the first parliamentary elections since the United States withdrawal from Iraq in 2011.

headline: Justices to Weigh Finance Law as It Was Applied to Little Fish
keywords: ['Sarbanes-Oxley Act', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Fishing, Commercial']
abstract: The Supreme Court will decide whether a Florida man who threw undersized fish overboard after an inspection at sea was in violation of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to decide whether a Florida fisherman ran afoul of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, a federal law aimed primarily at white-collar crime, by throwing three undersized red grouper back into the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: A Place for Yoga in the Great Smoky Mountains of Tennessee
abstract: A hidden gem of a resort, known for its delicious food and mountainous views, now has a health and wellness spa.

headline: Middle Seat Nightmare, Stuck Between Mother and Misbehavior
abstract: A luxury travel consultant describes one of her worst flights and how, as a vegetarian, she responded to a client’s five-course lamb dinner.
lead_paragraph: I’VE been a business traveler for the past 25 years. Now, with my own company, Kurtz-Ahlers and Associates, I’m traveling more than I ever have. I’m in the luxury travel business and meet with people all over the world. I love what I do, but whether I like business travel is debatable.

headline: Something to Sing About, Finally, at Airport Security
abstract: PreCheck, the expedited-screening program used by a quarter of all passengers in domestic airports, is making for a less irritable experience.
lead_paragraph: OOPS, I’ve lost still another Victorinox Swiss Army Classic pocketknife — the keychain-size one with handy tools, including tiny scissors and an inch-and-a-half blade. They’re $11.97 on Amazon, and I’ve already ordered a new one to replace the one that was confiscated last week at La Guardia Airport in New York.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | April 22-28, 2014
abstract: A Supreme Court decision, a historic ceremony and a 40th birthday celebration for a popular toy: How many of the questions in this week’s News Quiz can you answer correctly?
lead_paragraph: A Supreme Court decision, a historic ceremony and a 40th birthday celebration for a popular toy: How many of the questions in this week’s News Quiz can you answer correctly?

headline: Signature to Receive Tony for Regional Theater
abstract: Before this year theaters in the five boroughs were ineligible for the annual award.
lead_paragraph: Signature Theater will become the first New York City theater company to receive the noncompetitive Tony Award recognizing a regional American theater, the Tony Awards Administration Committee announced on Monday.

headline: Who Speaks for Pro-Israel Americans?
abstract: The influential Conference of Presidents of Major Jewish Organizations should accept J Street as a member.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday the influential Conference of Presidents of Major Jewish Organizations will vote on whether or not to admit J Street as a member. A vote to exclude J Street would, in a word, be crazy — sending an unfortunate signal about its willingness (or unwillingness) to reflect the broadest range of views, especially on a peace agreement between Israel and the Palestinians.

headline: Edgar Laprade, Center and Gentleman on the Ice, Dies at 94
abstract: Laprade was the N.H.L.’s rookie of the year in 1945-46 and was inducted into the Hall of Fame.
lead_paragraph: Edgar Laprade, the Hall of Fame Rangers center of the 1940s and ’50s who was known for his playmaking skills and his gentlemanly behavior on the ice, died on Monday at his home in Thunder Bay, Ontario. He was 94.

headline: Overriding Their Animal Impulses
abstract: Duke University scientists organized an international effort to test 36 species on cognitive skills related to self-control. The great apes did well, as expected, but there were surprises.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to animal intelligence, says Evan MacLean, co-director of Duke University’s Canine Cognition Center, don’t ask which species is smarter. “Smarter at what?” is the right question.

headline: ScienceTake | Shell Game for Animals
abstract: Intelligence is hard to test, but one aspect of being smart is self-control, and a version of the old shell game that works for many species suggests that brain size is very important.
lead_paragraph: Intelligence is hard to test, but one aspect of being smart is self-control, and a version of the old shell game that works for many species suggests that brain size is very important.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: April 25-27, 2014
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: “Gun control supporters have the blood of little children on their hands.”

headline: Grimm and Prosecutors Discuss Indictment
abstract: Representative Michael G. Grimm of Staten Island; Loretta E. Lynch, the United States attorney in Brooklyn; and George Venizelos, an F.B.I. assistant director, discussed the congressman’s indictment.
lead_paragraph: Representative Michael G. Grimm of Staten Island; Loretta E. Lynch, the United States attorney in Brooklyn; and George Venizelos, an F.B.I. assistant director, discussed the congressman’s indictment.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 45
abstract: Luiz Felipe Scolari, the coach of Brazil’s national team, said protests during the World Cup could cost his team the title.
lead_paragraph: It’s all about timing for Luiz Felipe Scolari, the coach of Brazil’s national soccer team, as the days tick off the calendar toward the start of the World Cup.

headline: Prosecutors Charge Utah Woman in Newborn Deaths
abstract: Megan Huntsman, who is accused of choking and suffocating her babies within minutes of their births, faces a life sentence on each of six counts of murder if she is convicted.
lead_paragraph: PROVO, Utah — Prosecutors on Monday charged a Utah mother with six counts of murder in the choking and suffocation deaths of her babies within minutes of their births. Their tiny bodies were found stuffed into cardboard boxes hidden in the garage of her home in Pleasant Grove, Utah, just south of Salt Lake City.

headline: Fox Plans Live Performance of ‘Grease’
abstract: The network is following NBC, which had success with a live production of “The Sound of Music” and is staging “Peter Pan” for the holidays.
lead_paragraph: No success in television is not worth imitating, as was proved again on Monday with the announcement that Fox will become the second network to commit to a live musical on television — a three-hour production of “Grease.”

headline: Key Justice Dept. Official Is Latest to Join Law Firm
abstract: Mythili Raman is the latest former senior Justice Department official to join the firm where Eric H. Holder Jr. practiced law before becoming attorney general.
lead_paragraph: Two blocks separate Covington & Burling’s offices in Washington from the Justice Department’s headquarters. Covington’s roster of lawyers shows a closer link.

headline: In the Heat of the Night
abstract: It doesn’t just feel that way — there usually is a small but significant rise in core body temperature before a hot flash, which is a mechanism for dispersing heat.
lead_paragraph: Q. When I’m having a hot flash, does my core body temperature actually rise, or does it only feel that way?

headline: Political Executions in Egypt
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Editorials']
abstract: It is clear from the sentencing of 680 people to death in a mass trial that the country’s judges have become a government tool.
lead_paragraph: An out-of-control government in Egypt has now sentenced more than 680 people to death in a mass trial that lasted a few minutes and is part of an organized effort not just to crush its political opponents but to eliminate them. Last month, a court delivered a similar sentence on 529 others. The sentences further demonstrate that the military-led government’s ruthless disregard for the law and its contrary political views go far beyond anything that former President Mohamed Morsi was accused of doing when he was deposed by the army in July.

headline: These Celebrities Want You to Vote for Marianne Williamson
abstract: Marianne Williamson, a spiritual adviser and New York Times best-selling author, is campaigning to represent California’s 33rd District. Here are some of Williamson’s splashiest celebrity endorsements.
lead_paragraph: Much has been made of Marianne Williamson — a spiritual adviser and New York Times best-selling author — and her glittering, celebrity-laden campaign in California’s 33rd District. “She is an exotic political animal and perfect media catnip,” writes Mark Leibovich in “The Real House Candidates of Beverly Hills,” his dispatch from the fight for America’s second-wealthiest congressional district.

headline: North Carolina’s Gay-Marriage Ban Is Challenged by Church
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Freedom of Religion']
abstract: The United Church of Christ, which has supported same-sex marriage since 2005, argues that the state’s ban violates the First Amendment.
lead_paragraph: In a novel legal attack on a state’s same-sex marriage ban, a liberal Protestant denomination on Monday filed a lawsuit arguing that North Carolina is unconstitutionally restricting religious freedom by barring clergy members from blessing gay and lesbian couples.

headline: Bitter Winter Limits the Offerings of Spring
keywords: ['Vegetables', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Winter (Season)', 'Spring (Season)', 'Seasons and Months', 'Restaurants', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Weather']
abstract: Growers struggle to meet the demand by chefs and diners for a fresh seasonal taste.
lead_paragraph: For cooks, particularly those in the Midwest and the Northeast, these are brutal days.

headline: And Baby Makes an Unusual Three
abstract: Lennon Parham and Jessica St. Clair play best friends committed to raising a child together in “Playing House,” a new comedy series on USA.
lead_paragraph: Think of any of the great television series for which friendship was the defining idea — whether six-sided, four-cornered or a simple pairing — and the word “effortless” might come to mind. The actors and the writers made it all look effortless, and thus the friendships were believable.

headline: Yo-Yo Ma and Audra McDonald Among Offerings at Sonoma Concert Hall
abstract: The Green Music Center in California’s Sonoma County will include an array of classical, jazz, pop and world-music concerts in its next season.
lead_paragraph: The effort to put California’s Sonoma County on the map for high culture as well as viniculture will continue next season when the Joan and Sanford I. Weill Hall at the Green Music Center plans to expand its offerings of classical, jazz, pop and world-music concerts.

headline: Art and Film Luminaries Salute Dennis Hopper at Paris Photo Los Angeles
abstract: Family and friends of the late star gathered at Paramount Studios for a screening of his lost 1971 classic, “The Last Movie.”
lead_paragraph: WhoThree of Dennis Hopper’s four children — Marin, Ruthanna and Henry — gathered at Paramount Studios with Hollywood friends like Andrew and Luke Wilson and Todd Phillips (director of the “Hangover” franchise and friend of Ruthanna, Hopper’s daughter with the “Zabriskie Point” star Daria Halprin) and art-world luminaries including Bill Viola and Sophie Calle for a screening of their father’s 1971 lost classic “The Last Movie,” in conjunction with the Paris Photo art fair. Jodi Wille, director of the documentary “The Source Family,” arrived with Hopper’s co-star Stella Garcia. The artist Larry Bell, a friend of Hopper’s since the late ’50s, introduced the film.

headline: An About-Face on a Risky Transplant
abstract: News of the first face transplant, in 2005, was greeted with doubts and criticism. But the first comprehensive review of the more than two dozen such procedures since then has removed many early concerns.
lead_paragraph: When the world’s first face transplant was performed in France in 2005, it pushed medical boundaries and made headlines. Yet the procedure’s future was very much in doubt.

headline: British Publicist Convicted of Indecent Assaults
abstract: Max Clifford, Britain’s best-known celebrity publicist, was found guilty of eight charges of indecent assault, including offenses dating back decades against women as young as 15.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Max Clifford, Britain’s best-known celebrity publicist, was found guilty on Monday of eight charges of indecent assault, including offenses dating back decades against women as young as 15.

headline: A Rubber Band With a Surprising Twist
abstract: A shape rarely seen in nature, a variation on the helix, was accidentally generated by researchers at Harvard.
lead_paragraph: While working with a complex rubber band, Harvard researchers accidentally generated a shape rarely seen in nature, a hemihelix, according to a new study in PLOS One. The unusual shape is a variation on the helix, which is often represented by a DNA strand. The hemihelix is a helix that changes direction midway, as indicated by the arrow, above.

headline: Muslim Leaders Denounce Police Over Raids in Czech Capital
abstract: The publisher of a book said to incite violence and xenophobia was arrested, and 20 people were detained during Friday Prayer at a Prague mosque.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Muslim leaders in the Czech Republic on Monday accused the police of abusing their power after armed officers raided Islamic institutions in Prague over the weekend, detaining 20 people during Friday Prayer at a mosque and a community center, and arresting the publisher of a book that law enforcement officials say incites xenophobia and violence.

headline: We Kill Germs at Our Peril
abstract: Dr. Martin J. Blaser offers a warning against the excessive use of antibiotics, saying it has distorted our internal microbial world, eliminating good bacteria and leading to various diseases.
lead_paragraph: You never get something for nothing, especially not in health care. Every test, every incision, every little pill brings benefits and risks.

headline: Visiting the Alps, With Liszt and Goats
abstract: Installments of David Lang’s “collected stories,” at Zankel Hall, are inspired by travel and folk and include world premieres as well as works by Liszt.
lead_paragraph: The titles of David Lang’s compositions are written in lowercase. There’s a self-effacing quality to his work as composer in residence at Carnegie Hall this season, too; among the six concerts he is presenting at Zankel Hall under the title “collected stories,” only one work is by him. But when it comes to the music of composers he has studied, admired, mentored or championed, it’s a different story: Here Mr. Lang’s interests run wide and include the grandiose and the quirky, the sidesplittingly funny and the extremes of virtuosic self-indulgence.

headline: Some Corals Can Adapt to Warmer Waters
abstract: One species of coral has built up a resistance to warm waters, and “coral stress tests” suggest that other species may be able to adapt, too.
lead_paragraph: Warming ocean waters have already devastated many coral reefs. But new research involving a species of coral that is resistant to higher temperatures suggests that others may be able to adapt, too.

headline: Militants Pose Threat on Eve of National Elections in Iraq
abstract: Iraq’s first nationwide election since the withdrawal of U.S. forces is set for Wednesday, and it is clear it will be held amid growing violence.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Snipers line the rooftops across Falluja, waiting for a chance to shoot at government soldiers, should they try to invade. Homes have been wired to explode, too, just in case the government rushes the city. And roads have been studded with countless steel-plated bombs, of the type that killed so many American soldiers here.

headline: Health Care Politics In One Sentence
abstract: No alternatives.
lead_paragraph: The politics of Obamacare are clearly starting to shift. It’s not that the public is coming to love it — not yet, anyway. But it’s less and less of a bogeyman, with polls suggesting a majority of the public against flat-out repeal. So there’s increasing pressure on Republicans to lay out an alternative — and continuing surprise about their inability to articulate one.

headline: Pakistani Says He Killed 3, Using Gay Site to Lure Them
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Serial Murders', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Hate Crimes', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The arrest of a man who has confessed to using the Internet to lure three murder victims has alarmed gay men and lesbians in Pakistan, where social media has quietly widened freedoms.
lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — The arrest of a confessed serial killer who used the Internet to lure his victims has caused alarm among gay men and lesbians in Pakistan, where social media has been quietly used to widen freedoms in a country where homosexuality is illegal.

headline: Arkansas Governor on Storm
abstract: Gov. Mike Beebe of Arkansas and David Hogue, a spokesman for Faulkner County, discussed the search-and-rescue operation after a series of deadly tornadoes in the state.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Mike Beebe of Arkansas and David Hogue, a spokesman for Faulkner County, discussed the search-and-rescue operation after a series of deadly tornadoes in the state.

headline: Merger Talks of 2 Mining Giants Devolve Into Dueling Statements
abstract: Barrick Gold and Newmont Mining had appeared eager to strike a deal, but the two engaged in a seething back-and-forth over terminated discussion talks.
lead_paragraph: Merger talks between two gold mining firms have devolved into a war of words.

abstract: This man dips his hand in the ice water. Can you tell if he’s really in pain?
lead_paragraph: This man dips his hand in the ice water. Can you tell if he’s really in pain?

abstract: This woman dips her hand in the ice water. Is she really in pain, or is she lying?
lead_paragraph: This woman dips her hand in the ice water. Is she really in pain, or is she lying?

headline: Paradigming Is Hard
abstract: Too many ways to be slightly stupid.
lead_paragraph: Mark Thoma sends us to Justin Fox, who tries hard to be sympathetic to the latest hard science/engineering guy bustling in to show those dumb economists how to do it. But as Fox clearly realizes, the reason we don’t have a new economic paradigm isn’t that economists are dumb, or even that all of them are rigid in their beliefs (obviously some are, or I wouldn’t have as many arguments as I do.) The reason, instead, is that it’s hard.

headline: DJ Rashad, Chicago Dance Music Producer, Dies at 34
abstract: Rashad Harden helped bring footwork, a style of Chicago dance music, to a global audience.
lead_paragraph: DJ Rashad, a producer who helped bring the Chicago dance music known as footwork to a global audience, was found dead on Saturday in Chicago. He was 34.

headline: Complicated Legacy of a Gospel Singer
abstract: Sixteen years after the rising gospel singer Raymond Myles was murdered in New Orleans, there is a renewed push to keep his music alive.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — When the RAMS gospel choir members took the stage on Friday afternoon at the New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival, they began by swaying to a recorded voice that came out of the loudspeakers like a ghost, imploring listeners about “learning to love yourself.”

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Busy day? Catch up on the stories that grabbed our attention.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: How Congress Is Actually Holding Down Medicare Spending
abstract: A rare word of praise for the Sustainable Growth Rate formula, the unsung hero of congressional efforts to control health costs.
lead_paragraph: It’s a rare health policy wonk who has a good word to say about Medicare’s Sustainable Growth Rate formula. That’s the formula created by Congress to govern the amount that Medicare pays to physicians for various treatments. It is supposed to adjust payments to meet an overall spending target tied to economic growth.

headline: John Oliver’s Premiere on HBO Draws 1.1 Million Viewers
abstract: The audience represents a relatively strong start for the network’s new host. “Game of Thrones” continued to break records for HBO.
lead_paragraph: HBO’s newest star, John Oliver, got off to a relatively strong start in his debut as a late-night host on Sundays, with 1.1 million viewers for his premiere.

headline: Noma Back on Top of ‘50 Best’ List
abstract: The Copenhagen restaurant, which was No. 2 in last year’s ranking of the World’s 50 Best Restaurants, has regained the perch it held from 2010 to 2012.
lead_paragraph: Two restaurants traded places Monday at the top of a list of the World’s 50 Best Restaurants, an increasingly influential but somewhat arbitrary ranking published by Restaurant Magazine since 2003.

headline: Photo Diary | Cosplay at the Cherry Blossom Festival
abstract: Scenes from the Sakura Matsuri photo diary of Dina Litovsky.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Sakura Matsuri photo diary of Dina Litovsky.

headline: What Does Today Owe Tomorrow?
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: That simple question goes to the heart of figuring out what we should spend now on efforts to deal with climate change.
lead_paragraph: If you had driven north on Highway 101 toward San Francisco a few summers ago, you might have noticed a banner hanging from a freeway bridge. “What have future generations done for us?” it asked.

headline: Ahead of Tony Nominations, a Look at the Broadway Box Office
abstract: The nominations, to be announced Tuesday morning, could add appeal to the current crop of new musicals.
lead_paragraph: Will the 2014 Tony Award nominations, which will be announced Tuesday morning, reflect the hottest-selling plays and musicals on Broadway? Or did the Tony nominators, who cast their votes in secret on Monday, favor shows with more artistic merit than box office juice? There is no clear front-runner in any of the four top categories, so anything goes.

headline: Podcast: The Origin of Genes, an Antibiotic Overload, Roommate Math
keywords: ['Genetics and Heredity', 'ANTIBIOTICS', 'Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus Aureus', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Mathematics', 'Hospitals', 'Bacteria']
abstract:
Genes make you ... you. But where do they come from? Antibiotics save lives, but their overuse is evolving supergerms and could be changing our bodies. Who pays what rent for which room? Just use this handy calculator and never fight at the end of the month again.
Subscribe to the Podcast »
lead_paragraph:
Genes make you ... you. But where do they come from? Antibiotics save lives, but their overuse is evolving supergerms and could be changing our bodies. Who pays what rent for which room? Just use this handy calculator and never fight at the end of the month again.

headline: Data Murky on Fertility Rates
keywords: ['In Vitro Fertilization', 'Infertility', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: In the multibillion-dollar fertility industry, there is little enforcement of regulations that require clinics to report their success rates.
lead_paragraph: Here’s the question on the minds of people who spend tens of thousands of dollars on fertility treatments: What are my chances of having a healthy baby?

headline: Albums From Wye Oak and Sd Laika
abstract: New music from the rock band Wye Oak and the electronic musician Sd Laika.
lead_paragraph: WYE OAK

headline: The Continuing Evolution of Genes
abstract: Scientists have found that genes are still emerging. Now they’re trying to see why some quickly take on essential tasks, and others fall to the wayside.
lead_paragraph: Each of us carries just over 20,000 genes that encode everything from the keratin in our hair down to the muscle fibers in our toes. It’s no great mystery where our own genes came from: our parents bequeathed them to us. And our parents, in turn, got their genes from their parents.

headline: Handel to Mozart to Morris in a Pastoral Tale of Love and Jealous Rage
abstract: Mark Morris’s two-act “Acis and Galatea,” a pastoral piece to music by Handel that had its premiere in Berkeley, Calif., sometimes tug in opposite directions.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — Mark Morris has often proved the most life-enhancingly musical choreographer alive. In his latest work, the two-act “Acis and Galatea,” you can’t miss multiple layers of his musicality, but sometimes they tug in opposite directions.  Its premiere here was on Friday; it will be seen in Boston in May and at New York’s Mostly Mozart Festival in August.

headline: Are These People in Real Pain or Just Faking It?
abstract: We all know what it’s like to experience pain that makes our faces twist into a grimace. But how do you know if someone else’s face of pain is real or feigned? And can only humans tell the difference?
lead_paragraph: We all know what it’s like to experience pain that makes our faces twist into a grimace. But how do you know if someone else’s face of pain is real or feigned? And can only humans tell the difference?

headline: Reading Pain in a Human Face
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Face', 'Medicine and Health', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Pain']
abstract: Researchers have found that a computer is much better than people are at telling the difference between real and faked pain, a discovery that may lead to methods to detect children’s pain and to treat depression.
lead_paragraph: How well can computers interact with humans? Certainly computers play a mean game of chess, which requires strategy and logic, and “Jeopardy!,” in which they must process language to understand the clues read by Alex Trebek (and buzz in with the correct question).

headline: Art Dealer Seeks to Avoid Prison
abstract: Lawyers for Hillel Nahmad, who pleaded guilty to a charge of operating a gambling business, want him to run and finance a program tied to the Metropolitan Museum of Art as part of his sentencing.
lead_paragraph: Two disparate punishment options will be among those on the table on Wednesday when the art gallery owner Hillel Nahmad arrives in federal court in Manhattan to be sentenced for his involvement in an international gambling ring.

headline: France Plays an Aggressive Hand in Alstom Deal Talks
abstract: The French government’s intimate involvement in a corporate takeover battle spoke volumes about France’s continued efforts to shield its economy.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Shortly after news leaked last week that General Electric was working on a multibillion-dollar deal to buy part of the French industrial giant Alstom, Patrick Kron, Alstom’s chief executive, got an urgent summons.

headline: Light Found in Darkness of Wartime
abstract: Boy meets girl in Anthony Doerr’s novel “All the Light We Cannot See,” but the circumstances are elegantly circuitous.
lead_paragraph: Boy meets girl in Anthony Doerr’s hauntingly beautiful new book, but the circumstances are as elegantly circuitous as they can be. The heroine of “All the Light We Cannot See” is blind, but anyone familiar with Mr. Doerr’s work, which includes the short-story collections “The Shell Collector” and “Memory Wall,” will know that its title has many more meanings than that.

headline: Turks and Armenians

abstract: Peter Balakian of Colgate University writes that Turkey’s recent gesture evades the moral reality of the genocide.

abstract: Sweden’s central bank objects to Paul Krugman’s analogy to Japan.

keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: An airline trade group supports a bill allowing fares to be advertised with the taxes and fees separated out.

headline: The Rights of the Accused
abstract: Two lawyers say those accused of sexual assault on campus lack the fundamental rights of our judicial system.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: For Lab Rats, a ‘Male Scientist’ Effect
abstract: Rodents left alone in a room with a man show a significant rise in a stress hormone, but not when left alone with women, a finding with possible repercussions for scientific research.
lead_paragraph: Male researchers may want to bring a female chaperone when working with rodents, a new study suggests: Rats and mice experience more stress in the presence of men than of women.

headline: From the Bleak Streets to the Ballet Stage
abstract: The French street artist J R, who recently photographed dancers but otherwise is new to ballet, now finds himself choreographing a piece for New York City Ballet.
lead_paragraph: “Don’t you think it needs something after he runs after her?” asked J R recently in a studio at New York City Ballet.

headline: My World Grew at the Fair
abstract: A reader recalls her experience as a college student working at the 1964-65 World’s Fair in Queens.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Silver Anniversary, and the Bride Still Wears White
abstract: The new version of the interactive play “Tony n’ Tina’s Wedding” is self-consciously updated, but strains for laughs.
lead_paragraph: It’s tempting to review the new “Tony n’ Tina’s Wedding” in the style of a “Vows” column in The New York Times: “The bride, a dimwit with a promising future in reality TV, wore a tasteful white gown that contrasted sharply with her bridesmaids’ dresses, which appeared to be on loan from a mid-20th-century jiggle joint.” Or perhaps as a restaurant review parody: “Guy Fieri’s main dish, an indifferent pasta, was garnished with a sprinkling of near-fisticuffs and tangy mother-of-the-bride histrionics.”

headline: Yahoo to Offer TV-Style Comedy Series on the Web
abstract: The move plunges Yahoo directly into the world of original programming, joining the likes of Amazon, Netflix and others to challenge traditional TV producers for viewers’ attention.
lead_paragraph: Yahoo’s chief executive, Marissa Mayer, is about to dive into the shark tank of television-style original video.

headline: Moogfest in Asheville
abstract: Images from the festival.
lead_paragraph: Images from the festival.

headline: Artificial, With a Human Touch
abstract: Moogfest 2014 celebrated electronic music in a five-day event in Asheville, N.C., the home of Moog Music.
lead_paragraph: ASHEVILLE, N.C. — Geekiness reigned, proudly and openly, at Moogfest 2014, the largest iteration yet of a festival created by Moog Music, which makes all of its synthesizers and other equipment by hand at a small factory here in downtown Asheville.

headline: Divide Your Rent Fairly
abstract: When you're sharing an apartment with roommates, it can be a challenge to decide who takes which bedroom, and at what price. Sit down with your roommates and use the calculator below to find the fair division.
lead_paragraph: When you're sharing an apartment with roommates, it can be a challenge to decide who takes which bedroom, and at what price. Sit down with your roommates and use the calculator below to find the fair division.

headline: To Divide the Rent, Start With a Triangle
keywords: ['Roommates', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Mathematics', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: An old mathematical proposition, Sperner’s lemma, can be used to resolve thorny modern predicaments fairly.
lead_paragraph: Last year, two friends and I moved into a small three-bedroom apartment in Manhattan. We chose it for its relatively reasonable price — around $3,000 a month — and its convenient location. Just finding it was a challenge, but then we faced another one: deciding who would get each bedroom.

headline: Security Flaw Hits Microsoft Browser
abstract: Although the security flaw affects various versions of Internet Explorer browsers, the problem is especially troubling for the millions of people still using Windows XP.
lead_paragraph: Updated with more reporting on security flaw. |

headline: After Hours | Bright Light Bright Light Strips Dance-Pop to Its Bare Essence
abstract: In New York last week, the Welsh singer Rod Thomas deconstructed his club-friendly sound, performing with only a piano and three backup singers.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who’s heard the vocals-only track of Whitney Houston singing “How Will I Know?” can attest to the mesmerizing power of dance-pop reduced to its simplest elements. That was the feeling Friday night at Joe’s Pub when the young Welsh singer Rod Thomas, who goes by the “Gremlins”-inspired name Bright Light Bright Light, performed his entire new dance album, “Life Is Easy,” with only a piano and three backup singers. Thomas, who recently moved to Brooklyn from London, has gained a small, obsessive following for his passionate, moody lyrics paired with shimmering dance-pop arrangements that recall the Pet Shop Boys and Erasure, and house tracks as mixed by Shep Pettibone for the “Vogue”-era Madonna.

headline: Three Contractors Sentenced to 20 Years in CityTime Corruption Case
abstract: Federal prosecutors said the defendants were responsible for more than $100 million in losses to New York City through the payroll modernization project.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Manhattan on Monday sentenced three men to 20 years in prison for their roles in the scandal-ridden payroll modernization project known as CityTime, and he also sharply criticized New York City’s contracting procedures for what he called a lack of “adequate and effective oversight.”

headline: From Volunteers, a DNA Database
abstract: The Personal Genome Project is gradually working its way toward 100,000 volunteers who are willing to have their genetic data in the public domain.
lead_paragraph: Abigail Wark wants to see your areolas.

headline: Giving Children of Alumni a Leg Up
abstract: Readers discuss whether the children of alumni should have an advantage over other college applicants.

headline: Reactions
abstract: Letters to the editor and online comments.
lead_paragraph: Nutrition

headline: AT&T Plans to Provide Wireless Internet for Airplanes
abstract: The company said that by late 2015, it would build a new air-to-ground network based on 4G LTE, the same type of cellular technology that many of the latest smartphones use to connect to the Internet.
lead_paragraph: AT&T is looking to expand the reach of its wireless network to devices in the sky. On Monday, the company announced plans to provide in-flight Internet connections for some airlines.

headline: Owners to Invest $800 Million More in Shanghai Disneyland

But despite much in common between the two laws — one in Texas, and the other, the subject of Monday’s hearing, in Mississippi — their effects would differ substantially, raising the possibility that the same court weighing similar laws might arrive at different conclusions.

Johnson is conducting a review of the policy with an eye to reducing deportations.

In Israel, which became the first modern Jewish state a few years after World War II, the observance of Holocaust Remembrance Day even stops traffic, if only for a moment.

headline: Place to Express an Opinion
abstract: Jules P. Markey expresses his opinion.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — When people ask what I do for a living, I always make sure to tell them specifically that I write a blog for the web version of The New York Times. It’s fun to watch the range of reactions cross their faces, because most people still think of The Times in term of the print newspaper, and not everyone is aware of our online presence. And while I thank the universe every day that print is still alive and somewhat well, The Times has come a very long way in terms of presenting the news online in ways that I think are both innovative and well-designed. [The preceding paragraph is not an advertorial, opinions expressed here are Ms. Amlen’s alone, your mileage may vary when driving on the highway, if your puzzle solve lasts for three or more days please consult a physician. –Ed.]

headline: William H. Honan, Journalist and Author, Dies at 83

lead_paragraph: William H. Honan, an author and journalist who directed coverage of the arts at The New York Times as its culture editor in the 1980s, died on Monday in Norwalk, Conn. He was 83.

headline: Three Mile Island, and Nuclear Hopes and Fears
abstract: The disaster at a Pennsylvania plant fueled misgivings about nuclear power, as have those at Chernobyl and Fukushima. But the fossil-fuel alternative still holds great allure.
lead_paragraph: There is a certain irony in the shorthand that experts commonly use when discussing this country’s closest brush with nuclear cataclysm: TMI. Today, those letters are widely understood to mean “too much information.” But well before the advent of social media, TMI referred principally to the Three Mile Island Nuclear Generating Station, a power plant on the Susquehanna River in central Pennsylvania. Disaster struck there in 1979, and when it did, too much information — solid, unassailable information — was not part of the mix. Months later, a presidential commission cited a “lack of communication at all levels” as cause for grave concern. Americans were frightened, and not just those in Pennsylvania. Fear was intensified because, as the commission said, their right to know what was going on had been sorely compromised.

headline: Met Museum to Offer Malian Music, Theater Works and More in Coming Season

headline: No Jail Time for Brooklyn Man Who Threw Bleach on a Rabbi
keywords: ['Assaults', 'Sex Crimes', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: A Brooklyn man avoided jail time in a plea deal that gave him five years of probation, a spokesman for the Brooklyn district attorney’s office said on Monday.
lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn man who threw bleach at an outspoken advocate for victims of sexual abuse in the borough’s ultra-Orthodox Jewish community avoided jail time in a plea deal that gave him five years of probation, a spokesman for the Brooklyn district attorney’s office said on Monday.

headline: Mexico: Mayor Detained in Organized Crime Investigation
abstract: The arrest of the mayor, Arquímedes Oseguera, on Monday came a day after five people were killed on the outskirts of Lázaro Cárdenas when vigilante groups clashed with gunmen who they suspected were criminals.
lead_paragraph: The mayor of Lázaro Cárdenas, the city with Mexico’s second-largest port, has been detained as part of an investigation into allegations that he is involved in organized crime, as Mexico struggles to regain control of a region under the thumb of a powerful criminal gang. The gang, the Knights Templar, had so infiltrated the port, in the Pacific Coast state of Michoacán, that the military took it over last year. The arrest of the mayor, Arquímedes Oseguera, on Monday came a day after five people were killed on the outskirts of Lázaro Cárdenas when vigilante groups clashed with gunmen who they suspected were criminals. Mexico this week plans to begin to disarm the vigilantes and restore state authority.

headline: Central African Republic: Hospital Raid
abstract: Doctors Without Borders expressed outrage on Monday over the weekend killings of 16 civilians, including three staff members, on the property of a hospital it runs in the Central African Republic.
lead_paragraph: Doctors Without Borders, the international medical charity that operates in some of the world’s most dangerous conflict zones, expressed alarm and outrage on Monday over the weekend killings of 16 civilians, including three staff members, on the property of a hospital it runs in Boguila, in the Central African Republic. In a statement on its website, the group said former members of the Seleka Muslim militia raided and robbed the hospital on Saturday, opening fire on community members invited to discuss medical access. Stefano Argenziano, who directs the group’s work in the country, said the group had suspended activities in Boguila and was evaluating whether to continue operations in other parts of the country, which has been split by Christian-vs.-Muslim mayhem. The group was forced to curtail work at an encampment of displaced people in Bangui, the capital, because of the violence and the collapse of government authority.

headline: Ethiopia: 9 Media Workers Arrested
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'United States International Relations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Nine bloggers and journalists were arrested in Addis Ababa last week just days before Secretary of State John Kerry’s scheduled visit to Ethiopia on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Nine bloggers and journalists were arrested in Addis Ababa last week, according to local media and Human Rights Watch, just days before Secretary of State John Kerry’s scheduled visit to Ethiopia on Tuesday. Six bloggers for Zone 9, an Amharic-language website whose writers have criticized the government, and three freelance journalists were arrested. No formal charges have yet been filed. “The timing of the arrests — just days before the U.S. secretary of state’s visit — speaks volumes about Ethiopia’s disregard for free speech,” Leslie Lefkow, deputy director of Human Rights Watch’s Africa division, said in a statement on Monday. Getachew Reda, an adviser to Prime Minister Hailemariam Desalegn, said the arrests had nothing to do with the journalists’ work. “The police have put under custody people who have been suspected of being involved in criminal activities,” he said.

headline: Disney Considered Buying BuzzFeed, but Balked at $1 Billion Price
abstract: Disney’s interest in the fast-growing digital media company, part of a routine effort to identify acquisition targets, faded after BuzzFeed provided a high valuation.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – At least for the Walt Disney Company, BuzzFeed quickly became a buzzkill.

headline: A Deal That Collapsed Leaves a Manhattan Synagogue in Shambles
abstract: The Fort Tryon Jewish Center in Washington Heights, a synagogue built in 1938, still sits in disrepair several years after rebuilding came to a halt.
lead_paragraph: Sitting in the plush velvet and mahogany pews inside the Fort Tryon Jewish Center in Washington Heights, ethereal light streaming in through 80-foot stained glass windows, it is possible to be transported back in time half a century, when the sanctuary was built as an addition to the synagogue, established in 1938.

headline: Nokia Announces New Strategy, and a New Chief to Carry It Out
keywords: ['Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Wireless Communications', 'Cellular Telephones']

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Finnish technology company Nokia announced a new strategy on Tuesday that focuses on its core mobile telecommunications infrastructure business, and it named the head of that division, Rajeev Suri, as its new chief executive.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (13); 11 P.M. (49) PRISON STATE “Frontline” reports on mass incarceration in the United States, where a disproportionate number of the 2.3 million people behind bars come from just a few city neighborhoods. This documentary, directed by Dan Edge, visits a housing project in Louisville, Ky., where a significant percentage of residents have been incarcerated, and follows four — including Keith Huff, who has been in and out of prison for 40 years, and Christel Tribble, 15, above, facing juvenile incarceration for truancy — who have vacillated between custody and freedom. “We’ve gone through an explosion of prison construction in this country, costing us billions of dollars to build and billions to operate, and we’ve come to a fork in the road where we just can’t do that anymore,” says Mark Bolton, the city’s director of corrections, who is working to return inmates to the community. “We can’t afford it — and we’re locking up people who don’t need to be locked up.”

headline: A Link Between Fidgety Boys and a Sputtering Economy
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Men and Boys', 'United States Economy', 'Gender', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Discrimination']
abstract: A gender difference in behavioral skills, seen as early as kindergarten, is hurting boys’ academic prospects and their earning potential.
lead_paragraph: The behavior gap between rich and poor children, starting at very early ages, is now a well-known piece of social science. Entering kindergarten, high-income children not only know more words and can read better than poorer children but they also have longer attention spans, better-controlled tempers and more sensitivity to other children.

headline: 2nd Publisher Pressured Over Hindu Book by U.S. Scholar
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'Censorship', 'Hinduism', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Writing and Writers']

lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — When Penguin India decided to withdraw a book on Hinduism by the American scholar Wendy Doniger in February, it cast a pall over the Indian publishing industry, which was already vulnerable to lawsuits because of the ambiguous language of Indian defamation laws.

headline: In Xinjiang, Xi Pushes Vision of Uighur Integration
abstract: On his visit to the restless province of Xinjiang, President Xi Jinping of China has cast himself as a paternal leader devoted to improving the lives of ordinary people, but also as a firm proponent of a security state dedicated to defending social stability and one-party power.
lead_paragraph: Two sides of China’s policy in Xinjiang — and two sides of China’s president, Xi Jinping — have been on display during Mr. Xi’s visit to the tense western region, where he enthusiastically endorsed policies to integrate the Uighur ethnic minority while warning that his government would be unforgiving toward separatist violence.

headline: Twenty Years After Apartheid
abstract: Joao Silva came of age as a photographer as his native South Africa was navigating a treacherous path to democracy. Twenty years later, he reflects on what has — and has not — changed.
lead_paragraph: In a sprawling South African township stands a tall slab of polished stone etched with names of people killed in the political violence preceding the country’s first democratic elections. It is dedicated to those from Tokoza, where almost 1,000 people died violently some 20 years ago, and sits on Khumalo Street, the very road where many died.

headline: Should Certain Animals Have Some of the Same Legal Rights As People?
abstract: Do chimpanzees have the right not to be kept in a cage? Do orcas have the right not to be held in captivity?
lead_paragraph: Our legal system divides the world into people and everything else. People (and associations of people) have legal rights. Everything else does not. But should animals — or at least certain highly intelligent animals — be given some of the same legal rights as people?In the Op-Doc “Animals Are Persons Too,” Chris Hegedus and D. A. Pennebaker tell the story of the lawyer Steven Wise and his campaign to expand the legal rights of certain animals with a high level of intelligence:

headline: No One Cares About Economic Data Anymore. That’s Good News.
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: There are lots of important reports coming out this week, but don’t expect much excitement. Sometimes dull can be delightful.
lead_paragraph: If people in your office seem to be tingling with excitement this week, it is probably because of all the big economic news on the way. The two biggest regular United States economic reports are scheduled to come out, with first-quarter gross domestic product on tap for Wednesday and April jobs numbers out on Friday. Federal Reserve policy makers are meeting Tuesday and Wednesday for one of their regular sessions to set the nation’s monetary policy. And a variety of other important data releases are coming, including personal income and spending, manufacturing and home prices.

I’d work out how to develop a brand and how to reach the right community of early adopters.

After months of on-again, off-again talks between the company, its owners and creditors, Energy Future Holdings went into Chapter 11 protection with a plan meant to avoid months in bankruptcy court in what will be one of the biggest Chapter 11 filings in history.

lead_paragraph: It had been very quiet in America’s tornado zone of late. But the deadly tornado outbreak Sunday night illustrated, once again, why it’s time for communities at risk to consider some new approaches to building — and learning — safely in harm’s way.

headline: MOCA Hosts a Retrospective of Francesco Vezzoli’s Star-Studded Art
abstract: The museum is showing a career-spanning survey of the artist’s work, much of it inspired by Hollywood — a subject he now says he’ll be moving away from.
lead_paragraph: The old-Hollywood hangout Musso and Frank Grill was an appropriate venue for a dinner last Friday celebrating Francesco Vezzoli’s new retrospective at the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art. Decades ago, iconic stars of a screen era that has long inspired the artist — from Charlie Chaplin to Greta Garbo — dined at the wood-paneled restaurant’s signature red booths. The Italian artist is perhaps most famous for his videos featuring stars like Michelle Williams and Natalie Portman; on Friday, a host of L.A. luminaries — including Bret Easton Ellis and Kate and Laura Mulleavy of Rodarte — turned out to show their support.

headline: In Performance: Tyne Daly of ‘Mothers and Sons’
abstract: The actress performs a scene from Terrence McNally’s new Broadway play.
lead_paragraph: This week’s video is a scene from the Broadway play “Mothers and Sons,” which today received two Tony Award nominations: for the actress Tyne Daly and the playwright Terrence McNally. Ms. Daly portrays Katharine Gerard, a widow who travels to New York to visit Cal, the former partner of her son Andre, who died of AIDS several years prior, and Cal’s new husband, Will. In this scene Katharine, who lives in Dallas, explains why she’s “angry about almost everything.” The show, directed by Sheryl Kaller, is at the Golden Theater.

headline: Where Tornadoes Are a Known Danger, the One That Hits Home Still Stuns
abstract: A series of tornadoes have ravaged large areas of the South this week, killing at least 35 people and leaving residents stunned and weary.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Miss. — Ilene Estes sorted through the rubble atop a concrete slab here that used to be her home of 46 years. Like thousands of others in the South whose homes and lives have been devastated by a series of deadly tornadoes this week, she was stunned and weary. Even in parts of the country where tornadoes are commonplace, when they directly hit your street, they are uncommon terrors, their savagery discovered as if for the first time.

abstract: The 30% Club is bringing about two dozen chief executives, corporate leaders and Warren E. Buffett together to push companies to voluntarily bolster the number of women in management.

Buffett, are joining together to push American companies to voluntarily bolster the number of women in company management, especially senior leadership.

headline: Rent Too High? Move to Singapore
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Income', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: It’s incredibly expensive to live in certain cities, and every fix seems to make it worse. But there is one city that has managed to surmount this problem.
lead_paragraph: Anyone in the market for a luxury apartment in Hong Kong, London or Washington toward the end of last year was in luck. The rents on prime flats were sagging a bit. Billionaires could lock in leases on pieds-à-terre at a slight discount. You might suppose that those savings would trickle down to regular working Joes, but no — middle-market rents in those cities continued their apparently inexorable upward march.

headline: Mike Leigh to Direct ‘Pirates of Penzance’ for English National Opera
abstract: Mr. Leigh will make his operatic directing debut next season, and Peter Sellars will direct Purcell’s “The Indian Queen” and John Adams’s oratorio “The Gospel According to the Other Mary.”
lead_paragraph: More than a few music fans who saw Mike Leigh’s 1999 film “Topsy-Turvy,” about Gilbert and Sullivan’s creation of “The Mikado,” have wondered what Mr. Leigh might do if he ever got the chance to stage one of their operettas. Now they will find out: the English National Opera announced Tuesday that Mr. Leigh would direct “The Pirates of Penzance” next season.

headline: Alliance Battles to Save Fannie and Freddie
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Mortgages', 'Political Advertising', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Bruce R. Berkowitz’s fund, an investor in Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, is helping a group that supports the companies that lawmakers are trying to wind down.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:31 p.m. | The investor Bruce R. Berkowitz is providing seed money for a new group that is running advertisements in newspapers and on television to support Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-sponsored mortgage finance companies that lawmakers are trying to wind down.

headline: Market Report | Busy Bodies
abstract: The bright, artsy one-piece suit is ready for its close-up.
lead_paragraph: With splashy prints that are artfully tropical, the classic one-piece is no longer just for conservative moms.

headline: Why Piketty’s Book Is a Bigger Deal in America Than in France
abstract: The varying reception of a work respected in its home country, but a sensation in English, speaks to the differences between two nations.
lead_paragraph: The American response to Thomas Piketty’s new book on inequality has been rapturous, with reviews comparing the author, a French economist, to Adam Smith, John Maynard Keynes and Karl Marx.

headline: Editorial Contest Winner | Intelligence Over Diversity
abstract: We’re publishing one of the Top 10 winners of our Student Editorial Contest each day. This essay is by Ashley K.
