headline: 90 and Facing Eviction
keywords: ['Elderly', 'Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Evictions']
abstract: Last month, 90-year-old Bella Hornung received an eviction notice from her assisted-living home in Brooklyn. She is determined to stay as long as possible, though aware that her options are dwindling.
lead_paragraph: Last month, 90-year-old Bella Hornung received an eviction notice from her assisted-living home in Brooklyn. She is determined to stay as long as possible, though aware that her options are dwindling.

headline: Senate Panel Approves Nominees to Help Fill Fed
abstract: The two nominees for the Federal Reserve’s board must be confirmed by the full Senate, which has a backlog of candidates awaiting confirmation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate Banking Committee on Tuesday approved the nominations of Stanley Fischer and Lael Brainard to join the Federal Reserve’s depleted board, and it approved the nomination of Jerome H. Powell to a new term.

headline: Up in Years and All but Priced Out of New York
keywords: ['Affordable Housing', 'Elderly', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Finding adequate housing has become an all-consuming preoccupation for many aging residents, a group whose explosive growth and changing needs pose challenges for the city.
lead_paragraph: Nubia Chavez and Manuel Acuña have been bouncing from rental to rental around New York City like millennials. They recently decamped to a $700-a-month room in a Queens apartment, with a shared bathroom and no access to the kitchen except to make coffee.

headline: More Severe Weather After Deadly Tornado Outbreak
abstract: More tornadoes were expected in the same parts of the South that were hard hit by severe weather on Monday.
lead_paragraph: At least 11 people died Monday in Alabama, Mississippi and Tennessee after a powerful storm system spawned multiple tornadoes and ripped across several states in the South, bringing the total death toll from the severe weather to more than two dozen people since Sunday, as our colleagues report.

headline: The Gun Report: April 29, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Guns are being traded for drugs in Vermont and Massachusetts, and it has law enforcement worried, the Boston Globe reports. Vermont is grappling with a heroin epidemic that started for many as a prescription drug habit, and Massachusetts has tough gun laws, creating a toxic opportunity.

headline: Stop Worrying and Enjoy Rising Wages
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: The Fed can relax: There’s no evidence that the recent bit of wage acceleration is feeding into faster inflation.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve’s Open Market Committee is meeting this week, and if I may slightly tweak the hit song from the Disney movie “Frozen” so that it’s more relevant to monetary policy:

headline: Justices Back Rule Limiting Coal Pollution
keywords: ['Coal', 'Air Pollution', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Clean Air Act', 'States (US)']
abstract: The Supreme Court upheld the E.P.A.’s authority to regulate coal-plant pollution that drifts from more than two dozen Midwestern and Appalachian states to the East Coast.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a major victory for the Obama administration, the Supreme Court on Tuesday upheld the authority of the Environmental Protection Agency to regulate the smog from coal plants that drifts across state lines from 28 Midwestern and Appalachian states to the East Coast.

headline: ‘If You Think Preschool’s Bad, Just Wait Until Kindergarten’
abstract: As my neighbors keep reminding me, preschool is just the first of the crazy New York City school admissions processes. Next up, kindergarten. Why do I put up with it?
lead_paragraph: I pushed the stroller into our packed elevator. “Did you decide on school?” a neighbor asked, smiling at Zee. But before I could nod, she went on, cackling, “If you think preschool’s bad, just wait until kindergarten.”

headline: Why Is It So Hard to Capture the Writer’s Life on Film?
abstract: Thomas Mallon and Dana Stevens discuss the difficulties of conveying what writers do on film.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. Thomas Mallon and Dana Stevens discuss the difficulties of conveying what writers do on film.

headline: More Catholic Than the Pope?
keywords: ['ADULTERY', 'Beatifications and Canonizations', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Marriages', 'Priests']
abstract: Further thoughts on divorce, doctrine, and potential Catholic divisions.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column used the double canonization of two of his predecessors to discuss some of the perils awaiting Pope Francis as his pontificate advances, and it concluded with a fairly stark claim: Some of the proposals on divorce, remarriage and communion that have been put forward by prominent figures in the church, I wrote, might lead to schism if the pope were to adopt and implement them.

headline: South Korea President Apologizes
abstract: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea apologized for failing to prevent a ferry disaster that left 302 people dead or missing and announced broad reforms to make the country safer.
lead_paragraph: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea apologized for failing to prevent a ferry disaster that left 302 people dead or missing and announced broad reforms to make the country safer.

headline: What Are Tonys Saying by Ignoring ‘Realistic Joneses’?
abstract: Adventurous producers shouldn’t be dissuaded by the “ostentatious snubbing” of Will Eno’s challenging play.
lead_paragraph: It’s a scandal! It’s an outrage! And it’s utterly predictable.

headline: Today in Small Business: More Frightening Than Skydiving
abstract: Six ways to collect customer reviews. And those reports about rising gas prices? They’re wrong.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

abstract: President Obama defended his strategy, saying “disputes must be resolved peacefully and not by intimidation or force.”
lead_paragraph: President Obama defended his strategy, saying “disputes must be resolved peacefully and not by intimidation or force.”

abstract: The oldest of the giant private equity firms is dipping a toe into social media.
lead_paragraph: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the oldest of the giant private equity firms, is dipping a toe into social media.

headline: How the Struggles of Boys Play Into the Still Sputtering Economy
abstract: The behavior gap between boys and girls is greater than the performance gap between low- and high-income children, and that, writes David Leonhardt at The Upshot, isn’t good for anyone.
lead_paragraph: At The Upshot, David Leonhardt links fidgety boys with the poorly functioning economy:

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 44
abstract: Adnan Januzaj is set to train with Belgium after recently pledging his international allegiance to the country.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Taking On a Pothole Law: In Winter, New York State Rejects Drivers’ Claims
abstract: Legislators want to amend a law that says Albany can be held liable for pothole damage that occurs only from May 1 to Nov. 15.
lead_paragraph: Thomas J. Abinanti, a Democratic assemblyman from Westchester County, was driving to Albany on the Taconic State Parkway in January when his car struck a pothole. He made it to the capital, but the tire had to be replaced. A few weeks later, he hit another pothole, this one on Interstate 95. Limping off the exit ramp in Mamaroneck on the dented rim, he pulled into a nearby gas station.

headline: 92nd Street Y Names Two Leaders
abstract: Henry Timms will become executive director and Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein will become director of Jewish community and the Bronfman Center for Jewish Life.
lead_paragraph: The 92nd Street Y on Tuesday announced two new major leadership appointments. Henry Timms will become its new executive director and Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein will become director of Jewish community and the Bronfman Center for Jewish Life.

headline: The Folly of Prudence
abstract: Potholes persisting for no reason.
lead_paragraph: Many American roads are in pretty bad shape — I can attest to that, after driving up to Massachusetts and back for family business last week. When you combine that fact with the underlying macroeconomic situation, of which more in a minute, the case for spending substantial sums on repair seems obvious.

headline: British Parliament Berates Officials on Royal Mail I.P.O.
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Privatization']
abstract: Both Conservative and Labour ministers attacked Vince Cable, the British business secretary, saying the initial public offering left as much as 1.2 billion pounds on the table.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Usually it is falling stock prices after initial public offerings that cause headaches for bankers and business executives. In the case of Britain’s Royal Mail, it is the company’s soaring value that has ignited outrage.

headline: Money Talks. Especially Boehner’s.
abstract: Right-leaning representatives would like to oust the House speaker, but his formidable fund-raising and willingness to share make him valuable.
lead_paragraph: Some House Republicans may feel they have good reason to oust John Boehner as Speaker next year, but there is at least one good reason not to: fund-raising. Mr. Boehner has been an increasingly important source of money for the National Republican Congressional Committee, the party wing that helps the G.O.P. maintain (and increase) its House majority.

headline: After Deriding G.O.P. on Immigration Bill, Boehner Shifts His Aim to Obama
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner and Democrats suggested that a narrow window for an immigration overhaul could open if Congress and President Obama built good will on smaller bills.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A week after mocking his Republican troops over their resistance to an immigration bill, Speaker John A. Boehner returned to Capitol Hill on Tuesday with a different message: Any movement on an overhaul will depend on a new White House attitude toward Republicans in Congress.

headline: Image of the Day: April 29
abstract: Summer season in India is synonymous with the arrival of mangoes.

headline: Pfizer Most Likely Just the Tip of the Tax Sword
keywords: ['Corporate Taxes', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Relocation of Business']
abstract: The biggest charm of Pfizer’s offer for AstraZeneca lies in switching to a lower-tax domicile, a strategy that is sure to be duplicated, Robert Cyran writes for Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Pfizer’s $99 billion tax arbitrage bid will encourage copycats. The biggest charm of the United States drug giant’s offer for AstraZeneca of Britain lies in switching to a lower-tax domicile. The latest and largest such deal to hit the headlines raises the odds Congress will tighten rules – but not yet.

headline: For Obama, a Familiar Region With Familiar Troubles
abstract: President Obama reiterated his ties to the region in his latest trip to Southeast Asia, coming amid concerns about the White House abandoning the Asia “pivot” of the first term.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — For President Obama, a visit to Southeast Asia is a homecoming of sorts. Nowhere was that more evident than in the town-hall-style meeting he conducted on Sunday in the Malaysian capital Kuala Lumpur with young people from across the region.

headline: Santander Offers $6.5 Billion to Buy the Rest of Its Brazil Unit
abstract: Santander announced a deal to acquire the 25 percent of Santander Brasil that it does not already own for 4.69 billion euros, or $6.52 billion.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Banco Santander announced on Tuesday a deal to acquire the 25 percent of its Brazilian unit, Santander Brasil, that it does not already own for 4.69 billion euros, or $6.52 billion.

headline: European Union Demand Lifts Gazprom Earnings
abstract: The 2013 results from the Russian gas supplier predated escalation of the crisis in Ukraine and sanctions, which the company acknowledged as risks.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Gazprom, Russia’s largest company, reported Tuesday a solid showing for its yearly earnings, which were up 10 percent in 2013, with most of the increase attributable to growing demand in the European Union.

headline: Instead of Saving for College, We Invested in Our Kids
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Parenting', 'Savings', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'United States Economy']
abstract: We began saving for our son’s college education soon after he was born—but prioritizing that saving became hard almost immediately. What was more important, sending our son to preschool or saving for college?
lead_paragraph: This spring break, I sent my 17-year-old-son and his dad off on a three-state college tour with a dozen hard-boiled eggs, a rolled-up tent and tears.

headline: Even When Expecting Tornadoes, People Don’t Plan Well
abstract: Polling shows that many residents of areas prone to deadly storms don’t have an emergency plan or an emergency supply kit for their families.
lead_paragraph: The recent rash of tornadoes and deadly storms was not unexpected. It is, after all, peak season in the South and Midwest for tornadoes. Polling shows that large numbers of people living in these regions recognize that their communities are liable to be hit by a natural disaster, but most don’t have an emergency plan or an emergency supply kit for their families.

headline: N.B.A. Bars Clippers Owner Donald Sterling for Life
abstract: Adam Silver, the league’s commissioner, also said he would try to force Donald Sterling to sell the team in the aftermath of racist remarks by Sterling that became public.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The National Basketball Association on Tuesday handed a lifetime ban to the longtime Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling, an extraordinary step in professional sports and one intended to rid the league of Mr. Sterling after he was recorded making racist comments.

headline: Art Matters | An Exhibition and Video Puts Art in the Hands of the Beholder
abstract: A lively, soon-to-be-viral clip narrated by Reggie Watts accompanies “Do It,” the latest iteration of the curator Hans-Ulrich Obrist’s instructional art show going on view at the Garage Museum of Contemporary Art in Moscow.
lead_paragraph: In 1919, Marcel Duchamp changed the course of art history when his sister Suzanne got married. Instead of mailing her a porcelain tea set or personalized table linens, the impish Duchamp sent several pages of text: a set of instructions that told Suzanne how to create the wedding present he imagined. (She was directed to hang a geometry textbook by strings from the balcony so that the wind could “choose its own problems.”) Since then, artists like Yoko Ono and Lawrence Weiner have taken Duchamp’s lead and run with it — making art by telling their audience what to do.

headline: Virginia Attorney General Opens In-State Tuition to Students Brought to U.S. Illegally
keywords: ['Tuition', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals']
abstract: Attorney General Mark R. Herring, a Democrat, issued the legal opinion after Republicans in the General Assembly killed a state Dream Act early this year.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Mark R. Herring of Virginia told the state’s public colleges and universities on Tuesday that children brought to the United States illegally and raised here, the so-called Dreamers, qualified for in-state tuition.

headline: Crunching the Numbers to Find the Best Airfare
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Budget Travel', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: What’s the cheapest day to book? To depart and return? A company called Hopper offers insight.
lead_paragraph: You may have heard that the best day to buy an airline ticket is a Tuesday.

headline: Hotel Review: Belmond El Encanto in Santa Barbara, Calif.

headline: Restaurant Report: Ristorante Oreade in Castiglioncello del Trinoro, Italy
abstract: This spot, which opened last summer, is evidence that Tuscan cuisine can be lifted higher.
lead_paragraph: Tuscany’s food scene has never left visitors wanting improvement, but that hasn’t stopped local restaurateurs from striving for it. One recent addition, Ristorante Oreade, which opened last summer, is evidence that Tuscan cuisine — from food quality and presentation to restaurant design — can be lifted higher.

headline: Britain Outlines Stress Test for Its Banks
abstract: The Bank of England says banks will have to have enough capital to withstand 12 percent unemployment and a 35 percent decline in housing prices.
lead_paragraph: Imagine that things started to look very gloomy in Britain. The value of the pound falls, inflation rises, interest rates spike to 4 percent. The economy shrinks by 3.5 percent, unemployment reaches 12 percent, and housing prices fall 35 percent, with commercial real estate declining 30 percent. Stocks and bonds weaken and bank funding dries up.

headline: Military Aid for Egyptians Loses Support in the Senate
abstract: Senator Patrick J. Leahy said he would not support additional aid in the wake of mass death sentences handed out by Egyptian courts this week.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Patrick J. Leahy, chairman of the Senate subcommittee that oversees foreign aid, said Tuesday that he would not support additional military aid to Egypt in the wake of mass death sentences handed out by Egyptian courts this week, adding significant pressure on the Obama administration to shift course.

abstract: On the Minute, the theater reporter Patrick Healy breaks down the nominees for the 68th Tony Awards. Find out who was nominated and who got snubbed.

headline: Ai Weiwei Erased From Show in Shanghai
abstract: Shanghai cultural officials ordered that the name and works of Ai Weiwei be removed from an art show.
lead_paragraph: The name and works of Ai Weiwei have been removed from a show in Shanghai about the history of Chinese contemporary art because of pressure from local government cultural officials, according to Mr. Ai and Uli Sigg, a Swiss art collector who helped organize the exhibition. Mr. Ai said he thought the move was in response to his vocal criticism of the Chinese government.

headline: Revisiting the Racial Gap in N.B.A. Coaching Tenure
abstract: A 2005 analysis found that black coaches were fired more quickly than white coaches.
lead_paragraph: With race and professional basketball in the news again, we thought it was a good time to revisit an article that Ford Fessenden and I wrote for The Times in 2005. I’d welcome thoughts and predictions on patterns in the last decade and in the future. Here are excerpts from the article:

headline: A Gust of Sesame and Saffron
abstract: Flavors of the Middle East are increasingly beguiling high-end chefs.
lead_paragraph: When Ghaya Oliveira was appointed head pastry chef for the restaurant empire of Daniel Boulud, she began a stealth campaign. As she constructed new desserts for Daniel, the very French flagship in a very upscale ZIP code, she started to sneak in the flavors of her childhood in Tunisia: jasmine and sesame, rosewater and saffron.

headline: Listen Up | More Fearless Storytelling from Sharon Van Etten
abstract: The celebrated Brooklyn singer-songwriter debuts a track from her new album, out May 27.
lead_paragraph: The first song on the singer-songwriter Sharon Van Etten‘s thrilling new album, “Are We There,” out May 27, features this refrain: “I need you/to be afraid of nothing.” She might, perhaps, be referring to herself. Van Etten’s songwriting shows little traces of fear, setting matter-of-fact descriptions of awfully complicated emotions against deceptively simple verse structures. The songs are brave, and bravely unflashy. And that voice of hers — gritty, lilting, with phrasing that suggests that efforts to reveal herself cause just as much of herself to hide — sounds not merely fearless but unafraid of fear itself.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Scott Brown’s Take on ‘Obamacare’
abstract: He thinks it’s disastrous, but seems to like everything it does.
lead_paragraph: Like confused poll respondents, Scott Brown, the former Massachusetts Senator who’s running for Senate in New Hampshire, says he thinks the Affordable Care Act is disastrous, but seems to like everything it does.

headline: A Corporate Paean to Frank Lloyd Wright
abstract: A museum replicating a lab in the Research Tower at S. C. Johnson’s headquarters in Racine, Wis., is opening as part of an eight-year, $30 million restoration project.
lead_paragraph: RACINE, Wis. — If anything is eternal in real estate, it is the dance of desire that exists between chief executives and their architects.

headline: Company Polishes Its Frank Lloyd Wright Collection
abstract: This week a portion of the Research Tower designed by Frank Lloyd Wright at the headquarters of S.C. Johnson in Racine, Wis., will reopen as a museum. The project is part of an eight-year effort by the company to restore its Wright campus.
lead_paragraph: This week a portion of the Research Tower designed by Frank Lloyd Wright at the headquarters of S.C. Johnson in Racine, Wis., will reopen as a museum. The project is part of an eight-year effort by the company to restore its Wright campus.

headline: After Data Breach, Target Plans to Issue More Secure Chip-and-PIN Cards
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Computer Security', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Credit Cards', 'Debit Cards']
abstract: The company also announced an accelerated timetable — by early next year — for shifting all of its Redcard debit and credit cards to chip-and-PIN technology, which is widely used in Europe and is considered more secure than cards that rely on magnetic strips.
lead_paragraph: Still pushing to right itself after an enormous data breach by cybercriminals, Target announced on Tuesday that it would switch its debit and credit cards over to a more secure technology by early next year, most likely making it the first major retailer in the country to do so.

headline: Justices Appear Divided on Cellphone Warrants
abstract: With everything from banking information to medical records stored on smartphones, the Supreme Court was asked to weigh law enforcement’s search procedure against personal privacy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday seemed torn as it considered a pair of cases about whether the police need warrants to search the cellphones of people they arrest.

headline: Jaclyn Moriarty Talks About ‘Cracks in the Kingdom’
abstract: Ms. Moriarty discusses the second volume in her fantasy trilogy for young adults.
lead_paragraph: Jaclyn Moriarty, an Australian writer of young-adult fiction, has just published “The Cracks in the Kingdom,” the second volume in her lively and engaging “Colors of Madeleine” trilogy. Book 1, “A Corner of White,” was a Boston Globe-Horn Book honor title. The novels tell the story of a girl named Madeleine, who lives in our world, and a boy named Elliot, who lives in the Kingdom of Cello. They begin writing letters to each other through a crack that opens between their worlds — a crack in a parking meter.

headline: Up for Discussion: Why Have an Advisory Board?
abstract: One owner said the company’s needs change so much that she has a different problem every day. Instead of forming a board, she has reached out to people in response to specific problems.
lead_paragraph: At the most recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, the owners continued their discussion of advisory boards.

headline: Middle Eastern Ingredients | Tahini
abstract: Rawia Bishara, the chef and owner of Tanoreen, discusses tahini made from sesame, one of the most universal flavors of the Middle East and the base for many of its staples.
lead_paragraph: Rawia Bishara, the chef and owner of Tanoreen, discusses tahini made from sesame, one of the most universal flavors of the Middle East and the base for many of its staples.

headline: Middle Eastern Ingredients | Za’atar
abstract: Lior Lev Sercarz, a New York spice purveyor, demonstrates how to prepare za’atar, a fundamental Middle Eastern seasoning.
lead_paragraph: Lior Lev Sercarz, a New York spice purveyor, demonstrates how to prepare za’atar, a fundamental Middle Eastern seasoning.

headline: Middle Eastern Ingredients | Yogurt
abstract: Ghaya Oliveira, the executive pastry chef at Daniel, discusses using yogurt as a sweet ingredient in Middle Eastern-influenced desserts.
lead_paragraph: Ghaya Oliveira, the executive pastry chef at Daniel, discusses using yogurt as a sweet ingredient in Middle Eastern-influenced desserts.

headline: Before Watchdog Mission, a Trail of Videos Warned of Chlorine Gas Attacks in Syria
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Terrorism', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons said that it was sending a mission to Syria, where activists have been posting video showing civilians coughing and struggling to breathe after attacks.
lead_paragraph: Syrian activists have been posting multiple videos in the past few weeks showing civilians at medical facilities in the village of Kafr Zita coughing and struggling to breathe, with the narrators during the footage identifying the cause of their condition as coming from the use of chlorine gas bombs.

headline: One Execution Botched, Oklahoma Delays the Next
abstract: An inmate’s execution was stayed after another condemned man, Clayton D. Lockett, died in what witnesses said was an agonizing scene: He writhed and said, “Oh, man,” after being declared unconscious.
lead_paragraph: McALESTER, Okla. — What was supposed to be the first of two executions here on Tuesday night was halted when the prisoner, Clayton D. Lockett, began to writhe and gasp after he had already been declared unconscious and called out “oh, man,” according to witnesses.

headline: Cast Is Announced for Next ‘Star Wars’ Film
abstract: The seventh installment of the space epic will feature seven newcomers and six stalwarts.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After months of fan speculation, J.J. Abrams on Tuesday finally switched off the cloaking devices protecting the identities of his “Star Wars” cast members. Seven newcomers and six stalwarts will star in the seventh installment of the space epic, which is scheduled for release in theaters in December 2015.

headline: Standing on the Sidelines With Virtual Reality
abstract: Imagine sitting on the sideline of a football game or hanging out next to a drummer of your favorite concert. Next3D, a movie company in Los Angeles, hopes to make this a reality by merging 3-D film technologies and virtual reality headsets.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — D.J. Roller, a filmmaker and explorer, has captured videos of sharks, taken cameras under the Antarctic ice, and documented the discovery of the remains of a Tyrannosaurus Rex.

headline: N.B.A. Bars Clippers Owner for Life
abstract: The league commissioner, Adam Silver, called remarks by the Los Angeles Clippers owner, Donald Sterling, “deeply offensive and harmful.”
lead_paragraph: The league commissioner, Adam Silver, called remarks by the Los Angeles Clippers owner, Donald Sterling, “deeply offensive and harmful.”

headline: Turks to Seek Extradition of Preacher Living in U.S.
abstract: The Turkish prime minister has accused the Pennsylvania-based preacher’s followers of trying to undermine his government through a corruption investigation.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan said Tuesday that Turkey would officially request that the United States extradite Fethullah Gulen, a Turkish preacher in Pennsylvania whose network of followers has been accused of trying to undercut Mr. Erdogan’s government through a corruption scandal.

headline: Mercedes Recalls 253,000 C-Class Cars for Fire Hazard
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: A wiring problem caused the recall, and a few customers reported minor trunk fires related to the defect.
lead_paragraph: Following an investigation by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Mercedes-Benz is recalling about 253,000 C-Class cars from the 2008-11 model years because the taillights could fail, according to a report the automaker posted Tuesday on the safety agency’s website.

headline: Godzilla’s Back, With Moral Authority
abstract: There are three versions of Godzilla stalking the landscape this Spring, including the 60th anniversary restoration of the anti-nuclear original.
lead_paragraph: There are at least three versions of Godzilla stalking the landscape this Spring. There’s the campy, frat-boy Godzilla who parties and water skis in the Snickers candy bar commercial. There’s the apocalyptic, computer-generated terror who roars at us with a gale-force voice in the trailers for the Hollywood blockbuster due out next month. And making its way quietly through select theaters across the country is the 60th anniversary restoration of the original Godzilla classic — featuring a mere actor in a latex monster suit.

headline: Dudamel & Adams: Resurrection
abstract: Part 11: John Adams recalls writing the final scene of “The Gospel According to the Other Mary.”
lead_paragraph: Part 11: John Adams recalls writing the final scene of “The Gospel According to the Other Mary.”

headline: Dudamel & Adams: Unrest in Venezuela
abstract: Part 10: Gustavo Dudamel reflects on the political situation and street protests in Venezuela.
lead_paragraph: Part 10: Gustavo Dudamel reflects on the political situation and street protests in Venezuela.

abstract: Part 9: John Adams talks about composing for chorus and explains how “The Gospel According to the Other Mary” was influenced by current events.
lead_paragraph: Part 9: John Adams talks about composing for chorus and explains how “The Gospel According to the Other Mary” was influenced by current events.

headline: Alliant Techsystems’ Break-Up and the Return of the Morris Trust
abstract: Alliant Techsystems chose to break itself apart through a rarely used corporate maneuver known as the Morris trust, meant to avoid incurring taxes.
lead_paragraph: It’s rare enough to see companies use the reverse Morris trust, a somewhat esoteric corporate finance maneuver used to cut down on taxes in a merger. But it warmed DealBook’s heart on Tuesday to see a company use the even less common Morris trust.

headline: The Quirk That Bolsters Allergan’s Defense
abstract: In any maneuvering around a proxy contest, the $45.6 billion takeover target has an advantage and it has time, writes Steven M. Davidoff in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: In the $45.6 billion takeover battle for Allergan, there has been much speculation about what will be the next steps.

headline: Pfizer’s Move Poses Challenge. Here’s a Solution.
abstract: The extremes to which companies go to minimize their tax liability suggests it’s time for a new approach, one focusing on shareholders instead.
lead_paragraph: This is what strange behavior our corporate tax policy produces: The pharmaceutical company Pfizer has offered $100 billion to buy AstraZeneca, a British competitor, and avoiding taxes has a lot to do with it.

headline: Shirley
abstract: Shirley Austin speaks about how her therapy dog has helped her.
lead_paragraph: Shirley Austin speaks about how her therapy dog has helped her.

abstract: Amber (who did not disclose her last name,) talks about how the voices of schizophrenia impact her life.
lead_paragraph: Amber (who did not disclose her last name,) talks about how the voices of schizophrenia impact her life.

headline: Alice
abstract: Alice finds that painting helps her deal with the stress of schizophrenia.
lead_paragraph: Alice finds that painting helps her deal with the stress of schizophrenia.

headline: A Texas Bankruptcy Seeks a Home in Delaware
abstract: Energy Future Holdings, a company concentrated in Texas, turned to a Delaware court for its bankruptcy case, prompting an objection, writes Stephen J. Lubben in the In Debt column.
lead_paragraph: Energy Future Holdings, the big Texas utility company formerly known as TXU, and its myriad related companies filed their Chapter 11 bankruptcy petitions in Wilmington, Del., on Tuesday morning.

headline: A Grande Dame Branches Out
abstract: Diana Kennedy, an authority on Mexican cuisine, is opening a center on ecology and food.
lead_paragraph: The day of reckoning came on a recent Tuesday for the tacos, enchiladas verdes, cactus salad and pork posole served at Tortilleria Nixtamal in Corona, Queens.

headline: Battery Park City: Quasi-Suburban
abstract: A place where financial-sector workers still live and walk to work, but a growing number of families are also drawn to the neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: Battery Park City, the 92-acre planned community developed since 1980 on landfill along the west side of Lower Manhattan, is for many New Yorkers akin to a new guest bedroom added to the side of a beloved old house. It’s sleeker and more functional than the main residence, but it lacks the character and inspired disorder of the creaky old place, and you never set foot in there without a very specific reason.

headline: Bending Tradition, and Bowing to It
abstract: A Japanese menu surprises; an Italian one treads softly.
lead_paragraph: “The chef calls this one the gun, because it hits you,” our server at Cagen said promisingly as she set the night’s last bite, a stubby little handroll, on the table. Glossy and dark, it looked, if you had a suggestible turn of mind, something like the barrel of a snub-nose revolver, with a metallic sheen it got from its seaweed wrapper, a rare blend of green and black kelp. The gunpowder was inside: an extra-hot, nostril-punishing slug of wasabi implanted alongside strands of sweet squash, waiting to go off when I bit into it.

headline: How Tax Laws Distort the Pfizer Deal
abstract: We don’t know if Pfizer is targeting a British rival because the combined firm will be more efficient or because of the tax savings, Victor Fleischer writes in his Standard Deduction column.
lead_paragraph: The United States tax code is fueling Pfizer Inc.’s $98.7 billion bid to take over the London-based pharmaceutical company AstraZeneca. If the deal goes through as proposed, a new parent company in Britain would own the combined entity, making it easier for the new firm to strip income out of its American tax base. The deal is one of several recent transactions known as “inversions,” where a multinational company like Pfizer, based in New York, becomes an expatriate by acquiring a smaller foreign target.

headline: Vancouver Art Gallery Names New Building’s Designer
abstract: Herzog & de Meuron will design the new home for the museum, doubling its current space.
lead_paragraph: The Vancouver Art Gallery has selected Herzog & de Meuron to design its new and expanded home in downtown Vancouver, the gallery announced on Tuesday. The new building, which doubles the museum’s current space, will be the Swiss architects’ first project in Canada.

headline: Heroin and Alcohol Led to the Deaths of Ex-SEALs
abstract: Autopsies of Jeffrey Reynolds and Mark Kennedy, the former SEALs, revealed that the men died of respiratory failure and possible heart attacks.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in the Seychelles said Tuesday that they had determined that a combination of heroin and alcohol was responsible for the deaths of two former members of the Navy SEALs working as guards on board a container ship in February.

headline: Reaction to Donald Sterling’s Punishment
abstract: The N.B.A. commissioner, Adam Silver, received strong support from current and former players on Twitter for barring the Clippers owner for life for making racist comments.
lead_paragraph: N.B.A. players have a publicly united message for Adam Silver, the league’s new commissioner: Thanks, boss.

headline: ‘The Velocity of Autumn’ to Close
abstract: Estelle Parsons was nominated for a Tony for her role, but Eric Coble’s drama is to close on Sunday after 22 previews and 16 regular performances.
lead_paragraph: The new Broadway play “The Velocity of Autumn” will close on Sunday after just four and a half weeks of performances, the producers announced on Tuesday.

abstract: Ed Schoenfeld and Joe Ng are finally opening their long-planned shrine to Peking duck.

headline: Baseball, Happiness and Immigration: Exploring American Society and History With New York Times Maps
abstract: In this lesson we surface some of our favorite United States maps in The New York Times. We also offer strategies to help students use careful observation and analysis to make sense of these data-rich maps so they can learn more about our current society, history and geography.
lead_paragraph: Like other images — whether photographs, charts or graphs — maps can tell a complicated story.

headline: Raw Feelings, With an Aesthetic of Naïveté
abstract: Frankie Cosmos is the recording alias of Greta Kline, who recently issued “Zentropy,” her first album recorded with a full band, after about four dozen releases.
lead_paragraph: Frankie Cosmos’s songs are alive with the raw pink of new feeling, tender to the touch. “I’m the kind of girl buses splash with rain” were the first words she sang on Monday night at Glasslands Gallery, and she didn’t even look that sad about it, because just being aware had its own power.

headline: Hot Flashes? Great News.
abstract: The director Henry Jaglom, whose films feel like gatherings of old friends, takes on menopause in “The M Word,” starring Tanna Frederick.
lead_paragraph: Most male directors would think twice before wading into a comedy about menopause, but not Henry Jaglom. For his 19th film, “The M Word,” this warmly humane and unfailingly indulgent observer of women and their distractions — as celebrated in “Babyfever” (1994) and “Going Shopping” (2005) — proves as comfortable with hot flashes as with cooling desire.

headline: A Circle of Composers, Intimate and Epic
abstract: The Second Empire sculptor Jean-Baptiste Carpeaux inspired a concert of French vocal music at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: There is an operatic quality coursing through the work of the Second Empire sculptor Jean-Baptiste Carpeaux (1827-75), the subject of a powerful exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, through May 26, that inspired a concert of French vocal music at the museum on Saturday evening.

headline: Celebrating Higher Powers With Performers Here on Earth
abstract: “Dancing the Gods,” an annual festival of Indian dance presented by the World Music Institute, introduced four lesser-known performers on Saturday and Sunday.
lead_paragraph: “Dancing the Gods,” an annual festival of Indian dance presented by the World Music Institute, has a record of attracting some truly godlike dancers. In the first year, there were Rama Vaidyanathan and Shantala Shivalingappa. Then came Surupa Sen and Bijayini Satpathy (who, it happens, will perform in an unrelated concert at Baryshnikov Arts Center on Thursday and Friday). These are all stars, dazzling and recognized.

lead_paragraph: The United States government escalated enforcement of its Iran sanctions on Tuesday, adding eight Chinese companies, a Dubai company and two Dubai-based executives to blacklists for evading American restrictions on Iranian weapons, oil and banking transactions.

headline: China’s Ruling Party Expels and Investigates Official
abstract: Party leaders have authorized a criminal investigation of Li Chuncheng, who was close to Zhou Yongkang, the former domestic security chief at the heart of an extensive graft inquiry.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s Communist Party has authorized a criminal investigation of Li Chuncheng, a disgraced senior official who was close to Zhou Yongkang, the former domestic security chief at the heart of an extensive graft inquiry.

headline: Definitely Not a Groupie, but Always With the Band
abstract: In her memoir, “There Goes Gravity,” Lisa Robinson tries to put her busy life into context as a rare female journalist in rock’s early period.
lead_paragraph: There are a pair of sentences on the first page of Lisa Robinson’s memoir, “There Goes Gravity: A Life in Rock and Roll,” that make you think her book is going to be a gift, in a Nora Ephron meets Chrissie Hynde sort of way.

headline: Blast in Gaza Damages Boat Meant for Protest
abstract: An explosion partially sank a small vessel that Palestinian and foreign activists had planned to use to challenge the Israeli-imposed blockade of the Gaza Strip.
lead_paragraph: GAZA — An explosion before dawn on Tuesday partially sank a small boat that Palestinian and foreign activists were planning to use to challenge the Israeli-imposed naval blockade of the Gaza Strip. Organizers of the protest said they suspected sabotage. The boat, Gaza’s Ark, an old fishing trawler refurbished as a cargo vessel, was docked in the Gaza harbor used by fishermen. In a statement, the organizers said a security guard received an anonymous phone call warning him to leave the boat shortly before the explosion. Palestinian fishing boats are permitted to sail up to six nautical miles from the coast under Israeli restrictions. The boat was scheduled to sail in June from Gaza to European ports carrying Palestinian goods for export. Attempts to breach the blockade have usually involved boats trying to sail to Gaza. In 2010, Israeli naval commandos killed nine activists during a raid at sea on a Turkish vessel after clashes broke out on board.

headline: What’s In It | Veggie Blend-Ins
abstract: Green Giant Veggie Blend-Ins offer vegetables in puréed form to those who routinely avoid them. Are there any potential pitfalls?
lead_paragraph: Green Giant Veggie Blend-Ins offer vegetables in puréed form to those who routinely avoid them. Are there any potential pitfalls?

headline: Stealth Vegetables
abstract: Two new strategies aim to get you to eat your vegetables, each involving a disguise.
lead_paragraph: For years, the government has been urging Americans to eat more vegetables for better health, with little to show for the effort. Consumption has been stuck at barely half the recommended amount. Now, from private enterprise, come two very different strategies. One aims to make vegetables more attractive and easier to use. The other would actually make them less visible, slipping them into other foods.

headline: A Marathon Performance (Aches, Too)
abstract: The Flux Quartet performed Morton Feldman’s String Quartet No. 2 for approximately six hours, without pause, at the Park Avenue Armory on Saturday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: The music of Morton Feldman, for me, is like an acquaintance you don’t really click with but whose virtues you can appreciate in small doses. I can admire Feldman’s spare, slow-moving aesthetic in moderation, but I find his larger works unbearably tedious. And large, by Feldman standards, is gigantic: His String Quartet No. 2 lasts around six hours. When I learned I’d been assigned to review a performance of the piece, I had a brief vision of being trapped in a never-ending Feldman loop, a sort of Sartrean aural damnation.

headline: Revenue Up at Twitter, but Growth Is a Worry
abstract: Twitter said that it had more than doubled revenues, but its stock fell more than 11 percent in after-hours trading because the number of people who joined it did not increase as fast as many had hoped.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter is struggling to convince Wall Street that it is still a company with plenty of potential to grow.

headline: Prana Living, Yoga Gear Maker, Is Sold to Columbia Sportswear
abstract: Prana will join Columbia’s stable of sports apparel brand, as health and lifestyle companies find a booming market.
lead_paragraph: As more Americans practice yoga, a booming market has sprung up for stretchy pants designed to accommodate poses like downward dog.

headline: Behind Focus on College Assaults, a Steady Drumbeat by Students
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Colleges and Universities', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Successful lawsuits by women, a stepped-up enforcement of civil rights and the political savvy of student groups have converged to tackle the problem on campuses.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In March, two women who were sexually assaulted when they were students at the University of North Carolina arrived unannounced at the office of Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand with a request: Help us stop sexual assault on college campuses.

headline: The N.B.A. Shifts to Maximum Outrage
abstract: Donald Sterling has a long history of bigotry, but the audio recording eliminated all complexity and doubt.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A.’s decision to ban Donald Sterling for life — to be followed shortly by the deletion of the Los Angeles Clippers from the Sterling family of mismanaged properties — was all the more impressive because of the huge reversal it represented. After decades of neglect regarding Mr. Sterling’s well-documented racial attitudes, the league suddenly threw everything it could find at him, the maximum penalty, the maximum fine, the maximum language of official fury.

headline: Real Madrid Routs Bayern Munich in Champions League
abstract: Cristiano Ronaldo scored twice as Real Madrid advanced to the Champions League final with a 4-0 win in the second leg against Bayern Munich.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — Cristiano Ronaldo sprinted toward the end line, his arms shaking and his eyes wide. Suddenly he stopped in front of a wall of Bayern Munich fans at the Allianz Arena, and held up 10 fingers. Then he dropped one hand and raised five fingers again.

headline: Artists Hold Up a Glass to a City’s Changing Face
abstract: “Hedge Two-Way Mirror Walkabout,” a work by Dan Graham with Günther Vogt, is in the roof garden of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: The idea of a Dan Graham pavilion in the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s roof garden is so obvious, so perfect, that it really should have happened years ago. But late is better than never, and Mr. Graham’s execution of the project more than makes up for lost time.

headline: For a New Mother, an Illness and a Legacy
abstract: In Oni Faida Lampley’s semi-autobiographical play, the mother of a newborn and her family deal with breast cancer.
lead_paragraph: Tucked into the program for Oni Faida Lampley’s “Tough Titty,” at the Paradise Factory Theater, is a pamphlet for a major breast cancer research charity, which brings to mind an early scene in this mordantly funny, quietly wrenching, semi-autobiographical play.

headline: Unfinished Revolution: The Artists Soldier On
abstract: An exhibition at the National Art Museum of Ukraine illustrates how the country has turned to the arts to assert itself.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — The National Art Museum of Ukraine has just opened an exhibition of objects from the compound of former President Viktor F. Yanukovych, including a folk-art portrait of him made of poppy seeds and beans. A folk-rock group, all women, performs a raucous cabaret at night, while other artists busily produce videos about the aftermath of the mass uprising.

headline: A Shot. A Man Falls, Clutching His Chest ... Etc.
abstract: O’Neill wasn’t known for his comedies, but the New York Neo-Futurists can play his work for laughs in “The Complete & Condensed Stage Directions of Eugene O’Neill, Volume 2.”
lead_paragraph: Eugene O’Neill — what a bully! His stage directions go on for pages at a time, dictating every aspect of a play’s set, costumes and performance.

lead_paragraph: When newly minted Ph.D.s go on the job market, they usually have questions about the teaching load, research money and tenure prospects.

headline: Tony Nominations Spread Across a Wide Stage
abstract: The major races for Broadway’s Tony Awards will be unusually wide-open this spring, with the nominations showing more love for Shakespeare than for Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: The major races for Broadway’s Tony Awards will be unusually wide-open this spring, with the nominations, announced on Tuesday, showing more love for Shakespeare than for Hollywood and for popular songs by Carole King and Duke Ellington than for original musicals. Ambitiously conceived productions like “Rocky” and “If/Then” fared poorly, and some of the season’s most praised performers — including the boldface names Daniel Radcliffe and Denzel Washington — were edged out.

headline: Ball Is in the N.B.A. Owners’ Court
abstract: Though Mark Cuban, the outspoken owner of the Dallas Mavericks, suggested thinking twice before rushing to force Donald Sterling to sell the Clippers, the N.B.A. vote on the matter should be an uncontested layup.
lead_paragraph: It’s the owners’ ball now. They are on the clock. Shame on them if they do not run the play that sends Donald Sterling out the N.B.A.’s back door within the procedural equivalent of a 24-second possession.

headline: Yahoo Chief’s Pay Tied to Another Company’s Performance
abstract: Such paydays illustrate that it is often good fortune rather than individual performance that account for the bulk of executive pay, Steven Davidoff writes in the Deal Professor column.

headline: A new bill will make it easier to spot wasteful federal spending.
abstract: But the government has up to three years to begin publishing the actual data.
lead_paragraph: In a year or three. The House and Senate this week unanimously approved a bill — the Digital Accountability and Transparency Act (DATA Act) — that will provide detailed information to the public on federal programs and checkbook-level payments for both internal agency spending and outside grants and contracts. That’s a big deal for researchers and watchdogs — when the changes show up on USASpending.gov.

headline: Peter B. Hennessy
abstract: Mr. Hennessy, 53, is the president for the tristate region at Cassidy Turley, a commercial real estate services company that was formed after the merger of eight firms.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Hennessy, 53, is the president for the tristate region at Cassidy Turley, a commercial real estate services company that was formed about four years ago after the merger of eight firms, including four former Colliers affiliates. The tristate division is made up of offices in New York and New Jersey and has about 470 employees.

headline: PEN World Voices Festival Opens ‘On the Edge’
abstract: The Syrian poet Adonis, Salman Rushdie, Judith Butler and others spoke at Cooper Union on Monday night.
lead_paragraph: The 10th annual PEN World Voices Festival got underway Monday night with a series of brief politically focused speeches by prominent international writers at the Great Hall at Cooper Union. The festival’s program promised that the evening, called “On the Edge,” would feature bouts of “unrestrained intellectual fury,” and the line to get in stretched around a corner of the building.

headline: The Basis for Sterling’s Punishment
abstract: The Times sports reporter Harvey Araton asked the N.B.A. commissioner, Adam Silver, whether the Clippers’ owner, Donald Sterling, was punished for a single incident or multiple acts.
lead_paragraph: The Times sports reporter Harvey Araton asked the N.B.A. commissioner, Adam Silver, whether the Clippers’ owner, Donald Sterling, was punished for a single incident or multiple acts.

headline: White House Wants to Lift Ban on Interstate Tolls
abstract: Ending a prohibition as old as the national highway system could help address a shortfall in funding for repairs, the Obama administration said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Drivers on the nation’s Interstates could soon be paying more to travel.

lead_paragraph: A scene from the film featuring Seth Rogen, Rose Byrne and Zac Efron.

abstract: Inspired by a project that challenges stereotypes about Africa, a Delhi-based freelancer aims to portray daily moments in Asia.
lead_paragraph: Inspired by a project that challenges stereotypes about Africa, a Delhi-based freelancer aims to portray daily moments in Asia.

lead_paragraph: A preview of the film.

headline: Growth in Global Trade Is in Ideas, Not Stuff
abstract: A new study offers a more nuanced look at the exchanges between nations, and how they’ve been changing over the past decade.
lead_paragraph: Most of us have a mental image of what globalization looks like. It’s garment workers in an overcrowded Bangladeshi factory, making clothing that will end up on sale at a discount store in a strip mall. It’s container ships stuffed with consumer electronics from China headed for American ports, or tankers full of Middle Eastern oil fulfilling the world’s demand for energy.

headline: Obama’s Pop Culture Legacy
abstract: Michael D. Shear examines how popular culture has incorporated the issues that President Obama has faced.
lead_paragraph: Michael D. Shear examines how popular culture has incorporated the issues that President Obama has faced.

headline: Trailer: ‘A Million Ways...’
abstract: A preview of the film.
lead_paragraph: A preview of the film.

headline: In Game 7, Sharks Are Going to Need a Bigger Effort
abstract: The Los Angeles Kings have rallied from a three-game deficit and will play at San Jose on Wednesday in Game 7 of their first-round N.H.L. playoff series.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For the San Jose Sharks and the Los Angeles Kings, Game 7 Wednesday night will feel familiar, for different reasons.

headline: The Rise of the Drone Master: Pop Culture Recasts Obama
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Movies', 'Television', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Art', 'Comic Books and Strips', 'Theater', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Drone strikes and government eavesdropping have become themes for movies like “Captain America: The Winter Soldier,” as well as for art exhibitions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In Marvel’s latest popcorn thriller, Captain America battles Hydra, a malevolent organization that has infiltrated the highest levels of the United States government. There are missile attacks, screeching car chases, enormous explosions, evil assassins, data-mining supercomputers and giant killer drones ready to obliterate millions of people.

headline: Geno Smith’s Progression Is Key to Jets’ Quarterback Competition
abstract: Marty Mornhinweg, the Jets’ offensive coordinator, said he expected Smith to “progress at a high rate” with Michael Vick’s help.
lead_paragraph: Marty Mornhinweg, the Jets’ offensive coordinator, will manage the quarterback competition between Geno Smith and Michael Vick with one objective in mind.

headline: Jaromir Jagr Is Set to Return, Devils Say
abstract: General Manager Lou Lamoriello added that a contract to bring back the team’s top scorer, expected to be a one-year deal for $4 million to $6 million, should be ready soon.
lead_paragraph: Jaromir Jagr is set to return to the Devils next season, General Manager Lou Lamoriello said Tuesday. Jagr, 42, led the Devils in scoring last season with 67 points on 24 goals and 43 assists. He played all 82 games, as well as each one of the Czech Republic’s six games at the Sochi Olympics. He is tied for sixth place with Steve Yzerman in N.H.L. career scoring, with 1,755 points, and is the league’s leading scorer among active players.

headline: A String of Violent Storms Across the South and Midwest
abstract: Severe weather across the country affected states from Michigan to Florida.
lead_paragraph: Severe weather across the country affected states from Michigan to Florida.

headline: The Right Way to Develop Shale Gas
abstract: The boom can benefit the economy and planet, if we get it right.
lead_paragraph: LISTENING to the polarized energy debate in the United States, you might think natural gas was an economic and geopolitical cure-all — or an environmental curse. Too many oil and gas executives behave as if this newly abundant resource, released from underground shale deposits by the combination of horizontal drilling and hydraulic fracturing, has no environmental challenges. Opponents often act as if it has no economic and environmental benefits.

headline: Nurses Are Not Doctors
abstract: They shouldn’t provide primary care without physician oversight.
lead_paragraph: EARLIER this month, the New York State Legislature passed a bill granting nurse practitioners the right to provide primary care without physician oversight. New York joins 16 other states and the District of Columbia in awarding such autonomy. (Most states still require nurse practitioners to work with physicians under a written practice agreement.) The bill’s authors contend that mandatory collaboration with a physician “no longer serves a clinical purpose” and reduces much-needed access to primary care.

headline: Report Finds Deportations Focus on Criminal Records
abstract: The Migration Policy Institute said that at least 75 percent of immigrants deported by the Obama administration in the past five years had been convicted of crimes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A program of cooperation between federal immigration authorities and state and local police departments has been effective at focusing deportations on immigrants with a criminal record, according to a report published Tuesday by the Migration Policy Institute, a nonpartisan research organization here.

headline: Do You Live Near I-35? Contribute to Our Reporting
abstract: A New York Times reporter, Damien Cave, and photographer, Todd Heisler, are traveling the length of I-35, chronicling how immigration is changing the U.S. Where should they visit?
lead_paragraph: A New York Times reporter, Damien Cave, and photographer, Todd Heisler, are traveling the length of I-35, chronicling how immigration is changing the U.S. Where should they visit?

headline: Bagels, Lox and Me
abstract: For most of us the foods we come to love as children are the foods that will cry out to us for the rest of our lives.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, I put on my running clothes, went out to the elevator, and pushed the button. In the time it took for my finger to travel from the wall back to my side, I’d decided that it was not a day for a run but for a trip to the market. I slipped a coat over everything and went to the store, where I bought bagels, lox and cream cheese, along with some badly needed staples. I then came home and ate. (While, of course, reading The Sunday Times. Sigh. Sometimes it’s tough to be a cliché.)

headline: Amid a Revived East-West Chill, Cold War Relics Draw New Interest
abstract: At the Museum of the Cold War, visitors are drawn as much by history as by the sense that current crises have reignited the conflict between East and West.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Stand in a dark tunnel as a red light flashes overhead and an air raid siren howls.

headline: New York State Makes New Efforts to Combat Payday Lenders
abstract: Benjamin M. Lawsky, New York State’s top financial regulator, is sending cease-and-desist letters to 20 companies suspected of making illegal payday loans.
lead_paragraph: Curbing abusive payday lending practices can sometimes resemble a game of Whac-A-Mole: every time regulators manage to push down one method the industry uses, another new method seems to crop up.

headline: Jewish Groups Consider Including J Street
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The major coalition of Jewish groups plans to vote on whether to admit the dovish organization J Street, which says it is pro-Israel and pro-peace but has been critical of some Israeli policies.
lead_paragraph: The American Jewish community, increasingly vexed by debate over Israel within its ranks, faces a closely watched test this week: The major umbrella organization of Jewish groups plans to vote on whether to admit a dovish lobbying organization that has been critical of some Israeli policies.

headline: Official Slams Brazil’s Olympic Planning
abstract: The International Olympic Committee’s vice president, John D. Coates, said Brazil’s preparations for the 2016 Olympic Games were “the worst” he has ever experienced.
lead_paragraph: The International Olympic Committee’s vice president, John D. Coates, said Brazil’s preparations for the 2016 Olympic Games were “the worst” he has ever experienced.

headline: Massachusetts: Under Fire, Leader of Children’s Agency Steps Down
abstract: Olga I. Roche, commissioner of the state Department of Children and Families, resigned Tuesday, after the deaths of three children and an outcry by officials.
lead_paragraph: After the deaths of three children and an outcry by officials, Olga I. Roche, commissioner of the state Department of Children and Families, resigned Tuesday. Gov. Deval Patrick had defended Ms. Roche in recent months, but on Tuesday he said, “She can no longer command the trust of the public or the confidence of her line staff.” In one case, the police in Grafton had sent a fax to the agency warning that a baby, Aliana Lavigne, might be in danger. But the police failed to make a follow-up phone call, and no one at the agency saw the fax for six days. By then, the baby was dead. The governor named Erin Deveney, a former motor vehicles official, as interim commissioner.

headline: Preparations for Rio Olympics ‘the Worst,’ Committee Official Says
abstract: Doubts are growing about the city’s ability to get ready for the 2016 Summer Olympics without international help, and officials say there is no Plan B.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — A top International Olympic Committee official on Tuesday called Rio de Janeiro’s preparations to host the 2016 Summer Olympics “the worst I have experienced,” adding to a growing chorus of doubts about the city’s ability to get ready for the Games without international help.

headline: Wooing Advertisers by Using Laughs
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Web-Original Programming', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Marketers like lifestyle content because it often attracts more affluent consumers. Also, humorous content is frequently sought out by younger men.
lead_paragraph: THE growing interest on Madison Avenue in digital video as an advertising medium is putting a new twist on 1980s-era television, as “Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous” gets remixed online as programming that is rich in lifestyle content or programming that tries to become famous by being funny.

headline: Hagel Seeks Review of Military Policies on Hairstyles
keywords: ['Hair', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel was responding to complaints lodged by the 16 women of the Congressional Black Caucus about an Army ban on large cornrows, twists and dreadlocks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel on Tuesday ordered the American military to review its policies concerning hairstyles popular with black women, telling critics of new Army regulations banning large cornrows, twists and dreadlocks that he takes “very seriously” concerns that military rules on hair have unfairly targeted black women.

headline: Two Giant Banks, Seen as Immune, Become Targets
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Prosecutors, in seeking guilty pleas from Credit Suisse and BNP Paribas, are looking to address public outrage and alter the belief that Wall Street institutions are “too big to jail.”
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors are nearing criminal charges against some of the world’s biggest banks, according to lawyers briefed on the matter, a development that could produce the first guilty plea from a major bank in more than two decades.

headline: Christie Nominates Ex-Attorney General to Lead Port Authority
abstract: John J. Degnan, a Democrat who served as New Jersey’s attorney general from 1978 to 1981, would replace David Samson, a confidant of Gov. Chris Christie’s who resigned.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey nominated a former state attorney general on Tuesday as chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey as he seeks to disentangle the agency and himself from the scandal surrounding the George Washington Bridge lane closings.

headline: With Peace Talks Off, Netanyahu Looks at Unilateral Moves
abstract: The Israeli prime minister has asked his cabinet to bring forward alternative approaches to the Palestinian conflict, which are likely to include annexing parts of the West Bank or withdrawing from some settlements and shoring up others.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — After halting peace talks with the Palestinians last week, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has asked his cabinet to bring forward alternative approaches to the intractable conflict, which are likely to include annexing parts of the West Bank or withdrawing from some settlements and shoring up others.

headline: Federal Judge Strikes Down Wisconsin Law Requiring Photo ID at Polls
keywords: ['Fourteenth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'State Legislatures', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Identification Devices', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: The judge found that the 2011 law, which required voters to produce state-approved photo identification cards at polling places, violated the 14th Amendment and the Voting Rights Act.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Tuesday struck down Wisconsin’s law requiring voters to produce state-approved photo identification cards at polling places, advancing a new legal basis — the Voting Rights Act — for similar challenges playing out around the nation.

headline: In the U.S., Punishment Comes Before the Crimes
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'Welfare (US)']
abstract: In 2012, 2.2 million Americans were in jail or prison, a larger share of the population than in any other country.
lead_paragraph: Few things are better at conveying what a nation really cares than how it spends its money. On that measure, Americans like to punish.

headline: Spotify Teams With Sprint on a Mobile Music Plan
abstract: The deal gives Sprint customers in the United States free access to Spotify’s paid version for up to six months, and further discounts beyond that.
lead_paragraph: Spotify, the streaming music company, has struck a deal with Sprint to help market and promote its service, which offers millions of songs free and by subscription.

headline: Challenging Putin’s Values
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: What if the sanctions on Russia work too well? We have to be ready for that.
lead_paragraph: While you can talk about Ukraine until the cows come home, this story is 95 percent about Vladimir Putin and how he has chosen to define Russia’s interests. The truth is, Russia and its neighbors need a different definition of Russia’s interests. That, however, raises a series of questions: Can Moscow ever define its interests differently under Putin? If not, how do we deter him without also weakening Russia to the point of instability? And if we do induce such instability over time with sanctions, do we know what comes next and will we be better off?

headline: Developer Scales Back Plans for Muslim Center Near Ground Zero
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Museums', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Mosques', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: Sharif El-Gamal, who once proposed a 15-story community center near the World Trade Center site, now plans to build a three-story museum devoted to Islam.
lead_paragraph: The developer whose proposal to build a Muslim community center and mosque near the World Trade Center failed amid a national controversy three years ago said Tuesday that he now plans to construct a museum devoted to Islam in the same location.

headline: Commissioner Sees Basis for Ousting Clippers’ Owner
abstract: The ability to bar Donald Sterling is not in question, but the league might not find it is simple to terminate his ownership.
lead_paragraph: N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver deployed the nuclear option on Tuesday to force the Los Angeles Clippers’ owner, Donald Sterling, out of the league for racist remarks he made in a recorded conversation. Now, will Silver’s actions — banishing Sterling for life from team and league business, and urging the other owners to vote to force him to sell the club — withstand any legal challenges?

headline: Voter ID Is the Real Fraud
keywords: ['Identification Devices', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Editorials', 'States (US)']
abstract: A federal judge struck down Wisconsin’s voter-identification law, making it clear that the law was a harmful solution in search of an imaginary problem.
lead_paragraph: For the first time since the Supreme Court junked a core provision of the Voting Rights Act in June, a federal court has used the strongest surviving part of the act to strike down a state’s voter-identification law, and, in the process, has set out a detailed road map for upcoming challenges to similar laws around the country.

headline: Milder View of Suspect in U.S. Case on Terror
abstract: Ahmed Abassi, who prosecutors in Manhattan once said had spoken of killing 100,000 people, was offered a plea bargain that could lead to a sentence of six months.
lead_paragraph: It was around a year ago that the government unsealed charges against a Tunisian citizen named Ahmed Abassi, saying he had come to the United States to develop a network of terrorists and commit acts of terror. Prosecutors said he had “radicalized” one supposed terrorist and spoken of killing 100,000 people through bioterrorism.

headline: Amid Iraq’s Unrest, Maliki Campaigns as Strongman
abstract: A strategy of showing toughness may help lift Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, but his success was far from certain in the first national vote since the withdrawal of American forces.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — When a well-known journalist was shot dead at a checkpoint here last month, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki rushed to the scene. Speaking to a television camera, he promised “blood for blood.”

headline: Not Getting Through to Mr. Putin
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations', 'Editorials']
abstract: The additional sanctions imposed on Russia are justified, but they are unlikely to change the aggressive behavior of the Russians.
lead_paragraph: The United States and the European Union announced another round of sanctions against Russia on Monday and Tuesday: the Americans against Russians close to President Vladimir Putin, including the president of the state-owned oil company Rosneft; and the Europeans against senior Russian officials and secessionist leaders in Ukraine. The stated reason is that Russia has fulfilled none of the commitments it made at a meeting with Ukraine, the United States and the European Union in Geneva on April 17, and that Russia’s “involvement in the recent violence in eastern Ukraine is indisputable.”

headline: Is Barry Whiffing?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Mr. President, a singles hitter doesn’t scare anybody.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stop whining, Mr. President.

headline: New York City Council Backs New Rules on Discretionary Money and Bills
abstract: If the changes are adopted, the speaker would be stripped of the authority to decide how much each council member is given to pay out to local groups and projects.
lead_paragraph: Members of the New York City Council united on Tuesday behind proposed rules that would democratize the bill-drafting process and the way in which discretionary funds are apportioned to individual lawmakers — steps that fell short of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s call to do away with such spending entirely.

headline: Author of the Book ‘Gravity’ Sues Warner Bros. Over Credit
abstract: The best-selling author Tess Gerritsen filed the suit, claiming the studio failed to give her a “based upon” film credit — and part of the profit — for her book published in 1999.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The best-selling author Tess Gerritsen filed a lawsuit against Warner Bros. on Tuesday that claims the studio at least partly based “Gravity” on one of her books and as a result, owes her 2.5 percent of the blockbuster film’s net profit.

headline: Cano and the Yankees Are Secure in Their Decisions
abstract: Robinson Cano is in Seattle for the long haul with a contract three years longer than the best the Yankees offered. But New York is in first place even without its former star.
lead_paragraph: At the end of the 1990s, when the Seattle Mariners lost more often than they won, their marquee player often grew exasperated when asked about the team’s struggles. Ken Griffey Jr. would sigh and say, “I bat third,” three words that spoke an essential truth about baseball.

headline: An Alarm Over the Incursion of Foreign Words
abstract: While a language’s absorption of foreign words is often seen as a positive mark of a society’s cosmopolitanism, the reaction in China has been anything but positive – at least according to state media.
lead_paragraph: Few major languages have felt the effects of globalization and modernization more acutely than Mandarin. The increasing use of keyboard devices, for example, has caused many Chinese to forget how to write characters by hand, to the extent that there is even a popular television show in which contestants compete to write complicated characters from memory.

headline: Can Voluntourism Make a Difference?
abstract: As students, retirees and others head abroad this summer in search of experiences volunteering, are they really looking to help others or just themselves?

headline: An Early Skyscraper Becomes a Hotel With a View
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Development of a hotel-condo project in the financial district comes as the area draws more residents and tourists.
lead_paragraph: For years, development plans came and went at 5 Beekman Street like City Hall workers filing in and out of their nearby offices in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Grabbing the Derby Roses a Second Time Is a Tricky Task
abstract: In the last 15 years, 15 different trainers and ownership groups have won the Kentucky Derby.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — The trainer Chip Woolley made an arduous drive when he took Mine That Bird from Sunland Park in New Mexico to Churchill Downs here five years ago. He had to use his left leg instead of his right, which had been fractured in a motorcycle accident, but he was comforted by the thought that he would be competing in his first Kentucky Derby with a horse that he believed belonged.

headline: Emails Show Sotheby’s Board Shared Some of Loeb’s Concerns
abstract: Directors of Sotheby’s have expressed concern about compensation and the board’s performance, according to emails disclosed in a dispute with Daniel S. Loeb.
lead_paragraph: WILMINGTON, Del. — Directors of Sotheby’s have expressed concern about compensation and the board’s performance, according to emails disclosed on Tuesday during a hearing in a dispute with the activist investor Daniel S. Loeb.

headline: Social Media in Afghanistan Takes On Life of Its Own
abstract: A U.S.-financed network to connect Afghans across forbidding physical and cultural divides still survives three years after American funding ended.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Afghans have long been resistant to central authority — as the United States has found to its frustration — with Afghanistan divided along tribal, cultural, religious and linguistic lines. Its mountains and valleys have stood in the way of communications breakthroughs that have unified other societies.

headline: Reinventing Rye Playland Ignites an Unexpected Battle
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS']
abstract: Neighbors of the Art Deco amusement park, built in 1928 and run by Westchester County, object to planned additions like a large field house.
lead_paragraph: RYE, N.Y. — It seemed, on its face, an unassailable approach to reinventing Rye Playland, the Art Deco amusement park in this wealthy shore town, for the 21st century — innocuous even. Spiff up the amusement rides, expand the green space, and draw year-round visitors to the county-run park with new playing fields and restaurants.

headline: Epic Battle in Technology
abstract: A certain war rages on in Zhouquin Burnikel’s puzzle.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Full disclosure: I am an unabashed MAC fangirl. Yes, I have used both PCs and MACs. This isn’t a case of “Oh, she’s just never tried using a PC …”. I have, and I have very strong opinions about this subject. Even so, I’m a professional, and I’m fairly certain that I will be able to cover this topic in a way that will not affect today’s blog post at all. [Uh oh. –Ed.]

headline: Old and Familiar Rivals Are Squaring Off in Texas
abstract: There are no secrets left between the Spurs and the Mavericks, two veteran teams engaged in yet another memorable playoff series.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — As Manu Ginobili ambled off the court at American Airlines Center on Monday night, it was fairly evident that playoff game No. 161 for him had taken its toll. At this stage, they all do.

headline: Williams Once Again Shows That He Is His Toughest Critic
abstract: Backcourt play has been a focal point in the first four games of the series, and the Nets say they need Deron Williams, their starting point guard, to perform.
lead_paragraph: Late Sunday night, shortly after the Nets fumbled away a close game to the Toronto Raptors, point guard Deron Williams, unprompted, said he put the burden of the loss on himself.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 29, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: April 29, 2014

headline: At Sentencing Hearing, Killer Hears From Police, and His Victim’s Mother
abstract: Petra Montañez-Vitale described her daughter’s 19 stab wounds at a hearing to determine how long Markeece Dunning, who had confessed to the crime, would spend in prison.
lead_paragraph: The mother’s voice began to break as she described her daughter’s 19 stab wounds, the blood, the abrupt end of dreams. She leaned over the court railing, her body rigid, her voice rising and splintering. The tears came.

headline: Slow Going on Overhaul of Mortgage Finance
