keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Mortgages', 'Law and Legislation', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: The Senate Banking Committee is drafting a bill that would dismantle Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac and create a federal regulator called the Federal Mortgage Insurance Corporation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the long, boggy work of overhauling the nation’s mortgage finance system, Tuesday morning was supposed to be an important milestone: the Senate Banking Committee was scheduled to meet and put the finishing touches on a bipartisan bill that would affect the ability of millions of Americans to buy a home.

headline: For Clippers, Transition in Decision Making Begins
abstract: The Clippers said: “We wholeheartedly support and embrace the decision by the N.B.A. and Commissioner Adam Silver today. Now the healing process begins.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Soon after N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver handed down a lifetime ban to Donald Sterling on Tuesday, the Clippers’ website, the one still owned but no longer operated under the direction of Sterling, went black.

headline: Allstate Case Shows Risk of Signing Away the Right to Sue
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Discrimination', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting']
abstract: A group of former Allstate agents are looking for their day in court after waiving their right to bring a lawsuit. They said they had no choice but to sign.
lead_paragraph: When his children were young, Nathan Littlejohn was a regional salesman in search of a position that would allow him to spend more time with his family. So when he heard about Allstate’s neighborhood agent program in 1990, he was intrigued.

headline: 20 Killed in Southern Yemen as Ground Assault Begins
abstract: The first day of a government ground offensive aimed at dislodging militants from Al Qaeda in southern Yemen led to the deaths of 20 people on Tuesday, mostly Yemeni soldiers, officials said.
lead_paragraph: The first day of a government ground offensive aimed at dislodging militants from Al Qaeda in southern Yemen led to the deaths of 20 people on Tuesday, mostly Yemeni soldiers, officials said. The assault by the army and allied militias on militant hide-outs in Shabwa and Abyan Provinces came days after heavy airstrikes in the area by Yemeni warplanes and American drones. The deadliest clash on Tuesday occurred in Shabwa Province when militants ambushed a convoy carrying security officials. A medical official in the provincial capital said the hospital there had received the bodies of 15 soldiers and treated 10 wounded soldiers. The Defense Ministry denied losing any soldiers in Shabwa, and the state-run news agency said that five militants were killed in fighting there. In neighboring Abyan, army convoys moved in without any reported resistance.

headline: Apple and Samsung Cite, and Rebut, Internal Memos in Patent Case
abstract: Lawyers for Apple and Samsung presented closing arguments in the latest billion-dollar patent dispute between the mobile phone and tablet makers.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — When Steven P. Jobs introduced the iPhone in January 2007, he said the device’s new touch-screen technology worked like magic. He also said, “And boy, have we patented it!”

headline: Two Rulings May Curb Lawsuits Over Patents
keywords: ['Inventions and Patents', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: The United States Supreme Court’s decision that existing law was too rigid should help cut the number of abusive or coercive patent suits brought by so-called patent trolls.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a pair of unanimous decisions, the Supreme Court on Tuesday made it easier for the winning side in patent cases to recover its legal fees from the loser. The decisions were welcomed by some technology companies, which said the rulings would help address what they say are abusive and coercive lawsuits brought by “patent trolls,” or companies that buy patents not to use them but to collect royalties and damages.

headline: Yet Again, Rangers Seem Averse to Prosperity
abstract: Propelled by three goals from Wayne Simmonds, the Flyers forced a Game 7 and extended the Rangers’ streak of 12 straight defeats while holding a lead in a playoff series.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Some streaks defy logic, but the Rangers’ current run of futility may be the strangest of all: an N.H.L.-record 12 straight defeats while holding a lead in a playoff series.

headline: Will Liberal Cities Leave the Rest of America Behind?
keywords: ['Local Government', 'Urban Areas', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Minimum Wage', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Relocation of Business', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: While testing new ideas, progressive mayors may exacerbate the differences between successful and unsuccessful urban areas.
lead_paragraph: How can governments adopt substantial, effective policies in order to benefit the poor and the working class when corporations, the affluent and owners of capital can pull up stakes and relocate with ease?

headline: Yanks Fall, Then Lose Pineda to Injury
abstract: After Robinson Cano helped the Mariners win in his return to the Bronx, the Yankees announced that pitcher Michael Pineda would be out for three to four weeks with a muscle strain.
lead_paragraph: On a cold, raw evening in the Bronx, with only a few thousand people in the stands, the focus of a dreary game was squarely on the return of Robinson Cano, who was roundly booed during each of his at-bats.

headline: ‘Fargo’ Recap: Dead Dogs, Spiders and Pestilence
abstract: The deadly plagues of “Fargo.”
lead_paragraph: O.K., after watching the third episode of “Fargo,” I am packing my “go bag” with Bactine, and perhaps a machete, a few guns and a helmet to wear in the shower, all in case of the apocalypse.

headline: Simmonds Sweeps In Puck 3 Times While Taking Care of Dirty Work
abstract: Wayne Simmonds recorded a hat trick to help the Flyers stay alive in their playoff series against the Rangers.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — When the Flyers are on the power play, it is not difficult to find Wayne Simmonds. He is the player stationed by the net, screening the goalie, buzzing across the crease, absorbing slashes and elbows and crosschecks, positioning himself in case the puck finds its way to him.

headline: India Election Digest: April 30
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Elections', 'Hinduism', 'Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: A roundup of local election-related news for Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: What you need to know about India’s election on Wednesday: This is the seventh of the nine phases of the parliamentary elections, with 89 seats up for grabs over seven states and two union territories. The areas going to vote are: Andhra Pradesh (17 constituencies), Bihar (7), Gujarat (26), Jammu and Kashmir (1), Punjab (13), Uttar Pradesh (14), West Bengal (9), Dadra and Nagar Haveli (1), Daman and Diu (1).

headline: Corrections: April 30, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on April 30, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Drop Everything
abstract: For instant glamour, pack the bright, dangling earrings this summer.
lead_paragraph: When worn with a slicked-back bun and a fresh face, a pair of dazzling pendant earrings is the perfect mate for a sunset stroll.

headline: Nearly Half of New Yorkers Are Struggling to Get By, Study Finds
abstract: Forty-six percent of New Yorkers in 2012 were making less than 150 percent of the poverty threshold, and New York City’s share of poor people appears to have plateaued since the recession, at 21.4 percent.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s share of poor people appears to have plateaued since the recession, at 21.4 percent, with more people working in 2012 than the year before, but at lower wages, according to a new city study. Contributing to the city’s economic problems were increases in the number of Asian-Americans, immigrants and residents of Queens slipping into poverty.

headline: Want to Be More Creative? Take a Walk
abstract: A brief stroll, even one just around your office, can spur creativity, according to a new study.
lead_paragraph: From our archives.

headline: Word of the Day | grate
abstract: This word has appeared in 126 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: grate•\ˈgrat\• noun and verb

headline: Frederic Schwartz, 63, Dies; Designed Sept. 11 Memorials
abstract: Mr. Schwartz was on a street corner near his home in Manhattan, just 10 blocks away, when he watched the trade center’s towers collapse in 2001.
lead_paragraph: Frederic Schwartz, an architect whose plan to rebuild the World Trade Center site finished second among hundreds of entries, and who went on to create memorials in New Jersey and Westchester County to victims of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 63.

headline: Niese Again Rises Above the Gloom
abstract: Rain delayed the game 1 hour 28 minutes and left the stands mostly vacant, but the Mets’ bad-weather ace, Jon Niese, let up just one run over seven innings to help defeat the Phillies.
lead_paragraph: By ZACH SCHONBRUN

headline: What’s On Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (FX) THE AMERICANS A new mission with global stakes forces Philip (Matthew Rhys, who stars with Keri Russell, above) to seek help from Annelise (Gillian Alexy), just as an old enemy returns to Washington with a vendetta. Stan (Noah Emmerich), meanwhile, makes a discovery that could help the F.B.I. close in on the K.G.B. illegals. The episode also features “It Must Be Done,” an original song written by Pete Townshend of the Who — his first for a television series — and the show’s composer, Nathan Barr.

headline: Insurance Site and Walmart in Deal to Sell Auto Policies
abstract: Walmart is teaming with AutoInsurance.com to allow consumers in eight states to review prices at several insurance companies.
lead_paragraph: Walmart plans to add a new consumer service to its arsenal of offerings on Wednesday, teaming up with a website that helps customers comparison shop for auto insurance.

headline: Wizards Oust Cold-Shooting Bulls
abstract: The Bulls had no answer for the young, talented Washington guards John Wall (24 points) and Bradley Beal (17) as they fell in five games to the Wizards in their first-round playoff series.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The Bulls scored on their second possession in Game 5 Tuesday night against the Washington Wizards when Carlos Boozer knocked down a high arcing jump shot. The ensuing cheer for the 2-0 lead at United Center was as much relief as excitement. In Game 4, the Bulls did not score until they spotted the Wizards 14 points in a blowout loss.

headline: Times Minute | Clippers Owner Banned
abstract: Sam Dolnick, the deputy sports editor, on what Donald Sterling’s ban means for the Los Angeles Clippers and the new N.B.A commissioner.
lead_paragraph: Sam Dolnick, the deputy sports editor, on what Donald Sterling’s ban means for the Los Angeles Clippers and the new N.B.A commissioner.

headline: Times Minute | The Clippers’ Next Steps
abstract: Sam Dolnick, the deputy sports editor, on what Donald Sterling’s ban means for the Los Angeles Clippers and the new N.B.A commissioner.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Alstom Backs G.E.’s Offer Despite French Government’s Concerns
abstract: The board of Alstom “has unanimously endorsed G.E.’s offer,” but the directors said they would also consider a rival offer from the German industrial conglomerate Siemens.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:43 p.m. | PARIS — General Electric and Alstom, the struggling French conglomerate at the center of a politically charged takeover battle, finally said publicly on Wednesday what the business world has known for a week: G.E. is ready to acquire Alstom’s energy business in a $13.5 billion deal.

headline: Shell Profit Falls 45 Percent as Oil Production Drops
abstract: Write-downs in refining and problems in Nigeria sapped first-quarter earnings, and the firm said it was monitoring the standoff between Russia and the West.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The European oil giant Royal Dutch Shell reported Wednesday a 45 percent decline in first-quarter earnings compared with a year earlier, as production fell sharply and the company took a large write-off in its refining business.

headline: BNP Paribas Says U.S. Penalties May Top the $1.1 Billion It Set Aside
abstract: In its earnings report, the bank said discussions over penalties show “a high degree of uncertainty” as to the amount the United States might impose.
lead_paragraph: The French bank BNP Paribas warned on Wednesday that it might have to pay penalties higher than the $1.1 billion it had set aside for an investigation by the American authorities into whether it processed payments for countries facing United States sanctions, including Iran.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, April 30, 2014
abstract: Can you calculate the amount a family spends on average for a child to go to Boston College, and what percentage of their income this amount represents?
lead_paragraph: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: European Court Rejects British Challenge to Tax on Trading
abstract: The court said Britain could not stop other European Union members from taxing securities trading — a tax the London financial community opposes.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The top court in the European Union on Wednesday cleared a legal obstacle to a proposed tax on financial transactions, a plan bitterly opposed by bankers in London.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | A Formal Breakup With Prom Wear
abstract: Who, interviewed in this article, wants to “punch prom in the face by wearing pants”?
lead_paragraph: In “A Formal Breakup With Prom Wear,” Marisa Meltzer reports on teenagers breaking with prom-fashion tradition.

headline: In Xinjiang, a Call to Report Extremism – and Long Beards
abstract: The Shayar County government in the far-western region of Xinjiang is offering rewards for intelligence that alerts Chinese officials to what they see as signs of extremism.
lead_paragraph: “Intelligence information” is the “essential factor” in safeguarding citizens’ lives and property, the Shayar County government in the far-western region of Xinjiang has said, announcing rewards ranging from 50 to 50,000 renminbi ($8 to $8,000) to anyone who reports people planning violent attacks or hoarding guns and bullets, men growing long beards, women wearing veils or youths under 18 visiting a mosque. Such activities are considered signs of Muslim extremism by officials who are grappling with rising violence in the region that is home to ethnic Uighurs, a mostly Sunni Muslim, Turkic-speaking people.

headline: Why Only One Top Banker Went to Jail for the Financial Crisis
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: The economic catastrophe of 2008 was the largest of its kind since the Depression. Who’s taking the fall?
lead_paragraph: This article is a collaboration between The Times and ProPublica, the independent nonprofit investigative organization.

headline: Everyday People in Everyday Asia
abstract: Inspired by a project that challenges stereotypes about Africa, a Delhi-based freelancer aims to portray daily moments in Asia.
lead_paragraph: It was June 2013 when Ian Thomas Jansen-Lonnquist, inspired by the work of the Everyday Africa project, registered the Instagram account @everydayasia. As a Delhi-based freelance photographer, he saw a chance to carve out a space similar to the @everydayafrica feed, which showcases mobile photography that captures familiar moments, even mundane ones, to counter a media narrative too often shaped by images of extreme famine and poverty.

headline: Do We Need New Ways to Identify Gender and Sexuality?
abstract: Do you think we need new ways to identify gender and sexuality differences beyond the binary choice “male” and “female,” whether on social media or on official forms like driver’s licenses and passports?
lead_paragraph: Non-binary, intersex, neutrois, androgyne, agender, gender questioning, gender fluid, gender variant, genderqueer: these are among the 50 possibilities and permutations of gender identification Facebook will now include in a drop-down menu for people who feel the binary choices “male” and “female” aren’t enough.

headline: With Election, Many Reminded of Horrors of 2002 Gujarat Riots
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Elections', 'Hinduism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: The former residents of a Muslim enclave that was attacked and razed by a Hindu mob in 2002 are warning voters that what happened to them could happen to anyone.
lead_paragraph: AHMEDABAD, India — Gulbarg Society, a complex of 18 bungalows and two apartment blocks once occupied by upper-middle-class Muslims in the largely Hindu neighborhood of Chamanpura, is now a cluster of doorless burned shells.

headline: Volkswagen Extends Offer to Acquire Full Control of Scania
abstract: Volkswagen, which already controls 62.6 percent of Scania’s capital, is hoping to coax more of the Swedish truck maker’s shareholders to sell.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Volkswagen said on Wednesday that it had extended its offer to take full control of the Swedish truck maker Scania, in hopes of coaxing more of the company’s shareholders to sell.

headline: Euro Zone Inflation Edges Up in April
abstract: Consumer prices rose at an annual rate of 0.7 percent, but continuing fears of deflation may keep pressure on the European Central Bank to act.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Inflation in the euro zone rose slightly in April, according to a preliminary official estimate, but probably not enough to ease fear of a damaging downward price spiral, nor enough to take pressure off the European Central Bank to undertake new measures to stimulate the economy.

headline: By One Measure, China Set to Become Largest Economy
abstract: In terms of purchasing power, China’s economy is poised to overtake the United States economy this year, but numbers don’t always tell the entire tale.
lead_paragraph: For years, Americans have told Gallup pollsters that China was the world’s pre-eminent economy. They were mistaken. The United States has held that spot for more than a century. A new report suggests they may soon be mistaken no more.

headline: New York Today: Umbrellas on Parade
abstract: What you need to know for Wednesday: The storm gathers force, a loophole in the pothole law, and restaurants collect oyster shells.
lead_paragraph: Good wet Wednesday morning to you. It will rain all day.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: What you need to know to start your Wednesday: a mishandled execution, a minimum wage vote, and whither the economy.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Xbox One to Go on Sale in China in September
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Xbox One (Video Game System)']
abstract: Microsoft says its latest game console, Xbox One, will go on sale in China in September, after a long ban on such products in the country.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE – Microsoft says its latest game console, Xbox One, will go on sale in China in September, after a long ban on such products in the country.

headline: By Its Own Yardstick, the Fed Is Falling Short
abstract: The Federal Reserve is expected to keep winding down its stimulus campaign.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve is failing to meet its basic responsibilities.

headline: The Politics of Gift Giving in India
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Elections', 'Gifts', 'Laptop Computers', 'Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: In Indian politics, offering freebies to voters is not as straightforward an exchange as the parties would like.
lead_paragraph: LUCKNOW, India – Every time second-year undergraduate law students at Lucknow University open up their 14-inch Hewlett-Packard laptops, they are reminded of the generous benefactors who gave them their computers.

headline: Verbatim: From Transcript to Performance
abstract: In our latest Op-Doc, for the Editorial Department’s section for short opinion-piece videos, an incensed lawyer deposes a beleaguered witness.
lead_paragraph: In our latest Op-Doc, for the Editorial Department’s section for short, opinion-piece videos, an incensed lawyer deposes a beleaguered witness. “When you say ‘photocopying machine,’ what do you mean?” the witness responds again and again. In its absurdity, the question becomes almost profound.

headline: BNP Paribas Says U.S. Penalties May Top the $1.1 Billion It Set Aside
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: In its earnings report, the bank said discussions over penalties showed “a high degree of uncertainty” as to the amount the United States might impose.
lead_paragraph: The French bank BNP Paribas warned on Wednesday that it might have to pay penalties higher than the $1.1 billion it had set aside for an investigation by the American authorities into whether it processed payments for countries facing United States sanctions, including Iran.

headline: The Urbane Face of the B.J.P. Nervous in Electoral Debut in Amritsar
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Elections', 'Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: What had seemed to be a smooth ride for Arun Jaitley of the Bharatiya Janata Party has been transformed into one of the most competitive and high-profile contests of this election.
lead_paragraph: AMRITSAR, India – On Sunday afternoon, Arun Jaitley, a senior leader of the Bharatiya Janata Party and leader of the opposition in Parliament’s upper house, was driven to Lawrence Road, a busy thoroughfare in Amritsar, the second-largest city in the western state of Punjab.

headline: House Budget Committee to Hold Hearing on Poverty
abstract: Representative Paul D. Ryan, a critic of redundant federal spending, is holding another hearing on the government and the poor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Is the federal government responsible for lifting millions of Americans out of poverty or trapping them in it?

headline: Daily Report: Twitter’s Revenue Rises, but Wall St. Worries About Growth
abstract: Twitter’s results were merely the backdrop to concerns about its ability to attract new people and keep them engaged.
lead_paragraph: Twitter is struggling to convince Wall Street that it is still a company with plenty of potential to grow, Nicole Perlroth reports.

headline: App Smart: Running Partners
abstract: Several smartphone apps can add a helpful boost of motivation, or just provide some fun information, to a run or walk.
lead_paragraph: Several smartphone apps can add a helpful boost of motivation, or just provide some fun information, to a run or walk.

headline: While on a Run, Apps to Match the Playlist to Your Pace
abstract: Apps for walking, running or cycling can offer motivation, or just deliver some interesting information.
lead_paragraph: IF you are headed out for a walk or jog, consider adding an app for your trip. Several smartphone apps can add a helpful boost of motivation, or just some fun information, to a workout or leisurely walk.

headline: 1964: Beirut is Travel Hub of the Middle East
abstract: In 1964, New York Herald Tribune writer Helen Barnes paints a picture of Beirut, a city in which “fast- paced sophistication, and slothful, time-worn customs are crazily juxtaposed.”
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT — Lebanon is as old as time and as new as tomorrow, and its face is constantly changing. This narrow strip of the eastern Mediterranean seaboard, which lies between Syria and Israel, has been an important trading center ever since the days when it was a stop on the spice route.

headline: Ukraine Says That Militants Won the East
abstract: Ukraine’s acting president on Wednesday conceded what had long been obvious: The government’s police and security officials had lost control in the areas surrounding the cities of Donetsk and Luhansk.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — It is by now a well-established pattern. Armed, masked men in their 20s to 40s storm a public building of high symbolic value in a city somewhere in eastern Ukraine, evict anyone still there, seize weapons and ammunition, throw up barricades and proclaim themselves the rulers of a “people’s republic.” It is not clear who is in charge or how the militias are organized.

headline: Profit at Carlyle Falls 18% as Real Estate Investments Underperform
abstract: Private equity may be a booming business, but the Carlyle Group was weighed down by declines in its global market strategies business and real assets segment.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:48 p.m. | Private equity may be a booming business, but that was not enough to lift the Carlyle Group’s earnings in the first quarter.

headline: Cloud Complexity, Simplified
abstract: Cloud technology is a mess that needs simplifying. That is why Equinix, a global provider of computer data centers and interconnections, will offer a way for companies to manage their services in one place.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard in technology to make things simpler, but there is usually good money in it.

headline: Celebrate Brooklyn! Festival Sets Lineup
abstract: The lineup includes concerts by Robert Glasper, who will appear with Talib Kweli; Dum Dum Girls; Bebel Gilberto; Shen Wei Dance and Dance Theater of Harlem.
lead_paragraph: The lineup for the 36th annual Celebrate Brooklyn! outdoor festival in Prospect Park has been announced and will feature free performances by acts like St. Vincent; the jazz and hip-hop fusion artist Robert Glasper, who will appear with Talib Kweli; the rock group Dum Dum Girls; and the Brazilian singer Bebel Gilberto.

headline: Why Dangerous Supplements Linger on Store Shelves
keywords: ['Diet and Nutrition', 'Dietary Supplements and Herbal Remedies', 'Medicine and Health', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Flaws in the way that dietary supplements are monitored and reported are causing potentially life-threatening delays in how long dangerous products linger on store shelves.
lead_paragraph: The first cases of liver problems linked to a popular weight loss supplement called OxyElite Pro began in Hawaii last May. But it wasn’t until four months later that the Food and Drug Administration, the agency responsible for getting dangerous products off the market, learned of the outbreak, and the product was finally recalled in November.

headline: ECO 348, The Great Recession: The New Normal
abstract: It’s all very sad.
lead_paragraph: Slides here (pdf).

headline: Countering ‘Too Big to Jail’
abstract: Federal prosecutors are poised to bring criminal charges against big banks. | Alstom’s board endorses G.E.’s offer. | Top officer at Barclays in America is leaving. | A look at Mayer’s good fortune at Yahoo.
lead_paragraph: “Federal prosecutors are nearing criminal charges against some of the world’s biggest banks, according to lawyers briefed on the matter, a development that could produce the first guilty plea from a major bank in more than two decades,” Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write in DealBook. In doing so, prosecutors are looking to address public outrage and alter the belief that Wall Street institutions are “too big to jail.”

headline: On Progressive Econoblogging
abstract: Echo chamber, or voices in the wilderness.
lead_paragraph: Chris House replies graciously to my critique of his critique. However, I have some further thoughts here. The crucial question, it seems to me, is what econobloggers — and in particular, those who happen to be political progressives — are doing, and what they should be trying to do.

headline: Tested Out Upstate: Classical’s Future
abstract: Symphony orchestras in Albany, Buffalo and Rochester are trying new methods and models to secure audiences beyond their traditional ones.
lead_paragraph: Two hours into the drive from Buffalo to Albany on the New York State Thruway, you pass Syracuse, a city with dark associations for classical music lovers.

headline: Hoping for Stability, Utility Operator Exelon Agrees to Buy Pepco for $6.8 Billion
abstract: The acquisition is the latest effort by a utility to cut costs by growing larger as the industry contends with declining electricity sales and gas prices.
lead_paragraph: The utility operator Exelon has again turned to deal making to expand, agreeing on Wednesday to buy Pepco Holdings for $6.8 billion to strengthen its operations on the East Coast.

headline: Once More, Economy Exhibits Weakness
abstract: The economy grew only 0.1 percent in the first quarter, hurt by harsh winter weather and slow gains in inventories after stockpiles grew robustly in the second half of 2013.
lead_paragraph: As has happened so many times since the recovery began nearly five years ago, the economy turned in another disappointing quarterly performance, surprising even the most pessimistic observers as growth in the first three months of 2014 slowed to a near-standstill.

headline: Congress Party Faces Uncertain Prospects in State It Helped Create
keywords: ['Elections, State Legislature', 'Law and Legislation', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: The newly created state of Telangana may not pay back its political benefactor, the Indian National Congress party, with seats in Parliament.
lead_paragraph: HYDERABAD, India — Ever since the bill recognizing Telangana as the nation’s 29th state passed unanimously through Parliament on Feb. 18, politics in this heart-shaped region of south India have been as muddled and dramatic as a soap opera, with failed alliances and accusations of broken promises and backstabbing between lawmakers.

headline: When a Restaurant Calls to Confirm a Reservation
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A poem for those who are tired of making a dinner reservation, and then being called up to confirm, and then calling back, and so forth.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Voters in City of Srinagar Heed Calls For Boycott
abstract: In Srinagar, the summer capital of Jammu and Kashmir, the election was taking on a familiar pattern: “Trouble mongers” were rounded up before the vote, and voter turnout was extremely low.
lead_paragraph: As Srinagar, the summer capital of Jammu and Kashmir, voted on Wednesday, the election was taking on a familiar pattern: In the first four hours of polling in the city, turnout was 5 percent, compared with 31 percent in Vadodara in Gujarat, where Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party was running for Parliament.

headline: Glisten in the Sun
abstract: Light, invigorating body oils will encourage any sun worshiper to put down the moisturizer.
lead_paragraph: Heavy moisturizers are so last summer, thanks to new body oils that are as weightlessly refreshing as a summer breeze.

headline: Intrade Co-Founder Opens Fantasy Sports Site
abstract: By styling the new company as a fantasy sports site and not a betting and prediction market, Tradesports.com hopes to avoid the kind of regulatory trouble that hastened Intrade’s demise.
lead_paragraph: The online betting and prediction market Intrade shut down last year after discovering financial problems and running afoul of regulators.

headline: Why U.S. Growth Slowed to a Halt at the Start of the Year
abstract: The readings were weaker than expected. Consumers are doing their part to drive the economy, but they’re nearly alone.
lead_paragraph: Well, that could have gone better.

headline: Energizer to Split in Two
abstract: Energizer said that it plans to split into two publicly traded companies: one for household products like Energizer batteries, the other for personal care products like Schick razors.
lead_paragraph: After years of buying up brands, Energizer Holdings has decided not to keep on going as a single consumer-products conglomerate.

headline: Editorial Contest Winner | National Parks: Ecology and Economy
abstract: Another winning essay from our Student Editorial Contest, this one by Matty H.
lead_paragraph: We are honoring the Top 10 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing an essay each day.

headline: More on Drones and James Risen — and a new AnonyWatch entry
abstract: The public editor empties out her notebook and leaves town.
lead_paragraph: I’m heading off to the International Journalism Festival in Perugia, Italy where I’m one of the (many) speakers this week. My speech has an admittedly unwieldy title: “What I’ve Learned at the New York Times (And What That Says About Journalism).” I have copious notes — and a long flight to get them in order.

headline: A Korean City With 250 Holes in Its Heart
abstract: There is a mournful stillness in the industrial city of Ansan, where nearly three quarters of a high school’s 11th graders died in the ferry disaster.
lead_paragraph: ANSAN, South Korea — The cluttered store next to the gate of Danwon High School in the drab industrial city of Ansan is jammed with school necessities. White gym uniforms hang in the window, behind dusty glass. Pens and pencils are sorted neatly into cubbyholes, and a freezer full of ice cream sits outside as a lure for passing students.

headline: Test Prep Endures in New York Schools, Despite Calls to Ease It
abstract: New York City’s schools chancellor said in December that she would limit state exams’ role in measuring student progress, but test prep, and the anxiety it causes, is as robust as ever.
lead_paragraph: For several weeks, Reanna Bhola and her sixth-grade classmates at Intermediate School 126 in Astoria, Queens, spent part of nearly every day focused on test preparation. First it was reading, with sample passages, questions and review sheets mirroring the actual tests.

headline: Teach the Teachers Well
abstract: When dealing with students’ emotional and behavior problems, like anxiety and bullying, common sense and good intentions are often not enough.
lead_paragraph: When Yvonne Ford started teaching at P.S. 133, a public elementary school in Brooklyn, her classroom wasn’t an easy place to learn. Students with behavior problems struggled to remain on task. Teasing and name-calling were common. Many students came to school angry and anxious. Ford wasn’t satisfied with how students treated each other or her. “I knew I needed to build a positive community in my classroom,” she recounts, but she didn’t know how. “The things they have to deal with on a daily basis are not things I had to deal with as a child,” Ford says of the students at P.S. 133, about 80 percent of whom are eligible for free or reduced price lunch and some of whom live in shelters or foster homes. She worried that she would say or do something that made students’ problems worse.

headline: A Seeger Fest to Honor Pete and Toshi, and It’s Free
abstract: Seeger Fest, a series of free concerts and events this summer, will honor Pete Seeger and his wife, Toshi.
lead_paragraph: “My grandfather didn’t leave a blueprint about the kind of memorial he wanted,” Kitama Cahill-Jackson, whose grandfather was Pete Seeger, said in a telephone interview. “But when my grandmother died, just a few months earlier, I planned her memorial with him, and nothing says more about what someone would like than to see what they planned for a loved one.”

headline: Stern Talk From Chief of F.C.C. on Open Net
abstract: Tom Wheeler, the F.C.C. chairman, says there is a shortfall in adequate broadband competition.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Federal Communications Commission’s chairman delivered a tough message to cable and broadband executives Wednesday, saying a lack of competition in their industry has hurt consumers.

headline: In California, Governor Pushes a Rainy-Day Fund
abstract: In his effort to right California’s finances, and secure a fourth term, Gov. Jerry Brown wants voters to approve a constitutional amendment requiring that surpluses be used to pay down debt.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — After overcoming years of fiscal dysfunction that stemmed in part from an antitax ballot referendum, Gov. Jerry Brown is trying to call California voters to the ballot again — this time to approve a constitutional amendment requiring that surpluses be used to pay down municipal debt and create an emergency fund.

headline: Alone at Sea
abstract: Two new picture books about giant turtles and tortoises take different tacks.
lead_paragraph: In two new picture books, stories of giant turtles and tortoises take different tacks, one casting facts aside to revel in the imaginative possibilities of such a creature’s life, the other taking a long view of its evolution over the course of a million years. One starts in isolation and ends companionably; the other begins in a community, and ends alone. They’re books for different age groups to be sure, but neither entirely succeeds as a picture book.

headline: Breaking From Her Norm to Connect With Her Tradition
abstract: Olga Bell of the Dirty Projectors has released her second solo work, “Krai,” inspired by regions in her native country: Russia.
lead_paragraph: At a sleepy ocean-side restaurant in Brighton Beach, a Russian enclave in Brooklyn, the singer-songwriter Olga Bell peered across the table stacked with traditional dishes — sliced herring with onions, hearty borscht, blini with red caviar. Her smile broadened at the sight of the pelmeni (meat dumplings). “The way my mom makes these, we put them in a broth with a little bit of soy sauce,” she said, spooning another helping onto her plate. “But we’re into fusion like that.”

headline: A Wide-Ranging Lineup for Lincoln Center Out of Doors
abstract: Performances at the Lincoln Center Out of Doors Festival will include country music, dance, indie-rock and more.
lead_paragraph: The world premiere of a work by the Pulitzer Prize winner John Luther Adams; a celebration of the 50th anniversary of John Coltrane’s “Love Supreme”; a memorial concert for Pete and Toshi Seeger; and performances by Emmylou Harris and Rodney Crowell; Rosanne Cash; and the Paul Taylor Dance Company are among the offerings at the year’s Lincoln Center Out of Doors Festival. All told, the 44th season of the festival will offer nearly 100 free events on Lincoln Center’s plazas between July 20 and Aug. 10.

headline: Assailants Attack Train Station in Restive Western China
abstract: At least three people were killed and 79 hurt at the rail station in Urumqi, Xinjiang, where President Xi Jinping had been visiting.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Assailants with explosives and knives killed three people and wounded at least 79 Wednesday evening outside a railroad station in Urumqi, the capital of western China’s restive Xinjiang region, where President Xi Jinping had just concluded a visit, state news media reported, calling it a brazen terrorist assault.

headline: Church Band With a Legacy
abstract: Those who passed through the Baptist Church Brass Band in the early years include Wynton Marsalis, Lucien Barbarin, Leroy Jones and Herlin Riley.
lead_paragraph: In 1970, the Fairview Baptist Church Brass Band — first called the Fairview Baptist Church Christian Marching Band — was created in New Orleans by the banjoist and guitarist Danny Barker, and the story of its evolution and influence is pretty much the story of how a cultural tradition rallied and flourished at a critical moment of declining interest. Those who passed through the Fairview band in the early years include Wynton Marsalis, Lucien Barbarin, Leroy Jones and Herlin Riley.

headline: Campaign to Save a Carny Mainstay
abstract: “Zipper: Coney Island’s Last Wild Ride,” Monday night at 10 on WNET/13, documents a way of life that increasingly seems as if it’s from another era.
lead_paragraph: “Zipper: Coney Island’s Last Wild Ride,” Monday night at 10 on WNET/13, documents a way of life that increasingly seems as if it’s from another era, and now that film itself has a bit of that aura. It was shot in a distant time when some guy named Bloomberg was mayor of New York and developers ruled the land. It documents the emergence of an ambitious redevelopment plan for Coney Island, one that critics contend would destroy the character of the place, and it does so through the eyes of the operators of the Zipper, an old-school ride that becomes a symbol of the carny world endangered by the plan.

headline: ‘Alice’ Lives, Right Here
abstract: “Alice Doesn’t Live Here Anymore” is being shown on Saturday night at 7:30 at BAM Rose Cinemas.
lead_paragraph: At the Academy Awards in Los Angeles in April 1975, Martin Scorsese had to accept Ellen Burstyn’s best-actress Oscar for her because she was busy starring in a play, “Same Time, Next Year,” in New York. Less than two weeks later, she won the best actress Tony for that play. Pretty good April.

headline: Whirling Forward Beyond a Founder
abstract: Since time dances ever on, modern-dance groups must eventually decide how to continue when their charismatic founding choreographers retire or die.
lead_paragraph: Since time dances ever on, modern-dance groups must eventually decide how to continue when their charismatic founding choreographers retire or die. One troupe that keeps thriving is the Limón Dance Company. Since the death of its founder, José Limón, in 1972, it has not stopped moving forward, and its director, Carla Maxwell, adroitly balances Limón revivals with premieres by other choreographers.

headline: Violin and Chorus In Unusual Hybrid
abstract: The composer Jennifer Higdon is best known for works that reflect old-school values of sturdy American craftsmanship and optimism.
lead_paragraph: The composer Jennifer Higdon is best known for works that reflect old-school values of sturdy American craftsmanship and optimism, with ruminative currents running just beneath their polished surfaces. Those qualities apply to “The Singing Rooms,” which receives its New York premiere at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday. Ms. Higdon wrote this unusual hybrid oratorio-concerto for the brilliant violinist Jennifer Koh, who recorded it in 2011 with the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra. At Carnegie, Ms. Koh will perform with the New York Choral Society and Orchestra, conducted by David Hayes. (8 p.m., 212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org.)

headline: A Lamentation for Assyria
abstract: Prepare to be rattled by “Roberto Cuoghi: Suillakku Corral,” if not by the onslaught of sound, then by the empty galleries in which it is presented.
lead_paragraph: Prepare to be rattled one way or another by “Roberto Cuoghi: Suillakku Corral,” if not by the onslaught of sound — described by one writer as “an assault without respite of music, chants, animal verses, animal sounds, noises and the sound of spitting” — then by the empty galleries in which it is presented or by its disturbing analogies. Opening at the New Museum on Wednesday, this show presents the latest from Mr. Cuoghi, a driven, often perverse Italian polymath who works in painting, sculpture, performance and animation. After several years of mind-boggling immersion into ancient Assyria, he has created an imagined lamentation for the fall of that militaristic civilization.

headline: Funds for Troubled Mortgages Are on the Rise
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Mortgages', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: Distressed-mortgage funds are suddenly hot, but it is unclear whether the strategy of investing in delinquent home loans will live up to the marketing hype.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:03 p.m. | In the world of hedge funds, distressed mortgage funds are suddenly hot, but it is unclear whether the strategy will live up to the marketing hype.

headline: N.B.A.’s Move Is Not Little, but It’s Late
abstract: A roundup of columns about N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver’s banishment of the Clippers owner Donald Sterling from the league on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: After the conga line of support spawned by N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver’s banishment of Donald Sterling on Tuesday — a carnival led by validated players, relieved owners and a Los Angeles Clippers staff that acted as if it had just been released from Guantánamo — there ensued a natural pause. Because in celebrating the first move to excise Sterling from the N.B.A. and pry the Clippers from his grubby hands, the next thought had to be why it had not been done sooner.

headline: Rescuers Turn to Boat as Storm Rocks Florida
abstract: A storm driven by heavy rainfall and high winds has also hit hard in Alabama, Arkansas, Georgia, Iowa, Mississippi, Oklahoma and Tennessee.
lead_paragraph: PENSACOLA, Fla. — His city stunned and saturated by floodwaters, Craig Hindsman, a pastor at the Marcus Pointe Baptist Church here, suddenly became an amateur rescuer on Wednesday.

headline: Remembering President Giuliani and President Brown
abstract: Hillary Clinton leads Jeb Bush by 12 points in a new poll. History tells us that doesn’t mean much.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton has a commanding lead over Jeb Bush, 53 percent to 41 percent, in a hypothetical 2016 matchup between the two, according to a Washington Post/ABC News poll Wednesday.

headline: Ishigaki, a Japanese Natural Wonderland
abstract: The remote island’s unspoiled beaches, coral reefs, tropical vistas and other splendors lead some to call it “the most beautiful place in Japan.”
lead_paragraph: Unruly stalks brushed against the windows of the white Suzuki minivan as it bumped down an unmarked dirt road through a field of sugar cane. When the road abruptly ended, we continued on foot down a barely perceptible path through thick tropical foliage, fighting through branches and brush.

headline: A Remote Colombia City That Really Does Exist
abstract: The writer Gabriel García Márquez, who died in April, once wrote in a novel that Mompós doesn’t exist. But the town is real, even if it’s close to nowhere.
lead_paragraph: The first time I heard of Mompós, officially called Santa Cruz de Mompox, was about a decade ago, while reading Gabriel García Márquez’s novel “The General in His Labyrinth.” “Mompox doesn’t exist,” Mr. García Márquez wrote, “we sometimes dream about her, but she doesn’t exist.” For years, I assumed that to be true.

headline: Seen on the Street | Outside the Almaty, Kazakhstan Fall/Winter 2014 Shows
abstract: A glimpse at what gals are wearing this season.
lead_paragraph: A glimpse at what gals are wearing this season.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: I’m Not a Cheese
abstract: Part 15: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall describe how they make decisions about future projects.
lead_paragraph: Part 15: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall describe how they make decisions about future projects.

headline: Yes, Silicon Valley, Sometimes You Need More Bureaucracy
abstract: A female engineer’s complaint of a culture of bullying at GitHub demonstrates the value of a human resources department.
lead_paragraph: The dirtiest word in Silicon Valley is bureaucracy. Tech executives want to move quickly — a Facebook company motto is “move fast and break things” — and layers of bureaucracy, such as human resources departments, are seen as the enemy of speed and efficiency.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: Taking on an Iconic Role
abstract: Part 14: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall explain their rehearsal process.
lead_paragraph: Part 14: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall explain their rehearsal process.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: The Importance of Naps
abstract: Part 13: Alan Cumming and Michelle Williams talk about what draws them to the roles they choose.
lead_paragraph: Part 13: Alan Cumming and Michelle Williams talk about what draws them to the roles they choose.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: Alan’s Fragrance
abstract: Part 12: The director Rob Marshall reflects on returning to theater after working exclusively in film for 15 years.
lead_paragraph: Part 12: The director Rob Marshall reflects on returning to theater after working exclusively in film for 15 years.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: Kander & Ebb
abstract: Part 11: The director Rob Marshall talks about the important role John Kander and Fred Ebb played in his career; Alan Cumming describes meeting Joel Grey, who originated the Emcee role.
lead_paragraph: Part 11: The director Rob Marshall talks about the important role John Kander and Fred Ebb played in his career; Alan Cumming describes meeting Joel Grey, who originated the Emcee role.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: Marilyn Monroe
abstract: Part 10: Alan Cumming and Michelle Williams reveal what their “Cabaret” roles share in common with other parts they’ve played.
lead_paragraph: Part 10: Alan Cumming and Michelle Williams reveal what their “Cabaret” roles share in common with other parts they’ve played.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: Not Just a Period Piece
abstract: Part 9: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall discuss the historical context and relevance of the show’s story and setting.
lead_paragraph: Part 9: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall discuss the historical context and relevance of the show’s story and setting.

headline: Children’s Art at Syria School, and Then a Bomb
abstract: Images of the school in Aleppo showed pools of blood and children’s drawings, after a blast that reportedly killed at least 20 people, including 17 students.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Organizers had worked until dawn hanging children’s artwork on the wall of an elementary school in Syria’s largest city: a bright green tank under a round yellow sun, a girl in pigtails defying a soldier’s bullets, a missile plunging from a warplane toward the school building.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: Broadway Has Changed
abstract: Part 8: Michelle Williams talks about how her daughter influences her career choices; the director Rob Marshall reflects on what Broadway has lost.
lead_paragraph: Part 8: Michelle Williams talks about how her daughter influences her career choices; the director Rob Marshall reflects on what Broadway has lost.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: A Lie Down
abstract: Part 7: Alan Cumming describes what it’s like to work simultaneously on “Cabaret” and “The Good Wife.”
lead_paragraph: Part 7: Alan Cumming describes what it’s like to work simultaneously on “Cabaret” and “The Good Wife.”

headline: ‘Cabaret’: Rob Marshall’s Special Skill
abstract: Part 6: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall explore their collaborative process.
lead_paragraph: Part 6: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall explore their collaborative process.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: Sally and the Emcee
abstract: Part 5: Alan Cumming and Michelle Williams discuss their “Cabaret” characters and the difference between musical and non-musical theater.
lead_paragraph: Part 5: Alan Cumming and Michelle Williams discuss their “Cabaret” characters and the difference between musical and non-musical theater.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: De-Liza-fication
abstract: Part 4: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall talk about how the 1972 film of “Cabaret” transformed the production.
lead_paragraph: Part 4: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall talk about how the 1972 film of “Cabaret” transformed the production.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: Concept Musical
abstract: Part 3: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall discuss why the show was groundbreaking when it first premiered and why it continues to be important.
lead_paragraph: Part 3: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall discuss why the show was groundbreaking when it first premiered and why it continues to be important.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: Evolution
abstract: Part 2: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall each recall how they first encountered “Cabaret” in their lives and careers.
lead_paragraph: Part 2: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall each recall how they first encountered “Cabaret” in their lives and careers.

headline: ‘Cabaret’: Intro
abstract: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the actors Alan Cumming and Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall.
lead_paragraph: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the actors Alan Cumming and Michelle Williams and the director Rob Marshall.

headline: TimesTalks | ‘Cabaret’: Preview
abstract: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and “Cabaret” co-director Rob Marshall talk about bringing the Tony-winning musical back to Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Alan Cumming, Michelle Williams and “Cabaret” co-director Rob Marshall talk about bringing the Tony-winning musical back to Broadway.

headline: Don’t be surprised that people still say racist things.
abstract: Racism is still more common than you may realize.
lead_paragraph: The condemnation of remarks by the Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling is almost unanimous. But racism is still more common than you may realize. In surveys, more than one-fifth of whites volunteer views consistent with negative racial stereotypes. While many fewer Americans express animosity toward blacks than they did 40 years ago, a CBS News poll from March showed that 46 percent of Americans thought racial discrimination would always exist.

headline: Cruise Line Will Return to Persian Gulf
abstract: Royal Caribbean International will resume cruises in the Persian Gulf in 2015.
lead_paragraph: Royal Caribbean International cruise line will return to the Persian Gulf next year, with 16 cruises planned between December 2015 and March 2016.

headline: N.Y.U. Appoints a Dean for the  Tisch School of the Arts
abstract: Allyson Green joined the university in 2012 as the associate dean of Tisch’s Institute of the Performing Arts.
lead_paragraph: Allyson Green, a dancer, choreographer, designer and curator, has been named the new dean of  the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University, the university announced on Wednesday.

headline: Today in Small Business: ‘My Idea Is Just Too Far Ahead of Its Time’
abstract: How to fire someone without getting sued. Are health care costs growing again?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: What You Get for ... $1,800,000
abstract: This week’s properties include houses on rivers in Oregon and Virginia and one with mountain views in Vermont.
lead_paragraph: BEND, ORE.

headline: The Once-Groovy Future of Flight
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Luxurious, fun planes seemed the only way to fly, then came deregulation.
lead_paragraph: It looks as if Austin Powers should be the next lucky passenger to descend into this scene — a prototype for a first-class Tiger Lounge, residing inside the belly of the first jumbo passenger jet, the Boeing 747, which was introduced in 1970.

headline: In 1918 Flu Pandemic, Timing Was a Killer
abstract: The outbreak was unusual in claiming many people in their late 20s. A new study says they may have died because they had antibodies to a different flu strain.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes a virus can cause more devastation than all the world’s armies. In 1918, at the end of World War I, influenza spread around the planet, reaching even Pacific islands and Arctic villages. The virus infected a third of all people on earth, and caused an estimated 50 million deaths — more than three times the number of people killed  in World War I.

headline: The Rent Is Too High
abstract: New York City stands at the epicenter of a national housing crisis that has placed low-income people at a steadily greater risk of homelessness.
lead_paragraph: New York City stands at the epicenter of a national housing crisis that has placed low-income people at a steadily greater risk of homelessness. As Mireya Navarro and Vivian Yee of the Times reminded us on Tuesday, that risk is increasingly apparent to elderly New Yorkers who hoped to retire in the city, but who now find that their modest incomes will not cover the cost of decent housing in even marginal areas.

headline: Communion, Catholicism and Conscience
abstract: More thoughts on Catholicism’s rules and their possible exceptions.
lead_paragraph: As a companion to my last post, I want to say something about an argument made by my friend Pascal-Emmanuel Gobry, like me (if I may so label him) a conservative Catholic with some heterodox tendencies, in defense of divorce-and-remarried Catholics taking communion, because I think it gets at a distinction that’s important to my own understanding of Catholic doctrine and practice. Here (I’ll be quoting at length) he’s discussing how advocates of communion might deal with the fact that the remarried, if their marriages aren’t annulled, are living in what the church considers a persistent state of public adultery, which they don’t intend to leave:

headline: New Award Recognizes Two Young Choreographers
abstract: Rebecca Patek and Jen Rosenblit are the first winners of a new mentorship prize called the Award.
lead_paragraph: A group of independent performers and choreographers that includes Dean Moss, Kimberly Bartosik and Joshua Lubin-Levy have established the Award, a mentorship prize for young choreographers, based on what the prize’s web page describes as “the goodwill of New York City’s experimental dance community.” The group describes its nomination and selection process as confidential – nominators are anonymous – with aesthetic rigor and innovation as the principal criteria.

headline: From Making Bagel Baskets to Thinking Much Bigger
abstract: With robots and skilled labor, Drew Greenblatt re-engineered his firm from one making simple wire baskets to one producing custom pieces for aerospace clients.
lead_paragraph: In the mid-1990s, Drew Greenblatt started dialing his way down a list of 800 brokers, lawyers and accountants, looking for a business to buy. He had sold a security alarm installation company, and he was looking for four qualities in his next venture: an honest seller, a viable market, a rational purchase price, and a business that sold to other businesses. He was through with coddling consumers.

headline: It’s a small world, after all.
abstract: An increasing number of Facebook users have friends in other countries, although the degree to which this is true varies by nation.
lead_paragraph: At least on Facebook.

headline: Times Minute | A Botched Execution
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Creativity', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The renewed debate about death penalty procedures. Also on the Minute, black women’s hairstyles in the Army and scientific evidence that walking increases creativity.
lead_paragraph: The renewed debate about death penalty procedures. Also on the Minute, black women’s hairstyles in the Army and scientific evidence that walking increases creativity.

headline: What’s Your Comfort Food?
abstract: Tell us your favorite.
lead_paragraph: I should’ve known comfort food would strike a chord, because as I wrote in today’s column, everyone has a favorite. Friends have been emailing, saying things like this: “For me, comfort food is caldo de fideo with a few stewed tomatoes and a good dose of lime juice. If the angel hair has first been toasted with onions to near burning, so much better for the nostalgia.” (Another told me that toasting bagels was heresy.)

headline: Times Minute | A Botched Execution
abstract: The renewed debate about death penalty procedures. Also on the Minute, black women’s hairstyles in the Army and scientific evidence that walking increases creativity.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: The 21st Century Is Calling, With Wi-Fi Hot Spots
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Wireless Communications', 'Telephones and Telecommunications']
abstract: Where pay phones stand, New York City envisions thousands of “public communications structures” with free Wi-Fi service and enough telephone service for calls to 911 or 311.
lead_paragraph: In the era of smartphones, pay phones look increasingly dumb.

headline: The Other Christie Scandal
abstract: Much worse than Bridgegate.
lead_paragraph: What is it that makes self-proclaimed centrists such easy marks for right-wing con men? Actually, it’s not that much of a mystery: the centrist creed is that the two parties are symmetrically extremist, and this means that there must, as a matter of principle, be Serious, Honest Republicans out there — so such people must be invented if they don’t actually exist. Hence the elevation of Paul Ryan despite clear evidence of his con-artist nature.

headline: Bob Hoskins, Actor Who Combined Charm and Menace, Dies at 71
abstract: The bullet-shaped film star played the hero in “Who Framed Roger Rabbit’' and ruthless British gangsters in “The Long Good Friday” and “Mona Lisa.”
lead_paragraph: Bob Hoskins, the bullet-shaped British film star who brought a singular mix of charm, menace and cockney accent to a variety of roles, including the bemused live-action hero of the largely animated “Who Framed Roger Rabbit,” has died. He was 71.

headline: Do You Think Small American Manufacturers Can Compete?
keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Small Business']
abstract: Drew Greenblatt offers examples of small companies that are excelling by emphasizing workplace safety, innovation and aggressive exporting.
lead_paragraph: We’ve just published a Conversation with Drew Greenblatt, chief executive of Marlin Steel Wire Products, which a decade ago manufactured only $12 wire baskets for bagels. Marlin now makes 80 to 100 varieties baskets a month, including customized designs for the aerospace and medical industries that cost as much as $5,000 apiece.

headline: Stop Worrying About Your Child Getting Into College. Worry About What Happens Next.
keywords: ['ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Community Colleges', 'Dropouts', 'Graduation Rates', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Parenting', 'Scholarships and Fellowships']
abstract: Amidst all the hand-wringing about elite college admission rates, many parents and students are missing the point. It doesn’t matter where you go to school if you can’t graduate.
lead_paragraph: As a college professor, former admissions officer and researcher on what happens to youths after high school, I believe the current panic over the increasing selectivity of elite schools misses the point. So much energy goes into getting into college. Many families can’t see that getting through college is far more important, and that graduating prepared for adult life will be more valuable than the name arched over the top of the degree.

headline: Democrats Assail G.O.P. After Filibuster of Proposal to Raise Minimum Wage
abstract: Democrats moved swiftly to frame the vote as an example of the gulf that exists between the two parties, saying the question is not just one of money, but of morality.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the Republican-led filibuster of a Senate proposal to raise the federal minimum wage to $10.10 on Wednesday, Democrats moved swiftly to frame the vote as an example of the gulf that exists between the two parties on matters of economic fairness and upward mobility.

headline: ‘Mom, This Looks Like the End of Me’: Doomed Vessel’s Last Minutes
keywords: ['Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Ferries']
abstract: Newly released videos show students’ excitement giving way to fear, confusion and then hopelessness aboard the doomed ferry.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — As a ferry carrying 476 people was badly listing off the southwestern coast of South Korea two weeks ago, one of the students on board asked, “Are we becoming a Titanic?”

headline: A Chelsea Apartment: The Reward of Staying the Course
abstract: After flirting with buying a place in other areas, Daniel Brass and Craig Manson realized they should stay true to their neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: Having owned property in London, where they had lived and worked, Craig Manson and Daniel Brass were interested in investing in the New York market. When the couple moved to New York for work a year and a half ago, they sublet a two-bedroom in Chelsea. It was well located, though small and dark, and rented for around $3,400 a month.

headline: A Store Where Everything is Made in the U.S.
abstract: The Made in America project sells fashion and housewares manufactured in America, and tells the stories behind them.
lead_paragraph: Boosting the domestic economy is as easy as the click of a mouse with The MiA Project, a new online marketplace that exclusively stocks goods made in America (hence the name). The site, which launches today, was founded by Micha Thomas, a former creative marketing director for an independent music-booking agency, and Jaime Lawson, whose fashion background includes a stint at Rodarte and her own bridal accessory line, Bleu Garters. The L.A.-based duo have curated a roster of designers and makers both traditional (Pendleton Woolen Mills) and new (Earth tu Face, Baggu) and will be telling some of their stories through studio visits and other editorial content on the site. The vast retail component, with price points ranging from $10 to about $3,000, includes men’s, women’s and children’s casual wear and accessories, decorative items for the home, an organic beauty apothecary and such only-in-America gifts as an aromatherapeutic “throne spray” (if you have to ask…). It’s an assortment as diverse and democratic as the U.S. itself.

headline: Stars’ Newest Must-Have Item: The Clippers
abstract: The Los Angeles Clippers franchise, which may be for sale soon, finds itself in a disorienting position: as the toast of Los Angeles and a coveted commodity in professional sports.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For most of the Clippers’ 30-year tenure in Los Angeles, they have been viewed as a punch line in hightops.

headline: Take My Buyout, Please …
abstract: Thomas H. Lee, who was honored Tuesday night for his philanthropy at an event organized by the UJA-Federation of New York, knows how to work a room.
lead_paragraph: Four decades ago, Thomas H. Lee was one of the pioneers of leveraged buyouts.

headline: Man Charged With Killing a Developer in January
abstract: The arrest of Kendel Felix followed the investigation into the death of Menachem Stark, the builder whose body was found smoldering in a trash bin on Long Island in January.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department has arrested a 26-year-old man in connection with the kidnapping and killing of a Brooklyn developer, whose body was found smoldering in a trash container at a gas station in Nassau County on Jan. 3.

headline: U.S. Attorney Subpoenas Records of Ethics Panel
abstract: The United States attorney’s office is seeking records from the Joint Commission on Public Ethics for all complaints the panel has received on public corruption.
lead_paragraph: The top federal prosecutor in Manhattan, who sharply criticized Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s shutdown of a commission he had formed to investigate political corruption in New York State, is now seeking records from the state’s ethics panel.

headline: Oklahoma Vows Review of Botched Execution
abstract: Criticism from death penalty opponents and others increased as officials scrambled to determine why the execution by lethal injection did not go as planned.
lead_paragraph: McALESTER, Okla. — As Clayton D. Lockett writhed and groaned on the gurney on Tuesday night after a large dose of sedatives had apparently not been fully delivered, the Oklahoma chief of corrections rushed to call the governor and the attorney general. Something had gone disastrously wrong with the lethal injection, he told them, and the execution of a second man must be delayed. Gov. Mary Fallin instantly agreed.

headline: Whither Dan Brown? Poll Lists Americans’ Favorite Books
abstract: “The Da Vinci Code” is no longer among Americans’ favorite books but the Bible is still tops, according to a new Harris poll.
lead_paragraph: Good-bye “Da Vinci Code,” hello “Moby-Dick”!

headline: Scenes from Severe Flooding in the Florida Panhandle
abstract: Videos and photographs show the extent of the damage from torrential rains in the Florida Panhandle that have caused at least two deaths and the collapse of a section of the Scenic Highway near Pensacola.
lead_paragraph: A section of the Scenic Highway near Pensacola, Fla., collapsed after more than 20 inches of rain caused severe flooding early Wednesday in the Florida Panhandle and in southern Alabama, as my colleague Alan Binder reports.

headline: Image of the Day: April 30
abstract: A worker navigating across a salt pan on the eve of Labour Day in Chennai, Tamil Nadu.

headline: Facebook to Let Users Limit Data Revealed by Log-Ins
abstract: The company’s move is part of its goal to become a platform on which other apps run, with Facebook accounts used as universal IDs.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Trying to become even bigger — and make more money — Facebook will allow users to reveal a little less.

headline: Hottest Hostess in Washington
abstract: In Anthony Giardina’s “The City of Conversation,” at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center, Jan Maxwell portrays a Washington political hostess.
lead_paragraph: If politicians brought the same clarity to their public positions that Jan Maxwell brings to her acting, the lives of voters would be so much easier. Whether portraying a scurrilous British witch in the days of the Crusades (in Howard Barker’s “The Castle”), a stroke survivor (Arthur Kopit’s “Wings”) or a self-dramatizing stage star (in “The Royal Family”), Ms. Maxwell has an unfailing gift for making you understand where her characters are coming from, even when they don’t seem to know themselves. So the idea of her going to Washington, to lend a little transparency to the capital of opacity, is irresistible.

headline: Everything’s Up-to-Date (or at Least From the Late ’80s)
abstract: New York City Ballet opened its spring season with a program devoted to 21st-century choreographers, including the premiere of J R, Lil Buck and Peter Martins’s collaboration, “Les Bosquets.”
lead_paragraph: As New York City Ballet opened its spring season at the David H. Koch Theater on Tuesday, one man in the audience stood out in a conspicuous disguise of fedora and sunglasses. Those in the know could recognize this as the costume of J R, the artist responsible for the giant photograph of City Ballet dancers that covered the floor of the theater’s promenade earlier this year.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 43
abstract: Another player expected to play a role for his national team, Andros Townsend of England, will miss the World Cup because of an injury.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The New York Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Forecasting a Speedup in Growth, the Fed Again Cuts Bond Purchases
abstract: At its policy-making meeting, the Federal Reserve said that it would pare its purchases of Treasury and mortgage-backed securities by another $10 billion, to $45 billion a month beginning this month.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve continued to retreat from its stimulus campaign on Wednesday, saying it was looking past the economic slowdown during an unusually cold winter because growth already was rebounding.

headline: Big Banks Erred Widely on Troubled Mortgages, U.S. Regulator Confirms
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Foreclosures', 'Mortgages', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: A new report from a banking regulator offers a snapshot of the morass of problems that mortgage holders who fell behind in payments experienced during the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:14 p.m. | A federal regulator confirmed on Wednesday that the country’s biggest banks committed widespread errors in dealing with homeowners who faced foreclosures at the height of the mortgage crisis, but the findings are unlikely to put to rest questions from lawmakers and others about the extent of the problems.

headline: Decoding the Fed’s Statement
abstract: The statement Wednesday from the Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making group of the Federal Reserve, offers its assessment of current economic conditions. At the last meeting, in mid-March, Fed officials saw economic weakness as being driven by winter weather. This time, they affirmed that view, and now view the economy to be growing faster.
lead_paragraph: The statement Wednesday from the Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making group of the Federal Reserve, offers its assessment of current economic conditions. At the last meeting, in mid-March, Fed officials saw economic weakness as being driven by winter weather. This time, they affirmed that view, and now view the economy to be growing faster.

headline: Is Your Pension Plan Stupid? Nebraska’s Isn’t
abstract: It’s common knowledge they are often underfunded. Less well known are that some have strange features that create perverse incentives.
lead_paragraph: Imagine you were 25 years old and considering a job with a company, and your employer told you these were the terms of the retirement plan:

headline: Building Firm Pleads Guilty to Defrauding Its Customers
abstract: Structure Tone, one of the nation’s largest construction firms, pleaded guilty to corruption charges and agreed to forfeit $55 million.
lead_paragraph: Structure Tone, one of the nation’s largest construction firms, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to corruption charges and agreed to forfeit $55 million for a scheme in which the company defrauded a roster of prominent financial institutions, law firms and ad agencies out of tens of millions of dollars.

headline: The Voice of the Clippers
abstract: The coach has done a masterly job on the court, leading the Clippers to a franchise-record 57 wins, but he has never been more valuable to the team than in the last few days.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When Doc Rivers walked into a conference room Tuesday night that was so packed that dozens of reporters were turned away, he took a deep breath and exhaled as he sat behind the microphone. He then proceeded to do what he had spent much of the previous three days doing: answering question after question about his employer, the Los Angeles Clippers’ owner, Donald Sterling.

headline: Barenboim Goes Digital
abstract: The conductor and pianist Daniel Barenboim, in partnership with Universal Music, creates a digital label.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — As digital music consumption becomes the norm the classical recording industry is looking to new models, from video apps to digital singles. Now the conductor and pianist Daniel Barenboim, in partnership with Universal Music, has created his own exclusively digital label.

headline: John Paul Stevens Gets That ‘Money Is Not Speech’
abstract: The former justice is at odds with the majority of the Roberts court.
lead_paragraph: Former Justice John Paul Stevens’ appearance before the Senate Rules Committee this morning was remarkable, and not just because retired Supreme Court justices rarely show up at Congressional hearings. It was remarkable for the clarity with which made the point that unlimited and undisclosed money are eliminating fairness from the American political system.

headline: Moving On, Even if It’s Back in Time
abstract: Ray LaMontagne’s new album, “Supernova,” reflects a shift from a roots sound to the floating harmonies and early psychedelia of the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: ASHFIELD, Mass. — Visiting Ray LaMontagne is like going back to another century. The question is, which one?

headline: Alibaba I.P.O. May Unleash Global Fight Over Users
abstract: While the Silicon Valley elite may not seem to care about the coming stock offering, it could signal the start of a global fight for users.
lead_paragraph: The largest technology stock offering in history is looming, but few in Silicon Valley seem to care.

headline: Energizer Split Leaves Biggest Problem Intact
abstract: The main challenge is mustering enough resources to take on the consumer products behemoth Procter & Gamble, writes Kevin Allison of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Energizer’s split into household and personal care companies should improve the $7 billion company’s focus. It could also make one of the newly independent businesses an acquisition target. But the proposed transaction doesn’t address the batteries-to-tampons conglomerate’s bigger challenge: mustering more resources to take on industry gorilla Procter & Gamble.

headline: Where Did You Get Those Genes? Researching Advances In Genetics
abstract: In this lesson, we offer a collection of teaching ideas using recent Times coverage about how genes work, how we can work with them and where they come from.
lead_paragraph: From junk DNA that, as it turns out, is not so junky after all, to the unique signatures in different cancer genes, our understanding of genetics is changing so rapidly that textbooks can’t always keep up. In this lesson, we offer a collection of teaching ideas using recent Times coverage about how genes work, how we can work with them and where they come from.Rethinking Junk

headline: Thailand Says It Will Try to Hold an Election in July
abstract: Opposition leaders refused to say whether they would participate in the vote, reflecting the dysfunction that has paralyzed Thai politics for months.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Thailand’s election commission on Wednesday said it would try to hold a vote in July but opposition leaders refused to say whether they would participate, underlining the country’s political paralysis.

headline: House Hunting in ... Cuernavaca, Mexico
abstract: The city’s climate attracts buyers from the United States, Canada and Europe, though the global real estate crisis has thinned their ranks.
lead_paragraph: A MEXICAN COLONIAL-STYLE HOME WITH POOL IN CUERNAVACA

headline: Classical Playlist: Stravinsky, Mendelssohn, Harrison Birtwistle and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: STRAVINSKY: ‘Oedipus Rex’ and ‘Apollon Musagète’London Symphony Orchestra, Monteverdi Choir; John Eliot Gardiner, conductor(LSO Live)As a dramatic work, Stravinsky’s “Oedipus Rex” is a riveting hybrid: both one-act opera with a Latin libretto and homage to the Baroque oratorio. It makes sense that the conductor John Eliot Gardiner, a pioneer of the early music movement, and the impressive Monteverdi Choir, founded by Mr. Gardner in 1964, would have a special feeling for the old-world musical elements of “Oedipus Rex,” all of which come through on this gripping recording taken from live performances with the London Symphony Orchestra last year. The actress Fanny Ardant delivers the narration in the original French version by Cocteau. Among the excellent soloists are the tenor Stuart Skelton as Oedipus and the mezzo-soprano Jennifer Johnston as Jocasta. (Anthony Tommasini)
