headline: New York City Police Officer Is Arrested in Westchester Shooting
abstract: Officials said the officer, who was off duty, was at a stoplight in Westchester late Tuesday when he fired at a car next to his, critically injuring a man in the passenger seat.
lead_paragraph: PELHAM, N.Y. — An off-duty New York City police officer shot a motorist six times at a stoplight in Westchester County this week, in what an official called a “completely random” attack.

headline: South Sudan’s Warring Leaders Draw Rebuke From U.N. Rights Chief
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: In a visit to South Sudan, the United Nations human rights chief said the leaders’ “personal power struggle” was destroying the country and that they would face a war crimes inquiry.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Navi Pillay, the United Nations human rights chief, sharply rebuked South Sudan’s warring leaders on Wednesday, saying they had to stop “blindly dragging their people down the path of self-destruction” and warning that they would face investigation for possible war crimes and crimes against humanity.

headline: Future’s New Album Hits the ‘Frozen’ Ceiling
abstract: The Atlanta rapper Future opened at No. 2 on the album chart with “Honest,” while the Disney soundtrack’s reign continued.
lead_paragraph: Another week on the music charts, another couple of victories for “Frozen” and “Happy.”

headline: Stalking the Role of an Operatic Stalker
abstract: Norm Lewis, the first black actor to play the title role in “The Phantom of the Opera” on Broadway, has longed to tackle the part for years.
lead_paragraph: Say a wish out loud enough times, and it might come true. It worked for the Broadway baritone Norm Lewis, anyway. For years, when Mr. Lewis, the star of 2012’s “The Gershwins’ Porgy and Bess,” was asked what his dream roles would be, he often mentioned Harold Hill in “The Music Man” or Billy Bigelow in “Carousel.” Yet the role he invariably named was the title character in the long-running musical “The Phantom of the Opera,” and at last it has come his way. Mr. Lewis will don the cape and mask for a six-month run starting May 12.

headline: Higher Minimum Wage Is Popular, but Voting on It Is Another Matter
keywords: ['Minimum Wage', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: A Times/CBS poll in February tested the impact six issues would have on voting in November, and the minimum wage provoked the least reaction.
lead_paragraph: Pollsters have known for decades that the public supports raising the minimum wage, and this past year has been no exception. What remains unknown is whether the Senate vote Wednesday killing the proposed minimum wage increase will affect the election in November.

headline: Time Warner’s Profit Rises On Strength in Film Unit
abstract: The growth from movie and cable businesses helped fuel a 9 percent increase in revenue to $7.5 billion, from $6.9 billion during the same period a year ago.
lead_paragraph: Time Warner reported on Wednesday that its first-quarter profit increased 7 percent, thanks largely to the successes of the Warner Bros. studio and Home Box Office.

headline: The Transformation of St. Agnes
abstract: A video documents how a decommissioned church in Germany has become a nexus of contemporary art and culture.
lead_paragraph: A video documents how a decommissioned church in Germany has become a nexus of contemporary art and culture.

headline: A Fight for Marriage Equality, and Over History
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Jo Becker, whose “Forcing the Spring” offers an inside look at a major same-sex-marriage case that went to the Supreme Court, has been criticized for how she framed the story.
lead_paragraph: Who makes history? That’s the essential question raised not so much by “Forcing the Spring,” Jo Becker’s account of the same-sex marriage struggle, but by the controversy that has surrounded the book since its publication last week.

headline: A Verdict on Comments, but the Conversation Isn’t Over
abstract: If, in the aftermath of Donald Sterling’s punishment, we declare the issue dead and the bad guy vanquished, we will all miss a golden opportunity for a deeper exploration of racism.
lead_paragraph: Adam Silver did what he had to do Tuesday.

headline: Finding Too Much of Nothing on an Irish Farm
abstract: In “Four Last Things,” by Lisa Tierney-Keogh, a young woman feels trapped on a farm in Ireland.
lead_paragraph: Jane isn’t built for country life. Stuck on her parents’ farm in Ireland, she longs for Dublin. “Swap the tractors for tour buses,” she commands, “the quiet for noise, the slowness for speed, the loneliness for no space to think.” Yet as Lisa Tierney-Keogh’s “Four Last Things” progresses, Jane’s rural exile seems less and less the problem. Jane may not be built for life at all.

headline: Bits and Pieces That End Up a Life
abstract: David Lang’s “collected stories” series ended on Tuesday with a program that featured John Cage works and Mr. Lang’s “mystery sonatas.”
lead_paragraph: The role of music in telling stories will of course change depending on the type of narrative being told. In planning “collected stories,” the fascinating series of six concerts at Zankel Hall that concluded on Tuesday night, the composer David Lang explored the various approaches composers have taken to relate tales of adventure, love, longing and spiritual questing.

headline: A Sneak Peek at a New Exhibition Co-Curated by Pharrell
abstract: The multi-hyphenated man of the moment has co-curated the inaugural show at Emmanuel Perrotin’s new art space in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Pharrell Williams is swiftly moving toward total cultural domination. Is it any surprise, then, that the multi-hyphenated man of the moment has been chosen to inaugurate a new art space in Paris next month? The 41-year-old first met the gallerist Emmanuel Perrotin seven years ago in Miami, and together, Perrotin says, they have been on an art adventure ever since: “meeting artists and visiting studios, brainstorming all along those great moments of artistic synergies and true happiness and friendship.” So it’s no surprise that Williams was present at the opening of Perrotin’s New York gallery late last year, where he treated Perrotin and friends to an early listen of his album “G I R L.” As one would expect, the tracks made Perrotin happy — a feeling he knew could transcend the record and fill his new art space, Salle de Bal, which opens on May 27 in a former ballroom in the 17th-century Hôtel du Grand Veneur in the Marais. So he invited Pharrell to collaborate on the inaugural show, also called “G I R L.”

headline: What Bank of America’s Accounting Mistake Can Teach the Market
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Do big banks have strong enough management of their risks and good internal controls to detect accounting problems? Mayra Rodríguez Valladares examines the problem in Another View.
lead_paragraph: Mayra Rodríguez Valladares is managing principal at MRV Associates, a capital markets and financial regulatory consulting and training firm based in New York. She is also a faculty member at Financial Markets World and the New York Institute of Finance.

headline: An Uneasy Inheritance of India’s Political Dynasty
abstract: Questions are growing in the Indian National Congress party as Rahul Gandhi, the scion of a political dynasty, appears poised to preside over a devastating defeat.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — On a visit to the rural constituency that has sent him or his relatives to Parliament for decades, Rahul Gandhi, the scion of India’s most powerful political dynasty, was asked a simple question: Can you name five party workers from the area?

headline: The Gun Report: April 30, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Just before 6 a.m. yesterday, Geddy Kramer, a 19-year-old package handler, opened fire with a shotgun at a FedEx shipping facility in Kennesaw, Ga. He wounded a security guard outside the building and five people in the warehouse, and was found dead of a self-inflicted gunshot wound in a trailer behind the FedEx site.

headline: Scene City: 100 Boldfaces in the Crowd
abstract: Celebrities toast Time magazine’s annual list of 100 influencers (and themselves.)
lead_paragraph: Celebrities toast Time magazine’s annual list of 100 influencers (and themselves.)

headline: Pictures of the Day: Palestine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Palestine, India, Florida and Spain.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Palestine, India, Florida and Spain.

headline: High Culture in Colorado
abstract: The Colorado Symphony Orchestra is planning a series of BYOC (bring your own cannabis) concerts this year.
lead_paragraph: Far from being bummed out by Colorado’s burgeoning legal marijuana market, the Colorado Symphony Orchestra is planning a series of BYOC (bring your own cannabis) concerts this year. Entitled “Classically Cannabis: The High Note Series,” the performances represent the orchestra’s attempt to reach a new, younger audience, so as to bolster its shaky finances and future. “You have to program your orchestra for the community you’re in,” Justin Bartels, a trumpet player in the orchestra, told the Denver Post, noting the classical ensemble has long caught the aroma of pot threading through its concerts. Why not go with the flow?

headline: Posing and Rubbing and Rolling and You Name It
abstract: Levi Gonzalez’s “The Craft of the Father” begins with a variety of bodily noises, then focuses on touch.
lead_paragraph: At the start of Levi Gonzalez’s “The Craft of the Father,” you can’t see anything. But in near-total darkness, you can hear breathing. Then you hear groaning, croaking, slurping. It sounds like indigestion, and then, as the noise grows louder and wilder, more like someone pretending to be possessed.

headline: Polished Yet Casual in the Flatiron District
abstract: Aristotle Torres wears his New York pride almost as well as his wax trench coat, vintage Rolex and Jordan sneakers.
lead_paragraph: Whether it’s tourists taking selfies under the Flatiron building, foodies wolfing down Eataly gelato or fashion enthusiasts flocking to buy the latest arrivals at boutiques, the Flatiron district offers some of New York’s biggest draws. The area is also packed with young entrepreneurs hustling to meetings at the towering office spaces nearby. Aristotle Torres was among them. The born-and-bred New Yorker from the Bronx was on his way to a company meeting wearing a waxed trench, a cashmere crew neck, a striped button-up and Jordan 8’s.

headline: A Playoffs’ Worth of Overtimes Already
abstract: The N.B.A. playoffs have been striking so far for the number of overtime games and the insignificance of home courts.
lead_paragraph: Serge Ibaka of the Oklahoma City Thunder caught the rebound of Kevin Durant’s missed 3-pointer and tipped the ball back toward the rim with the buzzer sounding at the end of overtime Tuesday night. As the ball fell through the hoop, Ibaka hit the ground with his arms raised. The Chesapeake Energy Arena crowd erupted in celebration. Ibaka’s teammate Reggie Jackson dived in for a hug. The Thunder had seemingly outlasted the Memphis Grizzlies to take a 3-2 series lead in their first-round playoff series.

headline: Florida State’s Jameis Winston Is Cited for Shoplifting Shellfish
abstract: The police said Jameis Winston, Florida State’s Heisman-winning quarterback, ordered $32.72 of crab legs and crawfish from a Publix but left without paying. His baseball coach suspended him.
lead_paragraph: Jameis Winston, Florida State’s Heisman Trophy-winning quarterback, found himself in off-the-field trouble once again on Tuesday night when he was cited for shoplifting seafood from a grocery store in Tallahassee, Fla.

headline: Voices on Iraq’s Election Day
abstract: Iraqi officials and voters discussed Iraq’s election as they cast their votes for the country’s new Parliament.
lead_paragraph: Iraqi officials and voters discussed Iraq’s election as they cast their votes for the country’s new Parliament.

headline: Murderers Are Shown With Warts Aplenty
abstract: “The Killer Speaks” and “Cell Block Psychic” address real murders, not the glossy TV kind.
lead_paragraph: Television loves the myth of smart, stylish murderers and the enigmatic detectives who pursue them, and if you enjoy those types of shows, don’t watch “The Killer Speaks.” The reality in it just might put you off those gritty, pretty fantasies.

headline: Senators Express Concern on Reverse Mortgage Rules
abstract: Senators Charles Schumer and Barbara Boxer urged the Department of Housing and Urban Development to clarify loans that have saddled middle-age children with their parents’ mortgages.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:20 a.m. |

headline: Nail Salon Lamps May Increase Skin Cancer Risk
abstract: Ultraviolet lamps used to dry and harden polished nails may pose a very low risk of skin cancer, new research shows.
lead_paragraph: Nail salon dryers, which use ultraviolet light to speed the drying and hardening of nail polishes and gels, emit varying levels of radiation that can lead to risky skin damage in as few as eight visits to the manicurist, a new study shows.

headline: Life in Canada, Home of the World’s Most Affluent Middle Class
abstract: Canadians have their share of complaints, but many also say they’re better off than their American counterparts.
lead_paragraph: The Canadian middle class may now be the world’s richest, but it has its anxieties, too.

headline: Garden Ice Does the Trick
abstract: As roars shook the arena, the Rangers earned an intense 2-1 victory on Wednesday and a trip to Pittsburgh to play the Penguins on Friday in Game 1 of the second round.
lead_paragraph: There must be ghosts in the rafters at Madison Square Garden, like those who once roamed the old Montreal Forum, even if they only come out for Game 7s.

headline: Political Preferences on Social Media Sites
abstract: A new study by the Harvard Institute of Politics found that people tend to flock to different social websites based on their political preferences.
lead_paragraph: Social media’s promise was that people with different views and political ties could mingle in digital bliss. But some social sites are more popular with one political party than another.

headline: When College Isn’t in the Cards
keywords: ['Anxiety and Stress', 'Careers and Professions', 'Children and Childhood', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Education (K-12)', 'Families and Family Life', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Many high school seniors are making decisions right now about where they want to begin college in the fall. But a traditional four-year college isn’t for everybody. We gathered stories from parents and students who made other choices.
lead_paragraph: If college isn’t in a high school student’s plan for any reason, the sense of pressure and judgment that some families feel at this time of year can be overwhelming. Many seniors are deciding where they want to begin college in the fall, decisions that will be final on May 1. “I feel judgment like I haven’t felt since my kids were babies,” Adrienne Jones posted on Facebook (where many parents are proudly posting acceptances and decisions). Her son does not plan to enter college.

headline: 10 Spice Blends to Enliven Any Dish
abstract: Sure, you can spend a lot of money on the perfect spice. Or you can make your own.
lead_paragraph: Sure, you can spend a lot of money on the perfect spice. Or you can make your own.

headline: Calling With Clarity
abstract: Molly Wood describes what you can do to improve the sound quality of your cellphone calls until new technologies like HD voice become more widely available.
lead_paragraph: Molly Wood describes what you can do to improve the sound quality of your cellphone calls until new technologies like HD voice become more widely available.

headline: With HD Voice, Better Call Quality Is Coming. Text Your Friends.
abstract: Phone carriers say HD voice is the solution to a longstanding problem, but will it arrive before we all switch to Skype or just give up calling completely?
lead_paragraph: CELLPHONE calls sound terrible.

headline: Headphones That Make Smartphone Calls Easier
abstract: Skullcandy, Klipsch and Bose offer hands-free accessories that improve sound and stability.
lead_paragraph: SMARTPHONES offer a lot of conveniences, especially for people on the go, but using one for its most basic function — making a phone call — can tie up your hands and actually limit your mobility.

headline: The Action of Adverbs, the Pathos of Prepositions
abstract: Grammar was the theme propelling Claire Porter’s collection of dance sketches at Joe’s Pub.
lead_paragraph: As a fun thing to do on a Friday night, attending a show about grammar is not an obvious choice. But grammar is the theme of “Sen•tence,” a collection of sketches in word, movement and music by the longtime dance comedian Claire Porter. And as presented by DanceNow at Joe’s Pub on Friday, the parts of speech cleverly parsed in “Sen•tence” made for a charming entertainment, at least in parts.

headline: No Extradition for Franco-Era Police Inspector
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Extradition']
abstract: The court on Wednesday ruled that the 13 counts of torture brought against Antonio González Pacheco in Argentina did not qualify as crimes against humanity.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Spain’s National Court on Wednesday dealt a setback to victims seeking justice for the abuses of the Franco dictatorship by refusing to extradite to Argentina a former police inspector accused of torture during the 1970s, the final years of the Franco regime.

headline: Redrawing ‘Map,’ From Different Angles
abstract: Shen Wei Dance Arts revives a 2005 work in the round at Judson Memorial Church, the new proximity exposing the subtleties of the choreography.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a regular at Judson Memorial Church you might not recognize the space this week. Filling the usually bare-bones sanctuary are multiple levels of seating, towers of theatrical lights and, sprouting up from the expansive floor, seven gargantuan balloons (cubes, globes) painted with arrows and other symbols, indecipherable maps.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Busy day? Catch up on the stories that grabbed our attention.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Unions’ Giant Video Near White House Urges Halt to Deportations
abstract: Labor leaders who normally side with President Obama planned to demonstrate their anger and frustration with his immigration policies through what they called “a massive public art display.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Labor leaders who normally side with President Obama planned to vividly demonstrate their anger and frustration with his immigration policies on Wednesday by projecting a 90-by-60-foot video onto the side of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. headquarters two blocks from the White House.

headline: Wheelies: The Don’t Clone Me Edition
abstract: G.M. limits availability of Camaro Z28 parts to prevent cloning; the federal government pushes for higher fines when automakers fail to issue recalls.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Happy Times
abstract: Vintage-style swimwear evokes the bygone days of stolen weekends and day trips to the beach.
lead_paragraph: Retro-feeling swimwear under an early summer haze harkens back to stolen weekends and simpler days.

headline: Atlético Bolts Past Chelsea and Mourinho
abstract: Atlético Madrid’s victory over Chelsea on Wednesday sets up an all-Madrid final in the Champions League in Lisbon on May 24.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Ten years ago, José Mourinho set off running on the big stage for the first time, his celebratory sprint in a designer suit and bulky overcoat serving as the indelible moment of Porto’s Champions League upset of Manchester United. It was bold. It was brash. It was perfect.

headline: More on the Life and Times of Anna Mae Aquash
abstract: The murder of Anna Mae Aquash, which many, including the prosecuting district attorney, still consider to be unsolved, has inspired two biographies and a history book.
lead_paragraph: In last weekend’s magazine Eric Konigsberg wrote about the investigation into the 1975 killing of the Native American activist Anna Mae Aquash, which has gone on for decades. Despite the fact that two lower-level members of the American Indian Movement were convicted of her murder, many people, including the prosecuting district attorney, still consider the crime to be unresolved. For those who would like to learn more about Aquash and the turbulent years of mid-’70s America, there are a couple of biographies and a history book that have been inspired by her case.

headline: Racism and Punishment in the N.B.A.
abstract: Readers discuss the N.B.A.’s decision to bar a team owner, Donald Sterling, from the sport because of racist comments.

headline: April 30, 1939: The New York World’s Fair Opens to the Public
abstract: On April 30, 1939, the New York World’s Fair opened and The New York Times covered it extensively the following day.
lead_paragraph: On April 30, 1939, President Franklin D. Roosevelt officially opened the New York World’s Fair in Flushing Meadows, Queens. Hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers and visitors gathered in the Court of Peace, near the park’s Trylon and Perisphere structures, to see the parade of uniformed soldiers and national flags waved by representatives from 33 countries.

headline: High Price in Utility Deal
abstract: There is a strategic logic to a merger between Exelon and Pepco, writes Christopher Swann of Reuters Breakingviews, yet there is also a high premium.
lead_paragraph: Just about any way investors crunch the numbers, Exelon looks to be overpaying for Pepco.

headline: Values and Data Meet at a Vatican Workshop on Sustaining Humanity on a Flourishing Planet
keywords: ['Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Environment', 'Global Warming', 'Religion and Belief', 'Science and Technology', 'Sociology', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: The Vatican hosts a meeting considering the mix of science, technology and values-laden choices that will determine the quality of life — human and otherwise — on Earth in coming decades.
lead_paragraph: I’m headed to the Vatican to participate in a novel workshop at which economists, theologians and seasoned researchers from many branches of science convene under the auspices of the Pontifical Academies of Sciences and Social Sciences to consider a subject that transcends the realms of data and values: Sustainable Humanity, Sustainable Planet, Our Responsibility.

headline: White Beans and Greens with Garlic and Olive Oil, or “Emma’s Beans”
abstract: And now a recipe from the VB6 Cookbook.
lead_paragraph: We’ve gotten some requests for this recipe, adapted from The VB6 Cookbook, so I thought I’d post this as well.

headline: Gelb Joins French Legion of Honor
abstract: Peter Gelb, the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, was honored by the French ambassador.
lead_paragraph: There have been plenty of chevaliers portrayed on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera in recent years: the Chevalier des Grieux in Massenet’s “Manon,” the Chevalier de la Force in Poulenc’s “Dialogues of the Carmelites,” and, earlier this year, a Viennese prison warden pretending to be a French chevalier in Strauss’s “Die Fledermaus.”

headline: A Suicide Stalks Young Spalding Gray
abstract: A young Spalding Gray appears in “The Wooster Group’s Rumstick Road,” which explores his mother’s suicide.
lead_paragraph: Ghosts are captured on camera in “Rumstick Road,” the genuinely haunting new work that runs through Wednesday at Anthology Film Archives. Described as a “video reconstruction” of a performance from the mid-1970s by the Wooster Group, the New York experimental theater troupe, Elizabeth LeCompte and Ken Kobland’s film is by its very nature phantasmal.

headline: Starry, Starry, Starry Night
abstract: Time magazine honors 100 people it considers most influential.
lead_paragraph: The Time 100 gala is one of those events where industries collide. There’s media (Rupert Murdoch), there’s tech (Eric Schmidt), there’s Hollywood (Alfonso Cuarón), there’s the Washington Beltway (Kirsten Gillibrand).

headline: Headwaters for a River of Stand-Up
abstract: Pop culture, and numerous comedians, have been influenced by Steven Wright’s singular way with a joke.
lead_paragraph: When Steven Wright started appearing on “The Tonight Show” in the early 1980s, he was such a change of pace that Johnny Carson once introduced him with the tone of a teacher taking a class of jittery kids to their first play. “Just let your mind go at ease here to follow Steven Wright,” he said, gingerly preparing the audience. “He’s unique and you have to listen to what he says.”

headline: Infidelity Under Wraps? They’d Rather Share
abstract: “True Tori” and “Mary Mary” are reality shows that revolve in part around celebrities’ reactions to infidelity.
lead_paragraph: Scene from one kind of celebrity uncoupling, a few weeks ago on “Mary Mary”: Tina Campbell, who with her sister Erica makes up the revered gospel duo Mary Mary, is in full meltdown mode. She’s just learned that her husband has been unfaithful on several occasions, and she’s venting to her sister and mother: “I’ve got to go out here and sing ‘Go get your blessing.’ I’ve got to stand in front of these people and be inspirational, and it’s so hard, because they don’t have a clue.”

headline: Nicaragua: In Shadows of Pain and Glory
abstract: “Magic Words (Breaking a Spell),” from the director Mercedes Moncada Rodríguez, is a meditation on Nicaraguan history.
lead_paragraph: In the poetic documentary “Palabras Mágicas (Para Romper un Encantamiento)” — “Magic Words (Breaking a Spell)” — the director Mercedes Moncada Rodríguez meditates on the fraught history of Nicaragua, starting with the years preceding the Sandinista overthrow of the Somoza dictatorship in 1979. Ms. Rodríguez, a sociologist turned filmmaker, has examined the country’s history before: Her 2005 documentary, “El Inmortal” (“The Immortal”), examined the scars left on a family whose members fought on opposing sides in the Contra war in the 1980s. Her new film, presented as part of the Museum of Modern Art’s series “Iberoamérican Images: The State of the Art,” covers decades, juxtaposing period footage with the director’s reflective narration and gorgeous images.

headline: Nigerians Hold Second Day of Protests Over Mass Abductions
abstract: Hundreds of demonstrators marched in the capital to demand that the government do more to find more than 200 schoolgirls abducted by armed militants.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Hundreds of protesters marched in the streets of the Nigerian capital on Wednesday, demanding that the government do more to find scores of schoolgirls abducted by armed militants more than two weeks ago. Parents of the girls have turned up sick in hospitals, overcome with worry. Some have even gone into the bush to search for the girls themselves, armed only with bows and arrows in the heartland of an Islamist insurgency.

headline: Augie Boehm at Honors Bridge Club
abstract: Boehm, a well-known bridge player, teacher and writer, is also an excellent concert pianist.
lead_paragraph: Augie Boehm of New York City is a well-known bridge player, teacher and writer. He is also an excellent concert pianist and on May 12 will be giving his 36th annual recital at the Weill Recital Hall in Carnegie Hall.

headline: Agnostic Lyricism in an Exploration of Spirituality
abstract: The Cecilia Chorus of New York performed Tom Cipullo’s “Credo for a Secular City” during a concert at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: A program about spirituality and theological doubt would seem to be a natural for the Cecilia Chorus of New York, which was known as the St. Cecilia Chorus from its founding, in 1906, until it dropped the heavenly honorific — and, presumably, the religious connotations that accompanied it — in 2012. The centerpiece of the chorus’s concert at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening was a new work, Tom Cipullo’s “Credo for a Secular City,” intended, in its composer’s words, as “a statement for the believers and for the nonbelievers as well.”

headline: Deconstructing Charles James
abstract: “Charles James: Beyond Fashion,” at the Met, includes animated videos that virtually peel garments, like his “Ribbon” dress, here, from their mannequins to illustrate how they were assembled.
lead_paragraph: “Charles James: Beyond Fashion,” at the Met, includes animated videos that virtually peel garments, like his “Ribbon” dress, here, from their mannequins to illustrate how they were assembled.

headline: A Shortcut to Spring
abstract: After a punishing winter, some women are opting for the breezy freedom of a bob.
lead_paragraph: In early April, a week before she was due to leave for South Africa to run an ultramarathon, Cortney Harding decided to get her hair cut. Ms. Harding, who is 33 and lives in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, went from hair that hit just above the shoulder to a short jaw-length bob with bangs. “I wanted to feel the sun on the back of my neck,” she said.

headline: Architectural Underpinnings of Cinderella
abstract: The glamorous dresses of Charles James, revealed with the help of animation for a show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: Charles James, the fabled fashion designer, once declared, “I’m the most copied person in the world.” But that Anglo-American couturier, who died in 1978, could never have imagined why his glamorous 1953 “Clover Leaf” dress was being meticulously recreated and scrutinized now — all 10 pounds of it.

headline: The Execution That Was Botched in Oklahoma
abstract: Readers respond to a front-page article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Guides to Four Flowers for Those Already Smitten
keywords: ['Gardens and Gardening', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: A new series of books, each devoted to a single bloom.
lead_paragraph: Garden books devoted to a single genus run the risk of simply being mind-numbing lists of species — this one found in the mountains, by the opening of a hermit’s cave; that one crossed with a Labrador retriever to win Plant of the Year at the Chelsea Flower Show. Timber Press is fond of publishing such books, because after all, gardeners tend to be a greedy, obsessive lot. If they fall in love with a snowdrop, they want every kind of snowdrop.

headline: A ‘Cabin’ in the Hamptons
abstract: This summer house with its modern design smells as good as it looks (it’s the cedar).
lead_paragraph: For years, Peter and Kathryn Mattis rented a house in the Hamptons for their family every summer, an annual ritual that is not without its challenges. But buying a home there, they recently discovered, can be even more trying. Particularly if you don’t want a traditional Hamptons showplace.

headline: Teenagers’ Risky Behavior
abstract: Dan Romer of the Annenberg Public Policy Center responds to a Sunday Review article, “Friends Can Be Dangerous.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ¿Vive cerca de la I-35? Contribuya a nuestro reportaje
abstract: En las próximas semanas, un periodista del New York Times, Damien Cave, y un fotógrafo, Todd Heisler, viajarán a lo largo de la I-35, relatando cómo es que la migración y las cambiantes tendencias demográficas transforman a comunidades enteras a lo largo de esta ruta. ¿A dónde deberían de ir él y el Sr. Heisler?
lead_paragraph: En las próximas semanas, un periodista del New York Times, Damien Cave, y un fotógrafo, Todd Heisler, viajarán a lo largo de la I-35, relatando cómo es que la migración y las cambiantes tendencias demográficas transforman a comunidades enteras a lo largo de esta ruta. ¿A dónde deberían de ir él y el Sr. Heisler?

headline: Discounts at Madeline Weinrib, Niche Modern and Intérieurs
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Carpets and Rugs', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Lamps and Lampshades', 'Textiles']
abstract: Sales this week on carpets, furniture and lamps.
lead_paragraph: Carpets, pillows, furniture and fabric are up to 60 percent off during Madeline Weinrib’s sample sale though Sunday (a Brooke cotton carpet in hot pink and orange, originally $1,075, is $699; an 18-inch-square Ikat pillow, originally $525, is $259); ABC Carpet & Home, 881 Broadway (East 19th Street), second floor, 646-602-3780.

headline: The East Blows into the West
abstract: A show of work by two emerging Chinese designers inaugurates Gallery ALL in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: The historic Bradbury Building in downtown Los Angeles is known as a setting for “Blade Runner.” But on Saturday it will present another kind of future when Gallery ALL, a contemporary design space, opens in a 2,400-square-foot storefront there. The inaugural show is of works by Naihan Li and Zhoujie Zhang, Chinese designers who hint at the creative promise of East Asia.

headline: Fighting Cholera in Haiti
abstract: The Coalition to Eliminate Cholera From Hispaniola responds to an editorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Rocking the Palazzo
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Finally, the Kips Bay show house gets the showplace it deserves.
lead_paragraph: Mudejar tiles, the appetites of Francis Cardinal Spellman and a colossal sculpture by Ron Arad made from a whorl of steel rods that cost more than $1 million are just a few of the colliding, often ravishing visions now on view in the elegant spaces that once held the Urban Center in the Villard Houses at Madison Avenue and 51st Street — the home, for the next month, of the Kips Bay Decorator Show House.

headline: Let Us Eat Bagels
abstract: An Indian-American reader describes her family’s passion for the Jewish favorite.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Shake-Up at Repsol, as New Chief Is Named
abstract: The management reshuffle comes after Repsol ended a bitter two-year dispute with Argentina in February over the country’s seizure of YPF.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Repsol, the Spanish oil company, announced Wednesday that its longstanding executive chairman, Antonio Brufau, would hand over the job of chief executive to Josu Jon Imaz San Miguel, who has been running the company’s upstream operations.

headline: Dressing the Man of Means
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: Fashion houses are waking up to an eager men’s luxury market willing to take more risks.
lead_paragraph: The lexicon describing male shopping has been lately enriched with newly minted acronyms and portmanteaux, following in the vaunted (and derided) footsteps of “metrosexual.” Bain & Company calls this spender-to-be Henry (High Earner, Not Rich Yet); the bank HSBC, more cringe-worthily, calls him a Yummy (Young Urban Male). But if you christen him, will he come?

headline: If Pollock Could Whinny
abstract: Metro, a retired racehorse that paints, is now decorating housewares.
lead_paragraph: Metro Meteor is a retired thoroughbred racehorse with congenitally bad knees and a fidgety personality. He was a star in his heyday, but after four and a half years of running hard (and winning big), and two operations to remove bone chips from his knees, he was not only no longer able to race, but he couldn’t even hold a rider.

headline: Parents Safely in the Closet
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The cartoonist’s latest work chronicles her parents’ decline, and she finds a spot for them.
lead_paragraph: RIDGEFIELD, Conn. — By way of introducing her parents, Roz Chast opened her closet door and rummaged through some stuff on the floor. This is where she keeps them, amid miscellaneous boxes and general bedroom marginalia: her mother’s ashes in a maroon velvet pouch; her father’s in the Channel 13 tote bag he took with him everywhere.

headline: Whose Glass Is Whose? Now, No Excuses
abstract: Lifefactory introduces silicone-wrapped wineglasses and containers.
lead_paragraph: Lifefactory has taken the silicone-wrapped glass it uses in its popular water bottle designs and applied it to wineglasses and food storage containers, both introduced this week. The colorful stemless wineglass “was on our original patent application,” said Daren Joy, a designer and founder of the company, which is in Sausalito, Calif. “They feel good in the hand, and are a great way to keep track of who has whose wineglass,” he added.

headline: The Raw and the Cool
abstract: Reclaimed Home, a purveyor of rescued and repaired furnishings, opens in Crown Heights.
lead_paragraph: Phyllis Bobb met Emilia DeVitis 29 years ago while both were handing out audio tour devices at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Through the years, Ms. Bobb (a photographer and fourth-generation Brooklynite) and Ms. DeVitis (an artist who was born in Italy but raised in Astoria) stayed close friends. They are now opening Reclaimed Home, a salvage and restoration shop in Crown Heights.

headline: Cool Your Heels on an Ottoman
abstract: More than a footrest, this piece can be a child-safe coffee table, informal seating or even a serving table.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to ottomans, bigger is often better.

headline: Spring Dresses to Rival Art
abstract: Spring dresses; 20 artists use the Charlotte Olympia platform pump as their canvas; from Ferragamo, the Fiamma bag and more shopping news.
lead_paragraph: The Frieze art fair and others descend on New York next weekend. Since splurging on some of spring’s graphically complex creations can cost the equivalent of an actual work of art, it makes sense to opt for a dress that will stand out in a sea of black and Céline (which are, of course, never less than chic). The interplay of geometric patterns, abstract brush strokes and scribble print in this selection could prompt even art-world grandees to pause. The model Soo Joo Park (shown here) had the right idea with her Chanel, rendering it extra cool with a bomber and a beanie.

headline: Deep in the Heart of Don
abstract: Why does the emotional reaction to interpersonal racism drown out the muted response to institutional racism, which actually does more damage?
lead_paragraph: Don Sterling’s racist rant, on a recording published by TMZ, has earned him a lifetime ban by the N.B.A. and cost him a second — second? — lifetime achievement award from the Los Angeles chapter of the N.A.A.C.P. The N.A.A.C.P.?!

headline: New York Said to Be on Verge of 9-Year Deal With Teachers’ Union
keywords: ['Teachers and School Employees', 'Organized Labor', 'Education (K-12)', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s potential agreement with the United Federation of Teachers, which would include retroactive pay, would settle a nearly five-year labor dispute.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio and New York’s main teachers’ union are on the verge of announcing a deal to settle a nearly five-year labor dispute in which the union has sought more than $3 billion in back pay from the city.

headline: Attorney General in Guatemala Excluded From Re-election Bid
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Claudia Paz y Paz, who has taken on a former dictator and top drug traffickers, was left off of a shortlist of candidates to be considered for re-election.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Guatemala’s attorney general, Claudia Paz y Paz, whose prosecution of a former dictator for genocide earned her the enmity of powerful members of the country’s political and business elite, has lost her bid for a second term.

headline: Abercrombie Settles Board Fight With Engaged Capital
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Boards of Directors', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: The move will end a battle between Abercrombie and Engaged, which argued that the retailer needed new blood on its board to help turn around a slump that has lasted for years.
lead_paragraph: Abercrombie & Fitch said on Wednesday that it had settled a proxy fight with the activist hedge fund Engaged Capital, agreeing to add four new independent directors to its board.

headline: Microscope and Telescope
abstract: Did something deep happen in last week’s Supreme Court decision on affirmative action in Michigan? It depends.
lead_paragraph: As anyone I’ve talked with during the past week knows, I have been obsessed with trying to get my mind around the Supreme Court’s 6-to-2 decision to uphold Michigan’s voter-approved ban on affirmative action in admissions to the state’s public universities.

abstract: A scene from the film directed by Marc Webb.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film directed by Marc Webb.

headline: White House on Oklahoma Execution
abstract: Jay Carney, the White House press secretary, said the botched execution fell short of the humane standards required when the death penalty is carried out.
lead_paragraph: Jay Carney, the White House press secretary, said the botched execution fell short of the humane standards required when the death penalty is carried out.

headline: When Black Hair Is Against the Rules
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hair', 'Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Military restrictions on African-American styles are discriminatory.
lead_paragraph: AMERICA has always had trouble with black hair. The United States Army is only the latest in a long line of institutions, corporations and schools to restrict it. On March 31, the Army released an updated appearance and grooming policy, known as AR 670-1. It applies to all Army personnel, including students at West Point and those serving in the R.O.T.C. and the National Guard.

headline: The Problem With Free Health Care
keywords: ['Tests (Medical)', 'Preventive Medicine', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Mammography', 'Colonoscopy']
abstract: The Affordable Care Act makes screening tests like mammograms free. But if you have a breast lump and need a diagnosis, you have to pay.
lead_paragraph: HANOVER, N.H. — NOW that it’s clear that Obamacare is here to stay, its supporters should focus on making the program better. Fixes are not a sign of weakness. They are a sign of responsiveness and of good management. And the Affordable Care Act does have its flaws. Here’s a big one: It favors screening over diagnosis.

lead_paragraph: A scene from the film, directed by Gia Coppola.

abstract: Mother’s Day is next weekend, but for the most personal presents, it’s best to start your shopping a bit early.

headline: A Mystery Beyond Price Tags
abstract: Idol, in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is the type of place that can take on items that make little to no sense, just because a few people understand.
lead_paragraph: I’ll tell you this: I miss not knowing things.

lead_paragraph: A scene from the film.

headline: Farfetch, an Online Boutique, Enjoys Its Moment
abstract: Farfetch.com, a six-year-old website, is a hit with global shoppers and private investors.
lead_paragraph: José Neves has a certain way of shopping, one that may make him very rich.

headline: Nicole Richie: Candid About Pushing Boundaries
abstract: Ms. Richie follows a simple beauty regimen, but for special events, she likes to experiment.
lead_paragraph: Raised and now based in Los Angeles, Nicole Richie, 32, is known for her fashion line House of Harlow 1960 and reality TV shows, including “The Simple Life” and “Fashion Star.” In July, she’s scheduled to add another, “#CandidlyNicole,” on VH1. The adopted daughter of Lionel Richie and Brenda Harvey, Ms. Richie is married to the musician Joel Madden, with whom she has a daughter, Harlow, 6, and son, Sparrow, 4.

headline: So Many, You Could Have a Beauty-Booking App a Day
abstract: A small cottage industry of beauty-booking apps has hit the market in the last two years.
lead_paragraph: It was a beauty emergency in search of an app.

headline: Rains Flood Florida and Alabama
abstract: Torrential rain overnight in Pensacola, Fla., and parts of Alabama left hundreds stranded in apartments and cars. The storm drenched the area with nearly 20 inches of rain.
lead_paragraph: Torrential rain overnight in Pensacola, Fla., and parts of Alabama left hundreds stranded in apartments and cars. The storm drenched the area with nearly 20 inches of rain.

headline: Sephora and the Upstarts
abstract: Beauty emporiums like Sephora, Space NK, Bluemercury, Ulta and Harmon with many brands, including their own, are riding a wave of popularity.
lead_paragraph: “When I was 29, I lived in Boston and had to drive 30 miles to get my M.A.C. lipstick,” said Marla Beck, who owns Bluemercury with her husband, Barry Beck. “It was frustrating. In 1999 you couldn’t find what you wanted, which was a friendly neighborhood store that sold highly selective cosmetics and skin care products.”

headline: I’ll Have What She’s Wearing
abstract: Love it or like it, Fausto Puglisi’s spring collection reveals his zest for life.
lead_paragraph: The Sicilian designer Fausto Puglisi was sitting at breakfast at the Carlyle Hotel this week, his Mike Tyson sweatshirt and foghorn stream of enthusiasms marking him out from the crowd. “I like to work very calm and uptown,” he explained of his taste in hotels, “while someone in Miami in my miniskirt is drinking.”

headline: El Salvador: Ex-President Faces Charges
abstract: Former President Francisco Flores will face embezzlement and other corruption charges related to what prosecutors said Wednesday was the misappropriation of at least $5.3 million in loans from Taiwan during his tenure, from 1999 to 2004.
lead_paragraph: Former President Francisco Flores will face embezzlement and other corruption charges related to what prosecutors said Wednesday was the misappropriation of at least $5.3 million in loans from Taiwan during his tenure, from 1999 to 2004. The country’s chief prosecutor, Luis Martínez, told a television interviewer that charges had been filed in court against Mr. Flores, who has been summoned to a court hearing on Friday. He has not been seen publicly in several months, but in a hearing in January called by the nation’s Congress, which is also investigating him, he denied any wrongdoing. President Mauricio Funes has said Mr. Flores received $10 million in donations in the final months of his term without accounting for them.

headline: China: Criticism of U.S. Move on Iran
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: China on Wednesday sharply criticized an American move to enforce sanctions against Iran that penalized eight Chinese companies and their owner, Li Fangwei, accused of supplying parts for Iranian ballistic missiles.
lead_paragraph: China on Wednesday sharply criticized an American move to enforce sanctions against Iran that penalized eight Chinese companies and their owner, Li Fangwei, accused of supplying parts for Iranian ballistic missiles. The move, announced on Tuesday by the Treasury, State and Justice Departments, also offered a $5 million reward for information leading to Mr. Li’s arrest or conviction. China’s Foreign Ministry spokesman, Qin Gang, told reporters in Beijing that “China resolutely opposes the U.S. citing domestic laws to unilaterally impose sanctions on Chinese companies or individuals.” He said the American move “will not help resolve the issue and will harm bilateral cooperation on nonproliferation.” It was unclear whether China’s anger would have an impact on the effectiveness of the American-led sanctions against Iran, which are mostly a response to the Iranian nuclear program. China and the United States are both in the group of big powers negotiating with Iran over its nuclear activities, seeking guarantees that the Iranians will not develop nuclear weapons.

headline: Veterans Agency Is Sued Over Handling of Trauma Cases
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Sex Crimes', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans']
abstract: A lawsuit against the Department of Veterans Affairs charges that veterans with PTSD from sexual assaults have more difficulty proving their illness to the department — and thus obtaining disability benefits.
lead_paragraph: Two veterans groups and a Yale legal clinic sued the Department of Veterans Affairs on Wednesday, charging that veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder from sexual assaults during their service have more difficulty proving their illness to the department — and thus obtaining disability benefits — than veterans with other forms of PTSD. The federal lawsuit asks the court to order the V.A. to adopt rules making it harder to reject sexual-assault PTSD claims, which plaintiffs say were granted 17 percent to 30 percent less often than other PTSD claims from 2009 to 2012. According to the V.A., in fiscal year 2013, these claims were granted about 6 percent less often than all PTSD claims combined. The suit was brought by the Yale Law School Veterans Legal Services Clinic, the Service Women’s Action Network and Vietnam Veterans of America.

headline: Parallel Lives
abstract: Meet Preston Chaunsumlit of VFiles’ “Model Files” web series.
lead_paragraph: AGE 34.
